headline: How to Visit Some of Paris’s Finest Museums but Skip the Crowds
abstract: Avoid the crush at the Louvre and explore places devoted to art in the 20th century, French architectural history and the life of Edith Piaf, without the annoyance of hordes of fellow museum goers.
lead_paragraph: Paris is home to the finest museums in the world. Unfortunately, they are also some of the most crowded. Nearly four million people head to the Pompidou Center and the Musée d’Orsay each year. The Louvre receives more than twice as many.

headline: Kicking Off the Lunar New Year
abstract: A firecracker festival in Roosevelt Park in Manhattan’s Chinatown on Friday is one of many events this weekend to mark the beginning of the Year of the Horse.

headline: Amanda Knox, Found Guilty in Italy Killing, Vows to Fight Extradition
abstract: The latest court decision is likely to set off years more of court battles in Italy and possibly the United States, legal experts said.
lead_paragraph: Appearing stunned and fighting back tears, Amanda Knox said Friday that she “will never go willingly back” to Italy and would fight any effort to extradite her “to the very end.”

headline: Give Malta Your Tired and Huddled, and Rich
abstract: A Mediterranean island is in search of wealthy foreigners with the means to buy citizenship and bring the government some cash.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Having been besieged by the Ottomans, and ruled over the centuries by foreign invaders from the Greeks to the Romans to Napoleon, the tiny Mediterranean island nation of Malta has seen plenty of unwelcome interlopers.

Besides, who would know the difference?

lead_paragraph: Vern L. Bengtson came from a religious family — to put it mildly.

headline: Child Pornography Charges Against Police Chief Roil a Town in Westchester
abstract: Brian Fanelli, the chief of Mount Pleasant, had taught children how to be alert for sexual abuse and was arrested last week, accused of having explicit images on his home computers.
lead_paragraph: VALHALLA, N.Y. — Betrayed. That was the word some parishioners used to describe how they felt about the arrest of a longtime member of their congregation who happened to be the police chief of Mount Pleasant.

headline: For Some, Retirement Is Out of Reach. For Others, Boring.
abstract: Americans are retiring later in life, on average, but many members of the baby boomer generation say they find the very idea unthinkable.
lead_paragraph: IN just a few days, Jay Leno, 63, the host of the “Tonight” show for the last 22 years, will be ceding his comedic throne to the 39-year-old Jimmy Fallon.

headline: France and Britain Agree on Outer Space, but Find No Common Ground on Europe
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain wants to revise the European Union’s rule book, but President François Hollande of France says no.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain and France are stepping up their cooperation in outer space, but in Europe they still move in very different orbits.

headline: A Library for Obama First Needs an Address
abstract: A foundation is in place to begin the effort to create a presidential library with Barack Obama’s name on it. Where it will be built remains unclear.
lead_paragraph: On election night in 1992, James L. Rutherford, known as Skip, was celebrating with other key Clinton supporters on the streets of Little Rock, Ark., when he felt the hand of Herschel Friday, a prominent Arkansas lawyer and member of the Clinton finance committee, on his back.

headline: Are You Ready for Some ... Nordic Voices?
abstract: In New York during the big game, many non-football events are scheduled, like a Carnegie Hall concert and standup comedy at Dangerfield’s.
lead_paragraph: Sunday promises to be a big night for Peyton Manning, the quarterback of the Denver Broncos; for Russell Wilson, his counterpart on the Seattle Seahawks; and for their teammates, competing in a stadium before 80,000 spectators and a television audience of more than 100 million people.

headline: Retailers Ask: Where Did Teenagers Go?
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The competition for teenage dollars, at a time of high unemployment within that age group, spans from more stores to shop in to more tempting technology.
lead_paragraph: Luring young shoppers into traditional teenage clothing stores has become a tough sell.

headline: Theodore Millon, Psychologist and Student of Personality, Dies at 85
abstract: Dr. Millon was a crucial figure in shaping the understanding of personality disorders, and a self-described exemplar of “secure narcissism.”
lead_paragraph: Theodore Millon, a psychologist whose theories helped define how scientists think about personality and its disorders, and who developed a widely used measure to analyze character traits, died on Wednesday at his home in Greenville Township, N.Y. He was 85.

headline: The Super Bowl and Sex Trafficking
abstract: A law enforcement crackdown built on a myth only hurts those it claims to help.
lead_paragraph: TENS of thousands of people have descended upon the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area this week for tomorrow’s Super Bowl, accompanied by the usual media frenzy. A now familiar feature of this coverage, wherever the Super Bowl is held, is an abundance of stories, from Reuters to CNN, reporting that the event will cause a surge in sex trafficking to capitalize on the influx of fans and tourists.

headline: Even Out of Office, a Wielder of Great Power in Yemen
abstract: Ali Abdullah Saleh, Yemen’s former president, is a rarity in the Arab world: an autocrat overthrown by popular revolt who nonetheless remains in his country, undisturbed.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — THE old man still rises at 5:30 a.m., as he did during the three decades he ruled this tumultuous country. He does some physical therapy to help his scarred body recover from the 2011 bomb blast that nearly killed him. He reads the papers. And then, sitting in a gazebo in a high-walled compound that rivals the presidential palace, he begins receiving the endless tide of visitors who still treat him as if he were the most powerful man in Yemen.

headline: In Rinks Beyond Sochi, a Chance for Players Left Behind
abstract: The highly ranked women’s ice hockey teams at Minnesota and Harvard, whose rosters were most affected by the Winter Olympics, have managed to continue to thrive this season.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — An expansive mural dominates a high corner wall at the University of Minnesota’s Ridder Arena. It depicts the seven Golden Gophers female hockey players who have participated in the Winter Olympics — six for the United States and goalie Noora Raty for Finland. Now, it may have to spill over to another wall. Four more Americans and another Finn have been named to teams for Sochi.

headline: Skyline? Yes. Night Life? Great! Lake to Skate On? No.
abstract: Despite frigid temperatures in New York City of late, skaters had to go to rinks, because the once popular pastime of skating on lakes is prohibited.
lead_paragraph: From Mount Kisco in Westchester County, N.Y., to Fair Haven on the Jersey Shore, ponds and lakes have frozen solid. “There’s something a little magical about it,” said D. J. Breckenridge, the director of parks and recreation for the Borough of Fair Haven, N.J., where a hundred children slipped and glided on McCarter Pond one afternoon this week.

headline: The Sound of a Tree Falling Is Not Ka-ching
abstract: Does it still count as a solo album if your cat meows on a couple of tracks?
lead_paragraph: For each member of a band the question may arise whether to do a solo project. Some bands consist of musicians who’ve already done projects on their own. But some people have known life only in the band, and the prospect of a solo venture can be both exhilarating and scary to ponder. I was of the latter variety.

headline: Harold Shaw, Manager of Major Classical Artists, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Shaw’s clients included Jessye Norman, Nathan Milstein, John Williams and Jacqueline du Pré.
lead_paragraph: Harold Shaw, an artist manager whose clients included some of the most famous performers in classical music, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: The Economic Road Ahead
abstract: The country has moved from recession to recovery, but not from recovery to strength.
lead_paragraph: Economists, politicians and investors gave the latest economic growth report, released on Thursday, a generally warm reception: The estimated annual growth rate in the fourth quarter of 2013, a decent 3.2 percent, could bode well for further growth this year. But there are, on balance, more reasons for caution than for optimism.

headline: Too Loud, Too Quiet: Those Alluring Seahawks
abstract: Seattle’s Richard Sherman attracted attention because of his outgoing nature while his teammate Marshawn Lynch gained notice for his silence.
lead_paragraph: This year’s N.F.L. playoffs have been a study in hypocrisy. Not from the N.F.L. — which is clear about the violence and mayhem it packages and sells — but from those of us who fight our battles with pens and pads, microphones and cameras. We have been pushed by technology — and vanity — to want it both ways: We capitalize on noise, and we capitalize on silence, and yet we complain about both.

headline: Fewer Benefits for Target’s Part-Timers
keywords: ['Part-Time Employment', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The retail giant ends health coverage for thousands of its employees.
lead_paragraph: Target has announced that it will no longer provide health insurance for part-time workers but will send them instead to the new health care exchanges established by the Affordable Care Act. The change could help low-income workers who will now have access to subsidized coverage. It might distress middle-income workers ineligible for a big subsidy, and it is likely to be bad news for taxpayers, who will foot the bill for the coverage Target had provided. But the biggest unanswered question is this: Will Target raise wages to make up for the loss of the company contribution? As a matter of fairness, it should.

headline: On 35th Anniversary of Diplomatic Ties With U.S., China Tries to Soften Image
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Lunar New Year', 'Classical Music']
abstract: China has moved to expand friendly cultural exchanges with the United States and promote a series of prominent collaborations in music, dance and education, particularly in New York.
lead_paragraph: With tensions between China and the United States growing over a range of political and economic issues, the Chinese government is using the 35th anniversary of diplomatic relations this year as part of an intensified effort to soften its image.

headline: Aid for Students With a Dream
keywords: ['Financial Aid (Education)', 'Tuition', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Editorials', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Education (Secondary)']
abstract: Undocumented students should get the same kind of financial assistance now given to legal residents.
lead_paragraph: With Congress circling immigration reform ever so slowly, it is up to the states to provide more help to young people who were brought to this country illegally by their families. Some states, like California, have already made it possible for undocumented students who graduate from high school to pay at the in-state tuition rate and get financial aid when they go to state colleges.

headline: Fight Over Effective Teachers Shifts to Courtroom
abstract: Nine public school students are challenging California’s tenure system, arguing that their right to a quality education is violated by job protections that make it too difficult to fire bad instructors.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They have tried and failed to loosen tenure rules for teachers in contract talks and state legislatures. So now, a group of rising stars in the movement to overhaul education employment has gone to court.

headline: Detroit Sues to Cancel Some Costly Contracts
abstract: The city contends that some of the complex transactions set up to finance pensions were illegal.
lead_paragraph: Detroit filed suit on Friday to invalidate some complex transactions it used to finance its pensions, contending they were illegal from the very beginning.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 31, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Russell Wilson, the Man Behind Center, Could Have Wound Up as a Second Baseman
abstract: Wilson, the Seattle Seahawks quarterback, was forced to choose between sports after being drafted by the Colorado Rockies in 2010.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Russell Wilson needed help, and he needed it right then. The next morning, he was to fly to Denver to sign his contract with the Colorado Rockies and work out at his new full-time position of second baseman before shipping off to the minors, and he did not know how to turn a double play.

headline: Obama Is Said to Plan Fence-Mending Trip to Saudi Arabia
abstract: An official said President Obama would seek to reassure King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia after a period of tension over American policies toward Iran and Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seeking to mend a frayed relationship with a major American ally in the Middle East, President Obama plans to travel to Saudi Arabia in March for a meeting with King Abdullah, an official with knowledge of the planning said Friday.

headline: Snacks Laced With Marijuana Raise Concerns
abstract: The popularity of edible marijuana has alarmed parents’ groups and others who say the highly concentrated snacks are increasingly landing in the hands of children too young to know the difference between pot brownies and regular ones.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — All day long, customers at LoDo Wellness Center, one of Colorado’s new recreational marijuana stores, reach into the refrigerator and pull out tasty ways to get high. They buy sparkling peach and mandarin elixirs, watermelon Dew Drops, and sleek silver bags of chocolate truffles, each one packed with marijuana’s potent punch.

headline: Unionized College Athletes?
abstract: Dreaming of an organization that can take on the all-powerful N.C.A.A., and getting a little encouragement from Northwestern.
lead_paragraph: Kain Colter is a senior at Northwestern University, a pre-med student majoring in psychology with a 3.1 grade-point average. For the last two years, he has also been the starting quarterback for the university’s football team, where he has shown himself to be a real leader and, in the words of his academic adviser, “a wonderful example of a true student-athlete.”

headline: Pipeline Opponents’ Hopes Now Rest Largely on Kerry

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Environmental activists have not been shy in their fight against the Keystone XL pipeline. They have wrapped a giant pipeline around the White House fence, marched on Washington in the frigid cold, been arrested, and followed President Obama around the country to press their concerns while raising millions of dollars for the cause.

headline: East Hampton Withdraws From Deer-Culling Program
abstract: The Village and Town of East Hampton are withdrawing from the federal program after facing boisterous opposition and lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: After vigorous opposition to deer culling, both the Village and Town of East Hampton have decided to withdraw from a program to bring in federal sharpshooters to significantly thin the local herd. The developments throw into doubt the future of what had been designed as one of the largest deer removal efforts ever undertaken by the federal government.

lead_paragraph: If one of the overt Democratic lines of attack against Republicans is that Republicans are conducting a war on women, one of the low-simmering, implicit lines of attack from Republicans is that Democrats are conducting a war on men, or at least traditional views of masculinity.

lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — After enduring years of industrial decline, the people of this northern city are not new to building, or to rebuilding, and they have experienced things far worse than the loss of a few more soccer matches than usual.

lead_paragraph: A move to protect freshly cooked meals in French restaurants, an interest rate increase in Turkey and a video camera maker that wants to become a media company.

headline: Presidential States
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A presidential promise and a pickle, and another trial for Amanda Knox.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s State of the Union address certainly lacked the raw drama that other presidents around the world generated last week: Viktor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine took “sick leave” as two months of protests sapped his powers; Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was snubbed in Brussels; the love life of France’s François Hollande remained stubbornly in the news; Mohamed Morsi of Egypt was confined to a soundproof cage at his trial; Bashar al-Assad of Syria heard no weakening of calls for his ouster at peace talks in Geneva.

headline: Tech Rides Are Focus of Hostility in Bay Area
keywords: ['Buses', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Rising resentment against elite technology firms manifests itself in demonstrations at public bus stops in San Francisco, where private shuttle buses ferry engineers to work.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Like huge lumbering beasts, the luxury buses shuffle down Valencia Street.

headline: Israeli Military Strikes Targets in Gaza
abstract: The Israeli military said it struck a plant for weapons manufacturing, a weapons storage site and what it called a “terror activity site.”
lead_paragraph: Israeli warplanes carried out raids against three Palestinian targets in Gaza early Friday, soon after militants fired a rocket from Gaza into southern Israel. The Israeli military said it struck a plant for weapons manufacturing, a weapons storage site and what it called a “terror activity site.” Ashraf al-Qedra, a spokesman for the Hamas-run Health Ministry in Gaza, said that five Palestinians were wounded, including a 6-year-old girl, who lived near one of the targets and was injured by flying glass. Later Friday, Israeli forces fired on Palestinians who had entered a restricted buffer zone in two areas along the fence separating northern Gaza from Israel, wounding seven. The military said that the soldiers opened fire to disperse rioters who were hurling rocks along the fence.

headline: Paul Allen, the Seahawks’ Man in the Shadows, Shows Them the Light
abstract: The unassuming Allen — a businessman, philanthropist and the owner of multiple sports teams — became the franchise’s patron, cheerleader and good-luck charm.
lead_paragraph: As the Seattle Seahawks prepared to play the San Francisco 49ers in the N.F.C. championship game two weeks ago, the anticipation at CenturyLink Field was palpable. The fans roared as the home team was introduced. They chanted fight songs. They booed the visitors.

headline: Texas: Historic Status for Astrodome
abstract: The Houston Astrodome, which has languished since being shuttered nearly six years ago, has earned a listing in the National Register of Historic Places.
lead_paragraph: The Houston Astrodome, which has languished since being shuttered nearly six years ago, has earned a listing in the National Register of Historic Places. But the federal listing, made public on Thursday, may not be enough to save the 48-year-old stadium from the wrecking ball. Officials in Harris County are undecided about its fate after voters last year turned down a $217 million plan to redevelop the site into a convention and event center. A spokesman for Harris County’s top elected official, Judge Ed Emmett, said the dome’s inclusion in the register “would have no practical effect on the county’s ability to either repurpose the Astrodome for future use or to demolish it.”

headline: Callahan Trade Talk Overshadows Victory
abstract: The Rangers’ victory over the Islanders was almost a side note as speculation mounted Friday that Ryan Callahan, the team’s captain, may be traded.
lead_paragraph: After the exhilaration of two victories at Yankee Stadium, it was back to reality, and a foreboding one at that, for Rangers fans on Friday. As they sat in Madison Square Garden and watched the Rangers beat the Islanders, 4-1, the fans knew they might be watching Ryan Callahan’s last game with the team.

headline: Bloomberg Picked to Be Climate Envoy
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire former mayor of New York City, has a new job: United Nations special envoy for cities and climate change.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire former mayor of New York City, has a new job: United Nations special envoy for cities and climate change. The United Nations secretary general’s office said Friday that Mr. Bloomberg would be responsible for nudging cities around the world to take steps to combat climate change, helping to “raise political will and mobilize action among cities” in the months before a climate summit meeting that is scheduled to take place in New York in September. The United Nations climate agenda has been entangled in arguments between rich and poor nations over who should more urgently take steps to reduce carbon emissions. As mayor, Mr. Bloomberg set a citywide goal to slash emissions by 30 percent by 2030. He tried to penalize taxi owners who did not use fuel-efficient hybrid cars, but the courts blocked that effort in 2011, calling it a de facto regulation of emissions standards — a power that, under existing laws, belongs to the federal government. Reuters first reported the news of Mr. Bloomberg’s appointment early on Friday. “I can’t think of a person better suited for this important new role,” Secretary of State John Kerry said in a statement.

headline: At Barclays Center, Nothing Can Stop Kevin Durant Except the Bench
abstract: Durant sat out the fourth quarter, ending his 12-game streak of scoring at least 30 points, but the Thunder routed the Nets for their 10th straight win.
lead_paragraph: Seconds before the opening tip on Friday night at Barclays Center, Kevin Durant skipped alone across the baseline — his eyes partly closed, his head tilted backward — and let out a prolonged scream. It was an aggressive posture that did not bode well for the Nets.

headline: Conservative Groups Outpaced in Fund-Raising Stakes
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections']
abstract: Republican-oriented outside groups last year raised $7.2 million for the 2014 campaign season.
lead_paragraph: A network of outside groups with close ties to Republican Party leaders raised just $7.2 million last year, group spokesmen said on Friday, suggesting some top donors remain on the sidelines as the 2014 campaign season begins.

abstract: Britton Colquitt, the punter for the Denver Broncos, talks about what it's like being from a family of punters, three of which have played in the N.F.L.

headline: Making Surveillance a Little Less Opaque
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Editorials']
abstract: Communications companies should be allowed to disclose government demands for private data.
lead_paragraph: One of the most disturbing aspects of the surveillance programs revealed by Edward Snowden is how little we knew about the information federal agencies have collected about millions of people. That is partly because these agencies have put severe limits on how much private telephone and Internet companies can disclose about the data they have been ordered to turn over to the government.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:15 P.M. (HBO) EPIC (2013) The spirited 17-year-old daughter (Amanda Seyfried) of an eccentric scientist (Jason Sudeikis), trying to prove the existence of a nearly invisible kingdom, ventures into a lush forest and shrinks to two inches, the better to ride on the backs of hummingbirds, in this animated film inspired by William Joyce’s children’s book “The Leaf Men and the Brave Good Bugs.” There, she meets the leader of the Leafmen (above, voiced by Colin Farrell), an army of ecowarriors committed to saving their environment from the evil Boggans, who want to turn it into a wasteland. Beyoncé Knowles provides the voice for the Leafmen’s ruler, whose 100-year reign will end when a flower pod bursts under a full moon to reveal the new queen; Christoph Waltz is the leader of the Boggans, who cruise on flying rodents; and Steven Tyler is the distracted yellow caterpillar in charge of recording the forest’s history. “The gorgeous 3-D adventure comedy,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, “suggests a warmer, fuzzier ‘Avatar,’ with a green heart. Directed by Chris Wedge, the movie is a hymn to nature rendered in phantasmagoric detail as refined as anything I’ve seen in a computer-animated family film. But as beautiful as it is, ‘Epic’ is fatally lacking in visceral momentum and dramatic edge.” Still, he added, “for what it’s worth, ‘Epic’ is on the side of the angels.”

headline: Fund-Raising by G.O.P. Rebels Outpaces Party Establishment
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Political Action Committees', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Underscoring a potential shift of power in the Republican Party, candidates are counting on outside groups critical of the leadership for campaign muscle.
lead_paragraph: Insurgent conservatives seeking to pull the Republican Party to the right raised more money last year than the groups controlled by the party establishment, whose bulging bank accounts and ties to major donors have been their most potent advantage in the running struggle over the party’s future, according to new campaign disclosures and interviews with officials.

headline: Reopening an Employment Door to the Young
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Careers and Professions', 'Internships', 'Youth']
abstract: Many employers lament recent graduates’ lack of specialized skills. But a management consultant says these young people still offer much potential for a company’s future.
lead_paragraph: Most of the leaders with whom I work as a management consultant are a level-headed lot. They rarely let their personal feelings interfere with business decisions.

headline: True South | New Orleans Dining, High and Low
abstract: In the first episode of True South, a new video series, T’s contributing editor Sara Ruffin Costello visits two buzzy just-opened restaurants, Killer Poboys and Marti’s, that capture the essence of the modern-day New Orleans culinary scene.
lead_paragraph: “The past doesn’t pass away so quickly here,” Bob Dylan said about New Orleans. In the debut of True South, a new video series, Sara Ruffin Costello, a T contributing editor, shows how that’s still true about eating out in the Big Easy, visiting two wildly popular new restaurants in the French Quarter that “springboard off the classics” in very different ways. One is Killer Poboys, a delicious sandwich shop in the back of a dive bar; the other is Marti’s, a onetime local institution that has been relaunched as a model for fun, upscale culinary excellence. Each in its own way offers up an essential New Orleans flavor.

headline: When Your App Is in the Cloud
abstract: Cloud-based communication services like Twilio are likely to promote even more connections between us and our devices, as developers add features to apps that can deliver a lot of personal information to a call center when it’s needed.
lead_paragraph: The telecommunications services business, worth about $1 trillion in annual, global sales, is starting to feel the effects of cloud computing, one of this era’s most important advances in high tech.

headline: The Work Before the Parachute Jump
keywords: ['Parachutes and Parachute Jumping', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An Army sergeant who packs parachutes for the military’s use says the work is intensive — involving up to 12 safety checks.

headline: Trying to See Apple From a Different Angle
abstract: Wall Street can’t decide whether a giant company can still grow by leaps and bounds — or whether it even needs to.
lead_paragraph: The stock market doesn’t know quite what to make of Apple.

headline: That Neurotic on the Team? Give Him Time
abstract: Research suggests that while neurotics in the workplace are initially seen as less capable than extroverts, peers’ estimation of them later tends to rise.
lead_paragraph: Neurotics rejoice. If you can.

headline: Jody Greenstone Miller, on Not Overselling the Job Ahead
abstract: The chief executive of the Business Talent Group says it’s important to tell prospective hires about both the positives and negatives of the work.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Jody Greenstone Miller, co-founder and C.E.O. of the Business Talent Group, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. The Business Talent Group provides independent professionals for project-based work.

headline: Phoning From Prison, at Prices Through the Roof
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Federal regulators are capping the cost of interstate phone calls between inmates and those on the outside, but rates on calls made within a state can remain sky-high.
lead_paragraph: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Get Some Sleep, and Wake Up the G.D.P.
abstract: Americans’ lack of sleep isn’t just making them cranky. It’s also hurting productivity, and thus the wider economy.
lead_paragraph: January is always a good month for behavioral economics: Few things illustrate self-control as vividly as New Year’s resolutions. February is even better, though, because it lets us study why so many of those resolutions are broken.

headline: Vows: Finding Love, Again
abstract: Anne Tarbell and William Marden III each lost their longtime spouses to cancer in 2010. Starting over again was frightening, but they adopted the mantra "life is for living."
lead_paragraph: Anne Tarbell and William Marden III each lost their longtime spouses to cancer in 2010. Starting over again was frightening, but they adopted the mantra "life is for living."

headline: How de Blasio Measures Up on the Court, Field and Ice
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio is New York City’s tallest mayor in the modern era. But just how tall is he compared to some notable New York professional athletes?
lead_paragraph: While Mayor Bill de Blasio towers above most characters on the New York political stage, he would hardly be an outlier among New York’s best known professional athletes, depending on the sport.

headline: 1959: Oslo’s Worry: What Will Tourists Think?
abstract: Even if visitors tend to overlook it, Oslo has a charm of its own, argued The New York Herald Tribune in 1959.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — Oslo is the Little Orphan Annie of the northern capitals. Stockholm is the “Venice of the North,” Copenhagen, we all know, is “wonderful,” but Oslo has no such label — and it feels the lack most bitterly. It is always panting to catch up.

headline: And Now, a Preview From Your Sponsor
abstract: Advertising columnist Stuart Elliott discusses which Super Bowl commercials have already generated the most buzz.
lead_paragraph: Advertising columnist Stuart Elliott discusses which Super Bowl commercials have already generated the most buzz.

headline: A Long Fight to Get What Was Theirs, in a 401(k)
abstract: After a five-year battle, retirement account holders of a collapsed company can finally touch their money.
lead_paragraph: Five years, two articles in this space, assistance from the Labor Department and the Internal Revenue Service and prodding from one no-nonsense bankruptcy judge — that’s what it took for owners of the 401(k) plan sponsored by Penn Specialty Chemicals to gain access to their money last month.

headline: Chasing Their Star, on YouTube
keywords: ['Video Recordings and Downloads', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: The message to aspiring video makers on YouTube is clear, and seductive: Attract an audience, build your brand. But success, let alone stardom and wealth, remains elusive.
lead_paragraph: It is 3 p.m., and outside another brilliant Los Angeles afternoon beckons. But Olga Kay has drawn her blinds, leaving her living room in a semidarkened haze.

headline: Heat Are Listing, but Righting Ship Will Not Take Much
abstract: Injuries have prevented Miami from gaining ground on highflying Indiana, but the Heat have virtually no competition for the No. 2 seed in the East.
lead_paragraph: When they came to New York to face the Knicks on Jan. 9, the Miami Heat were 27-8. Trailing the Indiana Pacers by one game for the best record in the Eastern Conference, the Heat seemed to be coasting through the season in their pursuit of a third consecutive championship.

headline: Variety: Out of Order
abstract: Patrick Blindauer, you evil genius… I’ll get you next time!
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — The man in this photo is Patrick Blindauer. He looks like a nice guy, right? You would never know that beneath that friendly, dapper exterior lurks the heart of a madman, and I say that as someone who is very fond of him. His mother probably says that about him, too.

headline: Super Bowl XLVIII Matchup: Seahawks vs. Broncos
abstract: For the first time since 1990, the Super Bowl will pit the N.F.L.’s highest-scoring offense (Denver) against the defense that gave up the fewest points (Seattle).
lead_paragraph: Seahawks vs. Broncos

headline: Major Volcanic Eruption Kills at Least 14 in Indonesia
abstract: Mount Sinabung, which has been erupting for months, unleashed a major eruption on Saturday, a day after evacuated villagers were allowed to return home.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An active volcano on Indonesia’s Sumatra Island unexpectedly erupted again on Saturday, killing at least 14 people and spreading toxic clouds of hot ash that hampered search and rescue teams, officials said.

headline: Gun Battle in Bangkok Escalates Election Protest
abstract: At least six were injured in a battle between protesters seeking to block the distribution of ballots and would-be voters demanding that protesters stop trying to obstruct elections on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — At least six people were injured Saturday in a prolonged daylight gun battle between protesters seeking to block the distribution of ballots in Bangkok and would-be voters demanding that protesters cease their attempts to obstruct national elections on Sunday.

headline: Glitches in State Exchanges Give G.O.P. a Cudgel
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)']
abstract: State-run health insurance exchanges are now the biggest laggards in fixing enrollment problems, and Republicans have vowed to make them an election issue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the federal online insurance exchange running more smoothly than ever, the biggest laggards in fixing enrollment problems are now state-run exchanges in several states where the governors and legislative leaders have been among the strongest supporters of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Law Doesn’t End Revolving Door on Capitol Hill
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Former officials have little trouble passing through loopholes in laws intended to keep them from immediately lobbying their onetime colleagues.
lead_paragraph: A top aide to a Republican congressman from Arizona helped promote a legislative plan to overhaul the nation’s home mortgage finance system. Weeks after leaving his government job, he reappeared on Capitol Hill, now as a lobbyist for a company poised to capitalize on the plan.

headline: As Players’ Agents, Women Face Extra Challenges
abstract: Agency is the very definition of an old boys’ club, a sharp-elbowed, cutthroat world, and few women are willing to put up with the skepticism and sexism that confront them at every turn.
lead_paragraph: Women who are agents for N.F.L. players have heard every criticism imaginable — of their credentials, their experience, their negotiating skills. Yet for Kelli Masters, perhaps the low point came when, just as she thought she had persuaded a player from Oklahoma to sign as a client for his first N.F.L. contract, she was stopped short by his mother, of all people.

headline: Macroeconomic Populism Returns
abstract: Sometimes heterodox policies are wrong, too.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Yglesias says what needs to be said about Argentina: there’s no contradiction at all between saying that Argentina was right to follow heterodox policies in 2002, but it is wrong to be rejecting advice to curb deficits and control inflation now. I know some people find this hard to grasp, but the effects of economic policies, and the appropriate policies to follow, depend on circumstances.

headline: Maturity’s Victories
abstract: In Peyton Manning’s path to the Super Bowl, you see the sweet side of Father Time.
lead_paragraph: BEAR in mind that what you’re about to read comes from someone whose creaky knees protest any run longer than three miles, whose achy left shoulder just got its first cortisone shot and whose haircuts are more ceremonial than functional, given that nature is doing a barber’s work. I have a vested interest in coming up with an argument that older is somehow better.

headline: Canada May Have to Go to Olympics Without Lightning’s Stamkos
abstract: The Olympic fate of the Tampa Bay Lightning’s Steven Stamkos, who has not played since breaking his leg in November, could be decided this week.
lead_paragraph: The Olympic fate of Canada’s Steven Stamkos, who has not played since breaking his leg in November, could be decided this week.

headline: Denver’s Offense (Unstoppable) vs. Seattle’s Defense (Unmovable)
abstract: Seattle’s hopes of containing the league’s best offense hinge on its ability to mount long drives, and its N.F.L.-leading defense’s success in hurrying Peyton Manning and jamming Bronco receivers.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Max Unger, Seattle’s starting center, hails from Hawaii, excelled as a rebounder for his high school basketball team and, about 100 pounds ago, loved to skateboard. None of that would be relevant to the outcome of the Super Bowl except that Unger’s chief adversary, Denver’s 335-pound defensive tackle Terrance Knighton, probably knew all those facts last week.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Before Hitting and Fielding, Young Mets Seek Edge by Running and Stretching
abstract: Team executives wanted to offer some of their younger players a regimented off-season training program, and Ruben Tejada wound up having the most to prove.
lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH, Mich. — Thirty minutes west of Detroit, at an indoor sports complex that could otherwise pass as a warehouse, several of the more intriguing members of the Mets gathered to train this off-season.

headline: He’s Pete Carroll’s Guardian Tweeter
abstract: As a reporter for his college newspaper, Ben Malcolmson tried out for Southern California’s football team and made it, beginning an enduring professional relationship with Seahawks Coach Pete Carroll.
lead_paragraph: Ben Malcolmson had a cool, if not totally original, idea. As an enterprising football beat reporter for the student newspaper at Southern California, he decided to try out for Coach Pete Carroll’s powerhouse team even though he had not played the game since the fifth grade back home in Dallas.

headline: Protesters Beat Police Officer in Ukraine, Ministry Says
abstract: Antigovernment protesters in Kiev captured and beat a plainclothes policeman in the part of the city controlled by demonstrators, the authorities said Saturday.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Antigovernment protesters here in the capital, who have become angrier and rougher in recent weeks, captured and beat a plainclothes police officer in the part of the city controlled by demonstrators, the authorities said Saturday.

headline: Remembering Nodar
abstract: The world knows Nodar Kumaritashvili as the luge athlete who died on the eve of the 2010 Winter Olympics, but his sister remembers a brother and a mentor.
lead_paragraph: The world knows Nodar Kumaritashvili as the luge athlete who died on the eve of the 2010 Winter Olympics, but his sister remembers a brother and a mentor.

headline: A Lethal Luge Accident Still Questioned
abstract: With a new Olympic competition approaching, friends and family continue to seek answers and action after the 2010 death of the luge athlete Nodar Kumaritashvili.
lead_paragraph: With a new Olympic competition approaching, friends and family continue to seek answers and action after the 2010 death of the luge athlete Nodar Kumaritashvili.

headline: A Swift and Fatal Luge Plunge, and Then an Abyss of Sorrow
abstract: Nodar Kumaritashvili of Georgia died at 21 in a luge crash as he practiced for the 2010 Winter Olympics, a tragedy that stunned the sports world and left his family seeking answers.
lead_paragraph: BAKURIANI, Georgia — To reach this tiny skiing village, carved into the north side of the Trialeti mountain range, one must weave through a long progression of switchbacks rising more than a mile above sea level. When it is snowing — which is often — the trip from the capital city of Tbilisi can take nearly three hours.

headline: Dylan Farrow’s Story
abstract: Now that Hollywood has told the story of Woody Allen’s long career in film, Dylan Farrow, his adopted daughter, is ready to have her say.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Woody Allen received a Golden Globe award for lifetime achievement a few weeks ago, there was a lively debate about whether it was appropriate to honor a man who is an artistic giant but also was accused years ago of child molestation.

headline: The Gospel According to Paul
