abstract: When it comes to fooling around with an intern in the Oval Office, is there a political statute of limitations?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — SO how do you make Monica haunt Hillary’s dreams?

headline: What G.O.P.-Style Reform Looks Like
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: An alternative plan falls far short of what the existing health care law already provides.
lead_paragraph: Three Republican senators — Orrin Hatch of Utah, Tom Coburn of Oklahoma and Richard Burr of North Carolina — have issued an alternative to the health care reforms that they deride as Obamacare. Conservative analysts have hailed their proposals as “an important milestone in the health care debate” and a “reform that has enormous promise.” But the plan, which is hard to parse because it has not been put into precise legislative language, looks inferior in most respects to the existing law.

headline: A Ghastly Injustice in India
abstract: The full weight of the law must be brought down on the perpetrators of another horrific gang rape.
lead_paragraph: Yet another horrific gang rape has grabbed headlines in India. This time, a village council in the Indian state of West Bengal ordered the rapes as punishment. The crime: falling in love and planning to marry.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Immigration Delusion
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Foreign Workers', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: This time, the base is right to just say no to reform.
lead_paragraph: THE debate over immigration reform, rekindled last week by House Republican leaders, bears a superficial resemblance to last fall’s debate over the government shutdown.

headline: Phedon Papamichael
abstract: The cinematographer for “Nebraska” on ethnic music and classic sports cars.
lead_paragraph: Phedon Papamichael is a Greek cinematographer whose visual sense has shaped more than 40 feature films including “Nebraska,” which brought him an Oscar nomination this year.

headline: Ashes to Ashes, but First a Nice Pine Box
abstract: Building my own coffin was a way to accept death and celebrate life.
lead_paragraph: PRAIRIE VILLAGE, Kan. — NOT long ago, my wife and I had a good friend over for a glass of wine. We had drunk just enough to feel pleasantly liberated in thought. Or at least that’s how I felt. Probably that’s why it seemed a good moment to bring it up. So, I calmly announced to my wife: “I’m going to build my own coffin. I just thought you should know.”

headline: A Wonderful Country
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Palestinians', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Why the success of John Kerry’s peace mission is so important.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — One of the most popular shows on Israeli TV is called “Eretz Nehederet” or “A Wonderful Country.” It’s a comedy show that lives to make fun of Israeli politicians and the absurdities of life here. It recently opened its 2014 season with a cartoon graphic of a beautiful, multicolored, flower-filled garden with a butterfly fluttering across the screen. Then, suddenly, a concrete wall rises up all around the garden, which was an image the producers used last year. But this season not only does the wall emerge but a glass dome rises out of the wall and seals off this Garden of Eden from above as well.

headline: How the Fed Learned to Talk
abstract: Communication is now a tool of economic policy.
lead_paragraph: BINGHAMTON, N.Y. — IN his nearly 19 years as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan was notorious for speaking in an elliptical, oracular, even mystifying style. Mindful that a single errant syllable might cause markets to soar — or tumble — Mr. Greenspan mastered a language, “Fed-speak,” so turgid that it made economics textbooks seem like children’s literature by comparison.

headline: Scribbling in the Margins
abstract: The jottings we make in the books we own may well be among the highest tributes we pay to authors.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, N.J. — THE graduate student thrust the library book toward me as though brandishing a sword. “This has got to stop,” she said. “It isn’t fair. How can I work on my dissertation with this mess?” As she marched out of my office, leaving the disfigured volume behind, her words stung — for the code of civility on which libraries depend had been violated. She was the third Ph.D. student in less than a year to bring me a similarly damaged volume, and each had expected me as the library director to turn sleuth, solve the mystery, and end the vandalism.

headline: When Pedestrians Get Mixed Signals
abstract: We choose to criminalize jaywalking. But why isn’t there an offense of “jaydriving?”
lead_paragraph: A FEW years ago, I was waiting to cross the street in Los Angeles.

headline: A Life After Prison
abstract: Readers discuss efforts to reduce the inmate population and help re-entry into society.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss efforts to reduce the inmate population and help re-entry into society.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 2
abstract: Reactions to the State of the Union address and preparations for the Super Bowl will dominate the conversation on the Sunday morning shows.
lead_paragraph: Several lawmakers gave responses to President Obama’s State of the Union address Tuesday, but they have more to say. Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin who gave the Republican rebuttal in 2011, will share his thoughts on the speech on ABC’s “This Week.” Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington delivered the Republican response this year.

headline: Picking Through a Volcano’s Destruction
abstract: Villagers rushed to clear rubble from a major eruption in Mount Sinabung, Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Villagers rushed to clear rubble from a major eruption in Mount Sinabung, Indonesia.

headline: Super Bowl Tickets Are a Bargain at More Than $2,000
abstract: According to TiqIQ.com, a search engine that scans online ticket resellers, the average asking price for a ticket is $2,645.12, which is 34 percent less than on the day of the A.F.C. and N.F.C. championship games on Jan. 19.
lead_paragraph: “Super Bowl” and “bargain” are words not typically linked. But the steady and precipitous decline in the offering price for tickets to Sunday’s game may invite some fans on a budget.

headline: As the U.S. Seeks a Scorer, One Player Finds the Goal
abstract: Chris Wondolowski, who had both goals in a 2-0 victory over South Korea, could be the goal scorer the Americans need as they head toward World Cup play.
lead_paragraph: CARSON, Calif. — When the United States goes to the World Cup this summer, a familiar question will greet Jurgen Klinsmann, just as it has the coaches who have preceded him: Where will the goals come from?

headline: An Open Letter From Dylan Farrow
abstract: Dylan Farrow, Woody Allen’s adoptive daughter, speaks out about her experience.
lead_paragraph: (A note from Nicholas Kristof: In 1993, accusations that Woody Allen had abused his adoptive daughter, Dylan Farrow, filled the headlines, part of a sensational story about the celebrity split between Allen and his girlfriend, Mia Farrow. This is a case that has been written about endlessly, but this is the first time that Dylan Farrow herself has written about it in public. It’s important to note that Woody Allen was never prosecuted in this case and has consistently denied wrongdoing; he deserves the presumption of innocence. So why publish an account of an old case on my blog? Partly because the Golden Globe lifetime achievement award to Allen ignited a debate about the propriety of the award. Partly because the root issue here isn’t celebrity but sex abuse. And partly because countless people on all sides have written passionately about these events, but we haven’t fully heard from the young woman who was at the heart of them. I’ve written a column about this, but it’s time for the world to hear Dylan’s story in her own words.)

headline: An Unconventional Path to Scripting the Broncos’ Offense
abstract: Adam Gase, 35, the Broncos’ innovative offensive coordinator, is among a small group of expert coaches who hardly ever played the game.
lead_paragraph: Between plays on the field, Peyton Manning appears just a bit unhinged. The body language is manic, an eruption of gesticulating arms, twiddling fingers and fidgeting, stamping feet.

headline: Elusive Cats and Their Endangered Prey
abstract: Threats to leopards’ prey vary widely over remote areas, where research is difficult at best. Here are three prey species known to be in decline.
lead_paragraph: Threats to leopards’ prey vary widely over remote areas, where research is difficult at best. Here are three prey species known to be in decline.

headline: Video Notebook: Peyton Manning
abstract: The Denver Broncos quarterback spoke to the media about the team's offensive coordinator, Adam Gase.
lead_paragraph: The Denver Broncos quarterback spoke to the media about the team's offensive coordinator, Adam Gase.

headline: AT&T Sweetens Offer for Family Plans
abstract: Responding to intense competition, AT&T, the second largest American phone carrier, on Saturday said it would offer a cheaper phone plan for families with multiple devices.
lead_paragraph: AT&T, the second largest American phone carrier, on Saturday said it would offer a cheaper phone plan for families with multiple devices. It was AT&T’s latest big move amid intense competition coming from rivals, especially T-Mobile US.

headline: Taking Cover in Thailand
abstract: Gunfire and violence turned the streets of Bangkok into confusion one day before national elections.
lead_paragraph: Gunfire and violence turned the streets of Bangkok into confusion one day before national elections.

headline: Saving More Than Just Snow Leopards
keywords: ['Leopards', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Wilderness Areas', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: The cat’s plight draws attention to its entire ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: THE cold and rugged mountains of Pakistan, Afghanistan, Tajikistan and China seem an unlikely place to find a flourishing combination of new community institutions and international diplomacy. Few people live there. Those who do are mostly desperately impoverished livestock herders. They have been largely isolated from the rest of humanity on these enormous mountains where the Indian subcontinent once crashed into Asia, buckling the earth’s crust and raising peaks over 20,000 feet.

headline: Indians Protest, Saying a Death Was Tied to Bias
abstract: Hundreds from India’s far northeast demonstrated outside a New Delhi police station, furious over the death of an 18-year-old and complaining of discrimination because of their East Asian features.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Hundreds of young protesters from India’s far northeast demonstrated outside a New Delhi police station on Saturday, furious over the death last week of an 18-year-old man who was injured in a fight with shopkeepers, and complaining of widespread discrimination against them because of their East Asian features.

headline: A Tradition of Stars With Something to Say
abstract: The N.F.L. has always had players who were as memorable off the field as they were on because they had style, a flair for drama and, more often than not, an attention-getting proclamation.
lead_paragraph: Before it was the No Fun League, the N.F.L. had loquacious characters with iconic nicknames. Dandy Don Meredith, Broadway Joe Namath and Deion Sanders, a.k.a. Prime Time, to name a few. They were as memorable off the field as they were on because they had style, a flair for drama and, more often than not, an attention-getting proclamation.

headline: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | Pregame With the Stars
abstract: The Friday before the big game, celebrities rubbed elbows at Cipriani in Midtown Manhattan for the Shape & Men’s Fitness Super Bowl party.
lead_paragraph: Standing weak-kneed and quavering, sometime after a kiss on the cheek from the model Tyson Beckford and a bear hug from the actor Ice T on Friday night, we searched for what exactly we were feeling. Our mind reeled and the stately marble columns of Cipriani in Midtown seemed poised to spin.

headline: At the Town in the Middle, Super Bowl Loyalties Are Difficult to Nail Down
abstract: Halfway between Denver and Seattle, as the crow flies, sits Arco, Idaho, where there is little consensus on which team to root for.
lead_paragraph: Halfway between Denver and Seattle, as the crow flies, sits Arco, Idaho, a farming community that is home to about 950 residents, the Pickle’s Place cafe, an airstrip, the Sawtooth Club, some gas stations and not much else.

headline: Stunned by Tragedy, a Village in Rural Quebec Turns Inward
abstract: After a fire swept through a retirement home in L’Isle-Verte, killing dozens, Quebec is experiencing a horrible sense of déjà vu: It has been only seven months since an oil train exploded into a fireball in Lac-Mégantic, killing 47.
lead_paragraph: L’ISLE-VERTE, Quebec — In the wintry days since a fire swept through the retirement home in this quaint, rambling village along the south shore of the St. Lawrence River, L’Isle-Verte has been overrun by police officers, firefighters, coroners and anthropologists, painstakingly chipping away at the layers of ice encasing the building and digging through the charred ruins.

headline: With Fortune Falling, a 1 Percent Divorce
abstract: Liz and Kent Swig swiftly scaled the heights of Manhattan real estate and social life. Then the market’s walls closed in.
lead_paragraph: This is a story of marriage and money in the 16-room, five-and-a-half-bath duplex world of luxury Manhattan real estate.

headline: Kerry and Hagel Defend U.S. Engagement Abroad in Face of Criticism
abstract: Speaking at the Munich Security Conference, Secretary of State John Kerry expressed some exasperation with the criticism that the United States was retreating from a leadership role.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — The American secretaries of state and defense on Saturday presented an emotional defense of the Obama administration’s engagement in international crises in the face of widespread European and Middle Eastern criticism that the United States was retreating from a leadership role.

headline: So Long, It’s Been Good to Know You, Pete Seeger
abstract: A final musical encounter with Pete Seeger.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a last visit with Pete Seeger, starting with a beautiful, if grainy, video vignette from the Beacon Sloop Club Corn Festival in August, 2012, as he led a chorus of “So Long it’s Been Good to Know You,” a Woody Guthrie tune that was a staple of the Weavers:

headline: Toil and Trouble
abstract: The puzzle that cannot be mentioned, by Dick Shlakman and Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Will Shortz Sighting! Sorry for the short notice, but Will Shortz will be interviewed at 3:30 p.m. Eastern today on MSNBC about competitive crossword solving, because there’s not enough competition going on in sports today.

headline: Maximilian Schell, Oscar-Winning Actor in ‘Nuremberg,’ Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Schell was an Austrian-born actor who won an Academy Award for his role in “Judgment at Nuremberg.”
lead_paragraph: Maximilian Schell, the ruggedly handsome Austrian-born actor who won an Academy Award for his role in “Judgment at Nuremberg,” died early Saturday in Innsbruck, Austria. He was 83.

headline: Political Candidate’s Aides Die in Afghanistan Attack
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Elections', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Two employees of Abdullah Abdullah, a presidential candidate, were fatally shot in the relatively secure city of Herat.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two aides to an Afghan presidential candidate were fatally shot in the relatively secure city of Herat in western Afghanistan on Saturday, officials said, raising questions about the prospects of a peaceful election one day before the official start of the campaign.

headline: Relocating Traditions in China
abstract: Village-based traditions once practiced by close-living families and neighbors are disappearing in an increasingly urban China.
lead_paragraph: Village-based traditions once practiced by close-living families and neighbors are disappearing in an increasingly urban China.

headline: In China, ‘Once the Villages Are Gone, the Culture Is Gone’
abstract: Rapid urbanization in China means village life, the bedrock of Chinese culture, is rapidly vanishing, and with it, traditions and history.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Once or twice a week, a dozen amateur musicians meet under a highway overpass on the outskirts of Beijing, carting with them drums, cymbals and the collective memory of their destroyed village. They set up quickly, then play music that is almost never heard anymore, not even here, where the steady drone of cars muffles the lyrics of love and betrayal, heroic deeds and kingdoms lost.

headline: F.C.C. Says It Will Double Spending on High-Speed Internet in Schools and Libraries
abstract: Financing for an increase to $2 billion a year will come from restructuring the $2.4 billion E-Rate program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission will double the amount of money it devotes to adding high-speed Internet connections in schools and libraries over the next two years, in an effort to meet President Obama’s promise to provide broadband service for an estimated 20 million American students in 15,000 schools, officials said Saturday.

headline: A Deepening Drought in the West
abstract: Near-empty reservoirs, parched fields, starving livestock, clouds of smog and outbreaks of wildfires.
lead_paragraph: Near-empty reservoirs, parched fields, starving livestock, clouds of smog and outbreaks of wildfires.

headline: Severe Drought Has U.S. West Fearing Worst
abstract: With no sign of rain, 17 rural California communities providing water to 40,000 people are in danger of running out within 60 to 120 days.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The punishing drought that has swept California is now threatening the state’s drinking water supply.

headline: Chris Christie’s Office Targets Former Ally in a Memo
abstract: The administration of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey portrayed David Wildstein as a loose cannon who was attacking the governor only in an effort to save himself.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie’s administration struck back hard and personally on Saturday against a former ally who accused the governor of lying about how much he knew about the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, a scandal that has become the biggest crisis in Mr. Christie’s political career.

headline: Strahan Is Among 7 Elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame
abstract: Among those chosen alongside the Giants’ Michael Strahan was Ray Guy, widely recognized as the greatest punter and now the first pure punter elected to the Hall.
lead_paragraph: A supersize smile that revealed a wide gap between his two front teeth made Michael Strahan appear to be a friendly giant roaming the fields of the N.F.L. in his 15 seasons with the Giants. But to opposing quarterbacks, he was far more menacing, registering 141 ½ sacks, including a single-season record 22 ½ in 2001.

headline: A Supersize Celebration in Manhattan
abstract: Before the big game, the National Football League has transformed 13 blocks of New York’s iconic Broadway into Super Bowl Boulevard.
lead_paragraph: Before the big game, the National Football League has transformed 13 blocks of New York’s iconic Broadway into Super Bowl Boulevard.

headline: Raiding Japan on Fumes in 1942, and Surviving to Tell How Fliers Did It
abstract: As a sergeant at 22, Edward J. Saylor was one of 80 Army Air Forces fliers on a mission to strike Japan after the attack on Pearl Harbor; at 93, he is one of four left.
lead_paragraph: ENUMCLAW, Wash. — At age 93, Edward J. Saylor still works in his shop behind the house, making stained-glass art and retreating to a cozy armchair for some afternoon TV when the weather turns cold. He lives, he says, quietly in a quiet spot, among the pastures and fields of this community 40 miles south of Seattle.

headline: College Basketball: Day’s Story Lines
abstract: Some of the top trends from Saturday’s games.
lead_paragraph: JUWAN STATEN, left, had a career day with 35 points as host West Virginia beat Kansas State, 81-71. He shot 8 of 13 from the field and 18 of 21 from the line, both career bests.

headline: A Mayor Most Everybody Looks Up To, Even When He Slouches
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, the tallest mayor in New York’s modern history, is discovering that bigness can also be a burden, requiring a host of ergonomic adjustments and feats of stagecraft in City Hall.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York is so tall that city workers had to build an oversize podium for him, installing a custom sliding step that can be pulled out for shorter speakers.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 1, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Pro-Business Stance That’s Bad for Business
abstract: The Texas environmental commission’s refusal to enact federal rules on issuing greenhouse gas permits has actually put the state at a competitive disadvantage during a natural gas boom.
lead_paragraph: Businesses in energy-related industries in Texas say they have been unable to take full advantage of the natural gas boom that is roaring across the state because of a delay in the issuing of greenhouse gas permits — an instance in which Texas’ antiregulation stance might have actually hurt business.

headline: Friends Are Nice, but Their Checks Are What Matter
abstract: Candidates brag about the number of supporters who donate small amounts, but the millionaires’ and billionaires’ club is thriving in Texas politics.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: Nets’ Williams Gets Start, but Pacers Hold On at End
abstract: Deron Williams, who had come off the bench in his previous six games, had 13 points and 6 assists, but the Nets were edged by the Pacers for their third straight loss.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The uncertainty, Deron Williams said, has been the most maddening thing.

headline: Corrections: February 2, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 2, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Spurred by Global Crises, Germany Weighs a More Muscular Foreign Policy
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Some German leaders are even suggesting that the country should no longer reflexively avoid some military deployments, as it did in Libya almost three years ago.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — German leaders are pushing a vigorous new case that it is time for their nation to find a more muscular voice in foreign affairs, even suggesting that Germany should no longer reflexively avoid some military deployments, as it did in Libya almost three years ago.

headline: The Lone Survivor Is Turning Retreats Into a Way Forward
abstract: Marcus Luttrell, the retired Navy SEAL member whose story became the basis for the movie “Lone Survivor,” is trying to help other veterans through a specialized course of healing.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Luttrell, the Navy SEAL whose 2007 memoir “Lone Survivor” inspired the movie, says he wrote the book to honor three Navy SEAL teammates who died fighting the Taliban in the mountains of northeastern Afghanistan, along with 16 other soldiers who were killed during a rescue attempt.

headline: As Gaming Halls Make a Comeback, a Crackdown Loses Steam
abstract: Gaming rooms, also known as eight-liners or maquinitas, are common again in Laredo, Tex., and officials have mixed opinions on whether to enforce the state’s $5-a-game limit on prizes.
lead_paragraph: LAREDO, Tex. —  The lights coming from the digital slot machines danced on rows of empty chairs on a recent night in a South Texas gaming hall that was only partially filled.

headline: ‘Girls’ Recap:  Kicked Out of a  Funeral
abstract: Fresh faces contributed to some of the funnier scenes.
lead_paragraph: “Solipsistic? Navel-gazing? Vainglorious?”

headline: Richard Grossman, Crusading Publisher of 1960s, Dies at 92
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Mr. Grossman published Ralph Nader’s “Unsafe at Any Speed,” the 1965 book that helped jump-start the modern consumer movement.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1960s, Richard Grossman, who died on Monday at 92, was a new publisher looking for a big book, and automobile safety appealed to him as a topic. He had been moved by an article on the subject in The New Republic.

headline: World’s No. 2 Player Ready to Challenge for the Top Spot
abstract: Levon Aronian dominated the Tata Steel Chess Tournament last week and may get a chance to take on the world titleholder, Magnus Carlsen, in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Levon Aronian wrapped up a dominating performance at the Tata Steel Chess Tournament in the Netherlands last Sunday, finishing well ahead of a field that included many of the world’s best players. It was the latest indication that he is ready to challenge the world champion, Magnus Carlsen.

headline: His Friends Know Him as Petroswickonicovick
abstract: Carrying an extraordinary name is remarkably widespread in Brazil. Just ask Wonarllevyston Garlan Marllon Branddon Bruno Paullynelly Mell Oliveira Pereira.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — When he became a teenager, Wonarllevyston Garlan Marllon Branddon Bruno Paullynelly Mell Oliveira Pereira did what any self-conscious person worried about merciless taunting from his peers might do: He pleaded with his parents and the courts to let him change his name.

headline: James Hotter Than Anthony, and the Knicks Lose
abstract: LeBron James scored 30 points, overshadowing Carmelo Anthony at Madison Square Garden, as the Heat ended the Knicks’ four-game winning streak.
lead_paragraph: Just when the Knicks were starting to build momentum, the Miami Heat cooled them off.

headline: Miklos Jancso Dies at 92; Made Stylized Films of War and Tyranny in Hungary
abstract: Mr. Jancso built an international reputation with a handful of early works, including “The Round-Up” and “Red Psalm,” that were distinct in both style and substance.
lead_paragraph: Miklos Jancso, a Hungarian filmmaker who used episodes from his nation’s history to create critically praised parables of war and oppression, died on Friday. He was 92.

headline: Mitch Landrieu Is Re-elected Mayor of New Orleans
abstract: Mr. Landrieu won 64 percent of the vote, which was partly seen as a referendum on the city’s progress since Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Mitch Landrieu cruised to a second term as mayor on Saturday, having successfully made the case to a large majority of this city’s residents that the recovery from Hurricane Katrina, while incomplete, is heading in the right direction.

headline: Tracy High, Roman Johnson
abstract: The bride is a partner in a law firm in New York; the groom is a personal trainer and fitness model.
lead_paragraph: Tracy Richelle High and Roman Wayne Johnson were married Saturday evening at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y. The Rev. Robert J. Allmen of the Reformed Catholic Church officiated.

headline: A Kiss She Just Couldn’t Forget
abstract: Many decades later, when they reconnected, she still remembered his kiss.
lead_paragraph: Diana Louise Biederman and Vincent Anthony DeLongis were married Saturday at Marina Jack, a restaurant and boat dock in Sarasota, Fla. Charles Cooper, a Florida notary public, officiated.

headline: Ye Chen and Jishang Wei
abstract: The bride is a researcher in dermatology; the groom is a research scientist.
lead_paragraph: Ye Grace Chen and Jishang Wei were married Saturday at the Stanford University Church in Stanford, Calif. The Rev. Scotty McLennan, the dean for religious life at Stanford and a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Anne Tarbell and William Marden III
abstract: The bride is an executive at an investment management firm; the groom is an executive at First Republic Bank.
lead_paragraph: Anne Adler Tarbell and William Walker Marden III were married Saturday at St. James’ Church in New York. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson, an Episcopal priest and the rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Lisa Udelson and Chris Nee
abstract: A wedding in Beverly Hills for a filmmaker and a producer of children’s television shows.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Jane Udelson and Chris Nee were married Friday at the Beverly Hills Courthouse in Los Angeles. Nancy Claibourne, a deputy marriage commissioner, officiated.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 2, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, February 2, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “There is no second, no minute, where I can escape this tragedy. Not even 1 percent remains of the person I was.”

headline: Chinese Lunar New Year
abstract: Ushering in the year of the horse.
lead_paragraph: Ushering in the year of the horse.

headline: What’s On Today?
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6 P.M. (Fox) SUPER BOWL XLVIII The Denver Broncos face off against the Seattle Seahawks at MetLife Stadium, above, in East Rutherford, N.J. Joe Buck provides play-by-play; Troy Aikman is the analyst. Kickoff is at 6:30. Bruno Mars will take the stage at halftime with the Red Hot Chili Peppers as special guests; Renée Fleming will perform the national anthem; and Queen Latifah and the New Jersey Youth Chorus will sing “America the Beautiful.” “Fox Super Bowl Sunday,” hosted by Terry Bradshaw and Curt Menefee, will offer pregame coverage, starting at 2 in Times Square before moving to the Meadowlands. Segments include a homage to the coach Vince Lombardi, presented by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York; a reading from the Declaration of Independence by National Football League owners and players; a tribute to the former player and broadcaster Pat Summerall, who died in April; and red-carpet coverage by Michael Strahan and Charissa Thompson. Bill O’Reilly will interview President Obama from the White House at 4:30.

headline: Founding Editor Is Dismissed as Head of El Mundo
abstract: Rather than blame his dismissal on El Mundo’s financial losses, Pedro J. Ramírez accused Spain’s government of engineering retribution for reports on a series of corruption cases.
lead_paragraph: The financial downturn in Spain’s newspaper industry has claimed its most prominent journalist to date, Pedro J. Ramírez, who was ousted as editor of El Mundo, the conservative newspaper he founded 25 years ago.

headline: Protesters Disrupt Thai Voting, Forcing Additional Elections
abstract: Opposition forces vowed to contest the results of Sunday’s election, in which their efforts to block polling sites mostly affected Bangkok and areas surrounding it.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Protesters seeking to overthrow the government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra disrupted Thailand’s general election on Sunday in what appeared to be a prelude to more political upheaval.

headline: Tech’s Diversity Problem Is Apparent as Early as High School
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Education (K-12)', 'Equal Educational Opportunities', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: In several states, no girls, black or Hispanic students took the Advanced Placement exam in computer science last year, illustrating the lack of diversity in the tech industry.
lead_paragraph: In three states, not a single girl took the Advanced Placement exam in computer science last year. In eight states, no Hispanic students took it. And in 11 states, no black students took the test.

headline: Death Toll Climbs After Major Volcanic Eruption in Indonesia
abstract: Toxic clouds of hot ash hampered teams searching for survivors from Saturday’s eruption at Mount Sinabung, which killed at least 15 people.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The death toll from the sudden eruption of an active volcano on Indonesia’s Sumatra Island rose to 15, officials said Sunday, as toxic clouds of hot ash hampered search and rescue teams looking for more victims and survivors.

headline: The Pregnancy Is Gone, but the Promotions Keep Coming
abstract: A month before what would have been my due date, the promotional box of Enfamil baby formula arrived. “You’re almost there!” it read. We weren’t.
lead_paragraph: My husband placed the package on the table. “You’re not going to believe this.”

headline: In Our Pages: February 3
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1889: Cloud Of Mystery Around Prince Rudolph’s Death

headline: N.F.L. Honors
abstract: The 3rd annual N.F.L. Honors awards ceremony was held at Radio City Music Hall on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: The 3rd annual N.F.L. Honors awards ceremony was held at Radio City Music Hall on Saturday night.

headline: Venture Will Mine Twitter for Music’s Next Big Thing
abstract: Twitter and 300, a new company started by Lyor Cohen, one of music’s biggest power brokers, announced a partnership that hopes to analyze users’ posts to identify promising talent.
lead_paragraph: For the music business, Twitter holds a vast haystack of data with no easy way to find the most valuable needles — like which acts are attracting the most attention, and where.

headline: Disruptions: Paying to Travel in the Internet’s Fast Lanes
abstract: Has the Internet become so fundamental to our lives that it is, in essence, a utility that should be subject to regulation?
lead_paragraph: For a subject that sounds mind-numbingly dull, “network neutrality” is the most important issue facing the Internet since, well, the Internet.

headline: The New Bern Raid
abstract: Robert E. Lee’s daring plan to capture a small North Carolina town — and keep his army fed.
lead_paragraph: By the end of 1863, Confederate soldiers in the Eastern Theater and Tennessee were surviving on a quarter pound of meat and a pound of cornmeal a day, if they were lucky. The Union Army could draw on food, clothing and livestock from untouched farms in nearby Maryland and Pennsylvania or shipped from the old Northwest. It was a crisis at the forefront of Gen. Robert E. Lee’s mind. But, he wrote Jefferson Davis on Jan. 2, 1864, there was a chance — right then — to feed, clothe and shod their soldiers for a spring campaign.

headline: Be Nice to Your Social Studies Teacher
abstract: You never know when it may turn relevant.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie’s political success in New Jersey was based on the perception that his personal style — which involved lots of yelling at people — was a sign of his governing effectiveness. This perception may have flourished most easily in a state whose informal motto is “You got a problem with that?”

headline: Super Bowl XLVIII: Seahawks Dominate Broncos to Win First Title
abstract: Hours before the MetLife Stadium gates open, a host of Times reporters, photographers and editors will offer live coverage of the weather, commute and the pregame atmosphere leading up to the N.F.L. championship game, followed by analysis of Super Bowl XLVIII, the commercials and the halftime show.
lead_paragraph: Seattle outmatched Denver from the beginning of the game to the end, crushing Peyton Manning and the Broncos offense. Times reporters, editors and photographers offered updates all day and throughout the game on everything from the weather to the commercials, from the traffic to the halftime show. They even mixed in some football analysis.

headline: The Great Recession: Causes and Consequences, 2/03/14
abstract: Oh what a lovely slump.
lead_paragraph: Slides for my first lecture are here.

headline: Netanyahu Criticizes Kerry Over Boycott Remarks
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized Secretary of State John Kerry for warning that Israel could face more foreign boycotts if the peace process fails.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and some of his senior ministers on Sunday strongly criticized groups who are threatening a boycott of Israel over its policies toward the Palestinians. Their remarks were a sharp retort to Secretary of State John Kerry, who warned a day earlier that the risk of boycotts would intensify should the current Middle East peace effort fail.

headline: The Revolving Door: An Annotated Case Study
abstract: Documents outline the speedy transition of a top congressional aide who went from working for changes to a mortgage law on the Hill to lobbying his old boss for a company that would benefit such measures.
lead_paragraph: Documents outline the speedy transition of a top congressional aide who went from working for changes to a mortgage law on the Hill to lobbying his old boss for a company that would benefit such measures.

headline: The Other Pre-Game Show
abstract: In the days before the Super Bowl, there is always a lot of attention on the parties. But the N.F.L. Honors, held this year at Radio City, gets a huge turnout of players
lead_paragraph: In the days before the Super Bowl, there is always a lot of attention on the parties. But the N.F.L. Honors, held this year at Radio City, gets a huge turnout of players, from legends to rookies like Eddie Lacy of the Green Bay Packers.

headline: Super Bowl Casts Shadow Over Movie Box Office
abstract: Two studios offered smaller films aimed at audiences considered the least likely to be interested in the football game.
lead_paragraph: Movie studios may line up to advertise during the Super Bowl, but they typically avoid releasing substantial new movies on game weekend – too much competition from beer and bean dip (and, oh right, football). This year, two studios offered smaller films aimed at audiences considered the least likely to be interested in televised sports: young girls and the intelligentsia. Both fizzled, albeit to differing degrees.

headline: Writers Guild Crowns ‘Her’ and ‘Captain Phillips’
abstract: The awards are considered imperfect predictors of Oscar success as eligibility rules differ.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:11 p.m. | NEW YORK — “Captain Phillips” and “Her” were the best adapted and original screenplays of the year, according to the Writers Guild of America, which gave out its prizes in simultaneous ceremonies in New York and Los Angeles on Saturday.

headline: Philip Seymour Hoffman, Actor of Depth, Dies at 46
abstract: Mr. Hoffman was among his generation’s most ambitious and admired American actors, playing sidekicks, villains and lead roles on stage and in film.
lead_paragraph: Philip Seymour Hoffman, perhaps the most ambitious and widely admired American actor of his generation, who gave three-dimensional nuance to a wide range of sidekicks, villains and leading men on screen and embraced some of the theater’s most burdensome roles on Broadway, died on Sunday at an apartment in Greenwich Village he was renting as an office. He was 46.

headline: You Could Call It Theater of the Cabsurd
abstract: “Take Me Home,” an immersive theater piece, treats audiences of three to a unique ride in a New York cab.
lead_paragraph: Driving in New York City is difficult enough. Imagine doing it while performing.

headline: Making a Dramatic Case for a Soviet-Era Composer
abstract: Gideon Kremer and his Kremerata Baltica put the spotlight on the composer Mieczyslaw Weinberg at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: It was a big night in New York on Thursday for a generation of composers who came of age in the former Soviet Union and who, since its fall, have increasingly flourished in the West. And for one of them, it was part of an even larger moment.

headline: Republicans Vague on Citizenship Question
abstract: Republican lawmakers, in television appearances, remained vague on whether they would support a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Republican lawmakers on Sunday remained vague on whether they would support a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants as many Democrats do, focusing instead on related issues like border security and enforcement while leaving uncertain the prospects for a broader overhaul of the system.

headline: Philip Seymour Hoffman Is Remembered by Fellow Actors on Twitter
abstract: His career in film and theater spanned many years and covered many roles, and fellow actors quickly took to social media platforms to react to news of his death.
lead_paragraph: Philip Seymour Hoffman’s career in film and theater spanned many years and covered many roles. And on Sunday, fellow actors quickly took to social media platforms to react as news of his death was confirmed.

headline: Greece’s Far-Right Party Tries to Evade Government Crackdown With a New Name
abstract: Golden Dawn announced the formation of a new political party as a way to circumvent possible efforts by the government to outlaw the organization.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Encircled by a phalanx of riot police officers, members of Greece’s far-right party Golden Dawn announced the formation of a new political party late Saturday as a way to circumvent possible efforts by the government to outlaw the organization ahead of European elections.

headline: Super Bowl Underscores the Big Business of Must-See, Live TV
abstract: At a time of atomization and endless special-interest hobbit holes, big live television events like the Super Bowl fulfill our need for something, anything, in common.
lead_paragraph: It is a fact of modern life that the mass has gone out of media, with television ratings reflecting that each of us is building our own little campfire on our phone, tablet and big screen at a time and place of our choosing.

headline: Hoping to Stay Independent, Jos. A. Bank in Talks to Buy Eddie Bauer
abstract: On Sunday, Jos. A. Bank publicly released a letter to Men’s Wearhouse accusing its bigger rival of failing to properly disclose the antitrust risks in its takeover bid.
lead_paragraph: As Jos. A. Bank continues to rebuff a hostile takeover bid by Men’s Wearhouse, the clothier is exploring at least one alternative deal that would keep it independent.

headline: Airline Sets Deadline on Talks With Alitalia
abstract: Etihad Airways of Abu Dhabi says its discussions with Alitalia over a possible investment in the troubled Italian airline have entered “the final phase.”
lead_paragraph: After reviewing Alitalia’s books for more than a month, Etihad Airways of Abu Dhabi said on Sunday that it was in serious negotiations over a possible investment in the troubled Italian airline, and it set a 30-day deadline to wrap up a deal.

headline: A Boyish Style Works Just Fine for the Man With the League’s Best Defense
abstract: Pete Carroll has put together an old-school, hard-nosed defense unit that relies on airtight man-to-man coverage in the secondary and hard knocks and no-frills pressure from the defensive front seven.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Pete Carroll was raised on the gospel of defense. On Sunday, Seattle’s effervescent coach added thousands — maybe millions — to his congregation.

headline: Shiffrin Hits Rare Bump on Way to Olympics
abstract: Mikaela Shiffrin, the 18-year-old star of American skiing, was in range of another victory in slalom, but she hit a deep rut that resulted in a seventh place finish at a race in Slovenia.
lead_paragraph: KRANJSKA GORA, Slovenia — At 18, the skiing wunderkind Mikaela Shiffrin of the United States has already proved that she has an uncommon ability to take on high-pressure situations and prevail.

headline: Feisty Opera Impresario Regrets Lost Opportunity
abstract: In a rare interview, Gerard Mortier talks about the demise of New York City Opera and his recent work at the Teatro Real in Madrid.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — “I have changed,” Gerard Mortier said immediately in an interview last week at Teatro Real, the opera company here. Until recently, he was its artistic director.

headline: Pro-Am Tournament Raises $100,000 for Parkinson’s Disease
abstract: Zeke Jabbour, an eight-time national champion, hosts an annual charity pro-am tournament to benefit the National Parkinson Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Zeke Jabbour, an eight-time national champion, hosts an annual charity pro-am tournament to benefit the National Parkinson Foundation. Led by Joanne Weingold and Molly O’Neill, this year’s event was held Jan. 26 at St. Andrews Country Club in Boca Raton, Fla. Simultaneously, anyone could play the same deals at the Common Game website, which was organized by Jay Whipple. With sponsorship from Netjets, the event raised about $100,000.

headline: Academy President Defends Ruling on Song
abstract: Cheryl Boone Isaacs, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, defended that organization’s decision to rescind an Oscar nomination for the song “Alone Yet Not Alone.”
lead_paragraph: Cheryl Boone Isaacs, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, defended that organization’s decision to rescind an Oscar nomination for the song “Alone Yet Not Alone,” from the film of same title, in an interview with The Hollywood Reporter on Saturday. The Academy had been criticized by some who said that it was biased because the song had come from a faith-based film. “This is not about the film,” Ms. Isaacs said. “We are adamant about keeping the integrity of our voting process.” She said that it was the appearance of undue influence by the song’s composer, Bruce Broughton, who emailed fellow members of the Academy’s music branch, prompting the decision to rescind the nomination. “Our purpose is to keep a level playing field and to keep it anonymous,” Ms. Isaacs said. “So when one person — in this case, Mr. Broughton — sends out an email driving the voting members to a specific song that’s his, it does break the rules.”

headline: Cataclysm Has Arrived: Man’s Inhumanity to Nature
abstract: Elizabeth Kolbert uses a rare rhino and crow and the stories of other endangered or already vanished species to illustrate the fallout of mankind’s transformation of the ecological landscape.
lead_paragraph: The plight of doomed, extinct or nearly extinct animals is embodied in Elizabeth Kolbert’s arresting new book, “The Sixth Extinction,” by two touching creatures.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Feb. 3
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Ringing in the Chinese Zodiac’s Year of the Horse
abstract: Three soloists and a Chinese superstar vocalist helped the New York Philharmonic celebrate the Chinese New Year at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: According to the Chinese zodiac, 2014 is the Year of the Horse. For the New York Philharmonic’s Chinese New Year celebration on Saturday night, two enormous, inflated golden horses were placed on the outer balcony of Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Underworld Notes, in the Homeric Sense
abstract: “Acheron,” a new work by Liam Scarlett at New York City Ballet, takes its place, and name, from Homer’s afterlife.
lead_paragraph: The young British choreographer Liam Scarlett still looks cherubic: curly-haired, wide-eyed, with a touch of puckishness. What’s curious is that his mind, by contrast, repeatedly turns to subjects of darkness, death and the dead.

headline: Poor Game Seals Season but Not Debate on Legacy
abstract: For Peyton Manning, winning the Super Bowl to burnish his reputation should have been beside the point. The best cannot afford to make their legacies a game-day obsession.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Seattle Seahawks ripped out the feel-good ending to Peyton Manning’s storybook season. Tore the final pages to shreds. Burned them in a fire. Left Manning and his Denver Broncos looking like outdated print in a digital world.

headline: Luring With Sound, but Aiming for Something Deeper
abstract: “Nous: A Musical Rite” included a mix of alternative music and dance at Basilica Hudson.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. — You could argue that any concert with a subtitle is not an inevitable occurrence — that it was theorized or curated into being. And so perhaps with “Nous: A Musical Rite,” a half-airy, half-aggressive three-hour interdisciplinary happening that had its first performance on Saturday night here at Basilica Hudson.

headline: Ethical Concerns Hit Oscar Races
abstract: Two controversies over the weekend renewed the question of whether Academy members should weigh moral and ethical concerns when they cast their votes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Next week, about 6,000 Oscar voters will start casting ballots for their favorite films of 2013 and those who made them.

headline: A Modigliani? Who Says So?
abstract: Art by Modigliani illustrates the confusion surrounding the authentication of expensive works, and a legal hearing on Thursday is one example of how the art market contends with this uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Three daunting facts confront anyone interested in buying one of Amedeo Modigliani’s distinctive elongated portraits. They tend to have multimillion price tags; they are a favorite of forgers; and despite an abundance of experts, no inventory of his works is considered both trustworthy and complete.

headline: Staying True to Greece While Drawing on Some Wider Influences
abstract: Eleftheria Arvanitaki, the Greek singer, tended to the traditional and included touches of pop in her show at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Greek singer Eleftheria Arvanitaki, who performed for an adoring crowd on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, is part of an international sorority of musicians who have merged national traditions with pop. She has collaborated with some of them, including Cesária Évora from Cape Verde, Buika from Spain and Dulce Pontes from Portugal, and in Greece Ms. Arvanitaki is so celebrated that she was chosen to sing her hit “Dynata” (“It’s Possible”; the word also means “strong”) at the closing ceremony of the 2004 Olympics in Athens.

headline: Checkout Counter Staple
abstract: A sweet puzzle by Sean Dobbin.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Before we discuss today’s puzzle, Will Shortz reports from the front lines of the 15th annual Westport (Connecticut) Public Library crossword puzzle contest that was held on Saturday, with about 120 puzzle enthusiasts from New York and Connecticut attending:

headline: How Inequality Hollows Out the Soul
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Income Inequality', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Our tendency to equate wealth with inner worth invokes deep psychological responses.
lead_paragraph: One of the well-known costs of inequality is that people withdraw from community life and are less likely to feel that they can trust others. This is partly a reflection of the way status anxiety makes us all more worried about how we are valued by others. Now that we can compare robust data for different countries, we can see not only what we knew intuitively — that inequality is divisive and socially corrosive — but that it also damages the individual psyche.

headline: Abortions Declining in U.S., Study Finds
abstract: Wider contraceptive use is a factor, as 1.1 million abortions were reported in 2011, the Guttmacher Institute said, compared with 1.21 million reported in a similar study in 2008.
lead_paragraph: The abortion rate among American women declined to its lowest level in more than three decades in 2011, according to a new report released Monday that is widely considered the country’s most definitive examination of abortion trends.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 27-Feb. 2
abstract: Collisions and precision in a week of action.
lead_paragraph: Collisions and precision in a week of action.

headline: Ex-Chicago Mayor Daley Still in Intensive Care
abstract: Richard M. Daley, 71, is undergoing tests to determine the nature of his illness.
lead_paragraph: Richard M. Daley, the former mayor of Chicago, remained hospitalized in an intensive care unit on Sunday and will most likely stay there for several days as doctors run tests to determine the nature of his ailments, officials said.

headline: The Dangers of Certainty: A Lesson From Auschwitz
abstract: How a single episode of a 1973 BBC series taught a young boy one of the most powerful moral lessons of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: As a kid in England, I watched a lot of television. There weren’t any books in our house,  not even the Bible. TV was therefore pretty important, omnipresent actually. Of course, most of what it delivered was garbage. But in 1973, the BBC aired an extraordinary documentary series called “The Ascent of Man,” hosted by one Dr. Jacob Bronowski in 13 hour-long episodes. Each episode was what he called an “essay” and involved some exotic and elaborate locations, but the presentation was never flashy and consisted mostly of Dr. Bronowski speaking directly and deliberately to the camera.

headline: U.S. Player Ratings: Wondolowski and Defense Stand Out
abstract: The United States defeated South Korea, 2-0, on Saturday to open its 2014 schedule, but the most important element is what Coach Jurgen Klinsmann learns from the game.
lead_paragraph: The United States men’s soccer team opened its 2014 schedule with a 2-0 exhibition win over South Korea on Saturday in Carson, Calif., thanks in part to a fine effort by Chris Wondolowski and a defensive unit that bent but would not break to preserve the shutout.

headline: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | An Extraordinary Hassle for an Extraordinary Party
abstract: To get into a Super Bowl party on the West Side, checkpoints, metal detectors and pat downs had to be endured.
lead_paragraph: Shunted by a police detail into a scrum of people on the corner of Morton Street and the West Side Highway at 9:30 on Saturday night, we realized that we were headed to no ordinary party.

headline: Detention and Deportation
abstract: Representative Bob Goodlatte responds to an editorial about detention of illegal immigrants.

headline: Obama Is Tackled by O’Reilly in Pre-Game Interview
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Super Bowl', 'Football']
abstract: Mr. Obama was grilled about the botched rollout of the health care law and the attack on the American post in Benghazi, Libya, among other issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some of the hardest hits of Super Bowl Sunday came a couple of hours before kickoff.

headline: Building a Better Battery
abstract: As tech companies focus on small, wearable devices, they have encountered an obstacle: Battery technology is largely stuck in the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The next breakthrough smartphone, or maybe the one after that, might not have a traditional battery as its sole source of power. Instead, it could pull energy from the air or power itself through television, cellular or Wi-Fi signals.

headline: Palestinian Leader Seeks NATO Force in Future State
abstract: Palestine, President Mahmoud Abbas said, would not have its own army, only a police force, so the NATO mission would prevent the weapons smuggling and terrorism that Israel fears.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Six months into peace talks dominated by discussion about security, President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority has proposed to Secretary of State John Kerry that an American-led NATO force patrol a future Palestinian state indefinitely, with troops positioned throughout the territory, at all crossings, and within Jerusalem.

headline: A New Way to Rein In Fat Cats
keywords: ['Government Procurement', 'Executive Compensation', 'Minimum Wage', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Limit the earnings of the top-paid federal contractors.
lead_paragraph: UNION VALE, N.Y. — PRESIDENT OBAMA’S planned directive to increase the minimum wage for employees of federal government contractors has prompted the usual tiresome reactions in Washington and the media echo chamber we euphemistically call “debate.”

headline: Sudan Tells Red Cross to Halt Work
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The government determined that the group, which helps more than a million people in Sudan, had not fulfilled unspecified conditions for its aid efforts, the state-run news agency said.
lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — The Sudanese government has ordered the International Committee of the Red Cross, which helps well over a million people in conflict areas in Sudan, to suspend its operations in the country, the organization said Sunday.

headline: We Need G.M.O. Wheat
abstract: Farmers are missing out on plants that can survive drought.
lead_paragraph: THREE crops — corn, soybeans and wheat — account for a vast majority of the value of America’s agricultural crop output. But wheat is different in one important respect. While more than 90 percent of the nation’s corn and soybean acres are now planted with seeds genetically engineered to resist insects, herbicides or both, there is not a single acre of genetically engineered wheat being grown commercially in the United States.

headline: Give the Data to the People
abstract: Results of clinical trials should be accessible to all scientists.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, Johnson & Johnson announced that it was making all of its clinical trial data available to scientists around the world. It has hired my group, Yale University Open Data Access Project, or YODA, to fully oversee the release of the data. Everything in the company’s clinical research vaults, including unpublished raw data, will be available for independent review.

headline: Abbas’s NATO Proposal
abstract: In an interview, Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, stepped up his call to use NATO forces to secure a future peace deal.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — At Tel Aviv’s Ben Gurion Airport there is a photo exhibition of great moments in Israeli airline history. One large black-and-white photograph caught my eye. It was a picture of Egypt’s President Anwar Sadat seated with Israel’s Prime Minister Menachem Begin on a flight, with both men laughing — their faces radiating friendship.

headline: Kerry and Iran Minister Confer on Nuclear Issue
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif said Iran wanted to negotiate seriously, and he offered to begin a dialogue on human rights issues with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, met for an hour on Sunday with Secretary of State John Kerry, another sign of serious efforts to solve the crisis around Iran’s nuclear program. The two met on the margins of the Munich Security Conference here, and Mr. Zarif later said on a public panel that Iran “will go to those negotiations with the political will and good faith to reach an agreement.”

headline: Texas Republicans Vying for Lieutenant Governor Lean Heavily Right
abstract: The four rivals in a close primary race for a position that is a powerful behind-the-scenes force are trying hard to appeal to grass-roots conservatives and Tea Party supporters.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — One candidate has called for the impeachment of President Obama. Another wants the National Guard to help secure the border. Yet another criticized the openly lesbian mayor here for marrying her longtime partner in Palm Springs, Calif., saying it was “part of a larger strategy of hers to turn Texas into California.” And all of the leading contenders want to allow Texans to carry handguns in holsters on their hips.

headline: For Restless Pioneer of Modern Tattoo Art, a Life Beyond Ink
abstract: Nowadays, it seems everybody has a tattoo, but if there is someone to thank for the art’s increased acceptance and visibility, it might be Thom DeVita.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the cluttered studio inside Thom DeVita’s Victorian house marvel at the artwork that covers the walls, his drawing table, even his hands. The images reflect not just his interests, but his skills, which he honed as a tattoo artist on the Lower East Side for some 30 years; a storied era to aficionados. The accomplishment was all the more remarkable because it was illegal in New York City at the time.

headline: With Renée Fleming, Super Bowl XLVIII Gets an Operatic Opening
abstract: The N.F.L. and Fox deserve credit for thinking outside the usual pop-music box in selecting the opera singer Renée Fleming to perform the national anthem at this year’s Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Renée Fleming became the first opera singer to perform the national anthem at the Super Bowl on Sunday at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., but the word “opera” went unmentioned in her introduction.

headline: Placed on Unpaid Leave, a Pregnant Employee Finds Hope in a New Law
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Paid Time Off']
abstract: The Pregnant Workers Fairness Act, which took effect in New York City on Thursday, requires employers to make reasonable accommodations.
lead_paragraph: Floralba Fernandez Espinal rose at 6:50 that morning. For the first time in weeks she felt no misgivings about going to work, no anxieties about her pregnancy.

headline: Imax Faces a Threat in China
abstract: Not only could competitors in China cut into its potential market share there, but Imax has charged in several courts that the Chinese system relies on technology that was blatantly stolen from its offices in Canada.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “We’ve got the future under control,” contends OmniCorp, the giant technology corporation in “RoboCop,” a blockbuster remake set for release by Sony Pictures and MGM next month.

headline: Philip Seymour Hoffman’s Many Roles
abstract: A look back at the career of Philip Seymour Hoffman, who was found dead Sunday. He was perhaps the most admired American actor of his generation.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the career of Philip Seymour Hoffman, who was found dead Sunday. He was perhaps the most admired American actor of his generation.

headline: Syria Hits Areas Held by Rebels in Aleppo
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Makeshift bombs were dropped across the south and east of the country’s largest city, killing at least three dozen people, most of them women and children, antigovernment activists said.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Syrian government aircraft continued to strike rebel-held areas in Aleppo with makeshift bombs on Sunday, killing at least three dozen people, most of them women and children, antigovernment activists said.

headline: The Middle Class Is Steadily Eroding. Just Ask the Business World.
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The post-recession reality is that the customer base for businesses that appeal to the middle class is shrinking as the top tier pulls even further away.
lead_paragraph: In Manhattan, the upscale clothing retailer Barneys will replace the bankrupt discounter Loehmann’s, whose Chelsea store closes in a few weeks. Across the country, Olive Garden and Red Lobster restaurants are struggling, while fine-dining chains like Capital Grille are thriving. And at General Electric, the increase in demand for high-end dishwashers and refrigerators dwarfs sales growth of mass-market models.

headline: Tamils’ Smuggling Journey to U.S. Leads to Longer Ordeal: 3 Years of Detention
abstract: Experts said the Sri Lankans’ saga shows the subjective nature of immigration enforcement and raises questions about how refugees who cooperate in human trafficking cases are treated.
lead_paragraph: Five Sri Lankan men left hometowns reeling from the remnants of a ruthless civil war and embarked on a monthslong human-smuggling journey that spanned seven countries.

headline: Halftime Brings a Much-Anticipated ‘Seinfeld’ Reunion
abstract: A few members of the show’s cast appeared in a truncated version of an episode of Jerry Seinfeld’s web series, “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee.”
lead_paragraph: The cast of “Seinfeld” – a couple of cast members, anyway — really did get together for a reunion on Sunday night, at the start of halftime in the Super Bowl.

headline: Documents in New Jersey Bridge Scandal Set to Start Pouring In
abstract: A leader of a joint legislative panel investigating the conduct of Gov. Chris Christie’s administration warned that reviewing the thousands of subpoenaed papers could take weeks.
lead_paragraph: For most people attending the Super Bowl on Sunday, the most important outcome on their minds was that of the clash between teams on the playing field.

headline: Delusions of Failure
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: On health care reform, the Republican Party is deceiving voters — and itself.
lead_paragraph: The Republican response to the State of the Union was delivered by Cathy McMorris Rodgers, Republican representative from Washington — and it was remarkable for its lack of content. A bit of uplifting personal biography, a check list of good things her party wants to happen with no hint of how it plans to make them happen.

headline: As Ukraine’s President Returns From Leave, His Options Seem Dismal
abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovych may need to choose between a bloody suppression of protesters or a surrender of authority that could leave him as president but empower his opponents.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — When President Viktor F. Yanukovych returns to work on Monday after a four-day sick leave, he will find that even after that brief absence his options for resolving Ukraine’s political crisis have already narrowed.

headline: In the Forecast, More of the Off-White Stuff
abstract: The city’s Department of Sanitation has used about 250,000 tons of road salt so far this season. On busy days at the Atlantic Salt Company on Staten Island, trucks start to line up at 3:30 a.m.
lead_paragraph: The business model for the Atlantic Salt Company on Staten Island basically boils down to passing the salt.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Cleanup Campaign
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo should be ready to campaign against any lawmaker who resists his crucial reforms, including public financing of New York elections.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants to make the fight against corruption in Albany a major theme in his re-election campaign this year. Given the arrests, convictions and accusations of misbehavior involving state legislators in recent years, that makes sense. And to show he’s serious this time, the governor has announced a package of reforms, including public financing of elections, as part of his 2014-15 budget. His task now is to persuade the Legislature to go along. It won’t be easy, but he should be ready to campaign against any lawmaker, Democrat or Republican, who resists these crucial reforms.

headline: Libya’s Cache of Toxic Arms All Destroyed
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'International Relations']
abstract: The United States and Libya in the past three months have discreetly destroyed what both sides say were the remnants of Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi’s arsenal of chemical arms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as the international effort to destroy Syria’s vast chemical weapons stockpile lags behind schedule, a similar American-backed campaign carried out under a cloak of secrecy ended successfully last week in another strife-torn country, Libya.

headline: Not Quite 75 and Sunny, but a Mild Day Dispels the Worries About the Weather
abstract: Snow and the polar vortex stayed away, and the mild weather at the Super Bowl gave hope to cold-weather cities hoping to host the event.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — John Dalena and his son Mike were prepared for the worst. In the back of their car parked near MetLife Stadium, they had snow pants, extra sweatshirts and other cold-weather gear to keep them warm after kickoff at the Super Bowl still three hours away.

headline: After Burying Thousands, a Gravedigger Retires
abstract: Frank Drahos is retiring after spending his career interring thousands of notables and commoners in Westchester’s Sleepy Hollow Cemetery.
lead_paragraph: SLEEPY HOLLOW, N.Y. — If there’s one thing a gravedigger knows, it’s that nothing lasts forever.

headline: A Tiny Glimmer From North Korea
abstract: Its unpredictable leader agrees to family reunions between citizens of South Korea but goes full tilt on his nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: North Korea recently reversed itself and accepted South Korea’s proposal to hold long-overdue family reunions between citizens of the two countries.

headline: Battles Loom in Many States Over What to Do With Budget Surpluses
abstract: Unexpectedly robust revenues from taxes and other sources are filling state coffers, prompting battles over what to do with the newfound money.
lead_paragraph: In a year when three dozen governors are up for election, unexpectedly robust revenues from taxes and other sources are filling most state coffers, creating surpluses not seen in years and prompting statehouse battles over what to do with the money.

headline: The Capitol’s Spinning Door Accelerates
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics (Institutional)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Editorials']
abstract: More former lawmakers and staff members are getting big paychecks from corporate interests.
lead_paragraph: The anonymous congressional staff members who write the nation’s laws generally work hard for fairly modest wages. Increasingly, though, they do so because there is a promise of K-Street riches at the end of their toil.

headline: News Giant in Japan Seen as Being Compromised
abstract: NHK is under criticism amid signs it is hewing to an agenda approved by the rightist government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — First, there was the abrupt resignation of the public broadcasting chief accused by governing party politicians of allowing an overly liberal tone to news coverage. Then, his successor drew public ire when he suggested the network would loyally toe the government line.

headline: Big-Band Lover Has a Second Houseful of Old Songs
abstract: Vince Giordano of Brooklyn bought a second home to store his collection of song arrangements, sheet music and piano rolls.
lead_paragraph: Vince Giordano owns a home in Brooklyn, where he lives with his music.
