abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Adoption, Does Race Matter?
abstract: Some advocates argue that interracial adoption harms minority children. Others say the best home may not always be with same-race parents.

headline: Newly Wary, Shoppers Trust Cash
keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Consumer Protection', 'Identity Theft', 'Personal Finances', 'Debit Cards', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: After disclosures about credit and debit card breaches at several major retailers, some shoppers are making the effort to use cash in lieu of cards.
lead_paragraph: Like dieters vowing to trade cupcakes for carrots, a number of American shoppers are making a new pledge: cash only.

headline: ‘Mass-Transit Super Bowl’ Hits Some Rough Patches in Moving Fans
abstract: In moving the masses — with many unfamiliar with the intricacies of the system — glitches developed and patience wore thin.
lead_paragraph: About four hours before Sunday’s Super Bowl kickoff, fans of all jersey colors appeared to achieve a moment of angry unity while stuck inside a Secaucus, N.J., rail station. The air was stale, the heat had become blistering, and the ordeal was going on and on, approaching an hour. “A.C.! A.C.!” the fans shouted in a plea for cooler conditions as they strained to get a little closer to the connecting trains to MetLife Stadium.

headline: Method of Study Is Criticized in Group’s Health Policy Tests
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Research', 'Clinical Trials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Medicare']
abstract: A research center funded by the Affordable Care Act is being criticized for not using proven methods like clinical trials to learn how to best deliver care.
lead_paragraph: The idea seemed transformative. The Affordable Care Act would fund a new research outfit evocatively named the Innovation Center to discover how to most effectively deliver health care, with $10 billion to spend over a decade.

headline: At DC, Comic Book Covers Get Cross-Marketing Role
abstract: DC Comics is using its covers to promote Scribblenauts Unmasked, a video game released by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment last year, as well as a line of toys that will come out this month.
lead_paragraph: Advertising for X-ray Specs and Sea-Monkeys has long appeared inside the pages of comic books. Now, DC Comics is turning its covers into a marketing tool.

headline: El Salvador and Costa Rica Hold Presidential Elections
abstract: Both elections were expected to be closely fought contests that focused less on ideology than on unease over unemployment, corruption and crime.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Two Central American countries, El Salvador and Costa Rica, put incumbent parties to the test on Sunday in what were expected to be closely fought presidential elections that focused less on ideology than on unease over unemployment, corruption and crime.

headline: Philip Seymour Hoffman Said to Be Found With Syringe
abstract: Mr. Hoffman’s body was discovered by a friend around 11:30 a.m. in the fourth-floor apartment at 35 Bethune Street, which he rented as an office.
lead_paragraph: The family and friends of the actor Philip Seymour Hoffman expressed shock and sadness after he was found dead on Sunday of an apparent drug overdose at an apartment in Greenwich Village.

headline: A Circus of Intimate Sensation
abstract: In the immersive tradition of “Sleep No More” comes “Queen of the Night,” an interactive experience including acrobatic acts, striptease, physical contact and lavish dining.
lead_paragraph: Do not forget to pack the Purell if you’re even mildly germ-phobic and planning to attend “Queen of the Night,” the latest invasive theater piece — sorry, I mean immersive theater piece — to open in New York. Should you be among the many attendees treated to close encounters with the comely young cast members, expect to have some skin-on-skin contact, albeit of a strictly PG-13 kind.

headline: A Screamer at the Museum of Modern Art
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A visitor to the Museum of Modern Art was moved to ask an understandable question about an unhappy child.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Recap: Showdown Between Lady Violet and Isobel
abstract: Fans of the series have been spoiling for several years for a decisive showdown – a “super bowl,” some called it – between these witty aristocrats.
lead_paragraph: Isobel Crawley headed into tonight’s championship game here at Downton Abbey with the righteousness of her convictions, a few well-chosen quips and a strategically placed letter-knife. But after a bruising and occasionally ugly battle, it was her longtime rival, Lady Violet, the Dowager Countess, who emerged with the only thing that mattered: a victory.

headline: Unlikely Allies Seek to Check Power of Activist Hedge Funds
abstract: The Shareholder-Director Exchange seeks to provide board members and institutional investors with a protocol to follow when either side wants to talk with the other.
lead_paragraph: Relations between big public companies and their largest shareholders can at times take on the qualities of a long, unsatisfactory marriage. Complaints from the shareholders are many, but they go mostly unspoken, leading to simmering resentment.

headline: Super Bowl Security Breach Comes After Game, in an Interrupted News Conference
keywords: ['Super Bowl', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Football', 'Stadiums and Arenas']
abstract: Perhaps the most bizarre security breach of the Super Bowl happened when a man leapt on the platform during a news conference and grabbed a microphone.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Tens of millions of dollars were spent securing the Super Bowl and the events beforehand, but perhaps the most bizarre security breach happened after the game, when Malcolm Smith, the game’s most valuable player, was speaking with reporters.

headline: After Risqué Years, Super Bowl Commercials Go Warm and Fuzzy
abstract: Most commercials during Super Bowl XLVIII put on a decidedly happy face, using upbeat themes and positive images to attract viewers.
lead_paragraph: ALMOST everyone seemed relieved that the first cold-weather Super Bowl played outdoors was not an ice bowl. As for the advertising extravaganza that took place during the game, it turned out to be a nice bowl.

headline: Petition Seeking to Void Brooklyn Murder Conviction Calls Verdict a ‘Sham’
abstract: The lawyer for John Giuca, who was convicted in 2005 for the murder of Mark Fisher, wrote a petition detailing serious prosecutorial misconduct and recanting witnesses.
lead_paragraph: The 2005 conviction of John Giuca for the murder of Mark Fisher, a college football player from New Jersey, was a “sham” built on prosecutorial misconduct, a feeble defense, contradictory evidence, a biased juror and the testimony of witnesses who have since recanted, Mr. Giuca’s lawyer wrote in a scathing petition to be sent to the Brooklyn district attorney on Monday.

headline: Corrections: February 3, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 3, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 3, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, February 3, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I saw him last week, and he was clean and sober, his old self. I really thought this chapter was over.”

headline: Forget Forecast: Seahawks Pour It On in the Super Bowl
abstract: Seattle’s fast, physical defense smothered Peyton Manning and the Broncos at MetLife Stadium as the Seahawks romped to their first Super Bowl title.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There was pressure, so much pressure at MetLife Stadium. The Seattle Seahawks embraced it, inflicted it, reveled in it. They spoke all week of their respect for Peyton Manning and the Denver Broncos’ high-powered offense, but, they said, wait until Sunday. Just wait.

headline: After Scandal, SAC Capital Begins to Fade to Black
abstract: Steven A. Cohen’s hedge fund is completing plans to change its corporate structure by mid-March, according to people briefed on the matter, an effort that comes after SAC pleaded guilty to insider trading.
lead_paragraph: SAC Capital Advisors, synonymous with an insider trading scandal that has consumed the hedge fund industry, will soon cease to exist as Wall Street has known it.

headline: No Friend to Mayors, a Groundhog Leaves de Blasio Empty-Handed
abstract: When Mayor Bill de Blasio clutched the groundhog and stood up, Chuck leapt out of the mayoral arms toward the crowd and onto the ground, where he was recovered, uninjured, by his handler.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after sunrise on Sunday, Mayor Bill de Blasio approached a little log cabin at the Staten Island Zoo — the home, at least for that morning, of a groundhog named Charles G. Hogg, or Chuck.

headline: Twitter Reports Earnings; Debt Ceiling Looms Again
abstract: Twitter will report fourth-quarter financial results, its first update on how the company is doing since it first sold stock to the public on Nov. 7., and more.
lead_paragraph: VERDICT NEARS IN MARTOMA TRIAL

headline: No Malfunctions at Halftime, Just Safe Entertainment
abstract: At 28, Bruno Mars was the youngest solo headliner at the Super Bowl, and he put on a show that was like a performance by an extremely gifted cover band.
lead_paragraph: For 10 years now, the Super Bowl has attempted to deliver a halftime performance that would be distracting, but maybe not memorable.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry for the Week of Feb. 3

headline: Sherman Quiet, but Rest of Seattle Defense Has a Lot to Say
abstract: The Seahawks seemed to play at a faster speed than the Broncos, with highlight moments sprinkled all across the Seattle defense.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — From the moment two weeks earlier that Seattle cornerback Richard Sherman made his postgame, high-decibel rant on the way to the Super Bowl, he became the attention-sucking foil to Denver quarterback Peyton Manning’s measured, soft-spoken personality and career.

headline: Smith Ends Up in Right Place to Be M.V.P.
abstract: The typical spectacle of pregame tailgates was muted Sunday as fans had been encouraged to use mass transit to get to MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. —   The ball found Seattle Seahawks linebacker Malcolm Smith in a big way during the postseason.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: The crop of 2013 animated films compares well to their live-action counterparts: the top five animated titles took in $1.296 billion domestically, compared with $1.639 billion for live films.
lead_paragraph: The crop of 2013 animated films compares well to their live-action counterparts: the top five animated titles took in $1.296 billion domestically, compared with $1.639 billion for live films.

headline: Warm Weather, Cold Manning at Super Bowl
abstract: The New York-New Jersey region concluded its big moment hosting the first outdoor Super Bowl in a northern climate with a dominating victory by the Seattle Seahawks, and a flustered Peyton Manning.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — As it turned out, the weather was not nearly as cold as Peyton Manning.

headline: The Week’s Men’s College Basketball Games to Watch
abstract: As the season marches on, it seems as if Wichita State has a real chance to go undefeated in the regular season. But Indiana State might be the team that could end the Shockers’ streak.
lead_paragraph: 16 IOWA STATE at 8 OKLAHOMA STATE

headline: Magic Carpets
abstract: A new line of flat-woven rugs by Oyyo, a Swedish firm, intertwines Nordic style with a diverse array of designs.
lead_paragraph: Lina Zedig and Marcus Ahren, the founders of the Stockholm-based design studio Oyyo, have introduced a line of cotton dhurries that stands apart from the ubiquitous stripes and chevrons of flat-weave designs. With their soft pastels and spare patterns, these rugs have a definite Nordic accent, recalling the textiles of the Swedish designer Marta Maas-Fjetterstrom, but a closer look reveals more diverse influences — everything from the Bauhaus textiles of Gunta Stölzl to the tree markings of itinerant laborers in the 1940s.

headline: Men’s Watches that Stop the Hands of Time
abstract: As seen at the SIHH watch fair in Geneva, the clock-halting chronograph is having a moment.
lead_paragraph: That age-old obsession with halting the passage of time took a literal turn at the recently concluded Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) watch fair in Geneva. A multitude of styles on view there made use of the chronograph — a feature that enables the rapid starting and stopping of hands on a dial to measure specific segments of time. Primarily used in the world of sports, where fractions of a second can make the difference between winning, losing and shattering records, this function was the must-have add-on at the show.

headline: As Peanut Allergies Rise, Trying to Determine a Cause
abstract: Peanut allergies afflict an increasing number of children, and recent studies are changing the conventional wisdom about what causes them.
lead_paragraph: Peanut allergy has become a nemesis for increasing numbers of children and parents in recent years, forcing them to maintain nut-free households and prompting many schools to ban a childhood staple, peanut butter, from the lunchroom.

abstract: Absent a grand bargain, there may still be an opening for bipartisan accord on tax-code changes and early childhood education, an economist writes.

abstract: The border talks with South Korea this week will discuss arrangements for reunions where relatives separated by the Korean War would meet for the first time in six decades.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea agreed on Monday to hold border talks with South Korea this week to discuss arranging reunions where relatives separated by the Korean War would meet for the first time in six decades, officials here said.

lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Richard Farago was just moments into calling his 10th Super Bowl when Denver Broncos center Manny Ramirez’s snap flew over Peyton Manning.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (NBC) SPORTS ILLUSTRATED SWIMSUIT: 50 YEARS OF BEAUTIFUL Heidi Klum, right, hosts this 50th-anniversary celebration of the Sports Illustrated swimsuit franchise, featuring behind-the-scenes glimpses of photo shoots, a countdown of top covers and reminiscences by Tyra Banks, Christie Brinkley, Kathy Ireland, Marisa Miller and Kate Upton. Enrique Iglesias, Lady Antebellum, the Fray, John Legend and Tim McGraw serenade them.

headline: Russell Wilson, the Forgotten Quarterback, Coolly Orchestrates ‘a Perfect Football Game’
abstract: Seattle’s Wilson was overshadowed by Peyton Manning and other players before the Super Bowl, but at game time he took center stage.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — He came into the game as the other quarterback — the undersize and underestimated foil to the record-setting, commercial-pitching Denver Broncos star Peyton Manning.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Gauging Western Contenders
abstract: Monday’s Thunder-Grizzlies game will be an opportunity to see how great a threat Memphis will be and just how much Oklahoma City will need Russell Westbrook in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Percy Harvin Finally Delivers on Seattle’s Investment
abstract: Harvin missed nearly all of the regular season with a hip problem, and much of the playoffs after a concussion, but was effective in the Super Bowl as a runner, receiver and returner.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Seattle Seahawks were so certain that Percy Harvin was the game-breaking offensive player they needed to advance to the Super Bowl that they traded first- and third-round draft choices in 2013 and their third-round selection this year to the Minnesota Vikings to obtain him.

headline: U.S. Skates to 6th Place in Bandy Tournament
abstract: The Americans were 3-3 in the international competition, which was won by Russia and featured a sport that was a forerunner of hockey.
lead_paragraph: With a 6-3 loss to Norway on Sunday, the United States finished sixth at the annual Bandy World Championship, played this year in Irkutsk, Russia. The American team, made up primarily of players from the Minneapolis-St. Paul and Duluth, Minn., areas, was 3-3 in the tournament, in which 17 countries participated. The matches, lasting 90 minutes apiece, were played outside in the Siberian cold.

headline: Enlisting Dad to Find a First Bra
keywords: ['Lingerie and Underwear', 'Women and Girls', 'Parenting', 'Baby Boomers', 'Widows and Widowers']
abstract: At 12 and in middle school, I worried that a bra was not in my future, but my father, who had to be both mom and dad, knew best.
lead_paragraph: When I was 12, I worried that I might never grow breasts. There I was, all of 80 pounds, nothing but skin and bones, bruised shins, a mouth full of braces, and not a curve in sight. I worried that I would remain forever a little girl with nothing on my chest but bumps — bumps that my busty classmate, Linda, referred to as “pimples in need of Band-Aids.”

headline: First the Safety, Then the Steamroller
abstract: Every so often, the Super Bowl turns into a rout, which is exactly what happened on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Every so often, the Super Bowl turns into a rout, which is exactly what happened on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium in New Jersey.

headline: India’s 1st Monorail Opens in Mumbai to Much Fanfare and Doubt
keywords: ['Buses', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Subways', 'Transit Systems', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Mumbai’s development agency touted the much-delayed monorail as a solution to the city’s notorious traffic congestion, but urban transportation experts say the $431 million project is not likely to be worth it.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — After five years, the first phase of the Mumbai monorail opened to the public on Sunday, a long-awaited addition to the city’s overwhelmed public transit system.

headline: From Today’s Paper: A Volcano’s Calling Card

headline: From Handel, Two Martyrs Full of Songs And Virtues
abstract: Handel’s seldom-performed oratorio “Theodora,” about Christian martyrs, was heard at Carnegie Hall with David Daniels and Dorothea Röschmann among the soloists.
lead_paragraph: While much of America prepared to watch the Super Bowl on Sunday, an equally enthusiastic crowd of Handel lovers gathered in Carnegie Hall to listen to “Theodora,” a three-and-a-half-hour oratorio about Christian martyrs.

abstract: The border talks with South Korea this week will discuss arrangements for reunions where relatives separated by the Korean War would meet for the first time in six decades.

abstract: Who won Super Bowl XLVIII? What was the final score?
lead_paragraph: In “Forget Forecast: Seahawks Pour It On in the Super Bowl,” Ben Shpigel writes about Super Bowl XLVIII.

headline: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Feb. 3, 2014
abstract: Fill in the blanks in this passage about the Sochi Olympics, then use Olympics photographs for a picture-dictation game.
lead_paragraph: View this interactive to see how a century-old cemetery in Sochi looked in 2005, when it was surrounded by farmland, and how it looks now that it is sitting among a ring of new arenas for the 2014 Olympics.

headline: For Just a Few Rupees, Mumbai Residents Ride a Symbol of Modern India
abstract: Thousands of people swarmed to India’s first monorail on the day it opened to the public, celebrating a major technological advance for the country.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — Sunday at 7 a.m. is usually not considered the ideal time for a picnic, but for one young family, the opening of India’s first monorail was a good enough reason for an impromptu celebration at that hour.

headline: Lloyds Bank to Take £1.9 Billion in Added Charges
abstract: The Lloyds Banking Group, which is partly owned by the British government, also said it expected to seek permission to begin paying a “modest” dividend again in the second half of 2014.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Lloyds Banking Group said on Monday that it would set aside 1.9 billion pounds, or $3.1 billion, to cover potential claims related to the improper selling of insurance and other products, the latest European bank to increase its reserves for past sins.

headline: The Beatles’ Visit, Revisited
abstract: Only four photos from Bill Eppridge’s 90 rolls of film, shot during his time with the Beatles on their first U.S. visit, 50 years ago this week, were published. Until now.
lead_paragraph: Bill Eppridge covered hundreds of assignments during his career at Life magazine and Sports Illustrated. Many of his photos are famous, like that of Robert F. Kennedy’s assassination and images from an intimate photo essay that followed the lives of two young drug addicts in New York.

headline: Should Sports Betting Be Legal Everywhere?
abstract: How would making sports betting legal everywhere affect the athletes, fans and those who gamble on games’ final outcomes?
lead_paragraph: As the introduction to the Room for Debate feature “The Stakes Off the Field” says, the Super Bowl is the biggest event of the year in sports gambling, despite such wagering only being legal in just a handful of states.

headline: New York Today: Get Out the Snow Shovel. Again.
abstract: What you need to know for Monday: four to eight inches, a primer on the city’s shoveling rules and a guide to post-Super Bowl goings-on.

keywords: ['Containers and Packaging', 'Medical Devices', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Montagu Private Equity said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the health care devices and prescription retail divisions of Rexam, the British consumer packaging company, for about $805 million in cash.

headline: Student With Rifles Kills 2 in Standoff at Moscow School
abstract: A police officer and a teacher were killed when the student opened fire without explanation.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A student armed with two rifles opened fire in a high school in Moscow on Monday morning, killing a geography teacher and a police officer as he held about two dozen students hostage in a rare case of gun violence in a school here.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: January 31, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses the Dow’s downward slide.
lead_paragraph: After months of steadily climbing and setting new records in 2013, the Dow Jones alone is down more than 4 percent this month. This downward slide comes even as the economy strengthens. This week on Money Talking, contributors Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine discuss the recent drops, the incoming Federal Reserve chairman Janet Yellen and whether there’s more volatility in store in the coming weeks and months. And the Super Bowl: Just how much of a financial boon is it for the host city?

headline: Finding the Discipline to Say No to Customers
abstract: During start-up mode, it’s tempting to take on any and all potential customers. At some point, that has to stop.
lead_paragraph: Recently, the She Owns It business group welcomed three new members, Jennifer Blumin, founder of Skylight Group; and the founders of Hukkster, Erica Bell and Katie Finnegan. (Recent members Jessica Johnson, Alexandra Mayzler, and Beth Shaw may return occasionally to discuss major developments at their companies.) At the group’s last meeting, the members learned more about each others’ companies, and discussed the challenge of saying no to new business and opportunities.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: James Vlahos on the United States of Sports Betting
abstract: Sometimes reporting a story requires visiting a strip club at 5 in the morning.
lead_paragraph: James Vlahos wrote this week’s cover story about hypercompetitive sports betting in Las Vegas. He last wrote for the magazine about life insurance.You note that one in five American men bet last year, according to a survey. Did you?

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 3, 2014

headline: Smith & Nephew to Buy U.S. Medical Device Maker
abstract: The British medical technology company Smith & Nephew said it would pay $1.7 billion in cash for the ArthroCare Corporation and introduce its products to additional markets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Smith & Nephew of Britain said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the medical device maker ArthroCare Corporation for about $1.7 billion in cash.

headline: New Opposition Merger Founders in South Africa
abstract: Within a week, the merger of two opposition groups that was depicted as a “game changer” that would end racial politics has collapsed amid mutual recriminations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The merger of two prominent South African political groups, announced with much fanfare last week as a political game-changer, collapsed in acrimony on Monday, further splintering the opposition to the governing African National Congress.

headline: Daily Report: Engineers Race to Improve the Battery
abstract: As tech companies focus on small, wearable devices, they have encountered an obstacle: battery technology is largely stuck in the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: The next breakthrough smartphone, or maybe the one after that, might not have a traditional battery as its sole source of power. Instead, it could pull energy from the air or power itself through television, cellular or Wi-Fi signals, Brian X. Chen and Nick Bilton report.

headline: Atlanta In New Jersey (Personal and Trivial)
abstract: OK, that wasn’t fun.
lead_paragraph: OK, the weather gods really didn’t want me to start this course. If I had left home 5 minutes later I might not have made it — I barely got up the quite mild slopes, and there were already accidents.

headline: SAC Fashioning a New Identity
abstract: SAC Capital Advisors will soon fade to black. | An unlikely alliance looks to check the power of activist investors. | Jos. A. Bank weighs a deal for Eddie Bauer. | Private equity is playing a major role in the defense industry.
lead_paragraph: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund started by Steven A. Cohen, will soon cease to exist as Wall Street has known it. The firm, whose reputation is now intricately linked to an insider trading scandal, is in the midst of rebranding itself, including changing its name and corporate structure. And recently, a major bank distanced itself from the firm. Together, these developments provide the most vivid illustration yet of SAC’s steep fall from powerful hedge fund to marginalized player,  Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook.

headline: Golden Eyes
abstract: From a faint sheen to a strong metallic, fashion’s top makeup artists got glowing this season. Here’s how to lay on the shine.
lead_paragraph: From a faint sheen to a strong metallic, fashion’s top makeup artists got glowing this season. Here’s how to lay on the shine.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: DirecTV and Dish Network announced a partnership to offer an advertising platform for political campaigns that can reach more than 20 million homes.
lead_paragraph: Michael Barrett joined Millennial Media, Baltimore, as chief executive. He succeeds Paul Palmieri, who founded the company; Mr. Palmieri resigned, Millennial Media said, and will join New Enterprise Associates as venture adviser. Mr. Barrett had most recently been chief revenue officer at Yahoo and before that was chief executive at AdMeld.

headline: Officials Scramble to Modify Slopestyle Course After Accident
abstract: Winter Olympics officials made changes to the slopestyle course after Torstein Horgmo of Norway crashed on the rail portion and broke his collarbone.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Four years after a luge athlete died on a training run in Vancouver on an Olympic course that had drawn widespread criticism, the Winter Olympics faced another safety issue four days before the opening ceremony.

abstract: A Sony commercial with a famous cast, and Jeffrey Tambor goes visual for Sabra.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

lead_paragraph: Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company under attack by the activist hedge fund manager William A. Ackman, said on Monday that it would increase its share buyback plan by $500 million.

headline: Bernanke Starts New Role as Yellen Takes Fed Helm
abstract: Ben S. Bernanke has joined the Brookings Institution, where he will write a book about his time at the Federal Reserve and contribute to an initiative on government economic policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the last eight years, on most weekdays and many weekends, Ben S. Bernanke was driven to work as chairman of the Federal Reserve. On Monday, he drove himself to a new job as an economic studies fellow at the Brookings Institution, a research group about a mile north of his old office.

headline: Image of the Day: February 3
abstract: Disabled men and women demonstrating at a rally at India Gate in New Delhi.

headline: Study Details Graft in European Union
abstract: More than three-quarters of citizens believe that graft is widespread in their countries, the European Commission said in a report.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Despite its relatively clean image, the European Union is losing at least 120 billion euros a year to corruption, and more than three-quarters of citizens believe that the problem is widespread in their countries, the bloc’s home affairs commissioner said on Monday.

headline: Elliott to Hint at Proxy Fight With Juniper
abstract: The activist investor Elliott Management plans to suggest that it has assembled a full slate of board nominees that it will put up for election if Juniper does not follow the hedge fund’s proposal.
lead_paragraph: As the networking equipment maker Juniper Networks prepares to announce its turnaround plan, one of the activist investors in its shares is pressing its own case for what the company must do.

headline: Al Qaeda Breaks With Jihadist Group in Syria Involved in Rebel Infighting
abstract: The Qaeda leadership said it was no longer connected to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, which has asserted an increasingly important role in the Syrian conflict.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Al Qaeda’s central leadership has officially cut ties with a powerful jihadist group that has flourished in the chaos of the civil war in Syria and that rushed to build an Islamic state on its own terms, antagonizing the wider rebel movement.

headline: Unpublished Chaplin Novella to Be Released
abstract: Called “Footlights,” the 1948 novella served as the inspiration for Charlie Chaplin’s 1952 film, “Limelight,” widely considered his last great film.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the Cineteca di Bologna, an Italian film restoration institute, will release a previously unpublished novella by Charlie Chaplin, which inspired his 1952 film, “Limelight,” widely considered his last great film. The release begins a series of events for the Chaplin centennial, which marks 100 years after the actor and director first appeared on film.

headline: More Bitcoin Regulation Is Inevitable
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Currency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The question is not whether there will be greater regulation of nongovernment currencies, but how much regulation they will face, Peter J. Henning writes in his White Collar Watch column.
