headline: Ask the Author: Economics and Online Dating
abstract: Paul Oyer, a Stanford professor who has written a book about the economics of online dating, is taking readers’ questions.
lead_paragraph: When Paul Oyer, an economist at Stanford’s Graduate School of Business, plunged into the online dating world a few years ago, he was struck — by the economics involved in his search.

headline: For Seattle, the Fun May Be Just Starting
abstract: With youthful enthusiasm, rah-rah coaching and some overlooked players, the Seahawks ran away with the Super Bowl and left others to figure out how to be more like them.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After the Super Bowl, in the concrete corridor connecting the locker rooms of the Seattle Seahawks and the Denver Broncos, players and coaches came and went.

headline: Warburg Pincus to Invest in Cloud-Based Facilities Manager
abstract: Warburg Pincus plans to announce on Monday that it will invest up to $100 million in Dude Solutions, a provider of cloud-based software that helps schools, hospitals and government agencies manage building maintenance.
lead_paragraph: Despite the torrent of money flowing into the technology sector, software to manage building maintenance services seems like an unlikely target for investors.

headline: Makers of Paper App Ask Facebook to Change Its New App Name
abstract: FiftyThree, the maker of a popular app called Paper, is asking Facebook to change the name of a new app that is being released Monday, also called Paper.
lead_paragraph: If you go to Google and type in the word “paper,” the top result doesn’t have anything to do with traditional pulpy vellum. Instead, it links to the well-known app Paper, which allows you to sketch on your iPad just as you can in a traditional notebook.

headline: Going Where 007 Has Gone Before
abstract: A London firm is offering customized trips in which clients can recreate the life –or at least some of it–of James Bond.
lead_paragraph: James Bond wasn’t just a legendary fighter of evil. He was a tremendous traveler, equally at home in a Monte Carlo casino as summiting a Swiss peak. Now one bespoke tour operator is offering clients the opportunity to live like 007 at home in England and around the world.

headline: Today in Small Business: GoldieBlox
abstract: Two failing small businesses get some branding advice and a new start.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: ‘Wolf’s’ Writer Avoids His Own Spoiler Alerts
abstract: With the Writers Guild Awards handed out on two different coasts, it’s possible to learn you lost before the winner is announced in your time zone, as Terence Winter knows.
lead_paragraph: Terence Winter, the screenwriter of “The Wolf of Wall Street,” did not win best adapted screenplay at the Writers Guild Awards on Saturday, but at least he knew better than to check his phone during the ceremony. Despite warnings to the contrary, spoilers are routinely delivered via text and social media throughout the bicoastal event, as awards are announced at different times.

headline: Raymond Weil, Whose Swiss Watches Told More Than Time, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Weil started his watch company at a time when most Swiss watchmakers were going bust, and he helped redefine the nation’s signature product.
lead_paragraph: Swiss watch companies had dominated the world of precision timekeeping for two centuries by the 1970s, when a technological marvel known as the quartz watch — a cheaper, more accurate work of horology mass-produced in Asia — threatened them with extinction.

headline: New Ads Urge Northerners to Follow the Sun
abstract: A campaign for the St. Petersburg/Clearwater Area Convention and Visitors Bureau focuses on Chicago, New York and Toronto in trying to entice tourists to Florida.
lead_paragraph: For years, ads during winter have encouraged residents of cold-weather states to visit warm-weather locales. Is there a baby boomer from states like New York or Pennsylvania who does not recall campaigns in which an actor named Jim Dooley proclaimed, “So come on down” to Florida on Northeast Airlines?

headline: Gyora Benedek’s Hidato
abstract: “Find the Path… Solve the Puzzle!” Give Hidato a try.
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Gyora Benedek, the Israeli computer scientist, inventor and adventurer. We first met Dr. Benedek while discussing Robert Torrence’s Lights Out Puzzle last September; Dr. Benedek shared, as one of the original inventors of Lights Out, some of the mathematics behind the game.

headline: Stir-Fried Brown Rice With Red Chard and Carrots
abstract: A colorful stir-fry with a variety of textures.
lead_paragraph: A lush bunch of red Swiss chard that I got at the farmers’ market was the inspiration for this stir-fry. The stems, which stay nice and crunchy, are an important ingredient in the stir-fry, so look for chard with nice wide ribs.

headline: Stir-Fried Rice and Black Quinoa With Cabbage, Red Pepper and Greens
abstract: The texture, flavor and look of black quinoa make for an interesting dish.
lead_paragraph: This is the kind of dish you can make on a whim if you make it a habit to freeze leftover grains. I used a combination of red chard and beet greens for this, but regular chard and kale would also work. I love the texture, flavor and look of the quinoa.

headline: Stir-Fried Rice Noodles With Beets and Beet Greens
abstract: Paper-thin sliced beets contribute crunch and color to this comforting stir-fry
lead_paragraph: I like to use golden or Chioggia beets for this stir-fry. Whatever beets you use, slice them very thin; for best results use a mandolin. Use a wok, not a pan, for stir-fried noodles as noodles will spill out of a pan. Tongs are a good tool for stirring and tossing the noodles, but a long-handled spatula will also work.

headline: Heroin Scheme to Support Terrorism Is Foiled, Police in India Say
abstract: The police reported the interception of 22 pounds of heroin headed from Pakistan to South India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian police said Monday that they had intercepted 22 pounds of heroin headed from Pakistan to South India, breaking up a network that included a police officer from Indian-administered Kashmir. The shipment was transported over the heavily militarized, hilly border between Pakistan and India, and was to be carried by train to New Delhi, said S. N. Srivastav, a senior police officer.

headline: Stir-Fried Soba Noodles With Shiitakes and Baby Broccoli
abstract: The nutty flavor of buckwheat noodles adds a delicious dimension to this unconventional stir-fry.
lead_paragraph: Soba noodles are Japanese, not Chinese, but I love using them in Chinese stir-fries. They have a wonderful nutty flavor, and buckwheat has a lot going for it nutritionally – it is a good source of manganese, copper and magnesium, and it is also high in phytonutrients. To make a quick vegetable stock simmer the shiitake mushroom stalks in a small amount of water for about 20 minutes.

headline: Presidential Elections in El Salvador and Costa Rica Are Headed for Runoffs
abstract: Top contenders in both nations failed to get enough votes on Sunday to win outright, in contests that tested the power of incumbent parties.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Presidential elections in two Central American countries, El Salvador and Costa Rica, will head to a second round after top contenders in both nations failed to get enough votes on Sunday to win outright, in contests that tested the power of incumbent parties.

headline: Kravis and Gordon Gekko at the Super Bowl
abstract: Spotted in the stands at MetLife Stadium on Sunday: a prince of Wall Street and an actor who played one in a movie.
lead_paragraph: One of the more memorable commercials broadcast during the Super Bowl on Sunday night featured a bevy of pop culture icons from the 1980s, including Hulk Hogan and the actor John Ratzenberger.

headline: Stir-Fried Soba Noodles With Turkey and Cabbage
abstract: Turkey cutlets are a good way to add just a bit of meat to a stir-fry.
lead_paragraph: Turkey cutlets are a great buy at most supermarkets. These thin medallions of turkey are perfect if you want to add small amounts of meat to a stir-fry. For the best texture, velvet the turkey before stir-frying (Steps 1 and 3).

headline: Catherine Deneuve Film Opens French Cinema Series
abstract: The actress stars as an aging beauty in the film, part of a lineup that focuses on filmmakers’ first and second features.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Rendez-Vouz With French Cinema will focus on first and second features, including work by directors, like Rebecca Zlotowski, who are considered part of France’s next new wave, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Coca Cola’s Super Bowl Ad
abstract: Not everyone appreciated the multilingual version of “America the Beautiful.”
lead_paragraph: Coca Cola’s Super Bowl ad, featuring a multilingual version of “America the Beautiful,” upset some right-wingers who apparently feel that the patriotic song should only be sung in English.

headline: Philip Seymour Hoffman, R.I.P.
abstract: The unusual greatness of a great actor.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you don’t realize how much an actor has achieved until he’s unexpectedly gone. Reading the tributes to Philip Seymour Hoffman, dead this weekend at forty-six, I have the sense that his passing woke a lot of people up to his true significance, the full measure of his greatness, his distinctive place among his generation’s great performers. Not that he was underappreciated, of course — not with a Best Actor Oscar in his pocket and plenty of other critical garlands as well — but I wonder how many writers would have reached for his name, or at least reached for it quickly, if they had been asked to pick the best English-speaking actor of the last two decades just a week ago. Not as many, I suspect, as are reaching for the “greatest actor” label now, to describe his tragically-truncated career.

headline: Reaction Time May Predict Longevity
abstract: There are many well established risk factors for cardiovascular death, but researchers may have found one more: slower reaction time.
lead_paragraph: There are many well established risk factors for cardiovascular death, but researchers may have found one more: slower reaction time.

headline: An Actor Who Made Unhappiness a Joy to Watch
abstract: Philip Seymour Hoffman, perhaps the best actor of his time, specialized in flawed, even detestable characters, and in making audiences care about them.
lead_paragraph: It was clear, at least since he won the Oscar in 2006 for “Capote,” that Philip Seymour Hoffman was an unusually fine actor. Really though, it was clear long before that, depending on when and where you started paying attention.

headline: Times Minute | Making Snow for Sochi
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Olympic Games (2014)', 'Elections', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Movies', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Also on the Minute, Thailand's political paralysis continues and controversy surrounding Woody Allen's Oscar nomination.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, Thailand's political paralysis continues and controversy surrounding Woody Allen's Oscar nomination.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Nascar Announces Sprint Cup Chase Changes
abstract: Nascar again shuffles rules for end-of-season Chase for the Championship; five men are inducted into the Nascar Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Nascar announced on Thursday changes to its end-of-season playoffs, the Sprint Cup Chase for the Championship. The changes, officials said, would place a greater emphasis on winning races. The old format pitted 12 drivers – the top 10 in points and two wild-card entries -- against one another in the final 10 races of the year in a runoff to decide the driving title. Jimmie Johnson, who won six races in 2013, collected his sixth championship, edging out Matt Kenseth, who had seven wins.

headline: Times Minute | Making Snow for Sochi
abstract: Also on the Minute, Thailand’s political paralysis continues and controversy surrounding Woody Allen’s Oscar nomination.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: ‘Frozen’ Takes Top Prize at Animation Awards
abstract: Though Disney, the studio behind “Frozen,” has a difficult history with the group giving out the awards, it did quite well this year, taking home prizes for its TV animation as well.
lead_paragraph: Talk about a thaw.

headline: Barclays Chief Declines Annual Bonus
abstract: Antony Jenkins, the chief executive of Barclays, said Monday that he would forgo a bonus offered to him by the bank’s board in light of the bank’s continued restructuring costs and litigation expenses.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:54 p.m. | LONDON — Barclays’ chief executive, Antony Jenkins, said Monday that he would forgo a bonus for 2013 in light of the bank’s continued restructuring costs and litigation expenses.

headline: British Regulator Warns Two of Potential Libor Charges
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority, one of Britain’s financial regulators, has issued warnings to two individuals that it planned to charge them for misconduct related to the rigging of Libor.
lead_paragraph: The Wells notice appears to be going global.

headline: Hedge Fund Chief Makes a Lonely Bet Against Portugal’s Debt
abstract: David Salanic, the chief executive of the hedge fund Tortus Capital, says he believed that Portugal would soon default on its private sector bonds — in the same way Greece did in 2012.
lead_paragraph: David Salanic cuts a lonely figure among the Manhattan power brokers eating breakfast at the Loews Regency Hotel restaurant on Park Avenue. Sure, he runs a hedge fund, but with $50 million, his fund may represent a year of commissions for some of the heavy hitters in the room.

headline: Beckham Back, as an Owner of a New Team
abstract: David Beckham will return to Major League Soccer, this time as an owner of a new club in Miami, the league is expected to announce at a news conference Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: David Beckham is set to return to Major League Soccer on Wednesday, this time as an owner of a Miami team that will become the league’s 22nd club.

headline: Fiat-Chrysler Merger Spawns New Logo
abstract: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles is keeping its new logo simple and to the point.
lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, the new company created from the merger of Chrysler and Fiat, has introduced a new logo made from the letters F.C.A. and rendered in light blue.

headline: Renée Fleming to Teach Master Class at Juilliard
abstract: Ms. Fleming’s class, on Feb. 13, will also be streamed online.
lead_paragraph: Renée Fleming seems intent on giving Plácido Domingo a run for his money as opera’s busiest star. Apart from singing the title role in the Metropolitan Opera’s current production of “Rusalka,” Ms. Fleming turned up to sing at Marilyn Horne’s birthday concert at Carnegie Hall a couple of weeks ago, and then, of course, there was her performance of “The Star-Spangled Banner” at the Super Bowl on Sunday, and the recent announcement that she will have her first role in a play, at the Williamstown Theater Festival in July. Between now and then, she plans to sing Strauss’s “Arabella” in Salzburg, in April.

headline: Months After Typhoon, Philippine City Suffers From an Exodus of Jobs
keywords: ['Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Nearly three months after a ruinous typhoon, Tacloban, once a thriving center, shows few signs of recovery, and those who can are leaving to find jobs elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — As Jesse Siozon waited for his grandfather’s funeral to begin, beneath the orange and blue tarps that serve as the roof for the storm-damaged Santo Niño Church, he spoke of a double loss.

headline: Hacker Group Accuses Merkel Government of Helping to Spy
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: The Chaos Computer Club filed a criminal complaint accusing the government of helping U.S. and British intelligence agencies to spy on German citizens.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — The Chaos Computer Club, a leading hacker organization based in Germany, filed a criminal complaint against Chancellor Angela Merkel and members of her government on Monday, accusing them of violating the law by helping intelligence agencies in the United States and Britain to spy on German citizens.

headline: Seeking Views From Your High or Low Perch
abstract: We’ve covered how some tall public figures in New York are living from their elevated viewpoint, but what about you, everyday New Yorkers? Tell us how your height affects your city life.
lead_paragraph: Good afternoon, City Room.

headline: The Read Around: Barry Werth
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: “Our health care system is broken,” says Barry Werth. In his new book, “The Antidote,” he provides an inside look at one company’s efforts to find innovative ways to treat disease.
lead_paragraph: “Our health care system is broken,” says Barry Werth. In his new book, “The Antidote,” he provides an inside look at one company’s efforts to find innovative ways to treat disease.

headline: Auto Sales for January Held Down by Harsh Winter Weather
abstract: General Motors and Ford lost ground in the month, while the Chrysler Group fared better, largely because of its truck division.
lead_paragraph: Automakers reported on Monday sharp declines in United States sales in January as a harsh freeze and winter storms thwarted purchases across much of the country.

headline: Full Picture of Airlines’ Punctuality Is Elusive
abstract: Statistics exclude segments of the industry that have grown in recent years, and a proposed rule that would require more accuracy remains delayed.
lead_paragraph: Travelers on Monday experienced a new round of cancellations and delays as another winter storm grounded planes yet again. But many of those flights won’t be counted as late or canceled in the government’s on-time statistics.

headline: A Souvenir and a Memory
abstract: While rummaging through a collection of keepsakes before moving from New Jersey to Washington, out popped a red flag and memories to go with it.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — As I cleaned out my room before moving to Washington, I found a small piece of red fabric crumpled among some keepsakes. I have stacks of journals that catalog my thoughts, hopes, fears and dreams, as well as anything and everything that reminds me of my various adventures over the years. You could say I’m more than slightly sentimental. Writings, photos, objects and song lyrics all transport me in time.

headline: Changing Circumstances, Graphed
abstract: Zero matters.
lead_paragraph: One recurrent theme on this blog has been that the effects of shocks to the economy, including policy shocks, depend a lot on circumstances — in particular, on whether short-term interest rates are constrained by the zero lower bound. I was putting together teaching materials, centered around David Romer’s IS-MP exposition, and came up with a graph that I think illustrates this point, um, graphically.

headline: At Canyon Ranch, ‘Sensuality Sessions’ for Valentine’s Day
abstract: In February, Canyon Ranch Hotel and Spa in Miami Beach will offer “Sensuality Sessions” as part of a two-night “Couples Intimacy Experience.”
lead_paragraph: Most hotels tout Valentine’s Day packages with rose petals on the bed and chocolate-dipped strawberries on the nightstand. But Canyon Ranch Hotel and Spa in Miami Beach takes a therapist’s approach to intimacy with a three-day program devoted to sensuality and bond-building.

headline: ‘Gravity’ Cinematographer Wins Peers’ Award
abstract: The American Society of Cinematographers gave its top prize to Emmanuel Lubezki, an Oscar front-runner, though he’s gone home empty-handed from the Academy Awards before.
lead_paragraph: Emmanuel Lubezki took the top prize from the American Society of Cinematographers this weekend, for his work creating and photographing outer space in “Gravity.” Mr. Lubezki, known as Chivo (Spanish for “goat”), is longtime friends and collaborators with Alfonso Cuarón, the director of “Gravity”: Mr. Lubezki was previously a winner for their film “Children of Men” in 2007 and is considered a favorite at the Oscars as well, although as the blog Gold Derby notes, the cinematographers’ group has a so-so track record in predicting the eventual Academy Award winner.

headline: The Great Mystery of Chinese New Year
keywords: ['Americans Abroad', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Lunar New Year', 'Parenting', 'Small Business']
abstract: When New Year’s break is over, we have no idea how many of our employees will return to work.
lead_paragraph: The week before the Lunar New Year, which fell this year on Friday, Jan. 31, is an exciting time in China. The streets are full of shoppers looking for last-minute gifts to take back to their relatives, and restaurants are packed with friends celebrating and companies holding their annual parties.

headline: Safety Agency Says 22 Million Vehicles Recalled in 2013
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Toyota issued the most recalls of any carmaker in 2013; Chrysler ranked second.
lead_paragraph: For the second year in a row, Toyota led the nation with the most vehicles recalled: nearly 5.3 million in 2013.

headline: Employees Get To Vote, Too?
abstract: What’s next? Women?
lead_paragraph: This is kind of funny: Eric Cantor feels the need to explain to his fellow Republican legislators that most Americans not only don’t own their own businesses, they have no desire to own their own businesses. It’s a message he’s apparently having a hard time getting across.

headline: Smith & Nephew Pounces on a Wounded Rival
abstract: Given that this is a friendly deal, shareholders might struggle to force a sweetener out of Smith & Nephew, writes Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Smith & Nephew, the British medical technology giant, has agreed to buy ArthroCare, an American specialist in sports medicine, for an enterprise value of $1.5 billion.

headline: The Value of Ripeness
abstract: Does ripeness affect the vitamin and sugar content of fruit?
lead_paragraph: Q. Do fruits that are ripe have greater vitamin value than those that aren’t? And what about sugar?

headline: As the Latest Christie Story Evolved, The Times Should Have Noted a Change
abstract: After a change in a breaking story, at least an editor’s note was in order.
lead_paragraph: In the digital age, news evolves before our very eyes. A story breaks and goes online with perhaps a few rough paragraphs. Soon after, more details are added, new angles explored and writing is tuned up. Finally — at least in organizations like The Times — a thorough and polished version makes its way onto the web and into both print and the archives.

headline: A Farm’s Lessons in Long-Term Planning
abstract: What may seem like a great decision now could be unsustainable in five or even 10 years and could easily undermine years of work.
lead_paragraph: When I ask you to think long term, what comes to mind? Ten years from now? One year? One week? In a world where excellence is now measured in milliseconds, it can be incredibly difficult to think past the moment that’s right in front of us.

headline: HP Revises Autonomy Financial Reports, Citing Accounting Errors
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Hewlett-Packard took an $8.8 billion charge in 2012, claiming discrepancies in Autonomy’s numbers. Now it has fleshed out those restatements. Autonomy continued to deny any impropriety.
lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard has disclosed to the authorities that it found what it said were serious accounting errors at Autonomy, the British software maker it acquired in 2011, leading to a number of major revisions in the acquired company’s financial report for 2010.

headline: On the Verge | A Star Is Born
abstract: The French fashion designer Simon Porte Jacquemus is storming Paris with his superclean designs and rowdy runway shows.
lead_paragraph: The French fashion designer Simon Porte Jacquemus is storming Paris with his superclean designs and rowdy runway shows.

headline: Cutting Straight to the Chase With Dessert
abstract: A handful of noteworthy restaurants allow you to sample a prix fixe menu of desserts without eating dinner first.
lead_paragraph: Dessert can be excess or antidote, solace or provocation, a stampede of the senses or a tickling of the mind. Rarely is it all at once.

headline: Both Sides Declare P.R. Victory in Skirmish Over SodaStream Super Bowl Ad
abstract: Both supporters and critics of Israel’s occupation of the West Bank declared victory after Scarlett Johansson’s Super Bowl ad for SodaStream was broadcast Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:10 p.m. | By the time the actress Scarlett Johansson’s critically unacclaimed Super Bowl commercial for SodaStream finally aired Sunday night, both supporters and critics of Israel’s occupation of the West Bank had pronounced themselves satisfied with the new attention her endorsement brought to the company’s factory in a Jewish settlement outside Jerusalem.

headline: First Event of Sochi Olympics: The Hotel Construction Sprint
abstract: Just days before the start of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, there are unfinished hotels, half-finished stores and a mall where the only shop that is open and thriving is a Cinnabon.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The official mascots for the Winter Olympics are a polar bear, a hare and a leopard. But walk around the complexes that will stage the Games here, with the opening ceremony Friday, and what seem more apt are a hand drill, a backhoe and a shovel.

headline: Weighing Testosterone’s Benefits and Risks
abstract: Testosterone products, heavily marketed as a cure-all for middle-aged men, also can carry seriously increased risks, recent studies have found.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade ago, researchers in Boston decided to see whether older men who were not in very good shape could benefit from daily doses of testosterone.

headline: U.S. and Europe Work on Aid Package for Ukraine
abstract: Senior officials are trying to assemble a new financial package intended to ease the way for the formation of a new government.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Looking to defuse Ukraine’s crisis, the United States and Europe are trying to assemble a financial package that could ease the path for a new government there to guide the country out of its current impasse between Europe and Russia, American and European officials say.

headline: In the End, It All Adds Up to – 1/12
abstract: A recent video purported to prove that adding an infinite series of natural numbers gives you a smaller answer than you might think, raising compelling questions about the entire notion of infinity.
lead_paragraph: This is what happens when you mess with infinity.

headline: Goldman’s Charitable Foundation Chief to Lead Urban Investment Group
abstract: Dina H. Powell will be the new head of a group which specializes in “social impact investing” through projects like the Citi Bike program and an anti-recidivism program for the jail at Rikers Island.
lead_paragraph: Dina H. Powell has already made a name for herself as the head of Goldman Sachs’s charitable foundation. Now, she is preparing to add a new revenue-generating role to her list of responsibilities.

headline: A Doctor Bridging Arts and Sciences
abstract: Dr. Frank Netter’s mother insisted he go into medicine, but he met her halfway, following his passion for art and becoming possibly the world’s best-known medical illustrator.
lead_paragraph: In history’s long parade of pushy mothers and miserably obedient children, no episode beats Dr. Frank H. Netter’s for a happy ending. Both parties got the last laugh.

headline: Preschool Push Moving Ahead in Many States
abstract: Once a mostly Democratic cause, government-funded preschool has been embraced by both parties outside Washington, with Republican governors pushing some of the biggest increases in preschool spending.
lead_paragraph: Preschool is having its moment, as a favored cause for politicians and interest groups who ordinarily have trouble agreeing on the time of day. President Obama devoted part of his State of the Union address to it, while the deeply red states of Oklahoma and Georgia are being hailed as national models of preschool access and quality, with other states and cities also forging ahead on their own.

headline: A Hard Climate for Penguins and Butterflies
abstract: Storms and warmer temperatures are killing the chicks of Magellanic penguins, while extreme weather and a shrinking habitat are taking a toll on monarch butterflies.
lead_paragraph: Adaptation can be tricky. Extreme weather is challenging the survival of certain penguins and butterflies, yet DNA from Neanderthals lives on in modern humans 30,000 years after they went extinct. It’s enough to turn a cave man’s eyes blue.

headline: Chris Christie Returns to High School
abstract: The press is now focusing on whether the governor was friends with his Port Authority appointee while in high school.
lead_paragraph: The investigations into Gov, Chris Christie’s traffic scandal are finally getting serious. The documents subpoenaed by New Jersey legislators are scheduled to start arriving at committee offices this week.

headline: At Work in Subzero Temperatures
abstract: “After a certain point our mouths and jaws were so cold we couldn’t talk.”
lead_paragraph: For this week’s Look column, we asked the photographer Massimo Vitali to visit Harbin, China, to take pictures of the Ice and Snow World there. Long days in the extreme cold — temperatures got as low as minus 40 degrees Fahrenheit — made for difficult work.

headline: On Kristof’s Column About Dylan Farrow and Woody Allen, ‘Only Questions’
abstract: A reader writes to ask about the wisdom and propriety of “ad hominem” columns.
lead_paragraph: As I’ve been thinking about Nicholas Kristof’s Sunday column and the related blog post that have caused so much discussion and disagreement, a number of thoughtful emails from readers have arrived.

headline: Super Bowl Slide Show
abstract: The Seattle Seahawks overwhelmed the Denver Broncos to win their first Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks overwhelmed the Denver Broncos to win their first Super Bowl.

headline: Muti Signs New Contract With Chicago Symphony Orchestra
abstract: Riccardo Muti, who has led the orchestra since 2010, signed a five-year contract to extend his tenure through 2020.
lead_paragraph: Riccardo Muti’s relationships with American orchestras have been enigmatic: after leading the Philadelphia Orchestra for a dozen years, starting in 1980, he reportedly grew weary of the social responsibilities that an American directorship involves. The New York Philharmonic courted him twice, with no joy, only to see him take up the baton in Chicago in 2010. Mr. Muti seems to have enjoyed his time there so far: On Monday, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra announced that the 72-year-old conductor has signed a second five-year contract, which will extend his tenure through August, 2020.

headline: Alive With a New, Old Liver
abstract: With a failing liver, Jonathan Nuñez underwent a rare transplant in which he kept part of his old organ, which eventually replaced the transplanted one. His success has his doctor wondering why the procedure isn’t done more often.
lead_paragraph: Five days a week, three hours a day, Jonathan Nuñez works out with a gymnastics coach on bars, rings, pommel horse and floor exercises.

headline: In India, a Pilgrimage to a Feast for Thousands
abstract: A respected centenarian throws open his doors to celebrate with the masses at a vegetarian feast.
lead_paragraph: RAYAVARAM, India — Palaniappa Chettiar has always been goal oriented, and when he turned 97 three years ago, he set himself a new one.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 28-Feb. 3, 2014
abstract: The Super Bowl, a paralyzing ice storm, a new head of the Federal Reserve: How many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl, a paralyzing ice storm, a new head of the Federal Reserve and more: How many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?

headline: Amid the Wreckage of the Broncos, Sports Books Strike Gold
abstract: A majority of the betting public counted on a storybook ending to quarterback Peyton Manning’s magical season, and it lost big as a result.
lead_paragraph: It was a good day at the office for Nevada sports books as the Seattle Seahawks’ 43-8 destruction of the Denver Broncos defied the expectations of the square money, representing the general betting public, which wanted to see a storybook ending to the record-breaking season of Denver quarterback Peyton Manning.

headline: Preschool’s Benefits Extend to Parents
abstract: By lifting at least one of the economic burdens of being both caregivers and breadwinners, the advantage of access to quality state-funded public preschool extends beyond the classroom.
lead_paragraph: If preschool is having a moment, it is due in part to its appeal to voters as a program designed to help children: preschool is “the most cost-effective” educational intervention, one that can set children up for greater success not just in reading and math, but in their social and emotional development. Any parent who has raised children in a truly diverse environment has had occasion to grieve how the lives of toddlers who once shared a park sandbox can diverge so dramatically as they grow older. Making preschool available to more children feels like an effort to level that particular playing field.

headline: For Hermione, It Shouldn’t Have Been Ron, Rowling Says
abstract: J.K. Rowling says that Hermione Granger should not have married Ron Weasley. “It was a choice I made for very personal reasons,” she said, “not for reasons of credibility.”
lead_paragraph: Harry Potter fans who were disappointed by the series’ happily-ever-after scenario got an early Valentine’s Day present of sorts, thanks to an interview in which Potter’s creator, J.K. Rowling, said that the wrong guy got the girl in the epilogue of the final volume.

headline: Alvin Ailey to Return to Koch Theater in June
abstract: A 15-show run will more than double the number of performances the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater gave at the theater last year.
lead_paragraph: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will return to the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center for a 15-performance engagement that will run from June 11 to 22, the company’s artistic director, Robert Battle, announced on Monday. The residency more than doubles the number of performances the company gave at the house last year, in its first appearance there since 2000.

headline: Two Families Battered by a Typhoon
abstract: The Picas, who struggled to keep a baby born during Typhoon Haiyan alive, are piecing their lives back together in Tacloban, while some of the Siozans, who lost their patriarch from an infection, have left.
lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Shortly before dawn, as Typhoon Haiyan thundered ashore, a man took his wife, son and very pregnant daughter on a motorcycle with a sidecar through rising winds to the hospital.

headline: Former BBC Director Apologizes for Failure of Digital Project
abstract: Mark Thompson, now president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, testified that he had never “knowingly misled” Parliament over the project’s progress.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mark Thompson, the former director general of the BBC, offered a general apology to a parliamentary committee on Monday for the failure of an expensive digital project, but he insisted that he had never knowingly misled Parliament or the BBC Trust, its oversight board.

headline: As Recovery Looks Weak, Stocks Take a Deep Dive
keywords: ['Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Nasdaq Composite Index', 'Quantitative Easing', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'United States Economy']
abstract: Poor numbers on factory orders and car sales left investors wondering if their view of the economy was too rosy, and the three major indexes each fell more than 2 percent.
lead_paragraph: Signs of weakness in the American economy pushed Wall Street to its worst day in an already bad year.

headline: Demography and Employment (Wonkish)
abstract: What demographic adjustment does and doesn’t show.
lead_paragraph: A blog post reporting research by Samuel Kapon and Joseph Tracy of the New York Fed is creating a splash in wonkworld today, and it is making an important point. However, the way that point is presented is, I think, likely to mislead, because it mixes two propositions together. One, which is clearly true, is that the aging of the adult population would have meant a considerable decline in the employment-population ratio over the past 7 years even if the economy had remained near full employment.

headline: Dull Super Bowl Made ‘Downton Abbey’ a Thrill, as Nearly 7 Million Watched
abstract: The British drama, perfect counterprogramming by PBS, was the second-most-watched show on Sunday night with 6.8 million viewers, a 3 percent rise from last year.
lead_paragraph: “Downton Abbey” went once more unto the breach on Sunday night, unafraid, as so many other competitors were, to take on the Super Bowl with an original episode.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: January 31-February 2, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: In September, Louis DiNatale and his wife, who are from Kentucky, drove over a bridge from New York to Ontario, Canada. They claim they were on their way to Vermont but were misdirected by an unreliable GPS, and when they tried to reenter the United States they were asked by a Canadian border crossing guard whether they had any weapons.

headline: Helping to Build a School for the Poor, by Selling One in a Wealthier Area
keywords: ['Charter Schools', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The Children’s Aid Society is selling a school on the Upper East Side, marketing it as a potential single family townhouse, with plans to use that money to build a modern school in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Ife Lenard, a charter school principal in the South Bronx, could not help but smile as she ran her hand over an architectural model of the school that the Children’s Aid Society plans to build for her young students, and described its future pottery kiln, science labs and library.

headline: Looking Beyond the Canonical Masterpieces
abstract: “This England,” a program of four works performed by the American Symphony Orchestra, seeks to revisit some less-performed compositions.
lead_paragraph: Leon Botstein, the conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra, is right. Classical music has far too long been in thrall to the cult of the masterpiece, the idea that the arts exist more or less solely for the purpose of identifying and codifying a canon of great works.

headline: VW Workers in Tennessee to Vote on Union
abstract: As part of a closely watched unionization drive, workers in Chattanooga will decide next week whether to join the United Automobile Workers.
lead_paragraph: In what will be one of the most closely watched unionization elections in the South in decades, Volkswagen announced on Monday that the 1,600 workers at its assembly plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., will vote next week on whether to join the United Automobile Workers.

headline: Tech Companies Offer Update on Government Data Requests
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Facebook, Google, Microsoft, LinkedIn, Yahoo and Apple have released information pertaining to the number of government data requests the companies receive for people who use these services.
lead_paragraph: Updated: This post now includes reaction from the American Civil Liberties Union.

headline: How It Happens | Snowmaking
abstract: Machines make snow the same way nature does – only much more quickly, and a lot closer to the ground.
lead_paragraph: Machines make snow the same way nature does – only much more quickly, and a lot closer to the ground.

headline: An Olympian Snow Endeavor in Sochi
abstract: To dress Alpine venues of the Sochi Games in white has required the help of science, a lot of machines and a little luck.
lead_paragraph: The people in charge of making snow for the Winter Olympics in Russia caught a break over the past two months, when for two periods of about a week each temperatures dropped enough to make good snow, and lots of it.

headline: Artists Gather for a Spoken-Word Tribute to the Diabolical Wit and Wisdom of John Baldessari
abstract: An eclectic assortment of guests appeared at a tongue-in-cheek tribute to the collected writings of the legendary conceptual artist, including Alex Israel, Hans Ulrich Obrist and Fred Savage — yes, that Fred Savage.
lead_paragraph: WhoA motley crew of L.A.’s artistic elite, including upstarts like Alex Israel, Sam Falls and Dawn Kasper and heavies such as Allen Ruppersberg, Suzanne Lacy, William Leavitt and Jim Shaw, gathered to read writings by John Baldessari, a father figure to the Angeleno art world. They were joined by the unlikely pair of the power curator Hans Ulrich Obrist and the child actor turned TV producer Fred Savage, who has no discernible connection to Baldessari and looks like he’s barely aged since “The Wonder Years.” Savage read Baldessari’s “Advice to Young Artists” (1968). Bettina Korek, founder of the arts organization ForYourArt, hosted.

headline: Brain Science to Beat Mental Disorders, Snow Made by Machine, Obesity Takes an Early Hold
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Obesity']
abstract: Dr. Thomas R. Insel, director of the National Institute of Mental Health, on attacking mental illness by way of brain research; the science of filling Sochi’s slopes with Olympic snow; a new study shows that obesity is established very early in life.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Thomas R. Insel, director of the National Institute of Mental Health, on attacking mental illness by way of brain research; the science of filling Sochi’s slopes with Olympic snow; a new study shows that obesity is established very early in life.

headline: These Two Leap to Judgment (Not That You Should, Too)
abstract: The playwright Christina Masciotti puts together a father and college-age daughter in the gentle comedy “Adult” at Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: Christina Masciotti treats her characters with a kindness and patience that are usually accorded to only the very young or the very old. Take the middle-age father and adolescent daughter who make up the entire cast of “Adult,” Ms. Masciotti’s gentle new comedy at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: China to Ramp Up Military Spending
abstract: China will spend $148 billion on its military this year, up from $139.2 billion in 2013, according to IHS Jane’s.
lead_paragraph: China already spends more on its military than any country in the world except the United States. Now, as defense budgets at the Pentagon and in many NATO countries shrink, China’s People’s Liberation Army is gearing up for a surge in new funding, according to a new report.

headline: Take a Dumpling Detour
abstract: Rice noodles can step in to fill out this spicy pork dish.
lead_paragraph: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: ‘Luminaries’ to Light Up Small Screen
abstract: The producer Andrew Woodhead plans to turn Eleanor Catton’s Booker Prize-winning novel into a television mini-series.
lead_paragraph: Eleanor Catton’s Booker Prize-winning novel, “The Luminaries,” will be turned into a television mini-series, according to New Zealand’s Greymouth Star.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Australia and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Australia, Russia, Central African Republic and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Australia, Russia, Central African Republic and Indonesia.

headline: Ethics Questions Arise as Genetic Testing of Embryos Increases
abstract: Genetic testing of embryos raises unsettling ethical questions that trouble advocates for the disabled and have left some doctors struggling with what they should tell their patients.
lead_paragraph: Her first thought after she heard the news, after she screamed and made her mother and boyfriend leave the room, was that she would never have children. Amanda Baxley’s doctor had just told her, over a speakerphone in her psychiatrist’s office, that she had the gene for Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease, or GSS, which would inevitably lead to her slow and terrible death.

headline: A Life Full of Dreams That Are Now Coming True
abstract: Patina Miller appeared at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: The story of Patina Miller, a star of “Pippin,” follows a familiar template. A girl from Pageland, S.C., grows up singing in church under the watchful eye of her grandmother. After studying musical theater, she makes a splash in the London production of “Sister Act.” Eventually she wins a Tony Award for best actress in a musical (the current revival of “Pippin”) and is now planning a June wedding.

headline: ‘Witness Uganda’ Wins Richard Rodgers Award for Musical Theater
abstract: A musical about a young man who goes to Uganda has won the 2014 Richard Rodgers Production Award for Musical Theater.
lead_paragraph: “Witness Uganda,” a musical by Matt Gould and Griffin Matthews, has won the 2014 Richard Rodgers Production Award for Musical Theater, the American Academy of Arts and Letters announced on Monday.

headline: What’s Behind the Declining Abortion Rate?
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A new report points to intriguing trends that are directly relevant to the battle over the contraception mandate.
lead_paragraph: A new study released on Monday finds that the abortion rate among American women declined to its lowest level in more than three decades in 2011. Prepared by the Guttmacher Institute, the report points to some intriguing trends directly relevant to the current political battle over the contraception mandate.

headline: A Frenchman Finds It’s True. They Really Are Out to Get Him.
abstract: In “An Officer and a Spy,” the novelist Robert Harris looks at the Alfred Dreyfus affair through a fictional lens.
lead_paragraph: Robert Harris’s novel “An Officer and a Spy” has a point of high drama when the main character, Col. Georges Picquart, is ushered into a room full of atypical characters: people who will actually listen to him. For the first three-quarters of this book Picquart has operated quietly, trying to piece together the facts of the infamous Dreyfus affair, which culminated in the conviction, humiliation and banishment of Alfred Dreyfus, a French officer convicted on impossibly scanty evidence of being a German spy. Dreyfus is a Jew swept away on a wave of anti-Semitism, but there is also a major element of malfeasance among military officers that brought him to his fate.

headline: ScienceTake: Fight Club for Flies
abstract: Why are males aggressive? Researchers have found clues in the brains of fruit flies.
lead_paragraph: Why are males aggressive? Researchers have found clues in the brains of fruit flies.

headline: A Waiting Game After the Super Bowl: Hours in Line for the Train
abstract: About 28,000 riders took New Jersey Transit to the game at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., and more than 33,000 used it to leave.
lead_paragraph: For months, the organizers of the Super Bowl coaxed fans to ride the rails, urging them to renounce private car travel in the name of the New York region’s famed public transportation system.

headline: New CDs From Broken Bells, Toni Braxton and Babyface
abstract: Broken Bells, Toni Braxton and Babyface, and the Haden Triplets have new albums.
lead_paragraph: BROKEN BELLS

headline: To Study Aggression, a Fight Club for Flies
abstract: Scientists are learning more about the brain activity underlying male aggression.
lead_paragraph: Males’ aggression toward each other is an old story throughout the animal kingdom. It’s not that females aren’t aggressive, but in many species, male-on-male battles are more common.

headline: You’re a Suspect. That’s the Drill.
abstract: “I Call My Brothers,” by the Swedish playwright Jonas Hassen Khemiri, sends an Arab-American to Times Square soon after suspicious explosions.
lead_paragraph: “I Call My Brothers,” by the Swedish playwright Jonas Hassen Khemiri, tracks a fraught 24 hours in the life of young Arab-American man as he runs errands in New York City. The play, mostly narrated by the protagonist, Amor (Damon Owlia), stokes suspense by intimating that the story will take a dark, dramatic turn. Perhaps Amor will be tragically mistaken for a terrorist. Or maybe his anxieties will get the better of him, and that knife in his pocket will come flashing out.

headline: A Master of Percussion, in Its Sounds and Gestures
abstract: The percussionist Steven Schick used a panoply of instruments, including his body, at the Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: Steven Schick, the percussionist, conductor and San Diego author and educator, turns 60 this year. As he likes to point out, that makes him older than Stockhausen’s “Zyklus” (1959), the first major composition for solo percussion.

headline: Dallas Museum Lands a Rich Trove of Islamic Art
abstract: Under an unusual agreement, the Dallas Museum of Art will become the long-term custodian of one of the most important collections of Islamic art in private hands.
lead_paragraph: While Texas may have the fifth largest Muslim population in the United States by some estimates, its public art collections have only recently begun to reflect the 14-century sweep of Islamic history. But on Friday, with the stroke of a pen — sealing a complex agreement hashed out over months — the Dallas Museum of Art will become the long-term custodian of one of the most important collections of Islamic art in private hands.

headline: A Conductor to Flex and See Through
abstract: Researchers say they have developed an electrical conductor that is highly flexible and transparent, a combination that could help usher in flexible flat-screen televisions and smartphones.
lead_paragraph: University of Houston researchers say they have developed an electrical conductor that is both highly flexible and transparent, an elusive combination that could help usher in an age of flexible flat-screen televisions and smartphones.

headline: Carly Rae Jepsen Takes a ‘Cinderella’ Risk
abstract: Pressure is on the singer Carly Rae Jepsen as she inherits the lead role in “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: When you are a newcomer who takes the charts — and auditory nerves — by storm, as Carly Rae Jepsen did with her runaway single “Call Me Maybe,” the pop-music playbook dictates what you’re supposed to do next: Get back into the studio and record another hit before the clock strikes midnight on your good fortune.

headline: How Much Is That Seat? A Travel Site Breaks It Down
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Business Travel', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Customer Loyalty Programs']
abstract: TripAdvisor is redoing its Flights feature to include details on price and in-flight amenities, as well as photos taken by customers.
lead_paragraph: THE online travel company TripAdvisor will introduce on Tuesday an ambitious redesign of its Flights search feature that will provide detailed information globally on any given flight’s price — including added charges for options like extra legroom — as well as on in-flight amenities like the availability of Wi-Fi and in-seat power ports.

headline: Hollywood Was Just One of His Stages
abstract: Philip Seymour Hoffman had many irons in the fire at the time of his death, most of them projects and roles that fans will never get to see.
lead_paragraph: For all his success in Hollywood — hits like “The Hunger Games,” an Academy Award for “Capote,” a promising Showtime series in the works — Philip Seymour Hoffman was the rare star who also worked nonstop in the less glamorous world of Off Broadway. It was his one professional constant during a 23-year career.

headline: New Book on Snowden Revelations From Guardian Writer
abstract: The first major book on the subject, from Luke Harding, a reporter for The Guardian, is being published in the United States on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Only eight months after Edward J. Snowden engineered the release of some of America’s most closely held secrets on electronic surveillance by the government, the first major book on the subject will be published.

headline: A Timeline for the George Washington Bridge Scandal
abstract: Events in the scandal that has settled around Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey regarding the motives behind the shutdown of some traffic lanes to the George Washington Bridge.
lead_paragraph: Events in the scandal that has settled around Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey regarding the motives behind the shutdown of some traffic lanes to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: A Proud Daughter Sways to Her Own Beat, While Dancing With Her Past
abstract: The singular talents of the Brazilian singer Maria Rita shone brightly, even singing her mother’s songs, in a show at City Winery.
lead_paragraph: The Brazilian singer Maria Rita’s exquisite concert on Sunday night at City Winery was daringly exposed in more ways than one.

headline: Australian Catch-and-Kill Shark Policy, Meant to Reassure, Horrifies Some
abstract: Citing swimmer deaths, Western Australia State has started a catch-and-kill policy for larger sharks, but environmentalists say it will have a deleterious effect on the ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — As Australians flocked to the beaches at the height of a hot Southern Hemisphere summer, a commercial fisherman hired for the task hauled in a 10-foot tiger shark caught on a baited line. The fisherman shot the shark in the head four times with a .22-caliber rifle off the coast of Western Australia and then towed the carcass out to sea, where it was dumped.

headline: Times Minute | A Push for Pre-K
abstract: State-funded preschool becomes a bipartisan issue. Also on the Minute, genetic testing on embryos and a miracle in Tacloban, the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | A Push for Pre-K
abstract: State-funded preschool becomes a bipartisan issue. Also on the Minute, genetic testing on embryos and a miracle in Tacloban, the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: State-funded preschool becomes a bipartisan issue. Also on the Minute, genetic testing on embryos and a miracle in Tacloban, the Philippines.

headline: Take the Road Less Traveled; It May Lead to Barbecue
abstract: Adam Rapp of Clothing Arts says that layovers and delays are a chance to go exploring, whether he is in Istanbul or South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: I LOVE business travel. I mean, I seriously love it, because every time I leave my home that means I’m doing something to develop my company. I’m the founder and designer for my business, Clothing Arts. We make travel apparel, so I might be meeting with a new buyer or an existing buyer or visiting some place to get inspiration. I’m a former Wall Street trader, and now I’m in the clothing business. I love every second of it. One business trip was five days long, and I was in India for a few of them, then Canada, then back to India, and then home. It was great.

headline: Losing Their Religion, and What’s Next
abstract: A documentary on PBS follows seven people who decide to leave their Amish orders — some of whom return.
lead_paragraph: “Breaking Amish,” “Amish Mafia,” “Amish: Out of Order,” “Amish in the City,” “Witness”: What did one small, quiet group of religious orders do to deserve all this?

headline: Intersection: Colorful Style in London
abstract: In London’s diverse Brixton neighborhood, Michael Donkor, a teacher, describes his style as smart with a playful edge.
lead_paragraph: In London’s diverse Brixton neighborhood, Michael Donkor, a teacher, describes his style as smart with a playful edge.

headline: Rihanna Joins Viva Glam by MAC to Fight AIDS
abstract: Sales of Viva Glam by MAC, a subsidiary of Estée Lauder, support the MAC AIDS Fund, which has become the second-largest private donor to AIDS organizations.
lead_paragraph: Slowly, the sales of one lipstick brand have grown so large that the little-known charity it supports, the MAC AIDS Fund, has become the second-largest private donor to AIDS organizations, after the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

headline: A. O. Scott on Philip Seymour Hoffman
abstract: The Times movie critic A. O. Scott talks about some of his favorite Philip Seymour Hoffman roles, and what defines the actor’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: The Times movie critic A. O. Scott talks about some of his favorite Philip Seymour Hoffman roles, and what defines the actor’s legacy.

headline: Three Views of Philip Seymour Hoffman
abstract: What it was like to make pictures of the notable actor, in photographers’ own words.
lead_paragraph: Moved by the news of Philip Seymour Hoffman’s death, we immediately thought of these photographs, which the magazine had specially commissioned of the notable actor over the years.In the summer of 2002 the magazine asked Gregory Crewdson to create the pictures for the inaugural edition of a photo essay section of the magazine, “Portfolio.” For his setting, he chose an empty house in Rutland, Vt., that had caught his imagination, and for our part we decided to pair him with well-known actors, a departure for Crewdson, whose mysterious, haunting images until then had all featured anonymous subjects. Our hope was to bring a new twist to celebrity portraiture and produce some unusual images. One of the actors cast for the “Dream House” portfolio was Philip Seymour Hoffman. He agreed to go up to Rutland on a Sunday in August. I remember thinking, as we were driving to meet up with him at our rendezvous in a shopping center parking lot, How will we know which car he is in? But there in the big empty lot, in one lone car smack in the middle of it, was a man reading The New York Times. Philip Seymour Hoffman knew how to make an entrance.

headline: Back to Job Hunt After Sharing State of the Union Spotlight
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: President Obama mentioned Misty DeMars’s job search in the State of the Union address, although it has not led to any offers. Yet.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a brief moment last week, at the request of the White House, Misty DeMars was the face of long-term unemployment in the United States. The attention has not led to any job offers, not yet at least, but she is hopeful. “I think I can boost my résumé by adding that I wrote part of the State of the Union 2014,” Ms. DeMars, 37, said wryly.

headline: Blazing Trails in Brain Science
abstract: Dr. Thomas R. Insel’s twisted path to his role as director of the National Institute of Mental Health is a tour of where psychiatric science has been, where it’s going and why.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — The police arrived at the house just after breakfast, dressed in full riot gear, and set up a perimeter at the front and back. Not long after, animal rights marchers began filling the street: scores of people, young and old, yelling accusations of murder and abuse, invoking Hitler, as neighbors stepped out onto their porches and stared.

headline: Joan Mondale, Who Merged Politics With Art, Dies at 83
abstract: Ms. Mondale learned the role of traditional political wife early in her marriage, but she expanded her reputation as a supporter of the arts throughout Walter F. Mondale’s career.
lead_paragraph: Joan Mondale, whose promotion and advocacy of painting, sculpture and other fine arts earned her the nickname Joan of Art in Washington during the vice presidency of her husband, Walter F. Mondale, in the late 1970s, died on Monday in Minneapolis. She was 83.

headline: Tax Expert Sees Abuse in a Stream of Private Equity Fees
abstract: A law professor argues that monitoring fees, payments that companies make to their private equity owners in exchange for what regulatory filings call consulting and advisory services over time, resemble dividends.
lead_paragraph: The tax practices of private equity firms have come under scrutiny from the authorities on several fronts. But there is an additional tax strategy that should merit a skeptical look, an academic argues in a new article.

headline: Art Matters | An Outlaw Art Fair Sets up Shop on L.A.’s Frontier
abstract: The Paramount Ranch show installed a global who’s who of young galleries in an only-in-So-Cal setting: the faux Western village where John Wayne filmed.
lead_paragraph: Despite its rising profile as an art capital, Los Angeles has never quite mustered an internationally attended art week until, arguably, just now. This year’s festivities, which concluded yesterday with the close of the Art Los Angeles Contemporary fair at the Barker Hangar in Santa Monica and the LA Art Book Fair at The Geffen Contemporary at MOCA in the Downtown area, felt buzzier than in years past — due, in part, to the addition of a newcomer to the circuit.

headline: Iran Giving Food Away to Millions for Relief
abstract: The authorities began the initiative, which drew long lines, both to help those with low incomes and to try to lower inflation on food prices, local news media reported.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The Iranian government has started handing out food packages for millions of its citizens both to help those with low income and to try to lower inflation on food, local news media reported on Monday.

headline: In Switch, Refusal to Testify Wins a Brooklyn Man His Freedom
abstract: The inmate, Gerald Koch, a self-described anarchist, had said he would not cooperate with what he called a fishing expedition against his political associations.
lead_paragraph: For the last eight months, a Brooklyn man had been held in jail because of his refusal to testify before a grand jury that was believed to be examining a 2008 explosion in Times Square.

headline: Dutch Reporter Is Forced to Flee Egypt as Pursuit of Al Jazeera Journalists Snares More Victims
abstract: Al Jazeera condemned what it described as “an attempt to demonize” two of its reporters, Peter Greste and Mohamed Fahmy, with the release of video recorded during their arrest in December in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Tuesday, 2:18 a.m. | As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, the Qatari news network Al Jazeera condemned on Monday what it described as “an attempt to demonize” two of its reporters, Peter Greste and Mohamed Fahmy, with the release of video recorded during their arrest in December at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo.

headline: Fast Internet Is Chattanooga’s New Locomotive
abstract: Internet service that is inexpensive and lightning quick has allowed the city to attract high-tech businesses, talent and capital.
lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — For thousands of years, Native Americans used the river banks here to cross a gap in the Appalachian Mountains, and trains sped through during the Civil War to connect the eastern and western parts of the Confederacy. In the 21st century, it is the Internet that passes through Chattanooga, and at lightning speed.

headline: Catering to the Chinese Shopper’s Grand Tour
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Purveyors of luxury brands are stepping up their efforts to sell to Chinese tourists in Europe, where many prefer to spend their money.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Xiaoyan Mao had not yet collected her luggage after landing at Charles de Gaulle Airport from Shanghai recently. But she and a friend were already mapping out a game plan for the three days they would spend in Paris before continuing a 10-day European blitz with additional stops in Switzerland, Italy and Germany.

headline: Trade Issue Goes Untouched as Obama and Reid Meet
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama met with Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, but made no effort to seek additional authority to negotiate trade deals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama met with Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, at the White House on Monday but made no effort to change Mr. Reid’s mind on the trade initiative that has divided them, according to Democrats briefed on the session.

headline: Tacloban Three Months Later
abstract: Nearly three months after Typhoon Haiyan devastated the Philippines, many still live in tents with little electricity. Keith Bradsher reports from Tacloban.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three months after Typhoon Haiyan devastated the Philippines, many still live in tents with little electricity. Keith Bradsher reports from Tacloban.

headline: U.S. Plans Car-to-Car Warning System
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Vehicles would broadcast location and speed to other vehicles to cut down on accidents by alerting drivers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government said on Monday that it planned to require all new cars to broadcast their location, speed, direction and other data, and to receive similar data from other vehicles, to warn drivers of impending collisions. But regulators cautioned that any new rules would be years away.

headline: Boycott Israel? A War of Words
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Palestinians', 'Boycotts', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Readers react to Sunday Review essays about the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement.

headline: Russia: 3 Jailed in Anti-Gay Case
abstract: A court in Russia’s Far East on Monday found three men guilty of murdering a man in an attack that prosecutors said was motivated by homophobia.
lead_paragraph: A court in Russia’s Far East on Monday found three men guilty of murdering a man in an attack that prosecutors said was motivated by homophobia. The three men were convicted of stabbing and beating the man, Oleg Serdyuk, to death in a forest near the village of Ust-Bolsheretskii in the Kamchatka region in May, and then burning his body in a car. Prosecutors said the defendants had killed Mr. Serdyuk because they believed he was gay. The men received sentences ranging from nine to 12 and a half years in a labor camp. Advocates for gay rights in Russia have claimed that the number of homophobic attacks has risen since the introduction of a law last year banning “gay propaganda” among children.

headline: Legalizing Immigrants
abstract: An immigration researcher questions the practicality of proposed bills in Congress.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Britain: French Comic Barred
abstract: The controversial French comedian Dieudonné M’Bala M’Bala has been barred from entering Britain because of his extreme views, the Home Office said Monday.
lead_paragraph: The controversial French comedian Dieudonné M’Bala M’Bala has been barred from entering Britain because of his extreme views, the Home Office said Monday. Mr. M’Bala M’Bala has been repeatedly convicted in France for inciting racial hatred, and his shows have been banned in several French towns. He has been criticized more recently for having invented the quenelle, a gesture that resembles a Nazi salute and carries anti-Semitic overtones, critics say. He says the gesture is social criticism, not aimed at any particular group. A spokeswoman for the Home Office said that Mr. M’Bala M’Bala was subject to an exclusion order, citing “public policy or public security reasons.”

abstract: Prof. Todd Gitlin urges the United States and Russia to abandon their launch-on-warning policies.

abstract: A New York City official assures residents of buildings with roof tanks that their water is safe to drink.

abstract: A reader and fellow “tree topper” offers Bill de Blasio an insight.
