headline: I.V.F. in Israel, With Unexpected Help From a Stranger
abstract: When fertility treatments seemed to be coming to an end, a stranger offered to help.
lead_paragraph: Decisions about fertility often come down to what you can change and what you have to accept. Do you accept an infertility diagnosis? Do you detoxify to conceive naturally, as suggested by Julia Indichova (“Inconceivable: A Woman’s Triumph Over Despair and Statistics”) and Sami S. David (“Making Babies: A Proven 3-Month Program for Maximum Fertility”)? Or do you move on to in vitro fertilization?

headline: Maintainer of City Watershed Fatally Shot, Officials Say
abstract: The authorities in Ulster County arrested one of the victim’s co-workers and charged him with second-degree murder. No motive was given for the shooting.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers seldom stop to think that the water they use comes from reservoirs in the forests and wooded hills that stretch from Westchester County to the Catskills, or of the workers who keep it flowing, and safe. But early Monday morning, something happened to remind them.

headline: Finnish Soul Is Reflected in Goalies
abstract: A quiet strength and pride were characteristics of a people who live in the northern reaches of Europe, and they brought it with them as they stood tall between the posts.
lead_paragraph: The duel at 178 feet between Antti Niemi and Tuukka Rask took place last month in California, with the fateful shot heard halfway around the world in Finland, long known for skiing, saunas, sunless winters and cellphones, and increasingly gaining notice for its puck stoppers.

headline: At Four Seasons, Picasso Tapestry Hangs on the Edge of Eviction
abstract: On the surface, the dispute about the planned removal of “Le Tricorne” at the Four Seasons in New York is about grout and tiles, but it is also a collision of values and taste.
lead_paragraph: For more than half a century, it has hung in the hallway of the Four Seasons Restaurant on Park Avenue, an immense work by one of the greatest artists of the 20th century. But Picasso’s curtain is coming down — and that might just destroy it.

headline: When Loud Music Turned Deadly
abstract: This video tells the story of a black teenager in Florida who was killed by a white man after an argument over loud music. The slain youth’s father shares his loss.
lead_paragraph: This video tells the story of a black teenager in Florida who was killed by a white man after an argument over loud music. The slain youth’s father shares his loss.

headline: Dissecting a Frog: How to Write a Humor Piece
abstract: Writing comedy is a highly logical exercise — fit idea X into form Y for humorous result Z.
lead_paragraph: Analyzing humor, as E.B. White famously said, is like dissecting a frog; few people are interested and the frog dies of it. Nonetheless, writing humor is a highly logical exercise — fit idea X into form Y for humorous result Z — and can therefore be broken down in ways that more slippery kinds of prose tend to resist.

headline: Born While Floods Surge
abstract: Yolando was born during the worst of typhoon Haiyan. He lives with his family in a region devastated by the storm.
lead_paragraph: Yolando was born during the worst of typhoon Haiyan. He lives with his family in a region devastated by the storm.

headline: Don’t Ask Your Doctor About ‘Low T’
abstract: How drug companies turned male aging into a disease.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — A FUNNY thing has happened in the United States over the last few decades. Men’s average testosterone levels have been dropping by at least 1 percent a year, according to a 2006 study in The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism.

headline: Detroit Turns Bankruptcy Into Challenge of Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'Government Bonds', 'Municipal Bonds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Financial institutions that helped raise money for Detroit’s pension system are dismayed now to see themselves portrayed as shady characters in the city’s lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Detroit’s bankruptcy is rapidly shaping up as a battle of Wall Street vs. Main Street, at least as far as the city’s creditors are concerned.

headline: Lawmaker Says Colleges Are Misleading on Aid Letter
abstract: Many colleges are misleading applicants about the paperwork needed to seek financial aid, possibly violating federal law and costing students extra money, a congressman said.
lead_paragraph: Many top colleges are misleading applicants about the paperwork needed to seek financial aid, possibly violating federal law and costing students extra money, a congressman said on Monday.

headline: Seahawks-Broncos Super Bowl TV Ratings Top 111 Million
abstract: With 111.5 million viewers, Fox’s Super Bowl audience was the largest in American television history.
lead_paragraph: The game was hardly an edge-of-the-seat thriller, but in the end the pull of the Super Bowl was all that mattered: A record 111.5 million viewers watched Fox’s coverage of the Seattle Seahawks’ dismantling of the Denver Broncos, the Nielsen company reported on Monday.

headline: ‘Puppy Love’ Warms Hearts; Diversity Draws Mixed Response
abstract: A golden lab puppy who refuses to leave his Clydesdale “bud” won plaudits; a Coca-Cola spot evoking the nation’s multicultural populace drew mostly positive reactions, but some raw comments as well.
lead_paragraph: THE annual flood of data after the Super Bowl indicates that the commercials during the game that did best among consumers on television, online and in social media were feel-good spots meant to be uplifting, inspirational, nostalgic or patriotic. And by almost all accounts, the spot that was discussed, liked and shared most was “Puppy Love,” a warm, emotional tale created by the Anomaly agency that Budweiser brought to viewers late in the fourth quarter.

headline: Super Bowl Again Proves Bigger Than the Game Itself
abstract: Though Sunday’s game was a rout and a dud, the Super Bowl is so iconic an event that Fox was able to set viewership records even as the game’s intrigue faded.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl can be a great game or a bad game, a dramatic struggle or a laugher. And viewership hardly wavers.

headline: Closing Arguments in Martoma Trial
abstract: The jury is expected to start deliberating on Tuesday in the trial of the former portfolio manager accused of using insider information to make trades.
lead_paragraph: Mathew Martoma, a former top portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, pursued a “canary in a coal mine” to give him an “illegal sneak preview” of the results of a clinical Alzheimer’s drug trial, a prosecutor said on Monday in closing remarks for the government’s closely watched insider trading case.

headline: Hoffman’s Heroin Points to Surge in Grim Trade
abstract: Packages of the drug found in the apartment where Philip Seymour Hoffman died offered a window into the actor’s struggle with addiction and exposed a seedy underground where heroin sells for as little as $6 a bag.
lead_paragraph: Detectives found dozens of small packages in the West Village apartment where Philip Seymour Hoffman, the actor, died on Sunday. Most were branded, some with purple letters spelling out Ace of Spades, others bearing the mark of an ace of hearts. At least five were empty, and in the trash.

headline: Love, Death and Sochi
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Olympic Games (2014)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Let these Olympics be a lesson. For too many gays, the heart is a prison.
lead_paragraph: There are few moments sweeter, more humbling or more thrilling than telling someone you love how you feel.

headline: Karzai Arranged Secret Contacts With the Taliban
abstract: President Hamid Karzai’s contacts with the Taliban about reaching a peace deal could explain why he has held up a security deal, straining his relationship with the United States.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has been engaged in secret contacts with the Taliban about reaching a peace agreement without the involvement of his American and Western allies, further corroding already strained relations with the United States.

headline: What Machines Can’t Do
abstract: What human skills will become more valuable as computers take over more and more duties?
lead_paragraph: We’re clearly heading into an age of brilliant technology. Computers are already impressively good at guiding driverless cars and beating humans at chess and Jeopardy. As Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology point out in their book “The Second Machine Age,” computers are increasingly going to be able to perform important parts of even mostly cognitive jobs, like picking stocks, diagnosing diseases and granting parole.

headline: Collegiate Women’s Bowling Gains in Popularity
abstract: In her eighth year as coach of St. Francis College’s bowling team, Dawn Gugliaro leads one of a growing number of N.C.A.A. women’s bowling programs.
lead_paragraph: Bowl season has a completely different meaning to Dawn Gugliaro.

headline: Second U.S. Bribery Trial Begins for Brooklyn Assemblyman
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'State Legislatures', 'Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: William F. Boyland Jr., who faces 21 counts, was acquitted of conspiracy to accept bribes in a federal trial in Manhattan in 2011.
lead_paragraph: In October 2010, William F. Boyland Jr., a state assemblyman from Brooklyn, shared fine cuts of meat, wine and whiskey with two businessmen who were trying to buy Mr. Boyland’s political influence.

headline: Olson and Boies, Legal Duo, Seek Role in 2 Cases on Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Theodore B. Olson and David Boies, who led the case that defeated California’s ban on same-sex marriage, want to play a central role in cases in Utah and Oklahoma, but they have not been met with open arms by the teams of lawyers already involved.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Theodore B. Olson and David Boies, the star legal duo who defied skeptics by successfully challenging California’s ban on same-sex marriage, are seeking to play a central role in the next round of marriage cases that appear to be on a fast track to the high court. But in doing so, they have touched off a debate over who gets the coveted job of arguing what could be a landmark gay rights decision.

headline: ‘When Loud Music Turned Deadly’
abstract: This Op-Doc video tells the story of a black teenager in Florida who was killed by a white man after an argument over loud music. The slain youth’s father, Ron Davis, shares his loss.
lead_paragraph: This Op-Doc video tells the story of how a black 17-year-old, Jordan Davis, was killed by a 45-year-old white man, Michael Dunn, now charged with first-degree murder. The shooting took place at a gas station in Jacksonville, Fla., the day after Thanksgiving in 2012. It followed an argument in which Mr. Dunn complained about loud hip-hop music playing in Mr. Davis’s friend’s car. Mr. Dunn has claimed he fired in self-defense after seeing a gun, which the police never found. Two lives, two outcomes, both tragic. Jury selection begins this week.

headline: Too Many Sorry Excuses for Apology
abstract: The art of the apology has become a choreographed dance: Say you’re sorry, act vulnerable, tell everyone you’re “taking responsibility” and end with, “I hope to put this behind me.”
lead_paragraph: It seems that just about every day a chief executive, politician or other prominent figure is apologizing for something.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 4, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, February 4, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Nothing says ‘hard-core’ like being cast out by Al Qaeda.”

headline: The Gun Report, 1 Year Later
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Gangs']
abstract: When you track gun violence every day, a few things really stand out.
lead_paragraph: It has been a year since my assistant, Jennifer Mascia, and I started publishing The Gun Report, an effort to use my blog to aggregate daily gun violence in America. Our methodology is pretty simple: We do a Google News search each weekday morning for the previous day’s shootings and then list them. Most days, we have been finding between 20 and 30 shootings; on Mondays, when we also add the weekend’s violence, the number is usually well over 100.

headline: Bill Would Put Face on Anonymous Attack Ads
abstract: Rough-and-tumble campaign tactics are nothing new in New York politics, but a new proposal aims to identify and ban those behind the trash-talk ads.
lead_paragraph: One campaign advertisement mailed to voters’ homes last fall suggested that a candidate for New York City comptroller deserved to be behind bars. Another highlighted accusations of sexual harassment against a City Council candidate. In a Russian-speaking enclave of Brooklyn, a robocall accused a Council hopeful of having once been an agent for the K.G.B.

headline: Calling for an Apology Cease-Fire
abstract: Virtually every aspect of our public lives is in the midst of a dangerous apology crisis. We should pause and think long and hard about what a real apology means and requires.
lead_paragraph: In 1976, Elton John sang the memorable phrase “Sorry seems to be the hardest word.” Well, “sorry” has become one of the easiest and most convenient — and therefore least meaningful — words there is.

headline: Firearms’ Toll Among the Young
abstract: A study shows that each day an average of 20 American children and adolescents end up in hospitals from gunfire.
lead_paragraph: The world at large heard instantly about the school massacre in Newtown, Conn., where 20 youngsters were murdered in 2012 in a terrifying spree of gunfire. Far less noticed but no less horrific is the unending toll from the more routine bursts of gunfire that each day send an average of 20 American children and adolescents to hospitals, many of them for long-term treatment.

headline: A Chill on Speech
keywords: ['Boycotts', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Palestinians', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Editorials', 'ACADEMIC FREEDOM']
abstract: A New York State bill in response to a resolution to boycott Israeli academic institutions would trample on academic freedoms and free speech.
lead_paragraph: The New York Legislature is moving to pass a bill that would bar state financing for academic groups that have taken official action to boycott higher-education institutions in Israel. The initiative, which last week passed the State Senate, is now pending before the Assembly. It should be voted down by lawmakers, or, if they prove feckless, Gov. Andrew Cuomo should veto it.

headline: Democracy in Thailand, Interrupted
abstract: The disruption of Sunday’s election by protesters could imperil the country and its economy.
lead_paragraph: These are dark days in Thailand, where an election on Sunday was disrupted by protesters whose demands for a suspension of democracy could lead to greater chaos. The country’s constitutional monarchy has faced coups and street protests in the past, but it has been a model of relative stability and development in Southeast Asia, a region known for its autocratic and brutal governments. As an American treaty ally, Thailand has been critically important in helping to reduce regional tensions and provided balance to the growing military assertiveness of China by championing trade and economic integration partly through the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. On Sunday, protesters disrupted the vote by blocking the distribution of ballot boxes to polling places in about 11 percent of the country’s electoral districts. Because Thailand’s Constitution requires that 95 percent of parliamentary seats be filled before a new government can be formed, the disruption means the country will remain in limbo for months as election authorities try to conduct elections in those districts where protesters prevented a vote from taking place. A gun battle between protesters and government supporters left seven people injured on Saturday, a day before the elections.

headline: The Mayor and the Unions
abstract: The looming negotiations with the city’s unions over new contracts will give Mayor Bill de Blasio the chance to be a tougher kind of progressive.
lead_paragraph: For Mayor Bill de Blasio, this is the month that the civic conversation shifts from lofty goals and progressive agenda setting — and, let’s hope, snow plowing — to the gloomier and more combative subject of money.

headline: They Often Elicit Blessings
abstract: Stepping out with David Steinberg.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the things I admire about young David Steinberg (calling him “young” probably grates on his nerves, but I’m old enough to be his mother so I claim that right) is his enthusiasm for pushing the constructing envelope in what I consider to be a very productive way. Many beginning constructors find it enough to develop a simple, relatively tight theme and be done with it. Not Mr. Steinberg. He goes for the tough stuff and then tightens it up even more.

headline: Parks Department Takes a Seat Behind Nonprofit Conservancies
abstract: Central Park, the High Line, the Battery and Prospect Park are in the hands of privately held conservancies that raise hundreds of millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere along the way, New York City lost its faith in its ability to run a parks department.

headline: Move to Red Bulls Gets Convey Close to Home
abstract: The M.L.S. veteran Bobby Convey, a Philadelphia native, was one of the Red Bulls’ few off-season acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: One of the Red Bulls’ new players has a familiarity with the team’s second-year coach, Mike Petke, that comes more from dynamic interchanges on the soccer field than from pedestrian chalk-talks after training.

headline: Immigrant Youth Leaders Signal They May Be Open to a G.O.P. Compromise
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)']
abstract: There were signs of a willingness to consider something less than a direct path to citizenship for all the estimated 11.7 million immigrants in the country illegally.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite a defiant tone, immigrant youth leaders gathered here on Monday gave signs that they could consider supporting a Republican compromise proposal offering a path to citizenship for young people but not for other immigrants in the country illegally.

headline: The Other Super Bowl Contest: Twitter vs. Facebook
abstract: Advertisers were chattering far more on Twitter than on Facebook during the big game, according to a social media platform that analyzed the traffic.
lead_paragraph: From the start of the Super Bowl on Sunday, it was obvious that it was a one-sided match-up: the Seattle Seahawks quickly took the lead, leaving the Denver Broncos further and further behind in every quarter.

headline: A Long Goodbye for a Lost Railroad
abstract: Only a few historical markers and dim memories remain of a railroad built by a Chinese man who made his fortune in the United States.
lead_paragraph: JIANGMEN, China — It has been decades since a train has passed through the old Beijie train station in southern China. On a recent winter morning, the only sign of activity came from a group of architecture students busy with their sketch pads.

headline: The Casual Couture of the Average American
abstract: From sweatpants on airplanes to flip flops in the workplace: Have Americans taken casual dressing too far?

headline: Corrections: February 4, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 4, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Championship Built in Carroll’s Image
abstract: At each coaching stop, Pete Carroll massaged his approach, and proved willing to take in players of all backgrounds and personalities as long as they shared his competitive spirit.
lead_paragraph: Pete Carroll bounded through the front doors of the Sheraton Times Square Hotel a little after 8 a.m. Monday. It was 10 hours after his Seattle Seahawks won Super Bowl XLVIII, so he had ample time to rest. He just didn’t.

headline: De Blasio Says New York Learned From Past Storm Mistakes
abstract: For the third snowstorm of his young administration, Mayor Bill de Blasio said he had implemented some changes to speed the city’s response.
lead_paragraph: Grappling with the first of three snowstorms expected to hit New York City in a week, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday that his administration had learned from its mistakes and had already made changes to speed snow removal.

headline: In Talk of Economy, Obama Turns to ‘Opportunity’ Over ‘Inequality’
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: President Obama has moved toward the Republicans, and voters, in his choice of words when discussing the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Like so many political fights, the one between President Obama and Republicans over income inequality has become a battle over language. Is it about inequality of incomes or of opportunity? On this question, the president and his party have moved in Republicans’ — and voters’ — direction.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 3, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: With New App, Facebook Aims to Make Its Users’ Feeds Newsier
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Mobile Applications', 'Online Advertising', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Editors will supplement Facebook’s computers in recommending articles and blog posts on a dozen topics.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg dreams of a day when Facebook’s computers would know you and your habits so well that it would deliver exactly the information you want to see — what he calls “the best personalized newspaper in the world.”

headline: While Asking for Help, Detroit Sells a Comeback
abstract: Even as Detroit emphasizes its need for financial support, it is pitching itself as the city of the future.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Consider this public relations challenge, perhaps not seen since the Edsel: At the same time that beleaguered Detroit is emphasizing its desperate need for financial support, it is pitching itself as the city of the future.

headline: Video of Journalists’ Arrest in Egypt Seen as Threat to Media
keywords: ['Propaganda', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Government critics called a leaked video of two journalists being arrested in a Cairo hotel room in December an attempt to intimidate opponents of the military-backed government.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A leaked video of the arrest of two journalists offered a cinematic close-up on Monday of the new military-backed government’s crackdown on dissent: slow-moving footage of a hotel room full of telecommunications equipment set to the thumping, sinister score of the recent superhero movie “Thor: The Dark World.”

headline: Dispute Over Italian Marines Prompts Bickering in Indian Court, but No Resolution
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: India’s Supreme Court refused to resolve a dispute with Italy over the prosecution of two Italian marines accused of killing two Indian fishermen in 2012.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — With black-robed lawyers crammed into a courtroom, India’s Supreme Court refused on Monday to resolve a major international dispute that a top Italian diplomat warned could soon damage ties.

headline: De Blasio Takes a Comedic Break on ‘The Daily Show’
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio gleefully played up his left-leaning image, matching Jon Stewart zinger for zinger and joking about rumors that he was out to rid the city of the rich.
lead_paragraph: He bragged about hanging Che Guevara posters in his office, announced plans to flood the Upper East Side with biblical insects, and declared that the horses of Central Park were being waterboarded in their stables.

headline: Toyota Is Reported With Most Recalls in 2013
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: For the second year in a row, Toyota led the nation with the most vehicles recalled: nearly 5.3 million in 2013.
lead_paragraph: For the second year in a row, Toyota led the nation with the most vehicles recalled: nearly 5.3 million in 2013. The cars and trucks from Toyota and its Lexus brand were among the almost 22 million vehicles recalled last year in 632 recalls, according to figures released by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. That figure compares with nearly 16.4 million vehicles recalled in 2012 and is the highest number since 2004, when recalled vehicles hit 30.8 million. The Chrysler Group ranked second, with almost 4.7 million vehicles recalled in 36 actions; and Honda and its Acura brand were third, with 15 recalls involving almost 2.8 million vehicles.

headline: As Kidd Hits Stride, Nets Keep Improving by Nipping Sixers
abstract: What a difference a couple of months made: Jason Kidd was named the Eastern Conference coach of the month in January and the Nets’ record in their past nine games was 6-3.
lead_paragraph: Nets Coach Jason Kidd walked into a pregame news conference at Barclays Center on Dec. 3 with a sobering bit of information: He was relieving his top assistant, Lawrence Frank, of a majority of his coaching duties.

headline: Former Aide to Christie Invokes Fifth Amendment Right
abstract: Bridget Anne Kelly resisted a subpoena from a legislative panel investigating the closing of lanes at the George Washington Bridge by citing her right against self-incrimination.
lead_paragraph: A former top aide to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey revealed Monday that she would not hand over documents in response to a subpoena from a legislative panel investigating the controversial closing of lanes at the George Washington Bridge last fall, citing her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.

headline: Trading Captain Isn’t a Rarity in the N.H.L., and Usually Isn’t a Productive Move
abstract: Several teams have traded their on-ice leaders — four have done so in the last year alone — but they have not always gotten a good return.
lead_paragraph: The uncertainty over the future of the Rangers’ captain, Ryan Callahan, continued Monday, with fans wondering whether he would be dealt before the trade deadline on March 5 or the Olympic roster freeze on Friday.

headline: Jean Babilée, Rebel of World Ballet, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Babilée was a French ballet star and choreographer who rejected conventions in dance and life.
lead_paragraph: Jean Babilée, who gained instant stardom in French ballet as the violent chair-throwing youth in Roland Petit’s “Le Jeune Homme et la Mort” (“The Young Man and Death”) in 1946, and who remained international dance’s great rebel, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 90.

headline: Falling to Bucks, the Knicks Continue a Pattern of Not Having One
abstract: The Knicks, inconsistent all season, lost to lowly Milwaukee after Brandon Knight answered Carmelo Anthony’s tying 3-pointer with a 3 of his own in the final seconds.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — The fourth-quarter scenes played out in a way that could only make Knicks Coach Mike Woodson shudder. Amar’e Stoudamire dribbled into a lane crowded with Milwaukee Bucks and lost the ball. Out of the pack came Milwaukee forward Giannis Antetokounmpo, his long limbs churning upcourt on the way to a dunk that pushed the Bucks’ lead to 10.

headline: Potent Pro-Israel Group Finds Its Momentum Blunted
abstract: A Senate bill to impose new sanctions on Iran, a top priority for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, has stalled after stiff resistance from President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time the nation’s most potent pro-Israel lobbying group lost a major showdown with the White House was when President Ronald Reagan agreed to sell Awacs surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia over the group’s bitter objections.

headline: Study Finds Changes in Brains of Hockey Players Who Had Concussions
abstract: The researchers conducted magnetic resonance imaging analysis of 45 Canadian university players before, during and after the 2011-12 season.
lead_paragraph: Hockey players who sustained concussions during a recent season experienced acute microstructural changes in their brains, according to a series of studies published in the Journal of Neurosurgery on Tuesday.

headline: How L.B.J. Pushed Through Kennedy’s Tax Cut
abstract: Lyndon B. Johnson successfully overcame bipartisan resistance to cutting taxes in putting through legislation he inherited from John F. Kennedy, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | carapace
abstract: This word has appeared in 17 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: carapace•\ˈker-ə-ˌpas, ˈka-rə-\• noun

headline: Study Puts Exonerations at Record Level in U.S.
abstract: The number of exonerations in the United States of those wrongly convicted of a crime increased to a record 87 during 2013, according to a report to be released on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The number of exonerations in the United States of those wrongly convicted of a crime increased to a record 87 during 2013, and of that number, nearly one in five had initially pleaded guilty to charges filed against them, according to a report to be released on Tuesday as part of a project led by two university law schools.

headline: Mets Sign Farnsworth
abstract: The Mets continued to fill out their bullpen, announcing that they had signed Kyle Farnsworth to a minor league deal.
lead_paragraph: The Mets continued to fill out their bullpen, announcing that they had signed Kyle Farnsworth to a minor league deal, with an invitation to spring training. Farnsworth, 37, had a 4.70 earned run average in 48 games last season, which he split between Pittsburgh and Tampa Bay.

headline: Indian Groups Question Public Child-Welfare Practices
abstract: Several prominent Native American groups on Monday called for the Justice Department to investigate the treatment of Indian children in public child-welfare systems and private adoptions.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Several prominent Native American groups on Monday called for the Justice Department to investigate the treatment of Indian children in public child-welfare systems and private adoptions.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) RUST AND BONE (2012) Ali (Matthias Schoenaerts), a former prizefighter fleeing with his young son (Armand Verdure) from a bad situation, arrives in Antibes, on the Côte d’Azur. At a club where he works as a bouncer, he meets Stephanie (Marion Cotillard, above, with Mr. Schoenaerts), a trainer for a Sea World-like amusement park. Then she loses her legs in an accident with a killer whale and calls him, thinking he might help rouse her from her despair. “A plot summary of ‘Rust and Bone’ might suggest a maudlin, therapeutic fable of healing, and in many ways — or, let’s say, in hindsight — the movie is just that,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But its conventional, sentimental essence (which is overtly revealed only at the end) is effectively complicated, indeed almost undone, by the jagged textures of the filmmaking and the naturalistic intensity of the performances.” He added: “The removal of Ms. Cotillard’s legs — including in scenes in which she wears a bathing suit or nothing — is surely one of the most impressive special-effects feats of the year, and a reminder that digital cinema is not all about accessorizing wizards, monsters and superheroes. But the greater marvel is Ms. Cotillard herself, an actress of limitless bravery and supernatural poise, who is both beauty and beast. Mr. Schoenaerts is her perfect foil and complement, as large and coarse as she is small and delicate, and also as tender as she is tough.”

headline: Adult Swim, No. 1 With Younger Adults, Is Expanding
abstract: Programming will soon begin at 8 p.m. to meet advertisers’ demands for more airtime on the cable network, which leads in the ratings for some coveted categories.
lead_paragraph: The big developments in late-night television are not all happening on NBC this week. Adult Swim, the network that is, in many ways, the new force in late night, has some significant news, too: It is expanding again.

headline: Stevie Nicks, Just Following Her Muse
abstract: At 65, she talks about vocal lessons, songwriting, the longevity of Fleetwood Mac and life on and offstage.
lead_paragraph: During her 40-year career as a member of Fleetwood Mac and a solo artist, the singer-songwriter Stevie Nicks has made more than 40 Top 50 hits and sold over 140 million albums. “In Your Dreams,” a documentary film about the making of her 2011 album of the same name, was recently released on DVD. Now 65, Ms. Nicks called from a rented house in Phoenix, her hometown. A condensed and edited version of our conversation follows.

headline: A Competition for Converts in Arunachal Pradesh
abstract: As indigenous peoplein the northeastern state convert to Christianity, society is increasingly being drawn along religious rather than tribal lines.
lead_paragraph: ITANAGAR, Arunachal Pradesh — Though the event they advertised had passed a month earlier, the neon-colored posters remained, clinging to the state capital’s walls, lampposts and storefronts. On them were invitations to Indigenous Faith Day celebrations on Dec. 1, with slogans like “Culture without faith is body without soul,” and, more pointedly, “Imitation of alien faith is slavery.”

headline: Foursquare Checks In With Microsoft and Gets $15 Million to Revitalize Itself
abstract: The money will be used to incorporate Foursquare recommendations into Microsoft’s local and search products over the next four years.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Foursquare, the location-sharing application, announced a data licensing partnership and $15 million investment from Microsoft.

headline: Profit Drops for BP, but Still Beats Analysts’ Forecasts
abstract: The oil giant reported lower earnings for the fourth quarter as production declined and its refineries struggled to turn a profit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — BP, the British oil giant, on Tuesday joined other oil companies including Royal Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil in reporting lower profit for the fourth quarter as production declined and the company’s refineries struggled to make money.

headline: Revamping and Tax Gain Help UBS Beat Estimates
abstract: Net profit for the fourth quarter was 917 million Swiss francs, or $1 billion, contrasted to a loss of 1.9 billion francs in the period a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:30 p.m. | The Swiss bank UBS reported higher-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday as a far-reaching revamping plan started to pay off and it benefited from a tax gain.

lead_paragraph: Nelson D. Schwartz writes about economic trends in the article “The Middle Class Is Steadily Eroding. Just Ask the Business World.”

headline: In Rapid Turnaround, Toyota Is on Track to Post Record Earnings
abstract: After enduring huge recalls, a tsunami in Japan and a steep drop in sales because of slowing demand, Toyota said it was on pace to earn its biggest-ever annual profit in its fiscal year that ends in March.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — While the American automakers have made drastic comebacks since the recession, no car company has had a bigger revival than Toyota.

headline: Outsourced Cancer Research, by Spacecraft
abstract: Researchers are hoping a Space Invaders-inspired cellphone game can outsource genetic analysis to the general public.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England – A cancer research lab on the outskirts of Cambridge seems like an unlikely place to find innovations in gaming.

headline: Can Marriage Cure Poverty?
abstract: Everyone in Washington seems to think so. It’s too bad they’re wrong.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a late-night television commercial aimed at Washington’s wonks: Tired of your same old tax credits and grant proposals? Ever dreamed of a policy tool that improved children’s health, bolstered income and eradicated poverty — all without costing the government a penny? Then, a smash cut to a wedding scene.

headline: In the Bronx, 20 Kids and Counting
abstract: Marshaling the chaotic life of one child is challenging enough. In one busy home in the Bronx, a lesbian couple have raised 20 foster children in 10 years.
lead_paragraph: One of the first things Stephen Reiss noticed about Eshey Scarborough-Harris’s office were the photos she had of her children. There were a lot. More than a dozen.

headline: If You Were Governor of Your State, How Would You Spend a Budget Surplus?
abstract: Would you want to spend more on education and other programs, cut taxes or put away money for a rainy-day fund?
lead_paragraph: We have become so used to hearing news about layoffs and spending cuts over the past several years that you may not remember what it’s like to have a government surplus — but that’s exactly what’s happening in many states. Politicians now have to figure out what to do with that extra money.

abstract: What you need to know for Tuesday: messy on roads and sidewalks, another storm tonight, and the mayor’s comic turn on late-night TV.
lead_paragraph: Updated 10:10 a.m.

headline: For a Select Few, the Transformative Power of Facebook — for Better or Worse
abstract: New York Times readers reflected on how the social network, as it turns 10, has altered their lives.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Facebook turns 10. Over the last decade, it has grown from a website coded in a dorm room to a Silicon Valley giant. It has been at the center of privacy and security backlashes and controversies — some short and others lasting — over new policies and one redesign after another.

headline: Rights Group Releases Video of LGBT Attacks in Russia
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: In the video, Human Rights Watch reveals disturbing violence in Russia against gay people, and says that the authorities there have failed to protect them and has emboldened attackers.
lead_paragraph: With just days left until the start on Friday of the Sochi Winter Olympics, Human Rights Watch released a video on Tuesday that highlights the disturbing violence and discrimination that gay, lesbian, transgender and bisexual people face in Russia.

headline: Photographer Shifts from Automotive Espionage to Fine Art
abstract: Brenda Priddy, an automotive spy photographer, has turned her lens away from manufacturers’ desert testing areas toward detail-oriented imagery.
lead_paragraph: CHANDLER, ARIZ. — Brenda Priddy has become known around the world for her automotive spy photography. In her line of work, she stalks heavily camouflaged prototype vehicles being driven in secret — or so the engineers at the wheel have thought.

headline: The Censorship Pendulum
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Censorship', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: People like to hear voices critical of the government, so social media companies can’t silence them entirely.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — IF you want to understand the current state of self-expression in China, the best indicator must be the line “Sorry, the text has been deleted.”

headline: Democracy in Thailand
abstract: Different visions are pulling the country in different directions.
lead_paragraph: Different visions are pulling the country in different directions.

headline: When Plan A Doesn’t Work
abstract: At a board meeting, I proposed that we scrap what we had developed and start over — while we still had money in the bank.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, I had an idea for a technology company. I noticed that the daily deal sites like Groupon and LivingSocial were starting to wane, and I thought I had a better model. I mocked up some designs, built a PowerPoint deck, and took the concept to investors. After a year of pitching, I raised the money, hired a team, and set about building the product, which we called Posse.

headline: Beating the ‘Curse of the Ninth’
abstract: The London Symphony Orchestra performed the premiere of the new 10th Symphony by Peter Maxwell Davies on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two years ago when Peter Maxwell Davies — doyen of British composers and Master of the Queen’s Music — produced a Ninth Symphony he was asked, repeatedly, if he shouldn’t be worried about the “Curse of the Ninth”: a long-cherished myth of classical music claiming that if you manage to write nine symphonies you probably won’t live to complete a 10th.

headline: Venture Capital Firm Focused on the Midwest Raises a $250 Million Fund
abstract: “We truly believe the best place in America to build your company is in the Midwest,” says one of the partners behind Drive Capital, which aims to bring Silicon Valley-style investing to the Midwest.
lead_paragraph: Mark D. Kvamme, a former partner at the venture capital firm Sequoia Capital, considers himself “a Silicon Valley guy through and through,” having grown up in the region and spent his professional life there.

headline: Veteran Banker to Lead Citigroup’s British Business
abstract: James Bardrick, Citigroup’s co-chief of corporate and investment banking for Europe, the Middle East and Africa, will succeed Maurice Thompson, who is leaving the bank.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – James Bardrick, a veteran banker in London, has been named head of Citigroup’s business in Britain.

headline: Close but Not Quite
abstract: A slightly unusual word choice can enliven a story. But we should make sure we know what our slightly unusual word actually means. Here are several recent cases where we reached for a word, only to come up with the wrong one or to use it incorrectly.
lead_paragraph: A slightly unusual word choice can enliven a story. But we should make sure we know what our slightly unusual word actually means.

headline: Where White Means Diversity
abstract: A ruling in Maryland has turned the spotlight on diversification of historically black colleges.
lead_paragraph: A FEDERAL COURT DECISION concerning competition between Maryland’s predominantly white public universities and its predominantly black ones has turned the spotlight on diversification of historically black colleges.

headline: Hard Times at Howard U.
abstract: A premier black college has been rocked by the economy, infighting and a changing demographic landscape.
lead_paragraph: IT COULD BE SAID that Dr. Wayne A.I. Frederick, acting president of Howard University, was to the manner born. On his birth 42 years ago in Port of Spain, Trinidad, his mother had already determined he would follow in the footsteps of the man she admired most: Eric Williams, who before leading Trinidad and Tobago to independence from Britain had taught at Howard.

headline: Spike Jonze Lives a 5-Year Relationship in 1 Day
abstract: The writer-director explains how he filmed the flashback scenes in “Her.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Spike Jonze, who won the Writers Guild Award for best original screenplay for “Her” over the weekend, has a slightly unusual writer-director process: he spends a long time in the edit room, as much as a year, tweaking the script continually as he goes. But in one way, “Her” appeared on screen as originally written: the flashbacks between Joaquin Phoenix’s character, Theodore Twombly, and his ex-wife, played by Rooney Mara. Those scenes flesh out his romantic life before he falls for his computer operating system, voiced by Scarlett Johansson.

headline: Playing on de Blasio’s Softball Team
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A teammate recalled the future mayor in center field on the 78th Precinct coed team in Carroll Gardens.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Hold the Apologies
abstract: The “Apology Watch” begins on the DealBook website. | A crowded courtroom heard closing arguments in the insider trading trial of a former SAC manager. | In Detroit bankruptcy, it is Wall Street vs. Main Street. | Stocks slumped Monday on disappointing economic data.
lead_paragraph: “What does saying ‘sorry’ mean when it’s tossed around with the frequency of a Justin Bieber scandal?” asks Andrew Ross Sorkin in the DealBook column. Almost every day, some prominent figure — a chief executive, a politician, an athlete — is apologizing for something — to say nothing of the average person. Are we in the midst of an apology crisis? To hear Dov Seidman talk about it, the answer is an emphatic yes. And in fact, Mr. Seidman is so sure that our mea culpas have become meaningless that he called for an “apology cease-fire” in front of several dozen chief executives and politicians at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Remembering to Pray
abstract: Finding my way back to religion, I find some prayers are composed in the sanctuaries of my making.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, toward end of day, I jog on a beach nearby on Mobile Bay. As the sun is sinking I look out at the pelicans wheeling in the sky, the fishermen on Fairhope Pier casting their nets, sailboats and channel markers changing to silhouette.

headline: The Moment | Back to the Land
abstract: There’s a handcrafted earthiness to urban dressing this season.
lead_paragraph: There’s a handcrafted earthiness to urban dressing this season.

headline: Microsoft Names New Chief; Gates Becomes Adviser
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The choice of Satya Nadella, an engineering executive, suggested that Microsoft viewed technical skill as critical for its next leader. Bill Gates will advise Mr. Nadella.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft on Tuesday announced that Satya Nadella was its next leader, betting on a longtime engineering executive to help the company keep better pace with changes in technology.

headline: After 2 Years in Moscow, U.S. Envoy Is Resigning
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Michael A. McFaul, a former senior adviser to President Obama, has been criticized by pro-Kremlin media for meeting with opposition politicians.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The United States ambassador to Russia announced Tuesday that he would resign after the Winter Olympics, set to begin in Sochi this week, ending a stormy two-year tenure during which relations between the two countries were at their lowest ebb since the end of the Cold War.

headline: Lenovo Shares Tumble in Wake of Company’s Deal Spree
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Tuesday was the stock’s first full day of trading since Lenovo announced it would buy Motorola Mobility from Google for $2.9 billion last week. The deal came a week after it agreed to acquire IBM’s low-end server business for $2.3 billion.
lead_paragraph: After taking off for the Chinese New Year holiday, shareholders in Lenovo appear to be having some cold feet about the computer maker’s recent deal spree.

keywords: ['Art', 'Auctions', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Finances', 'Museums']
abstract: The event’s organizers said a number of exhibitors sold all their offerings, and many local gallery owners said they were pleased by the results.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On the heels of Christie’s successful auction in India, the sixth edition of the India Art Fair demonstrated that demand in the country’s art market remains strong.

headline: ARM Reports Loss as Sales of High-End Smartphones Slow
abstract: The British chip maker said it was trying to offset the decline by increasing sales for other devices, like smartwatches and fitness bands.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the latest sign that the market for high-end smartphones is stalling, ARM Holdings, the British semiconductor designer, reported on Tuesday a net loss for its fourth quarter as royalties from its chip designs continued to falter.

headline: Market for Patents Was Softer in 2013, Firms Say
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Software', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Technology companies have for years been stockpiling patents as a defense against lawsuits. But patent prices and transfers were down in 2013, according to data from two companies, offering a possible signal that businesses may be anticipating changes in patent law.
lead_paragraph: Technology companies have for years been stockpiling patents as an aggressive defense against lawsuits. But patent prices and transfers were down significantly in 2013, according to data from a patent brokerage company and an intellectual property valuation and investment firm.

headline: The Embarrassing Debt Ceiling Ritual
abstract: The Treasury secretary notified Congress that the country’s running out of money, again.
lead_paragraph: Jack Lew, the Treasury secretary, must be tired of this embarrassing ritual by now. Every few months, he has to notify Congress that the entirely unnecessary borrowing limit that lawmakers have insisted on imposing must be raised yet again. Then he has to wait while Republicans contort themselves to keep the government out of default while trying to persuade the hard right that they really hate doing so.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Names Satya Nadella Its New Chief
abstract: Microsoft on Tuesday announced that Satya Nadella would be its next leader, betting on a longtime engineering executive to help the company keep better pace with changes in technology.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Tuesday announced that Satya Nadella would be its next leader, betting on a longtime engineering executive to help the company keep better pace with changes in technology, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: The Booming Blog Says Goodbye
abstract: After a year and a half, the Booming blog is ending, but much of its content will be found elsewhere in the newspaper and on the web.
lead_paragraph: The Booming blog, as now configured, is coming to an end.

headline: Brisk Business in Big Law Firms Hiring Other Firms’ Partners, Study Finds
abstract: As firms jockey to expand, lawyers specializing in corporate law are in greatest demand, according to data compiled by The American Lawyer.
lead_paragraph: The country’s biggest law firms are hiring other firms’ partners at a rapid pace, a new study has found. Lawyers specializing in corporate work are the hottest commodities, an annual tally by the legal journal American Lawyer showed.

headline: U.S. Push to Export Dirty Fossil Fuels Parallels Past Action on Tobacco
abstract: The U.S. is pushing to expand carbon exports, paralleling its history on tobacco.
lead_paragraph: I encourage you to read “How the U.S. Exports Global Warming,” a fine feature by Tim Dickinson in Rolling Stone showing how the United States, flush with coal, oil and the dirty tar sands byproduct petroleum coke, is working hard, from the White House down, to become a big exporter of carbon. Here’s the nut paragraph, which draws an apt parallel to the history of tobacco regulation and trade:

headline: How Does the Classic Marriage Plot Stand Up in 2014?
abstract: Francine Prose and Dana Stevens discuss whether the classic marriage plot — desire, courtship, happily ever after — is still relevant in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Dana Stevens discuss whether the classic marriage plot — desire, courtship, happily ever after — stand up in 2014?

headline: Amid Ethics Inquiry, South Jersey Democrat Is Giving Up House Seat for a New Job
abstract: Representative Robert E. Andrews announced that he is stepping down and joining a Philadelphia law firm, saying, “I love Congress, but I love my family more.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Robert E. Andrews announced on Tuesday that he would resign from Congress after more than two decades, but said it had nothing to do with a bleak outlook for Democratic chances of retaking the House or with an ethics investigation into alleged misuse of his campaign funds.

headline: Minnesota’s Olympic Hockey Cradle (Pop. 1,781)
abstract: The tiny town of Warroad, Minn., which has as many indoor rinks (two) as red lights, has produced eight Olympic hockey players. The hope is for a pair of golds at the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: WARROAD, Minn. — This time, no royal titles were conferred, like King and Queen of the Frosty Festival, which T. J. Oshie and Gigi Marvin were crowned at Warroad High School in 2005.

headline: Signs of Progress in UBS Investment Bank Overhaul
abstract: UBS has cut its personnel expenses, increased profitability and started looking past its scandals. As a result, the bank’s 2013 bonus pool was increased by 28 percent.
lead_paragraph: More than a year ago, UBS pledged to overhaul its investment bank after a prominent trading loss and a rate-rigging scandal. Those efforts appeared to be bearing fruit, based on the bank’s latest earnings report released Tuesday.

headline: Sphinx Organization to Join With IMG Artists in Aiding Student Musicians
abstract: The Sphinx Organization, which offers classical music training to minority students, will begin a partnership with the management agency IMG Artists.
lead_paragraph: The Sphinx Organization, an organization based in Detroit that offers classical music training to minority students, announced a partnership with the management agency IMG Artists on Tuesday, in which Sphinx’s orchestras would perform at festivals and other events run by IMG, and IMG’s artists would collaborate with Sphinx. Aaron P. Dworkin, the violinist who founded Sphinx in 1996 and has built it into a national program that runs competitions and sends touring ensembles around the country, described the agreement as a relationship unlike the usual arrangement between managers and artists.

headline: Moderate Me Me Me Blogging
abstract: Also, Peter Gabriel and stuff.
lead_paragraph: So Noah Smith has a piece about how moderate yours truly really is. It’s almost completely right, except that I wish Noah would stop saying that my views on monetary policy in a liquidity trap derive from Eggertsson/Woodford; it’s a fine paper, but they were following me, not the other way around. Also, Arcade Fire’s “My body is a cage” isn’t a cover of Peter Gabriel; he was covering them.

headline: For Adults Only
abstract: The cheeky British artist Sarah Lucas returns to New York with a solo exhibition at the Gladstone Gallery.
lead_paragraph: The cheeky British artist Sarah Lucas returns to New York with a solo exhibition at the Gladstone Gallery.

abstract: Started at Harvard in 2004 as a way for college students to connect with each other, Facebook over 10 years has evolved into a global icon.
lead_paragraph: Started at Harvard in 2004 as a way for college students to connect with each other, Facebook over 10 years has evolved into a global icon.

keywords: ['Ethics (Institutional)', 'Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A retired psychiatrist says pressure to increase profits has corroded medical ethics. Readers are invited to respond.

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A doctor told Nido Jose Apil that his nephew, Nido Tania, the 18-year-old man who died after a fight with two shopkeepers, also had swelling of the brain.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Initial autopsy results show that Nido Tania, an 18-year-old student from the northeast who was allegedly beaten by shopkeepers in south Delhi last week, had head injuries and brain swelling before he died, Mr. Tania’s uncle told India Ink on Tuesday.

headline: More Than a Dozen Killed in Attacks in Baghdad Area
abstract: A series of attacks, including in the secured government area, rocked the Iraqi capital, while violence continued in restive Anbar Province.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Two rockets slammed into the zone in Baghdad where diplomatic and government offices are located, and a wave of bombings struck across the rest of the city on Tuesday, killing more than a dozen people, according to security sources.

headline: Health Care Law Projected to Cut the Labor Force
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With the expansion of insurance coverage, more workers will choose not to work and others will choose to work fewer hours than they might have otherwise, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Congressional Budget Office analysis released Tuesday predicted that the Affordable Care Act would shrink the work force by the equivalent of more than two million full-time positions and recharged the political debate over the health care law, providing Republican opponents fresh lines of attack and putting Democrats on the defensive.

abstract: A New York City rule prohibiting waiters from serving water unless it is requested dates to at least 1991, but will soon disappear.
lead_paragraph: A local regulation on drinking, on the books even longer than Prohibition was, has been flouted so routinely that when its repeal goes into effect this month most New Yorkers will probably not even notice.

abstract: The film festival there has become a pit stop on the awards circuit, mainly because hundreds of Academy voters live nearby or visit.
lead_paragraph: The Santa Barbara International Film Festival, which began last week and runs through Sunday, is not shy about announcing its intentions to the Oscar crowd, touting itself as “a must-stop for front-runners on the awards-season fast track.”

headline: Today in Small Business: Spying on Employees
