lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: At Bouley Botanical, Planters Overflow
abstract: The latest project from the chef David Bouley is a downtown Eden overflowing with herbs, flowers and vegetables.
lead_paragraph: Outside, there was a marrow-freezing snowstorm. But inside, at the corner of Church and White Streets in TriBeCa, windows burst forth with green, midsummer-like vegetation. This is Bouley Botanical, the latest enterprise/experiment from the chef David Bouley.

headline: Time Inc. to Cut 500 Jobs Ahead of Spinoff
abstract: The job cuts, said to affect 500 employees, are part of a corporate restructuring as the company is spun off from its parent, Time Warner.
lead_paragraph: Time Inc., the magazine giant with brands including People, Sports Illustrated and Fortune, began a new round of layoffs on Tuesday as part of a companywide restructuring that will result in the loss of about 500 jobs, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: James J. Gallagher Dies at 87; Educator Focused on Disabled and Gifted
abstract: Dr. Gallagher’s work expanded educational opportunities for disabled and gifted children nationwide, and he championed the education of both groups as a civil rights issue.
lead_paragraph: James J. Gallagher, an authority on child development whose work expanded educational opportunities for disabled and gifted children nationwide, died on Jan. 17 at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 87.

headline: Evaporating Unemployment
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Population', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A study for the New York Fed asserts that the contraction of the work force is more a reflection of an aging population than of a troubled economy.
lead_paragraph: Before the recession, in December 2007, about 63 percent of American adults had jobs. Six years later, in December 2013, less than 59 percent of adults had jobs.

headline: Image of the Day: February 4
abstract: Hindu devotees offering prayers at Allahabad in Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Britain Says India Did Not Follow Its Advice in 1984 Army Raid
abstract: A British officer advised Indian forces before they stormed the Golden Temple in Amritsar, killing hundreds, but the advice had little impact, the British government said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain sent a military officer to advise India before Indian forces stormed the Golden Temple in Amritsar in 1984, leaving hundreds dead, but the advice was largely ignored and had little impact on the bloody outcome, the British government said on Tuesday.

headline: Designer Seed Thought to Be Latest Target by Chinese
abstract: China has long been implicated in economic espionage efforts, but recent cases suggest that the agriculture sector is becoming a greater target.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The case of the missing corn seeds first broke in May 2011 when a manager at a DuPont research farm in east-central Iowa noticed a man on his knees, digging up the field. When confronted, the man, Mo Hailong, who was with his colleague Wang Lei, appeared flushed. Mr. Mo told the manager that he worked for the University of Iowa and was traveling to a conference nearby. When the manager paused to answered his cellphone, the two men sped off in a car, racing through a ditch to get away, federal authorities said.

headline: Fraud in Army Recruiting Bonus Program May Cost Nearly $100 Million
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Army investigators said soldiers, civilians and National Guard recruiters used the program as a “bounty” from which they could illegally collect money.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An Army program meant to increase the number of recruits during the Iraq and Afghanistan wars devolved into an illegal free-for-all that could cost taxpayers close to $100 million, military investigators say, describing new details of what they called a long-running scheme among National Guard recruiters that went undetected for years.

headline: Mr. Fremantle’s Adventure
abstract: What a British officer saw during his famous tour through the Civil War South.
lead_paragraph: In early 1864, printers in New York and Mobile, Ala. began to publish one of the most unusual books of the Civil War: the diary of a British officer, Lt. Colonel Arthur Fremantle, who had spent three months observing the war, on both sides. Though he began his tour with a pro-Union bias on account of his opposition to slavery, Fremantle traveled extensively through the South. Entering through Mexico, he crossed the Rio Grande on April 7, 1863, and left New York to return to Britain 14 weeks later. His insights into the Confederacy, though at times myopic, especially on the question of slavery, offer one of the best single sources on life in the wartime South.

headline: Scenes From Hockeytown USA
abstract: Images from the tiny town of Warroad, Minn., the home of two indoor ice rinks and eight Olympic hockey players.
lead_paragraph: Images from the tiny town of Warroad, Minn., the home of two indoor ice rinks and eight Olympic hockey players.

headline: California Teacher Accused of Sexual Abuse in YouTube Video Is Arrested
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: A former teacher in California has been arrested on sexual assault charges after a former student confronted her on the telephone and then posted a video recording of their conversation on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: A former California teacher and school administrator is expected to be arraigned Thursday on 16 felony charges of sexual assault after a former student confronted her over the telephone and then posted a video recording of the conversation on YouTube, according to a statement from the district attorney’s office in Riverside, Calif.

headline: Bookshelf | Portraits of the Hudson Valley’s Creative Community
abstract: A new collection of photographs and stories chronicles a 500-mile bicycle ride along the mighty river — and the artisans found along the way.
lead_paragraph: When Pete Seeger died last week, folk music lost one of its greatest pioneers, but so, too, did the Hudson Valley. Seeger had called the bucolic area just north of New York City home since the late ’40s, when he spent $1,700 for 17 acres in Beacon. It was from his house there that Seeger began, in the ’60s, his crusade to clean up the polluted Hudson River via his environmental nonprofit, the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater. Seeger was inspired artistically throughout his lifetime by the force of the mighty, meandering river, and it was Seeger that the British graphic designer Nick Hand initially had in mind when he decided, in the spring of 2012, to log about 550 miles biking through the region to interview and photograph members of its artisan community. The results are compiled in his new and lovely little book, “Conversations on the Hudson” (Princeton Architectural Press).

headline: In London: Three Plays, Double Standards
abstract: Three plays onstage in London — “Ghosts,” “Blurred Lines” and “The Pass” — are rooted in sexual hypocrisy and double standards.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The exorcists’ job is far from over, it seems. More than a century after they were first conjured, the title figures of Ibsen’s “Ghosts,” those remnants of corrosive societal traditions, are still clinging to us like leeches.

headline: Christie’s Cancels Sale of Joan Miro Works Owned by Portugal
abstract: In recent weeks, the planned auction has sparked a public controversy in the country, led by opposition lawmakers and artists who have argued that the Miró collection was now part of Portugal’s cultural heritage.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — On Tuesday, the auction house Christie’s canceled a London sale of a collection of 85 works by the Catalan artist Joan Miró, owned by Portugal.

headline: A Portable Music Player That May Outdo Some Home Systems
abstract: Astell&Kern’s AK240, expected to cost at least $2,000, has the engineering that audio purists love.
lead_paragraph: Who needs a $2,000 iPod?

headline: At Microsoft, a Step Forward as Founders Step Back
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Software']
abstract: Satya Nadella will have to grapple with bad decisions, like the Nokia deal, and is unlikely to pursue a breakup. But the new chief executive can focus on what the company does best, contends Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s founding fathers are finally receding into the middle distance. Satya Nadella’s experience makes him a solid choice to succeed the longtime chief executive, Steven Ballmer. Better still, he will have greater room to maneuver as Bill Gates steps down as chairman. Mr. Nadella will need to grapple with his predecessors’ bad decisions, like the Nokia deal, and he’s unlikely to pursue a breakup. But he can focus on what the company does best.

headline: Team Harry vs. Team Ron
abstract: Fans react to J. K. Rowling’s statement that Hermione Granger should have ended up with Harry Potter, not Ron Weasley.
lead_paragraph: J. K. Rowling’s admission that Hermione Granger should not have ended up with Ron Weasley at the end of the Harry Potter series has sent shock waves through the lives of people heavily invested in the lives of fictional adolescent wizards.

headline: British Insurer Names R.B.S.’s Former Chief as Its C.E.O.
abstract: Stephen Hester, who took the top job at R.B.S. after a government bailout in 2008, replaces Stephen Lee, who resigned as chief of the RSA Group after a profit warning and a £200 million shortfall in the reserves.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British insurer RSA Group said on Tuesday that it had tapped the former chief executive of the Royal Bank of Scotland as its top executive two months after the insurer announced a huge hole in its balance sheet.

headline: Obamacare and the Decline of Work
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: How the health care law could accelerate the downward trend in workforce participation.
lead_paragraph: The headlines for the new Congressional Budget Office report on the health care law emphasize the botched roll-out’s potential impact on enrollment, but this strikes me as quite possibly the bigger deal:

headline: Same Old Stadium, Same Winning Approach for the A’s
abstract: The Oakland Athletics’ quest for a new stadium has been fruitless, but they are still menacing big-money teams with Billy Beane’s innovative approach.
lead_paragraph: Frustration is useless, so the Oakland Athletics insist they do not feel it. This is hard to believe, but maybe it is part of the reason that, as the game keeps evolving, the A’s remain one step ahead.

headline: Westchester Leader Moves Toward a Bid for Governor
abstract: Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, is considered to be a more conventional option than other potential Republican aspirants.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Nine months before Election Day, New York Republicans have inched closer to finding a potential candidate for governor, with word that Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, has formed an exploratory committee.

headline: Don’t Look for de Blasio in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade
abstract: The mayor won’t march, because the parade organizers don’t allow Irish gays and lesbians to march behind gay-pride flags.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio says he won’t be marching in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade because its organizers don’t allow Irish gays and lesbians to march behind banners, signs, flags or other symbols that proclaim gay identity and pride.

headline: Russia Says Syria Will Export Chemicals by March 1
abstract: Russia’s pledge came after international criticism of the Syrian government for missing deadlines in a deal to destroy its arsenal of chemical weapons.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to mollify international officials impatient with Syria for missing deadlines to destroy its chemical weapons, Russia said on Tuesday that the Syrian government planned to send a large shipment out of the country this month and to export its entire stockpile by March 1.

headline: L.A. Dance Project Finds a New Home at Ace Hotel
abstract: The L.A. Dance Project, will perform at the Theater at Ace Hotel, in downtown Los Angeles, starting on Feb. 20.
lead_paragraph: The L.A. Dance Project, started in 2012 by the former New York City Ballet dancer Benjamin Millepied, has a new home. It’s the Theater at Ace Hotel, a 1600-seat space in downtown Los Angeles that occupies the ground floor of a new boutique hotel created in in a 1927 building. The company will have its first performances there on Feb. 20, with Justin Peck’s “Murder Ballads,” a new work by Hiroaki Umeda, and Mr. Millepied’s “Reflections.”

headline: The Seeds of a New Generation
abstract: Midwestern farmers are planting alternatives to corn.
lead_paragraph: John D. Jackson lives in the heart of the Corn Belt, where most of the corn has nothing to do with sweet kernels on the cob. His farm in Southern Illinois typically grows field corn, the high-starch variety that is turned into ethanol and cattle feed. He also works as a logistics manager for Archer Daniels Midland, the agricultural giant that produces the other big artifact of this crop: high fructose corn syrup.

headline: Obama Announces Pledges of $750 Million for Student Technology
abstract: President Obama hailed the promises by business leaders as a way to ensure that all students receive a high-quality education as they prepare to compete in the global economy.
lead_paragraph: ADELPHI, Md. — Business leaders have pledged more than $750 million as part of a White House initiative to strengthen access to technology for 99 percent of students within five years, President Obama announced on Tuesday.

headline: Video: Filming ‘Dallas Buyers Club’
abstract: The director explains his approach involved long shots that breathe.
lead_paragraph: “Dallas Buyers Club” came away empty-handed from the Writers Guild Awards over the weekend, but the film, including its screenplay, is still very much in contention at the Oscars. The Bagger’s colleague Mekado Murphy spoke with the director, Jean-Marc Vallée, about his filmmaking approach, which could be summed up in a phrase: “let the shots breathe.”

headline: Regulator Compares Currency Investigation to Libor Case
abstract: Martin Wheatley, chief executive of the Financial Conduct Authority, said at a parliamentary hearing on Tuesday that he was surprised by the breadth of the investigation into accusations of manipulation of the foreign exchange market.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Expect more bad news from banks about accusations of manipulation in the huge foreign exchange market.

headline: What, Us Worry?
abstract: Americans are optimistic about growing old, compared with citizens in other countries, but perhaps not for the right reasons.
lead_paragraph: Reading the latest Pew Research Center report on global attitudes toward aging made me think of Mad magazine.

headline: The Best Time to Talk to Your Children About the Next National Tragedy? Now
keywords: ['Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Parenting', 'September 11 (2001)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: If you don’t choose how and when to have a tough conversation with your child, life is certain to choose for you.
lead_paragraph: The best time to think about how you’ll tackle difficult subjects with your children is before the need arises.

headline: Paying the Rent on Time Can Enhance Your Credit Report
abstract: A record of rental payments is a good way for young people without credit cards to build a credit history.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a young person just starting out in the working world, you may not have much of a credit history, especially if you don’t have student loans or have never had a credit card.

headline: The Gun Report: February 4, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.

headline: Target Vows to Speed Anti-Fraud Technology
abstract: John Mulligan, Target’s chief executive, testified at a Senate hearing on EMV, a European-based technology that embeds a small chip instead of a magnetic stripe on credit cards.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top executive of Target told a Senate committee on Tuesday that the company was accelerating plans to adopt a technology widely used in Europe but rare in the United States that reduces potential for credit card fraud, and lawmakers from both parties called on other businesses to do the same.

headline: Food Matters | Hot Dog!
abstract: From restaurants to bicycle-pushed carts, purveyors all over Paris are embracing the humble food, elevating it to something original and unexpectedly stylish.
lead_paragraph: From restaurants to bicycle-pushed carts, purveyors all over Paris are embracing the humble hot dog, elevating it to something original and unexpectedly stylish. At both of its 10th Arrondissement locations, Hutch Hotdog House serves all-chicken sausages blanketed with onion jam, homemade pickles and chili sauce. Custom-made franks, flavored mustards and Raclette give “le chien chaud” a gourmet twist at Little Fernand near the Porte Saint-Denis, while the organic all-beef dog entices an otherwise demure crowd at the new cocktail den Glass. Vegetarians can also get in on the action at Le Tricycle, a traveling cart specializing in meat-free dogs named after rappers (the Nate and the Snoop).

headline: Aston Martin Starts Recall Anew After Finding Counterfeit Material in Repair Pedal Assembly
abstract: The automaker found that a Chinese parts supplier used counterfeit material in an accelerator pedal assembly that had already prompted a recall.
lead_paragraph: After discovering that a supplier in China had used counterfeit material, Aston Martin said it would re-do a 5,000-vehicle recall issued because the accelerator pedal assembly could break. The automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration of the do-over in a report posted on the agency’s website.

headline: Activist Investor Takes Aim at Helen of Troy
abstract: Sachem Head Capital Management, a $1 billion activist hedge fund led by a protégé of William A. Ackman, sent a public letter to Helen of Troy’s board on Tuesday, demanding that the consumer company explore strategic alternatives including a sale of some of its assets.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:07 p.m. |

headline: An Unusual Partnership to Tackle Stubborn Diseases
abstract: The National Institutes of Health, 10 drug companies and seven nonprofits will collaborate to speed the development of treatments for Alzheimer’s, Type 2 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.
lead_paragraph: The National Institutes of Health, 10 large drug companies and seven nonprofit organizations announced  an unconventional partnership on Tuesday intended to speed up development of drugs to treat Alzheimer’s disease, Type 2 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

headline: Christie’s Other Congestion Problem
abstract: New Jersey’s transit system wasn’t ready for the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Adding to his troubles over the monster traffic jams that his aides deliberately caused at the George Washington Bridge last year, New Jersey’s Governor Chris Christie is now facing more bad press about gridlock in his state. The problem, as more than 33,000 football fans are still grousing about days later, is that New Jersey’s transit system wasn’t really ready for the Super Bowl on Sunday night.

headline: Senate Passes Long-Stalled Farm Bill, With Clear Winners and Losers
abstract: A long-awaited measure, in a bipartisan vote of 68 to 32, comes with clear winners and losers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No one was happier than Danny Murphy, a Mississippi soybean farmer with 1,500 acres, when the Senate on Tuesday passed a farm bill that expanded crop insurance and other benefits for agribusiness. “It’s a relief,” Mr. Murphy said.

headline: Navy Opens Inquiry Into Cheating in Reactor Training
keywords: ['Cheating', 'Nuclear Energy', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Officials said they are looking into whether senior enlisted sailors training on nuclear reactors have been cheating on written tests, adding to the list of recent military cheating scandals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Navy said Tuesday that it had begun an investigation into whether senior enlisted sailors training on nuclear reactors had been cheating on written tests, adding to the list of recent military cheating scandals.

headline: Familiar Hotel Brands Expand in China
abstract: Travelers are gaining more options as well-known international brands increase the number of their hotels in the country.
lead_paragraph: Chinese travelers are the biggest spenders when it comes to international tourism, according to the United Nations World Tourism Organization, and American hotels are pulling out all the stops to win them over, putting teakettles in the guest rooms, congee rice porridge on the menus and Mandarin speakers on staff.

headline: Hotel Review: W Singapore
abstract: The first W Hotel to open in the city-state, this property offers the chain’s trademark flashiness in the heart of an area of multimillion-dollar homes.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Drama League Fellowship to Support Female Writer-Directors
abstract: The fellowship will award one writer-director with a stipend and a professional reading at the Drama League Theater Center in Tribeca.
lead_paragraph: The Drama League, a New York organization that provides training and financial support to theater artists, is establishing a new fellowship for female writer-directors who are creating original work, league members announced on Monday night at their annual gala. The fellowship is named for Beatrice Terry, an alumna of the organization’s Directors Project who was an assistant or associate director on several Broadway shows including the Tony Award-winning musicals “Spring Awakening” and “Memphis.” Ms. Terry died in 2012 from cancer at the age of 52.

headline: His-and-Hers Jams, a New Cocktail Menu at the Dead Rabbit and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of Feb. 4.
lead_paragraph: To Savor: Macarons Arrive in SoHo, With a Little Company

headline: For Motorola Mobility, Third Place Was Far From Enough
abstract: New data from ComScore, the market research company, makes one thing very clear: In the brutal smartphone market, being No. 3 is not where you want to be.
lead_paragraph: New data from ComScore, the market research company, makes one thing very clear: In the brutal smartphone market, being No. 3 is not something to brag about.

headline: Easy Sheet Pan Chicken
abstract: Melissa Clark makes an entire family meal (crunchy chicken with broccoli rabe and sweet potatoes) on two simple sheet pans.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes an entire family meal (crunchy chicken with broccoli rabe and sweet potatoes) on two simple sheet pans.

headline: Behold, the Sturdy Sheet Pan
abstract: Versatile, affordable and a staple for any home cook.
lead_paragraph: Of all the fancy kitchen equipment in my prodigious collection — the copper gratin dishes, the pressurized siphon, the multifunctional immersion blender — it’s the humble sheet pans I reach for most often.

headline: In Yearlong Clash Over Herbalife, Innuendo Trumps Clarity
abstract: Without clear information on Herbalife’s business model, the speculation in its stock creates extreme volatility as investors trade on rumor.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman, the founder of the hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management, announced his “big short” on Herbalife more than a year ago, and many are still unsure whether he’s right or wrong. You might think that is a problem, but for some of Herbalife’s investors, the truth doesn’t appear to matter much as they have been profiting from the wild swings in the stock price.

headline: Christopher Sieber Joins the Cast of ‘Matilda’
abstract: The Tony-nominated actor will play the evil headmistress Miss Agatha Trunchbull, a role originated by Bertie Carvel on Broadway and in London.
lead_paragraph: The Tony-nominated actor Christopher Sieber will return to Broadway to play the evil headmistress Agatha Trunchbull in “Matilda the Musical,” the show’s producers have announced. Mr. Sieber is to make his debut as the character on March 18.

headline: Annisa
abstract: Anita Lo’s Greenwich Village restaurant earns a third star.
lead_paragraph: Anita Lo’s Greenwich Village restaurant earns a third star.

headline: U.S. Spy Chief Says Assad Has Strengthened His Hold on Power
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: James R. Clapper Jr., the director of national intelligence, also said that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria had benefited from a deal to abandon his chemical weapons arsenal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The country’s top intelligence official said Tuesday that President Bashar al-Assad’s hold on power in Syria had “strengthened” over the past year, and that he had benefited from a deal to abandon his chemical weapons arsenal.

headline: S.&P. Lowers Puerto Rico Debt to Junk Status
abstract: The move intensified a cash squeeze for the commonwealth, whose financial condition is of outsize importance to the rest of the United States because its debt is widely held by individual investors through mutual funds.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | Standard & Poor’s downgraded the debt of Puerto Rico to junk status on Tuesday, intensifying a cash squeeze for the commonwealth, whose financial condition is of outsize importance to the rest of the United States because its debt is widely held by individual investors through mutual funds.

headline: 200 Prompts for Argumentative Writing
abstract: For a coming student contest in which teenagers are invited to write on an issue they care about, we have gathered a list of 200 writing prompts on a wide range of issues.

headline: Developer From Peru Has Eye on Detroit
abstract: Fernando Palazuelo’s acquisition of the Packard site is part of the land rush occurring in Detroit, where investors are scrambling to buy vacant properties at the bottom of a historically distressed market.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It was late Friday afternoon before Labor Day weekend when Fernando Palazuelo reached the head of the line at the tax collection window of the treasurer’s office in Wayne County, Mich.

headline: Bodega Negra Opens a Branch in New York
abstract: A Mexican restaurant with two locations in London arrives; and other restaurant openings.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: How Many Non-Combatants Are Killed by Drones?
abstract: The government won’t release the numbers.
lead_paragraph: Adam Schiff, a Democratic congressman from California, urged the nation’s intelligence leaders today to get behind an important idea: The Obama administration, he said, should publish an annual report on American drone strikes, showing how many combatants and especially how many non-combatants are killed by unmanned aircraft each year.

headline: Michael Kors Is Now a Billionaire
abstract: A strong earnings report by Michael Kors Holdings not only drove up the stock on Tuesday, but also increased Mr. Kors’s net worth by about $34 million.
lead_paragraph: A high-flying stock price has made Michael Kors rich. Just how rich? On Tuesday, the clothing designer became a billionaire.

headline: Hearing Its Own Drummer
abstract: Swords-Smith, in Williamsburg, defies brand-name syndrome.
lead_paragraph: I THINK THE NEWS is out that Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has become overrun by glassy condos and slapped-up “townhomes” harboring gentlemen with archaic facial hair patterns sustained by 10-course tasting menus festooned with twigs. But it was still jarring, and not in an artisanal-jam kind of way, to glimpse Chanel and Prada placards looming in an optician’s window just outside the Bedford Avenue L stop, that culturally freighted crossroads of the new youthquake. So SoHo, so soon.

headline: Listen Up | Singer-Songwriter Jenny Lewis’s Perfect New Single for ‘Girls’
abstract: The solo artist and erstwhile Rilo Kiley frontwoman has contributed a winning new tune to the soundtrack of the HBO show.
lead_paragraph: The love-it-or-hate-it HBO series “Girls,” now in its third season, has had its share of memorable musical moments. The buried ’90s treasure “Steal My Sunshine” by Len made a hilarious comeback during a scene in Chris O’Dowd’s character’s luxury condo and Hannah all but launched the Swedish duo Icona Pop’s career when she let loose to their dance-floor anthem “I Love It.” This season, the “Girls” music team commissioned Jenny Lewis, the L.A.-based singer-songwriter and former frontwoman of the defunct L.A. indie band Rilo Kiley, to write a single, “Completely Not Me” — the crown jewel of the show’s new soundtrack album (which also includes tunes from Father John Misty, Lily Allen, Beck, Cat Power and others), out next week from Atlantic Records.

headline: On the Horizon: Bicentenary of Norway’s Constitution Day; New Languages From the Crowd
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Bicentenary This year marks the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Norwegian Constitution at Eidsvoll, on May 17, 1814. Within Norway, the bicentenary is being celebrated with events throughout the year. In January, Queen Sonja visited the Norwegian Folk Museum to open, “1814-The Game for Denmark and Norway,” an exhibit that details the countries struggles for independence during the “Year of Miracles.” Visitors can also tour Eidsvoll House, which has been restored to look like as it might have when the constitution was signed there. The house opens Feb. 16, and tours run all year.

headline: Rethinking Blogs at The New York Times
abstract: After we moved our article pages to a new framework and platform, we did the same with our blogs. Scott Taylor, senior software engineer on the Blogs team, wrote about it.
lead_paragraph: After we moved our article pages to a new framework and platform, we did the same with our blogs. Scott Taylor, senior software engineer on the Blogs team, wrote about it. Below is an excerpt from a longer post on Scott’s personal blog.

headline: Former Rwandan Intelligence Chief Goes on Trial for 1994 Genocide
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The trial in Paris of Pascal Simbikangwa is seen as an important effort by France to end its protection of Hutu fugitives accused of participating in the genocide against Tutsis.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In an unprecedented step, a French court opened a genocide trial on Tuesday against a former Rwandan intelligence chief in the first of what could be several prosecutions of former officials and others who fled Rwanda after the 1994 slaughter there.

headline: L. Stephen Hill
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Mr. Hill, 50, is a founder and principal of Goldstein, Hill & West Architects, which has focused mainly on residential design.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Hill, 50, is a founder and principal of Goldstein, Hill & West Architects, with Alan Goldstein and David West. The firm, which is based in New York and was founded in 2009, has focused mainly on residential design. The partners have worked on numerous projects, including Silver Towers, One Riverside Park and the Aldyn.

headline: Vignettes From a Much-Lauded Career
abstract: An American Songbook evening celebrated the theater songs of Michael John LaChiusa.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t so long ago that the gifted, indefatigably prolific theater composer Michael John LaChiusa was regarded as a theatrical wunderkind destined to be a future king of Broadway. It hasn’t turned out that way. Mr. LaChiusa, 51, has had his successes but no blockbusters. A major impediment has been his refusal (or inability) to write the kind of snugly packaged pop tunes that are Broadway’s bread and butter. To which I say, more power to him; the form needs composers as talented as Mr. LaChiusa, who have the courage to sacrifice commerciality and go their own way.

headline: The Needles in the Monumental N.S.A. Haystack
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A reporter collects the pieces of the Edward Snowden story into a book about how the world came to learn about the N.S.A.’s reach.
lead_paragraph: The saga of Edward J. Snowden, the man whose leaked documents revealed the Orwellian dimensions of the National Security Agency, reads like a le Carré novel crossed with something by Kafka — at least it does in Luke Harding’s new book, “The Snowden Files.”

headline: Typing Into PDF Forms
abstract: Plus, doing taxes on the iPad, and reporting phishing spam.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why is it possible to type into some PDF forms and not in others? Is there any way to fill out all PDF forms on the computer without having to print them out?

headline: Japan Is a Land of Rising Hopes for Ski Jumping
abstract: Japan’s once-thriving ski jumping program is seeking a revival, and Yuki Ito and Sara Takanashi have a key role as their sport makes its Olympic debut for women.
lead_paragraph: NAYORO, Japan — The sound of cicadas and the smell of pine trees in the thick summer air were interrupted by the whoosh of ski jumpers in bodysuits hurling themselves off the 90-meter hill here in the northern reaches of Japan.

headline: With Technology’s Aid, Banks Squeeze Their Branches Into Smaller Locations
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Science and Technology', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: As fewer customers use banks for routine transactions, back-office spaces have been eliminated and branches have been able to penetrate dense cities.
lead_paragraph: As machines do more, bank branches shrink.

headline: Keeping Her Passport Handy
abstract: The chef Anita Lo crosses culinary borders with ease at Annisa.
lead_paragraph: Anita Lo has been the chef of Annisa since it opened almost 14 years ago, and summing up her style has not gotten any easier. Even she, when naming the cookbook she wrote with Charlotte Druckman, defined her style by what it is not. The title is “Cooking Without Borders.”

headline: A Blend of Folk and Filigree, Raucous and Dreamy
abstract: The Philadelphia Orchestra, in a rescheduled visit to Carnegie Hall, played a program of Bartok, Smetana and Dvorak with Radu Lupu as featured soloist.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Orchestra, led by its music director, Yannick Nézet-Séguin, paid a memorable visit to Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, four months after its scheduled performance at the hall’s opening gala was canceled because of a strike by stagehands. But there were no audible hisses when those stagehands wheeled out the Steinway grand for the program’s piano concerto.

headline: Teaching Just Wasn’t Right for Him, Head of Mexican Drug Cartel Says
abstract: Servando Gómez, the head of Mexico’s feared Knights Templar drug cartel, reflected in an interview on his transition from schoolteacher to organized crime boss.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Wednesday, 2:35 p.m. | In an interview with Britain’s Channel 4 News broadcast last week, Servando Gómez, the head of Mexico’s feared Knights Templar drug cartel, reflected on his transition from schoolteacher to organized crime boss. Teaching, he said, was “an honest job, but for me, with my hyperactive nature and aspirations, it wasn’t satisfying.”

headline: Netflix Signs for a Third Season of ‘House of Cards’
abstract: Even before the second season airs, Netflix has agreed to another 13 shows for the series about a scheming congressman, played by Kevin Spacey.
lead_paragraph: Even before the second season becomes available to viewers, producers of the web-streaming series “House of Cards” have completed a deal with Netflix for a third season of 13 episodes.

headline: Colleagues’ Work Part of Alfred Schnittke’s Anniversary Party
abstract: The concluding concert of this year’s Focus! festival featured the American premiere of a Schnittke symphony, as well as works by Sofia Gubaidulina and Arvo Pärt.
lead_paragraph: Many artists have works they disdain later in their careers, pieces created before their mature voice had emerged. For the 82-year-old Russian composer Sofia Gubaidulina, her “Fairytale Poem” is one such score.

headline: Affordability in Kensington, Brooklyn
abstract: With about 53,000 residents over about 107 square blocks, densely populated Kensington is known for its diversity and affordability.
lead_paragraph: Deirdre Lehn became aware of Kensington’s neighborliness as soon as she attended an open house. “We went to the open houses, and all the neighbors would come by, and folks were chatting with us and inviting us to come by for coffee,” Ms. Lehn said. “These were, like, people we didn’t know.”

headline: MoMA’s Proposal for Sculpture Garden Pleases and Riles
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art’s plan to allow greater access to its sculpture garden is seen as step forward or backward, depending on the perspective.
lead_paragraph: Peace and quiet can be hard to come by in the middle of Manhattan. Maybe, if the ice ever melts, you might balance a lunch burrito on your lap in the sunken plaza outside the McGraw-Hill Building. Or park yourself in a hotel lobby and pretend to be a guest.

headline: Philippine Leader Sounds Alarm on China
abstract: Benigno S. Aquino III, the Philippine president, compared China’s claims to the seas near his country to Hitler’s demands for Czech land in 1938.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Benigno S. Aquino III called on Tuesday for nations around the world to do more to support the Philippines in resisting China’s assertive claims to the seas near his country, drawing a comparison to the West’s failure to support Czechoslovakia against Hitler’s demands for Czech land in 1938.

headline: New Inquiry on Sri Lanka Points to Possible War Crimes
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Experts said an investigation conducted by an Australian nonprofit legal advocacy group could point to criminal culpability by Sri Lanka’s leaders.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Senior Sri Lankan government officials and military officers may bear criminal responsibility for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed during an offensive near the end of the island’s civil war, according to a new investigation that backs calls for an international inquiry into those events.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Luxe Sweatpants
abstract: With trimmer silhouettes and fancy fabrics like double-faced cashmere, the casual pull-on pant is fast becoming a wardrobe staple for the best-dressed set.
lead_paragraph: Chalk it up to an increasingly casual workplace culture, the rise of the urban freelancer or the advent of the couch-to-dinner weekend wardrobe. Whatever the case, the old-school sweatpant, made modern with a slim cut and more refined fabrics, is now being heralded as the “new khaki.” Luxe versions of the stretch-waist pants are showing up on runways and in presentations in both Europe and New York, where the men’s shows continue this week. For his fall/winter 2014 collection, Michael Kors explained that he blended “New York City polish with the laid-back attitude of California,” and that he did away almost entirely with structured waistbands and belt loops. Made with double-faced cashmere or a more office-appropriate glen plaid, the newly refined track pant was the linchpin of Kors’s relaxed, elegant wardrobe. Meanwhile, Ralph Lauren introduced more sportswear styles under its Purple Label than ever before. A luxurious cashmere-knit jogging-style pant paired with a matching crew-neck sweater and trim topcoat stood in stark contrast to the nipped-waist suits that are at the heart of the tailored line, yet looked no less natty. And at Bottega Veneta, Tomas Maier paired belted coats, lightly tailored jackets and suede bombers with numerous iterations of the pull-on pant, from corduroy to cashmere, to signify his belief in this new trouser alternative.

headline: More Space for the Living and the Dead
abstract: “Roman Catacomb Mystery” and “Super Skyscrapers” on PBS stations explore how humans have looked below ground and far above for more space.
lead_paragraph: A serendipitous juxtaposition of programming on PBS on Wednesday night reminds us just how long humans have been trying to squeeze more space out of urban environments. The ancient Romans knew something we apparently don’t: If you build downward for people who don’t much care about the view rather than upward for billionaires who do, you don’t have to worry about how to wash the windows.

headline: A Dancer’s Rare Grace Survives a Horrible Fate
abstract: The documentary “Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq” traces the life of a great ballerina who was paralyzed by polio at the height of her career.
lead_paragraph: As you watch grainy kinescope footage of dancers in a mirrored studio executing a pas de deux in the documentary biography “Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq,” it is almost as though you are beholding mythological deities who have alighted briefly on the earth. Here today, gone tomorrow, they are like rare birds, seldom glimpsed, who remind us of the evanescence of all things, most of all physical beauty and the casual grace of youth. Therein lies a primal attraction of ballet: its evocation of the ecstatic moment is as fleeting as it is haunting.

headline: Health Law Goals Face Antitrust Hurdles
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: A judge in Idaho ruled against a hospital deal, saying that patient costs would have risen, but that outcomes would have been improved.
lead_paragraph: With the midterm elections fast coming into focus, politics in Washington will remain consumed by health care for months to come.

headline: Jay and Dave, With Jerry in the Middle
abstract: The comic Jerry Seinfeld is a friend to both Jay Leno and David Letterman and has had them both on his web series, "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee"
lead_paragraph: The comic Jerry Seinfeld is a friend to both Jay Leno and David Letterman and has had them both on his web series, "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee"

headline: AT&T Becomes First Major Advertiser to Protest Russia’s Antigay Law
abstract: The company says it stands against a measure outlawing “homosexual propaganda” that has led to protests aimed at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: AT&T has become the first major advertiser to come out against a measure outlawing “homosexual propaganda” that has led to protests aimed at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, as well as the first to urge “others involved with the Olympic Games” to do the same.

headline: Circadian Clocks May Be Tuned to Vibrations, Too
abstract: New research in flies suggest that the part of the brain that regulates sleep and wakefulness may be affected by vibrations, in addition to light.
lead_paragraph: In nature, the rising and setting of the sun help set an animal’s circadian clock, a part of the brain that regulates sleep and wakefulness. Fluctuations of light tell the body when to release melatonin, for example, or lower body temperature.

headline: N.E.A. Funds Benefit Both Rich and Poor, Study Finds
abstract: A new study challenges Congressional assertions that grants by the National Endowment for the Arts support programming attended mostly by the rich.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the late 1980s, when the performance artist Karen Finley started playing around with yams and chocolate, the National Endowment for the Arts has come under fire from some conservative lawmakers. Back then the agency was castigated for giving grants to provocative artists like Ms. Finley, whom some critics called obscene.

headline: On Silver Screen, a Bit of Gold
abstract: The Olympic film genre is lightly populated and the quality falls off quickly, but here are 10 that are definitely worth watching.
lead_paragraph: As the Sochi Olympics will remind the world again, there is a huge amount of human drama in the skiing, skating and snowboarding that seize the world’s attention every four years.

headline: De Blasio to Skip St. Patrick’s Day Parade; Cites Exclusion of Gay Groups
abstract: Bill de Blasio will be New York’s first mayor in two decades not to take part in the world-famous procession down Fifth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Tuesday that he would not march in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade in Manhattan next month, citing the event’s longstanding tensions with gay and lesbian groups.

headline: Times Minute | Army Recruitment Scam
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Also on the Minute, a territorial dispute in the South China Sea and the effect of the Affordable Care Act on the full-time work force.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Army Recruitment Scam
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'International Relations']
abstract: Also on the Minute, a territorial dispute in the South China Sea and the effect of the Affordable Care Act on the full-time work force.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, a territorial dispute in the South China Sea and the effect of the Affordable Care Act on the full-time work force.

headline: The Ballad of Leno and Letterman, Told by Seinfeld
abstract: As Jay Leno prepares to leave the “Tonight” show and David Letterman stays put, Jerry Seinfeld, a friend to both, looks at what they have in common.
lead_paragraph: The link between the careers of Jay Leno and David Letterman is long and deep, and their personal relationship has often been fractious, sometimes warm, certainly competitive.

headline: Morgan Stanley Reaches $1.25 Billion Mortgage Settlement
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Morgan Stanley settlement is the latest agreement between a Wall Street firm and the Federal Housing Finance Agency, which has sued several banks and financial institutions seeking relief over losses that were borne by taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley has agreed to pay $1.25 billion to the Federal Housing Finance Agency to resolve claims that it sold shoddy mortgage securities to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

headline: U.N. Report Details Abuse of Children in Syrian War
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Torture', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The document, quietly presented to the Security Council last week, details torture, abduction and grave abuse of children by both sides in the conflict.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — United Nations investigators say in a new report that children in Syria have been sexually abused in government detention, recruited to fight with the opposition, tortured and used as civilian shields.

headline: President of BAM Will Leave Next Year
abstract: Karen Brooks Hopkins will step down as president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music in June of next year, after more than 15 years in the job.
lead_paragraph: When Karen Brooks Hopkins first arrived at the Brooklyn Academy of Music more than three decades ago, it was considered a pioneering outpost for avant-garde theater, music and dance. Housed in a single Beaux-Arts building in what was then a gritty neighborhood, it struggled to attract theatergoers, some of whom would tell Ms. Hopkins they were more likely to travel to London than to Brooklyn to see a play.

headline: Polls Find Security Is Americans’ Top Olympic Concern
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: While critical of the decision to hold the Winter Games in Russia, a majority of Americans say they plan to watch the events.
lead_paragraph: Just ahead of the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics on Friday, a plurality of Americans say it was a bad decision to hold the Games in Russia, with security concerns the top reason, a new Pew Research Center poll found.

headline: Tanaquil Le Clercq as Muse: Onstage, in Photographs and in a New Film
abstract: “Tanny” Le Clercq, one of George Balanchine’s muses and wives, who never danced again after contracting polio, is the subject of a new documentary.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, the magazine published a photo essay about Mildred and Richard Loving, the couple whose case led to the Supreme Court’s striking down miscegenation laws in 1967. The pictures appeared at the same time as an HBO documentary about the Lovings directed by Nancy Buirski. Now Buirski’s next documentary, “Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq,” is coming out. It opens tomorrow at the Film Society of Lincoln Center; later this month the Berlin International Film Festival will screen it as an Official Selection.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Central African Republic, Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Central African Republic, Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: America’s Team? Yankees May Be Japan’s Team Instead
abstract: With the revered Japanese players Hiroki Kuroda, Ichiro Suzuki and now Masahiro Tanaka on their team, the Yankees are bracing for unprecedented news media attention from their home country.
lead_paragraph: There was a pitcher in Japan in the 1950s and ’60s named Kazuhisa Inao who was so good that the popular saying at the time was God, Buddha, Inao, in deference to the pitcher’s almost otherworldly talent.

headline: With New App, Photos Become a Travel Guide
abstract: Jetpac City Guides, a new application for iPhones, uses Instagram photos as the basis for its travel rankings in a variety of categories.
lead_paragraph: Applying snap judgments to snapshots, the new Jetpac City Guides for iPhones analyzes Instagram photos for commonalities to come up with top-10 lists of things like bars women love and coffee shops with popular latte art in 6,000 cities worldwide.

headline: With New Chief, Microsoft’s New Mantra Is ‘Innovation,’ Over and Over
abstract: In a number of press announcements, emails and videos, Microsoft executives promised lots of “innovation” from the appointment of Satya Nadella, the company’s new chief executive.

headline: Just Say No
keywords: ['Farm Bill (US)', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Vetoes (US)', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Law and Legislation', 'Food Stamps']
abstract: Unlike the farm bill, Keystone XL is not already seen as an inevitable compromise: here, the president has real power.
lead_paragraph: President Obama indicated in his State of the Union address last week that he will exercise his admittedly limited executive powers in this “year of action.” Though most of the mild proposals he made are welcome, one still wonders why he doesn’t say “no” more often. Two examples where this would be useful are the farm bill and the proposed extension of the Keystone XL pipeline, both of which will reach his office for decisions soon — the farm bill, perhaps, as you read this. (The Senate passed the bill Tuesday afternoon, so its next stop is Obama’s desk.)

headline: WellPoint, a Onetime Critic of Health Law, May Yet Profit
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']

headline: Tennessee Governor Urges 2 Free Years of Community College and Technical School
abstract: Tennessee would be the only state in the country to charge no tuition or fees to incoming students under the proposal by Gov. Bill Haslam, a Republican.
lead_paragraph: Public colleges have sharply raised their prices since the 1990s in the face of declining state support, but a plan by Tennessee’s governor to make two years of community college and technical school free for all students represents a striking reversal of that trend.

headline: The Third Intifada
abstract: The weapons of this uprising in the Middle East are nonviolent.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — For a while now I’ve wondered why there’s been no Third Intifada. That is, no third Palestinian uprising in the West Bank, the first of which helped to spur the Oslo peace process and the second of which — with more live ammunition from the Israeli side and suicide bombings from the Palestinian side — led to the breakdown of Oslo. You get many explanations from Palestinians: they’re too poor, too divided, too tired or that they realize these uprisings, in the end, did them more harm than good, especially the second. But being here, it’s obvious that a Third Intifada is underway. It’s the one that Israel always feared most — not an intifada with stones or suicide bombers, but one propelled by nonviolent resistance and economic boycott.

headline: Saving Ukraine
abstract: The United States and Europe need to move quickly on a financial package to tie the country more closely to the West.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Europe may finally be ready to put some real emergency aid on the table as part of an effort to resolve the political crisis in Ukraine and to tie the country more closely to the West. Without such an offer of financial support, Russia will continue to have leverage to bully Ukraine into its geopolitical orbit. The standoff over economic policy and whether Ukraine will ally with Europe or Russia is more than two months old and has led to violent protests in which at least six people were killed.

headline: Lawyers in Terrorism Case Seek Access to 9/11 Suspect

headline: Overselling Testosterone, Dangerously
abstract: A recent study shows the risk of cardiovascular disease in men who use testosterone for a variety of ailments.
lead_paragraph: A large study has found substantial risks in prescribing testosterone to middle-age and older men for a variety of ailments. One part of the study found that testosterone doubled the risk of cardiovascular disease in more than 7,000 men who were 65 years old or older, essentially confirming findings in previous studies. The other part found that testosterone almost tripled the risk of heart attacks in a group of more than 48,000 middle-age men with previous histories of heart disease. The harm in both cases occurred within 90 days of receiving the prescription.

headline: Title for the Seahawks Is a Triumph for the Profile of Yoga
abstract: After the Super Bowl, the yoga community did the Internet equivalent of back flips when Seattle won.
lead_paragraph: The Seahawks’ Super Bowl victory sent happy repercussions through the expected constituencies — namely, Seahawks fans, the anti-Manning crowd, proponents of the color green — but it also lit up a community not usually excited about football: yogis.

headline: Freeing Workers From the Insurance Trap
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Editorials']
abstract: A new report found that by reducing the number of full-time workers over a decade, the health care law will have a liberating impact for millions.
lead_paragraph: The Congressional Budget Office estimated on Tuesday that the Affordable Care Act will reduce the number of full-time workers by 2.5 million over the next decade. That is mostly a good thing, a liberating result of the law. Of course, Republicans immediately tried to brand the findings as “devastating” and stark evidence of President Obama’s health care reform as a failure and a job killer. It is no such thing.

headline: On the Luge, Safety Built Into Swerves

lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — On the day that the Winter Olympics opened in Vancouver, British Columbia, four years ago, a luger named Nodar Kumaritashvili was killed on a training run. Traveling almost 90 miles per hour at Whistler Sliding Centre, Kumaritashvili, a 21-year-old from the Republic of Georgia, lost control of his sled near the bottom of the course and was thrown from the track. He died after striking a pole.

headline: Don’t Know These Olympic Athletes? You Will
abstract: Although the Olympics sometimes crown established stars, they are just as often a coming-out party for athletes who emerge as national heroes with unexpected performances.
lead_paragraph: Although the Olympics sometimes crown established stars, they are just as often a coming-out party for athletes who emerge as national heroes with unexpected performances. And the title of breakthrough star of the Games is often judged through a nationalistic lens. In 2002, Americans were thrilled by Sarah Hughes’s unexpected figure skating gold medal; Croatians were stunned by Janica Kostelic’s three Alpine golds; and China celebrated its first Winter Games gold, by the short-track speedskater Yang Yang. Here are some of the candidates to emerge as the darlings of their nations in Sochi, Russia.

headline: California: Officers Faulted in Mistaken Shooting
abstract: Eight Los Angeles police officers violated Police Department policy when they fired on two unarmed women in a pickup truck during the hunt for a former Los Angeles police officer.
lead_paragraph: Eight Los Angeles police officers violated Police Department policy when they fired on two unarmed women in a pickup truck last February during the hunt for Christopher Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer accused of killing four people, a civilian oversight board said Tuesday. Police Chief Charlie Beck will determine how to discipline the eight, who have been removed from field duty since the episode. Chief Beck said actions could range “from extensive retraining to termination.” The women were delivering newspapers when officers mistook their truck for Mr. Dorner’s vehicle, and fired more than 100 rounds. Last year the city agreed to pay them $4.2 million. Chief Beck said that although he sympathized with the officers, he could not excuse their decision to open fire. “This was a tragic cascade of circumstance that led to an inaccurate conclusion by the officers,” he said.

headline: A Pianist With a Goal Taps Mozart and Chopin
abstract: Lang Lang’s aim in Tuesday’s program was clear: to play three Mozart sonatas to show that they plausibly anticipated Chopin’s four Ballades.
lead_paragraph: When last we saw the star pianist Lang Lang, it was at the Grammy Awards on Jan. 26, jamming with Metallica on its power ballad “One,” to loud and muddled effect. In the first half of Mr. Lang’s recital at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, Mozart was about as awkward a match for this pianist’s considerable talents as metal had been.

headline: Whose Turkey Is It?
abstract: The struggle for the future between a megalomaniacal prime minister, a cultish leader in the Poconos and thousands of citizens taking to the streets.
lead_paragraph: It is still a marvel to behold Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s self-confidence, even after 11 years of his rule. In recent weeks, a new poster featuring Turkey’s prime minister has appeared throughout Istanbul, on highway billboards and mass transit. Wearing his usual dark suit, Erdogan looks to be in purposeful motion, like an action hero. Two large words in block letters, SAGLAM IRADE, Turkish for “Iron Will,” accompany him. Surely some of his supporters appreciate this evocation of 1930s-era masculinity, but for others, it must feel like an invasion of personal space. The enormous billboards intensify the claustrophobia that many Turks have felt for years: that Erdogan is everywhere, in every tree or open space sacrificed for a building, in every traffic jam, in every newspaper column and pro-government tweet and call to prayer. The poster, which a group of his supporters claims to have put up, begs to be defaced, and Turks have torn at it or covered it with new slogans: “Iron Fascist,” “Iron Corruption,” “Iron Enemy of the People.”

headline: Add a Little Turf to the Surf
abstract: Meat gives an extra shot of flavor to fish stew.
lead_paragraph: I don’t subscribe to the belief that everything is better with bacon, but small amounts of meat do often improve many dishes — even those with fish. While there are plenty of classic fish stews that don’t use meat for flavoring, including bouillabaisse, there are also many that do. (Clam chowder, anyone?) Think about it: When you’re making stew, everything is fair game.

headline: It Takes a Village to Protect a Rhino
abstract: As Kenya makes efforts to save its critically endangered wildlife, like the white rhino, of which only eight remain, communities are learning the benefits of fighting poaching.
lead_paragraph: Ami Vitale is a photographer and filmmaker who has worked in more than 85 countries. She is a contract photographer for National Geographic and works with the Photo Society and Ripple Effect Images, and is represented by Panos Pictures. She is currently crowdfunding to complete a photography and multiplatform media project in northern Kenya, begun with the Nature Conservancy, on how local communities are protecting their wildlife from poaching. Her interview with James Estrin has been edited.

headline: What I Took Home From My Business in 2013
keywords: ['Bonuses', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Small Business', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: At the beginning of last year, I could see that my staff was now capable of doing the heavy lifting of selling. And that left me with a decision: What should I be doing instead?
lead_paragraph: Pick any workday, and most weekends, between 1986 and the middle of 2013, and you probably could have found me at my desk, doing the work of trying to sign up new customers. That effort ate six or more hours of every day, with the rest devoted to all of the other tasks involved in running a small business. So it was quite a change for me last year, when I finally handed all sales duties off to Don, Nate and Mary.

lead_paragraph: IN INTRODUCTION TO CREATIVE STUDIES at Buffalo State College, Cyndi Burnett tells her class to walk around campus for an hour and write down 100 things that bother them, then come up with ways to overcome the annoyances. “They are using divergent thinking, so the ideas could be outlandish,” she says. “The main goal is to have them begin to think about their problems as opportunities.” Here are edited excerpts from their log entries, and some of the big ideas students developed later in the class.

Standing before his Buffalo State College classmates and professor, Cyndi Burnett, Mr. Lahue displayed a device he concocted from a large washer, metal ring, wall hook, rubber bands and Lincoln Log. Slide the ring in the crack and twist. The door stays shut. Plus, the device fits in a jacket pocket.

headline: The Find | Studio Services
abstract: After achieving success on the West Coast, the furniture designer Charlie Ferrer has opened a meticulously curated Manhattan showroom that also doubles as his one-bedroom apartment.
lead_paragraph: After achieving success on the West Coast as one half of the furniture design duo Meier/Ferrer, Charlie Ferrer has branched out on his own and opened a meticulously curated Manhattan showroom that also doubles as his one-bedroom apartment. The 32-year-old has pooled pieces by a number of behind-the-scenes talents, like the sought-after industrial designer Billy Cotton and the lighting expert Kacper Dolatowski, both of whose work had only been available to decorators seeking custom commissions. The handmade designs Ferrer displays, in a range of materials from brass to oak to plaster, feel classic yet current. “I don’t like to call it a showroom, which feels static,” Ferrer says. “It’s really more of a studio, an active place where artists refine, resolve and share their ideas.”

lead_paragraph: The Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, Germany, led by Riccardo Chailly, will play Bruckner’s Symphony No. 7, which the orchestra gave its premiere in 1884. headline: Love for the Littlest

These four are more obviously intended — and appropriate — for children: Though all take a different approach, family and friendship are at their hearts.

headline: French Cultural Services to Present Visual Arts Festival in New York
abstract: The monthlong festival will have an academic tilt, with exhibitions, panels, lectures and workshops to explore the issues that animate the art world.
lead_paragraph: The cultural services of the French Embassy and the French American Cultural Exchange, in a partnership with 46 museums, galleries and universities, mostly in New York City, are presenting ART², a monthlong visual arts festival. The events have an academic tilt: museum curators, administrators, critics and artists will present exhibitions, panels, lectures and workshops meant to explore some of the practical and philosophical issues that animate the art world.

headline: Training to Bobsled
abstract: Chris Fogt is a U.S. Olympic Team bobsledder. He demonstrates some of the exercises in his workout, which is designed to improve the skills his sport requires.
lead_paragraph: Chris Fogt is a U.S. Olympic Team bobsledder. He demonstrates some of the exercises in his workout, which is designed to improve the skills his sport requires.

headline: New York’s Top Financial Regulator Investigates Currency Trading
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Currency']
abstract: The inquiry by the state’s Department of Financial Services into potential manipulation of the market comes in the face of departures and firings of foreign currency traders at major banks.
lead_paragraph: The business of trading currencies is in a state of flux as top executives leave and traders are suspended or fired in the face of investigations into potential manipulation of the $5 trillion-a-day foreign exchange market.

headline: The Workout: Training to Bobsled
abstract: Olympic bobsledders have to be fast, lean and powerful. We talked to Army Capt. Chris Fogt, a member of Team USA’s four-man bobsled team about what it takes to achieve a bobsledder’s body.
lead_paragraph: Being an Olympic bobsledder is a job that requires a precise balance of speed, muscle and weight. The athletes must explode off the starting line while pushing nearly 500 pounds of bobsled at full speed. They need to be strong enough for a powerful launch so the sled will reach speeds exceeding 90 miles an hour. But the athletes also need to be lean in order to lighten the load and wind resistance as they hunker down in the sled.

headline: Maintaining Ethics in the Move From Regulator to Regulated
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Life is fraught for financial watchdogs who switch to the private sector, especially if they try to have standards, writes Jesse Eisinger in The Trade column.
lead_paragraph: Sheila Bair took a banking job last week — an occasion for breaking out the axes and giving them a good grinding.

headline: New York Philharmonic’s Archives Going Online
keywords: ['Classical Music', 'Archives and Records', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Music']
abstract: The founding documents of the New York Philharmonic — back to its inaugural 1842-43 season — are now available online.
lead_paragraph: Just a year after the members of the brand-new New York Philharmonic adopted their first constitution in 1842 — players were to be paid $25 a season for three concerts, to rehearse every other Saturday and to be fined $5 for missed concerts — they passed some new bylaws.

headline: A Weekend in Hungary, Chosen at Random
abstract: The Frugal Traveler decided to spend a couple of days in a small Hungarian town just to see what would happen. So what did? Plenty, it turns out.
lead_paragraph: Was I ferfi or noi?

headline: Once Again Navigating an Icy, Snowy New York
abstract: How was your commute on this slushy morning? City Room wants to know.
lead_paragraph: It snowed again.

headline: Roy Choi’s Taste of South Korea
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Korean Food (Cuisine)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Cakes', 'Restaurants', 'Food Trucks']
abstract: The chef, who grew up in Los Angeles after immigrating from Seoul as a child, talks about eating his way through South Korea’s street stalls, bread stands and food markets.
lead_paragraph: Roy Choi grew up navigating the back streets and alleyways of a dozen Los Angeles neighborhoods. After immigrating from Seoul with his parents at age 2, his childhood was spent exploring South Central, Crenshaw and West Hollywood with a house key tied around his neck, while his parents tried to establish a business.

headline: Woodrow Wilson’s Family Home Reopens in South Carolina
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Museums', 'Travel and Vacations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Woodrow Wilson Family Home in Columbia, S.C., has reopened after eight years of renovation.
lead_paragraph: The Woodrow Wilson Family Home in Columbia, S.C., reopens on Feb. 15 after eight years of research and restoration. South Carolina’s only presidential site and the only home owned by the parents of the 28th president of the United States features artifacts, period vignettes and multimedia exhibits exploring the Wilson family’s life within the context of the Reconstruction era.

headline: Times Minute | Google's Antitrust Deal
abstract: Also on the Minute, Shaun White focuses on the halfpipe and a visit to Germany where to a former N.S.A surveillance hub is now a haven for graffiti artists.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, Shaun White focuses on the halfpipe and a visit to Germany where to a former N.S.A surveillance hub is now a haven for graffiti artists.

headline: Liberals, Obamacare and Work
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Parenting', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Unemployment']
abstract: What’s missing from the optimistic gloss on the new Obamacare workforce projections.
lead_paragraph: So far, nearly all of the left-of-center responses to the latest C.B.O. projections on Obamacare and workforce participation have emphasized the upside of the downward trend — the fact that what we’re seeing is just the end of job lock in action, which gives parents the freedom to cut their hours, near-retirees the chance to stop working a job they hate a little early, and so on down a sympathetic list.  “If Obamacare really does cause millions of people to voluntarily leave full-time employment,” Matt Yglesias writes in a representative piece, “that shows us how much avoidable suffering the earlier system was causing,” and you can find roughly similar arguments from Jonathan Cohn, Jonathan Chait, and others too numerous to name.

headline: Homes for $450,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a colonial in Maine, a midcentury modern in Austin and a Craftsman in Nashville.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a colonial in Maine, a midcentury modern in Austin and a Craftsman in Nashville.

keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Fuel Efficiency']

lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Freshly Spruced Up, Historic Tavern on the Green Is Set to Reopen
abstract: The historic structure, originally home to Central Park’s flock of sheep and later one of New York City’s most famous restaurants, has had sweeping renovations since it shut down in 2010.
lead_paragraph: If Central Park is quiet enough, and you listen closely enough, you can almost hear Tavern on the Green exhale in relief.

headline: As Minimum Wages Rise, Businesses Grapple With Consequences
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'States (US)']
abstract: Some owners who already made trims in the last economic downturn face difficult decisions to comply with the law.
lead_paragraph: Dolores Riley has many questions and few answers. Along with every other employer in New Jersey, she woke up on New Year’s Day to a new minimum wage — $8.25 an hour, up from $7.25. Even before the increase, Ms. Riley, who owns Gramma’s School House Childcare and Learning Center in Cinnaminson, had been operating on the razor’s edge.

headline: A Domino Theory for Marriage
abstract: The Pulitzer Prize-winning drama “Dinner With Friends” is being given a revival by the Roundabout Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: Matchmaking is a dicey endeavor, and not simply because of potential guilt or awkwardness if the pairing doesn’t take. Donald Margulies explored more complex ramifications in his Pulitzer Prize-winning drama “Dinner With Friends,” which is being given a revival by the Roundabout Theater Company. In the play, one couple long ago helped two friends get together and the four were inseparable for years. But one marriage eventually shatters, and Mr. Margulies, instead of focusing on what went wrong, steers our attention to some collateral damage: the surviving couple’s contentment begins to fray in the aftermath.

headline: The Beatles in the U.S., 50 Years On
abstract: I can still remember the first time I heard “Love Me Do.”
lead_paragraph: I can still remember the first time I heard a Beatles song. It was the fall of 1964, my second year in an American school after my family moved back from overseas, and I was standing on the corner of 64th street and First Avenue with my friend Larry Campbell. I had a brand new, red, plastic transistor radio, and he tuned it to WABC AM and “Love Me Do” came on the air. The soundtrack of my life changed at that moment, with The Beatles becoming the recurring and dominant theme.
