headline: Giving Up the Ultimate Bachelor Pad
abstract: Brad Chatellier and Talitha Fehr wanted a rental with a little bit more room.
lead_paragraph: Before he moved to New York two years ago, Brad Chatellier had been living out of a suitcase. For months, he had traveled the world and pursued wildlife photography.

headline: Todd Lodwick to Carry U.S. Flag at Opening Ceremony in Sochi
abstract: Todd Lodwick, 37, a skier competing in his sixth Olympics, was named on Wednesday as the flag-bearer of the United States for Friday’s opening ceremony of the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Todd Lodwick, who will be competing in his sixth Olympics, was named the United States’ flag-bearer for Friday’s opening ceremony at the Sochi Olympics.

headline: Architect Named to Transform Courtyard at MoMA PS1
abstract: David Benjamin’s firm, The Living, was selected as the winner of the 15th annual Young Architects Program, and will create a temporary installation for the museum’s courtyard this summer.
lead_paragraph: Every summer, an emerging architect gets the chance to transform the outdoor courtyard at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City and, in the process, gets put on the map as a talent worthy of attention.

headline: Can This Business Survive a Hike in the Minimum Wage?
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Small Business', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The owner has already laid off employees and raised prices. Another price increase, she says, will cause many of her clients to withdraw their children from her child-care center.
lead_paragraph: As discussed in an article we have just published, Dolores Riley, along with every other employer in New Jersey, woke up on New Year’s Day to a new minimum wage: $8.25 an hour, up from $7.25.

headline: LEDs Change Thinking About the Light Bulb
abstract: Able to be programmed and to change spectrum, LEDs are being seen as devices to change moods, help people sleep or stay awake, and help plants grow.
lead_paragraph: Lights are no longer just for lighting.

headline: Times May Publish Response From Woody Allen on Dylan Farrow’s Accusations
abstract: Editorial page editor says The Times is bending its rules for an unusual situation.
lead_paragraph: Woody Allen has asked for, and may get, a chance to respond — in an Op-Ed piece in The Times — to a recent column and blog by Nicholas Kristof in which the filmmaker’s adopted daughter detailed her memories of his sexually abusing her.

headline: Subway Strike Hobbles London, Underground and Above
abstract: The 48-hour strike was called by unions to protest planned job cuts as part of a restructuring.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A strike on the London Underground crippled much of the city’s transportation network on Wednesday, disrupting the plans of millions of travelers and forcing commuters to cram into overcrowded buses and trains or walk or cycle to work.

headline: Russia Blocks Yogurt Bound for U.S. Athletes
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Yogurt', 'Dairy Products', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The Russian government has kept from the United States Olympic team a shipment of Chobani yogurt, a booming business in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between the United States and Russia is deeply strained, with recent disagreements over weighty matters like the Syrian conflict, arms control, human rights and the granting of asylum to Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who has leaked troves of documents detailing the government’s eavesdropping programs.

headline: Gallery | The Stars of New York’s Old Downtown Scene, Like You’ve Never Seen Them Before
abstract: A new limited-edition book of Polaroids by the photographer, stylist and designer Maripol captures figures like Madonna, Grace Jones, Vincent Gallo and Naomi Campbell in intimate poses.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, the French-born, New York-based photographer, stylist and designer Maripol shared a secret box with her assistant, Adèle Jancovici. It was full of intimate Polaroids she’d taken in the ’70s and ’80s of herself, lovers and friends. “Don’t tell anyone,” she said. But when Jancovici founded Le Livre Art Publishing in 2011, she knew she wanted to make those photos the subject of the company’s first release. “I’m not good at keeping secrets,” she admits. “Maripola X,” a collection of approximately 171 Polaroids, 69 of her poems and a bonus CD with two of her songs, will be released in a limited edition of 600 signed and numbered copies on Feb. 7 with a signing at Bookmarc.

headline: And Now For Some Good News
keywords: ['Education (Pre-School)', 'Head Start Program', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Brooks and Collins talk about what the White House is doing right.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, I thought we’d go rogue today and talk about things we think President Obama is doing well. Unless, of course, you have a more pressing topic.

headline: App Smart: Finding Love
abstract: As Valentine’s Day approaches, smartphone apps can play a part in finding love, celebrating love and sharing things love-connected.
lead_paragraph: As Valentine’s Day approaches, smartphone apps can play a part in finding love, celebrating love and sharing things love-connected.

headline: Sweet Ways to Romance Your Valentine
abstract: Smartphone apps can play a part in finding love, celebrating love and sharing things connected to love.
lead_paragraph: Valentine’s Day is near and love is in the air. This ancient love fest goes back centuries, but it has gone high tech in recent years. In 2014, this means your smartphone apps can play a part in finding love, celebrating love and sharing things love-connected.

headline: A.I.G. Seeks to Delay Bank of America Mortgage Settlement
abstract: The American International Group gained a minor victory on Tuesday when a New York judge scheduled a new hearing on the $8.5 billion settlement.
lead_paragraph: The American International Group is continuing its quest to upend an $8.5 billion settlement between Bank of America and a group of mortgage securities investors.

headline: Billie Jean King Won’t Join U.S. Olympic Delegation
abstract: King’s expected attendance at the Sochi Games was seen as a rebuke of Russia’s ban on so-called gay propaganda. She cited her mother’s failing health for the decision not to go.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Billie Jean King is no longer scheduled to join the presidential delegation to the Olympics in Sochi, Russia, the White House announced Wednesday. King cited the failing health of her mother, Betty Moffitt, who is 91 and lives in Arizona, in her decision to stay behind.

headline: Zell Backs Tom Perkins’s Arguments About Class Warfare
abstract: Tom Perkins may have apologized for comparing attacks on the wealthy in the United States to Kristallnacht. But his core argument about class warfare found a supporter in Samuel Zell, the real estate tycoon.
lead_paragraph: The Silicon Valley venture capitalist Tom Perkins drew no small amount of criticism for drawing parallels between attacks on San Francisco’s wealthy class and Kristallnacht, a comparison for which he has since sort of apologized.

headline: An Invisible Message from Jane Austen?
abstract: Scholars are studying an elusive artifact — nearly invisible traces of Austen’s handwriting on the back of a scrap of paper discovered inside a copy of a book written by Austen’s nephew.
lead_paragraph: Objects associated with Jane Austen tend to draw intense scrutiny, whether it’s the turquoise ring bought at auction by the singer Kelly Clarkson or the proto-paper clips used to attach the manuscript pages of her abandoned novel “The Watsons.”

headline: Commuters Share Woes of Transport Chaos in London
abstract: The daily travels of millions of people were disrupted when parts of the subway network were shut down.
lead_paragraph: Commuters documented the chaos of getting to work on Wednesday, the first day of a strike on the London Underground that disrupted service for millions of people.

headline: Inviting a Picky Eater Into the Kitchen Pays Off
abstract: After four weeks of working with two experts to improve the eating habits of their twin 4-year-old boys, a couple’s new dinnertime routine was being met with little resistance.
lead_paragraph: So far, changing this family’s picky eating habits has been easier than expected.

headline: ‘Philomena’s’ Audience With the Pope
abstract: The real-life subject of “Philomena,” along with the film’s co-star, makes a stop in Vatican City.
lead_paragraph: The story of Philomena Lee — which began in the 1950s when she was a teenager forced by nuns to give up her child for adoption and includes an Academy Award-nominated film, “Philomena,” based on her search for her son decades later — can now add one more chapter.

headline: Classical Playlist: Andrew Parrott, Jeroen Van Veen, Ildar Abdrazakov and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: MONTEVERDI: ‘L’Orfeo’Taverner Consort and Players; directed by Andrew Parrott(Avie; 2 CDs)There are many fine recordings of Monteverdi’s landmark “L’Orfeo,” the first great opera, composed in 1607. A superb new recording features the distinguished conductor Andrew Parrott, directing the impressive singers and period-instrument performers of the Taverner Consort & Players. This account is exceptional for its fluidity, elegance and tenderness. The cast is headed by the poignant tenor Charles Daniels in the title role. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: What Made Me | Rachel Comey
abstract: The fashion designer talks about the cool teenagers she observed growing up, her early days in New York City and a very special gift her grandmother gave her over the course of many years.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer talks about the cool teenagers she observed growing up, her early days in New York City and a very special gift her grandmother gave her over the course of many years.

headline: Pussy Riot Members Take Tour to New York
abstract: Two women from the Russian punk group said they had no fear of prison and suggested they may even run for political office in Russia someday.
lead_paragraph: Two young women from the Russian punk group Pussy Riot said Wednesday that their 21-month incarceration in Russia’s penal system for having staged a political protest in a Moscow cathedral had emboldened them to speak out more forcefully against President Vladimir V. Putin, partly because of the global support they received.

headline: Elton John Plans Animated Film of ‘Technicolor Dreamcoat’
abstract: The singer’s production company has acquired rights to the Broadway musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Elton John on Wednesday said that his movie production company had acquired the film rights to “Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat” and planned to make a feature-length animated musical.

headline: Iraqi Tribes to Take Lead in Falluja Fight, U.S. Says
abstract: Brett McGurk, a top State Department official, provided new details about the Iraqi government’s effort to regain control of a key Sunni city now occupied by jihadists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Iraqi Army is planning to cordon off a key Sunni city now occupied by jihadists so that Sunni tribes can lead the mission to secure it one neighborhood at a time, a senior State Department official told Congress on Wednesday.

headline: French-Canadian Style in Portneuf
abstract: A three-bedroom French-Canadian-style home, built in 1820, is on the market for $493,993.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom French-Canadian-style home, built in 1820, is on the market for $493,993.

abstract: During the decade ending in 2010, home prices in Quebec grew, on average, about 10 percent a year. The appreciation has recently slowed, largely because of a slowdown in job creation.
lead_paragraph: A RESTORED FRENCH-CANADIAN-STYLE HOME IN QUEBEC

headline: What Tim Duncan Deserves, but Never Seems to Receive
abstract: Leaving Duncan, the Spurs center, off the Western Conference All-Star team is the latest proof that the N.B.A. values style over substance.
lead_paragraph: We know what N.B.A. All-Star voting has typically been: a chance for fans to participate in the selection process for a showcase. No registration is required to prove that one knows Kobe Bryant from Krusty the Clown. It’s a popularity contest that cannot be taken seriously.

headline: What Made Me | Rachel Comey, Fashion Designer
abstract: In the premiere of T’s newest video series, the cult designer recalls some of her formative experiences, including the cool older neighbors she observed as a kid and a unique gift her grandmother gave her.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 12 years, the designer Rachel Comey has built a cult following for her distinctive prints,  feminine dresses and signature jumpsuits, not to mention the personal relationships she has fostered with some of her most loyal fans. In the first installment of “What Made Me,” a new T video series that explores the influences and life experiences that shape creative figures, Comey talks about the cool teenagers she observed growing up in Connecticut, her early days in New York City and a very special gift her grandmother gave her over the course of many years. Comey, who plans to open her first boutique in SoHo this spring, will show her fall 2014 collection tonight in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: First the Doughnuts, Then the Debates
abstract: In “Beertown,” audience members are encouraged to bring and share food and to take part in the deliberations.
lead_paragraph: A shout-out to whoever brought the brownies to “Beertown.” They were tasty, as were the butter cookies. I didn’t try the powdered doughnuts or the cake — I was busy getting my souvenir T-shirt — though they looked a bit too sweet.

headline: A Report’s Real Message: It Wasn’t About Health Care
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A Congressional Budget Office study that assessed the labor market impact of the Affordable Care Act was more notable for its stark warning about the fiscal damage from diminished growth, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: New Recordings Made the Old-Fashioned Way
abstract: A documentary film appearing at South by Southwest tells the story of the 78 Project, in which musicians record a folk song using antique recording equipment.
lead_paragraph: It started off as a way to put an unusual acquisition to use. In 2010, Alex Steyermark, a director and music supervisor for films, and Lavinia Jones Wright, a music journalist, found a couple of Presto Model K8 recording machines, and though these 78-r.p.m. direct–to-disc recorders are generally regarded as antiques, of relatively low utility in these days of digital sound, they decided to buy them.

headline: No, ‘Obamacare’ Isn’t Killing 2 Million Jobs
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The C.B.O. director clearly distinguished between getting laid off and choosing not to work.
lead_paragraph: Opponents of the Affordable Care Act yesterday seized on a Congressional Budget Office report on the labor market, claiming it indicated that health reform would “kill” 2 million jobs. Actually, as our editorial on the subject explained, the C.B.O. predicted a reduction in the number of full-time workers. That may sound like a distinction without a difference, but it’s not. “Job-killing” implies layoffs; whereas the report found that many workers would choose to leave their positions — because they no longer have to depend on their employers for health insurance.

headline: From ‘Breaking Bad’ to Broadway
abstract: Bryan Cranston visits the New York Times photo archive in preparation for his role as President Lyndon B. Johnson in the Broadway play “All the Way.”
lead_paragraph: Bryan Cranston visits the New York Times photo archive in preparation for his role as President Lyndon B. Johnson in the Broadway play “All the Way.”

headline: Presidential Chemistry
keywords: ['Theater', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Bryan Cranston moves from illegal chemistry to hardball politics as he plays Lyndon B. Johnson in “All the Way” on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: With his rich baritone hinting of the American West and craggy handsome looks, Bryan Cranston seems custom built to play outsize heartland characters. Where was he, you wonder, when Sam Shepard was writing “Buried Child” and “True West”? Even at his most relaxed, when he leans in and taps your knee to drive home a point, you don’t want to be caught spacing out.

headline: The Gun Report: February 5, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Researchers at Chicago’s Cook County Hospital began screening victims of urban trauma—gunshot wounds, stabbings and other violent crimes—for post-traumatic stress disorder in 2011. While they expected to find some cases, they were shocked at just how many: 42 percent of the 307 patients surveyed had signs of the disorder. Patients with gunshot wounds were 13 times as likely as those with falls and twice as likely as those in a car accident to test positive for PTSD.

headline: Lazard Swims With the Big Fish
abstract: Lazard looks more like Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase than smaller rivals like Greenhill, contends Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Lazard has put its feet firmly in the big boys’ camp. The advisory and asset management firm didn’t just make progress on financial targets that its chief executive, Kenneth M. Jacobs, set two years ago. Its bankers also goosed revenue in the second half of the year. That makes Lazard look more like Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase than smaller rivals like Evercore Partners and Greenhill.

headline: Citadel Defied a Market Slump in January
abstract: Citadel, the hedge fund giant led by Kenneth C. Griffin, told its investors on Wednesday that its two flagship funds rose 3.4 percent in January, according to a person briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: In a dismal month for the stock market, one big hedge fund company in Chicago managed to record gains.

headline: Orley: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Hurdles Ahead for Beckham and M.L.S. in Miami
abstract: David Beckham announced that he would bring a Major League Soccer expansion team to Miami, but he could not say where or when it would begin play.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The soccer star David Beckham delivered a long-awaited but in many ways provisional commitment to Miami on Wednesday when he confirmed it as the future home of a Major League Soccer expansion team that he will own — alongside partners not yet named — and run.

headline: What’s Happening off the Runway During New York Fashion Week
abstract: Everything you need to enjoy the next eight days in style, from can’t-miss exhibitions and luxurious spa treatments to a restorative juice or meal.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week begins today, and out-of-towners and locals alike are making their final preparations for another season of back-to-back shows and snow-covered streets. Here, a guide to surviving (and enjoying) the festivities.

headline: CBO: ACA OK
abstract: The headline you didn’t see.
lead_paragraph: What with the fuss over the CBO estimates of employment effects of health reform — Appendix C — everyone seems to have overlooked Appendix B, on the reform’s effects in doing what it was supposed to do: cover the uninsured. How has the disastrous initial rollout affected CBO’s projections about reform’s near future?

headline: Jack Butler, a Top Bankruptcy Lawyer, Will Move to Hilco
abstract: John W. Butler Jr., a partner at the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, will move to Hilco Global, a financial firm whose services include liquidating bankrupt companies,
lead_paragraph: One of the bankruptcy bar’s biggest names is planning to leave the law to take up a different perch in the world of restructuring.

headline: Economists Sound the Alarm on Deflation in Europe
abstract: Inflation continues to fall in the euro zone, leading some to worry the region could get caught in a Japanese-style spiral of falling prices.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Whether or not Mario Draghi and his European Central Bank colleagues plan to do anything about it at the monthly meeting Thursday, many economists are sounding the alarm. It is time, they say, to act defensively against the danger of deflation.

headline: Germany’s Clean-Energy Plan Faces Resistance to Power Lines
keywords: ['Energy and Power', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: A proposal for a high-voltage conduit from wind farms in the north to the industrial south has aroused not-in-my-backyard opposition.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s resolve to embrace a clean-energy future may soon face another test of not-in-my-backyard public resistance.

headline: For Seattle’s Celebration, Russell Wilson Is an Unofficial M.V.P.
abstract: Overshadowed by Broncos quarterback Peyton Manning leading up to the game, Wilson, the Seahawks quarterback, did as much as anyone else to deliver his team a Super Bowl title.
lead_paragraph: Russell Wilson was the most valuable player on Sunday when Seattle routed Denver to win the Super Bowl. Wilson did not win the actual award — that honor went to one of his teammates, linebacker Malcolm Smith, who returned an interception for a touchdown and also recovered a fumble.

headline: 3 Arrests, but Violin Is Not Recovered
abstract: Three people were arrested in connection with the theft of a Stradivarius violin from the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Two men and a woman have been arrested in the recent theft of the Stradivarius violin played by the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, Milwaukee police officials announced Wednesday. But the instrument, which dates from 1715 and is valued at $5 million, is still missing.

headline: Instagram Envy Chain: Sochi Edition
abstract: Given that Russian authorities have apparently tried to police the imagery to come out of Sochi, I wanted to see how Russian photojournalists are documenting the region on Instagram.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia, have come under some criticism for their expense and expansiveness, so I wanted to see how Russian photojournalists were covering Sochi on their Instagram accounts, given that Russian authorities have apparently tried to police the types of images to come out of the area. Time for another Instagram envy chain!

headline: European Official Takes Measured Tone on Ukraine Aid
abstract: Europe’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, on a visit to Kiev sought to play down expectations of a big windfall, saying money would be part of a broader assistance package.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — On a visit to Ukraine to try to prod the country’s embattled president and his opponents into resolving a volatile standoff, Europe’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, said Wednesday that a package of economic assistance was in the works but dampened hopes of a sudden infusion of cash.

headline: An Italian Hotel Will Be a Guest Star in California
abstract: Shutters on the Beach in Santa Monica. Calif., will play host to Le Sirenuse of Positano, Italy, in a week–long partnership that will include lunches and dinners and a pop-up shop.
lead_paragraph: Amalfi Coast cuisine and style will merge with those of Los Angeles from Feb. 19 to 26, when Shutters on the Beach in Santa Monica, Calif., will host Le Sirenuse, the hotel in Positano, Italy.

headline: CBS Will Broadcast Thursday Night Games
abstract: The one-year deal was believed to be worth at least $250 million to the N.F.L., which wants Thursday games to someday approach the viewership of Sunday and Monday games.
lead_paragraph: CBS decided that carrying Sunday afternoon N.F.L. games, playoff matchups and, every third year, a Super Bowl was not enough. So it announced Wednesday that it would carry eight Thursday night games in 2014 on a one-year contract that was believed to be worth at least $250 million.

headline: When Love Hits, It Can Really Send You Reeling
abstract: “Almost, Maine,” a regional theater standard, is a world of love played out in vignettes.
lead_paragraph: “Almost, Maine,” that darling of regional theaters, now back in New York, is basically a higher-concept and more clever version of Hollywood hits like “Love Actually“ and “Valentine’s Day.” But this rom-com leans on shrewd writing rather than star power in its nine interlocking love stories, all happening in the same New England town on the same moonless night.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Is the Soundtrack of the Season
abstract: The soundtrack to Disney’s animated film “Frozen” held at No. 1 on the album chart, beating out a compilation of Grammy nominees.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy Awards last week brought expected sales gains for some of the night’s big stars, like Lorde and Daft Punk. But the top seller on Billboard’s album chart this week has nothing to do with the Grammys: the soundtrack to “Frozen,” an animated Disney film, earned its fourth No. 1 with 94,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Study of Drug for Blood Clots Caused a Stir, Records Show
abstract: Many of the documents, newly unsealed by a court, centered on whether research would undercut a selling point: that the blood-thinning drug, Pradaxa, does not require regular tests.
lead_paragraph: The makers of the blood-thinning drug Pradaxa were so worried that an internal research paper would damage drug sales that some employees not only pressured the author to revise it, but suggested it should be quashed altogether, according to newly unsealed legal documents.

headline: Below the Line: Scoring ‘Gravity’
abstract: Steven Price, the composer of “Gravity,” discusses his work on the film.
lead_paragraph: The previous film scores by the British composer Steven Price have included action comedies like Edgar Wright’s “World’s End” and Joe Cornish’s “Attack the Block.” The music often competed with the busy sounds of action. But his latest composition, for Alfonso Cuarón’s space thriller “Gravity,” is frequently competing with silence, or the voice of its main character Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock).

headline: Clip: 'The Lego Movie'
abstract: A scene from the film directed by Chris Miller and Phil Lord.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film directed by Chris Miller and Phil Lord.

headline: Google Appoints Its Most Senior Woman to Run YouTube
abstract: Susan Wojcicki, a senior vice president of ads and commerce at Google, will run YouTube, as it tries to collect more of the ad dollars currently going to TV.
lead_paragraph: The most senior woman at Google, Susan Wojcicki, who has been a senior vice president of advertising and commerce, is changing jobs at the company to run YouTube.

headline: South by Southwest Announces Midnight Slate
abstract: The South by Southwest film festival announces its collection of midnight movies.
lead_paragraph: This year, South by Southwest audiences in Austin, Tex., will witness a frightful forest creature, a killer loose at a musical theater camp and yet one more teenager who has sold her soul to the devil. It’s another installment of the festival’s Midnighters program, which organizers announced Wednesday.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Michael Bastian Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Rebecca Smeyne.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Rebecca Smeyne.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Central African Republic, South Sudan, Pakistan and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Central African Republic, South Sudan, Pakistan and New York.

headline: Missing Sprite Leaves Only Her Shadow
abstract: Joyce Carol Oates’s new novel, “Carthage,” centers on an enigmatic young woman.
lead_paragraph: Joyce Carol Oates, now in her mid-70s, is the author of some 140 books — approximately two a year from the moment she was born. I half expect someday to learn that she kept a real-time journal of her eviction from the birth canal.

headline: A Singular Artist Is Staking His Claim
abstract: The rapper Young Thug’s new release with Bloody Jay, “Black Portland,” is idiosyncratic yet focused.
lead_paragraph: At a certain point, it all comes down to voice. The story hip-hop has often told about itself is that it’s a game of lyrical one-upmanship, an ecosystem of artistes looking for words others couldn’t possibly use better. But just as often — more often — it’s a runway show of vocal eccentricity. Words, and how they’re arranged, take a back seat to how they’re delivered, the fresh paint on the tired old car.

headline: Early Start to Upfronts, as ‘The Real’ Cast Meets Advertisers
abstract: A multicultural talk show from Warner Bros, “The Real” was introduced to advertisers on Wednesday, the beginning of a season that hits its stride in May.
lead_paragraph: Upfront Nation, rejoice. It is that time again, when purveyors of video programming on television and online woo marketers and agencies to spend advertising dollars on commercial time ahead of the coming season.

headline: Even the Dancers Huddle for Warmth
abstract: New York City Ballet performed “Bal de Couture,” “DGV: Danse à Grande Vitesse” and other works at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: All dancers, but in particular those devoted to ballet, spend their lives in front of mirrors. I’m so glad they can’t see themselves in “Bal de Couture,” a dismal Peter Martins creation that dates to New York City Ballet’s 2012 fall gala, with costumes by Valentino. Sadly, it wasn’t, as Tuesday’s program promised, a “Scenic Delight.”

headline: Coca-Cola to Buy 10% Stake in Green Mountain Coffee
abstract: Coke will buy about 16.7 million shares in Green Mountain for about $1.25 billion. In return, Green Mountain will be the official maker of the soda giant’s single-serve cold beverages, built on its popular Keurig pod-based system.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola agreed on Wednesday to buy a 10 percent stake in Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, as it seeks to cement ties with the fast-growing coffee company.

headline: User Growth for Twitter Starts to Slow, and Stock Dips
abstract: The microblogging company said revenue for the quarter was $243 million, up from $112 million a year ago, and it reported a net loss of $511 million.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter has finally acknowledged what any newcomer could have told the company within five minutes of signing up: The messaging service is too hard to use.

headline: Toward a Kingdom Without Kitsch
abstract: Creators of “The Lego Movie” faced the visual challenge of conjuring a world that was deeply familiar yet original.
lead_paragraph: The colorful blocks and cheerful figures of the Lego world have entertained generation after generation of children worldwide and remain a source of artistic expression for adults, too. Now, they’ve been assembled for the first time in a full-length feature film.

headline: Your Best Selfie
abstract: A test of four top smartphones to find out which forward-facing camera takes the best selfie.
lead_paragraph: A test of four top smartphones to find out which forward-facing camera takes the best selfie.

headline: Narcissist’s Dream: Selfie-Friendly Phone
abstract: Many smartphones have superb primary cameras, but the front-facing cameras that we (well, some of us) use to take pictures of ourselves are inferior.
lead_paragraph: “Selfie” was Oxford Dictionaries’ word of the year in 2013. And selfies are powerful business; #me is the third-most-common tag on Instagram, appended to more than 184 million photos, according to the app’s Web viewer, Webstagram. (Numbers 1 and 2 are #love and #instagood.)

headline: You’re Who? Not Even Close
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Parties (Social)', 'Cloud Computing', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: Cloud-based IDs will make gate-crashing more difficult this Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: With the alighting of fashion’s air-smooching society, this week’s tempest of runway shows, private dinners and after-parties offers endless opportunities for gate crashers seeking social validation and free vodka. But prospective infiltrators beware: the sentinels of such entry points have added new weapons to their defensive arsenal.

headline: Qatari Court Rejects U.S. Couple’s Request to Return Home
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The court said the verdict in the case against Matthew and Grace Huang, accused of starving their adopted African daughter to death, would be announced March 27.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — An American couple standing trial on charges they starved their 8-year-old adopted African daughter to death in Qatar last year were dealt a setback on Wednesday when a court denied their request for permission to visit their two other adopted children, who are in the United States.

headline: A Last Centennial Tribute to Britten, in Five Songs
abstract: Along with pieces by Copland, Crumb, Wolf and Poulenc, Sasha Cooke’s recital at Alice Tully Hall featured “A Charm of Lullabies” by Benjamin Britten.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Britten’s centennial year ended on Dec. 31. But 2013 brought few tributes to him lovelier than that delivered on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall by the mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke.

headline: With El-Erian Leaving, Pimco Says It Is ‘Better’
abstract: “Believe me when I say, we are a better team at this moment than we were before,” said William H. Gross, the founder of the giant asset manager.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street was stunned when Mohamed A. El-Erian announced last month that he would step down as chief executive and co-chief investment officer of Pimco, the giant asset manager where he was considered the heir apparent.

headline: Ballads With a Big Dose of Melodrama
abstract: Michele Lee, a Broadway veteran also known for playing Karen in the long-running nighttime soap opera “Knots Landing,” had stamina to burn during a three-night stint at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: When a voraciously needy performer stirs up an audience by wringing the last drop of melodrama from a song, it’s known in the trade as schmacting. Audiences tend to embrace such shameless hamming. And on Thursday evening, the Broadway veteran Michele Lee, who is 71 but looks two decades younger and has stamina and enthusiasm to burn, schmacted up a storm at 54 Below, where she appeared with a pop quintet directed by Ron Abel.

headline: Channeling the Style and Emotional Heat of a Tuneful Era
abstract: John Lloyd Young brings his “Jersey Boys” singing style to Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happened to uncomplicated male passion in pop music? That question nagged at me during John Lloyd Young’s nostalgic concert of rock and R&B ballads at Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening.

headline: You Can Run, but Don’t Hide These Shoes
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Sneakers', 'Perfumes and Fragrances', 'Sunglasses']
abstract: Embellished sneakers make a statement on the runway and the street.
lead_paragraph: Sneakers have never been more chic. At the couture shows in Paris last month, first Dior and then Chanel showed spring confections with sneakers, albeit bedazzled ones. At Chanel, every model strode the runway in sneakers embellished with lace, tweed, python and pearls. It may be a stretch to think that Jennifer Lawrence will wear haute couture trainers with her Dior on the red carpet, but they seem totally reasonable with everything else. The ones here, which include Rick Owens’s architectural wonders designed in collaboration with Adidas, are surely as statement-making as any pair of heels. Expect to see some of them in the front row this week.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Orley Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Pussy Riot at The New York Times
abstract: Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova aren’t scared of going back to prison.
lead_paragraph: Pussy Riot members Maria Alyokhina, 25, and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, 24, visited The New York Times editorial board Wednesday morning. They were on The Colbert Report Tuesday night and will appear at the Barclay’s Center in Brooklyn tonight. This is why they’re getting so much attention.

headline: Simplicity of Movement Translated Into Something Much Larger
abstract: Pam Tanowitz Dance is at the Joyce Theater with a 50-minute double bill of world premieres, “Passagen” and “Heaven on One’s Head.”
lead_paragraph: Some of the dance steps, phrases and constructions by the choreographer Pam Tanowitz are among the finest being made anywhere today. They feature memorable footwork, strikingly elegant and witty combinations of lower- and upper-body movement, and complex, subtle, fascinating uses of stage space. And yet she’s an eccentric. What’s notable — especially in the 50-minute double bill of world premieres that opened at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday — is that her eccentricity is intimately connected to orthodoxy. Much of her dance vocabulary is taken from ballet and from Merce Cunningham technique, both of which she employs in ways that should often impress devotees of either genre.

headline: Disney Reports Strong First-Quarter Earnings, Helped by Animated Film ‘Frozen’
abstract: The animated musical, expected to generate nearly $1 billion in ticket sales, increased quarterly earnings to $1.84 billion, up from $1.38 billion a year ago.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A white-hot Walt Disney Company reported a 33 percent increase in quarterly profit on Wednesday, as the animated musical “Frozen” demonstrated why media giants still chase movie hits although investors prefer less risky pursuits.

headline: Louise Brough Clapp, Tennis Champion at Midcentury, Dies at 90
abstract: The former teenage star from Southern California won six singles titles, including four at Wimbledon, as well as 21 doubles championships and 8 mixed-doubles titles in Grand Slam events.
lead_paragraph: Louise Brough Clapp, whose powerful serve-and-volley game propelled her to 35 championships in Grand Slam tennis tournaments of the 1940s and ’50s and made her one of the most brilliant doubles players in the women’s game, died on Monday in Vista, Calif. She was 90.

headline: Jeff Westheimer’s Imaginative Play at Bridge Semifinals
abstract: Westheimer, one of the top players of the game in the 1960s, ’70s and ’80s, died on Monday at 79, in New York City, his hometown.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Westheimer made a very imaginative opening bid in the diagramed deal from the semifinals of the 1970 team trials. Westheimer, one of the top players of the game in the 1960s, ’70s and ’80s, died on Monday at 79, in New York City, his hometown.

headline: A Generous Spritz to Set the Mood
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Perfumes and Fragrances']
abstract: Scented runways are back for a handful of whimsical designers.
lead_paragraph: Of all the things that stood out at Prabal Gurung’s show last year — the clear plastic curtain, the satiny pencil skirts, the mannequin-like models — fashion editors still recall the one thing they couldn’t see: the smell.

headline: Fall 2014 Show Calendar
abstract: Here is a schedule of some of the fall 2014 shows

headline: McConaughey, Savoring the Underdog Role
abstract: Over his career, Matthew McConaughey has transformed from romantic comedy star to character actor. No matter the role, Mr. McConaughey says that he loves feeling like the underdog.
lead_paragraph: Over his career, Matthew McConaughey has transformed from romantic comedy star to character actor. No matter the role, Mr. McConaughey says that he loves feeling like the underdog.

headline: Potions, Lotions, Emulsions, Decisions
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Skin']
abstract: For the fashion designer Nanette Lepore, beauty is in the hand of the beheld.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer Nanette Lepore, 49, who recently dressed New York Mayor Bill de Blasio’s wife, Chirlane McCray, and their daughter, Chiara de Blasio, for his inauguration ceremony, is releasing a line of products for the home this month. Born in Youngstown, Ohio, she lives and works in Manhattan. Her beauty habits, like her fashion, are flirtatious and youthful.

headline: Olympics Spotlight for Russia’s Musical Profile
abstract: The opening of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, is likely to be a showcase for one of Russia’s proudest exports — classical music and dance.
lead_paragraph: Valery Gergiev is considered a lock to conduct. The Russian diva Anna Netrebko is widely suspected to be singing. And a host of top Russian ballet stars are expected to dance.

headline: Ex-King of Rom-Coms Finds Serious Success
abstract: Matthew McConaughey is in “The Wolf of Wall Street” and “Dallas Buyers Club,” both best picture nominees, but he’s up for the best actor award for his role as Ron Woodroof in “Dallas Buyers Club.”
lead_paragraph: There’s a little private thing that Matthew McConaughey likes to do to relax, a sort of call and response with his own body, a chest-thumping, masculine-humming rhythmic trance that he finds centering.

headline: Fortress of Solitude
abstract: One of the most sublime getaways in Europe just got even more transcendent.
lead_paragraph: In 1978, the English decorator Charlotte Scott decamped to the remote, semi-mountainous region of Andalusia. Fourteen years and four children later, she opened the doors at Trasierra, a 400-acre Anglo-pastoral guesthouse that she transformed from a crumbling 16th-century olive mill into a sanctuary of whitewashed courtyards, cushioned verandas and resplendent gardens. Starting in April, Scott’s 29-year-old daughter, Amber, who trained in Nepal and London as a yoga teacher and massage therapist, will be offering guests daily yoga classes. There will also be weekly retreats focused on meditation, hiking and massage sessions, combined with a delicious menu created by her sister Gioconda. Though Amber’s full-immersion programs happen in May and October, made-to-measure stays for parties of six or more are welcome year-round.

headline: How Did Your Recent Peace Corps Service Affect Your Life?
abstract: The Times invites recent Peace Corps volunteers to share how their service affected their lives after they concluded their commitment.
lead_paragraph: Serving in the Peace Corps can be both challenging and rewarding. Former Peace Corps volunteers often have good stories to tell — about their experiences in the field, what they learned and how those experiences shaped their lives after their service ended. Times journalists are writing about recent Peace Corps volunteers.

headline: How Eroding the Middle Hits Economic Growth
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy']
abstract: As distribution of the nation’s income has shifted more to the top end, economists say that output and consumer spending have suffered.
lead_paragraph: Since my article on Monday about the narrowing of the customer base for midtier restaurants, retailers and other consumer-oriented businesses like hotels and casinos, much of the discussion has focused on what that trend says about whether and how the American middle class is indeed shrinking.

headline: And on Drums, Jazzmen Who Take the Lead
abstract: Rudy Royston, Ulysses Owens Jr. and Jeff Ballard have new albums, projects that reflect drummers’ influence on the evolution of music.
lead_paragraph: The first and last sounds on “303,” Rudy Royston’s sit-up-and-take-notice debut album, involve a tranquil, mysterious, cooled-out funk groove, like an interlude on an early-2000s neo-soul production. Anchored by a soulfully simple bass vamp, with a smoky overlay of horns and guitar, the tune — “Mimi Sunrise,” an opener that resurfaces as a hidden track — calls barely any attention to Mr. Royston’s specific purview, which is drumming. There’ll be time for all that, he seems to imply.

headline: The Fashion Diaspora: Designer Shows Spread Out
abstract: Lincoln Center soldiers on, but other runways are well traveled.
lead_paragraph: Driver, thank God you’re here. Take me to ... where again?

headline: Presidio Asks Filmmaker to Try Again
abstract: The trust overseeing the Presidio, after rejecting a proposal by George Lucas to build an art museum, is asking him to consider other sites there.
lead_paragraph: National parks are open to everyone, even to the filmmaker George Lucas. That is the message from the Presidio Trust in San Francisco, which this week rejected proposals by Mr. Lucas and two other finalists to build “a cultural institution of distinction” on prized bayside parkland and then turned right around and invited him back.

headline: Small Dreams Set Afire on Marcos-Era Streets
abstract: Lino Brocka’s “Manila in the Claws of Light,” at the Museum of Modern Art, is a 1975 movie about the limits to life in the Philippines under the dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos.
lead_paragraph: Lino Brocka’s “Manila in the Claws of Light” begins with a whisper and ends with a howl. In between, there are grace notes, escalating horrors and the peripatetic journey of a country mouse, Julio (Rafael Roco Jr., later known as Bembol Roco), in the big city. It’s a story of struggle, survival, endurance and defeat that Brocka, perhaps the most celebrated of Filipino directors, filmed down and dirty in Manila when the Philippines was still in the grip of the dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos. Brocka, a political activist as well as a prolific filmmaker, died in a car accident in 1991 at 52, and is ready for rediscovery.

headline: Unsealed Court Documents in Pradaxa Case
abstract: Unsealed court documents made public by a federal judge who is overseeing thousands of lawsuits filed by patients and their families who say that Pradaxa’s manufacturer failed to properly warn them about the risks of taking the drug.
lead_paragraph: Unsealed court documents made public by a federal judge who is overseeing thousands of lawsuits filed by patients and their families who say that Pradaxa’s manufacturer failed to properly warn them about the risks of taking the drug.

headline: Times Minute | Vatican Sexual Abuse
abstract: A U.N. panel assails the Vatican over sexual abuse by priests. Also on the Minute, New York's wintry mess and an international yogurt feud between the United States and Russia.
lead_paragraph: A U.N. panel assails the Vatican over sexual abuse by priests. Also on the Minute, New York's wintry mess and an international yogurt feud between the United States and Russia.

headline: Times Minute | Vatican Sexual Abuse
abstract: A U.N. panel assails the Vatican over sexual abuse by priests. Also on the Minute, New York’s wintry mess and an international yogurt feud between the United States and Russia.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: The Life of a Poet Allergic to Endings
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Though she died in 1975, the Harlem Renaissance writer Anne Spencer remains a vivid presence in her home, a perpetual project in its own right.
lead_paragraph: LYNCHBURG, Va. — It was snowing hard on a recent afternoon, but Anne Spencer’s house glowed like a Vanessa Bell mural, more Bloomsbury than Old Virginia. Though Spencer, an iconoclastic poet and Harlem Renaissance figure, died in 1975, her singular house, with its purple, yellow and green rooms, its boldly patterned wallpapers and upholstery, its sheaves of newspaper clippings, photographs, N.A.A.C.P. ledgers, political fliers and her own copious writings that spill out of notebooks and climb the walls (Spencer was an enthusiastic wall-writer), is so vibrant that you would swear she was still living there.

headline: Like a Strand Within a Strand
abstract: “Artist Textiles: Picasso to Warhol,” an exhibition in London, explores the 20th-century influence of art on fashion.
lead_paragraph: Fabrics featuring art by Sonia Delaunay, Marc Chagall and Alexander Calder are among the 200 objects in “Artist Textiles: Picasso to Warhol,” at the Fashion and Textile Museum in London. The exhibition, which runs through May 17, also includes a Joan Miró dress and a Salvador Dalí tie.

headline: Breaking From Its Usual Pattern
abstract: From Dansk, a new line of plates, cups and bowls that take a departure into scribbles.
lead_paragraph: The new Lotta Jansdotter collection for Dansk is a departure for this nearly 60-year-old American company, which routinely hires Scandinavians to design its goods. “We haven’t always been known for pattern,” said Glenn DeStefano, Dansk’s president. “We’ve been about shape and high design, with wood and contrasting materials.” Ms. Jansdotter, who was born on an island between Sweden and Finland, has produced organic forms and whimsical scribbles ever since she started her company in 1996. Here, the imagery floats on plates and repeats on cups and bowls meant to be mixed and matched. Available at Bed Bath & Beyond, the line features five dinnerware patterns and four additional motifs on mugs and bowls only.

headline: Clay Aiken, Able to Carry a Tune but Hoping for a District
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Television', 'Music']
abstract: Mr. Aiken, best known as a country singer and an almost-winner on “American Idol,” plans to run for Congress in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Carolina has become difficult terrain for Democrats since the Republican-controlled legislature redrew congressional districts in 2011 with the goal of more or less eliminating them from the state’s House delegation.

headline: My Brother’s Bunkmate
abstract: The economics of urban living often mean that brothers and sisters must share bedrooms. But when does it become a case of oversharing?
lead_paragraph: Caleb and Harper cannot share a bedroom forever. For now, Rachel Goldstein cites a number of not-unconvincing reasons to keep her 7-year-old son and 4-year-old daughter together in the family’s Park Slope brownstone.

headline: Sales at Gretel Home, Love Adorned and Others
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Carpets and Rugs', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Discount Selling']
abstract: Bargains on trays, rugs and more.
lead_paragraph: Gretel Home is discounting many items up to 60 percent, while supplies last (a Folk Stripe tray by Ary Trays, originally $59, is about $35; the Ombre House money box by Ferm Living, originally $39, is about $23); 786-247-9003, gretelhome.com.

headline: Outfitting an Atelier in Mine and Yours
abstract: The Dutch architect Piet Boon opens a temporary studio in Manhattan, furnishing it with his own designs and the work of others.
lead_paragraph: Piet Boon, the Dutch architect and designer, recently opened a temporary studio at 404 Park Avenue South (28th Street), in a 1917 building that is being converted into 58 luxury apartments. Mr. Boon led the design team that outfitted the development, called Huys. He has furnished his atelier with his own creations, including Sam chairs upholstered in indigo fabric, shown with an oak Gerrit table. The studio also features other designers’ works, like Roderick Vos’s MaMa vase (on table), Frederik Molenschot’s brass numeral sculptures (on wall) and a Great JJ floor lamp by Centro Stile in Italy (shown in white). Though these items cannot be purchased on site, Mr. Boon’s staff can direct you to a dealer. The ground-floor space will be open until June, and then it will give way to a bank. Information: huys-nyc.com.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Jack Spade Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Creating Effortless Luxury
abstract: Reed Krakoff’s collection will be his first since leaving Coach.
lead_paragraph: Reed Krakoff’s collection will be his first since leaving Coach.

headline: Flocks, Flecks and Flicks
abstract: Judy Becker, the Oscar-nominated production designer for “American Hustle,” immersed herself in ’70s design to create the movie’s look.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lawrence’s wardrobe in “American Hustle” was one thing, but let’s talk about her kitchen, with its matching blue blinds and phone. Judy Becker, the movie’s production designer, was responsible for the 1970s-inspired décor, every square foot of flocked wallpaper. Now she has her first Oscar nomination (shared with Heather Loeffler, the set decorator). Speaking by phone from Cincinnati, where she is working on the Todd Haynes film “Carol,” Ms. Becker, who said she is in her late 40s, described her immersion in disco-era taste as an education. She even acquired some stuff. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Boutique Sinks for Small Bathrooms
abstract: Ablution solutions in Corian, concrete and onyx.
lead_paragraph: As far as most people are concerned, a bathroom is a bathroom, and there are only a couple of things it’s good for. That’s not how John Beckmann sees it.

headline: Plucky Horses, Lucky Year
abstract: Vintage playthings all dressed up and ready to rock in honor of the Year of the Wood Horse.
lead_paragraph: This Lunar New Year is not just the Year of the Horse, but the Year of the Wood Horse. In recognition of the pairing, Lane Crawford, the Chinese luxury department store, commissioned Squint Limited to make a lucky group of rocking horses.

headline: A Place to Park Himself
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ANTIQUES', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: An architect renovates a 1950s garage, turning it into a home filled with antiques (but not the four-wheeled type).
lead_paragraph: James van der Velden wanted something out of the ordinary in a home. But not in the conventional sense. He wasn’t interested, for example, in any of the beautiful 17th-century townhouses this city is known for.

headline: Behind the Garage Door
abstract: An architect renovates a 1950s garage, turning it into a home filled with antiques (but not the four-wheeled type).
lead_paragraph: An architect renovates a 1950s garage, turning it into a home filled with antiques (but not the four-wheeled type).

headline: With Snow Sports, a New Olympic Vocabulary
abstract: Snowboarders and skiers have an extensive repertoire of spins and flips. Some tricks are named for their technical requirements, others for their flair. Here, some of the best riders describe the joy and fear that come with these jaw-dropping maneuvers.
lead_paragraph: Snowboarders and skiers have an extensive repertoire of spins and flips. Some tricks are named for their technical requirements, others for their flair. Here, some of the best riders describe the joy and fear that come with these jaw-dropping maneuvers.

headline: Making His Name His Own

headline: Gloria Leonard, Publisher, Pornography Star and Advocate, Dies at 73
abstract: Ms. Leonard was a pornographic film star, and, later, a publisher of High Society magazine and a spokeswoman for the industry.
lead_paragraph: Gloria Leonard, who became a pornographic film star in her 30s and then a men’s magazine publisher and a prominent spokeswoman for her industry, died on Monday in Waimea, Hawaii. She was 73.

headline: The Stories We Tell
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Religion and Belief', 'ABORTION', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The story about a pending abortion case is less about a grandmother counseling women than it is a claim by religion for primacy in the public square.
lead_paragraph: “We tell ourselves stories in order to live,” Joan Didion famously wrote in her essay collection “The White Album.” It’s a haunting line, because it’s so universally applicable. We tell ourselves stories not only for profound reasons but for mundane ones as well: to process the ambiguous and complex events that unfold every day around us, or even to try to understand the issues presented in a major Supreme Court case.

headline: Baby’s All Right
abstract: The expansive bar, restaurant and music space Baby’s All Right has swiftly become a night-life preserver in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: As the Williamsburg scene drowns under waves of tourists and condo dwellers, Baby’s All Right has swiftly become a night-life preserver. The expansive bar, restaurant and music space, which opened in October on Broadway, has hosted an event for Opening Ceremony, held a New Year’s party with a performance by Dev Hynes, and booked acts like Smith Westerns. Among Southside insiders, nights now begin or end here.

headline: ‘Williams,’ the Princess and the Gender Pay Gap
abstract: The difference in median earnings isn’t just a women’s issue, but a societal and moral one.
lead_paragraph: One day when my twins, a boy and a girl, were about 7 years old, we were out running errands.

abstract: The first lady told a group of high school students and parents on Wednesday not to let financial concerns stand in the way of a college education.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — More than three decades after guiding the Los Angeles Lakers from mediocrity to excellence, and nearly two years after helping purchase the bankrupt Los Angeles Dodgers, Magic Johnson rescued another local team.

headline: Israel: Final Approval Is Given on East Jerusalem Apartments
abstract: The 500 new apartments are in neighborhoods, in territory Israel captured during the 1967 war and later annexed, that are considered illegal settlements by most of the world.
lead_paragraph: A city committee on Wednesday gave final approval for more than 500 new apartments in Jewish neighborhoods of East Jerusalem, a routine bureaucratic step that nonetheless could cause ripples in Washington’s efforts to broker a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians. The neighborhoods, in territory Israel captured during the 1967 war and later annexed, are considered illegal settlements by most of the world. Saeb Erekat, the chief Palestinian negotiator, has insisted that such moves undermine the peace process, and on Wednesday was quoted on the Times of Israel, a website, as saying, “The international community must hold Israel accountable for this policy.”

headline: Tech Industry Flexes Muscle in California Race
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The race in the 17th Congressional District in California underscores the tech industry’s push to elect candidates who will further its interests, even if it means trying to replace a party stalwart with a relative unknown.
lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Here in the land of technology start-ups, Ro Khanna is its political version. Backed by many of Silicon Valley’s top investors and executives at Google, Facebook, Yahoo and other tech companies, Mr. Khanna, a 37-year-old patent lawyer who has never held elected office, has mounted an aggressive campaign for the seat from the 17th Congressional District in the heart of the Valley.

abstract: A doctor has saved the lives of countless women. Now she has a message for all of us.

headline: Doctors Charged in Drug Scheme at Clinic Controlled by Traffickers, Authorities Say
abstract: A federal indictment charges that corrupt doctors were paid $300 in cash for fraudulent medical visits that lasted a minute or two and led to the writing of prescriptions for large doses of oxycodone.
lead_paragraph: It is not an uncommon scene: a waiting room filled with patients hoping to see a doctor. But the crowd of up to 100 people that gathered each day outside the Astramed clinic at 1228 Southern Boulevard in the Bronx, clamoring to get a prescription for the painkiller oxycodone, was a different story, the authorities say.

headline: Study Suggests Misplaced Fears in Longer Childbirths
abstract: A finding that epidurals are associated with a longer duration in the second stage of labor indicates that doctors might need to wait more time before intervening with drugs, forceps or cesareans.
lead_paragraph: Epidural anesthesia lengthens the second stage of labor, the one in which women push. But a study published on Wednesday has found that epidurals are associated with an even longer duration in the second stage than is generally recognized, suggesting that some women may be subject to unnecessary interventions by doctors who wrongly fear labor has become prolonged.

headline: Jihadist Return Is Said to Drive Attacks in Egypt
abstract: Egypt has been largely insulated from the Islamist violence in the region, but it is now facing increasing terrorism as Egyptians return from jihad abroad to fight the country’s military-backed government.

headline: A Missing Argument on Contraceptives

lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — A figure skating judge ordered a quick bowl of soup for lunch at the Cup of Nice international competition in France. She did not finish the meal that October day in 2012, putting her spoon down and walking away in shock and anger.

abstract: The defections of two prominent businessmen in eastern Ukraine, a stronghold for President Viktor F. Yanukovych, signal growing frustrations with him even among his base.

headline: Defenders of SodaStream Confuse Boycotts of Israeli Settlements With Movement to Boycott Israel
abstract: The antipoverty group Oxfam rejected claims that it has called for a boycott of Israel.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Thursday, 9:10 p.m. | It may be too soon to tell if SodaStream made a wise investment by hiring the actress Scarlett Johansson as a “brand ambassador” for the products it makes in a factory in the occupied West Bank — although its share price has dropped sharply since then, that could be just because the company also missed an earnings target the same week. But one thing is already clear: criticism of the deal from a charity the actress represented for nearly a decade, Oxfam, has been a publicity bonanza for a Palestinian-led movement to counter Israel’s military dominance with a campaign of boycotts, divestment and sanctions.

lead_paragraph: DADE CITY, Fla. — After fatally shooting a man after an argument over texting in a movie theater, a retired police captain pushed his glasses back and said, “I can’t believe what I’ve done,” a witness to the shooting testified Wednesday at a bond hearing.

headline: One From Berlin
abstract: In which Joe Krozel makes me scare my dog.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This 15 x 16 puzzle by Joe Krozel grew on me. I don’t always do this, but I started in the northwest and was a bit taken aback by the entries at 1 Across and 4 Down (BANG and GASHED, respectively). With all the news stories of shootings and other types of violence, I personally found the opening of Mr. Krozel’s puzzle disturbing.

headline: Months Later, Sniper Attack at Power Hub Still a Mystery
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Terrorism', 'Power Failures and Blackouts']

headline: In the Breath Between Winter Storms, Officials Scramble to Find More Salt
abstract: Faced with repeated barrages of snow, ice and sleet, New York City and surrounding communities are using up their road-salt supplies at a rapid rate.
lead_paragraph: As the latest winter storm bore down on New York City, officials faced with dwindling mounds of salt contacted the state and got an emergency shipment of 2,000 tons. New York State also deployed dozens of trucks to deliver salt from upstate to Long Island towns that are running short. And fielding requests from municipalities, New Jersey’s transportation commissioner called the head of a major supplier, International Salt, to urge the quickest possible delivery.

headline: Live (Streaming) From Russia
abstract: As the Winter Games from Sochi, Russia, begin, it is worth remembering that four years ago from Vancouver, NBC streamed only hockey and curling. Now, all 15 sports will be streamed live.
lead_paragraph: NBC’s moneyed grip on the Olympics means that it has traveled a technological path that no other network has. It has shown the Games entirely on broadcast television. It has added multiple cable networks. Now, it is live-streaming virtually every event to an ecosystem increasingly populated by tablets and smartphones.

headline: Subdued Send-Off, but Jay Leno Is Exiting on Top
abstract: Despite the diminished state of late-night television, and technology that has altered viewing habits, the “Tonight” show remains one of the signature franchises of broadcasting and still carries unusual resonance.
lead_paragraph: When Jack Paar left the “Tonight” show in 1962, he passed through a set of curtains and the camera zoomed in on a card that read: “No More to Come.” Three decades later, Johnny Carson had Bette Midler serenade him on his penultimate show, then sat and spoke directly to his fans in his emotional finale, watched by 42 million viewers.

headline: ‘Chill’ Seattle Savors Its Super Bowl Moment in the Sun
abstract: Seattle is a city not widely known for inchoate screaming and wildness. Until this football season, that is.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Drivers here often smile and wave at one another for no obvious reason. A study last year found that Washington residents were less likely than people elsewhere to swear at strangers. For many, “Seattle chill” sums up the conflicted local soul: polite but cool.

headline: Time and Luck Run Out as $1 Million Lottery Prize Goes Unclaimed in the Bronx
abstract: In the Bronx, a $1 million Powerball winner missed the deadline for cashing in the ticket, and other equal prizes remain unclaimed.
lead_paragraph: The lottery sign is proudly taped to the window of a discount beauty supply store in the Bronx, reminding customers that one of their own became a millionaire overnight.

lead_paragraph: Broadway theaters dimmed their marquee lights for one minute Wednesday in memory of the acclaimed screen and stage actor Philip Seymour Hoffman, who died on Sunday, apparently of a drug overdose.

headline: A Complicated Actor, Philip Seymour Hoffman, in His Last Days
abstract: Mr. Hoffman died, by all accounts, an addict’s death, with periods of outward normalcy interrupted by erratic behavior.
lead_paragraph: A father with his children in a Greenwich Village playground. A disheveled man hovering around the lone A.T.M. in a grocery store, withdrawing the exact sum of $200, over and over, for an hour. A guy texting his buddy to invite him over to watch the Knicks game at his apartment.

headline: Cycling Study Says Hearts Race With the Riders
abstract: A new study, analyzing data from cyclists who finished the 2012 Tour de France, suggests that good endurance is highly correlated with good looks.
lead_paragraph: It should be pretty clear that professional athletes are better at sports than you. It turns out, though, they may be better looking, too.

keywords: ['Home Appliances', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Snow and Snowstorms']
abstract: Electricity customers are being asked to avoid using nonessential appliances like washers, dryers, dishwashers and extra lights because of problems with cables in the area.
lead_paragraph: Con Edison has asked electricity customers in Harlem to avoid using nonessential appliances like washers, dryers, dishwashers and extra lights because of problems with electric cables in the area.

headline: With Felton a Step Slow, the Knicks Allow the Blazers to Run Away
abstract: Point guard Raymond Felton sat out the final 14 minutes for the Knicks, who lost a second-half lead and fell to Nicolas Batum and the Trail Blazers.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks had a third-quarter lead against one of the N.B.A.’s premier teams Wednesday night when Raymond Felton was slowed by a screen along the 3-point arc. He trailed the Portland Trail Blazers’ Damian Lillard for the rest of the play, relegated to the role of spectator as Lillard drove the lane before passing to Nicolas Batum for a layup.

headline: Temporary Insanity
abstract: A brief look at the harrowing and often hysterical week that kicks off every new fashion season.
lead_paragraph: For eight days in February and then again in September, more than 100,000 characters descend on New York City for the women’s fashion shows. Traffic grinds to a halt. Requests on Uber, the luxury car-service app, spike 40 percent. It’s harder to get a seat at certain restaurants, like Carbone or NoMad, than it is a front-row perch at Marc Jacobs. And there are enough crazed street-style peacocks clomping around and #NYFW selfies getting snapped to make the whole scene feel like some endless Kardashian nightmare. But it’s also serious business. The shows bring in an estimated $860 million for the city, more than the projected earnings of the U.S. Open, the New York City Marathon or the Super Bowl. Not bad for an event that began in 1941, when the International Ladies’ Garment Workers Union invited 30 journalists to attend a few designers’ showrooms. Here, a brief look into the harrowing and often hysterical week that kicks off every new fashion season.

headline: Shiny Shades of Cerulean
abstract: From tiny pops of bold, steely blue to large reflective swaths of teal, resort collections are full of space-age hues.
lead_paragraph: A bevy of shiny accessories in steely shades of blue are brightening up winter’s drab look. Monochromatic watches and jewelry, like David Yurman’s classic cable bracelet made anew with icy-blue aluminum, add modest pops of the eye-catching hues. But it’s the highly reflective sunglasses, shoes and bags that really make a statement. Saint Laurent’s teal duffle and sapphire high-tops scream space-age fashion while a pair of ombré Gucci shades are too attention-grabbing to hide behind.

headline: Europeans Undermining Trade Negotiations
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The European Union’s determination to include financial regulations in a new trade agreement with the United States is making passage unlikely, an economist writes.

McGaughey, 40, spent the last three seasons as the special-teams coach at Louisiana State. McGaughey was the Giants’ assistant special-teams coordinator for four seasons and has also coached in the N.F.L. in Kansas City, Houston and Denver.

headline: What’s on Thursday

(NBC) WINTER OLYMPICS Coverage of the 2014 Games from Sochi, Russia, begins with the men’s and pairs short programs in the inaugural figure skating team contest, which combines results in men’s, women’s, pairs and ice-dancing competition. Of the 10 competing teams, Canada, Russia and the United States are favored. (Above, a member of the Russian team, Yevgeny Plushenko.) Other segments feature women’s moguls in freestyle skiing and men’s and women’s slopestyle snowboarding. Shaun White has announced that he will drop out of the first-time slopestyle event.

headline: ‘An American in Madras’ Traces Career of Unlikely Pioneer in Tamil-Language Films
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Art', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Festivals', 'Language and Languages', 'Movies', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: The documentary’s director, Karan Bali, said Ellis R. Dungan, who made movies in the southern state of Tamil Nadu during the 1930s and 1940, introduced innovative techniques to the fledgling Tamil film industry.
lead_paragraph: As a college student in what is now known as Mumbai, the Indian filmmaker Karan Bali watched the 1947 Hindi classic “Meera,” a remake of the 1945 Tamil-language film of the same name, and loved it. However, it was not until in 2004, while researching an article for his portal on Indian cinema, Upperstall, that he discovered the director of both films was an American, Ellis R. Dungan.

headline: In Jaipur, New Feminists Are Born
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Discrimination', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Domestic Violence', 'Human Trafficking', 'Men and Boys', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Prostitution', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights", 'Writing and Writers', 'Youth']

lead_paragraph: The women’s rights activists Ruchira Gupta and Gloria Steinem are keeping a diary of their travels throughout India as they meet the country’s young feminists, writers and thought leaders. In this installation for India Ink, Ms. Gupta and Ms. Steinem take part in the Jaipur Literature Festival.

headline: Looted, but Not Lost: An African Artist’s Life Work
abstract: Amid the looting in Bangui, Central African Republic, Jerome Delay happened on photographic materials scattered on the ground. It turns out, they belong to the renowned photographer Samuel Fosso.
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic — Bangui has been a looters’ paradise for weeks now. Despite French and African Union peacekeepers, Christians have gone on a rampage burning Muslim homes and businesses in revenge for almost a year of Muslim Seleka rule of scorched earth and terror. Except now, with no rule of law, the looting has crossed religious boundaries and rampaging mobs sack their own neighborhoods.

headline: Does a More Equal Marriage Mean Less Sex?
abstract: He cooks, she cleans, they both work and take care of the kids. It’s the perfect egalitarian marriage. There’s just one problem.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I was at a dinner party with several couples in their 40s, all married except for my boyfriend and me. The mood was jovial until, over dessert, one guest made an offhand joke about Internet porn.

headline: Will You Be Watching the Sochi Olympics?
abstract: Not only are there concerns about terrorism at these Olympics, but many are outraged about Russian legislation that seems to discriminate against gay athletes and visitors. Will you be watching the Games? Why or why not?
lead_paragraph: “Never before has the pre-Olympic chatter been less about the athletes or the sports,” Juliet Macur writes in a piece for Wednesday’s special Sochi 2014  section. Not only are there serious concerns about terrorism, but many are also outraged about Russian legislation that seems to discriminate against gay athletes and visitors.

headline: European Hardship Hurts Vodafone’s Sales

headline: Egypt’s Despair, and Its Hope
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Young people made the revolution, and they won't be satisfied by either a new Mubarak, or the Muslim Brotherhood.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Last month, on the third anniversary of the revolution of Jan. 25 that led to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, millions of Egyptians came out onto the streets carrying Egyptian flags and pictures of Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, the army leader whom they considered their hero for siding with the will of the people and overthrowing the Muslim Brotherhood government in June. At the same time, supporters of the Brotherhood’s deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, continued their confrontations with the police, which resulted in 49 deaths and scores of injuries.

headline: As 2 Go Free, Brooklyn Conviction Challenges Keep Pouring In

lead_paragraph: Their wrists uncuffed, their ankles unchained, Antonio Yarbough and Sharrif Wilson walked out of a Brooklyn courtroom Thursday afternoon, free after more than two decades in prison for three murders they did not commit.

headline: In Japan, a Beloved Deaf Composer Appears to Be None of the Above
abstract: Japan reacted with remorse and outrage to Mamoru Samuragochi’s admission that he had hired a ghostwriter since the 1990s to compose most of his music.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — He was celebrated as a prolific musical genius whose compositions appeared in popular video games and the competition routine of a top figure skater in the coming Sochi Olympics. His deafness won him praise as Japan’s modern-day Beethoven.

headline: Democrats Aim for a 2014 More Like 2012 and 2008
abstract: They hope to make the 2014 midterm election resemble a presidential election year, when more traditional Democratic constituencies vote in higher numbers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Democrats’ plan to hold on to their narrow Senate majority goes by the name “Bannock Street project.” It runs through 10 states, includes a $60 million investment and requires more than 4,000 paid staff members. And the effort will need all of that — and perhaps more — to achieve its goal, which is nothing short of changing the character of the electorate in a midterm cycle.

headline: When Identity Theft Hits Home
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Credit Cards', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Debit Cards', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Identity Theft', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: What happens when your credit card information is among the millions stolen from a major retailer? Nothing good.
lead_paragraph: When I first heard about the extensive Target hack in December, I sighed in mild irritation. Sure, the breach’s size and scope was shocking, but these things have become so common I just assumed I’d receive a new card in the mail and that would be the end of it.

headline: A Social Network That’s Just for College Students

lead_paragraph: Start-Up: Blend.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England on Thursday decided to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low as Britain’s economic recovery continues at a slow pace.

headline: Downhill Is Already Causing Concern
abstract: Thanks to high speeds and long jumps, the women’s training session was stopped after only three skiers tried runs, while more than half of the men’s field missed gates.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The Olympic men’s downhill course begins with a descent so steep that skiers quickly reach 90 miles an hour. A subsequent jump catapults racers almost the length of a football field.
