lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — In snowboarding, it is extremely difficult to be the defending Olympic gold medalist in halfpipe and hold similar expectations in slopestyle. Shaun White knows this better than anyone — almost.

headline: Europe’s Central Bank, Defying Doomsayers, Holds Rate Steady
abstract: The bank did not change its record-low rate, despite warnings that the euro zone is sliding into the dangerous economic condition known as deflation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European Central Bank’s president, Mario Draghi, is taking a wait-and-see approach as the threat of deflation hangs over the euro zone and the region’s unemployment remains stubbornly high.

headline: A ‘Doll’ Who Pulls Her Own Strings
abstract: The British director Carrie Cracknell brings a version of “A Doll’s House” to the Brooklyn Academy of Music that has a 21st-century sensibility while it retains its 19th-century setting.
lead_paragraph: When Nora Helmer, the heroine of Ibsen’s “A Doll’s House,” left her family, slamming the door as she departed, the sound shook the theater and the world. “People left the theater, night after night, pale with excitement, arguing, quarreling, challenging,” an early critic remarked of that 1879 play. Many theater companies considered the ending so shocking, they changed it.

headline: Toying With Ideas Outside the Manual
abstract: “The Lego Movie” flirts with flouting its marketing imperative even as it embodies it.
lead_paragraph: When I was young I lacked the patience and fine-motor skills to do much with Lego, but I spent a lot of time with friends whose bedrooms and basements bristled with elaborate, snapped-together spaceships and skyscrapers. There was always something of a gap between the care and imagination that went into the constructions and what you did with them after the building was done. Those intricate structures became, like just about everything else, stages for car crashes and action-figure duels. Now and then there would be a pause for an argument about who was the bad guy and what the rules were, and then the battle would resume until it was time for a snack.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Commodities', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']

lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Mercuria Energy Group, a fast-growing energy and commodities trading company, is in exclusive talks to acquire the physical commodities business of JPMorgan Chase, according to a person familiar with the discussions.

abstract: Many wonder how Bill Gates, a luminary of the tech world, will choose to position Microsoft going forward.
lead_paragraph: The last time Bill Gates played an active role at Microsoft, as chief software architect, he witnessed the company muffing its earliest efforts to become a major player in search, smartphones and tablet computers, Nick Wingfield reports.

abstract: Plus, opting out of Google Plus auto backup.
lead_paragraph: Q. I want to install Linux on an old PC to get a few more years out of it, but I don’t know which version to use. What is the difference between Ubuntu and Mint for a new user and are there any free guides to using either?

headline: Fraternity Life, Islamic Style
abstract: At the country’s first Islamic fraternity, Alpha Lambda Mu, students get the opportunity to express both sides of their identity, the American and the Muslim.
lead_paragraph: SHORTLY BEFORE SUNUP, a dozen or so students at the University of California, San Diego, stumbled dutifully out of bed. They ironed their collared shirts, knotted their ties and piled into their cars. Their destination was the Islamic Center of San Diego, where they were to be initiated into the country’s first Muslim fraternity, Alpha Lambda Mu, named for three letters that start several chapters of the Quran: Alif Laam Meem.

headline: America’s First Muslim Fraternity

headline: A Shrug at Puerto Rico’s Debt Downgrade
abstract: The markets barely responded to a downgrade of Puerto Rico’s credit rating. | The jury in the insider-trading trial of a former SAC manager seeks to review transcripts. | The currency trading industry is in flux. | A.I.G. is seeking to delay the $8.5 billion Bank of America mortgage settlement.
lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s lowered Puerto Rico’s credit rating to junk status on Tuesday, but on Wednesday, the market responded with barely a flinch. While prices of some of the island’s bonds traded lower, there was nothing close to the kind of mass sell-off that might indicate a panic, Michael Corkery reports in DealBook.

headline: Designing a Dream Daytime Wedding
abstract: For T’s European editor Rita Konig, getting hitched near home on a Friday meant she could spoil her guests while spending less on her big day.
lead_paragraph: One of the things that has always struck me about weddings, these “very special days,” is how run of the mill they can sometimes feel. When it came time, at 40, to organize my own wedding, I realized that I wanted to do things a little differently, and that I needed to avoid the bridal market in order to keep things personal and on-budget. In the end, this approach to creating a meaningful and memorable day did cost less, and everyone in attendance felt truly spoiled.

headline: Christy Wyatt of Good Technology, on Minding the Details
abstract: The chief executive of a mobile security company says leaders have to discuss small issues as well as big ones, lest employees jump to conclusions.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Christy Wyatt, chief executive of Good Technology, a provider of mobile security solutions, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Jamaican Bobsledders Are Back, With Fans’ Help
abstract: An online fund-raising drive helped cover the expenses and upgrade the equipment of a long-shot two-man team.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — When Winston Watts put on his helmet to begin Jamaica’s first trip down an Olympic bobsled track in 12 years, he was surprised by what he felt in his eyes. It was not tears of emotion; no, this substance was grittier and chalkier. After a moment, he figured it out: He had protein powder dribbling down his face.

headline: Rise in Profit for G.M., but Europe Unit Falters
abstract: G.M. has changed its management team and made major strides in its core North American market, but the nation’s biggest automaker is still struggling in Europe.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors on Thursday reported its 16th consecutive profitable quarter — but consistent losses in its troubled European division continued to hurt its results.

headline: Labor Supply and the Meaning of Life
abstract: Choosing to work less versus losing a job.
lead_paragraph: I had some fun (for weird econonerd values of “fun”) yesterday thinking through the interesting possibility that our pre-Obamacare health system created a “reverse notch” that induced some people to work too much. But I think I should step back and talk about the broader issue here.

headline: The Start of New York Fashion Week
abstract: A look at the first official day of an event that is expanding in both time and geography.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, New York. Your Fashion Week is here. Today is the first official day of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week, though devoted showgoers have been hoofing through slush and snow for the better part of two days to reach earlier presentations. (As I note in today’s Thursday Styles article on the fashion diaspora, New York Fashion Week is expanding in both time and geography.)

headline: Austerity Memories
abstract: What we should have known in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Cooper writes about possibilities for a deal that actually does something to boost the economy. He suggests that with the deficit obsession fading, Democrats can go back to the old formula of spending increases in return for tax cuts — the formula that gave us, for example, the Children’s Health Insurance Program in the late 1990s.

headline: From a Forgotten Box, a Ray of Light
abstract: Noel Chanan’s book “The Photographer of Penllergare” traces the work of John Dillwyn Llewelyn.
lead_paragraph: This story begins in 1973 with a man in Wales tidying up the mess in his garage and discovering a box of daguerreotypes. Uncertain whether to throw it out, he waited until his brother-in law asked advice from a friend who was a photographer and documentary filmmaker. The friend, Noel Chanan, strongly advised him to hold tight onto a box that must be brimful of history.

headline: Student Contest | Write an Editorial on an Issue That Matters to You

headline: Stradivarius Is Recovered Unharmed After Theft

lead_paragraph: A Stradivarius violin stolen last month from the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra has been recovered seemingly unharmed, the authorities in Milwaukee announced on Thursday.

headline: Sugary Foods Increase Heart Risks
abstract: Eating sugary foods, researchers have found, increases the risk of dying from heart disease.
lead_paragraph: Eating sugary foods, researchers have found, increases the risk of dying from heart disease.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘The Grandmaster’
abstract: The costume designer for “The Grandmaster” explains why he and his team handmade some 100 dresses.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:00 p.m. | “The Grandmaster,” is the director Wong Kar-wai’s combined biopic and action film about the rise of one of kung fu’s masters, Ip Man, who would later go on to train Bruce Lee. The film’s stars, Tony Leung (Ip Man) and Ziyi Zhang (who plays Gong Er, a rival and, of course, love interest), went through several years of intense martial-arts training for the film.

headline: AOL Reports Solid Revenue, but Patch Weighs on Profit
abstract: The media company said it benefited by selling video advertising on the web globally, with 23 percent growth in that revenue.
lead_paragraph: AOL, the Internet portal-turned-media company, reported strong revenue for the fourth quarter of 2013 on Thursday, but costs related to Patch, its struggling hyperlocal news service, cut into its profits.

headline: What Does a School Crossing Guard Do?
abstract: Just in the course of our daily walk to school, my children and I see crossing guards whose actions (and attitude) vary wildly. What exactly are they supposed to do?
lead_paragraph: Bring up the subject of school crossing guards in New York City, and plenty of parents will have something spirited to say: “Ours is awesome! She holds my daughter’s hand!” Or perhaps: “Ours is useless! The other day I saw her texting while kids crossed the street alone!”

headline: Concern at Westchester Art House as Heavyweight Rival, Sundance, Plans Theater
abstract: Plans for a film complex 11 miles from the Jacob Burns Film Center will test the size of the county’s appetite for highbrow movies.
lead_paragraph: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y. — Even during film awards season, there have not been many theaters where residents of Westchester County could see quirky independent or foreign contenders like “Nebraska,” “Philomena” or “Inside Llewyn Davis.” Until the last few years, there has often been just one such dependable locale, the 12-year-old nonprofit Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville, the county’s only true art house.

headline: A Vegan-Focused Valentine’s Weekend
abstract: Windward House Bed and Breakfast in Maine is offering a Valentine’s weekend package free of animal products.
lead_paragraph: Not sure what to give your vegan sweetie for Valentine’s? The historic Windward House Bed and Breakfast in Camden, Me., which emphasizes locally sourced food and environmentally friendly products, is offering a weekend getaway free of animal products.

abstract: A visitor at a defense exhibition in New Delhi checking out a model of a Russian rifle.

abstract: Japan Industrial Partners, a little-known Japanese private equity firm that specializes in scouting the electronics landscape for turnaround opportunities, said it would buy Sony’s unprofitable personal computer unit.
lead_paragraph: For its latest restructuring, Sony has turned to a private equity firm that specializes in buying unloved assets from Japanese electronics giants.

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
abstract: Five designers discuss their work on recent book covers: first concepts that didn’t make the final cut, and then the cover as published.
lead_paragraph: Five designers discuss their work on recent book covers: first concepts that didn’t make the final cut, and then the cover as published.

headline: Imagining a New York City Flag for the 21st Century
abstract: A civic group commissioned artists, architects and graphic designers to reinvent the city flag, and will auction the flags at Sotheby’s to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the city’s landmarks law.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows the old joke about what has four wheels and flies. The answer, of course: a garbage truck. But what’s blue, white and orange, festooned with beavers, flour barrels, the blades of a windmill, a sailor, an Indian and an eagle? And flies, too?

headline: Russian Biathlon Coach Had Suspicions, Too
abstract: Wolfgang Pichler, who was hired to help Russia prepare for Sochi, said that he brought his suspicions to the Russian biathlon federation late last year, but that nothing was done.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Wolfgang Pichler, a prominent coach of the Russian biathlon team, said he knew that at least one Russian athlete was doping as far back as November, more than two months before she and another Russian biathlete were suspended for doping violations.

headline: Government Demands for Data About Twitter Users Continue to Grow
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Globally, government requests for Twitter data grew 22 percent in the last six months of 2013, compared to the first half of the year, with the United States making more than half the requests. But one gaping hole remains: the social network excludes data on requests made under American national security laws because of the restrictions on what can be disclosed.
lead_paragraph: As Twitter gets bigger, governments around the world are increasingly seeking information about its 241 million users and their accounts, the social networking company said Thursday as it released fourth semiannual transparency report.

headline: ‘Gravity’s’ Score, Playing Soon in Space?
abstract: Astronauts do listen to music in space, and there’s an outside chance that music could include the film’s score.
lead_paragraph: From the start, Alfonso Cuarón and his son and collaborator, Jonás, knew that sound would be a major part of “Gravity.”

headline: Profit Tumbles at Fox, but Cable Makes Gains
abstract: A loss of roughly $1 billion in income from discontinued operations in the year-earlier period accounted for much of the decline.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Higher costs for sports television, an advertising dip at local TV stations, crumbling ratings for “The X Factor” and lackluster movie releases sent quarterly profit tumbling at 21st Century Fox.

headline: Magazines Gain in Digital Sales but Newsstand Revenue Continues to Fall
abstract: Declines in single-copy sales offset a nearly 37 percent rise for digital editions in the last half of 2013, the Alliance for Audited Media reported.
lead_paragraph: Magazine circulation declined slightly in the last six months of 2013, according to new figures released Thursday by the Alliance for Audited Media, as big declines in single-copy newsstand sales offset gains in digital editions.

headline: Scholarly Editions of Mozart Librettos Going Online
abstract: The Mozarteum Foundation Salzburg has put the first installment of its libretto project online.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve always wanted to have the Mozart operas at your fingertips — in scholarly editions, no less — here is a start: the Mozarteum Foundation Salzburg has put the first installment of its Mozart libretto project online, and it turns out that the librettos are only the gateway: as you read along, you can click on a speaker icon, which will not only give you access to an audio recording of the relevant section of the opera but will also put a full orchestral and vocal score on your screen.

headline: Vodafone’s Investment Case Will Involve Deal-Making
abstract: Vodafone will probably be interested in deals that will give it fixed-line networks in places where it cannot build or rent others on favorable terms, writes Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Vodafone is starting to look healthier as a standalone company.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: shivering as exercise, CVS and peanut allergies. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: shivering as exercise, CVS and peanut allergies. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Religious Freedom Is a Tenet of Foreign Policy, Obama Says
abstract: President Obama on Thursday urged China to do more to allow the freedom of worship, called on North Korea to release a Christian missionary and insisted that Iran free a Christian pastor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday scolded China, Iran, North Korea and other countries known for repressing religious minorities and declared that promoting freedom of faith around the world was a central goal of American foreign policy.

headline: Caribbean Newcomers Dip Their Toes in the Snow
abstract: Dominica, a small Caribbean island nation, will make its Winter Olympic debut this week, led by a former investment banker from Staten Island and his Italian-born wife.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — When Dominica, a tiny Caribbean nation, makes its Winter Olympic debut on Friday, the cross-country skier carrying its flag at the opening ceremony will be a wealthy former investment fund manager from Staten Island who never tried cross-country skiing until after his 30th birthday.

lead_paragraph: Fans of the web series “Submissions Only,” which takes a humorous yet gimlet-eyed look at the life of the struggling New York actor, have been eagerly awaiting the release of the third season. One has only to read the comments on YouTube, below the trailer for the new season, to get a sense of the level of anticipation in this particular demographic.

lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey is in talks to make her Broadway debut in a revival of the Pulitzer Prize-winning play “’night, Mother,” starring opposite Tony-Award winner Audra McDonald as a mother struggling to stop her daughter from killing herself, according to two theater executives familiar with the plans.

headline: State Regulator Halts Deal Between Wells Fargo and Loan Servicer

lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:12 p.m. | A New York State regulator has dealt a blow to Ocwen Financial by halting the transfer of about $39 billion in servicing rights to the company from Wells Fargo.

headline: Boehner Doubts Immigration Bill Will Pass in 2014
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner’s pronouncement significantly narrowed the window for success on the issue this year and left it to President Obama to win the trust of Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The yearlong effort to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws, which had the support of President Obama, Republican leaders and much of American business and labor, was seriously imperiled on Thursday when Speaker John A. Boehner conceded that it was unlikely he could pass a bill.

headline: No Sex, Please, We’re on Medicare
abstract: A controversy over Medicare coverage of penis pumps highlights our deep discomfort with the sexuality of older people.
lead_paragraph: What could be more likely to draw international headlines, and jokes on late-night talk shows, than a government report that includes both an alleged waste of Medicare money and erectile dysfunction?

headline: European Lawmakers Try to Spur Market for Carbon-Emission Credits
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Air Pollution', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Europe’s carbon-permit trading system remains a global model. But prices are too low to create incentives for adopting cleaner energy sources.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European Union lawmakers moved on Thursday to support the bloc’s system for trading carbon-emission permits, hoping to revive Europe’s flagging effort to take a market-incentives approach to reducing greenhouse gases.

headline: After Boeing 787 Is Diverted, Air India Looks Into Software Problem
abstract: A glitch forced a Dreamliner that was bound for New Delhi to land in Malaysia, the latest in a series of technical issues for the aircraft.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — In the latest in a string of technical problems involving the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, a “software glitch” has caused an Air India flight to divert from its course and make an emergency landing in Malaysia.

headline: A Triumph for Putin, if Not for the Rest of a Sagging Russia
abstract: The Winter Olympics, whose opening ceremony began on Friday, represents a chance for President Vladimir V. Putin to demonstrate his mastery of the global levers of power, even if the cost of hosting the competition has added to economic anxiety.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — After President Vladimir V. Putin delivered Russia’s successful pitch to host the Winter Olympic Games in Sochi — in English and a smattering of French, no less — he declared it an international validation of the Russia that had emerged from the ruins of the Soviet Union.

headline: Today in Small Business: An Epic Local Commercial Goes Viral
abstract: Selling yarn online. Changing the face of email marketing. Requiring paid sick leave.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Cooper-Hewitt Museum Gets a $10 Million Donation
abstract: A $10 million donation from the Morton and Barbara Mandel Family Foundation will help the museum prepare to reopen after renovations are complete.
lead_paragraph: The Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York has been on a hot streak. In October, it received $5 million from the city to help with its $79 million renovation.  On Thursday, the museum announced a $10 million donation from the Morton and Barbara Mandel Family Foundation — the largest in this arts institution’s history.

headline: Words of Praise for the City’s Sanitation Chief
abstract: Readers took to the comments section of today’s article on John J. Doherty to offer thanks, praise and a few pot shots at Mayor Bill de Blasio, who some feel has been less than gracious to his commissioner.
lead_paragraph: It was always a rather thankless position, but with the addition of social media and tweeted complaints of unplowed streets amplifying New York’s renowned impatience, the position of sanitation commissioner comes with a new job requirement: extra thick skin.

headline: Russia Claims U.S. Is Meddling Over Ukraine
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Meanwhile, the Obama administration blamed Moscow for spreading an intercepted private conversation between two American diplomats.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The tense Russian-American jockeying over the fate of Ukraine escalated on Thursday as a Kremlin official accused Washington of “crudely interfering” in the former Soviet republic, while the Obama administration blamed Moscow for spreading an intercepted private conversation between two American diplomats.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Pity the One Percent
abstract: Sam Zell said the rich work harder.
lead_paragraph: In late January, Tom Perkins, a venture capitalist, called attention “to the parallels” between Nazi Germany’s “war on its ‘one percent,’ namely its Jews” and “the progressive war on the American one percent, namely the ‘rich.’”

headline: How to Identify a Stradivarius
abstract: Christopher Reuning, a rare-instrument dealer in Boston, explained how an expert would identify the Stradivarius stolen in late January from the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Reuning, a rare-instrument dealer in Boston, explained how an expert would identify the Stradivarius stolen in late January from the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Illustrating a Sexless but Equal Marriage
abstract: How we created the imagery for our cover story by Lori Gottlieb that asks what female empowerment means for the sex lives of modern married couples.
lead_paragraph: This week’s cover story by Lori Gottlieb asks what female empowerment means for the sex lives of modern married couples. While many partnerships these days are so-called peer marriages, in which both spouses work full-time as well as share household and parenting duties, the twist is that those apparently appealing dynamics may have a negative impact on a couple’s sex life.

headline: Creatures of the Wind: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

abstract: High-end luxury automakers, except Ferrari, enjoy strong sales; a G.M.-Isuzu diesel engine joint venture receives $60 million in upgrade money.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Kickoff
abstract: AmFAR kicked off New York Fashion Week, Details celebrated its March issue and VFiles partied late.
lead_paragraph: AmFAR kicked off New York Fashion Week, Details celebrated its March issue and VFiles partied late.

headline: Laurenne Ross on Downhill Practice
abstract: The American downhill skier Laurenne Ross talks about the women’s racing course in Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: The American downhill skier Laurenne Ross talks about the women’s racing course in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Green Mountain’s Deal With Coke Fails to Dent SodaStream
abstract: Analysts and investors think that a deal between Coke and Green Mountain may presage another one: some sort of tie-up between SodaStream and Coke’s archrival, PepsiCo.
lead_paragraph: When Green Mountain Coffee Roasters announced an investment from the Coca-Cola Company on Wednesday, many investors assumed that SodaStream, the D.I.Y.-soft-drink darling, would suffer.

headline: Restaurant Report: Serge et le Phoque in Hong Kong
abstract: Two stars of the French dining world bring a corner of Paris to the heart of the Wan Chai district.
lead_paragraph: Two stars of the Paris dining scene now have a pied-à-terre in Hong Kong. Last August, Fred Peneau, formerly the business partner of Iñaki Aizpitarte at Le Chateaubriand, and the chef Christophe Pelé joined with the interior designer Charles Pelletier to open Serge et le Phoque, a contemporary French restaurant in the heart of the Wan Chai district. (The restaurant was named both after and by Mr. Peneau’s young son, Serge, who thought that le Phoque, French for “the seal,” would be a good companion to Le Dauphin, or “the dolphin,” another of Mr. Peneau’s ventures.)

headline: In Cambodia’s Capital, an Infusion of Flavor
abstract: Chefs from around the world, lured by Phnom Penh’s development boom, are opening spots with cuisine that has never before been offered in the city.
lead_paragraph: As Phnom Penh’s traffic roared nearby on a recent late afternoon, George and William Norbert-Munns were busy decorating. Amid piles of rubble and cement bags, the brothers mapped their vision for the dark, compact space — solid timber banquette seating, chocolate-hued walls, large windows — that would transform it into a sleek gastro pub.

headline: Hotels With History in Goa, India
abstract: In this small territory along the Arabian Sea, aging buildings reborn as hotels are connecting guests with a textured past.
lead_paragraph: Half an hour before our plane touched ground in Goa, a crew member announced that we would be turning around and flying back to Mumbai. It was the middle of monsoon season, and the rain and lightning had grown so heavy, the pilot no longer thought it safe to land. I’m not sure what metrics led the flight crew to change their minds, because heavy rain and lightning are exactly what we lurched through when, moments later, our plane began its jarring descent to India’s good-time state.

headline: Ex-SAC Trader Convicted of Securities Fraud
abstract: With the conviction of Mr. Martoma, the nearly decade-long investigation of Steven Cohen and his hedge fund may have seen its last criminal prosecution.
lead_paragraph: Mathew Martoma had been on his way to being another American success story. Today, he is the eighth person who once worked for the hedge fund titan Steven A. Cohen to be convicted of insider trading.

headline: The Gun Report: February 6, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Curtis Reeves, the 71-year-old retired police captain who shot and killed a man who was texting in a Florida movie theater on Jan. 13, attended his bail hearing yesterday, and more details about the shooting came to light.

headline: Rules of Style | Edun’s Danielle Sherman on Surviving Fashion Week
abstract: The newly minted creative director on her boyish uniform, beauty routine and favorite pre- and post-show treats.
lead_paragraph: After under-the-radar stints at the Row (which she co-founded with her childhood friends Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen) and as the head of design for T by Alexander Wang, Danielle Sherman shot into the spotlight when the LVMH brand Edun hired her to take the reins last season. Design is in the L.A. native’s blood: Her grandparents ran the Swinging London label the Dollyrocker, and her father has a soccer-shoe company. Now, she’s reinventing the Africa-focused brand with a modern, easygoing take on luxury — and even shot the spring ad campaign herself (an avid photographer, she also happens to be engaged to the lensman-about-town Todd Selby).

headline: Where Lincoln Sat, Transfixed by Todd
abstract: A sofa on which Abraham Lincoln is thought to have sat while wooing Mary Todd has been refurbished for a parlor at an 1830s house in Springfield, Ill.
lead_paragraph: An unprepossessing 1830s couch that witnessed the 1840 courtship of Abraham Lincoln and Mary Todd is returning to one of her relatives’ parlors with its chipped mahogany trim and torn upholstery repaired.

headline: A Catalog of Cancer Genes That’s Done, or Just a Start
abstract: As the Cancer Genome Atlas project, started in 2005, comes to an end, scientists are debating where cancer research should go next.
lead_paragraph: Cancer is a disease of genes gone wrong. When certain genes mutate, they make cells behave in odd ways. The cells divide swiftly, they hide from the immune system that could kill them and they gain the nourishment they need to develop into tumors.

headline: North of Tokyo, Exploring the Sacred and Scenic
abstract: Temples and shrines co-star with waterfalls and mountains in Nikko, two and and a half hours from Tokyo by train.
lead_paragraph: To the right of the path, a fast-rushing river, blue and white, sped through a secluded gorge, breaking into rapids over dark rocks and tumbling over the occasional waterfall. To the left, a long line of timeworn Buddhist statues sat with their backs to a steep wooded bank, inviting passers-by to share their contemplation.

headline: Answer to Puerto Rico’s Debt Woes? It’s Complicated
abstract: Puerto Rico is in a jam, writes Stephen J. Lubben. It is not considered a state, which means it can’t resort to bankruptcy to deal with its debt problems. Nor is it a sovereign nation, which means it can’t rely on sovereign immunity.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico is in something of a jam at the moment.

headline: Legislation Merging Russia’s 2 Top Courts Stokes Worries
abstract: A new law is the final step in dismantling the Supreme Arbitration Court, which rules on business disputes, and incorporating it into the Supreme Court, the top criminal and civil judicial body.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday signed legislation merging Russia’s two top courts in a controversial decision seen by many as meant to consolidate the Kremlin’s power over the country’s judicial system.

headline: Senate Fails to Pass Three-Month Extension of Jobless Aid
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Senate failed to move forward on a three-month extension of assistance for the long-term unemployed on Thursday, dealing a setback to President Obama’s economic agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate failed to move forward on a three-month extension of assistance for the long-term unemployed on Thursday, leaving it unlikely that Congress would approve the measure soon while undercutting a key aspect of President Obama’s economic recovery plan.

keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Economy']

lead_paragraph: I wrote yesterday about my frustration with the various liberal responses to the Congressional Budget Office’s take on Obamacare and workforce participation, but this piece, from the sensible-centrist Ron Fournier, is actually much more exasperating:

headline: New Cord for Electric Vehicles Offers Charge-Anywhere Versatility
abstract: Able to plug into any 120- or 240-volt outlet, AeroVironment’s TurboCord is said to charge a battery E.V. in six hours, or a plug-in hybrid in three.
lead_paragraph: Range anxiety and limited charging infrastructure are among the reasons some consumers don’t consider buying an electric vehicle. Those two concerns are related, because if there’s no place to charge an E.V., that affects the distance a driver can travel.

headline: Ideas to Make Retirement Possible
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Individual Retirement Accounts', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: One proposal would bring back pensions while a plan by the Obama administration would give younger people a break on market risk.
lead_paragraph: Who killed pensions? Can they be resurrected?

headline: U.S. Points to Russia as Diplomats’ Private Call Is Posted on Web
abstract: In the recording, an American assistant secretary of state and the ambassador to Ukraine are heard talking about the political crisis in Kiev.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of taking grief for snooping on foreign leaders, the Obama administration found itself on the other side on Thursday after a private telephone call between two American diplomats appeared on the Internet in a breach that the White House tied to Russia.

lead_paragraph: New York

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Ethics Committee said Thursday that it would conduct a preliminary investigation into the campaign finances of Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington, the House’s highest-ranking Republican woman, who just last week delivered her party’s response to the State of the Union address.

headline: Broadcaster Releases ‘Gay Mountain’ Video for Olympics in Sochi
abstract: Channel 4 in Britain is is celebrating the opening of the Winter Olympics with a change in its corporate logo to rainbow colors, and a promotional advertisement to applaud the gay and straight athletes who are taking part.
lead_paragraph: A television broadcaster in Britain is celebrating the opening of the Winter Olympics in Sochi with a change in its corporate logo to rainbow colors, and a promotional advertisement that it will air on Friday to applaud the gay and straight athletes who are taking part.

headline: Syrian City to Receive Aid, Officials Say
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: A small step by the Syrian government to ease the plight of civilians in Homs is met with cautious optimism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Syrian government appeared to take a small step to ease the plight of civilians by agreeing to provide humanitarian access to the city of Homs, which has been under siege for over a year, American and United Nations officials said on Thursday.

headline: Should Doctors Wait Longer Before Intervening in Births?
abstract: A new study suggests that doctors may be intervening too soon during the second stage of labor.
lead_paragraph: Having a baby — the actual, in-labor, taking-that-baby-from- womb-to-world stage — takes time. As much as many of us feel that the lack of an easy mechanism to complete that process is something of a human design flaw, most women will labor for hours during delivery. How many hours depends on a range of natural factors (first births, for example, tend to take longer). It depends, too, on the willingness of any attending clinicians to let labor continue before intervening with oxytocin, forceps, vacuum or a cesarean.

headline: Romance at Arm’s Length
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Social Media', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: When the messy parts of us aren’t on display from the beginning of a relationship, it’s hard to catch up.
lead_paragraph: IN Spike Jonze’s mesmerizing new movie “Her,” a man falls in love with a sultry-voiced computer operating system whose presence in the film is so lifelike you have to keep reminding yourself she doesn’t actually exist. To make it easier for the audience to believe that a computer might be able to mimic human thought, emotion and speech so convincingly, Mr. Jonze sets his story in the not-so-distant future.

headline: ‘The Age of Small Things’
abstract: All the objects in this absorbing, cheerfully eclectic grab bag of a show have one thing and little else in common: smallness.
lead_paragraph: Dodge Gallery

headline: Robert Bechtle
abstract: Mr. Bechtle manipulates light and simplifies forms so as to undercut the seeming randomness of his compositions.
lead_paragraph: Gladstone Gallery

abstract: The Carlyle Group is paying $3.2 billion for the unit, which produces a range of products used in shipping and transportation.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:40 p.m. | Illinois Tool Works has agreed to sell its industrial packaging unit to the Carlyle Group for $3.2 billion, the companies announced on Thursday.

headline: ‘The Wayland Rudd Collection’
abstract: This group show, organized by Yevgeniy Fiks, is based on the little-documented history of the African-American presence in Russia.
lead_paragraph: Winkleman Gallery

headline: Living With Cancer: An Artist’s View
abstract: The cancer paintings of the Canadian artist Robert Pope remind us that the disease, as well as the effort to treat it, can take a toll on the human spirit.
lead_paragraph: Every time I sign a consent form, I wonder how informed I really am. Do physicians — can physicians— convey the consequences of their treatments to cancer patients? Or is this where artists step in?

headline: Lori Ellison
abstract: Few artists do small as well as Lori Ellison. Her miniaturist art is built on doodles, carefully cultivated and meditatively repeated.
lead_paragraph: McKenzie Fine Art Inc.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Bright Eyes at Creatures of the Wind
abstract: Eyes appeared extra white thanks to an underline of an electric shade of blue.
lead_paragraph: You couldn’t help but notice that flash of electric-blue liner peeking out from under models’ eyes at Creatures of the Wind this morning. But its reason for being there? Not entirely obvious. “It’s actually a lighting effect more than anything else,” revealed the makeup artist James Boehmer. “We pulled colors from the collection and eventually landed on this metallic blue since it gives the eyes a lit-from-within effect, and looks great on everyone.” To achieve the special-effects illusion, Boehmer traced a superfine streak of Nars Larger Than Life Long-Wear Eyeliner in Khao San Road on the waterline — that innermost part of the lower lid — so it would “catch the light,” he explained, and “shock the whites of the eyes so they stood out more.” The finished result was a bit ethereal, a bit punk and definitely pretty, even if that wasn’t the point.

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
abstract: Designers discuss their work on recent covers, including one for a new edition of Kafka’s “Metamorphosis.”
lead_paragraph: In the latest installment of “Before and After,” book designers discuss recent examples of their work: early concepts for a cover as well as the final design that ended up on the book.

headline: Hayley Tompkins: ‘Space Kitchen’
abstract: Ms. Tompkins has made a point of painting on anything but canvas — mobile phones, tree branches, spoons, scraps of found wood.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Kreps Gallery

headline: If Nature’s a Generous Benefactor, a Girl Can’t Help Sharing Her Gifts
abstract: The 1962 musical “Little Me,” starring Rachel York, Judy Kaye and Christian Borle, begins the season for the Encores! concert revival series.
lead_paragraph: If it is possible to leer sweetly, then that’s what they’re doing this weekend at City Center, where a likable if long-winded production of “Little Me” is running through Sunday. The Encores! concert revival of this 1962 musical manages to wipe the smirk off the face of a show about the rise and rise of a woman whose greatest assets are her mammary glands.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Finnish Goalie’s Mask Runs Afoul of I.O.C. Rules
abstract: The I.O.C. asked Noora Raty, the star goalie of Finland’s women’s hockey team, to cover a patriotic slogan on the back of her goalie mask.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — On her Olympic mask, the Finnish goaltender Noora Raty included the words “Hakkaa paalle,” which loosely translates to “Cut them down.” It is a battle cry with roots that go back four centuries, to the Thirty Years’ War, and it has become the national team mantra, something the players recite before every game.

headline: Anatomy: 'The Broken Circle Breakdown'
abstract: Felix van Groeningen narrates a musical sequence from "The Broken Circle Breakdown."
lead_paragraph: Felix van Groeningen narrates a musical sequence from "The Broken Circle Breakdown."

headline: For ‘Top Chef,’ a New Season of Cruises
abstract: Celebrity Cruises’ “Top Chef at Sea” will include four themed trips in 2014.
lead_paragraph: The Bravo television show “Top Chef” may repeat the basic concept each season, but the actual show is quite different every time nonetheless. It follows, then, that rather than simply reproduce “Top Chef: The Cruise,” a Celebrity Cruises charter that set sail last spring, allowing cruisers to fraternize with former contestants on the competition show, the network and the cruise line have partnered on a new venture in 2014.

headline: Olympic Dreams, Financial Reality
abstract: The 2014 Olympics in Sochi are estimated to be the most expensive yet. While host cities hope the games will bring in a profit, they have more often than not created long-term economic burdens.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 Olympics in Sochi are estimated to be the most expensive yet. While host cities hope the games will bring in a profit, they have more often than not created long-term economic burdens.

headline: The Olympics: A Costly Feel-Good Moment
abstract: The Games are often billed as a boon for the host, a bonanza of tourism and television time. But host countries don’t always benefit economically.
lead_paragraph: Even before the Olympic torch reached Sochi on Wednesday — after a 39,000-mile journey, the longest in the history of the Games — another Olympic record had already been shattered: the cost of the Games.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘The Broken Circle Breakdown’
abstract: Felix van Groeningen narrates a scene from his Belgian drama.
lead_paragraph: The Belgian drama “The Broken Circle Breakdown” follows the relationship that develops between a tattoo artist (Veerle Baetens) and a bluegrass musician (Johan Heldenbergh). The film was nominated for an Academy Award in the foreign-language category and is also available on demand this week. In this video, the director Felix van Groeningen narrates a scene from the film, where the two leads share a musical moment. They perform the song “The Boy Who Wouldn’t Hoe Corn,” first as a couple in their bedroom, then transitioning to a band rehearsal and finally in front of an audience onstage. Mr. Van Groeningen discusses some of his ideas behind the sequence.

headline: Letters: ‘My Life in Middlemarch’
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Rebecca Mead’s book about George Eliot’s masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: Glorious George

headline: Correcting the Film Version of a Sensational Story
abstract: In “Riding the Midnight Express With Billy Hayes,” Mr. Hayes recounts his prison ordeal in Turkey, and how it differed from the Oliver Stone screenplay for the movie.
lead_paragraph: There is intrinsic power in escape stories; consider films like “Papillon” or “Escape From Alcatraz.” With “Riding the Midnight Express With Billy Hayes,” the writer Billy Hayes tells his own. It’s been presented before: in “Midnight Express,” his 1976 memoir about five years he spent imprisoned in Turkey for trying to smuggle hashish, and in the 1978 movie adaptation. But as he makes clear in this one-man show, the movie omits much of his ordeal, and what it does present has, shall we say, a high degree of historical revisionism.

headline: The Ringing Sounds of ‘Dallas Buyers Club’
abstract: Scott Takeda and Matthew McConaughey in “Dallas Buyers Club.”
lead_paragraph: “Gravity” had a score that had to transcend the soundless void of space. “Dallas Buyers Club,” set in the 1980s in Texas, when there was no shortage of crescendo-ed pop songs and drifting ballads to set the scene, had almost no score at all.

headline: Excerpt: 'Bronx Bombers'
abstract: A scene from the new Broadway play about the New York Yankees.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the new Broadway play about the New York Yankees.

headline: Its Space Is No Object
abstract: At this diminutive restaurant in Carroll Gardens, it’s best to come with a party large enough to order every seafood dish.
lead_paragraph: The kitchen measures 3 feet by 5 feet and has no oven, only a few induction burners and a sandwich press. There is barely room for the two men in black aprons (the chef, Andrew D’Ambrosi, and his sous-chef, Anthony Mongeluzzi) who toil, heads bowed, behind a long glass case filled with gleaming slabs of raw fish.

headline: Looking Beyond the Canonical Masterpieces
abstract: “This England,” a program of four works performed by the American Symphony Orchestra, seeks to revisit some less-performed compositions.
lead_paragraph: Leon Botstein, the conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra, is right. Classical music has far too long been in thrall to the cult of the masterpiece, the idea that the arts exist more or less solely for the purpose of identifying and codifying a canon of great works.

headline: Skating at Home, Plushenko Has Already Won
abstract: Plushenko, with three Olympic medals and an untold number of surgical screws, finished second in the short program of the team figure skating event, which made its debut.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — On Thursday night, the first great Russian star competed at the first Russian Winter Olympics. The eager crowd was disappointingly small at the Iceberg Skating Palace, but Evgeni Plushenko never needed a big audience. He could put on a show in a phone booth.

headline: Coal-Flavored Water
abstract: The recent waste leak from an old coal-fired power plant in North Carolina should serve as a wakeup call to federal officials.
lead_paragraph: The recent waste leak from an old coal-fired power plant in North Carolina should serve as a wakeup call to federal officials who have been far too slow and timid about regulating the disposal of coal ash.

headline: ‘Cordial and Friendly’ Session as Pakistan and Taliban Open Talks
abstract: Representatives from the Pakistani government and the Taliban described their first formal negotiating session as “cordial,” with the hope of more peace talks being scheduled this month.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani government officials and Taliban representatives made their first formal contact on Thursday, each side handing the other a wish list as they began talks to end a debilitating conflict that has ravaged the country for years.

headline: Off-the-Field Fumbles and Passes
abstract: Poems about football “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org.
lead_paragraph: Traditionally, and in no particular order, Super Bowl Sunday tends to result in hangovers, gambling losses and chatter about the commercials. But what about romance? Can the big game inspire big love? The answer appears to be yes; at least according to the personal ads on Craigslist. The following poems about the erotic possibilities of the Super Bowl were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.com. They are printed verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

headline: A Fashion Meet-and-Greet With the Mayor
abstract: Bill de Blasio introduced himself to the fashion world today at a Council of Fashion Designers of America event.
lead_paragraph: The fashion industry and New York Mayor Bill de Blasio are officially in the getting-to-know-you phase of their relationship.

headline: A Sentimental Education
abstract: Writers in a variety of genres share the books that taught them about love — and a few that led them memorably astray.
lead_paragraph: Recent studies suggest that reading literature may make us smarter and more empathic, even more civic-minded. But what can literature tell us about love? Writers in a variety of genres share the books that taught them about love — and a few that led them memorably astray.

headline: Costello Tagliapietra: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: De Blasio Appoints Chirlane McCray, His Wife, to Lead Nonprofit Group
abstract: Introducing her as “my best friend in the world, my closest confidante, my No. 1 adviser,” Mayor Bill de Blasio announced at a news conference that he was naming his wife, Chirlane McCray, the chairwoman of the Mayor’s Fund to Advance New York City.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has at times teased his appointees about their diminutive statures, or in one case, an eye patch. But he had not, before Thursday, flirtatiously pinched a prominent official while announcing her new role. Or kissed her twice — on the lips — or given her a high-five.

headline: White Pine Trees Provide Canopy and Carpet
abstract: In New York City, it is far more common to find them in isolation than in dense groves, but there are one or two places where they proliferate.
lead_paragraph: There are few places on earth as silent or as fragrant as a grove of white pines. Showering down from above, the trees’ soft needles form a springy, thick carpet suffused with the bracing smell of pine resin. Mature pine groves have been accurately described as cathedral-like, the trees’ spires forming a dense canopy that effectively blocks out direct light and much ambient noise. Tangibly mysterious places, groves of pines frequently shelter wintering wildlife like owls and small mammals. Winter seems to be just a little more forgiving under the pine boughs.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kosovo and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos form Kosovo, South Africa, Israel and South Sudan.
lead_paragraph: Photos form Kosovo, South Africa, Jerusalem and South Sudan.

headline: Classic Lensman, Using Full Palette
abstract: The war photographer Robert Capa, best known for his stark black-and-white images, also worked with color film, as “Capa in Color” at the International Center of Photography shows.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the greatest revelation provided by “Capa in Color” is not that Robert Capa, best known as a war photographer, shot in color film. It is that he shot in color frequently, honing his technical facility and trying to get the work published in magazines that began printing color photographs in the late 1930s. In letters, wall texts and magazine layouts displayed in this exhibition at the International Center of Photography, however, you sense Capa’s enthusiasm for color bumping up against various conventions and commercial demands.

headline: How Ben Horowitz Avoided an Options Backdating Scandal
abstract: Ben Horowitz, a co-founder of the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, said in a blog post on Thursday that he narrowly avoided getting caught up in the options backdating investigations that swept corporate America in 2006.
lead_paragraph: Just by listening to his favorite rappers, Ben Horowitz has absorbed many tales of run-ins and near run-ins with the law. But the prominent Silicon Valley investor also lived one of his own.

headline: Second Shot
abstract: An aging photographer rents a rural cottage and reignites sparks of creativity and desire.
lead_paragraph: There comes a moment in every novelist’s career when she sloughs off the weight of the past — the conventions and obsessions, the stylistic fallbacks and linguistic tics, the influence of early masters — and ventures into new territory, breaking free into a marriage of tone and style, of plot and characterization, that’s utterly her own. Anna Quindlen’s marvelous romantic comedy of manners is just such a book.

headline: Seeing the Show With Their Ears
abstract: Watching “The Lion King” with the help of D-Scriptive, a technology that delivers real-time narrations to blind theatergoers.
lead_paragraph: “I DON’T know why you people have to go to the movies,” the man had barked. “You won’t get anything out of it anyway.”

headline: Postapocalyptic Survival Stories
abstract: In “After the Dark,” a philosophy teacher guides college students through hypothetical postapocalyptic events.
lead_paragraph: Like a high-minded “Choose Your Own Adventure” tale or a feature-length scenario from the holodeck of “Star Trek,” the risible “After the Dark” posits a number of postapocalyptic survival stories. Why choose one end of the world when you can safely have several by presenting them as lesson plans in a classroom?

headline: A Martian View of Our Pale Dot
abstract: Earth as (barely) seen from Mars.
lead_paragraph: Talk about small is beautiful.

headline: Ralph Kiner, Slugger Who Became a Voice of the Mets, Dies at 91
abstract: Kiner led the National League in home runs every year from 1946 to 1952, spent half a century broadcasting Mets games and was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1975.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Kiner, baseball’s vastly undersung slugger, who belted more home runs than anyone else over his 10-year career but whose achievements in the batter’s box were obscured by his decades in the broadcast booth, where he was one of the game’s most recognizable personalities, died on Thursday at home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Twitter’s Stock Crashes Back to Reality
abstract: Shares of the social network dropped 24 percent on Thursday following the company’s financial results, which disclosed a slowdown in user growth and declines in usage by existing users. However, the company also showed strong growth in advertising revenue, suggesting that if it fixes the user problem, it would have bright prospects.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s stock plunged on Thursday, dropping 24 percent to close at $50.05 a share, after a fourth-quarter earnings report on Wednesday showed significant declines in usage and a slowdown in the growth of the new users.

headline: Artists on Artists | Richard Tuttle on Frederic Remington, Purveyor of Wild West Nostalgia
abstract: The lauded Post-Minimalist sculptor heaps unexpected praise on the man who created the iconic bronze “The Broncho Buster,” currently featured in an exhibition about the American West at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: The Post-Minimalist sculptor Richard Tuttle is known for transforming humble materials like cloth, wire and plastic bags into something unexpected and new. Whether he’s nailing a bit of frayed rope to a wall or using a doormat, lumber and Kraft paper to build an Arp-like construction on the floor, he always creates work that is anti-monumental and abstract, as evidenced by “Looking for the Map,” at Pace Gallery on East 57th Street (Feb. 7 – March 15), which showcases 11 studies for his installation next October at Tate Modern’s Turbine Hall.

headline: When a Form Is Given Its Room to Play
abstract: The exhibition “A World of Its Own” uses a range of works from the Museum of Modern Art collection to explore how photographers over the years innovated their styles in the studio.
lead_paragraph: Something old, something new, nothing borrowed and not enough color. A variation on the venerable bridal dress code pretty much sums up the Museum of Modern Art’s latest foray into its photography collection, “A World of Its Own: Photographic Practices in the Studio.” In turn, the title of this fabulous yet irritating survey offers its own variation — on the name of Virginia Woolf’s famous essay about female independence, “A Room of One’s Own” — but the show itself, which opens on Saturday, dazzles but often seems slow and repetitive.

headline: Repaying Home Equity Loans
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Home Equity Loans', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: If you opened a home-equity line of credit during the housing bubble, you should brace for stiff increases in monthly payments.
lead_paragraph: Borrowers who opened home-equity lines of credit at the height of the housing bubble should brace for stiff increases in their monthly payments.

headline: At Wellesley, Debate Over a Statue in Briefs
abstract: Tony Matelli’s sculpture “Sleepwalker” has prompted a petition from two students at Wellesley College.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When Sruthi Narayanan, a Wellesley College senior, first saw a nearly naked man who appeared to be stumbling on campus, she assumed he was a drunk, about to be arrested.

headline: One-Acts From Young Playwrights
abstract: Candy Land, Risk and Life: Longtime board games inspired the bill for an evening of works by young playwrights, supported by Ars Nova.
lead_paragraph: Here in the 21st century, the Miser would have expected the two young gentlemen sharing his abode to be leagues beyond the analog board games that enriched the Miser’s childhood. Yet their Christmas lists included throwbacks like Battleship and Monopoly. There is obviously some lingering appeal to those flat, rectangular-boxed ensembles of cheap cardboard and plastic.

headline: Multiple Exposures, Looking Both Ways
abstract: Michael Snow’s work, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, stretches back to the 1960s, but some of it seems startlingly current.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In Michael Snow’s 45-minute film “Wavelength” (1967), the camera gradually zooms in on a wall in his studio. “Wavelength” is a classic of experimental cinema, but it ends with a photograph and might, in a way, be one. That interpretation is encouraged, at any rate, by “Michael Snow: Photo-Centric,” an engaging survey of his photography at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

headline: Mapping Clinton’s Trajectory
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “H R C” by Jonathan Allen and Amie Parnes is a largely sympathetic portrayal of Hillary Rodham Clinton as a smart and tireless A student, supportive of her teammates, loyal to President Obama.
lead_paragraph: Many people who worked with Hillary Rodham Clinton, from low-level aides in the State Department up to President Obama, “found themselves liking her more with each interaction, even if they had been worked over,” the authors of “H R C” write. They quote a member of Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates’s inner circle, who somewhat patronizingly describes it as traversing the “stages of Hillary”: “You know, you first dread the prospect of working with her, then you sort of begrudgingly begin to respect her, then you outright respect her and her incredible work ethic. You know, she’s inexhaustible, she’s tough-minded, and then you come to actually start to like her, and you just can’t believe it, but you actually like this person, and she’s charming and she’s funny and she’s interesting and she’s inquisitive and she’s engaging.”

headline: Writing Was on the Wall, and Some Still Remains
abstract: As told by the Museum of the City of New York’s exhibition “City as Canvas” and its catalog, the story of New York graffiti’s rise and fall is fascinating.
lead_paragraph: Some of my most vivid memories from occasional visits to New York in the late 1970s and early ’80s are of the graffiti-covered trains roaring through the city’s subway system. With their giant, pneumatic, spray-painted letters spelling names like Crash and Daze against apocalyptic backgrounds, those unauthorized moving murals amazed me. I thought they were beautiful and inspiring.

headline: A-Team Tracks Nazi Plunder
abstract: In “The Monuments Men,” George Clooney stars as an art historian who leads a quirky crew in a World War II operation to recover troves of artworks stolen by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: And here we thought that George Clooney was this era’s Cary Grant even if, with his squinty smile and no-sweat insouciance, he’s really closer to Clark Gable. As it turns out, Mr. Clooney seems to have been harboring a desire to tap into his inner Gregory Peck — noble, stolid, dull — as he does in “The Monuments Men,” which he both directed and stars in. It was Peck who led the team of World War II Allied saboteurs in “The Guns of Navarone,” one of those men-on-a-mission movies, a subgenre that includes everything from “The Dirty Dozen” to the “Ocean’s Eleven” trilogy, which starred Mr. Clooney in a fizzier, less sanctimonious mode.

headline: Off the Runway
abstract: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Senate Confirms One of Its Own as Ambassador to China
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Max Baucus, who has represented Montana since 1978, was an architect of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted 96 to 0 on Thursday to confirm Senator Max Baucus as the new ambassador to China.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 6
abstract: Freestyle skiing, figure skating, and a new sport — slopestyle snowboarding — on the first day of competition at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Freestyle skiing, figure skating, and a new sport — slopestyle snowboarding — on the first day of competition at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics.

headline: Olympic-ish Sport for Tyros Like Us
abstract: Synchronized ice skating, which isn’t yet an Olympic sport, offers a way for New Yorkers to fulfill Olympic dreams.
lead_paragraph: THE Winter Olympic Games are here, which means it’s time once again for couch-dwelling Americans not only to become instant experts in sports they barely knew existed, but also to ponder going out and trying them.

headline: Bryan Greenberg at Richard Chai
abstract: “I worked with Richard on ‘How to Make It in America,’ the actor said, “and I wanted to support him.”
lead_paragraph: It was quite the heartthrob lineup at Richard Chai’s fall 2014 show at Lincoln Center on Thursday morning. Seatmates Zachary Quinto, Bryan Greenberg and Joe Jonas (the latter doing “no press”), slid into their front-row assignments a few minutes after 11 a.m. Perhaps Mr. Greenberg, dressed in a dark leather jacket with quilting details, was in familiar territory, having once worked in the fashion industry — well, on screen anyway.

headline: Troubles With the Condo Board
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Boards of Directors']
abstract: Subjects include corrupt condo boards; improvements in rent-controlled apartments and what happens when your rental building is sold.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Legal Troubles Barely Subdue a Bitcoin Evangelist’s Sermons
abstract: Charles Shrem, the Bitcoin enthusiast, says he hopes one day to return to the world of the virtual currency, maybe as its chief aficianado.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks before his arrest at Kennedy Airport, Charles Shrem was standing behind the Manhattan bar he invested in with some of his Bitcoin fortune, buzzing about his big plans for the virtual currency and himself.

headline: Know-Nothings, Meet the Do-Nothings
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: John Boehner cast doubt on the possibility of passing an immigration bill this year.
lead_paragraph: Today Speaker John Boehner cast doubt on the possibility of the House passing immigration legislation this year, probably dashing whatever slim hopes there were for a deal.

headline: The Uses and Abuses of CT Scans
abstract: Sampling the many responses to an Op-Ed essay, “We Are Giving Ourselves Cancer.”

headline: CVS vs. Tobacco
abstract: Sheelah A. Feinberg of the N.Y.C. Coalition for a Smoke-Free City responds to a Business Day article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Times Minute | Ex-SAC Trader Convicted
abstract: A jury finds SAC Capital Advisors’ Matthew Martoma guilty in an insider trading case. Also on the Minute, “Japan’s Beethoven” confesses and Jay Leno’s last “Tonight” show.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

abstract: Senator Sherrod Brown responds to an article about greater transparency at the Federal Reserve.

abstract: Michael Mulgrew of the teachers’ union writes that it is time for a solution that includes taxpayers and schoolchildren.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Notes of John Paul II
abstract: John C. Hirsh of Georgetown writes that the controversial decision to publish the pope’s papers rather than burn them as ordered in his will was the right one.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Samuragochi’s Work, Now in Question
abstract: Mamoru Samuragochi, who won fame for overcoming deafness to write music, confessed many of his best-known works were ghostwritten. Then his ghostwriter said he was not actually deaf, either.
lead_paragraph: Mamoru Samuragochi, who won fame for overcoming deafness to write music, confessed many of his best-known works were ghostwritten. Then his ghostwriter said he was not actually deaf, either.

abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: New York Fashion Week Street Style: Day 1
abstract: Street-style photos from our NYTimesFashion Instagram account.
lead_paragraph: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for New York Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

headline: New York Fashion Week: BCBG Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Did Mother, Maybe, Not Know Best?
abstract: She always vehemently insisted that I didn’t need to get married, didn’t need a man.
lead_paragraph: After two decades of saying I would never get married, I did. I changed my mind one Sunday while sitting at my desk in front of my computer, as happily unmarried as ever.

headline: Giving and Forgiving
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Families and Family Life', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Addressing matters of a forgotten gift, loans to family, an unwanted match and entry-level job woes.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I are dear friends with a couple we cherish. At our son’s bar mitzvah last October, they approached my wife and told her they had forgotten their gift and would get it to us. When they came to dinner two weeks later, they had forgotten it again. We have seen them several times since, but the topic no longer comes up. We accept that they are never giving a gift; we love them anyway. Still, after every evening together, my wife points out the elephant in the room: “Still no gift.” How do we get past this, so it’s no longer on our minds? Should we say something?

headline: Eichmann’s Rabbi Gazes Backward
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Claude Lanzmann’s latest film, “The Last of the Unjust,” focuses on Benjamin Murmelstein but is a more personal film than Mr. Lanzmann’s previous works.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most haunting and enduring feature of “Shoah,” Claude Lanzmann’s nine-and-a-half-hour documentary — the closest thing to a definitive cinematic work on the Nazis’ mass murder of European Jews we are likely to have — is its dogged commitment to the present tense. Filmed mostly in the 1970s in some of the places where the killing was planned and carried out, “Shoah,” released in 1985, relies on face-to-face, after-the-fact testimony rather than archival footage or dramatic reconstruction. It is thus simultaneously about the imperative to remember and the inadequacy of memory. A masterpiece of historical detective work, the film is also a philosophical exploration of a gap that has only grown wider in the years since its release.

headline: This Is Your Captain Singing
abstract: Having rarely chosen to perform opera in recent years, Mark Padmore seems to be savoring a major role in “Billy Budd,” opening Friday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Singing careers tend to follow a pattern: early study, conservatory, a young artists’ program, smaller parts, larger ones, little-known companies, famous ones. A soprano who does the Third Norn in Wagner’s “Götterdämmerung” might, if she’s lucky, eventually graduate to Brünnhilde.

headline: Theater Listings for Feb. 7-13
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Ex-Brokerage Executives Charged With Fraud
abstract: The owner and two executives of the WJB Capital Group were arrested on Thursday and accused of defrauding at least 15 investors out of more than $11 million during the waning days of their now-defunct brokerage company.
lead_paragraph: The owner and two executives of the WJB Capital Group were arrested on Thursday and charged with defrauding at least 15 investors out of more than $11 million during the waning days of their now-defunct brokerage company.

headline: Romantic Intensity, Replete With Trills and Flourishes
abstract: A young Ukrainian violinist, Aleksey Semenenko, plays to his strengths in an appearance at Merkin Hall.
lead_paragraph: Even by the reliably high standards of the Young Concert Artists series, which has been promoting gifted young musicians since 1961, the performance on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall by the Ukrainian violinist Aleksey Semenenko proved particularly rewarding.

headline: Fashion Sketches and Cartwheel Practice With Betsey Johnson
abstract: On Sundays when the fashion designer is not planning a show, she typically relaxes with her daughter and grandchildren.
lead_paragraph: When Betsey Johnson, the celebrated fashion designer who, at 71, still does cartwheels on the runway, has a show in the works, as she does on Feb. 12 for Fashion Week 2014 at Lincoln Center, her Sundays are overwhelmed by casting calls for models and by the sudden need for decorative detail like, say, gold lamé rose petals. “I’m in a total panic, with adrenaline and excitement,” said Ms. Johnson, who filed for bankruptcy in 2012 and was later bought out by her friend and fellow designer Steve Madden. On a more typical Sunday — “my day of nothing” — she is happy to do little more than kick around her neighborhood, the Upper East Side, or look after her granddaughters, Layla, 7, and Ella, 5, who live in her apartment building with Ms. Johnson’s daughter, Lulu.

headline: What I Love | Sarabeth Levine
abstract: The co-owner of the restaurants that bear her name lives with her husband on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: The co-owner of the restaurants that bear her name lives with her husband on the Upper West Side.

headline: Where the Real Sarabeth Dines
abstract: Sarabeth Levine, the restaurateur, doesn’t have a fancy kitchen at home.
lead_paragraph: Be prepared to ditch the brogues or stilettos before setting foot in Sarabeth Levine’s immaculate (and she wants to keep it that way) two-bedroom co-op on the Upper West Side.

headline: Comedy Listings for Feb. 7-13
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Threads in the Tapestry, Dark, Bright and Scratchy
abstract: The Freiburg Baroque Orchestra presented the complete Brandenburg Concertos Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the Freiburg Baroque Orchestra, which originated as a conductorless period-instrument ensemble in 1987, has ventured beyond its original brief with well-received interpretations of 19th-century works, often in collaboration with noted conductors. Its performance of the complete Brandenburg Concertos by Bach at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday marked a return to its core mission. But the concert had a subdued quality in which fine solos could not make up for the overall lackluster sound and uneven performance.

headline: Movie Listings for Feb. 7-13
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Feb. 7-13
abstract: A selected guide to performances of garage rock, hip-hop, electronic dance music, post-punk and more in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: After a Bad Breakup, Anything Goes
abstract: “Love & Air Sex,” which follows two couples whose relationships have recently dissolved, is set in a city teeming with singles and air sex competitions.
lead_paragraph: Under its contemporary facade of buzzing cellphones and potty-mouthed insults, Bryan Poyser’s “Love & Air Sex” is a traditional romantic comedy that is desperate to please. Although the main characters, in their 20s and early 30s, communicate mostly via text message, often in sexually graphic detail, they are the same vulnerable relationship seekers they have always been but with extra mileage on their pedometers.

headline: Words Spoken and Sung in Service of Freedom
abstract: “Bringing Human Rights Home,” a benefit concert for Amnesty International, featured Imagine Dragons and other bands at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: The most powerful performance at “Bringing Human Rights Home,” a benefit concert for Amnesty International at Barclays Center on Wednesday night, didn’t need drums or electric guitars.

lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: As Seen on TV, a Medical Mystery Involving Hip Implants Is Solved
abstract: Two leading medical journals published case studies of the same puzzling ailment that, in one of the cases, was unraveled with the help of clues from the popular television show “House.”
lead_paragraph: By a strange coincidence, two leading medical journals on Thursday published case studies of the same arcane medical mystery. In one, doctors solved the riddle only after the patient, a middle-aged woman, got so sick she had to have a heart transplant. But in the other, a physician who teaches at the University of Marburg in Germany found the clues in Season 7, Episode 11, of the Fox television show “House.”

abstract: A guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: What to Look For in Friday’s Jobs Report
abstract: Economists expect the report for January to bounce back to recent norms after a big dip in December, but several factors complicate forecasting.
lead_paragraph: Did hiring pick up in January, or are we in for a repeat of December’s disappointing jobs report?

headline: Facebook and Football
abstract: Yes, every day humans post billions of likes and send trillions of messages, but there is a connective power in sports that goes beyond pixels.
lead_paragraph: The digital clench has never been stronger. This week, 10 years since the founding of Facebook, some new numbers showed just how much the social network produced in Mark Zuckerberg’s Harvard dorm has changed us all. Can I share?

headline: Veteran Actors To Dress Up For ‘Casa Valentina’
abstract: Patrick Page and Reed Birney are among those in the cast of Harvey Fierstein’s play, set to begin performances April 1 at Manhattan Theater Club.
lead_paragraph: An lineup of theater veterans, including Reed Birney (“Picnic”), John Cullum (“The Scottsboro Boys”), Patrick Page (“Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”), and Larry Pine (“The Designated Mourner”), will be among the ensemble cast in Harvey Fierstein’s new Broadway play “Casa Valentina” this spring, the producers announced on Thursday.

headline: Now They’ll Love Me, a Twin Sister Schemes
abstract: “The Pretty One” stars Zoe Kazan as a pair of twins, one mousy and insecure, the other vivacious. When the popular twin dies in a car accident, her sister decides to assume her identity.
lead_paragraph: In “The Pretty One,” Jenée LaMarque’s first feature, Zoe Kazan plays identical twins of contrasting temperament. Audrey, alluded to in the title, has a cute haircut, fashionable clothes and an exciting life in a city that might be Los Angeles. (The film is too coy to be specific about such things.) Her sister, Laurel, mousy and odd, lives with their widowed father (John Carroll Lynch) in a rambling house in a quirky town where she helps him paint copies of famous artworks.
