headline: There Can Be Frightening Things in the Canadian Woods
abstract: “Vic + Flo Saw a Bear,” starring Pierrette Robitaille and Romane Bohringer, starts with eccentric humor and ends as a scary tale of revenge.
lead_paragraph: The Québécois director Denis Côté throws a tight frame around his characters in “Vic + Flo Saw a Bear,” nearly boxing them in. That makes sense for this funny-eccentric, funny-scary story of two female ex-cons who having once been holed up together in prison are now holed up in a house in the deep woods. There’s a once-upon- a-time feel to both the location and the movie, which had its premiere at the 2013 Berlin International Film Festival, where it won an award. The title may sound like a children’s book and the bear may be metaphoric, but make no mistake: This is a story with surprisingly great, big teeth.

headline: How to Stop Heroin Deaths
abstract: An antidote to heroin overdose exists and should be made widely available.
lead_paragraph: PHILIP SEYMOUR HOFFMAN, who died of an apparent heroin overdose on Sunday, was just one of hundreds of New Yorkers who fall victim to this drug each year. Heroin-related deaths increased 84 percent from 2010 to 2012 in New York City and occur at a higher rate — 52 percent — than overdose deaths involving any other substance.

abstract: “The Attorney” is based on a notorious 1981 case of government oppression and has been a blockbuster in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: Shopping for a Bra With Betsey Johnson
abstract: A photographer shadows Betsey Johnson as she shops for a bra and works with models.
lead_paragraph: “How do I look with breasts?” asked Betsey Johnson, holding a push-up bra clasped over her shirt in a Victoria’s Secret showroom. I took several photos in quick succession, suspecting that it would not be long before security asked me to stop.

headline: West Bank: U.N. Staff Ends Strike
abstract: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency, the body that provides assistance to Palestinian refugees, announced that a two-month strike by its employees in the West Bank had ended.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency, the body that provides assistance to Palestinian refugees, announced Thursday that a two-month strike by its 4,500 employees in the West Bank had ended. The strike, over pay and other issues, kept more than 50,000 children out of school, closed down free health services and raised tensions in the volatile refugee camps. The United Nations agency said in a statement that its director of operations in the West Bank and a representative of the area’s staff union had signed a document outlining measures to improve conditions for the staff, without elaborating. The statement praised the government of the Palestinian Authority for its mediation efforts and said the agency was “looking forward to the immediate resumption of all services.”

headline: Italy: Toxic Waste Law Enacted
abstract: President Giorgio Napolitano signed an emergency law to tackle environmental crimes and the damage produced by the illegal dumping or burning of waste.
lead_paragraph: In the first strong legislative response to the dumping crisis in the southern region of Campania, President Giorgio Napolitano signed an emergency law on Thursday to tackle environmental crimes and the damage produced by the illegal dumping or burning of waste. Under the new law, burning garbage without authorization is a crime punishable by up to five years in prison. In the vast area north of Naples where the Camorra mafia has buried toxic waste for decades, health and environmental authorities will have to carry out tests on the agricultural fields to measure the toxicity levels in the soil. Parliament allocated about $676 million for the cleanup, and police officers or soldiers will conduct antidumping patrols. The law includes measures to clean up the environmental damage produced by a steel plant in the southern city of Taranto.

headline: Highlights From Our Social Feeds at NYFW, Day 1

headline: France: Seized Ivory Destroyed
abstract: In an effort to deter poachers and traffickers, France publicly destroyed a stock of about three tons of confiscated ivory from the tusks of African elephants on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to deter poachers and traffickers, France publicly destroyed a stock of about three tons of confiscated ivory from the tusks of African elephants on Thursday, making it the first European country to take such a step. The ivory was crushed in a large machine at a ceremony at the foot of the Eiffel Tower presided over by Environment Minister Philippe Martin. The impounded ivory included 698 elephant tusks that the police had confiscated and stockpiled since the 1990s. The operation was part of President François Hollande’s plan to “send a clear and precise message” against poachers, traffickers and buyers and “to show the French government’s solidarity to African countries,” the Environment Ministry said. The United States and China, ivory’s biggest market, have also destroyed seized ivory to help stem the illicit trade that endangers the survival of the elephants.

headline: Officers and Office Workers Find an Oasis in National Grid Café
abstract: A utility company’s cafeteria hidden away in the MetroTech complex in Brooklyn is a popular lunch destination for police officers, firefighters and others.
lead_paragraph: It looked like a casting call for “Law & Order: SVU.” Packs of police officers sat at long, white tables, chatting about arrests, ballistic tests and vacation time. Nearby, two fire dispatchers hurriedly ate meatloaf and pastrami while checking their phones. Other diners seemed to be standard-issue office workers, eating brown-bag lunches and drinking cups of coffee.

headline: A Woman and Her Tortoise on Quest for Family
abstract: In “Demi-Soeur,” a middle-age woman finds herself alone with her tortoise when her mother and caretaker dies.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Muchelney Under Water
abstract: Dozens of homes are flooded and much of the west coast of England and Wales are under fresh flood alerts.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of homes are flooded and much of the west coast of England and Wales are under fresh flood alerts.

headline: Accustomed to Floods, but ‘Nothing Like This,’ in Southern England
abstract: In parts of England, the wettest January on record has left whole villages flooded and residents cut off from vital services. And it is still raining.
lead_paragraph: MUCHELNEY, England — The village of Muchelney has become an island. Cars stand idle; locals canoe across the flooded plain or take a police boat down the road-turned-river connecting them to what they now call the “mainland.” About halfway, a silver sedan bobs in the water, its roof barely protruding. It has been there for five weeks.

headline: Letting the Kids in on the Charitable Giving Conversation
abstract: One family’s experiment in letting their daughter help decide how to divide the money it gives away each year.
lead_paragraph: Money is one of the most powerful tools we have to teach children the values and virtues we want them to adopt. Given how many of our own values are wrapped up in charitable giving, it makes sense to bring the kids in on some of the decision making.

abstract: “Nurse 3D” tells the tale of a vengeful, scantily clad member of the profession, played by Paz de la Huerta, and the men she murders.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: Uterine Surgical Technique Is Linked to Abnormal Growths and Cancer Spread
abstract: A power device used in the procedure called morcellation can scatter bits of fibroid tissue or undetected cancer cells around the abdomen.
lead_paragraph: Concerns are increasing among doctors about the safety of a procedure performed on tens of thousands of women a year in the United States who undergo surgery to remove fibroid tumors from the uterus, or to remove the entire uterus.

lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The brother of Iran’s president walked into Tehran’s only Jewish hospital on Thursday, delivering a surprise donation along with the message that the Health Ministry would give more attention to hospitals that traditionally serve Christian and Jewish Iranians.

headline: ‘There’s a Dark Cloud Over Our Sport’
abstract: Doping remains a scourge of endurance sports like cross-country skiing and biathlon, where testing and suspensions seem to be no match for temptation.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — When Don Catlin, the former head of the U.C.L.A. Olympic Analytical Laboratory, heard that three biathletes had tested positive for a “nonspecific substance” about a week before the Olympics, I could hear him sigh over the phone.

headline: Motion Is Filed to Silence Prosecutor in Sept. 11 Case
abstract: A defense lawyer for Walid bin Attash has filed the motion, saying that a prosecutor’s comments on a Sept. 11 case were undermining the right of her client to a fair trial.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The defense team lawyers for one of the five Guantánamo Bay detainees charged with aiding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks are seeking to muzzle the chief military commissions prosecutor, saying that his comments defending the tribunals system — including in a recent “60 Minutes” interview — are unethical and that they are undermining their client’s right to a fair trial.

keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Diesel Power', 'Electric Light and Power']

headline: Richard Hayman, a Pops Concert Figure in St. Louis and Boston, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Hayman was an American arranger of pops concerts in Boston, a harmonica player and a conductor.
lead_paragraph: Richard Hayman, who began his career as a harmonica player and went on to become the conductor of pops concerts in St. Louis and the arranger of pops concerts in Boston, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: U.S. Issues Penalties Over Violations of Iran Sanctions
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Nearly three dozen companies and individuals were accused of evading the economic measures — an indication that the United States was not relaxing its pressure despite a temporary nuclear agreement.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration penalized nearly three dozen companies and individuals in eight countries on Thursday, accusing them of evading Iranian sanctions. It was the administration’s most extensive enforcement action to target Iran since a temporary international agreement on that country’s disputed nuclear program was completed in November and put into effect last month.

headline: Death in the Afternoon, Then Drinks
abstract: At the Morbid Anatomy Library and Museum in Brooklyn, visitors can browse a collection of objects and books on death. Afterward, museum-goers can find their appetite at Runner & Stone.
lead_paragraph: Between the fetid Gowanus Canal and the South Brooklyn Casket Company lies the Morbid Anatomy Library and Museum. Two thousand books, whose titles include “Corpses, Coffins and Crypts” and “Stuffed Animals and Pickled Heads,” share 200 square feet with inert squirrels, a fetal possum, a human skeleton and about 25 live visitors on any given Saturday afternoon.

abstract: There’s less congressional appetite for brinkmanship this time, but the government has only a few weeks’ worth of cash left.

lead_paragraph: “I’ve never worked a day in my life,” Rene Ricard, then 32, wrote in an essay for The New York Times Op-Ed page in 1978. “If I did it would probably ruin my career, which at the moment is something of a cross between a butterfly and a lap dog.”

headline: Health, Work, Lies
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: From all the brouhaha over this week’s C.B.O. report, it seems as if job losses are the new death panels when it comes to attacking health reform.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Douglas Elmendorf, the director of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, said the obvious: losing your job and choosing to work less aren’t the same thing. If you lose your job, you suffer immense personal and financial hardship. If, on the other hand, you choose to work less and spend more time with your family, “we don’t sympathize. We say congratulations.”

headline: F.D.A. Tightens Rules on Infant Formula
keywords: ['Infant Formulas', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The changes require that the companies meet so-called good manufacturing practices, which include testing for contamination from pathogens.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration updated safety requirements for producers of infant formula. The changes require companies to tighten their quality control procedures and reporting requirements. They also require that the companies meet so-called good manufacturing practices, which include testing for contamination from pathogens like salmonella. Most companies already meet those standards, but the rule will give the agency more control over enforcing them. The rule will also ensure that infant formula contains all federally required nutrients. The changes will be open to public comment for 45 days.

headline: Luger’s Name Matches the One on His Waistband
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Luge Racing', 'Lingerie and Underwear', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Fuahea Semi won a contest to be Tonga’s first winter Olympian and took the name of Bruno Banani, an underwear company well known in Europe for unusual marketing campaigns.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Bruno Banani is a German men’s underwear company. The brand, which features styles with colorful names like Booty Bass, Rusty Iron and Blockbuster (it can come as a G-string), is well known in Europe for its unusual marketing campaigns. The company has sent its garments underwater to the Bermuda Triangle, and in 1998, Russian astronauts wore the underwear aboard a space station.

headline: Other People’s Views
abstract: When should you care about what your peers and friends think and when should you not?
lead_paragraph: Let’s say you’re turning 40 and you realize you want to leave accounting and become a hip-hop artist. People will say you’re having a pathetic midlife crisis, but should you do it anyway?

headline: In Royal Drama, Spain Sees Its Reality Reflected
abstract: The legal scandal involving Princess Cristina and her husband over money laundering has become a morality tale of excess whose themes are common enough in a country where the receding economic tide after 2008 exposed corruption and mismanagement.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Once upon a time, Spain’s Princess Cristina and her husband lived a life of royal splendor. Ensconced in a hillside mansion with a saltwater swimming pool outside Barcelona, they jaunted off to sailing regattas and charity balls with the Spanish elite.

headline: A Bellows Painting Moves From Virginia to London
abstract: The National Gallery in London has purchased its first major American painting, George Bellows’s “Men of the Docks,” for $25.5 million.
lead_paragraph: In 1920, students at what was then the Randolph-Macon Woman’s College in Lynchburg, Va., raised $2,500 to buy George Bellows’s “Men of the Docks,” a 1912 painting of workers milling around an ocean liner docked at the Brooklyn waterfront. It became the centerpiece of the college’s Maier Museum of Art.

headline: Brain-Dead, a Canadian Woman Remains a Silent Partner Awaiting Birth
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: The family of Robyn Benson, who sustained a fatal brain hemorrhage, hopes her fetus will mature enough to be delivered.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Nearly six weeks after a pregnant Canadian woman was declared brain-dead, she remains on life support in Victoria, British Columbia, because of her family’s hope that her fetus will mature enough to be delivered. The decision by Robyn Benson’s family to try to deliver her child has drawn growing attention in Canada, largely because of a series of moving blog posts by her husband, Dylan Benson.

headline: Counting Cars in a Comic Pileup
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Stanley Kramer’s mega-comedy “It’s a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World” (1963), now on Blu-ray, is as huge as its Ultra Panavision format is wide.
lead_paragraph: Coming soon to your iPhone (if you’re so inclined): the 70-millimeter Ultra Panavision Hollywood roadshow.

headline: Huge Leak of Coal Ash Slows at North Carolina Power Plant
abstract: The massive leak of toxic coal ash into the Dan River had dwindled, but workers had yet to seal the breach in a drainage pipe where the leak was detected more than four days ago.
lead_paragraph: A massive leak of toxic coal ash from a retired North Carolina power plant into a neighboring river dwindled on Thursday, utility officials said, but hundreds of workers had yet to seal the breach in a drainage pipe where the leak was detected more than four days ago.

headline: Three Sensational Deaths and Two Notable Lives
abstract: Recently published books with New York ties include an account of the 1937 triple murder by Robert George Irwin, a biography of Shirley Chisholm and a memoir by Harry Rosenfield.
lead_paragraph: The manhunt evoked the Lindbergh kidnapping case; the debate over the insanity defense echoed Harry K. Thaw’s trial for shooting Stanford White; the principal actors included Thomas Dewey and the defense lawyer Samuel Leibowitz. The triple murder on Beekman Place in 1937 by Robert George Irwin has been largely forgotten, but it captivated America for months.

headline: A Moving Glass Box Conquers Uneven Terrain at a Subway Station
abstract: A new elevator at the Dyckman Street station in Upper Manhattan will “open transportation to the city,” said a member of the board of Disability in Action.
lead_paragraph: The first subway line of New York, the No. 1, burst from the ground at a place in Upper Manhattan called Fort George Hill around March 1904, having traveled two miles north, from around 158th Street, through solid rock.

headline: Past Fictions, a Lack of Trust and No Deal in SAC Case
abstract: Mathew Martoma seemed to be able to cut a deal with prosecutors, but his handling of a years-old episode involving fabrication of documents casts doubt on his trustworthiness, James B. Stewart writes in the Common Sense column.
lead_paragraph: The guilty verdict on Thursday against the former SAC trader Mathew Martoma only deepens a mystery about the case: Given the overwhelming evidence against him, why did he fight the charges of insider trading, risking a lengthy prison term, rather than make a deal with the government to cooperate in return for leniency?

headline: The Homogeneous Federal Bench
abstract: Federal courtrooms are overwhelmingly run by former prosecutors and corporate lawyers. The courts need a more professionally diverse cast of judges.
lead_paragraph: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, in a dissent from a 2007 Supreme Court decision that made it harder for women to sue employers for pay discrimination, suggested that the court’s majority was not in “tune with the realities of the workplace.” Her background as general counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union, where she had co-founded the Women’s Rights Project in 1972, surely informed her thinking. Unfortunately, that kind of experience is both less common and more controversial on the federal bench today. If she were being considered for a seat on the court these days, Justice Ginsburg told an audience in 2011, “my A.C.L.U. connection would probably disqualify me.”

headline: Taking Tobacco Off the Shelves
abstract: CVS deserves a big round of applause for deciding to end the sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products at its stores.
lead_paragraph: CVS Caremark, the giant drugstore chain, deserves a big round of applause for deciding to phase out the sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products at its more than 7,600 stores by Oct. 1. The decision will cost the company a substantial amount of money but will place CVS where it and other pharmacy chains belong — on the side of customer health and against a product that still kills 480,000 Americans a year.

headline: Taking Stand, Nagin Defends Acts as Mayor in New Orleans
abstract: In his federal corruption trial, C. Ray Nagin insisted that he never received bribes for awarding city contracts worth millions as it rebuilt after Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — C. Ray Nagin took the stand in his federal corruption trial on Thursday, and under both the genial guidance of his defense lawyer and the unyielding press of a federal prosecutor, defended his conduct as the onetime mayor of this city and insisted he never received bribes for awarding contracts.

headline: Amid Flow of Leaks, Turkey Moves to Crimp Internet
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Censorship', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Many in Turkey see the new laws as an effort to stem leaks in a corruption investigation of the prime minister and those close to him.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Shortly after an audio recording in which Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is said to be heard talking about easing zoning laws for a construction tycoon in exchange for two villas for his family, SoundCloud, the file-sharing site where it was leaked last month, was suddenly unavailable to Internet users in Turkey.

headline: A Spotlight on Mr. Putin’s Russia
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Sochi Olympics should not be a reason to ignore the country’s soul-crushing repression.
lead_paragraph: The Olympic Games that open in Sochi, Russia, on Friday are intended to be the fulfillment of President Vladimir Putin’s quest for prestige and power on the world stage. But the reality of Mr. Putin and the Russia he leads conflicts starkly with Olympic ideals and fundamental human rights. There is no way to ignore the dark side — the soul-crushing repression, the cruel new antigay and blasphemy laws and the corrupt legal system in which political dissidents are sentenced to lengthy terms on false charges.

headline: Malaprops Were Part of the Charm of Kiner, an Enduring Met
abstract: Kiner was a character, a bon vivant, and not an overly polished announcer. His postgame show was required viewing, even if it looked like public access programming.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Kiner had not called many Mets games in the past few years. He did not want to travel much. He was usually at afternoon games for a few innings, maybe 12 or 15 times a season.

headline: Environmental Groups Denounce Arrests of Ecologists Near Olympic Sites
abstract: Arrests of two ecologists in Sochi, Russia, have alarmed environmental groups, which criticized the stringent controls that authorities have placed on public shows of dissent near Olympic sites.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The initial brunt of a police crackdown on protesters at the Winter Olympics — originally expected to target gay rights groups — has instead fallen on environmental activists.

headline: Behind Retreat on Immigration, a Complicated Political Interplay
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Reaching any agreement has become appreciably harder because of a deep Republican reluctance to get caught up in an internal party feud and stomp on their increasingly bright election prospects.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner would sorely like to help engineer an overhaul of immigration policy to bolster his legacy, help his party politically and address a difficult social and economic problem. He just cannot seem to persuade other Republicans, who see the immigration debate as a major threat to their drive to win the Senate and increase their House majority in November.

headline: Mother Pleads Not Guilty in Death of 2-Year-Old
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Ashley Diaz, 28, was charged with second-degree murder and first-degree assault on Thursday in the death of Kevasia Edwards.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 23, Ashley Diaz stood in Queens Family Court with her five children, ages 2 to 10, as a judge reviewed her efforts in parenting classes and therapy sessions mandated by the court after an abuse and neglect investigation two years ago.

headline: On Blog, an Ex-Christie Ally Showed Approach to Politics
abstract: David Wildstein is now the wild card in the scandal surrounding Gov. Chris Christie and the revenge-closings of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge in September.
lead_paragraph: As Wally Edge, political blogger, David Wildstein was so anonymous that when he sold his company, the buyer did not know his real name.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 6, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Designers Carve a Fashion Runway at the Games
abstract: Dressing the athletes who compete in the Winter Olympics is a sport unto itself that provides companies a chance to expose their brands to a global audience.
lead_paragraph: Beyond the thrilling victories and agonizing defeats, the Olympics are a 16-day fashion show, even for fans blithely unaware that the United States Alpine skiing uniforms are meant to evoke the nation’s flag reflected in the water off Fort McHenry the morning after the British bombardment, 200 years ago, that inspired “The Star-Spangled Banner.”

headline: If You Stage It, They Will Come
abstract: Eric Simonson’s “Bronx Bombers,” at Circle in the Square Theater, focuses on Yogi Berra and the 1977 New York Yankees, then brings in stars of other eras as well.
lead_paragraph: Talk about your fantasy baseball team. Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, for starters. Plus Mickey Mantle and Joe DiMaggio. Add the catcher Elston Howard, the first black player on the New York Yankees roster, and throw in the team’s current captain, Derek Jeter.

headline: Fourth-Brightest Star in the Sky
abstract: Friday fun with Ned White.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I struggled with this 66-worder by Ned White, but I wound up liking the struggle. I believe that’s why we have Friday puzzles, right? To both stretch your limits and entertain.

headline: Energy Role Is Lifting Democrat in Louisiana
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Elections, Senate', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: Senator Mary L. Landrieu’s new post as chairwoman of the Senate Energy Committee could help her in what is expected to be a tough re-election fight.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, is set to become chairwoman next week of the Senate Energy Committee, a powerful position that gives her jurisdiction over the oil and gas industry that fuels her state’s economy — and which will be a major source of contributions to Ms. Landrieu’s tough re-election campaign this fall.

headline: Twitter Q. and A. on Olympic Preparations
abstract: David Herszenhorn of The Times answered readers’ questions ahead of the 2014 Winter Olympics.
lead_paragraph: A day before the 2014 Winter Olympics begin in Sochi, Russia, David Herszenhorn, a Times correspondent based in Moscow, answered readers’ questions via Twitter on preparations for the Games. He discussed the importance of security concerns, current U.S.-Russian relations and how those abroad could help Sochi’s threatened stray dogs.

headline: Bench Empty, the Lakers Are Saved by a Technicality
abstract: When Los Angeles center Robert Sacre committed his sixth foul, officials informed the Lakers’ coach of a rule that is rarely invoked: No team can have fewer than five players on the court.
lead_paragraph: There were 3 minutes 32 seconds remaining in the Lakers’ game against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Wednesday when Los Angeles center Robert Sacre committed his sixth foul. Would the Lakers, who at the time had only five healthy players, be forced to play four on five?

headline: Abundance of Snow, Headache to Many, Is a Boon for Hundreds Without Jobs
abstract: The Emergency Snow Laborers program is intended to supplement New York City’s sanitation employees, and has assisted many unemployed men and women this season.
lead_paragraph: Nadji Colon never saw snow until he arrived in the Bronx in his late 20s from his homeland, Puerto Rico. He found it slushy and unpleasant to pick his way through.

headline: In Hong Kong, an Unexploded Bomb Forces Evacuations
abstract: Unexploded World War II bombs are an occasional fact of life in the prosperous and crowded city.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong residents have a lot to contend with. Soaring real estate prices. High pollution levels. Political meddling from mainland China. And, in at least one pricey neighborhood famous for its racetrack, unexploded American ordnance from World War II.

headline: Trial Brings New Scrutiny of Self-Defense Laws
keywords: ['Self-Defense', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: While race is woven into the background of the Florida trial of a man who killed a black teenager, the case appears likely to focus more on the mechanics of the state’s self-defense laws and how juries apply them.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Nearly seven months after a jury acquitted George Zimmerman, whose shooting of an unarmed black teenager made him synonymous with Florida’s so-called Stand Your Ground law, the state’s latest drama involving a fatal burst of gunfire and a claim of self-defense began to play out Thursday in a courtroom here.

headline: The Cohen Connections
abstract: The top hedge fund SAC Capital agreed to plead guilty to insider trading and pay a record $1.2 billion fine. At least eight current or former SAC employees have been convicted or pleaded guilty to insider trading.
lead_paragraph: The top hedge fund SAC Capital agreed to plead guilty to insider trading and pay a record $1.2 billion fine. At least eight current or former SAC employees have been convicted or pleaded guilty to insider trading.

headline: New Hampshire: Deal Reached on Medicaid Expansion
abstract: State senators said Thursday that they had reached a bipartisan deal on a framework to expand Medicaid to about 50,000 low-income adults.
lead_paragraph: State senators said Thursday that they had reached a bipartisan deal on a framework to expand Medicaid to about 50,000 low-income adults. Under the agreement, the state will use federal money to buy private insurance, similar to a method adopted last year in Iowa and Arkansas. Last year, the New Hampshire House passed a bill to expand Medicaid, but the Senate failed to agree on expansion. The House voted again to expand Medicaid in January. The new deal will be drafted into a bill, which will probably be voted on in March. Gov. Maggie Hassan, a Democrat, praised the deal during her State of the State address on Thursday.

headline: Power Failures Are Still Widespread After Storm
abstract: More than 500,000 people in Pennsylvania and Maryland went a second day without electricity on Thursday after heavy ice felled trees and damaged electrical equipment.
lead_paragraph: More than 500,000 people in Pennsylvania and Maryland went a second day without electricity on Thursday as utilities scrambled to restore power after heavy ice felled trees and damaged electrical equipment. Utility companies in Pennsylvania said that about 446,000 customers had no power on Thursday afternoon, a day after a storm knocked out electricity to about 800,000 people. In Maryland, utilities said about 50,000 customers remained in the dark. The companies said most customers would have their lights back by Friday night.

headline: Vasil Bilak, 96, Dies; Czech Communist Encouraged 1968 Soviet Invasion
abstract: Mr. Bilak was a former hard-line communist leader who paved the way for Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968.
lead_paragraph: Vasil Bilak, a former Communist leader in Czechoslovakia who in 1968 encouraged the Soviet Union to invade his country to halt efforts for change that he saw as a threat to socialism, died on Thursday in Bratislava, Slovakia’s capital. He was 96.

headline: Streak Over, Rangers’ Focus Turns to Penguins, Then Sochi
abstract: The Rangers’ bid for a fifth straight victory was halted by Nail Yakupov’s goal against Cam Talbot with 1 minute 38 seconds to play.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers’ drive for a fifth straight victory stalled at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night as they fell to the Edmonton Oilers, 2-1, on Nail Yakupov’s goal with 1 minute 38 seconds to play.

headline: In Trail Blazers, Woodson Sees a Lot to Like
abstract: While Mike Woodson’s team is still figuring things out, Portland, which is 35-14 after Wednesday’s victory over the Knicks, is continuing its surprising rise.
lead_paragraph: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson has had an aggravating season that could soon cost him his job. But amid everything that is going wrong with his team, he has found time to admire how the Portland Trail Blazers go about their business.

headline: Nets Keep Noses in Front Despite Fight From Depleted Spurs
abstract: The Spurs were missing several of their top players because of injuries and illness, but they still led for most of the first half before the Nets took over.
lead_paragraph: The San Antonio Spurs had just 10 players dressed to meet the Nets on Thursday night, and before the evening was done, two of them had blood dripping from their broken noses. They were absurdly depleted, seemingly reduced to a B-list squad. But it hardly mattered.

headline: Past, Future or Alien?
abstract: At a new exhibition in Brooklyn, sci-fi underlies both light homages to geeky pop-culture and artists’ political commentary.
lead_paragraph: “I’m a huge sci-fi nerd,” the curator Ginger Shulick says, “and I’ve been wanting to do an overtly sci-fi-themed show.” So she did. The exhibition, titled “Future/Past,” opens today at the Reverse gallery in Brooklyn and features works by a handful of global artists, some of them clearly speculative-fiction buffs themselves. “You can’t really tell if things are from the past, or if they’re alien or futuristic,” explains Shulick. “I like to present works that raise more questions than leave you with answers.”

headline: California Bill Would Require Antitheft Technology for Cellphones
abstract: A smartphone is sleek, compact and valuable, which makes it the perfect target for a thief. Californian lawmakers want to require cellphone companies to fix that problem.
lead_paragraph: A smartphone is sleek, compact and valuable, which makes it a perfect target for a thief. Californian lawmakers want to require cellphone companies to fix that problem.

headline: The Challenges of Running Responsible Supply Chains
keywords: ['Child Labor', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)']
abstract: Only an effective partnership of owners, local governments and international organizations can create effective safeguards for workers in developing nations, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and headed the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council under President Clinton.

headline: Word of the Day | apolitical
abstract: This word has appeared in 50 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: apolitical •\ˌa-pə-ˈli-ti-kəl\• adjective

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) BEFORE MIDNIGHT (2013) Nine years after rekindling a romance (“Before Sunset”) in Paris that began nine years before that (“Before Sunrise”) in Vienna, Celine (Julie Delpy) and Jesse (Ethan Hawke, above, with Ms. Delpy) are now in Greece, at the end of a summer vacation with their twin daughters (Jennifer and Charlotte Prior) and the son (Seamus Davey-Fitzpatrick) he left behind in Chicago. Jesse wonders if they could move from Paris to the United States to spend more time with his son. Celine sees his question as a demand to make it happen. And so they will fight about this — and the meaning of love, the nature of time and the difference between men and women — throughout the course of a day. “ ‘Before Sunrise,’ ‘Before Sunset’ and ‘Before Midnight’ are modest, charming movies that together add up to the great romantic epic of a generation defined, in the popular mind and our therapists’ offices, by hedged bets, easy ironies and perpetual confusion,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this trilogy from the director Richard Linklater. Celine and Jesse “can get on your nerves almost as much as they get on each other’s,” Mr. Scott added. “We have known them, and they have known each other, for a long time now, but we don’t know, from one moment to the next, what their future will be, or what it is that keeps them going. That kind of uncertainty, a scary fact of life, is something most movies avoid. We prefer the magical thinking of neat endings, tidy plots and clear character arcs. ‘Before Midnight’ is a wonderful paradox: a movie passionately committed to the ideal of imperfection that is itself very close to perfect.”

headline: Mark McMorris on Slopestyle
abstract: Snowboarding’s slopestyle event has been dominated recently by Mark McMorris, a 20-year-old from the flat plains of Saskatchewan, Canada.
lead_paragraph: Snowboarding’s slopestyle event has been dominated recently by Mark McMorris, a 20-year-old from the flat plains of Saskatchewan, Canada.

headline: Ban on Liquids for Carry-Ons on Direct U.S.-Russia Flights
abstract: No liquids, gels, aerosols or powders will be allowed in carry-on bags on nonstop flights between the United States and Russia during the Winter Olympics in Sochi.
lead_paragraph: Passengers on nonstop flights between the United States and Russia have been prohibited from packing liquids, gels, aerosols or powders in their carry-on bags during the Winter Olympic Games in Sochi under a new directive issued by the United States Transportation Security Administration.

headline: Woodson Shows Frustration
abstract: A day after the Knicks lost their third straight game, Coach Mike Woodson reiterated that he felt the team was capable of making the playoffs. But he also showed some frustration.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Knicks lost their third straight game, Coach Mike Woodson reiterated that he felt the team was capable of making the playoffs. But he also showed some frustration.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 7, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Report Says North Korea Is Improving Missile Capabilities
abstract: By expanding its main satellite launch site, North Korea may be able to accommodate larger rockets for its ballistic missile program.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has made progress in expanding its main satellite launch site, apparently to accommodate larger rockets that outside analysts said the country was developing for its intercontinental ballistic missile program, an American research institute reported Thursday.

headline: That ‘Old Guy’? He’s Retired Now, Right?
abstract: Jay Leno said goodbye after 22 years on the “Tonight” show in a send-off reflecting how his impact differed from that of his predecessor, Johnny Carson.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Carson’s departure from the “Tonight” show in 1992 was an abdication. Jay Leno’s last show, on Thursday, was closer to a retirement party — a bittersweet send-off for a loyal executive pushed out after 22 years.

headline: Amid Raft of Chinese Financial Numbers, One to Watch Carefully
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: China Development Bank, which lends billions for infrastructure projects, has seen its own borrowing costs soar by about 50 percent, adding to the debate over whether the country can defy pessimists and continue to outgrow its neighbors
lead_paragraph: China’s slowing growth and sputtering industrial output have helped fuel a global fall in stock prices this year. Economists are divided on whether ballooning debt in the world’s second-biggest economy will trigger a full-blown financial crisis or whether China, as it has time and again, will manage to defy the pessimists and continue to outgrow its neighbors.

headline: A Homegrown Comic Con Highlights Growth in Local Comics Market
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Books and Literature', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: Attendance at these fan conventions has grown over the past three years, and publishers have taken notice.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — In 2011, a group of comic book lovers in Delhi found it was too expensive to travel to the Comic Con fan conventions overseas and decided to hold their own event at home in the Indian capital.

headline: Criticizing the Vatican
abstract: The United Nations released a report this week sharply critical of the Vatican’s response to child abuse.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations this week released a report sharply critical of the Vatican’s response to child abuse.

headline: Petition to Nullify Thai Election Is Rejected in Setback for Opposition
abstract: Days after the election, there are contradictory signals about which side has the upper hand in Thailand’s debilitating power struggle.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A petition to nullify Thailand’s general election was rejected Friday on procedural grounds by the country’s ombudsman, a setback for the opposition Democrat Party, which is allied with protesters trying to overthrow the government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.

headline: Stranded Travelers Start ‘Riot’ at Airport
abstract: Flight delays caused by days of heavy snowfall came at the peak travel season for China, when billions of journeys are made over 40 days around the Lunar New Year holiday.
lead_paragraph: Holiday travel stress became too much for some of the 2,000 stranded passengers at an airport in central China, with some passengers smashing computers and causing a “riot,” the Global Times newspaper has reported.

abstract: Can you place the correct number of commas in a sentence from the article?

headline: Steel Maker ArcelorMittal Narrows Its Net Loss
abstract: The chief executive, Lakshmi Mittal, said he saw signs that the world economy was ticking up and he expected earnings to improve this year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Not long after Lakshmi Mittal formed ArcelorMittal through the takeover of Arcelor in 2006, the financial crisis dragged global demand for steel sharply down, hitting the company’s European base particularly hard. ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, has been on the ropes ever since, running losses in some years and struggling with an outsize debt burden.

headline: Indonesia Grants Parole to Australian Woman in Drug Case
abstract: The 20-year sentence given to Schapelle Corby for bringing marijuana to Bali angered many Australians and caused a diplomatic row with Canberra.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The Indonesian government on Friday granted parole to an Australian woman whose conviction in 2005 for smuggling drugs into the Indonesian resort island of Bali caused a diplomatic row between the two nations and public outrage in her home country.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Teaching Creativity
abstract: Why is creativity becoming more prized in the work world and more frequently taught in schools?
lead_paragraph: In “Learning to Think Outside the Box,” Laura Pappano writes about how and why creativity has become an academic discipline. Use the article and the related slide show of student projects, above, to answer the questions below.

headline: Alex Webb Looks Back in Black-and-White
abstract: The photographer Alex Webb is known for his color work, but his black-and-white 1976 project documenting Mound Bayou, Miss., is the one he regrets not completing.
lead_paragraph: Alex Webb was a 23-year-old photographer in 1976 when he put his belongings in a New York darkroom and headed south in his beat-up Volvo, which doubled as his bedroom. His experiences led his meanderings, and he occasionally picked up assignments that financed his work.

headline: What Are Five Everyday Problems That Bother You, and What Can You Do About Them?
abstract: Do a version of the assignment students in Introduction to Creative Studies at Buffalo State College did, and tell us what you find.
lead_paragraph: Do you hate it when you go into a public bathroom stall and the lock won’t work? How about when businesses you need close too early, or when umbrellas are more hindrance than help? What are some everyday problems, small or large, that really annoy you?

headline: Fashion Week Preview: Day 2
abstract: Fashion Week officially began Thursday — for proof, look no further than the legions mugging for street-style photographers in front of Lincoln Center — but Friday is the day when the action really revs up.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Week officially began Thursday — for proof, look no further than the legions mugging for street-style photographers in front of Lincoln Center — but Friday is the day when the action really revs up.
