abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: comparing human and rodent weather forecasters, a sunny day, and the vice president insults La Guardia Airport.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:01 a.m.

headline: In Signing Farm Bill, Obama Extols Rural Growth
abstract: The president signed the $956 billion farm bill after four years of debate in Congress over farm subsidies and Republican efforts to cut financing for food stamps.
lead_paragraph: EAST LANSING, Mich. — President Obama signed the $956 billion farm bill on Friday at Michigan State University, where he extolled the benefits of a thriving agricultural sector for the nation’s overall economy.

headline: Supporters Call for Investigation Into Death of Chinese Activist’s Father
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The authorities in Shandong Province told family members that Xue Fushun committed suicide by jumping from the fourth story of a procurator’s office building in the city of Qufu.
lead_paragraph: Chinese human rights lawyers have raised questions about the death of an activist’s father who fell from a government building while under detention in late January. The authorities have told family members that Xue Fushun committed suicide by jumping from the fourth story of a procurator’s office building in the city of Qufu in the northeastern province of Shandong.

headline: Report Finds Growth in Agriculture Economy
abstract: The Council of Economic Advisers released a report on Friday highlighting the growth in the agriculture economy as President Obama is set to sign the farm bill.
lead_paragraph: The Council of Economic Advisers released a report on Friday highlighting the growth in the agriculture economy as President Obama is set to sign the farm bill.

headline: The End of Snow?
abstract: Nothing besides a national policy shift on how we create and consume energy will keep our mountains white.
lead_paragraph: OVER the next two weeks, hundreds of millions of people will watch Americans like Ted Ligety and Mikaela Shiffrin ski for gold on the downhill alpine course. Television crews will pan across epic vistas of the rugged Caucasus Mountains, draped with brilliant white ski slopes. What viewers might not see is the 16 million cubic feet of snow that was stored under insulated blankets last year to make sure those slopes remained white, or the hundreds of snow-making guns that have been running around the clock to keep them that way.

headline: Without Scotland, Premier Says, Britain Would Be Less ‘Great’
abstract: The British prime minister appealed to Scottish voters to reject independence in a referendum that will be held in September.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Marking the formal beginning of the British government’s campaign to preserve the United Kingdom, Prime Minister David Cameron made an emotional plea to Scots to vote in September to remain in the union, saying on Friday that without Scotland, Britain would be “deeply diminished.”

headline: A New Vision for ‘Prince Igor’ at the Met
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s dreamlike new production of “Prince Igor,” directed by Dmitri Tcherniakov, reorders scenes and inserts filmed episodes to bring the audience eerily close to the characters.
lead_paragraph: It is common in contemporary opera for a director to update the setting of a story and impose some interpretive concept on a piece. Most directors do not go so far, however, as to reorder scenes, tweak the plot, excise whole ensembles and interpolate musical numbers from a different score.

headline: A Hotelier Corrects His Testimony on the Impact of the Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business', 'Working Hours']
abstract: In his initial testimony, Peter Anastos said that his company would make sure that its new hires worked fewer than 30 hours a week so that they would not qualify for health insurance.
lead_paragraph: Last week, The Agenda reported on a House committee hearing that examined a provision in the Affordable Care Act that requires companies with at least 50 employees to offer health insurance to any employee who works at least 30 hours a week. It appeared that a bill to raise that threshold to 40 hours, the Save American Workers Act, could be on a fast track to debate by the full House, and on Tuesday the legislation took a big step forward when it passed out of the Ways and Means Committee.

headline: Highlights: The Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony
abstract: The 2014 Winter Olympics began on Friday with a majestic opening ceremony that embraced classical music, ballet and certain aspects of the Soviet past.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times covered the Winter Olympics opening ceremony from inside of Fisht Olympic Stadium in Sochi — live as it happened, not on tape delay.

headline: A Virtual Airline, a Real Crash
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Start-ups']
abstract: As entrepreneurs invade regulated industries and evade traditional watchdogs, the question of who is responsible when something goes wrong looms large. Airlines that don’t really exist in the traditional sense might be a particular problem.
lead_paragraph: Europe is full of small upstart airlines, and Manx2, which served eight destinations in Britain and Ireland, certainly seemed to be one of them. Its planes were emblazoned with its name. The flight attendants said, “Welcome aboard this Manx2 flight.” Even the headrests and pilots’ ties advertised the airline.

headline: A Guilty Verdict for Former SAC Trader
abstract: Mathew Martoma, the former trader at SAC Capital Advisors, was convicted of insider trading. | Mr. Martoma’s handling of a years-old episode involving fabrication of documents cast doubt on his trustworthiness and may have hindered a deal with prosecutors. | Legal troubles are doing little to stem a Bitcoin leader’s exuberance. | Apple buys $14 billion of its own shares.
lead_paragraph: FORMER SAC TRADER CONVICTED OF INSIDER TRADING  |  A federal jury in Manhattan found Mathew Martoma guilty on Thursday of insider trading , culminating a case that prosecutors had never thought would go to trial in the first place. The case may be the last criminal case to emerge from a decade-long investigation of Steven A. Cohen and his SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund, Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. Mr. Martoma, who is married and has three young children, is expected to face a prison sentence of seven to 10 years.

headline: British Regulator Hires Former Goldman and UBS Executive
abstract: James Kelly, who will advise the Financial Conduct Authority, is the latest industry veteran to join the regulator in the past year as it bulks up its expertise.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain said Friday that it had hired a former managing director at Goldman Sachs and UBS as an adviser in its division that supervises wholesale banking and investment management.

headline: U.S. Issues Penalties Over Violations of Iran Sanctions
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Nearly three dozen companies and individuals were accused of evading the economic measures — an indication that the United States was not relaxing its pressure despite a temporary nuclear agreement.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration penalized nearly three dozen companies and individuals in eight countries on Thursday, accusing them of evading Iranian sanctions. It was the administration’s most extensive enforcement action to target Iran since a temporary international agreement on that country’s disputed nuclear program was completed in November and put into effect last month.

headline: Talking to Children About Consent
abstract: A sexual health educator discusses the kinds of conversations parents should have with their children about sexual misconduct.
lead_paragraph: HAVING THAT TALK with your child — the one about sex, babies and putting some distance between those two things — can be daunting. Now, a string of high-profile sexual assaults on campuses has put the topic of consent on the table. Debra Herbenick, a sexual health educator at the Kinsey Institute at Indiana University, discusses the kinds of conversations parents should have with their children about sexual misconduct.

headline: Making Consent Cool
abstract: Once the stuff of “Saturday Night Live” parody, “consent” today is proudly emblazoned on T-shirts, underwear and condom wrappers.
lead_paragraph: IN 1993, when Antioch College introduced its “ask first” policy — mandating that students solicit permission for every intimate advance, including kissing — the policy was widely derided.

headline: Stepping Up to Stop Sexual Assault
abstract: The goal of bystander intervention programs is to block bad behavior before it crosses the line from drunken partying to rape.
lead_paragraph: BYSTANDER INTERVENTION is so easy to grasp, even by the most inexperienced college freshman, that the program may well be the best hope for reducing sexual assaults on campuses. Mostly it is common sense: If a drunk young man at a party is pawing a drunk young woman, then someone nearby (the bystander) needs to step in (intervene) and get one of them out of there. Of course, that can be tricky at times.

headline: Syria Says It Will Stay in Peace Talks as Homs Evacuation Begins
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: Civilians who had been trapped in the Old City neighborhood of Homs began to leave under an agreement negotiated by the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Syrian government announced on Friday that it would participate in next round of Geneva peace talks aimed at ending the country’s civil war, as civilians trapped in a rebel-controlled part of Homs, one of the conflict’s urban epicenters, began trickling out under a deal negotiated by the United Nations.

headline: If Cineastes Could Pick the Oscar Winners
abstract: Kevin B. Lee of Fandor analyzes the races the way some fans would prefer: which work truly deserves an award?
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to the Oscars, prognosticators trip over themselves to divine the Academy’s choices — rather than, as cineastes might hope, showcase the most deserving performers and filmmakers of the year.

headline: Homeless and Too Tired for Food
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Beneath a poster promoting lottery riches, a volunteer tried to interest two sleeping men in free sandwiches from his cart.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Payroll Data Shows a Lag in Wages, Not Just Hiring
abstract: Payrolls in the United States grew by 113,000 in January, a weaker-than-expected increase that experts said may signal a loss of momentum in the economy. The unemployment rate dipped to 6.6 percent.
lead_paragraph: For the more than 10 million Americans who are out of work, finding a job is hard. For the 145 million or so who are employed, getting a raise is even harder.

headline: Biden Shows Interest in Another Presidential Run
abstract: The vice president said he was considering a third run for the White House.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said in an interview broadcast on Friday that he would run for president “if no one else” can fight for the domestic, economic and foreign policy issues he cares about and said he would decide by mid-2015.

headline: Apollo Profit Fell 36% in Fourth Quarter
abstract: Apollo Global Management was a big seller of its holdings last year, but that wasn’t enough to lift the private equity giant’s profit for the final three months of 2013.
lead_paragraph: Apollo Global Management was a big seller of its holdings last year, but that wasn’t enough to lift the private equity giant’s profit for the final three months of 2013.

headline: Desperate for Clean Air, Delhi Residents Experiment with Solutions
abstract: Air purifiers, indoor plants and masks are just some of the ways people in the Indian capital have tried to keep pollution out of their lungs.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — For some worried expatriates and Indians, the battle to keep pollution out of their homes and their lungs started well before renewed media coverage in the past weeks unofficially crowned New Delhi as the world’s most polluted city.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | January 2014
abstract: The latest monthly collection of stories about young people published in The Times.
lead_paragraph: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot. For ideas on how to use this series in your classroom, visit our lesson “Teaching With ‘Teenagers in The Times.’ ”

headline: Objects | Temptation Arises
abstract: Introducing clutches and sandals so elegantly modern and quietly sexy that they seem downright practical.
lead_paragraph: Introducing clutches and sandals so elegantly modern and quietly sexy that they seem downright practical.

headline: Now, the Sentencing for Martoma
abstract: Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital, faces what could possibly be a record prison sentence for insider trading, given the size of the trading gains by the hedge fund, writes Peter J. Henning in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: The impressive streak of 79 insider trading convictions won by the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan now includes Mathew Martoma, who dealt directly with the hedge fund titan Steven A. Cohen. But the verdict is unlikely to bring prosecutors any closer to what is apparently their aim: to bring criminal charges against Mr. Cohen.

headline: Second-Order Journalism
abstract: About CBOghazi.
lead_paragraph: Dave Weigel looks at the disastrous initial media handling of the CBO report — CBOghazi, hah! — and addresses one of my pet peeves: reporting that skips right past the actual policy issues to speculation about how they will play politically. I think of this as “second-order” reporting, and it’s almost always a bad thing.

headline: Car Seats Save Lives but Are Still Underused
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Children and Childhood', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Seat Belts']
abstract: More than 9,000 children under 12 died in motor vehicle accidents between 2002 and 2011, in many cases because they were not properly restrained in child seats or seat belts.
lead_paragraph: More than 9,000 children under 12 died in motor vehicle accidents from 2002 to 2011, in many cases because they were not properly restrained in child seats or seatbelts.

headline: Mixed Messages in the Employment Data
abstract: The two surveys in the monthly unemployment report offered different pictures for January, and one-time factors further clouded any conclusions.
lead_paragraph: It is generally wise to take individual jobs reports with a grain of salt. The data, as the economists say, are “noisy” – imperfect estimates subject to revision. But the jobs report for January might need an extra few shakes of the shaker.

headline: For the Sake of Argument: Writing Persuasively to Craft Short, Evidence-Based Editorials
abstract: In this lesson, we offer suggestions on how to guide students through the process when writing editorials — from brainstorming a topic to publishing their work — and all the steps in between.
lead_paragraph: Overview | How can writing change people’s worldview? How can it influence public opinion? How can it lead to meaningful action?

headline: Sticky Situations
abstract: Keynes and wages, again.
lead_paragraph: David Glasner has a thoughtful post about wage stickiness, a favorite topic of mine. And he is partially right in suggesting that there has been a bit of a role reversal regarding the role of sticky wages in recessions: Keynes asserted that wage flexibility would not help, but Keynes’s self-proclaimed heirs ended up putting downward nominal wage rigidity at the core of their analysis. By the way, this didn’t start with the New Keynesians; way back in the 1940s Franco Modigliani had already taught us to think that everything depended on M/w, the ratio of the money supply to the wage rate.

headline: Rewards Program Tries Bitcoin
abstract: The travel rewards website PointsHound is now including the virtual currency Bitcoin as a payout option.
lead_paragraph: PointsHound, a website that rewards travel reservations with frequent-flier miles and hotel points, is using the virtual currency Bitcoinin its payout system.

headline: Leaked Recordings Lay Bare E.U. and U.S. Divisions in Goals for Ukraine
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany criticized an assistant secretary of state’s undiplomatic comment on European efforts to resolve the political crisis in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — “Really Pretty Stupid” was the headline chosen by the august Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung on Friday to describe an editorial on the latest eruption between the United States and Europe, this time over who should take the lead in trying to calm the crisis in Ukraine, and how to do it.

headline: The North Carolina Story
abstract: It’s not about jobs.
lead_paragraph: I’ve just praised Dave Weigel for his take on CBOghazi, the media debacle over health reform and employment. Let me now give an example of how even someone as good and skeptical as Weigel can be (slightly) taken in by right-wing spin. In another fine piece on the health-employment link, Weigel mentions states with falling unemployment, including North Carolina — and appropriately is skeptical about claims for NC’s success. But not skeptical enough! In his footnote he writes:

headline: 36 Hours in Yangon, Myanmar
abstract: The major city of a complicated country, Yangon is hoping to become Southeast Asia’s next boomtown. What can you find during a visit in the meantime? Here’s a look.
lead_paragraph: It’s Myanmar’s moment, and the country’s major city, Yangon (formerly Rangoon), is hoping to become Southeast Asia’s next boomtown. Diplomatic missions, business delegations and tourists have filled Yangon’s hotels since the country’s military government began transferring power to civilian leaders in 2011. The spotlight continues this year as Myanmar, also known as Burma, takes on the chairmanship of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. For now, though, as the road map for laws and reforms is being drawn, the city remains in a kind of urban time warp, still awaiting a much-needed capital infusion to fuel what it hopes to be its renaissance. Golden pagodas, colonial-era buildings, traditional shop houses and moldering jazz-age mansions form a low-rise fabric unique to Asia, the whole stitched together by tree-lined avenues swarming with buses and cars. While ethnic and religious tensions simmer along Myanmar’s borderlands, including in remote Rakhine State, where there have been recent outbreaks of religious violence, Yangon is far from these areas. Still, time will tell whether the city will reclaim its former status as a cosmopolitan capital.

headline: Deep Inside Baz Luhrmann’s Creative Chaos
abstract: Whatever the director decides to do next, there’s a good chance he’ll make up his mind while not wearing pants.
lead_paragraph: Baz Luhrmann likes to say that his life is “a circus run like an army,” and to step into his boudoir is to begin to understand what he means. After noon on a Friday, the 51-year-old auteur is sitting up in bed, his lower half under the covers, silver hair and black T-shirt rumpled from sleep. His wife and frequent creative collaborator, Catherine Martin, known to everyone as C. M., lies curled beside him atop a flax-colored linen duvet. Four assistants occupy chairs around them, all holding laptops. Each of the young people who gather under Luhrmann’s big top has a fantastical back story, at least in his telling. One went to Eton and speaks perfect Chinese; another has a “grandpappy who created a little firm called the C.I.A.” All have areas of concentration — communications, for example, or “moving Baz through time and geography” — and all have been trained in “the Bazmark way,” which means that they carry portable tape recorders to capture his directives and strive always to anticipate his needs. Judging by their alert posture at this moment, something momentous is about to happen. The impish ringmaster is having a vision.

headline: Winter Superpower Gets Its Turn as Olympic Host
abstract: Despite the chaos and controversy leading up to the Sochi Games, that the Winter Olympics are finally being staged in Russia is nothing but logical.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — That the organizers here spent a record $50 billion — capital improvements and alleged baksheesh included — and did not quite get a finished product is difficult to fathom.

headline: All of the Pleasure. None of the Guilt.
abstract: A case for embracing the life of a cultural libertine.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine made a resolution once: No more guilty pleasures. I assumed at first that he meant he would no longer indulge in, you know, the usual cultural indulgences: those movies, books, TV shows, albums, et cetera, that are unabashedly enjoyable (like Miley Cyrus’s “Wrecking Ball”) but that also confer a patina of guilt to the self-conscious cultural consumer even as he’s enjoying them (like Miley Cyrus’s “Wrecking Ball”).

headline: Cecily Strong Is Being Serious
abstract: The “S.N.L.” cast member on finding comedy in drama — and the news.
lead_paragraph: You’re younger than “Saturday Night Live” itself. Were you a comedy nerd as a kid? Totally. I grew up on “S.N.L.,” doing all the sketches on the playground. A friend and I would play these Chicago newscasters that were actually just impressions of the Bears’ “Superfans.” Two 11-year-old girls with fake mustaches — we were joke stealers already.

headline: Pilgrims’ Progress
abstract: The path to the summit of Croagh Patrick in County Mayo, Ireland.
lead_paragraph: In A.D. 441, St. Patrick, Ireland’s patron saint, climbed the third-highest mountain in County Mayo and, according to legend, spent 40 days and nights fasting and praying at its summit. Modern pilgrims inspired by his example still flock to what is now known as Croagh Patrick. The Rev. Charlie McDonnell, a local priest, says that 50 years ago, most climbed the mountain on Reek Sunday, the last Sunday in July. But now, people visit the site every day. Some climb for spiritual reasons, barefoot and clutching rosary beads (Mass is celebrated frequently at the peak), others for their physical health. Even before St. Patrick’s famous ascent, the mountain was a pagan holy spot. “Patrick claimed the mountain for Christianity,” Father McDonnell says. “But we welcome everybody to the mountain. It is a sacred place.” Julie Bosman

headline: Reply All: The 1.26.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: PLANET HILLARY

headline: Sochi vs. Sacha Baron Cohen
abstract: Steven Yeun shares his character’s Michigan background; assessing veteran rom-com duos.
lead_paragraph: Steven Yeun shares his character’s Michigan background; assessing veteran rom-com duos.

headline: The Business-Dinner Spy
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Narcissism', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Restaurants', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Nudism and Nudity']
abstract: Plus: Tipping point and the problem with narcissism.
lead_paragraph: We recently had a teamwork dinner with the head of our division. One of my employees placed his iPhone on the table and recorded the discussion without anyone else knowing. The next day he transcribed what everybody said as a way to hold management accountable for things we’d talked about working on. Was he obliged to get our permission in advance for the recording? NAME WITHHELD, SALT LAKE CITY

headline: Who Made That Planetarium?
keywords: ['Stars and Galaxies', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Inventions and Patents']
abstract: Turning on the stars in an artificial sky.
lead_paragraph: “Late in 1924 there appeared something new under the sun, an apparatus that shows every object in the sky that is visible to the unaided eye, and in a most realistic manner,” wrote the scientist and educator Clyde Fisher a decade after the opening of the world’s first projection planetarium in Munich. “It matters not whether the audience be made up of children or adults, professional people or laymen, the emotional experience is always the same. When the light is gradually diminished bringing on the darkness of night in the dome, and the stars are ‘turned on,’ the audience gasps audibly in surprise at the breathtaking beauty of it.”

headline: U.S. Factory Report May Not Be as Dire as It Looks
abstract: The last time new industrial orders slowed as much as they did in January, the country was on the verge of a double-dip recession. But the recent figures may not portend any such downturn.
lead_paragraph: WORLD markets, already nervous over possibly fragile emerging-market economies, tumbled early this week after a survey of manufacturers in the United States showed a surprising drop in the proportion of companies saying their business was improving. On Monday, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index fell more than 2 percent, suffering its worst day since last June.

headline: As Knicks Fall Back, Amar’e Stoudemire Finds New Vigor
abstract: Stoudemire, who seemed to be losing a battle against age and injuries, credits diet and hard work for helping him recover his game and contribute again.
lead_paragraph: The loss was only seconds old when Amar’e Stoudemire, a towel draped around his neck, approached Giannis Antetokounmpo for a congratulatory handshake and some unsolicited advice.

headline: In the Eye of the Beholder
abstract: In 1988, Thomas Pynchon reviewed “Love in the Time of Cholera,” calling it “shining and heartbreaking.”
lead_paragraph: This week we turn our gaze to love stories, a subject that brought together one of the odder but more distinguished pairings in the Book Review’s history. In 1988, in his review of Gabriel García Márquez’s “Love in the Time of Cholera,” Thomas Pynchon judged that García Márquez wrote “with impassioned control, out of a maniacal serenity.” Calling the book “shining and heartbreaking,” he added it to the ranks of novels that can “return our worn souls to us.”

headline: The Body Politic
abstract: Throughout her 45-year reign, Elizabeth I’s private life was an urgent public concern.
lead_paragraph: It was six yards square and extravagantly swathed in purple and gold, from its velvet headboard and valance to its voluminous damask curtains. The Virgin Queen took it with her when she moved from one royal residence to the next, chased by winter drafts and the inevitable buildup of noisome effluvia emanating from the rudimentary sanitation of her privy. As Anna Whitelock’s “The Queen’s Bed” proves, there is still a new and fascinating vantage from which to consider Elizabeth I. While most historians of the period dissect the body politic, Whitelock doesn’t waste time in the halls of Parliament. Instead, she hastens straight to the boudoir of the queen who chose celibacy as a means of wielding power.

headline: Mash Notes
abstract: The editor of The Times’s Modern Love column teases apart “life’s most mystifying subject.”
lead_paragraph: The Modern Love column in this newspaper is a guilty pleasure for the many and a source of bitter rejection for the few: Over the past nine years only some 350 columns have been published out of 50,000 submissions. Imagine the countless Sunday brunches over which the previous night’s bad date / marital sex problem / unanswered Match.com posting was miserably rehashed, only to be transformed into the most glittering of silver linings: By God, this would make a fantastic Modern Love piece! And then — the flurry of typing, the excited phone calls to friends, the pinching-myself byline — the other shoe drops.

headline: GoPro to Go Public
abstract: GoPro is becoming the latest company to file for a “secret” I.P.O., joining the ranks cloud storage company Box, which began the process last month, and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:32 a.m. | GoPro, the video camera maker favored by extreme athletes and everyday adventurers, said on Friday that it planned to go public.

headline: Bridled Vows
abstract: Jenny Offill’s novel charts the course of a marriage, building the story from fragments, observations and meditations.
lead_paragraph: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Scenes From a Marriage
abstract: A psychologist challenges the common view of the Nixons’ union.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the White House who seek out the well-known portraits of Jacqueline Kennedy and Nancy Reagan — ­eerie, El Greco-like elongations executed by Aaron Shikler — are sometimes surprised to have their attention arrested by Henriette Wyeth Hurd’s rendering of the far-less-chronicled Pat Nixon. The picture was created several years after the Nixons’ abrupt departure from Washington, and only for the sake of the subject’s daughters. The painted Mrs. Nixon seems stricken, ready to brim with tears. If the portrait could speak, it would most likely say what she herself did after the helicopter lifted off from the South Lawn on Aug. 9, 1974: “It’s so sad. It’s so sad.”

headline: Passages
abstract: Interviews with women reveal how their sexual lives alter with their life circumstances.
lead_paragraph: Is the sexual self an essential thing — immutable? Or can the complex matrix of desire change? These questions are fundamental to ideas of behavior and morality. I find myself with a foot in both worlds, willing to argue either point of view. The theme of “Sex After . . . ” — how women’s sexual lives shift over time — is a significant one, rich with possibility.

headline: Love in the Time of Neuroscience
abstract: Sue Johnson introduces a new approach in couples counseling called Emotionally Focused Therapy.
lead_paragraph: In “The Devil’s Dictionary,” Ambrose Bierce defined love as “a temporary insanity curable by marriage.” Enter Sue Johnson, a clinical psychologist and couples therapist who says that relationships are a basic human need and that “a stable, loving relationship is the absolute cornerstone of human happiness and general well-being.” To repair ailing partnerships, she has developed a new approach in marriage counseling called Emotionally Focused Therapy, or EFT, which she introduces in her new book, “Love Sense.”

headline: French Kisses
abstract: Edmund White describes learning to live and love in Paris.
lead_paragraph: “I’ll be gone soon,” Gore Vidal told me, not long before he died. “Then Edmund White can be king.” Queen bee, perhaps?

headline: Le Mariage
abstract: An American teenager’s fleeting romance with Napoleon’s sibling.
lead_paragraph: “Elizabeth Patterson ­Bonaparte was an American celebrity,” ­Carol Berkin declares. Indeed, she was “perhaps the first of her era.” The extraordinary story told in this slim volume goes some way toward justifying that extravagant claim.

headline: Oops, There Goes Another Fall on the Ice
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Falls', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Ice', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Hospitals']
abstract: As New York prepares for a possible third snowfall in seven days, emergency rooms have reported as much as a 300 percent increase in traffic on recent snow days.
lead_paragraph: Conditions in New York City are prime for the antics of Buster Keaton and other masters of the pratfall. But as any number of orthopedists and emergency room doctors in the city can attest, most people do not share Keaton’s grace.

headline: A High-Water Mark for Women, in Retrospect
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: During the worst part of the credit crisis, women had more paid jobs than men for the first time, the Labor Department now says.
lead_paragraph: During the worst part of the credit crisis, women had more paid jobs than men for the first time, the Labor Department now says.

headline: Blythe Masters of JPMorgan Is Said to Decline Advisory Post
abstract: Blythe Masters, the head of the commodities business at JPMorgan Chase, has declined an invitation to join an advisory committee of the C.F.T.C., the agency that regulates futures and swaps trading, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:13 p.m. |

headline: A Conversation on Tobacco and Coal Exports and Moral Responsibility
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Energy and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: A discussion of the moral aspects of trade in tobacco and fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: I sent my recent post on exports of life-shortening tobacco and dirty fossil fuels to a variety of climate and energy scientists and analysts and the result was an interesting email conversation that is excerpted below.

headline: Correspondence Course
abstract: A trans-Atlantic relationship between a reader and a writer grows from their emails.
lead_paragraph: How rewarding to perch on the shoulder of a character Barbara Pym might have conjured — a late bloomer who possesses “brickish stoicism” and brews tea on an Aga. So when the British author Deborah McKinlay takes us to “the depths of the English countryside, in a house that was an advertisement for the English countryside,” we recognize that a Lively voice — à la Penelope, that is — will be reporting with wry detachment and affection.

headline: You Must Remember This
abstract: Michele Zackheim’s elderly protagonist finds reminders of her life and loves in pre-World War II Europe.
lead_paragraph: Michele Zackheim’s books, like treasure hunts, send their narrators scuttling after hidden gems. In “Violette’s Embrace,” an artist travels to Paris to unearth secrets about the writer Violette Leduc. In “Einstein’s Daughter,” Zackheim herself goes abroad to investigate the mysterious fate of the scientist’s illegitimate daughter. And in her new novel, “Last Train to Paris,” an elderly New York journalist named Rose digs through an old trunk of papers that holds reminders of her past life and lost love.

headline: Still in Thrall
abstract: A young curator is haunted by the phantom of her predecessor in this novel inspired by “Rebecca.”
lead_paragraph: “Last night I dreamt I went to Manderley again.” You can probably hear the late Joan Fontaine’s clipped Anglo-American voice declaiming that line in Alfred Hitchcock’s “Rebecca,” the voice of a young woman recalling the strange, wearying and totally dysfunctional secrets that once lay in wait for her.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Robert Harris’s novel “An Officer and a Spy,” at No. 8 on the hardcover fiction list, finds contemporary resonance in the details of the Dreyfus Affair.
lead_paragraph: L’Affaire: Some thriller writers pick a topic and stick with it, more or less: John Grisham writes about lawyers, Brad Thor writes about government agents. Then there’s Robert Harris. He’s hit the list with novels about imperial Rome and World War II, a contemporary political drama, an alternative history in which the Nazis have won the war and a financial thriller about a computer that goes rogue, Kubrick style.

headline: Recovering From Surgery, Wendy Whelan Postpones National Dance Tour
abstract: Wendy Whelan, the longtime New York City Ballet star who has been making a critically acclaimed foray into modern dance, announced Friday that she was postponing a national tour this spring because she needs more time to heal from hip surgery.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Whelan, the longtime New York City Ballet star who has been making a critically acclaimed foray into modern dance, announced Friday that she was postponing a national tour this spring because she needs more time to heal from hip surgery.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ALL JOY AND NO FUN: The Paradox of Modern Parenthood,  by Jennifer Senior. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.) Examining, with bracing honesty and authentic wisdom, what it means to be a parent, Senior presents both interviews and research.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MISSING OUT: In Praise of the Unlived Life,  by Adam Phillips. (Picador, $15.) One of Britain’s foremost psychoanalysts explores the alternative lives “we could be leading but for some reason are not.” Drawing on his own clinical experience and the works of Shakespeare and Freud, D. W. Winnicott and William James, Phillips encourages us to live, as gratifyingly as possible, the life we have, rather than be haunted by the “myth of our potential.”

headline: Sidestepping the Risk of a Privacy Breach
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Consumer Protection', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Personal Finances', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Debit Cards', 'Privacy', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Credit Cards', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: If breaches are nearly inevitable for now, what are your odds of being swept up in all this, and how do you reduce them?
lead_paragraph: This week, we reached the inevitable point in the controversy over the credit and debit card breaches where grim-faced retail executives from Target and Neiman Marcus, industry experts and consumer advocates turned up in Washington. They raised their hands and delivered well-rehearsed statements to our elected representatives.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Lego Movie,’ ‘The Last of the Unjust’ and ‘Vic + Flo Saw a Bear’

lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times movie critics share their thoughts on the Canadian drama “Vic + Flo Saw a Bear,” the animated “Lego Movie” and “The Last of the Unjust,” a documentary. See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Postal Service Reports a Decline in Losses
abstract: The service posted a $354 million net loss in the first quarter of its fiscal year, compared with a $1.3 billion loss the same period in 2012.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aggressive cost cutting and increased revenue from its packing and shipping business helped the Postal Service stem its losses in the first quarter of its fiscal year, which ended Dec. 31.

headline: 64th Berlinale Kicks Off With Premiere of ‘The Grand Budapest Hotel’
abstract: The festival, which runs through Feb. 16 and is funded in large part by the German government, showcases around 400 films from around the world.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The 64th annual Berlin Film Festival opened here on Thursday evening with the gala world premiere of Wes Anderson’s “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” a tender, urbane caper movie set in an imaginary world of interwar Eastern Europe starring Ralph Fiennes and inspired by the Austrian writer Stefan Zweig (1881-1942) and the films of Ernst Lubitsch (1892-1947).

headline: Entering the Era of Private and Semi-Anonymous Apps
abstract: A number of new apps, including Wut, Secret and Confide, are intended to let users either talk secretly or semi-anonymously online.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Web-enabled gadgets should come with a digital Miranda warning. “Anything you say or do online, from a status update to a selfie, can and will be used as evidence against you on the Internet.”

headline: I Was a Tonya Harding Look-Alike
abstract: On the impersonator circuit in the ’90s, I was Harding’s fan and defender — but I might have been using her too.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, I looked exactly like Tonya Harding. Would you have agreed? Doesn’t matter. Because the ultimate decision rested with an expert team of celebrity-look-alike judges assembled by Geraldo Rivera. Let’s put it this way: Twenty years ago, one Tonya did bring home the gold; it is cheap plastic and somewhere in my children’s dress-up box. And it symbolizes the era of my life that, if Olympic judges scored for weirdness, would nail a perfect 6.0.

headline: Hamptons House: Make Mine New
abstract: Today’s buyers want wall-to-wall luxury and every conceivable bell and whistle.
lead_paragraph: In the Hamptons, where million-dollar vacation homes are snapped up like flea-market finds and $10 million spec homes are in such high demand that their developers could moonlight as fortunetellers were they not so busy building more, buying new has become not only the fashion but the first choice. Buying vintage tends to spawn repair and renovation headaches; choosing turnkey promises convenience and five-star amenities.
