headline: Boycotting Israel and the First Amendment
abstract: Common sense seems to be stymying legislation that would undermine free speech in a misguided attempt to appear pro-Israel.
lead_paragraph: Common sense, and maybe a renewed appreciation for first principles, seems to be stymying dangerous legislation that would undermine free speech in a misguided attempt to appear pro-Israel.

headline: Highlights From the Chicago Auto Show
abstract: Subaru, Kia, BMW and Nissan were among the automakers to unveil production vehicles and concepts at this year’s show.
lead_paragraph: With the Detroit auto show already growing smaller in the rearview mirror, the next big show of the 2014 season is underway in Chicago. The noticeably confident Detroit automakers may have received most of the attention at the show in their hometown, but this week, on the other side of Lake Michigan, the spotlight was on foreign manufacturers.

headline: Employment’s Decline, for Men of All Ages
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Men and Boys', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The drop in the share of Americans with jobs is not just a reflection of an aging work force. For men in every age group, the employment rate is lower than it was in previous decades.
lead_paragraph: Men who graduated from high school between 1982 and 1986 were victims of bad timing. They entered their prime working years during a period of slow growth. By January 1994, only 83.3 percent of men 25 to 29 years old were working.

headline: River of Fundament | Matthew Barney
abstract: Matthew Barney's latest film was inspired by the mythology of ancient Egypt as imagined by Norman Mailer's historical novel, “Ancient Evenings.”
lead_paragraph: Matthew Barney's latest film was inspired by the mythology of ancient Egypt as imagined by Norman Mailer's historical novel, “Ancient Evenings.”

headline: One-Wok Meals
abstract: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist, offers new ways to showcase vegetables in under 20 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Last week my impulse purchases at the farmers’ market included a lush bunch of red chard and a beautiful bunch of golden beets with the greens attached. Normally I use these vegetables in Mediterranean dishes – you have seen many of them in Recipes for Health – but I was craving stir-fries.

headline: Helmets: Because Their Thick Skulls Aren’t Thick Enough
abstract: If you make your kids wear helmets while sledding and ice skating, they’ll look like Olympic athletes; they’ll be less likely to suffer a serious head injury, and maybe my children will stop complaining about having to wear theirs.
lead_paragraph: If you make your kids wear helmets when they’re sledding and ice skating, not only will they better resemble all the gnarliest lugers and hockey players in the coming Olympics, but also, more important, you’ll be helping to change the culture. And, most importantly, my children will therefore be less mad at me about having to wear them.

headline: Keeping Swindlers Out of Your Bank and Brokerage Accounts
abstract: Beyond employing offline common sense, individuals need to be vigilant about how they use technology and the systems their advisers have to prevent their accounts from being hacked.
lead_paragraph: Data breaches at Target and Neiman Marcus were certainly scary. Personal information from tens of millions of people fell into the hands of cybercriminals.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Harlem Renaissance
abstract: Another mixed jobs report.Why immigration reform is going nowhere. And how far would you go to get someone to invest in your business?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small business owners today.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Think Back: Olympics Meet Politics
abstract: From Berlin in 1936 to Sochi in 2014, the Olympic Games are not just an athletic stage but a political one, The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains.
lead_paragraph: From Berlin in 1936 to Sochi in 2014, the Olympic Games are not just an athletic stage but a political one, The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains.

headline: The Effect Crowdfunding Has on Venerable Nonprofits Raises Concern
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Crowdfunding (Internet)', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Websites now let people ask for charitable support for their own causes, but some fear that such sites will drain donations from established nonprofits.
lead_paragraph: THE ads ran for years. The global charity Save the Children  asked for a monthly donation, and in return, a few times a year the donors received a photo and handwritten note or drawing from children in impoverished places like Haiti.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Vic + Flow Saw a Bear’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Vic + Flo Saw a Bear.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Vic + Flo Saw a Bear.”

headline: Sexy Beast
abstract: Matthew Barney’s film “River of Fundament” summons Norman Mailer, Egyptian mythology, an oboe-playing porn star and one dead cow. In this oral history, Barney, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Ellen Burstyn, Aimee Mullins and others involved in the project reflect on the experience. Plus: exclusive video commentary from the artist.
lead_paragraph: Summoning Norman Mailer, Egyptian mythology, an oboe-playing porn star and one dead cow, Matthew Barney creates “River of Fundament,” a baroque and no less baffling art-world spectacle.

headline: Paul Taylor Dance Company to Begin Lincoln Center Run With $6 Tickets
abstract: The company is celebrating its 60th anniversary with a special performance at the Koch Theater on March 11 for which all tickets will cost $6.
lead_paragraph: It is the greatest bargain in modern dance: the Paul Taylor Dance Company is celebrating its 60th anniversary with a special performance at Lincoln Center at which all tickets will be only $6 — less than the cost of a child’s or senior’s movie ticket in Manhattan.

headline: Book Review Podcast: A Sentimental Education
abstract: Parul Sehgal, an editor at the Book Review, talks about this week’s Love Stories issue.
lead_paragraph: As part of the Love Stories issue of The New York Times Book Review, writers in a variety of genres share the books that taught them about love — and a few that led them memorably astray. Hilary Mantel writes:

headline: Too Much Winter, and Not Nearly Enough Propane
keywords: ['Propane', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Heating', 'Natural Gas', 'Shortages']
abstract: Analysts placed blame for the increases on record exports, frigid winter weather and rains last year that led to higher demand from farmers.
lead_paragraph: EASTABOGA, Ala. — In the midst of one of the great natural gas drilling booms in the nation’s history, millions of Americans are struggling with a problem that is chilling their bones.

headline: Senate Seat of Baucus Is Filled in Montana
abstract: Lt. Gov. John Walsh, who is a candidate for Senate, was named to succeed Senator Max Baucus, who is leaving become ambassador to China.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The Democratic governor of Montana appointed the lieutenant governor on Friday to fill the Senate seat left open by the departure of Senator Max Baucus, a move Democrats hope will improve their chances of retaining the seat in what is expected to be a fiercely fought election this November.

headline: Deception Foils Attempt to Hijack Turkish Jet to Sochi
abstract: Turkish officials said a passenger claiming a bomb was aboard wanted the aircraft diverted to Sochi, but it landed in Istanbul and he was arrested.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A passenger aboard a commercial airline flight from Ukraine to Turkey tried to hijack it to Sochi, Russia, on Friday after the Winter Olympics started. He threatened to set off a bomb with a cellphone if his demands were not met, but the crew fooled him — and the other passengers — into thinking the plane had landed in Sochi when it was actually in Istanbul, passengers and the authorities said.

headline: Emma Oak Transforms Backstage at Creatures of the Wind
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Emma Oak before (left) and after (right) makeup by James Boehmer and hair by Odile Gilbert.

headline: David Cameron's Plea for Scotland
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain made a plea to the people of Scotland to choose to remain part of the United Kingdom.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain made a plea to the people of Scotland to choose to remain part of the United Kingdom.

headline: Movie Review: 'The Last of the Unjust'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Last of the Unjust.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Last of the Unjust.”

headline: Gathering to Mourn Philip Seymour Hoffman
abstract: Celebrities and locals gathered at the funeral in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Celebrities and locals gathered at the funeral in Manhattan.

headline: Peter Som: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Young Thug as Vocal Stylist
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Young Thug and the hip-hop tradition of irreducible voices.
lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Young Thug and the hip-hop tradition of irreducible voices.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 1
abstract: Berluti opened Madison Avenue flagship; Target collaborated with Peter Pilotto; Vince toasted IPO; Todd Snyder hosted after party.
lead_paragraph: Berluti opened Madison Avenue flagship; Target collaborated with Peter Pilotto; Vince toasted IPO; Todd Snyder hosted after party.

headline: Tightrope for a Bad Boy Made Good
abstract: The country-rock performer Eric Church, whose album “The Outsiders” comes out this week, casts himself as a renegade even as he racks up one success after another.
lead_paragraph: What happens to the outlaw after he is embraced by the mainstream? It’s a recurring question in American culture, from “Huckleberry Finn” to Kurt Cobain. Eric Church’s fourth studio album, “The Outsiders,” is the follow-up to “Chief,” from 2011, which took him to No. 1 on the country charts and won the Country Music Association’s album of the year award. The new record, which EMI Nashville will release on Tuesday, represents a reaffirmation of his independent spirit in the face of an increasingly homogenized Nashville sound.

headline: Popcast: Young Thug as Vocal Stylist
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Young Thug and the hip-hop tradition of irreducible voices.
lead_paragraph: “Black Portland,” the new mixtape by the Atlanta rapper Young Thug and Bloody Jay, is full of southern cadence, trap beats, rhymes about cars and women, and mid-oughts Lil Wayne spaciness. But it’s more full of something else: Young Thug’s voice, which goes high and low, very young and very old. It sings and growls and yelps and moans and wobbles and articulates words or leaves them half-formed.

headline: Caught Between Cutie and the Boxer
abstract: The director of a nominated documentary about husband-and-wife artists says the finished film led to a typical disagreement between the two.
lead_paragraph: In an Oscar field dominated by films that address weighty questions of international politics, Zachary Heinzerling’s “Cutie and the Boxer” is a bit of an outlier in the feature documentary category. Much of the film was shot in a messy apartment-cum-studio in Brooklyn, and it focuses not on upheaval or genocide but on Ushio and Noriko Shinohara, a pair of Japanese artists who are also husband and wife.

headline: Movie Review: 'The Lego Movie'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Lego Movie.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Lego Movie.”

headline: A White-Shoe Firm Unbuttons
abstract: Cross & Cross were respectable white-shoe architects. So how to explain their flashy skyscrapers?
lead_paragraph: Eliot and John W. Cross were the perfect patrician designers, brothers born into a family with plenty of money and social standing. They put their Ivy League and Beaux-Arts connections into play in 1907, and quickly gained a practice in discreet townhouses, clubs, country houses and jewel-like banks, all shown in the luxuriously illustrated monograph on their work, “New York Transformed — The Architecture of Cross & Cross,” by Peter Pennoyer and Anne Walker (Monacelli Press, 2014).

headline: On Amazon, Pilots — and Potential — on View
abstract: A new round of originals is open to voting, including the service’s first two dramas.

headline: Why Europe’s Job Picture Looks Different
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Unlike the United States labor force, Europe’s isn’t shrinking, and the working habits of older women are a major reason.
lead_paragraph: A theme often heard on this side of the Atlantic about the world’s Great Recession and its faltering recovery is how American policy has been more effective than Europe’s, which has been hitched to an expensive currency and shackled to a set of austere economic policies that served nobody but Germany.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Stomach Bug Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 70-year-old women with 10 days of gastrointestinal distress that was just like an episode she’d had four years earlier.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 70-year-old woman with 10 days of gastrointestinal distress that was just like an episode she had had four years earlier.

headline: Wheelies: The Carrot and Stick Edition
abstract: With demand overtaking supply, Mercedes-Benz is rescinding incentives and raising prices; Renault introduces a tiny, drone-equipped off-road car.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: A Meeting That Couples Often Find Daunting
abstract: First encounters with future in-laws can be nerve-racking, and here are some examples.
lead_paragraph: With Valentine’s Day just ahead, now may be a good time to consider some of the more difficult things we do for love. Meeting the future in-laws is among the most daunting of those tasks, and since many of these meetings occur in the winter months, often a chilly one, too.

headline: Asphalt Orchestra Aims to Record Its Interpretation of a Pixies Album
abstract: The ensemble is trying to raise funds online to cover the cost of recording its orchestration of the 1988 Pixies album “Surfer Rosa.”
lead_paragraph: The Alarm Will Sound orchestrations of the Beatles’ “Revolution 9” and works by Aphex Twin and the Shaggs have long been among the most surprising scores to turn up in a classical music ensemble’s programming. But they may soon have company: Asphalt Orchestra, a quirkily eclectic 12-piece wind, brass and percussion ensemble that performs as a post-modernist marching band, is hoping to record its own version of “Surfer Rosa,” the Pixies’ influential debut album, released in 1988.

headline: Coke and Einhorn Take Opposite Sides of Green Mountain Bet
abstract: Coca-Cola presumably gave Green Mountain Coffee a comprehensive review before deciding to buy a stake. But the hedge fund manager David Einhorn can’t be easily dismissed either, Kevin Allison writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Betraying its renowned jingle, Coca-Cola is singing in perfect disharmony with David Einhorn. To feel good paying nearly $1.3 billion for a minority stake in Green Mountain Coffee, the beverage giant must have answered some nagging questions posed by the hedge fund manager a few years ago. Investors seem to figure that Coke did its due diligence. Procter & Gamble and Hewlett-Packard have shown just how much that can matter.

headline: Coming to Trafalgar Square: An Unusual Horse and a Giant Thumb
abstract: The winners of the Fourth Plinth commissions for Trafalgar Square are announced in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A skeletal, riderless horse by Hans Haacke and a giant thumb by David Shrigley are the winning proposals for 2015 and 2016 for the Fourth Plinth commissions in Trafalgar Square. The annual award, funded by the mayor of London and chosen by a commissioning group,  allows artists to propose a sculpture for the vacant plinth, built in 1841 to carry an equestrian statue of King William IV but left vacant until 1998, when this project began.

headline: Portrait of an Army Family
abstract: Alex Quade profiles the Pruetts, an Army family of eight who deployed 11 times.
lead_paragraph: “Some give some, and some give more. Some have no clue to what they’re really fighting for,” Kristin Pruett sang at her home piano in Boise, Idaho, recently. She tape-recorded her holiday tribute to the family of veterans she’d married into, and put it online with photos.

headline: Once You’re On the No-Fly List, It’s Hard to Get Off
abstract: Rahinah Ibrahim’s nine-year journey to clear her name with the U.S. government may be nearing an end.
lead_paragraph: Rahinah Ibrahim’s nine-year journey to clear her name with the U.S. government may be nearing an end.

headline: Big Moments on Campus
abstract: Jack Begg, supervisor of news research at The Times, traces the nation’s history through its centers of learning.
lead_paragraph: Jack Begg, supervisor of news research at The Times, traces the nation’s history through its centers of learning.

headline: Final Decisions
abstract: You’ve gotten into several colleges. Where to go? Make a mistake and you could be repeating the application process next year — to transfer out.
lead_paragraph: CONGRATULATIONS. You’ve been accepted to more than one college. Now comes the hard part: deciding which to go to. Make a mistake and you could be repeating the whole application process again next year — to transfer out.

headline: The Man With Nerves Like Sewer Pipes
abstract: E. Gordon Gee, six times a college president, answers questions on leading a university, raising money and wearing a bow tie.
lead_paragraph: OVER THE LAST 33 YEARS, E. Gordon Gee has presided over an astounding five universities — Ohio State, Vanderbilt, Brown, West Virginia (twice) and Colorado. But Dr. Gee, 70, has a habit of getting in trouble — comparing his job at Ohio State to running the Polish Army, calling the fathers at Notre Dame “holy on Sunday, but holy hell the rest of the week.” He has come under fire for his high compensation (he made nearly $2 million at Ohio State) and his high-flying expense account. (His response: If he’s not worth it, fire him.) Still, Dr. Gee, named Time magazine’s top college president in 2009, is a constant presence on state and national policy commissions. He is finishing a book on the politics of higher education, and after stepping down at Ohio State on July 1, he’s back in office — last month, he became interim president of West Virginia University, where he served as president in the 1980s.

headline: Love, Actually
abstract: The most elemental skills of romantic intimacy are going the way of cursive handwriting. Colleges can help — in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY OVERHEARD two students talking in a dining hall at the university where I teach. “Yeah, I might get married, too,” one confided. “But not until I’m at least 30 and have a career.” Then she grinned. “Until then? I’m going to party it up.”

headline: Adderall and Academics
abstract: Warning: this study aid may impair ability to study.
lead_paragraph: PRO BASEBALL PLAYERS and cyclists have nothing on college students come exam time, when the demand for performance-enhancing stimulants, from Red Bull to Adderall, skyrockets.

headline: Sponsored by the Letter B…
abstract: Grade inflation/deflation has returned as a hot point at the nation’s top colleges.
lead_paragraph: GRADE INFLATION has returned as a hot point at the nation’s top colleges (or maybe they just have darn good students).

headline: Investing (More) in Daughters
abstract: Parents of girls spend, on average, 25 percent more on education per year in a child’s lifetime than parents of boys.
lead_paragraph: TO THE LIST of expenses that make raising a girl pricey — clothes, makeup, smartphones — add one more item: education.

headline: Doctoral Cachet
abstract: What Ph.D.’s have in common with mechanics.
lead_paragraph: WHAT DO Ph.D.’s have in common with car mechanics? We knew you were wondering. So we asked.

headline: Dancing With the Book Carts
abstract: Book cart drill teams put spin on library science.
lead_paragraph: WHAT SPORT demands the precision of synchronized swimming and the book smarts of a librarian?

headline: A Look at Korea’s Culture From the Bathhouse
abstract: To see beyond the surface in South Korea, take a turn in one of its bathhouses or browse its beauty stores.
lead_paragraph: My friend Arcadia Kim has three children and a Harvard business degree, but when she tried to negotiate on our behalf with the lady in charge of exfoliation at the Dragonhill Spa in Seoul, she did not stand a chance.

headline: Feasts for the Eyes, and the Palate, in Xian, China
abstract: The main draw for visitors may be the site housing 8,000 terra-cotta warriors, but there is much more to explore in this central Chinese city, from architecture to street food.
lead_paragraph: On the “Muslim Street” in the Chinese city of Xian stands a bronze tableau in honor of street food. There, on a crowded lane packed with stalls selling Islamic-Chinese cuisine — lamb dumplings, mutton soup, pancakes and mung bean noodles — tourists can pose with statues of a soup seller and his customers. It’s a photo opportunity that brings together Xian’s two most famous tourist drawing cards: life-size human replicas and superb dumplings.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Second Cut to Junk Debt
abstract: The new downgrade was expected to further narrow the island’s room for tight financial maneuvering and has reportedly given rise to discussions with lenders about short-term relief on certain payments.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:35 p.m. | Moody’s Investors Service downgraded Puerto Rico’s general-obligation debt to junk status on Friday, intensifying a cash squeeze on the island and prompting some residents to blame hard-nosed creditors for their mounting troubles.

headline: Lacking a House, a Senator Is Renewing His Ties in Kansas
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: As the Republican mainstream has been threatened by the Tea Party, Senator Pat Roberts is desperate to re-establish ties to Kansas and adjust his politics to fit the rise of the right there.
lead_paragraph: DODGE CITY, Kan. — It is hard to find anyone who has seen Senator Pat Roberts here at the redbrick house on a golf course that his voter registration lists as his home. Across town at the Inn Pancake House on Wyatt Earp Boulevard, breakfast regulars say the Republican senator is a virtual stranger.

headline: Tanya Taylor: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Weekend Reading: Sochi Olympics vs. Wall St.
abstract: If you prefer CNBC to NBC Sports, check out DealBook’s alternative programming guide to the Winter Olympics.
lead_paragraph: If you prefer CNBC to NBC Sports, check out DealBook’s alternative programming guide to the Winter Olympics.

headline: Prepaid Debit Cards May Augment Bank Accounts
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Checks and Checking Accounts', 'Debit Cards']
abstract: Contrary to popular belief, most Americans who use prepaid cards also have checking accounts.
lead_paragraph: PREPAID debit cards are often thought of as an alternative for people who can’t qualify for traditional checking accounts, since you typically don’t have to undergo a credit check to get a prepaid card.

headline: A Policy Response to Job Market Weakness
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Even if the recent deceleration in job growth is temporary, congressional action — an unlikely prospect — could foster job creation and help the long-term unemployed, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: U.S. Charging Coal Companies Too Little for Land, Report Says
abstract: Some mining companies lease land at less than market rate and enjoy low royalty rates, at the expense of taxpayers, investigators say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some coal mining companies are paying lower-than-market rates to lease land from the federal government, while also enjoying low royalty rates, increasing their profits at the expense of taxpayers, investigators for the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee have found.

headline: Big Ticket | A Grand-Scale Restoration Yields $51 Million
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A 30-foot-wide neo-Georgian mansion, lavishly renovated after a fire, was home to the fashion designer Reed Krakoff.
lead_paragraph: An imposing Upper East Side mansion that underwent a flamboyant renovation after being gutted by a fire in 2006 and was rumored to be available for $52 million in 2009 has sold, quietly, for $51 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Monochromatic, but Many Folds
abstract: The British artist David Musgrave had his first solo show at Luhring Augustine in 2009, and now that gallery is mounting another.
lead_paragraph: The British artist David Musgrave had his first solo show at Luhring Augustine in 2009, and now that gallery is mounting another, with new work that includes drawing, sculpture and digital animation. This time around, Mr. Musgrave has worked in a larger format for some of his drawings, whose subjects “resemble discarded sheets of board or paper that have been torn, creased, faded, stained or scored with a blade,” the gallery said.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Prince Igor’ at the Met
abstract: Ildar Abdrazakov sings the title role in this scene from a recent dress rehearsal.
lead_paragraph: Ildar Abdrazakov sings the title role in this scene from a recent dress rehearsal.

headline: Relationship Repair for Valentine’s Day
abstract: The Wolcott Hotel in New York is offering an “On the Mend” package for for couples for couples who want to work on their romantic problems.
lead_paragraph: For those whose Facebook relationship status reads “it’s complicated,” the Wolcott Hotel in New York may have an appropriate Valentine’s Day getaway package. Taking a practical approach to the holiday, the Wolcott is offering an “On the Mend” deal this month aimed at couples who want some big city amusements while sorting out a troubled relationship.

headline: A Steady Hand in Uncertain Times
abstract: Bernard Haitink leads the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in two performances.
lead_paragraph: The great Bernard Haitink, who turns 85 on March 4 and is celebrating his 60th season as a conductor, is a fixer, with a gift for swooping in at troubled times for major ensembles. He steadied the Chicago Symphony Orchestra before Riccardo Muti’s arrival as music director in 2010; he was also the principal guest conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra from 1995 to 2004, then played a key role in recent years as it faced a future without James Levine.

headline: Farewell Jeté to a Long Career
abstract: What City Ballet fan doesn’t love Jenifer Ringer, and who won’t be sad to learn that she is retiring from the company?
lead_paragraph: What City Ballet fan doesn’t love Jenifer Ringer, and who won’t be sad to learn that she is retiring from the company? Gentle, lyrical, romantic and, above all, able to infuse her dancing with a rare warmth and humanity, Ms. Ringer, with her oval face, dark hair and eyes, looks like every little girl’s idea of a ballerina. She was picked out as particularly promising soon after joining City Ballet at 17, in 1990, and promoted to soloist by 1995. But at 23, she left City Ballet, plagued by depression, injury and weight issues.

headline: Singing Jazz for Lovers
abstract: Valentine’s Day has become a red-letter day for elite jazz singers in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Valentine’s Day has become a red-letter day for elite jazz singers in Manhattan. This Friday, options include Dianne Reeves, who has a new release suited to the occasion, at the Rose Theater; Gregory Porter, who just won the Grammy for best jazz vocal album, at Town Hall; and Tierney Sutton, a polished songbook interpreter, at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola.

headline: Tax on Austrian 'Champagne' Has High Society Fuming
abstract: At less than 1 euro, or about $1.35, a bottle, the planned tax is just one of several increases next month, but it is the one that has caused the greatest furor.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Just when it seemed that Austria was surviving Europe’s financial crisis unscathed, austerity has hit — in the form of a tax on sekt, the country’s version of Champagne.

headline: Immigrant’s Tale, Without Clichés
abstract: One of last year’s quiet surprises was “Mother of George,” a film by Andrew Dosunmu about a Nigerian couple in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: One of last year’s quiet surprises was “Mother of George,” a film by Andrew Dosunmu about a Nigerian couple in Brooklyn who, as the story begins, are being wed in a ceremony full of echoes from their homeland. But the opening joy gives way to stresses as the couple (played by Danai Gurira of “The Walking Dead” and Isaach De Bankolé) have trouble conceiving the child they are expected to produce.

headline: Sex and ... O.K., Just Sex
abstract: In “Jenny McCarthy’s Dirty Sexy Funny,” on Friday night at 11 on Epix, Ms. McCarthy — her gift for raunch on full display — tackles the plight of the modern woman.
lead_paragraph: As soon as a buxom blonde squeaks down a stripper pole, it’s pretty evident that there will be nothing remotely ladylike about this ladies’ night out. In “Jenny McCarthy’s Dirty Sexy Funny,” on Friday night at 11 on Epix, Ms. McCarthy — her gift for raunch on full display — tackles the plight of the modern woman with backup from the comedians Justine Marino, Tammy Pescatelli, Lynne Koplitz, Paula Bel and Tiffany Haddish.

headline: ’70s Photorealism: Revived and Still Relevant
abstract: An exhibit on view at Yale University Art Gallery suggests how photorealism, an offshoot of Pop Art, has remained influential, sometimes under different auspices, in recent art.
lead_paragraph: Photorealism was one of the major movements in American art of the early 1970s. A natural offshoot of Pop Art and heir to one-man movements like Edward Hopper, photorealist paintings depicted the postwar American landscape, highlighting Vietnam War pessimism and the plight of working-class people in the recession-era ’70s. The gritty realism of these painters mirrored the films of directors like Barbara Kopple, John Cassavetes or Robert Altman, or the minimalist fiction of Raymond Carver and Jayne Anne Phillips.

headline: Crossing Class Lines for Love, Again
abstract: Jessica Brown Findlay, formerly Lady Sybil in “Downton’s Abbey,” discusses her new role as the consumptive daughter of a New York mogul in the film “Winter’s Tale.”
lead_paragraph: Attention, “Downton Abbey” fans: Lady Sybil Crawley is alive and well and living in New York. Or at least someone uncannily like her. In the film “Winter’s Tale,” opening Friday, Jessica Brown Findlay, her ravishing tresses and plummy vowels intact, portrays Beverly Penn, the high-spirited consumptive daughter of an early-20th-century mogul. Colin Farrell plays the thief who breaks into her mansion to steal the silver — and absconds with her heart. And Russell Crowe, rejoining Akiva Goldsman — the writer for “A Beautiful Mind,” making his film directorial debut — is the gangster intent on putting their love asunder.

headline: For a Sage Tenor, It’s All in the Timing
abstract: The tenor Jonas Kaufmann, who stars in a production of “Werther” opening at the Met on Feb. 18, is deeply cautious about the roles he agrees to sing in New York.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t have more than this one life,” the tenor Jonas Kaufmann said in a recent conversation at the Metropolitan Opera. “I don’t have more to offer. And I’ve still got a family that I, from time to time, need to see. And that’s a problem.”

headline: Their Time Is Now
abstract: The groundbreaking designer Diane von Furstenberg and the Oscar-nominated director David O. Russell talk about the creative process.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday afternoon, David O. Russell, the director and screenwriter whose most recent film, “American Hustle,” is nominated for 10 Academy Awards, including best picture, best director and best original screenplay (which he co-wrote), arrived at the Beverly Hills home of the fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg like a gentleman caller with something to prove.

headline: Molding a Troupe to His Footprint
abstract: Ethan Stiefel left the American Ballet Theater and much of his family to become the artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet.
lead_paragraph: “I do miss it. It’s a wonderful thing to be a dancer,” the former American Ballet Theater principal Ethan Stiefel said recently, in an uncharacteristic moment of quasi-wistfulness. Mr. Stiefel was speaking by phone from Wellington, New Zealand, where, since September 2011, he has been the artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet.

headline: Olympics Opening Ceremony Offers Fanfare for a Reinvented Russia
abstract: After seven years of building to the opening of the Sochi Games, the message of Friday’s over-the-top ceremony was simply this: In a big way, Russia is back.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — With an outsize extravaganza that reached deep into the repertory of classical music and ballet, traversed the sights and sounds of the world’s largest geopolitical expanse, soared into outer space and swept across millenniums of history in a celebration of everything from czarist military might to Soviet monumentalism, a swaggering, resurgent Russia turned its Winter Olympic aspirations into reality on Friday night.

headline: Pope Francis’ Harley-Davidson Sells for $327,000 at Paris Auction
abstract: Money from the sale of the bike, which was donated to the Vatican by Harley-Davidson, will benefit a soup kitchen in Rome.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A private buyer on Thursday purchased Pope Francis’ 2013 Harley-Davidson Dyna Super Glide for about $327,000 at a Bonhams auction in Paris. The price far exceeded the $16,000 to $22,000 presale estimate.

headline: The Gun Report: February 7, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: In November 2012, Michael Dunn fatally shot Jordan Davis, 17, following a spat over loud music at a Jacksonville, Fla., gas station. Davis and three friends had stopped for gum and cigarettes, and Dunn, who was sitting in his Volkswagen, asked the teens to turn down the bass-heavy music blaring from their car. A verbal back-and-forth ensued, and Dunn opened fire into the car, hitting the victim three times. He then exited his car and fired off another half-dozen rounds. Dunn claims he saw a gun in Davis’s car, but a subsequent search turned up a basketball, some clothing and a camera tripod.

headline: Would You Lie for Me?
abstract: Why we underestimate our own powers of persuasion.
lead_paragraph: WHAT is the chance that you could get someone to lie for you? What about vandalizing public property at your suggestion?

headline: Through Russia, With Love (and a Few Leaks)
abstract: The 4-wheel-drive Lada Niva may be the closest thing to an automotive version of the Russian soul, as a 1,000-mile drive from Moscow to Sochi attests.
lead_paragraph: The 4-wheel-drive Lada Niva may be the closest thing to an automotive version of the Russian soul, as a 1,000-mile drive from Moscow to Sochi attests.

headline: Sochi or Bust: Have Niva, Need Hammer
abstract: A drive from Moscow to Sochi in a Lada Niva is an adventure in Russian hospitality and creative car repair.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Vlad Ketkovich, a documentary producer from Moscow, picked me up outside Domodedovo International Airport in a 4-wheel-drive, 4-door Lada Niva. He had rented that car in the belief that it is the closest thing to an automotive version of the Russian soul, and by far the best vehicle for the long drive ahead.

headline: Emotions Churning Under Armor
abstract: Joel Kinnaman, a star in Sweden, is moving from the American television series “The Killing” to the lead in “RoboCop” and to other high-profile features.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Veena Sud, the creator of the dark television procedural “The Killing,” remembers first hearing about Joel Kinnaman when her casting team told her that a “phenomenal” actor from Sweden had put himself on tape. “The minute I clicked on the link, I knew we found Holder,” Ms. Sud said of the rumpled, soulful homicide detective Mr. Kinnaman plays on “The Killing.” “He felt like a real guy, edgy. And he had amazing tats.”

headline: Gramercy Park Condop, Man-Cave Included
abstract: A ninth-floor aerie, with amenities from the Gramercy Park Hotel, is used as a pied-à-terre by the owner of the Philadelphia Flyers.
lead_paragraph: A sophisticated ninth-floor aerie with panoramic views of historic Gramercy Park from its loftlike great room, which has a 22-foot expanse of floor-to-ceiling windows facing south, is poised to enter the market at $8.75 million.

headline: Modern Dishes, Served Fireside
abstract: Peter Pratt’s Inn in Yorktown Heights is an ideal place to hunker down with friends and hearty food.
lead_paragraph: When February’s deep freeze sends us looking for a snug spot with a fireplace and hearty food and friendly people to tend us, the Tack Room at Peter Pratt’s Inn will do quite well. This cellar room, in a mid-18th-century house, flaunts its age: A whitewashed stone foundation supports a dark ceiling of hand-hewn beams, but the tables are dressed in white linen finery and nosegays of full-blown white roses, soothing reminders that spring is less than six weeks away.

headline: Exclusive | 50 Gramercy Park North
abstract: A ninth-floor condop with panoramic views of Manhattan’s historic private park is about to enter the market at $8.75 million.
lead_paragraph: A ninth-floor condop with panoramic views of Manhattan’s historic private park is about to enter the market at $8.75 million.

headline: ‘Aid in Dying’ Movement Takes Hold in Some States
abstract: Advocates of the practice, who shun the term “assisted suicide,” say they believe that as baby boomers watch frail parents suffer, support for their movement will grow further.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Helping the terminally ill end their lives, condemned for decades as immoral, is gaining traction. Banned everywhere but Oregon until 2008, it is now legal in five states. Its advocates, who have learned to shun the term “assisted suicide,” believe that as baby boomers watch frail parents suffer, support for what they call the “aid in dying” movement will grow further.

headline: Leno’s Farewell Drew More Than 14 Million Viewers
abstract: The end of his 22-year run at the “Tonight” show host brought in the largest audience since May 14, 1998, the night of the finale to “Seinfeld.”
lead_paragraph: Jay Leno pumped his ratings muscles one last time for NBC Thursday night, ending his 22-year run as the “Tonight” show host with a huge audience of 14.6 million viewers.

headline: Maxine Kumin, Pulitzer-Winning Poet With a Naturalist’s Precision, Dies at 88
abstract: Ms. Kumin, an author of essays, novels and children’s books, was best known for her volumes of sharply observed poetry, one of which, “Up Country,” won the Pulitzer Prize in 1973.
lead_paragraph: Maxine Kumin, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet whose spare, deceptively simple lines explored some of the most complex aspects of human existence — birth and death, evanescence and renewal, and the events large and small conjoining them all — died on Thursday at her home in Warner, N.H. She was 88.

headline: François Hollande: Casanova or Lout?
abstract: The French President, who is about to visit the United States, has adopted a new macho pose in the wake of his recent indiscretions, to the dismay of many onlookers at home in France.
lead_paragraph: François Hollande is acting liberated now that he has dismissed his live-in companion, Valérie Trierweiler, and eliminated — Pravda-style — all traces of her as first lady from the official Élysée Palace website. The French president is smiling more, telling colleagues he feels “relieved” that his relationship is over. During a trip to Turkey last week, he bantered with French journalists. The next day he decorated the Turkish chanteuse Candan Ercetin as a knight of Arts and Letters, kissing her on both cheeks before gushing over her interpretation of Edith Piaf songs, including “Non, je ne regrette rien.”

headline: Arrivederci, Roma. Ciao, Bank Street.
abstract: Cotto Wine Bar & Pizzeria offers a range of intriguing Italian dishes geared to pre- or post-movie or late night snacking, as well as leisurely dining.
lead_paragraph: It might be a challenge to try to maintain the ambience of a Roman trattoria in downtown Stamford, especially when the temperatures dip down to near zero.

headline: Making a Broken Family Whole Again
abstract: A fashion stylist becomes a wife to a widower and an “insta-mom” to three children.
lead_paragraph: Eric Fleiss recently recalled the first words that his wife Susan said to him after she learned she had colon cancer in early 2011: “I need to find you a new wife.”

headline: The Move From Celebrity to Ubiquity
abstract: The Bollywood star Priyanka Chopra makes the transition to becoming a top model for Guess.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Priyanka Chopra had a problem: what to do with the light.

headline: Review: 2014 Jeep Cherokee Limited
abstract: The original Cherokee’s design was so square, it could be mistaken for the box it came in. Jeep has revived the name for 2014 and has put quite a curve on the styling.
lead_paragraph: The original Cherokee’s design was so square, it could be mistaken for the box it came in. Jeep has revived the name for 2014 and has put quite a curve on the styling.

headline: The M.T.A. Switches Ad Agencies After 22 Years
abstract: Korey Kay & Partners, creator of “If you see something, say something,” is being replaced by two agencies: Pulsar Advertising and the Arcade Creative Group.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is changing advertising agencies after 22 years, parting ways with the firm that helped popularize the cautionary phrase “If you see something, say something.”

headline: Jason Wu: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Signs of Life in Home Building
abstract: Construction added 48,000 jobs last month, and residential home building has contributed a net gain of nearly 200,000 jobs to the economy since early 2012.
lead_paragraph: In a perfect world for the housing industry, the employment picture contains a virtuous cycle in which housing drives jobs and jobs drive housing. Some analysts found evidence of that Friday in the January jobs report.

headline: When Doctors Leave the Building
abstract: A growing availability of doctors’ offices for use as residences reflects a transformed medical environment.
lead_paragraph: Forget images of hulking X-ray machines and pocket-size exam rooms framed by cinderblock. Forget the lingering odor of rubbing alcohol. New York doctors’ offices have come a long way over the years. And in their latest incarnation, these spaces are increasingly attractive as residential properties, enticing buyers with their prime locations, sometimes-lofty ceilings and unrivaled privacy.

headline: Chrysler Recalls 9,700 Ram Vans for Sticking Accelerator Pedal
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A Chrysler employee found that a piece of trim was making an accelerator pedal stick.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler is recalling about 9,700 Ram ProMaster vans from the 2014 model year to correct a problem that can allow the accelerator pedal “to stick in the wide-open position,” the automaker said in a news release Friday.

headline: N.S.A. Program Gathers Data on a Third of Nation’s Calls, Officials Say
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: The once-secret initiative is collecting a large amount of landline data but has struggled to take in cellphone information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency’s once-secret program that is collecting bulk records of Americans’ domestic phone calls is taking in a relatively small portion of the total volume of such calls each day, officials familiar with the program said on Friday.

headline: New York Fashion Week: General Idea Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Clip: 'Child's Pose'
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Calin Peter Netzer.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Calin Peter Netzer.

headline: Graphic Novels to Graphic Prime Time
abstract: Inspired by the return of “The Walking Dead,” a proposal for adapting five graphic novels or comic book series for prime time.
lead_paragraph: Shuffle ... stagger ... chomp! Shuffle ... stagger ... chomp!

headline: Winter’s Chill Turns to Spring’s Love in the Forest
abstract: At the Two River Theater, the pastoral beauty of a Shakespearean comedy takes on a modern look.
lead_paragraph: “Blow, blow, thou winter wind” begins one of the songs that echo in the frosty forest of Arden while its denizens shiver through the middle scenes of “As You Like It.” As Shakespeare’s story progresses and its various romances blossom, however, the melancholy snows of winter gradually melt away into the greenery of spring, even as his characters are transformed for the better by love and kindness.

headline: Lord Zog, Your Ride Is Ready
abstract: The Juke Nismo is the performance version of Nissan’s quirky-looking crossover. The Nismo has sharper steering and a suspension setup that prioritizes cornering over compliance.
lead_paragraph: TESTED Nissan Juke Nismo

headline: Same Name, but Gentler in Attitude
abstract: The Trailhawk is competent, comfortable and can romp with real 4-by-4s, but is it a worthy successor to the classic Cherokee?
lead_paragraph: FREDERICK, MD. — “But is it a Jeep?”

headline: Reversal of Good Fortune
abstract: Flan, the custard crowned with a deeply caramelized underside, is a simple pleasure.
lead_paragraph: There’s something about a dessert that can be served with the bottom on top.

headline: From Private Repository to Public Forum
abstract: An exhibit at the Neuberger Museum of Art takes a global look at the evolution of the diary and its current role in social media.
lead_paragraph: The divide between public and private has lessened considerably in recent decades as social media reveals what near strangers had for breakfast and corporations and governments collect personal data for their own uses. Artists have taken note, and “Dear Diary: Update on All” at the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College offers a global look at how the diary form evolved, as the gallery release puts it, from “a private repository” to a public forum in which “the personal becomes a platform for social interaction, reflection and activism.”

headline: Morgan Stanley Adds 4 Executives to Operating Committee
abstract: Morgan Stanley does not often appoint new members to its operating committee, which made up of the top echelon of the firm’s leadership. On Friday, it added four new executives.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley has named four executives to its operating committee, the bank’s most senior group of managers.

headline: The 7-Day Digital Diet
abstract: When you commit to disconnecting, you wean yourself off the dopamine rush of external affirmation and information.
lead_paragraph: At first blush I may not seem like a prime candidate for a digital detox.

headline: Missed That Note? Wait a Few Minutes, and It’ll Return
abstract: A new work by the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho is played twice in its pairing with Bach’s Partita in D minor as part of a series at the Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: Many new scores languish unheard after the fanfare of a premiere; for a work to have its American premiere and its second performance on the same program, as happened at the Miller Theater on Thursday evening, is fairly rare.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Africa, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Africa, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Indonesia.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A Greenwich Village loft; an Upper West Side Co-op; and a unit in a Park Slope building.
lead_paragraph: A Greenwich Village loft; an Upper West Side Co-op; and a unit in a Park Slope building.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A converted barn in Stamford with a soaring ceiling; and an English manor in White Plains with eight bedrooms.
lead_paragraph: A converted barn in Stamford with a soaring ceiling; and an English manor in White Plains with eight bedrooms.

headline: A Not Quite Merry Christmas Reunion
abstract: Jon Robin Baitz’s crackling contemporary play portrays a family going through a predicament when a daughter returns home for Christmas with unwelcome news.
lead_paragraph: It is often bad news for a family when one of its members decides to write a memoir, since the focus is likely to be a miserable childhood or a calamitous event the others would rather forget. The Wyeth family at the center of Jon Robin Baitz’s crackling “Other Desert Cities,” now at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport, faces that unwelcome situation.

headline: Jazz Brimming With Ideas
abstract: The pianist Danilo Pérez played a set of material at the Jazz Standard that broke free of easy definitions.
lead_paragraph: Danilo Pérez began his early set at the Jazz Standard on Thursday night with a busily efficient overture, laying out many of his themes and protocols for the ensuing hour. Within the first minute of the piece, “Rediscovery of the South Sea,” there was an intriguing bramble of push-pull tensions between bass, violin and percussion; a more spacious motif that Mr. Pérez unhurriedly teased out at the piano; and a hale-sounding Yoruban chant by Roman Díaz, providing his own punctuation on a batá drum.

headline: Scores Detained in Russia Before Olympic Ceremony
abstract: Russian authorities detained at least 61 people on Friday for holding unauthorized protests, underscoring the government’s efforts to stifle dissent.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — From St. Petersburg to the Caucasus, the authorities detained at least 61 people on Friday for holding unauthorized protests ahead of the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics in Sochi. The detentions underscored the government’s efforts to stifle protests even far away from the Games.

headline: De Blasio’s Pick for Planning Puts Focus on Housing
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Zoning', 'Land Use Policies', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Carl Weisbrod, who led the transformations of Times Square and Lower Manhattan, will be the director of the Planning Department.
lead_paragraph: From its perch as overseer of New York City’s growth, the City Planning Commission has helped mayors put their own stamp on the landscape, whether with luxury Midtown towers or a revitalized waterfront. But Mayor Bill de Blasio mostly sees the realm of zoning and land use as another means to address economic inequality.

headline: McDonald’s Opens in Vietnam, Bringing Big Mac to Fans of Banh Mi
abstract: The fast-food giant is opening its first restaurant in the country, which some see as one of Asia’s last consumer markets with significant untapped potential.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — When Nguyen Hoang Anh and Nguyen Thi My Hao started dating, the 23-year-olds agreed to disagree about food: Mr. Anh adores Western-style fast food, but Ms. Hao mainly eats pho, a popular noodle soup, and other northern Vietnamese foods she has loved since childhood.

headline: Wine-Braised Oxtail
abstract: Melissa Clark braises oxtail with red wine, carrots and celery root for flavorful, fork-tender meat.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark braises oxtail with red wine, carrots and celery root for flavorful, fork-tender meat.

headline: Adversity, Relayed in Emoticons by a Troubled Gay Teenager
abstract: In David Roussève’s “Stardust,” a dance-theater piece presented at Montclair State, the troubled protagonist communicates with the audience in projected text messages.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The first thing to know about David Roussève’s “Stardust” is that you never actually see its protagonist, a black gay urban teenager named Junior. The voice at the heart of this 80-minute dance-theater piece, which had its regional premiere on Thursday in Montclair State University’s Peak Performances series, speaks to us via text messages, projected on the back wall of the theater.

headline: A Jeep That Serves Two Masters
abstract: The 2014 Jeep Cherokee Trailhawk faces a challenge: it must compete with the likes of the RAV4 and CR-V for the suburban market. and still get some respect from the Cherokee nation.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 Jeep Cherokee Trailhawk faces a challenge: it must compete with the likes of the RAV4 and CR-V for the suburban market. and still get some respect from the Cherokee nation.

headline: Latin America Venture Capital Fund Raises New $135 Million Fund
abstract: The new fund, Kaszek Ventures’ second, eclipsed its first one raised in 2011. It also signals that the region’s long-term prospects remain promising despite the current turbulence in emerging markets.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Despite the turbulence currently hitting emerging markets, the venture capital fund Kaszek Ventures, in Buenos Aires, recently raised a new $135 million fund, signaling that the region’s long-term prospects remain promising.

headline: Finding Warmth and Comfort in Noodle Soup
abstract: On a frigid winter’s day, the appeal of noodle soup, on the menu at several Long Island restaurants, transcends culinary boundaries.
lead_paragraph: At Noodles and Company in Garden City on a recent afternoon, Matt Neary, 44, of Merrick, lifted a bowl to his lips and drained what was left of the Thai curry noodle soup at the bottom. A repeat customer at the restaurant, at the Gallery at Westbury Plaza mall, Mr. Neary said he had been craving the coconut curry broth laced with ginger, cabbage, shiitake mushrooms and rice noodles. “It’s got to have some kind of noodle in it,” he said. “That’s what makes it a one-pot meal.”

headline: The Marriage, Pragmatic; The Relatives, Troubling
abstract: Lydia Wilson stars in the suspense film “The Making of a Lady,” based on a 1901 novel, with Linus Roache, James D’Arcy and Joanna Lumley.
lead_paragraph: Patience sometimes seems to be a lost art in creepy entertainment. The makers of such stuff, whether a television show about a hunt for a serial killer or a slasher film for the popcorn crowd, seem in a rush to get a scary abduction or bloody corpse onto the screen, as if they fear viewers will bail if they don’t see something ghastly in the first three minutes.

headline: Priyanka Chopra: The New Face of Guess
abstract: Priyanka Chopra is a household name in India. But she is a relative unknown in America, where she spent a part of her childhood. She hopes that being the new face of Guess will change that.
lead_paragraph: Priyanka Chopra is a household name in India. But she is a relative unknown in America, where she spent a part of her childhood. She hopes that being the new face of Guess will change that.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A converted barn in Stamford with a soaring ceiling; and an English manor in White Plains with eight bedrooms.
lead_paragraph: Click the slide show to view the On the Market properties in the region for this week: A converted barn in Stamford with a soaring ceiling; and an English manor in White Plains with eight bedrooms.

headline: For a Plucky Upstart, Icy Industry Tundra
abstract: The creators of the Inuit-theme “Legend of Sarila,” Canada’s first 3-D animated film, started off with high hopes that were dashed by a lawsuit and unenthusiastic reviews.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The Legend of Sarila” is Canada’s first 3-D animated feature film. The movie boasts a fine voice cast, including the Canadian-born Christopher Plummer and Geneviève Bujold, and a story that draws its inspiration from Inuit culture and legends. There are blizzards and avalanches, sled dog rides through twisting ice tunnels and mystical battles between rival shamans. After its premiere at the TIFF Kids International Film Festival in Toronto, the film opened in Canadian theaters; the producers later signed deals to distribute “Sarila” in more than 22 countries, including Germany, Russia, Israel and China.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A Greenwich Village loft; an Upper West Side Co-op; and a unit in a Park Slope building.
lead_paragraph: Click the slide show to view the On the Market properties in New York City for this week: A Greenwich Village loft; an Upper West Side Co-op; and a unit in a Park Slope building.

headline: Rodriguez Drops Suits Against Baseball and Union
abstract: The move ends Alex Rodriguez’s campaign to fight his ban for using performance-enhancing drugs and means he will miss all of the 2014 season.
lead_paragraph: After a year of warring with Major League Baseball, Alex Rodriguez effectively ended his battle on Friday, dropping his lawsuits against baseball and the players union over his doping suspension.

headline: Ode to a Slow-Cooked Oxtail
abstract: This meat is best eaten by picking the pieces up in your hands, then gnawing the bones.
lead_paragraph: A slice of oxtail terrine, with silken shreds of boneless beef molded into a neat square on the plate, is a refined and elegant dish. The meat is so soft and succulent you can eat it with a spoon. Teeth are purely optional.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Whiteout
abstract: Men in dress shoes leaping over slush-filled curbs added a humorous if precarious postscript.
lead_paragraph: Men in dress shoes leaping over slush-filled curbs added a humorous if precarious postscript.

headline: As Olympics Open, Social Media Is a Prism for Protests Against Russia’s Anti-Gay Law
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Discrimination', 'Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality', 'Olympic Games (2014)', 'Social Media', 'Transgender and Transsexual']
abstract: Protests against Russia’s discriminatory policies toward lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people are taking many forms, including corporate statements, music videos and messages on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues in Sochi write in their live-blog, the Winter Olympics have officially begun with the completion of the opening ceremony, and social media is again being used as a stage for expressions of L.G.B.T. rights.

headline: Sit Back, Relax and Enjoy the Show
abstract: At Marakesh, diners eat their hummus while sitting on couches amid a virtual museum of ceramics, pottery and fixtures and, some nights, belly-dancing.
lead_paragraph: Meals at Moroccan restaurants typically begin with salads, and if you begin yours at Marakesh with the mix of cold salads known as the sampler, you might want to come back and order it again the next day.

headline: The Singer’s Artifice, Flickering on Film
abstract: The performances in “Art Song on Film” at Lincoln Center suggest that, rather than dispensing with illusion, lieder recitals demand a public construction of “self.”
lead_paragraph: In Joan Didion’s Broadway adaptation of her memoir “The Year of Magical Thinking,” Vanessa Redgrave played a character named Joan Didion. Simple enough, but it suddenly gave a new twist to Ms. Didion’s large body of nonfiction, much of it written in the first person. While I used to take the authenticity of her narrative voice for granted, “The Year of Magical Thinking” reminded me that her “I” is as artificial, as carefully calibrated a construct, as any figure in a play or novel.

headline: Marc Jacobs’s Plans for the Future, The Duchess of Cambridge’s New Style and Zac Posen’s Bridal Designs
abstract: Plus, better diversity grades for designers, Scotland’s booming textile trade and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: For Many Older Americans, an Enterprising Path
abstract: People in the 55-to-64 age group, one study has found, had the highest rate of business start-ups in the last decade, despite the often difficult task of raising money.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Marilyn Arnold was 9 years old, her mother, a skilled seamstress, patiently taught her to sew on a vintage Singer treadle sewing machine.

headline: Gearing Up the Time Machine to Go Back to the ’90s
abstract: New music by Gorgon City, Sam Smith, Kazzie, Laura Cantrell and Jon Pardi.
lead_paragraph: Gorgon City

headline: Ex-Contractor at State Dept. Pleads Guilty in Leak Case
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Stephen J. Kim agreed to serve a 13-month prison sentence for leaking classified C.I.A. information on North Korea to a Fox News reporter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen J. Kim, a former State Department contractor charged with leaking information from a highly classified report about North Korea to a Fox News reporter in 2009, pleaded guilty on Friday and agreed to serve a 13-month prison sentence.

headline: Work by Graffiti Artists From 5Pointz on Display
abstract: Some of the artists who made 5Pointz what it was have work hanging on the walls of the Gold Coast Arts Center in Great Neck.
lead_paragraph: Subway riders who saw the graffiti-coated warehouse buildings in Queens known as 5Pointz from the 7 train and planned to visit them someday will never have the chance.

headline: Infusing Études With a Kaleidoscope of Flavors
abstract: Daniil Trifonov returned to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night with a recital that included the Scherzo from his own Piano Sonata as an encore.
lead_paragraph: Almost exactly one year after his Carnegie Hall recital debut, the young Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov returned to its main auditorium. Word of that triumphant debut, in which the then-21-year-old demonstrated his uncommon technical gifts and poetic sensibility in works by Scriabin, Liszt and Chopin, and the recent release of its live recording, contributed to the crush of ticket seekers outside the hall on Thursday evening.

headline: A Jeep That Must Serve Two Masters
abstract: The 2014 Jeep Cherokee Trailhawk faces a challenge: to compete with the likes of the RAV4 and CR-V for the suburban market, and still get some respect from the Cherokee nation.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 Jeep Cherokee Trailhawk faces a challenge: to compete with the likes of the RAV4 and CR-V for the suburban market, and still get some respect from the Cherokee nation.

headline: Loyalists Hit Closets as Zero Becomes 15
abstract: Barneys gave a party to celebrate the designer Maria Cornejo.
lead_paragraph: To her fans, she is an artist’s artist. Maria Cornejo has been dressing stars of the art, film and music worlds since she introduced her label, Zero & Maria Cornejo, in the late 1990s.

headline: Cushnie et Ochs: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: His Death, Their Lives
abstract: The death of Philip Seymour Hoffman, apparently of a heroin overdose, resonates particularly strongly with recovering addicts.
lead_paragraph: In the first hours and days that followed Philip Seymour Hoffman’s death from an apparent overdose of heroin, there was an outpouring of grief on Facebook, on Twitter and in columns by recovering addicts and alcoholics like the journalist Seth Mnookin and the screenwriter Aaron Sorkin about their own struggles with sobriety and the rarely distant fear of relapsing back into the throes of active addiction.

headline: Fashion Week Galas Worth the Weather
abstract: Neither rain nor sleet nor snow can keep the fashion flock from its appointed rounds during New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Neither rain nor sleet nor snow can keep the fashion flock from its appointed rounds during New York Fashion Week.

headline: First Resale in Walker Tower Flipped for Near $3 Million Profit
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: The sale follows a record-breaking $50.9 million transaction and a surge of wealthy buyers.
lead_paragraph: The renaissance of Walker Tower, the 24-story Art Deco office building at 212 West 18th Street that put Chelsea on the skyscraper map after Ralph Thomas Walker designed it for the New York Telephone Company in 1929, has been emphatic.

headline: Volvo Plan: 1 Platform for All Cars
abstract: The company will replace its entire model line, staking its immediate future on a single chassis architecture with one basic engine and transmission.
lead_paragraph: In an audacious reinvention of itself, Volvo Cars will replace its entire model line over the next few years, staking its immediate future on a single chassis architecture with one basic engine and transmission.

headline: Child Crash Deaths Decline 43%
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Children and Childhood', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: More than 9,000 children 12 or younger died in car crashes during the decade covered by a federal report.
lead_paragraph: Deaths of children 12 and younger in motor vehicle crashes fell by 43 percent from 2002 to 2011, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a report released on Tuesday. Still, automobile accidents remain a leading cause of death among children in the United States.

headline: For a Power Girl, Cheers and Disses
abstract: The Grammy Award-winning singer Lorde, a.k.a. Ella Yelich-O’Connor, impresses and vexes her peers.
lead_paragraph: Among the many chart-topping musicians who appeared at the Grammy Awards on Jan. 26, Lorde, the 17-year-old singer of the hit “Royals,” was the most mentioned on Twitter that night, according to the social media company’s blog. With her fingers dip-dyed in black (more reminiscent of the designer Michèle Lamy than a typical teenage pop star) and signature jerky dance moves, some young fans were giddy at her success. “Lorde might win four Grammys when I can’t even win the affection of my crush from school,” one wrote.

headline: Once Upon a Revolution: A Story With No End
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Few people in Egypt have seen “The Square,” an Oscar-nominated documentary about the Arab Spring uprising there, but those who have are mostly unhappy about it.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The discussion started decorously enough. The novelist Alaa al-Aswany had screened “The Square,” the Oscar-nominated documentary about the Egyptian revolution, at his monthly salon two weeks ago, and he opened by lamenting that the film focused on just a handful of articulate characters instead of the masses of “simple people.” And as in almost every conversation here about the “The Square,” it did not take long before the fighting began.

lead_paragraph: Employees of Boehringer Ingelheim, the German drug maker, continued to express concern over whether sales of their blood thinner, Pradaxa, could be harmed if the public learned that some patients might need regular testing for safety reasons, according to new documents unsealed by a federal judge in Illinois on Thursday.

abstract: For the first time, I understood what true terror was: Mr. He Who Sneers at Death was wearing skintight leopard print underwear.

headline: 22 Things The New York Times Has Called a ‘Guilty Pleasure’
abstract: What paparazzi photos, Jell-O, the L.P.G.A. Tour and ‘‘Breaking Bad’’ have in common.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s magazine, Adam Sternbergh riffs on so-called guilty pleasures. “How did these two concepts ever come to be married anyway?” he asks. “Aside from the obvious (sex), there are only three other arenas in life in which guilt and pleasure are habitually linked: gastronomy, religion and the arts. And while there are semi-plausible rationalizations for the first two (that cake was delicious, but I ate too much; I indulged in an act I’ve been taught to feel is wrong), for the life of me I’ve never been able to unravel how cultural guilt and cultural pleasure became so entwined.”

headline: Tauba Auerbach on Book Fairs, Knitwear and the Grateful Dead
abstract: The acclaimed visual artist, who designed the backdrops and costumes for a ballet opening this weekend in London, shares a few far-flung inspirations.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco-born, New York-based artist Tauba Auerbach is about to have a London moment. Opening this weekend is “Tetractys – Art of the Fugue,” a ballet at the Royal Opera House for which she created the backdrops and costume designs. Soon to follow will be The New Ambidextrous Universe, a major exhibition in the spring at the city’s Institute of Contemporary Arts. (Auerbach’s work can also currently be seen at the University of Chicago and the Contemporary Art Museum in Houston.)

headline: A Big Reveal Touches a Nerve
abstract: Rachel Frederickson lost 59.62 percent of her body weight to win Season 15 of “The Biggest Loser,” but not everyone celebrated her victory.
lead_paragraph: It is the moment “The Biggest Loser” viewers anticipate all season. That episode when the finalists emerge, one by one, to bare all — or rather less — to a waiting audience of millions. But on Tuesday night, when Rachel Frederickson, 24, walked onto the studio stage 155 pounds lighter than at the start of Season 15, the reaction was not one of awe, but shock, apparent even on the trainers’ frozen faces.

Staten Island? Never. The new public art project, New York (Outer Borough) Stories, now on display at two locations (24 Gouverneur Lane and 141 Water Street) near the South Street Seaport, was made for these provincials.

headline: Journalist Badly Wounded by Flare During Rio Protest
abstract: Video and photographs recorded during clashes in Rio de Janeiro on Thursday showed a Brazilian cameraman being struck in the head by an explosive device.
lead_paragraph: Santiago Andrade, a Brazilian cameraman, was badly wounded in Rio de Janeiro on Thursday evening when he was struck in the head by an explosive device while covering clashes between protesters and the police. He remained in critical condition on Friday after four hours of neurosurgery, according to the local Globo news site.

headline: China: Tibetan Dies in Act of Protest
abstract: A Tibetan man died after setting himself on fire in an act of protest against the Chinese government, according to information released Friday by Free Tibet, an advocacy group.
lead_paragraph: A Tibetan man, Phakmo Samdup, died Wednesday after setting himself on fire in an act of protest against the Chinese government, which has ruled Tibet since invading it in the 1950s, according to information released Friday by Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London. Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the American government, said the protest took place in the prefecture of Malho in Qinghai Province, in western China. The death raises to 126 the number of self-immolations in Tibetan areas ruled by China, Radio Free Asia reported.

headline: Canada: Government Deletes Drawings, Posted Online, of a Secret Spying Site
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: The government of Canada on Friday removed detailed architectural drawings of a secret electronic eavesdropping station that had been posted online.
lead_paragraph: The government of Canada on Friday removed detailed architectural drawings of a secret electronic eavesdropping station that had been posted online. About a dozen drawings, which detail the interior as well as mechanical and electrical specifications of the command center at Canadian Forces Station Leitrim in Ottawa were posted on Wednesday as part of a construction tender by Public Works and Government Services Canada. The military station conducts foreign communications interceptions and other work for the Communications Security Establishment Canada, Canada’s electronic spy agency. The public works department was unable to comment about the episode. The removal of the drawings followed the publication of an article in the newspaper The Ottawa Citizen.

headline: Try Your Luck, at the I.R.S. Wheel
abstract: If the government could make filing taxes more like a game — with penalties and rewards, and fabulous prizes! — maybe the process wouldn’t seem like drudgery.
lead_paragraph: “Taxes are Fun!” That’s the bright, bold and unconvincing message in an ad campaign from Jackson Hewitt, the tax preparers.

headline: A Taste Test for Three Flavors of Tax Software
abstract: The online versions of three leading tax software programs — TurboTax, H&R Block and TaxAct — contain many of the same strengths and weaknesses of their downloadable counterparts.
lead_paragraph: My choice of tax preparation software brands me an old coot, or at least out of sync with the modern moment. My wife, Mary Ellen, says my taste in music does, too — my apologies, Mr. Jagger.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Liner Notes at Rag & Bone
abstract: The makeup artist Gucci Westman made the cat-eye new again with bold, geometric black streaks.
lead_paragraph: You can always count on the Rag & Bone girl to make the call on what’s cool, beauty-wise. For fall, the answer is: loads of graphic eyeliner. “I was inspired by yé-yé girls from the ’60s, like Françoise Hardy,” the makeup artist Gucci Westman said of the “tomboy-ish” look she created backstage this afternoon. Her muse is “accessible and cool,” Westman continued, but has a “contemporary edge and toughness.” In the makeup chair, that translated into a modern cat-eye with a strong, geometric shape. The eyeliner “goes straight out, and doesn’t follow the lash line, which makes it slightly different,” Westman explained of her technique, which involved topping Revlon ColorStay Crème Gel Liner with Revlon ColorStay Liquid Eye Pen. To clean up the edges, Westman relied on an angled Q-Tip when necessary; she left the rest of the face relatively bare. “The eyeliner is meant to be your one trick,” she said. “This is not a high-maintenance girl.” Indeed, the British model Georgia May Jagger paid Westman the ultimate compliment by describing the finished look as “quite normal — it’s actually something I would wear out.”

headline: At the I.R.S., Trying to Collect More With Less
abstract: As the tax code grows more complex, the Internal Revenue Service’s enforcement budget continues to shrink.
lead_paragraph: The United States tax code is fast approaching 75,000 pages, and it is growing every year in complexity and bulk. Yet as the tax code has become more byzantine, the budget for enforcing it has been shrinking.

headline: Week After Being Hit by Bus, Rare Owl Is ‘Bright and Alert’ at Washington Clinic
abstract: Caretakers at a wildlife clinic said an injured snowy owl was eating well after suffering a head injury and broken toe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One week after being hit by a bus and an S.U.V. not far from the White House, the snowy owl that made bird-watchers out of smartphone-gazers is recuperating at a Washington wildlife clinic.
