keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: The Supreme Court’s ruling on the Defense of Marriage Act gives gay couples more rights, but also means that some will have to pay higher taxes.
lead_paragraph: Erin E. Miller and her wife may have to pay more income tax this year, but they aren’t about to protest. Quite the opposite.

headline: So Many Bribes, a Greek Official Can’t Recall Them All
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Defense Contracts', 'Arms Trade']
abstract: The testimony by a deputy in the Defense Ministry, if accurate, illustrates how arms makers from Germany, France, Sweden and Russia passed out payoffs to sell Greece weaponry that it could ill afford.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — When Antonis Kantas, a deputy in the Defense Ministry here, spoke up against the purchase of expensive German-made tanks in 2001, a representative of the tank’s manufacturer stopped by his office to leave a satchel on his sofa. It contained 600,000 euros, about $814,000. Other arms manufacturers eager to make deals came by, too, some guiding him through the ins and outs of international banking and then paying him off with deposits to his overseas accounts.

headline: Father and Son, Together on a Halfpipe Quest
abstract: Greg Bretz, one of the few snowboarders who has defeated Shaun White in the halfpipe, will ride alone in Sochi. But his father will be there, as he has been all along.
lead_paragraph: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif. — The maintenance building smells like a garage, all rubber and grease and metal parts, the scents of construction and repairs. The Coke machine has a sticker that reads “Bretz 2014.”

headline: Time Travel and the Ballad Tradition
abstract: Inspiration can come from unpredictable places: family history, 19th-century personal ads, a child’s eighth-grade project.
lead_paragraph: Since I was a kid, I’ve loved story songs, history ballads and concept albums. Songs with well-drawn characters, a strong sense of time and place, a narrative arc and a cinematic quality are endlessly fascinating. I remember hearing “The Battle of New Orleans” by Jimmy Driftwood (a hit for the country artist Johnny Horton) for the first time, as a very young, prekindergarten child, and being mesmerized by the march of the “bloody British,” at whom “we fired our guns” all the way “down the Mississippi to the Gulf of Mexico.” At the time I didn’t know who the “British” were, or why we wanted to kill them, or where the city of New Orleans might be, but the battle and the chase and the big river right in the center made an indelible imprint.

headline: Breaks in the Action
abstract: For all the ferocious gore of the Civil War, temporary battlefield truces — to collect the wounded, trade goods and even share some whiskey — were common.
lead_paragraph: Union and Confederate soldiers viewed one another as the enemy — except sometimes when they needed to bum a smoke. Then, in unofficial “soldier’s truces,” warring opponents set down their weapons and became the American brothers they were before the war. In a conflict that exemplified the military axiom that soldiering is 99 percent boredom and 1 percent sheer terror, the blue and the gray called timeouts from opposition to trade tobacco for coffee, share food, relate war stories and converse about home, or play cards during downtime on the battlefield.

headline: Historic Hysterics: Witnesses to a Really Big Show
abstract: Fifty years later, audience members who were present at the birth of Beatlemania remember the electric atmosphere and the screaming.
lead_paragraph: Debbie Gendler, a teenager from Oakland, N.J., had gone to television shows before, taking a seat in the studio audience and clapping dutifully when the “applause” light flashed. But this one was different. There were crowds outside the studio that chilly afternoon in February 1964, hysterical crowds, and a phalanx of police officers blocking the way.

headline: The Tax Wilderness, Untamed
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Income Tax', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Capital Gains Tax']

lead_paragraph: When Americans of a certain income level sit down to do their taxes this year, they may be in for an unpleasant surprise: The tax code, already byzantine, has grown even more complex — yet the prospects for a major improvement seem to have retreated into the distance.

But, nursing a broken rib, he will have to compete in the semifinals. Rivals like his countryman Max Parrot and Stale Sandbech of Norway advanced straight to the finals. NBC, 8 p.m.

headline: New York’s Affordable Housing Shortage
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Editorials']
abstract: With energy and some ingenuity, Mayor Bill de Blasio and his administration could make a dent.
lead_paragraph: New York City stands at the epicenter of an affordable housing crisis that has placed poor and elderly people throughout the country at greater risk of homelessness and forced low-income renters to forgo food and medical care to stay in their homes.

headline: Currency Wars, Revisited
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Currency', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Editorials']
abstract: Domestic problems, not foreigners, are to blame for a recent slump in emerging markets.
lead_paragraph: In recent years developing countries like Brazil complained that the United States and other industrialized countries were waging a “currency war” against them by artificially driving down the value of dollars, euros and yen. Now officials in some nations, like Argentina and Turkey, are blaming foreign “vultures” and “the interest rate lobby” for the sharp depreciation of their currencies.

headline: The Bloody Ivory Business
abstract: An assemblyman’s proposal to ban all ivory sales in New York State could send a strong signal.
lead_paragraph: The slaughter of the African elephant continues. Nearly 100 of these majestic animals are sacrificed every day for ivory trinkets — bracelets, statuettes and other baubles sold illegally around the world. Wildlife experts estimate the remaining African elephant population at 350,000 to 500,000, with poachers targeting 30,000 to 35,000 a year. Elizabeth Bennett of the Wildlife Conservation Society estimates that one subspecies, the African forest elephant, could become extinct in the next decade.

headline: De Blasio Tests Political Might in Pre-K Push
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio is now seeking to revive the populist zeal of his mayoral bid for a new campaign: persuading state lawmakers to back a tax increase to pay for prekindergarten.
lead_paragraph: He has phoned titans of finance and real estate to ask for donations. He has called on labor leaders to tap their war chests and lend their muscles. He has lined up endorsements from actors, musicians and movie producers.

headline: Knicks’ 20th Win Provides Relief for Woodson
abstract: Carmelo Anthony scored 31 points in three quarters, and the Knicks cruised past the Denver Nuggets, who played as poorly as the Knicks often do.
lead_paragraph: Late in the first quarter, Coach Mike Woodson left his seat on the bench and stood with his arms folded as he surveyed a familiar scene: missed box-outs, errant passes, poor defensive rotations. What made the situation unusual was that Woodson seemed to delight in the mistakes, largely because the Denver Nuggets were making most of them.

(Or, in the case of Russia, the gulag.)

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) 42 (2013) Chadwick Boseman, above, portrays Jackie Robinson, a shortstop for the Kansas City Monarchs of the Negro leagues, a four-sport athlete at U.C.L.A. and an Army officer during World War II. Harrison Ford plays Branch Rickey, the president and general manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers who selected Robinson to become the first black major leaguer of the modern era. But when Rickey calls his new player “superhuman,” what he means is that Robinson will have to rise above ordinary temptations in the face of prejudice and hostility to become a flawless exemplar of his race. “While ‘42,’ Brian Helgeland’s new film about Robinson, gestures toward the complicated and painful history in which its subject was embroiled,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York York Times, “it is blunt, simple and sentimental, using time-tested methods to teach a clear and rousing lesson.” He continued, “In other hands — Spike Lee’s, let’s say, or even Clint Eastwood’s — ‘42’ might have taken a tougher, more contentious look at the breaking of Major League Baseball’s color barrier.” But Mr. Helgeland “has honorably sacrificed the chance to make a great movie in the interest of making one that is accessible and inspiring. Though not accurate in every particular, the movie mostly succeeds in respecting the facts of history and the personality of its hero, and in reminding audiences why he mattered.”

headline: From Russia With Love: A Chronicle of J. Mendel
abstract: The story of J. Mendel is a fashion fairytale that has seen the storied house migrate from St. Petersburg to Paris to New York City, where Gilles Mendel is creating the most elegant of designs for the swans of New York. In this unique multimedia feature, we explore the brand’s heritage and showcase some of its most extraordinary new pieces.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Returns After a 16-Month Lockout
abstract: With many of the orchestra’s members not present, a veteran musical director was enlisted for the orchestra’s return performance.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — You knew that the Minnesota Orchestra wouldn’t let itself be embarrassed on Friday and Saturday evenings in its first concerts after management’s 16-month lockout of the players, concerts made even more prominent for being the first in Orchestra Hall since its $52 million renovation, completed last fall. In the event, the orchestra did itself proud, against long odds.

lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The snowboarder Sage Kotsenburg is not someone to hold big ambitions or make grand plans. Before winning a qualifying event last month that helped send him to the Winter Olympics in slopestyle, he had not won a snowboarding competition since he was 11.

headline: 1914: Barnyard Gaiety at the Paris Poultry Show
abstract: The fifteenth Paris Poultry show opened in the Grand Palais in 1914 with many technological novelties, as The New York Herald reported.
lead_paragraph: The President of the French Republic yesterday afternoon opened the Fifteenth International Exhibition of the Société des Aviculteurs Français, better known to Anglo-Saxons as the Paris Poultry Show. The show is being held in one of the wings of the Grand Palais, which from now until Monday next will resound with the noise and gaiety peculiar to the barnyard.

headline: A Seaside Surfing Town on Sydney’s North Shore
abstract: Manly, which hosts the Australian Open of Surfing beginning today, is fast becoming a popular getaway for good eats and great art with a fantastic view.
lead_paragraph: Sydney’s scenic enclave Manly has long been overshadowed by glitzy Bondi on the other side of the harbor, but that suits its laid-back nature just fine. Locals regularly hit the waves before heading to work in Sydney’s financial district, a five-mile ferry ride across Sydney Harbor; it’s not uncommon, while slurping fresh oysters, to spot a humpback whale leap out of the water just a shell’s throw away. Lately, artists, musicians and creative types drawn to Manly’s natural beauty and mellow pace have transformed the area into a new hub of culture and dining, and starting today, the nine-day Australian Open of Surfing takes place along its shores. Here, a field guide to enjoying the area.

headline: The Path to Reading a Newborn’s DNA Map
abstract: As technology becomes more sophisticated, genomic sequencing will inevitably expand into the world of newborns. The process has both medical and ethical implications.
lead_paragraph: What if laboratories could run comprehensive DNA tests on infants at birth, spotting important variations in their genomes that might indicate future medical problems? Should parents be told of each variation, even if any risk is still unclear? Would they even want to know?

headline: The Greater the Turmoil, the Stronger the Dollar. Again.
keywords: ['US Dollar (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: A familiar pattern is back in currency markets, even if U.S. policy is fueling some of the world’s financial problems.
lead_paragraph: Chronic problems have been flaring up in financial markets lately, and some of them may emanate from the United States. Yet none of these issues have seriously damaged the exalted status of what Washington Irving once called “the almighty dollar.”

headline: Why Emerging Markets Should Look Within
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Currency', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Self-inflicted political wounds, more than global economic tides, appear to be shaking nations like Argentina, Turkey, Ukraine and Thailand.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Argentina, Turkey, Ukraine and Thailand have endured plunging currencies, capital flight and political disruptions in varying combinations. While they have all been affected by global economic tides, these nations are facing crises because of problems in their national governance. And if we look elsewhere around the world, we find that governance has been re-emerging as a major factor behind success or failure in many emerging nations.

This week on Money Talking, Heidi Moore of the Guardian talks to Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine about how the decision could affect CVS’s bottom line.

headline: As Northwestern Players Pursue Unionization, a Voice in the Wilderness Gains a Chorus
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Organized Labor', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Football (College)', 'Basketball (College)']
abstract: Ramogi Huma is the president of the newly formed College Athletes Players Association, a union that is seeking to represent football and basketball players.
lead_paragraph: It began in the fall of 1995 with a few bags of groceries left anonymously at a teammate’s apartment. Ramogi Huma was a teenager then, a freshman linebacker at U.C.L.A., but he took notice when Donnie Edwards was suspended for accepting the food, a violation of N.C.A.A. rules. At workouts the next summer, Huma learned he was not covered by U.C.L.A.’s health insurance because some practices were voluntary. He began to see a pattern.

headline: Program Benefiting Some Immigrants Extends Visa Wait for Others

headline: Afghan Forces’ Killings of Civilians Rose in 2013
abstract: A United Nations report shows a rise in civilian casualties, with a reduced share of those attributed to international forces.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government’s share of blame for civilian casualties rose drastically last year, largely reflecting an intensification in the ground conflict between insurgents and Afghan troops, according to a new report from the United Nations released Saturday.

They thought the headline was presumptuous and made them sound as if they assumed they would win the World Series.

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A painful mosquito-borne virus common in Africa and Asia has advanced quickly throughout the eastern Caribbean in the past two months, raising the prospect that a once-distant illness will become entrenched throughout the region, public health experts say.

headline: Snowden Used Low-Cost Tool to Best N.S.A.
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Edward J. Snowden gathered National Security Agency secrets using cheap and widely available “web crawler” software, a breach that should have easily been detected, investigators say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intelligence officials investigating how Edward J. Snowden gained access to a huge trove of the country’s most highly classified documents say they have determined that he used inexpensive and widely available software to “scrape” the National Security Agency’s networks, and kept at it even after he was briefly challenged by agency officials.

headline: Where Is My Family on TV?
abstract: Mixed-race families are absent from our screens.
lead_paragraph: ONE of my earliest memories is of sitting in an idling car with my mom and sister outside a convenience store in Virginia. Dad’s inside, buying cigarettes and scratch-off lottery tickets. Suddenly, a wild-eyed man appears at the driver-side window, yelling about white women and black men and how they don’t belong together. My mother goes feral, blocking his access to us. My father runs out, furious and swearing, before driving us away. I don’t remember what happened next, just a confusing and searing shame about the ugliness that the sight of my family could provoke.

headline: Michio Kaku
abstract: A theoretical physicist who dresses up to sneak in a little ice-skating with his wife.
lead_paragraph: Michio Kaku is a theoretical physicist and professor at City College of New York. When not trying to complete Einstein’s theory of everything, he writes books that explain physics and how developments in the field will shape the future.

lead_paragraph: THE pope, a porn star and a parrot walk into a bar.

headline: Still Mad as Hell

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I OFTEN wonder what Paddy would think.

headline: The Games Begin in Russia, and an Actor’s Life Ends in New York
abstract: Sporting events in New Jersey and Russia and a sad loss for the arts.
lead_paragraph: From their inception in the 1890s, the modern Olympic Games have differed from other sporting tournaments (the Super Bowl, for example, on which more later) in the overlay of idealism that Baron Pierre de Coubertin, the father of the modern Games, concocted from the mythology of the ancient Greek Games and his own 19th-century aristocratic sporting traditions. Never mind that his idealized Olympic Games have long given way to commercialism, professionalism, corruption, politics and boycotts; the notion that the Games somehow elevate the world above its usual sordid nastiness has remained an integral part of their image.

headline: Whose Garbage Is This Anyway?
abstract: The Middle East peace process might benefit from a local eco-tour.
lead_paragraph: HEBRON, West Bank — It was not your usual Holy Land tour, but surely one of the most revealing I’ve ever had. A team from Friends of the Earth Middle East took me around to see how waste, sewage and untreated water flow, or don’t, between Israel and the West Bank. I never realized how political garbage and dirty water could be, or how tracking it could reveal just why making peace here is so urgent.

headline: Leaving Work Behind
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Working Hours', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Are the effects of Obamacare on employment a sign of things to come?
lead_paragraph: IN 1930, in the darkening valley of the Great Depression, John Maynard Keynes wrote an essay on “Economic Possibilities for Our Grandchildren,” which foresaw a much happier future — one of growth, abundance and the steady decline of full-time work. Eventually, he suggested, civilization might settle on a 15-hour workweek, with three hours of daily labor being sufficient “to satisfy the old Adam in most of us.”

headline: Why Nutrition Is So Confusing
abstract: We haven’t done the studies that would clarify what it takes to be lean and healthy.
lead_paragraph: NEARLY six weeks into the 2014 diet season, it’s a good bet that many of us who made New Year’s resolutions to lose weight have already peaked. If clinical trials are any indication, we’ve lost much of the weight we can expect to lose. In a year or two we’ll be back within half a dozen pounds of where we are today.

headline: How Single Motherhood Hurts Kids
abstract: The link between poverty and absent dads in the U.S. can’t be denied.
lead_paragraph: The last few weeks have brought an unusual convergence of voices from both the center and the left about a topic that is typically part of conservative rhetorical territory: poverty and single-parent families. Just as some conservatives have started talking seriously about rising inequality and stagnant incomes, some liberals have finally begun to admit that our stubbornly high rates of poverty and social and economic immobility are closely entwined with the rise of single motherhood.

headline: When We House Mentally Ill People in Prisons
abstract: Readers comment on my column about the de facto criminalization of psychiatric disorders
lead_paragraph: My sunday column is about the way the dearth of mental health services ends up propelling people with psychiatric disorders into prisons and jails, so that today many more mentally ill people are behind bars than in psychiatric hospitals. This column arose out of my earlier invitation to readers to suggest topics that we in journalism should cover more aggressively in 2014. I suggested that one of these is mental health issues, which I wrote about generally last month, and this is a follow-up. I’d welcome your thoughts on this.

headline: Can You Live on the Minimum Wage?
abstract: More than 4.8 million workers now earn the lowest legal pay. This calculator shows the hard choices that have to be made living on the smallest paychecks.
lead_paragraph: More than 4.8 million workers now earn the lowest legal pay. This calculator shows the hard choices that have to be made living on the smallest paychecks.

headline: The Case for a Higher Minimum Wage
abstract: An increase would help 27.8 million people. It would also help balance power in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: The political posturing over raising the minimum wage sometimes obscures the huge and growing number of low-wage workers it would affect. An estimated 27.8 million people would earn more money under the Democratic proposal to lift the hourly minimum from $7.25 today to $10.10 by 2016. And most of them do not fit the low-wage stereotype of a teenager with a summer job. Their average age is 35; most work full time; more than one-fourth are parents; and, on average, they earn half of their families’ total income.

headline: The Winning Formula of Luge’s ‘Old Man’

lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — To discover how the 40-year-old Italian luger Armin Zöggeler has remained at the top of his sport for more than 20 years, I persuaded him to tell me his secrets. “Apples,” he told me. “And I have lots of noodles for lunch, and steak for dinner every night.”

headline: Broad Museum in Los Angeles Delays Opening Until 2015
abstract: The construction of the $140 million contemporary art museum in downtown Los Angeles has run into “complications.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Officials at the Broad, the $140 million museum of contemporary art designed by Diller Scofidio & Renfro to showcase Eli and Edythe Broad’s vast collection, have for months been touting an opening here “by the end of 2014.” Mr. Broad has even been leading some of the hard-hat tours.

headline: Misstep Costs Bode Miller a Medal as Austrian Wins Downhill
abstract: Matthias Mayer of Austria, an unheralded 23-year-old, won the men’s downhill, while the American Bode Miller faltered and placed eighth.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Dominant in the training runs, Bode Miller charged out of the start to the men’s downhill Sunday and was soon leading by roughly a third of a second.

headline: From Runyon to the Runway
abstract: Fashion has already appropriated the Birkenstock and the Bermuda short. Now the maligned Teva feels the love.
lead_paragraph: Fashion has already appropriated the Birkenstock and the Bermuda short. Now the maligned Teva feels the love.

headline: Fashion Week Morning Report: No Day of Rest
abstract: Sunday’s shows range from street-wear influenced to pretty and polished.
lead_paragraph: When a Beckham beckons, the fashion set answers. This will be no day of rest. Sunday morning of New York Fashion Week starts bright and early with the Victoria Beckham collection at 10 a.m.

headline: Quora and the Search for Truth
abstract: The Internet is a place of unreliable facts and heavy socialization, so it makes sense that there is a website like Quora, where a registered community of users poses and answers questions about all sorts of things. With 450,000 topics, it’s a challenge to keep it all straight, but it’s necessary for a future ad business.
lead_paragraph: The Internet has a nagging problem: There is lots of information, but often confusion about what’s true. Many big websites try to solve this problem with their services. At least one, Quora, suggests that maybe we don’t care that much about the truth.

headline: In Our Pages: February 10
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Turkish Women Warned Against Western Dress

headline: Document | Made for More Than Walking
abstract: A single photograph of a woman’s legs may be titillating. But a cluster of 30 glamorous gams cut from the pages of glossy magazines is more than that.
lead_paragraph: A single photograph of a woman’s legs may be titillating. But a cluster of 30 glamorous gams cut from the pages of glossy magazines is more than that. “Legs,” by the German artist Hans-Peter Feldmann, questions, with an erotomaniac’s attention to detail, advertising’s ravenous commodification of beauty. The 73-year-old’s work, an obsessive appropriation of everyday objects — from photographs of unmade beds to the front pages of 250 newspapers dated Sept. 12, 2001 — is in line with that of American conceptualists like Richard Prince and Dash Snow. And yet, he has trouble explaining his ideas: “When they asked the Austrian composer Bruckner what inspired his masterwork ‘Te Deum,’ he said it came to him while . . . eating a cheese sandwich.” Feldmann frankly loves sitting in a cafe and admiring the pretty passers-by, but says that the best legs he knows belong to Ursula, his wife of more than 40 years. “Is it sexist of me to focus so much on a woman’s legs?” he wonders. “I don’t know. Ask the great inventor in the sky.”

headline: Jamie Anderson, Slopestyle’s Star, Is on Top Again
abstract: Anderson has won more of slopestyle’s big events than any woman in history, and her gold medal capped an American sweep of the inaugural Olympic slopestyle events.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Jamie Anderson stood at the top of the slopestyle course Sunday, her boots strapped to her snowboard and opportunity at her feet. She had won more of slopestyle’s big competitions than any other woman, but now the event was in the Olympics, and she had one run to capture the gold medal she was expected to win.

headline: Rejecting the U.S. to Skate for Russia
abstract: The speedskating star Ahn Hyun-soo chose Russia over the United States and changed his name to Viktor after switching allegiance from South Korea in 2011.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — In 2011, the South Korean short-track speedskating star Ahn Hyun-soo became a Russian citizen, changed his name to Viktor Ahn and pledged to compete for his adopted homeland at the Sochi Games. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was said to be especially pleased.

headline: Months After Deadly Fire, Owners of Bangladesh Factory Surrender to Court
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Delowar Hossain and his wife, Mahmuda Akther, the owners of the Tazreen factory, face homicide charges in the 2012 blaze, which killed 112 employees.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A husband and wife whose factory in Bangladesh was consumed by fire in 2012, a disaster that killed 112 employees, surrendered to a court on Sunday in Dhaka, the capital.

abstract: Alexander Wang used outdoor sports and survival skills as his inspiration for autumn 2014 while Joseph Altuzarra reveled in craftsmanship.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan was reduced to a skyline of high rises shimmering across the water. A tangle of transport gear covered the Brooklyn Navy Yard, while inside one of the vast industrial spaces was a set with silvered pillars.

headline: Household Worker Trips Up Britain’s Immigration Minister

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British immigration minister has resigned after revealing that his house cleaner of six years was living in the country illegally.

headline: For Austrians, Downhill Is the Extreme Sport to Own
abstract: Matthias Mayer surpassed favorites including Bode Miller to win Austria’s first gold medal in the men’s downhill in 12 years.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Competitors do all manner of spectacular things above the snow at this postmodern stage of winter sport’s development: backside rodeos, double corks, tail grabs, switch mistys. The gravity-taunting soars on, and as the quadrenniums roll by, the Winter Olympics keep adding fresh diversions in an attempt to catch up with the curve.

headline: Disruptions: For a Restful Night, Make Your Smartphone Sleep on the Couch
abstract: Many Americans now bring their smartphones into the bedroom, especially to use them as alarm clocks. But that may be a recipe for insomnia, studies show.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all been there. You wake up in the middle of the night and grab your smartphone to check the time — it’s 3 a.m. — and see an alert. Before you know it, you fall down a rabbit hole of email and Twitter. Sleep? Forget it.

(CBS) THE BEATLES: THE NIGHT THAT CHANGED AMERICA — A GRAMMY SALUTE Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr perform together and are interviewed by David Letterman (above right, with Mr. McCartney, left, and Mr. Starr) in this 50th-anniversary tribute to the Beatles’ appearance on “The Ed Sullivan Show” on Feb. 9, 1964. headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Parting Ways at Alexander Wang
abstract: The masculine hair at last night’s show was inspired by one of the designer’s own fashion sketches.
lead_paragraph: “I wanted to do hair that was very drawn on, like an illustration,” the hairstylist Guido Palau said of the superslick and tight-to-the-head looks he created backstage at Alexander Wang last night. Fittingly, the inspiration turned out to be a fashion sketch the designer penned himself in advance of the show. To bring it all to life, Palau etched a deep side part with his comb and saturated strands in Redken Control Addict 28 High-Control Hairspray before wrapping them firmly around the head. “It’s like a very low sweep-over, like a man’s hair,” he remarked (otherwise known as the comb-over; who knew it could look so cool?). Palau then patted on a Redken Shine Flash 02 Glistening Mist for some sheen, and pulled strands into a slim ponytail, which was later tucked out of sight into the models’ clothing. To reinforce this idea of hair-as-fashion-illustration, he also “painted away” the part lines with makeup to prevent any skin from showing, and gave the models who closed the show — including Karlie Kloss, Jacquetta Wheeler and Joan Smalls — a blast of colored hair powder for an ultra-matte effect, like ink set to dry on paper.

headline: Israel Orders Airstrike Against Gaza Militant
abstract: The target of the strike by the Israeli military, a Palestinian militant accused of firing rockets into Israel, was critically wounded, along with a bystander.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military said that it carried out an airstrike early Sunday against a Palestinian militant in Gaza responsible for firing rockets into Israel. Medical officials in Gaza reported that the target of the strike, who was riding a motorcycle, was critically wounded and a bystander was hurt.

headline: Figure Skating Gold Is Russia’s First
abstract: Russia won the long program in men’s, women’s and pairs competition for a resounding victory in the team event, a restorative achievement for a nation.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — In an arena filled with waving flags, the coronating presence of President Vladimir V. Putin, bouquets of tossed flowers and a whiff of scandal, Russia won its first gold medal Sunday as host of the Sochi Olympics, taking first place in a new team figure skating competition and reasserting its prominence in the marquee sport of the Winter Games.

lead_paragraph: “Questioning Darwin,” a documentary on Monday night on HBO, starts out with a refreshingly unusual approach to a polarizing subject, then finds a way to deepen it.

headline: Felix Loch Keeps Hold on Luge, Winning Second Straight Gold
abstract: Germany’s Loch extended his lead in the third run before officially claiming his prize, over two luge legends, with a solid final trip.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — There was little drama at the Sanki Sliding Center here Sunday night as Felix Loch of Germany continued his domination of the men’s luge event at the Sochi Games and won a second consecutive Olympic gold medal.

headline: Despite Frigid Relations, Chinese Relics Coming Home From Norway

lead_paragraph: Seven marble columns from the Old Summer Palace in Beijing, acquired more than a century ago by a former Norwegian cavalry officer who had settled in China, are set to return home this fall under an agreement between a Norwegian museum and a Chinese businessman.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: State-Sanctioned Snooping to Keep Progress at Bay
abstract: “Spies of Mississippi,” on PBS, traces the evolution of the state’s Sovereignty Commission from a propaganda outlet into a spy network aimed at stopping integration.
lead_paragraph: Peer into the history of the South, and it’s not hard to find things that once might have seemed acceptable to many people but today register as appalling. “Spies of Mississippi” is such an exploration, one with an especially clear parallel to today.

headline: With a Cloud Over Woodson, Durant Adds to the Knicks’ Troubles
abstract: After Mike Woodson acknowledged that his job security was probably an issue on his players’ minds, the Knicks fell to the Thunder, with Kevin Durant scoring 41 points.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — It was another day under the spotlight for Mike Woodson, another day spent trying to sidestep it.

headline: But You Can’t Deny Destiny
abstract: In “Hasee Toh Phasee,” a wedding is approaching, but the groom has some things on his mind, including his fiancée’s long-estranged sister.
lead_paragraph: Just days before his wedding, Nikhil finds himself in a bit of a bind: Not only does he need to prove his business savvy, and therefore worth, to his fiancée, but he also must keep her recently returned, long-estranged sister, Meeta, out of sight. It’s a recipe for failure. But in Vinil Mathew’s “Hasee Toh Phasee,” the setup is also the perfect foil to what is an imperfect union.

headline: Swiss Voters Narrowly Approve Curbs on Immigration
abstract: Voters backed measures to reintroduce restrictions on the number of foreigners allowed to live and work in the country, a move that could have implications for the nation’s ties with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A narrow majority of voters in Switzerland approved proposals on Sunday that would reintroduce restrictions on the number of foreigners who are allowed to live and work in the country, a move that could have far-reaching implications for Switzerland’s relations with the European Union.

headline: Bloody Trouble at School
abstract: “Vampire Academy,” based on Richelle Mead’s young adult series, uses many familiar themes of the bloodsucking genre.
lead_paragraph: The family line for the teenage flick “Vampire Academy” may trace back to “Dracula,” but the recycling policy is strictly from “Frankenstein.” Directed by Mark Waters and written by Daniel Waters, his brother, this genre rehash takes a helping of “Harry Potter,” a measure of “Mean Girls” and elements from various teenage adventures, monster movies and queen-bee stories and recombines the borrowed parts into an unsurprisingly familiar tale. What is surprising is that while the patchwork whole creaks terribly in places, the parts also show signs of life.

headline: Europe’s Painful Past Colors a Film Festival
abstract: Europe’s past is evident at the Berlin International Film Festival, as are topical issues like art repatriation and widespread intelligence gathering by the National Security Agency.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — From Wes Anderson’s “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” a tender, urbane caper set in a lost world of interwar Europe, to George Clooney’s “The Monuments Men,” in which the Allies try to save priceless art from the Nazis, Europe’s past — real, imagined, unresolved — is very present at this year’s Berlin International Film Festival.

headline: Fox Cancels ‘The X Factor’ After Three Seasons
abstract: The announcement followed a statement by the program’s creator, Simon Cowell, who said that he would resume his hosting duties this year on the original British incarnation.
lead_paragraph: Fox has canceled its version of the singing competition series “The X Factor” after three seasons. The announcement followed a statement by the program’s creator, Simon Cowell, who said that he would resume his hosting duties this year on the original British incarnation. “Last year, for a number of reasons, I had to make a decision to return to the U.K. version of ‘The X Factor’ in 2014,” Mr. Cowell said. “So for now, I’m back to the U.K., and I want to thank Fox for being an incredible partner, and I also want to thank everybody who has supported my shows.” “The X Factor” completed its third season in December, drawing 6.2 million total viewers for its finale. Before the series premiere in September 2011, Mr. Cowell said that if the show did not pull in 20 million viewers, it would have to be considered a failure. It fell well short of that, attracting 12.5 million at the start, and it never matched the ratings heights of “American Idol” (once the judging home of Mr. Cowell) on Fox or “The Voice” on NBC.

headline: ‘A Raisin in the Sun’ Loses Diahann Carroll
abstract: Ms. Carroll, 78, has dropped out of the Broadway revival of Lorraine Hansberry’s 1959 drama.
lead_paragraph: Diahann Carroll has dropped out of the Broadway revival of Lorraine Hansberry’s 1959 drama “A Raisin in the Sun.” Ms. Carroll, 78, below, was cast for the role of Lena Younger opposite Denzel Washington as Walter Lee Younger, but she has decided to withdraw “due to the demands of the vigorous rehearsal schedule and the subsequent eight-performances-a-week playing schedule,” according to Philip Rinaldi, a spokesman for the production. LaTanya Richardson Jackson (“Joe Turner’s Come and Gone”) is to assume the role in her place. This was to be Ms. Carroll’s first role on Broadway in over 30 years. She last appeared in a production of John Pielmeier’s play “Agnes of God” in 1983. In 2004, Ms. Carroll, a breast cancer survivor, also had to drop out of a Kennedy Center production of Ernest Thompson’s “On Golden Pond” because of a herniated disk and severe muscle strain. “A Raisin in the Sun” is scheduled to begin previews on March 8 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, with opening night set for April 3 for a 14-week run.

headline: Hailee Steinfeld at Prabal Gurung
abstract: The teenage actress arrived looking polished in a monochromatic knit ensemble and black felt fedora.
lead_paragraph: A streaker notwithstanding, Prabal Gurung’s show went off without a hitch Saturday morning. Hailee Steinfeld, the 17-year-old actress, arrived near 11:15 a.m., punctual by fashion standards, shepherded by her Teen Vogue pal Andrew Bevan. Despite what may be an early weekend hour for the teenage actress, she was preternaturally polished in a monochromatic knit ensemble and black felt fedora.

headline: A Writer’s Pantheon, Focused on the Details
abstract: “A Place in the Country,” first published in German in 1998, consists of lightly connected essays in which W. G. Sebald writes about six artists he admires.
lead_paragraph: It’s tempting to say that “A Place in the Country,” lightly connected essays in which W. G. Sebald writes about six artists he admires, will hold interest only for Sebald completists. But then, it’s hard to imagine a Sebald reader who isn’t an obsessive completist.

headline: Legacy in Mind, Taylor Plans a Center for Modern Dance
abstract: As Paul Taylor celebrates his company’s 60th anniversary, he announces a plan to keep it going on for at least “another 60 years” by establishing a center for American modern dance.
lead_paragraph: After Martha Graham’s death, a bitter and protracted legal dispute erupted over who had the rights to the revolutionary modern dances she created. When Merce Cunningham died in 2009, his dance company went on a farewell tour and then disbanded, according to his wishes.

headline: Pair Gain High Score in Parkinson Foundation Event
abstract: Rajat Basu and Jared Lilienstein achieved 77 percent in all of the 25 games that raised money for charity.
lead_paragraph: Rajat Basu and Jared Lilienstein of New York City achieved the highest score, 77 percent, among all of the 25 games, involving 262 pairs, at the Jan. 26 fund-raiser for the National Parkinson Foundation. They played at the Manhattan Bridge Club.

headline: At 41, Still Soaring, Still Rising
abstract: In a sport where many jumpers retire by the time they reach their 30s, Noriaki Kasai, 41, is taking part in a record-tying seventh Winter Games.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Japan’s top ski jumper, Noriaki Kasai, is already thinking four years ahead to the next Winter Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Feb. 10
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: At the Box Office, Little Plastic Bricks Have Legs
abstract: “The Lego Movie,” based on, well, Legos, was a surprise box-office leader this weekend, followed by George Clooney’s “The Monuments Men.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sorry, George Clooney. Hollywood’s biggest star, at least for the moment, is a Lego.

headline: How Do You Like Your Blue-Eyed Boys, Mr. Rap?
abstract: Aer, a white hip-hop and reggae duo, performed to an almost exclusively white audience at Irving Plaza.
lead_paragraph: It’s morning in Macklemore’s America.

headline: Flappy Bird Soars, Then Disappears, Along With a Weekend
abstract: For weeks, Flappy Bird nested atop the most downloaded app charts for Apple and Google mobile devices. The creator of the app, an independent developer in Vietnam, became an overnight success story. Then he pulled the plug on his hit.
lead_paragraph: My plan was to spend the weekend catching up on all the magazines that have been piling up in my house. Instead I’ve blown countless hours playing an almost sadistically difficult game with crude graphics and laughable sound effects.

headline: Band of Outsiders: Fall 2014 RTW

headline: Rectitude and Desire, Both at Sea
abstract: The powerful 2010 production of “Billy Budd” from Glyndebourne Festival Opera, directed by Michael Grandage, opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Britten’s opera “Billy Budd” is the wrenching story of its title character, a young, naïve and guileless sailor pressed into service aboard a British war ship in 1797. Rather than resent the loss of his liberty, Billy, a foundling, is grateful to be part of something important, a contributing member of a community.

headline: Bounding Toward Balletic Maturity
abstract: The young dancers of the American Ballet Theater’s Studio Company performed a program that included “Raymonda — Pas de Sept.”
lead_paragraph: Growing up involves successive acts of bravery. You must learn how to cross a street, pass examinations, take public transportation — things that so soon become standard fare that we forget their initial challenge. And so it is with dance. Child dancers regularly learn aspects of technique that are beyond the capacity of us nondancers. But in big theaters, it’s easy to take much for granted — whereas studio conditions bring us closer to the practical physics of ballet. On Saturday night, when the young dancers of American Ballet Theater’s Studio Company performed at the 92nd Street Y Buttenwieser Hall, their courage was evident — and admirable — in the opening ensemble adagio of the first item.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Hood by Air Fall/Winter 2014

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Julieta Cervantes.

headline: ‘Get Lucky,’ Sochi Style
abstract: A group of police officers became sudden celebrities by covering “Get Lucky,” Daft Punk’s Grammy Award-winning record of the year, shortly before the opening ceremony of the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: The Olympics usually mint new and unlikely stars. Nearly always, they are athletes. But on Friday night, a group of mostly stern-looking police officers became sudden celebrities by covering “Get Lucky,” Daft Punk’s Grammy Award-winning record of the year shortly before the opening ceremony of the Winter Games from Sochi, Russia. The performance by the Ministry of Internal Affairs choir of “Get Lucky” went viral: It has been seen about 750,000 times since NBC posted it online. The choir’s reward: an appearance on Monday morning on NBC’s “Today.” The incongruity of the choir, dressed in evergreen uniforms accented by yellow braided cords, performing the slightly racy song (“She’s up all night for good fun/I’m up all night to get lucky”), doubtlessly accounts for its appeal. The two lead singers were the stars (a baritone joined them later); some others bobbed their heads but did not get funky, while others looked uncomfortable at their surreal dip into dance music. Rolling Stone labeled the police choir’s rendition “incredible” and noted “the officers’ hilarious ‘old, goofy man dancing at a wedding reception’ dance moves.” A spokeswoman for Daft Punk had no comment on the choir’s cover. The performance followed a studio version of the same number that was posted on YouTube in November. That performance, even more animated than Friday’s, has been viewed nearly 4.4 million times.

headline: Eight Are Charged After a Cockfighting Crackdown That Finds 3,000 Caged Birds

lead_paragraph: Five people were charged after investigators raided a bloody late-night cockfight in the squalid basement of a vacant Queens storefront where birds waiting for later rounds were kept in sacks hanging from the walls, officials said on Sunday.

He insists that the important divide is between Keynesians and anti-Keynesians, who aren’t expressing so much a theory as an ideology.

headline: Writing Off the Unemployed
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs']
abstract: Fuzzy thinking meets lack of compassion as Republicans try to rationalize their refusal to extend benefits.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1987 my Princeton colleague Alan Blinder published a very good book titled “Hard Heads, Soft Hearts.” It was, as you might guess, a call for tough-minded but compassionate economic policy. Unfortunately, what we actually got — especially, although not only, from Republicans — was the opposite. And it’s difficult to find a better example of the hardhearted, softheaded nature of today’s G.O.P. than what happened last week, as Senate Republicans once again used the filibuster to block aid to the long-term unemployed.

headline: Mercy in the Justice System
abstract: President Obama needs to restructure the screening process for clemency applications, which is in a state of collapse.
lead_paragraph: The constitutional provision that gives the president virtually unlimited authority to grant clemency was not an afterthought. The founders understood very well that there could be miscarriages of justice even under the rule of law. By allowing the president to commute unjust sentences or pardon deserving petitioners who had served their time, they sought to ensure that the workings of the courts could be tempered with mercy.

headline: Closing In on Basic Mideast Principles
abstract: The Israelis and the Palestinians will soon have to decide whether they want to go deeper into peace talks.
lead_paragraph: For months, Israelis and Palestinians, with American mediation, have been working on a set of principles that would serve as the basis for negotiations on a final peace agreement. By the end of March, the world is likely to know whether they have been successful. If the two sides agree on basic principles — a framework for further talks — it will be an important step. But then comes the even tougher task of translating principles into a final deal that would recognize a Palestinian state alongside Israel.

headline: A More Useful Germany

abstract: A healthy debate has been sparked by the country’s president, who suggested Germany play a bigger role in international affairs, even if that means using the army.
lead_paragraph: Addressing the opening session late last month of the Munich Security Conference, a yearly gathering of top Western diplomats and defense officials, President Joachim Gauck of Germany expressed sentiments that not many years ago would have brought demonstrators into the streets. The Germans, he declared, should stop hiding behind guilt over their militaristic past and take more responsibility for shaping international affairs. If that meant using the Germany Army, “Germany should not say ‘no’ on principle.”

headline: Celebrating Bert Berns, Sometimes Overlooked, but Not Forgotten
abstract: The music journalist Joel Selvin has spent 16 years researching the career of Bert Berns, a songwriter who died young in 1967.
lead_paragraph: The songwriters who pounded out pop hits in the Brill Building and other New York hit factories in the 1950s and early 1960s, though eclipsed in the wake of the British Invasion, have mostly found a comfortable niche in pop music history by now. Carole King went on to have a rich career, and now her early days as part of the Goffin-King songwriting team are being revisited on Broadway in “Beautiful” — which also shines a light on the collaboration of their friendly competitors, Cynthia Weil and Barry Mann. Others, like Neil Sedaka, Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, and Jeff Barry and Ellie Greenwich have all maintained their hold on the spotlight.

headline: After Prize, Novel Gets 2nd Chance in the U.S.
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: The book “Where the Moon Isn’t” went by “The Shock of the Fall” in Britain, and its publisher is reintroducing it under the second title after it won an award.
lead_paragraph: Last November, St. Martin’s Press published a debut novel, “Where the Moon Isn’t,” that few people seemed to notice. Reviewers mostly ignored it. Sales were tepid. Somewhat confusingly, the book was released in Britain in May under a different title, “The Shock of the Fall,” which its publisher there preferred.

headline: Chamber Music Society Announces Season
abstract: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center plans to open its 45th anniversary season on Oct. 15 with the pianist Alessio Bax playing a pair of Mozart concertos for piano and string quintet.
lead_paragraph: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center plans to open its 45th anniversary season on Oct. 15 with the pianist Alessio Bax playing a pair of Mozart concertos for piano and string quintet, and will present more than 120 concerts, with about half in New York and half on tour. The season, which is being announced Monday, shows how large the society has grown since its first season in 1969, when it presented only 21 concerts; the society said that its ticket revenue has grown by 50 percent over the last five years. This season will include the German baritone Christian Gerhaher performing Schubert’s “Winterreise,” three performances of Bach’s “Brandenburg Concertos,” and a continuation of its new music series in the Kaplan Penthouse.

headline: Report Says Not Enough Children Get HPV Vaccine
abstract: The vaccine can protect against cancer-causing strains of the virus, which is transmitted by intimate contact.
lead_paragraph: Not enough children in the United States are being vaccinated against the cancer-causing human papillomavirus, or HPV, according to a report issued on Monday by the President’s Cancer Panel. The viruses, transmitted by intimate contact, cause cancers of the cervix, vagina, vulva, anus and penis and areas near the throat. Vaccines can protect against two strains that cause most of the cancers, and a series of three injections is recommended for boys and girls starting at age 11 to 12. But in 2012, only about a third of girls ages 13 to 15 and less than 7 percent of boys in the United States had received the shots. Vaccination rates are much higher in Australia (71.2 percent) and Britain (60.4 percent). Doctors and parents need better education, the report says, and it also urges that pharmacists be allowed to give the injections.

Judging begins on this opening night with the hound, toy, nonsporting and herding groups. Sporting, working and terrier groups, followed by best in show, are to be judged from 8 to 11 p.m. Tuesday on USA. David Frei and Erica Hill are the hosts. Banana Joe, an affenpinscher, is the reigning top dog.

headline: 50 Years Later, Beatles Steal Another Show
abstract: Sunday night’s tribute concert on CBS, like the 1964 broadcast it commemorated, belonged to the Beatles themselves.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing pop has learned in the last 50 years, it’s that Beatles songs never wear out their welcome. The Beatles’ original recordings have retained not only their musical brilliance but also the nearly universal good will that the band generated in its time, as well as the accumulated nostalgia that makes baby boomers conflate its music with all the pleasures of their youth. On purely musical grounds — the foundation of melodies, harmonies and lyrics — Beatles songs have thrived through half a century of remakes.

lead_paragraph: On Monday, Microsoft is officially releasing and pricing a new version of its Excel spreadsheet program. Excel is a cornerstone of Microsoft’s software sales to businesses, so it matters a great deal to the company’s future.

headline: A Farewell to the Maruti 800, Humble King of India’s Roads
abstract: The tough, no-frills hatchback, which has ceased production after more than 30 years, has earned the affection of legions of fans, who include the author.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After more than 30 years of production, Maruti Suzuki, one of the biggest car manufacturers in India, said late last week that it would no longer make its iconic model, the Maruti 800. After selling almost 3 million worldwide, declining sales and stricter emissions standards have convinced the company’s owners, nostalgic themselves, to let go.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Lori Gottlieb on the Sex Lives in Peer Marriages
abstract: The sexual dimension in an equal marriage often gets lost because even though people are running these well-oiled, cooperative machines at home, they can forget to create a space for this other side of their partners.
lead_paragraph: Lori Gottlieb wrote this week’s cover story about what a peer marriage can do to a couple’s sex life. A contributing editor for The Atlantic and a psychotherapist in Los Angeles, Gottlieb is the author of “Marry Him: The Case for Settling for Mr. Good Enough.” She wrote about the business of psychotherapy in the Nov. 25, 2012, issue of the magazine.

headline: Nepal Picks New Premier, Putting End to Stalemate

headline: A Chinese Official’s Job Plea to JPMorgan’s Chief
abstract: A confidential email shows a top Chinese insurance regulator directly asked JPMorgan Chase’s chief for a “favor” to hire a young job applicant. | Steven A. Cohen, the founder of SAC Capital Advisors, remains as elusive as ever. | Alibaba seeks control of AutoNavi. | Apple gains an ally in the fight against Carl C. Icahn. | Stealth I.P.O.’s are on the rise.
lead_paragraph: CHINESE OFFICIAL MADE JOB PLEA TO JPMORGAN’S CHIEF  |  In yet another potential setback for JPMorgan Chase, a confidential email shows a top Chinese insurance regulator directly asked Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan’s chairman and chief executive, for a “favor” to hire a young job applicant, a family friend of the regulator. Interviews, and the previously unreported email, show that Mr. Dimon met the applicant at a meeting in 2012, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The meeting came as JPMorgan was seeking lucrative work from Chinese insurance companies.

headline: Democrats Have Christie ‘Buyer’s Remorse,’ Buono Says
abstract: Now that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is in hot water over the bridge scandal, Barbara Buono, his rival in the 2013 election, said Democrats who didn’t support her are regretting it.
lead_paragraph: METUCHEN, N.J. — The former campaign workers who partied at the home of Barbara Buono this month were “just jubilant.” The people she bumps into on the street “are just happier to greet me.” And amid the deluge of supportive texts she receives, there are often pictures of Gov. Chris Christie sitting on the George Washington Bridge. She chuckles but doesn’t reply.

Characters playing characters.” Read here for more on Mr. Wilkinson’s work, which is up for an Oscar, then watch this video.

headline: Why Do You Care How Much Other People Work?
abstract: Getting past paternalism and prejudice.
lead_paragraph: The brouhaha over the CBO report – I don’t want to call it a debate, because that would suggest that people on both sides are making sense, or even listening – continues. But there is a massive lack of clarity. This is, no doubt, in large part because incoherence serves the interests of some parties. But I think there’s also some genuine intellectual confusion that might, for a few players at least, actually be reduced by careful analysis.

headline: Macroeconomic Winners and Losers (Implicitly Wonkish)
abstract: What’s publishable isn’t useful.
lead_paragraph: John Quiggin looks at a recent book that purports to explain the big ideas in macroeconomics, but doesn’t contain any, well, macroeconomics. His meditation on how that can happen involves a useful take on what happened to the profession in the decades that preceded the 2008 crisis, and a very interesting take on the current state of affairs (DSGE is “dynamic stochastic general equilibrium” — basically, the particular form of modeling that is more or less the only thing one can publish in journals these days):

headline: California’s Physician Directories Removed Because of Errors
abstract: Doctors and patients complained of numerous mistakes about crucial facts like which physicians were in which network, and what they specialized in.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The California health care exchange has taken down its physician directories, amid continuing complaints from doctors and patients alike that the lists of doctors and hospitals included in each insurance plan were error-riddled and unreliable.

headline: Victoria Beckham’s Grown-Up Collection
abstract: Perhaps the designer’s quirky second line has led her to take the original range so seriously.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Beckham turns 40 this spring, although you wouldn’t guess from looking at this young woman greeting her soccer star husband David and all four children, three boys and a girl.

headline: A Big Pot of Simmered Pintos
abstract: A simple pot of savory beans can be a meal or the first step in another dish.
lead_paragraph: This pot of beans was Step 1 for the other Recipes for Health this week. If I know that I’m going to use these beans for a Mexican dinner I season them with cilantro and, if I can find it, epazote. If I want Italian or Provençal flavors I make a bouquet garni with bay leaf, thyme, parsley, maybe sage, and most definitely a Parmesan rind. This week, since I am using my beans as a starting off point for other dishes, I season them only with onion, garlic, bay leaf and salt. The dishes that will follow throughout the week will introduce more flavors.

headline: Suicide Bomb Trainer in Iraq Accidentally Blows Up His Class
abstract: Twenty-two militants at a training session were killed after a commander mistakenly used an armed belt during a demonstration.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — If there were such a thing, it would probably be rule No. 1 in the teaching manual for instructors of aspiring suicide bombers: Don’t give lessons with live explosives.

headline: Pasta e Fagiole
abstract: A classic Italian bean and pasta soup makes a delicious meal.
lead_paragraph: This is a classic Italian bean and pasta soup. If you have already made a pot of beans using a pound of beans, and want to use it for this soup, just use half the beans but all of the broth as directed in Step 1.

headline: Vegetarian Chili With Winter Vegetables
abstract: A thick satisfying dish with sweet flavors and a comforting texture.
lead_paragraph: I have made several versions of vegetarian chili; in some the beans take center stage, others are just as focused on vegetables. This thick, satisfying chili is equally focused on both. I particularly like the way the sweet flavor and comforting, creamy texture of the winter squash plays against the spicy flavors in the chili.

headline: Bruschetta With Smashed Beans, Sage and Kale
abstract: Seasoned greens and a bit of cheese turns bruschetta into a meal.
lead_paragraph: This is comfort food – a generous spoonful of thick beans seasoned with fresh sage on top of a substantial slice of garlic toast. To make a meal of it I top the beans with seasoned greens and a little Parmesan.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Ballet Rehearsal Buns at Diane von Furstenberg
abstract: Russian ballerinas inspired the designer’s collection, which was topped off with slightly messy yet prim updos.
lead_paragraph: With show venues spread far and wide this season, there’s a certain athleticism involved in leaping around the city. On Diane von Furstenberg’s runway in Tribeca yesterday, the relative endurance of the day fit in well with the designer’s theme. “The collection was inspired by Russian ballerinas,” the hairstylist Orlando Pita said backstage. So naturally hair was whisked up into a bun. But Pita noted an important distinction: “Diane wanted the models to look like they were in rehearsal, rather than in performance.” Conveying that sense of unfinished, dashed-off elegance came down to misting BioSilk Dry Clean Shampoo on fine hair for body or rubbing BioSilk Silk Gel Medium Hold on thicker strands for control, and piling everything up into a high ponytail. The length of the tail was then twisted and wrapped around the base, and slightly spread out with the fingers to create a wide, round shape secured with a cupful of bobby pins. But just when the bun began to look too stage-ready, Pita pulled this last step: “The trick is to put finishing spray on your brush and comb back the hair vertically,” he said, demonstrating the technique around the crown. “This makes it look like someone has taken her fingers and combed her hair up.” It lent a subtle rawness, which did seem quite en pointe.

headline: Tostadas With Beans, Cabbage and Avocado
abstract: A great buffet dish that skips frying the beans in lard.
lead_paragraph: Beans are traditionally fried in lard, but I use a small amount of grapeseed or sunflower oil instead, and rely on the broth from the beans for flavor. This is a great buffet dish for a Mexican dinner party. I prefer to toast the tortillas using the microwave method, but you can also deep-fry them.

headline: Finally, a Way to Make a Selfie Statue
abstract: Ever wanted to have a status of yourself sitting on a bookshelf? Now you can thanks to 3D technology and a handful of young companies looking for a new way to satisfy the ego of the consumer.
lead_paragraph: In this, the Age of the Selfie, it figurines: You can now get yourself made into a tiny statue, using a three-dimensional printer and a common household gaming device.

headline: Two Founding Members of Pussy Riot Respond to Criticism
abstract: Nadezhda Tolokonnikova and Maria Alyokhina say the letter criticizing them “doesn’t follow the ideology of Pussy Riot.”
lead_paragraph: Hours before they departed the United States, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova and Maria Alyokhina, founding members of Pussy Riot, responded sharply to a letter that other members of that Russian activist collective had posted online  and sent to journalists. The letter disparaged some of the behavior of Ms. Alyokhina and Ms. Tolokonnikova, who are now advocating for prison reform, as unbecoming of the radical feminist group, which became known across the world after its members were arrested for performing a protest song in a Moscow cathedral in 2012.

headline: Kagan Says Her Path to Supreme Court Was Made Smoother by Ginsburg’s
abstract: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, 80, came of age when many legal careers were closed to women. Justice Elena Kagan, 53, credits the swifter rise of her own career to the ground her colleague broke.
lead_paragraph: They share New York City roots, a liberal outlook and a personal trainer. But a gap separates Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Elena Kagan, one they explored during an often lighthearted joint appearance last week at the New York City Bar Association.

headline: An Economist Answers Questions About Online Dating
abstract: Paul Oyer, an economist at Stanford’s Graduate School of Business and the author of “Everything I Ever Needed to Know About Economics I Learned From Online Dating,” responds to Economix readers.
lead_paragraph: Paul Oyer, an economist at Stanford’s Graduate School of Business, is the author of “Everything I Ever Needed to Know About Economics I Learned From Online Dating,” published last month by Harvard Business Review Press. Through his own experience, Mr. Oyer became intrigued by the economics at work in the online dating marketplace. His book explores how knowledge of economic concepts can help narrow Cupid’s aim. Mr. Oyer’s personal strategy turned out to be a winning one: he met his current partner online.

headline: A Conversation With: Leena Gita Reghunath, Editorial Manager at The Caravan Magazine
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Confessions', 'Hinduism', 'News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'Terrorism', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: The journalist spoke with India Ink about the startling revelations in her story about Swami Aseemanand, a former Hindu nationalist activist who has been charged with plotting five terrorist attacks, which collectively killed 119 people.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — From 2006 to 2008, a series of bomb attacks hit civilian targets around India, the deadliest of which was on Feb. 18, 2007, when 68 people died on a train traveling to Pakistan. Swami Aseemanand, a former activist with the influential Hindu nationalist group Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, or R.S.S., has been charged with plotting five of these attacks, which collectively killed 119 people.

headline: Solomon Northup and Other Weekend Winners

lead_paragraph: The Eddies were not the only awards handed out this weekend in prize-loving Los Angeles. The Art Directors Guild also announced its winners for production design in movies, and they were: “Gravity,” for fantasy film; “The Great Gatsby,” for period film; and “Her,” which despite being set in the near future, won in the contemporary category. (The future is closer than we think.) All three are nominees at the Oscars as well, so it’s bound to be a close race.

headline: Flooding and Landslides in Burundi Kill Dozens
abstract: At least 60 people died and dozens were injured after torrential rains that began on Sunday and continued into Monday.
lead_paragraph: At least 60 people were killed and dozens injured in Burundi after heavy rains caused flooding and landslides in the small, landlocked African country, a government spokesman, Willy Nyamitwe, said on Monday. Harimenshi Hermes, a spokesman for the police, said that thousands more had been displaced because of damage to their homes. “Many houses in the suburbs were destroyed by the rain,” said Beatrice Nibogora, an information officer for the United Nations in Burundi. “Many of the victims are children, and the houses collapsed on them.” The government said it would organize burials for the dead and treatment for the injured. Torrential rains began on Sunday night and continued into Monday morning, causing power failures and cutting off roadways around Burundi’s capital, Bujumbura. The city sits on the shore of Lake Tanganyika near the border with the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: Tiny Plants’ Loss May Have Doomed Mammoths
abstract: A change in diet may have led to the demise of the woolly mammoth, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: A 50,000 year analysis of Arctic vegetation history reveals that a change in diet may have led to the demise of the woolly mammoth, the woolly rhinoceros and other large animals, according to a study in the journal Nature. About 10,000 years ago in the Arctic steppe, grasslands began to replace forbs, a flowery plant cover. Animals may have relied on forbs as a source of protein.

headline: For Cows, Daughters Mean More Milk

lead_paragraph: The amount of milk a cow produces is affected by the sex of her fetus, a new study reports.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Racist Team Name
abstract: Two members of Congress are urging the league to recognize that “redskins” is a slur.
lead_paragraph: After Michael Sam, a defensive end at the University of Missouri, told The New York Times and ESPN that he was “an openly, proud gay man,” the National Football League wasted no time issuing a statement that was intended to show how open, inclusive and sensitive it is. Meanwhile, anonymous N.F.L. personnel were telling Sports Illustrated that they didn’t think football was ready for an openly gay player.

headline: Drug Shortages Continue to Vex Doctors
abstract: Most common are shortages of sterile injectable drugs, partly because the factories that make them are aging and prone to quality problems.
lead_paragraph: Despite efforts by the Obama administration to ease shortages of critical drugs, shortfalls have persisted, forcing doctors to resort to rationing in some cases or to scramble for alternatives, a government watchdog agency said on Monday. The number of annual drug shortages — both new and continuing ones — nearly tripled from 2007 to 2012.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: February 7-9, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: In light of the start of the Florida trial of Michael Dunn, who is accused of shooting an unarmed 17-year-old to death at a gas station, ThinkProgress reported last week that at least 26 children and teens have died in Stand Your Ground cases across the state. Dunn reportedly plans to invoke Stand Your Ground, which states that a person who feels he is in danger may be justified in the use of deadly force, and some are asking whether laws such as these, which have proliferated in at least 20 states, empower people to shoot first and ask questions later.

headline: Prescription Painkillers Seen as a Gateway to Heroin
abstract: The increased use of opiates like Vicodin and OxyContin can create an appetite that eventually leads addicts to cheaper street drugs.
lead_paragraph: The life of a heroin addict is not the same as it was 20 years ago, and the biggest reason is what some doctors call “heroin lite”: prescription opiates. These medications are more available than ever, and reliably whet an appetite that, once formed, never entirely fades.
