headline: Seeking the Keys to Longevity in ‘What Makes Olga Run?’
abstract: Bruce Grierson met 94-year-old Olga Kotelko, a record-holding track and field star, and swiftly became obsessed. Together, they embarked on a quest to explain Ms. Kotelko’s youthfulness.
lead_paragraph: No one would mistake Olga Kotelko for one of the Olympians competing in Sochi, Russia, but at age 94, she holds more world records than most: 26, to be exact, including age-group bests in the high jump, the hammer throw and the 200-meter run. Not bad for someone who took up track and field at age 77.

headline: Laurie Anderson Performances Planned for Spoleto Festival USA Are Canceled
abstract: Performances of Laurie Anderson’s “Language of the Future” have been canceled at the Spoleto Festival USA “due to unforeseen circumstances.”
lead_paragraph: Laurie Anderson’s “Language of the Future,” a work she performed at the River to River Festival in New York in June, was to have had three performances at the Spoleto Festival USA in Charleston, S.C., this spring. But Nigel Redden, the festival’s general director, announced on Monday that the performances, which had been scheduled for June 4, 5 and 7, had been canceled “due to unforeseen circumstances.” The festival would not elaborate, and a call to Ms. Anderson’s studio in New York was not returned. Mr. Redden, in a statement, said that the festival would not offer a substitution for Ms. Anderson’s work.

headline: Public School: The ‘It’ Boys of New York Fashion Week
abstract: Anna Wintour, Jenna Lyons and other fashion insiders showed up for the first formal runway show for Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne.
lead_paragraph: The Public School fashion show at Milk Studios on Sunday, the first formal runway show for Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne, had all the hallmarks of a full-fledged fashion event.

headline: Spain Seeks to Curb Law Allowing Judges to Pursue Cases Globally
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation', 'International Relations']
abstract: After crusading judges in Spain ordered international warrants for a former premier and an ex-president from China, a trade partner, the Spanish Parliament will debate limiting the practice.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — For nearly two decades, Spanish judges have been the provocateurs of international criminal law, pursuing human rights cases against Argentine military officers, Israeli defense officials or American soldiers in Iraq. Most famously, a Spanish judge opened the case that led to the arrest of the former dictator of Chile, Augusto Pinochet.

headline: Monique Péan’s Antarctica
abstract: The jewelry designer shares photos of the natural beauty she found on the other end of the world, which inspired her fall/winter collection.
lead_paragraph: Having traveled all over the world in search of rare materials, the designer Monique Péan sailed through Antarctica seeking inspiration for her latest sustainable jewelry collection.

headline: Freezing Out the Bigger Picture
abstract: What seems like unusually cold weather in the Northeast is still milder than what was normal a few decades ago, but it has stoked confusion and given fodder to global warming skeptics.
lead_paragraph: At the exact moment President Obama was declaring last month that “climate change is a fact,” thousands of drivers in Atlanta were trapped in a grueling winter ordeal, trying to get home on roads that had turned into ribbons of ice.

headline: As Investor Calls for a Sale, Helen of Troy Unveils a Big Stock Buyback
abstract: Helen of Troy said on Monday that it plans to buy back nearly 29 percent of its outstanding stock for $550 million. But it isn’t clear whether Sachem Head Capital Management, the hedge fund looking to shake up the consumer products maker, will find it enough.
lead_paragraph: Helen of Troy has already suggested that it would return money to investors, but it wasn’t interested in selling itself, despite calls from an activist investor.

headline: That Six-Serving Bar of Marijuana Chocolate? My Son Ate It
abstract: The food his roommate had left in the fridge didn’t look like medicine to my son. It looked like candy, and he ended up on suicide watch.
lead_paragraph: Just a week after leaving Boston for a summer internship in California, our 21-year-old son landed in an emergency room and was put on a suicide watch. I’m going to ruin the suspense and tell you what happened: His roommate told him to help himself to the food in the fridge, and he ate a marijuana-laced chocolate bar meant to be consumed as six servings.

headline: A Patient’s-Eye-View of Nurses
abstract: It is surprising that it was only after a long and complicated hospital stay that Dr. Arnold S. Relman, a noted medical educator and author, realized the importance of nursing care.
lead_paragraph: Last June, the month he turned 90, Dr. Arnold S. Relman, the eminent former medical educator and editor, fell down a flight of stairs at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He cracked his skull and broke three vertebrae in his neck and more bones in his face.

headline: Mind Over Matter, Battling a Bandersnatch
abstract: In “The Wong Kids” at LaMama’s Ellen Stewart Theater, siblings find super powers to fight off the bullies.
lead_paragraph: Like Clark Kent and Peter Parker, the 11-year-old Bruce Wong is a sweet guy who inhabits the dweebier end of the social spectrum. His big sister, Violet, implores him to stop being such a nerd.

headline: Strollers Are the Latest Airport Amenity
abstract: A number of airports are providing families with loaner strollers to ease the stress of traveling.
lead_paragraph: Families flying with very young children can now take advantage of a growing trend: A number of airports are providing loaner strollers to ease the stress of traveling.

headline: Next Reading for Big City Book Club
abstract: Our next reading for the Big City Book Club is “Bright Lights, Big City” by Jay McInerney.
lead_paragraph: This time we outsourced our selection for the Big City Book Club to the writer and satirist Gary Shteyngart. We asked him to pick his favorite book about New York, and remarkably he did not demand that we read his own, newly published memoir, “Little Failure,” about his upbringing as a Russian émigré in Queens. Instead, he selflessly selected “Bright Lights, Big City,” Jay McInerney’s touchstone novel of the hedonistic ’80s life on the other side of the East River. Join us for the online discussion of the novel with Mr. Shteyngart on Monday, March 10, at 6:30 p.m. To join the club and receive regular email updates, visit: nytimes.com/marketing/bigcitybookclub.

headline: Do Some Drugs Become Dangerous After Expiration?
abstract: A notable issue with expired medicines is reduced efficacy, but some, like the antibiotic tetracycline, can degrade into toxic chemicals.
lead_paragraph: Q. Are there drugs that turn into toxic substances as they age?

headline: Bundle of Joy, Confusion and Doubt
abstract: “Luna Gale,” a Rebecca Gilman play getting its premiere at the Goodman Theater in Chicago, takes on the knotty issues facing child services in the case of parents with drug addictions.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The sobering themes of “Luna Gale,” the new play by Rebecca Gilman having its premiere at the Goodman Theater here, have a sad, strange currency. Ms. Gilman’s drama, about a fight over the fate of a baby in jeopardy, concerns itself with two pathologies that have been much in the news: sexual abuse within a family and the corrosive effects of drug addiction. (I probably don’t need to explain why those problems have been screaming from the headlines lately.)

headline: A Question for Yellen
abstract: As the new Fed chief faces congressional committees this week, it’s worth asking what data might prompt the central bank to reconsider its plans to unwind monetary support, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: On Ski Jumping: Jessica Jerome
abstract: “It’s a great feeling because you can just float,” says Jessica Jerome of the United States, who will be competing in the first women’s ski jumping competition at an Olympics.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a great feeling because you can just float,” says Jessica Jerome of the United States, who will be competing in the first women’s ski jumping competition at an Olympics.

headline: Avoiding a Pillow Fight With New Zealand Customs
abstract: Michael Lindell, the chief and inventor of My Pillow, was worried he wouldn’t get his wares past customs agents during a crucial trip abroad.
lead_paragraph: UNTIL two years ago, I had never been to New York City, and I’m 52 years old. So I guess it’s fair to say that I never thought I’d be a frequent business traveler. I’m the C.E.O. and inventor of My Pillow, and when I started the company I was really hoping that I would begin to travel for business. That would mean we were doing well.

headline: Milly: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: If It’s Chili, It’s Personal
abstract: What goes into the pot matters to everyone involved, and we mean everyone.
lead_paragraph: Chili tastes are highly personal, often inflexible and loaded with preconceptions — the political party of culinary offerings.

keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health']

headline: Furious Bosnians Shut Down Central Sarajevo
abstract: Protests against politicians viewed as self-serving and corrupt spread to other cities as demonstrators urged those in authority to “resign today.”
lead_paragraph: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — Bosnia’s most widespread antigovernment protests in almost two decades shut down the center of Sarajevo and affected five other cities on Monday, as demonstrators vented their anger at politicians whom they view as self-serving and corrupt.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Goldman Promotes Ashok Varadhan to Co-Head of Securities
abstract: Ashok Varadhan had most recently served as head of macro trading in the securities division. He will join the co-heads Isabelle Ealet and Pablo Salame in his new role.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs on Monday named Ashok Varadhan as co-head of the securities division, a significant promotion that has in the past paved the way to the bank’s upper echelons for other top-ranking executives.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Opening Ceremony Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

headline: British Politicians Blame One Another for Regional Flooding
abstract: Parliament members and an emergency response agency pointed fingers about who was responsible for a lack of preparedness after thousands of houses were damaged.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As flood warnings move down the River Thames, and closer to the capital, the political tide is rising, too.

headline: Camels Had No Business in Genesis
abstract: Camels appear in stories of early Jewish patriarchs in the Bible, even though it was before the animals’ time, evidence that writing or editing of the book happened long after the events it narrates.
lead_paragraph: There are too many camels in the Bible, out of time and out of place.

headline: Call It So-So: Jepsen Not a Big Draw in Her First ‘Cinderella’ Week
abstract: “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” scored only modestly at the Broadway box office in its first week with Carly Rae Jepsen as Cinderella and Fran Drescher as the cruel stepmother.
lead_paragraph: The pop singer Carly Rae Jepsen (“Call Me Maybe”) and the television actress Fran Drescher (“The Nanny”) scored only modestly at the Broadway box office last week for their first performances in “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella,” according to data released Monday by the Broadway League, the trade association of theater owners and producers.

headline: The Real World Is Not an Exam
abstract: For students just entering medicine after tens of thousands of test questions, many medical problems don’t have the single best answer they do on exams.
lead_paragraph: My young friend had just finished the last months of his medical training. He had faced down many multiple-choice tests and triumphed over them all.

headline: Olympics Draws 26 Million Viewers, Even as Its TV Competitors Also Thrive
abstract: A Beatles anniversary show on CBS drew 14 million, nearly seven million watched “Downton Abbey” on PBS and “Walking Dead” locked up younger viewers.
lead_paragraph: The pileup at the ratings finish line Sunday night resembled the cross-country skiing events in Sochi, as a host of popular shows duked it out for ratings supremacy. Skaters and skiers were potent; but so, too, were zombies.

abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio delivered his first State of the City address on Monday at LaGuardia Community College in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio delivered his first State of the City address on Monday at LaGuardia Community College in Queens.

headline: Debating Evolution and Dealing With Climate Change
keywords: ['Avian Influenza', 'Global Warming', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news. This week: A deadly bird flu in China causes alarm and researchers suggest revising guideline on intervention during labor.
lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday’s debate between Bill Nye the Science Guy and Ken Ham, president of the Creation Museum, whipped up a Sharknado-like frenzy online. Five hundred thousand viewers and seemingly all of Twitter followed the event live, which pitted evolution against creationism. Some called it a modern-day Scopes “monkey” trial, others a waste of time. The video has more than a million views on YouTube.

headline: Movie Star Points Way to Sanity, Maybe
abstract: Matthew Quick’s “The Good Luck of Right Now” revolves around a dysfunctional middle-aged man who tries to figure out his life through a series of whimsical letters to the actor Richard Gere.
lead_paragraph: “The Good Luck of Right Now” is only the second nominally adult novel by Matthew Quick, whose attention-getting first was “The Silver Linings Playbook.” Mr. Quick’s other books have been categorized as young adult fiction, though, in his hands, the two genres are not that different. Among the adult aspects of this new book are the degrees of its characters’ dysfunctionality, the jokey fact that one of them can barely complete a word without inserting an obscenity in the middle of it, and that it takes the epistolary form of a series of letters to “Dear Mr. Richard Gere.”

headline: New York Fashion Week: Diane Von Furstenberg Fall/Winter 2014
keywords: ['Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Movie Date Night Can Double as Therapy
keywords: ['Dating and Courtship', 'Marriages', 'Medicine and Health', 'Movies', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: A study of couples seeking marriage counseling found that guided discussions after viewing relationship movies can be as helpful as two intensive therapist-led counseling methods.
lead_paragraph: One of the great divides in male-female relationships is the “chick flick” — movies like “Terms of Endearment” and “The Notebook” that often leave women in tears and men bored. But now, a fascinating new study shows that sappy relationship movies made in Hollywood can actually help strengthen relationships in the real world.

headline: The Science of Ice Skating
abstract: Science is aiming to help ice skaters meet the sport’s physical challenges without sacrificing their health.
lead_paragraph: Science is aiming to help ice skaters meet the sport’s physical challenges without sacrificing their health.

headline: Job Growth Slumps. Employment Surges.
abstract: Two Labor Department surveys on jobs are saying very different things.
lead_paragraph: More people have gone to work during the past three months than at any time in decades.

headline: Riders Cautious of Halfpipe Conditions
abstract: Snowboarders Kelly Clark, Hannah Teeter and Peetu Piiroinen gave their impressions of the halfpipe conditions in Sochi.
lead_paragraph: Snowboarders Kelly Clark, Hannah Teeter and Peetu Piiroinen gave their impressions of the halfpipe conditions in Sochi.

headline: Further Delays for Employers in Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Obama administration announced that it would again delay the mandate for employers to provide health insurance to employees, giving medium-size companies extra time to comply.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced on Monday that it would postpone enforcement of a federal requirement for medium-size employers to provide health insurance to employees and allow larger employers more flexibility in how they provide coverage.

headline: Aging the Stars, a Man-Made Extinction, Being Cold While Globally Warming
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Global Warming', 'Weather']
abstract: Stellar archaeologists go on the hunt for the oldest stars in our galactic neighborhood; Elizabeth Kolbert talks about her new book, “The Sixth Extinction”; the weather outside your window — no matter how cold and icy — does not change the reality of a warming climate.
lead_paragraph: Stellar archaeologists go on the hunt for the oldest stars in our galactic neighborhood; Elizabeth Kolbert talks about her new book, “The Sixth Extinction”; the weather outside your window — no matter how cold and icy — does not change the reality of a warming climate.

headline: Sorting iPad Apps by Name
abstract: A method to sort apps alphabetically, and how to edit the Facebook “Look Back” greatest-hits movies.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there any way that user-installed apps on an iPad can be sorted alphabetically?

headline: Suit Will Seek State Money Promised to Schools in 2007
abstract: After a 2006 court ruling, the state, in 2007, agreed to give $7 billion in additional aid to schools, but the entire amount did not materialize.
lead_paragraph: New York State has shortchanged the entire public school system by billions of dollars, ignoring an agreement that followed a landmark court ruling in 2006, according to a lawsuit to be filed Tuesday by an education advocacy group.

headline: Labor Battle at Kellogg Plant in Memphis Drags On
keywords: ['Lockouts', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Organized Labor', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Kellogg is pressuring for what Caterpillar, Boeing and Detroit’s automakers have sought in recent years — to reduce blue-collar compensation packages.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — It’s 11 a.m. and a bone-chilling 18 degrees as Joey Watts, wearing a picket sign that says “Locked Out,” trudges across an overpass overlooking the cereal factory, which has a big neon sign spelling out Kellogg’s in its red signature logo.

headline: Poor Nations Seek New Hepatitis C Drug
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Hepatitis', 'Medicine and Health', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Doctors Without Borders is hoping to get poor nations a cheaper version of a new pill that can cure hepatitis C and will cost $84,000 a treatment in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Now that wealthy nations have a simple pill regimen that can cure hepatitis C, calls are mounting from representatives of poor nations for the same drugs.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger’s Colorful Clogs
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a pair of rubber-soled, faux-fur flats made even better with colorful socks.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: The ‘Grandpas’ of Hockey
abstract: Five players in their 40s, some still making a difference in the N.H.L., are reminded by the Sochi Olympics of why they so love the game.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Old Men Winter will descend on the Sochi Games this week, leaving the men’s ice hockey tournament with a dusting of gray. The 12-team competition features five players in their 40s, including Petr Nedved of the Czech Republic and Sandis Ozolinsh of Latvia, who bumped into each other in the athletes’ village the other day at that soda fountain of youth, McDonald’s.

headline: Fourth Place: Just Missing a Medal
abstract: “It just wasn’t my night,” said Shaun White as he joined a group of athletes who barely missed a medal by finishing fourth.
lead_paragraph: “It just wasn’t my night,” said Shaun White as he joined a group of athletes who barely missed a medal by finishing fourth.

headline: Sometimes, Even the Young Know When to Slow Down
abstract: The Danish String Quartet gave its first performance at Alice Tully Hall, in a show that was so popular an encore event was added for Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has a hit ensemble on its hands with the remarkable Danish String Quartet. This season the group began a three-year residency with the society’s CMS Two program for outstanding younger performers. Having played to acclaim last fall at the Kaplan Penthouse, the ensemble gave its first performance at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. Demand was so great for this sold-out concert that an encore event of the same program was added for Monday night at the Rose Studio.

headline: Alarm and Anger Over Britain’s Lack of Preparation Flood Social Media and the Web
abstract: While officials posted pictures of their efforts and updates about the dangers of the rising water, residents complained of a lack of help and suggested class and politics played a role.
lead_paragraph: Video and other images shared online highlighted just how dire the flooding has become in England. Rivers are bursting their banks, railroad tracks are swamped and thousands of people have been stranded by flooding, particularly in southern England, over the past month.

headline: Fond Farewell to a Ballerina Who Mixes Warmth and Technique
abstract: The dancer Jenifer Ringer displayed her finest qualities in her last performance as a New York City Ballet principal on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A double bill of Jerome Robbins’s “Dances at a Gathering” and George Balanchine’s “Union Jack” might seem an odd choice of program for a ballerina’s farewell performance. Rather than star vehicles, these ballets are ensemble works: 10 fairly equal dancers share the first; an army of more than 70 floods the second. And yet at the David H. Koch Theater on Sunday afternoon, the program succeeded in displaying some of the finest qualities of Jenifer Ringer in her final show with New York City Ballet.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Charter C.E.O. Is Pressing All the Right Buttons on Time Warner Cable
abstract: Thomas M. Rutledge’s company may propose a full slate of replacement directors for its target and may have enlisted a powerful ally for a bid — both adept moves, says Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Thomas M. Rutledge seems like a man on a mission. The U.S. cable operator he runs, Charter Communications, is preparing a slate of replacement directors for larger rival Time Warner Cable, the target of his $60 billion hostile bid. He may also have roped in Comcast to alleviate financial worries about the plan to take over his former employer.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Julieta Cervantes.

keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Global Warming', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In “The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History,” the New Yorker writer Elizabeth Kolbert asks science-based questions about whether humans might be causing mass extinction.
lead_paragraph: When Elizabeth Kolbert joined The New Yorker in 1999, after more than a decade covering New York politics as a reporter and columnist for The New York Times, she began gravitating to environmental issues.

headline: Bookseller Cuts Jobs at Division for Nook
abstract: The layoffs are the latest sign of the bookseller’s challenges in carrying out its digital strategy.
lead_paragraph: The bookseller Barnes & Noble laid off employees in its Nook device unit on Monday, the latest sign of the company’s difficulties in executing its digital strategy.

headline: Flying Like a Rock Star, but It’s Not Cheap
abstract: Heathrow airport, following a trend toward lucrative luxury services, is now selling V.I.P. services once reserved for celebrities or dignitaries.
lead_paragraph: I HAVE had my complaints about air travel. However, I’m not sure that these are going to be addressed by buying a service that includes “bypassing the main terminals and other passengers” to be “whisked by luxury limousine” across the tarmac to the side of my airplane.

headline: Raging Ambition, and Then Some
abstract: In “Actress Fury,” a dance-theater piece at the Bushwick Starr, three performers join in playing a single striving actress.
lead_paragraph: The cacophony rises as the voices of the three women overlap: the first singing, the second talking into a microphone, the third speaking directly to the spectators while she moves among them. Eventually, the singer has had enough.

headline: Monday Motorsports: A Wild Start to a New N.H.R.A. Season
abstract: John Force, 64, collects his 139th N.H.R.A. national event trophy; Bernie Ecclestone predicts that bribery charges against him will be dropped.
lead_paragraph: A new National Hot Rod Association drag racing season opened pretty much the same way the 2013 season ended: John Force, the serial Funny Car champion, again outran Father Time.

headline: Plácido Domingo to Join a Celebration of City Opera
abstract: Although New York City Opera has closed, its history is being honored with a concert to benefit a musicians’ relief fund.
lead_paragraph: Plácido Domingo, the opera superstar who made his New York debut with New York City Opera, now defunct, has agreed to sing at a benefit concert celebrating the 70th anniversary of the company’s founding, musicians’ union officials said on Monday.

headline: Georgia Governor Promises State Is Better Prepared for Coming Storm
abstract: After strong criticism of Georgia’s response to a Jan. 28 storm that crippled Atlanta, Gov. Nathan Deal has declared a state of emergency before an ice storm coming on Tuesday. Meanwhile, outside of Philadelphia, thousands are still without power from last week’s ice storm.
lead_paragraph: After harsh criticism for the slow response to the ice and snow that paralyzed the Atlanta metropolitan area for days last month, Gov. Nathan Deal of Georgia issued a state of emergency on Monday, a day before a winter storm was expected to hit.

headline: Giant Magellan Telescope
abstract: The Giant Magellan Telescope, when built, will have a resolving power 10 times greater than the Hubble Space Telescope.
lead_paragraph: The Giant Magellan Telescope, when built, will have a resolving power 10 times greater than the Hubble Space Telescope.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Kenya, England, Afghanistan and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Kenya, England, Afghanistan and South Korea.

headline: Punch Lines Over Punches
abstract: With the release of Jazzpunk, the makers are hoping for the rare comic hit in video games.
lead_paragraph: Play is joyful and often filled with laughter, but you don’t usually think of it as funny. So perhaps it’s unsurprising that other than romance, comedy is probably the least developed genre in video games.

headline: Albums From Sun Kil Moon and Robert Ellis
abstract: Lyrics are the foreground in “Benji,” a new album from Sun Kil Moon, and Robert Ellis’s “The Lights From the Chemical Plant.”
lead_paragraph: SUN KIL MOON

headline: Blending Moorish Tradition With a Do-It-Yourself Credo
abstract: Che Chen and Rick Brown of the duo 75 Dollar Bill played numbers inspired by Mauritanian electric-guitar performances at Troost on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: What you heard foremost in 75 Dollar Bill’s Saturday night show at Troost in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, was Che Chen’s guitar: a cut-rate Japanese model sketching looped figures inside old Arabic modes, pushing jagged sound through a small amplifier.

headline: A Mutable Feast
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: The Hemingway Collection at the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum is giving researchers access to a newly digitized batch of the writer’s daily ephemera from his onetime Havana home.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Ernest Hemingway was a hoarder. His own prose style may have been spare and economical, but he was unable to part with the words, printed or written, of just about anyone else. According to his fourth wife, Mary, he was incapable of throwing away “anything but magazine wrappers and three-year old newspapers.” A trove of some 2,500 documents collected and preserved at Finca Vigía, Hemingway’s farm outside Havana, and now digitized and newly available at the Hemingway Collection in the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum here, includes diaries, letters, lists, telegrams, insurance policies, bank statements, passports, tickets to bullfights and the Longchamp racecourse in Paris, a brochure from a swimming pool filter company, a page of his son Patrick’s homework and seemingly every Christmas card Hemingway ever received.

headline: The Archaeology of the Stars
abstract: Stellar archaeologists have found some very old stars, hidden in space like a pharoah’s tomb and holding secrets of the cosmos’ chemical evolution.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Anna Frebel, a young astronomer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, found an ancient star in a neighboring galaxy whose chemical composition proved nearly identical to some unusual stars on the outskirts of our own galaxy, which are older than the Milky Way itself.

headline: Lawsuit Challenges Government’s $13 Billion Deal With JPMorgan
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: According to a lawsuit that a nonprofit group filed against the Justice Department on Monday, the crucial details of the deal were for the government’s eyes only.
lead_paragraph: With a record $13 billion sticker price, the settlement deal between JPMorgan Chase and the government captured the attention of Wall Street and Washington late last year.

headline: The iPhone and Its Ilk as Museum Exhibits for Future Generations
abstract: A new initiative at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art aims to preserve works made in fast-changing mediums like photography and technology design.
lead_paragraph: Putting an iPhone on display in an art museum is an easy, if still unusual, decision to make. Preserving an iPhone in such a way that museum-goers of the 22nd century will be able to appreciate its form and its function, as well as its role in cultural history, becomes somewhat trickier.

headline: Attack of the Flappy Bird Clones
abstract: People scrambled on Monday to hire developers to build Flappy Bird clones after the highly popular app was removed from app stores over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Legend has it that Pablo Picasso once said, “Good artists borrow, great artists steal.”

headline: On Top of Croagh Patrick
abstract: Photographs of pilgrims climbing the Irish mountain through the years.
lead_paragraph: This past weekend’s Look featured photographs taken last year by Kenneth O Halloran of some of the thousands of people who climbed Croagh Patrick in Ireland on Reek Sunday, the last Sunday in July. Tradition holds that St. Patrick spent 40 days and nights at the top of the mountain in A.D. 441, and it remains one of many pilgrimage sites still visited annually throughout Ireland.

headline: Sites to Manage Personal Wealth Gaining Ground
keywords: ['Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Financial Planners', 'Personal Finances', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications']

lead_paragraph: LIKE many financial activities, wealth management has become increasingly automated, although it is inherently more complicated than a “bot” that searches the Internet or simply stores portfolios.

headline: John Maynard Keynes’s Own Portfolio Not Too Dismal
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The British economist was also a portfolio manager whose strategy anticipated those of investors like Warren E. Buffett, and he created fortunes several times over.
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to John Maynard Keynes and his economic theories, the economist has long been a lightning rod as tall as the Empire State Building. Yet examining his investment success is another matter, and far less prickly.

headline: Even Among the Richest of the Rich, Fortunes Diverge
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances', 'Income Inequality', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The rich have pulled away from the average American, but those beyond the 1 percent have pulled away even more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — YES, we know the economic fortunes of the 99 percent and 1 percent have diverged over the last three or four decades. But the fortunes of the 1 percent and the 0.1 percent, or the 0.01 percent, or the 0.001 percent, have diverged even more. Economists have taken to calling it “fractal inequality.” It is not just that the rich have pulled away from the average American. It is that the richer you are, the more you have pulled away.

headline: Tinkering Too Much With an E.T.F. Might Not Pay
keywords: ['Exchange Traded Funds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Tactical funds, with more substantial adjustments than normal E.T.F.s, are growing in popularity, but they have their skeptics.
lead_paragraph: LOW cost, simplicity and ease of trading have attracted investors to exchange-traded funds. Many investment managers are being drawn to E.T.F.’s, too, and are building portfolios substantially or even entirely from them instead of using elaborate combinations of mutual funds and individual securities.

headline: What’s in Store for 2014? Here’s What to Watch

Treasury bonds continued their losing streak in the weeks after the Federal Reserve announced that it was reducing its bond-buying program — until the stock sell-off caused people to buy bonds. Interest in emerging markets has dropped.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Sporty 3-D Hair at 3.1 Phillip Lim
abstract: Hairstylist Paul Hanlon pumped up the volume (and the staying power) with layers upon layers of styling products.
lead_paragraph: Hairstyles captured in fashion photography look amazing — but those coifs need only hold up for a few shutter clicks. Backstage at 3.1 Phillip Lim this afternoon, hair pro Paul Hanlon whipped models’ manes into tousled, sporty-slick styles reminiscent of Bruce Weber’s “O Rio de Janeiro” book from the ’80s, but with a durability that would allow the ‘dos to withstand the rigors of the runway (and several hours’ worth of afterparties). “When you see those pictures, somebody’s gone in and done the hair, and it’s a moment. This is 3-D, the models are walking and moving, and you don’t want anything to fall out,” Hanlon explained. Perhaps that was his full-disclosure reason for applying what he admitted was an “excessive” amount of styling fixers: He first brushed through volumizing mousse for body, then massaged on a root booster to help form a pompadourish flip. Next he saturated strands, section by section, in Moroccanoil Treatment Light to create a wet, separated texture all over, and combed Moroccanoil Intense Curl Cream through on the front before pulling the hair tight on the sides and high on the top. To finish, Hanlon doused it all with hair spray. The maximalist approach went over well, creating a modern vibe that model Maggie Jablonski described as “punk, but artistic and beachy.” The only drawback: how to wash out all that product? Just follow Jablonski’s directive: “Stand and watch it melt away in the shower.”

headline: Use Force to Save Starving Syrians
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Responsibility to protect the innocent justifies armed intervention.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — THE Syrian people are starving. According to the United Nations, about 800,000 civilians are currently under siege. In areas around the cities of Homs, Aleppo and Deir Ezzor and in parts of the capital, Damascus, no food, medical supplies or humanitarian aid can get in, and people can’t get out. Many have already died under these “starvation sieges” and hundreds of thousands teeter on the brink, subsisting on grass and weeds. In Damascus, a cleric has ruled that under these conditions, Muslims are permitted to eat normally forbidden animals like cats, dogs and donkeys.

headline: Philadelphia School Chief Faces Down Budget Cuts and Crises
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Charter Schools']
abstract: William R. Hite Jr. has laid off almost 4,000 workers and closed 24 schools since becoming Philadelphia superintendent of schools in 2012.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — William R. Hite Jr., superintendent of schools here in one of the nation’s poorest cities, is known as a man who prefers collaboration to confrontation, but he has spent the academic year taking no prisoners. He laid off almost 4,000 workers to close a $304 million budget gap and threatened to keep school doors locked until officials found stopgap money to ensure what he considered a basic level of security for students. He says he was just warming up.

headline: Army Auditors’ Shock and Awe
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Lawmakers must demand the fullest accounting of a recruiting program that paid cash bounties for drawing thousands of enlistees into service.
lead_paragraph: War profiteering is presumably as old as warfare. But the costly fraud that Army officials recently disclosed to Senate investigators seems especially shameful. It took place on the home front and corrupted a supposedly legitimate special program to increase the number of recruits during the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. More than 1,200 people are under investigation, including 200 military officers, for allegedly defrauding a program that paid cash bounties for drawing enlistees into service.

headline: Paul Ash, Who Made Music Store a Chain, Dies at 84

headline: Environmental Group Proposes Options for Breached Pond at Jamaica Bay in Queens
abstract: New York City Audubon will release a report on Tuesday making the case for restoring part of the West Pond at Gateway National Recreation Area, of concern to birders and environmentalists.
lead_paragraph: On the shore of West Pond, a 45-acre freshwater body at the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge, a small sign proclaims, “Without freshwater this refuge would be a very different place.”

headline: Heroin’s Small-Town Toll, and a Mother’s Grief
abstract: Few understand the way addiction mangles families, said Karen Hale, who lost Alysa Ivy, 21, to an overdose in a Wisconsin town hit hard by heroin.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, Wis. — Karen Hale averts her eyes when she drives past the Super 8 motel in this picturesque riverfront town where her 21-year-old daughter, Alysa Ivy, died of an overdose last May. She has contemplated asking the medical examiner, now a friend, to accompany her there so she could lie on the bed in Room 223 where her child’s body was found.

headline: Extensive Enumeration
abstract: A debut by Matthew E. Paronto, with able assistance by Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Oh, right. I almost forgot. Time to pre-treat all the stains on the website. It’s LAUNDRY day.

headline: A Line of Defense Against the Theft of Personal Data
abstract: A security freeze on your credit report from the three big credit bureaus will stop anyone from opening a new account in your name.
lead_paragraph: The pattern with credit- and debit-card breaches tends to go something like this: A company like Target or Neiman Marcus announces that thieves may have stolen your card numbers or other information, then the company offers a year of credit-monitoring. But the chastened keeper of your personal data rarely if ever offers to pay for the most potent protection of all: A security freeze on the files that the three big credit bureaus keep on you.

abstract: Legislation to be introduced on Tuesday in the New York Assembly would prohibit the sale of personal care products that contain the plastic, which has turned up in lakes and rivers.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in Albany could make New York the first state to outlaw the tiny plastic beads used in personal care products like facial scrubs and toothpastes.

headline: Impatience Has Its Reward: Books Are Rolled Out Faster
abstract: While the television industry has begun catering to impatient audiences by releasing entire series at once, the book business is upending its traditional timetable by encouraging a kind of binge reading, releasing new works by a single author at an accelerated pace.
lead_paragraph: “Annihilation,” the chilling first novel of a trilogy by Jeff VanderMeer that was released last week, tells the story of a scientific expedition to a mysterious place called Area X that has been cut off from the rest of the world.

headline: What to Watch from Sochi: February 10
abstract: When Shaun White dropped out of the snowboard slopestyle competition, he put all his hopes on the halfpipe.
lead_paragraph: SKI JUMPING The women’s competition is making its Olympic debut largely because of the efforts of competitors like the Americans Jessica Jerome and Lindsey Van, who were at the center of the long legal struggle to have it added to the Games program. Another American, Sarah Hendrickson, is the reigning world champion, and she usually would have been the obvious favorite. But Hendrickson, 19, is coming back from a serious knee injury and has not competed since August. Hendrickson struggled in practice and qualifying for the normal hill, and now a different teenager, 17-year-old Sara Takanashi of Japan, is the leading contender to win the gold. NBCSN, 1:30 p.m.

headline: Jury Weighs Whether Former Mayor Tried to Help New Orleans or Himself
abstract: Closing arguments were made in the trial of C. Ray Nagin, who is accused of promising assistance to contractors and businessmen in exchange for personal favors.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — After hearing six and a half days of testimony in the federal corruption case of C. Ray Nagin, a jury will now have to determine whether Mr. Nagin was doing his honest best to help a rebuilding city or was a politician on the take.

headline: Clinton Scandal of ’90s Resurfaces With Papers
abstract: The release of documents from a close friend of Hillary Rodham Clinton during her time as first lady has put the indiscretions of her husband back in the public eye.

The once-embattled President Bill Clinton has assumed a postpresidential role as global philanthropist and the first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, is now a former senator, a former secretary of state, and a potential 2016 presidential candidate.

headline: Majority of Americans Favor Ties With Cuba, Poll Finds
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: In Florida, an even higher number approve of normalizing relations with Havana, according to the survey’s results, described as an unprecedented reflection of shifting American attitudes.
lead_paragraph: After more than a half-century of official United States hostility toward Cuba punctuated by a comprehensive trade embargo, a majority of Americans — and an even greater majority of Floridians, home to this country’s largest Cuban-American population — now favor normalizing relations or engaging more directly with the Cuban government, according to a nonpartisan survey.

headline: A Leading Chinese Economist Warns of a Difficult Year and ‘Dead’ Companies
abstract: Wu Jinglian is warning that China’s economy will face a “difficult” year as it contends with state-owned companies with high debt levels that depend on subsidies to survive.
lead_paragraph: Sounding warnings that could have been made 20 or even 30 years ago, one of China’s most renowned economists said the country’s economy faces a “very difficult” year as it continues confronting a host of problems that have intensified over the past decade.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) BUTCH CASSIDY & THE SUNDANCE KID Long before Paul Newman and Robert Redford immortalized them, Robert Leroy Parker (better known as Butch Cassidy) and Harry Alonzo Longabaugh (the Sundance Kid) captured the country’s attention in the 1890s with their train and bank robberies. But who were they? And how did they manage to pull off spectacular holdups while eluding Pinkerton security forces, only to ride off into the sunset and die in a shootout in Bolivia? In this latest installment in “The Wild West” series presented by “American Experience,” the director John Maggio follows the men as they formed the Wild Bunch, rode the Outlaw Trail finding work as ranch hands, and escaped to South America.

headline: How Credit-Card Debt Can Help the Poor
abstract: Americans need to save. But they also need to borrow.
lead_paragraph: Last October, Jeffrey Shavers, a hotel maintenance worker in Chicago, took out an extremely unusual $300 loan. Shavers might have liked to use the money to visit his daughter, a college student in New Orleans, or to buy his 10-year-old son a new bike. But he couldn’t, because Shavers never actually saw the money. The cash went into a locked savings account that he couldn’t access. “It’s like an abstract $300,” he explained.

headline: African-American History, From Family Albums to Museum Walls
abstract: A new documentary traces from the 19th-century to the 21st how African-Americans presented themselves in their own photos, often in contrast to how they were stereotyped by the larger society.
lead_paragraph: Although the photographer Hugh Bell had been part of “The Family of Man” exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art, he later realized inclusivity went only so far when he called to pitch a story to an editor at Esquire.

headline: Is It Unethical for a Zoo to Kill a Healthy Giraffe?
abstract: Do zoos have a responsibility to try to ensure that all animals under their care live a long and healthy life? Or, do zoos have a different mission?
lead_paragraph: This weekend a Danish zoo euthanized a healthy 2-year-old giraffe. Bengt Holst, the zoo’s scientific director, explained, “We don’t do it to be cruel; we do it to ensure a healthy population.” But many animal rights activists, who mounted a furious last-minute campaign to save the giraffe, angrily protested the killing.

headline: Banking While Russian
keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Russian-Americans']
abstract: Why had my account been closed? And where was all my money?
lead_paragraph: IT was the quintessential immigrant moment. Two weeks after my family and I had arrived in New York, a friend drove me to Costco. Half an hour later, at the cash register, I was hidden from view by the pyramid of diapers, napkins and other paper products in the shopping cart. My friend laughed and snapped a picture, promising to post it online with the caption, “Masha comes to America.”

headline: Fashion Week Morning Report: Globe-Trotters
abstract: Tory Burch leads off Tuesday of New York Fashion Week with a 9 a.m. show at Lincoln Center’s Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: Hers was the label that launched a thousand flats. Tory Burch leads off Tuesday of New York Fashion Week with a 9 a.m. show at Lincoln Center’s Avery Fisher Hall. Ms. Burch first struck retail gold with her medallion-bearing Revas, but she has since found hit after hit (and expanded to store after store after store worldwide). For spring, she went as far afield as her collection — in this case, poolside, Franco-American style, channeling Romy Schneider in the 1969 film “La Piscine.” Next up? Only Ms. Burch knows. Wherever first-class travel can take her, one supposes.

Even just grazing on your favorite websites and social media platforms can lead to discovering the outcome of an event before it hits TV, possibly deflating some of the joy in the drama.

headline: Such and Such
abstract: When “as such” is used correctly, with a clear antecedent, you should be able to substitute that antecedent for “such” and have the sentence make sense. But we frequently misuse “as such” in a much looser way to connect two thoughts. If there’s no clear noun antecedent for “such,” think again and rephrase.
lead_paragraph: A colleague notes that we frequently stumble with the phrase “as such.”

It was the second such attack in Peshawar, the capital of the restive Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province, this month.

headline: Artworks Removed From Austria Home of German Who Holds Huge Trove
keywords: ['Art', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Works, including some by Monet, Picasso and Renoir, were removed from the home of Cornelius Gurlitt in Salzburg, Austria, to ensure their safety.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For several days last November, reporters in Salzburg, Austria, staked out 9 Carl-Storch-Strasse, a rundown house in an elegant neighborhood identified as the home of Cornelius Gurlitt by a small metal plate on the door. Reports that the German authorities had confiscated a trove of 1,280 artworks, some of them suspected of having been traded or looted during the Nazi era, from Mr. Gurlitt’s apartment in Munich had set off a global outcry and deep curiosity.

headline: Stripe and Square Face Complexity Abroad
abstract: Several challenges await the American payment start-ups Stripe and Square as they pursue international opportunities.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – International users now generate the majority of traffic for the social media giants Facebook and Twitter, and fast-growing tech companies like Airbnb, the online property rental service, have expanded rapidly into non-American markets to ward off local competitors.

headline: One View of Merrill Lynch’s Fall
abstract: Winthrop H. Smith Jr., a senior Merrill Lynch executive and son of one of the firm’s founding partners, argues in a new book that E. Stanley O’Neal helped sow the seeds of Merrill’s fall by failing to hold true to Merrill’s founding principles.
lead_paragraph: In late 2001, Winthrop H. Smith Jr., a senior Merrill Lynch executive and son of one of the firm’s founding partners, walked into the office of his just-appointed boss, E. Stanley O’Neal, ready to accept a new job he was being offered.

headline: Holder Urges States to Lift Bans on Felons’ Voting
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s call underscores the Obama administration’s determination to elevate issues of criminal justice and race in the president’s second term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. called Tuesday for the repeal of laws that prohibit millions of felons from voting, underscoring the Obama administration’s determination to elevate issues of criminal justice and race in the president’s second term and create a lasting civil rights legacy.

headline: Daily Report: Software Error Shakes Bitcoin Exchange
abstract: Mt. Gox, once the largest Bitcoin exchange in the world, said its problems had been caused by a previously undetected glitch in the basic Bitcoin protocol that made it possible for users to falsify transactions.
lead_paragraph: What was once the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange, Mt. Gox, appeared near collapse on Monday, the latest symbol of the woes facing early players in the world of virtual currencies, Nathaniel Popper reports.

headline: Charter’s Bid for a Deal in Cable Heats Up
abstract: In its most aggressive move yet to take over Time Warner Cable, Charter is proposing a full slate of directors to its target’s board.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:16 p.m. | Some corporate takeovers happen in a flash. Others move as slow as molasses.

abstract: All your fractals are belong to me, me, me.

lead_paragraph: Janet Yellen, the newly installed chief of the Federal Reserve, made her first appearance before a congressional panel in that role as she testified before the House Financial Services Committee. Times correspondents covered the appearance in a live blog here.

headline: House Approves Higher Debt Limit Without Condition
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The vote, relying almost entirely on Democrats, ended three years of brinkmanship in which the threat of a default was used to wring concessions from President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ending three years of brinkmanship in which the threat of a devastating default on the nation’s debt was used to wring conservative concessions from President Obama, the House on Tuesday voted to raise the government’s borrowing limit until March 2015, without any conditions.

headline: Islamic Extremists Slaughter 15 Soldiers in Northern Iraqi City
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Terrorism', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The soldiers, deployed to guard an oil pipeline, were beheaded, shot or hanged by members of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Fighters from a Sunni extremist group attacked an army unit in a northern Iraqi city on Tuesday, killing 15 soldiers in a rampage of beheadings, shootings and a hanging, security officials said.

headline: Highlights of the Westminster Dog Show
abstract: The field of nearly 3,000 dogs at the 138th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show got whittled to one best in show at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night as Sky, a 5-year-old wire fox terrier, took the crown.
lead_paragraph: The field of nearly 3,000 dogs at the 138th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show got whittled to one best in show at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, as Sky, a 5-year-old wire fox terrier, took the crown.

lead_paragraph: With his Michelin-starred restaurant, In De Wulf, Kobe Desramaults is the latest innovative chef to turn nowhere — here, a remote corner of Belgium — into a culinary somewhere.

headline: Finance Magnates Among Top Donors in 2013
abstract: Among the givers on The Chronicle of Philanthropy’s 2013 list of top American donors were David Rubenstein, the co-founder of the Carlyle Group, and Stephen A. Schwarzman, the head of the Blackstone Group.
lead_paragraph: David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder of the private equity giant Carlyle Group, is a fan of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. So much so, in fact, that he donated $50 million to the center last year. His total donations of $121.7 million ranked No. 21 on The Chronicle of Philanthropy’s 2013 list of top American donors.

headline: Military Plane Crash in Algeria Leaves Scores Dead
keywords: ['Military Aircraft', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The plane, said to be carrying more than 100 passengers and crew members, went down in rough weather, according to the military.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — An Algerian military plane crashed in a mountainous area of northeastern Algeria on Tuesday, and by nightfall rescuers had recovered at least 77 bodies and one survivor, according to Algerian National Television.

headline: A.B.A. Nominates New Jersey Lawyer as President
abstract: Paulette Brown, a partner at Edwards Wildman Palmer in New Jersey, would be the first African-American woman to lead the American Bar Association.
lead_paragraph: The American Bar Association, the 400,000-member group that establishes standards for law schools and formulates codes of conduct and ethics for lawyers, has nominated Paulette Brown as its president.

headline: La Quinta’s I.P.O. Filing Continues Blackstone’s Selling Spree
abstract: With La Quinta Holdings moving toward an initial public offering, its parent, the Blackstone Group, has shown that it’s still an eager seller, having held stock sales for a half-dozen portfolio companies last year alone.
lead_paragraph: With La Quinta Holdings moving toward an initial public offering, its parent, the Blackstone Group, has shown that it’s still an eager seller.

headline: Karen O, Inspired by ‘The Jerk’
abstract: The frontwoman of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs is up for an Oscar for best song, which she says was inspired by a scene between Steve Martin and Bernadette Peters.
lead_paragraph: If there were a prize for most indie recording at the Oscars, Karen O’s “Moon Song,” featured in the film “Her,” would probably take it: she recorded it in her downtown Manhattan apartment, at her dining room table, as a demo for the actors to use. It was entirely off the cuff. “The first thing you hear” on the track, she said, “is the sirens going off on Lafayette Street,” from the nearby firehouse.

headline: Inequality and Indignity
abstract: Who really believes in the dignity of work?
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the CBO report, the initial botched reporting and political interpretation, and the subsequent backlash, conservatives have had two choices. They can stay with the lies about job destruction — and many have; or they can talk about the work disincentives and claim that they are a terrible thing.

headline: Every Dog Has Its Getaway
abstract: An inn in Maine has a weekend package that has plenty of perks for pooches.
lead_paragraph: Does Fido deserve some pampering?

headline: Donna Karan: Three Decades in Fashion
abstract: The designer, who put the emphasis on flesh in her winter 2014 collection, has given much to the universe of style.
lead_paragraph: With Rita Ora spilling out of a black wrap dress and Katie Holmes in a chiffon skirt and leather top that was as sleek as a rain-soaked Manhattan street, Donna Karan celebrated 30 years of serving women with meaningful fashion.

headline: When Marijuana Looks Like Candy, Not Drugs
abstract: Marijuana as candy doesn’t just change how people use it. It changes how parents need to talk about it, and how we need to ask that new laws be designed to balance legal use with protecting those who shouldn’t use it at all.
lead_paragraph: This is not what I thought marijuana looked like.

headline: The Great Civil War Escape
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Prison Escapes', 'Prisoners of War', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The amazing story behind the Union officers who broke out of Richmond’s infamous Libby Prison.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Rose could see the Union troops approaching from the east. After five days of torturous travel on foot, he was about to make good his escape from Richmond’s infamous Libby Prison. Awaiting the arrival of his comrades, he noticed three soldiers to his rear. Assuming they were a federal vanguard, he rose to greet them, only to find himself recaptured. After wrestling a musket from one of his captors and firing it into the air, Rose ran toward the approaching Yankees. A dozen rebel soldiers quickly knocked him to the ground and bound him for return to Richmond, ending the short-lived escape of one of the masterminds of the Civil War’s most celebrated prison break.

headline: Chasing Gold (and Jeans That Fit)
abstract: For Olympic skiers, there is a distinct body type, which includes enormous thighs and rear ends to match.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — There was no way to ask the question without sounding slightly creepy, but the downhill skier Jan Hudec kindly answered it with cheerful Canadian candor. “Yes, I have an enormous butt,” he said.

headline: Thomas Frank, Author and Historian, Will Join Salon
abstract: The author of “What’s the Matter With Kansas” will contribute feature articles every Sunday and comment on current events.
lead_paragraph: Salon Media Group said Tuesday that it was hiring Thomas Frank, the historian and author best known for his book “What’s the Matter With Kansas,” to write feature articles every Sunday as well as weigh in on current events as warranted.

lead_paragraph: Fitch Ratings lowered Puerto Rico’s debt to junk status on Tuesday, becoming the last of the top three ratings agencies to downgrade the financially struggling island.

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

lead_paragraph: Alibaba’s purchase of AutoNavi is a land grab, in two senses.

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Face-to-face peace talks between the Syrian government and opposition representatives here failed to make progress on Tuesday, both sides said, each making statements indicating that they were still talking past each other in this new round of discussions.

Among the crowd at Lincoln Center for the Carolina Herrera show at 10 a.m. was the actress Anna Kendrick, who was seated next to Emmy Rossum and across the runway from Tina Fey.

headline: A Lighthouse in Winter
abstract: The many faces of a Hudson River lighthouse in winter.
lead_paragraph: I occasionally try to step back from the nonstop flow of environmental news to consider the beautiful basics that too often hide in plain sight on a busy planet. I’ve explored the cycles of life on a farm and four seasons in a patch of woods in my part of the Hudson Valley. On Facebook, I’ve been enjoying an extraordinary photographic journal chronicling hour-by-hour changes in light and weather on the Hudson River around the Rondout Creek Lighthouse at Kingston, N.Y.  The images are taken by Carolyn Marks Blackwood, an award-winning film producer and photographer whose home and studio are perched on a ledge in Rhinecliff, on the opposite bank.

headline: The Dirty Martini Cleans Up Well
abstract: A more elegant version of the cocktail uses olives seven ways.
lead_paragraph: In this age of the aspirational cocktail, when bar menus can read like manifestoes or museum catalogs, certain drink orders are guaranteed to ignite the spleen of the serious bartender. Among them: the mojito (a lot of labor, particularly if customers ask for seven, which they often do); the Cosmopolitan (“Sex and the City” ended a while back); the vodka Red Bull (take your bad decisions outside); and the Bloody Mary, if ordered at night (seriously?).

Veerappa Moily, to look into whether the two men and others colluded to keep gas prices high.

lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase touched off a round of criticism when it disclosed that it would give its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, a big raise for 2013, a year in which the bank paid billions to resolve legal problems. But another Wall Street titan came to Mr. Dimon’s defense on Tuesday.

headline: Rare Afghan Polio Case Tied to Pakistan
abstract: Afghanistan is next door to Pakistan, where polio is much more widespread, and most of Afghanistan’s polio cases are traceable to that country.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A 3-year-old girl in Kabul has contracted polio, the first confirmed case in the capital in 12 years, health officials said Tuesday.

headline: Eye Infection Forces Costas to Step Aside From Olympics Coverage
abstract: Matt Lauer is filling in for Bob Costas, NBC’s longtime Olympic host, as he tries to get a painful and worsening eye infection under control.
lead_paragraph: The infection in Bob Costas’s left eye appeared Thursday and spread to his right eye Sunday. When he woke up Tuesday in Sochi, Russia, with his eyes swollen and crusted shut, he told NBC that he could not host that night’s prime-time Olympics broadcast.

headline: Pop’s Prairie Woman Finds a Jazz Home on Broadway
abstract: The singer-songwriter K. D. Lang, who takes over for Fantasia Barrino on Tuesday in the jazz revue “Before Midnight,” discusses her bold career move.
lead_paragraph: Few would dispute that the Canadian singer-songwriter K. D. Lang has one of the great pop singing voices of our time. But in recent years, Ms. Lang, now 52, has retreated from the spotlight. On Tuesday, in a bold career move, she is replacing Fantasia Barrino in the jazz revue “After Midnight” — set in the Cotton Club in Harlem in the early 1930s — singing four songs with Wynton Marsalis’s Jazz at Lincoln Center All-Stars.

headline: New York State’s Top Judge Permits Early Bar Exam in Exchange for Pro Bono Work
keywords: ['Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Legal Profession', 'Law Schools']
abstract: Chief Judge Jonathan Lippman’s decision to let third-year law students sit for the bar exam in February in return for public service would create a new pool of lawyers for the indigent, experts said.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to bolster the number of lawyers for the poor, New York State’s top judge has cleared the way for law students to take the bar exam early in return for devoting their last semester to pro bono work.

keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The exhibit aims to help identify some of the markings from the millions of books seized by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: The role of the Allied armies’ Monuments, Fine Arts and Archives section in saving thousands of European art masterpieces from Nazi plunder is getting a big Hollywood hurrah, thanks to the film “The Monuments Men.”

headline: Giffords to Write Book on Gun Violence
abstract: The new book “Enough” is co-written by the former Arizona congresswoman and her husband, Mark Kelly.
lead_paragraph: Gabrielle Giffords, the former Arizona congresswoman, has written a book with her husband, Mark Kelly, addressing the issue of gun violence, her publisher said on Tuesday. Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, previously released Ms. Giffords’s memoir in 2011, also co-written with her husband.

headline: Parents Are Poor Judges of Children’s Weight
abstract: More than half of parents of overweight and obese children underestimated their weight, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Many parents apparently believe their children are leaner than they actually are.

headline: Hilary Mantel Portrait to Be Displayed at British Library
abstract: The portrait of Hilary Mantel, by Nick Lord, will be the first painting of a living author displayed there.
lead_paragraph: You might think, given Britain’s long and celebrated literary history, that portraits of British authors would have found their way into the British Library while those writers were still alive. But you would be wrong, at least for the next few days. On Feb. 24, a portrait of Hilary Mantel, painted by Nick Lord, will become the first painting of a living author to be displayed at the museum.

headline: Arcade Fire Gets Inside Spike Jonze’s Brain
abstract: William Butler explains how the band had to learn to understand what the director of “Her” wanted in a soundtrack.
lead_paragraph: Like Karen O, the members of Arcade Fire have long known and collaborated with Spike Jonze. They worked on his last movie, “Where the Wild Things Are,” and he directed a short film for their  album “The Suburbs” (and a live video for their song “Afterlife” at the YouTube Awards). So even though the band, based in Montreal, was busy working on its latest record, “Reflektor,” the musicians were eager to help Mr. Jonze with “Her.”

headline: Goldman Sachs Adds Five to Management Committee
abstract: The five additions to the firm’s influential management committee, a group of Goldman insiders that has the ear of the bank’s top brass, bring the total number of members to 34, the largest it’s ever been.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has added five executives to the firm’s influential management committee, a group of Goldman insiders that has the ear of the bank’s top brass.

headline: Detainees Sentenced in Seconds in ‘Streamline’ Justice on Border
abstract: Under “Operation Streamline,” officials prosecute illegal immigrants en masse, seeking jail terms and deportation in mere minutes.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — “My record is 30 minutes,” Magistrate Judge Bernardo P. Velasco of Federal District Court here said one afternoon, describing the speed with which he had sealed the fates of 70 migrants caught sneaking into the country. Each of the accused had 25 seconds, give or take, to hear the charges against him, enter a plea and receive a sentence.

headline: With Christie Under Fire, Republican Governors Have Big Fund-Raising Month
abstract: The Republican Governors Association announced on Wednesday that it had set a January record for fund-raising, seeking to refute suggestions that Gov. Chris Christie’s troubles have scared away the group’s donors.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Governors Association announced on Wednesday that it had set a January record for fund-raising, seeking to refute suggestions that the troubles of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey have scared away the group’s donors.

headline: Former New York Cultural Commissioner Takes Fellowship at Southern Methodist University
abstract: Former New York City cultural affairs commissioner has been named a fellow at the National Center for Arts Research in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Kate D. Levin, New York City’s former cultural affairs commissioner, has been appointed the first fellow at Southern Methodist University’s arts research center in Dallas, the university announced on Tuesday.

headline: Modified Corn a Step Closer to Approval in Europe
abstract: If, as expected, the engineered corn gets a go-ahead for cultivation, genetic modification will remain a sensitive issue for Europe and the United States during trade talks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After 13 years, six scientific opinions and two legal challenges, an insect-resistant type of corn is on the verge of being approved by the European Union. It would be only the third genetically modified crop to be authorized for cultivation in the 28-nation bloc.

headline: The Gun Report: February 11, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, motorists in Beaumont, Tex., were treated to a peculiar sight: a man in a banana costume toting an AK-47 and a drum magazine with a 50-round capacity. He was promoting the grand opening of a nearby gun shop, Golden Triangle Tactical. Police let the 18-year-old go with a citation for violating a city ordinance which prohibits soliciting alongside roadways.

headline: The Debt Ceiling Is Now Pointless
abstract: Republicans now hate the division and embarrassment these votes cause. So why go through the motions?
lead_paragraph: After Speaker John Boehner announced this morning that he would let a clean increase of the debt ceiling pass with mostly Democratic votes, I imagined what the country would be like if he let all bills come to a majority vote, instead of just those bills Republicans approve.

abstract: President Obama and his French counterpart, President François Hollande, held a joint news conference to discuss a continuing alliance.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and his French counterpart, President François Hollande, held a joint news conference to discuss a continuing alliance.

lead_paragraph: A 1964 Shelby Cobra Daytona Coupe has become the first vehicle recorded under a federal program to identify and preserve important engineering marvels, the Historic Vehicle Association annouced last month.

headline: Appeals Court Allows Challenges by Detainees at Guantánamo Prison
abstract: A federal appeals court ruled that judges have the power to oversee inmates’ complaints about conditions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that judges had the power to oversee complaints by detainees about the conditions of their confinement at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The ruling was a defeat for the Obama administration and may open the door to new lawsuits by the remaining 155 Guantánamo inmates.

headline: U.S. Center for Russian Studies to Shut Moscow Office
abstract: The research center, co-founded by George F. Kennan, the seminal Cold War theorist, had been plagued by budget cuts and colder relations between Russia and the United States.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Kennan Institute, a research center co-founded by George F. Kennan, the seminal Cold War theorist, that has fostered the study of Russia and the former Soviet Union since 1974, will shutter its office in Moscow this spring.

headline: On This Red Carpet, Aging Is Desirable
abstract: The annual AARP awards drew more performers willing to admit their age this year, in part because it’s another opportunity to campaign for Oscar votes.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — You know something has shifted in Hollywood when well-known actresses in their 40s dare to show up at the AARP awards. Reminding a youth-obsessed town that time marches on? Career suicide, or at least it used to be.

headline: Vail Dance Festival Announces Lineup
abstract: Herman Cornejo of American Ballet Theater will the artist in residence at the Vail International Festival this summer.
lead_paragraph: The American Ballet Theater principal Herman Cornejo will be the artist in residence at the 2014 Vail International Dance Festival, performing with the Pennsylvania Ballet and the Martha Graham Dance Company. The festival, which runs from July 27 to Aug. 9 in Vail, Colo., and is led by Damian Woetzel, will also feature the return of Wendy Whelan, bringing her “Restless Creature” project; a collaboration between the Taiwanese modern dancer Fang-Yi Sheu and the classical Indian dancer Shantala Shivalingappa; and new works by the Memphis jooker Lil Buck, and the contemporary dance choreographers Brian Brooks and Matthew Neenan.

headline: German Wins First Women’s Ski Jump
abstract: Carina Vogt of Germany won the first women’s ski jump contested at the Olympics. The favorite, Sara Takanashi, was fourth.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — It took 90 years for women to earn the right to ski jump in the Winter Games and just a day to crown their first Olympic champion.

headline: Steve Reich Is Awarded $550,000 Prize by Spanish Foundation
abstract: The composer Steve Reich was named the winner of the BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award for contemporary music.
lead_paragraph: The composer Steve Reich has won the 2013 BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award for contemporary composition, Mr. Reich’s publisher, Boosey & Hawkes, announced on Tuesday. The award, which is given by a foundation associated with a Spanish financial services group, carries a cash prize of 400,000 euros (about $550,000), and is to be presented at a ceremony in June.

headline: In Paris, a Worldly Good Deal
abstract: In the heart of the city, the just-reopened, Christian Lacroix-designed Hôtel du Continent offers a globe-trotting theme at down-to-earth room rates.
lead_paragraph: Savvy travelers know that location is everything, so it’s likely that Jules Verne, the world-roving French author of the celebrated 1873 adventure novel “Around the World in Eighty Days,” would be impressed by the 25-room Hôtel du Continent on the Rue du Mont-Thabor in Paris, newly renovated just in time for Paris Fashion Week. It’s tucked away right in the heart of the city in the stylish First Arrondissement on a charming back street that runs parallel to the boutique-lined Rue Saint-Honoré — and it’s only steps from the Louvre, the Tuileries Garden, the Place Vendôme and the Place de la Concorde too.
