headline: Why Norovirus Crops Up on Cruises
abstract: In the aftermath of recent outbreaks, here’s a look at how the virus spreads, how often widespread illness occurs and recommendations for prevention.
lead_paragraph: It has not been the best season for cruise ships. By the time the Explorer of the Seas docked at Bayonne, N.J., late last month, more than 600 passengers and crew members were sick to their stomachs; the Caribbean Princess arrived in Houston the same day after an outbreak sickened at least 192 people onboard.

headline: In Letters, a Literary Force Lets Readers In
abstract: Hundreds of Malcolm Cowley’s letters, with ruminations on many things over several decades, make up “The Long Voyage.”
lead_paragraph: When The Paris Review finally got around to interviewing Malcolm Cowley in 1982, when he was 84, among the first questions the magazine posed was this: “Do you regret not having concentrated more fully on your poetry?” Cowley said yes. His problem, he added, “was the essentially middle-class feeling that I had to support myself.”

headline: Executions Are Suspended by Governor in Washington
abstract: The move makes Washington the latest in a series of states to step away from capital punishment and makes Gov. Jay Inslee the third Democratic governor in recent years to say something similar.
lead_paragraph: The governor of Washington, Jay Inslee, announced Tuesday that no executions would take place in the state while he remained in office, despite the fact that the death penalty was legal there.

headline: Social Media Dispatches: Death and Destruction in Central African Republic
abstract: Deadly attacks have gained pace against Muslims seen as supporting a Muslim rebel group that seized power last year and ruled through January.
lead_paragraph: Witnesses have been documenting the violence in the Central African Republic over the past few days, with relentless slaughter and traces of entire communities wiped out as thousands of Muslims fled their homes to escape retaliatory attacks.

headline: Back Home, Sense of Pride in Michael Sam
abstract: Michael Sam, a defensive end at Missouri who will enter the N.F.L. draft, announced Sunday that he was gay. People in his hometown of Hitchcock, Tex., and on his college team voiced their support.
lead_paragraph: Michael Sam, a defensive end at Missouri who will enter the N.F.L. draft, announced Sunday that he was gay. People in his hometown of Hitchcock, Tex., and on his college team voiced their support.

headline: Before Coming Out, a Hard Time Growing Up
abstract: The openly gay N.F.L. prospect Michael Sam said that he saw football as salvation during his childhood in tiny Hitchcock, Tex. His father is still struggling with the news that his son is gay.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Mo. — Michael Sam was the loud country boy who wore a tank top and a cowboy hat. He was the smooth-singing baritone who could irritate his coaches and crack up his teammates with his improvised songs.

headline: President Obama Speaks on Syria
abstract: President Obama answered a question from Mark Landler, a White House Correspondent for The New York Times, about the ongoing crisis in Syria and about putting pressure on the Assad regime.
lead_paragraph: President Obama answered a question from Mark Landler, a White House Correspondent for The New York Times, about the ongoing crisis in Syria and about putting pressure on the Assad regime.

headline: The Song Doesn’t Remain the Same
abstract: Sgt. Neil Gussman on the ritual of marching songs.
lead_paragraph: In January the U.S. military and I celebrated our 42nd anniversary. Sort of. I am one of those modern soldiers with commitment issues. I enlisted in the Air Force Jan. 31, 1972.

headline: Goldman Handed Out Cosmetic Mirrors and Nail Files at Women’s Coding Event
abstract: The swag that the Wall Street bank offered at the Women Engineers Code, or WECode, conference at Harvard was found off-putting by at least one attendee.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:43 p.m. | Goldman Sachs was the biggest sponsor of a Harvard event last weekend aimed at women interested in computer science. But the Wall Street bank’s conference swag at the event was found off-putting by at least one attendee.

headline: A Mad Den of Beasts, Maniacally Cackling
abstract: In its New York debut, LeeSaar the Company presented “Grass and Jackals” on Saturday at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: The seven women of LeeSaar the Company are a sleek pack. In “Grass and Jackals,” which had its New York premiere on Saturday in the troupe’s debut performance at the Joyce Theater, they are sheathed in black bodysuits. Under thick black slabs of painted-on eyebrows, their eyes gaze out with the look of animals encountered in the wild: now sanguinely alert, now spooked. Then they smile like contestants in a beauty pageant, a different kind of watched beast.

headline: The 13-Page Preschool Application
abstract: My working-class mother never schmoozed admissions staffs or wrote essays about my precociousness in turning books the right way up. I never thought I would. But if my daughter is going to go to preschool in Manhattan, I’ll have to learn.
lead_paragraph: Holding a 13-page form from the pile on our dining room table, I called out across our apartment, trying to get my husband’s attention. This preschool application asked for not only an essay about my 23-month-old daughter, but also a reference letter, both mine and my husband’s credentials, and whether we were trustees at any major institutions. But it was the line where I was supposed to write my email address that really made me palpitate.

headline: A World Unprepared, Again, for Rising Interest Rates
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: The pullout of capital from emerging markets eerily resembles the financial wave that emerged from Asia and swept across the globe in the late 1990s.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — I was living in São Paulo in 1997 when, out of the blue, an investment banker I knew in London called to ask about Brazilian cocktails. He didn’t want one. He needed a name for a potential economic crisis, in the vein of Mexico’s Tequila affair in 1994 and Thailand’s Tom Yum Kung debacle, which was unfolding at the time.

headline: Hugh Jackman to Host the Tony Awards
abstract: Mr. Jackman, a top Broadway box-office draw, will replace Neil Patrick Harris, who has hosted the Tonys for the past three seasons.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Jackman will once again host the Tony Awards ceremony, which will be held on June 8 at Radio City Music Hall, the producers of the event announced on Tuesday. (Mr. Jackman made his own announcement via Instagram). A top Broadway box-office draw in the shows “Hugh Jackman: Back on Broadway,” “A Steady Rain” and “The Boy From Oz,” Mr. Jackman will follow Neil Patrick Harris, who hosted the awards for the past three seasons. Mr. Harris may be a Tony nominee himself this year in his role as the lead character in the coming Broadway production of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch.”

headline: What Makes Older People Happy
abstract: Older adults more often find happiness in everyday events, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: Every year, my husband and I wonder what kind of birthday gift to give his dad, now 86 years old. The newest gadget, which may be admired but almost surely will be put in a drawer? Something much more ordinary, like one of the cardigan sweaters he wears day in and day out?

headline: Teaching the Sochi Olympics | History, Geography and Social Studies

lead_paragraph: L’Oréal’s deal to buy back 8 percent of itself from Nestlé has been a long time coming, with a number of big names involved.

headline: Yankees’ Newest Star Welcomes Biggest Stage
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka buttoned up a No. 19 pinstriped jersey at Yankee Stadium, tugged on that famous navy blue cap and proclaimed, in English, “I’m very happy to be a Yankee.”
lead_paragraph: Nobody sells hope like the Yankees. Nobody has such easy access to it. With their money and their marquee, they are a magnetic draw to an overseas sensation like Masahiro Tanaka, who buttoned up a No. 19 pinstriped jersey on Tuesday, tugged on that famous navy blue cap and proclaimed, in English, “I’m very happy to be a Yankee.”

headline: Yellen and the Labor Market
abstract: Of U3, U6, and the balance of risks.
lead_paragraph: In her first testimony as Fed chair, Janet Yellen said — as we all hoped and expected she would — that she doesn’t believe that the conventional unemployment rate gives a good picture of the amount of labor market slack. She mentioned, in particular, the high level of long-term unemployment and the large number of involuntary part-time workers.

headline: How’s Your Ballot Looking?
abstract: Judging by their ballots, Times readers see a two-way race for best picture.
lead_paragraph: With less than three weeks to go until the Academy Award for best picture is revealed, New York Times readers are in synch with many Oscar prognosticators — sort of. Everyone seems to agree that there’s more than one front-runner. But how many leaders are there?

lead_paragraph: Call it an early sign of spring in an especially punishing winter. The aptly nicknamed “first lady of jazz piano,” Barbara Carroll, opened her return engagement to Birdland on Saturday evening with a vigorous performance of “Let’s Face the Music and Dance.”

abstract: Daniele Gatti, the music director of the Orchestre National de France, has canceled all engagements for two months, citing inflamed tendons in his shoulders.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Feb. 14 Daniele Gatti, a conductor with a growing international career, has canceled two planned Carnegie Hall appearances with the Vienna Philharmonic — and the rest of his engagements for the next two months — citing inflamed tendons in his shoulders, Carnegie Hall announced.

Polished and sly, Ms. Majeski, a young American soprano, closed the program with the four songs that Britten wrote in the late 1930s for the singer and actress Hedli Anderson, to wry poems by Auden.

lead_paragraph: On Feb. 22, as the Olympics wind to a close, more than 150 teams will meet at the foot of a 1,300-foot volcanic dome, in Sobetso, Japan, to splatter each other with snowballs at the 26th annual Showa-Shinzan International Yukigassen (Snow Battle).

headline: Filling Club Spaces With Dance Beats and Arena-Size Sound

lead_paragraph: Oversize glasses, check. Asymmetrical haircut, check. Arm-pumping, climb-on-the-D.J.-desk enthusiasm, check. Lasers, check. And most of all: bass, check.

headline: Obama Greets France’s Leader, but Warns Against Doing Business With Iran
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: President Obama’s comments, made at a news conference with the French president looking on, were provoked by French executives’ recent trips to Tehran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the French president looking on, President Obama vowed on Tuesday to come down on companies that evade sanctions against Iran “like a ton of bricks.” He spoke a week after a delegation of French corporate executives traveled to Tehran looking for business opportunities amid diplomatic efforts to reach a nuclear deal.

headline: Antisurveillance Campaign Adds Itself to Washington’s Datebook
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Privacy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On a busy Tuesday in the nation’s capital, a concerted group of campaigners were trying to grab national political attention with “The Day We Fight Back.”
lead_paragraph: The antisurveillance crowd is trying to get onto the government’s radar. And though it’s a busy Tuesday in the nation’s capital, they seem to be having some success, repurposing an effective 2012 campaign to stop two Internet-related laws. But this time, instead of trying to block measures, a coalition of civil liberties groups and technology companies is flooding social media with calls to pass legislation that would limit the surveillance powers of the National Security Agency.

headline: Karen Elson at Tory Burch
abstract: The model Karen Elson, who later attended Rodarte’s “Star Wars” themed spectacle and has had quite the last few days, on the catwalk and off.
lead_paragraph: The morning rush hour didn’t wait for the Fashion Week faces who dotted Tory Burch’s 9 a.m. show on Tuesday. Anna Kendrick and Q-Tip made it minutes before the first model strutted the runway. Ditto the model Karen Elson, who later attended Rodarte’s “Star Wars” themed spectacle and has had quite the last few days, on the catwalk and off.

headline: Three Men Leap Forward at City Ballet
abstract: Three young male dancers have gained new eminence during City Ballet’s winter season, including Zachary Catazaro, who has become a worthy partner for the sparkling Sara Mearns.
lead_paragraph: Sara Mearns, a glory of New York City Ballet for several seasons, has recently brought a newly adult quality to her roles. But what consort has been worthy of her? An answer has at last emerged: Zachary Catazaro, who after Christmas danced in a couple of “Nutcrackers” as Cavalier to the Sugar Plum Fairy of Ms. Mearns and went on to partner her in other works. Their shared look of beauty, glamour, maturity and authority induced awe.

headline: S.E.C.’s Review of Stock Trading Will See Some of Its Own Work
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The S.E.C. may have helped create the problem it is now hoping to solve — where institutional investors say they are outgunned by high-frequency traders and individual investors are adrift, Steven M. Davidoff writes.
lead_paragraph: There are now at least 58 stock exchanges in the United States, many of them dark pools where the trades can be made anonymously. With institutional investors claiming they are outgunned by high-frequency traders, and individual investors adrift in fragmented markets, it’s no wonder that Mary Jo White, the new head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is moving to review and overhaul how stocks are traded. The issue is that the S.E.C. may have created the problem it is now hoping to solve.

headline: Graco Recalls Car Seats Over Faulty Buckle
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Child Car Seats']
abstract: Federal safety regulators pushed the company to expand the recall as parents complained that they had to cut the straps to remove their children.
lead_paragraph: Graco Children’s Products is recalling almost 3.8 million car seats because faulty buckles can make it hard to free the child in an emergency, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Build Your Own Chaos
abstract: The Lego Movie Videogame allows fans to indulge in the dark side of constructive play, smashing with abandon what has been created.
lead_paragraph: What is the best way to play with Lego bricks? From youth, we have been able to dabble with a choice: conformity versus creativity.

lead_paragraph: The snowboarder spoke about his legacy after finishing fourth in the men’s halfpipe final in Sochi.

headline: Art Matters | Old and New Worlds Collide Around Mexico City’s Zona Maco
abstract: The 11th edition of the fair and its satellite events in the rising art capital featured pickles as sculpture, granite golems and a host of other offerings.
lead_paragraph: While tradition is big in Mexico City, bureaucratic efficiency is not. This past weekend marked the 11th edition of the Zona Maco art fair, which this year switched its dates surreptitiously from April to February, risking administrative upheaval in today’s ever-more-scheduled and globalized art world. Though Zona Maco proclaims itself Latin America’s most important fair, international gallerists and collectors seem to return not out of obligation, but because of the adventures and the pleasures its host city has to offer.

headline: Exploring Black Americans’ Opinions of Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Movies', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Yoruba Richen explores African-American attitudes toward same-sex marriage in “The New Black,” which opens at Film Forum on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Perched precariously at the intersection of race, religion and sexual identity, “The New Black,” Yoruba Richen’s calm and nuanced exploration of African-American attitudes toward same-sex marriage, balances crude filmmaking with sophisticated insights.

headline: Beside the Flash of Gold, a Shadow
abstract: Competitors in extreme winter sports, like slopestyle skiing, operate in an environment of when, not if, an injury will occur.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The athletes willingly accept the risks in winter sports in which yesterday’s jaw-dropping trick too quickly becomes the new normal.

headline: Less Redemption, More Tears
abstract: An ordinary man gets a new life in “RoboCop,” directed by José Padilha.
lead_paragraph: The existential battle that rages through “RoboCop,” a nicely cast, respectable remake of the wittily corrosive 1987 Paul Verhoeven film, is less the struggle between man and machine than between the original’s pop nihilism and the bottom-line commercialism driving this new vehicle. Once again, an ordinary man, a Detroit cop, Alex Murphy (Joel Kinnaman), is transformed by corporate interests into a cyborg after being critically wounded in the line of duty. And, as before, the reanimated creature walks and talks like a latter-day Frankenstein’s monster, his recognizably human parts encased in an artificial carapace, although this version also mixes in tears with the bullets.

headline: Remembering Shirley Temple Black

headline: A Grizzly Answer for Obesity
abstract: Hibernating bears go diabetic. Unlike humans, they can reverse it without harm.
lead_paragraph: PULLMAN, Wash. — CLINICALLY speaking, about 1.5 billion people worldwide are overweight. According to the World Health Organization, more than 10 percent of the world’s adults are obese, arguably making them the largest patient population in existence. We can debate the causes, but the long-term consequences of obesity — diabetes, heart disease, cancer — place huge burdens on our society. Public health campaigns have made little impression on this spreading medical crisis.

lead_paragraph: If all politics were truly local, Brooklynites might be lobbying to rename the estuary that separates them from Manhattan. After all, it is only the East River if you happen to be a Manhattanite.

headline: In Skating, It’s All About Mind Games
abstract: For Patrick Chan, 23, the reigning figure skating world champion, the biggest challenge may be overcoming doubts. A former Olympian said the decisive question in the men’s individual competition is, “Who will wilt?”
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Figure skating is the only Winter Olympic sport in which a competitor is so alone for so many minutes, so isolated in a contained space, accompanied only by thoughts that can be as quivery as tired legs.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Fairytale Lips at Rodarte
abstract: Glitter, lipstick and gloss came together to create slightly dark, grown-up versions of the princess pout.
lead_paragraph: The innocence of childhood, glimpsed through the hazy filter of nostalgia, imparted a wistful, weirdly beautiful element to the makeup at Rodarte this afternoon. Backstage, the makeup artist James Kaliardos described the inspiration as the time when “you sort of romanticize things like movies and fairytales that stick with you, and affect the way you see beauty.” The Rodarte princess, however, is all grown up and has a dark side to her as well. Providing that much-needed edge: a pair of iridescent lip colors done in rich shades of mauve and lavender. “Kate and Laura are so into makeup, and the subtle differences in color,” Kaliardos said about the Mulleavy sisters, noting that they spent hours deciding on the final palette. The models’ skin tones largely dictated which of the two shades they would wear, but the application technique was the same: Kaliardos lined the mouth with either Nars Velvet Lip Liner Pencil in El Agua (a deep rose, to be released in the fall) or Nars Eyeliner in Mambo, a reddish brown, and then filled in the lips with a corresponding hue (Nars Lipstick in Dominique Audacious and Deborah Audacious, respectively; both available in the fall). Lastly, he topped everything off with a custom blend of glitter — rose and gold mixed into a base of lipstick and gloss — packed on the mouth with a small makeup brush for precision. (Note to those at home: Surgical tape helps to catch any sparkle fallout on your skin).

headline: Police Say Christie Copter Didn’t Fly Over Bridge
abstract: The New Jersey State Police said that none of the helicopter flights that carried Gov. Chris Christie during the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge flew anywhere near the bridge or Fort Lee, N.J.

headline: Wage Premium From College Is Said to Be Up
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Income', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A college degree is worth more for millennials than it was for earlier generations, but a high school degree alone is worth much less.
lead_paragraph: The millennials — born after 1980 — are the best-educated generation in history. By early adulthood, a third have college degrees, and those degrees help them earn more than ever before. So scholars at the Pew Research Center were puzzled when they found that the median, inflation-adjusted income of 25- to 32-year-olds had changed very little since 1965.

headline: Tiger Population Grows in India, as Does Fear After Attacks
abstract: Conflicts with humans have arisen in the few places where the endangered animals have rebounded thanks to conservation efforts.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — No one has lived long enough to describe the tiger in detail, but some things about her are known. She traverses great stretches of land in a day and is comfortable wandering deep into human territory. After killing her first three or four people, she began to eat her victims — starting rump-first, one expert said, as she would a deer.

headline: A ‘Repentant Rebel’ Addresses New York Abolitionists
abstract: E.W. Gantt’s path from Confederate general to Confederate pariah led him to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Henry Ward Beecher, the best known minister in the United States, took the platform in his beloved Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn sometime after 8 p. m. on Feb. 10, 1864. Under Beecher’s guidance the members of Plymouth Church stood as the most committed abolitionist flock in New York and even throughout the nation. On this night Beecher deferred to Brooklyn’s mayor, A. M. Wood, who introduced the evening’s speaker, E. W. Gantt, “late a General in the rebel army.” Gantt took the stage in the beautiful hall. Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims had occupied this building at the beginning of 1850 and while the exterior was not especially prepossessing, with its simple brick facade, the sanctuary looked very elegant. The hall, with a seating capacity of more than 2,500, boasted the largest pipe organ in the United States at the time. White pews trimmed in stained hardwood filled the floor and balcony, with the pews set in an oval, giving the space a theater-in-the-round sense rather than that of a cathedral or Puritan meeting house.

headline: New York Fashion Week Street Style: Day 6

headline: Israel’s Big Question
abstract: As Secretary of State John Kerry readies his framework for peace, there is some soul-searching to do.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written a series of columns from Israel in the past two weeks because I believe that if Secretary of State John Kerry brings his peace mission to a head and presents the parties with a clear framework for an agreement, Israel and the Jewish people will face one of the most critical choices in their history. And when they do, all hell could break loose in Israel. It is important to understand why.

abstract: Sky, a 5-year-old wire fox terrier, won the top crown at the 138th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday, becoming the 14th member of her breed to win best in show.
lead_paragraph: A bloodhound named Nathan stole the crowd’s heart Tuesday night at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Each time a camera caught his droopy-faced countenance, or a judge came within a few feet of him, his fans at Madison Square Garden erupted. They were nuts about Nathan, who was unfazed by the commotion.

headline: Christie Ridicules Democrats for Emphasizing Income Inequality
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government']

Chris Christie of New Jersey delivered an unexpectedly blistering broadside on Tuesday against the Democratic Party’s growing emphasis on income inequality, warning that the movement would “drive America toward mediocrity” and portraying its leaders, like Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, as local liberals unlikely to ignite a national cause.

headline: For Women, a More Complicated Choice on Mammograms
abstract: New research that questions the value of regular screening for breast cancer seems bound to produce public confusion and anger.
lead_paragraph: For women who dutifully keep their mammogram appointments year after year, the latest results from a long-term trial in Canada, which found no difference in death rates from breast cancer among women who had regular mammograms and those who did not, are bound to sow confusion, perhaps even anger.

headline: Panel Won’t Change Naproxen Labels
abstract: A panel convened by the Food and Drug Administration concluded that naproxen, the active ingredient in Aleve, did not pose a lower risk of cardiovascular problems than ibuprofen and similar pain drugs.
lead_paragraph: A panel convened by the Food and Drug Administration concluded that naproxen, the active ingredient in Aleve, did not pose a lower risk of cardiovascular problems than ibuprofen and similar pain drugs. The panel voted 16 to 9 on Tuesday not to change warning labels on naproxen, a broadly used anti-inflammatory pain medication, to say that it is less risky. Naproxen, which is widely used to treat arthritis pain, had been found in some studies included in a large analysis published last year in The Lancet to carry a lower risk for heart problems than others in its class. A large clinical trial comparing a number of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, including naproxen and ibuprofen, is nearing completion, and some participants said they expected that the results would allow for more definitive conclusions on naproxen.

headline: Rival Industries Sweet-Talk the Public
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Corn', 'Sugar', 'Political Advertising', 'Corn Syrup and Sweeteners', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: Court documents show that the corn refinery and sugar industries spent millions to enlist academics and lobbying groups to support a secret public relations war over the market for sweeteners.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The corn refinery and sugar industries, bitter rivals in the manufacture of billions of dollars’ worth of sweeteners for sodas and other high-calorie foods, covertly funded dueling nonprofit groups in Washington in a multiyear effort to grab market share, while also stoking fears among consumers about possible health risks, court records made public in a federal lawsuit between the two parties show.

headline: Union Drive Doesn’t Bother Management, but G.O.P. Fumes

lead_paragraph: As workers at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., prepare to vote this week on whether to join the United Automobile Workers, they are facing unusual pressure from the state’s Republican legislators to reject the union.

headline: Cuba’s Reward for the Dutiful: Gated Housing
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: With new apartments for families tied to the military and the interior ministry, President Raúl Castro is redoubling efforts to elevate the faithful and maintain their loyalty.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — In the splendid neighborhoods of this dilapidated city, old mansions are being upgraded with imported tile. Businessmen go out for sushi and drive home in plush Audis. Now, hoping to keep up, the government is erecting something special for its own: a housing development called Project Granma, featuring hundreds of comfortable apartments in a gated complex set to have its own movie theater and schools.

headline: Practice Is the Only Place Knicks Can’t Beat Themselves
abstract: If only practices were a barometer of a team’s success, the Knicks would be undefeated during the N.B.A. season.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Coach Mike Woodson called a timeout. His team was trailing by 3 points with 5.7 seconds left, so he broke out his whiteboard and drew up a play for a game-tying shot. On the ensuing inbounds play, his plan vaporized like a plume of talcum powder. A swarm of defenders quickly converged on Beno Udrih, who failed to squeeze off a jumper before the buzzer sounded.

headline: Britain: Thames Flooding Causes Cameron to Skip Middle East Visit
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron on Tuesday canceled a trip to Israel and the Palestinian territories to deal with extraordinary flooding in England.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister David Cameron on Tuesday canceled a trip to Israel and the Palestinian territories, which would have been his first to the region as prime minister, to deal with extraordinary flooding in England. In the Thames Valley, which currently faces the most severe flood warnings, about 1,000 homes have been evacuated, and 1,600 military personnel had been deployed. The prime minister spent the last two days touring a number of villages, even as questions arose over whether the floods were his “Katrina moment,” a reference to the American government’s response to the hurricane that hit New Orleans in 2005.

headline: Facing Jail Time, Until a Lawyer With Survival Skills Helped Her Find Her Way
abstract: Jessica Williams was essentially a dropout when she was arrested; with the help of her lawyer, she stayed out of prison and returned to school.
lead_paragraph: The .22-caliber pistol was in her waistband, not only unlicensed but defaced, its serial number scratched or sanded off. She had not been to school in at least six months. Sitting in a detention cell in December 2010 at age 17, Jessica Williams of East Harlem realized she had been caught cold and was about to be cooked: a year in jail on a Class D felony, and then lifetime membership in the Rikers Island Alumni Association. “Reality didn’t hit me until I was in Rikers Island, and thought, ‘Oh my God, this is not my life,’ ” Ms. Williams said this week.

lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn pastor with close ties to Mayor Bill de Blasio was arrested and then released in an unusual turn of events that included a call from the mayor to a top police commander late Monday. But the mayor’s office and the police both said Tuesday that Mr. de Blasio’s call came after a precinct commander had already decided to release the clergyman.

headline: Canada: Healthy Baby Is Delivered by Woman Declared Brain-Dead

abstract: The child was born over the weekend to Robyn Benson in Victoria, British Columbia, after she was declared brain-dead because of a cerebral hemorrhage.
lead_paragraph: A child was born over the weekend to a Canadian woman declared brain-dead after a cerebral hemorrhage on Dec. 28. Robyn Benson was 22 weeks pregnant when she was declared brain-dead in Victoria, British Columbia. But at the request of her husband, Dylan Benson, she was maintained on life support in a hospital intensive care unit and removed from life support shortly after giving birth. The case drew wide notice in Canada because of blog posts by Mr. Benson, who announced the birth on Monday.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 12, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, February 12, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It may not look good, but it does everything the law requires.”

headline: In Governors’ Races This Year, Lessons for 2016
abstract: Closely watched elections are approaching in Ohio, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, where white working-class voters were once solidly Democratic but are now up for grabs.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Three years after stripping public employee unions of the right to collectively bargain, Gov. Scott Walker began this election year by introducing workers who had found jobs since he took office. A dozen stood with him in the State Capitol, dressed for the workplace: a nursing assistant, an accountant, a maintenance technician at Milwaukee Valve.

headline: Hospital’s Plan to Expand Angers Many in Park Slope, Brooklyn
abstract: New York Methodist Hospital’s proposed outpatient center would dwarf the surrounding brownstones and cause traffic congestion, some residents say.
lead_paragraph: As Brooklyn residents in Bedford-Stuyvesant and Cobble Hill clamor to keep their flailing community hospitals open, a different kind of opposition has arisen in Park Slope, where the financially robust New York Methodist Hospital is embroiled in a battle over its plan to open an outpatient care center next to its main campus in the heart of the neighborhood.

lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged Tuesday in connection with the death of her 2-year-old son, the latest in a string of suspicious child deaths in New York City investigated by the police.

abstract: The suspect, Jamal Scott, was accused of murdering Jamal Green, a Queens rapper known in hip-hop as Mazaradi Fox, and a longtime associate of 50 Cent.
lead_paragraph: A 35-year-old man has been charged with killing a longtime associate of the rapper 50 Cent and wounding three other men last month when he opened fire on a sport utility vehicle as a group of men drove through the snowy streets of Queens, the authorities said on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton notified two powerful police chiefs on Tuesday that he planned to replace them as part of his efforts to change the New York Police Department, according to several people familiar with the discussions.

headline: Rights Group Details Kidnapping and Torture of Eritrean Refugees
abstract: Security officers in Egypt and Sudan have colluded with traffickers to extort money, Human Rights Watch said in a report.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Security officers in Egypt and Sudan have at times colluded with traffickers who kidnap and torture Eritrean refugees in order to extort money from the refugees’ relatives, according to a report released on Tuesday by Human Rights Watch.

headline: Proposed Hong Kong Tax Directed at Mainland Chinese Raises Alarms
abstract: With a sharp rise in visitors from mainland China, Hong Kong’s leaders find ways to tap into local anger about the effect of Chinese tourists.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong residents concerned about mainland China’s growing influence on their territory found yet another reason for alarm recently, with a report saying that a substantial increase in tourism last year was propelled by mainland Chinese — who accounted for 70 percent of the 54 million visitors in 2013.

headline: Salvadoran Who Told of Survival at Sea Flies Home
abstract: Jose Salvador Alvarenga, who washed ashore in the Marshall Islands, returned to El Salvador but seemed too overwhelmed to talk about the 13 months he said he had spent adrift.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A Salvadoran man who told the authorities he spent 13 months adrift in the Pacific Ocean before washing ashore in the Marshall Islands returned home to El Salvador on Tuesday, but seemed too overwhelmed to talk about his experiences.

headline: Nancy Holt, Outdoor Artist, Dies at 75
abstract: Ms. Holt was one of the few women to be a leader in the land-art movement, which places objects for natural settings.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Holt, a pioneer in the land-art movement of the 1960s and ’70s and the creator of one of the era’s most poetic works — “Sun Tunnels,” four huge concrete culverts set in the Utah desert to align with the sun on summer and winter solstices — died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 75.

headline: Demoralization Is Not a Policy Achievement
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Unemployment']
abstract: The White House and its allies are trying to put a very positive spin on the destructive aspects of some of its policies, including the Affordable Care Act, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Why Vitamins May Be Bad for Your Workout
abstract: Antioxidant supplements like vitamins C and E may actually reduce the benefits of training.
lead_paragraph: Many people take vitamins as part of their daily fitness regimens, having heard that antioxidants aid physical recovery and amplify the impact of workouts. But in another example of science undercutting deeply held assumptions, several new experiments find that antioxidant supplements may actually reduce the benefits of training.

lead_paragraph: Two prominent members of Congress, troubled by an enforcement action that the Federal Reserve imposed on large banks last year, are pressing for a big change in the way that Fed approves its crackdowns.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) TOM JONES (1963) In this “31 Days of Oscar” presentation, Albert Finney stars as an 18th-century English foundling turned Casanova in Tony Richardson’s Academy Award-winning adaptation of the classic novel by Henry Fielding. Susannah York (above, with Mr. Finney) is Sophie, the passionate daughter of the blue-blooded Squire Western (Hugh Griffith) and the woman Tom hopes to wed — though her father has other plans. Writing in The New York Times, Bosley Crowther called the film “surely one of the wildest, bawdiest and funniest comedies that a refreshingly agile filmmaker has ever brought to the screen.”

headline: Toyota Recalls Newest Priuses Over Software
abstract: The Japanese carmaker said it was recalling all 1.9 million latest-generation Prius cars sold worldwide because of a defect in the vehicle’s hybrid system.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toyota Motor is recalling all of the 1.9 million newest-generation Prius vehicles it has sold worldwide because of a programming error that could cause their gas-electric hybrid systems to shut down, the automaker said Wednesday.

headline: First Tie for Alpine Gold, Though Not Precisely
abstract: Tina Maze and Dominique Gisin had identical fastest times to the hundredths of a second in the women’s downhill, even though more precise times could have broken the tie.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A tie is not uncommon in most sports. Without it there would be no overtime, no extra innings and no sudden death. But a tie for the gold medal in an Alpine Olympic event had never occurred before Wednesday’s women’s downhill at the Sochi Games.

headline: Nanjing Meeting Leads to Pledge of Cross-Strait Communications
abstract: The chief outcome of the meeting between officials of Taiwan and mainland China, the first since 1949, was an agreement to set up a mechanism for regular communications between the two sides.
lead_paragraph: The chief outcome of Tuesday’s meeting between officials of Taiwan and mainland China was an agreement to set up a mechanism for regular communications between the two sides, which have previously relied on quasi-official bodies. Those organizations, Taiwan’s Straits Exchange Foundation and the mainland’s Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, will continue to operate alongside whatever official lines of communication are established, the Chinese state news agency Xinhua reported.

headline: Mayoral Victory in San Diego Offers Some Hope to California’s Struggling G.O.P.

lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The election of a Republican city councilman to become San Diego’s mayor became a rare bright spot for a party that has been eclipsed at the state level in California.

lead_paragraph: In “Freezing Out the Bigger Picture,” Justin Gillis writes about the difference between climate and weather.

headline: Can Wendy Davis Have It All?
abstract: A Texas-size tale of ambition, motherhood and political mythmaking.
lead_paragraph: One sunny Friday morning in late January, Wendy Davis took me on a two-hour tour of the life she led just a decade or so ago, back when she was a city councilwoman and the world knew nothing of her or the pink running shoes she wore during her epic filibuster, or her ambition to be elected this November as a Democratic governor in the deeply Republican state of Texas, or the way her parenting has become a point of debate in whether she’s a suitable candidate for that office. We were in Fort Worth, where Davis, who is a state senator, has lived for about 35 of her 50 years, most in utter obscurity. When she joined the City Council in 1999, she was only the third-most-prominent Wendy Davis in town (the other two were socialites), and to the extent that community leaders knew her at all, it was as the wife of Jeff Davis, an attorney and former city councilman, whose civic passions would spark her own. Once that fire was lit, everything would later change for her — for her marriage, for her city, for Texas and, who knows, perhaps even for a national Democratic Party in search of a post-Obama non-Hillary superstar.

headline: Freeing Vegetables From Side-Dish Purgatory
abstract: How to impress your dinner guests without showcasing a piece of meat.
lead_paragraph: Imagine this: Your dinner guests are seated around the table, waiting for you to parade out the main course. You triumphantly carry it in on a platter. Oohs and ahs ensue.

headline: Finding the Subject in the Shadows
abstract: A young photographer working in the Capitol in Washington drew inspiration from 17th-century paintings to render the recent government shutdown as it what was: a dark time.
lead_paragraph: Gabriella Demczuk, 22, was born in Stockholm, was raised mostly in Baltimore and graduated from George Washington University. She has worked for NPR and The Hill, a congressional newspaper, and photographs regularly for The New York Times as the photography intern at The Times’s Washington Bureau. Her Turning Point conversation with James Estrin has been edited.

headline: A Twist in Charter’s Pursuit of a Cable Deal
abstract: Charter Communications has played its latest move in its pursuit of Time Warner Cable, nominating a full slate of directors to its target’s board. | Federal prosecutors have filed actions against businesses that buy luxury cars at domestic dealerships and then send them to China. | The S.E.C. may have helped create the problem it is now hoping to solve. | Janet L. Yellen set a familiar direction for the Fed in her first public remarks before Congress on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: CHARTER’S BID FOR TIME WARNER CABLE HEATS UP  |  Charter Communications on Tuesday played its latest move in its pursuit of Time Warner Cable, nominating 13 directors to its target’s board. Now, as Time Warner Cable’s annual meeting approaches, shareholders will have to decide whether they want to force in a new board that would be more receptive to a deal with Charter, David Gelles writes in DealBook. Charter proposed to acquire Time Warner Cable for $132.50 a share last month, but Time Warner Cable maintains that Charter’s bid undervalues the cable operator.

lead_paragraph: In 2004, as Jimmy Fallon was leaving “Saturday Night Live” after a six-year run creating sketch characters and sharing the “Weekend Update” desk with Tina Fey, Lorne Michaels floated an idea.

headline: Take My Bro, Please
abstract: In “Someone Marry Barry,” three friends of the title character, an affable shlub, try to find him a wife.
lead_paragraph: For a gross-out movie, “Someone Marry Barry” has a respectable number of genuinely funny moments. Over all, it’s still kind of crass and lowbrow, showing a particular obsession with flatulence, but there’s a good-heartedness to it that somehow overrides your gut instinct to stop watching.

headline: Q. and A. | His Influence More Pervasive Than Ever, Boy George Stages a Comeback
abstract: The ’80s pop icon — and gay-rights trailblazer — on his new album “This is What I Do,” his sway on the gay-rights movement and the pitfalls of EDM.
lead_paragraph: After years of tabloid-documented drug addictions and run-ins with the law, Boy George at last has his feet on solid ground. The 52-year-old singer — born George O’Dowd and sober for the past five years — was one of the biggest pop stars of the ’80s, when he and his band, Culture Club, scored chart-topping hits with “Karma Chameleon” and “Do You Really Want To Hurt Me.” More importantly, George openly blurred the boundaries of sexuality in the era of AIDS, serving as a trailblazer for gay rights — and for the avant-garde personas of countless pop stars since.

abstract: Women are underrepresented across the financial sector, but the problem is particularly acute at the top levels of the hedge fund industry. Whitney Tilson asks why, and invites reader comments in the Another View column.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Tilson is the managing partner of the hedge fund firm Kase Capital Management, which he founded more than 15 years ago. Mr. Tilson is also the co-founder of Value Investor Insight, an investment newsletter, and the Value Investing Congress, a biannual investment conference.

headline: Poisonous Prey Turned Into Hunter’s Defense
keywords: ['Jellyfish', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Biodiversity', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: Delicate beauty can often belie dangerous weapons. For one sea slug, those weapons come courtesy of its stinging prey, which it can dispatch without missing a bite.
lead_paragraph: Delicate beauty can often belie dangerous weapons. Take the cnidarians (pronounced ni-DAR-ee-uns), a group of animals that includes jellyfish, corals, hydroids, and other predators both small and large. Many are colorful and beautiful, and all of them are loaded with stinging capsules that each contain a neurotoxin-filled harpoon.

headline: Atlanta Frozen Again as Winter Woes Chill South
abstract: A storm that meteorologists said could be the largest of the winter — at least in terms of geographical size if not precipitation or temperature — headed from the South to the North.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Here, in a nod to the Civil War, people joke that Atlanta is the city that won’t get burned twice. Wednesday, as the second major ice storm in two weeks froze the city in place, it proved true.

headline: Preparing for Disaster by Betting Against It
abstract: Catastrophe bonds are an increasingly popular type of storm insurance — and public finance innovation.
lead_paragraph: At 2 a.m. on Oct. 29, 2012, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (M.T.A.) shut down the New York City subway system in preparation for Hurricane Sandy.  By 9 p.m. storm surges reached nearly 14 feet at Manhattan’s Battery, as the waves of the East and Hudson Rivers deluged the city’s rail stations and tunnels, flooding tracks, corroding antiquated electric controls and wreaking $5 billion in damage on the largest regional transportation provider in the Western Hemisphere.  As it emerged from Sandy’s wreckage, the M.T.A. found it impossible to buy any existing kind of insurance against future storms.

headline: Vehicle Dependability Declines Significantly in J.D. Power Study
abstract: In its annual study, J.D. Power found that engine and transmission problems topped the list of reliability concerns.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since 1998, vehicle dependability has declined, according to the 2014 J.D. Power Vehicle Dependability Study released today. Most of the problems are with engines and transmissions, the report said.

headline: The First Daughters’ Club
abstract: In Rebecca Behrens’s debut novel, the fictional child of a president is inspired by the diary of Theodore Roosevelt’s daughter Alice.
lead_paragraph: Audrey Rhodes is a pretty typical 13-year old in every respect but one: The home she returns to at the end of the school day is 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. In Rebecca Behrens’s debut novel, “When Audrey Met Alice,” the perks that come with living in the White House (swimming pool, bowling alley, fresh-baked cookies on demand) fail to outweigh the loneliness and restrictions Audrey suffers in her role as “first daughter.” Her mother, the president, is distracted by matters of national importance. Her father, a medical researcher known as “the first gent,” is often away at his lab in Baltimore. Audrey’s ordinary teenage conundrums — how to make friends at a new school; how to act around a boy she likes — are amplified by the demands of presidential protocol and security: she can’t even choose her own clothes. It’s no wonder Audrey, who doesn’t mince words, says she sometimes feels “like punching a hole through one of my historic walls.”

abstract: Manchester United’s trophy tour, which includes the Premier League trophy, lands at New York’s Time Warner Center on Friday.
lead_paragraph: In and around the red half of Manchester, England, the Premier League of the present may look bleak — but the past has a resonance heard from Old Trafford to New Delhi, and now to New York.

In these interactive graphics and videos, learn their tricks and techniques — and then see how they used them to take home the gold.

headline: Earthquake Strikes Remote Area of China
abstract: The quake was powerful, but the mountainous region where it occurred is sparsely populated.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A mountainous part of the Xinjiang region in far western China was hit by an intense earthquake on Wednesday, but officials said the area was isolated and thinly populated and there were no initial reports of deaths.

headline: Supercell Revenue and Profit Soared in 2013
abstract: The Finnish gaming company behind the Clash of Clans and Hay Day franchises said revenue in 2013 rose nearly ninefold compared with 2012, and that pre-tax profit rose to $464 million from $51 million.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Supercell, the Finnish gaming company behind the popular Clash of Clans and Hay Day franchises, has pretty good reason to be happy.

keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:22 p.m. | Grupo Bimbo, a large Mexican baking company, is crossing North America for its latest bread deal.

headline: Dutch Speedskater Halts Shani Davis’s Reign in 1,000
abstract: Stefan Groothuis of the Netherlands won the 1,000 meters, keeping Shani Davis of the United States from becoming the first male speedskater to win three consecutive Olympic golds in one event.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Wednesday was supposed to provide the latest milestone moment in a career full of them for the American Shani Davis. Instead, it featured another dominant performance by the mighty Dutch speedskating team.

headline: Off the Runway | Shine On
abstract: Metallic, once the sheen of choice for louche after hours, is stepping out into the daylight in casual new ways.
lead_paragraph: Metallic, once the sheen of choice for louche after hours, is stepping out into the daylight in casual new ways.

headline: Hospitals’ Dialysis Plan Is Under New Scrutiny
abstract: A state council is set to vote on a deal to turn over dialysis at four of the city’s public hospitals to a for-profit franchise, though data show it did not perform as well as the hospitals themselves.
lead_paragraph: For 400,000 people across the country with failed kidneys, dialysis care is a matter of life and death. It is also a lucrative business, in part because Medicare pays for such treatment regardless of age.

headline: Foundation to Offer New Commission for Symphonies by Women
abstract: The Virginia B. Toulmin Foundation will fund two $15,000 commissions for women to compose symphonic works.
lead_paragraph: The women’s opera commissioning program that Opera America announced in December will have a symphonic counterpart, supported by the Virginia B. Toulmin Foundation program for commissioning women in the performing arts — the same foundation that is supporting the opera project. The new orchestral project, announced on Wednesday by the League of American Orchestras, is to be administered by the league, and is part of EarShot, a national network of orchestras that offer readings and workshops for composers in the early stages of their careers.

headline: Maybe I Do Like Carrots
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Food', 'Parenting', 'Vegetables']
abstract: With twins showing a new willingness to eat new foods, the parents of an avowed “picky eater” try a vegetable experiment.
lead_paragraph: Five weeks ago, 4-year-old Andrew Nostrame was a “picky eater.” Dinnertime was a succession of jump-ups for his parents, Christine Zanchi and Fran Nostrame, who were aggravated and defeated. Andrew’s twin brother, Nathaniel, had a much wider repertory and was more willing to try things, but even so, dinnertime was not a happy place. Christine and Fran weren’t battling so much as they were retreating. They needed to make a change and asked that Dr. David Ludwig and I step in to offer tools, including recipes and encouragement.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Diesel Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Dina Litovsky.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Dina Litovsky.

headline: TV Network Meets Social Network
abstract: Late-night television’s Gen X hosts each has a strong social media presence and a vision for viral content that appeals to his own, and younger, generations.
lead_paragraph: Late-night television is having a Gen X moment, with Jimmy Fallon, 39, and Jimmy Kimmel, 46, going head-to-head, and Seth Meyers, 40, soon to take over “Late Night.” Each has a strong social media presence and a vision for viral content that appeals to his own, and younger, generations.

headline: The Limbo of Asian Markets
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Foreign Investments', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The global currency crisis has forced markets to confront weak commodity exports before strong domestic demand can help them recover their balance.
lead_paragraph: SURABAYA, Indonesia — The docks at big Indonesian ports like this one are quieter these days, as China’s demand for raw materials has begun to cool.

headline: Image of the Day: February 12
abstract: A passing out parade in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh.

headline: Retail Businesses That Try Crowdfunding Face Some Skepticism
abstract: Commercial businesses seek to raise money through online donations from the public, and raise hackles instead.
lead_paragraph: After nine years in Brooklyn, the Chocolate Room — a popular purveyor of wine, cake, candy and coffee — experienced one of those cataclysmic events retailers fear: a crippling rise in rent. Informed in late 2012 that they would face an increase of more than 500 percent, the cafe’s owners, Naomi Josepher and Jon Payson, reluctantly decided to abandon their space and begin figuring out how to finance a $200,000 relocation.

headline: The Bulldozer
abstract: An Israeli journalist assesses Ariel Sharon’s complicated views.
lead_paragraph: When Ariel Sharon was elected prime minister of Israel in a landslide 13 years ago, many close to David Landau, a left-leaning British-born Israeli journalist, thought seriously of leaving the country. The future under Sharon, it seemed to them, held only war and bloodshed. Yet when Prime Minister Sharon collapsed from a stroke less than five years later, “We wept,” Landau writes. “Not just for him; for ourselves.”

headline: The Backup Singers Can Be Divas, Too
abstract: The director of the Oscar-nominated “20 Feet From Stardom” says the background performers who are the subjects of his film could behave just like pop stars.
lead_paragraph: In a career devoted largely to films about music, Morgan Neville has directed or produced documentaries about acclaimed performers as different as Ray Charles and Iggy Pop, and James Brown and Brian Wilson. But it took “20 Feet From Stardom,” his examination of a group of predominantly black, female backup singers known only to the kind of obsessive music fan who reads the fine print on the back of CD covers, for him to earn his first Oscar nomination.

headline: Was the Chocolate Room a Good Candidate for Crowdfunding?
abstract: Is it appropriate for a for-profit enterprise to solicit donations?
lead_paragraph: After nine years in Brooklyn, the Chocolate Room, a popular cafe that sells wine, cake, candy and coffee, experienced one of those cataclysmic events retailers fear: a crippling rent increase. As Stacy Cowley reports in an article we have just published, the cafe’s owners, Naomi Josepher and Jon Payson, were informed in late 2012 that they would face an increase of more than 500 percent. Reluctantly, they decided to abandon their space and begin figuring out how to finance a $200,000 relocation to their new store in Brooklyn.

headline: Technology Gives Ski Jumping Hills a Boost
abstract: The ski jumping hills at the Sochi Games are of a newer variety, with flatter, smoother curves on the inrun, and the facility has little snow around it.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — At its most basic, ski jumping looks simple: slap on a pair of skis, strap on a helmet and ski down a slope at roughly 60 miles an hour, leap into the sky and land one leg in front of another about a football field away.

headline: Classical Playlist: Danish String Quartet, Thomas Meglioranza, Gidon Kremer and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: CARL NIELSEN: ‘The Masterworks, Vol. 2 — Chamber and Instrumental Works’Danish String Quartet and others(Dacapo Records) The chamber music of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen, composed in the late 19th and early 20th century, has been enjoying a renaissance recently. The superb Danish String Quartet offers passionate, elegantly rendered interpretations of its compatriot’s lyrical, characterful quartets. The six-disc set also features the genial Piano Trio in G, as well as works for wind; piano and violin sonatas; and pieces for solo violin and solo piano. (Vivien Schweitzer)

headline: New York Fall 2014: Elements | Shape
abstract: A thematic visual diary of New York Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.
lead_paragraph: A thematic visual diary of New York Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

headline: Looks That Are Up to the Job
abstract: Three collections, including a nostalgic selection from Rodarte, tried to balance everyday needs and feminine flair.
lead_paragraph: No designer today can ignore the working woman. She is the one who demands the practicality (leaving aside perilously high heels) that was once reserved for the male of the species. So the conundrum becomes how to create appropriate clothes that still keep their feminine essence. That was the subject of three very different collections during New York Fashion Week for fall 2014.

headline: Folk Art Building May Be Lost, but Facade Will Live: In Storage Someplace
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art said it could not save the former home of the American Folk Art Museum in Midtown, but it is intent on saving an 82-foot-high sculptural ensemble of 63 panels.
lead_paragraph: Contrary to what you may have read lately, the Museum of Modern Art is intent on carefully preserving the former American Folk Art Museum next door.

headline: Work and Health Insurance: Is There An Alternative?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Income', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Why liberals accept the Obamacare work disincentive, and why theirs isn’t the only option.
lead_paragraph: Three blog posts and a column should probably suffice to cover the debate over Obamacare and work incentives, but I don’t want to let the topic drop without first stepping back and talking about the actual health policy disagreement here. My column and posts last week criticized what struck me as a kind of insouciance from liberals about this issue, shading into a post-work utopianism that doesn’t wrestle with what, in practice, the decline of work is actually likely to mean for issues of class, mobility, and social equality. But it’s also important to recognize that for many liberal writers, the controlling assumption here is not anti-work or pro-work. It’s just pro-universal health care as a basic standard for a decent society, with the consequences taken as they come.

headline: Meghan Collison Transforms Backstage at Rodarte
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Meghan Collison before (left) and after (right) makeup by Dick Page and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Gabriel Axel Dies at 95; Directed ‘Babette’s Feast’
abstract: Mr. Axel’s 1987 film, about a Parisian chef who transforms a Danish village, helped expand popular interest in haute cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel Axel, a director whose 1987 labor of love, “Babette’s Feast,” received the first foreign-language Oscar awarded to a Danish motion picture — and heralded a growing popular interest in all things food — died on Sunday in Copenhagen. He was 95.

headline: At Long Last, Westminster Gives Rat Terriers a Chance to Show
abstract: The persistence of a breed’s aficionados resulted in recognition by the American Kennel Club and a place at the Westminster Kennel Club’s show.
lead_paragraph: Harriett Browne had the chicken morsels that Q and Dinger coveted. They were hungry Tuesday afternoon, up on their hind legs, seeking their rewards after competing in the first breed judging for rat terriers in the history of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Q belongs to Browne, who lives in Columbus, Ohio, and Dinger is owned by her friend Darice Ragan, a rat terrier breeder from Greenback, Tenn.

headline: A Short Affair, Now With Songs
abstract: Expectations are high for Jason Robert Brown’s return to Broadway with “The Bridges of Madison County.”
lead_paragraph: Robert James Waller’s 1992 novel “The Bridges of Madison County” slipped onto best-seller lists despite being ignored at first by many major reviewers. The unapologetically romantic tale of a lonely Iowa farm wife’s short, tempestuous affair with a photographer who passes through town, though, captivated booksellers and readers. There was a film version in 1995, too, starring Clint Eastwood and Meryl Streep.

headline: On the Death Penalty, ‘Too Many Doubts’
abstract: The governor of Washington issued a moratorium on all executions in the state.
lead_paragraph: While multiple states continue to haggle over whether they can hide the way they kill people, the governor of Washington has decided to enter what he calls the “growing national conversation about capital punishment” on the other side — issuing a moratorium on all executions in the state because he is not convinced “equal justice is being served.”

headline: German Officials Discuss Plans for a New Center for Art Restitution
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The center is part of an effort to strengthen the country’s handling of restitution of art looted by the Nazis, in the wake of international criticism.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German culture officials will begin discussing plans for a new, independent center as part of efforts to strengthen the country’s handling of the restitution of art looted by the Nazis. The decision comes in the wake of international criticism over the handling of a discovery of hundreds of possibly stolen works.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Dina Litovsky.

headline: Browsing for Bargain Spring-Break Airfares
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The Frugal Traveler runs fare searches for three upcoming break periods to tease out clues about when, and where, to fly for less.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a student or teacher — or are in any way connected to the school schedule — you’ve are likely to have spring break coming up in March or April. Many public school systems have next week off, too.

headline: Paddling 2,500 Miles Around Florida
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Paddleboarding', 'Environment', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Justin Riney talks about what he did the year he spent exploring the state on a stand-up paddle board, from organizing trash cleanups to counting 183 alligators in a single day.
lead_paragraph: With a series of unfulfilling office jobs behind him, Justin Riney, 32, decided to “step off the ledge” three years ago. He spent the next year back home in Vero Beach, Fla., creating a plan to combine his attachment to the ocean with his desire to protect it. “I grew up a surfer, but I also loved fishing, camping, boating — anything that connected me with the water,” he said.

headline: After Marquee Roles, an Epiphany
abstract: Alexandra Silber discusses her role as a soldier’s wife in the musical “Arlington,” and why she stopped singing for years.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Silber stole the show at the Inner Voices series in November 2012, seated at an upright piano singing “Beautiful Dreamer” as if it had just been written by Taylor Swift (rather than in the 1860’s by Stephen Foster). The song was the highlight of Victor Lodato and Polly Pen’s “Arlington,” a mini-musical about war, which began performances Wednesday in an expanded version at the Vineyard Theater.
