headline: Standard Chartered Looking to Sell Swiss Private Bank
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The British bank, which makes much of its profit in Asia, is exiting or selling business lines outside of its core markets as part of a streamlining effort.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Standard Chartered, the British bank that earns most of its profit in Asia, is prepping its Swiss private bank for a sale as it prunes its non-core operations, a spokeswoman confirmed Wednesday.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 12
abstract: Women’s downhill skiing, men’s speedskating and women’s halfpipe on the seventh day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: Women’s downhill skiing, men’s speedskating and women’s halfpipe on the seventh day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: A New York City State of Mind
abstract: For Meg Crosby, recently of San Francisco, life in a Manhattan high-rise beckoned.
lead_paragraph: After 15 years in San Francisco, Meg Crosby was eager to return to the East Coast. “New York was on my mind for a long time,” said Ms. Crosby, a Maryland native.

headline: Mob Princess Wages War on Concept of Inevitable
abstract: In “Philosophy for Gangsters,” a college graduate being groomed to lead the family business puts the concept of determinism squarely in her cross hairs.
lead_paragraph: In “Philosophy for Gangsters,” a fitfully amusing dark comedy, Callie Rizzoli, a college-educated Mafia princess being groomed to lead the family business, is particularly aggrieved by the way her parents and brothers have departed — in a firefight with the police, shrugging that they were always meant to die that way.

headline: A. A. Gill Honored for Top Hatchet Job
abstract: Mr. Gill’s review of Morrissey’s “Autobiography” took home an annual prize for the best negative book review.
lead_paragraph: As conversations continue to swirl around whether negative reviews are a worthy use of the dwindling amount of space devoted to covering books, the Hatchet Job of the Year Award has been given to A. A. Gill for his dyspeptic view of the rock star Morrissey’s “Autobiography.”

headline: An Act of Surrender May Strengthen Boehner’s Control
abstract: By quickly and unilaterally ending a back-and-forth over a debt ceiling increase, Speaker John A. Boehner avoided another protracted public battle among Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Tuesday morning, after extended discussions of political fund-raising at the Capitol Hill Club, Speaker John A. Boehner stood to change the subject. He then told his House Republican troops that he would put to a vote a measure to raise the government’s borrowing limit, without preconditions.

headline: Disney Plans to Encourage Digital Start-Ups
abstract: As part of its search for new digital growth, the company is partnering with TechStars and will pair its executives with entrepreneurs for three months.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Magic Kingdom is letting 10 technology start-ups inside its walls as part of an effort to find new digital growth.

headline: Judge Sets Nov. 3 as Start of Trial for Boston Bombing Suspect
abstract: The start of the trial for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev is much earlier than the date requested by the defense team.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A federal judge here on Wednesday set Nov. 3 as the start of the trial for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused of the deadly bombing of the Boston Marathon last year.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Marc by Marc Jacobs Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: How Not to React When a Child’s News Surprises You
abstract: Michael Sam’s father offers an excellent example of how not to respond to a child’s surprising news — and a good opportunity to reflect on how you’d like to react.
lead_paragraph: Maybe this is a good time to take a moment and consider what you would say if your child made an announcement that really surprised you — especially if it both surprised and disappointed you. It could be, “Mom, I’m not going to college, because I’m traveling the country with my punk rock band.” Or it could be, “Dad, I’m leaving the Joffrey Ballet.” It doesn’t matter — but what you say does. That first reaction stays with your child no matter how you eventually turn it around, whether it’s disappointment in his choice of spouse or disbelief over her career decision.

headline: Doing the Math on Grupo Bimbo’s Deal for Canada Bread
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Economic fluctuations have little effect on demand for bread, and even with this acquisition, Bimbo has kept its debt to a reasonable level, Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: In its latest deal north of the border, Grupo Bimbo, the acquisitive Mexican bread maker, is spending $1.8 billion to buy Canada Bread. Paying 20 times earnings to move into a mature market may seem questionable. But Bimbo’s earnings fetch an even higher multiple at home — and the deal should lower its weighted average cost of capital.

headline: Backpack Key to Snowboarder’s Survival
abstract: The professional snowboarder Jeremy Jones trusts his life to the contents of his backpack. Whether in Alaska or Antarctica, the equipment he carries on his back is essential.
lead_paragraph: The professional snowboarder Jeremy Jones trusts his life to the contents of his backpack. Whether in Alaska or Antarctica, the equipment he carries on his back is essential.

headline: Below the Line: Makeup for ‘Dallas Buyers Club’
abstract: The makeup artist Robin Mathews discusses some of her designs for “Dallas Buyers Club.”
lead_paragraph: For “Dallas Buyers Club,” much has been said about the physical transformations  Matthew McConaughey and Jared Leto went through to portray characters struggling with the complications of AIDS. But their conversions were helped  by makeup artists who sometimes used experimental techniques to create their sickly looks. Robin Mathews, who, along with Adruitha Lee, is nominated for a makeup Oscar, said that because of the film’s low budget and 23-day shooting schedule, much of her design came together on the set.

headline: The Gaming Console Winner
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)']
abstract: Molly Wood tests the Sony PlayStation 4 and the Xbox One and declares one gaming console the winner.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood tests the Sony PlayStation 4 and the Xbox One and declares one gaming console the winner.

headline: Two Game Consoles Battle for a Dubious Prize
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'PlayStation (Video Game System)', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)']
abstract: With games readily available for smartphones and tablets, the question of which is better — Microsoft’s XBox or Sony’s PS4 — may be moot.
lead_paragraph: A philosophical war is being waged in the world of video game consoles.

headline: Russian Environmentalist, and Critic of Olympics, Gets 3-Year Prison Sentence
abstract: Yevgeny Vitishko, co-author of a report on the environmental impact of the Games, was sentenced to a penal colony.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — An environmentalist and leading critic of Russia’s preparations to host the Winter Olympics was sentenced Wednesday to serve three years in a penal colony, in a ruling that rights groups condemned as legally flawed and obvious retribution for his political activities.

headline: Chief Executive Turnover High in January, Report Says
abstract: More than 130 C.E.O.’s stepped down from their posts in January. It may indicate better times for the corporate sector, as boards are more inclined to shuffle management when business is good.
lead_paragraph: New year, new chief executive.

headline: Nagin Guilty of 20 Counts of Bribery and Fraud
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: A federal jury deliberated for about six and a half hours before finding C. Ray Nagin, the former mayor of New Orleans, guilty of accepting payoffs for city contracts.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — C. Ray Nagin, a former corporate executive who became mayor in 2002 pledging to modernize city government and instead became an emblem of government dysfunction in the months and years after Hurricane Katrina, was found guilty in federal court on Wednesday on 20 counts of bribery and fraud.

headline: High-Traffic Walkways in Bronx Become Slippery Obstacles as Snow Lingers
abstract: Many Bronx residents and community leaders say that the city has allowed some public walkways to remain covered with snow and ice, making them treacherous for those on foot.
lead_paragraph: Old men wielded their canes like ski poles across the slippery ice. Couples clung tightly to each other for balance. And subway riders climbing out of the 174th-175th Street station in the Bronx wobbled unsteadily as they tried to find a foothold.

headline: Mets Sign Reliever Jose Valverde
abstract: The Mets announced on Wednesday that they had signed Valverde, 35, who converted 9 of 12 save chances in 20 games last year, to a minor league contract.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — In 2012, pitching for the Detroit Tigers, Jose Valverde was considered a competent closer, perhaps on the verge of being elite. He had compiled 110 saves in his first three seasons in Detroit, but in the 2012 playoffs, as the Tigers marched to the World Series, they did so in spite of him. He imploded. He blew one save, allowed nine runs in four appearances, and was mercifully benched.

headline: Syrian Rebels Sketch Peace Plan That Omits Demand for Assad’s Ouster
abstract: The proposal signified a shift in tone for the opposition, which has long insisted on President Bashar al-Assad’s departure as the starting point for a political resolution.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Syrian opposition coalition on Wednesday presented its most detailed vision yet of a political transition to end Syria’s conflict, in a 24-point plan that, strikingly, made no mention of President Bashar al-Assad or his ouster, while outlining strong requirements for human rights and justice in a future Syria.

headline: Michael Kors: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Feeling For | Wearing Your Heart on Your Bag
abstract: Not just for Valentine’s Day, this red-and-white Stella McCartney number is less ephemeral than a rose and more droolworthy than a box of chocolates.
lead_paragraph: From heart-studded store windows to Cupid-covered dinner menus, it’s hard to ignore the fact that Valentine’s Day is just around the corner. But come this time next week, empty chocolate boxes will get tossed into recycling bins, love notes will be tucked away for safe keeping and red-and-pink decorations will give way to the next Hallmark holiday, perhaps Easter. For a sweet statement with more staying power, consider this Stella McCartney bucket bag. The drawstring shape gets a playful boost from a painterly coeur print accented with Stella’s signature chain-link trim. This bonbon of a bag is one long-term commitment we wouldn’t be afraid to make.

headline: Upstart Ends Gold Medal Run by the Big 3 in Women’s Halfpipe
abstract: Kaitlyn Farrington of the United States beat her two teammates, Kelly Clark and Hannah Teter, and Torah Bright of Australia, all of whom have won gold.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The cattle auctions were on Wednesdays, Kaitlyn Farrington remembered. On the ranch near Bellevue, Idaho, before she left for school, she and her father would load a cow, maybe two, into the back of a trailer attached to the pickup truck. Gary Farrington drove about 40 miles south to Shoshone and made the sale, maybe $1,000 a head.

headline: The Gun Report: February 12, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: One thing we have discovered since we began chronicling gun violence is that a surprising number of Americans use guns to end arguments or register their frustration. This probably would not happen if guns weren’t so readily available. Sometimes when these stories make their way into the press, you have to wonder whether you’re reading The Onion.

headline: Teaching the Sochi Olympics | Science, Health and Math
abstract: The 2014 Winter Olympics offer a chance for students to dig into some of the more technical subjects.

headline: Storm Causes Traffic Chaos in North Carolina
abstract: Widespread damage and power outages have been caused by an unusually strong ice storm in the South.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:35 p.m. Thousands of motorists in North Carolina found themselves stuck on snow-covered highways Wednesday in a situation that looked similar to what took place in Georgia only two weeks ago, when motorists were stranded for hours.

headline: Apple and Samsung Took All Handset Profits in Fourth Quarter
abstract: Last year, Asian handset makers like Huawei, Lenovo and LG gained traction in the mobile phone business. Yet Samsung Electronics and Apple, the top two handset makers in the world, made all of the industry’s profits.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Asian handset makers like Huawei and Lenovo gained major traction in the mobile phone business. Yet Samsung Electronics and Apple, the top two handset makers in the world, made all of the industry’s profits last quarter.

headline: Alan Alda Challenges Scientists to Explain Color to Kids
abstract: A contest seeks scientists who can explain color to children.
lead_paragraph: Alan Alda, the actor and evangelizer for effective science communication, is at it again, asking scientists for accurate, but engaging answers to a new question: What is color?

headline: Young Adults Need Flu Shots Too
abstract: Young adults who have not had a flu shot are at disproportionate risk of requiring hospital care this flu season, a small new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Young adults who have not had a flu shot are at disproportionate risk of serious illness and hospitalization this flu season, a small new study suggests.

headline: A Night of Comedy (and Political Jabs) for a Cause
abstract: The Creek and the Cave in Long Island City, Queens, hosts a night of comedy benefiting organizations founded by Eve Ensler and Lizz Winstead.
lead_paragraph: Feminism and comedy may seem like uneasy bedfellows: Does an activist, progressive cause thrive in an industry that prides itself on political incorrectness? But at “One Billion Laughing,” the comedy fund-raiser held on Tuesday night at the Creek and the Cave in Long Island City, Queens, it felt like a natural fit.

headline: Survey Suggests Voters Prefer Cuomo’s Proposal for Pre-K
abstract: Forty-seven percent of the state’s voters said they favored the governor’s plan to pay for prekindergarten classes, but the wording of the question makes the results much less conclusive.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A new poll released on Wednesday seemed to give a lift to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo as he quarrels with Mayor Bill de Blasio over the best way to pay for prekindergarten classes.

headline: Krawcheck Says Women on Wall Street Have ‘Gone Backwards’
abstract: It has long been a feature of Wall Street that women are underrepresented in the executive ranks. But since the financial crisis, the situation has gotten worse, said Sallie L. Krawcheck, a former executive at Bank of America and Citigroup, in an interview on Bloomberg TV.
lead_paragraph: It has long been a feature of Wall Street that women are underrepresented in the executive ranks. But since the financial crisis, the situation has gotten worse, according to one former big bank executive.

headline: In Marrakesh, Art by Churchill
abstract: Paintings by Sir Winston Churchill and the Moroccan artist Hassan el Glaoui will be shown at La Mamounia hotel in Marrakesh.
lead_paragraph: La Mamounia, the upscale hotel in Marrakesh, Morocco, is hosting an art exhibition in its Grand Salon from Feb. 20 to March 3 in which eight paintings by  Sir Winston Churchill and 17 by the 90-year-old Moroccan artist Hassan el Glaoui will be on display.

headline: Derek Jeter Says He’ll Retire at End of 2014 Season
abstract: Jeter, entering his 20th season with the Yankees, announced on his official Facebook fan page that 2014 would be his final year of professional baseball.
lead_paragraph: For the past several weeks, Derek Jeter has been doing what he has long done as the Yankees’ redoubtable shortstop for two decades: getting a head start on spring training by working out almost daily at the team’s complex in Tampa, Fla.

headline: ‘Death to America’ in Perspective
abstract: Despite extremist rhetoric, most Iranians are not eager for another war.
lead_paragraph: For many Americans, the familiar chants of “death to America” on the 35th anniversary of the Iranian Islamic revolution on Tuesday were no doubt infuriating. How can the United States ever complete a nuclear deal, much less consider normalizing relations in the future, with such a relentlessly hostile country?

headline: With U.S. in Sights, Norwegian Airline Wins Irish License
abstract: Norwegian Air Shuttle's plan to offer cut-rate flights across the Atlantic has been fiercely opposed by airlines and pilots in the United States and Europe.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Norwegian Air Shuttle said Wednesday that its long-distance subsidiary had formally received an operating license from Ireland, paving the way for the budget carrier to seek approval in the United States for a plan to offer cut-rate flights across the Atlantic that has been fiercely opposed by airlines and pilots there and in Europe.

headline: App Smart: Your Family Tree
abstract: The Times’s Kit Eaton on Ancestry, MyHeritage and other apps to trace your family tree.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Kit Eaton on Ancestry, MyHeritage and other apps to trace your family tree.

headline: Trace Your Family Tree, From Roots to Green Shoots
abstract: Several apps can help you unearth your relatives, using an assortment of databases.
lead_paragraph: I’m British, Welsh to be exact, which means if I consulted the right databases and cross-referenced family documents I could probably trace my ancestry back 400 or 500 years. Nowadays, I can even carry out genealogy research with my smartphone.

headline: Listen Up | Melody Maker
abstract: Mixing soulful R&B with thumping club beats, the singer Kelela is bringing her underground dance mash-ups to the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Mixing soulful R&B with thumping club beats, the singer Kelela is bringing her underground dance mash-ups to the mainstream.

keywords: ['Child Soldiers', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Social Media']
abstract: The Amnesty International report, based on field work and firsthand witness accounts, shows a campaign of ethnic cleansing of Muslim civilians.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 8, a man named Soba Tibati was sitting on a straw mat under a tree outside of his family’s hut in a small town called Boyali in the Central African Republic.

abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Former Top S.E.C. Enforcer Returns to Milbank
abstract: George Canellos, the latest Wall Street regulator to switch sides, will start his new job in mid-March, two months after leaving the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:03 p.m. | After spending the last few years investigating financial institutions, George Canellos will now be defending them.

headline: Video: Snowboarder Trusts His Life to His Backpack
abstract: Jeremy Jones knows that the 30 pounds of equipment he carries on his back for his big-mountain rides could save his life or the lives of his travel partners.
lead_paragraph: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: Scene City: The Benign King of Hollywood
abstract: Dozens of famous friends honor Bryan Lourd, the powerhouse agent of CAA.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of famous friends honor Bryan Lourd, the powerhouse agent of CAA.

headline: G.O.P. Senate Leaders Avert Debt Ceiling Crisis
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Senate Republican leaders rescued a measure to raise the nation’s borrowing limit, overcoming a threatened filibuster to clear the way for final approval.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a moment of real drama in a chamber known for its somnambulism. Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, counted votes on his hand, at one point holding up three fingers as he searched for the remaining votes. Senator John Cornyn of Texas, his No. 2, paced the Senate floor.

headline: I.M.F. Study Details Perils of Iranian Economy
keywords: ['Inflation (Economics)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: The International Monetary Fund warned that government mismanagement aggravated by the impact of sanctions had left Iran vulnerable to anemic growth and rampant inflation.
lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund issued a sobering appraisal of Iran’s economy on Wednesday, warning that years of government mismanagement aggravated by the impact of the West’s antinuclear sanctions had left the country vulnerable to anemic growth and rampant inflation that require urgent attention.

headline: Russia Prevails in Pairs Skating, Renewing a Tradition
abstract: Maxim Trankov and Tatiana Volosozhar recaptured gold for Russia in pairs skating, four years after a stunning shutout in Vancouver.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Maxim Trankov screamed and slid on his knees in a moment of triumph and renewal.

headline: BlackBerry’s Market Share Falls Below ‘Others’
abstract: BlackBerry ended last year with just 0.6 percent of the market, even less than the 0.7 percent attributed to operating systems so inconsequential that IDC lumps them together in a collective category.
lead_paragraph: Continuing a well-established pattern, BlackBerry posted a sharp market share loss in the latest global estimates released Wednesday by IDC, the market research company. Even though smartphone shipments rose 39 percent in 2013 compared with the year before, exceeding one billion units for the first time, BlackBerry shipments fell 41 percent.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 6
abstract: Miu Miu screened fashion film; Rodarte partied at Acme.
lead_paragraph: Miu Miu screened fashion film; Rodarte partied at Acme.

headline: 49th ‘Now’ Compilation Is No. 1
abstract: The latest “Now That’s What I Call Music!” compilation, with hits by Lorde, Miley Cyrus and One Direction, sold 98,000 copies to top the album chart.
lead_paragraph: “Now That’s What I Call Music!,” a series of pop compilation albums that have been coming out like clockwork in the United States since 1998 — and since 1983 in Britain — has topped the Billboard chart once again.

headline: Scientists Hope to Sequence Genome of Richard III
abstract: About a year and a half after finding the king’s corpse, British researchers will grind up his bones in hopes of discovering, for example, what bacteria he might have been hosting.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — About a year and a half after finding King Richard III’s corpse under a parking lot in Leicester, British scientists will proceed to grind up some of his bones to try to sequence his genome. They hope to discover his hair and eye color and see what kind of infectious bacteria he might have been hosting.

headline: 3.3 Million Enrolled on Health Marketplaces, Including More Young People, Government Says
abstract: About one-fourth of the total are the young adults so avidly sought by insurers because they are usually healthier and need fewer medical services.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 3.3 million people have signed up for health insurance through the marketplaces established by President Obama’s health care law, and about one-fourth of them are young adults, the administration said Wednesday.

headline: Sting’s Musical ‘The Last Ship’ Finds a Home and a Cast
abstract: The show is to start performances at the Neil Simon Theater on Sept. 30 with a cast that includes Michael Esper and Aaron Lazar.
lead_paragraph: Casting and a Broadway theater were announced on Wednesday for “The Last Ship,” the new show with music and lyrics by the Grammy Award-winning singer Sting and a book by the Tony Award-winning author John Logan (“Red”) and the Putlizer Prize winner Brian Yorkey (“Next to Normal”).

headline: Canada Rallies to Beat U.S. in Women’s Hockey
abstract: Hayley Wickenheiser, Canada’s 35-year-old star, helped her team end a four-game losing streak to the United States in women’s hockey in a preliminary game at Shayba Arena.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Since 2010, the United States women’s hockey team got younger and faster while Canada’s Hayley Wickenheiser, the game’s gold standard, merely grew older. That was the running narrative, anyway, as the Canadians, the three-time defending Olympic champions, lost four consecutive games to the speedy, streaking Americans in the lead-up to the Sochi Games.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Juliana Schurig at Vera Wang
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Juliana Schurig before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Jimmy Paul.

headline: An Antique Palazzo in Malta
abstract: A renovated four-bedroom mid-19th-century palazzo on a narrow, cobbled lane is on the market for $1.13 million.
lead_paragraph: A renovated four-bedroom mid-19th-century palazzo on a narrow, cobbled lane is on the market for $1.13 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Malta
abstract: During the global downturn, the Maltese market remained stagnant for a year before eventually picking up; foreign buyers seek refuge there from high taxes.
lead_paragraph: A RENOVATED PALAZZO IN BIRKIRKARA

headline: The Short Life of a Hard Choice
abstract: Both parties rushed to reverse a sensible cut in military pensions.
lead_paragraph: The real “cave” on Capitol Hill this week wasn’t the agreement to raise the debt ceiling, which was merely the victory of common sense over partisan posturing. It was actually the rush by both parties to reverse a small and perfectly sensible cut in a few military pensions.

headline: Left and Right Object to I.R.S. Plan to Restrict Nonprofits’ Political Activity
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Political Action Committees', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Organizations across the political spectrum say new regulations drafted to curb a surge in political spending and activity by nonprofits are far too broad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With time running short, both progressive and conservative advocacy groups are raising serious objections to new rules proposed by the Obama administration to rein in political activity by nonprofit organizations that are not required to disclose sources of their funding.

headline: The Art of Tuning Skis
abstract: A ski technician plays a behind-the-scenes role that is part crew chief, part caddie and part counselor. Ales Sopotnik spends countless hours tuning the skis of the American Alpine racer Leanne Smith.
lead_paragraph: A ski technician plays a behind-the-scenes role that is part crew chief, part caddie and part counselor. Ales Sopotnik spends countless hours tuning the skis of the American Alpine racer Leanne Smith.

headline: Making Instruments, Not Just Music: A Competition for Inventors
abstract: The Margaret Guthman Musical Instrument Competition at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta has drawn inventors from 14 countries.
lead_paragraph: Are you a musician who has always felt that the current crop of musical instruments can’t quite capture that special, otherworldly sound that you can feel permeating your soul? You may want to keep an eye on the Margaret Guthman Musical Instrument Competition at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, where 23 instrument inventors from 14 countries are competing for a $10,000 in prizes (the top prize is $5,000) and recognition for their design, performance and engineering ingenuity.

headline: Video: The Art of Tuning Skis
abstract: A ski technician plays a behind-the-scenes role that is part crew chief, part caddie. Ales Sopotnik spends countless hours tuning the U.S. Alpine racer Leanne Smith’s skis.
lead_paragraph: The Alpine skiers at the Sochi Games are reaching speeds in excess of 80 miles an hour — and at that velocity, the condition of their equipment can spell the difference between a spot on the podium and a helicopter flight to a hospital. Little wonder that ski technicians are so valued. Part crew chief, part caddie and part counselor, a ski technician is responsible for maintaining and tuning the dozens of pairs of skis a racer might use in a season.

headline: Highlights From the Owner’s Manual
abstract: This show feels like a blend of a bachelorette party at Chippendales and the embarrassing midnight act at a Pigalle tourist trap.
lead_paragraph: Every theater in New York should hire Stefan to make the precurtain announcements. With his baby face, bedroom eyes and alluring if indeterminate European accent, he can order us to turn off our cellphones and unwrap our hard candies any time.

headline: With His First Budget, de Blasio Hews to Familiar Campaign Themes
abstract: New York’s mayor called for spending millions more on education, housing, aid for the homeless and paid sick days.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday proposed his first budget for New York City, a $73.7 billion spending plan that gave more palpable, if not practical, shape to the robust liberal platform that carried him into office last year.

headline: Sid Caesar, Comedian of Comedians From TV’s Early Days, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Caesar was a force of nature who starred on “Your Show of Shows” in the early 1950s and influenced generations of comedians and comedy writers.
lead_paragraph: Sid Caesar, a comedic force of nature who became one of television’s first stars in the early 1950s and influenced generations of comedians and comedy writers, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Southern Gentleman as Hollywood Agent
abstract: A gala in honor of Bryan Lourd and his brand of soft power.
lead_paragraph: The actress Ellen Barkin strode onstage at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, champagne in hand, to toast her “best friend” Bryan Lourd, the powerful but low-key managing partner of the Creative Artists Agency.

headline: Giant Laser Complex Makes Fusion Advance, Finally
keywords: ['Hydrogen', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Science and Technology', 'Energy and Power', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)']
abstract: Two experiments in which hydrogen fusion generated more energy than had been put in to the hydrogen succeeded, an advance that revives optimism in thermonuclear fusion.
lead_paragraph: After years of disappointing results and missed deadlines, a $5 billion laser complex has now achieved a step that revives optimism that thermonuclear fusion, the process that powers the sun, can one day be harnessed for almost limitless energy.

headline: Conservative Group Enters Michigan Fray on Side of Tea Party
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Political Advertising', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: In its first such intervention into the broader battle between the party establishment and Tea Party conservatives, Americans for Prosperity will air ads supporting Representative Justin Amash.
lead_paragraph: One of the country’s most influential conservative political organizations announced Wednesday that it was diving into a bitter Republican primary in Michigan, its first such intervention into the broader battle  between the party establishment and Tea Party conservatives.

headline: Style Points Prove Scarce in Sochi
abstract: Conformity appears to be the fashion theme for the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: Bless the crazy-pants Norwegian curlers, the guys wearing trousers no one can quite believe, to compete in a sport few understand. For Sochi, the media-savvy Norwegians packed a wardrobe of multiple wacky changes — Missoni-on-acid zigzags (shout-out to Al Roker and Matt Lauer!); Mondrian squares; granny-print knickers, all designed by a California sportswear company specializing in golf duds — that garnered 500,000 likes on an unofficial Facebook page even before the Winter Games began.

headline: In Performance: Jonathan Groff
abstract: Jonathan Groff, who performed in Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series on Feb. 15, sings “I Got Lost in His Arms,” a number from Irving Berlin’s 1946 musical “Annie Get Your Gun.”
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Groff, who performed in Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series on Feb. 15, sings “I Got Lost in His Arms,” a number from Irving Berlin’s 1946 musical “Annie Get Your Gun.”

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Q. and A. With Dick Page
abstract: Behind the scenes at Michael Kors, the makeup artist dished on his friendship with the designer, how to be pretty but not boring and the virtues of under-eye bags.
lead_paragraph: Don’t ever accuse Dick Page of holding back. The British makeup artist fires off witty remarks and unvarnished opinions as effortlessly as he paints on the perfect lipstick. Here, we caught up with the affable pro backstage at Michael Kors for some straight talk (and friendly ribbing) on how to be pretty but not boring, the virtues of undereye bags and why the show must always go on — yes, even if it snows.

headline: Valentine’s Stays With a Little Spice
abstract: Hotels are offering Valentine’s Day packages that include body oils and chocolate body paint.
lead_paragraph: Rose petals on the bed? Been there. Champagne on ice? Done that. This year in honor of Valentine’s Day, hoteliers are edging into racier territory.

headline: How Nonprofits Have Played in Politics
abstract: The I.R.S. has proposed new restrictions to rein in the political activity of nonprofit “social welfare” groups, which has increased with changes to federal campaign finance laws over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: The I.R.S. has proposed new restrictions to rein in the political activity of nonprofit “social welfare” groups, which has increased with changes to federal campaign finance laws over the past decade.

headline: Rand Paul Files Lawsuit Over N.S.A. Call Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The legal action by the Kentucky senator is one of several challenges to the National Security Agency’s collection of phone records.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, on Wednesday filed a lawsuit against President Obama and the leaders of several intelligence agencies. The suit challenges as unconstitutional the National Security Agency’s once-secret program that is collecting bulk records about Americans’ phone calls.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Algeria and Elsewhere

lead_paragraph: Photos from Algeria, Syria, New York and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

abstract: On Wednesday, the federal agency charged with recommending cybersecurity standards introduced new, voluntary security guidelines for companies that oversee the nation’s critical infrastructure.

headline: How to Survive the Next Wave of Technology Extinction
abstract: So you bought a Betamax VCR? And also a Nook? Here’s a strategy to avoid betting on the wrong horse again.
lead_paragraph: Don’t mock the beleaguered Nook owner. That could have been you.

headline: While Earth May Tremble, This Pianist Is Unlikely To
abstract: A new work was on the program that the pianist Steven Lin presented at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday as part of the Concert Artists Guild series.
lead_paragraph: The ability to focus and perform well in myriad, and sometimes subpar, circumstances is a requisite skill for any successful musician. The Taiwanese-American pianist Steven Lin recently proved his unshakable mettle when he continued to play through an earthquake that struck during his performance in a competition in Sendai, Japan.

headline: Cate Blanchett’s True ‘Jasmine’
abstract: In “Blue Jasmine,” Cate Blanchett plays a wealthy socialite who has to start over again. The character is both palatable and unpalatable, Ms. Blanchett says, but the result is a richer role.
lead_paragraph: In “Blue Jasmine,” Cate Blanchett plays a wealthy socialite who has to start over again. The character is both palatable and unpalatable, Ms. Blanchett says, but the result is a richer role.

headline: Amid the Debris of Homs, a Guerrilla Is Born
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Movies']
abstract: Two filmmakers in a besieged Syrian city charted the transformation of a Syrian soccer player from peaceful protester to fighter.
lead_paragraph: Among the dwindling holdouts in the rebel-held Old City neighborhood of Homs, an area of the devastated Syrian city that international relief officials are trying to evacuate, is the former star goalkeeper of the national soccer team, transformed over three years from a pacifist antigovernment protest leader into a homegrown guerrilla fighter.

headline: Challengers Take On the Big Three in Gaming’s Arena
abstract: Game players’ options now include tablets, game-streaming services and controllers that work with televisions.
lead_paragraph: Here is a question with a surprisingly complex answer: What is the best option for playing video games these days?

headline: Sochi Video Notebook: Women's Halfpipe
abstract: Kaitlyn Farrington, Torah Bright and Kelly Clark, who won medals in the women’s halfpipe finals, spoke to the media after the event.
lead_paragraph: Kaitlyn Farrington, Torah Bright and Kelly Clark, who won medals in the women’s halfpipe finals, spoke to the media after the event.

headline: Young Talents Working With Those Comedians Stravinsky and Berlioz
abstract: Members of the Metropolitan Opera’s young artist program joined with the Juilliard Orchestra, led by James Levine, to present “A Concert of Comic Operas.”
lead_paragraph: James Levine was just 37 when, in 1980, he inaugurated what is now called the Metropolitan Opera’s Lindemann Young Artist Development Program. His desire to foster young talent has now taken him across the Lincoln Center plaza to the Juilliard School. On Tuesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, he conducted the opening performance of a program of comic scenes from works by Mozart, Berlioz and Donizetti along with “Mavra,” Stravinsky’s rarely heard one-act. This ambitious program, lasting three hours, was the fourth co-production between the Met’s young artist program and Juilliard Opera since the two institutions began a partnership in 2010.

headline: Drew Nieporent to Open Bâtard in Corton’s Former Space
abstract: “I have a long history with this space, going back 29 years,” the restaurateur said. “And there is a lot of good will here, so I wasn’t ready to give it up.”
lead_paragraph: The restaurateur Drew Nieporent has settled on the new venture he plans to install in the TriiBeCa space that once housed Montrachet: Bâtard, a name that references the Montrachet wines of Burgundy.

headline: Lebanese Bloggers Defend Olympian Criticized for Racy Photo Shoot
abstract: Lebanese bloggers rallied to defend the honor of a female Olympic skier accused of tarnishing the nation’s image by posing for seminude photographs.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Thursday, 11:44 a.m. | Lebanon’s fractured sense of national identity was on full display this week, as bloggers rallied online to defend the honor of a female Olympian, the skier Jackie Chamoun, accused by the country’s sports minister of tarnishing the nation’s image by posing for seminude photographs on the slopes outside Beirut.

headline: The Incomprehensible Sometimes Has Its Charms
abstract: An evening of baffling and occasionally entrancing dances by Dylan Crossman, Tara O’Con and Stacy Grossfield at Roulette.
lead_paragraph: The performing arts space of Roulette in Brooklyn appears only sporadically on the dance calendar. This week, however, its DanceRoulette season presents a different anthology of new pieces each evening.

headline: I Remember van Druten
abstract: John van Druten, a mid-20th-century playwright of romantic comedies, is enjoying a burst of interest on Off Broadway stages.
lead_paragraph: In 1953, a writer leveled harsh criticism at John van Druten’s romantic comedy “London Wall,” calling its story “almost shamelessly inadequate” and arguing that the play would never work for American audiences. His name: John van Druten.

headline: ‘Sweeney Todd’ (Progressive Rock Remix)
abstract: A theater company in Washington D.C. plans to present a rescored version of Stephen Sondheim’s musical.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:36 p.m. | When the demon barber of Fleet Street is next seen in the nation’s capital, he may be wielding an ax — six-string variety — rather than a razor. The Landless Theater Company of Washington has announced that it will stage “Sweeney Todd — Prog Metal Version” at the Undercroft Theater, in Washington, in August. And the project has Stephen Sondheim’s blessing, or at least his permission.

headline: Second Act | Screen Siren
abstract: Agnès Troublé is best known as the creator of the Agnès B. fashion brand, but she reveals that her true passion has always been edgy, experimental cinema.
lead_paragraph: Agnès Troublé is best known as the creator of the Agnès B. fashion brand, but with her directorial film debut this spring, the 72-year-old designer reveals that her true passion has always been edgy, experimental cinema.

headline: Long Island Bar in Brooklyn
abstract: The Long Island Bar, a fixture of Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn for more than 50 years until it closed in 2007, has reopened.
lead_paragraph: After sitting empty for nearly seven years, a Brooklyn bar and its beloved neon sign have been brought back to life. In October, Joel Tompkins and the mixologist Toby Cecchini (who ran Passerby in Chelsea during the 1990s and is an occasional contributor to The New York Times) reopened the Long Island Bar, a fixture of Atlantic Avenue for more than 50 years until it closed in 2007 when the owner moved to Spain.

headline: Bird Thou Never Wert
abstract: A biography of Marianne Moore by Linda Leavell concentrates on the poet’s little-known early life.
lead_paragraph: Half a century or so ago, when literate Americans still read poetry or thought they should, everyone knew about Marianne Moore, the white-haired, great-auntish New York writer who loved polysyllables, exotic animals and the Brooklyn Dodgers, and turned up around town in a signature Paul Revere hat.

headline: Levine to Tackle Six Operas for the Met
abstract: Next season will see the recovering James Levine double his conducting workload for the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: James Levine, who is continuing to recover from the spine injury that sidelined him for two years, plans to conduct six productions at the Metropolitan Opera next season, including a new production of Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro” on opening night and Wagner’s majestic “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg,” which is not exactly known for its brevity.

headline: He’s a Real Rebel: He’ll Tell You Himself
abstract: “The Outsiders,” a new album by the country singer Eric Church, describes this singer and songwriter as an unruly soul.
lead_paragraph: In Nashville, most houses are made of glass, and most people love living in them. Merely pointing that out can qualify you as a rebel.

headline: Sacrificing His Fries for a Starring Role
abstract: The British actor Samuel Barnett is starring in “Richard III” and “Twelfth Night,” Shakespearean plays in which men play female roles.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Barnett ordered a salad. It wasn’t exactly what he wanted at Cafe Luxembourg, especially with its noted French fries on the menu, but as he noted wryly, “I have to get into a corset.”

headline: Peeling Back Time at Marc by Marc Jacobs
abstract: The line’s new designers, Katie Hillier and Luella Bartley, looked to past designs as inspiration for their debut collection.
lead_paragraph: SITTING FRONT ROW at a fashion show on Tuesday afternoon was the designer Marc Jacobs, clad in Adidas track pants and surrounded by famous and powerful friends: Sofia Coppola, Alexa Chung, the LVMH executive Delphine Arnault.

headline: London Director to Draft Arts Vision for Ground Zero
abstract: David Lan, the artistic director of the Young Vic Theater in London, will draft a programming vision for the performing arts center planned at ground zero.
lead_paragraph: Executives developing a performing arts center at ground zero have hired a temporary artistic director from the Young Vic theater in London, one of a series of steps to be announced Thursday to advance a project that has long faced political and logistical hurdles.

headline: A Night for Art on the Floor and Onstage
abstract: For its second Arts Night, New York City Ballet presented works by Angelin Preljocaj, Christopher Wheeldon and Peter Martins.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet presented the second of its Arts Nights series last Friday, and in honor of the occasion the principal dancer Adrian Danchig-Waring spoke a few words. His talk had nothing to do with the repertory, even though that surely would have been helpful to the youngish crowd, drawn to the David H. Koch Theater for a peek at the current promenade installation by the artist JR.

headline: Conflict in Oil Industry, Awash in Crude
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Economy', 'Refineries']
abstract: The debate between oil producers and refiners over exports is a rare clash in a deeply guarded industry that involves arguments over national security, pricing at the pump and earnings.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — T. Boone Pickens has personified the nation’s oil industry for more than a generation. So when he made an offhand comment at a conference here a few weeks ago expressing reservations about lifting the nation’s ban on exports of crude oil, he startled some of his old allies in the business.

headline: Taking the Plunge at the Awards
abstract: Classic cleavage has been eclipsed by a new, more naturalistic ideal.
lead_paragraph: Out with the Wonderbra, in with the ... sag? (And we don’t mean the Screen Actors Guild.) Dresses with revealing necklines have been stealing the spotlight this awards season, signaling, perhaps, a new era in red-carpet décolletage.

headline: Blowing This Way and That
abstract: The Italian period-instrument ensemble Europa Galante mixed and matched movements at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: Few violin concertos are as tightly scripted as those making up Vivaldi’s “Four Seasons.” Four sonnets chronicling the agricultural calendar — possibly by Vivaldi himself — accompany the music. Their lines are written into the score like stage directions, instructing the player to evoke the sounds of buzzing gnats on a hot summer day, hunting calls in autumn or the motion of someone walking gingerly on ice. Additional labels identify particular kinds of birds — a finch, a cuckoo, a turtledove — and barking dogs.

headline: Unskewing Obamacare
abstract: I want my disaster!
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been tracking the news on signups under the Affordable Care Act – which is easy thanks to Charles Gaba’s invaluable site – you already knew that the program was making a pretty good recovery from the botched start. Now, however, it’s official: as of the end of January signups were only about a million behind their projected track as of last spring, which means that as of March 31 the total is likely to be 6-point-something million rather than the projected 7 million. In other words, basically OK.

headline: Tranquil Islands in Passionate Seas
abstract: The pianist Garrick Ohlsson played a challenging program of Beethoven, Schubert, Chopin and the American composer Charles Tomlinson Griffes at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: In both Beethoven’s Sonata No. 30 (Op. 109) and Schubert’s “Wanderer” Fantasy, quiet moments of resignation and introspection emerge suddenly from tempestuous thickets. In his admirable recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, the pianist Garrick Ohlsson rendered these elements with striking contrast.

headline: Record-Breaking Play at Bridge Base Online
abstract: The Internet has hurt attendance at bridge clubs, but it has been highly beneficial for pairs who live far apart.
lead_paragraph: The Internet has hurt attendance at bridge clubs, but it has been highly beneficial for pairs who live far apart. They can practice regularly online.

headline: The Problem With Mammograms
abstract: Peggy Orenstein’s reporting in the magazine last year led her to the conclusion that when it comes to mammograms, there is such a thing as too much screening.
lead_paragraph: The front-page news today that mammograms don’t decrease the death rates from breast cancer — but do increase the likelihood of unnecessary treatment — reminded me that it’s worth going back to Peggy Orenstein’s cover story from last April. Even before the results of the newly published study, involving 90,000 women, were released, Orenstein’s reporting led her to the same conclusion: There is such a thing as too much screening. And she made a powerful argument that the Komen Foundation’s pink-ribbon “awareness” campaign is a big part of the problem. She also wrote insightfully about how difficult it is not to have a mammogram even if the science tells us that isn’t helpful.

headline: Desperate Times Call for Her
abstract: Cate Blanchett found inspiration in Shakespeare for her part as Jasmine French, a New York socialite whose husband’s misdeeds shatter their lives.
lead_paragraph: Cate Blanchett has played Blanche DuBois, the Queen of England (twice), Katharine Hepburn and all manner of elegant yet troubled heroines. But to portray Jasmine French, the socialite on a swift and bumpy fall from rank, and grace, in “Blue Jasmine,” she looked to Richard II for inspiration.

headline: Costas’s ‘Pinkeye’ Keeps Him Away Another Day at the Olympics
abstract: The longtime NBC host of the Olympics tended to his sore eyes on Wednesday, while the “Today” co-host Matt Lauer again served double duty.
lead_paragraph: The viral infection in Bob Costas’s eyes did not clear up enough for him return on Wednesday to host the Winter Olympic broadcasts from Sochi, Russia, keeping Matt Lauer in the anchor seat while he co-hosts the “Today” show.

headline: Wheelies: The Half-Baked Jeep Edition
abstract: Consumer Reports is unimpressed with the all-new 2014 Jeep Cherokee; Japanese workers request higher pay as profits soar for automakers.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

abstract: Sotheby’s and Christie’s reported strong demand for works by Gerhard Richter, Cy Twombly and some young artists.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last week Sotheby’s and Christie’s proved that Impressionist and modern art hasn’t lost its luster, with a still life by Juan Gris fetching $56.7 million and a dreamy cityscape by Pissarro bringing $32 million.

headline: The Deficit on the Milk Carton
abstract: Suddenly, the scolds have vanished.
lead_paragraph: Has anyone noticed what we’re not talking about? I mean, really not at all? The budget deficit. After all those years when deficit scolds completely dominated the conversation, when Fix the Committee for a Responsible Debt Coalition were, if you listened to the press, the source of all that was good and noble and BowlesSimpsonish, quite suddenly the whole thing has dropped off the agenda.

headline: Blackstone’s Burger and Beer Night for Charity
abstract: Blackstone officials, including top executives like Hamilton E. James and Jonathan D. Gray, went behind the bar at a Midtown Manhattan burger joint Tuesday night to raise money for the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society.
lead_paragraph: High-flying financiers from the Blackstone Group would normally frequent power lunch spaces like the Four Seasons restaurant in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Beyond the Runway
abstract: From the guest blogger Joe Jonas, to the star turnout at Public School, to the streaker at Prabal Gurung, to the after-parties, much of the action took place away from the shows.
lead_paragraph: Although New York Fashion Week officially begins on a Thursday (and, unofficially, days earlier than that), Saturday is the day when the full force of the event begins to take its toll.

headline: Court Challenge on Bond Buying Poses Test for Central Bank, and for E.U.
abstract: A German decision to contest the pledge by Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, to buy bonds if necessary has raised more questions than it has answered.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Courts are normally supposed to resolve disputes. But a decision last week by the Federal Constitutional Court in Germany has raised more questions than it has answered about the legality of a financial weapon that many analysts say saved the euro in its darkest hour — without even firing a shot.

abstract: A look at what’s replacing the old incandescent and compact fluorescent bulbs.
lead_paragraph: A look at what’s replacing the old incandescent and compact fluorescent bulbs.

abstract: The figure skater Brown and his team spent countless hours creating and perfecting a program that landed him an Olympic berth.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Many of the fans in TD Garden were on their feet before Jason Brown finished his free program at the United States figure skating championships last month in Boston.

abstract: A sinkhole estimated to be 40 feet across and about 30 feet deep opened up beneath a museum building, causing part of its floor to collapse.
lead_paragraph: A huge sinkhole opened up early Wednesday at the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., swallowing eight rare and notable versions of the Chevrolet sports car.

headline: Warnings of Ethnic Cleansing in Central African Republic
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Tens of thousands of Muslims are being forced by Christian militias to flee the country in a violent exodus that has left neighborhoods in the capital empty.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Tens of thousands of Muslims are being forced by Christian militias to flee the Central African Republic in what human rights groups and a top United Nations official characterized on Wednesday as de facto ethnic cleansing.

headline: The Only Witches’ Brew Here Is the Beer
abstract: Witches of Bushwick is a social and creative group more in tune with Stevie Nicks than Elvira.
lead_paragraph: On a frigid evening in early January, 20-something hipster women of a boyish sartorial bent filled the Tandem Bar in outer Bushwick, Brooklyn, tall Narragansett beer cans in tow, sporting lots of arm-sleeve tattoos, knit stocking caps and their fair share of Theda Bara-esque kohl-rimmed eyes and blood-red lips. Several of them wore black football jerseys whose backs read “WITCHES 13.” (The number required for a coven.)

headline: Mayday Calls at the Navy Yard
abstract: Twitter lights up with gridlock anguish to and from the Alexander Wang show at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
lead_paragraph: The howls of anguish could be heard all the way to Manhattan. On Saturday night, as the fashion flock headed out in their town cars to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the unlikely and inconvenient space that Alexander Wang, above, had chosen to show his fall 2014 collection, New York Fashion Week entered its gridlock phase. Streets were packed, drivers got lost, anxiety mounted about missing the start time and Uber bills skyrocketed. If misery loves company, then Twitter was the place to be that night.

lead_paragraph: ELMENDORF AIR FORCE BASE, Alaska — Secretary of State John Kerry headed to Asia on Wednesday to seek China’s help to try to pressure North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program.

headline: A Little of This or a Lot of That
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Experts who applied minimal and maximal makeup during this Fashion Week explain how to try the same thing at home.
lead_paragraph: Runway beauty looks, usually concocted with some alien She-Ra in mind, are hard to translate into “trends” relatable to the average Jane. But this Fashion Week, a clear divide appeared between minimalist and maximalist makeup. Herein, experts who applied it explain how to attempt the same thing at home (if you dare).

headline: Even a Stationery Logo Pits Palestinians Against Israel
abstract: Israel has rejected the applications of Palestinian patients seeking treatment in Israel or the West Bank because they bear the logo “State of Palestine” rather than “Palestinian Authority.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The latest skirmish between Israel and the Palestinian Authority does not concern settlements or refugees, but stationery.

headline: At Reed Krakoff, Vivid Blue Sandals With a Plush Touch
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: cobalt sandals with a dynamic interplay of textures and materials.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Night Stands: Snooze but Don’t Lose
abstract: You go to bed next to them and wake up beside them. Sounds like a serious relationship.
lead_paragraph: At nearly three feet wide, the Ico Parisi cabinets at Bernd Goeckler’s antiques store in the East Village were much too big to be night stands. That was this reporter’s opinion, anyway. Barry Goralnick, an architect who has designed lighting for Visual Comfort, carpets for Starck and furnishings for Ferrell & Mittman, disagreed.

headline: A Marriage of Convenience
abstract: New nesting containers from Joseph Joseph take efficiency to a new level.
lead_paragraph: In 1999, Antony and Richard Joseph, twin industrial designers, were asked to update a part of their family’s 63-year-old British housewares business. Four years later, they created their own company, Joseph Joseph, which produces smartly functional items for the home like colorful stacking mixing bowls with integrated measuring cups. Their Nest containers, shown at the New York Now design show last week, tackle the problem of storage boxes that hog precious space when not in use. Whereas lids and bases often need to be stored separately, turning matchups into a problem, this design efficiently packs together bases and lids for up to six sizes of containers; color-coding makes the pairings foolproof. The containers are airtight and microwave-, freezer- and dishwasher-safe. A 12-piece set (6 containers, 6 lids) is $35, and an 8-piece set (4 containers, 4 lids) is $25. Information: 917-338-0900, or josephjoseph.com.

headline: Nature Woven in Silk
abstract: Lavish brocade fabrics designed by Rocio Moreno of Spain.
lead_paragraph: Rocio Moreno, a Spanish interior and product designer, works with artisans in northern India who hand-weave silk brocades in brilliant colors. Her newest collection includes Orissa, a wall hanging that depicts a stylized tree and takes the former name of a state in India. Orissa ($1,795), seen in magenta on green, is 29.5 inches wide by 79 inches long and available by special order from Barneys. To complement the garden theme, Ms. Moreno pored through a collection of natural history books for images of insects, which inspired two cushions, Mantis and Moth. Mantis ($365) is 24 inches square, and Moth ($350) is 20 by 24 inches. Both will be available in turquoise or orange at Barneys in late March. All three designs can be ordered in advance. Information: 212-450-8454 or rociomorenotextiles.com.

headline: Child-Proof Minimalism
abstract: A couple chooses a one-room suburban life with two young children. And their toys.
lead_paragraph: A couple chooses a one-room suburban life with two young children. And their toys.

headline: The Anti-McMansion
abstract: A couple chooses a one-room suburban life with two young children. And their toys.
lead_paragraph: Living in a one-room house with an ultra-minimalist aesthetic and two small children sounds more like the setup for a joke than something any reasonably sane person would attempt.

abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: The New Domestics
abstract: Forget the butler and the ladies’ maid. Those who serve today’s super-rich are more likely to have titles like videographer, curator and horticulturist.
lead_paragraph: Dylan Leonard Brown is all of 30, with a master’s in psychology and an expansive résumé that includes three years working as an estate manager for a former ambassador and overseeing a household staff of 12, along with three properties, one yacht, numerous automobiles and a multimillion dollar annual budget. Mr. Brown also planned around 100 events every year, including a three-day colloquium on human trafficking and an orchestral concert. (The ambassador was an amateur composer, so Mr. Brown hired an orchestra and choir, auditioned soloists and hired street canvassers to hand out fliers at the Gay Pride Parade in Boston to drum up interest.)

headline: Table Manners at Work
abstract: Clive Wilkinson has designed some pretty crazy offices. His newest one has a single desk with room for everyone on staff.
lead_paragraph: Clive Wilkinson, a 59-year-old architect, has designed attention-getting offices for TBWA\Chiat\Day and Google, and now he has done one for the Barbarian Group, an Internet advertising company in New York. Its centerpiece is the “endless table,” a 1,100-foot-long surface that snakes around the 23,000-square-foot office, providing work space for all 125 employees, including the chairman, Benjamin Palmer. The $300,000 table, which was installed last month, forms seven archways leading to conference rooms, a video screening room and restrooms. “In our last office, there were separate offices, and people had to hunt people down,” Mr. Palmer said, adding that now he is “seeing more people than I have in years.”

headline: 2 U.S.-Led Coalition Soldiers Are Killed by Attackers in Afghan Uniforms
abstract: The deadly episode was the first reported instance in 2014 of what are called green-on-blue attacks, in which uniformed Afghans turn on their Western allies.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two people wearing Afghan security forces uniforms opened fire on American-led coalition soldiers in eastern Afghanistan on Wednesday, killing two of the soldiers, officials said.

headline: Hot 97’s Owner in Deal for 2 Other Stations
abstract: The $131 million sale of WBLS-FM and WLIB will align some of New York’s most popular stations specializing in black music.
lead_paragraph: In a deal that will align some of New York’s most popular radio stations specializing in black music, the owner of WQHT-FM — the hip-hop station better known as Hot 97 — is buying WBLS-FM and one other station for $131 million in cash.

headline: Modernism’s Giant Showcase
abstract: The Palm Springs Modernism Show and Sale starts Friday.
lead_paragraph: The dealers who attend the Palm Springs Modernism Show and Sale must luxuriate in their home-field advantage: With its copious midcentury architecture, the city is one big ad for their wares. This year’s show, which is timed to Modernism Week and begins Friday, is the largest in its 14 years. More than 85 exhibitors will be selling furniture, jewelry, pottery, textiles and other items representative of 20th-century design, like a welded steel sculpture by Paul Kasper ($14,000, from Fat ChanceLos Angeles) and a signed lithograph by Alexander Calder ($3,150, from Palette Contemporary Art & Craft).

headline: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Ballard Designs and Others
abstract: Bargains on kitchen items, furniture and more.
lead_paragraph: A blanket and a pillow are on sale at Brookstone, while supplies last (the Nap throw blanket, regularly about $40, is about $15; the FOM fun pillow, regularly about $20, is about $15); 30 Rockefeller Plaza (Fifth Avenue), concourse level, 212-489-3234, brookstone.com.

headline: Furniture with a Magic Touch
abstract: Limited-edition pieces by Konstantin Grcic are on view in Paris.
lead_paragraph: “Man Machine,” which opens Thursday at Galerie Kreo in Paris, features nine limited-edition furniture pieces by Konstantin Grcic made of window plate glass. “Glass is seen as fragile, and sometimes it’s scary,” said Mr. Grcic. To make it dynamic as well, he has worked gas pistons into the designs: The reclining chair adjusts as a car seat would; the dining table glides up to standing height, and the crate can be opened with a pinkie.

headline: Facing Questions on Future, Cisco Posts a Revenue Drop
abstract: The company is struggling with sluggish emerging markets like China.
lead_paragraph: Changes in the technology business are hurting Cisco Systems, and so far its chief executive, John Chambers, hasn’t shown Wall Street many numbers that say his recovery strategy is working.

headline: Prices Skyrocket for Tickets to See Jeter’s Last Games
abstract: Upon hearing that 2014 would be Derek Jeter’s last season, many fans rushed to their computers to scoop up tickets to games in late September.
lead_paragraph: When Derek Jeter announced on Facebook on Wednesday that the 2014 season would be his last, fans fled to social media to express their reactions. More enterprising enthusiasts, though, rushed immediately to their computers for a different purpose — to scoop up tickets to games in late September at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Taking the Bite Out of Winter With a Crisp White Shirt
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Traditional tailoring, intricately designed leather accessories and more.
lead_paragraph: If you are eager to take the leap into spring (and who isn’t at this point?), a crisp and tailored cotton shirt is the easiest way to get a jump on the season. When indulging in trends, it’s always a plus to go with the classics, and the shirts now in the shops are easygoing tweaks on traditional tailoring. Among them, some shown in this sampling, are shirts covered in fringe (Junya Watanabe), cut with capelike backs (Margiela, Balenciaga) and accented with romantic needlework and lace (Carven, Chloé, Christopher Kane). While we are still in throes of winter, wear with wool pinstripe trousers and an oversize mannish coat; or, as Diane Kruger did at Sundance last month (above right), with a knee-length skirt and printed parka. When the days warm up, try with a sexy slit skirt — very Altuzarra.

abstract: New York’s Fashion Week for men shows modern men’s wear’s tug-of-war between upholding a set of traditions and embracing a set of disruptions.
lead_paragraph: Look, sometimes a cape is just a cape. When the first model hit the runway at the Public School show, he wore a wide-brimmed hat and a wool cape, beautifully cut, that suggested papal vestments and Amish rigor. Paired with a washed-out plaid shirt, it was structure and swagger in one.

abstract: It’s bad for the climate, and American taxpayers are being shortchanged.
lead_paragraph: EASTSOUND, Wash. — FROM where I live on Orcas Island in Puget Sound, north of Seattle, I can see Cherry Point across the wind-whipped waters of the Salish Sea. This sandy promontory jutting into Georgia Strait has become the focus of heated debate here in the Pacific Northwest.

headline: Italian Premier’s Latest Challenge Comes From His Own Party
abstract: Prime Minister Enrico Letta is again fighting to save his government, but this time, the pressure is coming from the leader of his Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Like a piñata that has been battered but remains unbroken, Enrico Letta has demonstrated an unexpected resilience as Italy’s prime minister. He took office in April amid predictions that his coalition government would quickly collapse. It did not. Then Silvio Berlusconi, the powerful former prime minister, vowed to bring him down. That did not happen, either.

headline: An Unexpected End to the Oscar de la Renta Show
abstract: André Leon Talley and several other magazine editors were stuck in an elevator last night while departing Oscar de la Renta’s show.
lead_paragraph: Urban nightmare, meet fashion emergency.

headline: Making College Pay
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Unemployment', 'Editorials']
abstract: Employment prospects for college-educated workers have eroded, so a degree doesn’t necessarily mean a good-paying job anymore.
lead_paragraph: It seems logical: College graduates have lower unemployment and earn more than less educated workers, so, the thinking goes, the fix for today’s anemic growth in jobs and wages is to make sure that more people earn college degrees. But that’s a common misperception, deflecting attention from the serious work that has to be done to create jobs and improve incomes.

headline: Laying the Lox on Thick, a Dating Site Focuses on Jewish Humor
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Dating and Courtship', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The campaign by the Jewish dating website, JDate, employs many Jewish cultural references, appealing to some but possibly leaving others bewildered.
lead_paragraph: AMONG married Jews, the intermarriage rate of those wed since 2000 is 58 percent, well above the rate of those wed before 1970, when just 17 percent tied the knot with non-Jews, according to a 2013 survey by the Pew Research Center’s Religion & Public Life Project. Now the Jewish dating website JDate is introducing an advertising campaign that hopes to help buck the trend, with ads that may strike a chord with Jews but leave others scratching their heads.

lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — If anyone has a right to resent the Sochi Olympics, it is Andrei Martynov, whose house was seized by the Russian authorities and then demolished without compensation to clear land near the hockey arena where Russia will play Slovenia on Thursday.

headline: Trade Dispute Centers on Ukrainian Executive With Ties to Clintons
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Steel and Iron']
abstract: The oligarch Victor Pinchuk illustrates the complications that come with Hillary Rodham Clinton’s network of deep-pocketed supporters.
lead_paragraph: Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have built a sprawling network of powerful friends around the globe, one that could aid Mrs. Clinton’s chances were she to seek the presidency. But those relationships often come with intersecting interests and political complications; few people illustrate that more vividly than the Ukrainian oligarch Victor Pinchuk.

headline: The Number Cisco Left Out
abstract: Cisco just reported a tough quarter, the latest sign of an incumbent struggling to adapt to a world of cloud computing, mobility, sensors, and lots of cheap competition. In an interview, John Chambers, Cisco’s chief executive, pointed to a number Wall Street didn’t hear that gave him confidence about his strategy.
lead_paragraph: Changes in the technology business are hurting Cisco Systems, and so far its chief executive, John Chambers, hasn’t shown Wall Street many numbers that say his recovery strategy is working.

headline: Jared Leto at Jeremy Scott
abstract: A nearly late Jared Leto showed up at Jeremy Scott’s show and shouted to the crowd: “My apologies! You all look fabulous.”
lead_paragraph: For those who enjoy a good fashion spectacle, the showman Jeremy Scott lived up to expectations. On the runway, male and female models wore football-inspired pieces as if from a Super Bowl gone mad, while the front row was a lurid scene, including the ubiquitous Joe Jonas, in his usual black jacket; Kat Graham, in a red snakeskin harness crop top and matching bondage-style skirt (“I’ve been wearing Jeremy’s crop tops since I was 16,” she said); and a nearly late Jared Leto, who shouted to the crowd: “My apologies! You all look fabulous.” It turns out Mr. Leto, who had dressed for the gelid weather in a roomy parka and a flannel around his waist, was only in the city briefly.

headline: U.N. Report Says Progress for Women Is Unequal
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Illiteracy', 'Sex Crimes', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Education', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)']
abstract: Strides in reproductive health, pay and literacy are noted, but the world’s poorest countries have not kept up, the report finds.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Twenty years after a landmark United Nations summit meeting in Cairo called on countries around the world to allow women greater control over their health and destiny, women worldwide have fewer children, are less likely to die of childbirth and have made great strides in literacy, according to a major report released Wednesday by the world body.

headline: For de Blasio, No Magic Lost in Budget Draft

lead_paragraph: Our new mayor can sound much taken with himself. He talks so insistently of progressive values, policies and appointees that I’m convinced someday soon he will unveil his progressive gone-to-lunch stroll. (Long-loping, left-leaning strides?)

lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — As Michael Dunn, the man accused of shooting a teenager to death during a dispute over loud music, sat stone-faced, a prosecutor hammered away on Wednesday at his self-defense claim, arguing that the teenager never pointed a weapon at Mr. Dunn.

headline: Why ‘Team G.B.’ Needs Scotland
abstract: Before the Scots vote on whether to become an independent nation, they should weigh all the pros and cons of leaving the United Kingdom.
lead_paragraph: Much of the debate over Scottish independence has focused on whether the Scots would be better off in or out of the United Kingdom. With the Sept. 18 Scottish referendum now only seven months off, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain has raised another critical question: Would Britain be better off without Scotland?

headline: Jeter’s Retirement Announcement Hits the Right Note

headline: Mr. de Blasio’s Welcoming Gesture
abstract: Offering an identification card to all New York City residents, regardless of legal status, is a brilliant idea.
lead_paragraph: Creating a citywide identification card for people who can’t get driver’s licenses — unauthorized immigrants, mostly — sounds like a modest, well-meaning, good-government initiative that is part practical, part symbolic. Cities like New Haven and San Francisco have already done it. Bringing such an innovation to New York City, as Mayor Bill de Blasio proposed on Monday, would be a big deal.

headline: We Need Proof on Marijuana
abstract: Where are the studies showing that it can treat epilepsy?
lead_paragraph: MANY people have heard the story of Charlotte Figi, a young girl from Colorado with severe epilepsy. After her parents began giving her a marijuana strain rich in cannabidiol (CBD), the major nonpsychoactive ingredient in marijuana, Charlotte reportedly went from having hundreds of seizures per week to only two or three per month. Previously, her illness, Dravet Syndrome, was a daily torture despite multiple high doses of powerful anti-seizure drugs.

headline: Ending ‘Gay Conversion’ for Good
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Law and Legislation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'States (US)']
abstract: Litigation and regulation are better than legislative bans.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — THERAPY programs that purport to “convert” lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender kids have caused immeasurable harm since they became prominent in the 1970s. Rigorous studies have shown again and again that efforts to change young people’s sexual orientation not only fail, but are also linked to suicidal behavior, depression, anxiety, drug use and risky sexual behavior.

headline: High-Level Talks Between Koreas End Without an Agreement
abstract: North and South Korea ended talks without an agreement Wednesday, casting doubt on prospects for reunions of families separated during the Korean War.
lead_paragraph: An unusual high-level dialogue between North and South Korea ended without an agreement on Wednesday, casting doubt on prospects for reunions of families separated in the Korean War that the two Koreas have planned to hold later this month. The meeting of senior officials, the highest-level government talks between the countries in seven years, was held at Panmunjom on their mutual border at the suggestion of the North, which has recently called for improved relations. The meeting stalled because of sharp differences over the terms of improving relations. North Korean delegates left Panmunjom without even exchanging handshakes with their southern counterparts, officials in Seoul said.

headline: Venezuela: At Least Two People Are Killed in Protests
abstract: The people were killed in unrest in Caracas on Wednesday, officials said, as thousands took to the streets of the capital in the largest antigovernment protest in months.
lead_paragraph: At least two people were killed in unrest in Caracas on Wednesday, officials said, as thousands of people took to the streets of the capital in the largest antigovernment protest in months. The violence erupted after government opponents attended a peaceful march and rally called to protest the arrest of student demonstrators elsewhere in the country. Following the march, several hundred young protesters threw rocks at riot police officers and broke windows in a government building. One demonstrator was shot in the head and killed, and protesters blamed armed pro-government supporters. Later, President Nicolás Maduro said a community activist he had known for years had also been killed. Diosdado Cabello, the president of the National Assembly, said the man was killed by “fascists,” a term the government uses for its opponents. Mr. Maduro later said on television, “I alert the world: we are facing a planned coup d’état.” The protests in various cities in recent weeks have sprung from widespread discontent amid increasing economic problems, including high inflation.
