headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 2 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE DIVING BELL AND THE BUTTERFLY (2007) Jean-Dominique Bauby, a 43-year-old French magazine editor and something of a playboy, had a stroke in 1995 that left him with a condition in which he retained vision, hearing and a functioning mind but was almost completely paralyzed. He told his story in a book that he dictated to an assistant by blinking. In this film from the artist Julian Schnabel, Bauby is played by Mathieu Amalric; Emmanuelle Seigner is Céline, the longtime partner he has recently left and the mother of his three children; and Marie-Josée Croze is the speech therapist who teaches him to use his left eyelid to communicate. “The phrase ‘triumph of the human spirit’ hovers over ‘The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,’ along with a swarm of other empty, uplifting clichés,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But Mr. Schnabel and the screenwriter, Ronald Harwood, have other themes in mind” — among them, limitation, constraint and incarceration — Mr. Scott said. (Both men were nominated for Oscars.) “Their common subject, however, is freedom, the self-willed liberation of a difficult, defiant individual,” Mr. Scott wrote, adding that Mr. Schnabel demonstrated this with “imaginative freedom in every frame and sequence, dispensing with narrative and expository conventions in favor of a wild, intuitive honesty.”

headline: Earnings Improve at Lloyds Despite Steep Provisions
abstract: In 2013, Lloyds returned to a statutory profit before tax of £415 million, an important measure for the lender. The bank, which last posted a statutory profit in 2010, also raised its bonus pool by 8 percent.

headline: How to Build a Perfect Refugee Camp
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Kilis is one of the cleanest, most humane, most efficiently run refugee camps in history. And therein may lie the problem.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, the temporary shelter for Syrian civilians in Kilis, Turkey, doesn’t look like an inviting place to live. It looks like a prison. All around are olive groves, but here, Turkey suddenly runs out. A metal archway announces the customs gate to Syria. To its right stands what is more formally known as the Republic of Turkey Prime Ministry Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency’s Kilis Oncupinar Accommodation Facility. High gates bar entry, and barbed wire tops the walls. Police officers and private security mill about.

headline: In Restive Remote China, Uighurs’ Piety and Peace
abstract: A photographer ventured to Xinjiang Province, where tensions seethe between the Muslim Uighur minority and the majority Han Chinese, and made pictures only a quiet, unobtrusive observer could.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare to see mainstream news media reports on Xinjiang, China’s western borderland region, that do not invoke “turbulent,” “restive,” “unstable” or some variation. The area has long been the site of ethnic tensions between the majority Han Chinese and the Uighurs, China’s Turkic-speaking Muslim minority. But tight government controls on information and access make reporting on such clashes and protests, as well as everyday life, exceedingly difficult.

headline: Sass & Bide's Global Expansion

But now he’s facing some stiff competition from the Sith Lords of “Star Wars.” On Thursday, Netflix said that it had struck a deal with Lucasfilm and the Disney/ABC Television Group (as well as the Galactic Republic) to show the sixth and final season of the animated series “Star Wars: The Clone Wars” on its streaming video service.

abstract: Investments in new long-haul aircraft and other expenses linked to its expansion into Southeast Asia and the United States weighed on the results.

The declines were the result of heavy investments in new long-haul aircraft and other expenses linked to its rapid and controversial expansion into Southeast Asia and the United States.

headline: Comcast Scoops Up Time Warner Cable
abstract: Comcast announced on Thursday an agreement to acquire Time Warner Cable in an all-stock deal valued at about $45.2 billion. | A former S.E.C. enforcer is switching sides. | The American Bankers Association dropped its suit to block part of the Volcker Rule from going into effect. | The Senate raised the debt ceiling after a last bit of drama.
lead_paragraph: COMCAST SWOOPS IN TO ACQUIRE TIME WARNER CABLE  |  Time Warner Cable has been dodging a takeover for months, but it finally accepted another suitor with a sweeter offer. Comcast on Thursday announced an agreement to acquire Time Warner Cable in an all-stock deal valued at about $45.2 billion. The merger will unite the biggest and second-biggest cable television operators in the country, David Gelles writes in DealBook. Under the terms of the deal, Time Warner Cable shareholders will receive $158.82 a share based on Comcast’s closing price on Wednesday.

headline: Olympic Officials Scramble to Counter Warm Weather
abstract: Officials have had to shuffle schedules and deploy crews to spread snow stockpiled from last year as the springlike sun sends temperatures into the upper 50s and higher in some areas.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — With the Winter Olympics melting under a heat wave, the effects could be seen Thursday from the coast of Sochi, where spectators were spotted sunbathing, to the mountains high above the city, where cross-country skiers raced in sleeveless jerseys. The balmy weather has forced changes in competition schedules, sent workers scrambling to harden the slushy snow and made Olympians reconsider what to wear for their warm-weather winter sports.

The man was treated by medics on the track and taken by helicopter to a hospital. A spokesman for the International Olympic Committee said the man was conscious and had two broken legs.

headline: Phantom Melodies Yield Real Clues to Brain’s Workings

headline: Students Who Lose Recess Are the Ones Who Need It Most
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Physical Education and Training', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Taking away recess as a punishment for behavior problems or academic lapses won’t help, and might hurt.
lead_paragraph: Despite overwhelming evidence that periods of unstructured play and social interaction are a crucial part of children’s cognitive, academic, physical and mental wellness, schools continue to take away recess privileges as a penalty for academic or behavioral transgressions. I’ve done it, many times. When students fail to hand in assignments or when a child acts up in class, I’ve taken their recess privileges hostage. I did it both as a way of punishing for bad behavior or as a way to carve out a few extra minutes of learning time in an otherwise packed day.

headline: U.N. Security Council Urged to Act on Humanitarian Aid to Syria

abstract: The United Nations top official for emergency operations said the cease-fire in Homs — the only achievement from peace talks — cannot be considered “progress,” and aid workers should be able to do their work without getting shot.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The hard-won humanitarian cease-fire in the Syrian city of Homs — the sole success that occurred during the peace talks in Geneva — cannot be considered “progress,” the United Nations’ top official for emergency operations said Thursday evening as she urged the Security Council to ensure that aid reach those who need it and aid workers can do their work without getting shot.

headline: In Haiti, Beauty That Plays Hard to Get (To)
abstract: Spectacular waterfalls and a striking coastal town await those willing to endure punishing journeys to reach them.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to know exactly how many waterfalls there are on the side of the mountain in a remote corner of southeast Haiti. From my vantage point on a nearby slope, I counted at least a dozen, and that was at the end of the dry season last year. The rainy season in the spring, I’d been told, puts the cascade in Cascade Pichon.

lead_paragraph: When I teach medical students about alcoholism, it is never easy. Students arrive with preconceived notions and stereotypes obtained from books, television and films — and their personal upbringings — about the subject.

headline: Take a Punch, Hope for a Hit

Somewhere in the middle of it all, taking a minute before a group stretch-and-limber session, was the man whose character’s name was already on the marquee outside and whose left eye was still black and blue from a poorly timed encounter with another actor’s glove a week or two earlier.

headline: Among the Believers
abstract: Adam Gopnik’s unconvincing portrait of contemporary faith.
lead_paragraph: I expected to be pained by Adam Gopnik’s New Yorker essay on atheism and belief, but I didn’t expect to be quite so … puzzled by his depiction of contemporary belief. Gopnik clearly has sympathy for the religious side of the argument he’s describing — or at the very least he’s straining to be sympathetic. But given the premises he’s working from, that sympathy manifests itself in a peculiar and telling misreading of what theists actually believe.

headline: Donald Trump’s Magical Powers
abstract: The frequent pretend-candidate said Gov. Cuomo cut tolls to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge “because I mentioned it.”
lead_paragraph: In addition to his other reality-based issues — thinking any serious person wants him to be president, for example — Donald Trump has a cause-and-effect problem. He believes that when he mentions something in public, any related action that follows was his doing. Like when a small child closes his eyes and thinks he made the world disappear.

headline: U.S. Backs New Global Initiative Against Infectious Diseases
keywords: ['Epidemics', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: The federal government announced it would spend $40 million to help develop and improve systems to detect and respond to threats of infectious diseases, epidemics and bioterrorism.
lead_paragraph: The United States government said on Thursday it would spend $40 million to help low and middle-income countries develop and improve sophisticated systems to detect and respond to threats of infectious diseases, epidemics and bioterrorism. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said it was already working with Uganda and Vietnam, and that it would expand to include India, Kenya, Ethopia and Tanzania. The project’s goals include creating high-tech laboratories and trained teams that would respond rapidly to threats from diseases such as Avian flu, SARS, tuberculosis, and antibiotic-resistant illnesses. The C.D.C. aims to extend the program to 30 countries over five years to cover 4 billion people.

headline: Comcast and Time Warner Cable Forgo a Breakup Fee
abstract: Comcast’s $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable has a lot of numbers that stand out. Among them is the break-up fee if either side walks away. That figure is zero.
lead_paragraph: Comcast’s $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable has a lot of numbers that stand out. Among them is the breakup fee if either side walks away.

headline: The 2,000 Year Apartment
abstract: Oligarchs, high above the crowd.
lead_paragraph: Bloomberg reports on the soaring prices of trophy apartments in Manhattan. The biggest sale so far was former Citigroup head Sandy Weill’s apartment, which he sold for $88 milion to the daughter of a Russian oligarch. But $100 million listings are out there.

headline: Fortress Buys Back Stake From Nomura
abstract: The hedge fund paid Nomura $363.4 million for its 12 percent stake. The move comes as banks around the world begin to shed noncore assets in light of new banking regulations.
lead_paragraph: The Fortress Investment Group, the first publicly listed hedge fund in the United States, has bought back a stake from Nomura, one of its principal investors.

headline: Israeli Forces Kill Palestinian at Gaza Border
abstract: Israeli forces stationed along the border with Gaza fatally shot one Palestinian man and wounded another on Thursday, according to a Palestinian official.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Israeli forces stationed along the border with Gaza fatally shot one Palestinian man and wounded another on Thursday, according to a Palestinian official.

headline: S.E.C. Close to Naming New Senior Official
abstract: Mary Jo White has privately indicated plans to name Stephen Luparello, a former regulator turned corporate lawyer, as the head of the agency’s division of trading and markets.
lead_paragraph: After months of deliberation, Mary Jo White is finalizing her inner circle.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Reed Krakoff Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Julieta Cervantes.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Julieta Cervantes.

headline: Verizon Wireless Expands Mobile Data Plans
abstract: Verizon Wireless is sweetening its phone plans, offering more mobile data and free international text messaging, after AT&T made several big moves to fight off T-Mobile US and keep customers.
lead_paragraph: AT&T has made several big moves recently, including price cuts for its family plans, to fight off T-Mobile US and hold onto its customers. Now Verizon Wireless is sweetening its phone plans, too.

headline: Apprehensive, Many Doctors Shift to Jobs With Salaries
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals']
abstract: A growing number of primary care doctors and specialists in private practice are becoming employees of hospitals, though experts caution that the change may not yield better or cheaper care for patients.
lead_paragraph: American physicians, worried about changes in the health care market, are streaming into salaried jobs with hospitals. Though the shift from private practice has been most pronounced in primary care, specialists are following.

headline: 19th Is as Good as Gold for Oft-Injured Downhill Skier
abstract: Chemmy Alcott competed in the women’s downhill at the Winter Olympics about six months after being hospitalized with a broken leg.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — It is never easy being a ski racer from a snow-challenged country like England, something Chemmy Alcott has known all her life. The path grew more arduous when she broke her neck skiing at 12 and had two vertebrae surgically fused.

headline: Italy’s Prime Minister Announces Resignation Amid Party Revolt
abstract: Prime Minister Enrico Letta said he would resign after his Democratic Party staged a dramatic insurrection and set the stage to replace him with the party’s new leader, Matteo Renzi.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Prime Minister Enrico Letta, whose weak coalition government has come under increasing criticism, announced on Thursday that he would resign, after his own Democratic Party staged a dramatic insurrection and set the stage to replace him with the party’s new leader, Matteo Renzi.

headline: A Timelapse of Snow Covering Washington
abstract: The biggest snowstorm of the year hit Washington Wednesday night, closing federal offices on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The biggest snowstorm of the year hit Washington Wednesday night, closing federal offices on Thursday.

headline: Charles Mingus-Inspired Jazz at Manhattan School of Music
abstract: The Manhattan School of Music hosts the Charles Mingus High School Competition & Festival, as well as related panel discussions and performances.
lead_paragraph: The Miser once showed up for a shift at his college radio station as the previous D.J. was winding down his set in rollicking style with Charles Mingus’s “Better Git It in Your Soul.” Emerging from his reverie, the Miser’s colleague turned and exclaimed, “If I had heard this when I was 12, I never would have bothered with punk rock.”

headline: Hopes, and Homes, Crumbling on Indian Tea Plantations
abstract: At two Indian plantations, workers said their overseers treated them harshly and denied them basic benefits, despite promises of better working and living conditions.
lead_paragraph: NAHORANI TEA ESTATE, India — For a century and a half, Madhu Munda’s forebears toiled on the same tea plantation that she lives and works on now. Belonging to central Indian tribes brought to what is now the northeastern state of Assam by the British in the mid-19th century, they and millions of other plantation workers survived as little more than indentured servants, even as the British Raj gave way to Indian democracy.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 7
abstract: Lil’ Kim performed for The Blonds; Jeremy Scott partied at Up & Down.
lead_paragraph: Lil’ Kim performed for The Blonds; Jeremy Scott partied at Up & Down.

headline: Prospect of Spanish Citizenship Appeals to Descendants of Jews Expelled in 1492
abstract: Spain expelled its Jews in 1492. Five hundred years later, it is near offering their descendants citizenship.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Spanish initiative that would offer citizenship to Sephardic Jews as a gesture of conciliation for Spain’s expulsion of Jews during the Inquisition has set off a flurry of interest in Israel.

headline: Neatness Doesn’t Count
abstract: The Nepalese cuisine at Dhaulagiri Kitchen in Queens is all the more genuine — and appealing — for being unpolished.
lead_paragraph: “You won’t like it,” we are warned.

headline: Matt Lauer’s Olympian Assignment for NBC Begins Early and Ends Late
abstract: With Bob Costas sidelined, Matt Lauer of “Today” is also on prime time, with little sleep. “I can’t do this schedule for any prolonged period of time,” he says.
lead_paragraph: Matt Lauer will pinch-host again Thursday night for Bob Costas, NBC’s prime-time anchor at the Winter Games in Sochi, as Mr. Costas continues to treat his infected eyes.

headline: Putin Encourages Egyptian’s Presidential Ambitions
abstract: Field Marshal Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, a universally acknowledged presidential candidate, received an early endorsement from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Field Marshal Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, a universally acknowledged but unannounced presidential candidate, received an early endorsement on Thursday from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: Scholastic Gives Kids a Video-Game Power-Up
abstract: Scholastic News published an article telling children that video games are good for your brain. Should it have given equal time to the more parent-friendly messages on that topic?
lead_paragraph: A friend’s son just brought home his Scholastic News, excited to share a particular article. Scholastic News isn’t available online, and it’s short, so I’ll share the item here:

headline: Obama to Nominate Jane Chu to Head Arts Endowment
abstract: President Obama plans to nominate Ms. Chu, chief executive of the Kauffman Center for the Performing Arts in Kansas City, to lead the National Endowment for the Arts.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced his intention to nominate Jane Chu, a pianist and arts administrator from Kansas City, Mo., to lead the National Endowment for the Arts, which has been without a permanent chief for more than a year.

headline: Letters: ‘The Burglary’ and More
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Betty Medsger’s “The Burglary” and “The Letters of Arthur Schlesinger, Jr.”
lead_paragraph: ‘The Burglary’

keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Ford says it will build its new Edge crossover near Toronto; Audi releases details of the S1 hot hatch it will unveil in Geneva next month.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Bobby Cannavale’s Modern Grease Monkey
abstract: The actor says that for the role of a mechanic in “Blue Jasmine,” he studied the script and found to his surprise that he didn’t conform to Stanley Kowalski type.
lead_paragraph: Like his co-stars Cate Blanchett and Sally Hawkins, Bobby Cannavale was party to Woody Allen’s idiosyncratic filmmaking process when he won a part in “Blue Jasmine.” For starters, he was only allowed to read his character’s part of the script, and even then, not for long.

headline: Live Stream | Calvin Klein’s Fall 2014 Collection at New York Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Calvin Klein at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The latest women’s collection from Calvin Klein at New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Year Later, Ackman Sticks With His Bet Against Herbalife
abstract: William A. Ackman, the head of Pershing Square Capital Management, returned to the place where he announced his $1 billion bet against Herbalife and struck a defiant tone.
lead_paragraph: It has been a little more than a year since William A. Ackman announced a $1 billion bet against Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company, and that wager is still in the red.

headline: Slovakian Player’s Absence Affects Teammates and Foes
abstract: Even the American player Paul Stastny, whose family is Slovakian, mourned the absence of Pavol Demitra from the first Olympics since his death in 2011.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — His family’s background could have made the game more complicated for United States forward Paul Stastny, so on the eve of his Sochi Games debut, his father, Peter, kept his advice simple. Have fun, he told his son, and savor every shift.

headline: When New Yorkers Use Umbrellas During Snowstorms
abstract: The snow continues to fall, we’re in the middle of a winter boot shortage and New Yorkers on Twitter and elsewhere are talking about a sensitive topic: Is it O.K. to use umbrellas in the snow?
lead_paragraph: The snow continues to fall, we’re in the middle of a winter boot shortage and New Yorkers on Twitter and elsewhere are talking about a sensitive topic:

headline: Anchorman
abstract: Dave Itzkoff analyzes the making of Paddy Chayefsky’s classic film “Network.”
lead_paragraph: Paddy Chayefsky’s Oscar-winning screenplay for the 1976 film “Network” was, and remains, the kind of literate, darkly funny and breathtakingly prescient material that prompts many to claim it as the greatest screenplay of the 20th century. In “Mad as Hell: The Making of ‘Network’ and the Fateful Vision of the Angriest Man in Movies,” Dave Itzkoff, a culture reporter for The New York Times, takes us behind the curtain and shows us why.

headline: Car Bomb Kills 5 Outside Airport in Somalia
abstract: The Shabab militant group claimed responsibility for the attack in Mogadishu, which was believed to be aimed at a passing United Nations convoy.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — At least five people were killed and a dozen wounded on Thursday when a car loaded with explosives blew up outside a restaurant next to the entrance to the international airport in Mogadishu, officials said.

headline: Assessing Who Benefits From the Latest Rulings on the Employer Mandate
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Small Business']
abstract: While most business interests were opposed to any form of a mandate, many trade groups were generally pleased with the final regulations.
lead_paragraph: Seth Perretta is a benefits lawyer in Washington who has represented several trade groups while the Internal Revenue Service has been writing the rules governing the Affordable Care Act’s employer mandate.

headline: ScienceTake: War of the Ants
abstract: Tawny crazy ants are replacing the notorious fire ant with the help of a never-before-seen chemical defense.
lead_paragraph: Tawny crazy ants are replacing the notorious fire ant with the help of a never-before-seen chemical defense.

headline: Shakespeare in the Park Lineup: ‘Much Ado About Nothing’ and ‘King Lear’
abstract: This summer’s season will begin with Lily Rabe and Hamish Linklater in “Much Ado About Nothing,” and John Lithgow will play the title role in “King Lear.”
lead_paragraph: The witty banter of Beatrice and Benedick and the avaricious scheming of Goneril and Regan will animate this summer’s Shakespeare in the Park, the Public Theater’s annual series of free performances at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. The series, which the Public announced on Thursday, begins with “Much Ado About Nothing,” which opens on June 3 for a five-week run. “King Lear,” the second of the two productions, opens on July 22 and runs through Aug. 17.

headline: Polo Lets Women Play, Too
abstract: The designer unveiled his Polo Ralph Lauren line for women, a colorful flash of the ’70s that was followed by the subdued main collection.
lead_paragraph: “I am launching Polo Ralph Lauren for women and opening a store, but I wanted to show that the two worlds are the same,” said Mr. Lauren, who gave a second dimension to his elegant Ralph Lauren presentation on Thursday, which was played out in pastel colors, easy fur pieces and draped, almost Grecian dresses.

headline: Odd Future Barred From New Zealand
abstract: The hip-hop group was denied entry to the country because they are “a potential threat to public order,” authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Odd Future’s past seems to have caught up with it. The hip-hop group, which is known for its violent and sometimes misogynistic lyrics, and for incidents like a 2011 Boston performance in which some witnesses said that the group’s frontman, Tyler, the Creator, incited fans to attack a policeman, has been barred from entering New Zealand, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Crazy Ant Invader Uses Acid to Its Advantage
abstract: In a unique defense, the crazy ant uses its own venom to neutralize that of its main competitor, the fire ant.
lead_paragraph: The crazy ant, the latest ant to invade North America, is having remarkable success at replacing its predecessor, the red fire ant, former king of the invaders. Part of the reason, according to research at the University of Texas, is that the newcomer can detoxify fire ant venom in a way not seen before in other insects or animals.

headline: Investors Eye Comcast’s Bid for Time Warner Cable With Caution
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: With Comcast shares down, the market reaction appears to signal that the company may have overpaid for Time Warner Cable, writes Steven M. Davidoff.
lead_paragraph: That long proxy fight to take control of Time Warner Cable that I predicted earlier this week? It lasted days, ending with the announcement on Thursday that Comcast would acquire Time Warner Cable. The questions now are whether Time Warner Cable can complete the deal, and what lesson we’ve learned for future hostile takeovers.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Returns
abstract: Alessandra Stanley, the chief television critic for The Times, discusses the new season of the Netflix political drama.
lead_paragraph: Alessandra Stanley, the chief television critic for The Times, discusses the new season of the Netflix political drama.

headline: Tracing Ancestry, Researchers Produce a Genetic Atlas of Human Mixing Events
abstract: Geneticists using new statistical approaches have taken a first shot at identifying and dating the major population mixture events of the past 4,000 years.
lead_paragraph: The rise and fall of empires, the march of armies, the flow of trade routes, the practice of slavery — all these events have led to a mixing of populations around the world. Such episodes have left a record in the human genome, but one that has so far been too complex to decipher on a global scale.

headline: The Making of a Rap Tribute to the Galleon Group
abstract: Riding high before his undoing, Raj Rajaratnam asked the rapper Jesse Jaymes to celebrate his hedge fund’s success. The result was “The Good Ship Galleon.”
lead_paragraph: What rhymes with Raj Rajaratnam?

headline: Hastings Joins Roster of Retiring House Members
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Representative Doc Hastings, Republican of Washington, announced that he would retire at the end of the year, joining a growing number of veterans heading for the congressional exits.
lead_paragraph: Representative Doc Hastings, a Republican who has represented Washington State for 20 years and who is chairman of the House Natural Resources Committee, announced Thursday that he would retire at the end of the year, joining a growing number of veterans heading for the congressional exits.

headline: Ralph Lauren: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Learning to Silence My Inner Editor
abstract: The rules of romance (or romanz) do not have to agree with the rules of grammar.
lead_paragraph: I am trained to be a critic. After several years of graduate school, I started to enjoy pointing out flaws in people’s writing, a ruthless activity with all the destructive pleasure of picking at a scab. The voice of my inner editor had become so powerful that it almost kept me from finding the love of my life.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 13
abstract: Warm weather, men’s slopestyle skiing, individual skating and skeleton headline the eighth day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: Warm weather, men’s slopestyle skiing, individual skating and skeleton headline the eighth day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Proenza Schouler Fall/Winter 2014

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Anna Moller.

headline: The School Snow Run
abstract: New York parents dragged their children to school through snow and ice Thursday, on a day when the governor declared a state of emergency. Some were creative about transport; not all were happy.
lead_paragraph: New York parents dragged their children to school through snow and ice Thursday, on a day when the governor declared a state of emergency. Some were creative about transport; not all were happy.

headline: Schumer Offers Long-Shot Option to Skirt House G.O.P. on Immigration
abstract: A discharge petition would allow supporters of immigration overhaul to circumvent the Republican majority in the House by bringing a measure directly to the House floor, bypassing the committee process.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, offered a long-shot option on Thursday to revive the moribund effort to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws that would require the support of more than a dozen House Republicans — and, if nothing else, pressure others to act on an election-year issue that Tea Party-aligned members strongly oppose.

headline: Study Sees Path to Cutting Substantial American Natural Gas Leaks
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Coal', 'Drilling and Boring', 'Energy and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Methane', 'Mines and Mining', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: A new study finds that natural gas leakage in North America is worse than official estimates, but identifies big opportunities for cutting the biggest sources.
lead_paragraph: A policy analysis published in Science today examines 20 years of research on leakage from natural gas production and distribution systems in North America, including hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, and finds big opportunities to cut the worst leaks and a substantial climate benefit from a coal-to-gas switch, even accounting for higher leak rates.

headline: From Flat on Their Backs, Sliders Rise to Play Tag for the Team
abstract: The luge relay was contested at an Olympics for the first time on Thursday, challenging supine athletes to pop up and smack a pad while sliding by to open the gates for their teammates.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — It is the Winter Games equivalent of a dropped baton, the sort of Olympic nightmare that haunts lugers as they lie on their sleds and that wakes them as they lie in their beds.

headline: Scots Told They Risk Losing the Pound if They Gain Independence
abstract: After the British prime minister appealed to Scots to reject the independence referendum, Britain’s three main parties sent a more steely message.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s three main political parties set aside routine disagreements on Thursday to issue an unusual collective warning to Scots that if they vote for independence, Scotland will lose the pound sterling as its currency.

headline: Modern Love | Under His Misspell
abstract: When a writer falls in love with someone whose spelling and grammar are poor, it challenges her assumptions about the type of man she'd want to marry.
lead_paragraph: When a writer falls in love with someone whose spelling and grammar are poor, it challenges her assumptions about the type of man she'd want to marry.

headline: A Post-Soviet, Punk-Feminist Story
abstract: Meg Miroshnik’s new play peers into the history and sociology of the former Soviet Union through the lens of czarist folklore.
lead_paragraph: “Sleep with one eye open,” Annie’s mother warns, as she packs her daughter off to visit the old country. It’s good advice — Annie’s adventures in Russia will pit her against insatiable witches, angry bears, pugilistic potatoes and, last but not least, terrifyingly tight minis and grotesquely high heels.

headline: Snowfall Totals Around the Region
abstract: Inches of snow and time of measurement as reported by the National Weather Service.
lead_paragraph: Inches of snow and time of measurement as reported by the National Weather Service.

headline: In Surprise Move, Terra Firma Shakes Up Renewable Energy Team
abstract: Terra Firma said that Damian Darragh, who worked for Terra Firma for 18 years and was head of its green power investments, was asked to leave the firm.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:48 p.m. | LONDON — Terra Firma, the European private equity fund founded by the British financier Guy Hands, is shaking up its management ranks.

headline: Bailout Gave Small Bank a Chance to Survive
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The government took a loss on Old Second National Bank in Illinois, but investors who bought its stake may come close to tripling their money.
lead_paragraph: The image of bank bailouts in the United States was set by the megabanks, and with it widespread public hostility to the bailouts.

headline: One-Fifth of New Enrollees Under Health Care Law Fail to Pay First Premium
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Paying the first month’s premium is the final step in completing an enrollment, and those who did not pay did not receive coverage in January.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One in five people who signed up for health insurance under the new health care law failed to pay their premiums on time and therefore did not receive coverage in January, insurance companies and industry experts say.

headline: J. Mendel: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Teaching the Sochi Olympics | English Language Arts, Journalism and Fine Arts
abstract: Ideas for using the Sochi Games to teach literature, journalism, media studies, and fine arts and English-language learning classes.
lead_paragraph: All week we’ve been posting lesson ideas related to the 2014 Winter Games. Below, our list for literature, journalism, media studies and fine arts classes, as well as suggestions for E.L.L. students. You can find ideas for social studies, science, math and more by scrolling through our full collection.

headline: Too Secret for Congress
abstract: The Obama administration won’t let most lawmakers learn about the drone program.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Times had a great story today that helps explain why few Americans — including the ones who make the country’s laws — know much about the drone program that is the vanguard of the endless war against terror. The basic reason, of course, is that the Obama administration wants to keep everyone in the dark, but the lengths to which officials will go can sometimes be surprising.

headline: The Gun Report: February 13, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: In response to federal gun restrictions proposed after the Sandy Hook massacre, some states have adopted new laws under the banner of “gun nullification.” In Missouri on Tuesday, senators endorsed legislation that seeks to invalidate federal gun restrictions, and even send federal agents to jail for enforcing such laws. The measure will likely face a court challenge if it gets approved. The Democratic governor vetoed a similar measure that passed last year.

headline: Global Citizens, Bound by Soul and Sinew
abstract: “Pawel Althamer: The Neighbors” is a stirring career survey of this Polish artist’s work at the New Museum, and is very much about both community and impermanence.
lead_paragraph: After passing through galleries filled with small, craftsy, poetic objects in last year’s Venice Biennale, you suddenly had a Dante moment in an installation of life-size figures by the Polish artist Pawel Althamer.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: happiness and age, chick flicks and brushing children’s teeth. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: happiness and age, chick flicks and brushing children’s teeth. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: New Antiques Websites Join Crowded Field
abstract: Incollect.com, thehighboy.com and thefinest.com are among the new websites that help antiques collectors click and buy.
lead_paragraph: The latest marketing craze in the antiques world, now that the recent wave of TV shows starring auctioneers and dealers has faded, is for websites that help collectors click and buy.

headline: Pro-Clinton ‘Super PAC’ Sets Event for Donors
abstract: The leading Democratic “super PAC” will hold a briefing for potential donors this month, its first such event since reorganizing in January as a vehicle to help elect Hillary Rodham Clinton as president.
lead_paragraph: The leading Democratic “super PAC” will hold a briefing for potential donors this month, its first such event since reorganizing in January as a vehicle to help elect Hillary Rodham Clinton as president.

headline: For New Age, the Next Generation
abstract: A music genre, once dismissed, finds fresh adherents.
lead_paragraph: A sign on the door of the Body Actualized Center in Bushwick, Brooklyn, promised “Cosmic Yoga,” but on a recent snowy Monday night, a crowd had gathered for a concert of electronic music. Slushy boots were politely confiscated in the lobby, and about 75 shoeless patrons in their 20s and 30s sat cross-legged on pillows or reclined on blankets on the floor. The space was lit, just barely, by botanica candles, placed amid potted trees and colorful crystals. The aroma of incense permeated the room.

headline: Study Finds Methane Leaks Negate Benefits of Natural Gas as a Fuel for Vehicles
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Methane', 'Diesel Power', 'Coal', 'Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide']
abstract: Natural gas is cleaner burning than diesel, but production leads to leaks of methane, which is more potent than carbon dioxide, a report says.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The sign is ubiquitous on city buses around the country: “This bus runs on clean burning natural gas.”

headline: Everyday Existence, With Eyes Wide Open
abstract: The collection of works by 23 artists at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art attempts to address the “core of our everyday lives.”
lead_paragraph: “Art at the Core: The Intersection of Visual Art, Performance and Technology” at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill feels more like an arbitrary collection of artworks than a specially curated show. Nonetheless, there is some attempt at binding the exhibition together with a common theme. According to a gallery release, the few dozen works by 23 artists “lend themselves to narrative interpretation” and look toward art to address “the very core of our everyday lives, our ‘Weltanschauung,’ ” or worldview.

headline: A Whodunit Asks, Why Isn’t He Dead?
abstract: Marcel Theroux’s new novel, “Strange Bodies,” centers on the seeming return to life of two dead men, including Samuel Johnson.
lead_paragraph: Edmund Wilson wasn’t an admirer of genre fiction, mystery novels especially. He asked, testily, “Who cares who killed Roger Ackroyd?”

headline: Rediscovering New Age
abstract: Mike Rubin and Ben Ratliff discuss the current state of new-age music.
lead_paragraph: Mike Rubin and Ben Ratliff discuss the current state of new-age music.

headline: Putting Music First
abstract: The Stone is considered, among its fans, a pinnacle of what a music space should be.
lead_paragraph: The Stone is considered, among its fans, a pinnacle of what a music space should be.

headline: For Dry Tastes, an Aromatic Altar to Bitters
abstract: At Amor y Amargo in the East Village, which specializes in aromatic concoctions, bitters have pride of place.
lead_paragraph: EVEN if love were not part of the name, I would fall for Amor y Amargo in the East Village.

headline: Kerry Rejects Delaying South Korea Exercise
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The request from North Korea came as Secretary of State John Kerry started a trip to Asia covering several countries and addressing several challenges.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Secretary of State John Kerry rebuffed North Korea’s demand that the United States and South Korea briefly delay a joint military exercise this month so that it does not coincide with the scheduled reunion of families separated by the Korean War.

headline: Caught Beneath the Wheels of the Comcast Juggernaut
abstract: The deal for Time Warner Cable appears set to generate a return on investment below Comcast’s cost of capital, which is not surprising given the medieval governance the Roberts family uses to oversee its fiefdom, write Rob Cox and Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Comcast’s deal machine has spit out a value destroyer. Digesting Time Warner Cable is ambitious even for a serial acquirer like Comcast’s chief executive, Brian Roberts. As with some of his many previous purchases, it looks set to generate a return on investment below Comcast’s cost of capital. That’s crummy but not criminal. It’s also not surprising given the medieval governance the Roberts family uses to oversee its fiefdom.

headline: N.S.A. Forces Out Civilian Employee With Snowden Tie
abstract: The move comes after an investigation to “assign accountability” for the disclosure of intelligence secrets by Edward J. Snowden, a former contractor for the National Security Agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency has told Congress that it has forced out a civilian employee after a lengthy investigation to “assign accountability” for the disclosure of intelligence secrets by Edward J. Snowden, one of its former contractors.

headline: Soap Opera Star, His Girlfriend and His Admirer
abstract: The comedy written and performed by Paul Dooley and Winnie Holzman, a married couple, is equal parts funny and frustrating.
lead_paragraph: “One of Your Biggest Fans” is a fairly good play with some fairly big problems, in a production that is equal parts funny and frustrating.

headline: Calvin Klein: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Choose the Artists, Ignore the Critics
abstract: Anthony Elms, one of three curators for this year’s Whitney Biennial, prepares his artists for the show.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Anthony Elms says that the first artwork he fell in love with, as a boy growing up in southern Michigan, was John Singleton Copley’s painting of a swimmer pulled from the clutches of sharks, at the Detroit Institute of Arts. Mr. Elms may soon be casting his mind back to that picture as he starts to feel like chum.

headline: Videos of Besieged Areas in Syria Highlight Need for Aid Access
abstract: Activists and aid organizations have published footage of the dire aid needs of civilians in besieged areas.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues reported  from Geneva, the halls of United Nations headquarters were quiet on Thursday morning, with no meetings between the two sides in the Syrian peace talks.

headline: A Loan Extends Museums’ Global Reach
abstract: The Frick Collection is lending significant artworks to the Mauritshuis, a museum of similar spirit in The Hague.
lead_paragraph: Life at the Frick Collection may be a bit quieter since its blockbuster exhibition “Masterpieces of Dutch Painting From the Mauritshuis” closed there last month, leaving its galleries devoid of two star paintings, Vermeer’s “Girl With a Pearl Earring” (1665), one of the most recognizable faces in art history, and Fabritius’s “The Goldfinch,” a tiny 1654 canvas that is the protagonist of the best-selling novel of the same title.

headline: State by State in the Aftermath of Deadly Winter Storm
abstract: A look at how states along the East Coast are faring In the aftermath of a deadly storm that caused havoc from Georgia to Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:42 p.m. Feb. 14 At least 50 vehicles, including tractor-trailers, were involved in two pileups along an ice-covered stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike on Friday morning, sending more than 30 people to area hospitals. Officials said that at least five people suffered serious injuries.

headline: Aesthetics Are Not the Point
abstract: A collection of French ceramics at the Metropolitan Museum of Art represents styles and influences from classic Chinese to European folk traditions.
lead_paragraph: Beauty is routinely dismissed by today’s progressive thinkers. It’s not politically or ethically meaningful, they’ll say. But this is wrong. Beauty is political. Groups of people convene around vehement feelings for particular forms of it. What some find beautiful, others find repulsive and morally disgusting, and sometimes even worth going to war over. The taste for certain styles of beauty is as likely to be aligned with revolutionary as with reactionary convictions.

headline: Retiring on the House
abstract: As the boomers age, reverse mortgages are expected to gain popularity as a means of covering living expenses.
lead_paragraph: As baby boomers age, reverse mortgages are expected to gain popularity as a means of covering living expenses. Hence, in the future, more homes passed on to children will come with a bill attached — the balance due on these equity loans.

headline: Relais & Châteaux Puts on a Show
abstract: GourmetFest is the first food and wine festival from the Relais & Chateaux group of hotels and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Relais & Châteaux, the collection of upscale hotels and restaurants, is holding its first wine and food festival from March 27 to March 30 in Carmel-by-the Sea, Calif.

headline: Clip: 'Jimmy P'
abstract: A scene from the Arnaud Desplechin film "Jimmy P: Psychotherapy of a Plains Indian," featuring Benicio del Toro and Mathieu Amalric.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the Arnaud Desplechin film "Jimmy P: Psychotherapy of a Plains Indian," featuring Benicio del Toro and Mathieu Amalric.

headline: De Blasio Defends Opening Schools
abstract: The mayor defended the decision to keep schools open during the snowstorm, despite criticism from some parents.
lead_paragraph: The mayor defended the decision to keep schools open during the snowstorm, despite criticism from some parents.

headline: Belgium Close to Allowing Euthanasia for Ill Minors
keywords: ['Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Law and Legislation', 'Children and Childhood', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The measure, which is expected to be signed by King Philippe, would make Belgium the first nation to lift all age restrictions on legal, medically induced deaths.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Belgian lawmakers gave final approval on Thursday to a measure that would allow euthanasia for incurably ill children enduring insufferable pain. King Philippe is expected to sign the measure into law and make Belgium the first country to lift all age restrictions on legal, medically induced deaths.

headline: Vintage French, Permitted to Breathe
abstract: The Boston Symphony Orchestra played Brahms and Schumann on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, but it was Wednesday’s Ravel program that truly took flight.
lead_paragraph: As one typically more drawn to Germanic repertory than to French, I expected to enjoy the Boston Symphony Orchestra’s first concert conducted by Bernard Haitink at Carnegie Hall this week, on Tuesday evening, at least as much as its second, on Wednesday.

headline: A Journey to Bollywood for the Food
abstract: Dhoom, a three-month-old place in Secaucus, offers diners a tour of Indian cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Any serious-minded restaurant named after a trilogy of Bollywood buddy-cop thrillers (imagine “Lethal Weapon” set in Mumbai) deserves some style points sight unseen. But it turns out there’s plenty more style on display once you enter Dhoom, an unusual three-month-old Indian spot in Secaucus.

headline: Bookshelf: Just Hatched
abstract: New picture books about young creatures include Jorey Hurley’s “Nest.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books about young creatures include Jorey Hurley’s “Nest.”

headline: De Blasio Defends Call to Police About Supporter’s Arrest
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said that his decision to check on the status of Bishop Orlando Findlayter, a key political ally, was “absolutely appropriate.”
lead_paragraph: Characterizing his actions as “appropriate,” Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday sharply defended his decision to call a top police official this week to inquire about the arrest of a Brooklyn bishop, a key political supporter.

headline: Serving the Standards for 35 Years
abstract: Sadler’s Ordinary exudes unpretentious country charm and serves an eclectic mix of dishes that includes steak, seafood, pasta and a comfort food.
lead_paragraph: Sadler’s Ordinary, occupying a barnlike structure in out-of-the-way Marlborough, recently celebrated its 35th anniversary. Few marriages last that long, and the restaurant business is even more fickle than matrimony. Perhaps the secret lies in knowing who you are — and who you aren’t. “We don’t try to be pretentious,” says the chef and owner, Kevin Haggerty, who has run Sadler’s since 1994. “People like the standards.” And so his back-to-the-future menu features surf and turf and quiche Lorraine. Welcome to 1978!

headline: Italian Food the Old-Fashioned Way
abstract: From Arthur Avenue bread to dessert, Alex’s Bar and Grille serves beloved Italian-American comfort food.
lead_paragraph: Alex’s Bar and Grille in White Plains has been open only about a year and a half, but dining there makes me feel nostalgic.

headline: Show Your Affection (or Test Your Love)
abstract: There are several quirky ways to celebrate Valentine’s Day in New York, from theater to film to haunted houses.
lead_paragraph: WITH same-sex marriage working its way into the mainstream of American life, straight people aren’t the only ones figuring out just how boring wedded bliss can be. So what’s a couple to do when the flames of romance sputter? Several events in New York City this Valentine’s Day weekend offer unconventional, dramatic and tasty ways for couples — married or not, gay or otherwise — to kindle or rekindle a love story.

headline: An Artist’s Paintings, and His Complexities, on Display
abstract: “Forrest Bess: Seeing Things Invisible,” at the Neuberger Museum of Art, dives deeply into this painter’s life and work.
lead_paragraph: PURCHASE, N.Y. — The small but potent paintings of Forrest Bess respond to the art world’s “either-ors” with a resounding “and.” Without resorting to big stretches of canvas or brash gestures, they merge inner and outer worlds, abstraction and representation, and ideas of masculinity and femininity. To a market still intent on labeling “insiders” and “outsiders,” they offer the conundrum of an artist who showed at the Betty Parsons Gallery in New York in the 1950s, alongside Rothko and Pollock, but made his living as a bait fisherman in Bay City, Tex.

headline: Effects of Raising the Minimum Wage
abstract: Readers respond to an editorial endorsing an increase.

headline: Celery Adds an Extra Dimension to Stewed Pork
abstract: The brightness of celery deserves to be played up front in this earthy dish of pork and lentils.
lead_paragraph: Celery is the underlying backbone of many dishes. But sometimes it deserves to be played up front. Its vegetal freshness and somewhat bitter finish add a bright dimension to this earthy dish of pork and lentils, elements that go a long way toward welcoming a bottle of Rosso di Montalcino.

headline: Beyond the Bread, Glimpses of Italy
abstract: Spezia is the kind of Italian restaurant where “anything you want” is a credo, but skip the bread.
lead_paragraph: Some believe they can foretell the success of a restaurant meal by the bread served at the outset. If the bread is good, the meal will be great; if it is bad, abandon all hope. Those people would be proved wrong at Spezia, a new Italian restaurant in St. James.

headline: Which Is Your Favorite Modern Love Column?
abstract: Why spend Valentine’s Day Eve helping children with their classroom valentines when there’s a good book at hand?
lead_paragraph: Modern Love’s editor, Dan Jones, and his new book, “Love, Illuminated,” have been all over The Times the past few weeks, with a review in a love-themed edition of the Book Review, an article in the Sunday Review and an excerpt in his home, the Style section (“Good Enough? That’s Great”). You might think it’s because Dan is one of our own, but I’d beg to differ.

headline: Connected: Love in the Time of the Internet
abstract: Young women respond to a Sunday Review essay, “Romance at Arm’s Length.”

headline: Nothing to See, Yet So Much Not to Miss
abstract: The festival Film Comment Selects includes 22 movies chosen by the editors of Film Comment magazine.
lead_paragraph: Moviegoers may be experiencing a moment of mathematical confusion. Are there too many movies or not enough? Could it be both? At this time of year, interesting new commercial releases slow to a trickle, as the Oscar pachyderms dominate the landscape, making room for a few smaller films and the usual genre offerings — action, rom-com, animation, whatever. Slim pickings for the discerning cinephile. At the same time, bulletins from Sundance and Berlin, and reports from the not-fully-charted wilderness of digital distribution, suggest a state of unmanageable abundance, a cornucopia of docs, foreign-language art and genre films, and post-mumblecore youthquakes. There is nothing to see, but so much that we’re missing.

headline: Pieces That Invite a Closer Look
abstract: An exhibition aims to unsettle viewers with artists’ responses to situations or ideas that are important to them.
lead_paragraph: Grace Beza of Islip had strapped a small light onto her forehead and entered a dark, cavelike room. Inside, dozens of images painted on the walls showed men wearing headlamps on helmets. When she emerged, she was intrigued but mystified. The figures looked like miners in a womb, Ms. Beza said.

headline: Making His Case for the Second Montalcino
abstract: If you’re thrilled by sangiovese, give Rosso di Montalcino a chance.
lead_paragraph: It could be because it’s the second wine of the region, made with grapes that for one reason or another didn’t make the cut for the first. Or maybe it’s because the status of Brunello di Montalcino, and therefore the wines of Montalcino, were under a cloud of scandal for several years, making them difficult to embrace.

headline: For DiCaprio, ‘Wolf’ Is ‘Reflection of the Truth’
abstract: Leonardo DiCaprio talks about the difficulties of making “The Wolf of Wall Street,” and the criticism that it glorifies criminals.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s hug it out,” Leonardo DiCaprio said, reaching in for an embrace.

headline: Images of Turkish Reporter Felled by Police Water Cannon Stir Anger Online
abstract: Outraged Turkish bloggers and journalists shared images of a female television reporter who was knocked down by a direct blast from a police water cannon during a protest in the capital, Anakara, on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Turkish bloggers and journalists expressed outrage on social networks Thursday at images of a female television reporter who was knocked down by a direct blast of red liquid fired from a police water cannon during a protest in the capital, Anakara.

headline: Trimmings NYFW, Day 7
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Hats and Caps', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Sunglasses']
abstract: Standout fall 2014 accessories from Proenza Schouler, Reed Krakoff, Michael Kors and more.
lead_paragraph: Standout fall 2014 accessories from Proenza Schouler, Reed Krakoff, Michael Kors and more.

headline: When Age Belies Buying Power
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The under-40 multimillionaire crowd eschews Park Avenue for Canal Street, and cares less about status and amenities than quality, character and privacy.
lead_paragraph: In the universe of ultraluxury real estate, much attention has been lavished on foreign investors who pay record prices for glassy Midtown condominiums, and the wave of previously staunch uptown residents suddenly spending big to embrace unlikely neighborhoods in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Volkswagen to Stop Using Primates in Ads, Withdrawing Teaser for Super Bowl Commercial
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The car company agreed to abide by a no-primates policy advocated by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.
lead_paragraph: The animal welfare organization People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals has scored again in its long-running fight against the use of primates in advertising, as Volkswagen of America agreed to abide by a no-primates policy and withdrew a video clip from online platforms that had served as a teaser for the company’s commercial during Super Bowl XLVIII on Feb. 2.

headline: That’s an Order!
abstract: President Obama signed an executive order to ensure that employees of federal contractors are paid at least $10.10 an hour starting in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Making good on a promise from his recent State of the Union address, President Obama signed an executive order on Wednesday to ensure that employees of federal contractors are paid at least $10.10 an hour starting in 2015.

headline: ‘Network’ Told the Future
abstract: Ron Bonn, a former CBS News producer, responds to a column by Maureen Dowd.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: PepsiCo Declines to Spin Off Beverage Unit
abstract: PepsiCo’s decision amounted to a rejection of a push by the activist investor Nelson Peltz, who has called the beverage business “wonderful” but stagnant.
lead_paragraph: PepsiCo Inc. said on Thursday that it had decided not to spin off its North American beverage business, effectively rejecting a push by the activist investor Nelson Peltz.

abstract: Veronica M. White, a New York City parks commissioner in the Bloomberg administration, responds to a Gotham column by Michael Powell.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

lead_paragraph: David Zwirner

headline: London’s West End, a Stage for Good Eating
abstract: Finding a good restaurant in a theater district isn’t always easy, but in London, these spots are worth pairing with a show.
lead_paragraph: It takes time to eat in a great restaurant, and time is precious pre- or post-theater. You’re either eating early and in a hurry to make the curtain, or you’re up late and half-ready for bed. In either case, a two-hour blowout is unlikely.

headline: New York Fashion Week Street Style: Day 8
abstract: Street-style photos from our NYTimesFashion Instagram account.
lead_paragraph: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC took over our Instagram account for New York Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

headline: Under Cover: Capturing Wendy Davis
abstract: Jeff Brown, the photographer for this week’s cover story, took cues from classic movies to produce a warm and highly-saturated portrait of State Senator Wendy Davis.

headline: In Chiang Mai, Thailand, a Hub for Creative Types
abstract: An area west of the old city center in this northern Thai town is home to quirky coffee shops, design boutiques and galleries.
lead_paragraph: Alongside its reputation for gilded, Buddha-filled temples and treks to hill tribe villages, Chiang Mai in northern Thailand has in recent years attracted creative types seeking a chilled-out alternative to Bangkok, 350 miles away. Nowhere is this more evident than Nimmanhaemin Road, a thoroughfare west of the old city center anchored by Chiang Mai University and known as Nimman. The area’s tranquil side streets, called sois, are home to quirky coffee shops, design boutiques and galleries. These, combined with boutique hotels like Artel Nimman, where guests access the ground floor by a slide, make Nimman an appealing base from which to explore the city.

headline: Learning the Language of Restaurant Week
abstract: A campaign for NYC Restaurant Week has some fun with pronunciation.
lead_paragraph: A new video campaign launched by NYC & Company, New York’s marketing and tourism organization, offers a comedic look at the orthoepic challenges of NYC Restaurant Week.

headline: Josephine Halvorson and Burt Barr
abstract: It’s interesting to compare Ms. Halvorson’s work with the deftly economical video loops by Mr. Barr.
lead_paragraph: Sikkema Jenkins & Company

headline: Beverly Semmes: ‘FRP’
abstract: In this exhibition, Ms. Semmes has drawn and painted over images of women published in pornography magazines.
lead_paragraph: Susan Inglett

headline: ‘Looking Back’: ‘The Eighth White Columns Annual’
abstract: As usual, the White Columns Annual presents a view of the past year in the New York art world that is idiosyncratic, ultrahip and useful.
lead_paragraph: White Columns

headline: Bill O’Reilly’s Gift for the Ages
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Imagine Walter Cronkite, Diane Sawyer, Terry Gross or Tim Russert devoting entire shows to praising their own work.
lead_paragraph: It’s been nearly two weeks now since Bill O’Reilly’s interview with President Obama on Super Bowl Sunday, and in the No Spin Zone of the host’s pretend world he’s still spinning the chat as the greatest conversation since Winston Churchill dined alone.

headline: In a Rare Visit, Three Chances to Impress
abstract: The Royal New Zealand Ballet began its New York run with three works chosen by Ethan Stiefel, its artistic director.
lead_paragraph: When the Royal New Zealand Ballet opened at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday night, it was a homecoming — not for the 61-year-old company, which hasn’t been in New York since 1993, but for its artistic director since 2011, a recently retired star of American Ballet Theater, Ethan Stiefel. Before an audience packed with ballet notables, Mr. Stiefel showed what he’s been up to, introducing his dancers through three recent works chosen for variety.

headline: Alex Katz / Dara Friedman
abstract: This show of the works of the painter Alex Katz and the video artist Dara Friedman finds both artists exploring the state of coupledom.
lead_paragraph: Gavin Brown’s Enterprise

headline: Fragmented Frames of the Love That Was, Taunting Yet Poignant
abstract: Film Forum opens a weeklong run of Alain Resnais’s “Je T’Aime, Je T’Aime,” whose central character travels through time, reliving a relationship nonchronologically.
lead_paragraph: Most stories begin once upon a time and, after the usual chronological tramp toward the inevitable and an occasional detour into the past or future, end happily ever after (or not). In “Je T’Aime, Je T’Aime,” a magnificent film from out of the past, the French director Alain Resnais takes dozens of interludes from one man’s life — images of everyday banality and commonplace delights, scenes of him at work and at play — and arranges them nonchronologically. One minute, Claude (Claude Rich) is emerging from a swim, the next he’s violently quarreling with a lover, and then he’s emerging from that exact same swim all over again, as if stuck in a loop.

headline: Times Minute | Snow Day Controversy
abstract: Under deep snow, New York public schools remained open today. Also on the Minute, the Olympic Games are beginning to melt under a heat wave in Sochi and a war between two ant species.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Treadmills, Without the Tedium
abstract: At the Superstar Gym in Manhattan, the treadmills are powered by the user rather than by electronics.
lead_paragraph: AT a fitness expo in Germany four years ago, the trainer Joe DiAngelo was struck by how boring everything seemed. He eventually came to a realization: Perhaps that old gym standby — the treadmill — could use a makeover.

headline: A Valentine for Restaurant Workers
abstract: Because of something called tipped minimum wage, many servers are dependent — way too dependent — on the largesse of their customers.
lead_paragraph: There is long-overdue support for raising the minimum wage. But among generally mistreated minimum wage workers there’s a subgroup of those whose wage experience is even more miserable and unfair.

lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Acidic Bonbons for V-Day Contrarians
abstract: Television shows for Valentine’s Day seem bent on ridding viewers of their romantic illusions.
lead_paragraph: If you were in danger of becoming all dewy eyed about someone this Valentine’s Day, two windy women stand ready to suck all the joy out of love for you. A science-y show may have already done so earlier in the week. But have patience. Next week, a wedding provides a dose of optimism, despite the skull on the cake.

lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: A Couplet Fantasy Denied
abstract: In “Adult World,” an aspiring 22-year-old poet takes the only job she can find, as an assistant in a pornographic bookstore, but persists in a fantasy about literary renown.
lead_paragraph: “I really feel a lot!” declares Amy (Emma Roberts), a pushy 22-year-old aspiring poet in Scott Coffey’s smart but wince-inducing satirical comedy “Adult World.” “I want to speak for all the people that suffer, that feel the pain that I feel.”

headline: Sex and Candy
abstract: The strange history of women, sensuality and chocolate.
lead_paragraph: NOTHING is more symbolic of the romance of Valentine’s Day than a box of chocolates, traditionally a gift from Him to Her. Chocolate, with its luxurious texture and pleasurable taste, has become the edible correlate to love and desire. And although scientists haven’t discovered any definitive difference in the way men and women respond to chocolate, conventional wisdom is that women naturally crave the stuff.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Feb. 14-20
abstract: A selected guide to performances of indie rock, Latin pop, hip-hop, folk-pop, EDM and more in the New York.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: With a Dentist’s Chair and a Chicken Mask, a Girl Can’t Say No
abstract: “About Last Night,” a raucously entertaining remake, follows the difficulties faced by two couples, one sensitive and well behaved, the other outrageously naughty.
lead_paragraph: It is now 40 years since the first performances of David Mamet’s “Sexual Perversity in Chicago” and almost 30 since the play was made into a movie, starring Rob Lowe and Demi Moore and directed by Edward Zwick, called “About Last Night ... .” Some things have changed (Mr. Mamet has evolved into a dyspeptic right-winger) and some have not (Mr. Lowe and Ms. Moore are still very good looking), but all in all, the thing holds up pretty well. Mr. Mamet’s title was always a bit of a misnomer — his jagged play is more interested in romantic confusion and emotional complication than in freaky bedroom matters — but his map of the crooked paths to heterosexual bliss remains useful and adaptable, even when softened and tidied up by Hollywood. The proof is in the new “About Last Night,” a sweet, silly, semi-raunchy Valentine’s Day confection directed by Steve Pink (“Hot Tub Time Machine”).

headline: Smartphone Sales Beat Feature Phones in 2013
abstract: Researchers at Gartner said that in 2013, worldwide smartphone sales neared 1 billion units sold and surpassed the sales of feature phones for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Watching the sales of smartphones and feature phones in recent years has felt similar to watching a Ferrari race a horse. You know the Ferrari is going to win, it’s just a matter of when.

headline: Once a Lowlife, Always a Lowlife
abstract: In “Easy Money: Hard to Kill,” the second film of a Swedish franchise, a former glamour boy escapes from prison and tries unsuccessfully to eke an honest existence.
lead_paragraph: Having just achieved Hollywood leading man status in the remake of “RoboCop,” Joel Kinnaman reappears as JW, a.k.a. Johan, in the Swedish gangster thriller “Easy Money: Hard to Kill.” It is the second movie of three in a popular Swedish franchise that follows the criminal career of this wily, serpentine social climber from the provinces.

headline: Faking It
abstract: Astroturf as far as the eye can see.
lead_paragraph: Three somehow related stories of the day:

headline: Hellbent on Fusing His Soul With Hers
abstract: “Endless Love, based on the 1979 novel by Scott Spencer, focuses on an all-consuming relationship between a boy and a privileged girl whose parents are deeply concerned about it.”
lead_paragraph: There’s a promising edge to the opening of “Endless Love,” which begins with a young man, David (Alex Pettyfer), speaking in voice-over about a young woman, Jade (Gabriella Wilde). It’s a high school graduation somewhere in Atlanta, and as the camera picks Jade out of the celebrating crowd, David reminisces about how he’s been watching her for years. From the way he talks, he seems to have been watching her closely. Closely enough to suggest that he’s been long nurturing a passion, perhaps an obsession — something deep, troubling and real.
