headline: Therapist and Patient, Odd and Charming
abstract: “Jimmy P.” unconventionally tells the story of a troubled American Indian and war veteran and the psychoanalyst who tries to unlock the secrets of his personality.
lead_paragraph: As played by Benicio Del Toro — flattening vowels, biting at consonants, pushing his tall, square frame though postures of graceful anguish — Jimmy Picard, a World War II veteran and a member of the Blackfoot Indian tribe, is the picture of a noble soul in torment. He is both charismatic and pathetic, and he inspires in his therapist, a French anthropologist and psychoanalyst named Georges Devereux (Mathieu Amalric), a complex mixture of responses, including sympathy, rivalry and unabashed ethnographic curiosity.

headline: Democrats Need Only Look to Past Voters
abstract: If Texas Democrats hope to make a comeback, they have to bring out the old voters, not just the new ones.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: A Culinary Dalí, Delving Into Palettes
abstract: An exhibition at the Drawing Center presents sketches, plating diagrams, notebooks and pictograms by Ferran Adrià, the chef behind the top-ranked El Bulli restaurant in Spain.
lead_paragraph: The only meal I ever ate at El Bulli, the Michelin-starred epicenter of Ferran Adrià’s innovative cuisine (now closed), began with hors d’oeuvres that included a deep-fried, mostly intact rabbit’s ear.  It seemed like a gauntlet thrown down, daring me to keep up. After a  pause, I plunged ahead.  It was surprisingly tasty, and I liked the economy of using overlooked parts of an animal, even bunnies.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Feb. 14-20
abstract: A critical guide to the visual arts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dates Blind and Less So in a Starry Metropolis
abstract: “Beijing Love Story,” adapted from a Chinese TV series, offers a string of romantic tales set in a throbbing urban landscape.
lead_paragraph: The urban tales in “Beijing Love Story” are shameless about conveying modern-age mores and old-fashioned sweetness. When two male friends speed down a road in a car, the cityscape is a riot of multicolored lights, and the techno music thumps as they fist-pumpingly exclaim, “This is life!” When two teenagers shyly get to know each other in another story, their hand-holding on a bus is played for its innocent romantic bliss.

headline: Challengers Say a Tea Party Favorite Shortchanged Constituents
abstract: State Senator Donna Campbell has been criticized by community leaders in her district — and her opponents in the Republican primary — for supporting an increase to vehicle registration fees.
lead_paragraph: As a freshman state senator in the last legislative session, Donna Campbell, Republican of New Braunfels, became known for her strong stance against abortion and for her impassioned speeches at committee hearings. But community leaders in her district have criticized Ms. Campbell, a darling of the Tea Party, for the establishment of a new taxing district in Wimberley and an increase in vehicle registration fees to build toll lanes in San Antonio. The criticism has fueled challenges from two fellow Republicans — Elisa Chan, a former San Antonio city councilwoman, and Mike Novak, a former Bexar County commissioner — hoping to unseat Ms. Campbell in the March 4 primary.

headline: Fantasy Girl at Your Service
abstract: In “Lucky Bastard,” a contest in which the winner is invited to have sex with an actress from a pornographic film has grim consequences.
lead_paragraph: Set in the world of online pornography — and with production values to match — Robert Nathan’s “Lucky Bastard” is a sorry-looking found-footage thriller as unconvincing as its characters’ thrashing orgasms.

headline: A Closer Look at Valentine’s Flowers
abstract: Flowers coming across the border from Mexico are being carefully scrutinized, but more for tiny pests and plant diseases than as hiding places for drugs.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO —  The flowers that decorate offices, homes and restaurants along the Mexico border have been inspected as closely at border crossings as many door panels and car trunks, well-known hiding places used by drug mules to export heroin, cocaine and marijuana from Mexico.

headline: Bridgestone Admits Guilt in U.S. Price-Fixing Case
abstract: More than two dozen Japanese automotive suppliers have agreed to plead guilty to conspiring to fix the prices of parts sold to automakers in the United States and abroad.
lead_paragraph: The Bridgestone Corporation became the latest automotive supplier to plead guilty to charges of conspiring to fix the prices of parts sold to automakers here and abroad, the Justice Department said on Thursday.

headline: Heightened Security, Visible and Invisible, Blankets the Olympics
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Tens of thousands of officers are just one aspect of the remarkable security in place in Sochi, an initiative that is adding to what is believed to be the most expensive Olympics.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Before boarding the new trains serving Sochi and the Olympic sites here, passengers must pass through metal detectors and place their bags on X-ray machines — just as in airports. What many do not realize is that they are also being scanned by a far more sophisticated system that gauges emotional state in an effort to identify potential terrorists.

headline: Demons at Work in Snowy Magic of New York
abstract: The film adaptation of “Winter’s Tale” partakes of wide-eyed mystical wonder but pitches helplessly into ridiculousness.
lead_paragraph: “Winter’s Tale,” Mark Helprin’s 1983 best seller, was the “Goldfinch” of its time: fat and ambitious, with a romantic view of New York City and an unabashed commitment to the kind of old-fashioned narrative abundance that seemed, then as now, to be missing from too much literary fiction. It is a bit surprising that the movie adaptation (written and directed by Akiva Goldsman) has taken so long to arrive, though perhaps less surprising that it should be so clumsy and inert, a lumbering white elephant rather than the flying white horse that is the novel’s magical mascot.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: New York Fashion Week: Calvin Klein Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: Spare Times for Feb. 14-20
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Talks on Hip-Hop (Thursday) Hip-hop may be one of the newer kids on the musical block, but its cultural impact runs as deep as any genre that has preceded it. It’s the focus of a slide show that will accompany a discussion with the photographer Jamel Shabazz and Wes Jackson, founder of Brooklyn Bodega, a branding and promotional company, at the Brooklyn Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn Heights.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 14-20
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘Mysteries of the Unseen World’

headline: Shedding the Cliché of High School Sex
abstract: “Date and Switch,” directed by Chris Nelson, is a new entry in the high school movie pool.
lead_paragraph: Like a fresh ripple in the near-stagnant high school movie pool, Chris Nelson’s “Date and Switch” balances formula with winning performers, genuine humor and a generosity of spirit that this genre too often lacks.

headline: Francis Bacon Work Sells for $70 Million at Christie’s Auction
abstract: Seasoned bidders also capture works by Richter and Koons at Christie’s Thursday night auction of postwar and contemporary art in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Trophy hunters fought over trophy paintings by Gerhard Richter and Francis Bacon, as well as a pink stainless-steel “Cracked Egg” by Jeff Koons, at Christie’s sale of postwar and contemporary art here on Thursday night. But of the three artists, it was Bacon who once again stole the spotlight when an unnamed American collector paid $70 million for “Portrait of George Dyer Talking,” a 1966 canvas depicting the artist’s lover perched on a stool, his twisted body positioned under a naked light bulb as though he were being interrogated.

headline: Giant Jumps
abstract: All but two of the top six skaters after the women’s figure skating short program have performed a difficult triple-triple combination in their long program this season. The highest-scoring combination, a triple lutz-triple toe, was the gold medalist Kim Yu-na’s signature move in 2010 but this year, others have also mastered it.
lead_paragraph: All but two of the top six skaters after the women’s figure skating short program have performed a difficult triple-triple combination in their long program this season. The highest-scoring combination, a triple lutz-triple toe, was the gold medalist Kim Yu-na’s signature move in 2010 but this year, others have also mastered it.

headline: Romance and Tourism
abstract: “Girl on a Bicycle,” a comedy set in Paris, centers on a tour bus driver who is entranced by a passing cyclist.
lead_paragraph: If you’re willing to believe the old moviemaking canard that beautiful, intelligent women are attracted to underachieving men with no ambition or prospects, then you’ll find “Girl on a Bicycle” to be a sweet, often witty romantic comedy.

headline: Pandora Suit May Upend Century-Old Royalty Plan
keywords: ['Royalties', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Music', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Pandora is squaring off against Ascap in a closely watched trial over royalty payments determined by a system developed long before digital streams and smartphone apps.
lead_paragraph: As the music industry races toward a future of digital streams and smartphone apps, its latest crisis centers on a regulatory plan that has been in place since “Chattanooga Choo Choo” was a hit.

headline: Belles of the Wrecking Ball
abstract: There are many candidates for greatest loss in the history of New York City building teardowns.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art’s decision to tear down the quirky little American Folk Art Museum, barely a decade old, has generated outrage; only the loss of Penn Station in 1963 and the fight that saved Grand Central in the 1970s have been more bitter.

headline: Trimmings NYFW, Day 7
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Hats and Caps', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Sunglasses']
abstract: Standout fall 2014 accessories from Proenza Schouler, Reed Krakoff, Michael Kors and more.
lead_paragraph: From snakeskin clutches to stiletto sneakers, these are the standout fall 2014 accessories from Proenza Schouler, Reed Krakoff, Michael Kors and more.

headline: Inequality, Dignity and Freedom
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Who really honors work and liberty? Probably not the 1 percent or the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Congressional Budget Office has explicitly denied saying that Obamacare destroys jobs, some (though by no means all) Republicans have stopped lying about that issue and turned to a different argument. O.K., they concede, any reduction in working hours because of health reform will be a voluntary choice by the workers themselves — but it’s still a bad thing because, as Representative Paul Ryan puts it, they’ll lose “the dignity of work.”

headline: Banks in London Devise Way Around Europe’s Bonus Rules
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bonuses', 'Executive Compensation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Big banks operating in London are adhering to the bloc’s rules on banking bonuses by revamping the way they pay top employees so they still receive the extra money.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A battle over banker bonuses is building in this financial capital.

headline: Opening Shouts and Whispers
abstract: This Fashion Week, designers including Duckie Brown, Baja East and Manolo Blahnik offered examples of both styles of debuts.
lead_paragraph: There are two ways to announce your arrival on New York Fashion Week’s gridlocked calendar: gingerly or brashly, a gentle tap or a sharp elbow. The handful of debuts this week — including, not exhaustively, the first women’s collection from the men’s provocateurs of Duckie Brown, the first presentation by the surf-slacker line Baja East, and the first in New York by Manolo Blahnik — offered examples of both.

headline: The Refiner’s Fire
abstract: One personal take on what it really feels like to be a politician shows politics as a hard and noble calling.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, Michael Ignatieff left a teaching job at Harvard to enter politics in his native Canada with hopes of becoming prime minister.

headline: Dropbox Hires a Google Executive, as It Starts Its Next Phase for Growth
abstract: Dennis Woodside, the chief executive of Motorola, which Google is selling, will become Dropbox’s first chief operating officer as it tries to become a grown-up company.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Woodside, the chief executive of Motorola, owned by Google, is leaving to join Dropbox, which competes with Google in cloud storage.

headline: Massachusetts Is Given Extension
abstract: The state, which had its own health insurance exchange before the Affordable Care Act, has been given another three months to manage a balky transition.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Massachusetts officials said Thursday that they have an additional three months to bring the state’s health care system in line with the national Affordable Care Act.

headline: Snow Day? That’s Great. Now Log In. Get to Class.
abstract: Public schools around the country are exploring whether they can use virtual learning as a practical solution to unpredictable weather, effectively transforming the traditional snow day into a day of instruction.
lead_paragraph: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J. — At 9 a.m. on Thursday the snow was piling high outside and officials had long since made the call to shutter the local schools.

headline: Should All Immigrants Get ID Cards?
abstract: Should cities issue identification for anyone who has no passport or driver's license, even if they are not in the country legally?

headline: Germans Propose Law to Ease Return of Art Looted by Nazis
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Law and Legislation', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Officials on Friday proposed a law that would lift the country’s 30-year statute of limitations for certain cases involving stolen property.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — German authorities proposed a law on Friday that would lift the country’s 30-year statute of limitations for certain cases involving stolen property, a move that would make it easier for Jewish families to seek the return of art, furniture or other valuables taken from them by the Nazis.

headline: Live Stream | Marc Jacobs’s Fall 2014 Collection at New York Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Marc Jacobs at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The latest women’s collection from Marc Jacobs at New York Fashion Week.

headline: William Zeckendorf Jr., 84, Dies; Developer Put Stamp on Skyline
abstract: Mr. Zeckendorf made big bets on big projects that helped refashion neighborhoods from the Upper West Side to Union Square.
lead_paragraph: William Zeckendorf Jr., the son of a celebrated developer who himself transformed New York City by making big bets on big projects that helped refashion neighborhoods from the Upper West Side to Union Square, died on Wednesday in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 84.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Feb. 14, 2014
abstract: The New York Times movie critics on "RoboCop," "Winter's Tale" and "About Last Night."
lead_paragraph: The New York Times movie critics on "RoboCop," "Winter's Tale" and "About Last Night."

headline: U.S. Dominance in Science Faces Asian Challenge
abstract: A new report suggests that the rise of increasingly competitive emerging economies, combined with underinvestment in research might translate to a less productive American economy in the future.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States’ predominance in science and technology is fading, a report released this month by the National Science Board warns.

headline: Bulldozer Clearing Snow Kills a Pregnant Woman
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A pregnant woman who was loading groceries into the trunk of her car with her husband was struck and killed by a small bulldozer in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The snow was falling heavily as Min Lin, pregnant and nearing her due date, and her husband loaded groceries into their car on Thursday in a parking lot in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Nearby, a small bulldozer ran back and forth, furiously working to keep the lot behind Fei Long Market clear of snow.

headline: Another Big Month for Sony Game Console
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)']
abstract: Citing data from the NPD Group, Sony on Thursday said the PlayStation 4’s United States sales for January were nearly double those of the Xbox One.
lead_paragraph: March can’t come soon enough for Microsoft. That’s when the game Titanfall will come out exclusively for the company’s Xbox game consoles and PCs running Windows.

headline: States Struggle to Add Latinos to Health Rolls
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: Enrollment of Latinos in the new health care law has fallen strikingly below the hopes of the law’s proponents, prompting officials to rush to expand marketing efforts.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With an estimated 15 percent of the country’s uninsured population, California is crucial to the success of President Obama’s health care overhaul. Here, that success cannot come without enrolling Latinos, who make up more than half of the state’s uninsured.

headline: Putting the Romance in Cold Medicine and Fabric Softener
abstract: Brands both expected and unexpected are advertising for Valentine’s Day, using a variety of promotions both online and in person.
lead_paragraph: FLORISTS, chocolatiers, jewelers and greeting card publishers typically promote aggressively for Valentine’s Day, but brands that few would associate with romance also are courting consumers this year.

headline: For Daredevils on Snow, the Edge Has Always Been Near
abstract: Events like slopestyle, halfpipe and aerials might have changed the look of the Olympics, but the risks they involve are nothing new. Just ask Billy Kidd, a skiing medalist fifty years ago.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The X Games generation is sometimes referred to as a new breed of Winter Olympian, daredevils unafraid — even excited — to push the limit of gravity in sports that inherently push the limit of safety. And the Winter Olympics’ new slopestyle events are their test track.

headline: California Seeing Brown Where Green Used to Be
abstract: Losses from farms idled by drought are hitting hard among farmers and those who relied on paychecks from working for them.
lead_paragraph: SELMA, Calif. — Fields that in any other year would be filled with broccoli, melons and onions are instead dusty patches of dirt. Farmers are calculating losses that add up with each arid day. Thousands of farm workers who rely on paychecks for tending the fields are expected to go unemployed this year.

headline: As Hate Crimes Rise, British Muslims Say They’re Becoming More Insular
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Discrimination', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: Backlash after the killing of a soldier by two Muslims last year and a rise in anti-immigrant feelings have made some Muslim residents feel unwelcome.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — Alum Rock, a neighborhood of Birmingham, looks the way Pakistan might, if Pakistan were under gray northern skies and British rule.

headline: A Huge Solar Plant Opens, Facing Doubts About Its Future
abstract: The Ivanpah solar power plant in California is the largest and first electric generator of its kind. It could also be the last.
lead_paragraph: NIPTON, Calif. — The Ivanpah solar power plant stretches over more than five square miles of the Mojave Desert. Almost 350,000 mirrors the size of garage doors tilt toward the sun with an ability to energize 140,000 homes. The plant, which took almost four years and thousands of workers assembling millions of parts to complete, officially opened on Thursday, the first electric generator of its kind.

headline: Free Online University Receives Accreditation, in Time for Graduating Class of 7
abstract: The University of the People, built to reach underserved students around the world, announced Thursday that it had received accreditation.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for its first graduates, the University of the People, a tuition-free four-year-old online institution built to reach underserved students around the world, announced Thursday that it had received accreditation.

headline: For Mayor, Keeping Schools Open Brings Another Headache
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s decision to keep New York City schools open drew rebukes from parents, principals and Al Roker, NBC’s “Today” show weatherman.
lead_paragraph: His education chief declared Thursday “a beautiful day” as sleet poured down on parents wondering why schools had not been closed.

headline: Iris van Berne Transforms Backstage at J. Mendel
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Iris van Berne before (left) and after (right) makeup by Dick Page and hair by Anthony Turner.

headline: Industry Shifts May Aid Comcast in Takeover Bid
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Comcast’s proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable will face extensive scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: On the face of it, the merger of the country’s two largest cable companies would seem like a nonstarter, given its steep regulatory hurdles and skepticism from consumer watchdogs.

headline: If a Cable Giant Becomes Bigger
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials', 'Television']
abstract: Buying Time Warner Cable would give Comcast more control over the media and the Internet, and ultimately more control over American consumers.
lead_paragraph: Regulators might be tempted to agree with Comcast that its proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable for $45.2 billion in stock poses no threat to competition and would actually benefit consumers by giving the company more resources to invest in new services. But government officials should not accept that argument without conducting a thorough investigation into what effect a merger between the country’s two largest cable companies would have on the media and the Internet.

headline: A First Stab at a Prudent City Budget
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s budget doesn’t break the bank on “progressive” agenda items and socks away some money.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday released a preliminary budget, his first, that surprised some fiscal watchdogs with its moderation and caution. It doesn’t break the bank on “progressive” agenda items. It restores $1 billion to a depleted trust fund for retiree health benefits and doubles, to $600 million, reserves set aside each year for unexpected shortfalls. The nonpartisan Citizens Budget Commission called it a “double dose of good news” that projected revenues are higher than expected, and that Mr. de Blasio is proposing to sock some money away.

headline: For New Air Force Secretary, a Baptism by Fire
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Cheating', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Deborah Lee James, hit with a scandal weeks after starting her new job, has been praised by some Pentagon officials for seizing an opportunity to practice greater openness.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Deborah Lee James had been Air Force secretary for less than three weeks when the email crash-landed in her inbox.

headline: For Comcast, Daring Deals to Expand Its Reach Across Industries
abstract: The deal for Time Warner Cable solidifies Comcast’s reputation as an enterprise with grand, even audacious, ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks ago, Comcast unveiled plans to build an addition to its headquarters, a gleaming steel-and-glass tower designed by the renowned architect Norman Foster that will cast a shadow over downtown Philadelphia.

headline: A Russian Protest Zone Where Almost No One Registers a Complaint
abstract: A park designated as the official protest site of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, whose main arenas are about 10 miles away, highlights how the Russian government often smothers dissent under a thick blanket of bureaucracy.
lead_paragraph: KHOSTA, Russia — In the small park here that has been designated by the Russian authorities as the official protest zone of the Sochi Winter Olympics, the only mobilization in sight on a sunny afternoon this week was a small armada of strollers, being pushed by a cadre of young mothers.

headline: More Engagement With India
abstract: Meeting with Narendra Modi, the controversial politician who could become the country’s next prime minister, was a pragmatic step.
lead_paragraph: The decision by the United States to have its ambassador to India, Nancy Powell, meet Narendra Modi, a star of the country’s Bharatiya Janata opposition party, reversed a long estrangement. It was a pragmatic step in engaging with India and the controversial and troubling politician who could well become the next prime minister after elections in May.

headline: Crowds Gather for Tanaka and Jeter, Who Is in a Joking Mood
abstract: Derek Jeter said on Thursday that he would answer questions at a news conference next week about his decision to retire.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter pulled up to a line of autograph seekers, rolled down the window of his cobalt blue Mercedes sedan and, after being asked a question, said the two words that thousands of young women would love to hear him say to them.

headline: In Debate Over Paying for Pre-K, Little Agreement Aside From the Goal
abstract: Questions and skepticism surround two competing early education plans by Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: Paul A. Dyster, the eldest of 10 children, spent many of his weekends as a teenager in western New York State moving tiny furniture around classrooms because his mother was an advocate and organizer of prekindergarten programs. “I had it pounded into me from an early age that this was important,” Mr. Dyster, 59, said. Now Bill de Blasio, the mayor of New York City, has proposed that the city be permitted to tax the income of rich people to pay for full-day prekindergarten classes.

headline: Kim Basinger at Ralph Lauren
abstract: Kim Basinger, seemingly ageless in an ivory and black blouse and black trousers, was aptly impressed.
lead_paragraph: A whirling blizzard and calf-deep snowdrifts did little to deter guests on the final morning of New York Fashion Week. Shrugging off puffers and stamping their snow boots, the full house at Ralph Lauren’s 10 a.m. show settled in under flattering chandelier light. Kim Basinger, seemingly ageless in an ivory and black blouse and black trousers, was aptly impressed.

headline: Let the Marketing of Derek Jeter’s Farewell Begin
keywords: ['Memorabilia and Souvenirs', 'Baseball', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: It’s not clear what kind of memorializing and monetizing of his final season Jeter will approve, but the sports collectibles business is well prepared to cash in.
lead_paragraph: The Derek Jeter farewell tour is coming, with the inevitable merchandising: caps and T-shirts with a Jeter-centric logo; dirt from his shortstop area packaged in vials; autographs; signed bases, balls, home plates and, well, almost anything else imaginable.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 13, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Prominent Opposition Leader in Venezuela Is Blamed for Unrest
abstract: Leopoldo López, a former mayor of a district of Caracas, said the government was responsible for the deadly violence during antigovernment protests.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Top government officials on Thursday blamed a prominent opposition leader for unrest that resulted in three deaths, amid growing tension over antigovernment protests.

headline: Brownback Leads Kansas in Sharp Right Turn
abstract: Sam Brownback, the Republican governor of Kansas who this year faces an election challenge, has pursued a bullishly conservative agenda while working to oust moderates.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — Sam Brownback took office as Kansas’ chief executive more than three years ago, promising a conservative revolution. By all accounts he has kept his promise.

headline: Heading Into Break, Talk of Anthony’s Next Act
abstract: The Knicks face delicate negotiations with Carmelo Anthony, who has most of the leverage as his free agency approaches.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Three years ago, Carmelo Anthony was the dominant figure during the N.B.A.’s All-Star weekend. The Denver Nuggets were in the process of completing a deal that would send Anthony to the Knicks (for no small price), and members of the news media formed concentric circles around Anthony, several cameras deep. A superstar was on the move, sending seismic tremors across the league.

headline: Wendy Davis, Texas Candidate, Offers Nuance on Abortion View
abstract: Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator who filibustered abortion restrictions last year, told a Dallas newspaper she would have supported one restriction had it been written differently.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator who became a national figure by filibustering abortion restrictions last year, told a Dallas newspaper that she would have supported one of those restrictions — a ban on abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy — had the bill been written differently and deferred to a woman and her doctor in making the decision.

headline: In Terrorism Case, New Path to Testimony From 9/11 Suspect
abstract: Government and defense lawyers have agreed to allow written questions to be submitted to Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 terror attacks.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden moved closer on Thursday to being able to use Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, as a defense witness to rebut the government’s terrorism case against their client, Sulaiman Abu Ghaith.

headline: What’s Next, Synchronized Slopestyle?
abstract: The Winter Games schedule of 98 events, including team luge and team figure skating, shows every sign of continuing to grow.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Having covered the last six Winter Olympics, and now one Summer Olympics in Sochi, I felt quite safe in saying that these Games, be they frozen or thawed, did not need a team luge event.

headline: Federal Agency and New York State Are in Accord Over $8 Billion Medicaid Waiver
abstract: The Obama administration has agreed “in principle” to grant an $8 billion Medicaid adjustment for New York State that could help stabilize some hospitals in Brooklyn and would reconfigure the delivery of health care there and throughout the state, state officials said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has agreed “in principle” to grant an $8 billion Medicaid adjustment for New York State that could help stabilize some hospitals in Brooklyn and would reconfigure the delivery of health care there and throughout the state, state officials said on Thursday.

headline: With Urgency, David Wright Is Waiting to Win
abstract: Although he expressed patience with the Mets’ payroll, Wright, 31, has made the playoffs only once in 10 seasons with the team.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Growing up, David Wright said, he idolized Derek Jeter. Jeter was polished. He was a winner. He played the game the right way. He played shortstop for the best team in baseball. He was who every high school player wanted to be.

headline: Off the Runway: Last Day
abstract: Scenes from the final day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the final day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Rude Awakenings of Middle Age
abstract: The Roundabout Theater revives “Dinner With Friends,” Donald Margulies’s Pulitzer Prize-winning drama about two married couples suffering from changes in marriage and friendship.
lead_paragraph: Does time erode everything it touches? This painful question lies at the heart of “Dinner With Friends,” Donald Margulies’s delicate-hued, Pulitzer Prize-winning drama about two married couples who come to a crossroads in their long friendship when one pair breaks up.

headline: Phrase From Virgil
abstract: Happy Valentine’s Day from Will Shortz, Wordplay and Bruce Haight.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — My, what a surprise! I really wasn’t expecting this, and I’ll bet you weren’t, either. Bruce Haight is back, and he has something special to ask us. If we all give him an enthusiastic “Yes,” this may be the first mass wedding the Internet has ever seen.

abstract: Behind the scenes of New York Fashion Week fall 2014.
lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes of New York Fashion Week fall 2014.

lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Kendall Jenner before (left) and after (right) makeup by Francois Nars and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Indian Publisher Withdraws Book, Stoking Fears of Nationalist Pressure
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Censorship', 'Hinduism', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: A retired headmaster’s campaign has led Penguin Books India to agree to destroy copies of a book deemed offensive to Hindus, prompting fears that an ideological shift is underway.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In a fight with a major company, a frail 84-year-old retired headmaster would seem to be the David to India’s publishing Goliath, Penguin Books India.

headline: Long-Lived Greatness
abstract: Derek Jeter not only has one of the highest batting averages among his peers, but also has shown extraordinary longevity.
lead_paragraph: Derek Jeter not only has one of the highest batting averages among his peers, but also has shown extraordinary longevity.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Fall 2014 RTW

headline: Facing Bulls, Nets Stumble in Final Game Before All-Star Break

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — At the close of 2013, less than two months ago, the Nets seemed to be on the brink of implosion. They had dealt with issues of futility (losing 12 of 15 games during one stretch), absurdity (their first-year coach, Jason Kidd, was fined for spilling a soda on the court on purpose) and personality (Kidd banished his top assistant, Lawrence Frank, from the bench).

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) NATIONAL THEATER: 50 YEARS ON STAGE In 1963, the National Theater in London raised its curtain with Laurence Olivier as its first artistic director. Eight hundred productions later, the organization celebrated its 50th anniversary in November with an evening of live performances and archival footage, overseen by its current artistic director, Nicholas Hytner, and presented here by “Great Performances.” Highlights include excerpts from “Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead,” with Benedict Cumberbatch; “The History Boys,” with its playwright, Alan Bennett, and two of its original stars, James Corden and Dominic Cooper; “Mourning Becomes Electra,” with Helen Mirren and Tim Pigott-Smith; “Bedroom Farce,” with Penelope Wilton; Judi Dench, above, singing “Send In the Clowns” from “A Little Night Music”; and archival scenes from “Hay Fever,” with Maggie Smith, and “Richard III,” with Ian McKellen. Joan Plowright, married for nearly 30 years to Olivier, recreates her Saint Joan on the stage of the Old Vic, home of the original National Theater.

headline: Ralph Waite, Depression-Era Patriarch in ‘The Waltons,’ Dies at 85
abstract: An acting assignment to “pick up a couple of bucks” turned into a nine-year job for Mr. Waite on one of America’s most popular television series.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Waite, a multifaceted actor who became etched in television history as the craggy-faced, big-hearted patriarch of a rustic Depression-era clan on the popular 1970s dramatic series “The Waltons,” died on Thursday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 85.

lead_paragraph: Howie Rose and Josh Lewin will return as the Mets’ radio team as the games shift to WOR-AM from WFAN-AM and FM. The announcement that they will still call the Mets took a while; the team revealed its move to WOR in November. The Yankees moved to WFAN from WCBS-AM.

headline: When Senator Kefauver Inspired the Scripts
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: “The Miami Story,” “New York Confidential” and “Hoodlum Empire” were among several films that took their story lines from the Senate hearings into organized crime in the early 1950s.
lead_paragraph: A sonorous introduction by a United States senator, location shots of a major American city taken over by “the syndicate,” didactic demonstrations of criminal power and an action-packed denouement in which the vaguely Latin vice lord is dispatched by a representative of the law: “The Miami Story” (1954), briskly directed by Fred F. Sears, a prolific specialist in juvenile delinquency scare films and sci-fi cheapsters — and a new manufactured-on-demand release from Sony Pictures — is a classic example of the Kefauver policier.

In this installation for India Ink, Ms. Gupta and Ms. Steinem visit Patna, Bihar state’s capital, and Forbesgunge, a small town on the border of India and Nepal, in Bihar.

headline: Do Kids Need Recess?
abstract: Is recess just for elementary school students, or should students in middle school — or even high school — have some form of recess or unstructured time?
lead_paragraph: Recess is one period in the day that many students don’t want to miss. Yet with all the pressures on increasing test scores, schools have cut back on the amount of time that kids get to be kids. Plus, teachers sometimes use recess as a privilege that can be taken away if students don’t behave. Of course, children hate to lose recess — but should the rest of us worry?

headline: The Self-Reflecting Pool
abstract: Swimming may well be that last refuge from connectivity — and, for some, the only way to find the solitary self.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Late last year, a designer and a geographer who met at M.I.T. revealed that they’d spent much of 2013 mapping every single swimming pool in Los Angeles — 43,123 of them, to be exact. Their satellite photos documented all the little aquamarine ovals and rectangles in a huge 74-book project called “The Big Atlas of L.A. Pools.” Though the cultural conversation mostly revolved around how unsettlingly easy it was for them to locate and discover personal details relating to each pool’s owner — address, property value, even sex-offender status — I found myself fantasizing instead about disappearing, and using those pools to do it.

headline: For Snowbound Elderly in Suburbs, a Season of Isolation
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Elderly', 'Home Health Care']
abstract: Unrelenting snow has left some elderly and infirm in the towns just outside New York City unable to get out of their homes, and treacherous roads have made it hard to reach them.
lead_paragraph: YONKERS — On Thursday morning, Tambudzai Marino, a nurse who makes house calls for the Visiting Nurse Service of Westchester, was weaving and skidding her car around icy, slushy mounds on clogged highways and unplowed side streets, even braving the hills of this Hudson River city, then getting stuck and reversing gears and finding flatter routes, finally slogging by foot along the last quarter-mile. All so she could change bandages on Selwyn Weston’s ulcerated right foot.

headline: Customer Service, Chinese Style

lead_paragraph: I have never written a bad online review of a business. If something about a company’s product or service seems out of character to me, I try to speak directly to management, because that’s how I like customers to deal with my business.

headline: The Pitfalls of Publishing Books in India

abstract: The publishing industry says books are often quashed because of the ambiguous language of laws, the protracted process of Indian courts and the government’s tendency to bow to threats of violence from extremist groups.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — In withdrawing “The Hindus: An Alternative History,” by the American scholar Wendy Doniger, Penguin Books India joined a long line of publishers that have pulled contentious books from the Indian market — a decision that they say has more to do with systemic problems in the country than a lack of commitment to freedom of expression.

headline: The Milk Carton Kids Tune Out an Auto-Tuned World
abstract: With a backdrop of the city’s lights, the Milk Carton Kids performed their folk music Wednesday night in New York.
lead_paragraph: There is something almost unnatural about the mellifluous harmonies of the Milk Carton Kids, something freakish. It’s hard to believe that two people can sync to each other like that. They did not, after all, spring from the same womb like the Everly Brothers or even from the same corner of Queens like Simon and Garfunkel. In fact, Joey Ryan and Kenneth Pattengale did not find each other until fairly recently, after they were already performing as independent artists, a yin and a yang seeking each other out through the chaos.

abstract: Jos. A. lead_paragraph: JOS. A. BANK TO BUY PARENT OF EDDIE BAUER  |  Jos. A. Bank Clothiers said Friday morning that it had agreed to buy the parent company of Eddie Bauer in a deal valued at $825 million, including cash and debt. The purchase of Eddie Bauer, which comes amid the monthslong merger battle between Jos. A. Bank and Men’s Wearhouse, will be done with a combination of $564 million in cash and approximately 4.7 million new shares of common stock of Jos. A. Bank.

Period. That’s what’s going to animate him and animate the team. That was our campaign message, and we did not swerve from it. And we were elected on it. Now we just have to fulfill the mandate.

headline: The Existential Anguish of the Tattoo
abstract: As your ink settles (and stretches) into middle age, it brings with it terrifying implications about free will.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere between the release of “Reality Bites” and the closing of MTV’s sports bureau, my generation got tattoos. We were not the first Americans to do so, but we were the first to do it en masse. Now, two decades later, we are becoming the first to carry them into middle age. It turns out tattoos are permanent, even when little else is.

headline: Fearing a Shootout at the E.R. Corral
abstract: Withholding medical treatment vs. risking the safety of bystanders.
lead_paragraph: My emergency unit handled a man who had been shot in the leg in the early hours of the morning. The trauma surgeons refused to have him transferred to the ward for wound management because they believed the victim would be pursued by his assailants, thereby posing a safety risk to staff members and patients. The police in the E.R. declined to pat down the injured man for weapons, as they were not legally empowered to do so. The man was retained in emergency for 12 hours. The emergency unit, which has an open-door policy for all comers 24/7, would most likely be the first place that assailants would look for an injured man. Are there ethical ramifications with the transfer of violent risk? JOSEPH TING, BRISBANE, AUSTRALIA

headline: Who Made That Pop-Up Ad?
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'E-Commerce', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Breaking free of branded banners.
lead_paragraph: When Brendan Eich set out to liven up the Internet in the spring of 1995, online ads were always banners: branded rectangles tucked into a home page. But over a 10-day stretch that May, Eich, a Netscape programmer and an amateur gymnast, worked up a new way to program on the web. Where pages had been inert and clogged with text, they now had wiggle room, and it was thanks to Eich’s language — called JavaScript. Elements could slide around or blink in response to user input. New windows could pop open on their own.

headline: What to Wear to My Gay Wedding
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Parenting', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: My mother wasn’t always happy about my life choices, but she knew me better than I thought.
lead_paragraph: The last time I wore a bow in my hair, I was 10 years old. It was 1961, and my cousin was getting married. My mother insisted I wear the bow and a tight frilly dress. The crinoline slip scratched my thighs. When I sneezed, the belt buckle broke.

headline: Reply All: The 2.2.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE SUPER BOWL OF SPORTS GAMBLING

headline: At Open-Mike Night, Anything Goes
abstract: Documenting New York’s “last vestiges of bohemianism.”
lead_paragraph: When the artist Jen Miller first started hosting “Reverend Jen’s Anti-Slam” in the mid-’90s, 100 people on a given night might have experienced anything from a comedy act to a primal-scream interpretive dance. These days, at a smaller venue on the Lower East Side called Old Man Hustle, the pool of audience members and participants might be 30 (though many now know one another). Miller, who considers her open-mike nights “the last vestiges of bohemianism in downtown New York,” attributes the decline to gentrification and the Internet, where people can more easily get their fix of performance art by up-and-comers. “There isn’t the incentive that we had in the ’90s to get out the door and actually do something.” But for Daniel Gallant, director of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe, which introduced open mikes in 1973, social media has been a boon: “The performances generate more viral activity online,” he says. Amy Kellner

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Stake in Malone’s Liberty Interactive
abstract: Jana Partners, the $8 billion hedge fund run by Barry Rosenstein, has bought 5.5 percent of John C. Malone’s Liberty Interactive, which owns the home-shopping channel QVC.
lead_paragraph: Jana Partners, the $8 billion hedge fund run by Barry Rosenstein, has taken a 5.5 percent stake in John C. Malone’s Liberty Interactive, which owns the home-shopping channel QVC and digital brands including TripAdvisor, Evite and Bodybuilding.com.

keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Olympic Games', 'Science and Technology', 'Seasons and Months', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Weather', 'Winter (Season)']

lead_paragraph: Updated below | There’s a noteworthy letter in today’s edition of the journal Science, titled “Global Warming and This Winter’s Cold Weather,” that aims to cut through the flood of overwrought assertions about recent Northern Hemisphere winter weather in the context of global warming.

headline: Rent Check
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Rents have declined across Manhattan over the past few months, and vacancies are up. But that has not stopped some ambitious rental projects.
lead_paragraph: Condos, condos, condos. Sometimes they seem to be all that anybody talks about.

headline: A Parodist Who Calls Himself Hanksy
abstract: Mashing up pop culture with acclaimed graffiti work by the street artist Banksy, an artist is straddling the line between mainstream humor and an underground scene.
lead_paragraph: This is a story about art in the age of social media — about anonymity and self-promotion, about feral cats and viral cat videos.

headline: Movie Review: 'About Last Night'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "About Last Night."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "About Last Night."

headline: ‘A Classic Case of Bullying’ on the Dolphins, Report Finds
abstract: An independent report into bullying accusations in Miami concluded that the taunting extended beyond the players Jonathan Martin and Richie Incognito.
lead_paragraph: On the Miami Dolphins’ practice field, players simulated sexual acts as they taunted a teammate about his sister. In the team’s hallways and meeting rooms, racist epithets and homophobic language flowed. One coach gave an offensive lineman an inflatable male doll as part of his Christmas stocking stuffer. Many of the Dolphins knew, but did not say or do anything.

headline: Snapshots of Hanksy’s Short-Lived Work
abstract: Hanksy, a street graffiti artist, is known for mashing up images of celebrity faces with silly puns. His fans online have been his strongest promoters.
lead_paragraph: Hanksy’s start as a street artist began when he downloaded a Banksy painting of a rat holding a paint roller and added an image of the actor Tom Hanks. He mashed the two together, pasted the cutout on a wall on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, signed it Hanksy and took a photograph of it to share. The image was an overnight hit on social media, and Mr. Hanks liked it, too.

headline: Movie Review: 'Winter's Tale'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Winter's Tale."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Winter's Tale."

headline: Tom Perkins, Defender of the 1% Once Again
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Tom Perkins has become the leading spokesman for the wealthy and privileged of Silicon Valley. If the tech world cannot come up with a better champion, it is in big trouble.
lead_paragraph: Like many semifamous people, Tom Perkins has publicly wondered how he will be remembered. As the venture capitalist who helped start Silicon Valley? As the extremely rich guy who built the most awesome sailing yacht of the era? Or even — although this is a long shot — as the author of the supremely trashy novel “Sex and the Single Zillionaire?”

headline: Movie Review: 'RoboCop'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "RoboCop."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "RoboCop."

headline: Today in Small Business: Weather!
abstract: Morning rituals. How to hire interns legally. Do most founders make bad chief executives?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

headline: Police Fatally Shoot 8 After What China Calls a Terrorist Attack
abstract: Official news accounts said the assailants, armed with bombs made from gas cylinders, attacked the police in the ethnically divided Xinjiang region.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The police in Xinjiang, the ethnically divided region in far western China, fatally shot eight people on Friday after what the state-run news media described as an attack by assailants armed with bombs made from gas cylinders. Three other attackers died in an explosion they set off, the reports said.

headline: New Guests (and Actors) Headed to ‘Downton Abbey’
abstract: Richard E. Grant and Anna Chancellor are among the additional cast members next season.
lead_paragraph: Good thing there are so many rooms at Downton Abbey, because that famous (if fictitious) Yorkshire estate will be receiving a few new visitors in its fifth season, which is currently being filmed in Britain.

headline: Friends of Bill de Blasio
abstract: The mayor seemed perplexed when reporters demanded to know why he’d called a high-ranking police official to ask about a friend who had been arrested.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio seemed perplexed on Thursday when the Q. and A. at a news conference about snow turned into a blizzard of tough questions about why he had called a high-ranking police official to ask about a friend and supporter of his who had been arrested.

headline: Beware the End-of-Year 401(k) Match
keywords: ['Retirement', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: So-called last-day rules allow a company to put its 401(k) contribution on the last day of the year, which deprives employees of some benefits.
lead_paragraph: AOL’s chief executive, Tim Armstrong, drew plenty of attention earlier this month when he seemed to attribute a change in the company’s 401(k) plan in part to a couple of employees whose infants required expensive care. But what was mostly lost in the discussion was just how much it would cost employees if every employer tried to do what AOL did.

headline: What I Love | Anna Trigiani
abstract: A visit to the West Village townhouse of the best-selling author and movie director.
lead_paragraph: A visit to the West Village townhouse of the best-selling author and movie director.

headline: Adriana Trigiani Follows the Map of Her Heart
abstract: Adriana Trigiani lives where many of her novels are set, in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: Adriana Trigiani considers herself extraordinarily lucky. She owns a four-story brick 1838 townhouse in the West Village, where she has lived since 1996. Her duplex apartment has a parlor floor with high ceilings, two fireplaces, period molding and a lower level that opens onto a private garden. She rents the upstairs duplex to her best friend, Michael Patrick King, a former “Sex and the City” writer and a creator of the TV show “2 Broke Girls.”

headline: Comcast Deal Shakes Up Adviser Rankings
abstract: Morgan Stanley, which advised Time Warner Cable, jumped ahead of competitors. Comcast’s advisers included James B. Lee Jr., JPMorgan Chase’s top deal maker.
lead_paragraph: Comcast’s $45.2 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable has shaken up a ranking of the biggest deal makers.

headline: Image of the Day: February 14
abstract: A man delivering roses on Valentine’s Day in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: The Valentine’s Day Treaty
abstract: Could Elijah Steele’s 1864 vision for settler-Indian compromise in the Pacific Northwest have averted the Indian Wars?
lead_paragraph: Elijah Steele knew he wasn’t authorized to negotiate an Indian treaty. As a lawyer, a judge, a former Wisconsin state senator, a founding settler of Siskiyou County, Calif., and the agent of Indian affairs for the Northern District of California, he was well aware of the protocols established by the United States Constitution. But Washington, D.C., was far away, and the nation was in the grip of civil war. And besides, on Feb. 14, 1864, Valentine’s Day, several hundred Klamath Basin Indians, much to his surprise, were camped outside his home in Yreka.

headline: Big Ticket | Two Floors of Flourishes for $23.4 Million
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A 10-room penthouse duplex with a pair of terraces on the Upper East Side was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A duplex penthouse with a pair of private terraces at 135 East 79th Street, a 19-story brick and limestone condominium developed by the Brodsky Organization, sold for $23,419,750 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Glorious Vienna, Warts and All
abstract: Not everything will be festive in a three-week New York celebration, Vienna, City of Dreams; the bleaker aspects of its history will be examined in some detail.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall’s imminent festival, Vienna, City of Dreams, promises to be one of the most lavish in its rich history: a three-week citywide celebration with more than 50 events, anchored by five programs from the Vienna Philharmonic and two concert operas from that orchestra’s parent company, the Vienna State Opera, at Carnegie. A broad representation of Viennese music from the 18th to the 21st centuries will range from Strauss family waltzes and other froth to those cathartically harrowing operas Richard Strauss’s “Salome” and Alban Berg’s “Wozzeck.”

headline: A Reader’s Hunting Guide
abstract: Madonna’s “Sex” tops a list of the most sought-after books currently out of print.
lead_paragraph: The search engine BookFinder.com has issued its annual list of the 100 most sought-after titles currently out of print, and no bookshelf could possibly offer a more diverse selection.

headline: Futuristic Thrillers
abstract: New books by Jeff VanderMeer, Adam Sternbergh and Paulette Jiles.
lead_paragraph: ANNIHILATION

headline: Times Minute | Why Fallon Moved Up
abstract: Also on the Minute, a novel solution to China's pollution problem and can chocolate really hurt dogs?
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, a novel solution to China's pollution problem and can chocolate really hurt dogs?

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Robin Cook’s “Cell,” No. 11 on the hardcover fiction list, may be the first thriller to open with an entire paragraph about insulin molecules.
lead_paragraph: The Doctor Will Thrill You Now: Like a lot of brand-name novelists, Robin Cook drops a new book every year or two — in Cook’s case, medical thrillers with punchy, ominous titles like “Outbreak,” “Terminal” or “Contagion” that invariably land on the list. His latest, “Cell” (new at No. 11), is his 28th hardcover best seller since “Coma” made his reputation in 1977. Cook started his career as a practicing doctor, but eventually devoted himself more and more to writing, where the malpractice premiums are presumably lower. From the start, he has applied himself studiously to his craft. “It’s easier to get a book published if it’s going to be a best seller,” he told an interviewer in 1977, “so I went back to some old New York Times best-seller lists and tried to find books that came from theretofore unknown writers, to try to determine what kind of book had the best chances of making the list. I found the mystery-thriller genre seemed to do this best.” If that approach seems more robotic than inspired, well, so can Cook’s prose — “Cell” may be the first thriller to open with an entire paragraph about insulin molecules. (“Rapidly infiltrating the veins, they rushed headlong into the heart, to be pumped out through the arteries.”) Then again, Cook doesn’t make great claims for himself as a writer. “I’m a storyteller,” he told the CBS reporter Don Dahler earlier this month. “I have never been tempted to wear a turtleneck — big turtleneck, white turtleneck. I don’t drink.”

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE DISPENSABLE NATION: American Foreign Policy in Retreat,  by Vali Nasr. (Anchor, $16.) This is an astute, nonideological analysis of the weaknesses of United States foreign policy under President Obama. Nasr, a former senior adviser to Ambassador Richard C. Holbrooke, sheds light on the infighting between the White House and the State Department, and argues that, from North Africa to Afghanistan and Pakistan, diplomatic efforts have been crippled by the administration’s fear of political reprisals and the specter of terrorism.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: DEPT. OF SPECULATION,  by Jenny Offill. (Knopf, $22.95.) Building its story from fragments, observations, meditations and different points of view, Offill’s cannily paced second novel charts the course of a marriage.

headline: Times Minute | Why Fallon Moved Up
abstract: Behind Jimmy Fallon’s promotion to the ‘Tonight’ show. Also on the Minute, a novel solution to China’s pollution problem and can chocolate really hurt dogs?
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Women of a Certain Era
abstract: Two books examine the lives of outrageous female celebrities of the 1920s.
lead_paragraph: “I find life quite impossible,” wrote Nancy Cunard, the English heiress famous in the 1920s for her fashionable excess, “as I cannot enjoy a thing without carrying it to all the extremes and then nearly dying of the reaction.” She wasn’t the only one blowing past her limits during that risky era, but as Judith Mackrell puts it in “Flappers: Six Women of a Dangerous Generation,” she was an audacious female forerunner preceding a “collective surge in expectation.” Women on the verge demanded more from life than marriage and motherhood. Joining Cunard in her restless experimentation were the outrageous actress Tallulah Bankhead, the brazen aristocrat Diana Cooper, the electrifying jazz dancerJosephine Baker, the Polish-Russian painter Tamara de Lempicka and America’s über-flapper, Zelda Fitzgerald. They shared an edgy ambition and a taste for immoderation that led them crashing through the public psyche, sometimes brilliantly, sometimes not, but always on toward emancipation — or at least on to the next great party. As Mackrell demonstrates so elegantly, their collective defiance redefined the feminine possible.

headline: To Kill a King
abstract: A stolen manuscript prophesies the assassination of Richard II in Bruce Holsinger’s novel.
lead_paragraph: In London last year, workers on Crossrail, a huge construction project tunneling a new rail network under the city, made a macabre discovery below Charterhouse Square: a burial pit dating from the period of the Black Death. Archaeologists were ecstatic. Such bones could reveal, one of them explained, “a snapshot of the population from the 14th century” — clues about what people ate and how they lived as well as how they died.

headline: Child, Slave, Soldier
abstract: Susan Minot’s novel tells converging stories about Joseph Kony’s young victims and an American journalist in Africa.
lead_paragraph: In March 2012, a small American charity based in San Diego posted a video online about the Ugandan rebel Joseph Kony, leader of the Lord’s Resistance Army. Within days, the video had 100 million hits, making it one of the most viral videos in history.

headline: Where Was I?
abstract: Two “memoirs of amnesia” discuss their writers’ sense of separation from themselves.
lead_paragraph: A memoir of amnesia is a paradox. To write an autobiography, one must be able to consult one’s past. But what happens when that history is obliterated? The experience of such loss and the hard-won reclamation of identity form the bases of two new books. One is by a young man whose amnesia was a side effect of a prescribed medication. The other is by a young woman who sustained a devastating head wound.

headline: Bodily Harm
abstract: In Harry Bingham’s “Love Story, With Murders,” Fiona Griffiths is still spending quality time in the morgue.
lead_paragraph: When she surfaced in Harry Bingham’s “Talking to the Dead,” Fiona Griffiths was a rookie on the South Wales police force who had more psychological quirks — including a disconcerting habit of spending quality time in the morgue — than most of the head cases she met in the line of duty. But the intensity she brought to the job made her a most intriguing, if peculiar, detective.

headline: It’s the Economy
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Books and Literature', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A historian argues that America’s supposed racial problems are in fact caused by economic exploitation.
lead_paragraph: Americans have struggled mightily since the nation’s birth to overcome racial prejudice. Recently, as symbolized by President Obama’s ascendancy and his message of racial reconciliation, we have basically succeeded and are now healing from our racial wounds. Or so the story goes. In “A Dreadful Deceit,” the distinguished historian Jacqueline Jones vehemently rejects this redemptive and self-congratulatory narrative. She believes that the country’s racial problems have little to do with racism and everything to do with economic exploitation. And, she claims, we have not even begun to come to terms with this.

headline: Ad Infinitum
abstract: An M.I.T. physicist takes a speculative look at space, time and the possibility of parallel universes.
lead_paragraph: Halfway into his new book, “Our Mathematical Universe,” the M.I.T. physicist Max Tegmark describes his “Dr. Jekyll/Mr. Hyde Strategy”: During the day he would do respectable work on mainstream topics in cosmology, but at night he would “transform into the evil Mr. Hyde” and indulge in writing “wacky” papers on “the ultimate nature of reality.”

headline: The Prophets’ Prophet
abstract: Shai Held examines the theology of Abraham Joshua Heschel against the background of contemporary thinkers.
lead_paragraph: Look at the famous pictures of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. marching on Selma, Ala., in 1965. In one of them you’ll see a man in big glasses two people to King’s left who looks halfway between Leon Trotsky and Santa Claus. That’s Abraham Joshua Heschel. From his perch at the Jewish Theological Seminary of New York, the Warsaw-born rabbi cast a long shadow over American Jewry, especially its Conservative variant, during the quarter-­century after World War II. He also became a byword for American Jewish social-justice activism — most of all for the alliance between Jews and blacks.

headline: Skills Practice | Cause and Effect
abstract: Use reporting on the weather at the Sochi Olympics and around the U.S. this winter to practice the skill of identifying cause and effect.
lead_paragraph: The Winter Olympics are supposed to be all about snow, ice and bulky parkas, right?

headline: Snowbound
abstract: In Karen Foxlee’s novel, set in a strange, wintry city, an unlikely heroine discovers an imprisoned boy who asks for her help.
lead_paragraph: It happens all the time in children’s literature: Beloved parents die, and their sons and daughters have to come to terms with their loss. In Karen Foxlee’s “Ophelia and the Marvelous Boy,” this premise is explored in an original and fantastical manner, as Foxlee (“The Anatomy of Wings,” “The Midnight Dress”) deftly borrows and transforms elements from Hans Christian Andersen’s “The Snow Queen.”

headline: A Port in the Storm
abstract: Trapped in New Orleans during Hurricane Katrina, this novel’s young hero teams up with an aging musician and a feisty girl.
lead_paragraph: Most of Rodman Philbrick’s new middle-grade novel, “Zane and the Hurricane,” is set in a battered green canoe floating on the oily sea that covered New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. The story is narrated by Zane Dupree, a mixed-race 12-year-old boy living contentedly in New Hampshire until his mother’s fateful discovery of the sole living relative on his father’s side, Miss Trissy.

headline: Kerry Says Obama Wants New Options for Syria Strife
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry, visiting China, said President Obama had asked aides to develop new policy options for dealing with the Syria conflict.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday that President Obama had asked aides to develop new policy options to deal with the deteriorating situation in Syria.

headline: Varieties of Loss
abstract: How to teach children about the violent past or the pain of abandonment? Three picture books offer some tools.
lead_paragraph: How does one teach children about the violence of history? How does one teach them to confront loss in the present day? Three new books take on these challenging tasks in the context of African-­American lives.

headline: Being Green
abstract: In Andrew Smith’s novel, a sexually confused 16-year-old chronicles the world’s demise brought on by praying mantises.
lead_paragraph: “Grasshopper Jungle” is two for one. On one level, it is a darkly comic story about the end of the world. The book’s narrator and protagonist — 16-year-old Austin Szerba, of the fictional town of Ealing, Iowa — accidentally unleashes an infestation of six-foot-tall praying mantises, products of a scientific experiment gone kookily awry. With exoskeletons “as tough as the exterior hull of an aircraft carrier” and razor-sharp barbs on their arms, the bugs are killing machines invulnerable to bullets, and they set about devouring humanity. The praying mantises are perpetually horny as well as ravenous, able to smell a mate four miles away, breeding ceaselessly while slaughtering everything in their path. The earth is consumed by implacable forces and mindless appetite.

headline: Big Crowds for De La Soul’s Online Buffet
abstract: An offer of free downloads of the group’s music seems to have overwhelmed capacity.
lead_paragraph: De La Soul may have underestimated the public’s interest in its music, or at least in getting it free. On Thursday, the hip-hop group announced a plan to offer seven of their albums for free downloading for a limited time, from 11 a.m. on Friday to Saturday at noon, Eastern Standard Time.

headline: Nods to Haiti and Other Traditions
abstract: New albums this week include offerings from Angel Olsen, Supreme Cuts and two with heavy Haitian influences.
lead_paragraph: Angel Olsen

headline: TV the Old Way: Watching What’s On
abstract: Forsaking his library of recorded episodes, a viewer finds that a random spree across the channels delivers its own pleasures.
lead_paragraph: Picture it: a cold, quiet night in December, little to do. On the television screen is the channel guide, a sea of possibility and a tantalizing burden. Scroll. Scroll. Scroll. Finally, a show with a title too blunt to resist: “Mega Shredders.”

headline: Step by Step, Into a New Dance Realm
abstract: “Rejoice in the Lamb,” part of a trio of Britten-themed work, showcases the craftsmanship of the choreographer Richard Alston.
lead_paragraph: CANTERBURY, England — “I hope you like steps,” said the choreographer Richard Alston in a talk before the performance of his new piece, “Rejoice in the Lamb,” here Wednesday. “Because there are a lot of them.”

headline: All by Herself, Friends Invited
abstract: Vanessa Anspaugh is a choreographer who has been steadily creating work in New York since 2006.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Anspaugh is a choreographer who has been steadily creating work in New York since 2006. But until now, with the premiere of “we were an island” at St. Mark’s Church, she has not had an evening-length program to herself. Her broad imagination and distinctive cast — Niv Acosta, Addys Gonzalez, Bessie McDonough-Thayer, Eleanor Smith and Jesse White — should be more than able to command the space alone.

headline: How ‘Let It Go’ Upended the ‘Frozen’ Plot
abstract: The songwriters gave Elsa, a villain in the original fairyt ale, a moment of self-acceptance, and the screenwriter says when she heard that, she knew she had to rewrite.
lead_paragraph: There is little stopping the momentum of “Let It Go,” the hit song from Disney’s blockbuster “Frozen.” The recording, by Idina Menzel, who voices the icy-but-thawing older sister Elsa in the movie, was certified platinum this week – that means at least a million sales – and the Academy also announced that Ms. Menzel was to perform it at the Oscars, where it is the favorite to win the prize for best song. The soundtrack, too, has been at or near the top of the charts for weeks.

headline: The World’s Best (Unaltered) Photos
abstract: World Press Photo announced the winners of its 2013 contest while its judges lamented the proliferation of digital alterations, which disqualified several top contenders.
lead_paragraph: Feb. 16 | Updated at bottom.

headline: Voices That Double as Camouflage
abstract: Pop listeners can consider their own reactions at two concerts featuring men who sound like women: Mike Milosh of the duo Rhye, and the Israeli songwriter Asaf Avidan.
lead_paragraph: Psychologists, biologists and literary critics have long pondered the complex signals sent by an androgynous voice: of brave boundary crossing and lonely vulnerability, of idiosyncratic individuality and gender-bending camouflage. Pop listeners can consider their own reactions at two concerts featuring men who sound like women: Mike Milosh of the duo Rhye, and the Israeli songwriter Asaf Avidan. Rhye — Mr. Milosh and Robin Hannibal — has come the long way around, via more abstract electronic music, to a comforting, if shallow, facsimile of the pop-R&B ballads of the early 1980s. (8 p.m., Friday, Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, 212-353-1600, websterhall.com.)

headline: No Rest for a Tenor
abstract: Jonas Kaufmann may be the finest all-around tenor in the business right now, certainly the most sought after.
lead_paragraph: Most tenors, just two days after singing the demanding title role of Massenet’s “Werther” in a new production at the Metropolitan Opera, would still be resting up. Not Jonas Kaufmann, who may be the finest all-around tenor in the business right now, certainly the most sought after.

headline: Grand Transport, as Envisioned
abstract: Preservationists get a chance to mourn all over again on Tuesday night, when PBS revisits the grand, sad story of the original Pennsylvania Station in an episode of “American Experience.”
lead_paragraph: Preservationists get a chance to mourn all over again on Tuesday night, when PBS revisits the grand, sad story of the original Pennsylvania Station in an episode of “American Experience.” The program, “The Rise and Fall of Penn Station,” conveys just how brash was the vision of Alexander Cassatt, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, when he decided late in the 19th century that he was no longer content to have the company’s lines stop in New Jersey. He would, he decided, extend them into Manhattan and out to Long Island via tunnels under the rivers. And he would have those lines converge in a lavish station.

headline: An Art Movement, Warts and All
abstract: Futurism is a tricky subject for curators because of the movement’s ties to fascism.
lead_paragraph: Futurism is a tricky subject for curators because of the movement’s ties to fascism. Museums tend to show pre-World War I works that exemplify “heroic Futurism,” the Boccioni sculptures and Balla paintings that glorify speed and dynamism, while ignoring the violence and nationalism of later Futurist art. But “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe,” opening Friday at the Guggenheim Museum, surveys this thrilling but troubled period in Italian art from beginning to end.

headline: Old World Meets New
abstract: The Danish Athletic Club, long a haven for Scandinavian immigrants in Brooklyn and now struggling with declining membership, is getting a lift from immigrants from Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The Danish Athletic Club, long a haven for Scandinavian immigrants in Brooklyn and now struggling with declining membership, is getting a lift from immigrants from Mexico.

headline: Polish Cinema on Display
abstract: Kino Polska: New Polish Cinema, a five-day series of nine recent Polish films presented by BAMcinématek, opens on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Kino Polska: New Polish Cinema, a five-day series of nine recent Polish films presented by BAMcinématek, opens on Wednesday with “Walesa: Man of Hope,” a biography of the charismatic Polish leader, trade-union organizer and co-founder of the Solidarity movement. Directed by the 87-year-old titan of Polish cinema, Andrzej Wajda (“Ashes and Diamonds”), it stars Robert Wieckiewicz, who portrays Lech Walesa as a firebrand with a big streak of paranoia. A soundtrack of Polish punk rock jacks up the mood of rebellion.

headline: The Xoogler Diaspora
abstract: Among the Google alumni scattered around the globe, several have risen to notable prominence, including as the chief executive of Yahoo and as the man who holds the purse strings at Uber.
lead_paragraph: #bits-xooglers strong { font-family: nyt-franklin, arial, helvetica, sans-serif; }

headline: The Danes’ New Amigos
abstract: As its Scandinavian base has faded, the Danish Athletic Club in Brooklyn has warmly welcomed its newest patrons, the Hispanic community.
lead_paragraph: In the candlelit banquet hall of the Danish Athletic Club, a 120-year-old institution near the border of the Bay Ridge and Sunset Park neighborhoods in Brooklyn, the annual St. Lucia procession is underway, led by a teenage girl crowned with a wreath of candles. Outside on 65th Street a light snow is falling. The auto repair shops and the warehouses bearing signs in Chinese that line this side of the block are shuttered, and across the street the park known as the Dust Bowl is the site of an early-evening soccer match between local Hispanic teams. Toward the corner of Seventh Avenue, the mall-size dim sum mecca East Harbor turns its outdoor lights on, bathing the slick four-lane industrial boulevard in a red and yellow glow.

headline: Financial Stability Board to Examine Currency Markets
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The task force set up by the Group of 20 last year said Friday that it would review foreign exchange markets in light of a series of investigations into potential manipulation of currency benchmarks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Financial Stability Board said Friday that it would review foreign exchange markets in light of a series of investigations into potential manipulation of currency benchmark rates.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Sixth Extinction’
abstract: This week, Elizabeth Kolbert talks about “The Sixth Extinction”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Dave Itzkoff discusses “Mad as Hell,” about the making of the movie “Network”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Elizabeth Kolbert talks about “The Sixth Extinction”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Dave Itzkoff discusses “Mad as Hell,” about the making of the movie “Network”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Obama Announces Aid for Drought-Stricken California
abstract: President Obama announced a push for a $1 billion “climate resilience” program, as well as several million dollars in drought aid for the state’s farmers.
