lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — President Obama arrived in the heart of California’s parched farmland on Friday afternoon to offer tens of millions of dollars in federal assistance to the state, where the lack of rain and snow this winter has led to the severest drought in its modern history.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Sixth Extinction’
abstract: This week, Elizabeth Kolbert and Dave Itzkoff.
lead_paragraph: This week, Elizabeth Kolbert and Dave Itzkoff.

headline: Populist Party Makes Strong Showing in British By-Election
abstract: The upstart U.K. Independence Party finished second, behind Labour, in the race for a vacant parliamentary seat.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s upstart U.K. Independence Party finished second in a by-election for a vacant parliamentary seat in Wythenshawe and Sale East, pushing the governing Conservative Party, led by Prime Minister David Cameron, into third place. The by-election, held Thursday, was won comfortably by the opposition Labour Party. It attracted almost 9,000 votes more than the U.K. Independence Party, which campaigns against immigration and membership of the European Union. The results embarrassed the Conservatives and their coalition allies, the Liberal Democrats, who finished fourth.

headline: Wheelies: The Global Pentastar Edition
abstract: Chrysler will no longer publish North American vehicle production reports; Ford’s aluminum F-150 sparks a run on the aluminum market.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: One Pot of Beans, Four Dinners
abstract: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers new recipes that make use of those bags of beans lying around the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: If you are good about keeping a well-stocked pantry, you probably have some bags of beans lying around. From time to time, check the “best before” date on the bags. Or if you buy in bulk and put the beans into jars, put a little sticker on the jars with the date you purchased the beans. Although dried beans won’t spoil, older beans can become hard and brittle, and sometimes they don’t soften properly when you cook them.

headline: More Reflection, Less Action
abstract: The more complex and demanding the work we do, the wider, deeper and longer the perspective we require to do it well, writes Tony Schwartz in the Life@Work column.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, I found myself talking with the chief of staff to the chief executive at a large company. The two of them had been on the road together for four consecutive weeks. I asked how that felt. “It’s brutal,” he said. “But it’s typical. My boss essentially has no openings on his schedule for the next three months.”

headline: Skiing in My Own Backyard
abstract: For a resident of central Oregon, there’s no need to jet off to the Rockies or the Alps to discover a world of snow.
lead_paragraph: I’d been motoring west across Oregon’s high desert in a jalopy full of holes when at last the snowy volcanoes I was aiming for bubbled up on the horizon. The drive from New Mexico had taken me all night and I was weary, but now the Cascades of central Oregon cut through the pale winter light like a beam. Those peaks would be my new backyard, and I was impatient to play. In the back of my truck bounced three pairs of my favorite skis.

headline: British Marmalade Cake
abstract: Melissa Clark makes butter-rich British marmalade cake topped with icing.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes butter-rich British marmalade cake topped with icing.

headline: Even Good Films May Go to Purgatory
keywords: ['Movies', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Thanks to motion picture copyright laws, a number of well-known films and some excellent obscure ones have ended up in the public domain.
lead_paragraph: They show up in discount DVD bins, or more often today online, sometimes looking a little worse for the wear. A general pall of darkness might cloud the image; the dialogue might be a bit tinnier than you remembered. Often the quality is not too shabby, though in the case of the web, it can be a surprise that they’re online at all. They’re films that have fallen out of copyright for one reason or another and must weather the wilds of the public domain.

headline: Sweetness Is Found in a Slice
abstract: Crumpets may be the highest use of good marmalade, but the next best is to bake it into a marmalade cake.
lead_paragraph: Long before the food revolution in England brought us gastro pubs, Jamie Oliver and the Fat Duck, there was British marmalade.

headline: 36 Hours in Baton Rouge, La.
abstract: It may not be the nonstop party of New Orleans, but Louisiana’s capital city offers plenty, from food to history to the arts.
lead_paragraph: Louisiana’s capital has neither the nonstop party scene nor the obvious cultural charm of its more celebrated neighbor to the southeast, yet this laid-back Mississippi River town offers a unique appeal. The French, Spanish, Creole and Cajun influences of its three-century history blend with the youthful spirit of Louisiana State University’s nearly 30,000 students, stewing up a Southern mélange that’s on full display during Baton Rouge’s own Mardi Gras celebrations, through March 1, as well as events like the Baton Rouge Blues Festival (April 12). Along rural roads and in revitalized downtown neighborhoods, inside strip malls and by industrial sites, this unheralded city reveals a dynamic musical heritage and rich culinary history that demand to be discovered.

headline: Welcome Words: Why The Times Bucked the Government on a Drone Strike Story
abstract: Newly appointed Washington bureau chief wants to “give readers as much information as possible” on a possible lethal strike against an American in Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: The United States is considering a drone strike to kill an American with alleged terrorist ties. That’s a pretty big deal – shocking to those of us who haven’t become completely inured to such news.

headline: For Two Snowboarders, the Calm After the Fall
abstract: Danny Davis and Greg Betz found what they love about snowboarding a few days after their Olympic runs ended in disappointment.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Danny Davis made his own jump, carving it out of a deep, crusty shelf of snow with the edges of his snowboard. He angled the ramp skyward, smoothed it, gave it a final look and hiked back up the hill.

headline: Zachary Catazaro Named a Soloist at New York City Ballet
abstract: Mr. Catazaro joined the corps de ballet at New York City Ballet in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Zachary Catazaro, a dancer who came to the New York City Ballet as an apprentice in 2007 and joined the corps de ballet in 2008, has been promoted to soloist, the company announced on Friday. Peter Martins, the company’s ballet master in chief, informed Mr. Catazaro about the promotion after rehearsals on Thursday.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Sixth Extinction’
abstract: Elizabeth Kolbert talks about mass extinctions, and Dave Itzkoff discusses “Mad as Hell,” his book about the making of the movie “Network.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Al Gore reviews Elizabeth Kolbert’s “The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History.” Mr. Gore writes:

headline: Racial Discrimination in Renting?
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Also addressed: Property easements and a problem with a broken key in a rental.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: The Greatest Film Role Ever Cast
abstract: Filmmakers try to find a Jesus who is a solemn soul, matinee idol, conflicted Messiah and now a hottie on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: When the matinee idol Jeffrey Hunter starred in the 1961 version of “King of Kings,” snarkier critics called it “I Was a Teenage Jesus.” When “The Last Temptation of Christ” played Paris in 1988, with Willem Dafoe as a conflicted Messiah, the theater was firebombed. In both “The Robe” (1953) and “Ben-Hur” (1959), Jesus was a character, but his face was never seen — out of respect, perhaps, but maybe out of caution, too.

headline: Cuomo Offers de Blasio Support, With Barbs
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo defended Mayor Bill de Blasio’s move to open schools in a snowstorm, but mocked his “two cities” mantra.
lead_paragraph: In politics, friendship can be a complicated thing.

headline: China Reports Another Case of New Bird Flu Strain
abstract: Chinese officials said the new strain of avian influenza, H10N8, has killed a second person, according to Xinhua, the state news agency.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese officials have said a new strain of avian influenza, H10N8, has killed another person, according to a report on Friday by Xinhua, the state news agency. The victim was a 75-year-old man living in Nanchang, the capital of Jiangxi Province, who entered a hospital on Feb. 4 after falling ill. He died on Feb. 8, Xinhua reported.

headline: Israeli Museum Receives $10 Million in Gifts for New Extension
abstract: The Museum of the Jewish People in Israel has received two large gifts from Americans who support its plan to build a new wing to celebrate synagogues.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of the Jewish People, known as Beit Hatfutsot, in Tel Aviv, has received a pair of $5 million gifts from American philanthropists.

headline: At Retromobile in Paris, Early Record-Setters Roar Again
abstract: A car that set a land-speed record and was restored after a crash that killed its driver in 1927 makes a noisy appearance at a classic-car exhibition in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On March 3, 1927, on a cold, windswept beach in Wales, John G. Parry-Thomas, a working-class engineer, steeled himself to set a land speed record. The year before, he’d pushed the mark to 169 miles per hour, then to 171. But his aristocratic archrival, Sir Malcolm Campbell, reached 174, and just a month later Parry-Thomas was trying to regain the record.

headline: 100 Years Later, Celebrating the Taxis That Saved Paris
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A display at Retromobile included three Renault FT17 tanks, a number of bone-shaking military trucks and two “Marne taxis,” which brought troops to the front during World War I.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The echoes of the guns of August 1914 had barely subsided when France faced its first crisis of World War I. By early September, the German army had moved through Belgium and was within 30 miles of Paris; the French government was preparing to decamp to Bordeaux, and panic spread through the city.

headline: Love and the Fed
abstract: To mark the day, economists and Fed-watchers are taking to Twitter to offer #FedValentines.
lead_paragraph: It’s Valentine’s Day, and economists and Fed-watchers are again waxing poetic on Twitter. Whether inspired by Federal Reserve leaders past and present, or the policies they represent, the ardent declarations are pouring forth, defying those who would say economics is a world without love. Here are some favorites from #FedValentines:

headline: Trade Pact With Asia Faces Imposing Hurdle: Midterm Politics
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. acknowledged that Congress will not grant President Obama fast-track trade promotion authority, which analysts call critical for deals with Asia and Europe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s ambitious trade agenda appeared to fall further victim to election-year politics on Capitol Hill on Friday when Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in a closed-door retreat with House Democrats, said he understood why they would not grant Mr. Obama the crucial authority he needs to conclude large trade deals with Asia and Europe.

headline: A Minister in Germany Steps Down Amid Uproar
abstract: Hans-Peter Friedrich defended his decision to tip off fellow members of the Social Democrats that the police were looking into a colleague.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German agriculture minister, Hans-Peter Friedrich, resigned on Friday after it was revealed that four months ago, as interior minister, he tipped off another senior politician to the criminal investigation of a prominent lawmaker.

headline: Headlines, Happy Meals, and Now Homes
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A reinvention emblematic of the changes afoot in a downtown neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Stepping into the lobby of the Lara, a new luxury rental building in the financial district, a visitor would never know that the site of this 30-story tower had been the birthplace of The New York Times.

headline: Microsoft’s Stakes in the Battle for Handsets
abstract: Trying to ensure the survival of Windows in a mobile universe, Microsoft enters a complex struggle, while Google abandons a money-losing handset unit.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft announced in September that it was buying Nokia’s struggling handset business and would meld its Windows operating system with the devices, it offered two major reasons for the $7.2 billion deal:

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 14
abstract: Figure skating, bobsled and skiing on the ninth day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: Figure skating, bobsled and skiing on the ninth day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Pharrell’s Hat and Karen O’s Brain Tricks
abstract: The best-song nominees taking part in the telecast include the man behind “Happy” and one of the composers of “Moon Song.”
lead_paragraph: It’s the first day of the final round of Oscar voting – a last countdown to the big broadcast.

headline: A Moment of Transparency
abstract: A new kind of transparency is coursing through fashion. From open weaves and sheer fabrics to slashed fringing and laser-print cutouts, each look offers a unique way to expose some skin.
lead_paragraph: A new kind of transparency is coursing through fashion. From open weaves and sheer fabrics to slashed fringing and laser-print cutouts, each look offers a unique way to expose some skin.

headline: Toyota Recalls 261,000 Trucks and S.U.V.’s for Traction Control Malfunction
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A part from a supplier in Ohio failed, according to complaints, leading the automaker to switch to a Japanese part and issue a recall.
lead_paragraph: Toyota is recalling about 261,000 pickups and sport utility vehicles because several electronic safety systems could be disabled, according to a report the automaker posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Change the Way Stock Prices Are Quoted to Help the Economy? The S.E.C. Is Skeptical
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Law and Legislation', 'Start-ups', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: To promote the I.P.O. market and thus job growth, Congress is considering changing the increments in which stock prices are quoted. But research suggests that this move may not accomplish those goals, writes Steven M. Davidoff in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Call it the JOBS Act’s little brother.

headline: In Libya, a Coup. Or Perhaps Not.
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Stealing a page from neighboring Egypt, a senior army officer in Libya announced a military takeover. But no one seemed to be taking him seriously.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Stealing a page from neighboring Egypt, a senior army officer in Libya on Friday announced a military takeover, the suspension of Parliament and a new “road map” for the future.

headline: An App for Diners to Pay Their Bill
abstract: The Cover app allows patrons at 43 New York City restaurants to take care of the check on their phone.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, a new dining app called Cover does something simple: It takes care of the bill. No, this is not a case of persuading Siri to be more generous. Rather, if you go to one of the 43 New York restaurants that support the app, and you tell your server that you are paying with Cover, the back and forth that usually accompanies the payment process disappears.

headline: In New York, a Showcase for Chinese Performers
abstract: A performance series at the Skirball Center in New York will feature dance, opera and theater from China.
lead_paragraph: New York University’s Skirball Center will bring China’s contemporary performing arts scene to New York for three months this year with its second annual Visions and Voices Global Performance series.

headline: The Gun Report: February 14, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: • On Thursday, a federal appeals court in California struck down rules permitting counties to restrict the right to carry a concealed weapon in public, saying that such restrictions violate the Second Amendment. The decision was hailed by gun rights advocates, while gun control supporters described the ruling as aberrant and reckless. The decision will affect populated areas like Los Angeles, San Diego and San Francisco, but the the rules will remain in effect pending appeals. California generally prohibits carrying guns, loaded or not, in public locations. Before the ban was enacted, state courts routinely upheld restrictions on carrying concealed weapons.

headline: ‘The Croods’ Team Can at Least Count on 2 Votes
abstract: The creators of “The Croods” have fully embraced their underdog status.
lead_paragraph: Kirk DeMicco and Chris Sanders, the writer-directors of the DreamWorks animated hit “The Croods,” know that they aren’t favored to beat out Disney’s “Frozen” for the best animated feature Oscar. “It’s the reality that we live with,” Mr. Sanders said, and joked, when asked about his chances: “I’m holding my head in my hands, trying to figure out how to answer that. So many feelings!”

headline: Yuzuru Hanyu of Japan Wins Men’s Figure Skating Gold
abstract: Hanyu, who fled the tsunami and earthquake in Japan in 2011, won the first men’s singles skating gold in his country’s history despite falling during his long program routine.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Yuzuru Hanyu was skating when the devastating earthquake and tsunami struck northeast Japan. He was 16, and he felt the ice rumbling and the ground thrusting and his legs wobbling. He ran from the rink in his skates, with no time even to put on skate guards.

headline: Lead Prosecutor’s Abrupt Departure Rattles a Military Sexual Assault Case
keywords: ['Courts-Martial', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Lt. Col. William Helixon, the Army prosecutor, left the closely watched case less than a month before the scheduled court-martial of Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair on sexual assault charges.
lead_paragraph: The military’s most closely watched sexual misconduct prosecution has been thrown into turmoil after the Army’s lead prosecutor abruptly left the case this week, less than a month before the scheduled court-martial of Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair on sexual assault charges.

headline: A Family Office for the Superrich, and Lessons for the Less Wealthy
abstract: Those who don’t have the millions needed for a private investing office can emulate the management services it provides.
lead_paragraph: STEVEN A. COHEN, the billionaire hedge fund manager, has been in the news for a string of insider trading convictions of current or former portfolio managers at his SAC Capital Advisors. But less attention has been given to his decision to convert his hedge fund into a family office to free himself from Securities and Exchange Commission regulations.

headline: Stretching the Mind and the Body
abstract: Grace Aneiza Ali, who teaches at City College and founded an online arts and activism journal, fills her Sundays with faith and culture, first at church, then on to museums and yoga.
lead_paragraph: When Grace Aneiza Ali moved to New York in 2006 for graduate school, she found herself immersed in a contradiction. There were 140,000 Guyanese immigrants in the city, the fifth-largest foreign-born population. Yet most New Yorkers knew little about her home country, she said. “They know Jim Jones and the Jonestown massacre,” she said. “Or they confuse it with Ghana.” Ms. Ali, 32, now an adjunct professor in the department of interdisciplinary arts and sciences at the City College of New York, has set out to change that — by founding Of Note magazine, an online journal about the arts and social activism; and curating a photography exhibition, “Guyana Modern,” scheduled for Aljira, a Center for Contemporary Art, in Newark in 2015. She lives alone in Harlem, where she worries about becoming too Manhattan-centric.

headline: ‘Are Parents Better Lovers?’
abstract: Now that I’m a mother — a single mother, a dating mother — I have come to believe, tentatively though it be, that the capacity for devotion to a child is a measure of the capacity for devotion to an adult.
lead_paragraph: “You have no room for anyone in your life but your kid,” said an amorous language director last year who ended up hiring instead of bedding me.

headline: A Deal Tailor-Made for Disaster
abstract: Jos. A. Bank is pursuing an ill-conceived $875 million purchase of Eddie Bauer, made worse by a stock buyback plan that will only squander cash, Robert Cyran writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Jos. A. Bank’s daft deal is knitting its shareholders in a bind. To avoid being acquired, or perhaps to fetch a higher price from rival Men’s Wearhouse, the company is issuing stock to buy Eddie Bauer at $56 a share, only to buy more back at $65. If the $875 million transaction isn’t unraveled, investors will find themselves painfully stitched up.

headline: Striking a Lone Star Pose at Betony
abstract: During New York Fashion Week, the two-tiered restaurant was a refuge for fashionistas, including a blogger from Texas.
lead_paragraph: Seeking a refuge from the runways during New York Fashion Week,  industry people flocked to nine-month-old Betony, a two-tiered restaurant on West 57th Street where cozy and trendy blend. Advertising executives from Glamour magazine and Macy’s enjoyed a business dinner with crisp cocktails and glasses of Riesling. Hair salon and boutique owners booked late reservations. Walk-ins landed in the lounge, resting between shows and fortifying themselves with velvety flavors. As food lovers and fashionistas know, it takes hard work to look good; harder work, still, to create great taste.

headline: Twitter, Can You Hear Me Now?
abstract: Everyone wants to be heard, but sometimes so much is too much.
lead_paragraph: O, the cawing and the self-directed cooing. Two recent events on Twitter have breathed new life into the question: At what point does jaunty confidence metastasize into abject bragging?

headline: Driving the Market for a Car Service
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Automobiles', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Uber dictates the comings and goings of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 8 at 7:45 p.m., after the spectacularly weird and amazing Moncler Grenoble presentation at the Hammerstein Ballroom in Midtown Manhattan, fashion editors and fashion show attendees were in a panic. They were running late and had only 45 minutes to make it to a choked-off-from-mass-transit portion of Brooklyn for Alexander Wang’s show at the Navy Yard. On 34th Street, cars idled and fashionistas forcefully marched through snow banks to find their car, or find any car at all.

headline: Activists Raise Stake in Williams Companies and Hire an Adviser
abstract: The two activist hedge funds, Corvex and Soroban Capital looking to spur change at the Williams Companies disclosed on Friday that they have raised their collective stake in the gas pipeline company and have hired Moelis & Company to aid them in their campaign.
lead_paragraph: The two activist hedge funds looking to spur change at the Williams Companies disclosed on Friday that they have raised their collective stake in the gas pipeline company and have hired an investment banker to aid them in their campaign.

headline: Won Tons Are Easily Domesticated
abstract: Making won tons at home is so easy, it almost feels like cheating.
lead_paragraph: Winter does not retreat. Here’s what I want: a table by a fogged-up window, with fat won tons, drizzled with hot pepper oil and stinking of garlic and ginger, bobbing in a huge bowl of steamy broth. Where? Why, at home — where else?

headline: Scenes of Indonesians Fleeing Eruption
abstract: The eruption of Mount Kelud, a volcano in Indonesia, covered villages in ash and forced people to evacuate.
lead_paragraph: The eruption of Mount Kelud, a volcano in Indonesia, covered villages in ash and forced people to evacuate.

headline: Ike Davis in Mets’ Camp With Revamped Swing and Trade Rumors Behind Him
abstract: After enduring a trying season, Davis is trying to reclaim his job as the Mets’ starting first baseman.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — All off-season, family members and friends asked Ike Davis if he was going to be traded. He had heard the rumors and read the newspaper reports. He figured he might be, but no, he told them. His father eventually spoke out about how the Mets were handling the situation. All the while, Davis was busy rehabbing his oblique and working yet again on his swing.

headline: Her Creative Exuberance Has No Limits
abstract: Once Florence Wint was relieved of her homemaking and caretaking duties, she plunged back into creating the art she had wanted to make for decades.
lead_paragraph: Florence Wint scoffs at the stereotype of spending her golden years relaxing.

headline: From Hugo França, Nature Sculpted
abstract: Burned pequi wood left over from deforestation at a rain forest in Brazil gets new life.
lead_paragraph: Hugo França was working as an industrial engineer for a computer company in São Paulo, in his native Brazil, when in 1981, at the age of 26, he moved to Trancoso, in the northeastern coastal area of Bahia, to live among the indigenous Pataxó people. The move was prompted by a love of nature, but it eventually led him to a new career as a wood sculptor.

headline: Studio Visit With Hugo França
abstract: The Brazilian designer Hugo França reclaims felled wood from the rainforest to create sculptural furniture.
lead_paragraph: The Brazilian designer Hugo França reclaims felled wood from the rainforest to create sculptural furniture.

headline: Is the Universe a Simulation?
abstract: If so, that would help explain some mysterious things about math.
lead_paragraph: IN Mikhail Bulgakov’s novel “The Master and Margarita,” the protagonist, a writer, burns a manuscript in a moment of despair, only to find out later from the Devil that “manuscripts don’t burn.” While you might appreciate this romantic sentiment, there is of course no reason to think that it is true. Nikolai Gogol apparently burned the second volume of “Dead Souls,” and it has been lost forever. Likewise, if Bulgakov had burned his manuscript, we would have never known “Master and Margarita.” No other author would have written the same novel.

headline: A Victory for Gay Rights in Virginia, but Opponents Vow to Fight On
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: Supporters celebrated the overturning of Virginia’s ban on same-sex marriage, as opponents condemned the decision as an infringement on states’ rights.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of gay rights celebrated on Friday their latest courtroom victory, the overturning of Virginia’s ban on same-sex marriage, as opponents condemned the decision as an infringement on states’ rights and vowed to take the issue to the Supreme Court.

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Fall/Winter 2014 Men’s Wear Shows in New York
abstract: Our men’s fashion director shares his favorites from the runways in New York.
lead_paragraph: Though New York Fashion Week is still officially focused on women’s clothing, in the men’s wear business, designers are increasingly making their own rules. Many presented their fall/winter 2014 collections days before the official start of the season in the Big Apple, while others snuck their men’s designs onto the runway alongside those for the ladies. Regardless of when, where or how the clothes were introduced, though, it was undeniably a week of great men’s fashion filled with wearable, updated takes on the sportswear for which the American men’s market is best known.

headline: In the Church of Difficult Music
abstract: The Stone is a landmark site for avant-garde and experimental music, and its sparse interior directs all the focus on the musicians.
lead_paragraph: They trickled in to an anonymous, mostly shuttered storefront on a rugged corner at Avenue C and Second Street, prompting occasional confusion from pedestrians walking by. They were entering a place of almost spartan simplicity: a dimly lit chamber with a brick wall and folding chairs, and no food or alcohol served. They paid $15 cash to a man seated inside.

headline: The Jig Is Up, if You’re Irish or Not
abstract: As “Riverdance” and the like have popularized Irish dance, youth competitions have become a more widespread, and more rigorous, subculture.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — Growing up in Woodlawn, a section of the Bronx also known as Little Ireland, Kristi Corcione envied her Irish-American friends. They got to take Irish dancing lessons, but as the self-described “token Italian” in her neighborhood, Ms. Corcione wasn’t allowed to join them.

headline: Venezuela’s Leader Pulls Foreign Channel Over Protest Coverage
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'News and News Media', 'Censorship']
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro said that the channel, Colombia-based NTN24, had tried to “foment anxiety about a coup d’état.”
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela’s president said that a Colombia-based cable news channel was ordered to be removed from cable lineups in Venezuela because of its coverage of an antigovernment protest. President Nicolás Maduro said Thursday that the channel, NTN24, had tried to “foment anxiety about a coup d'état.” He said that he gave the order to pull the channel because “No one is going to come from abroad and try to perturb the psychological climate of Venezuela.”

headline: A Wink and Then a Nod
abstract: An online pairing in the nick of time, before the subscription to the website expires.
lead_paragraph: The period during which Alex Chan and Sue Choe were on the Match.com dating site about four years ago wasn’t long, but somehow they both found that window, opened it and climbed through.

headline: Pomp and Coincidence
abstract: A shared name lands an outsider a coveted invitation to the ball and an insider’s look at how the other half play.
lead_paragraph: The countess stayed seated, but her gentleman companion chivalrously rose in his tuxedo to receive us. “Good evening,” he whispered with a continental bow. Uncertain how to answer him, I moved my head as he had, but didn’t really manage it as gracefully. While our tablemates looked on, he took a step behind me and kissed my girlfriend’s hand.

headline: Goodell’s Pay of $44.2 Million in 2012 Puts Him in the Big Leagues
abstract: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell’s compensation in 2012 made him among the best-paid executives in the country and perhaps the highest-paid leader of a nonprofit organization.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell was paid $44.2 million in 2012, making him among the best-paid executives in the country and perhaps the highest-paid leader of a nonprofit organization.

headline: Andris Nelsons to Conduct Lucerne Concerts
abstract: Mr. Nelsons will conduct two concerts this summer with the Lucerne Festival Orchestra that were planned by its founder, Claudio Abbado, who died last month.
lead_paragraph: Andris Nelsons will step in to conduct two concerts this summer with the Lucerne Festival Orchestra that were planned by its founder, Claudio Abbado, the festival announced. Mr. Abbado, who founded the orchestra in 2003, died last month at 80. Mr. Nelsons, who will officially become the music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra next season, will lead the Lucerne orchestra in Brahms programs on the festival’s first two nights, on Aug. 15 and 16. Michael Haefliger, the executive and artistic director of the Lucerne Festival, said in a statement that by performing works planned by Mr. Abaddo “the memory of the Lucerne Festival Orchestra’s founder remains alive in the festival’s artistic programming.” He will conduct the orchestra in Brahms in another pair pf concerts on Aug. 22 and 24.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Thailand, Indonesia, Syria and Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Thailand, Indonesia, Syria and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

headline: A Blushing Bride May Match Her Dress, and Her Guests
abstract: Once, it was simple. But increasingly, women are choosing colors other than white.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows not to wear white to a wedding so as not to upstage the bride, but what happens if a bride decides to wear pink, yellow or even blue? The answer: added stress for some brides and sartorial confusion for wedding guests.

headline: What Area Is Considered Upstate New York?
abstract: Questions are answered about what “upstate” New York really means, and Quonset huts in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Q. Living in a New York suburb, I’d like to know what people mean by “upstate New York.” Just how far do you have to be from the city to be upstate? Also, what are the boundaries of two upstate areas, the North Country and the Southern Tier?

headline: Every Men’s Figure Skating Jump, on One Page
abstract: Yuzuru Hanyu, the 19-year-old from Japan, stumbled on multiple jumps in his long program, but he did well enough to win the first men’s singles skating gold in his country’s history.
lead_paragraph: Yuzuru Hanyu, the 19-year-old from Japan, stumbled on multiple jumps in his long program, but he did well enough to win the first men’s singles skating gold in his country’s history.

headline: Weekend Reading: Cable Deals and JPMorgan Hiring
abstract: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.
lead_paragraph: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Being an Efficient Valentine
abstract: One economist responds to another on the field’s lessons for best expressing your affection.
lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: Paying for Pot, With Paper or Plastic
abstract: New Treasury Department guidelines should help marijuana entrepreneurs gain access to financial services.
lead_paragraph: At a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing in September, Senator Patrick Leahy brought attention to the financial aspect of the conflict between state and federal marijuana laws. Under federal law, it is illegal for banks to handle proceeds from drug sales, meaning marijuana businesses have to deal exclusively in cash. That’s not optimal, to say the least, since, as we put it in an editorial on the subject, “where there are piles of cash, there’s armed robbery.” Other potential problems include: Wage theft, money laundering and tax evasion.

headline: In U.S.-Russia Hockey Game, Cold War Shifts to the Ice
abstract: Russia, led by Alex Ovechkin, is seeking its first gold medal in hockey since a unified team won in 1992 after the demise of the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Around every corner, the face of Russia lurks. Not the stony visage of President Vladimir V. Putin, who delivered the Winter Games to his country, but the jack-o'-lantern grin of Alex Ovechkin, on whose stick the host nation’s success rests.

headline: Snap Sketch | Coco Rocha, Colin Self and the Faces of New York Fashion Week
abstract: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressions of the fashion set around New York City this week.
lead_paragraph: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressions of the fashion set around New York City this week.

headline: Strutting and Fretting Their Way Toward Bankruptcy
abstract: “The Faire,” Crystal Finn’s new play at the Fourth Street Theater, follows the behind-the-scenes lives of five performers in a bedraggled Renaissance fair somewhere in Northern California.
lead_paragraph: We know from theater’s long history of self-examination that what’s going on backstage during any given production is often more entertaining than what’s presented to the audience. The activity behind the curtain is particularly delicious in Fault Line Theater’s premiere of “The Faire,” a sharp comedy by Crystal Finn at the Fourth Street Theater about a sad-sack Renaissance fair and the actors who are watching it slowly die.

headline: Honoring a Bounteous Earth, While Warning of Man’s Destructive Trail
abstract: Joined by Charmaine Warren, Souleymane Badolo is presenting his dance work “Benon,” about nature’s gifts of sustenance, at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: As sleet pummeled the city on Thursday in the hours leading up to the premiere of Souleymane Badolo’s “Benon” at Danspace Project, the idea of a work about nature’s redeeming qualities, its gifts as opposed to its hazards, seemed attractive. A program note suggested that “Benon” would offer just that: Inspired by celebrations surrounding the harvest in Burkina Faso, where Mr. Badolo was born, it explores “the essential nature of food and the need to protect the environment.”

headline: Review: 2014 Chevy Silverado
abstract: The Silverado High Country is Chevy's first crack at a luxury pickup. It's a rig that's as comfortable at the symphony as it is on the farm.
lead_paragraph: The Silverado High Country is Chevy's first crack at a luxury pickup. It's a rig that's as comfortable at the symphony as it is on the farm.

headline: What the Elite Wear to Meet the Sleet
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Weather']
abstract: When the fashion crowd woke to the last day of Fashion Week — with Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein and Marc Jacobs still to show — New York was covered in a thick scrim of snow.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week came in like a lamb and went out like a lion.

headline: For Two Snowboarders, No Medals but Plenty of Sky
abstract: The American snowboarders Danny Davis and Greg Bretz had the mountain nearly to themselves on Friday when they headed to the slopes far from Olympic competitions.
lead_paragraph: The American snowboarders Danny Davis and Greg Bretz had the mountain nearly to themselves on Friday when they headed to the slopes far from Olympic competitions.

headline: For Interns, All Work and No Payoff
keywords: ['Internships', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Age, Chronological', 'Youth']
abstract: Unpaid internships are the bane of millennial workers with high aspirations.
lead_paragraph: Like other 20-somethings seeking a career foothold, Andrew Lang, a graduate of Penn State, took an internship at an upstart Beverly Hills production company at age 29 as a way of breaking into movie production. It didn’t pay, but he hoped the exposure would open doors.

headline: In the Pitch Darkness of the London Blitz, a Cover for Evil Doings
abstract: In the movie “Murder on the Home Front,” on PBS, a pathologist investigates a series of murders amid the devastation of the London Blitz.
lead_paragraph: In case this season’s next-to-last episode of “Downton Abbey” isn’t enough Anglostalgia for you on Sunday night, PBS is following it with “Murder on the Home Front,” a cheerfully preposterous British television movie set in London during the Blitz. The film is a slender but lively entry in the exceedingly crowded field of British period mysteries. Its World War II backdrop aligns it with the more serious “Foyle’s War,” while its focus on forensics as an as yet unappreciated science links it to the Victorian-era “Ripper Street.”

headline: Chief Minister of Delhi Resigns After 49 Days, Citing Resistance to Antigraft Bill
abstract: In stepping down, Arvind Kejriwal said his central anticorruption initiative was being stonewalled by legislators from two well-established parties.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Arvind Kejriwal, a protest leader who was vaulted into the top post of Delhi’s city government after a startling electoral victory, resigned from his seat after just 49 tumultuous days in office on Friday, saying his central anticorruption initiative was being stonewalled by legislators from India’s two well-established parties.

headline: For Cars, Aluminum Is a Back to the Future Metal
abstract: Automakers have long exploited aluminum’s advantages for reasons that include weight reduction, corrosion resistance and ease of recycling. Studebaker even used the metal in wagons.
lead_paragraph: While the 2015 Ford F-150 is on track to become the industry’s highest-volume aluminum-body vehicle — and a breakthrough in pickup truck design — it follows many earlier ventures in aluminum auto production. Since the dawn of the automobile, manufacturers have exploited the metal’s advantages for reasons that include weight reduction, corrosion resistance and ease of recycling, which is why a growing number of luxury brands and sports cars rely on aluminum structures.

headline: A Luxury-Class Metal Is Asked to Do Farm Chores
abstract: Ford is using aluminum, which is often found in Audis and Jaguars, in the body of its new F-150, a workhorse of a truck whose customers care about pulling power and payloads.
lead_paragraph: In the hotly contested part of the vehicle market where bragging rights go to the vehicle that has the engine with the most pulling power or the cargo bed that hauls the heaviest payload, Ford is testing its owners’ loyalty by building pickup bodies from a lightweight material more commonly used for luxury cars.

headline: Listen Up | Lo-Fang’s Globetrotting, Left-of-Center Pop
abstract: Jungle jam sessions and happy accidents are all in a day’s work for the singer-songwriter Lo-Fang, whose new video premieres here.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter Lo-Fang — the nom de musique of 30-year-old Matthew Hemerlein — wrote and recorded much of his debut album, “Blue Film” (out Feb. 25, 4AD), while globetrotting with friends. “There’s definitely a traveling quality to the record,” says Hemerlein, who worked with the acclaimed producer François Tétaz (Gotye) to bring his electro-tinged, “left-of-center pop” songs to life. In an interview last month, the singer described a nomadic recording process that took him to London, Nashville, Maryland and Southeast Asia, among other locales — including one particularly unusual violin session in Cambodia. “My friend who I went to Asia with was like, ‘Dude, you need to be playing while you’re riding an elephant up a mountain,’ ” he recalls. So he did just that, much to the delight of onlookers, as the friend recorded the melody.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 14
abstract: Subjects include: another snowstorm, the Columbia University fencing team and a fatal bus crash in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include: another snowstorm, the Columbia University fencing team and a fatal bus crash in Manhattan.

headline: Junior Exhibitors Vie for Westminster Prize
abstract: Teenagers show dogs as part of the Junior Showmanship competition of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers show dogs as part of the Junior Showmanship competition of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

headline: Maggie Gyllenhaal Withdraws From a Downtown Show to Focus on Broadway Debut
abstract: Ms. Gyllenhaal dropped out of MCC Theater’s production of “The Village Bike,” an acclaimed British play, to focus on her role in Tom Stoppard’s “The Real Thing.”
lead_paragraph: Academy Award nominee Maggie Gyllenhaal has dropped out of a downtown play in order to focus on making her Broadway debut in October in Tom Stoppard’s “The Real Thing,” several theater executives said on Friday.

headline: Exclusive | 845 United Nations Plaza
abstract: A four-bedroom unit on the 32nd floor of the Trump World Tower underwent a total makeover.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom unit on the 32nd floor of the Trump World Tower underwent a total makeover.

headline: An Overhaul That Looks More Like a Tuneup
abstract: The redesigned 2014 Chevrolet Silverado has many all-new features, but a new look isn’t among the changes.
lead_paragraph: Glencliff, N.H. — Not far from where some emergency vehicles had pulled off the dirt road, Douglas Dutile, the Grafton County sheriff, was keeping an eye on the traffic. When he saw me appear over the crest of a hill here in the White Mountain National Forest, he recognized the truck I was driving as the new-for-2014 Chevrolet Silverado.

headline: A Haunting, Sepulchral Note, and Then a Swirl of Hyperactivity
abstract: The pianist Christian Zacharias played a program of Beethoven, Schumann and Schubert on Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: You could barely hear the most memorable note in the pianist Christian Zacharias’s recital on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: A French Lesson in Speed and Power
abstract: Retromobile, the annual classic-car show held this month in Paris, turned its focus this year to racecars and World War I military vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Retromobile, the annual classic-car show held this month in Paris, turned its focus this year to racecars and World War I military vehicles.

headline: Checking the Fairness of College-Provided Debit Cards
keywords: ['Debit Cards', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Campus cards are the subject of a report by the Government Accountability Office, which recommends tougher regulations to make sure students get a fair deal.
lead_paragraph: When Harris Foster arrived at Portland State University in Portland, Ore., he was offered a special debit card promoted by his school as a convenient way to get access to his student aid funds.

headline: Fancy Face-Lift
abstract: A combination unit that transformed a modern bachelor pad into a contemporary showplace with spectacular East River vistas.
lead_paragraph: A combination unit at 845 United Nations Plaza that underwent a multimillion-dollar three-year renovation to transform a modern bachelor pad on the 32nd floor into a contemporary showplace with a 95-foot west/east wingspan, dynamic East River views, and an assortment of futuristic home-technology systems is about to enter the market at $25 million.

headline: Jos. A. Bank Takes a Page From a Long Ago Deal
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Back in 1989, the board of Time Inc. went ahead with plans for a merger with Warner Communications, despite a bid from Paramount that appeared to create more value. Jos. A. Bank is taking a similar tack in its deal for Eddie Bauer, albeit with a clever shareholder-friendly twist.
lead_paragraph: In purchasing Eddie Bauer, Jos. A. Bank Clothiers has cleverly structured its deal to try and avoid criticism that its pursuit of Eddie Bauer shuts down Men’s Wearhouse’s own bid for the men’s clothing company. It’s a deft maneuver, based on both Delaware law and a bit of ancient history.

headline: ‘Dreamgirls’ and Beyond
abstract: “The Songs of Henry Krieger,” featuring the catalog of this “Dreamgirls” composer, was the latest addition to the American Songbook series at Jazz at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: If I had to pick one song that encapsulates what is special about the Broadway composer Henry Krieger it might be “Here Is the Heart.” With a strong, declarative melody by Mr. Krieger, best known as the composer of “Dreamgirls,” and lyrics by Tom Eyen, his “Dreamgirls” collaborator, the ballad, from their musical “Dangerous Music,” is all heart.

headline: In the West, It’s Not Just About the Snow
abstract: There are new wintertime activities at resorts and parks in Colorado, Montana, and Wyoming.
lead_paragraph: Recent storms have dumped loads of fresh snow in the Western United States, welcome news for the region’s national parks and resorts, many of which have been adding history, wildlife and ecology tours to their usual winter menus.

headline: Addicted on Staten Island
abstract: New patterns of drug usage remind us that it is not marijuana that ought to be feared as a pathway to more insidious forms of addiction; it is substances that remain perfectly legal.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, Corey Epstein, a peripheral cast member on the reality television series “Jerseylicious,” was arrested along with 20 others in a drug sweep on Staten Island that grew out of a 16-month investigation called Operation Silent Hill. Mr. Epstein was charged with selling three oxycodone pills to an undercover officer, in front of his house on Nehring Avenue in New Springville, an area that had been largely rural until the 1970s, when malls and what has since become the vernacular architectural style of Staten Island — the deep-backed, two-family split level with a high, occasionally baroque stoop — imbued it and so much of Staten Island with a sense of inanimate prosperity.

headline: Puppy Love Is Not Enough
abstract: Ninety-one young dog handlers participated in the Junior Showmanship competition at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.
lead_paragraph: Every child begs for a dog. But to be a dog handler takes true commitment, from traveling to competitions around the country to grooming poodle hair for seven hours and trotting in circles in sensible flats. At the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in Manhattan last week, 91 once and future handlers from as far away as Alaska competed in the Junior Showmanship division. They were serious and professional, yet possessing those teenage flashes that the photographer Fred R. Conrad of The New York Times found captivating.

headline: A World-Changing Discussions
abstract: Somebody made a mistakes.
lead_paragraph: No, there’s nothing wrong with my headline. I’ve been walking around NYC today, and there are ads for the Wall Street Journal telling you that $1 can buy you either a 4-minute phone call or “a world-changing discussions”.

headline: Bail on This Bond
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Families and Family Life', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Addressing matters of sharing information about hookup apps, abstaining from social drinking and more.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I flip through Tinder (a matchmaking — or let’s face it, hookup — app that uses the geography, “likes” and other components of our Facebook accounts to find us frisky partners), my boss is nearly always suggested to me as a potential match. I know that talking to him about our sexual exploits would be inappropriate. But he’s chosen a very public app for his search, and I would like us to be better friends. Don’t you agree that talking with him about our Tinder experiences might be a great way to bond?

headline: Friday Night Music: Suzanne Vega
abstract: As good as ever.
lead_paragraph: Update: And that was excellent: Sarah Neufeld of Arcade Fire with Colin Stetson of Bon Iver ,performing Neufeld’s compositions. Virtuosic violin aside, who knew that Neufeld had such a lovely voice? And in the last piece, Stetson gave a spectacular demonstration of circular breathing.

headline: In the Air | In Living Color
abstract: Many fashion designers are collectively referencing a Pop aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: Many fashion designers are collectively referencing a Pop aesthetic.

headline: The Making of the Pinacoteca Agnelli
abstract: Ginevra Elkann discusses the Pinacoteca Giovanni e Marella Agnelli, the Renzo Piano-designed museum in Turin built around her grandparents’ trove of masterpieces from Canaletto to Matisse.
lead_paragraph: Ginevra Elkann discusses the Pinacoteca Giovanni e Marella Agnelli, the Renzo Piano-designed museum in Turin built around her grandparents’ trove of masterpieces from Canaletto to Matisse.

headline: On the Market in Los Angeles
abstract: Homes in Venice Beach; Brentwood; West Hollywood; Hollywood Hills; and Beverly Hills, priced from $999,000 to $8,145,000.
lead_paragraph: Homes in Venice Beach; Brentwood; West Hollywood; Hollywood Hills; and Beverly Hills, priced from $999,000 to $8,145,000.

headline: A Bridge Deal With Lindsey Weinger
abstract: Every once in a while, someone takes up bridge almost by accident and turns out to have a talent for the game.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while, someone takes up bridge almost by accident and turns out to have a talent for the game. One such player is Lindsey Weinger of New York City.

headline: WNET to Return $3.5 Million Grant for Pension Series
abstract: The New York public television broadcaster said it would return the funding in the face of charges that it solicited inappropriate underwriting for the series.
lead_paragraph: WNET, the New York City public television broadcaster, said on Friday that it would return a $3.5 million grant it received to sponsor an ambitious project on public pensions in the face of charges that it solicited inappropriate underwriting for the series.

headline: After a Snowy Overnight Trek, That Velvety Sound, Accented by Impetuosity
abstract: The St. Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra, under the conductor Yuri Temirkanov, performed at Carnegie Hall with the pianist Denis Kozhukhin as soloist.
lead_paragraph: There is a growing perception that the distinctive characteristics of orchestras from various national traditions are merging into an overall international style. If so, the St. Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra is an exception to this trend.

headline: Low-Key Makeover
abstract: Chevrolet has made numerous improvements to its Silverado pickup, though they’re not obvious to the naked eye.
lead_paragraph: Chevrolet has made numerous improvements to its Silverado pickup, though they’re not obvious to the naked eye.

headline: Scalia Has Seen the Future, and Its Name Is Marriage Equality
keywords: ['Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Supreme Court Justice predicted, correctly, that state bans on same-sex marriage would fall after the Windsor decision.
lead_paragraph: One must feel for Antonin Scalia. Which is not to say precisely what one must feel for him, but still: the 77-year-old Supreme Court Justice surely did not need another reminder of his prescience on the future of marriage equality in America, and yet he got one, thanks to the latest court ruling striking down a ban on same-sex marriage — this time in Virginia, which as we know is for lovers.

headline: Attuned to Strings, Plaintive or Manic
abstract: The New York City Ballet danced works by Jerome Robbins, Peter Martins and George Balanchine.
lead_paragraph: “Opus 19/The Dreamer,” a Jerome Robbins ballet choreographed in 1979 for Mikhail Baryshnikov and Patricia McBride, exists in a moody place where mystery and anxiety walk a delicate line. Is this strange, fitful landscape meant to evoke a dream or a nightmare?

headline: On the Market in Los Angeles, Calif.
abstract: This week’s properties are in Venice Beach; Brentwood; West Hollywood; Hollywood Hills; and Beverly Hills. Prices range from $999,000 to $8,145,000.
lead_paragraph: Click the slide show to view this week’s On the Market properties in Venice Beach; Brentwood; West Hollywood; Hollywood Hills; and Beverly Hills. Prices range from $999,000 to $8,145,000.

headline: An Editor’s Olympic Turn on TV
abstract: David Remnick, the editor of The New Yorker, provided context on President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia while acting as an Olympic correspondent for NBC.
lead_paragraph: It was a surprising voice to hear. David Remnick, the editor of The New Yorker, was on NBC explaining what the Olympic Games and the opening ceremony meant to Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: How ‘Rocky’ Learns to Fight
abstract: Andy Karl, who plays the title role in the new musical “Rocky,” can take a punch. Literally. The show’s choreographer designed stage fights that combine timed punches with old-fashioned theatrics.
lead_paragraph: Andy Karl, who plays the title role in the new musical “Rocky,” can take a punch. Literally. The show’s choreographer designed stage fights that combine timed punches with old-fashioned theatrics.

headline: Why Did Anyone Buy a TV? He Made It Indispensable
abstract: Sid Caesar made TV worth watching for many in the 1950s, and spurred sales of that new appliance.
lead_paragraph: Television owes a lot to people like Sid Caesar, who died on Wednesday at 91. I’m not talking about television the entertainment medium, although that, too, owes a lot to Mr. Caesar. I’m talking about television the appliance.

headline: Phoenixes Rise in China and Float in New York
abstract: After a long journey, two huge phoenixes by the Chinese artist Xu Bing have risen above the nave of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.
lead_paragraph: On a recent wintry afternoon, a team of eight was putting the final touches on a pair of monumental birds that had just been hung in the majestic nave of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights. As these phoenixes hovered some 20 feet above, their tiny, twinkling lights illuminated an array of unexpected materials: feathers fashioned from impeccably layered shovels; crowns made of weathered hard hats; heads created from jackhammers; and birds’ bodies sculpted from other salvaged construction debris, including pliers, saws, screwdrivers, plastic accordion tubing and drills.

headline: Why Did I Become a Comic? He Inspired Me
abstract: Billy Crystal looks back at Sid Caesar, the powerhouse of comedy who inspired him.
lead_paragraph: The death of Sid Caesar on Wednesday caused a chain reaction in my soon to be 66-year-old mind. I was saddened, of course, but felt a sense of relief that he was at last free from the indignity of aging. Then I felt a nostalgic breeze blowing over me as I remembered why he was so important to me.

headline: From Tender to Blustery to Haunted
abstract: The baritone Gerald Finley and the pianist Julius Drake performed Schubert’s “Winterreise” at Zankel Hall on Thursday, the final stop in a tour devoted to the song cycle.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian baritone Gerald Finley and the British pianist Julius Drake gave a recital at Zankel Hall on Thursday that was the final stop of a North American tour featuring Schubert’s “Winterreise.” The performance almost fell victim to 21st-century winter blues after a power failure plunged Zankel Hall into darkness earlier that day.

headline: Times Minute | Goodell’s Big Payday
abstract: A big payday for the N.F.L.’s commissioner, Roger Goodell. Also on the Minute, rethinking the benefits of natural gas and an adventure to Haiti’s hidden waterfalls.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Goodell's Big Payday
abstract: A big payday for the N.F.L.'s commissioner, Roger Goodell. Also on the Minute, rethinking the benefits of natural gas and an adventure to Haiti's hidden waterfalls.
lead_paragraph: A big payday for the N.F.L.'s commissioner, Roger Goodell. Also on the Minute, rethinking the benefits of natural gas and an adventure to Haiti's hidden waterfalls.

headline: The World Celebrates Valentine's Day
abstract: From a hugging marathon in Thailand to naked bungee jumping in Latvia, different cultures celebrate Valentine’s Day in their own way.
lead_paragraph: From a hugging marathon in Thailand to naked bungee jumping in Latvia, different cultures celebrate Valentine’s Day in their own way.

headline: Batista’s Flagship Company Presents Bankruptcy Plan
abstract: The outline of the plan converts debt to equity and ends the Brazilian businessman Eike Batista’s control of the petroleum company, now known as OGpar.
lead_paragraph: SAO PAULO — The flagship company of the Brazilian businessman Eike Batista took a big step toward exiting bankruptcy on Friday as it presented a court with its creditor-approved restructuring plan.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: André Leon Talley’s Secret Shoes, Valentino’s Morbid Mess-Up and Barbie’s Newest Designer Frocks
abstract: Plus, the “eyebrow party” after the Alexander Wang show, L’Wren Scott’s cancelled runway and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: A Murder to Solve, as Holmes Did
abstract: “The International Exhibition of Sherlock Holmes” offers a re-creation of 221B Baker Street, and asks visitors to figure out a killing.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — If you make your way to the Center of Science and Industry to see “The International Exhibition of Sherlock Holmes,” which opened here last Saturday, these are some of the cases you will not learn much about: the repulsive story of the red leech and the horrible death of Crosby, the banker; the singular tale of the politician, the lighthouse and the trained cormorant; and an account of Ricoletti, of the club foot, and his abominable wife.

headline: Hanyu Falls Twice, but Still Wins Gold
abstract: After a world record-setting short program performance, Yuzuru Hanyu, a teenager from Japan, fell twice in his free skate but still prevailed.
lead_paragraph: After a world record-setting short program performance, Yuzuru Hanyu, a teenager from Japan, fell twice in his free skate but still prevailed.

headline: Deferential Remarks in Martyrdom Video Said to Show Briton’s Last Words Before Suicide Attack in Syria
abstract: Video posted online appears to show a British man politely declining to speak in his own martyrdom video, just before a suicide attack in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Peering into the camera and shaking his head slowly, a British man in Syria, dressed in the white robe worn by suicide bombers, apologized for being at a loss for words. “Sheikh, I can’t speak,” the man said to the militant acting as his translator in video apparently recorded last week, just before he got behind the wheel of an explosives-laden truck. “My tongue’s got like a knot in it,” he explained. “Tell him I can’t speak.”

headline: WBAI, Still Fighting Deficits, Fires Its Programming Chief
abstract: The dismissal is the latest change in a tumultuous year for the struggling FM station.
lead_paragraph: WBAI, the liberal radio station in New York that occupies a powerful spot on the FM dial but has been struggling financially for years, this week dismissed its latest programming chief.

headline: The After-Party Circuit
abstract: Here are some memorable faces from eight nights of Fashion Week partying.
lead_paragraph: Here are some memorable faces from eight nights of Fashion Week partying.

headline: China Set to Press North Korea Further on Nuclear Aims, Kerry Says
abstract: The secretary of state said he urged Chinese leaders to “use every tool at their disposal” to persuade North Korea to rethink its nuclear ambitions.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — After a day of meetings with senior Chinese officials, Secretary of State John Kerry asserted on Friday that China was prepared to step up the pressure on North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons programs.

headline: U.S. Issues Marijuana Guidelines for Banks
abstract: The Obama administration policy is meant to give banks confidence that they will not be punished if they work with legitimate businesses in states that have legalized the use of the drug.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Friday issued guidelines intended to give banks confidence that they will not be punished if they provide services to legitimate marijuana businesses in states that have legalized the medical or recreational use of the drug, even though it remains illicit under federal law.

headline: Single Motherhood, Poverty and Kids
abstract: Readers react to an essay that said unmarried parents tend to create turmoil in their children’s lives.

headline: The Childless Plan for Their Fading Days
keywords: ['Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Elder Care', 'Wills and Estates', 'Elderly', 'Retirement']
abstract: The default option is to rely on children for help in one’s later years. Those who have no children have to plan and make those plans known.
lead_paragraph: HAVING children was never on Francine Tint’s to-do list. A painter of large abstract canvases, Ms. Tint never felt a biological imperative to reproduce or pass on her name to future generations.

headline: Chief Compliance Officer at SAC Capital Is Stepping Down
abstract: The departure of Steven Kessler, who worked at SAC for nine years, marks the latest turn in the the final chapter of Steven A. Cohen’s once wildly successful hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: Steven L. Kessler, the chief compliance officer at SAC Capital Advisors, will step down on Feb. 28, marking the latest turn in the the final chapter of Steven A. Cohen’s once wildly successful hedge fund.

headline: Capturing the Energy of Hood by Air
abstract: Upending all assumptions was the cult street-wear label’s show, where something irresistible was happening.
lead_paragraph: There were moments, there are always moments. Four hundred poetic soft-sculpture clouds were set afloat in the New York State Armory for a cool, masterly Marc Jacobs show on Thursday. An ostentatiously costly tableau vivant involving complex hydraulics and Alpine singers tested the endurance of hundreds who had braved bitter cold to see what essentially amounted to the latest news in puffer jackets (Moncler). A disaster movie scene played out in an elevator at Oscar de la Renta as a passel of overheated editors stood trapped with André Leon Talley, latter-day Shelley Winters, wearing a fur blanket and Uggs.

headline: In Fashion, Fame’s Last Bastion
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Parties (Social)', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Celebrities']
abstract: Free clothes are one of the draws during an extravaganza filled with shows and parties.
lead_paragraph: Free clothes, free clothes, step up celebrities, there are free clothes.

abstract: Readers in New York City discuss school closings and giving the jobless work beyond shoveling snow.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Women and Mammograms: Doctors Weigh In
abstract: Drs. Richard C. Wender of the American Cancer Society and Liane Philpotts of the Yale School of Medicine discuss the recent study that saw little value in the screening test.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Bill Cunningham takes a look at the fall 2014 collections.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cunningham takes a look at the fall 2014 collections.

headline: New York Fall 2014: The Fifth Element
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: Over the course of New York Fashion Week, it was hard to ignore the ubiquity of cellphones as a fashion accessory, a toy, a portable diary and an essential element of style.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of New York Fashion Week, it was hard to ignore the ubiquity of cellphones as a fashion accessory, a toy, a portable diary and an essential element of style.

abstract: Jordan D. Metzl, a doctor of sports medicine, responds to an Op-Ed article.

headline: Lawmakers Promise Scrutiny of Comcast Deal
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Members of Congress said they would look into antitrust issues raised by Comcast’s planned acquisition of Time Warner Cable.
lead_paragraph: The ink on Comcast’s $45.2 billion agreement to acquire Time Warner Cable is barely dry, but already lawmakers have begun to weigh in on the antitrust issues raised by the deal, the largest this year so far.

headline: Football’s Loving Culture
abstract: Focused on strength and bonding, it has a homoerotic component.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the football star Michael Sam, the all-American University of Missouri defensive end, came out this week, it meant that he might become the first openly gay N.F.L. player.

headline: Bill Cunningham | On the Street
abstract: Fashion and reality had a head-on smashup during Fashion Week, with more than 250 shows all over the city in often freezing, snowy or slushy weather.
lead_paragraph: Ugh! Fashion and reality had a head-on smashup during Fashion Week, with more than 250 shows all over the city in often freezing, snowy or slushy weather. The shows ended Thursday, with heavy snow in the morning and a downpour with thunder and lighting at night. While many dressed for the weather, left, others continued to dress up for a fashion show, right. In the end, reality triumphed.

headline: The Beat Goes On
abstract: Bill Cunningham takes a look at the fall 2014 collections.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cunningham takes a look at the fall 2014 collections.

headline: Why I Never Got a Mammogram
abstract: Patients have to make their own choices.
lead_paragraph: I HAVE never had a mammogram. I’m almost 50 — nearly a decade into the age when the screening is recommended by the American Cancer Society. I’m college educated, adequately insured. And I am the bane of my health care providers. Once, my midwife went so far as to request that I never speak of my decision in any space where other patients might hear.

headline: The Book on Jeter
abstract: It takes a lot of courage to do what he did this week: declare a self-imposed deadline and submit, finally, to history.
lead_paragraph: Every major league player is deeded real estate in the book of baseball. Some may be granted only one word, others a paragraph. And then there is Derek Jeter, who is closing out, in a masterly way, one of the great chapters in baseball’s history.

headline: It’s Not Much Fun Under a Little Paper Umbrella
abstract: Chasing a winter getaway in the sun and warmth can be like the New Year’s Eve of vacations.
lead_paragraph: Like everybody I know on the East Coast, I’ve been beaten down by the freezing winter and am desperate to get away to a warm place. But I’m wavering, because in my experience, the tropics are the New Year’s Eve of vacations: There is no way they are going to match your expectations.

headline: Lego Builds an Empire, Brick by Brick
abstract: The Lego Group’s venture into films demonstrates the company’s hope to expand its customer base as it faces increasing competition from other construction toy lines, especially in the digital spaces.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s top-grossing children’s movie, not only skyscrapers but actors built of tiny bricks inhabit a rather dystopian world known as “Lego-verse.”

headline: Guantánamo Bay Prosecutors Accuse Detainee of Conspiracy
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Terrorism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The move could set up a test of whether Congress may make conspiracy, not recognized as a war crime, something able to be prosecuted in a war-crimes tribunal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prosecutors for the military commission trials at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, disclosed in a document posted Friday that they had added a charge of conspiracy against an Iraqi detainee, potentially setting up a test of whether Congress has the power to make conspiracy a prosecutable offense in a war-crimes tribunal despite its not being recognized as an international war crime.

headline: Anthony Open to Pay Cut to Bolster Knicks
abstract: Carmelo Anthony planned to explore free agency, he said as he prepared for the N.B.A. All-Star Game, but his “first priority” was to re-sign with his current team.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Far removed from the prying eyes of his employers at Madison Square Garden, Carmelo Anthony sat on a dais inside a large ballroom at the Hyatt Regency on Friday afternoon and, with the news media gently nudging him along, decided to make some announcements.

headline: Roots of Bosnian Protests Lie in Peace Accords of 1995
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The violence that erupted a week ago across Bosnia and Herzegovina can be traced to the 1995 Dayton Accords, which brought peace but imposed a dysfunctional government that has stymied progress.
lead_paragraph: TUZLA, Bosnia and Herzegovina — The local government headquarters here is a shell, its 12 stories charred by fire. Shards of glass tumble from its smashed windows.

headline: A Funeral Fraud
abstract: An unusually vicious email scam is making the rounds.
lead_paragraph: The subject line of the email usually says something like “funeral notification” or perhaps “your friend’s memorial service.” It appears to come from a funeral home, maybe even a real funeral home.

headline: Plushenko’s Withdrawal Stirs a Backlash
abstract: Angry critics said the Russian Skating Federation should not have given the ailing Evgeni Plushenko a place on the Olympic team.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The crowd at the Iceberg Skating Palace in Sochi went silent when Evgeni Plushenko stumbled with the back injury that ended his figure skating career on Thursday. But the stunned silence that followed his withdrawal from the men’s short program and the almost immediate announcement of his retirement has quickly been replaced by angry questions about whether Plushenko should have been competing in the first place.

headline: The Real Deal
abstract: The mood fashion shows inspire is a far cry from the one many women feel in the morning while getting dressed, when a series of realities must be addressed and decisions made.
lead_paragraph: The mood fashion shows inspire is a far cry from the one many women feel in the morning while getting dressed, when a series of realities must be addressed and decisions made.

headline: A Conflict of Faith: Devoted to Jewish Observance, but at Odds With Israel
abstract: Religious American Jews who take a stand against Israel are likely to find themselves in the minority among family and friends.
lead_paragraph: There is no question that Charles H. Manekin is a rarity. Not because he is an Orthodox Jew who keeps the Sabbath, refraining from driving, turning on lights, even riding in elevators on Saturdays. Rather, this philosophy professor at the University of Maryland is rare because he believes that his Orthodox faith calls him to take stands against Israel.

headline: The Plus in Google Plus? It’s Mostly for Google
abstract: The social network, which gets relatively modest traffic, has remained valuable to Google because of the broad view it can give advertisers of people’s activity and interests.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google Plus, the company’s social network, is like a ghost town. Want to see your old roommate’s baby or post your vacation status? Chances are, you’ll use Facebook instead.

headline: Pope Pressed on Bishop Who Supervised Pedophile
abstract: Parishioners argued that Bishop Robert W. Finn should be subject to disciplinary action by the church for failing to notify authorities that a priest in his diocese was an active pedophile.
lead_paragraph: A group of Roman Catholics in Kansas City, Mo., and a priest with expertise in canon law petitioned Pope Francis this week to take disciplinary action against Bishop Robert W. Finn, who was convicted in 2012 of failing to report a priest who was an active pedophile.

headline: U.S. and Canada Feel Putin Charm, Hockey Excluded
abstract: The Russian president visited the headquarters of the American and Canadian teams on Friday, part of his personal outreach at the Games.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Turning on the charm as the host of the Winter Olympics, President Vladimir V. Putin dropped by the headquarters of the American and Canadian teams on Friday evening. He sipped red wine with leaders of the United States Olympic Committee, posed for photographs with stunned athletes and jokingly wished Canada luck — except on the ice in hockey.

headline: Winter’s Not Just Cold and Snowy. It’s Expensive.
keywords: ['Winter (Season)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Shopping and Retail', 'United States Economy', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Weather', 'Small Business']
abstract: A prolonged bout of unusually tough seasonal weather is taking a toll on small businesses.
lead_paragraph: The mighty $16 trillion American economy can easily shrug off a snowstorm or two, even in regions unaccustomed to wintry snow and ice. But a prolonged bout of unusual weather is taking a toll, especially on small businesses like Abbadabba’s, a shoe store chain in Atlanta, which has weathered two major storms this year.

headline: Lawyer Says Man Arrested in Hoffman Case Is an Addict, Not a Dealer
abstract: Robert Vineberg was arrested after police found heroin in his apartments as they looked for the source of the drug that killed the actor Philip Seymour Hoffman.
lead_paragraph: A studio musician who was  arrested on drug charges during the investigation into Philip Seymour Hoffman’s death argued through his lawyer on Friday that he was not a drug dealer, but merely a longtime heroin addict.

headline: Political Star Rises on Vow to Upend Italy’s Old Order
abstract: Matteo Renzi engineered the Italian prime minister’s removal and is poised to succeed him, but now he faces the challenge of shaking the country out of its malaise.
lead_paragraph: ROME — HE sometimes wears a leather bomber jacket, embracing the iconography of the rebel. He has rocketed through Italian politics by taking on the establishment, especially in his own left-leaning party. He is media savvy, evoking comparisons to Tony Blair, and he has tapped into a national yearning for change by cultivating a persona as a political wrecking ball with an Everyman appeal.

headline: Rhode Island Reaches Deal to Soften Pension Changes
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Government Employees']
abstract: The state’s tentative agreement with public employee unions eases changes facing some state workers under a sweeping 2011 law intended to control spiraling pension costs.
lead_paragraph: A tentative agreement between Rhode Island and representatives of its public employees, brokered by federal mediators and unveiled on Friday afternoon, softens some provisions in a sweeping 2011 law intended to control the spiraling cost of the state’s pension system.

headline: Terran Lyons, McDonald’s Crew Trainer, on Raising 2 on the Minimum Wage
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Parenting', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: I work the night shift. It’s a good job, except they pay us so little. It would be easier except right now, it takes me about two hours on buses to drop my kids off and get to work.
