lead_paragraph: I’m 24 years old. I’m a single mother. I work at McDonald’s. I make $9.85 an hour. I usually get about 40 hours a week. I like it. I work the night shift, because I’m a hard worker, and they have plenty of workers for the day shift. They need workers at night — good workers.

headline: With a Bigger Comcast May Come More Deals
abstract: With Comcast proposing to buy Time Warner Cable, other companies that own cable networks are watching nervously, and may look to consolidate.
lead_paragraph: Just last month, Discovery Communications, the owner of cable networks including Animal Planet and TLC, had considered acquiring rival Scripps Networks Interactive in a deal that would have been valued at more than $10 billion.

headline: Justice Dept. Defends Its Conduct on Evidence
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)']
abstract: Government prosecutors failed to tell a defendant that evidence derived from warrantless wiretapping would be used at trial.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has told a federal judge in Oregon that it did not engage in misconduct when prosecutors failed to tell a defendant that he faced evidence derived from warrantless wiretapping before his trial last year on terrorism-related charges.

headline: Pikus-Pace Goes Bump in the Night, but Still Wins a Silver
abstract: In her final Olympics, the American skeleton rider Noelle Pikus-Pace claimed the silver medal — despite an inopportune encounter with the wall.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Noelle Pikus-Pace thought she lost it. As she came out of the fifth curve at Sanki Sliding Center on Friday night, Pikus-Pace, the veteran American skeleton rider, felt her body bump the wall and her heart sink to her toes.

headline: Spring Women’s Fashion Issue
abstract: In the spring 2014 women’s fashion issue, T looks at the way women really want to dress.
lead_paragraph: In the spring 2014 women’s fashion issue, T looks at the way women really want to dress. Our cover subject is the cult fashion-designer Phoebe Philo, whose quiet, understated designs for Céline give new meaning to the term “power dressing” — and are coveted by some of the smartest, savviest women out there. In our Sign of the Times essay, Cathy Horyn examines the divide between what women actually want to wear — beautiful clothes that they feel good in — and the tricked-out, challenging get-ups that come down the runway. We also celebrate three women who insist on doing things their way: the designer Maria Cornejo, whose art-inspired designs stay true to her singular vision; the up-and-coming singer Kelela, who is finding her voice somewhere between electronic music and old-school R&B; and the Fiat heiress Ginevra Elkann, who juggles duties as a film producer, art museum boss and mother while building a legacy — and a home — that goes beyond her famous name. Additional highlights include a behind-the-scenes look at Matthew Barney’s epic new art film; a pair of New York icons, Elaine Stritch and Chloë Sevigny, tune in to the latest rap music; and five prominent novelists — Colson Whitehead, Douglas Coupland, Mona Simpson, Joyce Carol Oates and Roddy Doyle — invite us into the spaces where they created their latest works. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Efforts to Mark Turf When Snowstorms Hit Endure Despite Critics
abstract: In Boston and other cities, the winter tradition of shoveling out cars and staking out a parking spot with any household object is drawing resistance.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It is a time-honored winter tradition here: Shovel out your car, and guard your newly cleared parking spot with whatever you have handy — a traffic cone, a potted plant, a bust of Elvis.

headline: As Services Expand, Cable Bills Keep Rising
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Television']
abstract: The proposed merger of Comcast and Time Warner Cable has raised concerns about the rising cost of cable service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Of the many benefits that Comcast executives said would flow to consumers from its proposed $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable — more innovation, advanced technology, improved service — the one it did not mention is probably the one consumers care about most: their cable bills.

headline: De Blasio’s Vow to End Traffic Deaths Meets Reality of New York Streets
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio faces challenges in altering the balance of taxis, buses, trucks and cars amid the city’s deeply ingrained pedestrian culture.
lead_paragraph: The announcement was bold, if somewhat quixotic: Mayor Bill de Blasio, whose campaign was focused on reforming the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk tactics, would commit his administration to reducing traffic deaths “literally” to zero.

headline: Disgraced Scientist Granted U.S. Patent for Work Found to be Fraudulent
abstract: Dr. Hwang Woo-suk of South Korea received the patent for the method by which he claimed in 2004 to have extracted stem cells from cloned human embryos.
lead_paragraph: Korean researcher Hwang Woo-suk electrified the science world 10 years ago with his claim that he had created the world’s first cloned human embryos and had extracted stem cells from them. But the work was later found to be fraudulent, and Dr. Hwang was fired from his university and convicted of crimes.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
abstract: A bad winter for travelers, a submersible computer and a dispute over exporting oil from the United States.
lead_paragraph: A bad winter for travelers, a submersible computer and a dispute over exporting oil from the United States.

headline: A Steady Path to Supreme Court as Gay Marriage Gains Momentum in States
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'States (US)', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: A decision in Virginia striking down a ban on same-sex marriage is just the latest in a series of lower court rulings on the issue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sweeping decision on Thursday night struck down Virginia’s ban on same-sex marriage and continued a remarkable winning streak for gay rights advocates, putting new pressure on the Supreme Court to decide the momentous question it ducked last summer: whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

headline: Medicines Made in India Set Off Safety Worries
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Counterfeit Merchandise', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: India, the second-largest exporter of over-the-counter and prescription drugs to the United States, is coming under increased scrutiny by American regulators.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India, the second-largest exporter of over-the-counter and prescription drugs to the United States, is coming under increased scrutiny by American regulators for safety lapses, falsified drug test results and selling fake medicines.

headline: Innovation, Optimism and Jobs
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Productivity', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: What bounty will the digital revolution bring?
lead_paragraph: Is digital technology destroying middle-class jobs? Does it exacerbate income inequality? Does it boost economic growth and productivity — without creating the jobs that ought to come with economic growth?

headline: If You Shovel It, It’s Yours? Not so Fast
abstract: The neighborhood of South End wants to ban the practice of space saving: shoveling out a parking spot and then leaving anything from a chair to a laundry basket to reserve it.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhood of South End wants to ban the practice of space saving: shoveling out a parking spot and then leaving anything from a chair to a laundry basket to reserve it.

headline: The Common Core in New York
keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Missteps aside, the state cannot afford to let this project founder.
lead_paragraph: The new Common Core learning standards, which set ambitious goals for what students should learn from one year to the next, are desperately needed in New York, where only about a third of high school students graduate with the math and English skills necessary to succeed at college. But the standards, adopted in 2010, have had a bumpy rollout and are under siege from several constituencies.

headline: Making Retirements Less Secure
keywords: ['401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: The recent AOL controversy highlights how new 401(k) policies that use lump-sum payments can shortchange employees.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of AOL, Tim Armstrong, was roundly criticized for wrongly connecting the expensive health problems of two babies born to his employees and the health care reform law to the company’s rising health care costs. He eventually apologized for those remarks. Just as wrongheaded was his plan to deal with higher costs by changing the way the company contributes to retirement accounts.

headline: No Evidence of Coffee Break on Mars
abstract: Scientists did not find a Dunkin’ Donuts on Mars, but they did figure out where a rock that looks like a small jelly doughnut came from.
lead_paragraph: Scientists did not find a Dunkin’ Donuts on Mars, but they did figure out where a rock that looks like a small jelly doughnut came from. Last month, the rock, about an inch and a half wide, showed up in one of the photographs taken by the NASA’s Opportunity rover. In addition to the unusual appearance, it had not been there when Opportunity photographed the same spot on the Martian landscape less than two weeks earlier. A new photograph shows an overturned rock with a similar dark red center and white surface about a yard away. The jelly doughnut piece, named Pinnacle Island, broke off and rolled downhill when the rover drove over it in early January, scientists working on the mission said Friday.

headline: 2 Companies to Destroy Chemicals in Syria’s Arsenal
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons chose hazardous-waste disposal companies based in the United States and Finland.
lead_paragraph: Two hazardous-waste disposal companies, based in the United States and Finland, have been selected to help incinerate the chemicals in Syria’s weapons arsenal, the organization responsible for overseeing the destruction announced on Friday, as new worries emerged about possible Syrian procrastination in exporting the 1,200-ton stockpile.

headline: Next Move on Press Freedom
keywords: ['News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Editorials']
abstract: The United States attorney general should seize the opportunity to demonstrate his expressed respect for “constitutionally protected” news gathering.
lead_paragraph: Last July, Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. spoke eloquently of “the importance of the constitutionally protected news gathering process,” the essential role of a free press when it comes to “government accountability and an open society,” and the need to better protect journalists from federal leak investigations.

headline: New York Tries to Rid Its Sewers of FOG (Fat, Oil and Grease)
abstract: Cooking oil improperly disposed of accounts for many of the clogs in the city’s aging, 7,500-mile underground network, the city’s environmental agency says.
lead_paragraph: Out of sight of most New Yorkers is a sprawling underground labyrinth of about 7,500 miles of sewers, part of the city’s vast and, in many cases, aging subterranean infrastructure. Besides old age, the sewers, which are essential to the health of the city, are under assault from a nemesis above ground: grease.

headline: Time for N.F.L. Sponsors to Demand Change
abstract: The way to help rid the league of its abusive locker room culture is for corporate sponsors to take a stand. It should be an easy call, but there’s big money at stake.
lead_paragraph: You know those funny Campbell Soup ads starring N.F.L. players and their mothers? The ones where moms pop up in locker rooms and on fields to bring their sons bowls of steaming Chunky soup?

headline: Where to Read a Plot Summary
abstract: A Saturday brain-cruncher by Julian Lim.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial “Win Valuable Prizes” Alert! If you haven’t already signed up for the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, running from March 7 through March 9 in Brooklyn, New York — and why not? You can play along at home too, you know — you can still register here. Feeling shy? Don’t know anyone who will be there? Pish tosh. Sign up for the annual Cru dinner (click the first link to register) and meet your tribe: friendly folk who love crossword puzzles almost as much as you do.

headline: A Friend in Need, or Merely a Swindler
abstract: Schemes targeting old people were recently reported to the police in Forest Hills, Queens, including one in which a woman, 82, was told her grandson needed $3,500 for bail.
lead_paragraph: “She was approached by a male and a female,” the police captain explained. “Very well dressed. Late 40s, early 50s.”

headline: Volkswagen Vote Is Defeat for Labor in South
abstract: The United Automobile Workers’ loss is expected to slow the union’s plans to organize other auto plants in the South.
lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — In a defeat for organized labor in the South, employees at the Volkswagen plant here voted 712 to 626 against joining the United Automobile Workers.

headline: South China Sea Tensions a Backdrop to Kerry’s China Visit
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Typhoon Bopha (2012)', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Chinese officials take exception to statements by a U.S. Navy admiral that Washington would fulfill its obligations under a mutual defense treaty to help the Philippines if it came under attack
lead_paragraph: North Korea and bilateral relations between the United States and China are dominating Secretary of State John Kerry’s visit to East Asia this week, but tensions continue to simmer in the South China Sea as well.

headline: Genevieve Bell on Furby vs. Siri
abstract: During a lecture at Stanford University, Ms. Bell, an anthropologist at Intel Labs, compared the Furby toy with Siri, Apple’s personal assistant.
lead_paragraph: During a lecture at Stanford University, Ms. Bell, an anthropologist at Intel Labs, compared the Furby toy with Siri, Apple’s personal assistant.

headline: A Newscast Unveiled by Cuomo, for Cuomo
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Propaganda', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The governor’s office has released “The State of New York,” a mini-newscast with peppy music and upbeat news reports that will be broadcast every Friday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is often unhappy about the news coverage of his administration. So now his administration is starting to cover itself.

headline: Dining Outside in Little Italy: ‘I’m Starting to Miss My Mouth’
abstract: In the dead of winter, the table settings outside restaurants along Mulberry Street are intended to only lure diners inside — but one brave group called a restaurant’s bluff.
lead_paragraph: Even in the dead of winter, Mulberry Street in Little Italy does its best to look festive. The lights glow. Open-armed hosts in restaurant doorways greet prospective diners.

headline: Flips and Spins in Sochi and on Mammograms
abstract: The week brought grand spectacles at the Winter Olympics and in Washington at a White House state dinner.
lead_paragraph: It was a week of grand spectacles that would have made Julius “Bread and Circuses” Caesar proud. There were the Sochi Games, of course, a festival of sports both familiar and arcane, many set against the stunning white peaks of the Caucasus. And there was the state dinner on the South Lawn of the White House for President François Hollande of France, so rich in pomp and gossip that it was easy to forget that the host was a liberal and the guest a socialist, and that both their countries were forged in revolution.

headline: After Storm, 100% Attendance Is Not 100% Accurate
abstract: A few schools in New York City reported perfect or near-perfect attendance rates, but a few of them were inaccurately high.
lead_paragraph: On a day when more than half of the city’s students were marked absent, three public schools reported 100 percent attendance on Thursday, a seemingly miraculous feat in the face of all the ice and snow.

headline: Jeter’s Decision Makes Things Easier for Girardi and Yankees
abstract: Derek Jeter’s announcement that 2014 will be his last season lifts the burden of weighing his longer-term future with the Yankees from Manager Joe Girardi.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When Derek Jeter announced Wednesday that 2014 would be his final year in baseball, it probably removed a burden from the Yankees, particularly from Manager Joe Girardi.

headline: Legislator Up for Re-election Wants to Delay Bribery Trial
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Senator Malcolm A. Smith, who has been charged in a plot to bribe his way onto the ballot to run for mayor of New York, says his trial would interfere with his re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: State Senator Malcolm A. Smith, who has been charged in a plot to bribe his way onto the ballot to run for mayor of New York City, asked a judge recently to delay his corruption trial for a very practical reason: It would interfere with his re-election campaign.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 14, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Jim Fregosi, All-Star, Dies at 71; Angel Was Traded for Nolan Ryan
abstract: Mr. Fregosi was a baseball lifer who made six All-Star teams as a player and managed the 1993 Philadelphia Phillies to the National League pennant.
lead_paragraph: Jim Fregosi, a baseball lifer who made six All-Star teams as a player and managed the 1993 Philadelphia Phillies to the National League pennant, but who is probably best known — by New Yorkers, at least — as the player the Mets received from the California Angels in exchange for the future Hall of Fame pitcher Nolan Ryan in one of baseball’s more infamous trades, died Friday in Miami. He was 71.

headline: Alice Babs, Who Sang for Ellington, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Babs was already an established pop singer in Sweden when she drew praise for her appearances on Duke Ellington’s “Sacred Concerts.”
lead_paragraph: Alice Babs, a Swedish singer acclaimed for her work with Duke Ellington, died on Tuesday in Stockholm. She was 90.

headline: Curtain Call | New York Fashion Week
abstract: To mark the conclusion of New York Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of some fashion visionaries.
lead_paragraph: To mark the conclusion of New York Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of some fashion visionaries.

headline: It May Be a Nonprofit Theater, but the Tickets Look For-Profit
abstract: Faced with increasing costs, nonprofit theater companies like Roundabout and the Public Theater are raising some ticket prices past the $100 mark.
lead_paragraph: New York’s nonprofit theaters are acting more like for-profits, and there’s no greater sign than the return of “Cabaret” at Roundabout Theater Company.

headline: Obama Promises New Aid to Jordan in Refugee Crisis
abstract: The president announced the economic package during a meeting in Rancho Mirage, Calif., with King Abdullah II of Jordan.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — President Obama announced during a meeting here Friday night with King Abdullah II of Jordan that he would seek to renew a five-year aid package to help Jordan bear the burden of the more than 600,000 Syrian refugees who have fled the civil war there.

headline: Filipino Figure Skater Is Happy Just Being in Sochi
abstract: As the only representative of his country in the Winter Olympics, 17-year-old Michael Christian Martinez is satisfied with his 19th-place finish in the men’s singles competition.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Michael Christian Martinez did not win a medal at the men’s singles competition at the Iceberg Skating Palace. His 19th-place finish was marked by trips and tossups.

headline: Sweet, Slushy Valentine
abstract: Constantine Tribushniy trudged through the snow and icy conditions like a modern-day Cupid on Friday delivering several flower orders on the Upper West Side.

headline: Corrections: February 15, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 15, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: What to Watch at the Olympics: Saturday
abstract: Hockey, super-G skiing and speedskating are among Saturday’s highlights at the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: HOCKEY It may not be the Miracle on Ice — this game is merely about positioning for the medal round — but United States versus Russia seems worthy of setting an early-morning alarm. The Czech Republic then faces Switzerland in a noon game. They split their first two games and trail Sweden (2-0) in Group C. NBCSN, 7:30 a.m.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (CBS) 48 HOURS PRESENTS: THE WHOLE GRITTY CITY Wynton Marsalis hosts this documentary, in which the filmmakers Richard Barber and Andre Lambertson follow five students in New Orleans marching bands whose directors, while preparing them to perform in Mardi Gras parades, have also instilled survival lessons in a city with one of the highest murder rates in the country. The students have all lost someone close to them. “This is the street I don’t like, because it has guns,” says Jaron Williams, 11, not far from where his 19-year-old brother was shot to death. “I cried the whole day. I couldn’t get him out of my head.” Then Jaron, above, joined the Roots of Music, a free music education program for middle schoolers, and learned to play the trumpet, earning his way into the Marching Crusaders — and a parade. “I feel like I’m the best thing in the world and I can’t be stopped,” he says. It’s the power of the music, Wilbert Rawlins Jr., one of the featured band directors ,maintains. “I don’t care if you just had something very tragic that happened to you in your life,” he says. “Once that band gives you that downbeat, and that music is right, and it’s powerful — just for that brief two or three minutes, you forget everything, every problem you had. You have no cares in the world.”

headline: As Austrians Prevail, American Skiers Falter
abstract: Anna Fenninger of Austria won the gold medal and her teammate Nicole Hosp won the bronze medal to give Austria four Olympic medals at the halfway point of the 2014 Olympic Alpine competition.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The ski racing rivalry between Austria and the United States has been less than subtle at times in the last eight years.

headline: Oshie Lifts U.S. Over Russia in Hockey Shootout
abstract: T.J. Oshie scored the game-winning goal in a shootout — his fourth in six shots — to lift the United States to a 3-2 victory over Russia in an Olympic hockey game.
lead_paragraph: The United States defeated Russia, 3-2, in a shootout in men’s hockey at the Sochi Olympics.

headline: A List of Favorites From a Man Who Knows His Apps
abstract: We all have that friend who knows which new song you should buy, or the new movie you should watch, but what about that friend who knows about apps? Meet Michael Galpert, the app know-it-all.
lead_paragraph: Some people have a friend that can recommend the hottest new music album or latest and greatest upcoming television show. My friend Michael Galpert is my go-to person for the most obscure and often most useful apps that would otherwise be lost to me amid the million-plus options in the App Store.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of New York Fashion Week Take Their Bows
abstract: To mark the conclusion of New York Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 19 fashion visionaries.
lead_paragraph: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of New York Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 19 fashion visionaries.

headline: Suit Change Does Not Matter as U.S. Misses Podium Again
abstract: Shani Davis of the United States, the world-record holder, finished 11th in the 1,500-meter long-track speedskating event.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Zbigniew Brodka of Poland won the men’s 1,500-meter speedskating event here Saturday, but the continuing story at Adler Arena was the Americans’ baffling performances. The United States team includes world-record holders and Olympic and world champions. Yet Americans won none of the first 21 speedskating medals at the Sochi Games.

headline: Monopsony Begets Monopoly, And Vice Versa
abstract: The robber barons want to further fortify their castle.
lead_paragraph: Nothing to see here, folks, says Comcast. The cable giant’s defenders insist that its already awesome market power won’t be increased if it acquires Time Warner, because they serve (i.e., are local monopolists in) different geographical areas:

headline: What’s Happening Off the Runway During London Fashion Week
abstract: Everything you need to enjoy the next five days in style, from delicious and nutritious meals to cozy made-in-England sweaters.
lead_paragraph: London Fashion Week has begun, and out-of-towners and locals alike are making their final preparations for another season of back-to-back shows and star-studded events. Here, a guide to surviving (and enjoying) the festivities.

headline: Mentally Ill Inmates
abstract: Responses to Nicholas Kristof’s column about how jails have become mental hospitals.
lead_paragraph: Responses to Nicholas Kristof’s column about how jails have become mental hospitals.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Feb. 16
keywords: ['Barbie (Doll)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “A clean debt ceiling is a complete capitulation on the speaker’s part.”

headline: The Case for Swapping Roles With China
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A new book by Stephen Roach says it’s time for the United States to be more of a producer and for China to be more of a consumer.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Roach proposes to remake the two largest economies on the globe, ours and China’s. For decades, he writes, the United States and China relied too much on a “marriage of convenience” that guaranteed China a huge market for its exports. In exchange, China gave American consumers a cornucopia of inexpensive products, while creating a willing buyer of the United States government’s swollen debt. But that marriage has played out, Mr. Roach says; it has warped the two economies, leaving them ill-equipped for further growth.

headline: Patrolling a Bruised City
abstract: A Detroit police officer fights crime while worrying about what the city’s bankruptcy will do to his pay and pension.

headline: Drama, if Not Miracle, as U.S. Beats Russia
abstract: T. J. Oshie scored four times in the shootout to give the United States men’s hockey team a victory over Russia in preliminary play at the Sochi Olympics.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Every member of the United States men’s hockey team playing in the Sochi Games was born after the Americans’ shocking victory at the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, N.Y., against a Soviet team stocked with stars. Four times since that Miracle on Ice, the teams had met in Olympic competition, with the Americans compiling a 1-2-1 record, but none of the games were on Russian soil.

headline: Small Business, Joining a Parade of Outsourcing
keywords: ['Outsourcing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Research', 'Small Business', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Foreign Workers']
abstract: By using online job marketplaces to handle specific projects, companies of any size may be redistributing income toward lower-income countries, a research paper says.
lead_paragraph: Going abroad for cheap labor isn’t just for big businesses anymore. Thanks to the rise of online job marketplaces, small businesses are increasingly using foreign contract workers to lower their costs.

headline: Expedited Service, Except When It’s Not
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: An 87-year-old veteran pays to get a quick copy of his military record, and asks the Haggler for help when it doesn’t arrive.
lead_paragraph: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Where the Fish Swims, Ideas Fly
abstract: With the help of an incandescent fish hanging above his work space, an executive at a design consulting firm finds ways to inspire creativity among his co-workers.
lead_paragraph: When I was in Reykjavik, Iceland, last summer on vacation, a peculiar object in a local design store caught my eye. It was a cod that had been turned into a light.

headline: At the Ready, at the Sochi Games
abstract: A company is poised to evacuate athletes of the United States Ski and Snowboard Association who are competing at the Olympics, whether for medical or security reasons.
lead_paragraph: In January 2008, an American skier named Brett Buckles flew 10 feet into the air during a training run in the village of Tignes, France. Instead of landing gingerly on her skis, she came down with a thud 40 feet down the course and was knocked unconscious. Later, at a small local hospital, she learned that she had broken her pelvis in two places, fractured her sacrum, sustained a severe concussion and torn the labrum in her right shoulder.

headline: An About-Face for the Stock Market’s 5-Year Return
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: A huge change in a popular market gauge suggests that investors’ long-term view should be much longer.
lead_paragraph: Take the long view. That’s standard advice in investing, and it makes sense. After all, if you’ve salted money away for a serious purpose like retiring or buying a house or paying for a child’s education, you really don’t want to focus on how the stock market has done today or on what it might do tomorrow. You need a longer perspective.

headline: Microfoundations and Mephistopheles (Wonkish)
abstract: What was lost by aping the freshwater guys.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis asks whether New Keynesians made a Faustian bargain by accepting the New Classical dictat that models must be grounded in intertemporal optimization — whether they purchased academic respectability at the expense of losing their ability to grapple usefully with the real world.

headline: Yes, the Wealthy Can Be Deserving
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Inequality', 'Executive Compensation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income', 'United States Economy', 'Income Tax']
abstract: A fact that’s lost in the inequality debate: The top 1 percent of wage earners often accomplish extraordinary things, and at great risk.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, the actor Robert Downey Jr., played the role of Tony Stark, a.k.a. Iron Man, in “The Avengers.” For his work in that single film, Mr. Downey was paid an astounding $50 million.

headline: A Great Teammate Is a Great Listener
abstract: The C.E.O. of Ariel Investments says it’s crucial that leaders always hear and respect their workers’ ideas.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  John W. Rogers Jr., chairman, chief executive and chief investment officer of Ariel Investments, based in Chicago, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: The Untouchable Profits of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
abstract: An internal Treasury memo put the earnings of two mortgage giants off limits to their shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Would you buy stock in a company that barred you from sharing in its future earnings? Of course not. Participating in the upside is what stock ownership is all about.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent articles in the Sports section of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: What to Watch: Sunday
abstract: Televised Olympic events to watch on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: ALPINE SKIING It has been a rough Olympics so far for the stars of men’s skiing. Aksel Lund Svindal, Bode Miller and Ted Ligety are without medals entering Sunday’s super-G. Svindal won the event at Vancouver. NBC, 7 p.m.

headline: Comcast vs. the Cord Cutters
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Television']
abstract: Comcast’s deal to acquire Time Warner Cable won’t shake the industry’s game plan: Keep viewers wedded to cable.
lead_paragraph: The typical American household pays about $90 a month for cable television service, according to the NPD Group, the market research firm. But according to the research firm of You and Pretty Much Everyone You Know, when you click on your TV and browse the guide, what you often find hardly seems worth $90 a month.

headline: Variety: A Philosophical Diagramless
abstract: A philosophical diagramless by Fred Piscop.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — From 2005 to 2008, Nickelodeon broadcast an Asian-influenced animated series called “Avatar: The Last Airbender,” which my children watched fanatically, and which they insist was mangled as a live-action film in 2010. (The sequel, “The Legend of Korra,” is still in production.) In this series, some people are able to manipulate the classic ELEMENTs of FIRE, AIR, WATER and EARTH by “bending” them.

headline: Coveted Player to Train With U.S. Team
abstract: Julian Green, a 18-year-old wing who plays for Bayern Munich, could play for either Germany or the U.S. senior national teams.
lead_paragraph: Julian Green, a young, promising player for Bayern Munich, will train with the United States national team for two days before the Americans travel to Ukraine for an international friendly match on March 5.

headline: Creighton Is Succeeding on Strength of a Father-Son Bond
abstract: The Bluejays have the most victories over a four-year stretch in program history, led by Coach Greg McDermott and his son Doug, who is averaging 25.3 points.
lead_paragraph: Doug McDermott, a star forward for No. 18 Creighton, has almost wordless communication when he looks to his coach for guidance during a game. Sometimes, they are so alike in their thinking that nothing more than a nod is needed for a critical adjustment to be made.

headline: Defeat of Auto Union in Tennessee Casts Its Strategy Into Doubt
abstract: The United Auto Workers had planned to build on a success at a Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., to unionize several other Southern factories — but workers narrowly rejected the proposal.
lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Bob King has pursued one goal above all as president of the United Automobile Workers — to unionize several foreign-owned auto plants in the South. He said he viewed that as pivotal if his once-mighty union was to gain numbers and strength after decades of decline.

headline: A Debate Becomes a Brawl as Turkey’s Parliament Votes to Rein In Courts
abstract: Turkey’s Parliament met through the night, Friday into Saturday, and passed a controversial new bill that gives the government greater control over the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s Parliament met through the night, Friday into Saturday, and passed a controversial new bill that gives the government greater control over the judiciary — but not before a brawl on the floor of the assembly left one lawmaker with a broken finger and another with a bloodied nose.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 15
abstract: Hockey, skiing, and speedskating highlight the 10th day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: Hockey, skiing, and speedskating highlight the 10th day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Ugandan President Says He Will Sign Tough Antigay Measure
abstract: President Yoweri Museveni moved forward with a bill that would criminalize the promotion or recognition of homosexual relations.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Gay rights in Africa suffered another setback when President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda told members of his party on Friday that he would sign a bill imposing harsh sentences for homosexual acts, including life imprisonment in some cases.

headline: A Generational Wealth of N.B.A. Talent
abstract: Players like Tim Hardaway Jr. of the Knicks and Stephen Curry of the Warriors are picking up where their fathers left off in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Tim Hardaway Jr., a rookie swingman who has been a bright spot for the Knicks in an otherwise drab season, is a full-grown adult capable of his own decisions, but he still calls his father for advice.

headline: Behind Bars
abstract: The secret vocabulary of New York’s finest drinking establishments.
lead_paragraph: The secret vocabulary of New York’s finest drinking establishments.

headline: In Report on Bullying, the Vile and the Gripping
abstract: The lawyer Ted Wells’s report for the N.F.L. on the harassment by Richie Incognito and other Dolphins players contains a captivating portrait of Jonathan Martin’s anguish for not retaliating against his tormentors.
lead_paragraph: My first reaction to reading Ted Wells’s 144-page report on the Miami Dolphins harassment case was that Commissioner Roger Goodell should ensure that Richie Incognito never be allowed to play another down in the N.F.L. Incognito, the Dolphins’ suspended offensive lineman, was the ringleader and catalyst of a reign of terror directed primarily at his teammate Jonathan Martin for two seasons.

headline: Ancestral Enemies Meet at Olympics for a Toast to Amity
abstract: A Jewish reporter shares drinks and compares views on history with one of the Cossacks in charge of the security detail at the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — I nearly missed my tea with a Cossack.

headline: Lebanon Forms a Cabinet After 11 Months of Deadlock
abstract: The cabinet’s 24 members span the political spectrum, including Hezbollah, the militant Shiite organization, and its Western-backed foes.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon’s new prime minister, Tammam Salam, announced the formation of a cabinet on Saturday that represents many of the country’s deeply divided political factions, ending a nearly 11-month standoff that had left the government ill equipped to deal with increasing violence and a growing Syrian refugee population.

headline: At 18, Mikaela Shiffrin Has Envisioned the Best and the Worst
abstract: Shiffrin, the 18 year-old American and defending world champion in slalom, is looking to win a medal in two events at the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Mikaela Shiffrin, the 18-year-old defending world champion in slalom, arrived here Friday night, and less than 24 hours later reporters asked her if she could rescue the struggling American ski team.

headline: Document Describes Eavesdropping on American Law Firm
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: An excerpt of a National Security Agency document describes how Australian intelligence conducted surveillance of trade talks between Indonesia and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Following is an excerpt from a document provided by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden. It is from the February 2013 edition of a monthly bulletin of SUSLOC, the acronym for the N.S.A. office that handles liaisons with Australian intelligence. It describes how Australian intelligence conducted surveillance of trade talks between Indonesia and the United States and, in the process, monitored communications between Indonesian officials and an American law firm retained by Indonesia for help with the trade dispute. The Australians then sought legal guidance from the N.S.A. (The document refers to the D.S.D — the Defense Signals Directorate — the former name of Australia’s counterpart to the N.S.A. In May 2013, the agency was renamed the Australian Signals Directorate, or A.S.D.)

headline: Spying by N.S.A. Ally Entangled U.S. Law Firm
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: A document obtained by Edward J. Snowden shows that Australia consulted with the N.S.A. about monitoring an American law firm that was representing Indonesia in trade disputes with the United States.
lead_paragraph: The list of those caught up in the global surveillance net cast by the National Security Agency and its overseas partners, from social media users to foreign heads of state, now includes another entry: American lawyers.

headline: After Second Round of Syria Talks, No Agreement Even on How to Negotiate
abstract: The United Nations mediator for Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, wrapped up the second round of peace talks on Saturday without breaking a longstanding deadlock or setting a date for a third round.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations mediator for Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, wrapped up the second round of peace talks here on Saturday without breaking a longstanding deadlock or setting a date for a third round, and urged the parties to think seriously about their commitment to the negotiations.

headline: Chinese Ask Kerry to Help Tear Down a Firewall
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'United States International Relations', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'News and News Media', 'Censorship']
abstract: Meeting with Secretary of State John Kerry, a group of Chinese bloggers appealed to the United States to take up the cause of Internet freedom.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A group of Chinese bloggers asked the United States to take up the cause of Internet freedom in an unusual meeting on Saturday with Secretary of State John Kerry.

headline: Mob Attacks More Than a Dozen Gay Men in Nigeria’s Capital
abstract: A mob attacked gay people in a neighborhood in Abuja, Nigeria, beating them with whips and nail-studded clubs. When four victims were dragged to a nearby police station, police officers also beat them.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A mob attacked gay people in a neighborhood in Abuja, the capital of Nigeria, dragging young men from their homes, beating them with nail-studded clubs and whips, and shouting that they were “cleansing the community” of gays, several Nigerian activists and a witness said Saturday.

headline: J.W. Anderson: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Olympians May Go From Sochi to N.H.L. Trading Block
abstract: The league’s trade window opens shortly after the gold medal game in Sochi, and players whose contracts are about to expire are most vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: The best hockey players in the world are competing in the Olympics, but some of them face the prospect of being traded by their N.H.L. teams when the season resumes.

headline: A Severe Winter Breaks Budgets as Well as Pipes
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Plumbing', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Weather', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'States (US)', 'Local Government', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Winter (Season)']
abstract: Local and state authorities are facing new financial pressures this exceptionally stormy winter, with officials reporting increased spending on overtime, contractors and supplies.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE — Century-old water mains here have ruptured behind City Hall, popped in residential areas and split under the city’s bar and restaurant district. The mayor says she has personally reported three breaks, while exhausted crews work 18-hour shifts in subfreezing temperatures to repair the damage.

headline: The Remarkable One-Man Show Called T. J. Oshie
abstract: Oshie’s skill in shootouts and a quirk in Olympic rules made him the unquestioned star of the United States’ shootout victory over Russia.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Hockey is a team game, and this one was so big that it pitted country against country. But by the end, it turned into a simple contest of one-on-one.

headline: The Tame Truth About the Wolves of Wall Street
abstract: Unlike Hollywood’s idea of Wall Street partying, the only all-nighters I pulled were over spreadsheets.
lead_paragraph: MAYBE it’s those five Oscar nominations for “The Wolf of Wall Street,” including for best picture, best director and best actor, but we seem to be in another of those moments in popular culture when Hollywood plies us with skewed answers about how Wall Street miscreants caused so much mayhem.

headline: Driving to the Music of Chance
abstract: Listening to the car radio, I surrender control and let the D.J. take over.
lead_paragraph: I BOUGHT my car, a Jetta wagon, back in 2006. It was four years old and came with a five-CD cartridge lodged, impractically, over a rear wheel well. Not surprisingly, the CD player refuses to function on any less-than-perfect road — and in Brooklyn, where I live, there are few perfect roads. Even stop-and-start traffic makes the discs, well, stop and start. So when we want to hear music in the car, which is always, my family relies on the ad-riddled idiosyncrasies of commercial radio.

headline: The Never-Ending Candy Crush Saga
abstract: An obsession with a game app raises so many questions.
lead_paragraph: BY the end of 2013, more than half a billion people had installed Candy Crush Saga, and the addictive game app was generating just a little less than $1 million per day, according to its developer, King. Candy Crush Saga was the most downloaded app of the year in 2013, according to Apple.

headline: Start-Up America: Our Best Hope
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Start-ups', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The contrast between the vibe in Silicon Valley and the obstruction in Washington is quite telling.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — THE most striking thing about visiting Silicon Valley these days is how many creative ideas you can hear in just 48 hours.

headline: Marry First, Then Cheat
abstract: In France, it’s O.K. to cheat if you’re married, but not if you’re single.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — ONLY the French could have an etiquette scandal.

headline: The Line at the ‘Super PAC’ Trough
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Political Action Committees', 'Campaign Finance', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Political Advertising', 'Editorials']
abstract: An unlimited source of cash is now a requirement for contested congressional races.
lead_paragraph: If you need something out of Washington and want to give a satchel of cash to a political candidate, no need to give it directly to the candidate. Federal law limits those contributions to $2,600 anyway. The thing to do is to give the money to the candidate’s “super PAC,” where no limits apply, to pay for attack ads against the candidate’s opponent.

headline: An Encouraging Chinese Courtship
abstract: Beijing and Taiwan need to keep building on peaceful cooperation.
lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, the rivalry between mainland China and Taiwan was seen as one of the more likely triggers for international conflict. But while fundamental differences remain, the two sides have worked to ease tensions.

headline: James Bridle
abstract: The creator of the drone-mapping tool Dronestagram on playing in Nazi bunkers as a kid and watching art films online.
lead_paragraph: James Bridle is a British writer and artist whose work focuses on technology and how it shapes culture and societies. He is the creator of Dronestagram, on the photo-sharing site Instagram, which supplies images of the locations of drone strikes as they occur.

headline: Transgender, Schlumpy and Human
abstract: We finally have transgender characters in movies and TV. But what about transgender actors?
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — THERE’S a scene in the new Amazon show “Transparent” when the family patriarch, Mort, walks in on his oldest daughter in flagrante with her lesbian lover. The character, who’s been struggling throughout the pilot with how to come out as trans, stands there in drag with a bemused expression. “Hello, ladies,” Mort — now Maura — says.

headline: The Lore of Labor
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Midwives', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: Childbirth is a murky brew of science and tradition.
lead_paragraph: WHEN my water broke during the 35th week of my first pregnancy, I waddled down the block to our neighborhood’s brand-new hospital. This was in London, where I then lived, around 2 a.m., Dec. 13, 1993.

headline: Parental Pity Party
abstract: First comes the baby, and then all the whining starts about how impossible it all is.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I became a father, I expected to change in all the predictable ways — to become more responsible and more exhausted, to lose contact with friends and lean more heavily on relatives, to grow steadily balder of head and softer of belly.

headline: To Save Fish and Birds
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Research', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Birds', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Editorials', 'Fishing, Commercial']
abstract: A recent study found that, more often than not, marine-protected areas don’t work as well as they could.
lead_paragraph: One of the few bright spots in the struggle to protect the world’s fragile oceans has been the rapidly increasing number of “marine-protected areas,” places where fishing is limited or banned and where, presumably, depleted species can recover by simply being left to themselves. The benefits of hands-off environmental protection may seem self-evident. But creating a preserve and rebuilding a healthy ecosystem are not necessarily the same thing. A recent study published in Nature found that, more often than not, marine-protected areas don’t work as well as they could.

headline: Professors, We Need You!
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Graduate Schools and Students']
abstract: Academics are some of the smartest minds in the world. So why are they making themselves irrelevant?
lead_paragraph: SOME of the smartest thinkers on problems at home and around the world are university professors, but most of them just don’t matter in today’s great debates.

headline: Is Harlem ‘Good’ Now?
abstract: The neighborhood taught me, a Swedish chef of African descent, about hospitality.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was walking to work one day last summer, I noticed that Crab Man Mike was gone from his usual post at 125th Street and Fifth Avenue. Mike has been cooking shellfish in his special pot on the streets of Harlem for 23 years. Concerned, I began asking the other street vendors where he went. Johnny Portland, one of the Jamaican guys who also sets up some days at 125th and Fifth, told me Crab Mike had moved.

headline: Social Media, a Trove of Clues and Confessions
abstract: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and MySpace are creating new challenges for the legal system.
lead_paragraph: IT seems as if every week there’s a news story about someone committing a crime and confessing to it on Facebook, bragging about it on Twitter or sharing photos of it via Instagram. In many ways, social media has been a boon for law enforcement, handing the police ready admissions of guilt, equipping criminal investigators with new types of evidence and empowering prosecutors to better dispel reasonable doubt of guilt.

headline: Home, Dismantled
abstract: The first installment of a week-long series on grief, mourning, memory — and the clearing out of a childhood home after a father’s death.
lead_paragraph: This is the first part of an eight-part series.

headline: Let Our Lawmakers Hide!
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Behold the costume party that is Congress, where members wear faces at odds with their souls.
lead_paragraph: AN idea for the Senate: brown paper bags. You know, the kind in which you cut little holes for your eyes and your nose and a bigger, wider hole for your mouth. Senators could wear these in the chamber, so that the C-Span cameras and the outside world wouldn’t know precisely who’s supporting what. Or maybe ski masks, though those wreak havoc on hairdos. Alternately, the lawmakers could communicate in code: anything to obscure their actions and make it easier for them to actually cast votes in line with their best judgment and consciences. Oh, you thought they always did that? Well then I won’t spill the beans on Santa or the Easter bunny, either.

headline: Sochi Video Notebook: T. J. Oshie
abstract: T. J. Oshie, who took six of the Americans’ eight shots, scoring on four of them to lift the team to a victory over Russia, spoke to the media after the game.
lead_paragraph: T. J. Oshie, who took six of the Americans’ eight shots, scoring on four of them to lift the team to a victory over Russia, spoke to the media after the game.

headline: London Fashion Week: Central Saint Martins Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Photos Become Ads With New Technology
abstract: A new technology starting to catch the attention of publishers can turn any visual element on a web page, including editorial photographs and videos, into advertisements.
lead_paragraph: Online publishers have been doing a lot of soul-searching lately about how to give their advertising revenue a shot of adrenaline without upsetting their readers. Native advertising, in which stories commissioned by sponsors are dressed up to resemble editorial material, is one of the most widely discussed efforts by publishers (including efforts at The New York Times).

headline: A Long, Strange Trip to the Basketball Hall of Fame
abstract: Sarunas Marciulionis, a star for Lithuania and a top N.B.A. player off the bench, was directly elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame by the international committee last week.
lead_paragraph: In the 1992 Summer Olympics, most eyes were on the Dream Team. Perhaps the greatest group of players ever assembled, the Americans took the world by storm, reclaiming supremacy in basketball and inspiring the world to take up the sport in earnest.

headline: Out in the Cold
abstract: Cities deal with water main breaks, potholes and roof damage as a result of the severe winter weather.
lead_paragraph: Cities deal with water main breaks, potholes and roof damage as a result of the severe winter weather.

headline: In Short-Track Speedskating, Skill Struggles to Overcome Dumb Luck
abstract: Athletes can do exactly what they are supposed to do and still find themselves out of contention because someone else slipped up.
lead_paragraph: The collision that sent Eddy Alvarez sprawling on the ice and out of the men’s 1,000-meter short-track competition happened so fast that even his description of it, a few minutes later, was barely longer than a haiku.

headline: Bridging the Moat Around Universities
abstract: Readers comment on my column about the way academia removes itself from the grand public debates of America.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is about the unfortunate way America has marginalized university professors–and, perhaps sadder still, the way they have marginalized themselves from public debate. When I was a kid, the Kennedy administration had its “brain trust” of Harvard faculty members, and university professors were often vital public intellectuals who served off and on in government. That’s still true to some degree of economists, but not of most other Ph.D programs. And we’re all the losers for that.

headline: U.N. Panel Finds Crimes Against Humanity in North Korea
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: After a yearlong investigation, the panel said it found evidence of an array of offenses, including crimes against humanity, in a report that will be released on Monday.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — United Nations investigators say North Korea has committed wide-ranging crimes against humanity to sustain its political system, and recommend that it be referred to the International Criminal Court.

headline: Addendum: Geithner and Treasury Department on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
abstract: Comments were received from both a spokeswoman for Timothy Geithner, the former Treasury secretary, and a Treasury Department spokesman after the publication deadline of a recent column.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to obtain comment from both the Treasury Department and Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary, were unsuccessful before publication of “The Untouchable Profits of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac” (Feb. 16, 2014). A Treasury Department spokesman declined to comment, and Mr. Geithner did not respond to a request for comment. In both instances, they were asked why the department had not disclosed to Fannie and Freddie stockholders the administration’s commitment to deprive them of any future positive earnings generated by the companies.

headline: One Nation Under Guard
abstract: Growing inequality means we’re spending more on security, instead of making stuff.
lead_paragraph: Another dubious first for America: We now employ as many private security guards as high school teachers — over one million of them, or nearly double their number in 1980.

headline: Ahn Wins Second Medal in 1,000 Meters
abstract: Picture sequence showing who held the lead in each lap of the race.
lead_paragraph: Picture sequence showing who held the lead in each lap of the race.

headline: Obama Meets With the King of Jordan
abstract: President Barack Obama meets with King Abdullah II to pledge $1 billion in loan guarantees for Jordan and to consider new ways to pressure the regime of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.
lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama meets with King Abdullah II to pledge $1 billion in loan guarantees for Jordan and to consider new ways to pressure the regime of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

headline: Intel’s Sharp-Eyed Social Scientist
abstract: As part of Intel’s mission to be regarded as more than just a chip maker, the anthropologist Genevieve Bell leads a globe-trotting team that is trying to learn what people crave in their electronics.
lead_paragraph: Behind the gray, noise-absorbing cubicle walls at the Intel Corporation in Hillsboro, Ore., researchers who forecast the future of computing can sense her arrival.

headline: As Bubka Watches, His Record, Set in 1993, Falls
abstract: The French pole-vaulter Renaud Lavillenie broke Sergei Bubka’s nearly 21-year-old world record at an indoor meet in Donetsk, Ukraine, with Bubka, 50, watching from the stands.
lead_paragraph: The timing could have been better for the French pole-vaulter Renaud Lavillenie.

headline: On the Mountain, a Wild Ride
abstract: The Olympics’ outdoor venues, scattered along the slopes at various altitudes, are accessible via a confusing system of buses, vans and cable cars.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — I was not enjoying my cable car ride high above the mountains the other day, so I turned for reassurance to my gondola-mates, some Russian luge fans passing the time by cracking what seemed to be jokes about Kazakhstan. They did not understand me — I think they thought I was making the international signal for choking rather than for vertigo — so I tried to focus on the matter at hand: getting from the snowboarding park to the luge track sometime within the next 24 hours.

headline: Jury Reaches Partial Verdict in Florida Killing Over Loud Music
abstract: Michael Dunn, a white man who admitted shooting Jordan Davis, a black 17-year-old, was convicted of three counts of second-degree attempted murder, but not first-degree murder.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — After four days of deliberation, the jury in the racially tinged trial of Michael Dunn, a Florida man who set off another firestorm over the state’s self-defense laws when he shot a teenager to death in a parking lot during a dispute over loud music, said it could not agree on whether Mr. Dunn had acted to protect himself or was guilty of murder.

headline: A Hockey Rivalry Moves Beyond the Ice
abstract: Though the relationship between the United States and Russia has grown increasingly tense, none of that stress has trickled down to its playing fields, at least not yet.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The Sochi Games organizer Dmitry Chernyshenko has turned to the same line again and again when asked to describe how he and certain other Russians feel about the United States’ Olympic hockey team.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 16
abstract: The East Coast was blanketed by snow last week and California’s record-setting drought persists. The Sunday shows will discuss the extreme weather and 2016 presidential prospects.
lead_paragraph: A powerful storm dumped record amounts of snow and ice on the East Coast, leaving stranded travelers and downed power lines in its wake. North Carolina’s highways were littered with abandoned cars after snowfall during the day paralyzed the evening rush, a similar scene to Atlanta’s gridlock in late January.

headline: American’s Skeleton Run Goes Awry
abstract: John Daly had a chance for a bronze medal but lost control of his sled at the start and finished 15th.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — John Daly of the United States was in fourth place going into the fourth heat of the men’s skeleton final on Saturday when he botched his run just as it was beginning. It is unclear how exactly it happened — possibly he was too eager or too aggressive — but as he ran alongside and flung himself onto his sled at the top of the track, the sled popped out of the groove meant to guide it through its initial descent.

headline: Now No. 96 for Yankees, Possible Future Alternative to No. 13
abstract: The minor leaguer Peter O’Brien, a slugging catcher, played third base in the Arizona Instructional League and could eventually play there for New York if Alex Rodriguez is not welcomed back.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — There is no better time for wishful thinking, if not pure fantasy, than on the day of the first spring training workout for pitchers and catchers. So mull over the delicious possibility, however distant or remote, of Alex Rodriguez’s eventual long-term replacement at third base being a converted catcher who hails from Miami and happened to play a season of college baseball at the ballpark that bears A-Rod’s tainted name.

headline: Polish Ski Jumper Sweeps Individual Events
abstract: Kamil Stoch won the gold medal on the large hill, making him only the third person to win two individual ski jump events in the same Winter Games.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Kamil Stoch of Poland and Noriaki Kasai of Japan seemed to wait forever as they watched the scoreboard to see who would get the gold medal and who would settle for the silver in the large-hill ski jump on Saturday.

headline: The Oddities of Olympic Park
abstract: In many ways, the vast park caters avidly to the West, and the United States in particular. But behind the familiar trappings, many aspects of the Games are distinctly Russian.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Snicker all you like at the well-publicized oddities and spectacular expense of these Winter Games, but give it up for the train that delivers visitors to Olympic Park. A digital sign on the platform at the next-to-last stop says that it will arrive at 1:14 and leave at 1:15, and it delivers on that promise, right down to the second.

headline: Mets Hope an Aging Ace Can Still Provide a Lift
abstract: Bartolo Colon, 40, who in the past energized the Expos and Athletics among others, is being counted on to help replace Matt Harvey in the Mets rotation this season.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Early in the summer of 2002, Omar Minaya, the general manager of the Montreal Expos, made what he thought was an easy trade. After five consecutive losing seasons, the Expos, behind Vladimir Guerrero and Jose Vidro, were surprise contenders, in need of a boost. This was perhaps their last hurrah.

headline: Tanaka Gains a Mentor but Loses His Breath
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka, 25, who went through his first official workout with the Yankees on Saturday, has much to learn from the 39-year-old Hiroki Kuroda.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Soon after Masahiro Tanaka signed with the Yankees last month, one of the first things he did was to call Hiroki Kuroda, his new teammate and Japanese compatriot. It was part of Tanaka’s duty in accordance with the senpai-kohai relationship.

headline: Passing Grades
abstract: Yaakov BenDavid grades us on a curve, thank goodness.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s always a relief when you find out the teacher is grading on a curve, and that’s precisely what Yaakov BenDavid has for us today. You wouldn’t want to get all the way to the end of your solving week just to find out that you had failed.

headline: London Fashion Week: J.W. Anderson Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: A Ukraine City Spins Beyond the Government’s Reach
abstract: Lviv and the surrounding region have largely achieved what protesters in Kiev have been demanding since November: the end of the authority of President Viktor F. Yanukovych.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, UKRAINE — Oleh Salo, the Ukrainian state’s senior representative in this western region, was hard at work keeping up appearances. He had just completed a new budget, he explained, and had an urgent meeting with the newly appointed local chief of Ukraine’s security service.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: February 14, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses a different type of auto union in Tennessee and the Comcast/Time Warner deal.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen autoworkers in Tennessee may form the nation’s first “works council,” a type of union popular in Germany in which employees and management work together to make decisions. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine examine how significant the move would be for the nation’s labor movement, and why some officials and policy groups are opposed to it. Plus, a discussion of Comcast’s purchase of Time Warner Cable.

headline: Crossing Borders and Changing Lives, Lured by Higher State Minimum Wages
abstract: A rolling borderland of onion farms and strip malls provides a test tube of sorts for observing how the minimum wage works in daily life.
lead_paragraph: ONTARIO, Ore. — Carly Lynch dreams of a life one day on the professional rodeo circuit, but for now she commutes 20 miles from Idaho to this small city in eastern Oregon to work as a waitress. There are restaurant jobs closer to home, but she is willing to drive the extra miles for a simple reason: Oregon’s minimum wage is $1.85 higher per hour than Idaho’s.

headline: Pete Camarata, Who Fought Fellow Teamsters for Reforms, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Camarata headed the dissident group Teamsters for a Democratic Union, which grew to more than 8,000 members.
lead_paragraph: In 1976, Frank Fitzsimmons, president of the Teamsters, struck a defiant note in a speech at the union’s convention in Las Vegas. “To those who say it is time to reform this organization, and it’s time officers stopped selling out the members,” he said, “I say to them, ‘Go to hell.’ ”

headline: Examples of Health Care 'Props'
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Healthcare Reform']
abstract: Both Democrats and Republicans like to use real-life examples to back up their positions on the Affordable Care Act. But sometimes reality is more complicated.
lead_paragraph: Both Democrats and Republicans like to use real-life examples to back up their positions on the Affordable Care Act. But sometimes reality is more complicated.

headline: In the Debate Over Health Care, ‘Real People’ Become Human Volleyballs
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: Democrats and Republicans alike resort to “real people” to get their messages across, sometimes with unexpected consequences.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the Republican response to the State of the Union address, Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington lamented the travails of “Bette in Spokane,” whose insurance policy had been canceled because of the health care law and who faced huge premium increases to replace it.

headline: Reconsidering the Legacy of Lyndon B. Johnson
abstract: Relatives and friends of Lyndon Baines Johnson say that his legacy has been tainted by the Vietnam War, and they are working to put forth a broader view of his presidency.
lead_paragraph: Relatives and friends of Lyndon Baines Johnson say that his legacy has been tainted by the Vietnam War, and they are working to put forth a broader view of his presidency.

headline: Legacy of L.B.J.
abstract: “The agony of Vietnam looms over all of us,” said Luci Baines Johnson, who argues that the war overshadowed the domestic achievements of her father, President Lyndon B. Johnson.
lead_paragraph: “The agony of Vietnam looms over all of us,” said Luci Baines Johnson, who argues that the war overshadowed the domestic achievements of her father, President Lyndon B. Johnson.

headline: A New Resource for Buddhist Scholars
keywords: ['Buddhism', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: The Tibetan Buddhist Resource Center opened its library, with 12,000 works, at the Southwest University for Nationalities in Chengdu, China, in October. Archivists plan to scan the texts digitally.
lead_paragraph: The Tibetan Buddhist Resource Center opened its library, with 12,000 works, at the Southwest University for Nationalities in Chengdu, China, in October. Archivists plan to scan the texts digitally.

headline: In the Party, but Trying Hard to Stand Out
abstract: With so many open races and ambitious candidates, particularly on the Republican side, using party labels is an insufficient means of swaying voters in the March 4 primary.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: After Winding Odyssey, Tibetan Texts Find Home in China
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Buddhism', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: An American scholar’s trove of 12,000 Tibetan-language texts has a new home, a lavishly decorated library on the campus of the Southwest University for Nationalities in Chengdu, China.
lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — Decades ago, the thousands of Tibetan-language books now ensconced in a lavishly decorated library in southwest China might have ended up in a raging bonfire. During the tumultuous decade of the Cultural Revolution, which ended in 1976, Red Guard zealots destroyed anything deemed “feudal.” But an American scholar, galvanized in part by those rampages, embarked on a mission to collect and preserve the remnants of Tibetan culture.

headline: Rescuing a Vietnam Casualty: Johnson’s Legacy
abstract: As the 50th anniversary of Lyndon B. Johnson’s presidential milestones approaches, his allies are highlighting domestic successes they say were overshadowed by the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Luci Baines Johnson leaned forward in her father’s private suite at the L.B.J. Presidential Library, her voice breaking as she recounted the “agony of Vietnam” that engulfed Lyndon Baines Johnson and the pain she feels to this day of witnessing his presidency judged through the prism of a failed war.

headline: Union Hears From Potential Leaders
abstract: The N.B.A. players union gathered for a meeting during which candidates to become its executive director gave presentations and answered questions from about 30 players.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The N.B.A. players union, which has been without an executive director since Billy Hunter was fired a year ago, gathered Saturday afternoon for a two-hour meeting during which candidates for the position gave presentations and answered questions from about 30 players, including the Knicks’ Carmelo Anthony.

headline: ‘Las Marthas’: Debutantes in Laredo, Surprisingly Colonial
abstract: Cristina Ibarra’s film reveals a longtime Laredo tradition, of young Latinas making their debuts through the Society of Martha Washington, which reveres America’s Colonial and very Anglo past.
lead_paragraph: Most contemporary entertainment set along the Mexican border tends to focus on the brutal drug wars that have killed scores of thousands. Consider the film “No Country for Old Men,” or the FX series “The Bridge.” And with the exception of the occasional hard-driving female detective, women in these stories tend to be passive figures or the victims of grisly violence.

headline: Elite Couple’s Valentine: Be Mine but Be Rested
abstract: Ashton Eaton and Brianne Thiesen-Eaton passed on the romantic dinner and got a good night’s sleep before their track and field events at the Millrose Games.
lead_paragraph: On the sixth anniversary of their first date, Ashton Eaton and Brianne Thiesen-Eaton skipped the fancy dinner and were in bed by 9 p.m., forgoing romance for much-needed rest. A big afternoon awaited.

headline: The Confederate Washingtons
abstract: Why many of the descendants of the first president fought for the South during the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Lincoln must have been pained by the number of Washingtons on the other side during the Civil War. He idolized George Washington. One of the first books he read as a boy was Parson Weems’s apocryphal biography of the first president, and it made a lasting impression. Later, as a congressman, Lincoln made a pilgrimage to Washington’s Mount Vernon and regaled his friends afterward about the experience.

headline: The Next Colorado or Washington: Probably Not Here
abstract: Texas’ marijuana laws are considered less severe than the state’s tough-on-crime reputation would suggest, but analysts do not expect the state to legalize or decriminalize the drug anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — It was not long after Gov. Rick Perry’s remarks that states should enact their own marijuana laws that social media sites began wondering if the theory of relativity was a sham or whether Pink Floyd’s estranged founder would finally rejoin the band.

headline: Pregnant Inmates Find Help to Ease Shift to World Outside
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Mentors', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Mentoring Moms, a program at the Harris County Jail, teaches inmates who are pregnant or have young children how to find jobs, beat addictions and be better parents.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — At the “pregnancy tank” at the Harris County Jail, asking a female inmate “How much longer do you have?” can get a puzzled look in response. She could answer with a due date or an anticipated date of discharge from jail.

headline: Afghan Army’s Test Begins With Fight for Vital Highway
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: A week with Afghan troops safeguarding Highway 1 offers glimpses of a road war in which powerful leaders on all sides battle for control of Afghanistan’s crucial artery.
lead_paragraph: CHAK, Afghanistan — In a deserted village off Highway 1, southwest of Kabul, an Afghan Army bomb disposal team was unearthing its 15th bomb of the day when sniper shots began to rain down.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 15, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: After Unexpected Climb Into Playoff, Bulgarian Is King of the Rock
abstract: Ivan Cheparinov, who was ranked as No. 17 in the tournament field, won a playoff to take the crown at the Tradewise Gibraltar Chess Festival.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Cheparinov won a three-way playoff to take the title at the 12th Tradewise Gibraltar Chess Festival this month.

headline: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund Trust and Estate Donors
abstract: Following are the trusts and estates that contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund’s 102nd campaign.
lead_paragraph: TRUSTS

headline: Fund Provided Relief, and Then Readers Gave Even More
abstract: A host of empathetic readers and donors helped those seeking a change in their lives, raising nearly $6 million for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund during its 102nd campaign.
lead_paragraph: Once again, a host of empathetic readers and donors helped those seeking a change in their lives, with their contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund during its 102nd campaign.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 16, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, February 16, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Nobody wanted that war less than Lyndon Johnson. No matter how hard he tried, he didn’t seem to be able to get out of that quagmire. Not only did he not get out of it in his lifetime, but his legacy indeed has that weight of the world on it.”

headline: Slave No More
abstract: As the runway revolves, one front-row fashion fixture ponders how practical dressing has come to feel like the most modern of ideas, and why designers haven’t quite caught on.
lead_paragraph: As the runway revolves, one front-row fashion fixture ponders how practical dressing has come to feel like the most modern of ideas, and why designers haven’t quite caught on.

headline: Corrections: February 16, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 16, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Adam Rose and Peter McQuillan
abstract: The couple — a president of a family real estate development and management firm and a retired New York City police sergeant — met at the former Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center in 1991.
lead_paragraph: Adam R. Rose, a son of Sandra Priest Rose of Rye, N.Y., and the late Frederick P. Rose, was married Tuesday evening to Peter R. McQuillan, the son of Celia M.
