McQuillan of Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Richard J. McQuillan. Betsy Gotbaum, a friend of the couple who until 2009 was the public advocate of the City of New York, became a Universal Life minister for the occasion and officiated at the couple’s Manhattan apartment.

headline: Danielle McFall, Schuyler Weiss
abstract: The bride is the manager of a dance company; the groom is a film producer.
lead_paragraph: Danielle Renée McFall and Schuyler Sussman Weiss are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Nikki L. DeBlosi at the Park restaurant in New York.

headline: Eve Weston, Zachary Pincus-Roth
abstract: The bride is a comedy writer for television; the groom is an arts and culture editor for a weekly newspaper.
lead_paragraph: Eve Meryl Weston and Zachary Pincus-Roth are to be married Sunday at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in San Diego, where Rabbi Wayne D. Dosick will officiate in the Robert Paine Scripps Forum for Science, Society and the Environment.

headline: Delia Pais and Joseph Kristol
abstract: The couple met at Harvard, from which they graduated.
lead_paragraph: Delia Ann Pais, a daughter of Mara D. Pais and Richard A. Pais of Bel Air, Md., is to be married Sunday evening to Joseph Max Kristol, the son of Susan S. Kristol and William Kristol of McLean, Va. Rabbi David Kalender is to officiate at the Columbus Club, an event space at Union Station in Washington.

headline: Diana Dosik and Matthew Schwab
abstract: The bride, a graduate of Yale, and the groom, a graduate of Penn, help devise strategies at a consulting firm.
lead_paragraph: Diana Alix Dosik and Matthew Aaron Schwab were married Monday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the city clerk’s office, officiated. On Sunday, Dr. Mark H. Kaplan, the bride’s uncle who became a Universal Life minister for the event, led a ceremony that incorporated Jewish traditions at the St. Regis Bahia Beach Resort in Rio Grande, P.R.

headline: Julia Foster, Mark Mezrich
abstract: The bride is the marketing director in New York at City Harvest; the groom is a vice president for MTV, VH1 and CMT.
lead_paragraph: Julia Kurz Foster and Mark Nathaniel Mezrich are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Steven A. Exler at the Harvard Club of New York.

headline: Carrie Kingsley, Marc Miller
abstract: The bride is the general counsel for M. Safra & Co.; the groom is a senior software programmer for Google.
lead_paragraph: Carrie Beth Kingsley and Marc Matthew Miller were married Saturday evening at the City Winery in Manhattan. Rabbi Lauren Grabelle Herrmann officiated.

headline: Kathryn McLoughlin, Christopher LaVine
abstract: The bride works in Princeton, N.J., as a district business manager for Bristol Myers Squibb. The groom is a portfolio manager at Rational Group, a New York financial advisory and technology company.
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Towler McLoughlin and Christopher Dalton LaVine were married Saturday at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in George Town, Grand Cayman. The Rev. Suresh Rajaian, a Roman Catholic priest and pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: David Rodriguez Lind and George Thomas II
abstract: Mr. Rodriguez Lind was a mortgage closer for a bank; Mr. Thomas is a privacy and security manager for a medical center.
lead_paragraph: David Anthony Rodriguez Lind and George Arthur Thomas II were married Saturday at the Loft at Prince, an event space in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Gregory Anton McCants, a Baptist minister, officiated.

headline: Varinda Missett, Eric Straus
abstract: The couple’s five children all became Universal Life ministers and are to contribute to the ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Varinda Singh Missett and Eric Peter Straus are to be married Sunday evening at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in New York. Jacob Straus, the groom’s son who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate. The couple’s other four children, Mitchell Kuhnert, Samantha Missett, Madison Missett and Emily Straus, also became Universal Life ministers, and will contribute to the ceremony.

headline: Courtney Booth and Gus Christensen
abstract: The bride is an assistant vice president in trusts and estates at Sotheby’s; the groom is a candidate for the New York State Assembly.
lead_paragraph: Courtney Elizabeth Booth and Gus Christensen were married Saturday at St. Christopher’s Church in Gladwyne, Pa. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: From Love to Friendship and Back Again
abstract: The bride is a litigation associate; the groom is a trial lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Erin Elizabeth O’Brien Breen and Steven Daniel Zecca were married Saturday in Port Jefferson, N.Y. The Rev. Patrick M. Riegger performed the ceremony at Infant Jesus Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Clarissa Cruz, Theodore Maniatis
abstract: The couple are married in Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: Clarissa Lynn Cruz and Theodore Jason Maniatis were married Saturday at SS. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Pacific in Honolulu. The Rev. Alexander Leong, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Natalia Bedoya and Timothy McGinn Jr.
abstract: The couple, both graduates of Harvard, received law degrees from Duke.
lead_paragraph: Natalia Beatriz Bedoya and Timothy John McGinn Jr. were married Saturday at Gesù Catholic Church in Miami. The Rev. Eduardo J. Alvarez, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Beth Rosen, Maryann King
abstract: Ms. Rosen is a psychotherapist; Ms. King is an administrator at Congregation Habonim in New York.
lead_paragraph: Beth Susan Rosen and Maryann King are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Sharon A. Kleinbaum at Congregation Habonim in New York.

headline: Always Room at the Inn for Another Medal
abstract: Norway’s Kjetil Jansrud won gold, Andrew Weibrecht was the surprise silver medalist and Bode Miller finished in a tie for bronze.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Displayed next to the reception desk at the Mirror Lake Inn in Lake Placid, N.Y., is a bronze medal from the 2010 Winter Olympics, a prize taken home by the son of the inn’s owners.

headline: What’s On Today?
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Telemundo) TOP CHEF ESTRELLAS Eight Hispanic celebrities — above from left, Nancy Álvarez, David Chocarro, Erika De La Rosa and Christian Chávez, along with Fernando Arau, Christian de la Campa, Lorena Herrera and Cynthia Olavarría — demonstrate their culinary skills in an effort to win $100,000 for charity in this new Spanish-language series, based on Bravo’s “Top Chef” franchise. The actress Aylín Mújica hosts; the chefs Lorena García, Jaime Martin Del Campo and Ramiro Arvizu are the judges. In a twist, eliminated contestants will become sous chefs instead of going home. “Suelta La Sopa Extra,” at 10, features recaps with cast members and behind-the-scenes footage.

headline: At Asia Air Show, Plenty of Competition for Sales of Drones
abstract: Military contractors from Austria, Australia, Israel, the United States and other countries showcased unmanned aerial vehicles throughout the week at the Singapore Airshow.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — While the supersonic jets, attack helicopters and surface-to-air missiles longer than a stretch limousine wowed an estimated 80,000 people who attended the final days of the Singapore Airshow over the weekend, it was a small, silent and unarmed weapon that took center stage as major players in the Southeast Asia weapons market hawked their wares.

headline: Preen: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: In Carolina Herrera They Trust
abstract: The designer’s winter 2014 collection was another example of why clients, including Michelle Obama, rely on her for elegant creations.
lead_paragraph: When Michelle Obama wore a Carolina Herrera dress, with a scoop front lacy embroidered top and “French blue” ball skirt, to greet President François Hollande of France at the White House, she could not have given a better fillip to New York Fashion Week.

headline: Jason Wu Debuts at Hugo Boss
abstract: The designer’s 100-piece collection needed more belief in female tailoring and, perhaps, fewer cocktail dresses.
lead_paragraph: Men’s wear companies expanding their female lines seem to be a strong fashion trend. Even before Ralph Lauren made his bold New York Fashion Week statement by showing a new female Polo range, Hugo Boss, the German men’s fashion powerhouse, had tapped Jason Wu to expand and clarify its women’s collection.

headline: Anna Sui: Asia Through Western Eyes
abstract: The designer’s collection was inspired by the 1920s film star Anna May Wong.
lead_paragraph: The idea of designers with Asian roots being inspired by a Western parody of their countries’ clothes would have been unthinkable a decade ago, but fusion fashion is fast following the food version.

headline: Reed Krakoff: Fusing Luxury and Minimalism
abstract: His winter 2014 collection mixes fabulous fabrics and surprising surfaces.
lead_paragraph: Reed Krakoff has finally found his comfort zone for modern style. His collection for winter 2014 was all about a rare but important species: the WWWs, or the “wealthy who work.”

headline: Lindsey Jacobellis Again Comes Up Short in Snowboard Cross
abstract: Jacobellis crashed in the semifinal while holding a big lead and failed to win a medal at her third Olympics.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Again, there was nothing in front of Lindsey Jacobellis but open snow, a finish line and a mountain of possibility. She was in the lead, a pack of women chasing with little hope of catching the most accomplished female snowboard-cross rider in history.

headline: Coach’s New Designer Puts the Emphasis on American Luxury
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Stuart Vevers’s collection includes a square-cut coat, shearling hoodies and handbags with useful pockets.
lead_paragraph: When Bonnie Cashin, the inventor of American sportswear, worked at Coach from 1962 to 1975, she revolutionized the handbag, giving it color, practical inside pockets for a dynamic new woman and the silver toggle — an early brand hallmark — that was inspired by the hood fastening on her convertible.

headline: Marchesa Goes to the Scottish Highlands
abstract: The red carpet label, along with collections by Zac Posen and Vera Wang, seemed to have taken a trip north for winter 2014.
lead_paragraph: Could Marchesa, a fashion child of the red carpet, really be pulling back from celebrity and migrating to the Scottish Highlands? The most immediate statement from Keren Craig and Georgina Chapman might have been the colors, inspired by copper pans, a fiery hearth, smoky fog and cinnamon in the soup. It all seemed a long way from the duo’s favored Los Angeles.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: In Our Pages: February 17
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1889: A Church Scandal

headline: The Dog’s One Big Headache, but My Kids Adore Her
abstract: She’s a 125-pound nervous, incontinent beast with a carpet-destroying digestive system, but I can’t bring myself to find her another home.
lead_paragraph: Our dog, who is nervous, incontinent and prone to other “accidents,” has been a liability since Day 1. The sensible thing for me to do would be to find her a good new home, which I’m sure I could do. But not only do I feel like that would be a failure on my part, I also suspect it might send the message to my kids that problematic family members can be cast off when they become burdensome. As an older parent, I need to consider these things carefully.

headline: 18 Feared Dead in Nepalese Air Crash
abstract: An official at the airport in Katmandu, the capital, blamed bad weather for the crash, saying it had been snowing for much of the day.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — A Nepal Airlines plane bound for the city of Jumla from Katmandu, the capital, crashed in the forests of western Nepal on Sunday, almost certainly killing all 18 people aboard, officials said.

headline: Difficult Day for South Koreans as Native Son Wins Gold, for Russia
abstract: Viktor Ahn, formerly Ahn Hyun-soo, was a celebrated speed skater in South Korea — until circumstances changed.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — When the short-track speed skater Viktor Ahn waved the Russian flag on his victory lap and sang the Russian national anthem on Saturday after winning the gold medal in the men’s 1,000 meters at Winter Olympics on Saturday, it was a poignant scene for South Koreans.

headline: Bombing of Tourist Bus Kills at Least Three in Sinai
abstract: The cause of the explosion was not certain, but it raised fears that Egyptian militants were expanding their campaign against the security services to include civilians.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — At least two South Korean tourists and their Egyptian driver were killed on Sunday when an explosion ripped through a tour bus in a resort town in the Sinai Peninsula, in what officials said was the first deadly attack on tourists by militants in Egypt in at least three years.

headline: Iron Men of Wall Street
abstract: Enough with the movie stars.
lead_paragraph: Greg Mankiw has written another defense of the 0.1 percent — and this one is kind of amazing.

headline: Disruptions: Using Addictive Games to Build Better Brains
keywords: ['Addiction (Psychology)', 'Brain', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Memory', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Research']
abstract: Researchers are studying the qualities that make some video games hard to put down, in order to build games that improve memory or other functions or even treat disorders.
lead_paragraph: First it was Doodle Jump. Then Dots. And now — will it never end? — Flappy Bird.

headline: Iraqi Cleric Says Again He’ll Quit Politics
abstract: Moktada al-Sadr, who became one of Iraq’s most popular political leaders, has made such announcements before, but his statement added uncertainty to the political situation in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Moktada al-Sadr, the anti-American Shiite cleric who became one of Iraq’s most powerful political leaders, said he was withdrawing from politics and would no longer be represented in the Iraqi government or Parliament.

headline: Phil Kessel’s Hat Trick Gives Americans a Win
abstract: Kessel scored two of his three goals in the opening 4 minutes 33 seconds against Slovenia and became the first U.S. player with an Olympic hat trick in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Both goaltenders making their Sochi Games debuts in Sunday’s round-robin game between the United States and Slovenia had a certain measure of international success in 2010.

headline: Christopher Raeburn
abstract: Christopher Raeburn is known for repurposing materials in exciting ways. At London Fashion Week, Suzy Menkes talked with the designer about his vision and the future of his work.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Raeburn is known for repurposing materials in exciting ways. At London Fashion Week, Suzy Menkes talked with the designer about his vision and the future of his work.

headline: ‘Black Coal, Thin Ice’ Wins Top Prize at Berlin Festival
abstract: A film noir feature by the director Diao Yinan took the Golden Bear prize for best feature film at the Berlin Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese film noir, “Black Coal, Thin Ice,” directed by Diao Yinan, took the Golden Bear prize for best feature film at the Berlin Film Festival, while “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” a period caper set in interwar Europe took the Silver Bear Grand Jury Prize.

headline: A Harrowing Trip, Far From the Runways
abstract: Why was there a packed auditorium for a fashion house best known for its outerwear and the hiking boots the British call wellies?
lead_paragraph: Never let it be said that the Brits don’t have a sense of irony. Whether by design or odd coincidence, the models in the Marios Schwab show here on Sunday morning strutted out to the strains of the Doors’ “Riders on the Storm,” which drew a wry smile from more than a few people sitting in the front row.

headline: The Dutch Speedskaters Are Thrilled, the Americans Baffled
abstract: Abandoning their high-tech suits didn’t change the fortunes of the U.S. speedskaters, who failed to win a medal in the women’s 1,500 while the Netherlands won three.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — It was another tale of two speedskating teams here on Sunday night, with the Dutch team sweeping the podium yet again in the women’s 1,500 meters and the United States coming up empty-handed.

headline: South Africans in Mine Rescued and Then Arrested
abstract: The miners were working illegally in an abandoned shaft near Johannesburg, and they told rescuers that more than 200 others were trapped underground, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Emergency crews in South Africa rescued 11 miners who were trapped while working illegally in an abandoned gold mine near Johannesburg on Sunday, but other miners decided to stay underground to avoid being arrested, emergency workers said.

headline: Protesters Vacate Kiev’s City Hall in Deal for Amnesty
abstract: As they left the building that they had occupied for more than two months, the protesters said they would seize it again if the authorities did not drop all charges against political activists.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ending an occupation of City Hall here that began in December, Ukrainian protesters cemented an amnesty deal with the authorities on Sunday amid signs that both sides in a volatile political crisis were seeking to reduce tensions.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: Russian Skier Who Broke Her Spine Is Moved to a German Hospital
abstract: After a delicate operation to repair her spine, which she injured in a training run, the Olympic ski cross racer Maria Komissarova was in “grave but stable” condition, doctors said.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A day after a six-and-a-half-hour operation to repair her spine, which was fractured when she fell during a training run, the Russian ski cross racer Maria Komissarova was transferred to a hospital in Munich, where she will receive additional treatment, the Russian Olympic Committee said Sunday.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: Kerry Implores Indonesia on Climate Change Peril
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'United States International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said Indonesia’s failure to act would jeopardize its resources, damage its economy and put much of the capital under water.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Secretary of State John Kerry urged Indonesia on Sunday to take steps to combat climate change, warning that failure to act would jeopardize the nation’s resources and damage its economy.

headline: ‘Lego Movie’ Tops Box Office, With ‘About Last Night’ Strong Second
abstract: “About Last Night” took in $30 million to be the top newcomer, while “The Lego Movie” reigned at No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Bookended by Valentine’s Day and President’s Day, the weekend was a strong one for Hollywood, despite a flatlining “Winter’s Tale” and worries that winter storms in parts of the United States would keep moviegoers on their sofas. Certifying itself as a full-blown phenomenon, “The Lego Movie” (Warner Brothers) will take in a projected $60 million between Friday and Monday, for a two-week domestic total of roughly $140 million. “About Last Night” (Sony), one of three 1980s-era remakes to arrive over the weekend, was expected to be the No. 1 newcomer by selling a strong $30.2 million in tickets. Co-starring the popular comedian Kevin Hart, “About Last Night” cost $13 million to make. Third-place “RoboCop” from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Sony was a disappointment considering that it had a production budget of at least $100 million; if analyst projections hold, the science-fiction remake will take in $25.1 million over the long weekend, for a total since opening on Wednesday of about $30 million. (A Sony spokeswoman noted that “RoboCop” is performing “very strongly” overseas, where it has taken in more than $70 million since opening earlier this month.) “The Monuments Men,” also from Sony, was expected to be a solid fourth, generating a projected $17.3 million, for a two-week total of about $46 million. Analysts estimated that Universal’s poorly reviewed remake of “Endless Love” would take in about $15.2 million, which is fine for a lightly marketed movie that cost about $20 million to make. But Akiva Goldsman’s “Winter’s Tale” (Warner) bombed badly, taking in a projected $8.5 million. Adapted from the 1983 magical realism novel, “Winter’s Tale” cost Warner and financing partner Village Roadshow at least $45 million to make.

headline: Kerry on Climate Change
abstract: On Sunday, Secretary of State John Kerry delivered remarks on climate change to an audience of students in Jakarta, Indonesia. He accused climate change deniers of burying their heads in the sand.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Secretary of State John Kerry delivered remarks on climate change to an audience of students in Jakarta, Indonesia. He accused climate change deniers of burying their heads in the sand.

headline: Obama Condemns Uganda’s Tough Antigay Measure
abstract: After the Ugandan president signaled that he was likely to sign a bill to criminalize homosexuality, President Obama on Sunday warned that the measure could harm ties with the United States.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — President Obama on Sunday condemned a measure to criminalize homosexuality in Uganda, publicly warning the country’s president that such discrimination could harm its relationship with the United States.

headline: Mulberry Bags Raise Eyebrows
abstract: The model Cara Delevingne, known for her bold brows, collaborated on a capsule collection.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “They call me ‘bag lady,' ” said Cara Delevingne, better known in the fashion world as Ms. Eyebrows. And on Sunday, the model of the moment staged a handbag happening, surrounded by greyhounds and a fairy tale forest created by the British set designer Michael Howells.

headline: Deadly Blast on a Bus in Egypt
abstract: A television news feed captured the explosion of a tourist bus in Saba, Egypt, that killed at least four people.
lead_paragraph: A television news feed captured the explosion of a tourist bus in Saba, Egypt, that killed at least four people.

headline: Obama on Uganda’s Antigay Bill
abstract: President Obama said the bill, likely to be signed by Uganda’s president, would “be more than an affront and a danger to the gay community in Uganda.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama said the bill, likely to be signed by Uganda’s president, would “be more than an affront and a danger to the gay community in Uganda.”

headline: Author Resigned to Ill Fate of Book in India
abstract: The recall and destruction in India of Wendy Doniger’s book “The Hindus: An Alternative History” settled a legal case and didn’t surprise the author.
lead_paragraph: After Penguin Books India recently decided to recall and pulp all copies of “The Hindus: An Alternative History” in the face of legal action, the book’s author, Wendy Doniger, was not surprised.

headline: A Mad Dash for Salt Rescues Olympic Slopes
abstract: Soft snow threatened Alpine events at the Sochi Games, but a hastily arranged purchase from Switzerland of 24 tons of a large-grain variety of salt unavailable in Russia saved the day.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A senior adviser to the Sochi Olympics convened an emergency meeting late last week with top winter sports officials at the Park Inn hotel in the Alpine village here.

headline: Jazzman, Newly Lauded, Stays Contained but Loose
abstract: During a concert in Manhattan, the jazz singer Gregory Porter performed songs including selections from his Grammy-winning album, “Liquid Spirit.”
lead_paragraph: About an hour into his Town Hall concert on Friday night, Gregory Porter, a good man singing good-man music on Valentine’s Day, started to ease out of Nat Adderley’s “Work Song.” He gripped the microphone stand at chest level, humming slowly in a blues scale, with the same level, deliberate, ethical steadiness he’d put into everything else up to that point. His band played a vamp, waiting for signals. The humming seemed as if it could go on for a while.

headline: Kerry Blames Syrian Government for Deadlocked Talks
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry’s statement appeared aimed at keeping up the pressure on President Bashar al-Assad, and to bolster the hope that a political settlement might be reached.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Secretary of State John Kerry issued a statement on Sunday night that blamed the Syrian government for the deadlock in peace talks but asserted that the United States remained “committed to the Geneva process.”

lead_paragraph: Sergei Filin, the Bolshoi Ballet artistic director who was wounded in an acid attack last year, will come to New York in April as one of the judges in the Youth America Grand Prix ballet competition, officials from the contest announced.

lead_paragraph: Among the highlights were Bode Miller’s bronze medal, a victorious Czech woman’s painted-on mustache and a postponement of a biathlon because of fog.

headline: Don’t Mess With Malvolio
abstract: The Pig Iron Theater Company outfits its interpretation of “Twelfth Night” in outrageousness, with colorful costumes, loud characters and a Balkan band.
lead_paragraph: How do you exact revenge on people who have cruelly tricked you and humiliated you in front of the woman you work for and hope to marry? You steal the show, that’s how.

abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Fighters for Freedom Abroad Found Another Battle at Home
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Television']
abstract: “Breath of Freedom” on the Smithsonian Channel traces links between the civil rights movement and desegregation in the armed forces.
lead_paragraph: The short version of the relationship between the military and racial equality goes like this: “In 1948, President Harry S. Truman issued an executive order desegregating the armed forces, and that spurred the civil rights movement.” The documentary “Breath of Freedom,” Monday night on the Smithsonian Channel, is clumsily structured and unnecessarily sentimental, but at least it puts across how oversimplified that narrative is.

headline: A Program That Honors Two Vital Mentors
abstract: The choreographer Pascal Rioult presented a preview of “Martha, May and Me,” his salute to his mentors May O’Donnell and Martha Graham, at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve managed to run your own dance company for 20 years, chances are you haven’t made it alone. Pascal Rioult, the director of Rioult Dance New York, had some serious mentors as a young artist: May O’Donnell and Martha Graham, with whom he danced in the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: Honing Their Chances With Photos and Wit
abstract: Dance and pairs teams using images taken year-round and off the ice to connect with their fans, and more important for them, with Olympic judges.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Each ice dance and pairs figure skating team at the Olympics will have no more than seven minutes of ice time, if they are lucky, to prove to a panel of judges and the world that they are a single unit, a duo that can twizzle, trot and leap harmoniously as one.

headline: Disparate Backgrounds but a Common Thread
abstract: Works by Elena Demyanenko and Dai Jian showed their shared history with the Trisha Brown company.
lead_paragraph: When two dancers as eloquently meticulous as Elena Demyanenko and Dai Jian decide to choreograph a work, you know that you’re in for silky fluidity: movement that emanates from deep under the skin, where joints are loose, and the spine is airy.

headline: A Bit of Sondheim, a Bit of Judy Garland, and a Whole Lot of ‘Glee’
abstract: Jonathan Groff had his New York concert debut at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: A garrulous apple-cheeked farm boy with a grin on his face, stars in his eyes, and Judy Garland in his heart: that describes the Broadway and TV star Jonathan Groff in his New York concert debut at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series on Saturday evening. The only thing wrong with that description is the word “boy.” Mr. Groff may look and act 15, but he is 28 and has amassed an impressive list of theatrical and TV credits, including “Spring Awakening,” “Glee,” and the new HBO series “Looking.”

headline: Bandit Buddies Separated by a Woman
abstract: Boyhood friends who become bandit kings are put to the test by a beautiful woman in “Gunday,” a Bollywood film set in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Bikram and Bala, the outlaw heroes of “Gunday,” are all hair spray, body oil and swagger. Their chests — no shirts can contain them — glisten; and their muscles bulge as they grimace and run in slow motion. As for their personalities, it takes an hour or so before you discern, or even care, which one is which: Bikram (Ranveer Singh) is shorter, and his hair does more tricks; Bala (Arjun Kapoor) has a temper.

headline: 40 Kilometers to Glory
abstract: Sweden, Russia and France won medals in the men’s 4x10-kilometer cross-country race in Krasnaya Polanya, Russia.
lead_paragraph: Sweden, Russia and France won medals in the men’s 4x10-kilometer cross-country race in Krasnaya Polanya, Russia.

headline: Fighting the Last Macro War? (Slightly Wonkish)
abstract: Not how I see it.
lead_paragraph: Oh, good — Noah Smith has given me some more economic methodology stuff to waste time on, instead of turning to my various deadlines. OK, I’ll make this shortish.

headline: Family Life Was Complicated, Then the Body Turned Up
abstract: In Laura Lippman’s “After I’m Gone,” a shady businessman flees the country, leaving behind his wife, three daughters and a mistress, whose body is found many years later.
lead_paragraph: The characters in Laura Lippman’s “After I’m Gone” are so well drawn that it’s easy to forget why they happen to be connected. Almost all of them are strong, willful women, starting with this novel’s matriarch: Bambi Brewer, née Gottschalk, a raving beauty whose role in the story spans more than 50 years. Even as a teenager at a high school dance, Bambi is aware of how valuable her allure can be. She plays it to her best advantage, even after life hands her an exceedingly raw deal.

headline: A Breezy Chameleon, Blurring Social Borders
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Books and Literature', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: “American Cocktail” is the newly published memoir of an early-20th-century black woman who breezily recounts her racial passing in elite social and artistic circles.
lead_paragraph: When the literary scholar George Hutchinson was in the archives at Howard University one afternoon a decade ago, he thought he knew which story of a neglected African-American woman writer he was chasing.

abstract: Tubby Stayman turned 90 two weeks ago. The milestone was celebrated with 34 family members in Palm Beach, Fla., her winter retreat.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Drama Plays On

lead_paragraph: Just over a month ago, on Jan. 14, the warring parties of the Minnesota Orchestra — management and musicians — agreed to a treaty, of sorts, though in some ways it seems more like a truce. The peace still feels all too tentative.

headline: A Romance From Beyond Mars and Venus

lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The ice dance teams train together in suburban Detroit, tossing world titles back and forth like jugglers. One seems certain to win a gold medal after Monday’s free skate.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — You could assemble a rewardingly hybrid festival of all the choreography of note that’s been made to the music of Bach. His scores welcome dance anachronisms: point work or bare feet, jeans or leotards.

headline: Cost of Preterm Births
abstract: Jennifer L. Howse of the March of Dimes Foundation responds to the controversy at AOL.

headline: For Parents Juggling Work, a Snow Day Is No Holiday
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio has been criticized for keeping schools open during last week’s snowstorm, but many families appreciate not having to deal with work and children with little notice.
lead_paragraph: I am interrupting my previously scheduled column on issues of great weight and importance for a commuting parent’s lament.

headline: Transgender Former Member of Italian Parliament Detained in Sochi
abstract: Vladimir Luxuria was detained by Russian authorities Sunday after holding up a sign that said, “Gay Is OK,” in the Olympic Park, according to the leader of an Italian gay rights group.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Vladimir Luxuria, a transgender former member of the Italian Parliament, was detained by the Russian authorities Sunday after holding up a sign that read, “Gay Is OK,” at Olympic Park, the leader of an Italian gay-rights group said.

headline: Real Discipline in School
keywords: ['School Discipline (Students)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Minorities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Dropouts', 'Graduation Rates']
abstract: Reducing suspensions improves graduation rates.
lead_paragraph: LAST month, Maryland became one of the first states to tackle the widespread injustice of overly harsh discipline policies in our schools, adopting regulations that require an end to practices that have doubled the number of out-of-school suspensions for African-American students in the past decade.

headline: A Berlusconi Reminder as Italy Faces Another Unelected Premier
abstract: Matteo Renzi will become the prime minister and has promised to change election laws so that voters can have a clearer say about who becomes premier in the future.
lead_paragraph: ROME — It speaks to the strange state of Italian democracy that Silvio Berlusconi, the disgraced former prime minister, is now claiming the high moral ground in politics — and that his claim is not completely without merit as Italy prepares for its third consecutive unelected prime minister.

headline: For Yankees, Big Money Can’t Buy Certainty
abstract: The Yankees have assembled a team with more training camp questions than answers on the subjects of age, injury and anonymity.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Soon after Mark Teixeira became the first high-priced veteran to arrive in training camp and concede that “I’d be lying if I said there wasn’t” some anxiety about his surgically repaired right wrist, C. C. Sabathia seconded the motion that uncertainty might be one of the few certainties about the 2014 Yankees.

headline: Reframing ‘Obamacare’
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: As Democrats head into the 2014 midterm elections, they are taking a new approach to talking about the Affordable Care Act: acknowledging that the law has problems, and offering their own solutions.
lead_paragraph: As Democrats head into the 2014 midterm elections, they are taking a new approach to talking about the Affordable Care Act: acknowledging that the law has problems, and offering their own solutions.

headline: On Health Act, Democrats Run in Fix-It Mode
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Political Advertising', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Party leaders have urged Democratic candidates to talk openly about the health care law’s problems while also offering their own prescriptions to fix them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The ad supporting Representative Ann Kirkpatrick, Democrat of Arizona, opens with a montage of Americana Main Streets, followed by the green fields and dirt roads of the West — the “small towns and wide-open spaces,” the narrator explains, where Ms. Kirkpatrick “listens and learns.”

headline: Common Core Curriculum Now Has Critics on the Left
abstract: The newest chorus of complaints about the common learning standards is coming from one of their earliest champions: New York State.
lead_paragraph: The Common Core has been applauded by education leaders and promoted by the Obama administration as a way to replace a hodgepodge of state standards with one set of rigorous learning goals. Though 45 states and the District of Columbia have signed on to them since 2010, resistance came quickly, mostly from right-leaning states, where some leaders and political action groups have protested what they see as a federal takeover of local classrooms.

headline: Mary Katrantzou’s High-Heeled Loafers
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: sensible, neutral pumps from an ornate collection.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: In Egypt, a Chasm Grows Between Young and Old
keywords: ['Youth', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Many young Egyptians say the government’s heavy-handed reaction to protests has hampered their ability to establish a role in shaping the nation’s future.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Shady el-Ghazaly Harb says he has given up trying to help the military-backed government address its worries about losing the support of young Egyptians.

headline: A Watchful Eye in Hospitals
abstract: Are hidden cameras a violation of patients’ right to privacy?
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, N.H. — DESPITE the intensely personal moments that happen in hospitals, patient privacy can be elusive. Hospitals are multimillion-dollar corporations that look like shopping malls and function like factories. Doctors knock on exam room doors to signal they are about to enter — not to ask permission. The curtain that encircles the hospital bed always lets in a crack of light.

headline: Barons of Broadband
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Why did we stop worrying about monopoly power?
lead_paragraph: Last week’s big business news was the announcement that Comcast, a gigantic provider of cable TV and high-speed Internet service, has reached a deal to acquire Time Warner Cable, which is merely huge. If regulators approve the deal, Comcast will be an overwhelmingly dominant player in the business, with around 30 million subscribers.

headline: Florida Self-Defense Law Complicated Jury’s Job in Michael Dunn Trial
abstract: The jurors in Dunn’s murder trial wrangled with knowing when lethal force is justified, where nothing is straightforward and perception counts as much as fact.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — In failing to acquit or convict Michael Dunn on the most significant charge — the premeditated murder of a teenager in a dispute over loud music — a jury on Saturday may have run headlong into the breadth and reach of Florida’s contentious self-defense law.

headline: In Praise of Disregard
abstract: Don’t let every outrage get the better of you. Sometimes it’s best to ignore things.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps this experience sounds familiar to you: Sometimes, particularly during elections or other politically feverish moments, I spend many hours reading about the issues; but I have a tendency to dwell on stories I find truly distressing, such as tales of leaked videos showing the blunt discrepancy between a politician’s on- and off-screen selves. I am drawn to the most hopeless headlines, the reports that make humans seem like wolves, the kind that make it impossible to stifle my expletives. I feel it physiologically: My adrenaline surges, my breaths get quick and short, and I pace and fume around the apartment trying to get rid of this nervous energy.

headline: Scenes of Confusion
abstract: The first attempts at clearing out a family home after a parent’s death.
lead_paragraph: This is the second part of an eight-part series.

headline: Labor Regroups in South After VW Vote
abstract: Workers at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., had voted against joining the United Automobile Workers.
lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Volkswagen labor officials in Germany renewed calls on Sunday for the company’s three-year-old plant here to establish a German-style works council even though its workers voted days earlier against unionizing.

headline: At Church Service, Pastor Makes No Mention of de Blasio or Arrest
abstract: Bishop Orlando Findlayter, whose arrest last week prompted Mayor Bill de Blasio to call the police, has said nothing publicly about the controversy that has entangled the mayor.
lead_paragraph: The pastor whose arrest last week has turned into a political headache for Mayor Bill de Blasio appeared publicly on Sunday for the first time since the incident, leading a rousing service in Brooklyn but saying nothing about his arrest — or the controversy that has entangled the mayor.

headline: Regulatory Favoritism in North Carolina
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Coal', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Editorials']
abstract: The state’s largest utility gets a wrist slap for coal ash pollution, while federal regulators dawdle.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina citizens have good reason to wonder just whom their environmental regulators are trying to protect. The state’s Department of Environment and Natural Resources has engaged in a series of maneuvers that seem designed to protect the state’s largest utility, Duke Energy, from paying big fines for water pollution from coal ash ponds and meeting reasonable requirements that it move toxic coal ash to lined landfills away from rivers and lakes used for drinking water and recreation.

headline: Stealthily, Comcast Fortifies Its Arsenal
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: With the Time Warner Cable deal, Comcast would not only lock up 30 percent of the cable market, but pricing leverage in all directions — with customers, networks and over-the-web providers like Netflix.
lead_paragraph: Big media companies are generally warships, bristling with firepower and declaring their might long before they attack. But Comcast, which is headed toward being one of the biggest of them all, is much more like a submarine, silently running beneath the waves and making its presence known only when it is too late for its targets.

headline: The New College Campus
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Editorials']
abstract: There has been a worrisome increase in the hiring of adjunct instructors, who are generally poorly paid and have less time for research.
lead_paragraph: Imagine meeting someone who says she works at a university. Some years ago, it would have been fairly safe to assume that she was a professor, and a member of the middle class with enviable job security. Not anymore. Two reports make clear that the nature of the college work force has changed substantially, possibly to the detriment of educational quality.

headline: Japan’s Growth Slows, Raising Concerns About Obstacles That Lie Ahead
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The Japanese economy grew at a tepid rate of 1.0 percent in the final quarter of 2013, heightening concerns that Japan’s recovery may not be strong enough to weather further challenges expected this year.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese economy grew at a tepid rate of 1.0 percent in the final quarter of 2013, falling short of analyst expectations and heightening concerns that Japan’s recovery may not be strong enough to weather further challenges expected this year.

headline: New York’s Broken Parole System
abstract: For low-risk inmates, early release into parole should be the default and the board should have to articulate a good reason to keep them locked up.
lead_paragraph: The fact of a crime never changes, but the person who commits it can, and often does. This is the basic principle of parole — that while people must be punished for their wrongdoing, most are capable of growing, changing and rejoining society before the end of their sentence.

headline: One Group Sees Silver Lining in Winter’s Storm Clouds: Meteorologists
abstract: Scientists at the National Weather Service have been taking advantage of the relentless cycle of snow to slush, adding to research to refine their forecasts.
lead_paragraph: Brian A. Colle woke up at 1 a.m. on Thursday and headed out into the snow. Using plates of glass he had been storing in a freezer in his garage, he collected snowflakes for analysis with a powerful microscope.

headline: The Games’ Unfamiliar Honor (Even Among Its Recipients)
abstract: For the near-medalists — and a few not-so-near-medalists — left looking up at the podium, recognition comes in the form of a personally inscribed, autopen-signed, formal Olympic diploma.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Gold. Silver. Bronze. Paper?

headline: Magnet Schools Find a Renewed Embrace in Cities
abstract: In Miami and many other cities, public schools that admit students districtwide and focus on themes like art, law or technology are gaining popularity after largely falling off the radar.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Nearly five decades ago, as racial tension raged in cities, magnet schools were introduced here and elsewhere as an alternative to court-ordered busing in the hope that specialized theme schools would slow white flight and offer options to racial minorities zoned for low-performing schools.

headline: Turnabout in Bolivia as Economy Rises From Instability
abstract: With a growing economy, a reduced debt and an enviable rainy-day fund, Bolivia has become a nation whose fiscal policy is praised by international financial institutions.
lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia — Argentina’s currency has plunged, setting off global worries about developing economies. Brazil is struggling to shake concerns over years of sluggish growth. Venezuela, which sits atop the world’s largest oil reserves, has one of the world’s highest inflation rates. Farther afield, countries like Turkey and South Africa have watched their currencies suffer as investors search for safer returns elsewhere.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 17, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, February 17, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It’s kind of like the one you get for participation. It’s really nice. I mean, it’s not the same as medaling, of course.”

headline: In Kansas, Right Joins Left to Halt Bill on Gays
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The legislation would have allowed the denial of business services to same-sex couples because of religious beliefs.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A bill that would have allowed individuals to refuse to provide business services to same-sex couples in Kansas because of religious beliefs met a surprising and quick end last week when conservative senators sided with liberal advocates in saying that the measure promoted discrimination.

headline: De Blasio Strikes Conciliatory Note on Pre-K
abstract: At a church service in Albany, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was joined by Mayor Bill de Blasio, in town for the New York State Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic and Asian Legislative Caucus Weekend.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A strong winter sun streamed through the green and yellow stained-glass windows at Wilborn Temple as worshipers swayed and clapped to rousing hymns and chants of “Praise the Lord.”

headline: Body of Michele Savoia, Fashion Designer, Found in Hudson River
abstract: The 55-year-old, who designed costumes for Broadway shows like “Swing,” “Promises, Promises” and “Evita,” apparently fell into the water while trying to board his boat early Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The body of a fashion designer known for his flamboyant vintage clothing was pulled from the Hudson River on Sunday, days after he apparently slipped and fell into the water while trying to board his boat at the Chelsea Piers, the police and a friend said.

headline: Sleepless in New York
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Restless in the small hours, a man prays to the god of sleep and peers out at the night scene.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Downton’ Recap, Episode 7: Advice From the Dowager
abstract: A fictional advice column for a fictional family.
lead_paragraph: [Programming note: this week’s regularly scheduled recap of “Downton Abbey” will not be seen, so that we can bring you this edition of “Dear Dowager Countess,” the popular advice column that is syndicated in hundreds of fictional British newspapers of the early 20th century. Lady Violet, the Dowager Countess of Grantham, is a member of the aristocracy, president of the Downton Cottage Hospital and a multiple winner of the Best Bloom in the Village award. She is not a licensed therapist and her views do not necessarily represent those of this newspaper or anyone born after World War I.]

headline: ‘Tonight’ Show Returns to New York After Nearly 42 Years
abstract: The studio where Jimmy Fallon will hold court is the same one that Johnny Carson reigned over before he left for California in May 1972, and that Jack Paar filled before him.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, for the first time in almost 42 years, NBC’s “Tonight” show will be hosted from New York. The show, which invented the form of entertainment known as late-night television, is returning to the place of its birth: Manhattan.

headline: Polk Awards Honor Articles on N.S.A. Surveillance
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Polk, George, Awards', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Four journalists who broke news of government surveillance were among 30 reporters praised for their investigative work on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Four journalists who revealed the National Security Agency’s vast electronic data mining operation were among the winners of the George Polk Awards in Journalism for 2013, announced on Sunday by Long Island University, which administers the prizes.

headline: Merkel Backs Plan to Keep European Data in Europe
keywords: ['Data Storage', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Computer Security', 'E-Mail', 'Privacy']
abstract: After the revelations of U.S. spying, Chancellor Angela Merkel said she would raise the matter at a meeting with the French president this week.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has embraced proposals to create European data networks that would keep emails and other communications on the European side of the Atlantic, farther from prying American eyes, and said she would raise the matter this week with President François Hollande of France.

headline: Science Linking Drought to Global Warming Remains Matter of Dispute
abstract: While a trend of increasing drought that may be linked to global warming has been documented in some regions, there is no scientific consensus yet that it is a worldwide phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: In delivering aid to drought-stricken California last week, President Obama and his aides cited the state as an example of what could be in store for much of the rest of the country as human-caused climate change intensifies.

headline: Crossing His Fingers, Yankees’ Teixeira Counts on Full Comeback From Wrist Injury
abstract: Mark Teixeira, who had wrist surgery in July, has been working out at home. “The team needs me,” he said.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Robinson Cano is gone, Derek Jeter is trying to come back from a twice-broken ankle at 39, and Alex Rodriguez is suspended. In other words, the Yankees’ infield, once a dominant feature of a World Series champion, has been sacked by free agency, age, infirmity and penalty.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 16, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Poet Mines Memories of Drug Addiction
abstract: Gil Fagiani writes poetry that he hopes will connect with people in a way that his political writings could not.
lead_paragraph: Gil Fagiani pulled out a copy of “White Lightning,” a tabloid from 1972, whose yellowed, brittle pages declared revolution. Inside, he pointed to a polemic he wrote headlined “Racism and Dope.” It described how he — a heroin addict with white, middle-class roots — was let off by the police with a warning inside an East Harlem tenement while his would-be connection, a Puerto Rican ex-con, was stripped, arrested and clubbed.

headline: Tunisian B-Boys’ Biggest Battle: Keeping Youths From Extremism
keywords: ['Break Dancing', 'Youth', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Disc Jockeys', 'Dancing', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: In a small town, where some say many young people are drifting into drugs or even militancy, break dancing and a youth center offer alternatives.
lead_paragraph: BEN AOUN, Tunisia — The youth center in this small provincial town is brimming with energy on a Saturday morning. Teenage girls in pink tracksuits compete in a fencing tournament in one room, and soccer teams play on a bright emerald green patch on the far side of the compound. But the most intense activity is inside a classroom where youths of all ages are crammed around a dance floor watching break dancers test their skills and wits against one another to a thumping music track.

headline: Fallout From the Auto Union’s Defeat
keywords: ['Collective Bargaining', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Organized Labor', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The rejection of the union at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., is a setback for the United Auto Workers and for American workers, who would benefit from new unions.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, a majority of workers at the Volkswagen car assembly plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., reportedly signed cards in favor of joining the United Auto Workers.

headline: Abbas, Talking to Israeli Students About Peace, Finds a Receptive Audience
abstract: The Palestinian president struck a conciliatory tone during a well-publicized meeting in the West Bank with about 300 students and youth leaders from Israel.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A decade ago, after the suicide bombings of the second Palestinian uprising, Israelis mostly came to Ramallah and the Mukata, the West Bank headquarters of the Palestinian leadership here, in tanks or armored military vehicles. On Sunday, about 300 Israeli students and youth leaders arrived in busloads to meet President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority for a conversation about the peace process.

headline: ‘Girls’ Recap: A Beach House and a Fight
abstract: “Beach House” was one of three episodes selected for the Girls premiere party in early January, and it’s easy to see why. A lot happens.
lead_paragraph: How perfect is it that the Shoshi Games tumblr was born mere days ago?

headline: Love Fine With Timberwolves but Hungry to Win
abstract: The All-Star power forward Kevin Love said he remained committed to the perennially struggling franchise, but he could become a free agent in 2015.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The amateur mind-reading bothers Kevin Love the most, even though he caused most of it.

headline: Reporting From the Web’s Underbelly
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: Brian Krebs’s widely read blog, Krebs on Security, covers a particularly dark corner of the Internet: profit-seeking cybercriminals who make billions off spam, malware and frauds.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the last year, Eastern European cybercriminals have stolen Brian Krebs’s identity a half dozen times, brought down his website, included his name and some unpleasant epithets in their malware code, sent fecal matter and heroin to his doorstep, and called a SWAT team to his home just as his mother was arriving for dinner.

headline: One Step Goes Awry, and Mulder’s Pitching Comeback Ends
abstract: Mark Mulder, who last pitched in the majors in 2008, hoped to return with the Angels this season, but he tore an Achilles’ tendon Saturday in camp.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — Mark Mulder was always proud that the competition never drove him from the game. When Mulder was healthy, he was a force. His shoulder betrayed him after 103 major league victories in his 20s, and he accepted the occupational hazard. He did not miss baseball, he said, because he knew his body would not let him play it.

headline: South Africa’s Growing Pains
abstract: A meaningful opposition party seemed possible, but only for a moment.
lead_paragraph: South Africa — the democratic version fathered by Nelson Mandela — turns 20 this year. Like most adolescents emerging into adulthood, it has issues. It could use more impulse control, better self-esteem, less conformity to peer pressure and some plain old parental wisdom. For those of us who watch and root for this struggling young democracy, the year began with a disappointing setback.

headline: The Highs and Lows of City Life
abstract: We wondered about how tall New Yorkers navigate the city, and whether for them bigness is a burden. Here are some of the stories.
lead_paragraph: Early this month, Michael M. Grynbaum of The New York Times took a look at New York’s “Bunyanesque” mayor, Bill de Blasio, and how he takes in his new job from his elevated viewpoint. At 6-foot-5⅞, Mr. de Blasio is the tallest mayor in the city’s modern history, requiring City Hall to make a series of ergonomic adjustments. So we wondered about other New Yorkers, how they navigate the city daily, and whether for them bigness is a burden too. Here are some of the stories — edited for space — that we heard from New Yorkers, tall or not:

headline: What to Watch: Monday, Feb. 17
abstract: Televised Olympic events to watch on Monday.
lead_paragraph: FIGURE SKATING The Americans Meryl Davis and Charlie White, who won the Olympic short dance Sunday, are a solid free dance performance away from a gold medal. Davis and White, the reigning world champions, earned 78.89 points and lead the 2010 gold medalists, Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir of Canada, by 2.56. The two teams train together in the Detroit area and share a coach. NBCSN, 10 a.m.

headline: Corrections: February 17, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 17, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Punching Above Its Weight, Upstart Netflix Pokes at HBO
abstract: If there is a rivalry between the two, it is by many measures a mismatch. But that hasn’t stopped the salivation at the story line: Netflix, the Silicon Valley interloper, taking on HBO, the establishment player.
lead_paragraph: On the night of the Golden Globes ceremony last month, Netflix and HBO held dueling parties at the Beverly Hilton hotel. Bono and Julia Roberts mingled underneath a bejeweled tent as Netflix, the upstart streaming service, joined forces for the party with the Weinstein Company and celebrated a small piece of history — its first Globe, for “House of Cards,” its splashy entrant into original programming. At HBO’s party, Matt Damon and Lady Gaga sipped drinks by the pool as the cable network toasted its two awards, pushing its total to 101.

headline: U.S. in Nordic Combined: It’s About Now
abstract: The United States won four out of a possible nine medals at the Vancouver Games and has a chance to win back-to-back medals at the Winter Games for the first time.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — It is one of the rarest of rarities: Americans attempting to win medals in Nordic combined in consecutive Winter Games.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Longtime Critic of Police Policies Basks in a de Blasio Moment
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: Eric L. Adams was once known for the often incendiary curbside news conferences he held outside One Police Plaza in Lower Manhattan. Now he is the Brooklyn borough president.
lead_paragraph: If Mayor Bill de Blasio’s announcement on Jan. 30 that his administration would agree to reform the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk tactic was a stunning about-face for a city that has promoted aggressive policing for nearly two decades, there was a smaller surprise, for those with long memories, in his choice of one guest. Sitting near the mayor was Eric L. Adams, a former police officer, longtime irritant to several mayors and police commissioners, former state senator, and now, Brooklyn borough president.

headline: Saving an Endangered British Species: The Pub
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Changing economics and tastes in Britain have claimed roughly one out of every five “locals” in the last 20 years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One by one, the pubs are disappearing in Hampstead, a jewel-box village of cobbled lanes and Georgian homes that has become one of this city’s most fashionable neighborhoods. The Nags Head has become a realty office. The King of Bohemia is now a clothing shop. The Hare & Hounds has been replaced with an apartment building.

headline: Biathlon Penalty Loop Is Like the Dunce Cap of the Olympics
abstract: It’s akin to hockey’s penalty box, but a better comparison for the biathlon’s penalty loop might be basketball players doing push-ups for each missed shot in a game.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — For many Olympians, there is no place more wretched these days than a 150-meter patch of snow, ringed with bright red cones, that sits in the corner of the biathlon stadium.

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: Because of Washington’s Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.
lead_paragraph: Because of Washington’s Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Writers Guild Plans Forum on Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: “This is not about advising writers; we’re in search of information,” said Michael Winship, the president of the Writers Guild of America East.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Tuesday night, an expected crowd of 100 or so screenwriters and others will gather in Lower Manhattan at the headquarters of the Writers Guild of America East to hear thoughts about the Affordable Care Act and its place in comedy and drama.

headline: Hudson, Gallerist and Nurturer of Artists, Dies at 63
abstract: Hudson was an art dealer and mentor who ignored trends and kept a mysterious air.
lead_paragraph: Hudson, a former dancer and performance artist known only by his last name, who went on to become one of the most prescient, independent-minded and admired gallerists of his generation, died on Feb. 10 at his home in Manhattan. He was 63.

headline: Venezuelan Leader Announces Expulsion of 3 U.S. Officials
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro, a focus of student-led protests in recent days, did not identify the consular officials, who he said had been visiting private universities in Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — After several days of student-led protests against his government, President Nicolás Maduro said Sunday that he was expelling three American consular officials who he said had been visiting universities here.

headline: Bollywood Superstar’s Movie Gets Tangled in Electoral Politics
abstract: Salman Khan has come under fire from Muslims, a big portion of his fan base, after his public appearances with Narendra Modi of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — For most Bollywood movies, earning 1 billion rupees at the box office would be seen as a resounding success.

headline: Jacques le Sourd, Theater Critic, Dies at 64
abstract: Mr. le Sourd was syndicated nationally in Gannett Company newspapers for three decades.
lead_paragraph: Jacques le Sourd, a theater critic whose Broadway and Off Broadway reviews for The Journal News of Westchester were syndicated nationally in the Gannett Company’s newspaper chain for three decades, died on Feb. 5 in Preston, Lancashire, England. He was 64.

headline: Water-Cleaning Technology Could Help Farmers
abstract: A project developed by WaterFX, a start-up in drought-stricken California, exploits two things the Central Valley possesses in abundance — fallow land and sunshine — to cut desalinization costs.
lead_paragraph: FIREBAUGH, Calif. — The giant solar receiver installed on a wheat field here in California’s agricultural heartland slowly rotates to track the sun and capture its energy. The 377-foot array, however, does not generate electricity but instead creates heat used to desalinate water.

headline: Lashing Out
abstract: From growth-enhancing serums to mink-fur extensions, options for enhancing eyelashes abound — but how much is too much of a good thing?
lead_paragraph: So much happens in the blink of an eye. A single flutter, a slow sweep downwards: What will a woman’s eyelashes reveal? Interest? Curiosity? Sexual chemistry? Ennui? Tenderness? Excitement? Or distress, as in that most famous Man Ray image of 1930-32, “Tears”? Those perfect globules of glass are clearly fake, but the eyelashes give pause for thought. How did their owner get such precise separation? Such fabulous length? Those wonderful eighth-note-shaped ends?

headline: Before Blaming the Robots, Let’s Get the Policy Right
keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Productivity', 'Robots and Robotics', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Job growth has ceased to track productivity growth in recent years, but whether and how technology has been a factor is hard to discern because of other damage to the economy, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Caring for the Alzheimer’s Caregiver
abstract: Watching over loved ones with dementia frequently presents new challenges, and a new book focuses on caregivers and the stressful situations they face.
lead_paragraph: Paul Divinigracia does not consider himself a saint. But to observe how he cares for his wife, Virgie, now 11 years into Alzheimer’s disease, you might think otherwise.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13) LAS MARTHAS (2014) In the border town of Laredo, Tex., debutante season is centered on bicultural celebrations, many of them involving its city sister, Nuevo Laredo, Mexico. The pre-eminent event is the invitation-only Colonial Ball, hosted by the Society of Martha Washington, in which young women, most of them Mexican-American, make their debuts in elaborate colonial gowns — weighing as much as 100 pounds and costing up to $30,000 — representing figures from America’s revolutionary history. Their goal: to recreate a party hosted by Martha herself. In this “Independent Lens” documentary, the director Cristina Ibarra follows two of the debutantes — one from a prominent Laredo family, the other a newcomer from Mexico — as they prepare for this rite of passage. (Above, the debutante Laura Garza Hovel.)

headline: Electrifying Rivalry and Overheated Scoreboard in N.B.A. All-Star Game
abstract: LeBron James and Kevin Durant were at the center of a growing debate over James’s legacy, and defense fell by the wayside at the N.B.A. All-Star Game.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — After 45 minutes’ worth of pregame festivities that included a music concert, an appearance by Snoop Dogg, streamers that fell from the ceiling and player introductions, LeBron James finally christened the N.B.A. All-Star Game on Sunday night in familiar fashion: with a steal near midcourt, a handful of loping strides and a dunk with just the right amount of ferocity.

headline: Well-Conditioned St. John’s Runs Georgetown Out of the Garden
abstract: The Red Storm continued on the roll they began after an 0-5 start to their Big East schedule, turning in a convincing victory over the Hoyas at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the course of its march back to respectability in the Big East, St. John’s came to rely on two numbers.

abstract: After the All-Star break, the league’s two biggest names face off when LeBron James and the Heat visit Kevin Durant and the Thunder.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Smartphone sales totaled 968 million units in 2013, capturing 53.6 percent of the worldwide market and outselling feature mobile phones for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Smartphone sales totaled 968 million units in 2013, capturing 53.6 percent of the worldwide market and outselling feature mobile phones for the first time.

headline: The Week’s Men’s College Basketball Games to Watch

headline: NBC Pushes Too Far in Bringing Bode Miller to Tears
abstract: An NBC interviewer repeatedly questioned Miller about his brother, who died last year, after the skier tied Sunday for a bronze medal in the men’s super-G.
lead_paragraph: Bode Miller had just tied for a bronze medal in the men’s super-G at the Olympics in Sochi, Russia, on Sunday and it was time to be interviewed. NBC had already established Miller’s quest as an emotional story line, putting a microphone on his wife, Morgan, to hear her reactions to his races, and having the couple sit for an interview with Tom Brokaw. He was being humanized — as the changed man, the family man, the mature 36-year-old whose brother had died last year.

headline: Indonesia Takes Aim at Australia Over Spying on Talks
abstract: At a news conference with Secretary of State John Kerry, Indonesia’s foreign minister called surveillance by Australia’s intelligence agency “mind-boggling.”
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s foreign minister said Monday that it was a “bit mind-boggling” that the Australian intelligence agency had spied on his nation’s trade deliberations with American officials.

headline: Economic Growth in Thailand Cools to 0.6%
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The unrest that has shaken Thailand since November is taking a potentially lasting toll on the country’s economy, just when regional growth over all is facing headwinds.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It was, until recently, one of the fastest-growing economies in Asia. It shrugged off coups, street protests and natural disasters. And it earned the nickname “Teflon Thailand.”

headline: Ethiopian Co-Pilot Hijacks Jet, Then Asks for Asylum in Geneva
abstract: All passengers and crew members on the Ethiopian Airlines flight were released safely, and the hijacker surrendered after saying he was in danger in Ethiopia.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The co-pilot of an Ethiopian Airlines passenger jet en route to Rome from Ethiopia seized control of the Boeing 767-300 early on Monday and flew it to Geneva, where he asked for asylum, a spokesman for the Geneva police said.

headline: As Edgy Chinese Films Sweep Berlin Festival, Pride and Caution at Home
abstract: With Chinese films winning prizes and grabbing critical attention at the Berlinale, sharp differences were highlighted between the filmmakers’ truth-telling artistry and the Chinese state’s less realistic visions of culture.
lead_paragraph: “After a very long wait, Chinese films have finally burst forth magnificently again in the world’s film festivals, with fireworks,” the state news agency Xinhua wrote. The proud statement was a play on the Chinese title for “Black Coal, Thin Ice,” the gritty detective movie by Diao Yinan that took the top award at the just-concluded 64th Berlin International Film Festival: “Fireworks in Daylight.”

headline: Differing Accounts of Recent Violence in Xinjiang
abstract: A German-based group that advocates for Uighur self-determination said the incident was typical of the Chinese authorities’ use of violence to quell Uighur dissent and called for evidence to back up the government’s accusations of a terrorist attack.
lead_paragraph: The ethnic polarization troubling the northwestern Chinese region of Xinjiang has brought a grim succession of bloody incidents pitting Uighurs against security forces – and has also been echoed in the vastly different interpretations from the government and from advocates of Uighur self-determination that invariably follow those incidents. The latest bloodshed has followed that pattern.

headline: A Note on Presidents’ Day
abstract: We are off for the holiday on Monday, but will be back with most of our usual content the rest of this week.
lead_paragraph: We are taking the day off on this national holiday — and, since many schools will be out this week, we are also suspending daily lesson plans until Monday, Feb. 24.

headline: The Hunter Collection
abstract: Alasdhair Willis is the creative director for Hunter, the English boot maker, and its new Hunter Original clothing. The advice from his wife, the designer Stella McCartney? Trust your instincts.
lead_paragraph: Alasdhair Willis is the creative director for Hunter, the English boot maker, and its new Hunter Original clothing. The advice from his wife, the designer Stella McCartney? Trust your instincts.

headline: For the Love of Art, and Money
abstract: With record prices at auctions, new breeds of collectors are emerging.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A record 413 million pounds of Impressionist and modern art sold at Sotheby’s and Christie’s in one week. Nearly £200,000 went for a canvas painted by a 24 year-old with a fire extinguisher a week later. Auctions of high-end artworks were booming in London in February, to be sure. But in the 21st century’s increasingly financialized market — where art is treated as an investment and where paintings are tracked and traded instantaneously — one has to ask, what does the word “collector” mean nowadays?

headline: Bouygues to Take 1.4 Billion Euro Write-Down on Its Alstom Stake
abstract: Bouygues, Alstom’s largest shareholder, said the reduced value of its shareholding reflected weaker forecasts by the maker of trains and power plants.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The French conglomerate Bouygues said on Monday that it would take a 1.4 billion euro write-down on its stake in the transport and energy company Alstom.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Robert Draper on Wendy Davis and the Challenge of Biography
abstract: Our contributing writer reflects on the complexities of covering Wendy Davis, a state senator in Texas, for this week’s cover story.
lead_paragraph: Robert Draper, a contributing writer for the magazine, is the author of this week’s cover story about the Texas gubernatorial candidate Wendy Davis. Draper is the author of “When the Tea Party Came to Town.” He last wrote for the magazine about the National Rifle Association.

headline: South Korean Lawmaker Jailed on Treason Charges
abstract: Lee Seok-ki is the first lawmaker found guilty of the charges since the country’s past military dictators used them to silence dissidents decades ago.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean court sentenced an opposition lawmaker to 12 years in prison on Monday for forming a “revolutionary organization” and conspiring to start an armed revolt to overthrow the Seoul government in the event of war with North Korea.

headline: Waffle House Shows Atlanta How to Handle a Snowstorm
abstract: Most businesses made the decision on Monday — long before the “storm” hit — to send everyone home.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta’s second snow jam of 2014 shut down practically every business of every size in the city. But I don’t think we can entirely blame Mother Nature or even the governor this time for the lost revenue and customers we will all be adding up at the end of the month.

headline: The Trouble With Being Abstruse (Slightly Wonkish)
abstract: Making sure you yourself know what you’re saying.
lead_paragraph: Political scientists who write clearly for a broader audience are upset with Nick Kristof for saying that political scientists no longer write for a broader audience. I’m not going to get into that fight. I do want to register one point, however: In my field there is indeed a problem with abstruseness, with the many academics who never even try to put their thoughts in plain language.

lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — As fans gathered for the men’s snowboard cross race on Monday at the Winter Olympics, they could barely see beyond the finish line. Competitors headed to the starting area on a chairlift, but it was an ascent into a white unknown, the thick fog obscuring even the chair in front of them.

abstract: Threes, a new puzzle game for iOS, is beautifully designed, highly addictive and has a soundtrack that makes you feel like you’re in a haunted house.
lead_paragraph: If I can just connect the red “2” card with the blue “1” card, and then slide together those “3’s,” I’ll be able to get another “12” and… Sorry, you’ll have to excuse me, I’m in the middle of another game of Threes, the latest game for iOS that I’m slightly obsessed with.

headline: Tepid Economic Growth in Japan
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Sales and Excise Taxes']
abstract: A 1 percent expansion in the fourth quarter heightened concerns that the country’s recovery might not be strong enough to weather a sales tax increase.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese economy grew at the tepid rate of 1 percent in the final quarter of 2013, data showed Monday, falling short of analysts’ expectations and heightening concerns that the country’s recovery might not be strong enough to weather an impending sales tax increase, a worsening trade balance and other problems expected this year.

headline: ‘Philomena’s’ Composer: Turning a Secret Into a Score
abstract: Alexandre Desplat says he was concerned about not overpowering Judi Dench’s performance in the title role.
lead_paragraph: Having been nominated now six times in eight years, the composer Alexandre Desplat is a veteran of Academy campaigning. He called his latest Oscar-nominated work, the score for “Philomena,” among his most difficult assignments, and not only because it had more music than his first Oscar-nominated film, “The Queen.”
