lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:16 p.m. | LONDON — Regulators in Britain said on Monday that they had begun criminal proceedings against three former Barclays employees suspected in the manipulation of a global benchmark interest rate.

headline: Standing Out Amid Monotony in Residential Design
abstract: Some owners and designers are doing different and interesting work, highlighting Williamsburg’s industrial past while adding modern elements.
lead_paragraph: David Boyle did not build his house out of shipping containers to be hip, though he does live in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He left the water pipes exposed not in pursuit of an industrial chic aesthetic, but to make them easier to fix.

headline: No Beauty Goes Unexplored in ‘La Clemenza di Tito’
abstract: The Russian-born conductor Kirill Petrenko gets an opportunity to demonstrate his command of Mozart in a new production at the Bavarian State Opera.
lead_paragraph: Munich — Kirill Petrenko, the new general music director of the Bavarian State Opera, is enjoying a honeymoon with his audience. He assumed the post in September, fresh from conducting Wagner’s “Ring” cycle at the Bayreuth Festival, where he won a slew of accolades, even as Frank Castorf’s new production was roasted to a crisp by critics.

headline: Apple Compote
abstract: Freshly made applesauce is several cuts above the store bought variety.
lead_paragraph: Apple compote is what the French call applesauce. It is utterly simple to make, but freshly made it is several cuts above storebought. Serve it warm, for a comforting dessert, topped with a dollop of crème fraiche if you like. Or use it as a filling for crêpes.

headline: Apple and Bitter Lettuces Salad
abstract: A salad with many contrasts: sweet and bitter, crunchy and juicy.
lead_paragraph: You can use a mix of lettuces for this salad, and you can also add some milder lettuce. My favorite combination is endive, radicchio and arugula. It is a simple salad with wonderful contrasts. Dice the apples small.

headline: Apple, Lime and Chia Smoothie
abstract: A pale green smoothie with a kick.
lead_paragraph: I love the pale green color of this smoothie. Granny Smith and lime make a great marriage and the yogurt and chia seeds make the sweet and tart smoothie substantial enough to get me through the morning.

headline: Buckwheat Crêpes With Caramelized Apples
abstract: Flavorful crêpes that can be handle both sweet and savory toppings.
lead_paragraph: Buckwheat crêpes have wonderful earthy/nutty flavor. They are equally at home with a sweet or savory topping. If you have any caramelized apples left over, stir them into your yogurt for breakfast.

headline: Country Bread With Apples
abstract: A moist, rustic country bread with a sweet touch.
lead_paragraph: This is a whole wheat version of a classic Norman country bread. Normandy is apple country and apples find their way into many dishes in this region. I came across the bread in “Bread Alone” by Daniel Leader, and have adapted the recipe. The dough ferments overnight in the refrigerator, and after it has come back to room temperature the chopped apples are kneaded in. It goes beautifully with cheese.

headline: On Short-Track Speedskating
abstract: Short-track speedskaters whip around a relatively small oval, pushing forward in short bursts of acceleration on extremely sharp blades.
lead_paragraph: Short-track speedskaters whip around a relatively small oval, pushing forward in short bursts of acceleration on extremely sharp blades.

abstract: Ivane Merabishvili is the most senior official to be convicted in a series of seemingly politically motivated prosecutions that followed a change in government leadership in 2012.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — A former prime minister of Georgia, Ivane Merabishvili, was convicted on Monday of public corruption charges and sentenced to five years in prison, making him the most senior official yet to be convicted in a series of seemingly politically motivated prosecutions that followed a change in control of the government in 2012.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It was the biggest demonstration so far concerning the Sochi Olympics, and it had nothing to do with gay rights, environmental damage or corruption.

headline: Humble-Nishiyama Randomness Game
abstract: Is it possible to increase your chances of winning a seemingly random card game?
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was suggested by Steve Humble (aka Dr Maths), a mathematics educator from Newcastle University. The game starts with a standard 52-card deck of playing cards, which includes, obviously, 26 red cards and 26 black cards. At the start of a game, each player announces, one player after the other, a three-color sequence she will be watching for as the deck of cards is dealt out card by card. Cards are then dealt, and when a player’s sequence appears in a series of three consecutive cards, all cards in play are removed from the game as a winning trick. This continues until the full pack of 52 cards is exhausted. At the end, the player with the most tricks is declared the winner.

lead_paragraph: On Feb. 9, 1964, the Beatles took to the stage on “The Ed Sullivan Show.” It wasn’t long before other bands — the Rolling Stones, the Kinks, the Who and the Yardbirds, among others — joined what is now known as the British Invasion.

headline: Wireless Charging: Still Plenty of Kinks in the Cord
abstract: Wireless charging is promising and has been promised for several years. But it is a mess of competing standards and technologies. Will this tangle of cords ever get unraveled?
lead_paragraph: As personal devices proliferate — smartphones, wearable fitness bands, Kindles, tablets, smart glasses — our charger collections are starting to look like the electrical outlet in the movie “A Christmas Story.”

headline: Driving Under the Influence, of Marijuana

abstract: While there are effective tests for alcohol intake, it’s difficult to judge who is driving under the influence of marijuana.
lead_paragraph: If you are pulled over on suspicion of drunken driving, the police officer is likely to ask you to complete three tasks: Follow a pen with your eyes while the officer moves it back and forth; get out of the car and walk nine steps, heel to toe, turn on one foot and go back; and stand on one leg for 30 seconds.

headline: Indian Journalist Charged With Rape of a Reporter

abstract: Researchers at Yale are building large libraries of spider venoms that can be used to identify toxins as potential painkillers and other drugs.

headline: Retreat on Debt Fight Seen as G.O.P. Campaign Salvo
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'National Debt (US)']
abstract: With their party on offense in its push to capture the Senate, Republicans say they are determined to avoid the mistakes and stumbles that Democrats exploited in 2010 and 2012.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators Mitch McConnell and John Cornyn, two Republican leaders facing primary challenges, knew they would take an immediate political hit from the Republicans’ Tea Party wing by voting to clear the way for a debt-limit increase. They also knew that their willingness to cast that vote would enhance their party’s chances of gaining a majority in the Senate next year.

headline: At New-York Historical Society, Civil War History Told Through Textiles
abstract: In time for the upcoming sesquicentennial marking the end of the Civil War, the New-York Historical Society is featuring the exhibition “Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts & Context in the Civil War,” which runs April 4 through Aug. 24 and uses approximately 130 objects.
lead_paragraph: In time for the upcoming sesquicentennial marking the end of the Civil War, the New-York Historical Society is featuring the exhibition “Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts & Context in the Civil War.” Running April 4 through Aug. 24, the exhibition uses approximately 130 objects, including quilts, clothing and other artifacts, to explore the ways that textiles expressed the era’s politics and culture. The show, from the American Textile History Museum in Lowell, Mass., where it was shown in 2012, includes additional artifacts from the New-York Historical Society’s collection.

headline: Treating Tuberculosis and AIDS Together Saves Lives
abstract: Those with multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis and AIDS are more likely to live if they get simultaneous treatment for both diseases, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: Patients who have multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis and AIDS are more likely to live if they get simultaneous treatment for both diseases rather than waiting weeks to start the AIDS treatment, a new study has found.

headline: Cigarette Ads Come Back to British TV
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Television']
abstract: Electronic devices are bypassing a loophole in the 50-year-old advertising code, but health officials and critics still have their doubts.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — About 50 years after Britain banned television advertisements for cigarettes, they are back. Except this time they are for the electronic kind.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Ugh!
abstract: Fashion and reality had a head-on smashup during Fashion Week, with more than 250 shows throughout the city in often freezing, snowy or slushy weather.
lead_paragraph: Fashion and reality had a head-on smashup during Fashion Week, with more than 250 shows throughout the city in often freezing, snowy or slushy weather.

headline: Russia to Release Loan Money for Ukraine, Lifting Leader
abstract: The Russian move does an end run around Europe’s sluggish efforts to support the Ukrainian opposition by coming up with an aid package of its own.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The protracted struggle for Ukraine between Russia and the West was on vivid display on Monday with Russia throwing an unexpected financial lifeline to the embattled Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, just as Germany rolled out an unusually high-level reception for two of the president’s most ardent opponents.

headline: A Writer Recalls His Amnesia
abstract: In “The Answer to the Riddle Is Me,” David Stuart MacLean tells of losing his memory and how his condition has subsequently affected his life.
lead_paragraph: David Stuart MacLean’s first book, “The Answer to the Riddle Is Me,” opens with a scene out of Robert Ludlum: The protagonist wakes from a blackout to find himself on a crowded train platform in India, with no idea who he is or what he’s doing in a foreign country.

headline: The Tall and the Small
abstract: Though there has long been a popular assumption that taller people are healthier and likely to live longer, recent studies suggest the opposite may be true.
lead_paragraph: Q. Among dogs, small breeds often live longer than larger ones. Is there any evidence that life expectancy for taller humans is also briefer?

headline: Monday Motorsports: A Demolition Derby at Daytona
abstract: Crashes prevail and a Sprint Cup rookie takes the pole at Daytona 500 qualifying; Simona de Silvestro becomes a Sauber Formula One affiliate.
lead_paragraph: A new Nascar season got off to an exciting start over the weekend at Daytona International Speedway in Florida with a demolition derby-caliber Sprint Unlimited shootout. Denny Hamlin won the bruising Unlimited after a late race rally, and a Sprint Cup rookie, Austin Dillon, set the fastest qualifying time for the Feb. 23 Daytona 500.

headline: U.S. Bombards One Swedish Goaltender, Then Another
abstract: Sweden’s starting goalie, Valentina Wallner, was under siege from the start, and though she did an admirable job, she was buried in a scoring onslaught by the Americans, who reached the gold-medal game against Canada.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Add another competitor to the list of extreme athletes at the Winter Olympics, those skicross racers, snowboarders and skiers who risk life and limb for their one shining moment. Valentina Wallner is her name, and it can be argued that there was no rougher patch of ice in all Rosa Khutor Extreme Park than the goal crease Wallner tried mightily to defend Monday when her country, Sweden, played the United States in a women’s hockey semifinal at Shayba Arena.

headline: Little Optimism as Iran Nuclear Talks Resume
abstract: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, expressed his mistrust of the motives of the United States and its allies and said he saw little chance of success in the negotiation effort.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Talks with Iran over a permanent agreement on its nuclear program begin on Tuesday in Vienna, but there is little immediate optimism over a negotiation that is expected to last up to a year.

headline: Skating With a Smile, No Matter What
abstract: Ice dancing, a grueling sport, demands that the athletes exert great discipline over every aspect of their facial expressions.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Hockey players gnash their teeth. Ski jumpers can hide their fear behind goggles. Speedskaters huff and puff as they round the bend.

headline: Russians Return to Cyprus, a Favorite Tax Haven
abstract: Despite efforts by international officials to curb Cyprus’s allure as a tax haven, it remains a magnet for investors and companies from Russia.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — When the Cypriot government forced bank depositors — many of them Russian — to pay their share of an international bailout last spring, Vasilis Zertalis’s phone started ringing.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Dewy Skin and Modern Mermaid Hair at Mary Katrantzou
abstract: Natural-looking makeup and effortless waves allowed the designer’s intricately crafted clothes to take center stage.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know why I’m telling you this, but we have changed the makeup three times in the past hour,” the makeup artist Val Garland said backstage at Mary Katrantzou. Garland’s early tests had included stronger, darker eyes and lips in an attempt to go someplace different from Katrantzou’s typical fresh-faced runway look. But why do away with a great thing? The designer and Garland decided to stick with what Garland called “very Mary” makeup. “The Katrantzou woman is pure and statuesque,” Garland said. “What stands out ultimately is her skin.” To complement the architecture and craftsmanship of the new collection, which strayed from the designer’s famed and oft-imitated digital prints, Garland opted for a down-to-earth and dewy look created using MAC products. Models’ lips were matte and natural, cheekbones were dusted with pink blush and eyelids sported a faint wash of silver. “I haven’t picked up a tube of mascara yet in London,” Garland said.

headline: Quadruple Bombing in Baghdad Kills at Least 25
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Three bombs targeted public markets and a Shiite mosque, the police said, the latest in a run of Sunni radical mayhem.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Three bombs that targeted public markets and a fourth bomb placed outside a Shiite mosque exploded Monday night in Baghdad, killing 25 people and wounding dozens, the police reported.

headline: Holcomb Skilled at Ending 62-Year Slumps
abstract: Steven Holcomb piloted an American bobsled to a third-place finish for the country’s first medal in 62 years in the two-man event.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Four years ago at the Vancouver Games, Steven Holcomb helped end a 62-year medal drought in bobsled by piloting the United States to a gold medal in the four-man event. On Monday at Sanki Sliding Center here, Holcomb did it again, this time teaming with Steve Langton to drive an American sled to its first medal in 62 years in the two-man.

headline: Chinese Officials Widen Campaign Against Vices
abstract: The operation appears intended to send a message similar to the so-called anticorruption campaign promoted by President Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government has widened a crackdown on prostitution, gambling and drug use to major provinces across the country, according to reports on Monday in state-run news organizations.

headline: Itching: More Than Skin-Deep
abstract: Long overshadowed by pain in terms of research and treatment, chronic itching is getting a serious look beyond just throwing antihistamines at it.
lead_paragraph: The experiment was not for the squirmish. Volunteers were made to itch like crazy on one arm, but not allowed to scratch. Then they were whisked into an M.R.I. scanner to see what parts of their brains lit up when they itched, when researchers scratched them and when they were finally allowed to scratch themselves.

headline: Giles: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Earwax’s Smell Influenced by Ethnicity
keywords: ['Smells and Odors', 'Ears and Hearing', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The earwax of Caucasian men contains more volatile organic compounds than that of East Asian men, researchers at the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia found.
lead_paragraph: The smell of a person’s earwax depends partly on his ethnic origin, a new study reports, suggesting that the substance could be an overlooked source of personal information.

headline: Understanding Opioid Abuse (2 Letters)
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Heroin', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Letters to the Editor of Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: The Distinct Role of Nurses (1 Letter)
abstract: A letter to the Editor.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Hills to Scientific Discoveries Grow Steeper
abstract: Moments of scientific triumph are harder to come by as scientists push against barriers both physical and mental.
lead_paragraph: Armed with a stopwatch and a perfume atomizer, Robert Millikan embarked in 1909 on a landmark discovery in physics. Squirting out a mist of oil drops and timing how quickly they fell in the presence of an electrical field, he ultimately showed that the world is awash with tiny, identically charged specks of matter — subatomic particles called electrons.

headline: Valery Kaufman Transforms Backstage at Peter Pilotto
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Valery Kaufman before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pica and hair by Anthony Turner.

headline: Pakistan Suspends Taliban Peace Talks Over Killings
abstract: The government refused to meet with Taliban representatives after the reported killing of 23 paramilitary soldiers in militant captivity.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Peace talks between the Pakistani government and the Taliban were suspended in acrimony on Monday, as a government committee refused to meet with Taliban representatives in the aftermath of the reported killing of 23 paramilitary soldiers in militant captivity.

headline: King Richard III’s Eyes, and the Munchies
abstract: Scientists in England are trying to sequence a long-dead monarch’s genome, and European researchers find more evidence that marijuana increases the appetite.
lead_paragraph: It was a week of revived hopes. Thermonuclear fusion is looking a bit more promising; a moon rover thought dead may yet work; and we may finally discover the color of King Richard III’s eyes. Keep your fingers crossed.

headline: A Battle for Gold and Posterity
abstract: Kim Yu-na of South Korea can become only the third woman to win consecutive Olympic gold medals in figure skating; Yulia Lipnitskaya of Russia can be youngest champion in 16 years.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Kim Yu-na had arrived on a long flight from South Korea to defend her Olympic figure skating title. This was her first practice, near dusk on Thursday, and dozens of reporters and photographers recorded every jump and spin and mop of the brow. The whir of cameras made a hushed, clattering sound like cards in the spokes of a bicycle tire.

headline: It’s Snack Time in the Cosmos
abstract: A gas cloud that has been hurtling toward the center of the Milky Way is expected to collide with a black hole, an exciting experience for astronomers.
lead_paragraph: Black holes, the ultradense collapsed objects predicted by Einstein’s theory of general relativity, are often depicted as voracious feeders whose extraordinary gravity acts like a one-way membrane: Everything is sucked in, even light, and virtually nothing leaks out.

headline: Why Russian Men Don’t Live as Long
abstract: A Russian male has a 1-in-4 chance of dying before he turns 55 years old, compared with a 1-in-11 chance for American men. Blame the vodka and cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: The probability that a Russian man will die before he turns 55 is 25 percent.

headline: Happy to Fly, When the Alternative Is Driving Off a Cliff
abstract: Kim Metcalf-Kupres, the chief marketing officer of Johnson Controls, is a fearless flier, but riding in a car with her husband can be different.
lead_paragraph: I’VE traveled most of my career, but until about five years ago, most of my business trips were domestic. I’m starting my 20th year with Johnson Controls, and as its chief marketing officer now, most of my trips are international. Whether I like flying is debatable. It’s probably fairer to say that I’ve gotten used to flying. At one time, I was a horrible “white-knuckle” flier, and now I’m just kind of numb to it. Takeoffs and landings don’t worry me as much anymore, and I don’t even think twice about turbulence.

headline: Just Ahead, Your Next Office
keywords: ['Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Business Travel', 'Workplace Environment', 'Co-Working']
abstract: The concept of co-working, in which independent workers share office space, is being expanded to provide work spaces on the road.
lead_paragraph: Joe Bunner, a sales executive from Austin, Tex., recently found himself in Denver for the day, with no place to work after a meeting had been canceled. “I didn’t want to go back to the hotel and get holed up in that box all day,” said Mr. Bunner, who works for Dynamic Signal, a marketing company.

headline: Q&A With Bayern Munich’s Jérôme Boateng
abstract: The central defender for the defending champion in Germany’s Bundesliga spoke with Jack Bell of The Times.
lead_paragraph: Jérôme Boateng, a disciplined central defender for the German powerhouse Bayern Munich, is bound for London this week and the first leg of a knockout home-and-away series against Arsenal in the UEFA Champions League.

headline: A New Kind of Transplant Bank
abstract: The nation’s first human stool bank was created to fight a potentially fatal infection, against which fecal transplants have proved more effective than antibiotics.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. — Around noon on a recent Friday, Donor Five, a healthy 31-year-old, walked across M.I.T.’s frigid, wind-swept campus to a third-floor restroom to make a contribution to public health.

headline: London Fashion Week: Christopher Kane Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: Tom Ford: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: A Picture of Detroit Ruin, Street by Forlorn Street
keywords: ['Abandonment (Property)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Land Use Policies', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Urban planners are watching the census of blight in Detroit for what it might mean for the way the most troubled cities can track empty, decaying structures and decide what do about them.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A midnight blue Chevy rolls slowly down a snow-covered street, an emergency strobe light on its roof and a sign on its side that promises this is “official business.” At each house, business, even vacant lot, workers in the car pause to decide whether someone lives there and what shape the place is in before snapping a photo and beaming it to “mission control” miles away.

headline: A Fresh Case for Breast Self-Exams
abstract: A Canadian study that produced negative results for mammography may give renewed momentum to clinical and self-exams.
lead_paragraph: Scientists produced dismal news last week about mammograms. After tracking 90,000 women for 25 years, researchers in Canada found that those who received regular mammograms did not experience fewer deaths from breast cancer or from all causes, compared with those who did not.

headline: From India, Proof That a Trip to Mars Doesn’t Have to Break the Bank
abstract: India’s recently launched mission to Mars was remarkable for its relatively low cost given the normally sky-high expense of space exploration.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — While India’s recent launch of a spacecraft to Mars was a remarkable feat in its own right, it is the $75 million mission’s thrifty approach to time, money and materials that is getting attention.

headline: A Website Offers Help Finding a Hotel Where You Can Light Up
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Business Travel']
abstract: A new website, Smoketel.com, books only smoking rooms at hotels around the world.
lead_paragraph: SMOKERS are often reviled and pitied by those with lesser vices, but do not they who smoke also need a place to lay their weary heads? Yes, they do, insists Shawn Bradley, who runs an odd little website called Smoketels.com, where those who puff can book a hotel that welcomes them.

headline: Bravado and Longing
abstract: Sabina Sciubba of Brazilian Girls has released her solo debut album, “Toujours,” and Ben Chasny and Donovan Quinn, as New Bums, have done “Voices in a Rented Room.”
lead_paragraph: SABINA

headline: U.S. Takes Gold in Ice Dancing
abstract: Meryl Davis and Charlie White won the United States’ first gold medal in ice dancing on Monday by a large margin over Canada and Russia’s top teams.
lead_paragraph: Meryl Davis and Charlie White won the United States’ first gold medal in ice dancing on Monday by a large margin over Canada and Russia’s top teams.

headline: Lorrie Moore’s New Book Is a Reminder and a Departure
abstract: The novelist Lorrie Moore’s new book, “Bark,” is her first story collection in 15 years.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Lorrie Moore doesn’t much resemble a Lorrie Moore character. She’s shy and self-deprecating but not melancholy, witty but not jokey. Her conversation doesn’t bristle with wordplay or throwaway one-liners; there are no zingers. Two of her favorite expressions are “I don’t know” and, added to the end of a sentence, “Or maybe not.”

headline: Notes From an Unpredictable Maestro
abstract: The St. Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra, which Yuri Temirkanov has led since 1988, played at Carnegie Hall last week.
lead_paragraph: The veteran maestro Yuri Temirkanov is famous not only for his podium mastery, but also for his unpredictability, personal as well as musical. Certainly, few could have foreseen the benighted comments about female conductors that he made a couple of years ago and that Alex Ross reported on The New Yorker’s website last fall: “The essence of the conductor’s profession is strength. The essence of a woman is weakness.”

headline: Amusement, Absurdity and Abuse
abstract: Pina Bausch’s Tanztheater Wuppertal took its “1980” back to the Sadler’s Wells in London after 32 years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For 25 years before her death in 2009, Pina Bausch and her Tanztheater Wuppertal were an international phenomenon. But her singular genre of dance theater reached many countries for the first time in the 1980s.

headline: Oh, Penn Station, Where Are You Now?
abstract: “The Rise and Fall of Penn Station,” on PBS’s “American Experience,” remembers a New York landmark whose demise kick-started the preservation movement.
lead_paragraph: The legacy of Pennsylvania Station, opened in 1910 and demolished a half-century ago — the bulldozers started work in October 1963, a New York sidebar to the country’s early-’60s upheavals — is more than a little contradictory. Built to celebrate America’s immense ambitions, in its death it became the poster building for historic preservation, the effort to protect our architectural heritage from those very ambitions in their later, lesser forms.

headline: Fighting (and Dancing) Like Bruce Lee
abstract: David Henry Hwang’s “Kung Fu,” about the life and legend of Bruce Lee, highlights the complexities of making stage fighting look real to an audience while remaining safe for the performers.
lead_paragraph: There was an audible thud when Ari Loeb fell on his backside in the midst of a scrappy, eight-against-one brawl at the Signature Theater Company recently. The fight was fictional, of course: Mr. Loeb was rehearsing the finale of “Kung Fu,” the new play by David Henry Hwang about the martial arts master Bruce Lee that is now in previews at Signature, where it opens on Monday.

headline: London Fashion Week: Erdem Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Waespi.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Waespi.

headline: France Tries to Tempt In More Foreign Investment
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Investments', 'Labor and Jobs', 'International Relations', 'Corporate Taxes']
abstract: Hoping for foreign investment, France’s president pledged tax stability to a group of high-ranking executives from the world’s multinationals. But forgetting some of his campaign rhetoric may not be easy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France has begun a major charm offensive to convince the world that France is open for business in a bid to lure back investments, which have slumped since he took office.

headline: Manifest Destiny: Into the Wild With a Tool Belt
abstract: Cable channels are offering several new shows about building rustic cabins, including “Mennonite Made,” “Building Wild” and “Timber Kings.”
lead_paragraph: The dead of winter may not seem like the liveliest time in the real estate business, but on television one segment of the new-construction market is booming: the cabin-in-the-woods market.

headline: A Nation Perpetually Under a Thumb
abstract: “Russians: The People Behind the Power,” by Gregory Feifer, gives a portrait of the nation in the age of Putin.
lead_paragraph: The extravagant, sometimes kitschy opening ceremony of the Sochi Olympics on Feb. 7 gave us a cleaned-up, World’s Fair version of Russian history, celebrating the glories of its scientific and artistic achievements while airbrushing the horrors of its Stalinist past. At the same time, the ceremony was devised to try to make the world forget the dark side of President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia — its smothering of dissent, its oppressive antigay laws — and to promote an image of the country as a modernizing great power ascendant on the world stage.

headline: Neil Gaiman to Perform ‘Black Mountains’ in U.S.
abstract: The novelist Neil Gaiman, who turned his novelette “The Truth Is a Cave in the Black Mountains” into a performance, is bringing the show to the United States.
lead_paragraph: The novelist Neil Gaiman (“American Gods”; “The Graveyard Book”). who turned his novelette “The Truth Is a Cave in the Black Mountains” into a performance that is a synchronized mix of music, art and storytelling for audiences abroad, is bringing the show to the United States. At a performance on June 25 at the Warfield in San Francisco and one on June 27 at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Gaiman, above, will read his tale of crime and search for buried treasure, accompanied by a score written for the event from the FourPlay String Quartet, from Sydney, Australia. As Mr. Gaiman reads, the images from the story will be displayed on a screen behind him, courtesy of the artist Eddie Campbell. Mr. Campbell will also illustrate a hardcover edition of “The Truth Is a Cave in the Black Mountains” when the story is published in June by William Morrow. The story had been in an anthology, but the new edition draws on the art created for the live performances. The 90-minute multimedia event was commissioned by the Sydney Opera House for its Graphic Festival in 2010 and was performed a year later in Tasmania for Mona Foma, an arts festival. The show is scheduled to travel to the Barbican in London on July 4 and 5.

headline: In Shampoo Ads for Men, It’s Not Just the Hair, It’s What It Does for You
abstract: While unisex personal care products proliferated a generation ago, the shampoo aisle remained a haven for unisex products, but that, too, is shifting.
lead_paragraph: WHILE unisex personal care products proliferated a generation ago, today the antiperspirant and soap aisles, for example, are dominated by products marketed to just men or women. The shampoo aisle remained a haven for unisex products, but that, too, is shifting, with Old Spice now introducing a hair care line, joining men’s brands like Axe, which began selling hair products in 2009, and Dove Men+Care, which did so in 2013.

headline: In a Village, Love Is in the Air Before a Doll Comes Into Play
abstract: New York City Ballet is staging a production of “Coppélia,” a comedy involving a girl who’s a doll.
lead_paragraph: The doll that the ballet “Coppélia” is named after never comes to life. That the ballet itself is still living, nearly 150 years after its first staging, is largely because of Léo Delibes’s vivacious score. New York City Ballet’s production, which will be 40 this summer, has further life-extending virtues: folk dances theatricalized by Petipa and others, as remembered and restaged by Alexandra Danilova and George Balanchine; a third act of allegorical dances by Balanchine, framed by 24 adorably well-trained little girls from the School of American Ballet.

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,297 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,297 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

lead_paragraph: Bitcoin is facing significant growing pains as it struggles to move beyond a stormy adolescence.

headline: At Newark Airport, the Lights Are On, and They’re Watching You
keywords: ['Light-Emitting Diodes', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Airport Security', 'Privacy', 'Lighting', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Sensors', 'Cameras']
abstract: LED lighting systems that observe people and gather data are being introduced worldwide, but some experts see potential for misuse.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to Terminal B at Newark Liberty International Airport may notice the bright, clean lighting that now blankets the cavernous interior, courtesy of 171 recently installed LED fixtures. But they probably will not realize that the light fixtures are the backbone of a system that is watching them.

headline: Speaking Up for the Mute Swan
abstract: The real threat to New York’s wetlands is not a nonnative bird, but people.
lead_paragraph: THE Department of Environmental Conservation is proposing to kill New York State’s entire population of free-ranging mute swans, those graceful white water birds long treasured as symbols of romance and fidelity. New Yorkers have until Feb. 21 to submit responses to a plan that calls for the removal by 2025 of the estimated 2,200 birds by methods that could include shooting, gassing, decapitation and egg addling.

headline: Eyes in the Skies, City of the Future, Your Virtual Self
abstract: This week the podcast hits the road, traveling to Chicago for the annual American Association for the Advancement of Science conference to track a stream of data that flows from above Earth, along city streets and inside your body.
lead_paragraph: This week the podcast hits the road, traveling to Chicago for the annual American Association for the Advancement of Science conference to track a stream of data that flows from above Earth, along city streets and inside your body.

headline: The Podcast Hits the Road
abstract: This week, we travel to Chicago to the American Association for the Advancement of Science conference to sample science from outer space to inner space.
lead_paragraph: This week the Science Times podcast hit the road. I traveled to Chicago for the annual American Association for the Advancement of Science conference.

headline: Small Towns in Southwest Fear Loss of Cherished Train Line
abstract: The Southwest Chief route, a lifeline to rural communities, is in danger if Amtrak cannot persuade three of the states it runs through to help fund track repairs and maintenance.
lead_paragraph: LAMY, N.M. — For 18 years, Maryalice Garrigan has been taking the train from this wisp of a town near Santa Fe to visit her family in Albany, spending four days to reach New York via a connection in Chicago. She cherishes the annual ritual: Sipping the whiskey she packs in a cooler, and tracing the creeks and mesas that whiz by with a map she brings on each trip.

headline: Watching Sliding Sports Live? The Athletes Wish You Luck
abstract: Sliding sports, like bobsled or luge or skeleton, are often decided by thousandths of a second, making it difficult for fans to watch and to know when to cheer.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Sergei and Oksana Barilo traveled to Sanki Sliding Center from Novocherkassk, a city about 400 miles away. They dressed warmly. They took their two children. And they packed plenty of patience.

headline: VHS vs. Communism
abstract: In Communist Romania in the 1980s, a young translator became an unlikely voice of freedom. She illicitly dubbed thousands of foreign films, distributed on VHS tapes, turning B-movie stars into heroes.
lead_paragraph: In Communist Romania in the 1980s, a young translator became an unlikely voice of freedom. She illicitly dubbed thousands of foreign films, distributed on VHS tapes, turning B-movie stars into heroes.

headline: ‘VHS vs. Communism’
abstract: In Communist Romania, Chuck Norris and Bruce Lee became popular heroes thanks to a translator who illicitly dubbed thousands of foreign films.
lead_paragraph: I was raised in Romania in the 1980s, under a Communist regime that, among countless repressions, reduced television to two hours a day of dull propaganda, traditional music, patriotic poems and censored films. One day when I was 6, my parents found a way to borrow a VCR. They invited their friends, and all night they watched grainy VHS tapes of Hollywood B-movies. I remember the films, but more so I remember how I felt when I stepped into the living room — like walking into a secret, magical and free world.

headline: A Big Bet on Gluten-Free
abstract: The number of people who must avoid gluten for health reasons is relatively small, but other consumers have joined them to create a lucrative market the food industry covets.

lead_paragraph: Her perseverance often awes me. Her arrogance sometimes galls me. And her particular braid of high-mindedness and high-handedness almost always leaves me puzzled and exhausted.

headline: Beltran and Roberts Note Honor and Responsibility in Being Yankees
abstract: Carlos Beltran, who fulfilled a personal ambition by signing with the Yankees in the off-season, said he was looking forward to helping the team win a championship.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Piece by piece, player by player, the 2014 Yankees are assembling here. Two days ahead of the official reporting date, Carlos Beltran, Brian Roberts and Kelly Johnson were the latest players to arrive at spring training Monday, working out together at the team’s minor league complex in anticipation of what some of them say could be a special season, perhaps even ending in ultimate glory.

headline: The Prodigal Sons

lead_paragraph: We take as our text today the parable of the prodigal sons. As I hope you know, the story is about a father with two sons. The younger son took his share of the inheritance early and blew it on prostitutes and riotous living. When the money was gone, he returned home.

abstract: Work on three subterranean projects in Manhattan have enabled them to see rock formations and faults they had only been able to imagine.
lead_paragraph: Imagine the frustration faced for so many years by Eric W. Jordan and his colleagues. They could take a pretty good guess at what lay hundreds of feet beneath the macadam-sealed surface of New York City’s streets. They just had no way of knowing for sure.

headline: Nobel Winner’s Frank Advice to China’s Leadership
abstract: To make the transition to a high-income economy, A. Michael Spence calls for bolstering domestic demand and exposing state firms to more market pressure.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — A. Michael Spence won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 2001 for esoteric research on how people make decisions when critical information is hard to obtain. But by that time, after more than a decade and a half as an academic dean at Harvard and Stanford, many of Mr. Spence’s colleagues had begun referring to him as a “former economist.”

Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: A Curse to Many in New York Is a Thrill for the More Daring

lead_paragraph: The white stuff that has fallen unrelentingly on New York this winter goes by a number of printable words in several languages — neve, neige, thalj, sneg — but on a sparkling Presidents’ Day in Central Park, the snow on the ground translated into one unified cry of fun: “Aiiiieeeee!”

headline: In Diluting Measure to Ban Gay Marriage, Indiana Shows a Shift

The notion had sped through Indiana’s legislature a few years ago, the first of two required votes.

headline: Chad Kellogg, a Speed Climbing Pioneer, Dies in Rock Fall at 42

lead_paragraph: Chad Kellogg, an elite climber known for his speed ascents of large mountains, died on Friday after being struck on the head by a falling rock while descending the Patagonian peak Fitz Roy. He was 42.

keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations']

headline: Banning Ivory Sales in America
keywords: ['Ivory', 'Elephants', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'ANTIQUES', 'Editorials', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: If rigorously enforced, new rules issued by the Obama administration should help slow the slaughter of African elephants.
lead_paragraph: The slaughter of the dwindling elephant herds in Africa grows worse by the year as organized criminals get rich from selling elephant tusks in lucrative black markets around the world, where a pound of ivory can fetch $1,500. African elephants, whose numbers have been reduced in less than a century from several million to an estimated 500,000, are being killed at a rate of 30,000 to 35,000 a year.

headline: What to Watch: Tuesday, Feb. 18
abstract: Jessica Lindell-Vikarby of Sweden is at her third Olympics but still seeking her first medal; the giant slalom could be her best chance.
lead_paragraph: SPEEDSKATING Sven Kramer of the Netherlands won a gold medal in the 5,000 meters at the 2010 Games but is better remembered for the one he lost. That came in the 10,000, where he was on pace to win easily when his coach, Gerard Kemkers, directed him into the wrong lane. Kramer was disqualified, and inconsolable. Now he is back, and still the favorite in the grueling, 25-lap 10,000. And you know who else is back? Kemkers, who still coaches him. They will be paying especially close attention today. NBCSN, 8 a.m.

headline: The Confederate Submarine
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Submarines and Submersibles']
abstract: The strange story of the H.L. Hunley — and the legend of its last captain.
lead_paragraph: The moonlit sea was unusually calm on the bitterly cold night of Feb. 17, 1864, when a watchman spotted a strange, partially submerged shape gliding steadily toward the side of the Union sloop-of-war Housatonic. The steam-powered warship was serving blockade duty outside Charleston Harbor, and was one of the Union’s biggest, best-armed vessels. Its men had heard reports of a new Confederate weapon, a “sub-torpedo”; still, it took a few minutes for the officer of the deck, John Crosby, to comprehend what he was seeing. By the time he did, it was too late.

headline: Stalin and Soap
abstract: It’s easy, in dismantling the family home and possessions, to decide what to do with the sugar-packet collection, but what about the Soviet-era propaganda?
lead_paragraph: This is the third part of an eight-part series.

headline: The Art of Vernacular Voice
abstract: Capturing the true cadence of any region’s dialect in written form is tricky, because it should harmonize sounds with words and grammar patterns that may be centuries old.
lead_paragraph: In an interview with the Pulitzer Prize-winning writer Rick Bragg, John Sledge tells the story of Mr. Bragg’s encounter with the acclaimed author Willie Morris, who opened Mr. Bragg’s memoir “All Over But the Shoutin’,” and read several pages aloud. He slammed the book and leaned forward, telling Mr. Bragg, “You say it’s the story, and I say it’s the language.” Mr. Sledge is talking about the voices in Mr. Bragg’s books, which ring true down to the red Alabama grit on their shoes. Every voice on paper has a linguistic and social history that needs to be heard.

I flipped for her music when I first heard her last spring at Birdland, in Midtown Manhattan, and I’ve been listening to her, more or less obsessively, ever since.

headline: An Interview Up Close, and Far Too Personal

Then there was Christin Cooper’s interview of Bode Miller on Sunday after he won the bronze medal in the Super-G, which has ignited a debate about whether she poked too deeply at the scar tissue of his brother’s recent death.

lead_paragraph: Stuart Hall, a pioneering Jamaican-born British academic who argued that culture is in fact multicultural — not high or low, good or bad, or black or white, but a constantly shifting convergence reflecting the range of people who create and consume it — died on Feb. 10 in London. He was 82.

headline: Q.&A.: Steven I. Levine on the Tiananmen Initiative Project
abstract: Steven I. Levine, a historian of China who is retired from the University of Montana, explains his effort to encourage candid commemoration of the events that culminated in the 1989 crackdown.
lead_paragraph: This year will mark 25 years since the upheavals of 1989 in China, when student protests prompted by the death of Hu Yaobang — the relatively liberal Communist Party leader who was pressed into resigning in 1987 — grew into huge, passionate demonstrations in Beijing and other cities demanding clean government, democratic change and respect for human rights. The party patriarch Deng Xiaoping deemed the demonstrations, based in Tiananmen Square in Beijing, a grave threat to party power. He authorized martial law in urban Beijing, ousted Mr. Hu’s successor as party general secretary, the reform-minded Zhao Ziyang, and ordered the People’s Liberation Army to end the demonstrations. The crackdown culminated in troops taking Tiananmen Square in the early hours of June 4. Across Beijing, many hundreds of protesters and ordinary citizens caught in the wrong place died from military gunfire, and soldiers also died at the hands of incensed residents. The precise number of dead has been in dispute ever since 1989.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:20 P.M. (Starz Edge) CELESTE AND JESSE FOREVER (2012) Rashida Jones portrays Celeste, and Andy Samberg is Jesse (above, with Ms. Jones), a married couple in Los Angeles who have split up without moving on or out in this wistful romantic comedy. Ms. Jones plays a hard-driving trend forecaster who lives in the house they once shared; he is a laid-back artist who now flops in the backyard studio. Though they are best friends bound by the same adolescent humor, Jesse’s lack of ambition doesn’t allow the focused Celeste to stay with him. But she can’t quit him, either — until suddenly she must. “While ‘Celeste and Jesse’ is decidedly conventional in most respects, it’s pretty swell as an exploration of a relationship between a man and a woman that’s no longer predicated by mutual desire,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Should Felons Be Allowed to Vote After They Have Served Their Time?
abstract: Does someone give up the right to participate in our democracy for committing a felony at any point in life?
lead_paragraph: Almost six million Americans have been stripped of their right to vote — many for the rest of their lives. Most states prohibit prisoners in jail from voting, but some states bar felons from ever voting, even decades after they are released, unless they receive clemency from the governor. Felonies can include violent crimes like murder and assault, but also nonviolent crimes like tax evasion, drug dealing and check fraud.

headline: Daily Report: The Lights Are Watching You
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Light-Emitting Diodes', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: LED lighting systems that can observe people and gather data are being introduced worldwide, but some experts say there is potential for misuse.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to Terminal B at Newark Liberty International Airport may notice the bright, clean lighting that now blankets the cavernous interior, courtesy of 171 recently installed LED fixtures. But they probably will not realize that the light fixtures are the backbone of a system that is watching them, Diane Cardwell reports.

headline: Kiev Protesters Set Square Ablaze to Thwart Police
abstract: Street battles in Kiev between protesters and the riot police underscored the volatility of the political crisis. More than a dozen people were killed, including two security officers, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — With hundreds of riot police officers advancing from all sides after a day of deadly mayhem here in the Ukrainian capital, antigovernment protesters mounted a final desperate and seemingly doomed act of defiance late on Tuesday evening, establishing a protective ring of fire around what remained of their all-but-conquered encampment on Independence Square.

headline: Protest Installation to Document Prisoners in Iran
abstract: The Parisian street artist J R will unveil a pair of pop-up installations on Tuesday that protest incarcerations in Iran.
lead_paragraph: The “Inside Out” project, created by the Parisian street artist J R, joined forces with the Iran Human Rights Documentation Center in a pop-up protest against the incarceration of journalists, artists, feminists and other activists in Iran on Tuesday morning outside the United Nations. Like the J R project, in which large portraits of ordinary people are plastered on walls and sidewalks, the installation at the protest included portraits of 11 people who are currently imprisoned in Iran, and two who were recently executed. A second protest, originally scheduled for noon in SoHo, has been postoned until Thursday because of the weather, a spokeswoman for the center said on Tuesday morning.

And the best place to introduce a new band here is at South by Southwest in Austin, Tex. — the world’s largest conference for new music. Each year, along with thousands of others from around the world, I would stage a campaign to make some band the hottest new act of the conference.

headline: A $25 Billion Deal for Drug Makers
abstract: The drug maker Actavis will acquire Forest Laboratories for about $25 billion. | King Digital Entertainment, the maker of Candy Crush Saga, has filed for an I.P.O. | Bitcoin is experiencing some growing pains. | Britain’s Serious Fraud Office has begun criminal proceedings against three former Barclays employees suspected in the manipulation of Libor. | Comcast’s proposed deal for Time Warner Cable could set off a frenzy of deal-making.
lead_paragraph: DRUG MAKERS ANNOUNCE $25 BILLION DEAL  |  Actavis, the world’s second-largest generic drug maker by market value, will acquire Forest Laboratories for about $25 billion, the companies announced on Tuesday. The deal is a coup for the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, who gained a seat on the board of Forest Labs in 2012 and is one of the company’s largest shareholders, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: A Troubled Winter Olympics? We’ve Seen This Before
abstract: Cost and construction problems, insufficient snow and fear of terrorists surrounded the 1980 Lake Placid Games, just as they have the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: Once, a relatively obscure city prepared to stage a Winter Olympics and it was not going well. Costs spiraled. Construction was repeatedly delayed. Environmental concerns kept cropping up. Transportation was predicted to be a nightmare. Closer to the Games, terrorist threats emerged, an absurdly warm winter left the mountain almost bereft of snow and rising political tensions threatened to overrun the whole show.

headline: Can an Insecure Parent Raise a Secure Child?
abstract: In classroom after classroom on our school tour, I saw the same thing: no desks. Can a collaborative, gentle education really turn out a child as determined to succeed as I was?
lead_paragraph: The colorful classroom had enormous windows that overlooked a leafy yard with a state-of-the-art sandbox. This modern school, in a quaint brownstone, was gorgeous. I glanced at the other parents — all coiffed, thin and seeming like they’d just come from mommy-and-me physics — happy that a friend had warned me not to wear jeans. Crossing my arms over my old jacket and non-designer handbag, I decided to peek at the attached elementary school.

headline: Finding 3 Ways to Enjoy Alaska’s Winter
abstract: On a January trip to the Anchorage area, the author finds that coffee, beer and winter sports can inject some life into the season’s cold, dark days.
lead_paragraph: Alone on a ridge in the Chugach Mountains of southern Alaska, I struggled to see. The wind was blowing upslope from the south, pelting my face with snow. Around me, all was white — or purple, as after a few hours of trying to rise in the sky, the sun had given up, leaving me alone in the dark. There was no shelter from the cutting wind as trees didn’t even try to grow at this extreme elevation. I had already had an exhausting day of climbing and descending the ridges, and I wasn’t sure how much more I could handle. Far below, the sea ice boulders strewn across the low tide line of the Turnagain Arm pointed the way back toward Anchorage, and civilization. But right about then, I didn’t know what I was going to do.

headline: Lower House in India Passes Bill to Create a 29th State
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Few questions in Indian politics have generated as much raw emotion, pro and con, as the proposed creation of Telangana State. The vote set off celebrations and protests.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Few questions in Indian politics have generated as much raw emotion, pro and con, as the proposed creation of Telangana, a 29th state, out of an inland slice of south India largely covered with cornfields and rice paddies.

headline: ‘Act of Killing’ Director Says He Is Not Safe in Indonesia
abstract: The filmmaker has been under fire from the government for a documentary that it says portrays the country as “a cruel and lawless nation.”
lead_paragraph: An Oscar nomination confers certain privileges — red carpet receptions, better future projects — but political protection is not among them.

headline: Lower House of Parliament Approves Creation of New State
abstract: A contentious bill to bifurcate the southern state of Andhra Pradesh and create the state of Telangana was passed by the lower house on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After several disruptions and delays, the controversial Telangana Bill, bifurcating the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, was passed by the lower house of Parliament on Tuesday.

headline: Money Lessons From Where the Air Is Thinner
abstract: The climber Alison Levine has learned that the skills needed to tackle a mountain are also useful in making decisions about money.
lead_paragraph: I had a conversation this month with Alison Levine, a polar explorer and mountaineer who has climbed the tallest peak on every continent. While I’m a casual climber in comparison, we do share a love of the mountains and the things they can teach us. In fact, Alison’s new book, On the Edge: The Art of High-Impact Leadership, is full of lessons she learned outside and how they apply to making decisions of all sorts, including smarter ones about money.

keywords: ['Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Legal Profession', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: In Missouri, advocates for indigent clients hope an analysis of time spent on cases will bolster budget requests for more staff.
lead_paragraph: CLAYTON, Mo. — On a typical recent morning Colleen M. Polak, a St. Louis County public defender, ran upstairs and down and up again and in and out of four courtrooms, simultaneously representing clients in 10 cases. She consulted, negotiated and sometimes just waited.

headline: De Blasio Outlines Steps to Eliminate Traffic Deaths

lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday unveiled a sweeping set of proposals aimed at improving street safety in New York City, pledging considerable police resources and even precious political capital in Albany to a most ambitious goal: eliminating traffic deaths.

headline: 2 Egyptians Charged With Spying for Israel
abstract: Egyptian prosecutors also announced charges against two Israeli citizens, who it said were agents of Mossad, Israel’s spy service.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Prosecutors announced Tuesday that they had arrested two Egyptian citizens on charges of spying for Israel, saying the suspects had confessed to supplying Israeli agents with information on Egypt’s military, its political movements and about the 2011 uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Known for ambitious plans in China for business parks the size of cities, Xu Weiping says he cannot wait to start work on his first project abroad: turning an abandoned London dock into Europe’s main hub for Chinese companies.

lead_paragraph: An exhibit of items relating to the original 1959 Broadway production of Lorraine Hansberry’s “A Raisin in the Sun” has opened at the New York Public Library, in conjunction with the revival starring Denzel Washington, which begins previews on March 8.

headline: For Fleet-Footed Karlsson, Safety Comes in a Sock

lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The Swedish defenseman Erik Karlsson moves like an ice dancer, his feet a blur of motion. He has a quick first step that allows him to jump into rushes like a 500-meter speedskater bursting off the starting line. Through the first three games of the Olympics, Karlsson’s feet did not fail him.

headline: CBS Drops Two and Adds Gonzalez to ‘NFL Today’

lead_paragraph: CBS Sports changed the cast of its “NFL Today” pregame show on Tuesday by hiring Tony Gonzalez to the panel and parting with Shannon Sharpe and Dan Marino.

headline: Lewis Carroll Letter Illustrates How He Hated Fame
abstract: In a letter headed to auction, the pseudonymous author of “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” wrote that he loathed being recognized.
lead_paragraph: J.K. Rowling drew headlines recently with her regrets about how she handled the romantic pairings at the end of the “Harry Potter” series. But Lewis Carroll, according to a letter to be sold at auction next month, once declared that he regretted having written his “Alice in Wonderland” books at all.

headline: Iraqi Cleric, Exiting Politics, Urges Others to Keep Serving

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Moktada al-Sadr, the influential anti-American Shiite cleric, reaffirmed in a speech in Najaf on Tuesday that he was withdrawing from Iraqi politics, telling his followers in Parliament to continue to serve but not on his behalf.

headline: New Murakami Novel Coming in August
abstract: “Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage,” a hit in Japan, will be published in the United States in August.
lead_paragraph: Haruki Murakami’s latest novel, “Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage,” will be published in the United States on Aug. 12, Alfred A. Knopf has announced. The novel was an enormous hit in Japan in April, where it sold more than a million copies in its first week, according to Knopf.

headline: Taking Their Investments Elsewhere
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy']
abstract: For the first time since 1992, foreigners were net sellers of American stocks in 2013.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury on Tuesday released its estimates of international capital flows into and out of the United States, and they indicate that foreigners were net sellers of $40.2 billion of American stocks in 2013. That is hardly a large amount, but it is the first year since 1992 that they were net sellers.

lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 6:50 p.m. | As the deadly clashes in the Ukrainian capital, Kiev, continued late Tuesday, hundreds of thousands of people followed the violence as it unfolded, watching a live YouTube video stream from the besieged protest camp provided by the local website Espreso.tv, and reading Twitter updates from reporters and activists in Independence Square.

lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Actavis Deal May Become the Standard for Drug Deals
abstract: Actavis is not alone in its penchant for acquisitions, Robert Cyran writes for Reuters Breakingviews. Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Endo Health Solutions are among those that have also enhanced their market values by snatching up rivals, slashing costs and minimizing taxes.
lead_paragraph: Actavis makes pharmaceutical deals look generic. Its $25 billion acquisition of Forest Laboratories follows a familiar formula in the sector. Agitating investor? Check. Low-tax jurisdiction? Check. Buyer’s stock rises? Check. And with over $8 billion of value created, financiers will keep busy with their own merger success.

headline: Minimum Wage Increase Would Have Mixed Effects, C.B.O. Report Says
abstract: The analysis provided instant fuel for both supporters and critics of raising the federal minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A popular Democratic proposal to raise the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour, championed by President Obama, could reduce total employment by 500,000 workers by the second half of 2016. But it would also lift 900,000 families out of poverty and increase the incomes of 16.5 million low-wage workers in an average week.

lead_paragraph: Mavis Gallant, an acclaimed short-story writer who was abandoned as a child and later left Canada for Europe, where she made her name writing about the dislocated and the dispossessed, died on Tuesday at her home in Paris. She was 91.

headline: The Stimulus Anniversary
abstract: Good economics, bad political economy.
lead_paragraph: Lots of discussion around the fifth anniversary of the Recovery Act. I don’t have time for an extended discussion today, but my quick verdict remains the same as it was right from the beginning: this was a plan that did considerable economic good but considerable political harm.

headline: There Is a Salary Gap Even When Women Pay Themselves
abstract: Female entrepreneurs went into the Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses program with average salaries that were 80 percent those of their male counterparts.
lead_paragraph: Most of us have heard that in the workplace, women are paid less than men. But here’s a surprising corollary, courtesy of a recent study by Babson College: Female entrepreneurs actually pay themselves less than male entrepreneurs pay themselves.

headline: Stew Season Gets a New Star
abstract: Beef, chicken or fish become a treat, not a main feature.
lead_paragraph: There is an extreme version of just about every stew you can name — beef stew, Irish stew, curry, cassoulet, bouillabaisse — in which vegetables are used, if at all, as “aromatics.” You may start by sweating a little bit of onion, carrot, celery, maybe garlic, with a bay leaf and a thyme sprig, and then you proceed to brown your main ingredient, usually chunks of meat, and add some liquid.

headline: The Harder They Fall: Shared Slopes Take Bigger Toll on Women
abstract: Unlike some sports of risk, including Alpine skiing, few concessions are made for women in snowboarding and freestyle skiing events like slopestyle.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Sarka Pancochova, a Czech snowboarder, led the slopestyle event after the first run. On her second trip down the course of obstacles and jumps, she flew through the air, performed a high-arcing, spinning trick and smacked her head upon landing. Her limp body spun like a propeller into the gully between jumps and slid to a stop.

headline: A Timelessness for Seven Blocks

lead_paragraph: Anybody who’s had a hard time remembering what store used to be on a certain corner, despite having walked past it every day for years, may understand how ephemeral New York can be, even when it comes to landmarks etched in stone.

abstract: Can a Scandinavian cuisine escape its chilly image? Some chefs are working on it.

headline: Liberal Donors Pollute Politics, Too
abstract: Whether it comes from the Koch brothers or Tom Steyer, big money hurts the system.
lead_paragraph: Those who are worried about man-made climate change might be tempted to welcome the news that Tom Steyer, a Democratic billionaire, will spend $100 million this year to fight it. Mr. Steyer plans to put up half the money himself for attack ads against governors and lawmakers who ignore climate change, and will raise the rest from like-minded rich people.

headline: Readers Respond to School Snow Days
abstract: Readers respond to the parenting burdens of a snow day.
lead_paragraph: The snow has finally tapered off in most places around the city, but the truth is the mere forecast of snow makes me anxious these days. In my column this week, I describe the way many suburban parents, including my husband and myself, have been struggling to cope with the slew of snow-related school closings. We have been trying to juggle work — conference calls, column writing — and caring for our antsy little ones. It is no easy task. We have had seven snow days so far this winter in Montclair, N.J., which is why I commended New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio for keeping city schools open during most of these storms, despite some complaints from parents.

headline: Smuggling Case Against Antiquities Collector Is Dismissed
abstract: A federal judge has dismissed criminal charges against an antiquities collector from Virginia who had been accused of a role in smuggling Egyptian artifacts.
lead_paragraph: Joseph A. Lewis II, a Virginia businessman and avid collector who was indicted in 2011 on charges that he conspired to smuggle Egyptian antiquities and to launder money, has been cleared of wrongdoing. A federal judge in New York dismissed all the charges against him last month.

headline: European Finance Ministers Revisit Plans for Failing Banks
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Taxation', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The leaders looked at new ways to appease critics who said their proposal would be too cumbersome and take too long to introduce.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With their plans to create a banking union facing deadlock, European finance ministers promised Tuesday to explore new ways to assuage critics who contend that their proposed system to deal with failing banks would be too feeble, too cumbersome and take too long to introduce.

headline: Riding a Chef’s Twists and Turns
abstract: Danny Bowien’s Mexican dishes are hit or miss, but at these prices you can try again.
lead_paragraph: IF YOU HAVE a wide-ranging appetite and more time than money, there’s never been a better time to eat in New York. Every corner of the city is churning out affordable hits of deliciousness, and a long wait is often the only obstacle between wanting some and getting some. Even acclaimed chefs are in this game now, making creative cooking more accessible than ever. And if the meal turns out to be less exciting than you had hoped, you’ve lost only a few hours and a few dollars. The next day will bring some new taste, a Filipino tapas bar or an artisanal spaetzle truck.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere

lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Thailand, South Africa and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

headline: Coaching Americans and Canadians, but Russian Through and Through

headline: Capital One to Revisit Credit Card Contract Terms After Outcry
abstract: Capital One on Tuesday said it would rethink the wording of its credit card contracts after a provision that said the bank could “contact you at your home and at your place of employment” began attracting a lot of unwanted attention.
lead_paragraph: Banks are known for sticking terms into the fine print that don’t always sit well with consumers. But on Tuesday, Capital One said it would rethink the wording of its credit card contracts after a little-known provision began attracting a lot of unwanted attention.

headline: At a California Resort, a Tequila Tutorial
abstract: The Rancho Valenica Resort and Spa in California has started a club dedicated to the study (and sipping) of tequila and mezcal.
lead_paragraph: A resort in Southern California is capitalizing on the recent proliferation of mezcal and other agave-derived liquor distilleries to draw new devotees to a members-only club. The Rancho Valencia Resort and Spa near San Diego recently started its All Agave Project, a series of seminars and tastings for the cocktail crowd.

headline: Funny, You Don’t Look Like My Wife
abstract: In Ken Urban’s drama “The Correspondent,” a widower’s wife returns in the body of a man.
lead_paragraph: Technology hurtles forward, spinning off new surprises by the year, but I’ve not yet heard that emails can be sent from beyond the grave. This startling concept is among the many oddities of “The Correspondent,” a psychological drama by Ken Urban that shovels on the preposterous twists in depicting the desperation of a widower trying to make contact with his dead wife.

headline: App Smart: Walking
abstract: The same smartphones that often keep us sitting down can also encourage us to get up and walk more by tracking our steps.
lead_paragraph: The same smartphones that often keep us sitting down can also encourage us to get up and walk more by tracking our steps.

headline: These Apps Are Made for Walking
abstract: Several apps count your steps and calories burned, and maybe can help motivate you to move a little more.
lead_paragraph: We spend too much time sitting around. It’s true. Luckily the same smartphones that often keep us sitting down can also encourage us to get up and walk more by tracking our steps.

headline: A Crusader on What Ails Artists
keywords: ['Art', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: An online video project, “Healthy Artists,” about the problems faced by uninsured artists, has culminated in a documentary by Julie Sokolow, a filmmaker and health care advocate.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Beer bottles clinked and indie-rock classics played overhead at a gallery opening here on a Friday night recently, as one artist after another chatted with Julie Sokolow, a filmmaker and health care advocate who has documented the Pittsburgh scene in detail.

headline: A Frustrated Woman on the Verge of More of the Same
abstract: “Child’s Pose,” by Calin Peter Netzer, is a family drama set in the new Romania.
lead_paragraph: All kinds of monstrous mothers rage and rail in the movies, including those who love too little or too much. In Douglas Sirk’s 1959 melodrama, “Imitation of Life,” Lana Turner plays one type, a selfish white woman who’s blissfully indifferent to her child’s needs. Yet the more disturbing mother is played by Juanita Moore as a black domestic who smothers her own daughter in so much goodness that it’s no surprise that the girl flees. At the end, the saint’s daughter throws herself on her mother’s coffin; it’s a wonder she doesn’t leap in front of a train. In “Child’s Pose,” a drama with a story as cold, merciless and inevitable as a tomb, escape proves every bit as futile.

headline: American David Wise Wins Men’s Ski Halfpipe

headline: ‘Today’ Claws Ahead of ‘Good Morning America’ With Help of Olympics

lead_paragraph: It took all the power of the Winter Olympics, but NBC’s “Today” show clawed its way back to the top of the ratings last week, besting by an average of 211,000 viewers a day the now-consistent morning leader, “Good Morning America” on ABC.

headline: Off to a Bigger Journey, After Years in the World of ’30s-Style Swing Music
abstract: The young jazz singer Brianna Thomas, who played at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Monday, begins a bigger journey with the release of her new album.
lead_paragraph: The young jazz singer Brianna Thomas has been playing clubs and festivals off and on since 2006. She has also led her own band for several years, but if you haven’t come across her it could be because she’s done a fair amount of work in the specialized world of ’30s-style swing music. That world generates work, but it also obscures.

headline: Hitler’s Germany, Seen Through Young Eyes
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: In “Not I,” a memoir completed shortly before his death, the writer Joachim Fest discusses his influences and moral education in 1930s and ’40s Germany.
lead_paragraph: In 1936, Joachim Fest, 10 at the time, was summoned by his father, Johannes, to come with his older brother for a heart-to-heart talk in the study of their house in Berlin.

headline: President Obama Writes Apology to Art Historian
abstract: The president apologized for what he described as an “off-the-cuff” remark he made last month about the value of an art history degree.
lead_paragraph: President Obama raised hackles last month when, during a speech at a factory in Wisconsin, he said that people could make more money with skills in manufacturing or the trades “than they might with an art history degree.”

headline: Amid Blunders on Ice, a Few Signs of Grace
abstract: Forget about the perennial question: Is figure skating an art or a sport? The main concern is the disintegration of performance quality.
lead_paragraph: It’s a consolation to know you aren’t alone. A few days before the Sochi Olympics started, several figure skating luminaries gathered for a screening as part of the Dance on Camera festival at Lincoln Center. After viewing a clip of the transcendent British skater John Curry, Dorothy Hamill made an astute observation: “This was the first time I watched skating in a long time without swearing at the television set.” There’s nothing like the Olympics to incite foul language. It’s not just the flawed judging system, in which skaters who hope to win a medal must focus more energy on racking up points than on refining their artistic point of view, or even Scott Hamilton’s effusive screech.

headline: Hedge Fund Suit Seeks Identity of Anonymous Blogger
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The suit by David Einhorn’s Greenlight Capital hedge fund illustrates the tension between a money manager’s ability to safeguard his trading strategies and the rights of others to report on them.
lead_paragraph: David Einhorn has filed a lawsuit seeking to unmask the identity of an anonymous financial blogger who, he says, disclosed that Mr. Einhorn’s hedge fund was buying shares in a technology company. The legal maneuver illustrates the tension between a money manager’s ability to safeguard his trading strategies and the rights of others to report on them.

abstract: Maximo Caminero says he destroyed an Ai Weiwei vase on display at the Pérez Art Museum in Miami to protest its neglect of local artists.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Any new museum can expect teething problems.

headline: DC Home Buzz
