headline: White House Responds to Net Neutrality Petition
abstract: The Obama administration said the Federal Communications Commission is an independent agency and the president cannot order it to reclassify broadband service as a utility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials said Tuesday that the president continues to support a free and open Internet but that he cannot order the Federal Communications Commission to reclassify broadband service as a utility that is subject to the same rules and rate regulation as local telephone service.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Burberry’s Bloomsbury Chic
abstract: Soft, painterly makeup and effortless hair enhanced a collection inspired by the lore of literary London.
lead_paragraph: “Our girl is in touch with her artistic side this season,” the makeup artist Wendy Rowe said backstage at Burberry Prorsum. To complement Christopher Bailey’s collection, which was inspired by the romance of the early 20th-century circle of British writers and artists known as the Bloomsbury Group, Rowe mixed Burberry Fresh Glow Fluid in two colors — Nude Radiance and Golden Radiance — to achieve the relaxed, “slightly sun-kissed” aesthetic of a woman with greater things on her mind than makeup. Brows were groomed and lashes were left bare, while the aubergine-hued eye shadow — Rowe’s tribute to the group’s painters, such as Vanessa Bell and Roger Fry— tied in with the one-off painted pieces in the collection.

headline: Schumer Recuses Himself From Review of Comcast Deal
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Legal Profession', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, has recused himself from reviewing Comcast’s agreement to buy Time Warner Cable after the revelation that his brother, the lawyer Robert Schumer, worked on the merger.
lead_paragraph: Senator Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, has recused himself from reviewing Comcast’s agreement to buy Time Warner Cable after the revelation that his brother, the lawyer Robert Schumer, worked on the deal.

headline: Lending Where Banks Can’t, Blackstone Thrives in Ireland
abstract: Crippled by bad loans and regulatory restraints, European banks are ceding ground to firms like Blackstone and others that can lend money like a bank but are not scrutinized as such.
lead_paragraph: Bankers have been blanketing Ireland in search of cheap assets and lucrative deals, and few firms have been as aggressive as the Blackstone Group.

headline: F.B.I. Joins Ole Miss Inquiry After Noose Is Left on Statue
abstract: The F.B.I. and the University of Mississippi are looking for two men who left a noose and flag with a Confederate battle emblem on a statue of the university’s first black student.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, Miss. — The Federal Bureau of Investigation said Tuesday that it had joined the inquiry into an act of vandalism at the University of Mississippi, where a statue of the university’s first black student was found with a noose and a flag with the Confederate battle emblem.

headline: Former Aides to Christie Again Reject a Subpoena
abstract: Two former aides to the New Jersey governor have again refused to provide material sought by a legislative panel investigating the lane closings leading to the George Washington Bridge.
lead_paragraph: Setting up a likely court battle, two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey refused again on Tuesday to provide materials subpoenaed by the legislative panel investigating the politically charged lane closings leading to the George Washington Bridge last September.

headline: After Delays, Musharraf Appears Before Pakistani Court
abstract: Pervez Musharraf, the former military ruler of Pakistan, finally made an appearance before a special court that is deciding whether to try him for treason.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pervez Musharraf, the former military ruler of Pakistan, finally made an appearance on Tuesday before a special court that is deciding whether to try him for treason, after he failed to appear at a series of earlier proceedings.

abstract: Miller Fortune, at 6.9 percent alcohol by volume, is meant to appeal to a generation that buys distilled spirits more than its older siblings.
lead_paragraph: FORTUNE, they say, favors the bold. Will Fortune also favor a brewer?

abstract: Roger Clegg of the Center for Equal Opportunity writes that those who break the law should not automatically get back the right to help make the law.

headline: Godot Arrives in Sarajevo
abstract: Across Bosnia and Herzegovina, protesters are taking control of their future.
lead_paragraph: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — A BOY, his voice heavy with embarrassment and regret, was performing Samuel Beckett in Serbo-Croatian. “Mr. Godot,” he said, “told me to tell you that he won’t come this evening, but surely tomorrow.”

headline: Alison Jolly, Who Found Female Dominance in Lemurs, Dies at 76
abstract: Dr. Jolly, who did not receive as much attention as her contemporary Jane Goodall, found that male primates are not always dominant, upending a bedrock assertion in evolutionary biology.
lead_paragraph: Alison Jolly, an American-born primatologist whose research in the forests of Madagascar shed new light on the evolution of social intelligence and helped disprove a longstanding scientific tenet that males were dominant in every primate species, died on Feb. 6 in Lewes, East Sussex, England. She was 76.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Catsimatidis, 65, is the owner and chief executive of the Red Apple Group, a New York company with holdings in real estate, oil refining, retail petroleum products, convenience stores and the Red Apple and Gristedes supermarkets.

keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Officials hope that a new complex in north-central Philadelphia will reconnect the area to the central business district.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Plans for expansion of a Mormon complex along two blocks of north-central Philadelphia are providing city officials with a hope of reconnecting those sections to the city’s core business district of Center City.

headline: Ex-U.S. Lawmaker Charged With Pornography Possession in Zimbabwe
abstract: The arrest is the latest legal entanglement for former Representative Mel Reynolds of Illinois.
lead_paragraph: A former United States congressman from Illinois has been arrested in Zimbabwe and charged with possession of pornographic material, a local law enforcement spokeswoman said on Tuesday.

headline: South Sudan’s Forces Clash With Rebels Near U.N. Base
abstract: A battle in an oil-rich part of South Sudan was the most significant violation of the nearly month-old cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A fierce battle erupted between government and rebel forces in an oil-rich part of South Sudan on Tuesday, in the most significant violation of the cease-fire that was supposed to help bring peace to the fractured young nation.

headline: Profit Slides 8.5% for Coke, as Weak Sales Abroad Hit Hard
abstract: The company blamed cooling growth in emerging markets and the negative impact of foreign exchange rates, which it expects to have even greater impact this year.
lead_paragraph: Changing consumer tastes and concerns about the role of soda in the nation’s obesity crisis were among the problems cited by analysts as responsible for lower earnings and sales for Coca-Cola in the fourth quarter.

headline: Olympics Can Be a Coaching Wilderness
abstract: There are a lot of Winter Olympics sports where coaches can do little besides sit up and hope for the best. But biathlon may be the sport where coaches can make the most difference.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Coaches for Norway’s men’s biathlon team fanned out around the track for the 15-kilometer mass start race Tuesday afternoon with much of the equipment you would need for a really good bank heist. They had a truck, walkie-talkies, spotting scopes and 14 people, staked out along the course.

headline: In N.Y.U. Merger, One University and, for Now, Two Teams
abstract: Although the former Polytechnic University officially became the N.Y.U. Polytechnic School of Engineering, some of its sports teams were allowed to remain intact.
lead_paragraph: On a recent night in Brooklyn, the N.Y.U.-Poly volleyball team won an exciting point in the first game of a match against visiting Purchase College.

headline: Loan Program for Reactors Is Fizzling
abstract: At one point, $50 billion in federal loan guarantees were meant to cover nuclear projects, but a plant in Georgia may receive the only guarantees made.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz is set to announce on Wednesday that he will finish a $6.5 billion loan guarantee this week and another soon for $1.8 billion to help three Georgia electric companies build the first new nuclear reactors in the United States in three decades.

headline: Breakfast Before the MOOC
abstract: Arab youths, eager for the educational tools and resources to realize their full potential, are leading once again.
lead_paragraph: Beginning March 2, Prof. Hossam Haick, will teach the first ever massive open online course, or MOOC, on nanotechnology in Arabic. What’s more interesting, though, he explained to me the other day over breakfast is some of the curious email he’s received from students registering for his MOOC from all over the Arab world. Their questions include: Are you a real person? Are you really an Arab, or are you an Israeli Jew speaking Arabic, pretending to be an Arab? That’s because Haick is an Israeli Arab from Nazareth and will be teaching this course from his home university, the Technion, Israel’s premier science and technology institute, and the place we were having breakfast was Tel Aviv.

headline: An Ambiguous Omen, U.S. Household Debt Begins to Rise Again
abstract: American households saw the largest quarterly increase in debt since before the recession, but whether this signals increased optimism or continued overextension is open to interpretation.
lead_paragraph: American households took on $241 billion in additional debt in the fourth quarter of last year, signaling the end of an extended period of hunkering down. Total household debt increased 2.1 percent, the largest quarterly increase since before the recession, according to a new report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Candidate for Texas Governor Stands By Outspoken Musician
abstract: Attorney General Greg Abbott of Texas defended his decision to campaign with the pro-gun musician and conservative commentator Ted Nugent.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Attorney General Greg Abbott of Texas, the leading candidate for the Republican nomination for governor, on Tuesday defended his decision to campaign with the pro-gun musician and conservative commentator Ted Nugent a month after Mr. Nugent called President Obama a “communist-nurtured subhuman mongrel.”

headline: Germany’s Coal Addiction
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Coal', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Germany is in the midst of an unprecedented shift to renewable energy, but is still dependent on brown coal. The village of Atterwasch may become a victim of Germany’s hunger for brown coal.
lead_paragraph: Germany is in the midst of an unprecedented shift to renewable energy, but is still dependent on brown coal. The village of Atterwasch may become a victim of Germany’s hunger for brown coal.

headline: 54 Drawers
abstract: In my father’s old file cabinets, a life in paper: grade-school report cards, notes on a Belgian insane asylum, telexes about Mick Jagger.
lead_paragraph: This is the fourth part of an eight-part series.

headline: Violent Crimes Declined Across Country in First Six Months of 2013, F.B.I. Says
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: According to figures from the bureau, violent crimes, including murders, fell by 5.4 percent in the first six months of 2013 compared with the same period in 2012.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation said Tuesday that violent crimes, including murders, fell by 5.4 percent in the first six months of 2013 compared with the same period in 2012, continuing a long reduction in violent crime across the country.

headline: German Village Resists Plans to Strip It Away for the Coal Underneath
keywords: ['Coal', 'Mines and Mining', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: Even as Germany tries to wean itself from fossil fuels and nuclear power, its hunger for coal threatens the existence of villages like Atterwasch that lie atop coal deposits.
lead_paragraph: ATTERWASCH, Germany — A grove of apple saplings grows on the lee side of Ulrich Schulz’s barn. He did not plant them for the fruit, he said, but as an act of rebellion against a nearby mining company that wants to raze his farm, which his family has owned since 1560, to get at the coal beneath his land.

headline: Puerto Rico Wants to Incur More Debt to Regain Financial Footing
abstract: Puerto Rico wants to sell billions in bonds to raise money to pay its debts, but some are concerned that the American territory may be overstepping its ability to repay.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico still has the capacity to issue more than $3 billion in new debt, senior officials said Tuesday, adding that they hoped to tap the credit markets in March despite concern about whether the commonwealth can sustain its current large debt load.

headline: Outrage Over Wall St. Pay, but Shrugs for Silicon Valley?
abstract: Opposition to outsize pay packages should not be reserved just for executives on Wall Street, Steven M. Davidoff writes.
lead_paragraph: Big paydays on Wall Street often come under laserlike scrutiny, while Silicon Valley gets a pass on its own compensation excesses. Why the double standard?

headline: Difficult Turns in Footwork Sequence
abstract: Gold gets additional points by skimming across the ice while doing a series of turns, called a twizzle, which helps increase the difficulty level of her footwork sequence.
lead_paragraph: Gold gets additional points by skimming across the ice while doing a series of turns, called a twizzle, which helps increase the difficulty level of her footwork sequence.

lead_paragraph: Gold enters a high-scoring combination spin with a challenging entry, known as a back entrance, then holds her camel position for two revolutions.

headline: A Quick Turn Before a Jump
abstract: Height and distance matter in jumps. But a quick turn, called a bracket, before the takeoff of Gold's double axel, can add almost 10 percent to the jump's value.
lead_paragraph: Height and distance matter in jumps. But a quick turn, called a bracket, before the takeoff of Gold's double axel, can add almost 10 percent to the jump's value.

headline: In Figure Skating, the Second Team Shines
abstract: NBC’s sports cable network is covering every figure skater, every pair and every dance team. And the commentators Tara Lipinski and Johnny Weir are making the comprehensive programming a success.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Winter Olympics have added ultra-acrobatic sports familiar mainly to X Games fans, figure skating has remained a bedrock event for the network that carries the Winter Olympics.

headline: Loan Complaints by Homeowners Rise Once More
abstract: Shoddy paperwork, erroneous fees and wrongful evictions — abuses that previously dogged the nation’s largest banks — are now cropping up among mortgage servicers that collect payments.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of homeowners trying to avert foreclosure are confronting problems on a new front as the mortgage industry undergoes a seismic shift.

headline: Venezuelan Protest Leader Jabs at Government on the Streets and Online
abstract: Leopoldo López, the political face of ongoing demonstrations against the government, came out of hiding, as he had promised, to face charges of terrorism.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Wednesday, 9:12 a.m. | As my colleague William Neuman reports, the Venezuelan opposition leader Leopoldo López came out of hiding on Tuesday, as promised, and surrendered to the authorities to face charges of terrorism. Mr. López, a Harvard-educated former mayor of a wealthy section of Caracas, is the political face of ongoing demonstrations against President Nicolás Maduro’s government.

headline: ‘Rhapsody in Blue’ or Rap? Skating Will Add Vocals
abstract: Beginning next season, new rules will allow men, women and pairs skaters to use music with lyrics in their programs. But some wonder whether the innovation will harm the sport’s credibility.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The music you hear during the figure skating competition this week is the sound of an era ending.

headline: Obama’s Vote-Getting Tactics Struggle to Find the Uninsured
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare']
abstract: Canvassers deployed by groups supporting the Affordable Care Act are searching door to door for people who lack health coverage, with little success.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — The hunt for the uninsured in Broward County got underway one recent afternoon when 41 canvassers, armed with electronic maps on Samsung tablets, set off through working-class neighborhoods to peddle the Affordable Care Act door to door. Four hours later, they had made contact with 2,623 residents and signed up exactly 25 people.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Bold Step on Prison Education
abstract: One solution against the stubbornly high rate of recidivism has long proved to be both reliable and cost-effective: education behind bars.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest obstacles to reducing America’s enormous prison population is the stubbornly high rates of recidivism. Nationwide, as many as half of those released end up back in prison within three years.

headline: Venezuelan Opposition Chief Surrenders, but Not Without a Rally
abstract: Before giving himself up, Leopoldo López, accused of inciting violence during recent antigovernment protests, addressed the largest rally in over two weeks of growing demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — A prominent Venezuelan opposition leader surrendered to the authorities on Tuesday in the midst of a large crowd of supporters who tried to block his arrest on accusations that he was responsible for violence that erupted during recent antigovernment protests.

headline: What Next for Syria?
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: As peace talks collapse and the carnage of the civil war continues, President Obama needs to persist on searching for a peaceful solution.
lead_paragraph: With the apparent collapse of the United Nations-mediated peace talks on Syria, the United States and its allies find themselves in a difficult spot. Absent a diplomatic and political option, what can the world do about a civil war that has killed an estimated 136,000 people, produced nine million refugees, displaced 4.25 million civilians internally and now threatens to destabilize several other countries in the region?

headline: ‘Too Perfect’ Job Offer Lures a Parks Expert Back to Work
abstract: Tupper Thomas, former chief of the Prospect Park Alliance, is coming out of retirement to lead New Yorkers for Parks.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers for Parks, the city’s leading parks advocacy group, has named Tupper Thomas, former leader of the Prospect Park Alliance and a nationally known parks expert, to be its new executive director.

headline: Gracie Gold's Extras
abstract: Extras -- small maneuvers before, during or after a major move -- could give U.S. champion Gracie Gold a needed boost for the Olympic podium.
lead_paragraph: Extras -- small maneuvers before, during or after a major move -- could give U.S. champion Gracie Gold a needed boost for the Olympic podium.

headline: Change the Rules on Secret Money
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'Political Advertising', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Political Action Committees', 'Editorials']
abstract: The I.R.S. should ignore protests on the right and left and crack down on abuse of the tax code.
lead_paragraph: In November, when the Internal Revenue Service finally stirred itself to propose a modest crackdown on the abuse of the tax code by political groups, it was immediately attacked by tax-exempt nonprofit groups on the right. That wasn’t too surprising; secret donations from conservatives to these groups are the principal reason American politics is now dominated by those with huge bank accounts.

headline: History: Get Me Rewrite!
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Vietnam War', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Some mistakes in American history cannot be painted over.
lead_paragraph: I found myself sitting on a bar stool last winter next to Robert Caro at an Irish wake in Times Square for my irreplaceable Times colleague Frank Prial.

headline: Mariners and Cano Focus on Winning Now
abstract: Seattle, which has had four losing seasons in a row, is counting on Robinson Cano to revive a sagging brand.
lead_paragraph: PEORIA, Ariz. — The Seattle Mariners rebuilt their spring training complex this year, and now, they hope, they have reshaped their identity. The man with three lockers — one with his name above it, between two empty stalls in the far left corner of the clubhouse — is the cornerstone, charged with reviving a sagging brand.

headline: Chief of New Jersey Transit to Quit After a Rocky Tenure
abstract: James Weinstein’s four-year run was pocked by the agency’s poor performance during Hurricane Sandy and the recent Super Bowl in East Rutherford, N.J.
lead_paragraph: The executive director of New Jersey Transit is resigning, bringing an end to a four-year run pocked by the agency’s often-maligned performance during Hurricane Sandy and the recent Super Bowl in East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Satellite Images of the Protests in Kiev
abstract: A satellite image showing the site of the protests in Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A satellite image showing the site of the protests in Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine.

headline: Doctors Train to Spot Signs of A.D.H.D. in Children
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Doctors', 'ADDERALL (DRUG)']
abstract: Some psychiatrists are teaching pediatricians how to evaulate children’s mental health issues like attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, which some doctors diagnose despite having little training.
lead_paragraph: Jerry, 9 years old, dissolved into his Game Boy while his father described his attentional difficulties to the family pediatrician. The child began flitting around the room distractedly, ignoring the doctor’s questions and squirming in his chair — but then he leapt up and yelled: “Freeze! What do you think is the problem here?”

headline: Politics to Shadow Obama’s Trade Talks in Mexico
abstract: President Obama will make a brief trip to Mexico to forge closer trade ties with Mexico and Canada, as his party’s leaders in Congress vow to undercut his efforts.
lead_paragraph: TOLUCA, Mexico — President Obama traveled to Mexico on Wednesday for a brief but politically fraught visit aimed at forging closer trade ties with America’s two closest neighbors even as his party’s leaders back home have vowed to undercut his efforts.

headline: Sentencing and the 'Affluenza' Factor
abstract: To what extent should life circumstances affect sentencing in criminal cases?

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 19, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, February 19, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “We will come out of Maidan either free or slaves. But we don’t want to be slaves.”

headline: Northwestern Quarterback Makes His Case for Players’ Union
abstract: The quarterback Kain Colter offered more than four hours of testimony before the National Labor Relations Board, insisting he was on campus to play football.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Kain Colter, a football recruit, arrived at Northwestern University with dreams of becoming an orthopedic surgeon. But the summer before his freshman year, he said, he was steered away from a chemistry class toward less strenuous options like sociology and African history. He is now pursuing a psychology degree instead of the premed track.

headline: Motivational Words
abstract: Michael Dewey orders us around.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Atten-shun! Eyes right here, soldiers, we’ve got us a puzzle to discuss.

headline: Educating Doctors About A.D.H.D. Without Resorting to ‘Ritalin Wars’
abstract: Experts concerned about the over-diagnosis of A.D.H.D. too often attack parents in their zeal for change.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, amid what felt like a rising tide of criticism of parents of children who were being medicated for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (A.D.H.D.), readers in this space complained, and I joined them. It’s offensive, we said, to accuse parents (and teachers, and doctors) of using drug treatment to get “off the hook” for more complex problems, or teaching children to “reach for a pill” instead of finding another way to cope with a problem. It’s also useless. If A.D.H.D. is being over-diagnosed or overmedicated, pointing fingers won’t help either children who do need treatment or those who need something else.

headline: City’s Safety Net on Trial Over a Baby Killed in ’07
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A civil trial began in Brooklyn on Tuesday to determine whether the city can be held liable for Hailey Gonzalez’s violent death at the hands of her mother’s boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: By all accounts, Hailey Gonzalez’s life was short, impoverished and brutal. She was born in November 2005 to unwed parents living in a homeless shelter. Her mother, Marlene Medina, a foster child herself, had already lost custody of another daughter, Elizabeth, because a judge had determined that she was not fit to care for her.

headline: Former Marine in Tehran Jail Retains a Top Iranian Lawyer
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Amir Hekmati, held on spying charges, has retained a lawyer with influential political ties who has lobbied successfully for another foreigner who was detained in Iran.
lead_paragraph: Amir Hekmati, a former Marine incarcerated in Iran on spying charges, has retained a prominent Iranian lawyer to represent him in a new effort to gain his release after nearly two and a half years in Tehran’s Evin Prison, Mr. Hekmati’s family reported on Tuesday.

headline: Militant Group Says It Attacked Tourist Bus in Sinai
abstract: The assertion by Ansar Beit al-Maqdis signaled an ominous turn in a battle militants have waged against the government since the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian militant group that has carried out months of deadly assaults on the police and the military has claimed responsibility for the bombing of a tourist bus that killed four people in the Sinai Peninsula on Sunday.

headline: In Ryan, Yankees Have Understudy Who Knows His Role
abstract: Brendan Ryan, one of the best defensive shortstops in the game, realizes he will be used when Derek Jeter needs a day off or is used as the designated hitter.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Just before he left Los Angeles for Tampa a few days ago, Brendan Ryan, the Yankees’ backup shortstop, made sure to go to Staples Center to watch his favorite team, the Los Angeles Clippers. He felt the need to go, he said, because the three previous times he had seen the Clippers this season, their star point guard, Chris Paul, did not play because of injury.

headline: From Plains to CUNY, New Chief Is ‘Coming Home’
abstract: The president of the University of Nebraska, James B. Milliken, strikes many as having a talent for making people feel listened to.
lead_paragraph: The University of Nebraska is a moderately sized institution with a Big Ten athletic program, 50,000 students spread over four campuses, and winds sweeping over the plains lately dwindling into the low double digits — below zero.

headline: Joba Chamberlain’s Motto: No More Weirdness
abstract: After signing a one-year, $2.5 million deal with the Tigers, Chamberlain is trying to leave behind the strange saga of his seven seasons as a Yankee.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — There are no Joba Rules here at the Detroit Tigers’ spring training base, other than those he has set for himself.

headline: Snowboarders and Skiers Fly in Face of Logo Rules
abstract: The International Olympic Committee fiercely protected the Games from logos not linked to its official sponsors, but loopholes remained and companies that make snowboards and skis took full advantage.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The Olympic Games work extremely hard to disguise their vast corporate ties. Fans at the venues and viewers at home will not see any business logos in the background, except the ubiquitous Olympic rings and Sochi 2014 emblem. Compared with Nascar cars, international soccer uniforms or outfield fences, the illusion of the Olympics is one of noncommercial purity.

headline: Bob Casale, Guitarist in Devo, Dies at 61
abstract: Mr. Casale was a guitarist who was an original member of the influential rock band Devo.
lead_paragraph: Bob Casale, a guitarist who was an original member of the influential rock band Devo, died on Monday. He was 61.

headline: Afghan Ethnic Tensions Rise in Media and Politics
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Hazaras (Ethnic Group)', 'Uzbeks (Ethnic Group)', 'Pashtun (Ethnic Group)', 'Tajiks (Ethnic Group)', 'Politics and Government', 'News and News Media']
abstract: In Afghanistan, a growing uproar over ethnicity — Pashtun, Tajik, Hazara and Uzbek — has many concerned about possible violence, especially those who remember the country’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — It started with a heat-of-the-moment comment on a partisan television talk show, drawing an ethnic line that was bold even by Afghan standards.

headline: Citing ‘Inequality Crisis,’ Mayor Names Top Legal Adviser and Fills 2 Other Jobs
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio appointed Maya Wiley as legal adviser on Tuesday and appointed the leaders of the Department of Aging and the Department of Environmental Protection.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio named Maya Wiley, a longtime advocate for racial and social justice, as his chief legal adviser Tuesday, giving her a forceful role in addressing what he called an “inequality crisis.”

lead_paragraph: In New Event, the American David Wise Wins Gold

headline: Rob Reiner to Receive Film Society Honor
abstract: The director and actor will be given the annual Chaplin Award, named for the filmmaing comedian.
lead_paragraph: The director and actor Rob Reiner will receive the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s annual Chaplin Award at a gala in April, the organization announced Tuesday.

headline: Artists Named for Hammer Museum’s Los Angeles Biennial
abstract: The museum has finalized the list of 35 artists whose work will be included in the 2014 “Made in L.A.” biennial, which opens June 15.
lead_paragraph: The Hammer Museum in Los Angeles has finalized its choice of 35 artists for the second edition of “Made in L.A.,” the West Coast answer to the Whitney Biennial. While the Whitney features artists from across the country, the Hammer focuses on new or under-recognized artists working in Los Angeles.

headline: As Knicks Lose Ground, It’s Back to the Grind for Anthony
abstract: After trailing by as many as 18 points in the first half, the Knicks relied on their defense to go ahead by as many as 7 late in the fourth quarter before falling in Memphis.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — As the ball left Mike Miller’s fingertips, Carmelo Anthony could only hope for something unscripted. Perhaps Miller would forget to follow through, Anthony said. Of course, he knew it was unlikely. After everything that had happened against the Grizzlies on Tuesday night — the early deficit, the late comeback — Anthony and the Knicks could only watch.

headline: Nets, as Rested as Can Be, Steel Themselves for Second Half
abstract: The Nets, coming off a four-day All-Star break, face a six-game, 11-day trip that will include the distraction of Thursday’s trade deadline.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — After the four-day All-Star break, the Nets reconvened for a nighttime practice at Jon M. Huntsman Center at the University of Utah. They joked that their time off was too brief. They were serious about the task at hand.

headline: Inquiry Into Queens School Calls for Firing of Principal
abstract: A report by the special commissioner of investigation for the school district recommended that Marcella Sills, the principal at Public School 106, be banned from working for the Education Department.
lead_paragraph: Officials took steps toward firing a Queens elementary school principal after a report on Tuesday found that she regularly arrived late to work and called a custodian to help her enter the building through a side door.

headline: James Cahill, Influential Authority on Chinese Art, Dies at 87
abstract: Professor Cahill, a scholar of Chinese painting, interpreted China’s great masters to the West.
lead_paragraph: James Cahill, one of the foremost authorities on Chinese art, whose interpretations of Chinese painting for the West influenced generations of scholars, died on Friday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 87.

abstract: Ted Ligety of the United States, still without a medal in these Games, competes in his best event, the giant slalom.

headline: Warner in Deal to Sign Acts Found on Shazam
abstract: The agreement will create a label imprint for new artists who are discovered through Shazam, and allow Warner to use Shazam’s data to see what songs are catching on and where.
lead_paragraph: In the good old days of digital music — say, five or six years ago — high-tech talent scouting by record labels meant trawling MySpace for hot new bands. Labels still hunt for acts online, but the pools of data they consult have become much more vast, and access to them highly competitive.

headline: The Employer Mandate: Dukakis All Over Again
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The delays in carrying out various aspects of the Affordable Care Act are eerily similar to those of a Massachusetts health care law passed in 1988 at the urging of Gov. Michael Dukakis, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: The Genetics of Being a Daredevil
abstract: A recent study that looked at skiers and snowboarders intimates that risky behavior may be motivated, at least in part, by DNA.
lead_paragraph: Watching participants in slopestyle and half-pipe skiing and snowboarding flip, curl, cartwheel and otherwise contort themselves in the air during the Winter Olympics competition, many of us have probably wondered not only how the athletes managed to perform such feats but also why. Helpfully, a recent study of the genetics of risk-taking intimates that their behavior may be motivated, at least in part, by their DNA.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: Noon (IFC) THE LIFE AQUATIC WITH STEVE ZISSOU (2004) Bill Murray, above center, is Steve Zissou, a flashy oceanographer far past his prime, who, after the death of his friend (Seymour Cassel), is confronted by his own sense of mortality, the sudden appearance of an airplane pilot (Owen Wilson) who may or may not be his son, an investigative reporter (Cate Blanchett) and a bond company stooge (Bud Cort) in this comedy from Wes Anderson, who wrote the screenplay with Noah Baumbach. “In my ideal cinémathèque, ‘The Life Aquatic’ would play on a permanent double bill with ‘The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie,’ ” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Anderson and Stephen Hillenburg, Mr. SquarePants’s creator, share not only a taste for nautical nonsense, but also a willingness to carry the banner of unfettered imaginative silliness into battle against the tyranny of maturity.”

headline: A Chilling Phone Call Adds to Hurdles of Publishing Xi Jinping Book
abstract: Plans to publish a book depicting China’s president, Xi Jinping, as a thuggish politician have encountered worrisome hurdles in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: The exiled writer Yu Jie takes a bleak view of President Xi Jinping of China. In his latest book, still awaiting publication, Mr. Yu describes Mr. Xi as a thuggish politician driven by a dangerous compound of Maoist nostalgia and authoritarian, expansionist impulses.

headline: Ukraine Leader Strains for Grip as Chaos Spreads
abstract: Opposition leaders confirmed overnight that a truce had been reached with the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovych, but it was uncertain that any pause in the conflict would hold.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine spiraled deeper into disarray on Wednesday as the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovych and several thousand grimly determined protesters, along with their supporters in Russia and Europe, faced off in a confrontation over the fate of this fractured country of 46 million.

headline: North Korea Arrests Christian Missionary From Australia
abstract: The arrest of John Short, 75, comes as North Korea continues to face pressure to release Kenneth Bae, an American missionary it has held for more than a year.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — North Korea has arrested a Christian missionary from Australia, his family said on Wednesday, taking him into captivity even as it continues to face pressure to release an American missionary it has held for more than a year.

headline: Ted Ligety Extends Reign With Giant Slalom Win
abstract: Ligety on Wednesday became the first American man to win the Olympic giant slalom and the first to win two Olympic Alpine gold medals over all.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Shut out at the 2010 Vancouver Olympics, Ted Ligety arrived at the Sochi Games as a medal contender in three events.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 19, 2014
abstract: Can you calculate the percentage increase in Super Bowl viewers since the 1970s?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: China’s Quick Slide to Curling Success
abstract: A Winter Olympics event that has a mere 15-year history in China is evidence of the country’s ability to devote significant resources to niche sports.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:04 p.m. | China’s rise as an Olympic powerhouse is full of stories of athletes becoming champions in sports their parents could not have imagined playing. But perhaps the most rapid journey to the top has been in curling, a sport that has a mere 15-year history in China.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Tunisian B-Boys’ Biggest Battle: Keeping Youths From Extremism
abstract: Why, in this small town, and across much of Tunisian society, is there is an important battle going on for the minds of young people?
lead_paragraph: In “Tunisian B-Boys’ Biggest Battle: Keeping Youths From Extremism,” Carlotta Gall writes about young men in Tunisia who see themselves as artists through free performances of dance, graffiti and theater.

headline: What Crazy Adventure Would You Want to Take?
abstract: Where would you go? How would you travel? Would you go alone or with friends?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever wanted to take a break from your everyday life and do something out of the ordinary? Maybe kayak around Lake Superior or go hang gliding in the Outer Banks? Or, would you rather take a road trip across the country with friends, or hitchhike through Vietnam?

headline: Rejecting Stereotypes, Photographing ‘Real’ Indians
abstract: A young photographer grappling with her own Native American identity wants to make an extensive and accurate depiction of America’s tribal people, and challenge what defines a “real” Indian.
lead_paragraph: It started with a dream. Matika Wilbur’s great-grandmother, who had died years before, was urging her to return home.

headline: Pity Brazil’s Military Police
abstract: The country needs a legitimate police force where officers deal with civilians not as their enemies but as fellow citizens.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — In Brazil, police officers kill an average of five people every day. In 2012, according to a security report from the Brazilian Forum on Public Security, 1,890 Brazilians were killed by the police, 351 here in São Paulo. That was around 20 percent of all homicides in the city. At the same time, 11 police officers were killed on duty here and around 100 were executed off-duty, allegedly by organized crime. Police officers are three times more likely to be murdered than the average Brazilian.

headline: State Media Outlets Call Xi Jinping Cartoon a First
abstract: The infographic portrays President Xi Jinping as diligent and hard-working, depicting how he is kept busy even during public holidays.
lead_paragraph: Outfitted in a simple, gray zip-up jacket and blue trousers, round belly in plain sight, President Xi Jinping of China made his cartoon debut in the state media on Wednesday.

headline: Daily Report: The Quest for Higher Wireless Speeds, Even in Crowds
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: A new technology called pCell is one of many techniques that companies are looking at to address the rising public appetite for mobile data, especially video.
lead_paragraph: A recent demonstration in San Francisco showed off a technology that Steve Perlman, a serial entrepreneur and inventor who sold WebTV to Microsoft for more than $500 million in the late 1990s, contends will give mobile users far faster cellular network speeds, with fewer dropped phone calls and other annoyances, even in stadiums and other places where thousands of people use mobile phones at the same time, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: After Two Centuries, Peugeot Family Cedes Control
abstract: As part of a 3 billion euro plan to raise new capital, the family will reduce its holding to 14 percent from just over 25 percent.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The family business that grew into PSA Peugeot Citroën got its start more than 200 years ago, making manufactured goods like pepper mills, bicycles and whale-bone corsets on its way to becoming the largest automaker in France. This week the Peugeot family, one of the country’s wealthiest, agreed to give up control of the company it had been running for eight generations.

headline: Learning to Cut the Sugar
abstract: Many know Dr. Robert Lustig as “the anti-sugar guy,” but he’d prefer being known as the “anti-processed food guy.” His latest book, “The Fat Chance Cookbook,” offers recipes for more healthful eating.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert Lustig became widely known as “the anti-sugar guy” after a lecture of his called “Sugar: The Bitter Truth” was posted on YouTube and gained widespread attention. In his talk, Dr. Lustig explains why all calories are not created equal, and why he believes those from sugar in particular are driving an epidemic of obesity and chronic disease.

headline: Things End Badly for a Poet, but Quite Well for the Tenor
abstract: The tenor Jonas Kaufmann stars in Richard Eyre’s production of “Werther,” Massenet’s 19th-century opera, at the Met.
lead_paragraph: Last February, the German tenor Jonas Kaufmann had a triumph at the Metropolitan Opera when he performed the title role of Wagner’s “Parsifal” in the company’s very bleak but theatrically riveting new production. On Tuesday night, a year later, Mr. Kaufmann was back at the Met in the title role of Massenet’s “Werther” on the opening night of Richard Eyre’s new production. It was another success for Mr. Kaufmann, currently the most in-demand, versatile and exciting tenor in opera.

headline: Andhra Pradesh’s Chief Minister Resigns to Protest Creation of Telangana State
abstract: The coastal and southern regions of the state were shut down as political leaders denounced the lower house of Parliament for allowing the division of Andhra Pradesh.
lead_paragraph: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh — The coastal and southern regions of this southern state were shut down Wednesday as political leaders called for a strike and denounced the lower house of Parliament’s approval of the new state of Telangana, which will be created out of the northern areas of Andhra Pradesh.

keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: The explosions were the latest in a series of bomb attacks on civilians in the city, and an offshoot of Al Qaeda claimed responsibility.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two powerful explosions struck a busy area in southern Beirut near an Iranian cultural center on Wednesday, killing at least five people and wounding dozens in the latest in a series of bomb attacks on civilians here as violence continued to spill over from the war in neighboring Syria.

headline: Loaves, Fishes, Hot Dogs, and Buns
abstract: Misunderstanding why technology can cause problems.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Yglesias tries to explain why productivity growth has nothing to do with deflation using a parable of loaves and fishes. I did something kind of similar long ago, arguing against a naive view of technological unemployment in terms of hot dogs and buns.

headline: As Far as Possible From His Sitcom
abstract: Neil Patrick Harris has a hectic schedule around Manhattan as he prepares for the lead role in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Sporting a Marc Jacobs tuxedo and fashionably mussed hair, Neil Patrick Harris sweeps into the Pierre Hotel looking super-duper, as he likes to say, but craving his usual pick-me-up, a sugar-free Red Bull. It’s 7 p.m. on a Monday, and he has just finished his first rehearsal for the Broadway rock musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” testing his vocal range against the show’s thrashing score. Ahead are hours of schmoozing as the 2014 honoree of the Drama League, an organization that usually celebrates Tony Award-winning stars.

headline: LinkedIn Wants to Be Your Soapbox, Not Just Your Résumé
abstract: The business-oriented service introduced a new tool to encourage its 277 million users to share their professional insights in essays posted to their profiles.
lead_paragraph: LinkedIn has established itself as the digital résumé service for the white-collar world, with 277 million users globally. On Wednesday, it will announce features that will help users enhance their profiles with essays, work samples or industry manifestos to stand out from the crowd.

headline: Doubts About Candy Crush’s Sweetness
abstract: Candy Crush’s meteoric rise has raised fears of a bubble following the I.P.O. filing of its parent, King Digital Entertainment. | Few firms have been as aggressive as the Blackstone Group in searching for lucrative deals in Ireland. | Homeowners trying to avert foreclosure are confronting problems on a new front. | It may be time to call a truce on the Wall Street bias in looking at executive compensation.
lead_paragraph: SUGAR RUSH FOR CANDY CRUSH  |  King Digital Entertainment’s filing of a $500 million initial public offering on Tuesday had many investors salivating. But it remains to be seen whether the company behind the addictive game Candy Crush can sustain its sweetness and avoid the pitfalls of other game makers, Jenna Wortham and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. Indeed, Candy Crush attracts 93 million players each day and accounts for nearly 80 percent of the company’s revenue, which neared $1.9 billion by the end of 2013 from $164 million in 2012.

headline: Amid Efforts to Expand Marine Preserves, a Warning to Focus on Quality
abstract: New studies find that some conservation areas have no more fish than unprotected areas and that reserves tend to be set up in areas with low biodiversity.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A generation ago, when Tommy Remengesau Jr. went fishing off the beautiful island nation of Palau, the seas were so rich, he said, that “I could see great stocks of fish.” Such bounty has since dwindled, in Palau and worldwide.

headline: U.S. Imposes Visa Ban on 20 Ukrainian Officials as Further Sanctions Are Threatened
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Visas', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Relations']
abstract: The United States and the European Union scrambled for a quick response to the violence in Ukraine, with European officials planning to meet in emergency session to consider penalties.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Expressing alarm at the lethal escalation of political violence in Ukraine, the European Union and the United States scrambled for a quick response Wednesday, threatening punitive sanctions against senior figures in the Ukrainian government. The Obama administration later said it had placed 20 top Ukrainian officials on a visa blacklist.

headline: This Kind of ‘Picky Eater’ Is Made, Not Born

headline: Why Candy Crush I.P.O. Could be a Dangerous Game
abstract: King Digital, the fast-growing maker of Candy Crush Saga, could be worth nearly $6 billion given the valuations of rivals. But there are considerable risks for investors, writes Dominic Elliott of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Candy Crush is destined to be a heart breaker. The addictive mobile app’s Europe-based maker, King Digital Entertainment, is ready to capitalize on the hype with an initial public offering in the United States. With its top hit Candy Crush Saga generating about 80 percent of revenue, though, investor infatuation would be a dangerous game.

headline: Truth Is Beauty, and Beauty Can Be Subversive
abstract: Ragnar Kjartansson brings his work “Der Klang der Offenbarung des Göttlichen,” or “The Explosive Sonics of Divinity,” to the Volksbühne theater in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For decades,  the Volksbühne theater, in the former East Berlin, has been at the heart of political theater in Europe. Its bold productions, often involving nudity, women in men’s roles and anticapitalist rhetoric, have helped shape the avant-garde.

headline: Letting Lehman Fail
abstract: Who thought it was a good idea?
lead_paragraph: One of the really good things about teaching a new course is that the work you put into developing your lectures often leads you to stuff you didn’t know about, missed, or had forgotten. Today’s class was a sort of narrative walkthrough of the financial crisis, and in the course of preparing I found myself trying to recall who actually thought letting Lehman fail was a good idea.

headline: Two Burches Branch Out with a Chic New Brand
abstract: Trademark, Pookie and Louisa Burch’s new women’s wear line, is a fun, fresh mash-up of different periods, styles and inspirations.
lead_paragraph: Like the mountainous collection of trinkets scattered throughout Pookie Burch’s East Village apartment, Trademark, the new women’s wear line she started with her younger sister Louisa, is tempting to close-read. The collection’s influences — Donald Judd, Maine in the 1960s — are apparent but ineffable, abstracted to an obscure likability. The clothes are the product of two self-taught designers who embrace eclecticism without veering into quirk — and whose father just so happens to be the billionaire venture capitalist J. Christopher Burch.

headline: Ligety Wins Gold in Giant Slalom
abstract: Ted Ligety, whose distinctive, hips-on-the-snow turns have redefined giant slalom, won the gold medal with a first run that put him well ahead of the field.
lead_paragraph: Ted Ligety, whose distinctive, hips-on-the-snow turns have redefined giant slalom, won the gold medal with a first run that put him well ahead of the field.

lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Man Pleads Guilty to Reduced Charge in Terrorism Case
abstract: Jose Pimentel, who was accused of planning pipe bombings, pleaded guilty to a single count of attempted possession of a weapon as a crime of terrorism.
lead_paragraph: Five days before his trial was to start, a Manhattan man accused of planning to wage a personal jihad against the United States with pipe bombs pleaded guilty on Wednesday to reduced charges in a deal with prosecutors.

headline: Court in Thailand Limits Crackdown on Protesters
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The Bangkok court barred the authorities from dispersing protesters one day after violent clashes left five people dead.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Describing the movement to overthrow the Thai government as peaceful, a Bangkok civil court on Wednesday sharply curtailed the powers of the authorities and barred them from dispersing protesters, a decision that a prominent legal analyst described as “one step closer to a full-scale judicial coup.”

headline: Clashes Continue in Ukraine
abstract: Antigovernment protests in Kiev continued overnight and into the early hours of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Antigovernment protests in Kiev continued overnight and into the early hours of Wednesday.

headline: In West Asheville, N.C., Bistros Mix With Tattoo Parlors
abstract: As people move to this part of the city to escape downtown’s escalating rents and tourism, the area has become a blue-collar hybrid.
lead_paragraph: Gritty is still an operative description for West Asheville, N.C., a section of this city where pawn shops, tattoo parlors and auto repair shops have reigned. But as Ashevillians move to this side of the French Broad River to escape downtown’s escalating rents and tourism, the area has become a blue-collar hybrid with yoga studios and bistros joining longtime establishments along the main drag, Haywood Road. West Asheville has been called the “Worst Asheville,” said Jodi Rhoden, who owns a bakery, Short Street Cakes. “So there’s a sense of embattled pride and a determination to make it work.”

headline: Home-Front Heroines
abstract: Cokie Roberts has distilled her book “Founding Mothers” into a picture book intended for children from 7 to 12, illustrated by Diane Goode.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Cokie Roberts, the political commentator and contributor to National Public Radio’s “Morning Edition,” published “Founding Mothers: The Women Who Raised Our Nation.” Now she has distilled that much longer work about women’s roles at the time of the American Revolution to create “Founding Mothers: Remembering the Ladies,” a picture book intended for children from 7 to 12, engagingly illustrated by Diane Goode.

headline: An Awards Night Suited for Royalty
abstract: The presence of Prince William helps the Bafta ceremony in London break out of the season’s familiar pattern.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the minutes ticked down to the start of the Bafta Awards on Sunday night, Uma Thurman, magisterially dressed in a floor-length, strapless navy blue Atelier Versace gown, had a pressing question for one of the show’s organizers: What should we do when Prince William arrives?

headline: After an Apology Comes the Rebuilding of Trust
abstract: As the apology of the chief executive of AOL demonstrates, the issue of trust is at the core of corporate culture and the critical ingredient to long-term sustainability, Dov Seidman writes in an Apology Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:03 p.m. |

headline: London Fashion Week: Meadham Kirchhoff Fall/Winter 2014

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

abstract: Prince Williams and Stars at the Bafta awards, the British version of the Oscars.
lead_paragraph: Prince Williams and Stars at the Bafta awards, the British version of the Oscars.

headline: F.C.C. Seeks a New Path on ‘Net Neutrality’ Rules
abstract: After a court ruling last month, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission will propose new rules to encourage equal access to the web.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Regulators are taking another crack at their effort to keep the web free and open, introducing new rules that would discourage Internet service providers from charging companies to stream their movies, music and other content through a faster express lane.

headline: Below the Line: Editing ‘Captain Phillips’
abstract: The editor Christopher Rouse discusses his work on the drama “Captain Phillips.”
lead_paragraph: The film editor Christopher Rouse has built an intimate collaborative relationship with the director Paul Greengrass over the past decade. Their partnership began with  “The Bourne Supremacy” in 2004, and he won an Oscar in 2008 for his editing of “The Bourne Ultimatum.” He’s up for another Oscar for his  work on “Captain Phillips,” based on the  hijacking of an American container ship by Somali pirates. Whether Mr. Rouse is editing fiction features or ones based on true events (“United 93”), he is driven by the characters’ motivations.

headline: The Audi S3 Cabriolet is Sporty, but Is Not Headed for U.S.
abstract: Audi released details about its diminutive 300-horsepower convertible on Wednesday, but did not say anything about selling it in North America.
lead_paragraph: Audi released details Wednesday about its S3 Cabriolet, which will be equipped with a 300-horsepower turbocharged 2-liter 4 cylinder engine. The car is expected to hit dealerships during the summer.

headline: When Work Disappears
abstract: The depressing center-left vision for a post-work future.
lead_paragraph: At the risk of exhausting my readers, I wanted to return yet again to the debate over workforce participation, because a couple of recent pieces that aren’t directly about the recent Obamacare argument have been helpful in clarifying the deeper issues in play. The first one is from Martin Wolf of the Financial Times, a sensible man of the center-left, making recommendations for how the developed world might adapt to automation, computerization and the disappearance of low-wage, low-skilled work:

headline: Repeated Good Fortune in Timing of C.E.O.’s Stock Sale
abstract: Good things keep happening to Questcor in the middle of the month, which coincides with the stock selling plan of its chief executive, Jesse Eisinger writes in The Trade column.
lead_paragraph: This is the story of a company and its fortunate chief executive.

headline: Classical Playlist: Jenny Lin, Joshua Rubin, David Aladashvili and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: STRAVINSKY: Solo Piano WorksJenny Lin, pianist(Steinway & Sons)Stravinsky may not have written that many works for solo piano. But he left pianists some astonishing scores, especially the Piano Sonata and the Serenade in A, along with many smart shorter works and charming miniatures. The excellent and inquisitive American pianist Jenny Lin, born in Taiwan in 1973, plays just about the complete Stravinsky solo piano music on this impressive release, from Steinway & Sons, which some years ago started a recording label. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Immigrants Welcome Here
abstract: With foreign-born populations in many midsize American cities growing, some communities are taking creative steps to ease the attendant tensions.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, John Boehner declared that it was unlikely that the House of Representatives would pass major immigration reform legislation this year. Given the desperate need for an overhaul of the system, the political gridlock is dismaying. But thankfully it’s not the whole immigration story.

headline: A Content Company Weighs Becoming a Technology Company
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A start-up looks for a way to get stalled revenue growth moving again.
lead_paragraph: TPR MEDIA creates and distributes medical-related messages and information to patients. Co-founded by Betsy Weaver in 2002, the company, which is based in Boston and has 20 employees, helps hospitals reduce the number of calls doctors receive from patients and keeps people informed of what to expect on their medical journeys.

headline: The Lady Reappears
abstract: Nina Arianda makes a most welcome return to the stage this spring in David Grimm’s “Tales From Red Vienna.”
lead_paragraph: Nina Arianda made one of the more arresting New York stage debuts of the past decade portraying an actress with a will to power in the dark, sexy “Venus in Fur.”

headline: Documentary on the Rapper Nas Will Open Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: “Time is Illmatic,” a documentary about the rapper Nas, will open the festival on April 16.
lead_paragraph: The Tribeca Film Festival is bringing more hip-hop to the big screen. “Time Is Illmatic,” a documentary on the rapper Nas, will open this year’s festival, organizers announced Wednesday.

headline: Detention of Snowden Journalist’s Partner by British Is Upheld
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A British court said the authorities had been within their rights to detain David Michael Miranda, the partner of Glenn Greenwald, for nine hours.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The partner of Glenn Greenwald, the journalist who published information leaked by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, lost his legal challenge on Wednesday over his nine-hour detention at London’s Heathrow Airport last August under counterterrorism laws. Mr. Greenwald’s partner, David Michael Miranda, was stopped while in transit from Germany to Brazil and was told he was being detained under Section 7 of the British Terrorism Act.

headline: A Look at the ‘Shills,’ ‘Skeptics’ and ‘Hobbyists’ Lumped Together in Climate Denialism

lead_paragraph: In his contribution to the recent discussion of Secretary of State John Kerry’s speech on global warming, David Victor of the University of California, San Diego, included this line:

abstract: Updates on the unrest in Ukraine. Also on the Minute, Neil Patrick Harris's Broadway transformation and the genetics of daredevils.
lead_paragraph: Updates on the unrest in Ukraine. Also on the Minute, Neil Patrick Harris's Broadway transformation and the genetics of daredevils.

headline: Can a Content Company Become a Tech Company?
abstract: TPR Media used to grow 30 percent a year — until the growth stopped. What should the owner do?
lead_paragraph: We just published a case study about the owner of a company that delivers health care-related messages to patients via email and is faced with some big decisions. When Betsy Weaver started TPR Media in Boston in 2002, she was working with hospital maternity divisions to send emails to patients that explained what they needed to bring to the hospital, what medications to take, what happens after they see the doctor and more. Her service allowed physicians to cut down on the many patient phone calls they had been receiving.

headline: Aides’ Emails Provide Detailed Look at Wisconsin’s Governor
abstract: A release of 27,000 emails and hundreds of court documents portrays Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin as having presided over an office where aides concealed that they were mixing government and campaign business.
lead_paragraph: Even as Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin looks ahead to 2016 and a possible presidential bid, his political past as Milwaukee County executive has come back to haunt him.

headline: The Loyal Users of Google Plus Say It Is No Ghost Town
abstract: Some people who use Google Plus say it is a thriving social network, useful for photography, video chats, in-depth online conversations and meeting new people who have similar interests.
lead_paragraph: A front-page article last weekend called Google Plus a ghost town. Since then, dozens of the very passionate ghosts who hang out there have let me know that, in fact, it is a lively, conversation-filled place that is unlike any other Internet social network.

headline: One Banksy Sells in Miami; Two Works From New York Do Not
abstract: A piece originally stenciled on a wall in Brighton, England, sold for $575,000, while two works from the artist’s New York stay did not meet their minimums.
lead_paragraph: “Kissing Coppers,” a mural by the British street artist Banksy, sold for $575,000 (including fees) on Tuesday, at an auction of graffiti-style art in Miami that failed to draw expected prices for three Banksy works.

lead_paragraph: The Disney hit “Frozen,” considered a near-lock to win the best animation Oscar, was not always the story of two feuding but loving sisters.

headline: CeeLo Green to Leave ‘The Voice’
abstract: The singer was there at the start of the hit NBC show, but says he has other projects to pursue, including a development deal with NBC.
lead_paragraph: “The Voice” has seen the last of CeeLo Green — at least as a regular coach on the hit NBC singing contest.

headline: Preparing to Retire, Jeter Prefers to Discuss Work
abstract: The Yankees’ captain, addressing last week’s retirement announcement for the first time, showed no emotion as he kept his focus on a final bid for a title.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — All but one person expected it to be a grand show, a well-attended farewell announcement for a revered sports figure, perhaps even ending in tears. But that one person was sitting behind the microphone, answering questions as if he were discussing just another Wednesday game in Cleveland or Chicago.

headline: Russian Protest Group Members Assaulted

lead_paragraph: While performing under a sign advertising the Sochi Olympics, members of Pussy Riot, along with their supporters, were attacked by Cossack militia members with horsewhips Wednesday.

headline: Members of Russian Protest Group Attacked by Cossacks in Sochi
keywords: ['Music', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Cossacks wielding horsewhips attacked members of Pussy Riot while they were shooting a music video by the city’s seaport.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Activist members of the protest group Pussy Riot were attacked in downtown Sochi on Wednesday by plainclothes police officers using an irritant spray and by Cossacks brandishing horsewhips.

headline: Weight Gain and Older Women
abstract: Excess weight is linked to an increase in the risk of chronic disease among older women, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama has done an excellent job mobilizing the nation to combat childhood obesity and encouraging kids to eat better and move more. But now her efforts may be needed on another front.
