headline: Silver Is the Winter Color for a Summer Gold Medalist
abstract: Lauryn Williams missed a chance to become the first female athlete to win gold medals in both the Summer and Winter Olympics.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Lauryn Williams is not certain where her Olympic track medals are — she thinks the silver from the 2004 Olympics may be at her mother’s house — so it was not hard to believe her on Wednesday night when she said that missing history by a measly tenth of a second was not especially disappointing.

headline: Thin-Skinned Spies
abstract: The N.S.A. objected to a line of parody mugs and t-shirts mocking its surveillance programs.
lead_paragraph: Dan McCall, operator of the website Liberty Maniacs, uses the National Security Agency seal on T-shirts and mugs that say “Spying on you since 1952” and “The only part of government that actually listens.” He also sells merchandise with a “Department of Homeland Stupidity” logo.

headline: The Gun Report: February 19, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: About 60 more people than usual have been murdered with firearms each year since Missouri got rid of background checks for gun sales in 2007, according to a new study by the Johns Hopkins Center for Gun Policy and Research. The state has seen a 23 percent increase in firearm homicide rates, even as the murder rate dropped 5 percent nationally. The rise in murders occurred only for those involving a firearm.

headline: Nerd Factor Aside, Bluetooth Headsets Are Useful on the Go
abstract: The technology has changed for the better, and new features abound. But a stubby plastic device attached to the side of your head still looks peculiar.
lead_paragraph: After about an hour of getting odd looks from co-workers, I felt compelled to explain myself. The Jawbone Era headset sticking out of my right ear, I said, was for this review.

headline: Video From Kiev and Images of Violence in Other Ukrainian Cities
abstract: Video from Kiev and other Ukrainian cities showed that violence continued on Wednesday after the authorities used deadly violence to try to regain control of the capital city’s streets.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:10 p.m. | As my colleagues Andrew Higgins and Andrew Kramer report from Kiev, a violent standoff between protesters and the riot police continued on Wednesday in the center of the Ukrainian capital.

headline: Harding-Kerrigan Rivalry, by Way of ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race’
abstract: The Logo television channel is parodying the Olympic scandal in the series “Ice Queens,” starring former “Drag Race” contestants.
lead_paragraph: With the world watching the Olympians in Sochi, television isn’t skipping a beat in reviving another Winter Games story, the 20th anniversary of the Tonya Harding-Nancy Kerrigan rivalry.

headline: New York State in Deal to Limit Solitary Confinement
abstract: The state agreed to sweeping reforms intended to curtail the use of solitary confinement, including barring its use in disciplining prisoners under 18.
lead_paragraph: New York State has agreed to sweeping reforms intended to curtail the widespread use of solitary confinement, including prohibiting its use in disciplining prisoners under 18.

headline: Gucci: ’60s Without the Sex
abstract: Frida Giannini’s collection felt more polite than the era built on free love and miniskirts.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — What excitement at Gucci! Smartphones were waved deliriously, photographers fought for position and, above the melee, a black cap peeked out as if there were a soldier on parade.

headline: Undeterred, Fed on Track to Temper Its Stimulus
abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers were surprised by the strength of the United States economy when they met in January, according to minutes of their meeting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Federal Reserve officials last met at the end of January, they were surprised by the strength of the economy, cheered by the optimism of consumers and convinced they should continue to dismantle the Fed’s economic stimulus campaign, according to an account the Fed released Wednesday.

headline: Google Offers a Guide to Not Being a ‘Creepy’ Google Glass Owner
abstract: Google released a set of do’s and don’ts for people who wear Google Glass, noting that in some situations, Glass wearers can be perceived as “creepy or rude.”
lead_paragraph: Google is finally realizing what the rest of the world has known for some time: People who wear Google Glass can sometimes be “creepy or rude.”

headline: London Fashion Week Street Style Wrap-Up
abstract: In the courtyard of Somerset House and the surrounding streets, for many the heart of London Fashion Week, all day long fashion enthusiasts, bloggers, students gather.
lead_paragraph: In the courtyard of Somerset House and the surrounding streets, for many the heart of London Fashion Week, all day long fashion enthusiasts, bloggers, students gather.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Gucci Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: If Acne Doesn’t Bother My Son, Why Should It Bother Me?
abstract: For three afternoons a week in sixth grade, I was “Zit Face.” But no one says a word to my son about his acne, and it doesn’t bother him at all.
lead_paragraph: My 15-year-old son doesn’t care about his acne. This astonishes me. How could acne not ruin his life? When I was his age I thought it had ruined mine.

headline: Celebrating a Building That Has Stood for Decades as a Symbol of the Press
abstract: Few commercial structures of any era embody the personality and purpose of their occupants as well as the De Vinne Press Building at Lafayette and East Fourth Streets.
lead_paragraph: The exhibition occurs within the genteel precincts of the Grolier Club on the Upper East Side. But the principal object is a muscular industrial fortress almost three miles downtown.

headline: The Tall-Order Rental
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Beatrice Gomberg and Ray Barba wanted a one-bedroom with a washer-dryer and a dishwasher.
lead_paragraph: In California, where they used to live, Beatrice Gomberg and Ray Barba had no trouble finding housing. “We got offered every apartment we could have possibly wanted,” Ms. Gomberg said.

headline: Where Timelessness Meets Time Travel
abstract: Nellie McKay mixes her own songs with standards at Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: With a head full of blond curls, and wearing a glittery blouse, Nellie McKay flounced into Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening, ushering a gust of downtown freshness into this elegant uptown precinct. Ms. McKay, 31, has been a presence on the cultural scene for at least a decade. But she still wears the mystique of a willful prodigy who is smarter, more talented and hipper than everyone else: a performer who answers only to herself. Gifts that others spend years refining seem to come naturally to her.

headline: Harper Lee Settles Lawsuit With Museum
abstract: Ms. Lee has reached an agreement with the Monroe County Heritage Museum, according to court documents.
lead_paragraph: Harper Lee, the author of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” is settling a lawsuit filed last year against a museum in her Alabama hometown claiming that it had sold merchandise featuring her name and the title of her novel without compensation.

headline: House Hunting ... Outside Paris
abstract: In Neuilly-sur-Seine, a western suburb, prices for the very best properties have held up through the European recession and sovereign debt crisis.
lead_paragraph: A DUPLEX PENTHOUSE IN NEUILLY-SUR-SEINE

headline: The Auditing Roadblock: It’s Not Just China
abstract: It is widely known that American authorities are prevented from inspecting Chinese audit firms, but few realize there are more such uninspected firms in the European Union, where some countries are unwilling to cooperate with American regulators.
lead_paragraph: The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board is out with a list of 58 international audit firms that it has been unable to inspect for at least four years. Those firms all audited companies registered in the United States, and — under American law — must be inspected by the board. The board has tried to arrange joint inspections with regulators from other countries, but a variety of impediments have arisen.

headline: Luck’s on Their Side, but Americans Don’t Need It in Rout
abstract: The United States men beat the Czech Republic and Canada edged Latvia, 2-1, to set up a rematch of the 2010 gold medal game.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The bounces seemed to go the Americans’ way on Wednesday.

headline: A Case That Lets You Be the Designer
abstract: A start-up, Caseable, offers easy tools on its website that let customers create cases for devices from Apple, Samsung and others.
lead_paragraph: With a sea of device accessories designed by other people, one company, Caseable, is turning the tables and letting you be the designer.

headline: Port Authority Official ‘Deeply Sorry’ for Closed Lanes
abstract: Months after lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge were closed, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey offered an apology to commuters.
lead_paragraph: Amid unyielding scrutiny into the role of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and his administration in the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, a top official of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey apologized on Wednesday to the commuters who sat in manufactured traffic over the course of several days in September.

headline: Still Life in Motion From a Road Trip Across South America
abstract: David Guttenfelder captures scenes along the Interoceanic Highway.
lead_paragraph: David Guttenfelder captures scenes along the Interoceanic Highway.

headline: A Bloody Night in Cres
abstract: Eager to please my hosts, I didn’t hesitate when asked to help kill a lamb — or when presented with the surprising meal that followed the slaughter.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I spent a month with Aniza and Dinko Muskardin, residents of the Croatian island of Cres, enjoying their emphatic Balkan hospitality in exchange for a few weeks’ help around their farm. I was besotted by my elderly hosts. I helped Dinko cut oak and juniper, search the hills for lost sheep and bottle the evil-smelling yellow wine that he aged in a cracked, slimy barrel. I was so besotted, in fact, that I didn’t hesitate when my host said to me, with an ominous gleam in his eyes, that it was time to kill the year-old “pecorina.” (Dinko was old enough to remember the Mussolini era, and we spoke in a pidgin of Italian.)

headline: A Busman’s Honeymoon
abstract: On a trip through France and Northern Italy, my new wife and I learned that “sophisticated” cooking did not have to mean “complicated.”
lead_paragraph: I had been cooking avidly for six years when, in the fall of 1976, thinking it was important to learn about “French” and “Northern Italian,” I flew to Rome with my new wife to begin what we called a “sort of honeymoon.”

headline: Wet Hot Israeli Summer
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Writing and Writers', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: I thought the trip might provide an opportunity to meet hot girl-sabras. I didn’t realize that it was really a chance to be with my father.
lead_paragraph: In 1990, just before Saddam Hussein began lobbing Scud missiles at Tel Aviv and Haifa, my father and I paid our first visit to Israel. The men in my family can be adventurous: Before he emigrated from the Soviet Union, my father had taken to marching outside Leningrad’s Grand Choral Synagogue chanting: “We! Are! Jews!” with a group of fellow believers, a beautiful and lunatic gesture under an increasingly anti-Semitic regime. Likewise, the looming threat of Iraqi Scuds made us giddy at the thought of floating in the Dead Sea hoisting copies of The International Herald Tribune with its daily war cries by Saddam’s ever-present little buddy, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz.

headline: In the Company of Truckers
abstract: How I learned the code of roadside kindness.
lead_paragraph: One summer in the late 1990s, I was driving across the country on Interstate 80, having just stopped to visit some friends in Des Moines. I was behind the wheel of a 1963 Chevrolet Impala I bought outside Asheville, N.C. The car ran well and was beautiful — champagne body with a cream top, no dents, no rust. It still even had these original plastic discs, like thin translucent washers, that fit between the window roller and the door panel to keep the upholstery from being indented or pinched. I was planning to sell it in Los Angeles, where a ’63 two-door Impala in such cherry condition was the ultimate low rider and worth a lot of money.

headline: ‘We Were About Half a Mile From Shore, Naked and Drunk to a Man’
abstract: As we floated away from the Hamptons home, I could see what I had never been able to understand in reading “The Great Gatsby”: This was pretty appealing.
lead_paragraph: On a sticky day in late June 2003, I was walking down West 16th Street in New York feeling sorry for myself — the only person in a city of eight million without Fourth of July plans — when I ran into a beautiful and sophisticated woman I slightly knew. She was sitting on a stoop with an equally glamorous friend, drinking iced coffee. She had been meaning to call me. She knew it was late notice, but she wondered if by any chance I was free for a party at a friend’s compound — compound! — in the Hamptons that weekend. Oh, um, well . . . yes.

headline: The ‘Braveheart’ Fantasy
abstract: I don’t want you to think I’m the type of person who brings the “Braveheart” soundtrack on a trip to Scotland. But I am.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, two friends and I rented a car and drove through the Scottish Highlands, stopping at bed-and-breakfasts and drinking whisky. The rental car had only a CD player, and one of the few CDs we had was the soundtrack to “Braveheart,” which I’d brought with me as kind of a joke. (I say “kind of a joke” because I don’t want you to think I’m the type of person who brings the “Braveheart” soundtrack on a trip to Scotland. But I am.)

headline: 5 Books to Take on Your Travels
abstract: The worst trips make the best reading.
lead_paragraph: 1. The Moronic Inferno: And Other Visits to America, by Martin Amis (1987)

headline: Traveling From Ocean to Ocean Across South America
abstract: The new highway that crosses Brazil and Peru is transformative — both for the villages it now connects and for the travelers who make the journey.
lead_paragraph: Before the passengers turned on the driver and began plotting a mutiny, the ride was smooth. The bus rolled out of the station in São Paulo at about 4 o’clock on a Wednesday afternoon last July, and within an hour it had shaken free of the city’s clotted tunnels, jammed overpasses and coded graffiti. By 6, we were barreling straight into a lurid sunset that endowed everything with the candied luster of fresh paint. Green hills, silver ponds, golden palms. Two parrots soared in tandem over a sugar-cane field, inviting us to drift into a pastoral trance.

headline: An Instagram Travel Diary
abstract: Picking up and going, with only a phone to capture the journeys.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been to 55 places in the past year. I pick a spot and some dates, and then whoever wants to come can come, even if I don’t know them that well. I look for naturally beautiful spots that I’ve never been to before. There was a phase last summer when it was only swimming holes in upstate New York. And then after that, I wanted to go only to places with the biggest, weirdest rocks. Two specific memories come to mind from the past year: one is sleeping on a boat deck with my brothers under what felt like the darkest sky with the brightest stars in the Andaman Sea off Myanmar. And the other is standing with friends at the throat of an eroded volcano in New Mexico called Shiprock, right as the sun was setting on one of the last days of the year. Both places were shockingly beautiful and isolated and contained only a handful of people I really love.

headline: A Tour of the Center of the World
abstract: Just head toward the 21-foot pyramid in the middle of the desert.
lead_paragraph: Just head toward the 21-foot pyramid in the middle of the desert.

headline: In Soweto, History From Those Who Live It
abstract: A guide takes the Frugal Traveler on a personal tour through an area victimized by apartheid.
lead_paragraph: Three sounds competed to rule the Soweto night, at least as heard from the roof deck of Flossie’s B&B in Pimville Zone 1: a surround-sound chorus of crickets; the intermittent barking of neighborhood dogs; and cars zooming by on Chris Hani Road two blocks north. The roof’s shiny railing arced out like an observation deck, but all there was to observe was the intersection of Dube and Gonsi Streets, a brick house with corrugated metal roof and satellite dish on the corner, other just slightly neater houses beyond.

headline: Where the World’s Greatest Photographers Go to Get Away
abstract: They may be off the clock, but they still have their cameras.
lead_paragraph: They may be off the clock, but they still have their cameras.

headline: A Journey to the Center of the World
abstract: And the weird, wonderful old couple making their life there.
lead_paragraph: One morning in late January, Jacques-André Istel woke up at his home in Felicity, Calif., did 100 push-ups and 125 squats, swam in his elegantly lit lap pool, then went back upstairs, where he took a light breakfast in bed, as has been his custom since his boyhood in Paris. After breakfast, he dressed in a blue shirt and ascot and walked to his office at 1 Center of the World Plaza. It was Istel’s birthday; he was turning 85.

headline: From England to the Edge of Africa
abstract: Tom Allen talks about his 32-country solo bike ride and the video he made about it.
lead_paragraph: After graduating from college, Tom Allen searched for an escape from an unfulfilling, deskbound career. A plan to bike through a few countries snowballed into a four-year trip through 32 countries, from his home in England through Europe, the Middle East and down the northeastern edge of Africa.

headline: A ‘Creativity Conference’ at the Cloister
abstract: The Cloister in Sea Island, Ga., will offer a “Creativity Conference” with speakers like the photographer David Hume Kennerly.
lead_paragraph: The Cloister at Sea Island in Georgia has taken a cue from the popular TED series and will produce its own speakers event, the Creativity Conference, which organizers hope will become an annual attraction.

headline: Nets Add a Guard and Pick Up a Victory
abstract: The Nets sent Jason Terry and Reggie Evans to Sacramento for Marcus Thornton and then overcame a slow start to beat the Utah Jazz.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Before the resumption of a wilting title chase came a minor retooling.

headline: Signet and Zale Deal Casts 2 Other Deals in a Poor Light
abstract: The stock of the jewelry retailer Signet rose after it agreed to buy its smaller rival Zale on Wednesday. That’s what happens when the cost savings effectively cover the purchase price, writes Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Leave it to a couple of diamond dealers to show how to make mergers and acquisitions sparkle. The stock of the jewelry retailer Signet rose after it agreed to buy its smaller rival Zale at a 41 percent premium for an enterprise value, which includes debt, of $1.4 billion. That’s what happens when the cost savings effectively cover the purchase price. It makes the shareholder-unfriendly transactions involving Comcast and Jos. A. Bank all the more noticeable.

lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Kim Seizes Lead; Then the Surprises Start
abstract: Kim Yu-na, trying to become the third woman to win consecutive Olympic gold medals in her sport, overcame anxiety to take the lead in the short program, but two other favorites fell.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Her choice of music for Wednesday’s short program, “Send In the Clowns,” might have suggested departure and regret instead of victory for Kim Yu-na of South Korea, the defending Olympic women’s figure skating champion.

headline: Lawmaker Urges U.S. Regulators to Scrutinize Mortgage Servicers
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Representative Maxine Waters is urging federal banking regulators to scrutinize the sale of billions of dollars of mortgage-servicing rights to specialty firms.
lead_paragraph: Representative Maxine Waters of California is urging federal banking regulators to scrutinize the sale of billions of dollars of mortgage-servicing rights to a fleet of specialty firms, a move that comes amid mounting concerns that some of the most vulnerable homeowners are facing fresh abuses in battles to save their homes.

lead_paragraph: Eric Church, a country singer with a taste for big rock ’n’ roll riffs, opened at No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart with his latest release, “The Outsiders” (EMI Nashville). The album, his second to reach the top, sold 288,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Escape Plan: It Starts With the Dress
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Bathing Suits']
abstract: Dresses in tropical prints; a colorful take on the classic beach bag; the latest swimwear and sandals for the après beach hours.
lead_paragraph: Bone-chilling temperatures, snow — and let’s not even talk about the treacherous black ice. No one needs to tell us it’s time for an escape. A few personal days and an inexpensive ticket, and you’re in a warm place. Here’s what to take with you.

lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Elodia Prieto (left) and after (right) makeup by Lloyd Simmons and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: A Freshman Representative Sizes Up Congress
abstract: Gloria Negrete McLeod served less than a full term in the House before deciding she’d rather run for a seat on the San Bernardino County Board of Supervisors.
lead_paragraph: Representative Gloria Negrete McLeod of California required less than a full term in the House to size up the place and decide it was better to go back home and run for a seat on the San Bernardino County Board of Supervisors. I doubt she regretted her choice when the fellow Democrat she had defeated in 2012, former Representative Joe Baca, denounced her as “some bimbo” for quitting.

headline: Two Authors Ask Indian Publisher to Pulp Their Books
abstract: Two Indian writers wrote to the publishing house Penguin India to say its decision to pulp a history of Hinduism had undermined their faith in the publisher.
lead_paragraph: Penguin India drew strong criticism from authors earlier this month after it decided to withdraw and pulp the scholar Wendy Doniger’s book “The Hindus: An Alternative History,” thus ending a four-year legal battle with Hindu nationalists who argued the book violated Indian laws against giving religious offense.

headline: Tony Blair Emerges as Figure in Tabloid Hacking Case
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'E-Mail', 'News and News Media']
abstract: According to an email read at trial, the former British prime minister told a major figure in the scandal, Rebekah Brooks, to “keep strong,” and offered to act as an “unofficial adviser.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tony Blair is the latest high-profile person to surface in the British phone hacking trial, a high-stakes criminal prosecution of shadowy practices at Rupert Murdoch’s tabloid The News of the World.

headline: Bill in Albany to Allow Lawsuits by Those Who Falsely Confess
abstract: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman’s proposal would allow someone who falsely confesses or pleads guilty to a crime to sue the state even if the person cannot prove coercion.
lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general proposed legislation on Wednesday that would allow people who have confessed or pleaded guilty to a crime they did not commit to sue the state for damages.

lead_paragraph: Bound for Australia, the prison ship is packed with Irishwomen brought aboard in chains.

headline: Winklevoss Brothers Offer an Index to Track Price of Bitcoin
abstract: Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, famous for their legal battle with the Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, have created a financial index that provides a regularly updated figure for the price of Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:03 p.m. | Stock traders have the Standard & Poor’s 500. Bitcoin bettors will have the Winkdex.

headline: Passage to Midlife on Broken Pavement
abstract: “Bark,” Lorrie Moore’s new collection of stories, deals with loss, divorce, disappointment and all sorts of hurt.
lead_paragraph: “Bark,” the title of Lorrie Moore’s disappointing new collection of stories, seems to refer to several things at once: the yelp of a dog, the peeling garb of a tree and the process of “debarking” from a plane. Each meaning can be taken to allude to the animal fact of human mortality, and the experience of loss and departure that marks the human condition. The multiple meanings also underscore Ms. Moore’s love of wordplay and puns — her hyper-awareness of language and her attunement to what one character calls the “missingness” of life.

headline: Pushing Back Against Government Surveillance
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: When the Beijing lawyer Xie Yanyi asked his government to tell him about its spying on citizens, he got a no-reply answer. But the problem is worldwide and needs to be solved worldwide, he said.
lead_paragraph: As Edward J. Snowden’s revelations of the extent of spying by the United States National Security Agency roiled the world last June, Xie Yanyi, a Beijing lawyer, asked the Ministry of Public Security to tell him about Chinese security officials’ spying on their own citizens, especially regarding online and telephone communications.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Lebanon, Thailand and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Lebanon, Thailand and India.

headline: Self-Examination for All to See and Hear
abstract: Personalities based on real people (Moss Hart, Lyndon B. Johnson) and imagination (Violet, Hedwig) add psychological complexity to the Broadway season.
lead_paragraph: We are all in the constant process of creating, refining or redefining our identities. Today, it has become practically a full-time job, as social networks spread like kudzu, and people spend countless hours considering how best to present themselves to the watching world. Who do you think you are? The question has become ever more pressing and ever more public: I Instagram, therefore I am.

headline: Those Brand-Name Musicals
abstract: The stage keeps looking to the screen for its musicals — this season, “Rocky,” “Aladdin” and “Bullets Over Broadway.”
lead_paragraph: Back in the days of vaudeville — or to be precise, a 1959 musical’s version of vaudeville — a wise old stripper delivered some immortal advice for anyone starting out in showbiz: “You gotta have a gimmick, if you wanna have a chance.” Thus spake the trumpet-tooting Mazeppa, addressing the title character of “Gypsy.”

keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'Elections', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: A Supreme Court ruling paved the way for a decision to release the prisoners, who were convicted in the 1991 assassination of the former prime minister.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — The chief minister of Tamil Nadu said Wednesday that her government would free six men and one woman who were convicted of plotting the 1991 assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, the former prime minister of India.

headline: The Corcoran Gallery of Art May Cede Control of Its Collection
abstract: Facing mounting debts, the long-struggling Washington gallery is exploring a plan to give up its independence and partner with the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University.
lead_paragraph: Facing mounting debts, a shrinking endowment and tens of millions of dollars in renovations, the long-struggling Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington is exploring a plan to give up its independence as the oldest privately supported art museum in the nation to form a partnership with the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University.

lead_paragraph: The jewelery retailer Zale was in a bind in 2010. Its sales were flagging in the recession, and stock market investors were turning their backs on the company.

lead_paragraph: A new music video by Lord Huron.

headline: Slithering Through the Air With the Greatest of Ease
abstract: Scientists studying the paradise tree snake, a born glider, are investigating how the animals can achieve better lift than some conventional wing shapes.
lead_paragraph: Some people might view a snake that can launch itself from trees and glide through the air as their worst nightmare, something to be avoided, proof positive that human beings were not meant to venture out of doors.

headline: And Surrogacy Makes 3
abstract: Surrogate baby-making, though restricted in many states, has been growing among gay men.
lead_paragraph: A month before their baby’s due date, Brad Hoylman and David Sigal got a call from the woman they had hired to have their child.

headline: A New York Chef’s Home-Cooking Essentials
abstract: Camille Becerra opens her TriBeCa apartment, sharing her kitchen must-haves just days before her new gig as the executive chef of a new SoHo restaurant begins.
lead_paragraph: Camille Becerra is no stranger to departures and homecomings. “We actually lived here before,” the chef and food stylist says, waving around her sun-filled TriBeCa loft. “That day the towers went down, we physically left,” she says of Sept. 11, which prompted her to flee with her then six-month-old daughter to the Brooklyn neighborhood of Greenpoint, where they lived for seven years. During that period in her new neighborhood, Becerra opened Paloma, a restaurant housed in a converted parking garage, which she named after her daughter. In 2008 the restaurant burned down, and Becerra returned to her beloved loft in Manhattan.

headline: Derek Jeter Keeps His Cool, but His Outlook Has Changed
abstract: Without control of his environment, baseball can no longer be a little boys’ game for Jeter. He talked about wanting to start a family, and about his foundation work and publishing venture.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Control was the defining issue. If he could ward off distractions, if he could make it all about the ball, the glove and his opportunistic bat, baseball would forever be the little boys’ game even when it was being played for riches once beyond his imagination.

headline: Jimmy Fallon’s Audience Stays Large, but Where Will It Settle?
abstract: With more than 7 million viewers Tuesday night, the new host of the “Tonight” show is still drawing an unusually large audience, but expect those numbers to drop.
lead_paragraph: The falloff was predictable for Night 2 of “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” — down to 7.3 million viewers from 11.3 million viewers for his premiere on Monday.

headline: Russian Riot Grrrls Beaten but Not Arrested in Sochi
abstract: There were signs of confusion in the official response to a new performance by the Russian protest band Pussy Riot on Wednesday in Sochi.
lead_paragraph: There were signs of confusion in the official response to a new performance by the Russian protest group Pussy Riot on Wednesday in Sochi, as the activists were first set upon by Cossack militiamen and beaten with whips and pepper spray, but then allowed to retrieve their guitar from a trash can and leave without being arrested.

headline: Forget the Fantasy, Keep It Friendly
abstract: At Ami, Alexandre Mattiussi argues forcefully that real clothes deserve exposure, too.
lead_paragraph: The basement of the Palais de Tokyo was staged like a snowbound park at twilight. Lampposts glowed faintly throughout the sea of white. This winter wonderland during the rainy men’s fashion shows in Paris last month was courtesy of Alexandre Mattiussi, the designer of the nascent label Ami.

headline: Sic Transit New Jersey
abstract: After three massive foul-ups on his watch, James Weinstein is resigning as executive director of New Jersey Transit.
lead_paragraph: After more than four years on the job and three massive foul-ups on his watch, James Weinstein is resigning as executive director of New Jersey Transit. Gov. Chris Christie has already announced his replacement, and we can only hope that Veronique Hakim, head of the state’s thruway authority, is independent-minded enough to worry first and foremost about commuters.

headline: Facebook Enters $16 Billion Deal for WhatsApp
abstract: Including an additional $3 billion in restricted stock units, the acquisition price for WhatsApp amounts to $345 million for every one of the company’s 55 employees.
lead_paragraph: The frenzy to acquire fast-growing technology start-ups reached new heights on Wednesday as Facebook announced its largest acquisition ever, saying it would pay at least $16 billion for WhatsApp, a text messaging application with 450 million users around the world who pay little or no money for it.

headline: Excerpts as Obama Signs the Farm Bill
abstract: President Obama on Friday signed the $956 billion farm bill into law. It replaces direct crop payments to farmers with an insurance program, and trims the food stamp program.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Friday signed the $956 billion farm bill into law. It replaces direct crop payments to farmers with an insurance program, and trims the food stamp program.

headline: A Star From Norway Stands Alone
abstract: If you want to keep an image in your mind of how Ole Einar Bjorndalen became the most decorated Winter Olympian in history, it is best to see him skiing solo: through the woods, through the years.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — His tie with his countryman Bjorn Daehlie was broken, and Ole Einar Bjorndalen was posing for group photographs.

lead_paragraph: Shares of Safeway climbed in after-market trading on Wednesday after the supermarket chain disclosed that it was “in discussions concerning a possible transaction involving the sale of the company.”

headline: Study Finds Drops Are Best Treatment for Ear Tube-Related Dripping
abstract: Medical research showed that topical drops were superior to oral antibiotics in tackling discharge caused by an infection in children with tubes.
lead_paragraph: For children with ear tubes, topical antibiotic drops treat the leaky discharge caused by an ear infection much more effectively than oral antibiotics or observation, according to a study published in The New England Journal of Medicine on Wednesday.

headline: James Patterson Giving Cash to Bookstores
abstract: Mr. Patterson sells heaps of books and makes piles of money. Now he is sharing the wealth with independent booksellers.
lead_paragraph: Independent bookstores, with their paper-thin profit margins and competition from Amazon, have found themselves a Daddy Warbucks.

headline: To Be Young in a Vienna That’s Headed Nowhere Good
abstract: “Pains of Youth,” from 1926, revived by the Cake Shop Theater, paints of portrait of disillusionment in Vienna.
lead_paragraph: Consider Desiree, a Viennese medical student in 1923: Young, sexually knowing and effortlessly good at her studies, she seems at first blush like a wunderkind in a red slip. But to Desiree, the future looks bleak. “Bourgeois existence or suicide,” she says, “there are no other choices.”

headline: 350,000 Ways to Harness Energy From the Sun
abstract: Jamey Stillings, a photographer from Santa Fe, N.M., has photographed the development of the Ivanpah Solar thermal plant for more than three years.

headline: Her Blog, Her Brand
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Nails (Body Part)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Beauty', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Skin', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Social Media']
abstract: A new generation of beauty bloggers is managing to parlay social-media success into entrepreneurship.
lead_paragraph: On her popular blog, Maskcara.com, Cara Brook, 28, sings the praises of highlighting and contouring one’s facial features, a process she refers to as HAC’ing (pronounced “hacking”). She gleaned the technique, in which a color a few shades darker than the skin is used to create shadows on the edges and in the hollows of the face while a slightly lighter one plays up the high planes of the cheekbones, nose, forehead and chin, from books by the makeup artist Kevyn Aucoin, which she pored over as a teenager obsessed with the beauty business. “It’s a magical thing,” she effused in a how-to video.

headline: Derek Jeter Talks Retirement
abstract: The New York Yankees’ Derek Jeter held a news conference Wednesday to discuss his retirement at the end of the 2014 season.
lead_paragraph: The New York Yankees’ Derek Jeter held a news conference Wednesday to discuss his retirement at the end of the 2014 season.

headline: The Nominees Are Blockbusters
abstract: This year’s film songs have familiar composers.
lead_paragraph: The story in “Frozen,” the blockbuster Disney musical, did not originally center on two sister princesses. Based loosely on “The Snow Queen” fairy tale, it always had a pair of girls at its core, but it wasn’t until several years into the production process, at a story meeting in the company’s Burbank, Calif., headquarters, that someone suggested that Elsa and Anna be siblings.

headline: This Phone Is Great, Till It’s Time to Add Apps
abstract: The new Nokia Icon, a Windows Phone, matches Android and iPhone in many critical areas except one: Its app store is seriously lacking.
lead_paragraph: If the tech business were fair, you would be considering the Nokia Icon for your next smartphone.

lead_paragraph: “WE WERE TALKING about getting older,” Diane von Furstenberg said not long ago as she reminisced about a conversation she had shared over lunch with Anna Wintour. What are a few furrows and frown lines? Ms. Wintour said blithely. “We’re legends, you know.”

lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:32 p.m. | When the billionaire hedge fund manager Kenneth C. Griffin was a sophomore at Harvard, he was betting on convertible bonds in his dorm room — thanks to a satellite dish he had hooked up on the roof — while his fellow students were going to classes.

headline: A Mexican Showcase for Ambition
abstract: The Museo Jumex, a new contemporary art museum in Mexico City sponsored by the art patron Eugenio López Alonso, has internationalist ambitions but a style of its own.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Churning and wired, this city is a place of many devotions. Some of them revolve around art. Worshipers throng the Señora de Guadalupe shrine to gaze on a miraculous painting of the Virgin. Secular pilgrims on the hunt for saints crowd Casa Azul, “The Blue House,” Frida Kahlo’s home. Every tourist makes a must-see stop at the National Museum of Anthropology with its hair-raising sculptures of Aztec gods.

headline: Makeup That Can Enliven Winter Skin
abstract: To invigorate winter-weary skin, there are several new versions of illuminator.
lead_paragraph: With the tan now a beauty boogeyman, some consumers are looking for different ways to enliven winter-dulled skin. Enter the illuminator, several new versions of which have come to market recently.

headline: Which Is Better, Shower Curtain or Glass Door?
abstract: It depends on the layout of your bathroom and the style of your home.
lead_paragraph: Q. I want my shower to look as high-end as possible, but I’m on a budget: Which is better, shower curtain or glass door?

headline: Preindustrial Design Meets Politics
abstract: A retrospective of Studio Formafantasma opens at the Stedelijk Museum’s-Hertogenbosch in the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: “Prima Materia,” which opened this week at the Stedelijk Museum’s-Hertogenbosch in the Netherlands, is the first retrospective of the work of Studio Formafantasma, the partnership of Simone Farresin and Andrea Trimarchi.

headline: A Treasure Trove of Wood-Block Prints
abstract: Zucchi, an Italian company, introduces a new line of linens, rugs and throws based on an archive of more than 50,000 fabrics made from 1785 to 1935.
lead_paragraph: Though the technique of printing fabrics with wood blocks is ancient, Western Europeans adopted it only a few hundred years ago. Zucchi, an Italian textiles manufacturer, has amassed a collection of some 56,000 examples from 1785 to 1935, and has created a museum for them in Rescaldina, near Milan. Now the company has dipped into this trove to create a line of bedding, table linens, throws and area rugs.

headline: Whatever Floats Your Soap
keywords: ['Wood and Wood Products', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The Salish Sea, a wood bathtub by Seth Rolland, looks like a boat and costs as much as a Honda.
lead_paragraph: It looks like a teak salad bowl and costs as much as a new Honda. The Salish Sea is a wood bathtub by Seth Rolland, a furniture maker in Washington State. “I live in Port Townsend, the wooden-boat-building capital of the West Coast,” he said. He started building boats, but switched to furniture because it offered more artistic license. “A table has to have a flat surface and be about 28 inches high,” he said. “After that, everything is open.” Making the tub, for a client in Tennessee, involved 200 pieces of sustainable sapele wood, glued with epoxy, hand sanded, then waterproofed by a local wood kayak maker with layers of epoxy over an invisible fiberglass lining, on top of which went six coats of varnish. Shown above, it is 85 inches long and 36 inches deep. Prices start at $28,000. Information: sethrolland.com or 360-379-0414.

headline: Paper Furnishings
abstract: Egg carton lamps, corrugated cardboard chairs and other designs too good to be disposable.
lead_paragraph: Luca Nichetto is an Italian designer who grew up professionally among the glassmaking studios of Murano. These days, however, he often finds himself inspired by a humbler medium.

headline: What Goes Beep in the Night
abstract: Machines that quietly monitor your behavior are worrying, but those that bombard you with reminders of their presence may be even more disturbing.
lead_paragraph: Machines that insinuate themselves into their surroundings, quietly monitoring your behavior, may be worrying, but as far as I’m concerned, those that bombard you with reminders of their presence are more disturbing.

headline: Some Bot to Watch Over Me
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: New home-monitoring systems promise of peace of mind, but at what cost to your privacy?
lead_paragraph: For a month now, I have been spying on my apartment.

headline: If It’s Icky, She Has the Solution
abstract: Jolie Kerr dispenses cleaning advice free of judgment about sex toys, bongs, purses and hair. Who knew about denture tablets?
lead_paragraph: For a generation overwhelmed not just by dust bunnies, but by bong water on the carpet, pee stains on the ceiling and vomit seemingly everywhere, Jolie Kerr, 37, dispenses cleaning advice free of judgment. Writing first on The Hairpin, The Awl’s girlish sister blog, and now on Jezebel and Deadspin, Ms. Kerr gently cautions her readers to beware of their handbags, noting that researchers have found that the stuff banging around inside carries more bacteria than most toilet seats. But microbes are not the worst Coach-invader.

keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Beds and Bedding', 'Carpets and Rugs', 'Storage', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Deals on rugs, storage pieces and more.
lead_paragraph: Discontinued rugs, pillows and bedding are 60 percent off at Company C, while supplies last (the Chevron Julep ColorSpree pillow, usually $65, is $26; a 5-by-8-foot Hyannisport aqua ColorSpree rug, usually $395, is $158; the Gidget multi pillow, usually $125, is $50); 800-818-8288, companyc.com.

headline: Small World, Big Idea
abstract: A micro-cottage community offers a national template for homeless housing projects.
lead_paragraph: OLYMPIA, Wash. — On Christmas Eve, Kevin Johnson received the following gifts: a bed and mattress, a blanket and sheets, a desk and chair, a toilet and sink, towels and washcloths, toothpaste and floss, and a brand-new house.

headline: As Obama Vows to Act on Climate Change, Justices Weigh His Approach
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Clean Air Act', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: On Monday, the Supreme Court will consider the limits of executive authority, in a case on greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama in recent days has been announcing muscular executive actions to address climate change, making good on his promise to act on pressing problems “with or without Congress.” On Monday, the Supreme Court will consider the limits of that approach, in a case on greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Strikes and Spare Wood
abstract: CounterEvolution’s furniture is made from wood reclaimed from bowling alleys.
lead_paragraph: Jim Malone, the owner of CounterEvolution, a Brooklyn company that makes furniture out of wood reclaimed from bowling lanes, discovered the material while sourcing kitchen countertops several years ago and has used it in his tables and slat-back chairs ever since. He began by selling pieces at the Brooklyn Flea and now produces furniture for Shake Shack and Starbucks; recently, the company opened a Manhattan showroom.

lead_paragraph: Melena Ryzik explores the Disney animation studios and speaks with the creators of the Oscar-nominated film “Frozen.”

headline: Facebook’s Deal for WhatsApp: The Chatter on Twitter
abstract: While analysts grapple with the implications of the WhatsApp deal, the immediate take came via tweets.
lead_paragraph: Facebook made a huge splash in the tech world on Wednesday with a $16 billion deal to buy WhatsApp, a messaging start-up — the social media giant’s biggest acquisition by far.

headline: Denver Museum Returns Artifacts to Kenyan Government
abstract: The Denver Museum of Nature and Science on Wednesday returned to Kenya a collection of 30 spiritual carvings.
lead_paragraph: Museums hoping to return stolen cultural items to indigenous tribes that may have lost them generations ago often say they are stymied by the difficulty of identifying a “rightful owner” to take legal custody of the objects. But on Wednesday, one museum, the Denver Museum of Nature and Science, with a large collection of East African spiritual carvings known as vigango, resolved that problem by returning 30 of the artifacts to the Kenyan government.

headline: For Super Bowl, Familiar Ads And Star Endorsements
abstract: Answers to lingering questions about some spots that showed during the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: AFTER each Super Bowl, there are lingering questions about the 50 or more commercials that viewers watched during the game on what is typically the biggest day of the year for advertising as well as for football. (This year, it was certainly the biggest day for television with a record average audience of 112.2 million viewers.) What follows are answers to questions about some spots in Super Bowl XLVIII.

headline: Why Actors Act Out
abstract: The meaning of Shia LaBeouf’s erratic behavior.
lead_paragraph: THE recent erratic behavior of Shia LaBeouf, the 27-year-old actor best known as the star of the “Transformers” movies, has sent the press into a feeding frenzy. Though the wisdom of some of his actions may seem questionable, as an actor and artist I’m inclined to take an empathetic view of his conduct.

abstract: See the Winter Games in a series of composite images.
lead_paragraph: See the Winter Games in a series of composite images.

abstract: Polina Edmunds, 15, stands out in women’s figure skating, a sport that, like gymnastics in the Summer Games, routinely churns out top young competitors.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — It’s hard enough to be a 15-year-old girl.

headline: Start-Up Site Hires Critic of Wall St.
abstract: Matt Taibbi will start his own publication focusing on financial and political corruption at First Look Media, which is financed by the eBay founder Pierre Omidyar.
lead_paragraph: Matt Taibbi, who made a name as a fierce critic of Wall Street at Rolling Stone magazine, has joined First Look Media, the latest big-name journalist to leave an established brand to enter the thriving and well-financed world of news start-ups.

headline: Google Fiber, Ultrahigh-Speed Internet, May Expand to 34 New Cities
abstract: Google is asking 34 cities to pave the way for Fiber without guaranteeing it will install it, a change in approach as the Internet giant grapples with real-world challenges like tearing up roads.
lead_paragraph: Google is taking steps to expand Google Fiber, its nascent ultrahigh-speed Internet service, to 34 cities in nine metropolitan areas across the country as it grapples with the challenges of working with local governments.

headline: Russians’ Hockey Elimination Prompts Anger and Dismay
abstract: Fans hoping for victory in the nation’s most popular sport issued harsh verdicts after the men’s team lost to Finland.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — For the home-country fans here celebrating the first Winter Games on Russian soil, there could be no bigger debacle than failing to win a medal in hockey, the nation’s most popular sport.

headline: Global Bond Frenzy Raises Concerns
keywords: ['Third World and Developing Countries', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: As growth falters in several developing nations, regulators are worried about the consequences of the borrowing frenzy and the risks associated with the funds that have largely replaced commercial banks.
lead_paragraph: Prospecting for oil in Brazil, manufacturing steel in Russia, erecting skyscrapers in China: Global bond investors have financed some of the grandest investment projects taken on by emerging economies in recent years.

headline: Law and Politics
abstract: Robert A. Dahl, the late Yale political scientist, said a mixing of law and politics is to be expected from the Supreme Court rather than feared.
lead_paragraph: I first read about Robert A. Dahl’s death earlier this month in the Yale Daily News. Why would the editors of a student newspaper publish a Page 1 obituary of a 98-year-old political science professor who had retired from teaching well before any of today’s undergraduates were born?

headline: Year in Prison for Ex-Guard Who Had Child With Inmate
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Guards']
abstract: Nancy Gonzalez, the former correction officer who was impregnated by an inmate who was twice sentenced to the federal death penalty, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Gonzalez, the former correction officer who was impregnated by an inmate who was twice sentenced to the federal death penalty, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison on Wednesday for her role in the illicit relationship.

headline: Hard Times Leave Some Greek Car Owners With Nothing but Rust
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Automobile Registration and License Plates', 'Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Taxation', 'Abandonment (Property)']
abstract: Greeks have long had a love affair with cars, but lately, Greece has become a vast graveyard of abandoned automobiles, with motorists who can no longer afford to pay the taxes on their vehicles turning in piles of car plates.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — No longer able to pay for gas, Giannis Zgourakis parked his prized BMW on the street near his home and turned to a motorcycle. That was more than a year ago. Now, the car sits there a forlorn wreck, its battery dead, its tires ruined.

headline: Bank of America’s Chief Receives $12.5 Million in Stock
abstract: During Brian Moynihan’s tenure as chief executive, Bank of America has been digging out from mortgage problems, shoring up its capital levels and laying off employees.
lead_paragraph: Brian T. Moynihan, the chief executive of Bank of America, received about $12.5 million in restricted stock grants for 2013, according to a regulatory filing on Wednesday night.

headline: Cheer Everyone? Russian Biathlon Spectators Are Still Learning
abstract: Russian fans have failed to abide by two unspoken rules — stay quiet when a biathlete is shooting and do not cheer after missed shots.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — From their perch in the bleachers high above the shooting range, biathlon fans generally follow two unspoken rules: Stay quiet when a biathlete is shooting at the target, and do not cheer when a competitor from another country misses.

headline: Loss Tapers at Tesla as Its Sales Still Climb
abstract: The automaker gave a rosy outlook on production and deliveries of its cars this year, especially overseas, which cheered investors.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 20 months after delivering the first all-electric Model S sedan to customers, Tesla Motors is narrowing its losses as sales of its cars continue to climb.

headline: The Bias Against Black Bodies
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Jury System', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Corporal Punishment', 'Racial Profiling']
abstract: The conundrum of the current African-American experience: How to rescue people from a system and culture that threatens to drown them?
lead_paragraph: The Michael Dunn case has caused us to look once again at the American culture and criminal justice system, and many don’t like what they see.

headline: Disillusionment in Libya Over Vote on Charter Assembly
abstract: Increasingly frustrated Libyans on Thursday will elect 60 lawmakers to write a new constitution after Parliament failed to appoint the charter-drafting body.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — For the second time since the overthrow of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi two and a half years ago, Libyans are being asked to go to the polls to elect lawmakers responsible for preparing a new constitution. On Thursday, increasingly frustrated voters will directly elect a 60-member assembly to draft the charter after Parliament failed to appoint the body as originally planned.

headline: Amid Toxic Waste, a Navajo Village Could Lose Its Land
abstract: A tiny community in the Navajo reservation in New Mexico is bearing the brunt of the environmental damage caused by decades of uranium mining, and may have to leave.
lead_paragraph: CHURCH ROCK, N.M. — In this dusty corner of the Navajo reservation, where seven generations of families have been raised among the arroyos and mesas, Bertha Nez is facing the prospect of having to leave her land forever.

headline: The Least We Can Do
abstract: How we ended up with a can’t-lose proposal that can’t win.
lead_paragraph: Can we talk about the United Nations? I know, I know. But give me a minute. We don’t do this very often.

headline: Missing Costas? Fleeting Glimpses of a Lasting Presence
abstract: Bob Costas’s longevity at NBC has fed the notion that he is highly visible in each Olympic show, but he was on screen for a mere 5 minutes 28 seconds on Monday.
lead_paragraph: How much time would you guess Bob Costas spends on the air during one of NBC’s prime-time Olympic shows?

headline: A City Safe for Walking
abstract: What steps can city officials, pedestrians and drivers take to reduce the number of accidents?

headline: At Lunar New Year, a Big, Red Target for Pickpockets
abstract: Though many Chinese residents see an increased risk of theft year round, crime rates often spike during the Lunar New Year, when elders traditionally give cash gifts to younger relatives.
lead_paragraph: There is no red bunting on the front door of Helen Hsu’s home in Rego Park, Queens, no festive garlands or totems that often bedeck Chinese homes like hers during the monthlong Lunar New Year celebration, which began more than two weeks ago. If she were in her native Taiwan there would be fluttering red paper streamers, glinting mirrors and equine caricatures heralding the Year of the Horse. Here in Queens, though, Ms. Hsu has tacked up only military flags and a crest from her son, a United States Marine.

headline: Gap to Raise Minimum Hourly Pay
abstract: Gap said the move would ultimately raise pay for 65,000 of its 90,000 American employees to $10 an hour by next year.
lead_paragraph: In a surprising move, Gap Inc. informed its employees on Wednesday that it would set $9 as the minimum hourly rate for its United States work force this year and then establish a minimum of $10 next year.

headline: A Piece of DNA
abstract: In one drawer is a nondescript piece of scrap metal that turns out to be part of the object that first revealed how life on this planet works.
lead_paragraph: This is the fifth part of an eight-part series.

headline: A Church So Poor It Has to Close Schools, Yet So Rich It Can Build a Palace
abstract: Archbishop John J. Myers of Newark is adding 3,000 square feet to a 4,500-square-foot vacation home in Pittstown, N.J.
lead_paragraph: KEARNY, N.J. — Mater Dei Academy sits shuttered, blue drapes pulled across its windows, atop a hill in this working-class city. From its steps, you can peer across the mist-shrouded expanse of the Meadowlands to the distant spires of Manhattan.

headline: Is That Sausage Worth This?
abstract: Most sows live, give birth and then die in cages hardly bigger than their bodies. Now, that’s changing.
lead_paragraph: Modern factory farms have so much wrong with them, but a starting point is the practice of turning pigs into cannibals.

headline: Calmer Streets, Safer City
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Jaywalking', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s focus on public safety is sensible, and his plan to prevent traffic deaths could make a difference to New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday released his plan to eliminate traffic deaths in New York City. Every preventable traffic death is unacceptable, he said, and New Yorkers deserve a systematic, citywide campaign for safer streets. He’s right on both counts.

headline: Nationalistic Remarks From Japan Lead to Warnings of Chill With U.S.
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Comments criticizing the United States by associates of Japan’s prime minister have furthered concerns that a rift is growing between the two governments.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A series of defiantly nationalistic comments, including remarks critical of the United States, by close political associates of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has led analysts to warn of a growing chill between his right-wing government and the Obama administration, which views Japan as a linchpin of its strategic pivot to Asia.

headline: Brit Awards Red Carpet
abstract: View looks from Rita Ora, Kylie Minogue, Pharrell Williams, Iggy Azalea and more.
lead_paragraph: View looks from Rita Ora, Kylie Minogue, Pharrell Williams, Iggy Azalea and more.

headline: Ukraine’s Deadly Turn
abstract: It has become clear with each new effort to block reforms that the Yanukovych government is destroying its credibility to achieve a settlement.
lead_paragraph: Three months of confrontations in Kiev, Ukraine, erupted in sudden and brutal violence on Tuesday and Wednesday, leaving at least 25 dead and the heart of the capital city in flames.

headline: Defendant in Terror Trial Gets Access to Detainee
abstract: A federal judge in Manhattan cleared the way for a terrorism defendant’s lawyers to question, in writing, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 attack.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan on Wednesday cleared the way for a terrorism defendant’s lawyers to question, in writing, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 attacks, to see if his testimony might help their client’s case.

headline: The Clear Benefits of a Higher Wage
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: The benefits to millions of low-wage workers overwhelmingly outweigh the questionable possibility of job losses.
lead_paragraph: Republicans sputtered with outrage when the Congressional Budget Office said that immigration reform would lower the deficit, strengthen Social Security and speed up economic growth. They called for the office to be abolished when it dared to point out that tax cuts raise the deficit or when it highlighted the benefits of health care reform. But now that the budget office has predicted (and exaggerated) the possibility that an increase in the minimum wage might result in a loss of jobs, Republicans think it’s gospel.

headline: Violence in Ukraine Creates Deepening Clash Between East and West
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: As Russia denounced what it called a coup by extremists, the United States and Europe threatened to impose sanctions on those responsible for the violence — and each side accused the other of interference.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The two sides in what is developing into an East-West clash over Ukraine hardened their positions on Wednesday, with Russian officials denouncing what they called a coup by right-wing extremists, even as the United States and Europe threatened to impose sanctions on those responsible for the violence that has erupted in the capital, Kiev, and spread to other cities.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 19, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Figure Skaters Battle for Steady Nerves and Legs
abstract: Skaters in the Olympics can do the programs. They can land the jumps. It’s only their pesky nerves that get in the way.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Usually, the legs are the first to go. They get tight. Or turn into jelly. Or in the worst case, they are unable to move at all.

headline: Divorced From My Husband, and My Faith
abstract: I expected judgment and rebuke; instead, the rabbi told me a story.
lead_paragraph: I stood before the panel of rabbis, waiting to have a religious divorce conferred upon me. I was dressed as the Orthodox Jewish woman I was supposed to be, modestly, in a below-the-knee navy skirt and buttoned cardigan. But I felt exposed. What kind of shameful woman, I imagined the rabbis thinking, leaves her marriage; what kind of mother uproots her life?

headline: What to Watch: Thursday, Feb. 20
abstract: Canada will face the United States in the women’s hockey gold medal game, and the women’s free skate will be shown live in the morning and on tape in prime time.
lead_paragraph: WOMEN’S HOCKEY Canada and the United States traded wins and punches on their way to Sochi, but the Olympics have long been Canada’s turf. The Canadians have won the last three gold medals, and they have not lost a game at the Olympics since 1998. They also beat the Americans, 3-2, in the teams’ first-round meeting here. So the gold is Canada’s to lose. But it can happen. The last team to beat the Canadians at the Olympics? The United States, in the gold medal game in Nagano. NBC, noon

headline: Federal Lawsuit Accuses For-Profit Schools of Fraud
keywords: ['For-Profit Schools', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Vocational Training', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Community Colleges']
abstract: Former employees of the Premier Education Group say officials falsified records to keep students enrolled in order to secure government grant and loan money.
lead_paragraph: LINWOOD, N.J. — It was the electronic monitor around a student’s ankle that first gave Kelli J. Amaya serious doubts about the Harris School of Business.

headline: Getting Stares on the Streets of Cambodia: Buses for the Masses
abstract: Phnom Penh is experimenting with a public transportation system, beginning with 10 buses, in a program underwritten by the Japanese government.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — This city of nearly two million people has many of the amenities of a modern metropolis — broadband Internet, automated teller machines and fancy restaurants, to name a few. But until this month, the capital of Cambodia had no public transportation system. To get around, residents had to inure themselves to perilous rides on motorcycle taxis or dust-smothered commutes in open three-wheeled tuk-tuks.

headline: In Mexico Meeting, a Show of Friendship With Few Results on Immigration and Trade
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'International Relations', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: At a summit meeting, President Obama and his Mexican and Canadian counterparts promised enduring cooperation, but the show of friendship did not mask the stress points.
lead_paragraph: TOLUCA, Mexico — They call it the “Three Amigos” summit meeting, and President Obama and his Mexican and Canadian counterparts played their parts on Wednesday. They shared a lunch, joshed about the Olympics, promised enduring cooperation, and took a staged stroll through a botanical garden, complete with requisite smiles for the cameras.

headline: Paul Colby, Whose Club Helped Fuel Greenwich Village’s Rise, Dies at 96
abstract: Mr. Colby was a longtime owner of the Bitter End, a music club where young performers like Bob Dylan, Joni Mitchell, Billy Crystal and countless others were first showcased.
lead_paragraph: Paul Colby, the owner since 1974 of the Bitter End, a celebrated coffeehouse-cum-nightclub that helped make Greenwich Village a legendary place by showcasing young performers like Bob Dylan, Joni Mitchell, Billy Crystal and countless others, died on Feb. 13 at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 96.

headline: University of Maryland Computer Breach Exposes Records of Students and Staff
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: The university is the latest victim of a sophisticated cyberattack that compromised Social Security numbers, birth dates and names for 300,000 students, faculty and staff.
lead_paragraph: The University of Maryland said on Wednesday that more than 300,000 records for students, faculty and staff were stolen in a sophisticated cyberattack.

headline: 57 Bits of Emotional Knowledge
abstract: Caryl Churchill’s new play, “Love and Information,” unfolds with miniplots that deal with the ways we lust for, process and reject knowledge.
lead_paragraph: Tell me. I want to know. I need to know. I have to know. Oh, I’m sorry you told me. I wish I didn’t know that.

headline: Millard Fillmore and Company
abstract: A Thursday puzzle out of the woodwork from Zhouqin Burnikel and Don Gagliardo.
lead_paragraph: Ulysses. Abraham. Millard. Be it here resolved that the presidents of the United States have had some pretty rad first names. It’s a topic that comes up in this puzzle, coming as it does just on the heels of Presidents Day. You’ll have to flip through your mental Rolodex of commanders-in-chief to come up with the one name that will explain today’s theme.

headline: Phnom Penh’s First Buses
abstract: A Japanese-sponsored pilot project introduced a bus service to the chaotic streets of the capital of Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: A Japanese-sponsored pilot project introduced a bus service to the chaotic streets of the capital of Cambodia.

headline: Mike Stepovich, Who Led Alaska to Statehood, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Stepovich was the last presidentially appointed governor of the Territory of Alaska and also helped lobby Congress for statehood.
lead_paragraph: Mike Stepovich, the last presidentially appointed governor of the Territory of Alaska, who helped lobby Congress for statehood, died on Friday in San Diego. He was 94.

headline: 3 Opposed First-Degree Murder Conviction in Florida Trial, Juror Says
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Jury System', 'Self-Defense']
abstract: Fellow jurors believed Michael Dunn acted in self-defense in a dispute with four teenagers over loud music, she said.
lead_paragraph: A juror in the Florida trial of a man who fatally shot a teenager in a dispute over loud music said in an interview broadcast Tuesday that three jurors believed the gunman had acted in self-defense, which negated any chance of a first-degree murder conviction.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 20, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, February 20, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I have lost any desire to stay here any longer. There is no sense to stay. As for me, the Olympic flame can be put down as well.”

headline: Yahoo Introduces Service for Buying Mobile Ads
abstract: The new service, Yahoo Gemini, is an online marketplace for buying mobile search and so-called native advertisements.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo introduced a new service for companies to buy different forms of mobile advertising, as it seeks to build its clout in two increasingly important parts of the advertising business.

headline: California Health Insurance Enrollments Rise, but Hispanics Still Lag
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: The state-run online marketplace did not offer applications in Spanish until late December, and a Spanish-language site was dogged by translation errors.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With six weeks left in the open enrollment period for insurance under President Obama’s health care law, more than 828,000 Californians have signed up for private coverage through the state’s online health care exchange, state officials announced Wednesday.

headline: F.B.I. Papers Yield Clues in Vanishing of Civil Rights Activist
abstract: The disappearance of Ray Robinson is one of the enduring mysteries of the bloody siege staged by American Indian activists in South Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Cheryl Robinson says she has waited more than four decades to find out what happened to her husband, an Alabama civil rights activist who disappeared, and now she thinks she has at least the beginning of an answer.

headline: Shumpert Hurts Knee Amid Talk of a Trade
abstract: Carmelo Anthony scored 13 of the Knicks’ final 15 points in a victory that was overshadowed by an injury to Iman Shumpert, whom the team viewed as a marketable trade asset.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Iman Shumpert had a bad day. It started with seeing his name in trade reports, and about an hour before the Knicks faced the Pelicans on Wednesday night, Shumpert acknowledged what everyone else was thinking: that the game had the potential to be his final one with the Knicks. All he could do, he said, was play.

headline: Animal Prints in Living Color
abstract: The resort collections featured softly colorful reinterpretations of classic wildlife spots.
lead_paragraph: For resort, designers offered up a delightfully fresh interpretation of classic animal prints, switching the expected natural colors for a rainbow-hued, yet slightly subdued, palette. A zesty shade of lime adds punch to a sweater from Equipment and bag from Valentino, while cool-toned touches look refreshing on a phone case from Marc Jacobs, a ring from Marc Alary and brogues from Robert Clergerie. Acidic shades of apple liven up a DSquared2 slingback and Eugène Riconneaus skate deck, while Amaya Arzuaga’s draped miniskirt with lemon-speckled spots lets the print whisper and the silhouette roar.

headline: Colorado: New Psychiatric Exam Is Ordered for Theater Gunman
abstract: A judge on Wednesday ordered a new psychiatric examination for James E. Holmes, who killed 12 people in an Aurora theater in 2012, saying that an earlier evaluation by a state doctor was “incomplete and inadequate.”
lead_paragraph: A judge on Wednesday ordered a new psychiatric examination for James E. Holmes, who killed 12 people in an Aurora theater in 2012, saying that an earlier evaluation by a state doctor was “incomplete and inadequate.” The ruling, by Judge Carlos A. Samour, orders the state mental hospital to have a new mental-health expert examine Mr. Holmes and offer an opinion on whether he was sane on the night of the shooting. Mr. Holmes’s lawyers have admitted he was the gunman, but argue he is not guilty by reason of insanity. The exam is to be completed by July 11, further delaying the trial.

headline: Nebraska: Judge Blocks Pipeline Route
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: A judge on Wednesday blocked the Keystone XL pipeline’s planned route through the state, a new hurdle for the embattled project.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Wednesday blocked the Keystone XL pipeline’s planned route through the state, a new hurdle for the embattled project. The judge, Stephanie F. Stacy of the Third Judicial District Court, ruled that the law giving Gov. Dave Heineman, a Republican, the authority to approve a crude oil pipeline was unconstitutional. The governor said he would appeal. The proposed pipeline from Canadian oil sands in Alberta to Gulf Coast refineries has become a touchstone fight for environmentalists, and the State Department is considering whether to allow it to cross the border.

headline: Airlines Warned of Possible Shoe Bombs
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The Department of Homeland Security alerted airlines on Wednesday to a possible new threat from shoe bombs and urged carriers to pay extra attention to flights arriving from overseas.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security alerted airlines on Wednesday to a possible new threat from shoe bombs and urged carriers to pay extra attention to flights arriving from overseas. Intelligence officials recently detected what they considered credible warnings of terrorist efforts to strike passenger jets using explosives concealed in shoes. The threat information, first reported by NBC News, was not related to any particular airline, country or date, the officials said.

headline: Elton John and Kanye West Among Performers Set for Bonnaroo Festival
abstract: The Tennessee festival in June will also include Jack White, Lauryn Hill and Neutral Milk Hotel.
lead_paragraph: It could be, like the man sang in “Bennie and the Jets,” weird and wonderful, or it could be just plain weird. But either way, Elton John will be one of the headlining performers at this year’s Bonnaroo festival, its organizers said on Wednesday, after several days of rumors that that best-selling pop pianist and showman would make a rare appearance at this annual outdoor music and comedy event in Manchester, Tenn. He’ll have no shortage of competition for most outrageous eyewear at Bonnaroo, which will run from June 12 through June 15, and will also see Kanye West, Jack White, and Lionel Richie atop the bill. Other artists on the lineup, which is expected to include more than 125 bands, are Vampire Weekend, Ms. Lauryn Hill, Skrillex, Damon Albarn, Arctic Monkeys, Frank Ocean, Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds, Ice Cube, Wiz Khalifa and Neutral Milk Hotel. The announced comedians include Taran Killam of “Saturday Night Live” and Hannibal Buress, the standup comic and co-star of “Broad City.” More information can be found at the festival’s official website, bonnaroo.com.
