headline: Sochi Under Siege
abstract: Built on corruption, run by repression, the Winter Games are a microcosm of Putin’s Russia.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — ON Feb. 7, the opening day of the Olympics, several people walked out onto Red Square in Moscow. When they attempted to sing the Russian national anthem, all were arrested and taken to the nearest police station. “We were holding small rainbow flags to show support for the L.G.B.T. community,” wrote my protester friend, who found herself taken into custody for the first time in her life.

headline: How Obamacare Could Unlock Job Opportunities
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: By redistributing financial risk, the new health-insurance system might prove a boon to entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: During college, Lauren Braun worked at a health clinic in Peru, where she spent an inordinate amount of time tracking down mothers in an effort to get them to bring their children in for vaccinations. The experience was frustrating, but through it Braun came up with a business plan: Make silicone bracelets that function as punch cards, to remind mothers about upcoming appointments. Back in the United States, she consulted with mentors and perfected the idea, but then, she set it aside after graduation, going to work for a large health-insurance company, taking a salary and benefits over the uncertain life of an entrepreneur.

headline: This Ain’t No Disco. It’s a Photograph.
abstract: While Studio 54 dazzled New York in the late 1970s, Tod Papageorge braved the miasma of pleasure-seeking to make clear pictures that had an authority to match his bulky camera.
lead_paragraph: A paradox of Studio 54 was that it was both the most exclusive party in town, stopping all but the chosen few at its impenetrable velvet rope, and the most accessible, bombarding the public with images of the glitterati and the high life inside. The club was a fantasy about which it was not necessary to fantasize, since torrents of ink and celebrity photographs did the work for you. If you wanted to know what it was like to rub shoulders (or more) with Halston or Liza or Name-Your-Boldface-Name, you could pick up a magazine that chronicled the rubbing. It was not just a place to see and be seen. In the miasma of sex and fame and money and pleasure that swirled around New York in the late 1970s, it was a place to be photographed, mass-produced and consumed as a shimmering commodity.

headline: Deal Reached to Resume Expansion of Panama Canal
abstract: Work on the expansion was set to start again on Thursday after the builders and the canal authority agreed on a way to pay suppliers.
lead_paragraph: Work on the planned expansion of the Panama Canal was set to resume on Thursday after the construction consortium and the canal authorities reached a preliminary accord to pay suppliers and put an end to their dispute over $1.6 billion of cost overruns.

headline: Should Terminally Ill Patients Be Allowed to Die on Their Own Terms?
abstract: When patients and their families want it, should doctors be allowed to end a patient’s life by some painless means?
lead_paragraph: When the term “assisted suicide” is used, many people think it should be illegal. But when “aid in dying” and “death with dignity” are used instead, support increases dramatically. But no matter what we call the practice, the idea is still the same. A small group of people face an outlook of imminent suffering and death. Should they have the option to end their life on their own terms?

headline: Facebook’s $16 Billion Deal for WhatsApp
abstract: Facebook scoops up WhatsApp, a text messaging application with 450 million global users, for at least $16 billion in cash and stock. | The supermarket chain Safeway is exploring a sale of the company to private equity. | Harvard lands its largest gift ever, $150 million, from the hedge fund founder Kenneth C. Griffin. | The Winklevoss twins create a financial index called the Winkdex that will provide a regularly updated figure for the price of Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: BIG DEAL: FACEBOOK BUYS WHATSAPP FOR $16 BILLION  |  When Facebook offered to buy Snapchat last year for $3 billion, the messaging app turned Facebook down. So this time, Facebook made it harder for its target to say no. On Wednesday, Facebook announced it would acquire WhatsApp, a text messaging application with 450 million users, for at least $16 billion in cash and stock, its largest acquisition by far and one that represents a new height in the frenzy to acquire popular technology start-ups, David Gelles and Vindu Goel write in DealBook.

headline: Seeking a Break in a 252 Million-Year-Old Mass Killing
abstract: An M.I.T. geologist wants to understand how an estimated 96 percent of all species on Earth became extinct at the end of the Permian Period 252 million years ago.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bowring is officially a geologist at M.I.T. Unofficially, he’s a homicide detective trying to solve the ultimate cold case. Dr. Bowring wants to understand how an estimated 96 percent of all species on Earth became extinct at the end of the Permian Period 252 million years ago. It was the biggest of the five mass extinctions recorded in the fossil record. But because this killing happened so long ago, the culprit has evaded discovery for decades.

headline: Zachary’s First Shiva

headline: Confusion and Courage at Olustee
abstract: On a north Florida battlefield, black soldiers once again proved their worth to the Union cause.
lead_paragraph: “We [are] off on another tramp,” Cpl. James Henry Gooding reported to the readers of his hometown newspaper on Feb. 8, 1864, “but with no knowledge of our destination.” His regiment, the 54th Massachusetts, the first regiment of African-American troops recruited from the Northern states, had won fame six months earlier when they attacked Fort Wagner on the South Carolina coast. Since then, they had been involved in mundane siege operations around Charleston, and morale was sinking. However, now that they were aboard steamers heading south, Gooding noted, “the excitement on board” was “intense.”

headline: Learning to Deal With Billboards
abstract: Lo-Fang, whose real name is Matthew Hemerlein, has a new album coming out, is opening for Lorde and trying to define the sound of the decade.
lead_paragraph: “It’s really fast,” Matthew Hemerlein, an electronic pop musician who records under the name Lo-Fang, said of his recent career trajectory. In the next month, he’ll release his debut album, “Blue Film”; appear on the ABC drama “Revenge”; perform on the “Late Show With David Letterman”— oh, and he’ll be opening for Lorde, the 17-year old Grammy winner, who handpicked him for a tour that kicks off on March 3. (They’ll be at the Roseland Ballroom in New York on March 10, 11 and 12.)

headline: Milan Fashion Week Street Style: Day 1
abstract: Street-style photos from our NYTimesFashion Instagram account.
lead_paragraph: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for Milan Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

headline: Things You Don't Know: Freeskiing
abstract: Freeskiing, which includes halfpipe and slopestyle events, is new to the Olympics this year. Skiers say the sport is different from any other.
lead_paragraph: Freeskiing, which includes halfpipe and slopestyle events, is new to the Olympics this year. Skiers say the sport is different from any other.

headline: Valentine’s Day: Outside the Chocolate Box
abstract: We invited readers to show us the unique ways in which they (single or coupled) celebrate the day of love. Here, a selection of photos.
lead_paragraph: We invited readers to show us the unique ways in which they (single or coupled) celebrate the day of love. Here, a selection of photos.

headline: Live Stream | Prada’s Fall 2014 Collection at Milan Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Prada at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The latest women’s collection from Prada at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Europe Plans New Limits on Aid to Money-Losing Regional Airports
abstract: The overhaul follows more than a decade of breakneck expansion in European air traffic, led by budget airlines like Ryanair and EasyJet.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European Commission announced new limits Thursday on the amount of financial aid that member states can provide to money-losing regional airports, a move that could eventually lead to higher fares for passengers traveling to some out-of-the way terminals served by low-cost carriers.

headline: NBC Expects Record Online Viewership for U.S.-Canada Semifinal
abstract: Officials at the network are expressing concern that demand for its live stream of Friday’s game could slow the nation’s office computer networks.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 800,000 people watched an Internet live stream of the United States’ 5-2 victory over the Czech Republic on Wednesday in men’s ice hockey at the Winter Olympics, NBC officials began to wonder how many more would stream the United States-Canada semifinal Friday.

headline: Darkness Arrives Onstage
abstract: Berg’s “Wozzeck” will return to the Metropolitan Opera with James Levine at the helm, and Matthias Goerne and Deborah Voigt in the lead roles.
lead_paragraph: Few operas are as challenging, or as cathartic, as Berg’s “Wozzeck,” the 1925 setting of Georg Büchner’s play about an army private driven by poverty, illness and countless acts of humiliation, to murder Marie, his common-law wife. With its atonal score, poured into traditional forms that are as concise as they are eloquent, and passages of speechlike singing, it’s the early masterwork that defined and in many ways dominated 20th-century opera.

headline: Today in Small Business: No Exit
abstract: Unlocking entrepreneurship. Why Facebook may NOT have paid too much. And have you met Entrepreneur Barbie?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small business owners today?

headline: Guantánamo Detainee Pleads Guilty in 2002 Attack on Tanker Off Yemen
abstract: The plea deal means that Ahmed Muhammed Haza al-Darbi will spend at least three and a half more years on Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, before he is sentenced, and then most likely transferred to Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — A Saudi detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, pleaded guilty on Thursday before a military commission to terrorism-related offenses involving a 2002 attack by Al Qaeda on a French-flagged oil tanker off the coast of Yemen. The plea deal will give him a specific sentence and a prospect of leaving the American military prison, where he has been held in indefinite detention.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Max Mara Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Iran’s Judiciary Closes a New Pro-Government Newspaper
abstract: The closing seemed aimed at preventing the government from having any news media outlets other than its official newspaper and news agency.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — An Iranian newspaper aligned with the country’s reform-minded new president was closed on Thursday by Iran’s judiciary, only six days after its first issue, local news outlets reported.

headline: Graham Center Gets $1 Million for Dance Archive
abstract: The Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance will use a grant from the Mellon Foundation to help preserve choreography on Graham dances.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest revolutions in the dance world over the past century has been the use of technology to help preserve choreography and pass it on from one generation to the next. The Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance announced Thursday that its efforts in that direction had received a major boost: a $1 million grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation that will allow it to build on, digitize and organize its archive of materials on Graham dances.

headline: A Look Inside Prada's Milan Boutique
abstract: As part of Milan Fashion Week, the brand’s boutique reopens with a Harlem Renaissance-inspired design.
lead_paragraph: As part of Milan Fashion Week, the brand’s boutique reopens with a Harlem Renaissance-inspired design.

headline: Times Minute | Truce Shatters in Ukraine
abstract: The truce in Ukraine is shattered by battle. Also on the Minute, why the Affordable Care Act can create job opportunities and a new wave of sophisticated home surveillance.
lead_paragraph: The truce in Ukraine is shattered by battle. Also on the Minute, why the Affordable Care Act can create job opportunities and a new wave of sophisticated home surveillance.

headline: Times Minute | Truce Shatters in Ukraine
abstract: The truce in Ukraine is shattered by battle. Also on the Minute, why the Affordable Care Act can create job opportunities, and a new wave of sophisticated home surveillance.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: India’s Upper House Approves Creation of New State
abstract: After hours of shouting and chanting, lawmakers passed a bill creating the state of Telangana.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After hours of shouting, paper-shredding and chanting in India’s upper house of Parliament, lawmakers on Thursday passed a bill creating a 29th state by dividing Andhra Pradesh, a large southern state, in two.

headline: Hey, You Guys, Come and See This!
abstract: “Bronx Bombers,” “Kung Fu” and “Rocky” are among the new shows looking to attract more men to their audiences.
lead_paragraph: Roughly two-thirds of the theatergoers at Broadway shows are female, a disparity that many producers have tried to address. With its mullets and strip clubs, the hair-metal jukebox musical “Rock of Ages” made some progress in attracting men in 2009, and shows like “The Book of Mormon” and “That Championship Season” have aggressively courted them since. Several contenders on and Off Broadway are vying for the male demographic this season, flinging enough testosterone to make that Super Bowl takeover of Times Square look like a pillow fight. Still, by the final round (hint), the title belt (hint hint) for Ultimate Guy Show can go to just one contender, shadowboxing alone at the top of the TKTS steps (hint).

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Fendi Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Early Shot at Redemption for U.S. Hockey Team
abstract: The American men, who face Canada on Friday in a semifinal, have waited four years for a chance to unseat their North American rival.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The groom has fled the altar, leaving a jilted Russia, which paid $51 billion for the once-in-a-lifetime ceremony, only to watch one of the four groomsmen, none with blood ties, commandeer the celebration.

headline: Parting Glance: Frank Espada
abstract: Frank Espada, a photographer, community activist and teacher, died this week. He left behind the masterwork “The Puerto Rican Diaspora” and many grateful friends.
lead_paragraph: I went to El Barrio this week thinking of Frank Espada. On blocks where renovated tenements stood alongside luxury high-rises, I strained to imagine what he had witnessed more than a half-century earlier, before anyone thought this stretch of Manhattan would sit in the cross hairs of gentrification. When it was home to people like him, who came to this frozen city, exiled from the verdant hills of Puerto Rico. When it was among the few havens for the dispossessed.

headline: An Open Letter on Homosexuality to My Fellow Scientists in Uganda
abstract: A geneticist explains why the science behind Uganda’s anti-gay law is all wrong.
lead_paragraph: President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda is about to sign into law a vehement anti-gay law after “medical experts presented a report that homosexuality is not genetic but a social behaviour,” according to a tweet from Ofwono Opondo, a Ugandan government spokesman. It is sad and ironic that Mr. Museveni will do so just as scientists at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science report that they have robustly confirmed my original finding of molecular linkage between male sexual orientation and a specific genetic region, Xq28.

headline: In Store | Prada’s Harlem Renaissance Homage
abstract: An exclusive video documents the fashion-week transformation of the brand’s Milan store into a lavish, Roaring Twenties-themed installation.
lead_paragraph: With its ongoing Iconoclasts project, Prada has commissioned some of the world’s top fashion stylists to reinvent its flagship stores with immersive themed installations. Tonight, as part of Milan Fashion Week, the brand’s boutique there reopens with a Harlem Renaissance-inspired design — complete with Art Deco bar and handpainted flapper mannequins — by the creative director Edward Enninful. Here, a video documents the process of transforming the space from minimalist gallery to lavish speakeasy — and provides an up-close look at the rich textures and details of Prada’s just-arrived spring collection.

headline: ‘Buyer & Cellar’ Gets a New Star
abstract: Christopher J. Hanke will take over the starring role, as Michael Urie starts a national tour.`
lead_paragraph: The Off Broadway understudy Clancy O’Connor drew attention and full audiences last month when he went on for Michael Urie in the hit play “Buyer & Cellar,” but he didn’t end up with the permanent gig when the time came to recast the one-man show. The producers announced on Thursday that Christopher J. Hanke, who played Bud Frump in the 2011 Broadway revival of “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,” will begin performances on March 18 as Alex More, a struggling actor who takes an unusual job working for Barbra Streisand.

headline: Parallels Seen in Two Jet Crashes in 2013
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board heard testimony about the use of a computer system that did not perform as the crew of a United Parcel Service cargo jet had planned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The crew of a U.P.S. cargo jet that crashed on approach to Birmingham, Ala., last August had planned to land by using a method that was rare for them, following a computer-generated path to give vertical guidance, according to testimony given Thursday at a National Transportation Safety Board hearing. But the crew changed its strategy in the last minutes because the onboard computer did not perform as they had planned, investigators said.

headline: Art Auctions Without the Attitude
abstract: At smaller auction houses a world away from the likes of Sotheby’s and Christies, there are lower prices and no air-kissing, but a clear love of art.
lead_paragraph: EILEEN OGLE of Brooklyn comes so often to shop at Hutter Auction Galleries on West 55th Street in Manhattan that she admits she may have a bit of “collectivitis.”

headline: Street Style in Shoreditch, London
abstract: Valery Demure, whose office is around the corner from the Broadway market, was recently perusing the stands with her daughter.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway Market and Columbia Flower Market in East London are vibrant weekend shopping hubs, where you can find anything from Cornish pasties to vintage clothing. The cobblestone streets are packed with merchants and shoppers until sunset, when the action moves to the pubs.

headline: Hotel Review: Shangri-La Toronto
abstract: A chic, Asian-accented approach to luxury city lodging.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Wall Street: Working for the Weekend or Through It?
abstract: Do you work on Wall Street as an analyst? Are you taking work-free weekends out of town? Or toiling as hard as ever? Share how this transition is going, and how you are spending your new-found free time (if you have it).
lead_paragraph: Last month, Bank of America Merrill Lynch told its junior bankers to take four days off a month, on the weekends. Credit Suisse discouraged its analysts and associates from working on Saturdays. Last year, Goldman Sachs recommended that its analysts take weekends off whenever possible.

headline: A Homey Addition to a Dallas Hotel
abstract: The Hotel ZaZa in Dallas has added 12 suites with wraparound porches; five of them have full kitchens.
lead_paragraph: Hotel ZaZa, the more-than-decade-old 165-room luxury hotel in the Arts District of Dallas, recently expanded with the Bungalows, a collection of 12 suites on a separate residential leafy street near the main property.

headline: Worst Spill in 6 Months Is Reported at Fukushima
abstract: About 100 tons of highly radioactive water leaked from one of the hundreds of storage tanks at the devastated Fukushima nuclear plant, its operator said.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — About 100 tons of highly radioactive water leaked from one of the hundreds of storage tanks at the devastated Fukushima nuclear plant, its operator said Thursday, calling the leak the worst spill at the plant in six months.

headline: Little Happens, but Much Changes
abstract: The intimacy of Luna Stage amplifies the penetrating examination of hatred in Athol Fugard’s 1982 play, set in 1950 in Port Elizabeth, South Africa.
lead_paragraph: More than 30 years since its premiere, Athol Fugard’s “ ‘Master Harold’ ... and the Boys” endures as an understated yet meaningful study in racism.

headline: Sid Caesar on Dick Cavett
abstract: The comedian, in character, during one of his “good” periods.
lead_paragraph: The comedian, in character, during one of his “good” periods.

headline: Promotion for CBS’s Head of Programming
abstract: Nina Tassler, who introduced a string of successful comedies, was named chairman of CBS Entertainment, with a contract through 2017.
lead_paragraph: CBS rewarded its long-time programming president, Nina Tassler, with a new contract and a new title Thursday, elevating her to chairwoman of CBS Entertainment.

headline: The Other Big Winner in the WhatsApp Deal: Your Wallet
abstract: By helping people bypass exorbitant texting fees charged by mobile carriers, WhatsApp saved heavy users of texting a lot of money. There’s a larger lesson here for all telecom carriers.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s acquisition of WhatsApp for at least $16 billion has minted dozens of new millionaires and billionaires this week, but there was another big winner in the deal: Parents and their teenage children, who have most likely saved hundreds or even thousands of dollars in texting fees thanks to the hugely popular messaging app, and will continue to do so after the deal.

headline: No, Employment Protections Aren’t Like Segregation
abstract: Some conservatives think the Employment Nondiscrimination Act creates “special privileges” for gays and lesbians.
lead_paragraph: Since the 1960s federal law has recognized various protected classes. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 made it illegal to discriminate on the basis of race, color or religion; the 1990 Disabilities Act on the basis of disability. It should be screamingly obvious that a “protected” class isn’t a “privileged” class — but apparently it isn’t.

headline: A Digitally Printed, Star Studded, Cashmere Scarf
abstract: Benjamin Seidler, a 27-year-old designer, beautifully illustrates cashmere scarves for the decades-old British luxury goods house Asprey.
lead_paragraph: The heritage brand Asprey has been around since 1781 and is best known for its mega-watt jewelry. But in recent years, the company has recruited a slew of fresh design talent to reinvigorate the brand, a roster that includes Shaun Leane, Katie Hillier and, most recently, Asprey’s newest contributing designer Benjamin Seidler.

headline: Vampires and Aging Rockers Make the Cut for New Directors/New Films
abstract: The complete lineup of the annual series is announced.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:20 p.m. | It’s a moody forecast for this year’s New Directors/New Films series. The complete lineup, announced Wednesday by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, includes an eclectic mix of 40 features and shorts ranging from the tale of a bloodthirsty teenager to a documentary about modern colonialism in war-torn Sudan and a semi-factual look into the life of an aging rocker.

headline: Jonathan Martin and the Soft, White, Private School Question
abstract: Jonathan Martin blames “soft” schools and “white private school conditioning” for part of his trouble in dealing with N.F.L. bullying. Those are loaded terms to parents and educators.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. lineman Jonathan Martin encountered a Miami Dolphins team culture that was sick at its core. But was his private-school upbringing partly responsible for his inability to cope with the locker-room bullying he encountered there?

headline: Every Women’s Figure Skating Jump, on One Page
abstract: Adelina Sotnikova, the 17-year-old gold medal winner from Russia, skated a more difficult program than the South Korean Kim Yu-na, who took silver.
lead_paragraph: Adelina Sotnikova, the 17-year-old gold medal winner from Russia, skated a more difficult program than the South Korean Kim Yu-na, who took silver.

headline: Miuccia Prada’s Powerhouse
abstract: The designer’s winter 2014 collection offers women a choice.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — “It’s a mix of the sophisticated and things that look plain vulgar,” Miuccia Prada said backstage, pulling forward a glitzy oversized blazer before greeting the front row guests Valentino Garavani and Giancarlo Giammetti. They were treated to the designer wiggling the crystal fringes on her Miu Miu skirt.

headline: Letter From Hackley to Alumni
abstract: Read the letter sent from Hackley to alumni regarding allegations of sexual abuse in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Read the letter sent from Hackley to alumni regarding allegations of sexual abuse in the 1960s.

headline: 36 Hours in Upper Manhattan
abstract: Museums and music, cocktails and cuisine, history and Hudson River views are all part of a weekend in this richly textured part of the city.
lead_paragraph: In the 18th century, the northern half of Manhattan Island served as a bucolic escape for New Yorkers with the cash to afford it and the horse and carriage to get them there. It’s easier to visit these days (the A train to Harlem being the most famous of many routes) and easier to get around, with the city’s newfangled green cabs in abundance in neighborhoods where yellow cabs have always been scarce. There’s also a whole lot more to do these days. Harlem, the Dutch settlement that became the black capital of America, is in the throes of gentrification: a mix of old and new, from gospel-filled black church services to fine cocktail bars abuzz with young professionals of all races. Meanwhile, farther north, between the island’s oldest surviving house and its largest swath of never developed land, is a Latino neighborhood the likes of which you can no longer find south of Central Park.

headline: Escaping to the Cloisters
abstract: A visit to this branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art could make you forget you’re in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A visit to this branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art could make you forget you’re in Manhattan.

headline: The Gun Report: February 20, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: • Trustees at Occidental College in Los Angeles are pledging to stay away from any investments in companies that manufacture military-style assault weapons and high-capacity ammunition magazines for public sale. The recent move came at the urging of faculty members, who were horrified by the Newtown massacre. The college, President Obama’s alma mater, found that its endowment does not have investments in companies that manufacture such weapons for public sale, and its board of trustees voted to ensure it stays that way. “It’s a statement of principle about the mission of higher education to be a voice of reason in a world of a lot of violence,” said Occidental politics professor Peter Dreier, who was a prime mover on the issue.

headline: ‘Frozen’ and the Art of Breathing in Animation
abstract: The animators talked with Idina Menzel to better understand singers’ complicated breathwork. But new problems cropped up when clothes were added to the characters.
lead_paragraph: Animating snow is no easy feat, as the creators of Disney’s “Frozen” discovered sort of late in the process: do it wrong and it winds up looking like “Styrofoam packing peanuts,” as Chris Buck, a director of the movie, put it.

headline: Music at Minton’s
abstract: Drop in for a set or supper at this Harlem spot.
lead_paragraph: Drop in for a set or supper at this Harlem spot.

headline: Eating at Margot Restaurant
abstract: This spot in Upper Manhattan draws loyal diners for its Dominican cooking.
lead_paragraph: This spot in Upper Manhattan draws loyal diners for its Dominican cooking.

headline: Russian Is Surprise Winner in Women’s Figure Skating
abstract: Adelina Sotnikova used a boost from the crowd to become the first Russian woman to win gold in singles figure skating, knocking Kim Yu-na off her perch at the top of the sport.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Many expected a Russian to win a gold medal in women’s figure skating at the Sochi Games, but hardly anyone expected that it would be Adelina Sotnikova.

headline: Romantic Fendi
abstract: The collection by Karl Lagerfeld and Silvia Venturini Fendi was witty, furry, sporty and from the heart.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — A furry monster dangled from the model’s hand at the start of Fendi’s show in Milan on Thursday. It had white hair with a punk Mohawk tip in pink, a stiff white high collar and a black necktie above a gray fur jacket.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: dogs, cats and adrenaline junkies. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: dogs, cats and adrenaline junkies. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: BBVA Buys Banking Start-Up Simple for $117 Million
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Start-ups']
abstract: The online banking start-up Simple, which seeks to distinguish itself from traditional banks by eschewing fees and offering its customers data-rich analysis of their transactions, is selling itself to a giant of European finance.
lead_paragraph: The online banking start-up Simple, which seeks to distinguish itself from traditional banks by eschewing fees and offering its customers data-rich analysis of their transactions, is selling itself to a giant of European finance.

headline: Masterpieces in Miniature
abstract: An exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich displays compelling dioramas that are part paintings, part sculptures and part essays in art history.
lead_paragraph: Black-and-white floor tiles at his feet, brass chandelier overhead, work table at his left, an artist in 17th-century pantaloons sits at his easel with his back to us, a beret cocked smartly on his head, a brush lightly grasped in his right hand. His model, her satiny blue robe aglow in the angled light, stands in front of the large creased map hanging on the wall.

headline: Where It’s All Served Sotto Voce
abstract: The half-secret Wallflower in the West Village is where you go for a rendezvous or lying low.
lead_paragraph: Wallflower lies in the shadows just off Greenwich Avenue, without a sign, barely exhaling light. Inside, the space is tight in that way called bijou, two brief rooms under a tin ceiling painted gold, requiring you to lean close to your companions and reminding you that New York really does live up to its myth, as a city of half-secret places like this one.

headline: Prada: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Liverpool and Manchester City Will Play at Yankee Stadium
abstract: The summer exhibition is part of a multicity preseason tournament featuring some of Europe’s top soccer clubs.
lead_paragraph: Liverpool and Manchester City will play at Yankee Stadium on July 30 as part of a multicity preseason tournament featuring some of Europe’s top soccer clubs.

headline: Fei Fei Sun Transforms Backstage at Max Mara
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Fei Fei Sun (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Luigi Murenu.

headline: Herbalife to Make Presentation to Lawmakers
abstract: The nutritional supplements company will conduct a briefing on Friday to educate congressional staff members about its business in what appears to be an effort to increase its lobbying efforts in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:37 p.m. | Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company, will conduct a briefing on Friday to educate congressional staff members about its business in what appears to be an effort to ramp up its lobbying efforts in Washington.

headline: Quinoa Spaghetti With Cauliflower, Almonds, Tomatoes and Chickpeas
abstract: Cauliflower is often matched with pasta in Italy; this version is all about texture.
lead_paragraph: Pasta with cauliflower comes in many variations throughout Italy. This one is all about texture — crunchy almonds, tender (but not mushy) cauliflower and plush chickpeas.

headline: Living With Cancer: Wigged Out
abstract: Dealing with hair loss also can mean accepting a new persona, writes Susan Gubar.
lead_paragraph: The targeted cancer drug extending my life is killing my hair. Especially at the top of my head, a beige scalp gleams through sparse black and white wires. For obvious reasons, I’m not complaining.

headline: Public Sector Cuts Part-Time Shifts to Bypass Insurance Law
keywords: ['Part-Time Employment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Government Employees', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Cities, counties and public schools, lacking the option of passing along increased costs to consumers, are drawing a line at 30 hours.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Cities, counties, public schools and community colleges around the country have limited or reduced the work hours of part-time employees to avoid having to provide them with health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, state and local officials say.

headline: An Exhibition With a Sweet Spot for Sound
abstract: Visitors can hear as well as see the artwork of a longtime faculty member in the exhibition “David Jacobs: Sight and Sound” at Hofstra.
lead_paragraph: Talk to David Jacobs about his sound sculptures — tall, columnar forms that make up about half the exhibition of his work now at Hofstra University’s Emily Lowe Gallery — and you might also find yourself discussing vacuum cleaners, in his life and his art.

headline: WhatsApp and the Rage for Eyeballs
abstract: Startup technology companies are often valued on the basis of how many active users they have.
lead_paragraph: As I read about Facebook’s acquisition of the messaging service WhatsApp, one word kept coming to mind: eyeballs.

headline: Letters: ‘Inside a Pearl,’ and More
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Edmund White’s “Inside a Pearl,” the love-themed issue of the Book Review and more.
lead_paragraph: His Majesty

headline: Canadian Women Rally to Beat U.S. in Overtime for Hockey Gold
abstract: The United States, trying to end Canada’s streak of three consecutive Olympic championships, had a 2-0 lead with four minutes left in regulation but lost in overtime.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The decisive goal in Canada’s 3-2 overtime victory against the United States in the Olympic women’s hockey final Thursday night could not have been diagramed on a whiteboard any better. Never mind that it was not the play Canada’s coach, Kevin Dineen, had drawn up. Who was he to complain?

headline: Restaurant Review: Bones in Paris
abstract: An Australian chef brings a little Brooklynesque touch to eastern Paris with a scaled-down restaurant that’s stripped to the...you know.
lead_paragraph: In the last few years, Paris, particularly in the eastern arrondissements, has had a miniboom of laid-back, tiny, Brooklyn-meets-bistronomique restaurants. Not surprisingly, the chef is often not native to France. Although many local food lovers are already bemoaning the trend, these kitchens are still going strong. One of the most lively of the bunch is Bones, which opened in January 2013, a small dining room on two levels, overseen by James Henry, a 32-year-old Australian chef.

headline: For Christie, Awkward Return to a Setting He Once Ruled
abstract: The first town-hall-style meeting for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey since controversy enveloped his administration showed how difficult it may be for him to recreate political magic.
lead_paragraph: PORT MONMOUTH, N.J. — When Chris Christie started to talk over a complaining questioner, a signature tactic of the bellicose, pre-scandal governor, the audience here briefly turned on him.

headline: Life Unleashed
abstract: In Lorrie Moore’s first collection of stories in 16 years, her characters still use humor to deal with dread.
lead_paragraph: “Bark” is the first collection of stories in 16 years by Lorrie Moore, and I’ll admit that when I first saw its modest size and table of contents — eight stories? one every two years? — I felt let down. I would have traded her moving but relatively conventional 2009 novel, “A Gate at the Stairs,” for a horse-choking stack of 15 long, dense stories, each with the specific gravity (and the desperate levity) of “People Like That Are the Only People Here,” the astonishing centerpiece of her previous collection, “Birds of America.” But I was wrong! (Moore is one of the all-time great deployers of the exclamation point, that cheap and skinny punctuational powerhouse — she’s also a great deployer of the epithet — so I thought I’d try one and see how it felt. Felt transgressive!)

headline: Madame Secretary
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: An admiring account of Hillary Clinton’s years at the State Department.
lead_paragraph: On the day Hillary Clinton returned to Capitol Hill after losing the 2008 Democratic nomination for president, her staff donned sweatbands and gym shorts and staged a Ping-Pong tournament in her office to cheer her up. Frustrated at the way Barack Obama had left her in the technological dust, she turned herself into a digitally charged secretary of state, champ­ioning the use of Twitter for diplomacy and once telling a group of technology executives, “Use me like an app.”

headline: Turkish Beyond the Facade
abstract: There is more to Ephesus’s cuisine and décor than its modest storefront exterior suggests.
lead_paragraph: Ephesus, a modest storefront a stone’s throw from the Massapequa Park railroad station, has the best Turkish food I’ve had outside Turkey. It beats out all the well-regarded Turkish restaurants I’ve been to in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

headline: Buoyed by Olympics, Fallon’s Ratings Stay Strong
abstract: The audience for the “Tonight” show, hosted by Jimmy Fallon, was 7.3 million on Wednesday, the same as the night before.
lead_paragraph: NBC’s strategy of starting Jimmy Fallon’s “Tonight” show following its Olympics coverage appears to be working, as the third night of the new version of the show improved modestly over its second night, defying the usual pattern of a steady falloff in ratings after a premiere.

headline: Tragedy and Farce
abstract: From the collapse of the Soviet Union to Pussy Riot, two journalists examine the paradoxes of modern Russia.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Feifer’s “Russians: The People Behind the Power” joins a list of classic books by Western correspondents who have covered the politics and culture of what was once the Soviet Union. ­Hedrick Smith, Robert G. Kaiser, David K. Shipler and David Remnick, among others, wrote acclaimed accounts of what they witnessed as the Soviet Union first challenged the West and then gradually collapsed under the weight of a sclerotic regime. In August 1991, Feifer was an undergraduate spending a summer in Moscow when a group of hard-line Communist officials tried to carry out a coup in a last-ditch effort to prolong Soviet rule. Their failure only sped up the process of dissolution and led to an initial period of such euphoria that many people inside and outside the country believed — as did Feifer himself — that “the U.S.S.R. would be a part of the international community, enjoying the West’s previously unimaginable freedom and prosperity.”

headline: Freezing January for Easterners Was Not Felt Round the World
abstract: Despite ice storms in the American South, it was the fourth-warmest January on record for the earth as a whole.
lead_paragraph: For people throughout the Eastern United States who spent January slipping, sliding and shivering, here is a counterintuitive fact: For the earth as a whole, it was the fourth-warmest January on record.

headline: Facebook Looks to Become Big Fish in Another Big Pond
abstract: The acquisition is part of its effort to create a series of applications on a user’s mobile device instead of relying on its core social network alone.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Facebook is already the world’s biggest social network. Now it wants to be the biggest player in a new global field by buying WhatsApp, the global leader in mobile messaging.

headline: Lessons in Street Art
abstract: A Bronx exhibition of the Brazilian political artist Paulo Bruscky’s work includes a free workshop on how to make statements of your own.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of precocious adolescents animated by the spirit of punk, the Miser and his cronies put in more than a few hours down at the local Kinkos, with scissors, Sharpies and glue sticks at the ready. We were building a body of agitprop works to promote the causes and bands du jour across a forest of posters, fliers, pamphlets, skateboard decks and, inevitably, to our parents’ chagrin, our T-shirts, jeans and leather or denim jackets.

headline: Modeling the Financial Logic for Facebook’s Huge Deal
abstract: A new Reuters Breakingviews calculator shows how the social networking giant can bring the messaging start-up’s valuation in line with its own.
lead_paragraph: For mere mortals who haven’t partaken in whatever Kool-Aid Mark Zuckerberg is serving at Facebook’s Hacker Way headquarters, is there any way to justify the $19 billion ($16 billion, plus $3 billion in restricted stock units that vest in four years) it is paying for WhatsApp?

headline: When a Wig Parts Ways With Its Scalp
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: On a rainy afternoon, a woman found herself running after an unobservant man who was strolling off with her wig.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Rinspeed’s XchangE: From Tesla Model S to Living Room on Wheels
abstract: Rinspeed, known for its offbeat automotive creations, will introduce an autonomous driving leisure system in Geneva next month.
lead_paragraph: Whatever your opinion of the Tesla Model S, it stands as an impressive technological achievement. Rinspeed, the Swiss customizer, decided to take things a few steps further and turned one into a study in autonomous driving interior space and leisure time.

headline: An Aggressive Fed Faces Criticism on Wall Street
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Quantitative Easing', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Even though the Federal Reserve’s economic stimulus has benefited Wall Street’s bottom line, top bankers and big investors remain some of the central bank’s most vehement critics.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:41 p.m. | Every time Janet L. Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, testifies in Congress, she can expect some senators to scoff and representatives to question.

headline: Massachusetts Regulators Approve a Gas-Fired Power Plant With an Expiration Date
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Natural Gas', 'Energy and Power', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: A state regulator accepted a plan to let a natural gas-fired plant be built, with emissions to be gradually reduced until a set closing date.
lead_paragraph: For years, proponents of natural gas, including President Obama, have promoted it as a “bridge fuel,” cleaner than coal but not clean enough to solve the climate problem. On Thursday, regulators in Massachusetts, in an unusual vote, put that theory into practice when it approved a new gas-fired power plant with only a limited life span.

headline: A Chinese Spy Novelist’s World of Dark Secrets
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Chinese Language', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Mai Jia, who once worked for the Chinese military in the secretive world of cryptography, is a top-selling novelist. His first novel to appear in English, “Decoded,” is about to be published.
lead_paragraph: Mai Jia, a top-selling Chinese espionage novelist and former soldier, has been writing about secrets for years.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Prada Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Child Astronauts and Other Would-Be Oscar Moments
abstract: It’s that time of the awards season when kids re-enacting Oscar-nominated films is a welcome idea.
lead_paragraph: Ask yourself: have you ever wanted to see children in bad wigs spouting very adult dialogue, pretending to drive minivans or scamming drugs while dressed as priests? As usual, the Internet has provided a solution, in the form of kids re-enacting Oscar-nominated movies. Check out the montage above with nuggets of kid wisdom (like this scene from kid-“Gravity”: “You have to let go.” “Why?” “It’s the theme of the movie!”). And don’t worry, they went tasteful for “12 Years a Slave.”

headline: Obama’s Budget Omits Trims to Social Security
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Social Security (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: White House officials said Republicans had shown no willingness to meet President Obama’s proposal on an entitlement overhaul by closing loopholes for corporations and the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s forthcoming budget plan will not include a proposal to trim cost-of-living increases in Social Security checks, the gesture of bipartisanship he made to Republicans last year in a failed strategy to reach a “grand compromise” on reducing projected federal debt.

headline: A Strange, Familiar Place in ‘Planetary Omnibus’
abstract: “The Planetary Omnibus” reprints all 27 issues of the comic book by Warren Ellis and John Cassaday.
lead_paragraph: “The Planetary Omnibus” is a junkyard wonderland that revels in the cultural detritus of a certain kind of childhood — one in which plastic Aurora models of classic monsters stalked the dresser, Marvel and DC comics tumbled from the closet and “The Outer Limits” and the local “creature feature” were must-see TV.

headline: Kurdish Travels With the Tramp
abstract: In “Chaplin of the Mountains,” two Americans hoping to show silent films to Iraqi Kurds meet a couple of young Kurdish women who have agendas of their own.
lead_paragraph: A charmingly shaggy road trip with clear political undertones, “Chaplin of the Mountains” winds its way across the Iraqi Kurdistan region, using silent movies to give voice to the troubles of a war-battered people.

headline: Questions Raised About AT&T’s Transparency Report
abstract: The most common requests that AT&T received from federal, state and local government agencies were related to criminal and civil litigation. The company said it received roughly 302,000 of these requests.
lead_paragraph: Updated with additional comment from AT&T

headline: Artistic Forecasts, From Sun to Snow
abstract: New art books display Gerhard Richter’s abstracts, Leonora Carrington’s Surrealism and William Christenberry’s look at the American South.
lead_paragraph: New art books display Gerhard Richter’s abstracts, Leonora Carrington’s Surrealism and William Christenberry’s look at the American South.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 20
abstract: A 17-year-old Russian took figure skating gold and France swept the men’s ski cross on Day 15 of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: A 17-year-old Russian took figure skating gold and France swept the men’s ski cross on Day 15 of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Man Framed by Detective Will Get $6.4 Million From New York City After Serving 23 Years for Murder
abstract: The settlement of a claim filed by David Ranta was made by the comptroller’s office because of overwhelming evidence, lawyers said.
lead_paragraph: A man who was framed by a rogue detective and served 23 years in prison for a murder he did not commit will receive $6.4 million from the City of New York in a settlement that came before a civil rights lawsuit was even filed, lawyers involved in the case said on Thursday.

headline: Moschino: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: An Elegant Space for Creative Sushi
abstract: Sushi is the main attraction at Wafu Asian Bistro in Southport, but the menu is also full of other options.
lead_paragraph: As sushi bars go, Wafu Asian Bistro in Southport is as fancy as they get, at least in Connecticut. Wafu’s main dining room has double-glass walls with shimmering, curtainlike strands pressed between the panes of glass, and its ceiling dazzles with rows and rows of round mirrors.

headline: The Stresses of a Tough Winter
abstract: Answers to questions about clearing snow and advice on nudging a former neighbor to retrieve items held for him in storage.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Clinging to Each Other, We Survived the Storm
abstract: When life was so unbelievably tenuous, we paid attention to what mattered.
lead_paragraph: Every couple has a story, and this was ours. We were prepared to weather storms. For our wedding, we skipped the tissue paper and cream-colored card stock of standard invitations. Instead, we glued a photograph of ourselves swing-dancing onto a black-and-white picture of stormy ocean waves.

headline: F.C.C. Wants Better 911 Location Tracking for Cellphones
abstract: The agency proposes requiring wireless phone companies to specify location for 911 calls to the correct floor in a multistory building within five years.
lead_paragraph: Want to dial 911 from a mobile phone? Better go outside. Chances are an operator cannot automatically find the location of an emergency call made indoors.

headline: Sports Bar Chain Agrees to Pay $6.8 Million for Violating Wage Laws
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Waiters and Waitresses', 'Working Hours', 'Restaurants', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The government said Chickie’s & Pete’s, which has nine bars in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, illegally underpaid and took a percentage of tips from servers.
lead_paragraph: A popular chain of sports bars based in Philadelphia has agreed to pay $6.8 million in back wages and damages for improperly taking tips from waiters and bartenders and for violating minimum wage and overtime laws, the Labor Department announced Thursday.

headline: Gracie Gold Places Fourth and Finds She’s in Good Company
abstract: The Olympic medalists Evan Lysacek and Sasha Cohen, like Gracie Gold, finished fourth in their first Olympics.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Gracie Gold, an 18-year-old American who placed fourth in women’s figure skating Thursday, said she knew the competition would be fierce. Based on international rankings, she was not necessarily a medal favorite going in. But with the surprising tumbles of Yulia Lipnitskaya of Russia and Mao Asada of Japan in the short program, Gold had to feel as if she could make the podium.

headline: The Hefty Yoke of Student Loan Debt
abstract: As student loan debt continues to rise, the loans’ underwriting standards remain almost nonexistent, and the economy may pay the price.
lead_paragraph: More than five years after the binge of irresponsible lending led to the credit crisis and Great Recession, the amount of consumer debt in the United States has begun to rise again, but with an important difference. This time the credit standards appear far tougher. Those who should not borrow generally do not.

headline: A Drive-In Flickers to Life for a Teenager
abstract: Alicia Silverstone seeks a man as salvation, while her teenage daughter, played by A J Michalka, talks to an imaginary friend.
lead_paragraph: “Angels in Stardust” ends up being too tidy to be a great coming-of-age movie, but it’s a decent one, with nice work by Alicia Silverstone as an indifferent mother and A J Michalka as her daydreaming teenage daughter, Vallie Sue.

headline: Variations on Doughnuts
abstract: Freshness is part of the appeal of New Jersey’s independent doughnut shops, which cater to a wide range of tastes.
lead_paragraph: When Vincent DePaola and Nick Giannakopoulos opened DoCo, the Donut and Coffee Company in Farmingdale in July, they knew they were steering their career paths in an improbable direction.

headline: Who Were the Figure Skating Judges?
abstract: Among the judges: the wife of the Russian skating federation’s general director and a man who was suspended for his role in the 1998 Nagano scandal.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Rarely does a Winter Olympics pass without something happening that invites intense scrutiny of the figure skating judges. On Thursday night, the latest issue emerged — this time at the most high-profile moment, after the reigning gold medalist, Kim Yu-na of South Korea, performed the final free skate of the competition.

headline: The Change That Just Might Come
abstract: Among the highlights of this spring’s dance season is the Lincoln Center stand by the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which might radically alter its repertory thereafter.
lead_paragraph: No one spring is quite like another. Buds, blooms, and leaves arrive in different conjunctions every time. The annual season by the Paul Taylor Dance Company is always a highlight of the New York dance calendar; the openness and energy of the Taylor troupe leave a beloved, truly springlike impression in the mind. Its nature changes subtly each year.

headline: Varied Pitches to Fill Empty Spaces
abstract: The composer Georg Friedrich Haas explores microtonality — a system that divides the conventional scale of Western classical music into many more than its usual 12 semitone pitches — in his works.
lead_paragraph: “Is the idea that this is the right world, and this is the destroyed world?” the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas asked recently, after playing and comparing the same chord on the three upright Yamaha pianos — each tuned differently — that form a triangle in his small studio at Columbia University.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Central African Republic, Afghanistan and Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Central African Republic, Afghanistan and Italy.

headline: Big Dreams, Then Rude Awakening
abstract: For a creative programming event that brings regional orchestras to Carnegie Hall, this year brings one last week of concerts.
lead_paragraph: It is with gratitude and sadness that I am looking forward to the fourth annual Spring for Music festival. Gratitude because each year this weeklong series of orchestra concerts at Carnegie Hall has been so exciting. Sadness because this spring’s festival (running from May 5 to 10) will be its last.

headline: A Dane Is Getting His Due
abstract: The Danish symphonic master Carl Nielsen can be heard in a number of New York concerts in coming months.
lead_paragraph: Alan Gilbert’s most important efforts as music director of the New York Philharmonic have been in the realm of new music, hoisting the orchestra into the 21st century with initiatives like the Contact! series and the forthcoming NY Phil Biennial. But some of his biggest successes have been with a composer who died in 1931, the Danish symphonic master Carl Nielsen.

headline: Conjuring Thrills From the Living and the Dead
abstract: Gustavo Dudamel is returning to Avery Fisher Hall next month to lead the Los Angeles Philharmonic in concerts featuring works by Rachmaninoff, Bjarnason, Corigliano and others.
lead_paragraph: Reviewing a concert featuring the “Infernal Dance” of Stravinsky’s “Firebird” that Gustavo Dudamel led with the Los Angeles Philharmonic last March at Avery Fisher Hall, Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times that Mr. Dudamel “drew such blazing colors, slashing attacks and sheer terror from the orchestra that at the climax of the dance, some people in the hall broke into applause and shouted ‘Bravo.’ ”

headline: Open Restaurant. Pack With Patrons. Repeat.
abstract: Fans of Polpettina, a pizza kitchen in Eastchester, should not expect a clone in the new Polpettina from the same owners.
lead_paragraph: Having enjoyed a nice run with Polpettina, their close-quartered pizza kitchen in Eastchester, Michael Abruzese and Kyle Inserra must have gotten to wondering: With ardent fans and not enough space to satisfy demand, why not open a second place nearby, with the same name and the same wholesome, high-spirited menu?

headline: No, Not So Smart
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Addressing matters of reacting to cellphone-use critics, cautioning relatives on children and guns and more.
lead_paragraph: I went to a screening of several Academy Award-nominated short films, each ranging from 4 to 15 minutes. Between shorts, I took notes on my cellphone. I didn’t have a pen and paper, and wouldn’t have been able to see them in the dark if I had. The woman beside me asked me sternly to take my phone out of the theater because it was bothering her. I did. But at the end of each short, I had to walk in front of an entire row of people, causing more disruption than if I had simply typed a few notes on my dimly lit phone. Should I have asked the woman to reconsider?

headline: ‘Bronx Bombers’ to Close on Broadway
abstract: The show, with Peter Scolari as Yogi Berra, will close on March 2, less than a month after opening.
lead_paragraph: First A-Rod. Then Jeter. Now Yogi, too? “Bronx Bombers,” an homage to the New York Yankees, will end its run at Circle in the Square Theater on March 2, less than a month after its official Broadway opening, its producers announced Thursday.

headline: Outkast Reunion, Rain or Shine
abstract: The proliferation of music festivals over the last decade or so has partly homogenized their lineups.
lead_paragraph: The downpour at last year’s Governors Ball music festival, which turned the open fields of Randalls Island into shoe-sucking mud pits, hasn’t daunted its ever more ambitious promoters. In June, Governors Ball will bring to New York the top booking of this year’s festival season: the reunion of the hip-hop band Outkast. That reunion was first announced by the Coachella festival, held in the California desert, which — with its advantage of climate — opens the major festival circuit in the United States, on the weekends of April 11 and 18.

headline: So Far, a Chanteuse Mainly for the Camera
abstract: Her videos have gotten the English singer FKA Twigs as much notice as her music. That may soon change.
lead_paragraph: FKA Twigs is a mixed-race, tawny-skinned 26-year-old singer and dancer from rural Gloucestershire, England; her real name is Tahlia Barnett, and her old nickname was Twigs, hence “Formerly Known as Twigs.” Her music, on two EPs released in the space of a little more than a year, is tremulous and slow and commanding, with eerie barren stretches. (The second EP was produced by Arca, who worked on Kanye West’s “Yeezus.”) The methodical, strangely placed stresses of the beats signify a lot: isolation, displacement, missed connections. Something of interest — a little burst of rhythm or a bending, decaying electronic tone — occurs in nearly every bar. There’s some deconstructed, first-generation drum-and-bass in there, and Portishead and mid-period Madonna, too; she seizes on and transforms some drowsy energies in early-’90s pop.

headline: Go on, Rant and Rave: It Shows You’re Real
abstract: Donald Glover, who raps under the name Childish Gambino, will perform at the Hammerstein Ballroom in New York on March 29.
lead_paragraph: Last October, Donald Glover had a modern meltdown, or something like it. On his Instagram account, he posted a series of notes handwritten on a hotel pad: “I feel like I’m letting everyone down. I’m afraid people hate who I really am. I’m afraid I hate who I really am.” And so on.

headline: Investments in Brazil Rose Last Year, Study Says
abstract: Despite Brazil’s economic woes, $6.04 billion in private equity and venture capital money was committed to the country last year. Oil, gas and energy were the most sought sectors.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Despite its economic woes, Brazil experienced an increase in private equity and venture capital investments in 2013 over the year before, the Latin American Private Equity and Venture Capital Association said on Thursday, in presenting its annual survey.

headline: A Trail of Tears and Corpses
abstract: As the prime suspect in a cocaine heist, a retired gangster with a gap in his memory seems to be on everyone’s to-do list.
lead_paragraph: Taking a credibility-straining premise and running with it, the Dutch director Arne Toonen gives “Black Out” way more energy than sense. Luckily, his antihero, Jos (Raymond Thiry), lacks neither: A retired gangster whose weary face belies a still-up-for-it body, Jos is less dismayed than most when he wakes up the day before his wedding to find a bloody body sharing his bed.

headline: Rates Rising for Modified Loans
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Homeowner Affordability and Stability Plan', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Borrowers whose mortgages were modified through the government’s HAMP program in 2009 can expect to see monthly payments rise.
lead_paragraph: The federal government’s Home Affordable Modification Program, known as HAMP, was designed to keep borrowers from losing their homes to foreclosure. It has resulted in lower monthly mortgage payments for more than a million homeowners.

headline: Katherine Bernhardt: ‘Stupid, Crazy, Ridiculous, Funny Patterns’
abstract: Ms. Bernhardt’s exuberant new paintings embed repeating images of common objects in fields of intense color.
lead_paragraph: Canada

headline: ‘Queer Threads: Crafting Identity and Community’
abstract: This exhibition posits fiber art as the ideal lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender medium.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Lohman Museum of Gay and Lesbian Art

headline: Alex Prager: ‘Face in the Crowd’
abstract: Ms. Prager’s latest photographs are large, meticulously staged crowd scenes of seemingly ordinary people who never quite blend into a crowd.
lead_paragraph: Lehmann Maupin

headline: David Altmejd: ‘Juices’
abstract: A lot is going on in “The Flux and the Puddle,” the labyrinthine sculpture that dominates Mr. Altmejd’s latest solo exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Rosen Gallery

headline: Wheelies: The Aluminum Bandwagon Edition
abstract: General Motors makes moves to produce an aluminum-body pickup truck by 2018; Toyota tests a wireless E.V. charging system.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Sardinian Food and History, Via Bike
abstract: The Boston chef Jody Adams will be the host of a culinary bike trip in Sardinia.
lead_paragraph: Ciclismo Classico has enlisted the skills of a James Beard Award-winning chef (and former competitor on Bravo’s “Top Chef Masters”) to entice tourists into a culinary-focused bike tour through Sardinia. The tour will be a combination of eating and exercise, with the Boston chef Jody Adams as host.

headline: ‘American Folk Art’
abstract: For a glimpse of old, weird America, consider this wonderfully spooky selection of paintings, sculptures and curiosities dating from 1830 to 1930.
lead_paragraph: Edward Thorp

headline: Indoor Food Market Planned for Midtown
abstract: A developer has rented space in a Helmsley Building passageway for new food stalls and stands.
lead_paragraph: Don’t drag out the shopping cart just yet, but a spacious new food market is planned for Midtown Manhattan. Urban Space, the company that runs the pop-up markets at Union Square Park, Madison Square Park, Columbus Circle and elsewhere, has rented 12,000 square feet in the Helmsley Building, the grand Beaux-Arts tower that straddles Park Avenue at 46th Street.

headline: Prada’s Industrial Evolution
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: Wedge sandals inspired by the Machine Age.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Violence Threatens U.S. Soccer Friendly in Ukraine
abstract: The United States national team’s March 5 friendly against Ukraine seems increasingly likely to be played elsewhere — if at all.
lead_paragraph: Political violence in Ukraine continued to imperil the United States national team’s friendly against Ukraine, which is scheduled to be played in the eastern city of Kharkiv in March but seems increasingly likely to be played elsewhere — if at all.

headline: For a Kurdish Woman, No Way Out
abstract: In “One Candle, Two Candles ...,” the heroine is pressured to marry a rich older man.
lead_paragraph: There may be knee-slappers to be written about forced marriage, but they aren’t to be found in the goofy, slapdash “One Candle, Two Candles ....” The Kurdish filmmaker Jano Rosebiani, who directed the well-received drama “Jiyan,” about the aftermath of chemical attacks, inflicts an antic approach on the story of a teenager betrothed to a rich older man. Sparks do not fly.

headline: New York Versus New Jersey: Airport Wages Edition
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s pushing to get a better deal for employees at J.F.K. and La Guardia. Gov. Chris Christie isn’t doing the same at Newark.
lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, as the name suggests, is supposed to be one uber-agency that makes transportation-related decisions for both states. Too often, however, it is really two authorities—a New York operation run by Gov. Andrew Cuomo and a New Jersey version dominated by Gov. Chris Christie.

headline: Waiting With Bittersweet Anxiety for Their Moment
abstract: The director Stephanie Riggs follows the tribulations of three actors who are on call to step in for a star in a stage show.
lead_paragraph: “You get paid for the groan,” an actress named Aléna Watters says in the engaging documentary “The Standbys,” perfectly summing up the bittersweet reality of life as a backup performer on Broadway.

headline: A Pretty Mental Patient Comes Home to Meet the Folks
abstract: “Barefoot” stars Evan Rachel Wood as a young woman with a bit of psychosis but who is charming nonetheless.
lead_paragraph: “Barefoot,” a catastrophic American remake of “Barfuss,” a 2005 German romantic comedy, wastes the talents of respectable actors like Kate Burton, Treat Williams, J. K. Simmons and, most painfully, Evan Rachel Wood. Ms. Wood is miscast as Daisy, a possibly psychotic woman-child enlisted by Jay (Scott Speedman), the black sheep scion of a wealthy New Orleans family, to pose as his girlfriend when he returns home for the wedding of his younger brother.

headline: A Scallop for a Sherry
abstract: A memorable midcourse of sea scallops with pistachios and licorice at Restaurant Daniel inspires this recipe, ideal for pairing with amontillado.
lead_paragraph: Amontillado is the broad-spectrum sherry, the one I would happily sip with a meal from start to finish. You want a fino with your oysters? Consider amontillado in a classic style, not sweetened, and go from there. During the tasting I wanted big sea scallops with a deep, almost candied burnish. That very evening, a memorable midcourse of sea scallops with pistachios and licorice at Restaurant Daniel suggested the pairing may be worth a test run. Raj Vaidya, the sommelier, was on board at once, with glasses of good amontillado. Though pistachios are sweeter and more herbaceous than the toasty essence of hazelnut that wraps the sherry, they drove the dish in the right direction. The recipe is my interpretation.

headline: Juniper Networks Reaches Deal With Hedge Fund
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Boards of Directors', 'Hedge Funds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The networking equipment company said on Thursday that it had reached an agreement with Elliott Management to nominate two new directors to its board and return more money to shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Juniper Networks, the networking equipment company, said on Thursday that it had reached an agreement with the hedge fund Elliott Management to nominate two new directors to its board and return more money to shareholders, avoiding a possible proxy fight with the hedge fund.

headline: French and Americans in a Moving Dialogue
abstract: A new festival of French choreographers and dancers will use 14 venues over three weeks in May.
lead_paragraph: It’s been far too long — choreographically speaking — since France invaded New York. In the spring of 2001, France Moves, a festival programmed by Yorgos Lukos, the artistic director of the Lyon Opera Ballet, filled New York with a wealth of dances by established and experimental French dance artists. Remember, in his American debut, the breath of fresh air that was Boris Charmatz?

headline: The Book on Amontillado
abstract: The collective story of this sherry will be rewarding if you are up for the challenge.
lead_paragraph: Diving into amontillado is the equivalent of committing to a long, complicated novel. You may be surprised, even astounded by what you find. You will almost certainly be rewarded if you permit yourself to be challenged.

headline: The Ukraine Divide, Explained
abstract: Ukraine is being pulled in different directions: one toward Russia, the other toward Western Europe.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine is being pulled in different directions: one toward Russia, the other toward Western Europe.

headline: Next Step for Force in Ballet
abstract: Justin Peck, acclaimed for his choreography in his mid-20s, has a new piece coming in May, again with music by Sufjan Stevens but with a larger cast.
lead_paragraph: Identifying the next great ballet choreographer isn’t exactly like recognizing the Messiah, yet for the ballet-obsessed there are similarities. Since the deaths of George Balanchine, Frederick Ashton and Jerome Robbins at the end of last century, the sense of loss has remained so strong that critics and audiences have been both desperate to find successors and reflexively skeptical about candidates. Thus it was a big deal in January 2013 when Alastair Macaulay declared in The New York Times that Justin Peck was “the third important choreographer to have emerged in classical ballet this century.”

headline: Lava and Lust
abstract: In Paul W. S. Anderson’s gladiator disaster film “Pompeii,” the lone survivor of a Celtic tribe becomes a slave, but his horse-whisperer talents helps redirect his fate.
lead_paragraph: In Paul W. S. Anderson’s last three movies, a swashbuckler and two films based on the “Resident Evil” video game, he trained his camera on his wife, Milla Jovovich, in the obsessive way Josef von Sternberg once filmed Marlene Dietrich. In “Pompeii,” Mr. Anderson’s latest 3-D extravaganza, and his first film without Ms. Jovovich since 2008, he seems to be without visual focus.

headline: Get the Laughs, but Follow the Rules
abstract: The comedy troupe Upright Citizens Brigade has a new manual for improvisation that adds further discipline to the Second City lessons on the form.
lead_paragraph: Is there anything improv can’t do?

headline: From Zola, With Blood, Lust and Bloodlust
abstract: “In Secret” is the latest adaptation of Émile Zola’s “Thérèse Raquin.”
lead_paragraph: “In Secret,” the latest adaptation of Émile Zola’s “Thérèse Raquin,” opens with a dip in the water and quickly comes ashore with furiously galloping horses and sweeping camera movements. The galloping suggests urgency; the camera movements imply narrative grandeur, or maybe directorial ambition. The darkly muted colors, evoking gathering storms and winter chill, add a brooding note. The river that runs alongside the road like a parallel boulevard will probably mean something only to those who have read Zola’s book, a classic of literary naturalism, which was published in 1867 and greeted by one appalled critic as “a pool of mud and blood.”

headline: Clip: 'Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me'
abstract: A scene from the documentary.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the documentary.

headline: Hackley School Tells Parents of Accusations of Abuse From the ’60s
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: The school in Tarrytown, N.Y., acknowledged accusations of previous abuse, joining a group of elite private schools that have recently grappled with claims of long ago sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: Another prominent private school in the New York area has acknowledged accusations of long-ago sexual abuse of students, joining a small group of schools that have grappled in recent years with claims of abuse that happened decades earlier.

headline: White House Discusses Ukraine Unrest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The White House principal deputy press secretary, Josh Earnest, told reporters that the Ukrainian government had primary responsibility for stemming its country’s violence.
lead_paragraph: The White House principal deputy press secretary, Josh Earnest, told reporters that the Ukrainian government had primary responsibility for stemming its country’s violence.

headline: Recalling Velvet, Pretzels and Beer, She’s Still Here
abstract: There is no one quite like Elaine Stritch, who is captured in a film biography as she prepares a cabaret show of Sondheim songs.
lead_paragraph: “A Molotov cocktail of madness, sanity and genius.” That is one description of the great Broadway and cabaret entertainer Elaine Stritch in Chiemi Karasawa’s acutely intimate documentary portrait, “Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me.”

headline: Former Hedge Fund Analyst Charged With Stealing Data
abstract: The charges against Kang Gao, who worked at the hedge fund Two Sigma Investments, are part of a crackdown by the Manhattan district attorney on suspected violations of cybersecurity.
lead_paragraph: A former hedge fund analyst has been charged with stealing confidential computer data from his previous employer, the latest crackdown by the Manhattan district attorney on suspected violations of cybersecurity.

headline: My First Apartment, Guiltily Remembered
abstract: A first unforgettable apartment introduces a young man to rent shenanigans and architectural salvage.
lead_paragraph: I was lucky in 1970, when I backed into my first apartment, a $45-a-month railroad flat built in 1887 at 1422 Third Avenue, south of 81st Street. It was with apartment 2C I learned how to circumvent the rent laws and that when it comes to housing in New York, even a friend will stab you in the back.

headline: Hedge Fund Commercial
abstract: Topturn Capital, a $100 million hedge fund, created an ad with images of a professional surfer interspersed with the company’s two founders discussing how managing money is a lot like surfing.
lead_paragraph: Topturn Capital, a $100 million hedge fund, created an ad with images of a professional surfer interspersed with the company’s two founders discussing how managing money is a lot like surfing.

headline: For Your Consideration: Apathy
abstract: In a longer campaign season before the Oscars, Hollywood’s mood is dampened by moral disputes and low box-office bumps.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — HOLLYWOOD’S biggest party of the year is only nine days away, but festive the movie capital is not.

headline: Times Minute | Women’s Skating Upset
abstract: Adelina Sotnikova wins gold in the women’s skating competition. Also on the Minute, quiet nuclear diplomacy and cities cut hours for part-time, public government workers.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Figure Skating', 'HEALTH INSURANCE', "Iran's nuclear program"]
