lead_paragraph: Adelina Sotnikova wins gold in the women's skating competition. Also on the Minute, quiet nuclear diplomacy and cities cut hours for part-time, public government workers.

headline: Ask a Question About the Crisis in Ukraine
abstract: What would you like to know about the clashes in Ukraine and the political crisis that has gripped the country for the past three months?
lead_paragraph: Violence erupted in the center of the Ukrainian capital, Kiev, this week as protesters and riot police officers used firearms against each other. Bodies were lined up on a sidewalk on Thursday, a hotel lobby was turned into a medical center and fears grew that the president would declare a state of emergency.

headline: G.M. Recalls Some Cars, but Not All, With Ignition Switch Problem
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: General Motors recalled 778,000 vehicles last week, but not 643,000 others that have the same problem.
lead_paragraph: General Motors in 2006 sent dealers a technical service bulletin warning that because of an ignition problem, a heavy key chain hanging from the ignition could turn off the engine on six models. But only two of those models were covered in last week’s recall  of 778,000 vehicles in the United States and Canada for the problem that the automaker now says could keep air bags from deploying in a crash.

headline: With Ban on Ads Removed, Hedge Funds Test Waters
abstract: Years of lackluster performance and growing competition for institutional investors like pension funds have made hedge funds warm to the idea of branding. Just do not call it advertising.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:58 p.m. | It looks like the kind of motivational poster on a college student’s dorm room wall. Snowboarders stand at the peak of a steep mountain, reveling in victory, with the tag line, “Performing in all conditions.”

headline: Fragments of a Monastery, Reunited in Body and Spirit
abstract: An ancient Tibetan Buddhist monastery demolished in the 20th century is partially reimagined through bits of its art installed in an Asia Society show, “Golden Visions of Densatil.”
lead_paragraph: You have to hate or fear something a lot to do what China did to Tibetan Buddhism. In the early 20th century, Tibet had thousands of active monasteries; when the Cultural Revolution ended in 1976, it had fewer than 10. The politics of blame are always tricky; some scholars argue that Tibetans themselves, for complicated reasons, contributed to the purge. But one reality is plain: By the time the mass demolition wound down, centuries’ worth of religious art was gone.

headline: Events in Westchester for Feb. 23-March 1
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Mondrian Inspires Moods and Form
abstract: The prolific choreographer Jessica Lang brought a handful of her pieces to the Joyce Theater on Wednesday, including a few New York premieres.
lead_paragraph: One point is undeniable about Jessica Lang: She is prolific, having created more than 80 dances since she started working as a freelance choreographer in 1999. But what drives her vision? After the curtain fell on the last of six pieces presented by Jessica Lang Dance at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday, I still wasn’t sure.

headline: ‘We’re Really Happy You Decided to Come’
abstract: A new work by Laure Prouvost, the Turner Prize-winning visual artist, has its debut at the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: The Turner Prize has lost much of its capacity to shock, but it can still deliver modest surprises: Critics and bookies were caught off guard in December when the 2013 honors went to Laure Prouvost. Ms. Prouvost, born in France but based in Britain, was the dark horse on the shortlist for the Turner, presented to a British visual artist under the age of 50; this year, it also included the puckish draftsman David Shrigley, the painter of imaginary figures Lynette Yiadom-Boakye and the conceptual-performance artist Tino Sehgal.

headline: Events in Connecticut for Feb. 23-March 1
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: War of Words Signals a Changed BlackBerry
abstract: John S. Chen, BlackBerry’s relatively new chief executive and executive chairman, engaged in some exceptional online sniping this week with his counterpart at T-Mobile US.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — In one of the more public illustrations of how things have changed at BlackBerry, John S. Chen, the company’s relatively new chief executive and executive chairman, engaged in some exceptional online sniping this week with his counterpart at T-Mobile US.

headline: Ill-Fated Love, Made Intimate
abstract: In the Juilliard Opera’s “Eugene Onegin,” Tchaikovsky’s charming folkish choruses are jettisoned, and the emotional wrenches lie right on the surface.
lead_paragraph: Student opera productions, often mounted to highlight an individual star talent or two, typically prove uneven. Such, evidently, was the case when the Juilliard Opera last presented Tchaikovsky’s “Eugene Onegin,” in 2002.

headline: Dan Graham to Design Met Museum Rooftop Exhibit
abstract: Dan Graham will create a steel-and-glass pavilion to be shown on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: The American Conceptualist Dan Graham has long worn many art world hats. He has produced films and videos, drawings and prints; chronicled rock culture; and collaborated with bands like Sonic Youth and Japanther. But Mr. Graham is perhaps best known for his architectural environments and glass pavilions, which he has been designing since the 1980s. Often constructed of two-way mirrored glass and steel, they are created in such a way that the viewer and the surrounding landscape can become actors in his creations.

headline: Venturing Into Noise in Search of Melody
abstract: The JACK Quartet performed Helmut Lachenmann’s three string quartets on Wednesday evening at the Morgan Library & Museum.
lead_paragraph: It’s been hard to hear some of the most beautiful music played in New York recently. Last week, one of the finest moments in the pianist Christian Zacharias’s recital at Alice Tully Hall was the quiet dying away of a sepulchral A flat at the end of the Funeral March in Beethoven’s Sonata No. 12.

headline: The Impact of Four Decades, Experienced Room by Room
abstract: “Re-View: Onnasch Collection,” a large exhibition at Hauser & Wirth, explores four decades in the progression of post-World War II art.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to mega-dealers like David Zwirner and Larry Gagosian, it’s no surprise these days to see art exhibitions in commercial galleries that resemble ambitious, high-quality museum shows. But “Re-View: Onnasch Collection” at Hauser & Wirth raises the bar. The show more effectively simulates the experience of a modern art museum than any private gallery exhibition I’ve seen in New York. It is, in many ways, a terrific show. So why does it make me feel so bad?

headline: Treachery Thrives Where Trust Withers
abstract: The title character of “Omar” is a sensitive young Palestinian who believes a happy ending can spring from the despair of his homeland.
lead_paragraph: Hany Abu-Assad’s new film, “Omar,” is about Israeli-Palestinian violence and also about three friends, young men who seem familiar almost as soon as we see them together. Tarek (Eyad Hourani) is the leader, Amjad (Samer Bisharat) is the joker, and Omar (Adam Bakri) is the sensitive one, handsome and athletic with the soul of a poet. He and Amjad are both in love with Tarek’s sister Nadia (Leem Lubany), but their rivalry is kept in check by their affection for each other and by strict customs governing courtship and family life.

headline: In Thrall to Machines, War and a More Manly Future
abstract: “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe” is an epic exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum.
lead_paragraph: Was any avowedly modern art movement as obnoxious and noisily contradictory as Italian Futurism? By turn aesthetically revolutionary and politically reactionary, farsighted and visually challenged, not to mention officially misogynist, it is both a stain on the Modernist brand and a point of pride. It needs all the help it can get and it receives a large dose from “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe,” an epic exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum.

headline: Anti-Putin Punk Activists Release New Music Video
abstract: The new Pussy Riot video, released on Thursday, was made with the inadvertent cooperation of the authorities.
lead_paragraph: Suspicions that footage of Pussy Riot activists being manhandled by the police in Sochi, Russia, on Tuesday and whipped by Cossacks on Wednesday might help the feminist collective make its point about state repression were proved correct on Thursday, with the release of the group’s latest music video, “Putin Will Teach You How to Love the Motherland.”

headline: Events in New Jersey for Feb. 23-March 1
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: The Furniture and Life of Paul Evans
abstract: The Michener Art Museum in Doylestown, Pa., explores the life and work of the furniture designer Paul Evans, and Guernsey’s is selling acoustic guitars from Hank Risan’s collection.
lead_paragraph: Aggressive metal furniture by the designer Paul Evans is not easy to categorize.

headline: Down and Armed in Paris, Teenager in Tow
abstract: In “3 Days to Kill,” Kevin Costner plays a much-put-upon C.I.A. assassin in Paris with bad guys to dispatch and child-care issues.
lead_paragraph: In the new movie “3 Days to Kill,” Paris is full of thugs for hire with bald heads and dark suits, and the last thing they want to see — in many cases the last thing they do see — is Kevin Costner, unshaven and in faded jeans, shuffling down the hallway in their direction. Sometimes these tough guys make fun of the fact that Mr. Costner’s character, Ethan Renner, is American, calling him “cowboy” and other hilarious names. The deeper joke, perhaps unintentional, is that Ethan looks more French than most of the Parisians he encounters. With his loosely tied scarf and graying stubble, his sunglasses and his world-weary demeanor, he could easily pass for a philosophy professor or the leader of a Serge Gainsbourg tribute band. If he spoke any French, that is.

headline: Look, but Mostly Listen: Remembering Sept. 11
abstract: “Bikeman: A 9/11 Play” is a docudrama by Thomas F. Flynn that recounts his experiences on Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: The portentous narration begins soon after Dan Rather delivers a windy recorded video message to start “Bikeman: A 9/11 Play,” a docudrama by Thomas F. Flynn that recounts his experiences on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Events on Long Island for Feb. 23-March 1
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Celebrating Bondage Over Bonds of Marriage
abstract: In the Bollywood movie “Highway,” a woman suffocated by her coming wedding finds escape in her kidnapping and love with her abductor.
lead_paragraph: “In bondage, she found freedom.” That’s the tagline in the trailer for the Hindi movie “Highway,” and it makes you wonder if the film will be appalling or merely clueless. It’s neither, though it has tone trouble as it searches for a genre to contain a story with built-in believability problems.

headline: Conversation Hearts, More ‘Scram’ Than ‘Be Mine’
abstract: “Til Divorce Do Us Part,” a not-so-bitter pill with lyrics by Ruthe Ponturo, is at DR2 Theater.
lead_paragraph: The set designer Mitchell Greenberg’s proscenium for “Til Divorce Do Us Part: The Musical” nicely suggests the show: enlarged Valentine’s Day candies — those hearts inscribed with messages — surround the stage. But these pink morsels don’t offer words of love; they have expressions like “Really?,” “Scram,” “Bite Me,” “Buh Bye” and “Be Mine Not.” They look good enough to eat. Maybe revenge truly is sweet.

headline: Theater Listings for Feb. 21-27
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York City, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Suit Against Sony Music Seeks ‘American Idol’ Royalties
abstract: The company behind “Idol” accused Sony on Thursday of underpaying royalties for digital streams of music by stars from the show’s early seasons.
lead_paragraph: The company behind “American Idol” sued Sony Music Entertainment in federal court on Thursday, saying that Sony had underpaid royalties for digital streams of music by Kelly Clarkson, Carrie Underwood, Chris Daughtry and other stars from the show’s early seasons.

headline: How Sotnikova Beat Kim, Move by Move
abstract: The scores for Adelina Sotnikova and Kim Yu-na were close for most of their long program elements. But Sotnikova took a significant lead in two areas. Adam Leib, a coach and national technical specialist for U.S. Figure Skating, breaks down the performances.
lead_paragraph: The scores for Adelina Sotnikova and Kim Yu-na were close for most of their long program elements. But Sotnikova took a significant lead in two areas. Adam Leib, a coach and national technical specialist for U.S. Figure Skating, breaks down the performances.

headline: Two Senior Living Companies to Merge
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Nursing Homes', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living']
abstract: Brookdale Senior Living and Emeritus Corporation, in announcing the $2.8 billion merger on Thursday, said that 6.5 million people 80 years or older will live within 10 miles of a Brookdale community once the deal is completed.
lead_paragraph: Many octogenarians will not have to travel far to find senior living housing after the merger of two of the country’s leading elder care companies.

headline: Former Liverpool Star Fowler Paints New York Red
abstract: Robbie Fowler did a turn as a Reds ambassador as his former club announced details of its summer tour of the United States.
lead_paragraph: Robbie Fowler's 330 games and 171 goals for Liverpool, the club he joined as a boy three decades ago, earned him the affectionate nickname of God in his hometown. He was a local boy made good, a so-called Scouse scally from a rough side of town who endeared himself to the club’s rabid fans at Anfield stadium for 11 seasons during his heyday in the 1990s.

lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spare Times for Feb. 21-27
abstract: A listing of author readings, discussions, walking tours and events related to black history month in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Beatles vs. Rolling Stones (Thursday) Which group is top dog? That question will be debated, starting at 6 p.m., at the New York Library for the Performing Arts, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street, Lincoln Center.

headline: American Meat Plants Said to Face Shortages of Inspectors
abstract: The shortfalls, linked to slow hiring in a new Agriculture Department program, raise the possibility that contaminated products could reach consumers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Agriculture Department is suffering from a shortage of inspectors at some of the nation’s meat and poultry plants, a top inspectors’ union official and a food safety group said this week, raising the possibility that contaminated products could reach consumers.

headline: The Prodigal Son: A Parable for Today?
abstract: Readers react to a column by David Brooks.

headline: My Night in Solitary
keywords: ['Solitary Confinement', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Driving prisoners crazy won’t make the public safer.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — AT 6:45 p.m. on Jan. 23, I was delivered to a Colorado state penitentiary, where I was issued an inmate uniform and a mesh bag with my toiletries and bedding. My arms were handcuffed behind my back, my legs were shackled and I was deposited in Administrative Segregation — solitary confinement.

headline: Robert M. Fresco, Oscar-Winning Documentary Filmmaker, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Fresco won an Academy Award with Denis Sanders for their documentary short “Czechoslovakia 1968.”
lead_paragraph: Robert M. Fresco, an Academy Award-winning documentary filmmaker who began his career as a writer of horror pictures, died on Feb. 14 in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Days of Desiccation
abstract: California is a precursor of what could happen elsewhere if we think we can out-engineer a fevered planet.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The bathtub rings in the reservoirs that hold California’s liquid life have never been more exposed. Shorelines are bare, brown and bony. Much of the Sierra Nevada is naked of snow. And fields in the Central Valley may soon take to the sky. A Dust Bowl? Not yet. Though this drought will surely go down as the worst in the state’s recorded history. Until next year.

headline: Russian Punk Group Ends Protest Tour of Sochi
abstract: During a three-day stay in Sochi, members of Pussy Riot were detained three times, whipped by a Cossack and hounded by pro-government activists.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — For an Olympics that was anticipated by critics of the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, as a rare public platform to bring together and amplify Russia’s scattered voices of dissent, the protest here had largely turned out to be a bust. And then Pussy Riot came to town.

headline: Back From Suspension, Braun Hopes to Get Back in Game
abstract: Ryan Braun has reported to the Brewers’ spring training camp in Arizona after serving a 65-game suspension for using banned substances.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Ryan Braun’s second chance began Thursday at Maryvale Baseball Park, the site of his greatest embarrassment. It was here, two years ago, that Braun said he would bet his life that he had never used performance-enhancing drugs. Braun lost the bet, of course, but has emerged with his life and career intact.

headline: 2 Former Christie Aides Who Ignored Subpoenas Are Ordered to Court
abstract: A judge has ordered two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie to appear in court on March 11 to explain their refusal to turn over potential evidence to the George Washington Bridge lane closings investigation.
lead_paragraph: A judge in New Jersey has ordered two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie to appear in court to explain their refusal to turn over potential evidence to a legislative committee investigating the politically charged closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: Pussy Riot, Putin and the Law of the Cossack
abstract: If I were Vladimir Putin, I would have thought twice about messing with Pussy Riot again.
lead_paragraph: When two members of Pussy Riot, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova and Maria Alyokhina, spoke to the Times editorial board a few weeks ago, someone asked them what they expected upon their return to Russia. They made it clear they were not going to remain silent. Beyond that, they couldn’t say. “We don’t know what’s going to happen,” Ms. Alyokhina said. “The state might have other plans for us.”

headline: Amarillo Struggles to Handle Influx of Refugees
abstract: More refugees have settled in Amarillo in terms of ratio to population than in any other Texas city, and local officials say the situation is straining the city’s capabilities.
lead_paragraph: For the last five years, Titus Pa Thawng has lived thousands of miles from his native Myanmar in Amarillo, where he is a Christian pastor for a congregation of fellow refugees. “God has sent us here,” said Mr. Thawng, 45, a married father of three daughters.

headline: Texas G.O.P. Eagerly Jumps on Neglected Bandwagons
abstract: Senator John Cornyn and the state Republican Party are hard at work using technology and social media to reach out to minority voters, a major priority in the next elections.
lead_paragraph: When a group of data-savvy operatives from Barack Obama’s presidential campaigns created Battleground Texas a year ago and vowed to work day and night to make the Republican-ruled state politically competitive again, Gov. Rick Perry, a Republican, described the idea as unalloyed fantasy.

headline: New Russian Protest Video
abstract: The Russian punk group Pussy Riot released a new music video protesting the human rights record of President Vladimir V. Putin during the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: The Russian punk group Pussy Riot released a new music video protesting the human rights record of President Vladimir V. Putin during the Olympics.

headline: Abbott’s Choice of Help on Campaign Trail Is a Real Puzzle
abstract: Attorney General Greg Abbott, the favorite in a Republican primary race for governor, has made what some are calling risky campaign appearances with Ted Nugent, whose views are seen as misogynistic.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Banana Republic Ads With Real-Life Unions Include a Gay Couple
abstract: Banana Republic will present Nate Berkus with his fiancé, Jeremiah Brent, as one of the stylish pairs who are together in real life.
lead_paragraph: TO help a new campaign stand out in the crowded marketplace for apparel retailers, Banana Republic decided, among other things, to change ad themes, adopting “The true outfitters of modern American style,” and feature pairs of models who are also coupled up in real life — with a twist. Amid the stylish men and women wearing the new spring line for Banana Republic is a couple composed of two men, the interior designer Nate Berkus and his fiancé, Jeremiah Brent, who is also an interior designer.

headline: He Came, He Saw, He Conquered ... Hilariously
abstract: I had cut class to hang around in the city of my dreams, and even gone to Lindy’s, but the day’s unexpected highlight — Sid Caesar — still lay ahead.
lead_paragraph: I had cut a college class or two and hopped the rickety New Haven R.R. to New York on one of my many jaunts to the Apple. I did this whenever possible to hang around the city of my dreams and the world of show business, sneaking into TV studios and Broadway play rehearsals — a star-struck, show-struck kid, accosting the famous on the streets, in restaurants and in dressing rooms. It’s a wonder I was never knocked cold.

headline: Whitman’s Vision for H.P. in 2017
abstract: Hewlett-Packard turned in a respectable quarter, raising the credibility of Meg Whitman’s multiyear plan to stabilize and renew the troubled tech giant. The problem is, the world keeps presenting new challenges to her legacy businesses. Here’s what she thinks the world will look like in three years, and what H.P. will do in it.
lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard’s boss has a plan. Or at least a vision for the long-struggling company.

headline: Venezuelan Beauty Queen Is Among Protesters Killed
abstract: Genesis Carmon quickly became the face of the growing student protest movement as news of her death spread.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old beauty queen, shot while attending a protest march in Venezuela, is one of five people killed since demonstrations around the country turned violent in the last week.

headline: Do Curlers Make Good Housekeepers? Don’t Ask!
abstract: Athletes in little-known sports field the same inane questions over and over from people who believe their remarks to be both amusing and original.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The conversations follow a wearying and familiar pattern. First, Troels Harry identifies himself as a curler, master of a sport many people know (if they know about it at all) as the thing that looks like shuffleboard on ice, with brooms.

headline: Contraception in the Shadow of Abortion
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Babies and Infants', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Marriages', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Sex']
abstract: A response to Will Saletan and James Taranto on the sexual revolution and the decline of marriage.
lead_paragraph: I’m late turning to this, but before it disappears down the memory hole I wanted to say something about some of the criticisms of my column from a few weeks back, on the link between liberal victories on abortion and divorce law and the subsequent decline of marriage. I’m particularly interested in addressing the point, raised by Will Saletan and James Taranto, that my argument also implies a sweeping case against legal contraception — with Taranto accusing me of “a subtle deception” in eliding that point, and Saletan writing that I’m tiptoeing around an anti-contraception position that he doesn’t think I have “the stomach to defend.”

headline: Racist Episodes Continue to Stir Ole Miss Campus
abstract: Students say the University of Mississippi needs to mount a more aggressive stand against bigotry after two men placed a noose around a statue of the school’s first black student.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, Miss. — On the campus of the University of Mississippi, a few hundred yards from a monument honoring Confederate soldiers, a statue of the university’s first black student, who enrolled in 1962 amid rioting that left two people dead, stands as what administrators call a powerful symbol of progress.

headline: Murdoch Is Said to Pay $57 Million for Condo
abstract: Recently divorced, Rupert Murdoch has bought the top four floors of One Madison, near Madison Square Park in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The media mogul Rupert Murdoch has paid more than $57 million for the top four flours of One Madison, a steel and glass luxury condominium tower in downtown Manhattan, according to people briefed on the sale.

headline: Canada Defeats United States for Women’s Hockey Gold
abstract: The Canadians won, 3-2, in overtime to take the top honor in the Olympic tournament.
lead_paragraph: The Canadians won, 3-2, in overtime to take the top honor in the Olympic tournament.

headline: For Facebook, It’s Users First and Profits Later
abstract: The social networking giant’s agreement to buy the messaging start-up WhatsApp for up to $19 billion is risky, but follows a trend in valuing the number of users over revenue.
lead_paragraph: Technology companies have always been paranoid about missing the next big thing, be it email, e-commerce or social media.

headline: 14-Year Term for Leader in Bronx Antigay Attack
abstract: Idelfonso Mendez, the reputed leader of a gang calling itself the Latin King Goonies, pleaded guilty on Thursday in connection with the beating and robbery of a gay man.
lead_paragraph: The leader of a street gang that lured a man to an apartment in the Bronx and then beat and tortured him for hours in one of New York’s most savage antigay crimes will be sentenced to 14 years in prison under a plea deal announced on Thursday.

headline: Weighing the Ice Cream
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes']
abstract: The division of property among siblings is notorious for causing family rifts.
lead_paragraph: This is the sixth part of an eight-part series.

headline: The Stimulus Tragedy
keywords: ['American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: Five years after the stimulus took effect, it is clear that, though the program did much good, it was also a political disaster.
lead_paragraph: Five years have passed since President Obama signed the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act — the “stimulus” — into law. With the passage of time, it has become clear that the act did a vast amount of good. It helped end the economy’s plunge; it created or saved millions of jobs; it left behind an important legacy of public and private investment.

headline: Syrian Rebels Sought to Bolster Coalition’s Case in Peace Talks
abstract: Leaders from Syria’s insurgent coalition attended peace talks in Geneva with the aim of securing military backing from the United States and others.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — In a crowd of suits in the softly lighted lobby of the InterContinental Hotel here, the military men stood out, wearing leather jackets, overcoats and skeptical expressions. They represented the dominant surviving faction of the Free Syrian Army, the first active leaders of that military arm of the Western-backed exile coalition who attended peace talks earlier this month — a milestone, since many insurgents view the talks with the Syrian government as tantamount to treason.

headline: Colorado Expects to Reap Tax Bonanza From Legal Marijuana Sales
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Medical Marijuana']
abstract: The state predicts $100 million a year in revenues, and a budget proposal from Gov. John W. Hickenlooper estimates that the industry could reach $1 billion in sales in the next fiscal year.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — For Colorado’s new flock of recreational marijuana growers and sellers, Thursday was Tax Day — their first deadline to hand over the taxes they had collected during their inaugural month of sales. And as store owners stuffed cash into lockboxes and made the nervous trek to government offices, new budget numbers predicted that those marijuana taxes could add more than $100 million a year to state coffers, far more than earlier estimates.

headline: With Eye on Summer of 2015, Knicks Are Quiet at Trade Deadline
abstract: The Knicks did not do anything rash or imprudent ahead of Thursday’s trade deadline. At the same time, they did nothing to improve their roster, and that might be a problem.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The Knicks did not do anything rash or imprudent ahead of Thursday’s 3 p.m. trade deadline, like take on an onerous long-term contract. Given their history, it was always a possibility.

headline: Capitalism for the Masses
abstract: In this era, the invisible hand may not be enough.
lead_paragraph: When Arthur Brooks was 24, he was playing the French horn in a chamber music concert in Dijon, France. He noticed a beautiful woman smiling at him from the front row, so, after the recital, he made a beeline for her and introduced himself.

headline: Muzzling Speech in India
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Editorials']
abstract: The wanton abuse of laws restricting expression is creating a climate of fear.
lead_paragraph: The decision last week by Penguin India to withdraw from publication and pulp copies of “The Hindus: An Alternative History” is only the latest assault on free speech in India. The publisher’s move is likely to encourage more demands for censorship.

headline: A Billionaire Philanthropist in Washington Who’s Big on ‘Patriotic Giving’
abstract: David M. Rubenstein, whose fortune is estimated at $3 billion, stands nearly alone in shoring up institutions generally under the purview of the federal government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The expansive reach of David M. Rubenstein into the public life of the nation’s capital can be seen during a brief excursion from his downtown office at the Carlyle Group, the private equity firm that he co-founded and that made him a billionaire.

headline: Comcast’s Web of Lobbying and Philanthropy
abstract: The company is beginning a carefully orchestrated campaign, seeking support from members of Congress, state officials and leaders of nonprofit and minority-led groups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only a few hours had passed after the $45 billion merger between Comcast and Time Warner Cable was announced last week when an early voice emerged endorsing the giant deal.

headline: Haitian Dictator May Be Charged With Human Rights Crimes, Court Says
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: An appeals court rejected an argument from Jean-Claude Duvalier, known as Baby Doc, that the statute of limitations had expired for the charge of crimes against humanity.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — An appeals court in Haiti ruled Thursday that one of the country’s most brutal dictators could be charged with crimes against humanity but stopped short of ordering a trial to proceed, calling for further investigation.

headline: The Go-To Congresswoman on Gun Control Packs It In
abstract: After 18 years of meeting with victims and their families, Representative Carolyn McCarthy can move on and know that she tried to make a difference.
lead_paragraph: Representative Carolyn McCarthy hopes she can quit Washington for good before another group of families left grieving by gun violence arrives at her office. She suspects otherwise, since she’s got another 10 months to go before finishing out her 18-year career at the end of the year, and she knows better than anyone in Congress the unyielding rhythm of the nation’s gun trauma.

headline: Deal Reached on Litigation Over Long Island College Hospital
abstract: Under a settlement, the State University of New York would have to solicit new bids for the troubled hospital, which unions and community organizations are fighting to keep open.
lead_paragraph: The State University of New York and a coalition including unions and community groups in northern Brooklyn have agreed to settle litigation that has kept the troubled Long Island College Hospital open for a year, officials on both sides said on Thursday.

headline: Founders of an Anti-Facebook Are Won Over
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Science and Technology', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: The co-founders of WhatsApp are not brash young Silicon Valley entrepreneurs. They are just two guys who wanted to create a simple messaging service.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jan Koum fled the former Soviet Union with his mother when he was 16, leaving his father behind. He worked in the engineering trenches for a decade at Yahoo before starting out on his own. When he was a young man growing up in Mountain View, Calif., his family relied on food stamps to get by.

headline: Los Angeles’s Costly Lesson for the Vatican
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Priests', 'Sex Crimes', 'Editorials']
abstract: A decade of litigation and shameful denial has cost the archdiocese more than $740 million in monetary damages, with the spiritual toll far from tallied.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis has been meeting this week with eight cardinals he selected to shape proposals for reforming the Roman Catholic Church. It is too early to tell what will result from an agenda that will range from Vatican finances to the recruitment of new believers. But the deliberations surely cannot afford to overlook the shocking price tag announced as a final figure that the Los Angeles Archdiocese paid to victims of child sexual abuse by priests.

headline: 2 Plead Guilty in Beating of Giants Fan Outside Dodger Stadium
abstract: A judge issued an eight-year sentence for mayhem and a four-year sentence for assault in the 2011 attack that left Bryan Stow unconscious.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two men pleaded guilty on Thursday in the 2011 beating of Bryan Stow, a San Francisco Giants fan who was attacked outside Dodger Stadium and left with permanent brain injuries.

headline: New York Rethinks Solitary Confinement
keywords: ['Solitary Confinement', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Prison officials took a major step when they agreed to reform this cruel yet far too common practice.
lead_paragraph: The New York State prison system has for years been among the nation’s worst when it comes to the overuse of solitary confinement. At any given time about 3,800 inmates across the state are held in windowless isolation for 23 hours a day, the vast majority for disciplinary infractions. The average length of a stay in solitary is five months, and from 2007 to 2011, nearly 2,800 people  were in solitary for a year or more.

headline: Adelina Sotnikova’s Upset Victory Is Hard to Figure
abstract: The scoring and judging that gave Sotnikova the gold medal over Kim Yu-na shows why figure skating is popular among mainstream fans only every four years.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — I ran to the first skating insider I could find: Kurt Browning, a four-time world champion who had been commentating for Canadian television. Could he explain what just happened?

headline: Police Coercion Cited in Order for Retrial in Upstate New York Killing
keywords: ['Police', 'Confessions', 'Interrogations', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A chief judge said the lies and deceptions of police detectives in Troy, N.Y., taken together, amounted to psychological coercion that violated a suspect’s constitutional rights.
lead_paragraph: Declaring that there are limits to the lies and deceptions the police can employ to get a person to confess to a crime, New York State’s highest court on Thursday ordered a new trial for a man convicted five years ago of killing his infant son.

headline: Life After Gluten
abstract: For people who don't suffer from celiac disease, is the gluten-free diet a fad or an innovative way to approach eating?

headline: No. 3 Returns, Stirring Painful Memories for Earnhardt’s Fans
abstract: The car number had not been used in the Cup series since Dale Earnhardt died in a crash at the 2001 Daytona 500. Austin Dillon is driving it this season.
lead_paragraph: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — Jackie King held back tears as she sat outside the old Dale Earnhardt Inc. race shop, which serves as a shrine to Earnhardt, the revered Nascar driver. Tuesday was the 13th anniversary of the crash on the last lap of the 2001 Daytona 500 that killed Earnhardt, and King had come to attend the annual candlelight tribute there.

headline: Flu Rate Rises in the Young and the Middle-Aged
abstract: The flu is hitting young and middle-aged people particularly hard this season, as a tough flu strain re-emerged and too few people were vaccinated, health authorities said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The flu is hitting young and middle-aged people particularly hard this season, as a tough flu strain re-emerged and too few people were vaccinated, health authorities said on Thursday. More than 60 percent of the severe flu cases in the United States this season have been in people 18 to 64 years old — about double the usual rate, they said. Typically, people at risk for flu complications include pregnant women, the elderly, children and people with compromised immune systems. The main flu circulating this season is H1N1, the “swine flu” that caused a pandemic four years ago. Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, chief of the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said that only a third of people ages 18 to 64 were vaccinated as of November, compared with nearly two-thirds of children and elderly people.

headline: At Olympic Curling Matches, Hands Speak Louder Than Words
abstract: Elsewhere, etiquette provides for a quiet atmosphere when a stone is delivered, but the Sochi crowds can be rowdy.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — As the fans roared in the background at a recent curling match here, the Swedish skip, Margaretha Sigfridsson, examined the smattering of stones on the ice, her red hair pulled back and her face stern. Her team trailed Russia by 2 points in the third end.

headline: Egypt Extends Its Crackdown to Journalists
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The military government has been detaining reporters, as well as other perceived enemies like activists and Islamists.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The three men, wearing white prison scrubs in metal cages reserved for criminal suspects, listened to the list of explosive charges accusing them of aiding a plot to undermine Egypt’s national security.

headline: He Played Blues Concerts Where the Admission Price Was Subway Fare
abstract: Elijah Staley, who died at 87 on Sunday, played his guitar in the subway for more than 20 years under the name Carolina Slim and treated his performances as concerts worthy of a blues hall.
lead_paragraph: Carolina Slim appeared at Avery Fisher Hall once, but mostly he plugged in his guitar and performed underground. Not in one of those clubs in a subbasement with a two-drink minimum. In subway stations.

headline: ‘Elijah and Jeremiah’
abstract: A short documentary on Elijah “Carolina Slim” Staley and Jeremiah Lockwood, musicians who played the blues on the subway together for years.
lead_paragraph: A short documentary on Elijah “Carolina Slim” Staley and Jeremiah Lockwood, musicians who played the blues on the subway together for years.

headline: Hearts Ache in the Heartland
abstract: Kelli O’Hara confirms her position as one of the most exquisitely expressive stars in musical theater in “The Bridges of Madison County” on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: “Iowa.” When Kelli O’Hara sings that word, a plain place name becomes a prism of rippling ambivalence.

headline: Of Clogs and Cordwainers
abstract: Read between the lines for this Friday puzzle from Patrick Berry.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s no unifying theme in this Friday puzzle from Patrick Berry, but he has decided to GO BIG OR GO HOME by stacking the puzzle with plenty of brilliantly worded clues that tease the solver with double meanings and subtle misdirection.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 20, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Coping with Retirement
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: Thomas James Brennan tries to move on with his life after being medically retired from the Marine Corps and finds a number of obstacles in his way.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, I have been trying my hardest to move on with my life after being medically retired from the Marine Corps. I have developed compensatory strategies that allow me to succeed personally and professionally, despite having suffered a traumatic brain injury in Afghanistan more than three years ago. I haven’t just had to overcome T.B.I. since leaving the corps, though: I have also had to battle post-traumatic stress disorder, something that Luke, my service dog, has made much easier.

headline: Jason Collins Is Considered Candidate for the Nets
abstract: The Nets, seeking a free-agent big man, are looking at Collins, a 35-year-old free-agent center who last spring announced that he was gay.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After failing to acquire a frontcourt player before the N.B.A.’s trade deadline passed Thursday afternoon, the Nets shifted their focus to a list of free-agent big men they could sign and plug into their rotation down the stretch.

headline: A Packed Forum for a Rising Concern: New Skyscrapers Near Central Park
keywords: ['Buildings (Structures)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Empire State Building (Manhattan, NY)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A Manhattan community board meeting attracts 425 people to discuss a new set of ultra-luxury buildings designed for West 57th Street.
lead_paragraph: The image on the screen was arresting: four long foreboding shadows thrown by a new set of skyscrapers across one of New York City’s brightest green gems, Central Park.

headline: A Pharmacy Provides Salves for a Community’s Spirits
abstract: Dichter Pharmacy has become a salon and nosh stop and gift store, filled with lotions and potions aimed at the new tide of more-affluent people living in Inwood.
lead_paragraph: Just about no one knows the territory like a neighborhood pharmacist, membrane by membrane.

headline: Knee Injury Will Keep Islanders’ Tavares Out for Season
abstract: John Tavares tore the medial collateral ligament and meniscus in his left knee on Wednesday when he was checked awkwardly during Canada’s Olympic quarterfinal win over Latvia.
lead_paragraph: SYOSSET, N.Y. — John Tavares is featured this month on the cover of the Islanders’ program, wearing a red and white Team Canada sweater. But when fans return to Nassau Coliseum on Feb. 27 for a game against Toronto, the Islanders’ first matchup after the Olympic break, they will not see Tavares, the team’s captain, on the ice.

headline: Obama’s Plan to Meet Dalai Lama Draws Swift Chinese Rebuke
abstract: The meeting is likely to anger the Chinese government, which has tried to diminish the influence of the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader and his efforts to promote the autonomy of Tibet.
lead_paragraph: President Obama plans to meet at the White House on Friday with the Dalai Lama, a visit that drew a swift rebuke from the Chinese government, which has tried to diminish the influence of the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader and his efforts to promote the autonomy of Tibet.

headline: Junior’s Brooklyn Site Will Be Sold to Developer, but Restaurant Will Return
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Junior’s Restaurant in Brooklyn will be torn down by a developer, but its owner says he plans to strike a deal that will allow its return as a ground-floor tenant.
lead_paragraph: The reigning dessert of Downtown Brooklyn is so creamy it sticks to the teeth, so famous it has fed presidents and princes, so precious that when the building where it is made nearly burned to the ground in 1981, people rushed to the scene to wail, “Save the cheesecake!”

headline: Converts Join With Militants in Kiev Clash
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: Groups of young men with far-right political affiliations in Ukraine have provided much of the front-line muscle in increasingly bloody clashes with the police.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As the center of the Ukrainian capital tipped into a maelstrom of gunfire and blood on Thursday, a man wearing a helmet stood on a street corner near Independence Square, the epicenter of the violence, holding a leaf of printer paper.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Like Father, Like Son? The Mets Can Only Hope
abstract: Cory Vaughn, the Mets’ fourth-round pick in 2010, is trying to make an impression at the Mets’ major league camp. His father, Greg, hit 355 home runs in 15 seasons.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — At an early age, Cory Vaughn was conditioned to act like a professional baseball player. His father, Greg Vaughn, who hit 50 homers for the San Diego Padres in 1998, would bring him to the ballpark, where he let him shag fly balls and take grounders. But there were rules. It was not a playground, his father said. He had to be respectful and carry himself seriously. He was about 5 years old.

headline: Leader of Port Authority’s Police Union to Reduce Role Amid Bridge Scandal
abstract: Paul Nunziato, the president of the union, told his membership on Thursday that he would step aside from the union’s day-to-day operations.
lead_paragraph: The president of the union that represents police officers for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, who has come under increasing scrutiny in connection with the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, told his membership on Thursday that he would step aside from the union’s day-to-day operations, a person briefed on the matter said.

headline: Toshiko d’Elia Dies at 84; Gritty Runner Was Champion in an Age Group
abstract: A powerful and resilient runner who took up the sport at age 44, d’Elia emerged from the destitution of postwar Japan to achieve renown in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Toshiko d’Elia, who emerged from the destitution of postwar Japan to achieve renown in the United States as a marathon runner, taking up the sport at age 44 in the 1970s when few older women were doing so, died on Wednesday in Allendale, N.J. She was 84.

headline: Protests Swell in Venezuela as Places to Rally Disappear
abstract: As Venezuelans take to the streets to condemn perennial problems like crime and shortages, the intensity of the protests is fueled by a sense that the spaces to demonstrate are shrinking.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The only television station that relentlessly broadcast voices critical of the government was sold last year, and the new owners have softened its news coverage. Last week, President Nicolás Maduro banned a foreign cable news channel after it showed images of a young protester shot to death here.

headline: Jeter Savoring His Last Season but Not Letting It Distract Him
abstract: Derek Jeter got to work in the Yankees’ first day of full-squad workouts before a larger-than-normal crowd and had a good day.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — In the ninth inning of the penultimate game at the old Yankee Stadium in 2008, Derek Jeter was trying to absorb every aspect of the final moments at the sacred grounds. He knew there would be only a few more at-bats there, and he wanted to soak them up.

headline: Greek and Turkish Cypriots Unite to Restore a Church and a Bond
abstract: The people of Cyprus have started to do what their political leaders have been unable to accomplish: reconcile after the island was partitioned in 1974.
lead_paragraph: KONTEA, Cyprus — In the days before this island was cleft between Greek and Turkish control, the church of St. Charalambos in this tiny village was a gathering place for all. But after decades of division, and fruitless talks between political leaders, local people grew tired of watching its paint peel and its altar decay. They took matters into their own hands.

headline: Kiev: Triage in Crisis
abstract: In the Ukrainian capital, triage centers have sprung up around Independence Square, where dozens of people have died in the fighting.
lead_paragraph: In the Ukrainian capital, triage centers have sprung up around Independence Square, where dozens of people have died in the fighting.

headline: Libyan Vote on Charter Assembly Is Marred by Violence and Low Turnout
abstract: Efforts to draft a new Constitution in Libya hit another hurdle when elections for a 60-member drafting committee fell short of expectations.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Libya’s long-delayed efforts to prepare a new charter hit another obstacle on Thursday when elections for a 60-member constitutional drafting committee fell well short of expectations, with a low turnout and 13 of 60 constituencies failing to elect candidates by the end of the day.

headline: Dead Guards on Freighter Are Identified as Former Navy SEAL Members
abstract: The two men, who had been hired to protect a ship that was attacked by Somali pirates in 2009, were found dead while the ship was docked in the Seychelles.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Two former Navy SEAL members who had been hired to protect the container ship that was attacked by Somali pirates in 2009 — an episode that became the basis of the Oscar-nominated film “Captain Phillips” — were found dead while the ship, the Maersk Alabama, was docked in the Seychelles, officials said Thursday.

headline: Greece: Far-Rightists’ Immunity at Risk
abstract: Judges handling a criminal investigation into the country’s far-right party Golden Dawn asked Parliament on Thursday to permit the prosecution of nine more of the party’s 18 lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: Judges handling a criminal investigation into the country’s far-right party Golden Dawn asked Parliament on Thursday to permit the prosecution of nine more of the party’s 18 lawmakers. If the judges’ request is approved, in a vote in Parliament to lift the lawmakers’ immunity from prosecution, all 18 of the party’s lawmakers will face charges of belonging to a criminal organization. Since a police crackdown on the party last fall, prompted by the killing of a rapper by a Golden Dawn supporter, nine of the party’s lawmakers have been prosecuted on criminal charges.

headline: Governor of Nigeria’s Central Bank Is Fired After Warning of Missing Oil Revenue
abstract: President Goodluck Jonathan’s dismissal of Lamido Sanusi, who had charged that billions in oil revenue was missing, was seen as a lack of resolve in tackling corruption.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — President Goodluck Jonathan of Nigeria removed the governor of the country’s central bank from his post on Thursday, after the bank governor repeatedly charged that billions of dollars in oil revenue owed to the treasury was missing.

headline: Britain: Defense Heard in Hacking Case
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper unit, testified in court on Thursday that she did not know about the activities of a private investigator who has admitted that he hacked phones on behalf of The News of the World.
lead_paragraph: Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper unit, testified in court on Thursday that during her time as the editor of the tabloid The News of the World she did not know about the activities of a private investigator who has admitted that he hacked phones on behalf of the newspaper. Ms. Brooks, 45, is accused of condoning hacking into telephone voice mail systems while she was the editor of The News of the World; of authorizing the bribing of a public official for an article; and of trying to hide evidence from the police. She denies it all. On the first day of her defense in the trial’s fourth month, Ms. Brooks’s lawyer asked if the involvement of the investigator, Glenn Mulcaire, in intercepting voice mail messages was ever brought to her attention between May 2000 and June 2003. “No, not at all,” she said. Earlier, she was cleared of a charge that she had authorized a reporter to pay for a picture of Prince William in a bikini.

headline: China: Dissident’s Wife Is Hospitalized
abstract: Liu Xia, the wife of Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned dissident who won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize, has been hospitalized, according to family friends.
lead_paragraph: Liu Xia, the wife of Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned dissident who won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize, has been hospitalized, according to family friends. Ms. Liu, who has been under house arrest for the past three years, is said to be suffering from a heart ailment and severe depression. A poet and photographer, Ms. Liu, 52, has not been charged with any crime. Her husband, a writer and democracy advocate, is serving an 11-year sentence after being convicted of subversion charges. She was admitted to a Beijing hospital on Tuesday, and family members have been pressing the authorities to let her leave the country for medical care.

headline: New York Is Removing Over 400 Children From 2 Homeless Shelters
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio will announce on Friday that his administration is removing hundreds of children from two shelters that inspectors have repeatedly cited for deplorable conditions, officials said.
lead_paragraph: In the face of New York’s mounting homeless crisis, Mayor Bill de Blasio will announce on Friday that his administration is removing hundreds of children from two city-owned homeless shelters that inspectors have repeatedly cited for deplorable conditions over the last decade, officials said.

headline: In Ukraine’s West, a Jumping-Off Point for Volunteers Heading to Kiev
abstract: Lviv is the recruiting center for volunteers to staff the bloodied protest ramparts in the capital, 330 miles to the east.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — This rebellious city in western Ukraine, which basically declared itself autonomous as the nation’s political crisis escalated into deadly violence this week, is the recruiting center for volunteers to staff the bloodied protester ramparts in the capital, Kiev, 330 miles to the east.

abstract: Operating under the radar, the creators of the app have worked to fulfill a singular vision: Create a good messaging service.
lead_paragraph: Operating under the radar, the creators of the app have worked to fulfill a singular vision: Create a good messaging service.

headline: Iraq: Mortar Fire Kills at Least 21 People
abstract: Seven mortar shells fell on the Shiite town of Musayyib, south of Baghdad, on Thursday, killing 21 people and wounding 65, Iraqi officials said.
lead_paragraph: Seven mortar shells fell on the Shiite town of Musayyib, south of Baghdad, on Thursday, killing 21 people and wounding 65, Iraqi officials said. Security officials said the shells had been fired from a Sunni area near Musayyib where security forces were conducting a weeklong search for fighters from the militant group the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria. No group immediately claimed responsibility for Thursday’s attack on the residential area. The Sunni area, Jurf al-Sakhar, was one of Al Qaeda’s strongholds during some of the worst of the sectarian fighting in 2006 and 2007. Now members of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria have moved to the area, according to officials, prompting the sweeps.

headline: U.N. Secretary General Seeks More Help for Central African Republic
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Ban Ki-moon called on Thursday for an immediate deployment of more troops and aid to rescue the Central African Republic from a de facto partition of the country into Christian and Muslim areas.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, on Thursday called for an immediate deployment of more troops and aid to rescue the Central African Republic from a de facto partition of the country into Christian and Muslim areas. France has already increased its contingent, and the European Union has said it will start sending as many as 1,000 soldiers to the country in March.

abstract: Alpine skiing, curling and men’s hockey are among Friday’s highlights at the Sochi Games.

headline: ‘Anchorman 2’ Returns (Call It 2 ½)
abstract: “Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues,” released in December and still on a handful of screens, is being rereleased next week, with new, raunchier jokes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — TAKE a raunchy Hollywood comedy, remove the jokes, and what do you have left?

headline: What’s on Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13) STING: THE LAST SHIP Sting performs songs from his latest album, “The Last Ship,” and regales the audience with memories of growing up in the shipbuilding community of Wallsend, England — including how, when the queen’s motorcade drove by, he longed to be in her car — in this concert recorded on Oct. 2 at the Public Theater in Manhattan and presented here by “Great Performances.” The program also chronicles the creation of the Broadway musical “The Last Ship,” with music and lyrics by Sting, above, and a book by John Logan and Brian Yorkey, which is to begin previews on Sept. 30 at the Neil Simon Theater. “ ‘The Last Ship’ contains Sting’s first new songs in nearly a decade, and he has said that they came in a surge,” Nate Chinen wrote in The New York Times. “The breakthrough was in writing for voices other than his own,” though Sting admits that one song features “the self-taught, pompous intellectual of the shipyard, played by me, of course.” Mr. Chinen added, “The dream-filled boy that Sting once was, and the privileged artist he became, have that much in common.”

headline: The Red Chains of Bureaucracy That ‘Torment’ Chinese
abstract: A politician in the southern city of Guangzhou has listed more than 100 documents the average citizen needs in a lifetime, arguing that China’s bureaucracy is too tortuous. His proposal for streamlining has been met with approval.
lead_paragraph: The Germans coined a word for its excesses: Behördengang. Franz Kafka, the great novelist of pain, described its dehumanizing effect: “The chains of tormented mankind are made out of red tape.” And Confucian China may have perfected it: bureaucracy.

headline: North Carolina Rallies Late to Upset No. 5 Duke
abstract: The Tar Heels used key baskets by Marcus Paige and a 43-30 rebounding edge to secure the first win by an unranked North Carolina team over a top-five Duke team since March 1990.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Inside the Dean Smith Dome, fans clad in Carolina blue lusted for an upset. They roared for it, demanded it and urged the underdog Tar Heels to complete their mission against No. 5 Duke.

headline: Ukraine Has Deal, but Both Russia and Protesters Appear Wary
abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovych agreed to reduced powers and Parliament moved to free his imprisoned rival, but many protesters want him to resign.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — A deal aimed at ending a lethal spiral of violence in Ukraine began to show serious strains late Friday just hours after it had been signed, with angry protesters shouting down opposition members of Parliament who negotiated the accord and a militant leader threatening armed attacks if President Viktor F. Yanukovych did not step down by morning.

headline: Profit Falls at French Luxury and Sportswear Group Kering
abstract: A sharp drop in earnings at Puma, a sponsor of the Olympic sprinter Usain Bolt, and a slowdown in growth at Gucci marred the company’s annual results.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Profit at Kering, the French luxury-to-lifestyle conglomerate, slumped last year, reflecting sharply weaker sales at Puma, its struggling sportswear brand, as well as a slowdown in growth at Gucci, its flagship high-end brand.

abstract: What role does the song “Let It Go” play in the film “Frozen”?
lead_paragraph: In “The Nominees Are Blockbusters” Melena Ryzik writes about the making of “Frozen.” Watch the video and read the article to answer the questions.

headline: Born by a River, Watching the Change
abstract: For some, Braddock, Pa., embodies the decline of the small Rust Belt town. For LaToya Ruby Frazier, it is home, which she explores in a series of elegiac images.
lead_paragraph: The interplay of images in LaToya Ruby Frazier’s “Landscape of the Body (Epilepsy Test)” is haunting: a portrait of the artist’s mother in a disheveled hospital bed hooked up to monitors, juxtaposed with a shot of the Braddock, Pa., hospital’s demolition taken shortly after her stay, its tangled wiring exposed (Slide 14).

headline: How Much of a Daredevil Are You?
abstract: How much physical stimulation do you need? How comfortable are you in taking physical risks when you do sports? Are you always trying to go faster or higher, or are you happier with a slower, more controlled experience?
lead_paragraph: How much physical stimulation do you need? How comfortable are you in taking physical risks when you do sports? Are you always trying to go faster or higher, or are you happier with a slower, more controlled experience?

headline: Shell to Sell Refinery and Gas Stations in Australia
abstract: The $2.6 billion deal with the commodity trading house Vitol illustrates changes in the international oil business as companies give up less profitable assets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Royal Dutch Shell said Friday that it would sell most of its Australian refining and marketing business to Vitol, a large commodity trading house, for about $2.6 billion.

headline: Snapdeal, the EBay of India, Sees Plenty of Room to Grow
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Customer Relations', 'E-Commerce', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Foreign Investments', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The e-commerce company has been called the eBay of India, but its chief executive has been drawing parallels to the Chinese juggernaut Alibaba.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE – Snapdeal and Flipkart, India’s two largest online marketplaces, are frequently recipients of honorific, hopeful nicknames. They are, respectively, called the eBay and Amazon of India.

headline: The Courage of Transgender Soldiers
keywords: ['Gender', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Why does the U.S. military still define gender nonconformity as a disorder?
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — IT was 2 a.m., just a few days before Christmas, in a remote part of Afghanistan. Eight hours into a 16-hour shift, Ryan, a 23-year-old American naval sailor, was standing tense and alert, watching the footage of soldiers undertaking a nearby mission on a screen in front of him.

headline: South Korea Aids North as Families Are Reunited
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Families and Family Life', 'Korean War']
abstract: The shipment of medicine and powdered milk to North Korea was seen as another sign of thawing relations between the two countries.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea on Friday approved a shipment of $988,000 worth of medicine and powdered milk for North Korea and promised more humanitarian aid as the two Koreas continued the emotional reunions of families separated by the Korean War six decades ago.

headline: New York Today: Winter Interruptus
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: rain today, glorious weather tomorrow, and following the mayor’s speeding car.
lead_paragraph: Updated 11:32 a.m.

headline: Stray Dogs and Stateless Babies
abstract: The Bosnian government’s paralysis has reached its limit — and angry protests are spreading.
lead_paragraph: ON National Geographic Traveler Magazine’s Best of the World list this year, Sarajevo joined such select destinations as Liechtenstein, Puglia and Rocky Mountain National Park. But had the innocent tourist recently visited “the Balkan urban phoenix,” as the list labeled the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, he would most certainly have run into packs of stray dogs roaming the city.

headline: Sleep Apnea May Worsen Diabetes
abstract: Sleep apnea can worsen blood sugar control in people with Type 2 diabetes by disrupting the deepest stage of sleep, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Sleep apnea can worsen blood sugar control in people with Type 2 diabetes by disrupting the deepest stage of sleep, a new study suggests. The findings provide another good reason for people with sleep apnea to wear a CPAP mask that helps assure uninterrupted breathing, the standard treatment for the condition, throughout the night.

headline: Billionaire’s Arrest Intensifies Focus on Former Security Chief
abstract: Liu Han is one of several tycoons arrested in the southwestern province of Sichuan in the past year, in a crackdown on corruption that has netted several former associates of China’s former head of internal security, Zhou Yongkang.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese billionaire, Liu Han, stands accused of running a “mafia-style gang’’ that ran roughshod over one of the country’s most populous provinces for more than a decade, reportedly killing nine people and bullying villagers into surrendering their land to fuel his growing empire that included real estate, mining and natural gas.

headline: Beijing Official Detained in Investigation of Former Security Chief
abstract: The investigation, centered on the former head of law and order policy, reaches a secretive realm in China’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Communist Party corruption investigation focusing on the former head of China’s domestic security apparatus has reached into the secretive realm of the intelligence services with the detention of a senior official, people close to party and military leaders said this week.

headline: Sweden Beats Finland, 2-1, to Advance to Hockey Final
abstract: Times reporters offer live updates, and analysis of the men’s hockey semifinal between Finland and Sweden.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in three Olympics, Sweden will be playing for the gold medal in men’s hockey. Sweden, the 2006 gold medalist, defeated its longtime rival Finland, 2-1, Thursday.

headline: Your Ancestors, Your Fate
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Names, Personal', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Surnames reveal that social mobility is much slower than we think.
lead_paragraph: Inequality of income and wealth has risen in America since the 1970s, yet a large-scale research study recently found that social mobility hadn’t changed much during that time. How can that be?

headline: 2 Prominent Women Under Detention Are Hospitalized
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Lawyers and friends of Liu Xia and Cao Shunli said long-term detention had damaged their health.
lead_paragraph: Two prominent women — Liu Xia and Cao Shunli — were hospitalized in poor health this week, after months or years of detention, according to their lawyers and friends.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Bets on Users First and Profits Later
abstract: The social networking giant’s agreement to buy the messaging start-up WhatsApp for up to $19 billion is risky, but follows a trend in valuing the number of users over revenue.
lead_paragraph: Technology companies have always been paranoid about missing the next big thing, be it email, e-commerce or social media, David Gelles reports.

headline: A Business Owner Talks About Having to Cut Costs to Stay Competitive
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Small Business', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: That leads to a discussion of how important it is for a business to grow.
lead_paragraph: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, Susan Parker shared some of the challenges facing her company, Bari Jay.

headline: Militants Attack Presidential Palace in Somalia
abstract: President Hassan Sheik Mohamud was unhurt, according to a United Nations official, after explosions and gunfire rocked the compound in the capital.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — In a deadly attack on the heart of the Somali government, multiple explosions and a firefight erupted on Friday near the presidential palace in Mogadishu, killing 12 people, nine of them militants, officials said. The Shabab, the militant Somali Islamist group, claimed responsibility.

headline: Detroit Outlines Map to Solvency, Stressing Repair
abstract: The city presented its bankruptcy judge with the first official road map to its future: a plan for settling its debt and making Detroit livable again.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Seven months after this city entered bankruptcy, its leaders on Friday presented a federal judge with the first official road map to Detroit’s future — documents designed to show how it aims to settle its $18 billion debt to creditors and make itself livable again.

headline: Tech’s New Feeding Frenzy
abstract: Facebook’s deal to acquire WhatsApp shows that competition has never been more intense between technology companies fighting for the same customers and wallets. | Hedge funds are dipping their toes in advertising thanks to recent changes in S.E.C. regulations. | Banker go-to GrubHub Seamless files for an I.P.O. | The Fed finds vitriol among Wall Street’s financiers.
lead_paragraph: TECH’S NEW FEEDING FRENZY  |  As soon as Facebook announced on Wednesday that it would acquire WhatsApp, a text messaging start-up, for up to $19 billion, almost everyone asked the same question: Why? What it boils down to is Facebook’s fear of missing out (F.O.M.O., for you cool kids). “Today, with Google, Facebook and others all fighting for the same customers and wallets, the competition has never been more intense, and big companies have never had to act so quickly — and with such conviction — to avoid being left behind,” David Gelles writes in DealBook. But the deal has raised fears that, by valuing the number of users above revenue, Facebook is inflating another dot-com bubble.

headline: Applying for College? Writing About Money?
abstract: The New York Times asks high school seniors who are applying for college this year to send us application essays that have to do with money.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times is seeking college application essays about money, working or social class from current high school seniors. We will publish the best ones in a “Your Money” column in May (and pay the writers our normal freelance rate), as we did last year. Please send essays to MoneyEssays@nytimes.com.

headline: Structural Reform is the Last Refuge of Scoundrels
abstract: The OECD strikes again.
lead_paragraph: OK, let’s be clear: I’m in favor of structural reform (as long as it’s the right kind of reform). I’m also in favor of peace, kindness, and good coffee for everyone.

headline: Behind These Olympic Doors Is Anyone’s Guess
abstract: Mysterious rooms with odd signs at venues in Sochi underscore how the Games occupy an exotic alternative world complete with its own secret language.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Deep in the back alleyways of the Ice Cube Curling Center in the Olympic Park stands a door marked “TER Secondary.” It is not clear exactly what goes on in there or why it is so close to doors labeled “Language Services” and “Venue Technology Operations,” but it is further evidence, if any was needed, that the Olympics occupy an exotic alternative world that makes sense only on its own terms.

headline: Court Convicts 8 in 2012 Protest Against Putin
abstract: The prolonged trial of the eight over their role in a violent protest before the inauguration of President Vladimir V. Putin in 2012 has become a symbol of the Kremlin’s stifling of dissent.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Eight people were convicted on Friday of taking part in a violent protest before the inauguration of President Vladimir V. Putin in 2012, after a prolonged trial that became a symbol of the Kremlin’s renewed stifling of political dissent.

headline: HearSay Economics
abstract: Keynes was right to do battle with a very real fallacy.
lead_paragraph: David Glasner has another interesting post on the history of economic thought, this time on Say’s Law — which, at least since Keynes, has come to be identified as the doctrine that shortfalls in overall demand aren’t possible, because money has to be spent on something. If people save more, well, their money goes into banks, which lend it out, so it finances business investment, and overall spending doesn’t change.

headline: Shredlocks and Lucky Socks
abstract: Olympic athletes in Sochi talk about the rituals and superstitions that help them focus.
lead_paragraph: Olympic athletes in Sochi talk about the rituals and superstitions that help them focus.

abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Near the scene of several recent pedestrian fatalities, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton displayed his concern and a quick wit.

headline: ‘Act of Killing’ and Oscar Voters’ Aversion to Violence
abstract: The director of the film about mass murder in Indonesia says his biggest challenge has been getting Academy members to see the documentary.
lead_paragraph: No feature documentary film in recent years has provoked more debate than Joshua Oppenheimer’s “Act of Killing,” one of five nominees for the Oscar in that category. It’s not only that Mr. Oppenheimer tackles an extremely difficult subject — the mass murders that followed a military coup in Indonesia in 1965 and resulted in the deaths of as many as a million people — but also the way he tells the story, through extensive use of re-enactments featuring members of death squads that carried out the killings.

headline: Ain’t It Not Grand?
abstract: BowlesSimpsonism is dead.
lead_paragraph: Hurray: President Obama has dropped his notion of using a change in the price index to cut Social Security benefits.

headline: In Slalom, Mikaela Shiffrin Zips to Bottom and Reaches the Pinnacle
abstract: Looking powerful and poised, Shiffrin, 18, fulfilled her talent and secured a gold medal in an event last won by an American 42 years ago.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Mikaela Shiffrin, the 18-year-old wunderkind of ski racing, is a product of a countercultural movement in American youth sports, an initiative of parents who encourage their children to focus on the process of athletic achievement instead of the results. In theory, both the journey and the destination are enhanced.

headline: Inadvertently Baring Necessities
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Blu-Ray Disc', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Disney’s animated “The Jungle Book,” newly released on Blu-ray, reflected the times in which it was made, intentionally or not.
lead_paragraph: Although the name Disney is synonymous for some with timeless entertainment, “The Jungle Book” occupies a special place in Disney company history. Newly released on Blu-ray (as well as on DVD and digital HD), it was the last of the studio’s animated features to have been made under Walt Disney himself. That pop-culture titan died in December 1966, three years after work on the movie began and 10 months before its release.

headline: In the Back of the Bobsled, the Not-So-Scenic Route
abstract: Brakemen never lay eyes on the finish line: with their heads buried and their trust in the pilot, they basically hang on, speeding along at 80 m.p.h. in total darkness.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Judith Vis is a member of the Dutch women’s bobsled team and, by all accounts, a dutiful and conscientious athlete. Yet earlier this month — only minutes after she completed a practice run at the Sanki Sliding Center — she struggled with a relatively basic question.
