abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Stasha Yatchuk (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: No Surprise, Fed Was Biggest Buyer of Treasuries in 2013
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: Japan was the largest foreign investors in Treasuries, replacing China.
lead_paragraph: THE Federal Reserve financed most of the government’s deficit in 2013, in sharp contrast to the year before, when the Fed did not add to its holdings of Treasury securities. The American private sector appears to have been a net seller of Treasuries in 2013, but the foreign private sector was a substantial buyer, according to government estimates released this week.

headline: The Final Battle for a REIT May Be Drawing Near
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: A year after two investment firms announced a campaign to “maximize value” at CommonWealth REIT, Steven Davidoff wonders in the Deal Professor column if the fight for control is really over.
lead_paragraph: Is this the endgame for the battle to control CommonWealth REIT, or will shareholders once again be left to wait for the Portnoys, the father and son who control the real estate investment concern, to admit defeat?

headline: Fed Misread Crisis in 2008, Records Show
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The transcripts provide new insights into the debates, miscalculations and actions of the Federal Reserve in assessing and countering the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the morning after Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy in 2008, most Federal Reserve officials still believed that the American economy would keep growing despite the metastasizing financial crisis.

headline: California: 4 Killed at Indian Tribal Meeting
abstract: A former tribal leader in California opened fire during eviction proceedings on Thursday, killing four people and injuring two others, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A former tribal leader in California opened fire during eviction proceedings on Thursday, killing four people and injuring two others, the police said. The former leader, Sherie Rhoades, 44, shot five people inside the headquarters of the Cedarville Rancheria in Alturas, the police said, before stabbing a sixth person with a knife. Leaders were holding a meeting about evicting several residents, including Ms. Rhoades, the Modoc County Record, a local newspaper, quoted the police as saying. Ms. Rhoades is facing murder and attempted murder charges. The police had not identified the dead, two men and two women, as of midnight Thursday. According to its website, the Cedarville Rancheria is a small, federally recognized tribe of 35 members on 26 acres in Cedarville, about 20 minutes from Alturas.

abstract: Japan promised to begin an investigation into the mutilation of hundreds of copies of Anne Frank’s diary and other books related to her at public libraries across Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan on Friday promised to begin an investigation into the mysterious mutilation of hundreds of copies of “Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl” and other books related to her at public libraries across Tokyo.

headline: In Store | Pamela Love’s Finer Things
abstract: Seven years after she began creating jewelry, the young designer makes her first foray into the realm of precious stones.
lead_paragraph: “I love to layer on a lot of big sterling silver statement jewelry,” says Pamela Love, “but I’m getting a bit more delicate.” The young jewelry designer has drawn a celebrity and fashion-world following to her signature bohemian aesthetic since she began making pieces in her Brooklyn apartment in 2006. She has since gotten married and moved into a design studio in Manhattan — and is starting to notice that her clientele has been growing up, too. And so, this week, Love has reached another milestone: her first fine-jewelry line called, appropriately, Pamela Love Fine.

headline: The Home Crowd at the Sochi Games
abstract: Russian fans have welcomed the Sochi Games as an opportunity to be creative and patriotic in the way they dress for the events.
lead_paragraph: Russian fans have welcomed the Sochi Games as an opportunity to be creative and patriotic in the way they dress for the events.

headline: A Wine Trail, by Ski and Snowshoe
abstract: A winter wine trail in the Leelanau Peninsula in Michigan can be covered by skis or snowshoes.
lead_paragraph: In many wine regions of the world, aficionados can bike or hike between tasting rooms. But Michigan offers a novel vineyard-to-vineyard option: by ski and snowshoe.

headline: Send a Payment With Square Cash, the Service That’s Free, for Now
keywords: ['Mobile Commerce', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Debit Cards', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: The service from the mobile payment company Square does not charge a fee, a rare benefit. But the downside is that you cannot use a credit card.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare that any new product or service quickly and simply makes our financial lives a whole lot easier. It’s rarer still that the offering is free.

lead_paragraph: The prime minister’s cat; get a haircut.

headline: Who Made That Ski Lift?
abstract: If it worked for bananas in Honduras, why not for humans on the slopes?
lead_paragraph: “It is essential,” wrote the railway magnate William Averell Harriman in a telegram dated April 15, 1936, “. . . to develop a method of lifting skiers 2,000 feet above the valley floor.” For America’s first ski resort — Idaho’s Sun Valley — Harriman wanted a new approach to moving skiers up the slopes that would be more comfortable than the pulls and hoists that had come before. So he posed the problem to his staff at the Union Pacific office in Omaha.

headline: Reply All: The 2.9.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: SEXLESS BUT EQUAL

headline: Red(dit) Alert at the Workplace!
abstract: What to do with a socially overnetworked colleague.
lead_paragraph: I recently realized a colleague posts several times a day to the website Reddit. If the opinions he shares on this site are about his boss or his work environment (or even reveal his political leanings), he could potentially lose his current contract and have a hard time getting a new position in our insular field. I find this colleague to be immature and ill suited for our profession — he seems to spend most of the day posting on Reddit — and some of his posts have made his identity obvious to me. Do I have an ethical obligation to tell him that this behavior could hurt his career? NAME WITHHELD, PENNSYLVANIA

headline: David J. Hand’s Lottery Tips
abstract: If you insist on playing, the statistician thinks randomness is the best policy.
lead_paragraph: Your latest book, “The Improbability Principle,” aims to prove that extremely improbable events are in fact commonplace. Can you explain that a bit?  Things like roulette wheels coming up in strange configurations or the same lottery numbers hitting two weeks in a row are clearly very rare events, but if you look at the number of lotteries and the number of roulette wheels, then you realize that you should actually expect these sorts of things to happen. I think within the statistical community people accept this. They’re aware of the impact of the law of truly large numbers.

headline: Milan Fashion Week Street Style: Day 2
abstract: Street-style photos from our NYTimesFashion Instagram account.
lead_paragraph: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for Milan Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

headline: Working to Block Those Advertising Annoyances
abstract: There are simple, free ways to stop automated calls, paper junk mail and targeted online ads.
lead_paragraph: WITH so much attention to digital overload — too much email, too many photos on Facebook, too many mindless tweets — some of life’s biggest annoyances are still analog, especially when people want to sell you things.

headline: Inside the Fed’s 2008 Proceedings
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A running analysis of the transcripts of the Federal Reserve’s policy meetings at the height of the financial crisis, released Friday.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the Federal Reserve released the transcripts of its policy meetings of 2008, a year that began with little hint that a recession and a world financial crisis were unfolding. The transcripts provide new insights into the debates, miscalculations and actions of the Fed’s policy making council, the Federal Open Market Committee, in assessing and countering the crisis. In a running analysis of the documents, reporters for The New York Times shared their findings.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Canada Defeats United States in Men’s Hockey Semifinal
abstract: Times reporters offer updates, analysis and observations from the men’s ice hockey semifinal between the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: Canada defeated the United States, 1-0, in the semifinals of the men’s hockey tournament to advance to the gold medal game.

headline: That Sweet Lamb in Wolf’s Clothing
abstract: Leonardo DiCaprio brings a duality to his roles, an ambivalence about wealth and success and their moral cost.
lead_paragraph: It seems likely that Leonardo DiCaprio will not win an Oscar next Sunday for his portrayal of the financial scam artist Jordan Belfort in “The Wolf of Wall Street.” As a rule, Academy voters prefer displays of suffering and stoicism in the face of adversity from leading men. Jordan’s brief sojourn in a country-club prison hardly qualifies; nor do the ill effects of too many quaaludes in the film’s most celebrated scene not involving cocaine and a prostitute’s rear end. And though Jordan gives up stock swindles for sales seminars, he can hardly be said to undergo the kind of redemption that the Academy likes to consecrate.

headline: Being Human Seems Enough
abstract: Jennifer Lawrence, at 23, has displayed personal qualities, in work and life, that make her more than a collection of performances.
lead_paragraph: It was at the 2008 Venice Film Festival that Jennifer Lawrence — future Oscar winner, squirrel skinner, American warrior — signaled that she was no ordinary starlet. She wasn’t yet famous then, just a paparazzi afterthought to Charlize Theron, her co-star in “The Burning Plain,” one of those agonizingly dopey movies that play at major festivals because of their red-carpet power. During a pseudo-event for the movie, Ms. Theron spoke about the limited number of older actresses working in the industry and showered praise on another co-star, Kim Basinger, who wasn’t there. Ms. Lawrence apparently silenced the room by joking that Ms. Basinger had died. The girl can’t help it!

headline: Start-Up Disguises Wearable Tech as Jewelry
abstract: Cuff, a new wearables start-up, unveiled a line of accessories this week that look more like the jewelry featured in an issue of Vogue, than hardware from the pages of Wired.
lead_paragraph: There are two broad strains of wearable technology emerging: the doo-dads that proclaim their techiness from the wrists, faces and other body parts that they are fastened to, and those that try to conceal that quality.

headline: Video and Tweets From Kiev’s Independence Square
abstract: As live video streams and messages posted on social networks from Kiev’s Independence Square showed, Ukrainian protesters remained defiant on Friday, calling for the resignation of the president.
lead_paragraph: This post will be updated as new information becomes available.

headline: New Yorker to Be Music Director of Phoenix Symphony
abstract: The symphony’s new music director is Tito Muñoz, a native New Yorker has led French orchestras in Lorraine and Nancy.
lead_paragraph: The Phoenix Symphony’s new music director is a native New Yorker who goes west by way of France: Tito Muñoz, who has led French orchestras in Lorraine and Nancy.

headline: Crossing a Divide, Seeking Good
abstract: Secular and religious cultures meet when the Crossing, an evangelical church in Missouri, sponsors the True/False Film Festival’s award to subjects of documentaries.
lead_paragraph: As he does every year, David Wilson recently faced a decision about which documentary film to honor with a major prize in the True/False Film Fest, which he co-directs. And as he does each year, he reached out to the Dave Cover, a founding pastor of the Crossing, a 4,000-member Evangelical Presbyterian church in Columbia, Mo., to set up a screening of a candidate.

headline: Miscarriage, Superstition and the Jewish Baby Shower
abstract: After my first pregnancy ended in miscarriage, I spent my second following every superstition in hopes of avoiding a repeat of my misfortune.
lead_paragraph: No baby shower. No baby names. No nursery set up in the appropriate bedroom or apartment corner. That’s the common Jewish approach to pregnancy. The baby shower mishegas is an outright invitation to the evil eye to descend upon the unborn baby in vengeance for rubbing your happiness in others’ faces and “counting your chickens before they hatch.”

headline: Special Squalor
abstract: Reviews in The Times captured the variety of reaction to William S. Burroughs’s “Naked Lunch.”
lead_paragraph: Within a five-day period in 1962, two reviews in The Times captured the variety of reaction to William S. Burroughs’s “Naked Lunch.” The book had appeared three years earlier in more lenient Paris; Charles Poore wrote that it arrived in the United States “already somewhat barnacled with notoriety and no doubt considered demi-passe in demi-avant-garde quadrangles.” Poore sniffed at the news that participants at an Edinburgh festival “pronounced it a work of considerable influence. This we can easily believe, in view of the more esoteric tendencies of current writing. The sad realm of squalor may look to it for, shall we say, inspiration.”

headline: Rural Life
abstract: New books by Lynn Darling, Suzanne McMinn, Bryce Andrews and Evelyn I. Funda.
lead_paragraph: OUT OF THE WOODS

headline: An Indian Appetizer, Subtly Spiced
abstract: “The Lunchbox,” opening in the United States on Friday, is a rarity in the Indian film industry: a quiet movie of unexpressed anguish and yearning set in brash Mumbai.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Mumbai is one of cinema’s great divas. She storms onto the screen with blasts of color, noise and music. She can be beautiful, with ocean views and stunning tableaus. And she can be ugly, her slums among the world’s worst.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

lead_paragraph: Seigo Neckwear on Madison Avenue is a small boutique specializing in regular ties, bow ties and pocket squares.

lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me."

headline: Etro: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Pledging a Fraternity of Silk
abstract: Many newscasters, doctors and lawyers are united by neckties designed by Seigo Katsuragawa, who cares for his creations deeply.
lead_paragraph: There is a certain kind of man who, even amid the sea of New York men in ties, can spot a fellow Seigo traveler. Yo-Yo Ma, Eliot Spitzer and select others — newscasters, doctors, lawyers — are members of this tacit clique, which extends well beyond the city limits. These ties that unite them come from Seigo Neckwear, and each one is the handiwork of Seigo Katsuragawa, the designer and proprietor, who cares for his creations deeply. “Each tie is our baby,” he said.

headline: Pharrell Williams Auctioning Grammy Hat for Charity
abstract: Bidding has surpassed $10,000 for the Vivienne Westwood hat Mr. Williams wore at the Grammy Awards.
lead_paragraph: The Vivienne Westwood hat that earned Pharrell Williams a great deal of attention at the Grammy Awards last month is now for sale on eBay. With nine days to go, the high bid stood at $10,500 on Friday, with 64 bids so far. Proceeds are to benefit From One Hand to Another, a nonprofit that Mr. Williams founded in 2008 to support community centers and education.

headline: Movie Review: 'In Secret'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "In Secret."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "In Secret."

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE HOUR OF PERIL: The Secret Plot to Murder Lincoln Before the Civil War,  by Daniel Stashower. (Minotaur, $16.99.) This is a swift and detailed rendering of the little-known Baltimore-based plot to assassinate Abraham Lincoln in February 1861, days before he assumed the presidency. Stashower’s narrative hurtles along Lincoln’s train route from Springfield, Ill., to Washington; standing tall among the conspirators and politicos is the “fierce and incorruptible lawman” Allan Pinkerton, who led efforts to thwart the scheme.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SIXTH EXTINCTION: An Unnatural History,  by Elizabeth Kolbert. (Holt, $28.) A powerful examination of the role of man-made climate change in causing the current spasm of plant and animal loss that threatens the planet.

headline: Out of Character
abstract: B. J. Novak’s story collection covers Justin Bieber, Nelson Mandela and cereal box sweepstakes.
lead_paragraph: Before you dismiss B. J. Novak’s debut fiction collection, “One More Thing,” as the latest example of a Hollywood actor’s trespassing into the far more glamorous and affluent gated community of short stories, read his humor piece “If I Had a Nickel.”

headline: ‘A Guest of My Time’
abstract: George F. Kennan’s diaries display his estrangement from contemporary America.
lead_paragraph: “All conservatism begins with loss,” Andrew Sullivan writes. “If we never knew loss, we would never feel the need to conserve.” That’s why the first and still canonical conservative text is Edmund Burke’s “Reflections on the Revolution in France,” a lamentation on the uprooting of that country’s monarchical order. And that’s why America, as an experiment in modernity, hasn’t had many genuine conservatives in its history.

headline: Monument Man
abstract: The 16th president surveys his life in Jerome Charyn’s novel.
lead_paragraph: No president has written as well as Abraham Lincoln. He could thrill, reason, prophesy, mourn and crack jokes. Who wouldn’t want to read a book in his own words — all the more enticing if it scanted the political and administrative minutiae that fill his collected works and gave us a window into his inner life?

headline: Poet of the Caribbean
abstract: A collection of Derek Walcott’s poems offers work from the whole of his 65-year career.
lead_paragraph: “Writing poetry is an unnatural act,” Elizabeth Bishop once wrote. “It takes skill to make it seem natural.” The thought is kin to the one John Keats expressed in an 1818 letter to his friend John Taylor: “If Poetry comes not as naturally as the Leaves to a tree it had better not come at all.” Bishop and Keats both evoked a double sense of “natural”: that which is concerned with nature, with landscape, flora and fauna, and that which is unforced and fluent. In both senses, Derek Walcott is a natural poet.

headline: The Rage in Harlem
abstract: The many lives of the early-20th-century cultural impresario Carl Van Vechten.
lead_paragraph: One of the milestones of modernism occurred in Paris on May 29, 1913, when “The Rite of Spring” debuted at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées and almost caused a riot. Startled by Stravinsky’s pounding rhythms and Nijinsky’s salacious choreography, the well-heeled philistines in the audience roared with disapproval while the connoisseurs, the happy few, tried shouting them down. One of the most memorable accounts of that first night was written by the American critic Carl Van Vechten, who allied himself decidedly with the latter camp, reporting that a kindred soul in the seat behind him was so carried away that he began beating a tattoo on the critic’s head with his fists. “My emotion was so great,” Van Vechten wrote, “that I did not feel the blows for some time.” Sharing his box was another pillar of the avant-garde, Gertrude Stein, who remembered certain details differently — as well she should, Van Vechten assured her. They had actually attended the less eventful second night of the ballet, but, as he suavely added, “one must only be accurate about such details in a work of fiction.”

headline: King of Cool
abstract: In “Naked Lunch” and dozens of other works, William S. Burroughs laid down a vision that shaped ’60s youth culture.
lead_paragraph: William S. Burroughs “didn’t say anything for shock value,” his student Sam Kashner once observed. “His life had shock value.”

headline: The Last Trial
abstract: Short stories about Kafka and people who loved him, including Max Brod and Milena Jasenska.
lead_paragraph: In Jay Cantor’s 1988 novel, “Krazy Kat,” the feline heroine praises Rube Goldberg contraptions: “Krazy liked having her mind pulled through one of Goldberg’s gadgets. He was a real artist; he had a vision.” Cantor’s vision often fo­cuses on public figures: George Herriman’s cartoon cat and J. Robert Oppenheimer; Che Guevara in Cantor’s first novel, “The Death of Che Guevara”; and now Kafka in “Forgiving the Angel.” These works and his graphic novel, “Aaron and Ahmed,” are contraptions of mixed materials: animal and human characters in “Krazy Kat,” fact and invention in “Che Guevara,” lucid writing and hallucinatory illustrations (by James Romberger) in “Aaron and Ahmed,” and now a story putatively by Kafka and stories about contemporaries who loved him. All of Cantor’s fiction (including “Great Neck,” his un-­gadgety novel of the American 1960s and ’70s) pulls the reader’s mind through sensitive history: atom bomb tests at Alamogordo; the Cuban revolution; the events of 9/11; and, in “Forgiving the Angel,” Stalin’s gulag and Hitler’s death camps.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Omar,’ ‘Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me’ and ‘In Secret’
abstract: Times critics on “Omar,” “Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me” and “In Secret.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Omar,” “Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me” and “In Secret.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: A Singular Ballerina’s Multiple Paths
abstract: Misty Copeland, the sole black soloist in American Ballet Theater, has expanded her presence with a memoir, ads and concert appearances with Prince.
lead_paragraph: The dancer Misty Copeland has performed with the singer Prince and the pop group TLC. She has appeared in commercials for Diet Dr Pepper and Coach handbags, is national youth of the year ambassador for Boys & Girls Clubs of America and has a contract with the Under Armour sports clothing brand. She has her own dance wear line, and next month Simon & Schuster will publish her memoir, “Life in Motion: An Unlikely Ballerina.”

headline: Lundqvist and Sweden Return to Gold Medal Game
abstract: Henrik Lundqvist made 25 saves and Erik Karlsson scored the game-winning goal as Sweden beat Finland.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — In 2006, Henrik Lundqvist was a 23-year-old rookie for the Rangers who went to the Turin Games motivated to win a gold medal for the older players on the Swedish team that he grew up idolizing.

headline: Garrick Utley, a Mainstay at NBC News, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Utley was one of a rare breed in television news, a full-time foreign correspondent. He reported from some 75 countries in a career that included 30 years at NBC.
lead_paragraph: Garrick Utley, a former anchor for NBC News who for many years was one of a rare breed in television news reporting, a full-time foreign correspondent, died Thursday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: “Out of the Black” featuring Robyn
abstract: A single from Neneh Cherry’s new album, “The Blank Project.”
lead_paragraph: A single from Neneh Cherry’s new album, “The Blank Project.”

headline: ‘All Is Lost’s’ 2 Crucial Characters: Redford and That Boat
abstract: Aside from Robert Redford’s character makes, the boat provides all the sounds in the film, a challenge when it comes to creating the sound design.
lead_paragraph: Sound design is one of the technical aspects of filmmaking that may be the most mystifying to non-filmmakers; at the very least, sound editing and mixing are the categories that will probably cause you to lose your office Oscar pool.

headline: Ole Miss Students May Face Charges in Racist Episode
keywords: ['Vandalism', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Fraternities and Sororities']
abstract: The university said three freshmen from Georgia were refusing to speak with investigators about the desecration of a statue honoring the college’s first black student.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, Miss. — The University of Mississippi said Friday that students could face criminal charges for placing a noose on a statue honoring the college’s first black student, and a fraternity announced that it had expelled three men because of the incident.

headline: The Sounds of Things Ending, Continuing and Reshaping
abstract: Neneh Cherry has her first solo album since 1996, while the new album from Dawn Landes seems inspired by her recent divorce.
lead_paragraph: Neneh Cherry

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Martin Sixsmith, whose book “Philomena” inspired a movie nominated for four Oscars, plays a much smaller role in the book than he does in the film.
lead_paragraph: The Contender: Martin Sixsmith’s book “Philomena” was originally published in 2009, under the title “The Lost Child of Philomena Lee.” But once the movie version appeared last year, with its sleeker name and attention-­grabbing story of a single mother forced by nuns to give up her child for adoption, Sixsmith’s publishers retitled the book in a successful effort to cash in: Last week, “Philomena” was No. 17 in its fifth week on the paperback nonfiction list.

headline: Movie Review: 'Omar'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Omar."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Omar."

headline: The Marxist Dalai Lama Visits a Washington Shrine to Free Markets
abstract: The Dalai Lama, a self-described Marxist, discusses the possibility of “moral free enterprise.”
lead_paragraph: The Dalai Lama, who has said, “Deep inside, as far as social economic theory is concerned, I am a Marxist,” spent Thursday morning speaking on two panels at a Washington shrine to free markets and limited government — the American Enterprise Institute.

headline: From Johnny Weir’s Team, a Fresh Voice for NBC
abstract: NBC’s use of two figure-skating announcing teams created an opportunity to compare how each performed Thursday at an important moment.
lead_paragraph: NBC’s deployment of two figure skating announcing teams for the Sochi Games creates an opportunity to compare how each performed at an important moment.

headline: Getting Together to Say Goodbye
abstract: Vivian Girls died so that Williamsburg could ... live? Die? Get really into dance music?
lead_paragraph: Vivian Girls died so that Williamsburg could ... live? Die? Get really into dance music? For a time, it was the most exciting band in the city, and then, in the way the city squashes all good things, it was a band in pieces. Its legacy: three albums of dirty lite-garage-rock with strong instinctual melodies, some EPs and singles, a warp-speed tour through the Internet’s hype cycle — and a mention in a “Jeopardy” clue.

headline: Kentucky Challenger Sets Sights on Senate G.O.P. Heavyweight
abstract: Democrats are coalescing around Alison Lundergan Grimes, Kentucky’s secretary of state, who is seeking to unseat Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Alison Lundergan Grimes leaned across a table at an upscale bar near her home in this city’s historic district, sipped Maker’s Mark bourbon — a Kentucky staple — mixed with Diet Coke, and let out a belly laugh. “We’re in this campaign to kick butt!” she said.

headline: Son of Robert Johnson to Retain Photograph Rights
abstract: The Mississippi Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the son of the Delta blues musician retains the rights to the only two known photographs of his father and the profits from those pictures
lead_paragraph: The Mississippi Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the son of the Delta blues musician Robert Johnson retains the rights to the only two known photographs of his father and the profits from those pictures, The Associated Press reported.

headline: When Muscle Meets Tension
abstract: “Game of Arms” is to have its premiere Tuesday at 10 p.m. on AMC.
lead_paragraph: “In all of us there’s that little monster inside that comes out to play when the time is right,” says Cobra Rhodes, a trained chef and Zen master. “When it happens, it’s pretty intense. You’re trying to impose on someone, and they have other ideas. Someone’s going to eat, and someone’s not. Arm wrestling is when my monster comes out.” Mr. Rhodes, a world champion arm wrestler on the Rolling Thunder team of Kansas City, Mo., is one of the incredible hulks on view in “Game of Arms,” to have its premiere Tuesday at 10 p.m. on AMC.

headline: Tales of Vienna (With Coquette)
abstract: Hot on the heels of the Met’s recent production of Johann Strauss Jr.’s comic opera “Die Fledermaus” comes Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s “Oh ... Rosalinda!!” (1955).
lead_paragraph: Hot on the heels of the Met’s recent production of Johann Strauss Jr.’s comic opera “Die Fledermaus” comes Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s “Oh ... Rosalinda!!” (1955), an adaptation of the same material, playing March 1 at the Museum of Modern Art as part of Vienna Unveiled: A City in Cinema. The program, which marks the 50th anniversary of the Austrian Film Museum, runs from Friday through April 20 and spotlights some 70 movies pertaining to that city by the likes of Max Ophuls, Erich von Stroheim, Billy Wilder, Ernst Lubitsch, Michael Haneke, Carol Reed and Richard Linklater.

headline: A Little Sizzle for a Cold City
abstract: Starting Wednesday, the Joyce hosts a showcase of Brazilian dance.
lead_paragraph: When will it stop snowing? No, seriously: When? Brazil sounds good right about now, and a holiday in the theater is better than none. Starting Wednesday, the Joyce hosts a showcase of Brazilian dance starting with Mimulus Companhia de Dança’s take on the darkly humorous films of the Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar in “Dolores,” created by the artistic director, Jomar Mesquita, and company members.

headline: Protests Swell in Venezuela
abstract: In February, Venezuela was convulsed by the biggest protests since the country’s longtime president, the charismatic Hugo Chávez, died 11 months earlier.
lead_paragraph: In February, Venezuela was convulsed by the biggest protests since the country’s longtime president, the charismatic Hugo Chávez, died 11 months earlier.

headline: Still Rebels, Even as Maturity Looms
abstract: Calle 13’s new album, “Multi _Viral,” explores the Puerto Rican duo’s global concerns while looking at “more existential” themes.
lead_paragraph: Interviewing Calle 13, the firebrand Puerto Rican hip-hop duo, involved a little 21st-century technology. René Pérez Joglar, the rapper who calls himself Residente, was at Electric Lady Studios in Greenwich Village, where Calle 13’s new album, “Multi_Viral,” was being mixed. Residente’s stepbrother and partner in Calle 13, Eduardo Cabra Martínez, the producer and musician who calls himself Visitante, was on a tablet screen in a Skype window, speaking from his studio, Música Satánica, in San Juan.

headline: Filling a Museum With Baroque Art
abstract: The charismatic French countertenor Philippe Jaroussky has recently released a disc of arias written by the Baroque composer Porpora for Farinelli, his student and a famous castrato.
lead_paragraph: The charismatic French countertenor Philippe Jaroussky has recently released a disc of arias written by the Baroque composer Porpora for Farinelli, his student and a famous castrato. Sparks should fly on Tuesday, when Mr. Jaroussky joins the Venice Baroque Orchestra and the conductor Andrea Marcon to perform selections from the disc; the ensemble will also offer works by Vivaldi and Geminiani. (7 p.m., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 212-570-3949, metmuseum.org/tickets.)

headline: Many Losses, and Fans, Surround Yeshiva Coach’s Departure
abstract: Yeshiva University officials told Jonathan Halpert, its men’s basketball coach for 42 years, that his contract would not be renewed for next season.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Halpert has coached at Yeshiva University for 42 years, the longest tenure of any men’s basketball coach in New York City history. But even Division III Yeshiva, which has not had a winning season since 2007, is not immune to the pressures that much larger N.C.A.A. institutions face.

headline: Piecing Together Dream Fragments
abstract: Laure Prouvost, born in France in 1978 and now living in London, was the dark-horse winner of the 2013 Turner Prize, but she is still something of a mystery in New York.
lead_paragraph: Laure Prouvost, born in France in 1978 and now living in London, was the dark-horse winner of the 2013 Turner Prize, but she is still something of a mystery in New York. And for all the right reasons, her solo show at the New Museum lets the mystery be. Multimedia is her form: The New Museum installation combines video, painting, drawing, sculpture and found objects. Narrative is her mode.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: George F. Kennan’s Diaries
abstract: This week, Fareed Zakaria talks about “The Kennan Diaries”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jodi Kantor discusses “HRC”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Making Antifreeze Less Deadly for Pets, and People
keywords: ['Ethylene Glycol', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Manufacturers are adopting a novel strategy for to try and reduce poisonings with antifreeze: Make it taste terrible.
lead_paragraph: Toxicologists have long considered ethylene glycol, the active ingredient in many antifreeze and engine coolant formulas, to be a seductive and uniquely dangerous poison.

headline: How Do You Like These Apples?
abstract: Take apples beyond the pie and try them in smoothies, sauces, salads, crepes and breads, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.
lead_paragraph: When I was in France late last fall, every time I went to the market I was reminded of what an integral part apples play in everyday cooking in that country. This is especially true in fall and winter, when shoppers buy them by the kilo to use for compotes, pies, cakes, savory dishes and salads. Bakers in Normandy, the region of apples, even work them into rustic country breads.

headline: Mayor Do as I Say
abstract: Bill de Blasio gave an impassioned presentation about traffic safety on Tuesday. On Thursday he was caught barreling down the highway over the speed limit.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio gave an impassioned presentation about traffic safety on Tuesday. On Thursday, under the immutable law of political comeuppance, he got busted by a TV news crew that caught his two-S.U.V. detail rolling through stop signs, changing lanes without signaling and barreling down the highway over the speed limit.

headline: Protest All You Want, but It’ll Cost You

abstract: Olympic coaches must be sure to carry cash, which is required as a sort of processing fee for lodging protests with officials.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — When the coach of the Canadian women’s snowboarding team gathers his belongings each morning, he makes sure he has his hat, his sunglasses, his cellphone and 100 Swiss francs.

lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — There was a certain paradox to the Canadian men’s curling team’s victory Friday night in the Olympic final against Britain.

abstract: Evi Sachenbacher-Stehle of Germany and William Frullani of Italy have been kicked out of the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A German biathlete and an Italian bobsledder were kicked out of the Olympics Friday for doping, the first known violations of the Sochi Games.

headline: Four Decades of Preservation
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The long history of efforts to preserve Bedford-Stuyvesant’s resplendent Victorian architecture.
lead_paragraph: Although the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was once considered among the nation’s most devastated neighborhoods, efforts to preserve its resplendent Victorian architecture have been pursued energetically for more than four decades.

headline: Argument Over a Brownstone Neighborhood
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Brownstones']
abstract: The proposed Bedford Historic District in Bed-Stuy is dividing residents. It all boils down to whether you think designation helps or hurts a community.
lead_paragraph: Most people would agree that the brownstones and small apartment buildings nestled in the southwest corner of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, are for the most part drop-dead gorgeous. The 800 largely intact residential buildings, representing Italianate, Queen Anne, Romanesque Revival and Renaissance Revival styles, are executed in rich rusts, browns and terra cottas, and adorned with gracious bowed windows, generously proportioned stoops and adorable little turrets. The result, in the opinion of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, is “an extraordinary well-preserved late-19th-century streetscape.”

headline: Toledo Museum Announces Review of Items Received From Suspect Dealer
abstract: The Toledo Museum of Art has announced it is reviewing the provenance of a number of items it obtained from an antiquities dealer accused of smuggling.
lead_paragraph: The Toledo Museum of Art has announced that it is reviewing the legality of 64 Indian artifacts it obtained from Subhash Kapoor, a former Madison Avenue art dealer who is accused by United States officials of operating one of the largest antiquities smuggling rings uncovered on American soil.

headline: On Being Both the Wolf and the Lamb
abstract: A woman opens up about a man groping her on a street corner in a rapidly gentrifying Brooklyn neighborhood. Since the incident, she has struggled to find a sense of belonging amid crime.
lead_paragraph: One of the first questions you confront in any five-borough conversation is, “Where do you live?”

headline: An East-West Divide, Played Out on TV News
abstract: The differences in how Russian and American news shows report on the unrest in Kiev provide an instant Rorschach test of the disconnect in their countries’ viewpoints.

headline: The Fed’s Actions in 2008: What the Transcripts Reveal
abstract: On Feb. 22, the Federal Reserve released the transcripts of the 2008 meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy. The transcripts provide a detailed account of some of the Fed’s key decisions during that crisis year.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 22, the Federal Reserve released the transcripts of the 2008 meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy. The transcripts provide a detailed account of some of the Fed’s key decisions during that crisis year.

headline: Accord Signed in Ukraine
abstract: Opposition leaders and President Viktor F. Yanukovych signed an agreement on Friday to try to defuse a deadly political crisis that has left scores of protesters and security officers dead or wounded.
lead_paragraph: Opposition leaders and President Viktor F. Yanukovych signed an agreement on Friday to try to defuse a deadly political crisis that has left scores of protesters and security officers dead or wounded.

headline: Listen Up | Neneh Cherry Makes a Cathartic Comeback
abstract: The Swedish-African songstress and late-’80s style icon returns with a soulful, genre-blending new album.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 18 years since Neneh Cherry released her last solo album. During that time, she’s been highly productive: she’s worked as a D.J. around Europe; formed a band, cirKus, with her husband and daughter; had guest spots on countless other records; co-hosted a cooking series on BBC Two and focused on raising her three children. It was the pain of loss, however, that brought her back to the spotlight. When her mother, the Swedish painter and textile artist Monica Karlsson (known as Moki), passed away in 2009, Cherry began to write in a journal, documenting dark emotional recesses she hadn’t previously explored. Her entries became the basis for “The Blank Project,” a soulful new album that’s danceable, but comes from the deep.

headline: Back to Borneo, and an Eden at Risk
abstract: A return to the Kelabit Highlands, before logging transforms a lush rain forest into barren lands.
lead_paragraph: There are no roads to the village of Pa Lungan, just a mucky water buffalo trail beneath a tight-knit canopy — among the last standing highland jungles on the island of Borneo. In spots, the trail is more swamp than path. But that does not mean all is quiet: The rain forest is a cacophonous place. Cicadas squeal and monkeys hoot as they romp through the trees. Bamboo creaks in the breeze as its stalks grind and rub in a primitive dance.

headline: Exploring a World of Animals

lead_paragraph: Dinaw Mengestu, 35, has racked up a list of enviable accomplishments. He is a highly acclaimed novelist. He was a recipient of a MacArthur “genius” grant in 2012. The New Yorker named him one of its “20 Under 40” writers in 2010. And on Sundays, he says, he makes a mean roast chicken. “All Our Names,” the third novel by Mr. Mengestu, who was born in Ethiopia and raised in Illinois, is being published next month by Knopf. Mr. Mengestu lives in West Harlem with his wife, Anne-Emanuelle Mengestu, 41, and their sons, Gabriel, 4, and Luis-Selassie, 3.

headline: Haters Going to Hate, Research Suggests
abstract: Researchers found that winning a literary prize led to worse reviews from readers online.
lead_paragraph: Not only is it lonely at the top, but a paper by two business professors suggests that, at least for literary prize winners, the view can get a little ugly, too. The study, by Balazs Kovacs of the University of Lugano and Amanda Sharkey of the University of Chicago, compared online reader reviews for 32 pairs of books that either won or were nominated for a major literary prize. They found that winning a prestigious award not only garners more attention for a book, but also more negative reviews.
