headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Moschino’s Tomboy Tresses
abstract: To complement the McDonald’s and SpongeBob SquarePants references on the runway, the house stuck to a simple, down-to-earth look for hair (and makeup).
lead_paragraph: Despite the loud pop-culture references in Jeremy Scott’s first Moschino collection — strewn with McDonald’s, SpongeBob SquarePants and candy bar insignia — hair and makeup felt fairly down-to-earth. Backstage at yesterday’s show, the makeup artist Lucia Pieroni explained the inspiration for the “gorgeous, tomboyish” look. “It’s a Linda Evangelista kind, with very boyish eyebrows, brushed up to make them strong,” she said, adding that the flawless finish on the skin was inspired by Peter Lindbergh’s photography. To achieve the milky complexions, Pieroni stuck to the basics: a light foundation base, cream color on the eyes for a bit of shine and nude M.A.C. lipsticks that ranged from peachy and pink to soft shades of mocha. And on top of all those neutral faces, Paul Hanlon’s shaggy, pixie-cut wigs lent just enough attitude to the models as they walked past the front row, from which a very happy Katy Perry cheered them along.

headline: Fitbit Recalls Force Device After Complaints of Rashes
abstract: The company said it would also stop selling the wrist-worn fitness tracker immediately because some customers had reported red, itchy rashes.
lead_paragraph: Fitbit said on Friday that it was issuing a voluntary recall for the Fitbit Force wrist-worn fitness tracker and would stop selling the device immediately after determining that the device caused serious skin irritation for some users.

headline: Casting Shadows on ‘Ice Cream Castles in the Air and Feather Canyons Everywhere’
abstract: Jessica Molaskey applies her acting skills to interpreting the songs of Joni Mitchell, adding another dimension.
lead_paragraph: An actor first, and a singer second: that was how Jessica Molaskey described herself during her enthralling Thursday evening concert of Joni Mitchell songs, “Portraits of Joni: Jessica Molaskey Sings Joni Mitchell,” at the Allen Room, presented as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.

headline: How Mikaela Shiffrin Won the Slalom
abstract: Looking powerful and poised, the 18-year-old American dominated the first run and hung on in the second to pick up the gold medal.
lead_paragraph: Looking powerful and poised, the 18-year-old American dominated the first run and hung on in the second to pick up the gold medal.

headline: Descents Into Sounds Of Dementia and War
abstract: A premiere by Lisa Renée Coons about mental illness and dementia was a highlight of “Lines on a Point,” a program by the American Composers Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Discerning the correlation between a composer’s description of a new piece and its actual sound is not always easy. But there was no such ambiguity in “Vera’s Ghosts” by Lisa Renée Coons, which received its premiere on Thursday evening at Zankel Hall by the American Composers Orchestra, conducted by George Manahan.

headline: Plan to Limit Some Drugs in Medicare Is Criticized
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medicare', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Health care groups and members of Congress are opposing an Obama administration proposal to limit coverage for three classes of drugs.
lead_paragraph: An alliance of drug companies and patient advocates, joined by Democrats and Republicans in Congress, is fiercely opposing an Obama administration proposal that would allow insurers to limit Medicare coverage for certain classes of drugs, including those used to treat depression and schizophrenia.

headline: Philharmonic Clarinetist to Return to Chicago Symphony
abstract: The New York Philharmonic hired Stephen Williamson as principal clarinet a year ago, but he is now returning to the Chicago Symphony.
lead_paragraph: It seemed as if the New York Philharmonic had successfully poached some talent from the competition last year when it announced it had lured Stephen Williamson away from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra to be its new principal clarinet player. But Mr. Williamson remained technically on a leave of absence, and on Friday he announced that he would be taking his woodwind back to Chicago next season.

headline: Semifinals of the District 24 Grand National
abstract: A second team in the semifinals of the qualifying event is Kelley Hwang, Michael Kopera, Michael Lipkin and Michael Radin, all of New York City.
lead_paragraph: One team in the semifinals of the District 24 (New York City and Long Island) Grand National Teams qualifying event is Kelley Hwang, Michael Kopera, Michael Lipkin and Michael Radin, all of New York City.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Tod’s Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: In Drag, It Turns Out, There Are Second Acts
abstract: Far from vanishing to wherever it is ’90s sensations go, RuPaul Charles is back on top, presiding over Season 6 of the TV show “Drag Race.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — RuPaul Charles zoomed down Sunset Boulevard in a 1979 red Volvo he inherited from his mother. He wore a pinstripe suit and an open-collar shirt revealing a wedge of shaved chest.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A tour of homes in Greenwich Village, Lincoln Square and Downtown Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s On the Market properties in New York City include a two-bedroom loft in Greenwich Village; a hotel-like studio in Lincoln Square; and a Downtown Brooklyn condo corner unit.

headline: Brooklyn on the Spree
abstract: An increasingly powerful cadre of New Yorkers is invading Berlin’s club community and electronic music scene.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — “The music reminds me of Brooklyn!” said Winston Chmielinski, a 25-year-old painter who moved here from New York last year. Like one of the cranes hanging over the city but never managing to create a skyline, he was dancing with outstretched arms, lowering and raising himself at the Panorama Bar, the upstairs dance floor at Berghain, a popular club.

headline: Leaders in Supporting Roles
abstract: In the Hollywood movie machine, these behind-the-scenes stars make everything happen before the first Oscars are distributed.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Forget the celebrity stylists. That persnickety bunch tends to a handful of the highest-wattage Oscar contenders. There are 203 nominees this year.

headline: Cost $1,000, Sold for $21 Million
abstract: A 1958 Ferrari 335S was sitting in a U.S. Customs warehouse when a car dealer rescued it in 1963 for the price of the storage fee. Last year, the car’s new owner hit the jackpot.
lead_paragraph: The bull market in vintage racing cars recently gained an eye-opening data point: A 1958 Ferrari 335S that had been bailed out of a United States Customs warehouse in New York for $1,000 in 1963 was sold for $21.5 million in a private transaction to an Austrian collector, Andreas Mohringer.

headline: A Stable Full of Thoroughbreds
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)"]
abstract: A New Jersey car collector has garages full of classics, including cars sufficiently special enough to have taken Best in Show honors at the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance four times.
lead_paragraph: Found among the holdings of collectors — any of the millions of enthusiasts who accumulate stamps, coins, autographed baseballs, ticket stubs, anything from bottle caps to Rembrandts — are both the detritus of civilization and the objects that recall its finest hours.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Unbuttoned
abstract: The nonchalant style of coats worn wide open on the coldest days was popular during New York Fashion Week (when daytime temperatures were in the 20s).
lead_paragraph: The nonchalant style of coats worn wide open on the coldest days was popular during New York Fashion Week (when daytime temperatures were in the 20s).

headline: A Singular Obsession, Ranging Far and Wide
abstract: Sam Mann, a New Jersey industrial designer, has a collection that reflects everything from his background as an engineer to his fascination with the dirt-track competitors of his youth.
lead_paragraph: Sam Mann, a New Jersey industrial designer, has a collection that reflects everything from his background as an engineer to his fascination with the dirt-track competitors of his youth.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
abstract: Lighting systems that watch and gather data, conversations inside the Federal Reserve during the financial crisis and a new wave of mortgage problems for homeowners.
lead_paragraph: Lighting systems that watch and gather data, conversations inside the Federal Reserve during the financial crisis and a new wave of mortgage problems for homeowners.

headline: The Music of Fire, Stars, Tears and Light
abstract: Angel Olsen brought her second album, made of indie rock with country as a mode of thinking rather than a style guide, to Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: “I feel so lonesome I could cry,” Angel Olsen sings at the beginning of “Hi-Five.” And sure, she sounds the part — ravaged, tense, dark, history-minded.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Unbuttoned
abstract: The nonchalant style of coats worn wide open on the coldest days was popular during New York Fashion Week (when daytime temperatures were in the 20s).
lead_paragraph: The nonchalant style of coats worn wide open on the coldest days was popular during New York Fashion Week (when daytime temperatures were in the 20s). This vanity dates from 1940s Hollywood stars, who wore their coats on their shoulders. A few women left their coats in chauffeured cars, expecting to rush into a runway show — only to wait in the freezing cold. Tourists (above) were buttoned up to the chin. Near right: another laugh-at-the-cold look, shredded jeans, resembled icicles.

headline: Evening Hours | On the Catwalks
abstract: Fashion Week took us from heaven to earth, and then to church.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Week took us from heaven to earth, and then to church.

headline: Adventure With an Italian Accent
abstract: The Aprilia Caponord 1200 Travel Pack provides high style and a lot of technology, although it’s rather late to the adventure-touring market.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — No international motorcycle manufacturer, it seems, can afford to be without an adventure-touring offering — and an attendant line of high-couture color-coordinated rider apparel — in its lineup.

headline: The Magnetic Pull of Touching, and Not Touching
abstract: TAO Dance Theater reprises “4,” in which four dancers move as a pack with no physical contact, and debuts “5,” where five dancers roll across the floor and on one another without letting go.
lead_paragraph: Tao Ye doesn’t think in terms of Eastern or Western where his art is concerned. This Chinese choreographer, who formed his company in Beijing in 2008, avoids such categorical boxes; his dances, he believes, should stand on their own, and they do, with a quiet, dazzling resolve.

headline: Sculptural Slip-Ons at Tod’s
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: White loafers topped with shiny brass discs.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Fannie Mae Posts Profit That Sets a Record
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The company said the fourth quarter was its eighth consecutive profitable quarter.
lead_paragraph: The mortgage giant Fannie Mae passed a symbolic milestone at the end of the fourth quarter, generating profits that will push its total payments to the federal government higher than the amount it received in the 2008 bailout, the company reported Friday.

headline: Times Minute | Preps and Superstitions
abstract: Whether it’s the N.F.L. scouting combine or luck at the Olympics, a look at how athletes prep. Also on the Minute, Fed transcripts from the 2008 financial crisis reveal Janet Yellen’s actions before she was chairwoman.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Preps and Superstitions
abstract: Whether it's the N.F.L. scouting combine or luck at the Olympics, a look at how athletes prep. Also on the Minute, 2008 Fed transcripts reveal Janet Yellen's actions before she was chairwoman.
lead_paragraph: Whether it's the N.F.L. scouting combine or luck at the Olympics, a look at how athletes prep. Also on the Minute, 2008 Fed transcripts reveal Janet Yellen's actions before she was chairwoman.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A tour of homes in Colts Neck, N.J. and Sea Cliff, Long Island.
lead_paragraph: This week’s On the Market homes in the New York region include a six-bedroom home on 1.27 acres in Colts Neck, N.J., and a five-bedroom home with a separate 1,000-square-foot artist’s studio in Sea Cliff, Long Island.

headline: A ‘House of Cards’ Binge Takes Its Toll
abstract: The athleticism of binge-watching “House of Cards” episodes.
lead_paragraph: As last weekend approached, I was astonished to hear how many people were planning on binge watching Netflix’s “House of Cards.” I had dismissed the show the very first episode when the hot female journalist tried to seduce the bad Congressman Frank Underwood, played by Kevin Spacey, as a shortcut to what we in the business call reporting. I understand the impulse. Reporting can be deadly dull and take days, whereas the hottie’s method can be dispensed with in 20 industrious minutes.

headline: Imitation of Life, Outsiders Version
abstract: “Macho Man, Tell It to My Heart,” a group show running through Sunday, includes drawings by James Benning that copy works by outsider artists.
lead_paragraph: I thought of James Benning exclusively as an experimental filmmaker until I saw four of his drawings in “Macho Man, Tell It to My Heart,” the marvelous exhibition at Artists Space, which closes on Sunday. Displaying works by nearly 50 artists, it is based on the collection and many friendships of Julie Ault, the artist, writer and founding member of the Group Material collective.

headline: High School Wrestlers in New Jersey Apologize for Photo Seen as Racist
abstract: Members of the Phillipsburg High School wrestling team apologized after they were accused of staging a racist photo and barred from coming district championships.
lead_paragraph: Eight members of one of New Jersey’s top high school wrestling teams were suspended and barred from participating in a state tournament this weekend after they arranged a photo that looked like a lynching scene, with a black dummy hanging by a rope around its neck.

headline: Exonerated. Now What?
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Inmates declared innocent of a crime lack some of the post-release services available to former prisoners, so some have turned to each other for support.
lead_paragraph: It had been a while since Jeffrey Deskovic hosted one of his weekday evening singalongs, so last month he made a few calls and brought some friends together at the Karaoke Cave, a noisy little bar on East 13th Street in Manhattan. At 6 p.m. the place was filled with young professionals sipping beers and shouting into microphones in an undemanding, if embarrassing, environment. But to Mr. Deskovic and the men who joined him, standing up in public and singing cheesy pop songs was more than an innocent release.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,298 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,298 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Singular Art, Made by Plurals
abstract: An energetic collective of mostly black, mostly queer artists from Seattle to Paris plans to debut work at the 2014 Whitney Museum Biennial.
lead_paragraph: In Sienna Shields’s spacious studio in Dumbo, Brooklyn, with homemade rag dolls decorating one wall and hair-bead sculptures dangling from the ceiling, the mood was festive one recent frigid night. The Yams, as members of her high-energy artist collective call themselves, danced, sipped wine and traded tales about projects. “If you’re doing it, I’m in it” was a frequent refrain.

headline: Photographers Band Together to Protect Work in ‘Fair Use’ Cases
abstract: As courts try to decide which artists make “fair use” of others’ work in “transformative” pieces, groups of photographers are entering the legal and legislative debates.
lead_paragraph: To many photographers, a federal appeals court ruling last spring that permitted Richard Prince to use someone else’s photographs in his art was akin to slapping a “Steal This” label on their work.

headline: Was Anyone Killed at the Knickerbocker Club?
abstract: Readers ask questions about killings at a city landmark as well as the first policeman in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Q. Has there ever been a murder at the Knickerbocker Club?

headline: Week in Pictures for Feb. 21
abstract: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Valentine’s Day deliveries, sledding in Central Park and pothole repairs in Queens.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes Valentine’s Day deliveries, sledding in Central Park and pothole repairs in Queens.

headline: Venezuela Battles Media, Social and Otherwise, to Restrict Protest Coverage
abstract: Tensions escalated further in Venezuela on Friday, as protesters turned out for a tenth day of demonstrations and the government continued to clamp down on coverage of the unrest in the broadcast media and online.
lead_paragraph: Tensions escalated further in Venezuela on Friday as street protests that began nine days ago continued and the government persisted in clamping down on coverage of the unrest in the broadcast media and online.

headline: The Fun of Having a Single Parent
abstract: This weekend NBC is introducing two feel-good sitcoms about the healing properties of broken homes.
lead_paragraph: NBC is on a love campaign.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | At Blumarine, Low-Maintenance Loveliness
abstract: Bare skin, black-lined eyes and soft waves let models’ natural beauty take center stage.
lead_paragraph: “This collection reminds me of the times of Mr. Yves Saint Laurent,” the makeup artist Tom Pecheux said backstage at Blumarine, where models were dressed in lavish brocades and furs. “There is a richness, there is a glamour. So we had to make the girls look so beautiful.” To achieve that aim, Pecheux kept things simple. He left skin almost nude, with only a light application of M.A.C foundation — no blush or highlighter necessary. He didn’t touch the eyebrows or eyelashes either; the sole element of visible makeup was a simple sweep of M.A.C black eyeliner around the inner rims of the eyes and in the tiny spaces between eyelashes.

headline: Where Death Was a Friend, and Gods Were Ordinary Folk
abstract: “Masters of Fire,” at New York University’s Institute for the Study of the Ancient World, offers a look at a trove from the Copper Age.
lead_paragraph: I can imagine worse fates for my bones than being housed for eternity — or at least 6,000 years or so — in one of the astonishing ossuaries now on display at New York University’s Institute for the Study of the Ancient World in a modest but weighty new exhibition, “Masters of Fire: Copper Age Art From Israel.” If facial expressions have any enduring meanings across cultures and time (and it often seems that they do), the figures who adorn these ancient clay burial vaults would provide congenial company.

headline: Collectors of Keith Haring Works File Lawsuit
abstract: A lawsuit accuses the Keith Haring Foundation and its directors of hurting the value of collectors’ property.
lead_paragraph: A group of nine collectors of artwork by Keith Haring sued the foundation that bears his name and its directors on Friday, accusing the defendants of “wrongfully destroying” the value of their paintings by publicly labeling them as fakes and refusing to consider information that would establish their provenance.

headline: Hollywood and the City, Take 2
abstract: Books about the surge in movie and television production in New York; a significant figure in Off Broadway theater; and inventions that came from New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: By the early 1970s, New York’s reign as a television and filmmaking capital seemed to be over. The transplanting of Johnny Carson and the “Tonight” show to California, coupled with the demise of “The Ed Sullivan Show” the year before, Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times, “marked the end of Manhattan’s parity with Hollywood as a glitz capital for a national audience.”

headline: More Ex-Players Join Concussion Suit Against N.H.L.
abstract: The federal action contends that the league failed to adequately respond to serious health risks posed by head injuries sustained during games.
lead_paragraph: Four more former N.H.L. players have joined the concussion lawsuit against the league, their lawyers said Friday.

headline: Children in School, and Out of Court
abstract: Readers, including Judith S. Kaye, the former chief judge of New York State, respond to an Op-Ed article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Changing Seasons to Take Woolmark Prize
abstract: The International Woolmark Prize scours the world for talent, then travels the world to reward it. This afternoon, when the finalists presented their collections, the jury chose Rahul Mishra in an upset.
lead_paragraph: The International Woolmark Prize scours the world for talent, then travels the world to reward it. This year, it has arrived in Milan.

headline: A Sharp-Eyed Squirrel, Leaping Into the Darkness
abstract: It is hard to say how many flying squirrels populate New York City’s five boroughs. An uncommon habitat and our avoidance of late-night walks through obscure woodlands make finding one a deliberate effort.
lead_paragraph: Few of us ever get a good view of a flying squirrel, but then again, not many of us know they truly exist. Not unlike its cartoon depiction, as the brainy, be-goggled sidekick of Bullwinkle the Moose, the Southern flying squirrel is an impressively well-adapted resident of New York City. With a preference for older beech and oak woods, these squirrels are primarily nocturnal. An uncommon habitat and our very urban instinct to avoid late-night walks through obscure woodlands make finding one a deliberate effort.

headline: The Joy of Swimming, and Meditating
abstract: Readers share their love of the pool as a place to experience the delight of uninterrupted thought.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Uninsured? Get Covered
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A Florida reader canvassing for Obamacare says it’s worth pounding the pavement.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Reforming the Port Authority
abstract: Two professors from the Rutgers University School of Planning and Public Policy offer ideas for overhauling the Port Authority.

headline: The Once and Future Gowanus
abstract: The Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn is home to a polluted canal, yet it has rising housing values and residents who want to see it prosper without becoming the next Dumbo.
lead_paragraph: By a recent and not remotely exacting tally, the Gowanus neighborhood in Brooklyn has at least eight community groups dedicated to its planning and self-analysis: the Gowanus Alliance, the Gowanus Canal Conservancy, Bridging Gowanus, the Gowanus Canal Community Advisory Group, the Gowanus Canal Community Development Corporation, Friends and Residents of Greater Gowanus, Save Gowanus and the Gowanus Ecology Initiative. This does not include the block associations and housing groups that have an interest in the area, nor does it take full measure of the conferencing that Gowanus has inspired. Four years ago, after the Gowanus Canal was designated a Superfund site, a summit called Reconsidering Gowanus was held. Last month, Gowanus was the subject of its own TEDx talks.

headline: Under Cover: The Voyages Issue
abstract: This week’s cover features a photograph taken by David Guttenfelder of a game of soccer played in the afternoon light of Brazil.
lead_paragraph: This week’s cover image features a photograph of the beach in Santos, Brazil, taken by David Guttenfelder, a photographer for The Associated Press. Guttenfelder traveled across South America on the recently opened Interoceanic Highway for the magazine’s Voyages issue.

headline: Women in Labor
abstract: An obstetrician appeals for enough understanding to practice good medicine.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Basque Separatists Display Surrendered Weapons, in Front of Picasso’s ‘Guernica’
abstract: Basque separatists staged a video in front of a replica of Picasso’s famous painting.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Raphael Minder reports, an international verification commission said on Friday that the Basque separatist group ETA had disabled “some of the weapons that allowed it to wage a lengthy terror campaign for independence that has claimed more than 800 victims.”

headline: Marriage, a Matter of Law
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: A reader emphasizes that marriage equality is a matter for the courts.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Discussion About ‘Bright Lights, Big City’
abstract: Join us for the online discussion of the novel “Bright Lights, Big City” by Jay McInerney on March 10 at 6:30 p.m.
lead_paragraph: This time we outsourced our selection for the Big City Book Club to the writer and satirist Gary Shteyngart. We asked him to pick his favorite book about New York, and he did not demand that we read his own newly published memoir, “Little Failure,” about his upbringing as a Russian émigré in Queens. Instead, he selflessly selected “Bright Lights, Big City,” Jay McInerney’s touchstone novel of the hedonistic ’80s life on the other side of the East River. Join us for the online discussion of the novel with Mr. Shteyngart on Monday, March 10, at 6:30 p.m.

headline: Unequal From the Start
abstract: A reader responds to a column by David Brooks, “The Prodigal Sons.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New York, Behind the Facades
abstract: The photographs of Sean Vegezzi go beyond closed doors and down subway tunnels.
lead_paragraph: The photographs of Sean Vegezzi go beyond closed doors and down subway tunnels.

headline: David M. Herszenhorn Answers Questions on Ukraine
abstract: Mr. Herszenhorn, a correspondent for The New York Times who has been covering the crisis since it began three months ago, offers insight.
lead_paragraph: The center of Ukraine’s capital, Kiev, came to resemble a war zone this week when protesters and riot police officers used firearms against each other as they battled for control. On Friday, President Viktor F. Yanukovych and opposition leaders signed a political deal aimed at ending the days of violence and three months of protests, and Parliament voted to allow the release of the president’s imprisoned rival. David M. Herszenhorn, a Moscow-based correspondent for The New York Times who has been covering the crisis in Ukraine since it began in November, answered readers’ questions on the situation submitted via comments, Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Closed Doors? Not a Problem
abstract: Sean Vegezzi challenges himself by capturing the city from high above, underground and in areas that are off-limits.
lead_paragraph: It’s safe to say that most New Yorkers have a limited, even literal view of their city: The door to that building over there leads to a lobby, right? The stairs to that subway station head down toward the J train.

headline: U.A.W. Asks Labor Board to Examine Vote at Tennessee Plant
abstract: The United Automobile Workers has asserted that Tennessee lawmakers interfered with a unionization vote at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers asked the National Labor Relations Board on Friday to order a new unionization election at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., asserting that the union’s loss last week was because of improper interference by the state’s lawmakers.

headline: Attorney General Signs New Rules to Limit Access to Journalists’ Records
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: The guidelines signed by Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Friday are intended to ensure a balance between protecting national security and safeguarding freedom of the press, a preamble says.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who drew fire last spring over the Justice Department’s aggressive tactics for secretly obtaining reporters’ phone logs and emails as part of leak investigations, on Friday signed new guidelines narrowing the circumstances in which law enforcement officials may obtain journalists’ records.

headline: Friday Night Music: Fleetwood Mac, The Chain
abstract: But we did break the chain!
lead_paragraph: In honor of President Obama’s decision not to propose cutting Social Security by switching to a chain-linked price index, a blast from the past:

headline: Flaws Persist in L.I.R.R.’s Disability Claims, a Report Finds
abstract: A federal report concluded that the method of granting occupational disability payments to former Long Island Railroad employees remains severely flawed.
lead_paragraph: A federal watchdog has concluded that the method of granting occupational disability payments to former employees of the Long Island Rail Road is still so flawed that roughly 96 percent of those who apply receive it, roughly the same approval rate as before a vast cheating scandal was first exposed more than five years ago.

headline: F.D.A. Orders 4 Bidi Cigarette Brands Removed From Shelves
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: In a first for the agency, the Food and Drug Administration ordered the brands cleared from the American market within 30 days because of the company’s failure to provide ingredient data.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday ordered four tobacco products removed from the market, the first time the agency has done so since being given the legal authority in 2009.

headline: Yankees’ Top Starting Pitchers Impress Girardi
abstract: Manager Joe Girardi said he liked what he saw of the four pitchers assured of spots in the rotation: C. C. Sabathia, Hiroki Kuroda, Ivan Nova and Masahiro Tanaka.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Before Friday, the last time Masahiro Tanaka had thrown a pitch to a batter was in the ninth inning of Game 7 of the Japan Series against the Yomiuri Giants — “Nov. 3,” Tanaka said in English, a date he will find difficult to forget. He threw a split-fingered fastball to get the final out and secure the Rakuten Golden Eagles’ first championship.

headline: Ted Nugent Apologizes for Obama Insult
keywords: ['Apologies', 'Attorneys General', 'Elections, Governors', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The musician said he regretted referring to President Obama as a “subhuman mongrel,” but the Texas attorney general, with whom Mr. Nugent has been campaigning, has ignored calls for his own apology.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The rock guitarist Ted Nugent, responding to cascading criticism that had become an embarrassment for his conservative Republican allies, apologized Friday for calling President Obama a “subhuman mongrel.” But Democrats expressed frustration that their calls for an apology from the Texas Republican who took Mr. Nugent on the campaign trail had been ignored.

headline: Another Step on the Path to Settling Frisk Cases
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: A federal appeals panel has sent the lawsuits challenging New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practices back to a lower court, which will supervise settlement discussions.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan cleared the way on Friday for the lawsuits challenging the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practices to be sent back to a lower-court judge, a step toward negotiating a final settlement in the longstanding legal dispute.

headline: Streaming of Olympic Hockey Continues to Expand
abstract: Numbers were so large that NBC was concerned that office computer networks would become overloaded by employees watching the contests at work.
lead_paragraph: With each succeeding United States Olympic hockey game from Sochi, Russia, this week, NBC Sports watched as the number of people streaming the game live grew.

headline: In Sake, Japan Sees a Potential Stimulus
keywords: ['Sake', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Sake is among the soft goods that the government is promoting to help improve the country’s exports.
lead_paragraph: NIHONMATSU, Japan — As Japan confronts troubling economic data and memories of its stagnant “lost generation,” the country’s government is offering a little something to take the edge off: a bottle or two of sake.

headline: Will the Net Stay Neutral?
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Net Neutrality', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: If the Federal Communications Commission can’t ensure equal Internet access, maybe companies like Google can.
lead_paragraph: It is no doubt a coincidence that six days after the Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger was unveiled, Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, announced that his agency was planning — yet again — to come up with rules to ensure that no Internet service provider could discriminate against any company or website. And it is also a coincidence — for sure! — that on the same day as the Wheeler announcement, Google let it be known that it was going to begin discussions with 34 cities to expand its Google Fiber business. Google Fiber provides high speed Internet service, though so far only in Kansas City and Provo, Utah. (It is about to begin service in Austin, Tex.)

headline: To Make Shipping Oil Safer, Railroads Agree to 8 Measures
abstract: The Department of Transportation said the major railroads had approved voluntary steps, including lowering speed limits and increasing the frequency of track inspections, to ensure safety.
lead_paragraph: Responding to concerns about the safety of trains carrying oil around the country, federal regulators on Friday outlined steps to reduce the risk of rail shipments and bolster confidence in the fast-growing industry.

headline: Coping With Infectious Disease
keywords: ['SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Epidemics', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Avian Influenza', 'Tuberculosis', 'MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Viruses', 'Medicine and Health', 'Editorials']
abstract: A growing threat from emerging viral diseases requires better ways to find and contain them.
lead_paragraph: The list of infectious diseases that could leap from remote areas of the world to strike countries thousands of miles away is growing. A warning of what can happen occurred a decade ago when an outbreak in China of a mysterious new viral disease, known as SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, was covered up by the Chinese authorities, allowing infected airline passengers to carry the virus to more than two dozen other countries. The disease killed nearly 800 people and caused large economic losses in Asia and Canada.

headline: Army General’s Lawyers Seek Dismissal of Sexual Misconduct Charges
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'ADULTERY', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Defense lawyers for Brig. General Jeffrey Sinclair asked a military judge to throw out the charges, asserting weaknesses in the case.
lead_paragraph: One week after the lead prosecutor in the court-martial of Brig. Gen. Jeffrey Sinclair abruptly quit the case, defense lawyers have asked a military judge to dismiss sexual misconduct charges against General Sinclair in a motion that asserts that officials all the way up to Gen. Raymond T. Odierno, the Army chief of staff, have acknowledged weaknesses in the case.

headline: Uncovering Legacies in Staten Island’s Neglected Graveyards
abstract: Lynn Rogers and a group of volunteers have been cleaning up 11 abandoned cemeteries and helping families not only find their ancestors’ graves, but also learn about their past.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Rogers is proud of her work and is not concerned that she receives no recognition from those whose stories she unveils. Not that they could sing her praises — they are all dead.

headline: Alcoholics Anonymous, Without the Religion
abstract: A growing number of A.A. meetings offer a 12-step program for nonreligious people in recovery: agnostics, atheists, humanists or freethinkers.
lead_paragraph: Three floors above a Manhattan street of loading docks and coffee shops, in a functional room of folding chairs and linoleum tile, a man who introduced himself as Vic began to speak. “Today is my 35th anniversary,” he said. The dozen people seated around him applauded, and several even whooped in support.

headline: Fed Fretted Over Reaction to Demise of Lehman
abstract: The documents published on Friday provide one of the fullest pictures yet of the thinking of top government officials on the bank’s implosion.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks after Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy in September 2008, Ben S. Bernanke, then chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave his central bank colleagues an imitation of the people who were already criticizing the government’s decision to let the Wall Street bank collapse.

headline: Rewriting the Gettysburg Address
abstract: Lincoln didn’t finish writing his famous speech until February 1864 — at least not the version we know today.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Lincoln did not give the Gettysburg Address on Nov. 19, 1863 — at least, not the one engraved on the Lincoln Memorial, the one memorized by millions the world over. Lincoln actually wrote the words recognized today as the Gettysburg Address months after the cemetery dedication, during a full and complete revision of his speech that he finished in February 1864.

headline: To Read or Not to Read?
abstract: I adored my mother, gone 20 years now, but I didn’t know her well. And here were her diaries.
lead_paragraph: This is the seventh part of an eight-part series.

headline: Don’t Let Up on Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Congress can strengthen Obama’s hand in nuclear talks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — LIKE all Americans, we strongly hope that the Obama administration’s diplomatic efforts lead to the peaceful dismantling of Iran’s nuclear weapons program. To achieve this key national security goal, we support a policy that complements the current negotiations with a range of congressional actions that threaten greater economic and diplomatic pressure on the Iranian government.

headline: Montessori Schools Surge in Popularity Among New Generation of Jewish Parents
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Arguing that the traditional Jewish day-school model is outmoded and too clannish, many Jews are flocking to schools that combine secular studies with Torah and Hebrew lessons.
lead_paragraph: In the boys’ classroom at Lamplighters Yeshivah in the Hasidic Jewish stronghold of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Montessori number-counting boards and decimal beads share space with Hebrew-learning materials. A colorful timeline on the wall shows two strands of world history in parallel: secular on the left, Jewish on the right. A photo of the grand rabbi of the Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic movement hangs above a list of tasks that children perform individually: make a fractions poster, practice cursive, learn about the moon’s phases.

headline: In Sochi, Connecticut Is a Winner
abstract: Nine Connecticut natives competed at the Sochi Games — more representatives than 37 other states — and their performances were closely watched back home.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Conn. — The board of selectmen for this tranquil shoreline town addressed an unusual request on Feb. 10. Andrea Perullo, the proprietor of a local jewelry store, asked if this year’s Presidents’ Day could be formally recognized as Mac Bohonnon Day.

headline: Medals of Honor, Denied Because of Prejudice, to Be Belatedly Awarded
keywords: ['Medal of Honor (US)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Discrimination', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: President Obama will award the Medal of Honor next month to 24 Army veterans, most of them Hispanic or Jewish, who were passed over because of their race or ethnicity.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will award the Medal of Honor next month to 24 Army veterans, most of them Hispanic or Jewish, who were passed over for the nation’s highest military award because of their race or ethnicity, the White House announced on Friday.

headline: Collins Would Be an Asset on the Court, the Nets Say, Not a Distraction Off It
abstract: Deron Williams said that Jason Collins would be welcomed by the Nets if he joined them as the N.B.A.’s first openly gay player.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Nets continued internal conversations on Friday about potential frontcourt players to add to their roster. After the team practiced at the Olympic Club, a private athletic and social club, Coach Jason Kidd said he had briefly joined discussions with the front office.

headline: Texas Strikes Again
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Voting has begun in the primaries, and one thing you can say about this election season in Texas is that it certainly is not boring.
lead_paragraph: Election season in Texas! They’re voting right now in the primaries. And I know you are interested because whatever happens in Texas has a way of coming back and biting the rest of the nation.

headline: Terror Case Has Lawyer With Several Distinctions
abstract: Zoë J. Dolan said she had not raised her transgender background with her client Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, who is about to stand trial in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: When the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, begins next month in Manhattan, his defense team will include one lawyer with a particularly interesting background.

headline: Accommodating Divisiveness
abstract: The ugly words of Ted Nugent don’t belong in politics.
lead_paragraph: Ted Nugent, a.k.a. the Motor City Madman, an ex-rocker who’s off his rocker, is at it again.

headline: Turkey’s Internet Crackdown
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media', 'Censorship', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Editorials']
abstract: A new law that would lead to the blocking of many websites is the latest assault on democracy.
lead_paragraph: President Abdullah Gul, Turkey’s head of state, has now joined Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan in the government’s assault on free speech. On Tuesday, Mr. Gul approved a new law, passed earlier by Parliament, that is intended to help protect Mr. Erdogan and his allies from a widening corruption scandal by tightening government control of the Internet. It would allow the authorities, without a court order, to block web pages under the guise of protecting personal privacy, and to collect users’ browsing histories.

headline: An End to the Grand-Bargain Charades
abstract: President Obama is planning for a 2015 budget based on the country’s needs, not on impossible Republican demands.
lead_paragraph: The phony budget games finally came to an end this week. After years of trying to entice Republicans into serious negotiations over a fiscal deal — years of instant rejection and painful austerity — the White House announced it was giving up.

headline: Syrians Seek New Delay in Export of Chemical Arms
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The Syrian government has asked for a delay until mid-May for the export of its chemical weapons arsenal, an indication that the country’s pledge to eradicate that arsenal is fraying.
lead_paragraph: The Syrian government has sought a new delay, until mid-May, for the export of its chemical weapons arsenal and is balking at a deadline looming in three weeks to destroy the 12 facilities that once produced the munitions, Western diplomats said Friday. The announcement is a new indication that Syria’s pledge to eradicate the banned arsenal — under a timetable already weeks behind schedule — is fraying.

headline: G.O.P. Congressman in South Carolina Takes a Risk With a Foray Into Immigration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Representative Mike Mulvaney, who convened a town-hall-style meeting on the issue with an audience of Latinos, could face the ire of Tea Party conservatives if he moves too far on a push for an overhaul.
lead_paragraph: GAFFNEY, S.C. — After the sterling conservative voting record he has established during three years in Washington, Representative Mick Mulvaney, a Republican, can take a few political risks in his South Carolina district, one of the most conservative in this reliably Republican state. This week he did just that.

headline: New Comptroller Stands by Handling of a Wrongful Conviction Case
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: The city comptroller’s decision to pay $6.4 million to a man wrongfully convicted of murder before he even filed a lawsuit is both praised and dissected.
lead_paragraph: The city comptroller’s decision to pay $6.4 million to a man wrongfully convicted of murder before he even filed a lawsuit marked a sharp break with past practice and could have ramifications for similar cases, lawyers who specialize in wrongful convictions said.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 21, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Religious Right in Arizona Cheers Bill Allowing Businesses to Refuse to Serve Gays
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona must decide whether to sign the legislation that would allow religious beliefs as a legal justification for denying service to same-sex couples.
lead_paragraph: In New Mexico, a photographer declined to take pictures of a lesbian couple’s commitment ceremony. In Washington State, a florist would not provide flowers for a same-sex wedding. And in Colorado, a baker refused to make a cake for a party celebrating the wedding of two men.

headline: What to Watch at the Olympics: Saturday
abstract: It’s the final full day of competition in Sochi. Why not watch something new, like pursuit speedskating?
lead_paragraph: MIX AND MATCH You’ve feasted on hockey, skiing, figure skating and biathlon during the past two weeks, so why not use the final full day of competition in Sochi to experience something new? Skip the hockey bronze medal game (NBCSN, 10 a.m.) and the figure skating gala (NBCSN, 12:30 p.m.) and opt instead for snowboarding’s parallel giant slalom (NBC, 2:30 p.m.). Or wait for the pursuit events in speedskating (NBC, 8 p.m.), in which teams of three skaters start on opposite sides of the ice and race as groups to the finish, mano-a-mano-a-mano-a-mano. It’s just like the cycling version held at the Summer Games. Only colder.

headline: A Week of Fire and Ice
abstract: The images of riot police officers pummeling demonstrators contrasted with those from Sochi of swirling skaters and daredevil skiers.
lead_paragraph: That barricades remain a brutal but effective final resort for desperate citizens was amply on display this past week, not only in Ukraine, where President Viktor F. Yanukovych appeared finally to surrender, but also in Venezuela, where the batons and tear gas of riot police officers failed to quell anti-government demonstrations, and in Thailand, where the police engaged in bloody efforts to clear sites occupied by protesters since late November.

headline: Bad Egg
abstract: A wicked Saturday puzzle from Evan Birnholz.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Something wicked this way comes.

headline: As Crisis Loomed, Yellen Made Wry and Forceful Calls for Action
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Janet Yellen was a nonvoting member of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee as global finances soured, but she called for swift action and disarmed critics with gallows humor.
lead_paragraph: As the world’s financial system stood on the verge of collapse in October 2008, Janet L. Yellen was not even a full voting member of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee, but she was not shy about admonishing her colleagues for not acting faster.

headline: With Tumult Around Him, Russian Diplomat Keeps Calm
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations', 'Music']
abstract: Vitaly I. Churkin finds his country the focus of international attention both at home with the Olympics, and at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Sweptback silver hair, polar blue tie, signature pinstripe suit: The only thing out of place was a bandage around Vitaly I. Churkin’s right thumb as he departed for a meeting of his fellow United Nations Security Council ambassadors the other day to have what he called a thorny discussion about Syria.

headline: U.S. Proposes Cuts to Rates in Medicare Payments
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: An Obama administration proposal to reduce Medicare payment rates for managed care plans was met with resistance by Republicans, who said beneficiaries would suffer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday proposed cuts in Medicare payment rates for managed-care plans serving more than one-fourth of all beneficiaries, and Republicans immediately pounced on the proposal, which appears likely to become a significant issue in this year’s midterm elections.

headline: In Struggles of Artist With His Work, Hints of Mexico’s Own
abstract: Damián Ortega’s installation outside the new Museo Jumex in Mexico City has become a commentary on modern Mexico, in even more ways than he had intended.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — DAMIÁN ORTEGA’S completed installation outside the new Museo Jumex here looks, at first, like a workaday kitchen filmed in space. A teapot, plates, bowls and utensils slowly spin above an unassuming wooden table. A chair, then another, seem to be balancing on one leg.

headline: Video Notebook: Mexican Art
abstract: The Times’s Damien Cave tracks the delayed debut of Damián Ortega’s modern art installation outside the new Museo Jumex in Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Damien Cave tracks the delayed debut of Damián Ortega’s modern art installation outside the new Museo Jumex in Mexico City.

headline: Walter Ehlers, Last of Medal of Honor Recipients in D-Day Attack, Dies at 92
abstract: The World War II veteran said he remained haunted by the Omaha Beach death of his older brother, who enlisted in the Army in 1940 alongside his younger sibling.
lead_paragraph: Walter D. Ehlers, who received the Medal of Honor for his exploits as an Army sergeant in the D-Day invasion of France and came to personify the heroism of the G.I.’s who stormed the beaches of Normandy on June 6, 1944, died on Thursday in Long Beach, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Richard Cabela, Who Sold the Great Outdoors, Is Dead at 77
abstract: Mr. Cabela founded Cabela’s after he had bought $45 worth of hand-tied fishing flies while on a business trip to Chicago for the family’s furniture store near the Colorado border.
lead_paragraph: Richard N. Cabela, founder of the hunting and outdoors retail chain Cabela’s, one of the largest sellers of guns and ammunition in the country, died on Monday at his home in Sidney, Neb., where the company is based. He was 77.

headline: Amid Fence-Mending, Another U.S.-Russia Rift
abstract: The political crisis in Ukraine has underscored the difficulties of restoring constructive ties between Washington and Moscow.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After putting the tense Russian-American relationship on “pause” last year, President Obama and his team have lately been working to get it back on track by quietly planning a possible meeting this summer with President Vladimir V. Putin. The two sides have even begun discussing a trade agreement for the two to sign.

headline: Two Ticks of Clock Against Magic Prove Microcosm of the Knicks’ Fading Season
abstract: On Tyson Chandler’s dunk attempt in overtime, the ball caromed off his head and bounced back out of the basket, another example of the Knicks getting in their own way.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The entire sequence lasted less than two seconds, yet it provided the perfect summation of everything that had gone wrong for the Knicks this season.

headline: Two Sexual Assaults Are Reported at Yale
abstract: The Yale University Police Department has received anonymous reports that two undergraduate students were sexually assaulted at an off-campus party this month, the university said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Yale University Police Department has received anonymous reports that two undergraduate students were sexually assaulted at an off-campus party this month, the university said on Friday night.

headline: Growing Support, and Tea From Young Women, Embolden Kiev Street Fighters
abstract: Young men on the front lines of the antigovernment protest said the adulation expressed by many people in Ukraine’s capital has inspired them to keep fighting.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The street fighters in Independence Square, kitted out with motorcycle helmets, plywood shields and baseball bats, are an intimidating lot by any measure, and this week they turned whole battalions of riot police officers on their heels in epic, bloody clashes that stunned the world.

headline: WhatsApp Deal Bets on a Few Fewer ‘Friends’
abstract: In buying WhatsApp, Facebook is betting that the future of social networking will depend on the ability to quickly and efficiently communicate with your closest confidants.
lead_paragraph: The address book is making a billion-dollar comeback.

headline: U.N. Office Criticizes Australia Detention Policies
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: Australia’s treatment of asylum seekers sent to offshore processing centers is cruel, inhuman and degrading and it violates international law, the United Nations’ human rights office said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s treatment of asylum seekers sent to offshore processing centers is cruel, inhuman and degrading and it violates international law, the United Nations’ human rights office said Friday.

headline: Response From Latin American Leaders on Venezuelan Unrest Is Muted
abstract: Street protests in which at least four have died do not evoke the type of criticism that is reserved for the United States.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — When President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela arrived in Havana for a regional summit meeting last month, Latin American and Caribbean solidarity seemed triumphant. The United States was not invited, and in speech after speech, the region’s leaders expressed confidence in a shared, unified future.

headline: Hope Springs, Again, for Yankees and Mets
abstract: With new faces and renewed optimism, the Yankees began training in Tampa, Fla., while the Mets opened their camp in Port St. Lucie, Fla.
lead_paragraph: With new faces and renewed optimism, the Yankees began training in Tampa, Fla., while the Mets opened their camp in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

headline: Brushing Up On the Most Curious New Beauty Tools
abstract: Futuristic brushes from M.A.C took center stage backstage during New York fashion week.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at Diane von Furstenberg’s fall show, there was an unusual makeup tool being swept across the preternaturally smooth complexion of the singer Annie Clark, a.k.a. St. Vincent. From a distance, it looked a bit like a toothbrush or perhaps one of those hand-held, skin-firming wands. Nope! Turns out, it was one of three new Masterclass Makeup Brushes from M.A.C. Launched this winter, these newfangled tools perform all the usual beauty tasks — blending eye shadow, smudging eyeliner, buffing foundation into the skin, saturating the lips with color — albeit with a supercool design unlike that of a traditional brush. The most noticeable difference: The head and handle point toward the face, rather than away from it, which allows you to actually see what you’re doing in the mirror without hands getting in the way (imagine that!). Another plus: The densely packed synthetic bristles — or, rather, “cosmefibres” — evenly disperse makeup particles over the face, sans streaks. Oh, and the rubberized handles are just comfy to hold, which is key for a busy makeup artist like Regan Rabanal, who spent hours painting faces at numerous New York Fashion Week shows, including Zac Posen, Cushnie Et Ochs and Badgley Mischka.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) NOW YOU SEE ME (2013) A group of magicians — a sleight-of-hand virtuoso (Jesse Eisenberg, above), a mentalist (Woody Harrelson), a pickpocket (Dave Franco) and an escape artist (Isla Fisher) — turned Robin Hoods try to outrun an F.B.I. agent (Mark Ruffalo) and an Interpol detective (Mélanie Laurent), sending cash showering down on their audiences. “Up to this point, ‘Now You See Me’ is an enjoyable goof that in its giddy way evokes a world propelled by technological wizardry enabling those who are clever enough to steal from everybody else,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this caper directed by Louis Leterrier, which also stars Morgan Freeman and Michael Caine. But “long before the story culminates with a preposterous final revelation, whatever hopes you had that ‘Now You See Me’ might have had anything to say about the profession of magic, rampant greed or anything else have been dashed.”

headline: U.S. Army Seeks Better Ties With China’s Military

abstract: As tensions rise between China and other Asian nations, a top U.S. general is working on improving contacts with China’s military.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A top American military commander said Saturday that the United States Army was working to start a formal dialogue and exchange program with the Chinese People’s Liberation Army before the end of the year.

headline: Archrival Is Freed as Ukraine Leader Flees
abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev, denouncing what he called a violent coup, as his nemesis, former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, was released from prison and Parliament found him unable to fulfill his duties.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Abandoned by his own guards and reviled across the Ukrainian capital but still determined to recover his shredded authority, President Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev on Friday night to denounce what he called a violent coup, as his official residence, his vast, colonnaded office complex and other once impregnable centers of power fell without a fight to throngs of joyous citizens stunned by their triumph.

headline: White Sox Lean on Sale, the Skinny Guy Throwing Strikes
abstract: White Sox pitcher Chris Sale, 6 feet 6 inches and 180 pounds, has made the All-Star team in both of his seasons as a starter.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Chris Sale stands 6 feet 6 inches and weighs only 180 pounds. In the history of baseball’s major leagues, only one pitcher at least that tall, weighing no more than Sale, has ever made more starts. His name was William Jennings Bryan Harriss, but he was known, naturally, as Slim. He pitched in the 1920s.

lead_paragraph: John Brunetti Sr., owner of Hialeah Park, revived the famed track with quarter horse racing and a casino, and he hopes thoroughbreds will follow.

lead_paragraph: HIALEAH, Fla. — John Brunetti is 83, which makes him slightly younger than Hialeah Park, the famous racetrack he owns. Both are looking pretty good for their age.

(Incidentally, guys, whatever you want to call 2008, the one thing it definitely wasn’t was a FISCAL crisis. A case of BowlesSimpson on the brain?) I’m a bit surprised, but that’s not the most surprising thing.

headline: Caution: Stuffed Shirts Ahead
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Careers and Professions']

headline: 1964: U.S. TV Corps Grapples with Cops, Alps and Lingo

headline: Chicken Soup for Flu-Weary Guests
abstract: Hotels are offering menus to help ward off the sniffles, or worse.
lead_paragraph: With flu season at its peak in the United States, some hotels, especially in New York City, are trying to help guests ward off the illness or at least make it easier to manage. The Kitano in Midtown Manhattan has a new immune-system-boosting menu with ingredients like ginger and plum paste in dishes like steamed egg custard with crab meat. The Hotel Chandler in the Murray Hill neighborhood has a “Flu Away” package through the end of March — a room with a pamphlet that has tips on staying healthy and a Vicks GermFree humidifier. Prices start at $250 a night.

headline: Going the Distance Grows Shorter for Many Runners
abstract: Half-marathons have become more popular across the country as organizers discover that shorter races are cheaper to operate than marathons.
lead_paragraph: When 30,000 competitors considered what distance to run in this weekend’s Gasparilla Distance Classic, they had five choices: traditional or stroller-friendly 5-kilometer, an 8k, a 15k or a half marathon.

abstract: In the arts, low-cost digital technology allows more niche players a chance to compete. Yet entertainment’s giants still have vast advantages.
lead_paragraph: It’s clear that the lives of many creative artists are being transformed by digital technology. But competing schools of thought cite the very same technology in support of strikingly different conclusions.

headline: David Rosenblatt of 1stdibs, on Teamwork at the Top
