headline: A New Light on Regulators in the Dark
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Federal Reserve transcripts show a board playing catch-up with the events of 2008.
lead_paragraph: In the five years that have elapsed since the direst days of the financial crisis, we’ve learned much about how the nation’s high-level banking regulators worked to keep the debacle from turning into a full-blown economic Depression. Tales of these herculean efforts have emerged in books by some of the major players, and in the exhaustive testimony they’ve presented before congressional inquisitors and others trying to determine what went wrong and why.

headline: A Young Inventor, Finding the Crunch Factor
abstract: How should General Mills gauge the texture of its granola bars? An inventor in his 20s has come up with an answer.
lead_paragraph: The way Mark King tells the story, the idea came to him in an instant just three years ago, when he was a 21-year-old community-college dropout. Like the proverbial Edisonian light bulb, there it was: an organoleptic analyzer.

headline: In His Office, There’s Always Cause for Celebration
abstract: Scott Painter, chief executive of TrueCar, an automotive pricing and information website, keeps champagne at the ready at its headquarters. “At TrueCar,” he says, “we celebrate everything.”
lead_paragraph: Reluctant officeholder

headline: Jimmie Johnson Does Triathlons, but Is He an Athlete?
abstract: Although some question whether racecar drivers are athletes, Johnson, the Nascar Sprint Cup champion, competes in triathlons and marathons to stay in shape.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — A typical week in the life of Jimmie Johnson on the way to winning his sixth Nascar Sprint Cup championship last season included five miles of swimming, 40 miles of running, 100 miles of cycling and one race.

headline: Oysters Make a Comeback
abstract: Connoisseurs across the country are binging on oysters. The trend is, at least in part, the result of a rapid growth of oyster farms on the East and West Coasts.
lead_paragraph: Connoisseurs across the country are binging on oysters. The trend is, at least in part, the result of a rapid growth of oyster farms on the East and West Coasts.

headline: Loss Leaders on the Half Shell
abstract: A nationwide binge on oysters is transforming an industry (and restaurants’ economics).
lead_paragraph: The joint is jumpin’: Three mixologists in striped dress shirts, dark slacks and suspenders pour drinks almost as fast as three shuckers send platter after platter of raw oysters to their fate. A bluesy soundtrack wafts over the standing-room-only din as patrons sip and slurp, oblivious to the crowd that has gathered outside for what can be a 90-minute wait.

headline: Jil Sander: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Wisconsin’s Legacy for Unions
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Education (K-12)', 'Government Employees', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Could a law that so swiftly deflated unions’ power become the pattern for other states? It’s labor’s worst fear.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, a labor leader named Marty Beil was one of the loudest opponents of Gov. Scott Walker’s “budget repair bill,” a proposal that brought tens of thousands of protesters out to the Wisconsin State Capitol in Madison in frigid February weather. A gruff-voiced grizzly of a man, Mr. Beil warned that the bill was rigged with booby traps that would cripple the state’s public-sector unions.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Versace’s Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Test in Northwestern Case: Is College Football a Job?
abstract: In a hearing before the National Labor Relations Board in Chicago, Northwestern players have laid out an argument that they are employees entitled to unionize.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For four days last week in a courtroom on the 13th floor of the Dirksen Federal Building, a National Labor Relations Board panel heard testimony concerning whether Northwestern football players should have the right to collectively bargain as university employees.

headline: Jordan Keeps Haunting Knicks’ Playoff Hopes
abstract: First it was Michael Jordan’s Bulls blocking the Knicks’ way in the N.B.A. playoffs, and now it is his Bobcats.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when it felt as if the only thing standing in the way of a Knicks championship was Michael Jordan. Throughout the 1990s, the Knicks would charge into the playoffs looking for the team’s first title since 1973 only to be sent home unceremoniously by Jordan’s Chicago Bulls.

headline: N.H.L. and Players Differ Over 2018 Games
abstract: While the players welcome the exposure of the Olympics, owners and league officials bristle at interrupting the season and the potential for injuries.
lead_paragraph: No moment symbolized the uncertain future of N.H.L. Olympic participation more than the friendly disagreement between Commissioner Gary Bettman and René Fasel, the president of the International Ice Hockey Federation, at their news conference last week in Sochi, Russia.

headline: U.N. Orders Both Sides in Syria to Allow Humanitarian Aid
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The resolution, unanimously adopted by the Security Council, calls on the Syrian government to allow relief agencies to enter the country, and strongly condemns terror attacks, plainly referring to some of the rebels.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In a rare show of unity among world powers, the United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution on Saturday ordering the warring parties in Syria to stop blocking the delivery of humanitarian aid, though without the immediate prospect of punishment for those who disobey.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Bottega Veneta Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Shiffrin Wants 5 Alpine Wins in ’18
abstract: Mikaela Shiffrin, who won the gold in slalom, said her dream is to repeat and win the giant slalom, downhill, super-G and super combined in the next Olympics.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Less than 24 hours after winning her first Olympic gold medal, Mikaela Shiffrin announced that her goal in the 2018 Winter Olympics was to win all five Alpine events. It would be an unprecedented sweep for a ski racer.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: February 21, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses net neutrality and Facebook’s big acquisition.
lead_paragraph: The F.C.C. is making a renewed push to pass net neutrality rules to keep the Internet free and open. This week on Money Talking, Joe and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine examine whether broadband Internet service should be regulated like a utility, similar to power, water or telephone service. They also weigh in on Facebook’s $19 billion acquisition of the messaging app WhatsApp, and the imminent I.P.O. from King, the creator of the ubiquitous cellphone game Candy Crush Saga.

headline: Variety: Miracle on Ice
abstract: Strap on your ice skates for this acrostic, courtesy of Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — The Sochi Olympics are underway, and this week’s acrostic takes inspiration from some of the events held during the Winter Games. The quote has to do with ice skating, and several answers and clues are related to sports done in an ice rink, like hockey and figure skating.

headline: With President’s Departure, Ukraine Looks Toward a Murky Future
abstract: Gone along with President Viktor F. Yanukovych was any trace of a Friday peace deal that had sought to freeze the country’s tumult.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As ranks of riot police officers, Interior Ministry troops and even the president vanished from the capital, Ukraine slipped, with often-eerie calm after months of tumultuous protests and a week of bloody mayhem, into the hands of revolution.

headline: El Chapo, Most-Wanted Drug Lord, Is Captured in Mexico
abstract: Mexican marines and the police, aided by information from the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and the United States Marshals Service, took him into custody without firing a shot.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Just before 7 a.m. on Saturday, dozens of soldiers and police officers descended on a condominium tower in Mazatlán, Mexico, a beach resort known as much as a hangout for drug traffickers as for its seafood and surf.

headline: Translating Thrills on the Skiing Trails
abstract: A trio of polyglot announcers have informed and entertained the multilingual crowds at Olympic cross-country skiing events.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — For the past two weeks, cross-country skiing fans have been among the most boisterous, screaming, waving flags and ringing cowbells as the athletes circled on the trails around them.

headline: Updates on a Day of Upheaval in Ukraine
abstract: Video and social media updates on a day of upheaval in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Andrew Higgins and Andrew Kramer report from Kiev, on a day of upheaval, Ukraine’s president, Viktor Yanukovych, fled the capital, the Parliament called for early elections to replace him, protesters strolled the grounds of the abandoned presidential palace and the jailed opposition leader Yulia Tymoshenko was released from a prison hospital in eastern Ukraine where she was being held.

headline: What to Watch at the Olympics: Sunday
abstract: The men’s gold medal hockey game and the closing ceremony are the highlights of the day.
lead_paragraph: MEN’S HOCKEY Gold medals will be awarded in four-man bobsled, the men’s 50-kilometer cross-country race and, finally, men’s hockey. The final game will not feature the beloved home team, but it is a meeting of hockey heavyweights nonetheless. Canada and Sweden have won three of the four gold medals since N.H.L. players became part of the men’s tournament in 1998, Canada in 2002 and 2010 and Sweden in 2006. Neither team has lost in the tournament. Henrik Lundqvist and Sweden have given up just six goals in the tournament; Carey Price and Canada have allowed only three NBC, 7 a.m.

headline: How It All Began: A Cold War Battle Heats Up
abstract: Three core factors led to the chaos in Ukraine: a broken promise between a leader and his people, a lingering Cold War-era fight, and public outrage at the government’s response to protests.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Three months of civic unrest in Ukraine spiraled out of control last week with dozens of people dead, the center of this elegant city turned into a burning war zone and the eventual flight from the capital on Friday by the president. Puzzled about the conflict and how it got so bad? Here’s a primer.

headline: Holdout’s Faith Rewarded Amid Olympic Makeover
abstract: Prokofey Drovichev, 73, turned down the money he was offered to relocate, hoping he would not have to move, and the Olympic Park development stopped just short of his home.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — It was a year ago, almost to the day, that Prokofey Drovichev stood in his mud yard and wondered what would happen to him and his family. The Olympics were coming, and he needed to get out of the way.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Roberto Cavalli Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Antonio Marras: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: U.S. Fans Snap Up World Cup Tickets
abstract: Other than fans from Brazil, the U.S. has received the greatest number of tickets allocated for the 2014 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: More tickets to the 2014 World Cup have been allocated by FIFA to fans from the United States than to those in any other nation, other than Brazil, the host.

headline: Live Stream | Emilio Pucci’s Fall 2014 Collection at Milan Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Emilio Pucci at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The latest women’s collection from Emilio Pucci at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: In a First for Spain, a Woman Is Convicted of Inciting Terror Over Twitter
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Social Media', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The case is one of a recent handful that have pushed social media into courtrooms worldwide and raised issues of the limits of speech on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The line between youthful rebelliousness and something more dangerous is not always clear. But in her angry musings on Twitter, Alba González Camacho, 21, who describes herself as a “very normal girl,” sailed across it. After she posted messages calling for a far-left terrorist organization to return to arms and kill politicians, Spain’s national court convicted her of inciting terrorism using a social media network.

headline: Resolution From the United Nations Security Council on Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: In a hard-fought show of unity among world powers, the United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Saturday to order the warring parties in Syria to stop blocking the delivery of humanitarian aid, though without the immediate prospect of punishment against those who disobey.
lead_paragraph: In a hard-fought show of unity among world powers, the United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Saturday to order the warring parties in Syria to stop blocking the delivery of humanitarian aid, though without the immediate prospect of punishment against those who disobey.

headline: Celtics-Lakers Rivalry, Once Lustrous, Is Now Lackluster
abstract: The Celtics, who have lost 25 of 32, and the Lakers, who have dropped 23 of 29, have plummeted to unusual depths. For only the second time in 65 seasons, it seems, both teams will miss the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was just four years ago that the Celtics were beaten by the Lakers, and Coach Doc Rivers went around the visitors’ locker room and collected $100 from every player and coach. He removed a ceiling tile and hid the money, then told his players they would be coming back in June to collect it.

headline: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 22
abstract: Saturday was the next-to-last day of competition at the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: Saturday was the next-to-last day of competition at the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 23
abstract: As violence boiled over in Ukraine and President Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev this week, lawmakers will weigh in on how President Obama’s responding to the situation.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian Parliament voted Saturday to oust President Viktor F. Yanukovych after weeks of antigovernment protests and violent clashes with the military. Protesters claimed to have established control of the capital city, while Mr. Yanukovych called the events a “coup” in a television interview on Saturday.

headline: Flying High While Still on the Ground
abstract: Emily Cook, of the United States freestyle ski team, visualizes each aerial jump as part of her training for the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Emily Cook, of the United States freestyle ski team, visualizes each aerial jump as part of her training for the Olympics.

headline: Olympians Use Imagery as Mental Training
abstract: Visualization has long been a part of elite sports, but the practice of mentally simulating competition has become increasingly sophisticated, essential and elaborate.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The Canadian bobsledder Lyndon Rush had not yet arrived in Sochi. But he was already on the Olympic sliding track as he sat in a chair in the Munich airport several days before the Winter Olympics, his eyes wide open but his mind’s eye far away as he traced a sinuous path through the air with his left hand.

headline: When Doctors Need to Lie
abstract: Misleading your patient? Defying his wishes? Sometimes in medicine these things are necessary.
lead_paragraph: I ONCE had the unenviable task of informing a 22-year-old Jamaican man that he was suffering from severe heart failure and would probably need a heart transplant. The man’s father warned me that his son would be devastated to hear the diagnosis. “It would mean a lot to me if you could go back in and tell him he’s going to be all right,” the father pleaded. “Please tell him that if he does the things you say, he’s going to be O.K.”

headline: Audiobooks and the Return of Storytelling
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Ears and Hearing', 'Audiobooks', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Illiteracy']
abstract: We shouldn’t regard reading a book as more serious than hearing it out loud.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — THE ferns under my oak trees evoke moments from “The Great Gatsby” for me. I read the book many years ago, but I listened to it last summer while planting 50 polypodium californicas and 50 festuca idahoensis in the dappled light beneath my oaks. Now, when I look at them, I think about that last awful accident, the yellow Rolls-Royce screaming past the repair shop, and what F. Scott Fitzgerald’s narrator called Gatsby’s extraordinary gift for hope.

headline: A Picasso in Trouble
abstract: A developer wants to get rid of a bullfighting scene that was once part of a stage curtain for the Ballets Russes.
lead_paragraph: The largest and most endangered Picasso many of us have never seen lives on Park Avenue, in the Seagram Building. To get to it, walk to East 52nd Street, past the idling Town Cars, through the door of the Four Seasons restaurant. Give a nod to the friendly coat-check guy, then head up the stairs, into the soaring space of the Grill Room, where the city’s uppermost crust is having lunch or drinks. Keep going into the corridor that leads to the Pool Room. Look right, and up.

headline: Can God Make It in Hollywood?
abstract: Can Hollywood still find common ground with religious audiences?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — SOME years ago, when I was producing films at Columbia Pictures, I learned up close how hard it was to make Hollywood get religion. It was in the mid-1990s, and a good writer, earlier nominated for an Oscar, had an earnest modern-day Christ story about a damaged man in Los Angeles who might or might not be the Messiah. “The Greatest Story Ever Told” meets “Falling Down,” more or less.

headline: How to Get a Job at Google
abstract: Hint: Getting hired is not about your G.P.A. It’s about what you can do and what you know.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — LAST June, in an interview with Adam Bryant of The Times, Laszlo Bock, the senior vice president of people operations for Google — i.e., the guy in charge of hiring for one of the world’s most successful companies — noted that Google had determined that “G.P.A.’s are worthless as a criteria for hiring, and test scores are worthless. ... We found that they don’t predict anything.” He also noted that the “proportion of people without any college education at Google has increased over time” — now as high as 14 percent on some teams. At a time when many people are asking, “How’s my kid gonna get a job?” I thought it would be useful to visit Google and hear how Bock would answer.

headline: The F.C.C. Tries Again
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: A promising approach to rewriting federal Internet rules has its risks.
lead_paragraph: After losing two court cases on the issue, the Federal Communications Commission last week came up with a promising way to prevent broadband companies from giving preferential treatment to big players like Netflix and Google, which could hurt smaller businesses and start-ups, as well as consumers.

headline: Happiness Is a Warm iPhone
abstract: What does it mean to be in love with a computer?
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — IN Spike Jonze’s new film “Her,” Theodore Twombly, a lonely writer living in the nearish future, develops feelings for Samantha, an operating system. It is a love story wrapped around a thought experiment wrapped around a metaphor: We fall in love with our technology. That’s how we talk about our gadgets — with the language of emotional attachment, with irrational expectations about happily ever after. Now that I’m holding you, my sexy 5G smartphone, my life will never be the same.

headline: Elias Ghanem
abstract: When navigating Middle Eastern cultures for the Red Cross, smoking cigars and working on your signature are part of the job.
lead_paragraph: Elias Ghanem is the director of the Middle East and North Africa division of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.

headline: On Campaign Trail, Missteps on Gender
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Gender', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: With a bizarre illustration of Hillary Rodham Clinton and a profile of Wendy Davis, The Times Magazine has tripped over gender-based double standards.
lead_paragraph: KATHA POLLITT’s judgment, on Twitter, was harsh. The feminist writer observed: “NYT mag: First Hillary as giant bald fleshball, now ‘Can Wendy Davis Have It All?’ Sexist much?”

headline: The Games Putin Plays
abstract: The events in Ukraine offer a lesson in the limits of Russia’s grand strategy.
lead_paragraph: THE last time geopolitics intruded into an Olympics, during the 2008 Beijing Games, Vladimir Putin was the crisis’s winner: his military delivered a decisive spanking to Russia’s neighbor Georgia, whose government had fatally overestimated the West’s willingness to intervene on its behalf. The mini-war sent a clear message: after a long period of retrenchment, the Russian bear still had an appetite for power politics, and the claws to satisfy it.

headline: Mumbai’s Empty Parlor Games
abstract: Socializing with sycophants and hypocrites.
lead_paragraph: GOA, India — THERE was a time, only a few years ago now, when I prided myself as a host of parties — soirees, as some plummy guests called them. Before one such gathering, I was asked: “Are you having another sorry this week?” Rather than correct my guest’s French, I simply furnished the time, and the usual address: my sparse studio in the north Mumbai enclave of Juhu, overlooking a pond and a parking lot dotted with identically hooded black and yellow rickshaws.

headline: In the Treetops, a Winter Gift
abstract: A vaulted corridor of the branches of American elm trees in Manhattan forms “a tabernacle of the air.”
lead_paragraph: THEY looked, at first glance, like trees in a paint-by-number picture, snow outlining branches in idiot-proof chiaroscuro — a child’s “Winter Scene.” Yet as I stood in a recent wet snowstorm on 110th Street, looking down Fifth Avenue along Central Park, I saw that the elms flanking the sidewalk had an aspect in winter less observable in other seasons, when their branches are cloaked in leaves.

headline: When Even the Starting Line Is Out of Reach
abstract: One little boy’s story illuminates how we can build opportunity for all.
lead_paragraph: POINT PLEASANT, W.Va. — JOHNNY WEETHEE, a beautiful and beaming child who at the age of 3 still struggles to speak, encapsulates the shortcomings of our approach to poverty.

headline: A Viable Common Core?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Mathematics']
abstract: Educators and others take part in a national debate over the new learning standards.
lead_paragraph: Educators and others take part in a national debate over the new learning standards.

headline: Christie Puts the Gloves On
keywords: ['George Washington Bridge', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Chris Christie returns to his forum of choice, the bully is on his best behavior.
lead_paragraph: PORT MONMOUTH, N.J. — THERE’S nothing more amusing than a bully forced to be on his best behavior.

headline: What the Stimulus Accomplished
keywords: ['American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'Editorials', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Though ridiculed by Republicans, the 2009 Recovery Act saved the American economy.
lead_paragraph: Of all the myths and falsehoods that Republicans have spread about President Obama, the most pernicious and long-lasting is that the $832 billion stimulus package did not work. Since 2009, Republican lawmakers have inextricably linked the words “failed” and “stimulus,” and last week, five years after passage of the Recovery Act, they dusted off their old playbook again.

headline: Slalom Champion Sets an Age Record
abstract: Mario Matt, 34, had never finished higher than 34th in three previous Olympic races. His teammate Marcel Hirscher won the silver, and Henrik Kristoffersen of Norway took the bronze.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A day after Mikaela Shiffrin became the youngest women’s Olympic slalom champion, the 34-year-old Mario Matt of Austria became the oldest men’s Olympic slalom champion on Saturday, winning the gold medal over his teammate Marcel Hirscher by 28-hundredths of a second.

headline: Parliament Votes to Dismiss Yanukovych
abstract: The Ukrainian Parliament voted to declare Viktor F. Yanukovych constitutionally unable to be the president of the country. It scheduled an early vote for May 25.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian Parliament voted to declare Viktor F. Yanukovych constitutionally unable to be the president of the country. It scheduled an early vote for May 25.

headline: Classics Aflame at Bottega Veneta
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: Simple black pumps with a sculptural fire silhouette.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Emilio Pucci: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: New York City Chancellor Meets With Charter School Leaders
abstract: New York City’s schools chancellor, Carmen Fariña, met with more than 100 representatives from the city’s charter schools, and they found common ground over serving at-risk children.
lead_paragraph: The meeting was something like an early gathering of merging families. Both sides already knew each other, but no one was ready to broach potential conflict, lingering instead in the space of common interest: the well-being of the children.

headline: At N.F.L. Combine, Michael Sam Says He Wants Focus on Field
abstract: In a session that lasted more than 12 minutes, Michael Sam conducted his first news conference since he publicly declared that he was gay.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Like the other top N.F.L. draft prospects this year, Michael Sam met with reporters Saturday at Lucas Oil Stadium. Unlike any other soon-to-be professional football players, Sam wore a special button on the lanyard that hung around his neck.

headline: Chain of Betrayal
abstract: Some Social Security history.
lead_paragraph: It was big news this past week when President Obama dropped the notion of effectively cutting Social Security benefits by switching to “chain-linked” consumer prices, because it marked a turn away from BowlesSimpsonized discourse, from Grand Bargain-seeking. But there’s a bit more to it: an acknowledgement, finally, that today’s Republicans are utterly cynical and untrustworthy, that there’s no point in seeking compromise.

headline: Investing in Kids
abstract: Yes, we need a higher minimum wage. But above all, we need to invest in children at the dawn of life to create opportunity and help snap the cycle of poverty.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column, about the importance of anti-poverty efforts that focus on children, was motivated by a sense of frustration about the debate in this country. On the one hand, it’s terrific that we’re beginning to have a serious discussion about inequality, poverty and opportunity. On the other, the debate is mostly about the minimum wage and unemployment benefits, which to my thinking are useful but not the most cost-effective measures. The single most important measures we could take to build opportunity is to invest in children at the dawn of life to try harder to snap the cycle of poverty.

headline: Age of Austerity
abstract: And how.
lead_paragraph: Zachary Goldfarb defends the argument that we’ve been living in an age of austerity against conservative denialists. He’s right, of course — but I think there are more graphic ways to make the point.

headline: Mets’ Matt Harvey Tosses a Ball for the First Time Since Surgery
abstract: “I feel brand-new,” Harvey said after 20 throws. But he acknowledged that he could not rush his recovery from Tommy John surgery.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Exactly four months after having Tommy John surgery on his right elbow, Matt Harvey stood in the outfield grass at the Mets’ complex Saturday and tossed a baseball 20 times to the bullpen catcher Dave Racaniello about 60 feet away.

headline: Ready to Shed 2 Players, Knicks Let Game Get Away
abstract: The Knicks, already without three injured players, fell to the Hawks after moving to part ways with two others, Beno Udrih and Metta World Peace.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — As the ball went up for the opening tip at Philips Arena on Saturday night, Cole Aldrich draped his left arm over the back of the folding chair next to him. It was empty.

headline: Reel-Life Anniversary
abstract: Victor Fleming makes a name for himself with this Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s a strange feeling when someone has the same name as you.

headline: The Memory Stone
abstract: One of the things that scared me about leaving the house was leaving behind the memories of 32 years.
lead_paragraph: This is the last part of an eight-part series.

headline: Obama to Propose Shift in Wildfire Funding
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Wildfires', 'Global Warming', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: President Obama is to propose on Monday that Congress pay the costs of fighting wildfires in the same way it finances federal responses to disasters like hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s annual budget request to Congress will propose a significant change in how the government pays to fight wildfires, administration officials said, a move that they say reflects the ways in which climate change is increasing the risk for and cost of those fires.

headline: Behind Gates, Bizarre Vision of Opulence
abstract: After the departure of President Viktor F. Yanukovych, his sprawling compound was opened, revealing a golf course, a private zoo, classic cars and a restaurant in the form of a pirate ship, among other things.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — An eerie calm and a light mist shrouded President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s sprawling residential compound just outside the capital on Saturday morning as street fighters from the center of Kiev made their way inside, gingerly passing a wrought-iron gate and cautioning one another about booby traps and snipers.

headline: South Korea Puts Anger Aside After Olympic Skating Disappointment
abstract: When the figure skater Kim Yu-na was dethroned in Sochi by a Russian teenager, her country, which has long tied sports achievements to self-worth, reacted with anger.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Yu-na was a perfect heroine for her country. Like postwar South Korea, she rose from a humble start, skating on a tatty rink as a 6-year-old, to win gold for a nation that had felt sidelined in a sport dominated by Western athletes.

headline: 30 Seconds with Kyle Larson
abstract: Kyle Larson, who will begin his first full season in the Nascar Sprint Cup Series at the Daytona 500 on Sunday, is expected to contend for rookie of the year honors.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Larson will begin his first full season in the Nascar Sprint Cup Series at the Daytona 500 on Sunday, driving the No. 42 car for Target Chip Ganassi Racing.

headline: A Hot Debate Over E-Cigarettes as a Path to Tobacco, or From It
abstract: Some public health experts see e-cigarettes as a gateway to tobacco use, while others think they could help eradicate conventional cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Michael Siegel, a hard-charging public health researcher at Boston University, argues that e-cigarettes could be the beginning of the end of smoking in America. He sees them as a disruptive innovation that could make cigarettes obsolete, like the computer did to the typewriter.

headline: After Farmers Commit Suicide, Debts Fall on Families in India
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: India’s small farmers, once the country’s economic backbone and most reliable vote bank, are increasingly being left behind.
lead_paragraph: BOLLIKUNTA, India — Latha Reddy Musukula was making tea on a recent morning when she spotted the money lenders walking down the dirt path toward her house. They came in a phalanx of 15 men, by her estimate. She knew their faces, because they had walked down the path before.

headline: Opening the Corporation
abstract: The way people handle open source projects, by sharing a maximum amount of information, may become a standard for all kinds of corporate behavior. Get ready to move faster.
lead_paragraph: Software may be eating the world, as Marc Andreessen likes to say, but the habits around modern software seem to have just as profound an impact.

headline: An Underground Eye for the Border Patrol
abstract: Federal agents rely on military-grade robots to search drug-smuggling tunnels in Nogales, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: Federal agents rely on military-grade robots to search drug-smuggling tunnels in Nogales, Ariz.

headline: Border’s New Sentinels Are Robots, Penetrating Deepest Drug Routes
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Smuggling', 'Drug Cartels']
abstract: Robots, valued for their speed and maneuverability, can serve as the first eyes on drug-smuggling tunnels that traverse the United States border with Mexico.
lead_paragraph: NOGALES, Ariz. — Tom Pittman has made a career as a Border Patrol agent here guarding this city’s underground drainage system, where the tunnels that carry sewage and storm runoff between the United States and Mexico are also busy drug-smuggling routes. Over the years, he has crawled and slithered past putrid puddles, makeshift latrines and discarded needles left behind by drug users, relying on instincts, mostly, to gauge the risks ahead.

headline: Opponents of Same-Sex Marriage Take Bad-for-Children Argument to Court
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Children and Childhood', 'Homosexuality', 'Parenting', 'Research']
abstract: Those testifying in defense of Michigan’s ban will wield sharply disputed recent studies finding that the children of same-sex couples did not fare as well as children raised by married heterosexuals.
lead_paragraph: As they reel from a succession of defeats in courtrooms and legislatures, opponents of same-sex marriage have a new chance this week to play one of their most emotional and, they hope, potent cards: the claim that having parents of the same sex is bad for children.

headline: Officer Shoots Knife-Wielding Woman in Brooklyn, Police Say
abstract: After police responded to a 911 call from a Crown Heights apartment, one of the officers fired a single shot, injuring a woman who had lunged at them with a knife, an official said.
lead_paragraph: A police officer shot a woman inside a Brooklyn apartment on Saturday after she lunged at officers with a knife, an official said.

headline: Mexican Drug Kingpin Is Captured
abstract: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, “El Chapo,” one of Mexico’s top drug bosses and a Forbes list billionaire since 2009, was captured today in a Mexican resort after a 13-year manhunt.
lead_paragraph: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, “El Chapo,” one of Mexico’s top drug bosses and a Forbes list billionaire since 2009, was captured today in a Mexican resort after a 13-year manhunt.

headline: Asylum Fraud in Chinatown: An Industry of Lies
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: More Chinese immigrants seek asylum than any other immigrant group in the country, and most of them apply from New York, where federal officials regard the applicant pool with suspicion.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese woman walked into a law office in New York’s Chinatown and asked to see her lawyer. She had applied for asylum, claiming that she had been forced to get an abortion in China to comply with the country’s family-planning laws, and she was anxious about her coming interview with immigration officials.

headline: Wildcat Red Emerges as Derby Contender
abstract: Wildcat Red, a 2-year-old trained by Jose Garoffalo, established himself as a contender for the Kentucky Derby with a victory in the Fountain of Youth Stakes.
lead_paragraph: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — The trainer Jose Garoffalo spent all of his $30,000 budget last June to buy Wildcat Red as a 2-year-old, never imagining the bargain he was bringing home.

headline: A Lesson for Detroit in Efforts to Aid a New Orleans Devastated by Katrina
abstract: Detroit can learn from New Orleans, where a fix that appeared rational to some was thrown aside for a way forward that has been messier but politically more palatable.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — As Detroit confronts some of the most intractable challenges of any city in America, with an array of civic leaders and urban planners offering solutions and ideas, it may be helpful to consider Harvey Bender.

headline: In Japan’s Drill With the U.S., a Message for Beijing
abstract: American military officials insisted an annual exercise, called Iron Fist, had nothing to do with a dispute over islands, but this year, the Japanese team came packing.
lead_paragraph: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. — In the early morning along a barren stretch of beach here last week, Japanese soldiers and American Marines practiced how to invade and retake an island captured by hostile forces.

headline: Horst Rechelbacher, ‘Father of Safe Cosmetics,’ Dies at 72
abstract: He started as a hairdresser making organic hair-care products with herbs and other plants, eventually beginning the company that made natural cosmetics popular in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Horst Rechelbacher, an Austrian-born hairstylist who went on to found Aveda, a company whose pledge to eliminate toxic chemicals from its products helped give rise to a vast market for so-called natural cosmetics in the United States, died on Feb. 15 in Osceola, Wis. He was 72.

headline: The Wisconsin Labor Fight
abstract: An epic fight with unions continues to dominate the tenure of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: An epic fight with unions continues to dominate the tenure of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin.

headline: Princeton a Repeat Champ at Amateur Tournament
abstract: Princeton University’s “A” squad was only the second team to ever win the Amateur Team East championship two years in a row, and the last time that happened was in the mid-1970s.
lead_paragraph: Princeton University’s A team won the United States Amateur Team East championship last week for the second year in a row.

headline: Terry Adkins, Composer of Art, Sculptor of Music, Dies at 60
abstract: Mr. Adkins brought genres together to create multidimensional works about historic figures and cultural themes.
lead_paragraph: Terry Adkins, a conceptual artist whose work married the quicksilver evanescence of music to the solid permanence of sculpture, died on Feb. 8 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 60.

headline: Lviv, in Western Ukraine, Mourns One of Its Own Killed in Kiev
abstract: A university lecturer who was shot to death had made several trips east to the capital to take part in antigovernment protests, a friend said.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Under a leaden sky that wept intermittent rain, this fiercely proud city bade farewell on Saturday to one of its sons, a 28-year-old university lecturer killed by a bullet on Thursday in Kiev in the carnage on and around Independence Square.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 22, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Environmental Groups Resort to Suing Industries Directly
abstract: Environmental groups are suing industries for excess pollution directly, rather than relying on the government to take action, as some say agencies have been slow to enforce laws.
lead_paragraph: Starting Monday, a federal judge in Waco will hear arguments from the Sierra Club that Luminant Generation Company, the state’s largest electric generator, has been spewing far more pollution into the air from an East Texas coal plant than is allowed by federal and state law.

headline: For the Sake of the Primaries, a Simple Vision
abstract: Discussing real problems is tricky, so many candidates skip talk of boring business in favor of topics that resonate: President Obama, border security, prayer in schools.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Kerry Says Venezuela Crackdown Is ‘Unacceptable’
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: As the demonstrations continued to grow, Secretary of State John Kerry strengthened his criticism of the Venezuelan government’s response to the protesters.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Secretary of State John Kerry has markedly stepped up his criticism of Venezuela over its response to more than two weeks of antigovernment demonstrations, as the protests continued to grow this weekend.

headline: Trying to Help Thousands in Colonias Obtain Health Coverage
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Minorities', 'Poverty']
abstract: Because Texas declined to expand Medicaid eligibility for poor adults, thousands of people, especially in the state’s impoverished colonias, are finding it almost impossible to obtain health insurance.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURG — Sitting at an old picnic table in front of a dilapidated house, María Díaz, a hotel housekeeper, tells stories of the rejection that comes with living in impoverished Texas colonias.

headline: Let’s Talk a Bit More About Bates and Anna
abstract: “Downton Abbey” fans who watch Houston PBS don’t have to leave Edwardian England after each episode ends; they can keep the mood going with Ernie Manouse’s “Manor of Speaking.”
lead_paragraph: Ernie Manouse traveled to Amsterdam at the end of August 2012 but spent the three-day trip holed up in his hotel room, unexpectedly binging on the first two seasons of “Downton Abbey.”

headline: After Boeheim Leaves in a Rage, Syracuse Exits With a Loss
abstract: Coach Jim Boeheim was ejected from a regular-season game for the first time in his 38-year career for arguing an offensive foul call with his team trailing Duke by 2 late in the game.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — Forward C. J. Fair had never played at Cameron Indoor Stadium before Saturday night. Point guard Tyler Ennis had never dribbled on Coach K Court. Guard Trevor Cooney had never risen for a 3-pointer with the Cameron Crazies screaming at him.

headline: Declaring Victory in Kiev
abstract: After months of protests and a week of bloody mayhem, demonstrators in Independence Square celebrated the departure of President Viktor F. Yanukovych.
lead_paragraph: After months of protests and a week of bloody mayhem, demonstrators in Independence Square celebrated the departure of President Viktor F. Yanukovych.

headline: A Forensic Approach to a Sidewalk Nuisance
abstract: Although some officials were not amused, many Neapolitans welcomed a new campaign to track down owners who do not pick up after their dogs by using the animals’ DNA samples.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — Problems? Yes, conceded Tommaso Sodano, the vice mayor here, Naples has problems. Unpaid debts have reportedly topped $2 billion. Many streets are pocked with potholes. The police department is underfunded, organized crime operates like a shadow state, and illegal dumps are scattered around what is still a grittily beautiful port city.

headline: Taliban Raid Afghan Army Base, Killing Soldiers in Their Sleep
abstract: The attack, which left 21 soldiers dead, came as the insurgents acknowledged they had suspended talks with the Americans aimed at a prisoner exchange.
lead_paragraph: ASADABAD, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents overran an Afghan National Army base near here on Sunday morning, killing 21 soldiers in their bunks in what appeared to be the worst single blow to government forces since 2010, according to both government and insurgent officials.

headline: Ukraine Rushes to Shift Power and Mend Rifts
abstract: Lawmakers fired top cabinet members in President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s government and restored state ownership of the presidential palace.

Yanukovych’s flight and ouster on Saturday, and in sudden fears that the country might fall into civil war.

headline: Sochi Olympics Closing Ceremony Latest Updates
abstract: Times reporters offer updates, notes and observations from Fisht Stadium as the 2014 Winter Games draw to a close.
lead_paragraph: Russia had so much to prove at the Winter Games. That spending however-many-billion dollars to build an Olympics-industrial complex from scratch on the edge of the Black Sea was worth it. That despite a thicket of security worries, logistical obstacles, weather annoyances and the darkening specter of revolution in nearby Ukraine, the country could put on a Games that ran seamlessly, at times even exuberantly.

headline: Strong Finish Gives Russia Most Medals
abstract: As Nicklas Backstrom of Sweden was barred from the hockey title game after failing a drug test, bobsledder Alexander Zubkov and cross-country racer Alexander Legkov helped the host nation top the final medals standings.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The host country shone on Sunday, the final day of the 2014 Winter Olympics, as Alexander Zubkov drove Russia to victory in the four-man bobsled, Alexander Legkov led a Russian sweep of the 50-kilometer cross-country skiing race, and Russia ended the Games at the top of the medals table.

headline: The Price of a Child I Wouldn’t Let Go
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Parenting', 'Personal Finances', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Eleven years ago, when we learned about our then-unborn son’s critical heart defects, we chose to fight for him. I’ve never regretted that choice, but it’s a choice that came at a price measured in time, blood and treasure.
lead_paragraph: When I was a child, my family never discussed money. It was sufficient to know we didn’t have any. I was the quintessential American dream: girl from a trailer park who ate government cheese but became a first-generation high school graduate. I went on to earn a master’s degree and sit solidly in the top 25 percent of taxpayers, hovering around six figures as a family, a demographic reached with great effort.

headline: Stingy Defense Adds to Canada’s Gold Pile
abstract: Sidney Crosby scored his first goal of the tournament as the Canadian men won their second consecutive Olympic title. Canada defended its title in men’s hockey with a 3-0 victory over Sweden on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The Canadian men’s hockey team was one of the favorites to win the gold medal here when the Winter Games began, and on the road to the final, it steamrollered Norway and Austria before winning battles over Finland, Latvia and the United States.

headline: Samsung Introduces Two New Smartwatches
abstract: The devices have a better battery life and use Samsung’s own operating system.
lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics introduced two new smartwatches on Sunday, the Gear 2 and Gear 2 Neo, and dropped the popular Galaxy branding from its first smartwatch, the Galaxy Gear. Also, unlike Samsung’s first smartwatch, the new products use Tizen, an operating system that Samsung developed with several partners, instead of Google’s Android.

lead_paragraph: In recent days, The Deseret News, a newspaper in Salt Lake City, prominently displayed on its website a feature about Mormons on reality TV shows. The Atlantic magazine’s home page, meanwhile, drew readers to an article on why women struggle to write about sex.

lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Four people were killed, including three children, and more than 50 injured at antigovernment protests in Thailand over the weekend as the country’s protracted power struggle gave rise to more violence.

headline: What Did I Know and When Did I Know It?
abstract: More and earlier than the Fed, apparently.
lead_paragraph: The big takeaway from the 2008 Fed transcripts is that for the most part Fed officials other than Janet Yellen and Eric Rosengren failed to appreciate the danger the economy was in — that many were preoccupied with the supposed threat of inflation even as a once-in-three-generations crisis in demand was building.

headline: The Myth of German Austerity
abstract: Don’t rely on what you think you heard somewhere.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while I hear people trying to dismiss the overwhelming evidence for large economic damage from fiscal austerity by pointing to Germany: “You say that austerity hurts growth, but the Germans have done a lot of austerity and they’re booming.”

headline: Can California Avoid a ‘Shock to Trance’ Approach to Water Policy?
abstract: Can California battle inertia and pressure from its agriculture industry and become water resilient?
lead_paragraph: Forecasters predict heavy rains will sweep in from the Pacific Ocean over much of California late next week. The state’s extreme drought will be far from over, but the shift from parched days to downpours illustrates on a short time scale one factor explaining why it’s hard to change deeply ingrained and wasteful approaches to water policy.

headline: What’s on Sunday

(NBC) NANCY & TONYA (2014) In this documentary, Mary Carillo looks back at events leading up to the 1994 Winter Olympics, which pitted the figure skater Nancy Kerrigan against her rival Tonya Harding (above left, with Ms. Kerrigan), just weeks after Ms. Harding’s ex-husband and bodyguard were charged with plotting an attack on Ms. Kerrigan that injured her knee. Both women are interviewed, as are their coaches, the skater Scott Hamilton and members of the media. The closing ceremony of the Sochi Games follows at 8.

headline: Nicklas Backstrom Misses Final After Failed Drug Test
abstract: The Swedish hockey player has taken an allergy medicine for seven years, his Olympic committee said, and his N.H.L. status will not be affected.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Nicklas Backstrom, a player for the Washington Capitals in the N.H.L. who represented Sweden in its five victories on the way to the Olympic gold medal game, failed a drug test at the Sochi Games. He was removed from Sweden’s lineup Sunday before the final, which Canada won, 3-0.

headline: Those Lego Bricks Keep Piling Up at the Box Office
abstract: “The Lego Movie” took in an estimated $31.5 million over the weekend at North American theaters, for a new domestic total of $183.2 million.
lead_paragraph: And the Lego pieces keep marching on. For the third weekend in a row, “The Lego Movie” was the top draw at North American theaters, while an expensive new volcano adventure, “Pompeii,” blew its chance at profitability. “The Lego Movie” (Warner Brothers) took in an estimated $31.5 million, for a new domestic total of $183.2 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles box-office data.

headline: Bottega Veneta: Tomas Maier Turns Soft Into Sharp
abstract: The designer’s winter 2014 collection was built on dresses with a geometric flair.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Taking a scalpel to all that is fancy, yet controlling pattern in a defined space. It sounds so easy. Yet only a designer of the caliber of Tomas Maier atBottega Veneta can pull off such a combination.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana Create a Fashion Fairytale
abstract: The designers sent out a collection of hoods, cloaks and fanciful appliqués that was both whimsical and charming.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — There was not a church, a cross or a Sicilian landscape in sight as Dolce & Gabbana sent out its winter 2014 show on Sunday. Instead, falling snow, the bare branches of winter trees and Tchaikovsky’s soaring music started a fashion fairy tale.

headline: Ominous Stirrings In a Fitful Realm
abstract: Georg Friedrich Haas’s new “dark dreams,” performed by the Berlin Philharmonic, delves into a world of lurid excesses, with sound juxtapositions, swift shifts in volume, and microtonal elements.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The nightmares evoked by the title of Georg Friedrich Haas’s new “dark dreams,” which the Berlin Philharmonic played with its chief conductor, Simon Rattle, on Saturday evening at the Philharmonie here, involve repetition and circling back: the ominous sense that even as things change, they remain the same.

headline: A Fall Collection, and a Giant New Boutique, From Cavalli
abstract: Roberto Cavalli’s fall collection at Milan Fashion Week unleashed a rotisserie effect on those sitting in the front rows: a ring of flames encircling the lake.
lead_paragraph: Roberto Cavalli’s ambitions have never run small. Not content to simply put on a show at Milan Fashion Week, he staged what his team called a Roberto Cavalli Day.

headline: Jason Collins, First Openly Gay N.B.A. Player, Signs With Nets and Appears in Game
abstract: The 35-year-old center signed a 10-day contract and took the court Sunday night against the Lakers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jason Collins, a 35-year-old center, signed a 10-day contract with the Nets on Sunday afternoon and played against the Lakers hours later, appearing in an N.B.A. uniform for the first time since last spring, when he announced that he was gay.

headline: Q.&A. With Joe Belfiore on the Future of Windows Phone
abstract: Joe Belfiore, the corporate vice president of Microsoft Windows Phone, discusses goals for 2014 and the potential upside of the company’s Nokia deal.
lead_paragraph: Joe Belfiore is the corporate vice president of Microsoft Windows Phone, and he oversees the software that powers handsets using the company’s operating system. Microsoft is expected to close its $7.2 billion deal to buy the handset and services division of Nokia by the end of March. The acquisition will give Microsoft control of both mobile software and hardware, as it looks to expand its 4 percent market share in global smartphone sales. Mr. Belfiore will play a crucial role in Microsoft’s efforts to take on Apple and the cellphone makers that use Google’s Android operating system.

headline: Strutting With Style in Sochi
abstract: Russians at the Olympics displayed their national pride with an array of costumes drawing on national symbols and stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: They come in Red Army hats, silly hats, even cowboy hats. They have painted faces and wigs in the national colors. A few wear bear costumes, tongue-in-cheek displays as much for the television cameras as for the tourists.

headline: Michigan Beats Michigan State to Grab Big Ten Lead
abstract: Nik Stauskas, who took three shots in the first half, finished with 25 points for the Wolverines and led a 16-4 run that effectively sealed the victory.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Nik Stauskas had been quiet and cold for the better part of February. Stauskas, a sophomore guard, had scored more than 11 points once in Michigan’s past five games, and with him taking just three shots in the first half against Michigan State on Sunday, the dormancy seemed likely to continue.

lead_paragraph: In a sign that the tech industry may have moved past computers, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, will be the most prominent speaker this week at the Mobile World Congress, a trade show in Barcelona that revolves around smartphones and other devices.

abstract: Ukrainians turned out in Kiev to mourn those who died in last week’s conflict while pro-Yanukovych protests took place in several cities in the south and east.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainians turned out in Kiev to mourn those who died in last week’s conflict while pro-Yanukovych protests took place in several cities in the south and east.

headline: Salvatore Ferragamo’s Quietly Luxurious Knee-High Boots
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: an all-leather pair with just the right amount of opulence.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Old Railroad Stirs Memories of a Pre-Industrial China
abstract: A reporter visits his family’s ancestral home in Guangdong Province, where his father had taken the old Xinning Railway in 1936 with his family, Hong Kongers who were going into the lush countryside to build a new family home.
lead_paragraph: My father rode the Xinning Railway once. He was 4 years old and traveling from Hong Kong with his parents and older brother to their ancestral village in Guangdong Province. It was 1936, in a China without six-lane highways and gleaming airports. They were returning to the countryside to build a new family home.

abstract: Athletes discuss their experiences getting into the 2014 Olympics and once in Sochi.
lead_paragraph: Athletes discuss their experiences getting into the 2014 Olympics and once in Sochi.

headline: Comcast and Netflix Reach Deal on Service
abstract: Comcast and Netflix announced an agreement Sunday in which Netflix will pay Comcast for faster and more reliable access to Comcast’s subscribers.
lead_paragraph: Comcast, the country’s largest cable and broadband provider, and Netflix, the giant television and movie streaming service, announced an agreement Sunday in which Netflix will pay Comcast for faster and more reliable access to Comcast’s subscribers.

headline: Happy Days and Happy Feet, Despite the Depression
abstract: “Sweepin’ the Clouds Away: Boom, Bust and High Spirits,” in the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series, presents giddy and euphoric songs from the Depression era.
lead_paragraph: What, if anything, does it mean that the giddiest, most euphoric popular music ever produced in the United States bubbled and kicked up its heels while the country was sliding into the Great Depression? That question hovered over the joyous opening-night performance on Saturday of “Sweepin’ the Clouds Away: Boom, Bust and High Spirits,” presented by the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series, almost all of whose songs were written between 1929 and 1932.

headline: A Hint of Jazz From a Classical Quartet
abstract: The French classical ensemble Quatuor Ébène played Schumann and Errol Garner at its Zankel Hall performance.
lead_paragraph: The superb Quatuor Ébène has made a name for itself not only as an elegant purveyor of classical fare but also for jazz performances. That influence could be heard on Friday evening at Zankel Hall in the group’s encore, an arrangement of Erroll Garner’s “Misty,” and in its interpretation of Schumann’s String Quartet in A (Op. 41, No. 3).

headline: Floating Together, Staring and Circling
abstract: In Vanessa Anspaugh’s “we were an island,” at Danspace Project, the dancers can seem less like islands than like flotsam in tidal currents, floating together.
lead_paragraph: No man is an island, John Donne said, and it would seem that the choreographer Vanessa Anspaugh agrees. In her “we were an island,” which debuted at Danspace Project on Thursday, the five performers are distinctive, but the connections among them are more various and ineluctable than they appear on the surface. Once the dancers have all made their entrances, no one escapes the others’ gaze.

headline: Balanchine and Robbins, With Echoes of a Long-Ago Star
abstract: A New York City Ballet program featured choreography by Balanchine and Robbins.
lead_paragraph: What seemed like just another New York City Ballet program on Friday night at the David H. Koch Theater turned out to be nothing of the sort. It was impossible to be in the presence of Jerome Robbins’s “Afternoon of a Faun” and George Balanchine’s “La Valse” without thinking of Tanaquil le Clercq.

headline: Stories and Explanations Rooted in the Personal
abstract: Asaf Avidan, the Israeli singer and writer of songs in English, gave a concert with cabaretlike spoken segments at Irving Plaza.
lead_paragraph: One part of Asaf Avidan, the Israeli songwriter who gave a solo concert on Friday night at Irving Plaza, is a lot like Leonard Cohen: the Leonard Cohen who sings delicately fingerpicked songs full of finely calibrated metaphors, aphoristic phrases, paradoxes and mournful romance. “I said, Baby you are magic/ She said, No, hon, just a trick,” he sang in “Anchor.”

headline: A Four-and-a-Half-Ring Circus Ends, and a Relieved Russia Roars
abstract: The Sochi Games’ closing ceremony was advertised as a celebration of Russian culture and heritage, but it seemed just as much a great sigh of happy relief.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Russia had so much to prove at the Winter Games. Was spending however-many billions of dollars to build an Olympics-industrial complex from scratch on the edge of the Black Sea worth it? How could the country overcome a thicket of potential problems: security worries, logistical obstacles, weather annoyances and the darkening specter of revolution in nearby Ukraine?

headline: A Show of Love: Farewell, City Opera
abstract: New York City Opera’s concert at City Center marked its 70th anniversary and served as something of a proper farewell.
lead_paragraph: Often, when a performing arts institution is forced to shut down, it at least is able to present a special closing performance, an occasion for artists and audiences to look back at all the accomplishments and find comfort together.

headline: Audiences That Devise Game Plans
abstract: “On Trial Together” by the Serbian artists Sasa Ascentic and Ana Vujanovic is a problem-solving exercise with the audience doing the solving.
lead_paragraph: On Friday at New York Live Arts, in the wake of a government collapse, 63 citizens — “humanoids,” we were called — gathered to develop strategies for rebuilding society. There to help us were two experts in catastrophe survival from the former Yugoslavia.

headline: Thailand at an Impasse
abstract: Thailand rolls to a democratic standstill.
lead_paragraph: Thailand rolls to a democratic standstill.

headline: Seth Meyers: Smart Guy in the Wiseguy Seat
abstract: Seth Meyers is the oldest, most experienced and most hostlike comedian to take the reins of NBC’s “Late Night.” Will he be as funny as the three men who preceded him?
lead_paragraph: Seth Meyers is the oldest, most experienced and most hostlike comedian to take the reins of NBC’s three-decade-old “Late Night.”

headline: Writers’ Biographer Creates a Portrait of His Own Family
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: In “The Splendid Things We Planned,” Blake Bailey, who has written of Richard Yates and is writing about Philip Roth, offers a slender volume about his own troubled family.
lead_paragraph: Blake Bailey has now written four books about families blessed with literary talent and plagued by the ravages of alcohol. His fierce affinity for these subjects is now a little easier to understand. The writers Richard Yates, John Cheever (my father-in-law) and Charles Jackson, who wrote what he knew in his novel “The Lost Weekend,” all spoke to Mr. Bailey’s own turbulent background. Both he and, to a much greater extent, his older brother, Scott, walked a thin line between self-discipline and drunken disaster.

headline: Applying Olympic Sinew to Strauss
abstract: The Philadelphia Orchestra performed a muscular program of Strauss’s “Metamorphosen”, Shostakovich’s Cello Concerto No. 1 and Beethoven’s “Eroica” Symphony on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Winter Olympics may have been seven time zones away, in Sochi, Russia, but energy, athleticism and showmanship also filled the air at another Olympus, Carnegie Hall, on Friday evening, in a concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra.

headline: Looking for Characters
abstract: A bookish Monday puzzle from Adam G. Perl.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Time to hit the reset button and get started on a brand new week. After two challenging Sunday puzzles, a Monday crossword is a most welcome sight.

headline: Listening to Ancients in Zimbabwe and Finding a Prehistoric Fable
abstract: Chris Berry says his tale, “The Legend of Yauna,” came to him in Zimbabwe, through a spiritual medium, from people who lived 12,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Coming up with the right story for a new musical is notoriously difficult. Yet the measures that Chris Berry took to get the narrative for “The Legend of Yauna” still count as extreme. Mr. Berry, a musician of European descent, has said that the tale came to him in Zimbabwe, through a spiritual medium, from people who lived 12,000 years ago.

headline: What the West Must Do for Ukraine
abstract: The E.U. should offer full membership to Ukraine, and Germany must take the lead.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Thanks in part to the coordinated efforts of Germany, Poland, France and the United States, irrevocable change has finally come to Ukraine, with President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s flight from Kiev and Parliament’s vote to call for new elections in May.

headline: ‘12 Years a Slave’ Is Headed to Schools
abstract: Starting in September, the film, the book and a study guide will be distributed to public high schools.
lead_paragraph: High school students could soon be studying “12 Years a Slave.” Starting in September, the film, the book and a study guide will be distributed to public high schools by the National School Boards Association in partnership with New Regency, Penguin Books and the filmmakers. Montel Williams coordinated the program, which is modeled after similar distribution by “The Montel Williams Show” of copies of the Civil War film “Glory.” “When Hollywood is at its best, the power of the movies can be harnessed into a powerful educational tool,” Mr. Williams said in a statement. “This film uniquely highlights a shameful period in American history, and in doing so will evoke in students a desire to not repeat the evils of the past while inspiring them to dream big of a better and brighter future.” Steve McQueen, above, the film’s director, said: “Since first reading ‘12 Years a Slave,’ it has been my dream that this book be taught in schools.”

headline: NBC to Bring Back ‘Heroes’ in New Form
abstract: NBC announced it would resurrect the onetime hit science-fiction series as “Heroes Reborn,” a 13-episode series in 2015.
lead_paragraph: They’re coming back: once-dead television series, that is — revived as so-called event series by networks discovering a form that has distinguished cable drama for much of the past decade. The latest example is the onetime hit science-fiction series “Heroes,” which NBC announced it would resurrect as “Heroes Reborn,” a 13-episode series in 2015. The network used its platform of the Winter Olympics to tease out the announcement on Saturday, running a brief promotion. The news release that followed on Saturday night confirmed a few details: Tim Kring, who created the original “Heroes” in the 2006 television season, will be back as the executive producer. Before that, NBC is to create a digital series that will introduce the new story and characters. (Some original cast members may return.) Jennifer Salke, NBC’s president for entertainment, said in a statement that most details about the new version would be “appropriately shrouded in mystery.” Exactly when the show might appear is not known. Perhaps NBC will wait to see how the most immediate progenitor of the idea, Fox’s revival of “24,” fares this summer. CBS fashioned a hit last summer out of “Under the Dome” and has another such event-style short-run sci-fi series, “Extant,” with Halle Berry, planned for this summer.

headline: At New England Knockout Team Regional, Rules Are Rules
abstract: At the New England Knockout Team Regional in Cromwell, Conn., this month Jared Lilienstein and Michael Polowan of New York City entered the two-session Wednesday A/B Pairs.
lead_paragraph: At the New England Knockout Team Regional in Cromwell, Conn., this month Jared Lilienstein and Michael Polowan of New York City entered the two-session Wednesday A/B Pairs. In the diagramed deal, they got a tied top, but it cost them first place. How?

headline: Piers Morgan and CNN Plan End to His Prime-Time Show

lead_paragraph: There have been times when the CNN host Piers Morgan didn’t seem to like America very much — and American audiences have been more than willing to return the favor. Three years after taking over for Larry King, Mr. Morgan has seen the ratings for “Piers Morgan Live” hit some new lows, drawing a fraction of viewers compared with competitors at Fox News and MSNBC.

headline: New Generation of Stars Emerges in Alpine Events
abstract: Mikaela Shiffrin, 18, of the United States, and two Austrians, Anna Fenninger, 24, and Matthias Mayer, 23, are among the racers who have changed the landscape.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — One of the earliest images of the Alpine competition at the 2014 Winter Olympics was Bode Miller as he streaked down the treacherous downhill course far ahead of the field in training. Miller, an Olympian since 1998, was somehow turning back the clock and had made himself the favorite in the opening, and premier, ski racing event of the Sochi Games.

headline: As a Painter Grows Older, His Creativity Endures
abstract: Age has not stopped Ed Clark, 87, an abstract expressionist who was a fixture of the 1950s art scene in New York, from working; it has just slowed him down a little.
lead_paragraph: Ed Clark stood silently before the canvas on the floor of his studio. He considered the muted morning light, the paint and its promise. Then he pushed a broom across the surface, capturing the hues of daybreak and twilight with each stroke.

keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Deportation', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: After months of rallies brought no movement in the House on immigration, a national network of young immigrants has decided to turn its protests on President Obama.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — More than 500 leaders of a national network of young immigrants, frustrated that House Republicans said they would not move on immigration this year, have decided to turn their protests on President Obama in an effort to pressure him to act unilaterally to stop deportations.

headline: Amid the Triumphs, an Argument for Tolerance
abstract: The Olympics were a success for Vladimir V. Putin, but the Games also exposed a less endearing side of Russia.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The closing ceremony of the Sochi Games on Sunday night was a celebration of everything Russian, and everything that Russia does so well.

headline: Expand Pre-K, Not A.D.H.D.
abstract: The lurking danger of over-medicalization.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — THE writing is on the chalkboard. Over the next few years, America can count on a major expansion of early childhood education. We embrace this trend, but as health policy researchers, we want to raise a major caveat: Unless we’re careful, today’s preschool bandwagon could lead straight to an epidemic of 4- and 5-year-olds wrongfully being told that they have attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

headline: Genetically Modified Babies
keywords: ['Genetic Engineering', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'Reproduction (Biological)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mitochondria']
abstract: Regulators consider radical biological procedures.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — AN advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration is set to begin two days of meetings tomorrow to consider radical biological procedures that, if successful, would produce genetically modified human beings. This is a dangerous step. These techniques would change every cell in the bodies of children born as a result of their use, and these alterations would be passed down to future generations.

headline: Health Care Horror Hooey
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: When bad things happen to imaginary people.
lead_paragraph: Remember the “death tax”? The estate tax is quite literally a millionaire’s tax — a tax that affects only a tiny minority of the population, and is mostly paid by a handful of very wealthy heirs. Nonetheless, right-wingers have successfully convinced many voters that the tax is a cruel burden on ordinary Americans — that all across the nation small businesses and family farms are being broken up to pay crushing estate tax liabilities.

headline: How a Kingpin Above the Law Fell, Incredibly, Without a Shot
abstract: The takedown of the world’s most wanted man — Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the head of a sophisticated narcotics enterprise — upended assumptions about the impunity of Mexican mobsters.
lead_paragraph: MAZATLÁN, Mexico — They reacted here with utter disbelief. Joaquín Guzmán Loera, El Chapo, drug kingpin to the world, the Robin Hood of Sinaloa, had been arrested in his home state, in the resort town that is a loyal fief of his empire?

headline: For Detroit, New Stage in Its Race to Recover
abstract: Leaders of other financially troubled cities will be watching to see how efficiently Detroit proceeds after the bankrupt city filed a proposal that creditors and city labor unions criticized as unfair.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Labor union leaders said they hated it. Financial creditors said it was lopsided against them. Some community leaders said it favored the banks over ordinary people. And at least one pension fund official called it premature and draconian.

headline: Crime and Punishment and Obama
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Crime and Criminals', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Where’s the community organizer when we need him?
lead_paragraph: I DOUBT any president has been as well equipped as Barack Obama to appreciate the vicious cycle of American crime and punishment. As a community organizer in Chicago in the 1980s, he would have witnessed the way a system intended to protect the public siphoned off young black men, gave them an advanced education in brutality, and then returned them to the streets unqualified for — and too often, given the barriers to employment faced by those who have done time, disqualified from — anything but a life of more crime. He would have understood that the suffering of victims and the debasing of offenders were often two sides of the same coin.

headline: Let the E.P.A. Do Its Job
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Clean Air Act', 'Air Pollution', 'Global Warming', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']

lead_paragraph: On Monday, for the third time in seven years, the Supreme Court will consider the scope of the federal government’s power to regulate the emission of greenhouse gases, which are a major contributor to global climate change.

headline: Locked Away in Immigration Jails
abstract: Locking detainees up indefinitely is not a path to a more rational immigration system.
lead_paragraph: You can find examples of federal detainees held inexplicably for years without criminal charges or bond hearings much closer to home than Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

abstract: The next generation YotaPhone builds on the ideas of the first edition, in a thinner unibody shape with curved edges.
lead_paragraph: The Russian start-up Yota Devices will reveal on Monday the next generation of its unusual two-faced YotaPhone at the Mobile World Congress event in Barcelona. The phone stands apart from many of its smartphone peers — which often appear similar to each other — by having a conventional color touchscreen on one side and a low-power electronic paper display filling its other side.

headline: Blast Kills 12 Riding in Van in Pakistan
abstract: Sixteen others were injured in the blast in a town with a history of sectarian and militant violence in Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 12 people were killed and 16 injured when a bomb went off in northwestern Pakistan on Sunday, according to police officials, as security forces continued to attack militant hide-outs in the country’s tribal regions with airstrikes.

headline: A Second Front in the Privacy Wars
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy', 'Consumer Protection', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Obama administration has to renew its commitment to protecting consumer data.
lead_paragraph: More than a year before Edward Snowden exposed the vast reach of government surveillance, President Obama proposed a Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights to protect Americans from the prying eyes of Internet companies, advertisers and other businesses. In a February 2012 report, his administration offered a well-reasoned argument for giving consumers more control over how much and what kind of data companies can collect about them and what businesses can do with that information.

headline: First Companies Give to Fund for Victims of Bangladeshi Factory Collapse
