lead_paragraph: ROME — Five global clothing brands and retailers on Sunday became the first contributors to a new fund raising $40 million for victims of the Rana Plaza factory disaster in Bangladesh, and activists are campaigning to pressure other brands to also make donations.

headline: Yankees Add Four Years to Gardner’s Deal
abstract: The Yankees made good on their insistence that they would keep Brett Gardner — even after signing Jacoby Ellsbury in December — with a new deal that starts in 2015 and is worth $52 million.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — From the moment the Yankees signed Jacoby Ellsbury on Dec. 7, the speculation began that they would trade Brett Gardner. Who, after all, would need two speedy, leadoff center fielders?

headline: Fed’s Aid in 2008 Crisis Stretched Worldwide
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)']
abstract: The Federal Reserve pumped hundreds of billions of dollars to nations to bolster global banks when dollars were scarce, newly released transcripts of 2008 Fed policy committee meetings reveal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tuesday morning, Sept. 16, 2008, was perhaps the darkest time for the United States economy in modern memory — even if nobody knew it quite yet. It was barely 24 hours removed from the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers, and a few hours before the government would rescue the insurer American International Group.

headline: N.B.A.’s 10-Day Contract Is Essentially a Job Tryout
abstract: With Jason Collins agreeing to a 10-day contract with the Nets it is worth looking into what the contracts mean and how they work.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. is known for its guaranteed contracts, which stand in stark contrast to the free-for-all in the N.F.L., where a player can generally be terminated anytime. An exception in basketball is the 10-day contract, which serves as a risk-free, on-the-job tryout for a player attempting to make a team’s roster.

headline: As His Fortunes Fell in Ukraine, a President Clung to Illusions
abstract: Between the signing ceremony for a peace deal and a break to congratulate Ukraine’s Olympic team, President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s prospects took a dramatic turn for the worse.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As his allies deserted him and throngs of people bayed for his blood almost within earshot of his office, President Viktor F. Yanukovych took time out on Friday to celebrate Ukraine’s first gold medal at the Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia. In a message of congratulations to the women’s biathlon relay team, he praised its “power and will to win.”

headline: Pentagon Plans to Shrink Army to Pre-World War II Level
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s budget proposal would eliminate an entire class of Air Force attack jets and scale back the size of the Army not just to pre-9/11 levels, but to the force’s size in 1940.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel plans to shrink the United States Army to its smallest force since before the World War II buildup and eliminate an entire class of Air Force attack jets in a new spending proposal that officials describe as the first Pentagon budget to aggressively push the military off the war footing adopted after the terror attacks of 2001.

headline: N.Y.U. Hospital’s Political Fund-Raising Questioned
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: A major benefactor of NYU Langone Medical Center has sent emails to employees and hosted fund-raisers for Senate and House members who helped pass $60 billion in post-Hurricane Sandy disaster aid.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 9, 2012, less than two weeks after Hurricane Sandy made landfall, Kenneth G. Langone pulled on a pair of construction worker’s bright yellow galoshes and accompanied Senator Charles E. Schumer and other officials through a foul-smelling mix of diesel oil and water in the basement of his namesake, NYU Langone Medical Center.

headline: Visiting Prisoners, Without Visiting Prison
abstract: People are often imprisoned far from home, but family connections are seen as a key to success. Is "video visitation" a solution?

headline: In Manhattan, Children of Ukrainians Connect to Revolution
abstract: Streaming video and social media fostered a sense of involvement in the recent political upheaval.
lead_paragraph: A group of young boys huddled on Second Avenue in the East Village on Sunday, talking about Ukraine.

headline: Yahoo Aims to More Deftly Blend Ads With Content
abstract: Yahoo is starting to push into two of the hottest areas of Internet advertising: stream ads and so-called native ads.
lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — To Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo, fashion magazines like Vogue and InStyle have achieved the holy grail of advertising.

headline: Now What? A City Fears a Flameout
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: After a building boom, Sochi needs tourists but has no clear strategy for attracting them now that the Olympics are over.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Now comes the hard part.

headline: Subway Show Time Confession
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: An exceptionally nimble gymnastic routine inside a subway car made even jaded commuters reach for their wallets.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Ad Campaign Seeks to Increase Chances of Cuomo’s Campaign Finance Plan
abstract: A national group that seeks to lessen the influence of big campaign donors plans to unveil a $1 million advertising campaign aimed at promoting the governor’s plan.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo delivered a pleasant surprise to skeptical liberal activists last month by tucking a long-discussed plan to provide public financing for state political campaigns into his state budget proposal.

headline: Fresh From Prison, a Former Prime Minister Returns to the Political Stage
abstract: Yulia V. Tymoshenko denied seeking a new political role amid speculation that she might want to resume her duties as prime minister.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — For nearly two years, foreign officials pleaded with President Viktor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine to let his archrival, former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, leave prison for medical care abroad, but he refused, convinced that she had just one destination in mind: a return to the political stage.

headline: Indians Catcher Hopes to Spread His Sport in Brazil
abstract: Catcher Yan Gomes, the major leagues’ first Brazilian player, earned the Cleveland Indians’ starting job last season and hopes to spread the sport in his native country.
lead_paragraph: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — The Cleveland Indians gathered around the television in their clubhouse here Friday, most pleading for the United States men’s hockey team to come back against Canada at the Olympics. Only John Axford, the reliever from Ontario whose maple-leaf sweater hung proudly in his locker, grinned as the clock ran out.

headline: In the DeMint Era at Heritage, a Shift From Policy to Politics
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Law and Legislation', 'Research', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Under Jim DeMint, the Heritage Foundation, long known as an incubator for Republican policy ideas, has become more of a political organization feeding off the Tea Party movement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after Jim DeMint took over the Heritage Foundation last spring, his team summoned the staff for a meeting unlike any the decorous conservative policy organization had ever convened. Music blared in the auditorium. Policy analysts began with a few awkward jokes and then scampered about in a series of skits that laid out the foundation’s goals.

headline: Power Shift Inspires Joy in Kiev, Fury in East
abstract: Two gatherings in the coal-mining city of Donetsk illustrated the diverse forces tugging at Ukraine now that President Viktor F. Yanukovych has fled the capital.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Red Communist flags flew on Sunday in front of a massive bust of Lenin in this hardscrabble coal-mining city, a stronghold of pro-Russia sentiment in Ukraine. About 500 yards away, a few hundred pro-democracy activists, harangued by hundreds of counterdemonstrators, laid wreaths for the victims of last week’s bedlam in Kiev at a memorial to one of Ukraine’s most revered figures, the 19th-century poet Taras Shevchenko.

headline: Kerik, Out of Prison and More Subdued, Seeks to Rebuild His Reputation
abstract: The former New York City police commissioner Bernard B. Kerik, who served three years on fraud charges, hopes to build a new career as a speaker and consultant.
lead_paragraph: The burly Bernard B. Kerik of old may not have recognized the newer, slimmed-down version who showed up to speak to an impressionable group of aspiring police officers in Queens on Saturday morning.

headline: Moviefone Is Hanging Up, but Its App Will Go On
abstract: Overtaken by new technology and shifting consumer habits, the telephone movie listing and ticket service will be disconnected, and a free Moviefone app will be revised.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Mr. Moviefone’s lines are going dead.

headline: To Some Drivers’ Dismay, Parking Rules Return
abstract: For three weeks, bad weather allowed motorists to ignore the complicated rules that govern alternate-side parking.
lead_paragraph: It is back to the parking line for Sharon Walker.

headline: Another Helping of ‘Downton,’ M’Lord?
abstract: Julian Fellowes, the creator and writer of “Downton Abbey,” talks about the show’s most recent season, and its future.
lead_paragraph: The fourth season of “Downton Abbey” concluded on Sunday with the servants Mrs. Hughes and Mr. Carson joining hands on a beach as they walked into the water together. It was a serene image that belied a year on this PBS “Masterpiece” period drama that was filled with tumultuous events — a character’s rape and the fallout from it, the introduction of race as a plot point — and, at times, tumultuous audience reaction.

headline: Moving Leonardo’s Horse: A Question of Logistics or Pedigree?
abstract: A statue that was meant to pay homage to a destroyed 15th-century work by Leonardo da Vinci has been relegated to a racetrack in Milan, far from the public eye. Now some are trying to find a more suitable home.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Thousands of years after the citizens of Troy learned about the complications posed by outsize equine sculptures, the modern residents of Milan find themselves embroiled, again, in a debate about how to make the most of a gift horse: a colossal bronze steed presented by a group of American donors.

headline: Julian Fellowes on Viewer Criticism and ‘Downton Abbey’s’ Future
abstract: The creator and writer of the show discusses storylines that have drawn angry reactions and his thoughts on future seasons.
lead_paragraph: After a royal audience with King George V and Queen Mary of England, and guest appearances by Shirley MacLaine and Paul Giamatti, the fourth season of “Downton Abbey” came to a conclusion on PBS’s “Masterpiece” on Sunday night. No major characters met their demises, but this year, which dealt with the rape of the servant Anna and the introduction of a jazz singer who pursues a perilous romance with Lady Rose, among other story lines, was hardly free of conflict or controversy.

headline: ‘Girls’ Recap: A Night at the Gramercy Park Hotel
abstract: Adam gets a part. Marnie gets a hug. Hannah gets advice. And “Girls” finds a heart.
lead_paragraph: Golly. Did anyone see that coming? “Girls” found a heart.

headline: Garbage Truck Fatally Strikes Rabbinical Student in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: A Sanitation Department truck struck and killed a 25-year-old on Sunday morning as he stepped into a crosswalk in Crown Heights, police officials said.
lead_paragraph: A garbage truck struck and killed a rabbinical student in Brooklyn on Sunday morning, officials said.

headline: Faulty Pipe Led to Deadly Gas in Restaurant
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Carbon Monoxide', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Restaurants', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: Carbon monoxide seeping from the pipe was spread by a ventilation system in a Long Island restaurant, killing a manager and sickening 27 others.
lead_paragraph: A faulty flue pipe attached to a water heater caused the carbon monoxide leak that killed a restaurant manager and sickened 27 others on Saturday on Long Island, a fire official said.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 23, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Venezuela Is Divided Even on Its Death Toll
abstract: At least 11 people have died in the antigovernment demonstrations, though officials disagreed over whether the latest death was related to the protests.
lead_paragraph: SAN CRISTÓBAL, Venezuela — At least 11 people have died in more than two weeks of antigovernment protests, according to government and news media reports, and there are no signs of anything calming down. But even the death toll was a cause for argument on Sunday in this bitterly divided country, as officials disagreed over whether the latest death was related to the protests.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, miscellaneous news from advertising agencies and more.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Stability and Chaos, Hallmarks of Presidential Races, Swap Parties
abstract: Republican primaries usually amount to coronations, nominating whomever is deemed next in line, while the Democratic contests are often messier affairs. This time the roles are reversed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For generations, the two major political parties have taken strikingly different approaches to picking their presidential candidates: Republican primaries usually amount to coronations, in which they nominate a candidate who has run before or is otherwise deemed next in line, while the Democratic contests are often messier affairs, prone to insurgencies and featuring uncertain favorites.

headline: Miracle-Gro Wants More People to Try Their Hand at Gardening
abstract: A new campaign focuses on the gardeners, not the products, but once people are at the store, Miracle-Gro will promote its effectiveness on displays and packaging.
lead_paragraph: A STAPLE of hardware stores and garden centers for more than six decades, Miracle-Gro — with its descriptive, almost cartoonish name — is so recognizable to consumers that other brands, including AT&T and Hyundai, have featured it in their advertisements. To promote its Mini Countryman, which is much larger than its Cooper model, for example, in 2013 Mini USA produced billboards and print ads in which a giant box of Miracle-Gro blue plant food appeared to have spilled onto a green Cooper and caused a growth spurt.

headline: Despite Stroke, Algerian Leader Says He’ll Run for Re-Election
abstract: The announcement that Abdelaziz Bouteflika will run again ended months of speculation about the country’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Algeria’s ailing president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who has been largely incapacitated since a stroke last year, intends to run for a fourth term in an election scheduled for April 17, Algerian officials announced Sunday.

headline: From a Backpack, Mountain Refreshment
abstract: The Olympics offered scenes of poignancy and joy, from cups of tea on a mountain to festive hats in a grandstand. Reporters for The New York Times describe a few of their favorite moments.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — There was a ski-rental shop at the base of the gondola. In exchange for 1,400 rubles (about $40) and temporary custody of my American driver’s license, I got skis, poles, boots and a helmet for the day.

headline: For Hints at Apple’s Plans, Read Its Shopping List
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Handheld Computers', 'Mobile Applications', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Apple has avoided jaw-dropping takeovers in favor of a series of smaller deals, using the companies to buttress or fill a gap in products that already exist or are in development.
lead_paragraph: One company used sensors to read body movements. Another recommended TV programs. Several others offered location and mapping services.

headline: Jihadist Mediator Killed in Suicide Attack by Rival Extremists
abstract: Opposition activists blamed the extremist group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria for the bombing in which five others were also killed.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — A high-ranking jihadist operative who was sent to Syria by Ayman al-Zawahri, the head of Al Qaeda, to mediate conflicts between fighters was killed there on Sunday in a suicide attack by another extremist group, activists said.

headline: Nets’ Win Is Ordinary, Though the Night Is Anything But
abstract: Jason Collins, who said he was trying to focus on his job rather than on his place in history, was scoreless with two rebounds in a victory over the Lakers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On the basketball court, Jason Collins has never had any illusions about who he is: a lunch-pail player who has forged a 12-year career by doing the not-so-glamorous chores of setting screens, rebounding, defending and using as many of his six fouls as necessary.

headline: Maria von Trapp, ‘Sound of Music’ Daughter, Dies at 99
abstract: Ms. von Trapp was the last survivor of the singing Austrian siblings made famous by Broadway and Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Maria Franziska von Trapp, the last surviving sibling of seven brothers and sisters who were portrayed in the Broadway musical and the film “The Sound of Music,” died on Tuesday at her home in Stowe, Vt. She was 99.

headline: Tech Industry to Gather; Commerce Dept. to Release New Estimate
keywords: ['Mobile World Congress (Trade Show)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']

lead_paragraph: TECH INDUSTRY WILL GATHER AT MOBILE WORLD CONGRESS

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: The Second Tier at Its Best
abstract: The return of point guard Chris Paul has elevated the offense of the Clippers, but they will also have to do a solid job on defense against the Rockets.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Marty Thau, Manager in Early New York Punk Scene, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Thau, a promoter of bubble gum hits, later managed the New York Dolls. His label released albums by Suicide and the Fleshtones, among others.
lead_paragraph: Marty Thau, a music executive who was a catalyst for some of the most influential rock acts of New York in the 1970s, including the New York Dolls, the Ramones and Suicide, died on Feb. 13 in Richmond, Va. He was 75.

headline: Deeply Bound to Ukraine, Putin Watches and Waits for Next Move
abstract: Mr. Putin faces the task of reasserting Russia’s influence in a country that it considers an ally with deep cultural, social and political connections, since the Kremlin-backed government has collapsed.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The sudden collapse of the Kremlin-backed government in Ukraine has for now delivered a profound setback to President Vladimir V. Putin’s strategy to deepen political and economic ties with the country and thus keep it from embracing Europe.

headline: Book Review Byline Tally Shows Gender Disparity
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'News and News Media', 'Gender', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: In its annual count of male and female bylines in book reviews, magazines and literary journals, VIDA, a women’s literary organization, revealed that in 2013, the publications still largely favored men over women.
lead_paragraph: Reading a book review in a well-known periodical? Chances are, the byline belongs to a man.

headline: Federal Prosecutors Seek Return of Mexican Drug Kingpin to U.S.
abstract: Prosecutors in Brooklyn are competing with several other jurisdictions seeking the extradition of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, who was captured on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn want Joaquín Guzmán Loera, a Mexican drug lord captured on Saturday, to return to the United States to face a long list of charges, competing with several other jurisdictions seeking his extradition.

headline: Progress Against Hepatitis C, a Sneaky Virus
abstract: Hepatitis C can go undiagnosed for decades, sometimes becoming evident only after liver damage has already occurred. But there is good news on the pharmaceutical front.
lead_paragraph: Forty years ago, a beloved neighbor was bedridden for weeks at a time with a mysterious ailment. She knew only that it involved her liver and that she must never drink alcohol, which would make things worse.

headline: IBM: More Cloud, Less People
abstract: Big Blue is moving large amounts of its software into the cloud, and launching a program to draw more outside software developers to use its products.
lead_paragraph: There is something very different about the latest $1 billion IBM is throwing at cloud computing. This sum says as much about the way the cloud is changing IBM as it says about the way IBM is pursuing the business of renting software and computing power over the Internet.

headline: Play About Detroit Riots Wins Kennedy Drama Prize
abstract: Dominique Morisseau’s “Detroit ’67,” which had its premiere in March 2013, has won the Edward M. Kennedy Prize for Drama Inspired by American History. Columbia University and Jean Kennedy Smith are expected to announce the award on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Dominique Morisseau’s “Detroit ’67” has won the Edward M. Kennedy Prize for Drama Inspired by American History, Columbia University and Jean Kennedy Smith are expected to announce on Monday. The prize, which was created in 2012 and first awarded last year, was endowed by Ms. Smith to honor her late brother’s legacy and is announced around his birthday, Feb. 22. The award includes a $100,000 cash prize as well as assistance from the Columbia Center for New Media Teaching and Learning at Columbia University Libraries in creating a teaching website that will put the work in historical context, and offer study guides and scholarly discussion.

headline: Local Policies That Work for Workers
abstract: Years of effort to improve wages and working conditions on the local and state levels are beginning to pay off, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Panel Seeks Greater Disclosures on Pension Health
abstract: An actuarial board is recommending that public pension plans disclose something they have long resisted discussing: the total cost, in today’s dollars, of their workers’ pensions.
lead_paragraph: A panel of risk experts sees a teachable moment in Detroit’s bankruptcy and pension woes.

headline: After a Long Rain Delay, Earnhardt Takes His Second Daytona Title
abstract: Dale Earnhardt Jr. previously won the race in 2004. During a delay of more than six hours, a TV replay of last year’s race led many viewers to believe Jimmie Johnson had won.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Ten years had passed since Dale Earnhardt Jr. captured Nascar’s most prestigious race, the Daytona 500, in 2004. He won six races that season driving the old No. 8 for Dale Earnhardt Inc., his father’s team.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Investigation Discovery) THE INJUSTICE FILES: SUNDOWN TOWNS By 1936, the practice of forcing African-Americans from all-white communities after the sun set was so prevalent that Victor Green, the Harlem civic leader, wrote the “Negro Motorist Green Book,” a guide to help black travelers avoid places where they might be threatened or even killed. In 1968, the Fair Housing Act, which made it a federal crime to deny equal housing opportunities based on race, creed or national origin, in effect outlawed the existence of these “sundown towns.” But did it eliminate them all? The filmmaker Keith Beauchamp, above, travels the country to find out.

abstract: The top songs on Spotify reflect hits found on the airwaves and online: they include “Dark Horse,” which moved to No. 1 after 10 weeks on Billboard’s radio chart, and “Royals,” which won Song of the Year at the 2014 Grammy Awards.
lead_paragraph: The top songs on Spotify reflect hits found on the airwaves and online: they include “Dark Horse,” which moved to No. 1 after 10 weeks on Billboard’s radio chart, and “Royals,” which won Song of the Year at the 2014 Grammy Awards.

headline: Underneath the Quiet in Kashmir, Youthful Anger Simmers
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Curfews', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Strikes', 'Terrorism', 'Youth']
abstract: Behind closed doors, young Kashmiris are increasingly talking of violence, frustrated with their inability to protest in the streets and losing faith in separatist leaders.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — Before Feb. 9, the anniversary of the death of Muhammad Afzal, a Kashmiri who was hanged for his role in a 2001 attack on Parliament, the state government took its usual precautions to head off unrest. A curfew was imposed, Internet access was cut off, and additional police officers were posted around Srinagar.

headline: Philips and Ericsson to Use Streetlights to Expand Cellphone Coverage
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Light-Emitting Diodes', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Urban Areas', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: The two companies will incorporate cellphone antennas into energy-efficient LED streetlights that can be placed in parts of cities where carriers want to increase their network coverage.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA – Cellphone operators worldwide are struggling to keep pace with growing demand for mobile data.

abstract: Gildo Zegna turns to Stefano Pilati, the design force behind Zegna men’s wear, to expand the Agnona brand.
lead_paragraph: Gildo Zegna turns to Stefano Pilati, the design force behind Zegna men’s wear, to expand the Agnona brand.

headline: Military Brick-Breaking Demonstrations Face the Chop
abstract: Military officials are acknowledging that displays of showmanship by troops have few practical applications, and are reconsidering the amount of time that troops spend on such training.
lead_paragraph: Many fighting forces have their own marching bands, singers and performing groups to rally the troops. But few can put on a display like the Chinese People’s Liberation Army. In addition to its famous contingent of singers and dancers, who include China’s first lady, Peng Liyuan, China’s military is known for soldiers who can break bamboo poles on their backs and smash bricks on their heads.

headline: Cinven to Buy Clinical Research Firm
abstract: Cinven will pay $915 million for the Cincinnati-based Medpace, which operates in more than 45 countries. Cinven purchased the stake from CCMP Capital Advisors, which acquired Medpace in 2011.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European private equity firm Cinven said Monday that it had acquired a majority stake in Medpace, a clinical research firm, for $915 million.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Winter Games Come to a Close

lead_paragraph: In “With Olympics’ Closing Ceremony, a Chance to Exhale” Sarah Lyall writes about the end of the Winter Games.

headline: Amid Political Upheaval, Ukraine Faces Dire Need for Economic Help
abstract: The new head of the Ukrainian National Bank said one of his top priorities would be to secure aid from the International Monetary Fund.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — With a manhunt underway for the deposed Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, who was charged on Monday with mass murder, officials in Parliament pushed ahead with the monumental task of rebuilding the collapsed government. The country’s most pressing problem, however, is largely out of their control: a fast-approaching economic disaster that they cannot solve without international assistance.

headline: Keeping Jazz’s Rhythm With a Shutter
abstract: Alexandra Avakian recalls her father, Aram, whose passions — photography and jazz — came together when he photographed the now-historic recording sessions of Duke Ellington, Chet Baker, Miles Davis and others.
lead_paragraph: My father, Aram “Al” Avakian, was probably just a kid when he picked up the family camera one day and started taking pictures. I never asked him what year it was. But photography was part of his young life. So was jazz.

abstract: In London, where a clock is one of the most famous landmarks, time inspires watch shop arcades and public art works.
lead_paragraph: In London, where a clock is one of the most famous landmarks, time inspires watch shop arcades and public art works.

abstract: Where is a bill under consideration to protect business owners who do not want to serve gay people?
lead_paragraph: What happens when religious beliefs lead business owners to refuse to serve gay people? Is it living according to their faith? Is it discrimination?

headline: Grief and Anger Over Killing of 21 Afghan Soldiers
abstract: As some Afghans began raising money for the soldiers’ families, many expressed outrage at the fact that they had been killed in their sleep.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A public outpouring of grief mixed with patriotic anger whipped through Afghanistan on Monday in the aftermath of the killings of 21 Afghan soldiers by Taliban insurgents in Kunar Province.

headline: Young, Rich, and Too Fast for L.A.
abstract: Commentators and social media in China have erupted in sarcasm and anger after a Chinese college student was booked for a high-speed car chase in the United States. He faces criminal charges.
lead_paragraph: It’s a familiar playbook here in China — a wet-behind-the-ears scion of a wealthy family goes to America to study, buys a pricey car, breaks the law.

headline: Uganda’s President Signs Antigay Bill

abstract: President Yoweri Museveni signed into law a bill imposing harsh sentences for homosexual acts, including life imprisonment in some cases.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Brushing aside Western threats and outrage, President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda significantly strengthened Africa’s antigay movement on Monday, signing into law a bill imposing harsh sentences for homosexual acts, including life imprisonment in some cases, according to government officials.

headline: Nokia Taps Android for New Low-Cost Phone
abstract: The move to use the Android operating system of Google — a main rival of both Nokia and Microsoft — will offer users far more applications than they can access with phones running on Microsoft’s Windows Phone operating system.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA – Nokia is going out with a bang.

headline: Google, Riding Off Into the Sunset
abstract: There is so much hype around new technologies, it is difficult to distinguish between what might exist real soon and what will only be real eventually or never. Case in point: the driverless car.
lead_paragraph: Cabbies and limo drivers have so much to think about. Should they ally themselves with Uber or Lyft or Sidecar or someone else promising to revolutionize ground transportation? If they do, will they be insured if they get in an accident while working with their own car? And what of the future? Will they be replaced by a fleet of driverless cars, a technology that has been talked about so much it seems just around the corner?

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Monte Reel on Traveling Across a Changing South America
abstract: The new highway that crosses Brazil and Peru is transformative — both for the villages it now connects and for Monte Reel, who writes about his journey along the highway.
lead_paragraph: Monte Reel is the author of this week’s cover story about a new highway that transects South America. Reel is the author of “Between Man and Beast” and “The Last of the Tribe.” He last wrote for the magazine about the makeup artist Stuart Freeborn.

headline: Daily Report: Apple’s Unsplashy Acquisitions Point to Future Plans
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The companies acquired by Apple in a 15-month period were small and apparently carefully targeted to existing projects, in contrast to the jaw-dropping deals seen among its rivals.
lead_paragraph: As some tech giants have reached billion-dollar deals in recent years to add significant new arms to their businesses — like Facebook buying WhatsApp for as much as $19 billion, and Microsoft buying Nokia’s handset business for more than $7.1 billion — Apple has ventured down a different path, Brian X. Chen reports.

lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: How to Avoid a Crowdfunding Backlash
abstract: To raise money, businesses have to give back something of value, but every dollar given back is one less dollar that goes toward the goal.
lead_paragraph: I recently wrote about the backlash some retailers, including the Chocolate Room, have experienced while trying to raise money through crowdfunding platforms like Kickstarter.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 24, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Update: Feb. 25, 2014

headline: A Clearer Picture on Lehman’s Collapse
abstract: Federal Reserve transcripts released on Friday provide the fullest picture yet of the thinking of top government officials on Lehman’s implosion in 2008. | Facebook’s deal for WhatsApp, which could be worth up to $19 billion, is all about the address book. | Greater pension fund disclosure may have helped Detroit avoid bankruptcy. | Comcast and Netflix strike a deal on service.
lead_paragraph: LEHMAN REVISITED  |  The Federal Reserve let Lehman Brothers fail more than five years ago. But it wasn’t until Friday that the Fed released transcripts of the 2008 meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee that provide the fullest picture yet of the thinking of top government officials on Lehman’s collapse, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook.

headline: China Accused of Firing Water Cannons at Filipino Fishermen
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Philippine military said the Chinese Coast Guard tried to drive away Filipino fishing vessels at the disputed Scarborough Shoal.
lead_paragraph: A top Philippine military official accused China on Monday of firing water cannons at Filipino fishermen near a disputed shoal in the South China Sea.

abstract: Because it never existed.
lead_paragraph: The organization never had any.

abstract: Thomas Middelhoff, a German business executive, will not seek re-election to The New York Times Company’s board in April.

headline: DreamWorks Plans Interactive Attractions Tied to Shrek Franchise
abstract: The studio is announcing a partnership with Merlin Entertainments, the operators of such themed attractions as Legoland parks and Madame Tussauds.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There are no new “Shrek” movies. “Shrek: The Musical” closed on Broadway. “Shrek 4-D” at Universal Studios Florida now plays second fiddle to a newer animation-based attraction: “Despicable Me Minion Mayhem.”

headline: Chinese Microblogging Service Weibo Plans Public Offering
abstract: The offering by the Sina Corporation for Weibo, which has not been formally announced, could raise up to $500 million later this year in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:10 p.m. | The Sina Corporation, one of China’s biggest Internet portals, is preparing an initial public offering in the United States for Weibo, its Twitter-like microblogging service, according to people close to the matter.

headline: Scots Wha Hae
abstract: Breaking up is hard to do.
lead_paragraph: I don’t have a position on Scotland becoming independent; as an American, I like my democracies big and diverse, but I also understand the frustration of Scots tied to David Cameron’s England.

headline: WhatsApp to Start Offering Internet Phone Calls
abstract: On the heels of its $16 billion deal to be bought by Facebook, WhatsApp said Monday that it would start offering voice services later this year — diversifying beyond its main messaging service into phone calls.
lead_paragraph: Updated with the number of WhatsApp users in several countries.

lead_paragraph: Some readers ask why I can’t do graphs and figures in the column, the way I do on the blog.

headline: The Work of a Sound Designer: 4 Days of Recording Breaths
abstract: On “All Is Lost,” the sound editors tried a sound-alike for the main character’s breathing, but they redid it with Robert Redford’s voice.
lead_paragraph: Robert Redford was notably snubbed by the Academy for his performance in J.C. Chandor’s “All Is Lost.” Perhaps if he’d let his Oscar-nominated sound editor, Steve Boeddeker, handle his campaign, he would have walked off with a best actor nod.

headline: Choosing Health Coverage as Deadline Nears
abstract: If you don’t have health insurance, there is still time to enroll through the public marketplaces created by the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t have health insurance, there is still time to enroll through the public marketplaces created by the Affordable Care Act. But don’t delay too long: The deadline for obtaining coverage for this year is March 31.

headline: Kremlin Says Ukrainian Instability Threatens Russian Interests
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Russia’s prime minister, Dmitri A. Medvedev, questioned the legitimacy of the new government in Ukraine, signaling that the Kremlin could react strongly in response to the tumult there.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia ratcheted up its anger over the new government in neighboring Ukraine on Monday, questioning the legitimacy of the interim authorities and accusing them of using dictatorial and “sometimes terrorist methods” to usurp power and silence dissent in the country’s Russian-speaking south and east.

headline: Men’s Wearhouse Raises Its Bid for Jos. A. Bank
abstract: Men’s Wearhouse on Monday announced that it had increased its tender offer for the rival men’s suit retailer to $63.50 per share, up from $57.50 per share, and filed a lawsuit to block Jos. A. Bank’s proposed acquisition of Eddie Bauer.
lead_paragraph: The hostile takeover battle between Men’s Wearhouse and Jos. A. Bank Clothiers just grew even more heated.

headline: Radio Frequency Chip Makers to Merge
abstract: The combination of RF Micro Devices and TriQuint Semiconductor will create a chip maker with more than $2 billion in annual revenue.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:20 a.m. |

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Salvatore Ferragamo Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: John Dingell to Retire After Nearly 60 Years in House
abstract: Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and the longest serving member of Congress in history, announced that he would not seek re-election. He was first elected to the House in 1955.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No member of the House has served as long as Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan. So it resonated when Mr. Dingell announced on Monday that he would not seek re-election to a seat he has held since the Eisenhower administration in part because the institution he once revered had become “obnoxious,” riven by acrimony and marked by lack of productivity.

headline: Icahn Accuses EBay Board of Conflicts of Interest
abstract: The e-commerce giant says that the activist investor is engaging in “mudslinging attacks” against two of its directors.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn has accused the eBay board of “certain material conflicts of interest, which we believe could put the future of our company in peril.”

headline: Chief of Mt. Gox Resigns From Bitcoin Foundation
abstract: The resignation is the latest blow to Mt. Gox, once the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange, and the virtual currency, which has encountered several technical problems recently.
lead_paragraph: Mark Karpeles, the chief executive of Mt. Gox, once the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange, has resigned from the board of the Bitcoin Foundation.

abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Snooki and Squibb? The Season Enters the Silly Phase
abstract: In years past, this has been the time when contenders go a little cuckoo: when there’s just a few days left for voting.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was the Oscar equivalent of an emergency-room Code Blue: “Melissa Leo has gone rogue! Melissa Leo has gone rogue!”

headline: Leopard on Loose Paralyzes Northern Indian City
abstract: The big cat has attacked a police official, a TV news cameraman and four residents.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A roaming leopard has caused life in the northern Indian city of Meerut to come to a halt.

headline: Blogger Keeps Focus on Brooklyn Architecture, but Now Mostly From Upstate
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Brownstones', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: The blogger Suzanne Spellen still delves into the history of the borough even though she can no longer afford to live there.
lead_paragraph: The old industrial cities along the Hudson River in upstate New York have become magnets in recent years for creative former Brooklynites seeking cheaper, larger spaces in which to work and live. Among them is Suzanne Spellen, a lay historian who writes eight times a week about Brooklyn architecture but who found she could no longer afford to live in the borough.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: National Geographic Channels will work with the New York office of We Are Social to expand social media marketing.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Allspaugh joined VSA Partners, Chicago, as an associate partner, responsible for helping expand the agency’s business-to-business marketing strategy discipline. He had been executive director for marketing strategy and analytics at the Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of WPP.

headline: Share Your Stories of Street Harassment in New York City
abstract: For a coming series of articles and first-person accounts, City Room would like to hear your stories of street harassment and subway harassment.
lead_paragraph: Let’s consider this the beginning of what we hope will be a continuing conversation.

headline: The Ballad of El Chapo
abstract: A street performer in Mexico sings a ballad about the capture of the drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, otherwise known as El Chapo.
lead_paragraph: A street performer in Mexico sings a ballad about the capture of the drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, otherwise known as El Chapo.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Unnervingly blue eyes in an ad, and Walmart’s choice of a song is questioned.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Investor Pushes to Block Red Lobster Spinoff
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The investment firm Starboard Value, which has a 5.5 percent stake in Darden Restaurants, announced it would seek a special shareholders meeting in an attempt to thwart the proposed spinoff of Red Lobster.
lead_paragraph: Darden Restaurants, the parent company of the Red Lobster seafood chain, is having trouble pleasing any of its investors.

headline: Lessons From the Recovery Act
keywords: ['American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Five years after the Obama administration’s stimulus program to fight the economic crisis became law, an economist who helped shape it assesses its impact.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Government and Premier of Egypt Quit in Abrupt Move
abstract: There was speculation that the move was somehow intended to clear the way for Field Marshal Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, the defense minister and the dominant figure in the government, to announce his candidacy in the coming presidential election.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s prime minister surprised members of his cabinet on Monday by abruptly announcing the resignation of the military-backed government, which had struggled to manage the country over seven months of political unrest and growing criticism of its performance.

headline: Marriage May Be Good for Your Blood Pressure
abstract: People who were married were more likely to exhibit daily patterns in their blood pressure readings that are considered healthy, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Being married may be good for your blood pressure.

headline: Polish Your Hooves When the Devil Calls a Tune
abstract: “La Damnation de Faust,” usually presented in concert versions, is being staged by a choreographer at the Deutsche Oper in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — “In the name of the Devil, dance,” Méphistophélès orders his minions in Berlioz’s “La Damnation de Faust,” and they follow suit with a sprightly minuet.

headline: HSBC to Sidestep European Union Bonus Cap as It Cuts Costs
abstract: The bank said it would pay an allowance to high-ranking executives in order to circumvent European compensation limits and announced earnings for 2013 that fell short of analyst expectations.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:14 p.m. | LONDON — As it reported a profit for last year that fell short of analysts’ estimates, HSBC on Monday laid out how it was changing its compensation for senior executives, becoming the first major bank here to describe in detail how it was circumventing a new European Union cap on bonuses.

headline: Mijo Mihaljcic Transforms Backstage at Marni
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Mijo Mihaljcic (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Paul Hanson.

headline: Bill Thomas, 89, Dies; Editor Guided Los Angeles Times to 9 Pulitzers
abstract: Under his leadership, The Times greatly expanded its range, opening six more foreign bureaus and six more domestic ones, often concentrating on big projects.
lead_paragraph: Bill Thomas, the editor who led The Los Angeles Times from the Watergate years through the presidency of Ronald Reagan, a period in which the paper vastly enlarged its ambition and won nine Pulitzer Prizes, died on Sunday at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Gluten-Free Spaghetti With Baby Broccoli, Mushrooms and Walnuts
abstract: The walnuts add texture and flavor to this pasta dish.
lead_paragraph: This week I was really into adding nuts to many of my pasta dishes. They contribute substantial “meaty” texture and wonderful flavor. Baby broccoli is more elegant than regular broccoli, with long wispy florets and thin stems.

headline: Gluten-Free Fettucine With Brussels Sprouts, Lemon and Ricotta
abstract: Creamy ricotta and Brussels sprouts add color and texture to this dish.
lead_paragraph: Brussels sprouts love a whisper of lemon, which is what the zest provides in this combo. The ricotta becomes creamy when you add a small amount of cooking water from the pasta to it, but you have to serve this right away or the ricotta will stiffen up again. I used gluten free Le Veneziane fettucine made with cornmeal, and thought the color and texture were very good. It only took 5 to 6 minutes to cook.

headline: Gluten-Free Penne With Peas, Ricotta and Tarragon
abstract: A simple dish that is sweet with tarragon and a breeze to make.
lead_paragraph: The reason I choose penne for this dish is because I always like the way the peas find their way inside the little tubes. The dish is simple, sweet with tarragon, and very quickly made. You must serve it right away or the ricotta will stiffen.

headline: Facebook Stock Not So Different Than Bitcoin
abstract: The risk for Facebook and Bitcoin, respectively, is that someone creates a better social network or decentralized digital currency, writes Rob Cox of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: With its extraordinary swoop on WhatsApp last week, Facebook proved its stock is not so different from the crypto-currency of the moment, Bitcoin. They can both be used for certain, specific purposes. Neither is backed by a government. Both depend on vast networks of individuals. And their worth reflects demand, which is based on murky fundamentals. The trick: monetize them while they still have value.

headline: Gluten-Free Spaghetti With Shrimp, Kale and Tomatoes
abstract: A robust winter pasta with a spicy kick.
lead_paragraph: I like to use black kale for this. I blanch it in the pasta cooking water, then I add the chopped blanched leaves to the tomato sauce at the end of cooking, just so they will heat through and soften a little more. I sear the shrimp and make the tomato sauce in the same pan. You can toss shrimp in the tomato sauce or just top each serving with them, which is the way to go if there are vegetarians at the table.

headline: With a Classical Violinist’s Composing Debut, Watch Magazine Adds Music to Its Content
abstract: The violinist, Charlie Siem, has composed a score to accompany marketing efforts for the magazine, a CBS Television publication.
lead_paragraph: Not that long ago, it would have sounded silly for a magazine to commission a musical score, perhaps akin to a radio show hiring a staff photographer.

headline: A Conversation With Alan Alda
abstract: The actor turned educator talks about how science can be made clearer and more accessible to the public if served with a helping of improvisation.
lead_paragraph: The actor turned educator talks about how science can be made clearer and more accessible to the public if served with a helping of improvisation.

headline: For 2018, a Different Plan Is in Place
abstract: Five of 13 venues are already built for the Pyeongchang Games, which will emphasize the mountain venues, unlike the Sochi Games, which were built from scratch and centered in the city.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The sun was shining once more by the Black Sea, and the jackets were off with the Olympic flame still a few hours away from being extinguished.

headline: Alan Alda, Spokesman for Science
abstract: An actor with a love of science seeks to apply techniques of drama to help scientists be better communicators.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The most popular speaker at the recent meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science was not a scientist but one of science’s most high-profile advocates: the actor and writer Alan Alda.

headline: George London Vocal Contest Recognizes American and Canadian Singers
abstract: Seven opera singers were awarded the George London Award, named for the great American bass-baritone, which includes a prize of $10,000.
lead_paragraph: The George London Foundation Awards Competition, a vocal contest for American and Canadian opera singers, named for the great American bass-baritone who died in 1985, and held annually since 1971, wrapped up on Friday evening, when the final round was held at the Morgan Library & Museum.

headline: Suicide Bomber in Pakistan Strikes Near Iran’s Consulate
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Two were killed and 11 were wounded in the attack, but none were hurt in the consulate complex because of security that diverted the attacker.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A suicide bomber detonated near the residence of the Iranian consul general in Peshawar on Monday, killing two security personnel and wounding 11 others, a security official said.

headline: Dinner Rolls
abstract: How many dinner rolls are reasonable?
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was provided by Numberplay regular Giovanni Ciriani. As with many complicated-looking puzzles, a key first step might be to simplify — but in this case it may not be clear right away what gets simplified. Let’s tuck into —

abstract: An arrest warrant has been issued for former President Victor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine. Also on the Minute, Egypt's government unexpectedly resigns and Comcast strikes a deal with Netflix.
lead_paragraph: An arrest warrant has been issued for former President Victor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine. Also on the Minute, Egypt's government unexpectedly resigns and Comcast strikes a deal with Netflix.
