headline: Today in Small Business: A Salon on Wheels
abstract: A guide to social media etiquette. How to reduce employee absence. And how a very smart Girl Scout sells 117 boxes of cookies in two hours.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

headline: Armani in Green
abstract: The designer made slight changes to his traditional silhouette for this winter 2014 collection and used subtle shades of green shifting to gray.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — To be both peaceful and forceful in fashion is a special achievement. And who but Giorgio Armani could have made an entire collection out of subtly redrawn silhouettes colored only in the softest green, shaded to gray? Those colors enveloped the show that closed the Milan collections on Monday.

headline: The Academy and Diversity, by the Numbers
abstract: An infographic looks at the Academy’s track record (or lack thereof) on honoring the work of minorities.

headline: Microsoft Should Keep Nokia’s Android Phones
abstract: Nokia announced an Android-based line of phones for emerging markets, putting strain on its marriage with Microsoft before the companies even walk down the aisle.
lead_paragraph: In news both expected and still slightly naughty, Nokia announced its line of Android phones at Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain. If the phones are successful, as I expect they will be, Microsoft should swallow its pride and keep them around.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Dsquared2 Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Public Pension Tabs Multiply as States Defer Costs and Hard Choices
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Government Employees', 'State Legislatures', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'States (US)']
abstract: States and cities continue to face a problem that stems from demographics, financial markets and reluctance to make politically tough decisions.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey overhauled the state’s pension system in 2011, he celebrated it as a bold, bipartisan step toward paying down the state’s costly promises to its retired workers. Some would have to work longer, some would lose inflation adjustments, and both workers and taxpayers would have to pay more into the system.

headline: Ukrainian Protesters See Too Many Familiar Faces in Parliament After Revolution
abstract: The prospect of a new order dominated by established opposition parties has left a bitter feeling that what comes next could be disappointing.
lead_paragraph: KIEV — As Ukraine’s parliament moved to fill a power vacuum left by the ouster of President Viktor F. Yanuovych, Irina Nikanchuk, a 25-year-old economist, stood outside the legislature building on Monday to give voice to a widespread feeling here: Throw the bums out.

headline: Nets and Collins Mostly Shrug Off Milestone Game
abstract: Jason Collins’s teammates played down his return to the N.B.A. as the league’s first openly gay and active player, acting as if it were just another normal night.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Was it a big deal?

headline: Excerpt: 'Kung Fu'
abstract: A scene from David Henry Hwang's play "Kung Fu," at the Signature Theater.
lead_paragraph: A scene from David Henry Hwang's play "Kung Fu," at the Signature Theater.

headline: Protesters Block Streets in Venezuela
abstract: On Monday, traffic came to a halt in parts of the Venezuelan capital as opposition protesters set up barricades. Unrest has roiled the country for nearly two weeks.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, traffic came to a halt in parts of the Venezuelan capital as opposition protesters set up barricades. Unrest has roiled the country for nearly two weeks.

headline: Natural Big Lies
abstract: Bubbles too big to see for what they are.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been doing some more Fed transcript readings, and noticing how implausible everyone found it that what did happen, could happen. And I have a small insight as I remember the days of bubble denial. It involves a violation of Godwin’s Law, but in a good cause.

headline: Huntington’s Conflicts, Fukuyama’s World
keywords: ['Cold War Era', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Today’s foreign crises and their ideological context.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column, on Russian grand strategy and Ukrainian turmoil, doubles as the latest installment in my semi-recurring series dedicated to the idea that ours is still essentially a Francis Fukuyaman world — that is, a world in which the West’s combination of liberal cosmopolitanism and democratic capitalism has no ideological rivals worthy of the name. To elaborate a little on that theme and its significance, let me quote from a Walter Russell Mead essay that ran in the Journal late last week, under the Fukuyama-invoking headline “Putin Knows History Hasn’t Ended”:

headline: Kiss Won’t Play the Rock Hall of Fame Induction
abstract: Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley said they wanted to credit all members of the band.
lead_paragraph: The rock band Kiss is about to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and fans of the group have been hoping for a full-scale in-costume reunion of the four players who started the band 40 years ago – Gene Simmons, bass; Paul Stanley, rhythm guitar; Ace Frehley, lead guitar; and Peter Criss, drums. Mr. Frehley and Mr. Criss left and returned several times, and last performed with Kiss a decade ago. But Kiss has continued with other players, including its current guitarist, Tommy Thayer, and drummer, Eric Singer.

headline: Thailand’s Army Chief Cautions Antigovernment Protesters
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The head of Thailand’s army, after months of neutrality, tells government opponents to “ask yourselves whether this would end peacefully.”
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The head of Thailand’s army, one of the most powerful institutions in the country, appeared to distance himself from the goals of antigovernment protesters in a nationally televised speech on Monday that analysts said was a signal to the Thai public.

headline: Paying the Price for Insider Trading Profits
abstract: A court opinion empowers the Securities and Exchange Commission to seek money from defendants even when they did not personally receive proceeds from insider trading activity, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Can a criminal be held responsible for what others gained from his violation? An appeals court answered “yes” when the crime was insider trading and the profits went to a hedge fund rather than directly to the defendant.

headline: ‘How Much Do You Want?’
abstract: As we were walking through the dark house, it occurred to me that I had no idea what game my potential client was playing; I just knew that I was losing.
lead_paragraph: Fast growth entrepreneurs are usually fast talkers, but one of the most valuable lessons that any entrepreneur can learn is when to keep your mouth closed during a negotiation. The hard part is when the other person has learned the same lesson. The hidden rule here is usually this — the one who speaks first loses.

headline: Samsung Unveils Galaxy S5 and Gear Fit, With a Focus on Simplicity
abstract: Samsung’s new flagship smartphone and new smartwatch, both announced Monday at a relatively low-key media event in Barcelona, Spain, focus on being good at just a few things.
lead_paragraph: Samsung must have made a New Year’s resolution to stay more focused.

headline: Road-Tripping Through the Wild West, in the Name of Fashion
keywords: ['Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Recreational Vehicles', 'Road Trips']
abstract: The designers of the men’s wear label FairEnds recount their RV journey from Montana to the Capsule trade show in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: Martin Carvajal and Ben Ferencz, the designers of the men’s clothing and accessories brand FairEnds, live in New York and Missoula, Mont., respectively. This duality shows through in their fun and functional backpacks, bags, hats and shirts — the sort of urbane yet outdoorsy pieces that feel equally at home on Rivington Street or the Ruby River.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Feb. 11-25, 2014
abstract: The News Quiz took a week of vacation last week, so the 10 questions in this quiz cover headline-making events from the last two weeks, from the Olympics to Ukraine to gay rights.
lead_paragraph: The News Quiz took a week of vacation last week, so the 10 questions below cover headline-making events from the last two weeks, from the Olympics to Ukraine to gay rights.

headline: Barcelona Pays $19 Million Tax Related to Neymar Acquisition
abstract: The payment may be an attempt to settle a legal dispute that has highlighted the opaque system of payments used by soccer clubs to acquire players.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — F.C. Barcelona said Monday that it had made a payment of $18.6 million to Spanish tax authorities related to last year’s acquisition of the Brazilian star Neymar in an attempt to settle a legal dispute that has highlighted the opaque and convoluted system of payments used by soccer clubs to sign players.

headline: Why a Fed Governor Bought a Home When He Knew the Market Was Teetering
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: It was a purchase, he said, to please his wife. Sometimes we make decisions that appear irrational, but they make sense when viewed on the balance sheet of life.
lead_paragraph: Frederic Mishkin was in a bind. In January 2008, his wife wanted to buy a house, but as we all know now, the housing market was in the midst of a crash. More than one person probably shared similar doubts with friends around the same time, but Mr. Mishkin is a little different. He told his story during a Federal Reserve meeting, as we learned when the minutes were released late last week.

headline: Wall of Riot Police Greets Demonstrators at Sentencing of Moscow Protesters
abstract: A response in Russia underscored why even President Vladimir V. Putin’s critics doubt that the nation will experience the kind of government-shaking protests that toppled Ukraine’s leader.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The riot police officers massed in force on Monday morning outside a courthouse here, well before the judges and the defendants had even arrived, to confront the demonstrators who came to criticize what the authorities have done to political dissent in today’s Russia. The officers erected barriers half a block away and, with blue-and-white police buses parked nearby, formed phalanxes of shields and body armor.

headline: New Italian Premier, in First Speech, Outlines Early Priorities for His Tenure
abstract: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi called for lawmakers to have the courage to make radical change, and promised bold measures to revive the economy.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Making his first appearance before Parliament since becoming prime minister, Matteo Renzi on Monday called for lawmakers to have the courage to make radical change, pledged to push through political and electoral overhauls, and promised bold, innovative measures to revive the moribund economy.

headline: Netflix, Comcast and Net Neutrality
abstract: What is Netflix getting from the deal, how will that affect other companies on the Internet?
lead_paragraph: A deal announced Sunday between Comcast, the nation’s largest cable and broadband company, and Netflix, the popular video streaming service, raises several troubling questions about the future of the Internet. Under the agreement, Netflix will hook its servers directly to Comcast’s network for an undisclosed fee, cutting out the middlemen that previously connected the companies together.

headline: Ugandan President Discusses Antigay Law
abstract: President Yoweri Museveni signed into law a controversial bill that introduces lengthy prison sentences for “the promotion or recognition” of homosexual relations.
lead_paragraph: President Yoweri Museveni signed into law a controversial bill that introduces lengthy prison sentences for “the promotion or recognition” of homosexual relations.

headline: Reaction to Uganda Antigay Law
abstract: Gay rights activists continue to oppose the law as the evangelical group that supported it say they would have preferred a less harsh version.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Alan Cowell reported, the president of Uganda, Yoweri Museveni, significantly strengthened Africa’s antigay movement, signing into law a bill imposing harsh sentences for homosexual acts, including life imprisonment in some cases.

headline: Where Has My Equilibrium Gone?
abstract: Age-related changes in the inner ear’s structure can lead to balance and equilibrium problems, but simple exercises often help.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’m 43. I used to love to swing and spin, like my young sons, but now it makes me feel sick. What has happened to my equilibrium?

headline: More Preschool Could Lead to More A.D.H.D. Diagnoses
abstract: Pressure to show success in state- and federally funded preschools may lead to a similar rise in diagnoses in even younger children.
lead_paragraph: From Stephen P. Hinshaw and Richard M. Scheffler on the Op-Ed page:

headline: The Read Around: B. J. Novak
abstract: B. J. Novak, whose debut collection of fiction is “One More Thing,” says, “I love to act, but I’m always thinking with the mind of a writer.”
lead_paragraph: B. J. Novak, whose debut collection of fiction is “One More Thing,” says, “I love to act, but I’m always thinking with the mind of a writer.”

headline: A Taste You Hate? Just Wait
abstract: Are there really foods that we don’t like, or just foods that we haven’t liked yet?
lead_paragraph: A life breaks down into epochs, with bright dividing lines between them. There’s the period of impotence and innocence before a driver’s license, and the insurance premiums and speeding tickets after. There’s pre-mortgage, when a landlord handles plumbing emergencies, and post-mortgage, when you’re on your soggy own.

headline: 7 Egyptians Found Shot in Head in Libya
abstract: The seven men had all been shot in the head, an official from the security directorate in Benghazi said, and might have been the victims of a robbery.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Seven Egyptians were found dead in a coastal area of Libya outside the eastern town of Benghazi, a Libya security official said Monday.

headline: An Environmental Film Festival and High-Tech Music
abstract: A film festival investigates risks to humans and animals, and music takes a turn for the high-tech with healing through vibrations and a prosthetic arm that specializes in drumming.
lead_paragraph: March events at the intersection of science and culture.

headline: Habitat Loss Speeds Up a Kestrel’s Life
abstract: With the forests that were once their homes destroyed, the birds have adapted by having more offspring earlier in life. They also die younger.
lead_paragraph: To survive the destruction of forests in its island habitat, a rare bird called the Mauritius kestrel has adopted a new strategy, researchers say: Live fast and die young.

headline: How Many Best-Picture Nominees Have You Seen?
abstract: A poll finds most Americans have seen none of the nine hopefuls. That could mean a dent in the ratings on Oscar night. Then again, it could also mean a post-ceremony box office bump for the studios.
lead_paragraph: With blockbusters like “Gravity” and films with more than respectable box office receipts, like “The Wolf of Wall Street,” “American Hustle” and “Captain Phillips,” in the running for best picture, Academy organizers and producers of the Oscars broadcast may be thinking they’re in for a sizable home audience. (Viewership correlates most closely to the box office tally for the nominated films; a year of little-watched indies portends badly for the ratings.) But despite what critics and pundits consider an unusually strong cinematic field, most people have still not seen any of the best picture contenders, according to one recent poll.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Pap Smears in Perpetuity
abstract: Many women receive Pap smears well after age 65, despite recommendations to reduce testing and evidence that they have little value.
lead_paragraph: Most older women don’t need the routine Pap tests used to check for cervical cancer.

headline: A Token of Anne Frank’s Childhood, on View
abstract: A set of marbles Ann Frank played with before going into hiding with her family is on display in “The Second World War in 100 Objects” in Rotterdam.
lead_paragraph: The set of marbles that Anne Frank played with before she was forced into hiding are on display for the first time.

headline: Obama Delivers Remarks to Governors
abstract: President Obama speaks to members of the National Governors Association in the White House State Dining Room.
lead_paragraph: President Obama speaks to members of the National Governors Association in the White House State Dining Room.

headline: Zuckerberg Says WhatsApp Deal Was a Bargain
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook said the acquisition, the largest ever by his company, would allow WhatsApp to focus on connecting more people around the world.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain – Many analysts and technology insiders have suggested that Facebook is overpaying for WhatsApp, the mobile messaging service that it is buying for up to $19 billion.

headline: Indonesia Urged to Spend to Make Birth Less Risky
abstract: Even as Indonesia has gotten richer, it has maintained a decentralized system in which most rural women are attended by local midwives.
lead_paragraph: If Indonesia wants to better its “embarrassingly suboptimal performance” in deaths of newborns and their mothers, it will have to make far-reaching and expensive changes in its health care system, American and Indonesian experts say in a new report.

headline: How a College Roommate Can Affect Your Child
abstract: Research has shown that while drinking can be “contagious,” mental health issues are not. But a relationship with a randomly assigned college student can pose special problems.
lead_paragraph: When you have a child off at college, you worry about his general health, state of mind, alcohol use — and, as you sign those tuition checks, academic achievement.

headline: Coming Soon: Heroes of the Higgs
keywords: ['Higgs Boson', 'Movies', 'Large Hadron Collider', 'Physics', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The documentary “Particle Fever” tracks the ultimately successful search at CERN for a linchpin of modern theories about the universe.
lead_paragraph: Physicists get to discover a new particle once in a generation, if they are lucky.

headline: G.O.P. Leaders Draw Re-election Challenges From the Right
abstract: Although upsets are unlikely, the long list of candidates trying to unseat high-ranking Republicans in the primaries reflects fissures within the party.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — There is the Tea Party Patriots “Fire the Speaker” petition, which is not to be confused with the FreedomWorks “Fire the Speaker” petition, or the websites variously urging people to “Fire John Boehner” and “Pledge to Fire Boehner.”

headline: As Kennedy Trial Opens, Questions on Awareness of a Drug’s Effects
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Ambien (Drug)']
abstract: Kerry Kennedy said she accidentally took a sleeping pill the morning her car swerved into a tractor-trailer, but a prosecutor said she should have pulled over the minute she realized something was wrong.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — There was the matriarch, Ethel Kennedy, 85 and somewhat frail, entering the Westchester County Courthouse in a wheelchair, and two of the brothers, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Douglas Kennedy, with their familiar family looks and style, all recorded by a dozen television cameras stationed outside in a biting cold.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: February 21-23, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last month, John Wayne Rogers, 40, escaped first-degree murder charges for shooting his friend to death with an assault rifle after a long drinking session in a Florida hotel room in 2012. After spending two years awaiting trial, a judge granted his Stand Your Ground motion for immunity and ruled that Rogers acted in self-defense. Rogers had testified that the victim, James DeWitt, 34, punched him and threatened his life.

headline: After Meeting With Obama, Governor Goes on the Attack
abstract: Emerging from the annual meeting of the nation’s governors at the White House, Gov. Bobby Jindal omitted the usual happy-talk to discuss his views of President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is definitely an election year in Washington.

headline: Tenants Living Amid Rubble in Rent-Regulated Apartment War
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Real estate disputes are a fact of life in New York City, but who wins and who loses has acquired new urgency amid rising rents that are putting some neighborhoods out of reach for lower-income residents.
lead_paragraph: The letter from the landlord said he needed access to the apartments for a couple of weeks to make repairs.

headline: From Buffett, Lessons From His Farm
abstract: In an excerpt from his annual letter to shareholders, Warren Buffett describes how investments he made in a farm and real estate illustrate the importance of a long-term view.
lead_paragraph: Investors around the world hang on Warren Buffett’s every word, hoping for a scrap of advice from a legendary businessman. Mr. Buffett often dishes out a few morsels of that advice in a letter that coincides with the annual report from his firm, Berkshire Hathaway.

headline: Pope Moves to Reshape Management of Vatican
abstract: Pope Francis’ actions are the latest example of how he is moving to confront management problems in the Vatican as part of his broader mandate to overhaul the Roman Curia, the administration that runs the Holy See.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis on Monday announced a major restructuring of the Vatican’s outdated administrative and economic bureaucracy as he established an agency to oversee budgets and financial planning and also created a powerful post of auditor general to guard against fiscal mismanagement.

headline: Blood Pressure Drugs Tied to Risk of Falls
abstract: Older adults who take blood pressure drugs have a greater risk of serious falls and related injuries, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: Older adults who take blood pressure drugs have a greater risk of serious falls, a new study reports.

headline: Parenting When Even Minimum Wage Is Out of Reach
abstract: I live in Milwaukee. They just raised the minimum wage here, but I don’t have a job. There’s not many options out there.
lead_paragraph: I live in Milwaukee. They just raised the minimum wage here, but I don’t have a job. There are not many options out there. I’m 24 years old, and I have two kids — my son is 4 years old and my daughter is 6.

headline: The Fight for 98 Linden
abstract: After 23 years of living in their rent-stabilized apartment, Noelia Calero and her family are fighting to stay. The landlord, they say, is using intimidating tactics to push them out.
lead_paragraph: After 23 years of living in their rent-stabilized apartment, Noelia Calero and her family are fighting to stay. The landlord, they say, is using intimidating tactics to push them out.

headline: After Hours | A Digital Deconstruction of Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya”
abstract: At Long Island City’s Chocolate Factory, an experimental theater group reworks the classic play into performance art, to sometimes bewildering effect.
lead_paragraph: “This Was the End,” an experimental meditation on Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya” at the supercool Long Island City arts space The Chocolate Factory Theater through March 8, begins both mesmerizingly and gratingly. Actors walk and run in and out of the set — a wall of doors of various shapes and sizes, sliding open and closed — while, ingeniously, the same actors do a version of the very same thing in a film projected imperfectly onto it. It’s an eye-popping sight. Meanwhile, a soundscape, chopped up from the Beatles’ “White Album,” assaults you, from speakers fitted close to the audience, half of whom covered their ears. The overall effect is hypnotic and somewhat unbearable. To what end? Is this collage meant to unpack the existential tedium of “Vanya” itself — a play in which characters frustrate us and break our hearts with their doddering romantic and career obsessions and resentments, all the while knowing that nothing will change?

headline: Step 1 Before Red Bulls’ Opener: Remove Foot of Snow
abstract: Workers at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., began the process of removing compacted snow from the playing surface so they can prepare the grass field for a March 15 game.
lead_paragraph: Soccer players can be among the most fickle of professional athletes. Things have to be just so, from the cut of their uniforms to the look and feel of their cleats. But what really gets their attention, their extreme, undivided attention, is the condition of the playing surface.

headline: Secrets of the Ages
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Longevity', 'Medicine and Health', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A wide-ranging look at the puzzle of longevity, which varies across species in often confounding ways.
lead_paragraph: Think too much about your life span and you will never get out of bed in the morning. Once you do, though, all the scientific mysteries of the subject may lie panting on the rug at your feet. Why should your good old faithful dog (avid exerciser, nonsmoker, nondrinker) be condemned to age and die after barely a decade, while you remain firmly in your prime — and the neighbor’s African gray parrot lives loudly on and on?

headline: Monday Motorsports: Dale Earnhardt Jr. Outruns Rain, Crashes and Competition at Daytona
abstract: Dale Earnhardt Jr. wins his second Daytona 500, a decade after his first victory in the race; Alexis DeJoria wins her first N.H.R.A. race in the Funny Car class.
lead_paragraph: Dale Earnhardt Jr. took the victory Sunday in the bruising 2014 running of the prestigious Daytona 500, staying out front much of the second half of a race interrupted for more than six hours by a rain delay.

headline: A Weeknight Fish Chowder Reminiscent of the Shore
abstract: This chowder is not the New England ideal, but it’s got the richness and balance of the classic recipe while keeping things simple.
lead_paragraph: What’s for Dinner answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: A Mouse Brain to Guide Us, Ear Tubes and Infections, Alan Alda Improvs Science
abstract: In new efforts to map every nook and neuron of the brain, a mouse is more important than you might think; this one is for the parents out there — a quick primer on how to deal with infections if your child has ear tubes; the actor best known for his role in “M*A*S*H” brings acting techniques into science class.
lead_paragraph: In new efforts to map every nook and neuron of the brain, a mouse is more important than you might think; this one is for the parents out there — a quick primer on how to deal with infections if your child has ear tubes; the actor best known for his role in “M*A*S*H” brings acting techniques into science class.

headline: In a Flood, Ants Really Come Together
abstract: To protect their queen and her brood, the insects link themselves to form a raft.
lead_paragraph: When the need arises, ants that live in flooded areas can link their bodies together to form buoyant rafts that protect the queen and much of her brood. Now scientists have figured out how they do it.

headline: Help for Endangered Lemurs
abstract: The animals have suffered from decades of habitat loss and poaching, but researchers say there’s hope.
lead_paragraph: Lemurs are the most endangered mammal group on the planet. Native to Madagascar, off Africa’s Indian Ocean coast, lemurs have suffered from decades of habitat loss and poaching. If protected in conservation sites managed by local communities, they could see a revival, a group of researchers report in the journal Science.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Stella Jean Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Slow Start for Newly Opened ‘Bridges of Madison County’
abstract: The new Broadway musical “Bridges of Madison County” is struggling to sell tickets.
lead_paragraph: The new Broadway musical “Bridges of Madison County,” based on a best-selling novel and starring an acclaimed musical theater performer, Kelli O’Hara, opened on Thursday to generally favorable reviews, including some raves. Yet the show is struggling to sell tickets, with a middling gross of $364,888 for eight performances last week, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

headline: Like Columbus, It Floated Here
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Flowers and Plants']
abstract: The answer of how the useful plants got to the Americas has stumped scientists, until now.
lead_paragraph: By the time Columbus arrived in the New World in 1492, bottle gourds had already conquered much of the globe. After evolving in Africa, one species, Lagenaria siceraria, made a break for East Asia around 11,000 years ago and eventually took up residence in Polynesia, China, Peru and beyond, earning the title of most widely distributed pre-Columbian domesticated plant.

headline: Harold Ramis, Director, Actor and Alchemist of Comedy, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Ramis’s hilarious and sometimes absurd comedy constructs appear in “Groundhog Day,” “Ghostbusters” and other classic movies of the 1980s and ’90s.
lead_paragraph: Harold Ramis, a writer, director and actor whose boisterous but sly silliness helped catapult comedies like “Groundhog Day,” “Ghostbusters,” “Animal House” and “Caddyshack” to commercial and critical success, died on Monday in his Chicago-area home. He was 69.

headline: For the Supreme Court, a Case Poses a Puzzle on the E.P.A.’s Authority
abstract: A puzzling case for the Supreme Court involves whether the agency properly raises emission thresholds for regulation under the Clean Air Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In trying to decide whether the Environmental Protection Agency has the authority under two programs to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from stationary sources like power plants, the Supreme Court on Monday faced what Justice Elena Kagan called “the conundrum here.”

headline: New ‘Sleeping Beauty’ to Mark American Ballet Theater’s 75th Anniversary
abstract: The new production, choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky, will premiere in 2015 at the Segerstrom Center for the Arts in Costa Mesa, Calif.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater will mark the 75th anniversary of its founding next year with a new production of “The Sleeping Beauty” choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky and based on the production Léon Bakst created for Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes in 1921, the company announced.

headline: Clues to a Very Old Extinction and Pizza for War Zones
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Snakes', 'Meningitis', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Global Warming', 'Breastfeeding', 'Cats', 'Paleontology']
abstract: Science and health news from the past week, including a mass extinction 252 million years ago, and vaccines and pizzas that don’t spoil.
lead_paragraph: A homicide trail that had been cold for 252 million years is suddenly warm. A new vaccine can withstand high temperatures, and here comes pizza that doesn’t need a fridge. Even January, it turns out, was warmer than you thought.

headline: Syria War Stirs New U.S. Debate on Cyberattacks
abstract: Considerations that led President Obama to hesitate about using cyberweapons against Syria reflect larger concerns about a new and untested tactic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after the uprising in Syria turned bloody, late in the spring of 2011, the Pentagon and the National Security Agency developed a battle plan that featured a sophisticated cyberattack on the Syrian military and President Bashar al-Assad’s command structure.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Russia, Thailand and South Sudan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Russia, Thailand and South Sudan.

headline: The Secrets of Film Sound
abstract: Melena Ryzik visits Skywalker Sound and learns how sound designers make movies come to life.
lead_paragraph: Melena Ryzik visits Skywalker Sound and learns how sound designers make movies come to life.

headline: Thomas Is Getting a New Chance to Break Precedent (if Not Silence)
abstract: Expect Justice Clarence Thomas to have more to say in writing than in arguments next week when the Supreme Court considers overruling a 1988 securities-fraud decision.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Here is a good way to get a belly laugh from Justice Clarence Thomas: Suggest to him that the Supreme Court’s decisions should seldom be overruled.

headline: Flappy Bird Copycats Keep on Flapping
abstract: While the original version of Flappy Bird has since been removed from Apple’s App Store, clones of it now exists on dozens of platforms, including the Commodore 64 and even a graphics calculator.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 9, the Western world fell into chaos as Flappy Bird, a highly addictive game, was removed from mobile app stores by Dong Nguyen, an independent developer in Vietnam.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Color-Blocked Fur Coats
abstract: Plush statement outerwear is popping up in fall/winter collections so often, it’s bordering on wardrobe-staple status.
lead_paragraph: Last season, Miuccia Prada presented furs printed with hibiscus flowers and the artistic renderings of ladies’ faces in a rainbow of bright colors. This season, the ripples of those statement pieces have hit designers’ collections like a tidal wave, making the multicolored fur coat a must-have item for fall 2014. Although it is a trend we have seen before — especially at Céline, where color-blocked fur has become a signature of sorts — the frequency with which we’re now seeing fur with a graphic quality is making what once seemed like a luxury item feel like a new wardrobe staple. We first saw a version in New York at Altuzarra, where the young designer dressed up a simple, dark fur coat with vibrant colors like Yves Klein blue and tangerine. Then at J. Mendel, the house run by a long line of furriers, bold colors and abstract, latticelike color-blocking offered a fresh and modern take on the brand’s signature material. Finally at Marni in Milan, vertical panels of cobalt, white and crimson made an oversize silhouette seem long and lean — and a fluffy, neutral-colored collar provided the ultimate luxurious top-off.

headline: When Men Get Breast Cancer
abstract: A provocative new series by the New York-based fashion photographer David Jay features the faces, and scars, of men with breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: Breast cancer is not always pink.

headline: Trailer for Ukraine’s Uprising Stars Will Smith and Sylvester Stallone
abstract: A Ukrainian video blogger’s tribute to the courage of protesters in Kiev mixes footage of the demonstrations with inspirational speeches borrowed from two Hollywood action movies.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a way to pay tribute to the courage of protesters in Kiev, who refused to be dislodged from Independence Square over the past three months despite violent attacks from the security forces, a Ukrainian video blogger found the words he needed in dubbed versions of two Hollywood action movies.

headline: Closing Olympics Ceremonies Give NBC a Narrow Win on a Crowded Sunday
abstract: The Games drew more than 15 million viewers, but “Walking Dead” on AMC had more than 13 million, and “Downton Abbey” had 8.5 million.
lead_paragraph: The final night of the Winter Olympics coverage on NBC was the most-watched event on television Sunday night but the competition was formidable, as “Downton Abbey” posted its best audience total ever for a finale on PBS and “The Walking Dead” on AMC scored its usual enormous rating with younger audiences, doubling the total for the Olympics.

headline: A Chilling Vision of a Television Future and Its Prescient Seer
abstract: “Mad as Hell” recounts the making of the 1976 film “Network” and its vision of the future, which may not turn out to be that unhinged, after all.
lead_paragraph: In the closing chapter of “Mad as Hell” — informatively subtitled “The Making of ‘Network’ and the Fateful Vision of the Angriest Man in Movies” — Dave Itzkoff lays out how the American media has become even more Chayefskyian in the decades since Paddy Chayefsky, the angry man in question, wrote his crazed, perceptive, unwieldy, galvanizing satiric fantasia set in the world of network television news.

headline: Nodding to Brahms, but Honoring Stern
abstract: Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax played a Brahms program in honor of the violinist Isaac Stern at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, while the great violinist Isaac Stern was still alive, Carnegie Hall named its main listening space the Isaac Stern Auditorium, to commemorate his role in helping to save the building from the wrecking ball in 1960. Stern died in 2001, and what more could Carnegie possibly do to honor his memory?

headline: In a Petipa Program, the Exotic Shares Space With the Classical
abstract: “Petipa Exotique,” part of the Guggenheim’s Works & Process series, featured ballets by the French master Marius Petipa.
lead_paragraph: Nineteenth-century ballet, like much of 19th-century European art, loved the Orient. Ballets set in Turkish harems or Indian temples, with costumes and plots that seemed exotic, were highly popular. Yet, as the dance historian Doug Fullington pointed out in an entertaining and enlightening program at the Guggenheim Museum on Sunday, the actual dancing in these productions was almost all classical ballet.

headline: Musicians Sing for a Cause That’s Their Own
abstract: Content Creators Coalition is having an event at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday to help its on-the-air royalties campaign on behalf of performers.
lead_paragraph: In the music industry’s big fights over issues like copyright and royalties, it’s usually the titans — record conglomerates, Silicon Valley giants — that clash. But as individual musicians feel squeezed by the digital revolution, they are beginning to speak out in increasing numbers.

headline: Sounds for the Start of the Day
abstract: In new albums, Beck, St. Vincent and Dierks Bentley go back in time in different ways.
lead_paragraph: On first listening to Beck’s placid, self-possessed 12th studio album, “Morning Phase,” I did not look him up on Wikipedia to see if he’d broken up with his wife. I was not fully functional: The record’s beauty approaches slowly, floats, surrounds and shuts off external awareness in the brain stem.

headline: Chinese Arts Company Goes Public in Bid to Grow
abstract: The state-run Poly Culture Group Corporation of China is planning an initial public stock offering that could bolster its prospects in the world’s biggest and fastest-growing art and auction market.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The China Poly Group Corporation, a state-run conglomerate that got its start selling weapons to the People’s Liberation Army, has over the past few decades successfully branched into developing real estate, selling sports cars and producing television sitcoms. Now the company’s huge arts and culture division — Poly Culture Group Corporation — is planning an initial public stock offering that could raise up to $330 million and bolster the prospects of the company in the world’s biggest and fastest-growing art and auction market.

headline: Staying on Script, for Now
abstract: The debut of “Ronan Farrow Daily” on MSNBC did not surprise and followed a standard formula.
lead_paragraph: MSNBC turned Ronan Farrow, 26, a handsome celebrity activist, into Chuck Todd.

headline: Developer Is Shot in the Head Outside His Long Island Castle
abstract: A masked gunman shot Gary Melius, a well-known Long Island developer and prominent political patron, in the parking lot of his estate, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: Gary Melius, a well-known Long Island developer and prominent political patron, was shot in the head by a masked gunman on Monday in the parking lot of his opulent Gold Coast estate in Suffolk County, the police said.

headline: Holder Sees Way to Curb Bans on Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Attorneys General', 'States (US)']
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said that state attorneys general who believe that laws in their states banning same-sex marriage are discriminatory are not obligated to defend them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Monday injected the Obama administration into the emotional and politicized debate over the future of state same-sex marriage bans, declaring in an interview that state attorneys general are not obligated to defend laws that they believe are discriminatory.

headline: New Land, New Tongue, New Fame
abstract: Yiyun Li, whose new novel, “Kinder Than Solitude,” comes out this week, began writing in English, a language she began speaking later in life.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Growing up in Beijing as the daughter of a physicist, the writer Yiyun Li seemed destined for a career in science. But she would surreptitiously read from “this big book of Tang dynasty poetry,” she said, while “pretending to do math.” Years later, studying for a Ph.D. in immunology at the University of Iowa, she adopted a similar strategy, reading short stories clipped from The New Yorker as she did lab work.

headline: Two Sisters With Secrets, Desperate for Escape
abstract: Brian Watkins’s play, “My Daughter Keeps Our Hammer,” tells the story of two sisters in their 20s, living with their ailing mother on the high plains, and desperate for a way out.
lead_paragraph: Part Sam Shepard gothic drama, part “Moth Radio Hour” yarn, “My Daughter Keeps Our Hammer,” by Brian Watkins, tells the story of Sarah and Hannah, sisters in their 20s, living with their ailing mother in the farm country of Eaton, Colo., and desperate for a way out.

headline: When in India | Spiritual Healing
abstract: A tranquil spa retreat near the foothills of the Himalayas is taking wellness to new heights.
lead_paragraph: While North India has no shortage of ashrams, the recently opened Vana, Malsi Estate, located in Dehradun near the foothills of the Himalayas, is taking wellness to new heights. The 31-year-old physics major-turned-organic farmer Veer Singh has spent nearly five years and $155 million building this tranquil spa retreat, which offers everything from a few days of yoga to three weeks of Ayurvedic healing.

headline: The One-Eyed Witness
abstract: When Anthony Ray Hinton was on trial for his life in Alabama, his lawyer hired an expert witness on the cheap.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has hired a lawyer knows $1,000 doesn’t buy you much. But when Anthony Ray Hinton was on trial for his life in Alabama, that’s the total amount his court-appointed attorney thought he could spend on a key expert witness in firearms evidence. All he could find for that price was an elderly one-eyed man with a degree in civil engineering who was laughed out of court for his inability to answer basic questions.

headline: Customizing a Mash-Up
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s revival of its popular pasticcio “The Enchanted Island” features a pair of substitute arias tailored to its stars, Plácido Domingo and Susan Graham.
lead_paragraph: When opera was a much younger art form, star singers could choose which arias they wanted to sing, often swapping in favorite numbers that showed off their voices to best advantage for whatever the lowly composers and librettists had originally written.

headline: Times Minute | Tea Party Challengers
keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Tea Party challengers enter congressional primary races. Also on the Minute, tenants battle for rent-controlled units in New York and the actor Alan Alda talks science.
lead_paragraph: Tea Party challengers enter congressional primary races. Also on the Minute, tenants battle for rent-controlled units in New York and the actor Alan Alda talks science.

headline: Science Takes On a Silent Invader
abstract: A New York biologist has found a bacterium that kills invasive zebra and quagga mussels but leaves other mollusks unharmed.
lead_paragraph: Since they arrived in the Great Lakes in the 1980s, two species of mussels the size of pistachios have spread to hundreds of lakes and rivers in 34 states and have done vast economic and ecological damage.

headline: Target Push Into Canada Stumbles
abstract: Shoppers’ habits and other factors figure into a projected $800 million to $900 million loss in the retailer’s first international expansion.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — When Canadians crossed the border into the United States on shopping excursions, Target was a prime destination. But when Target crossed the border last year and brought its stores to Canada, the magic somehow vanished.

headline: LinkedIn Goes to China

lead_paragraph: Hoping to greatly increase its presence in one of the world’s great labor markets, LinkedIn has announced the formation of a site dedicated to China.

headline: Jazz at Lincoln Center Season to Include Tributes to Billie Holiday and Wayne Shorter
abstract: The 2014-15 season will also see the Allen Room renamed in honor of Robert J. Appel.
lead_paragraph: Jazz at Lincoln Center’s 2014-15 season, running from September through next June, connects musical traditions that start with jazz and open out to the Americas in general — North and South, Cuba and the Antilles. The details of the concerts, lectures, workshops and other events on the organization’s premises within the Time Warner Center and elsewhere are to be released Tuesday, with a piece of added news. What was formerly the Allen Room — the amphitheater within Frederick P. Rose Hall, with 50-foot-high glass windows overlooking Columbus Circle — will be renamed the Appel Room, in honor of Robert J. Appel, chairman of Jazz at Lincoln Center’s board, who donated $20 million to the organization earlier this year. (Allen & Co., the financial company for which the room was named in 2004, agreed to give back naming rights to a new donor.)

headline: A Bonus: Some Play on a Trip for Work
abstract: Forty-seven percent of all American business travelers added leisure days to at least one of their business trips in 2011, a research company found.
lead_paragraph: On a business trip to London last fall, Caroline Michaud took the last flight out of Heathrow Airport to Chicago on a Saturday night so she would have time to visit the National Portrait Gallery, take a run by Buckingham Palace and spin through St. James Park.

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Clay Reid decided to leave his job as a professor at Harvard Medical School to become a senior investigator at the Allen Institute for Brain Science in Seattle in 2012, some of his colleagues congratulated him warmly and understood right away why he was making the move.

lead_paragraph: Several playoff contenders — the Chicago Blackhawks, the St. Louis Blues, the Montreal Canadiens, the Anaheim Ducks, the Vancouver Canucks, the Pittsburgh Penguins and the Rangers — sent seven or more players to the Sochi Olympics.

headline: On a Plane, and Learning the Finer Points of Farming
abstract: It can be fascinating to talk to the person next to you on a flight, whether they are a security guard, a sailor on a submarine, or a farmer.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up in the Midwest and didn’t fly much when I was younger. Now, as a consultant and author of “Your Network Is Your Net Worth,” I’m traveling all the time. I find business travel tiring, so I can’t say I love it. But I do love being able to support myself in a nontraditional way.

lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — For nearly a century, Ford’s River Rouge factory and its neighboring steel mill have worked in close harmony to produce some of America’s most popular vehicles, from the Model A to the F-150 pickup truck.

C. Penney and Unilever. Those spots will, however, be only part of the marketing efforts that seek to walk the red carpet with Oscar.

headline: Live Nation Cut Its Losses Last Year
abstract: The concert promoter had $6.5 billion in revenue in 2013, compared with $5.8 billion the year before. It had a net loss of $36 million, improving from its $162 million loss in 2012.
lead_paragraph: The giant concert company Live Nation Entertainment’s revenue rose by 11 percent last year and its net loss narrowed significantly, as attendance grew for country and electronic dance events, the company reported Monday.

lead_paragraph: Aereo, the start-up that uses tiny antennas to stream the free signals of TV stations to its customers’ Internet-connected devices for a fee, is stealing from the broadcast networks on a giant scale, the broadcasters asserted in a filing with the Supreme Court on Monday.

headline: Ford to Drop Microsoft From Car Systems
abstract: Ford has made plans to use software from BlackBerry to power its in-car entertainment and communications systems.
lead_paragraph: Ford has found a new software partner to power its in-car entertainment and communications systems, making plans to drop technology from Microsoft in favor of software from BlackBerry.

lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — As the Arizona Legislature sent a bill to her desk Monday that would grant business owners the right to invoke religion to refuse service to gays and others, Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, faced pressure from many corners to veto the measure, which has cast unwanted national attention on Arizona.

headline: Confessions of a Lifelong Eavesdropper
abstract: You could say it’s a hobby. These slices of language come through the air, begging to be heard, mini vacations into other lives.
lead_paragraph: Confession: I eavesdrop. Not only that, I make my students do it.

headline: Supreme Court Declines Tennis Channel Appeal
abstract: But a dispute over the placement of the company’s cable channel lineup on Comcast may not be over quite yet.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an appeal from the Tennis Channel in its dispute with Comcast over placement on the company’s cable channel lineup.

headline: Coverage of Olympic Games Delivers a Win for NBC
abstract: The network crushed the competition for the 17 days of the international sporting colossus, averaging 21.4 million viewers, while live streaming of events skyrocketed.
lead_paragraph: A network buys the rights to the Olympics to beat its prime-time competition for 17 nights in a row.

headline: Man Charged in Series of Fires at 2 Queens Shopping Centers
abstract: Dereck Sumair, 23, of Queens, was charged with five counts of arson in connection with fires at Rego Center and Queens Center.
lead_paragraph: A 23-year-old man was charged on Monday night in connection with a series of small fires over several days at two shopping centers in Queens, the police said.

headline: Indictments for 28 More in Fraud Case
abstract: Twenty-eight more people have been indicted as part of the Manhattan district attorney’s investigation into an extensive scheme to defraud Social Security disability insurance, law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-eight more people, including retired police officers and firefighters, have been indicted as part of the Manhattan district attorney’s investigation into an extensive scheme to defraud Social Security disability insurance, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Pentagon Officials Say They’re Willing to Assume Risks of a Reduced Army
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel formally unveiled the department’s $496 billion budget for the 2015 fiscal year and acknowledged the risk of a proposed troop reduction.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In shrinking the United States Army to its smallest size since 1940, Pentagon officials said Monday that they were willing to assume more risk the next time troops are called to war.

headline: ‘The Wild West of Privacy’
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Consumer Protection', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Just what should be included in a consumer privacy bill of rights? We asked the experts.
lead_paragraph: We are fast approaching a privacy crisis in the United States. Google, Facebook and other big Internet companies collect information about us, which they deploy in the service of advertisers. Big data brokers, like Acxiom, have developed sophisticated tools that allow them to know almost as much about us as we know about ourselves; they then sell that data to all kinds of companies that want to learn everything from our habits to our health, from our sexual orientation to our finances. The digital age has made it easy to collect medical data, which is supposed to be protected under federal law. Huge data breaches at big retailers like Target have made it seem unsafe to use credit cards. And I haven’t even mentioned the Edward Snowden revelations about the massive data collection by the National Security Agency.

headline: Rash Repression in Venezuela
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Freedom of Assembly', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Venezuelans take to the streets to defend the very right to protest.
lead_paragraph: PROTESTS have rocked Venezuela in recent weeks, but no one seems to agree on why huge numbers of people have suddenly taken to the streets. Some observers see the demonstrations as a verdict on food and medicine shortages, inflation and economic stagnation. Others see them as the tantrum of a retrograde former elite bent on nullifying the results of the last election. The government, for its part, is sticking to the old script: Venezuela is falling victim to a fascist conspiracy cooked up by American officials who are terrified of its revolutionary aspirations.

headline: Connecticut Plans to Market Health Exchange Expertise
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The next chapter in an insurance marketplace’s success story: offering technology and services to other states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Connecticut has been so successful in getting people to sign up for health insurance through its online marketplace that it is setting up a consulting business to help other states build and operate websites where people can compare and buy private insurance policies.

headline: The Capture of Chapo Guzmán
abstract: The United States and Mexico share a responsibility for the tragedy that spawned criminals like Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the world’s most elusive drug lord.
lead_paragraph: Many Mexicans may have found it hard to believe that it was really him. That the pudgy little man with the Super Mario mustache being marched into a helicopter by a masked marine with gloved hand firmly on his neck was El Chapo, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the world’s most wanted, most elusive drug lord.

headline: Apple’s Serious Security Issue: Update Your iPhone or iPad Immediately
abstract: A serious security flaw in Apple’s Safari browser means web sessions you thought were secure might not be. There’s a fix for iOS: go get it now.
lead_paragraph: This week, Apple rushed out a patch for its iOS 7 and iOS 6 operating systems to fix a serious security issue. Before I explain further, let me just say this: If you’ve gotten the prompt to update and you haven’t, do it now. If you’re still running older versions of iOS on your iPhone, iPod, or iPad, update now.

headline: A License to Discriminate
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Editorials']
abstract: A veto-worthy Arizona bill would authorize ill-treatment of gay people in the name of religion.
lead_paragraph: There are 17 states where it is legal for same-sex couples to marry, and there is no evidence that the accelerating progress toward equality has compromised anyone’s freedom to worship or hold religious beliefs.

headline: Scottish Oil and Gas an Issue in Vote on Independence
abstract: Alex Salmond, Scotland’s first minister, who supports independence, and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, who does not, also differ on the future of oil and gas reserves in the North Sea.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — They have disagreed over whether an independent Scotland could retain the British pound as its currency. They have sparred over whether Scotland would remain in the European Union if it votes in September to leave the United Kingdom. And on Monday, two of the most prominent advocates of the arguments for and against Scottish independence — Alex Salmond, Scotland’s first minister, and David Cameron, the British prime minister — turned to another crucial economic issue at stake in the battle: the future of the still-substantial oil and gas reserves in the North Sea.

headline: Prosecutors Talk to Mayor of Fort Lee
abstract: Mayor Mark Sokolich met last week with the federal prosecutors investigating the closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge in September, his lawyer said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Fort Lee, N.J., met last week with federal prosecutors investigating the closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge in September, his lawyer said on Monday.

headline: Ukraine’s Uncertain Future
abstract: Europe, the United States and Russia can play a role in preventing war in a deeply divided country.
lead_paragraph: The venal president of Ukraine is on the run and the bloodshed has stopped, but it is far too early to celebrate or to claim that the West has “won” or that Russia has “lost.” One incontrovertible lesson from the events in Kiev, Ukraine’s capital, is that the deeply divided country will have to contend with dangerous problems that could reverberate beyond its borders.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 25, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, February 25, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “The truly distressing thing about these folks leaving is that they’re the ones who know how to negotiate, know how to legislate, know how to get things done.”

headline: Happy Workers, Healthy Bottom Line
abstract: Are there forms of compensation that are clearly “win-win” – worth more to workers than the cost to employers?

lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — A brochure for the University of Michigan features a vision of multicultural harmony, with a group of students from different racial backgrounds sitting on a verdant lawn, smiling and conversing.

headline: Pension Funds Sue on a Deal Gone Cold
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Alphonse Fletcher Jr., a flashy hedge fund manager, has been accused of running something akin to a Ponzi scheme, and the pension systems that say he misled them are hoping to get their money back.
lead_paragraph: Sitting around a table in Baton Rouge, La., in February 2008, a handful of board members of the Firefighters’ Retirement System of Louisiana heard an investment pitch that would later come back to haunt them.

headline: A Dragon Returns, This Time Onstage
abstract: “Kung Fu,” the new play about Bruce Lee by David Henry Hwang, never achieves the fluid grace in its dialogue and dramaturgy that it does in its action sequences.
lead_paragraph: Fists fly with all the fury an action fan could want. Legs flash from the hip like lightning strikes. Twirling kicks and jabbing arms all but set your own head spinning. The fight sequences in “Kung Fu,” the new play about Bruce Lee by David Henry Hwang, bristle with kinetic drive and an innovative combination of dance and martial arts.

headline: U.S. and Britain Join Forces in Bank Misbehavior Cases
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: British and American authorities investigating bad behavior at large banks have reached an uneasy truce.
lead_paragraph: It seemed to be a thumb in the eye of the Justice Department. Britain last week criminally charged a former Barclays employee suspected of trying to manipulate global interest rates, even though the authorities in London were aware that the employee had been assisting American prosecutors in a related investigation for more than a year.

headline: Role Reversal
abstract: A mixed-up Tuesday with Matthew E. Paronto and Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — There are certain words that pop up time and time again in crosswords. It might be because they’re really common, or it might be because their letters are really helpful in puzzle construction. I tend to think it’s more the latter. That’s why we see fairly specialized words like epee appear in the grid so often.

headline: Two Dolphins’ Paths to a Bullying Scandal
abstract: While Miami’s Richie Incognito has been the leading figure in a bullying scandal, two offensive linemen, John Jerry and Mike Pouncey, served as henchmen, a report found.
lead_paragraph: Three days after Jonathan Martin checked himself into a South Florida hospital for psychiatric help, he received a string of conciliatory messages from Richie Incognito, his Miami Dolphins teammate and tormentor, who asked about his health and said that he missed him.

headline: @GSElevator Tattletale Exposed (He Was Not in the Goldman Elevator)
abstract: The person posting as @GSElevator on Twitter, thought to be a Goldman Sachs employee, is actually a 34-year-old former bond trader in Texas.
lead_paragraph: A three-year parlor game has been taking place on Wall Street to identify the Goldman Sachs employee behind a Twitter account that purports to reveal the uncensored comments overheard in the firm’s elevators.

headline: Bobby Jindal After Meeting With Obama
abstract: The Louisiana governor accused the president of “waving the white flag” on the American economy.

headline: Israeli Warplanes Strike Near the Border of Syria and Lebanon
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Israel has struck Syria at least three times in the past year, according to United States officials, to prevent sophisticated weapons from reaching Hezbollah amid the chaos of Syria’s war.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Israeli warplanes launched two raids near the Syrian-Lebanese border late Monday, according to Lebanon’s National News Agency, raising speculation that Israel might have targeted a weapons convoy to prevent the Syrian government from delivering missiles to its Lebanese ally, Hezbollah.

headline: Rangers’ Darvish a Model of Success for Tanaka
abstract: The Yankees are hoping Masahiro Tanaka, who they signed for $155 million, can match the results of Yu Darvish, who has starred in two seasons in Texas.
lead_paragraph: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Would you believe that the first batter Yu Darvish faced in live competition this spring was named Tanaka? He was a nonroster infielder, Kensuke Tanaka, and he did not inspire an intense winter bidding war. But as Darvish pitched the first inning of the Texas Rangers’ first intrasquad game on Monday, it was hard to miss the link.

headline: Rodriguez Still Belongs to Union Despite Lawsuit Rancor, Director Says
abstract: The new director of the M.L.B. players union said that “the page has been turned” on Alex Rodriguez’s short-lived lawsuit that implicated the union and a respected former director.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — During his one season with the Yankees, in 2004, Tony Clark, now the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, was teammates with Alex Rodriguez. It was 10 years ago, a season that ended in excruciating defeat for the Yankees, who were beaten by the Red Sox in the American League Championship Series.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Hats and Caps', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Sunglasses']

headline: Injuries at the Olympics Deplete Several Rosters
abstract: Some of the N.H.L.’s top scorers were among the players who left Sochi in far worse shape than when they arrived.
lead_paragraph: The most palpable effect of the Olympics on N.H.L. teams’ performance is through injuries. The toll in Sochi was high.

headline: Wary Stance From Obama on Ukraine
abstract: While George W. Bush was inspired by Ukraine’s 2004 revolution, Barack Obama has approached the unrest of 2014 with a more clinical detachment aimed at avoiding instability.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Televisions around the White House were aglow with pictures of Ukrainians in the streets, demanding to be heard and toppling a government aligned with Russia. It was an invigorating moment, and it spurred a president already rethinking his approach to the world.

headline: Young Mets Pitcher Is Quietly on the Rise
abstract: Rafael Montero, who will start the Mets’ first exhibition game Friday, has earned praise for his excellent mechanics.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — In the middle of the Mets’ clubhouse here, two of the organization’s brightest pitching prospects have their lockers next to each other. To the left is Noah Syndergaard, a 6-foot-6-inch, 230-pound 21-year-old from Texas, who is hard to miss and has already received much attention and praise this spring.

headline: Simón Díaz, Venezuelan Folk Musician Heard Worldwide, Dies at 85
abstract: For over 50 years Mr. Díaz was a presence in the cultural life of Venezuela and surrounding countries, “Uncle Simón” to fans of his cuatro music, radio and television shows and movies.
lead_paragraph: Simón Díaz, one of Venezuela’s most popular singers and comedians who also earned recognition worldwide for his prowess as a player of the cuatro, a guitar-like instrument, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Caracas. He was 85.

headline: De Blasio Answers Critics on Road Safety
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio was questioned by reporters after a television news crew filmed his chauffeur-driven car breaking traffic rules, only days after he announced a street safety campaign.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio was questioned by reporters after a television news crew filmed his chauffeur-driven car breaking traffic rules, only days after he announced a street safety campaign.

headline: This Time, de Blasio Confronts S.U.V. Issue Head-On
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday finally fielded inquiries about his motorcade’s caught-on-camera violations of traffic laws — but he could not resist offering reporters some pointed criticism of his own.
lead_paragraph: Three days after walking out of a news conference as reporters shouted questions at his back, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday finally fielded inquiries about his motorcade’s caught-on-camera violations of traffic laws — but he could not resist offering reporters some pointed criticism of his own.

headline: Seeking Details on Plan to End Traffic Fatalities
abstract: The New York City Council heard testimony Monday on Mayor Bill de Blasio’s ambitious pedestrian safety plan, known as Vision Zero, which is based on the idea that all traffic deaths are preventable.
lead_paragraph: Speed humps. Crossing guards. Police officers on patrol just being more alert to lawbreaking drivers around them.

headline: Just Like His Power, Ukrainian Ex-Leader Vanishes Into Thin Air
abstract: Accused of mass murder, Viktor F. Yanukovych has disappeared, along with a handful of loyalists and perhaps his girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Ukraine’s acting government on Monday declared the former president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, a fugitive sought for mass murder, but it seemed at a loss to find the man whose authority had crumbled over the weekend.

headline: In New Home, Policy Group Gets Big Gift
abstract: Daniel A. D’Aniello gave $20 million to the American Enterprise Institute, which is aiming to increase its staff and expand its conservative mission.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American Enterprise Institute — one of the nation’s oldest conservative think tanks, but one that has never had its own home — is getting financial help for its new headquarters in a stately Dupont Circle building from a $20 million donation by Daniel A. D’Aniello, a co-founder and chairman of the private equity firm the Carlyle Group.

headline: A Sudden Demand for No. 98 Jerseys
abstract: On Monday, inquiries by those eager to buy a Nets jersey with Jason Collins’s name started to multiply. On Tuesday, Collins jerseys will go on sale at the N.B.A.’s retail shop in Manhattan and online.
lead_paragraph: Jason Collins fell asleep Saturday night without a team. On Sunday, he became the Nets’ most publicized player, the first openly gay athlete to play in an N.B.A. game, although one on a 10-day contract.

headline: Corrections: February 25, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 25, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: In Venezuela, Protest Ranks Grow Broader
abstract: In a coordinated action against the government, residents of Caracas and other cities have taken to the streets to protest a litany of problems that have long troubled the country.
lead_paragraph: SAN CRISTÓBAL, Venezuela — As dawn broke, the residents of a quiet neighborhood here readied for battle. Some piled rocks to be used as projectiles. Others built barricades. A pair of teenagers made firebombs as the adults looked on.

headline: A Border City on the Edge of the Law
abstract: Mong La, Myanmar, draws Chinese over the border to gamble, as well as buy ivory and other animal parts, despite official disapproval of the casinos in China.
lead_paragraph: MONG LA, Myanmar — The smuggling route into this rebel-run jungle outpost just over the Chinese border begins on the back of a motorcycle that takes passengers through steeply terraced rubber plantations, and skirts the official crossing before ending at an outdoor market where bedraggled prostitutes mingle with Chinese tourists haggling over tiger claws, bear paws and desiccated squares of elephant skin.

headline: This Is Your Conductor Writing: I’m Sorry
abstract: Michael Shaw, a Metro-North conductor, apologized to commuters for mistakenly instructing them to wait for a train that ended up being canceled on Friday.
lead_paragraph: As the doors opened to the 6:52 a.m. train from New Haven, the single sheets of paper, one on every seat, came quickly into view.

headline: A Lucrative Market in Myanmar
abstract: Mongla market in Myanmar is best known among Chinese tourists for its large selection of rare and endangered animals.
lead_paragraph: Mongla market in Myanmar is best known among Chinese tourists for its large selection of rare and endangered animals.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 24, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Vigilantes, Once Welcome, Frighten Many in Mexico
abstract: Some residents and businessmen, many of whom have provided support to so-called self-defense forces, are now worried those groups will turn on them.
lead_paragraph: LOMBARDÍA, Mexico — They have been hailed as saviors, vigilantes marching into town with military-style rifles and submachine guns, wearing no uniforms and threatening to whip miscreants as they bring order to this lawless Mexican region known as Tierra Caliente, or hot lands.

headline: What Is a Majority Vote in the State Senate? The Answer Goes Beyond Simple Math
abstract: After indictments, resignations and independent-mindedness of one kind or another, vote-counting in the New York State Senate has become more like a calculus problem.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — There has been a curious question bouncing around certain quarters of the New York State Senate: How many votes, exactly, does it take to pass a bill?

headline: Sri Lanka: U.N. Official Seeks International Inquiry
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The United Nations’ human rights chief called for an independent international inquiry into possible war crimes committed during Sri Lanka’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ human rights chief on Monday called for an independent international inquiry into possible war crimes committed during Sri Lanka’s civil war, saying the Sri Lankan government lacks the political will to mount a credible investigation. The United Nations official, Navi Pillay, said “national mechanisms have consistently failed to establish the truth and achieve justice” with respect to the large number of killings and other abuses in the final chapter of the two-decade-long war in 2009 and continuing abuses that include attacks on religious minorities, journalists and human rights activists. She added that an investigation “is fundamentally a question of political will.” Sri Lanka rejected the report. President Mahinda Rajapaksa’s administration called the recommendations “arbitrary, intrusive and of a political nature.”

headline: Mexico: Legal Wrangling Begins Over Drug Kingpin
abstract: Two days after Mexican marines arrested the drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, questions are being asked about whether he will be tried in Mexico or in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Two days after Mexican marines arrested the drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, questions are being asked about whether he will be tried in Mexico or in the United States. Lawyers for Mr. Guzmán, who was charged Sunday with offenses related to organized crime and cocaine trafficking stemming from a 2009 investigation, are seeking an injunction against extradition. Federal officials in Chicago and New York have said they want to try him in those cities, and he faces additional indictments in Texas and Florida. But Mexico’s interior minister, Miguel Ángel Osorio Chong, said Monday that the government’s security cabinet would “make the most appropriate decision.” Mexico’s ambassador to Washington, Eduardo Medina Mora, said Saturday that Mr. Guzmán should face charges in Mexico first. Mr. Guzmán, who is being held in a high-security prison outside Mexico City, escaped from a Guadalajara prison in 2001 and spent almost 13 years as a fugitive.

headline: In Plan to Dump Contaminated Soil, Classic New Jersey Politics Emerge
abstract: The Christie administration appears poised to let a company, Soil Safe, dump millions of tons of petroleum-contaminated soils on a site which lies directly west of Staten Island and the Arthur Kill.
lead_paragraph: CARTERET, N.J. — We slip slided, a zoologist, two environmentalists and I, across ice, snow and mud toward a wire fence with a sign: Environmental Investigation Cleanup.

headline: Dark Side of the Moon

lead_paragraph: Keep time while tracking the many lunar phases with spring’s most out-of-this-world watches.

headline: Five Sweet Stops for Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Just in time for this next round of shows, the inimitable Irish cookbook author and food writer Trish Deseine shares her list of must-hit pâtisseries.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Vogue Paris named the inimitable Irish expat and award-winning cookbook author Trish Deseine one of its 40 “women of the decade.” That they included her alongside icons like Marion Cotillard and Zaha Hadid is a testament to her talent, to be sure, but also a nod to her invaluable contribution to the annals of French cuisine. Deseine’s work, which spans 17 books and a long-running recipe column for French Elle, has succeeded in both lifting the complexity from French home cooking and exhorting fat-free hardliners to consider (and taste) the merits of butter and sugar, which she insists are two of the greatest boons to food.

headline: Remaking Film Comedy With a Straight Face
abstract: Many movie fans would barely recognize Harold Ramis, who died Monday at 69, but as much as anyone, Mr. Ramis invented modern film comedy.
lead_paragraph: Harold Ramis, who died Monday at 69, made everyone around him look better. A startlingly creative distributor of laughs, he was a master orchestrator who knew how to create conditions for funny people to excel.

keywords: ['Consumer Price Index', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Producer Price Index', 'Statistics', 'United States Economy']

lead_paragraph: A new study about police stop-and-frisk encounters in Newark found that one quarter of police stops ended in an arrest or a summons, about twice as often as they do in New York City.

headline: Camels Linked to Spread of MERS Virus in People
abstract: A study suggests that camels are the major source of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, a viral disease that has sickened 182 people and killed 79 of them since it was first detected in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that camels are the major source of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, a viral disease that has sickened 182 people and killed 79 of them since it was first detected in Saudi Arabia in 2012.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SECRETS OF THE VATICAN In February 2013, Pope Benedict XVI resigned, the first pope to do so in nearly 600 years. He left behind a divided Vatican, mired in scandal: a sexual abuse crisis; suspected money laundering and corruption at the Vatican bank; and the leak of internal documents revealing cronyism, power struggles and accusations of blackmail. But has Benedict’s successor, Pope Francis, managed to lift the Roman Catholic church out of crisis? “Frontline” uses undercover footage and interviews with Vatican insiders, abuse victims and whistle-blowers to address that question and others in this 90-minute special, nearly a year in the making. “It is necessary to open the windows of the church, because we need fresh air,” says one of Francis’s closest confidants, Cardinal Óscar Andrés Rodríguez Maradiaga.

headline: Pakistan Bombs Militant Area as Officials Weigh a Wider Offensive
