headline: A Magazine Cover for a Famously Humble Ambassador
abstract: In an interview with the Chinese edition of Men’s Health, Gary Locke, the departing United States ambassador to China, said he could hold a plank position for 51 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Even before he arrived in Beijing, Gary Locke, the United States ambassador, achieved a rare sort of national prominence in China. A 2011 photo of him with his daughter at a Starbucks in the Seattle airport, carrying his own backpack, was widely circulated on Chinese social media sites. Many praised Mr. Locke for his apparent humility — carrying his own bag and trying to pay for his drink with a coupon. Others, including some state media commentators, questioned whether Mr. Locke’s behavior was a carefully calculated display.

headline: @GSElevator’s Big Reveal
abstract: The identity of the person behind the Twitter account @GSElevator, long though to be a Goldman Sachs employee, is actually a 34-year-old former bond trader in Texas. | The Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox is on the verge of collapse. | U.S. and British authorities unite against rate-rigging. | Pension funds sue a hedge fund manager on a deal gone cold. | Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg thinks WhatsApp deal was a steal.
lead_paragraph: @GSELEVATOR EXPOSED  |  For three years, Wall Street has been trying to identify the employee behind the Twitter account @GSElevator, which reported anonymous snippets purportedly overheard in elevators at Goldman Sachs. But it turns out, the tweeter doesn’t work at Goldman and never did, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. In fact, the tweeter is a 34-year-old former bond trader in Texas named John LeFevre.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British police said on Tuesday that they had arrested Moazzam Begg, a former detainee at the American prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, along with three other people on suspicion of terrorism offenses related to the war in Syria, where, intelligence officials say, hundreds of British militants have been drawn to the fight against President Bashar al-Assad.

On social media sites, the yellow, choking air has become something of a meme, as residents post depressing photos of their blackened air purifier filters and hazy urban vistas with comments like #nuclearwinter.

Adding to the Indian government’s worries about the return of violence in the region, particularly among the youth, is the reappearance of Maulana Masood Azhar, the leader of the Pakistani militant group Jaish-e-Muhammad.

headline: The Preschool Parent Interview: An Elevator Pitch for My 2-Year-Old
abstract: Maybe the contrived (some might say insane) atmosphere of the parent-preschool interview was actually helping me to see my daughter as an individual — a useful exercise in “detachment” parenting.
lead_paragraph: We’d just completed the school tour, and, with six other parents, were being escorted into a boardroom. Jon and I had spent the morning asking endless questions. (Do the ages mix? How do you handle separation? Where’s the coffee? No Danish?) Finally, I thought, we could sit back and listen to the preschool’s spiel, doodling with their branded pads and pencils. But the director, sitting at the head of the long table like a C.E.O., began. “Let’s go around,” she said. “One by one, describe your child in one word. Then, explain why this school is a good fit.” My heart galloped. She was asking us to pitch our kids — in public? Though this environment was contrived (some might say insane), it brought up a question I’d been contemplating: What is the best way to talk about my child?

headline: Feminist Tales, Up to a Point
abstract: Paris Opera Ballet is pairing Agnès de Mille's 1948 "Fall River Legend" with Birgit Cullberg's 1950 "Miss Julie" in a program reflecting a preoccupation with social and psychological realism.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The list of important 20th-century female ballet choreographers isn’t long, but Birgit Cullberg, often forgotten today, is certainly on it. Cullberg, for whom the Swedish government formed the eponymous Cullberg Ballet in 1967, was regarded as a major choreographer well into the 1980s. Today, however, her work is almost unknown outside her native country. (Her son, Mats Ek, has achieved far greater renown).

headline: The Sorry State of Campaign Finance in Albany
abstract: New ads compare Albany’s urgent need for public financing to the shabby condition of the Statue of Liberty a few years ago.
lead_paragraph: Campaign finance reform is incredibly important, but, frankly, it’s not very sexy. How do you rouse a full-throated rallying cry for a system that could clean up politics by encouraging more people to run for office? It’s not a bleat against new taxes. It’s not a tale of two cities.

headline: The Secret to a Bulletproof Antidoping Test?
abstract: Stop looking for the drug. Look to the genes.
lead_paragraph: In the lab of Yannis Pitsiladis, a physiologist in Scotland, athletes spend their days injecting synthetic EPO, a popular performance-enhancing drug that tricks bone marrow into churning out more red blood cells, allowing athletes’ bodies to absorb more oxygen. Pitsiladis hasn’t gone rogue. He’s at the forefront of an effort to revolutionize the hunt for dopers in sports by scouring his subjects’ blood cells for a distinctive, long-lasting genetic “fingerprint” left by the drug.

headline: The Goldman Sachs Elevator Stalker Is Revealed — as a Fibber
abstract: A DealBook story failed to mention a 2011 DealBook interview with the mysterious Twitter writer.
lead_paragraph: It’s safe to talk on the elevator again at Goldman Sachs. The author of a snarky Twitter feed — @gselevator — has been revealed as John LeFevre, 34, of Texas, described as a former bond executive. As it turns out, he doesn’t work at Goldman and never did.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Best Apps for Start-Ups
abstract: Advertising on a small budget. Arizona’s bill allowing businesses not to serve certain people. And the sudden popularity of jersey No. 98.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

headline: A Leading Analyst of Global Food Solutions Gets a Deserved Honor
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Food', 'Population', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: A leading analyst and communicator of global food problems and solutions gets a deserved plaudit.
lead_paragraph: I can’t find an unjustified line in the Heinz Award citation for Jonathan Foley, the director of the Institute on the Environment at the University of Minnesota. An excerpt is below, along with links to background on the four other winners of this annual prize, which honors the memory of Senator John Heinz and is given to people improving the human condition and environment through work in areas ranging from poverty alleviation to the arts and sciences.

headline: Times Minute | Inside Yanukovych's Home
abstract: Ukrainians explored the compound of their ousted president, Viktor F. Yanukovych. Also on the Minute, swelling protests in Venezuela and a look at mussels that pose threats in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainians explored the compound of their ousted president, Viktor F. Yanukovych. Also on the Minute, swelling protests in Venezuela and a look at mussels that pose threats in the United States.

headline: Times Minute | Inside Yanukovych’s Home
abstract: Ukrainians explored the compound of their ousted president, Viktor F. Yanukovych. Also on the Minute, swelling protests in Venezuela and a look at mussels that pose threats in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Scene City: Partygoers Come Out of Their Shell
abstract: Art-world types and night-life denizens support the Turtle Conservancy.
lead_paragraph: Art-world types and night-life denizens support the Turtle Conservancy.

headline: F.D.A. Weighs Fertility Method That Raises Ethical Questions
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Babies and Infants', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Birth Defects']
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration is considering a fertility technique that combines the genetic material of three people to avoid certain defects.
lead_paragraph: GAITHERSBURG, Md. — The Food and Drug Administration is weighing a fertility procedure that involves combining the genetic material of three people to make a baby free of certain defects, a therapy that critics say is an ethical minefield and could lead to the creation of designer babies.

headline: Image of the Day: February 25
abstract: A villager transporting milk on a horse cart on the outskirts of Jammu city.

headline: Former City Ballet Dancer to Lead Academy in Los Angeles
abstract: Jenifer Ringer, who retired from New York City Ballet this month, has been named head of the Colburn Dance Academy in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The dancer Jenifer Ringer, who retired this month from New York City Ballet, has been appointed head of the Colburn Dance Academy, a new division of the Colburn School in downtown Los Angeles, The Los Angeles Times has reported.

headline: A Brooklyn Inspiration for ‘Frozen’
abstract: The Oscar-nominated composers Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez say that in some part, inspiration for the songs they wrote for “Frozen” came from Prospect Park.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-nominated composers Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez say that in some part, inspiration for the songs they wrote for “Frozen” came from Prospect Park.

headline: Long Island Developer Recovering; Gunman’s Identity Remains Elusive
abstract: The police continue to look for clues in the attack on Gary Melius, a prominent political patron who was shot in the head on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A day after being shot in the head by a masked gunman, Gary Melius, a well-known Long Island developer and prominent political patron, was recovering on Tuesday, and remarkably lucid.

headline: BlackBerry Chief Demurs on Sale of Messenger Service, for Now
abstract: The prospect of a deal for BlackBerry’s messaging service has helped buoy the ailing smartphone maker’s fortunes. The company’s chief executive hinted that a sale or spinoff may happen, though not quite yet.
lead_paragraph: BlackBerry has had a rough couple of years. But the prospect of a deal for its messaging service, on the heels of Facebook’s blockbuster takeover of WhatsApp, has helped buoy the ailing smartphone maker’s fortunes.

headline: Arguments Against God
abstract: Is the existence of a supreme deity merely unproven? Or is it false?
lead_paragraph: This is the second in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Louise Antony, a professor of philosophy at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst and the editor of the essay collection “Philosophers Without Gods: Meditations on Atheism and the Secular Life.”

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Milan Women’s Shows
abstract: A glimpse at what gals are wearing this season.
lead_paragraph: A glimpse at what gals are wearing this season.

headline: John Lennon Manuscripts Go to Auction
abstract: More than 100 Lennon manuscripts, including short stories, poems and line drawings, will be auctioned at Sotheby’s in New York in June.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 John Lennon manuscripts, including short stories, poems and line drawings, most of them produced for the two books Lennon published during his lifetime, “In His Own Write” (1964) and “A Spaniard in the Works” (1965), will be auctioned at Sotheby’s in New York on June 4.

headline: Newcomers in Bidding Fight for Catskills Casino Weigh Site Closer to New York City
abstract: As developers focus on Orange County, which critics say needs an economic boost less than other parts of the state, competition and tension are mounting.
lead_paragraph: The battle to build a potentially lucrative $500 million casino resort amid the wooded hills and craggy economy of the Catskills has been a gentlemanly affair, with a half-dozen rivals gently competing for one, if not two state licenses for the region.

headline: At Helmut Lang, a Changing of the Guard
abstract: Michael and Nicole Colovos leave as creative directors at Helmut Lang.
lead_paragraph: The guard has changed at Helmut Lang. The label announced today that its creative directors, the husband-and-wife team Michael and Nicole Colovos, will leave after eight years in the post.

headline: No Bailout for Bitcoin Holders
abstract: The distance from the official world is great enough that Mt. Gox customers are almost totally on their own, writes Edward Hadas of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that the leading stockbroker in a country closed its doors without giving any reason. Its clients would be in a panic and customers of rival firms would be very nervous. That is exactly what has happened to Bitcoin, the leading pseudo-currency.

headline: Lexus Ranked No. 1 on Consumer Reports’ Annual Brand Report Cards
abstract: Japanese brands take seven of the top 10 slots, joined by three German manufacturers; American automakers take the bottom five.
lead_paragraph: For the second year, Lexus, Toyota’s luxury brand, earned the top overall score in the Consumer Reports’ Car Brand Report Cards, the publication announced Tuesday. Honda’s Acura luxury division took second place, and Audi was third.

headline: Study Links Temperature to a Peruvian Glacier’s Growth and Retreat
abstract: Scientists from Dartmouth say heat, not other factors like diminished snowfall, is the prime culprit in the melting of the Peruvian Quelccaya ice cap.
lead_paragraph: Sitting on a flat volcanic plain 18,000 feet above sea level, the great Quelccaya ice cap of Peru is the largest piece of ice in the tropics. In recent decades, as scientists have watched it melt at an accelerating pace, it has also become a powerful symbol of global warming.

headline: Navalny Is Convicted of Resisting Arrest at Moscow Protest, Despite Video Evidence
abstract: Three Russian dissidents arrested during protests in Moscow argued that images posted on social networks undermined police claims that they had resisted arrest or waved banners.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:31 p.m. | As my colleague Andrew Roth reports from Moscow, the dissident blogger Aleksei A. Navalny was sentenced to seven days in jail on Tuesday after a judge found him guilty of resisting arrest at a protest in Moscow the night before. The conviction of the activist lawyer, despite visual evidence posted on his blog that appeared to show him going peacefully into custody, raised concerns that Mr. Navalny could face a much longer term in jail in one of the other cases filed against him for what he insists are political reasons.

headline: Are the New ‘Golden Age’ TV Shows the New Novels?
abstract: Adam Kirsch and Mohsin Hamid discuss whether shows like “The Sopranos” and “The Wire” can be compared to the novels of writers like Charles Dickens and Henry James.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Mohsin Hamid discuss whether TV shows like “The Sopranos” and “The Wire” can be compared to the novels of writers like Charles Dickens and Henry James.

headline: California Endangered Species: Plastic Bags
keywords: ['Shopping Bags', 'Environment', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Plastics', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Lawmakers are working to make the state the first to approve a blanket ban on single-use plastic bags, long viewed as a symbol of environmental wastefulness.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On a recent drizzly day, Esha Moya found herself standing outside a grocery store in South Los Angeles, her half-dozen paper bags falling apart in the rain, wishing she had a few small items that had been free and plentiful her entire life but are now banned in this city: plastic shopping bags.

headline: ‘Late Night’ Gets Sunny, and a Family Tree Grows
abstract: Seth Meyers was at ease in his debut as host of “Late Night,” which was not surprising, considering all the ties there are at NBC with his former boss Lorne Michaels.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Fallon felt the need to explain how a monologue works when he became the new host of “The Tonight Show.” Seth Meyers, 40, who on Monday took Mr. Fallon’s place on “Late Night,” was more relaxed and self-mocking, telling viewers not to expect anything too new. Or, as he put it, “I’m going to shake stuff up and open this thing with a monologue!”

headline: Audra McDonald to Return to Broadway as Billie Holiday
abstract: The five-time Tony Award winner Audra McDonald will star in the musical play “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill.”
lead_paragraph: The five-time Tony Award winner Audra McDonald will make an unexpected return to Broadway this spring — in time to qualify for the 2014 Tonys — to play Billie Holiday in the musical play “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill,” its producers announced on Tuesday. While the show had been in the works for the 2014-15 theater season, the unusually swift closing of the Broadway play “Bronx Bombers” provided a theater, Circle in the Square, which also happened to suit the intimate nightclub setting of “Lady Day.” Performances will begin March 25 with an opening night of April 13. It is a limited engagement, scheduled to run for 10 weeks, or 70 performances.

headline: Venezuelans Document Unrest
abstract: Despite government efforts to minimize news coverage of the growing protests, residents are presenting proof on social media.
lead_paragraph: The student protests that began just a few weeks ago in Venezuela have swept the country, as my colleague William Neuman reports, evolving into the biggest demonstrations seen since the death of the longtime leader Hugo Chávez last year.

headline: Geithner’s Book Has a Title: ‘Stress Test’
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Books and Literature', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The title gives a flavor of the upcoming memoir by Timothy F. Geithner, who, as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and then as Treasury secretary, was a central player in the government’s effort to fight the financial crisis and economic recession.
lead_paragraph: For the title of his memoirs, Timothy F. Geithner has employed a somewhat wonky phrase evocative of the financial crisis: “Stress Test.”

headline: Apollo’s Co-Founder Sees Opportunities to Invest in Distressed Debt
abstract: Private equity firms don’t have to have a “global recession to have good distressed opportunities,” Leon Black, co-founder of Apollo Global Management, said at the SuperReturn International conference in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN – Despite a frenetic period of sales and spin-offs, Leon Black, the co-founder of Apollo Global Management, said Tuesday that there were still attractive opportunities for private equity firms to invest in distressed debt.

headline: Nissan Recalls 13,500 Frontier Pickups for Potential Fire Hazard
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: An incorrectly installed circuit breaker could cause a short circuit and fire; Yamaha and Mitsubishi recall vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Nissan is recalling about 13,500 Frontier pickup trucks from the 2012-14 model years for a possible fire hazard, the automaker said in a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: What’s Happening off the Runway During Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Everything you need to enjoy the last leg of shows this season, from a delicious meal of fresh fish and French veggies to a yoga class in your hotel room.
lead_paragraph: Paris Fashion Week begins today. And while the fashion set may be feeling the lag of the final leg of shows, the City of Light is geared up to stimulate and pamper wary showgoers when they’re off duty. Here, a guide to surviving (and enjoying) the festivities.

headline: Sri Lanka Denounces Push to Open War Inquiry
abstract: The government said the call by the United Nations’ top human rights official reflected a “preconceived, politicized and prejudicial agenda.”
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Sri Lanka’s government on Tuesday forcefully rejected a call for an international war crimes investigation into the country’s bloody civil war, adding to tensions with the United Nations’ human rights body.

headline: Aid Group Sees Daunting Obstacles to Health Care for Afghans
abstract: Doctors Without Borders in Afghanistan released a study on 800 patients and found that 18 percent knew someone who died because they could not reach medical care.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The patients in the four hospitals run by Doctors Without Borders in Afghanistan are the lucky ones, by all accounts, having arrived at well-stocked facilities that maintain international standards with high-quality free care.

headline: Truth and a Prize Emerge From Lies About Hoffman
abstract: After the death of Philip Seymour Hoffman, The National Enquirer quoted his friend David Bar Katz, but Mr. Katz had not spoken with The Enquirer. A settlement followed, and it will fund a new playwriting award.
lead_paragraph: Herding his three younger sons out the door to school on Feb. 5, David Bar Katz was stopped for a moment by his eldest, who was browsing the Internet.

headline: Elliott Raises Bid for Riverbed to $3.3 Billion
abstract: The hedge fund Elliott Management raised its bid for Riverbed Technology on Tuesday and continued to criticize the networking equipment company for failing to begin a process to sell itself.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:48 p.m. |

headline: Orange-Currant Scones
abstract: Julia Moskin shows how to master the art of making sweet, tender scones with a firm crust and a soft, crumbly texture.
lead_paragraph: Julia Moskin shows how to master the art of making sweet, tender scones with a firm crust and a soft, crumbly texture.

headline: Cédric Charlier: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: In His Words | Stillness in the Move
abstract: Teju Cole’s new book extols the streets of Lagos, Nigeria, where he spent his youth. Here, he expounds on what’s so great about living in New York.
lead_paragraph: Teju Cole’s new book extols the streets of Lagos, Nigeria, where he spent his youth. Here, he expounds on what’s so great about living in New York.

headline: Tax Overhaul Plan Faces Key Hurdles
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A proposal by Dave Camp of Michigan, the top Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, to simplify the tax code is coming under scrutiny from fellow Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The proposal by the top Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee to overhaul and simplify the nation’s tax code is already coming under scrutiny from fellow Republicans, with at least one party leader, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, saying the plan has no chance.

headline: Sochi Performances That Deserve a Mention, if Not a Medal
abstract: A look back at some of the best and worst performances of the Sochi Games, on the snow and ice and in the air.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The first Winter Olympics by the Black Sea ended Sunday after 98 events, abundant sunshine, occasional fog and one more gold medalist than expected because of a tie in the women’s downhill between Tina Maze and Dominique Gisin.

headline: Biscuits and Scones Share Tender Secrets
abstract: A bit of sugar and an egg are all that separate biscuits from scones. Don’t tell the purists.
lead_paragraph: The American scone is a confection in crisis. Puffy and pale, supersized and supersweet, it has lost its purpose. Is it a muffin? Is it a pastry? Does it exist to be frosted with icing, or spread with jam — or only to crumble into the crevices of car upholstery?

headline: Brazil Real Estate Start-Up Draws U.S. Investment
abstract: Amid continuing concerns about Brazil’s sputtering economy, the Dragoneer Investment Group of San Francisco has made its first investment in an Internet company in the country, leading a $12.75 million round in VivaReal, an online real estate classifieds start-up.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Amid continuing concerns about Brazil’s sputtering economy, the Dragoneer Investment Group of San Francisco has made its first investment in an Internet company here, leading a $12.75 million round in VivaReal, an online real estate classifieds start-up, the companies said on Tuesday.

headline: In Ukraine, Both Sides Exploit Jewish History
abstract: Sieg Heil salutes were seen around Maidan Square, but President Putin went too far in comparing the uprising to a “pogrom.”
lead_paragraph: Thanks to extermination and emigration, the Jews of Ukraine, who numbered about 2.7 million at the beginning of the 20th Century, are now down to perhaps 250,000 and falling. But their history is playing an oversized role in the drama of revolution unfolding in Kiev, as both sides exploit them and their memory to gain an upper hand in public opinion.

headline: Justices Rule on Home Searches and Defendants’ Frozen Assets
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled that the police may search homes over the objections of one of the residents and that defendants are not entitled to hearings to gain access to frozen assets to pay lawyers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a pair of 6-to-3 decisions, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that the police may sometimes search homes over the objections of one of their residents and that criminal defendants are not entitled to hearings to try to gain access to frozen assets to pay their lawyers.

headline: U.S. Game in Ukraine Is Moved to Cyprus
abstract: Ukraine’s soccer federation said on Tuesday that it had agreed to move the March 5 friendly to Cyprus for safety reasons, after a request by the United States federation.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s soccer federation announced Tuesday that it would move a March 5 friendly against the United States men’s national team to Cyprus from the eastern city of Kharkiv. The federation said it had agreed to move the match out of Ukraine, after a request from U.S. Soccer, for safety reasons.

headline: It Remembers, You Fold: Packing-List Apps
abstract: Whether you’re absent-minded, detail-oriented or fashion-forward, these apps can help you decide what to pack and when.
lead_paragraph: Can a smartphone help you pack for a vacation?

headline: Cranbury, N.J.: One Town, Many Personalities
abstract: A Middlesex County town with a historic downtown surrounded by residential neighborhoods and agrarian lands.
lead_paragraph: When the Helstrom family decided to downsize last summer, they moved just nine houses away from the home they had been living in for 10 years in Cranbury. Jane Helstrom said it felt as if they had moved not just to a new neighborhood but to another region of the country, such as from New England to Nebraska.

headline: Rajoy Vows to Cut Taxes, Saying Spain Is Recovering
abstract: The prime minister suggested that Spain had turned a corner, after coming out of recession in the third quarter of last year.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Mariano Rajoy, the Spanish prime minister, on Tuesday announced an income-tax cut for low earners and a reduction in social security contributions by employers, citing an economic recovery he said would let Spain shift away from austerity measures.

headline: With ‘Drone to Home’ Service, Netflix Uses Satire Against Amazon
abstract: Riffing on Amazon’s plan to deliver via drone, Netflix’s parody video shows Netflix DVDs being dropped from the sky, sometimes with unfortunate consequences.
lead_paragraph: Netflix on Tuesday released a satirical video promising “Drone to Home” delivery of DVDs to customers, taking an obvious swipe at Amazon’s plan to deliver items to consumers via small octocopters, a.k.a. drones.

headline: Lucy Kirkwood Wins Blackburn Play Prize
abstract: Ms. Kirkwood won the award for her play “Chimerica,” about Chinese-American relations.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Lucy Kirkwood has won this year’s Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, given “to recognize women who have written works of outstanding quality for the English-speaking theater,” for her play “Chimerica.” The award, which is to be presented by the director Phyllida Lloyd on Tuesday night at a ceremony in London, comes with $25,000 and a signed print by the artist Willem de Kooning.

headline: White House Meeting Turns Into a Lightning Round for Obama and Boehner
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner met to discuss a long list of issues, and aides to both men called the rare meeting constructive, but offered no evidence that gridlock is over.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner sat across from each other for an hour on Tuesday in the leather-bound chairs of Mr. Obama’s office and quickly ticked through a remarkably long list of issues.

headline: Bustan Opens on the Upper West Side
abstract: The restaurant will feature the Middle Eastern equivalent of a wood-fired pizza oven, and more restaurant openings.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Anthony Vaccarello: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: The Gun Report: February 25, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the Supreme Court declined to review two cases involving the rights of those under 21 to own handguns. One case involved a Texas law that bars nearly all 18-, 19- and 20-year-olds from obtaining a handgun permit. The other involved a federal law that prohibits licensed firearm dealers from selling handguns to people under 21, which was instituted in 1968 and aimed at diminishing violent crime. Both appeals were filed by the National Rifle Association.

headline: Share Your Experience With Race on Campus
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Social Media']
abstract: Tell us about your experience with race on your campus with the hashtag #TellNYT.
lead_paragraph: For my article today on racism on college campuses, I spoke with students from around the country about how race is still very much an issue for young Americans despite openness to interracial dating, marriage and friendships. I also read dozens of posts on Twitter and other social media platforms and used Facebook to help find people to interview.

headline: Day After Uganda’s Antigay Law Is Signed, a Tabloid Publishes Names
abstract: Fears of a violence were heightened by the publication and photographs of names of gay and lesbian Ugandans, with some people recalling David Kato’s death in 2010.
lead_paragraph: In October 2010, a tabloid newspaper in Uganda called Rolling Stone published a front-page headline: “100 Pictures of Uganda’s Top Homos Leak. Hang Them.”

headline: Considering a New G.M.O.: Baby
abstract: An F.D.A. panel will convene to consider a fertility procedure that genetically modifies a fertilized or unfertilized human egg.
lead_paragraph: From Fear of ‘Designer Babies’ as F.D.A. Weighs Fertility Procedure:

headline: G.M. to Expand Small-Car Recall to 1.4 Million Vehicles
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: By including vehicles mentioned in a 2006 technical service bulletin, G.M. nearly doubled an ignition-switch recall.
lead_paragraph: General Motors will more than double the size of a recall issued this month for an ignition switch defect in some of its small cars, the automaker said in a news release Tuesday. The expansion brings the number of vehicles covered by the recall to nearly 1.4 million in the United States.

headline: Fresh Maine Scallops; Hefty Sandwiches and a Wine Club in Manhattan
abstract: Recommendations for the week of Feb. 25.
lead_paragraph: To Sear: Sea Scallops That Taste Just Like Maine

headline: Starring a (Reluctant) Journalist
abstract: The documentary “Dirty Wars” wasn’t initially supposed to feature the reporter who was unearthing the information. But that was one of many elements that shifted.
lead_paragraph: In the race for the Oscar for best feature documentary, so much attention has been paid to “The Act of Killing” and “The Square” — the first about mass killings in Indonesia, the other about the revolution in Egypt — that a third film about international politics has been overshadowed. But Richard Rowley’s “Dirty Wars” is even more global in its focus, examining clandestine American military operations in places like Afghanistan, Somalia and Yemen.

headline: Creative Writing, via a Workshop or the Big City
abstract: Edited by the gifted novelist (“The Art of Fielding”) and n + 1 editor Chad Harbach, “MFA vs NYC” asks whether fiction writing can, or should, be taught.
lead_paragraph: The four most influential young literary magazines in America, each founded within a few years of the turn of this century, are n + 1, based in Brooklyn; McSweeney’s and its sibling The Believer, both based in San Francisco; and Tin House, based in Portland, Ore. Tell me which you prefer, and I will, more or less, tell you who you are.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Magdalena Frackowiak at Anthony Vaccarello
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Magdalena Frackowiak (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Anthony Turner.

headline: Another Dingell Is Expected to Run for Congress in Michigan
abstract: Debbie Dingell, the wife of Representative John Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who announced his retirement, will declare her intentions on Friday, a person briefed on her plans said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Debbie Dingell, the wife of Representative John Dingell, the Michigan Democrat and longest-serving member of Congress who announced his retirement on Monday, is expected to announce a bid for her husband’s seat.

headline: In Idaho, Thin Snow Means Fat Tires
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Cycling, Mountain Bike', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']
abstract: When snow on the trails is too soft for regular mountain bikes yet too sparse for skiers, fat bikes fill the gap.
lead_paragraph: Snow has been so scant in Idaho this winter that bicycles started showing up in shop windows in the middle of January, and cyclists began booking ski huts during a season when it’s usually backcountry skiers who are seeking accommodations.

headline: Roy Simmons, 57, Lineman Who Later Came Out as Gay, Dies
abstract: Simmons, who played three years for the Giants and went to the 1984 Super Bowl with the Redskins, kept his sexuality a secret until 1992 despite a raucous social life.
lead_paragraph: Roy Simmons, a former offensive lineman for the Giants and the Washington Redskins and one of only a handful of N.F.L. players to have said publicly that they were gay — all after their playing careers ended — died Thursday in his apartment in the Bronx. He was 57.

headline: InterMune Lung Drug Is Successful in New Trial
abstract: The company said it would apply for United States regulatory approval of pirfenidone to treat idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, a scarring of the lungs.
lead_paragraph: A drug being developed to treat a fatal scarring of the lungs has succeeded in an important clinical trial and could become the first medicine to be approved for that disease, known as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

headline: Who Can Consent to a Warrantless Search?
abstract: The Supreme Court issued an important Fourth Amendment ruling on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever been in a home the police urgently wanted to search? What if you disagreed with someone under your own roof about whether to let the cops in without a warrant? That’s the position Roxanne Rojas found herself in one October day in 2009, stuck quite literally in between an abusive boyfriend and police officers in the heat of a robbery investigation.

headline: Obesity Rate for Young Children Plummets 43% in a Decade
abstract: The data, reported in a major federal health survey, offered the first clear evidence that America’s children have turned a corner in the obesity epidemic, and came as a surprise to researchers.
lead_paragraph: Federal health authorities on Tuesday reported a 43 percent drop in the obesity rate among 2- to 5-year-old children over the past decade, the first broad decline in an epidemic that often leads to lifelong struggles with weight and higher risks for cancer, heart disease and stroke.

headline: Regulators Weigh In on Online Educational Services
abstract: Federal regulators say online educational services for schools may use personally identifiable information they collect about students only for the purposes that the schools intended.
lead_paragraph: As school districts around the country increasingly turn to online educational services that can collect and analyze details about how individual students learn, some parents and legislators have been raising questions about whether the personal information collected by such programs is federally protected from being shared or sold by technology vendors.

headline: A Digital Detective
abstract: Alison Chung followed her lifelong love of solving mysteries to found a forensic technology firm.
lead_paragraph: Alison Chung followed her lifelong love of solving mysteries to found a forensic technology firm.

headline: Kiev in Chaos: Teaching About the Crisis in Ukraine
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the political and economic crisis consuming Ukraine, first by getting an overview of the basic facts and then by digging deeper in small research groups.
lead_paragraph: Updated: March 3, 2014

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Cédric Charlier Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Ladies and Gentlemen, the Polls Are Almost Closed
abstract: Academy voting ends today at 5 Pacific standard time.
lead_paragraph: This is it. Soon the equivalent in Oscar circles of the checkered flag  will be waved: at 5 p.m. Pacific Standard Time, voting ends for the 86th Academy Awards. All ballots are due in — the paper versions that some members still prefer, or the online ones, which the majority of the Academy now uses.

headline: Watching TV Without Paying for Cable
abstract: Depending on where you live, an antenna could bring in a lot of free broadcast channels.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is it possible to dump cable and still view my television, even if it is just local channels? I am really tired of paying the cable prices.

headline: An Inside Look at Cooking and Dining in Tel Aviv
abstract: The festival Open Restaurants in Tel Aviv will take guests inside some of the city’s most popular dining destinations.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Tel Aviv tapped into its inner voyeur when it joined the international movement “Houses from Within,” a festival in which residents of some of the city’s most interesting (and opulent) homes fling open their doors and allow the public to visit.

headline: In Performance: Bebe Neuwirth
abstract: The actress sings “Nowadays” from the Kander and Ebb musical “Chicago,” on Broadway at the Ambassador Theater. She is appearing in the show through March 9.
lead_paragraph: The actress sings “Nowadays” from the Kander and Ebb musical “Chicago,” on Broadway at the Ambassador Theater. She is appearing in the show through March 9.

headline: Mixed Results, but Strong Outlook, for Home Depot and Macy’s
abstract: The companies, two of the country’s biggest retailers, partly blamed a stormy January for slow sales, but they did well compared with other retailers.
lead_paragraph: Home Depot and Macy’s, two of the country’s biggest retailers, reported mixed earnings for their fourth fiscal quarters on Tuesday, both partly blaming an unusually cold and stormy January for slow sales. Compared with many retailers, however, the companies did fairly well.

headline: Keyboard and Function Keys Returning to BlackBerry Phones
abstract: “In my first 90 days on the job, I consistently heard from our ardent BlackBerry customers that the hard buttons and track pad are an essential part of the BlackBerry Qwerty experience,” said John S. Chen, the company’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Last year, BlackBerry’s vision of the future was an all-touch-screen phone. Now John S. Chen, who became chief executive and executive chairman after that plan’s spectacular failure, is proposing a return to BlackBerry’s past as its path to the future.

headline: Religious Experience and the Modern Self
keywords: ['Ghosts', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Psychics and Psychic Phenomena']
abstract: On Japanese ghosts, Paul Verhoeven, and the buffered and the porous self.
lead_paragraph: I have a couple of posts coming that aren’t quite direct follow-ups to what I wrote last week about Adam Gopnik’s New Yorker essay on atheism and belief, but deal with issues related to the whole modernity/belief/atheism tangle. For the first one, I wanted to juxtapose two pieces whose intended audiences don’t necessarily overlap that much — a London Review Books essay on Japan and “the ghosts of the tsunami,” and a Grantland career retrospective on the Dutch director Paul Verhoeven, of “Robocop” and “Showgirls” fame.

headline: First Lady Announces After-School Initiative
abstract: The initiative will provide healthy snacks including fruits and vegetables and opportunities for at least 30 minutes of physical activity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama on Tuesday introduced a broad, five-year initiative to make after-school programs a healthier, more active environment for millions of children, saying the changes would also help the children’s performance during the other hours of the day.

headline: Unlikely Partners: Rookie Agents and Gay Player
abstract: If life has been dizzying for Michael Sam since announcing he would try to forge an N.F.L. career as a publicly gay man, it has been no less head-spinning for the men Sam is entrusting to manage it.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Joe Barkett loves to play chess, appreciating how the game rewards those who can think four or five steps ahead, an approach he has applied to his fledgling career as a sports agent. Yet for all the well-prepared plans that Barkett made with Cameron Weiss, his business partner and college friend, their unimaginably sudden rise began with a single, serendipitous keystroke.

headline: G.M. Report Shows Recall Investigation Took 10 Years
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: G.M. says its decade-long investigation into an ignition problem was “not robust enough.”
lead_paragraph: Alan Batey, president of General Motors North America, said Tuesday that the automaker’s nearly decade-long investigation of a defect for which it is now recalling 1.4 million vehicles – and which is related to 13 deaths — “was not as robust as it should have been.” The admission came as the automaker tried to explain to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration why it took so long to recall the vehicles.

headline: In 1930s Britain, an Office Lothario and the Women Who Endure Him
abstract: “London Wall,” a 1931 office comedy by John van Druten, depicts the limited choices available to working women then.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1930s, when the Great Depression had the planet in its grip, the playwright John van Druten could be counted on to provide Broadway audiences with a particular brand of escape: sophisticated modern comedies set amid London’s privileged classes.

headline: Many in China Can Now Have a Second Child, but Say No
abstract: A relaxing of the one-child policy will allow two children in a family when just one parent is an only child, but the cost of child-rearing has given some couples pause.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — After three decades of a Chinese policy that limits most families to one child, many families say they will not take advantage of a major change allowing a second child because of the rising cost of child-rearing.

headline: A Good Ratings Night for Another New NBC Late-Night Show
abstract: The first night of Seth Meyers’s hosting “Late Night” drew 3.4 million viewers, the biggest audience for a Monday show in nine years.
lead_paragraph: NBC’s introduction of its new late-night lineup continued in high gear Monday night as the first edition of the Seth Meyers version of the “Late Night” show opened with strong ratings numbers.

headline: Islamist Militants Blamed for Deadly College Attack in Nigeria
abstract: It was the fourth deadly attack on a Nigerian school by the Boko Haram group in less than a year.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — After herding the female students into a classroom, Islamist militants from the group Boko Haram fatally burned or shot dozens of male students in an attack late Monday on a state college in northeastern Nigeria, officials said on Tuesday. It was the fourth school assault attributed to the group in less than a year.

headline: Mozilla Hopes to Reduce Smartphone Prices Radically
abstract: The announcement this week of new phones that run on Firefox’s mobile operating system represents the latest efforts to offer handset makers an alternative to Google’s Android operating system.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Can a cellphone maker produce a smartphone for just $25?

headline: A Respite From the Season and the Scene
abstract: The cooking at Dover, French in spirit, aims to steer clear of the Brooklyn clichés.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve been keenly aware of needs I didn’t realize I had, like dress shoes with ice cleats, an age-appropriate ski cap, self-shoveling sidewalks and a car that can hop sideways over snowbanks into empty parking spots. With the first bite of my first course at a new restaurant in Brooklyn called Dover, I knew I’d been missing something else, too.

headline: Credit Suisse Helped U.S. Clients Hide Billions in Assets, Senate Report Says
abstract: The report says the bank helped its American customers evade taxes through a variety of means, including opening accounts in the name of shell companies and sending Swiss bankers to the U.S. to secretly recruit new clients.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An elevator controlled remotely. A bank office referred to by its code name. A sheaf of bank statements hidden in the pages of Sports Illustrated.

headline: The Theater of Faith and Doubt, Love and Pain
abstract: Craig Lucas answers questions about his descent into despair, which provided inspiration for his new play, “Ode to Joy,” which he is also directing.
lead_paragraph: Craig Lucas has a romantic comedy about a not so funny topic opening on Thursday at the Cherry Lane Theater. “Ode to Joy,” produced by Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, is about addiction. Mr. Lucas, the prolific writer of “Reckless,” “Prelude to a Kiss,” “Longtime Companion” and the musical collaborations “Marry Me a Little” and “The Light in the Piazza,” also directs the new play, his follow-up to “The Lying Lesson” of last season. In an interview, he talked about the tricky art of keeping things light when the truth is hard to hear. Excerpts from the conversation follow.

headline: Frailty, Thy Name Is ...
abstract: “Legit,” a male-oriented FXX comedy starring Jim Jefferies, opens a second season with its three self-absorbed roommates coping with problems from sex addiction to relationship troubles.
lead_paragraph: There’s something distinctly unpromising about the Australian comedian Jim Jefferies, or rather, the fictional version of himself he plays on the FXX comedy “Legit”: paunchy, with a peculiar ridge of hair and the hesitant manner of a man expecting disaster.

headline: Battle Over London Market Raises Development Issues
abstract: The dispute over the Smithfield Market project underscores broader issues, including the soaring cost of London real estate, the resulting inequality and the challenge of upgrading the infrastructure of culture-rich cities.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Trying to renovate a Victorian market and tack on some offices hip enough for Google in the oldest part of this ancient city is not a task for the weak of heart. Just ask Geoff Harris.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Chad and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Chad, Turkey, North Korea and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Chad, Turkey, North Korea and India.

headline: Canadian Firm Buys Tower on Park Avenue
abstract: An investment group has agreed to pay $575 million for a 33-story tower in Midtown, one of the highest prices ever paid for a Manhattan office building.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian investment firm has agreed to pay $575 million for a 33-story office tower at Park Avenue and 57th Street in the latest indication of a soaring real estate market spurred by foreign investment.

headline: Apple Issues Fix for Security Problem on Macs
abstract: The flaw allows a hacker to penetrate communications a user would have believed were safely encrypted.
lead_paragraph: Apple has finally issued a security update to its OS X Mavericks software for Macintosh computers, patching a bug that could have let hackers eavesdrop on supposedly encrypted connections and steal everything from usernames and passwords to location data.

headline: The Official, if Possibly Unnecessary, End of Acetaminophen Use During Pregnancy
keywords: ['Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Babies and Infants', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Research']
abstract: A study says children whose mothers used acetaminophen during pregnancy were at higher risk of receiving a hospital diagnosis of hyperkinetic disorders, but caution is needed in considering its results.
lead_paragraph: This is the kind of research result that changes behavior.

headline: S.&P., in Lawsuit Defense, Seeks Documents About Obama-Geithner Meetings
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Standard & Poor’s is seeking information about certain meetings between President Obama and Timothy F. Geithner in 2011, hoping the details will help show that a lawsuit filed by the government in 2013 against the company was done in retaliation for a ratings downgrade of American debt.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | For Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary, meetings with President Obama were nothing out of the ordinary.But one such meeting has taken on outsize significance for Standard & Poor’s, the ratings agency that is defending itself against the government’s claims of fraud.

headline: Beauty in the Details
abstract: The Royal Opera House’s “The Sleeping Beauty” shows that the company pays attention to the little things when presenting a classic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Watching Elizabeth McGorian and Thomas Whitehead performing the Queen and Cattalabutte in “The Sleeping Beauty” at the Royal Opera House, it’s easy to think, “Only with the Royal Ballet.” The Queen is the loving, solicitous mother of Princess Aurora, the heroine whose finger prick casts the court into a hundred-year sleep; Cattalabutte is the fussy, officious master of ceremonies, whose oversight enrages the fairy Carabosse, causing all the trouble.

headline: Why Most Small-Business Owners Will See Premiums Rise Under A.C.A.
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: But how significant will those increases be?
lead_paragraph: A new report from the federal government that says more small employers will see premiums increase than fall under the Affordable Care Act appears to have put the Obama administration on the defensive once again. But the report is remarkable as much for what it reveals about the current state of the small-group market as for how it might look under Obamacare, as the law is commonly known.

headline: You Think You Know Your Neighbors, but ...
abstract: “The Americans,” about Soviet spies in the United States in the Reagan years, remains as engrossing for the complexity of the characters as for their secret dealings.
lead_paragraph: “The Americans,” which returns Wednesday on FX, has a sly title that suggests how deeply deceptive this thriller is at its core.

headline: A Wasteland, With Aliens
abstract: Joe Begos’s horror movie “Almost Human” should not be confused with the Fox television drama of the same name.
lead_paragraph: “Almost Human,” a cheap-looking amalgam of “Fire in the Sky” (1993) and Philip Kaufman’s vigorous 1978 remake of “Invasion of the Body Snatchers,” should not be confused with the Fox television drama of the same name. That show features quirky writing, confident actors and at least one character who inspires empathy; this project, on the other hand, has clearly diverted too much of its small budget toward special effects.

headline: Stars! Or So They Can Seem
abstract: An artist and a villain square off in a spectacle of light and darkness in “iLuminate,” at New World Stages.
lead_paragraph: Before a recent performance of “iLuminate,” I felt like a schoolgirl who’d stolen an advance copy of the final exam. Having seen the show’s first version six months ago and read its publicity material, I knew what was going to unfold.

headline: Curtain Call | Milan Fashion Week
abstract: To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.
lead_paragraph: To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.

headline: After Inquiry, SAC Capital Says It Intends to Hire a Trading Monitor
abstract: Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire hedge fund owner, is looking to hire a former prosecutor or securities regulator to monitor trading at his investment firm after the federal government’s insider trading investigation.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:01 p.m. |

headline: Plaza-Saving Efforts Earn Honors for Groups
abstract: The Cultural Landscape Foundation and the Minnesota chapter of Docomomo US have received the Advocacy Award of Excellence.
lead_paragraph: For their efforts to save Peavey Plaza in Minneapolis from the wrecking ball, the Preservation Alliance of Minnesota, the Cultural Landscape Foundation and the Minnesota chapter of Docomomo US have received the Advocacy Award of Excellence, one of three inaugural Modernism in America Awards. Established by Docomomo US, a nonprofit conservation organization dedicated to the modernist movement, the juried awards honor those working to preserve and rehabilitate midcentury architecture and design.

headline: Hiding in the Shadows, Scavenging for Clues in Every Drawer
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)', 'PlayStation 3 (Video Game System)', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)', 'Xbox 360 (Video Game System)']
abstract: Thief is a stealth video game laden with locks to pick, tunnels to crawl through and secret passageways to explore.
lead_paragraph: On a widely discussed and admired recent episode of HBO’s “True Detective,” Rust Cohle, played by Matthew McConaughey, escaped from drug dealers, white supremacists and law enforcement through a series of improbable actions. He hid between two scraggly bushes, sneaked beneath a clothesline, paused behind a tree trunk, dashed into the shadowy section of a street and occasionally persuaded his pursuers to give up the chase by beating them into submission. At one point, Cohle waited quietly, gun aloft, against a wall as four armed men burst from a nearby door — only to run in the opposite direction.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Milan Fashion Week Take Their Bows
abstract: To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.
lead_paragraph: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.

abstract: The president said two new manufacturing institutes would be located in Chicago and Detroit in an effort to create high-quality jobs.
lead_paragraph: The president said two new manufacturing institutes would be located in Chicago and Detroit in an effort to create high-quality jobs.

keywords: ['Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Mortgages', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']

lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley has tentatively agreed to pay $275 million to resolve a federal securities investigation related to subprime mortgage bonds the investment firm underwrote in 2007.

headline: A Buyout Offer That Raises Questions of Board Fairness and Duty
abstract: American Financial’s actions as it tries to buy out minority shareholders of one of its insurance subsidiaries appear deeply flawed, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: If you happen to control a public company and want to buy out the remaining shareholders, avoid the mistakes made by the American Financial Group in its attempt to squeeze out the minority at the National Interstate Corporation.

headline: Choose Your Monetary Adventure, Mt. Gox Edition
abstract: The bandit factor.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin was, of course, created in part to cater to libertarian dreams – to provide a way to store your wealth where governments can’t steal it through taxation or currency debasement.

headline: Tour’s Director Criticizes New ‘Annie’
abstract: If the Broadway revival of “Annie,” a financial failure, is to go on tour, it will be with a non-Equity cast and the show’s 1977 director.
lead_paragraph: The $12 million Broadway revival of “Annie” closed last month as a critical disappointment and commercial failure. But it turns out that the musical’s hard-knock life continues.

headline: Knights in Shining Opera, at the Met
abstract: Gotham Chamber Opera’s performances in galleries at the Metropolitan Museum shed new light on the surrounding art.
lead_paragraph: They did a Haydn opera about a supposed trip to the moon at the Hayden Planetarium, a rare Baroque piece featuring a decadent Roman emperor at a decadent downtown nightclub, and a Daniel Catán opera set in a poisonous garden at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Argentina Takes Its Debt Case to the U.S. Supreme Court
abstract: In 2001, Argentina defaulted on $80 billion in government bonds, and some bondholders are still trying to collect.
lead_paragraph: Argentina has now staked the future of its debt, and perhaps its financial fate, with the United States Supreme Court. Yes, you read that right. Argentina wants the nine justices to weigh in on a case involving its obligations to holders of its government bonds and to resolve the mess created by a handful of federal judges.

headline: A View From Iran: ‘Respect Rather Than Sanctions’

headline: Study Finds Limited Benefit to Some ‘Medical Homes’
abstract: RAND Corporation researchers said that small or medium-size pilot practices did not always meet expectations of improved care, but that they could still benefit patients.
lead_paragraph: You may have heard the term “medical home” to describe a way of organizing doctors’ practices to provide more comprehensive, less costly, patient-friendly treatment. Insurance companies often offer more money to practices that become recognized as medical homes, which use a team approach to coordinate care. States are even looking to medical homes to help save money in their Medicaid programs.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Cédric Charlier’s Side-Swept Locks
abstract: An edgy rock’n’roll hair style looked wet but wasn’t, so as not to ruin the furs on the runway.
lead_paragraph: For the Cédric Charlier runway, the hairstylist Laurent Philippon created a look based on a severe part. Starting above the left eye, he divided the hair all the way back, in a perfect line, to the bottom of the neck — a style inspired by the coifs of film noir heroines and silent-movie stars. To the left of the divide, tousled locks were tucked behind the ear and draped naturally over the shoulder. And on the right, they were pushed forward over the ear for what Philippon described as a “rock ‘n’ roll twist.” “I loaded the hair with Bb.Gel from Bumble and Bumble,” he explained while combing the product through and then ruffling it with his fingers. To finish, he used Bumble and Bumble’s new City Swept spray, which provided “beautiful natural shine.” The texture of this look is in fact quite stiff, but it offers the illusion of soft, wet hair. “I would have left it wet,” Philippon noted, “but we had fur.”

headline: As Rest of Economy Weakens, Chinese Exports Surge
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Steel and Iron']
abstract: With the real estate boom starting to fade, Chinese companies once again see the future in overseas markets.
lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — The vast steel mill here on the south bank of the Pearl River was supposed to have closed more than three years ago, its labyrinth of rusty chutes and sheds bulldozed and its huge cranes with gigantic steel claws dismantled for scrap.

headline: Andrew Silberfein
abstract: Mr. Silberfein, 49, is the chief executive of Rouse Properties, a publicly traded real estate investment trust based in New York.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Silberfein, 49, is the chief executive of Rouse Properties, a publicly traded real estate investment trust based in New York. The company owns and operates 34 malls in 21 states, or around 24.5 million square feet of retail property.

headline: Ukrainian Journalists Launch YanukovychLeaks
abstract: Hundreds of documents found at the abandoned presidential retreat outside Kiev since Ukraine’s leader fled the capital have been posted on a new site, YanukovychLeaks.
lead_paragraph: Viktor Yanukovych may have vanished early Saturday from Ukraine’s presidential palace outside Kiev, but not without a trace. His entourage left behind security-camera images of a hasty flight from the lavish compound, and something else — tens of thousands of apparently incriminating documents that were still floating near a dock at the waterfront residence when journalists and curious spectators arrived.

lead_paragraph: Bank of America said that it was facing two new investigations related to its activities in foreign currency exchange markets and its handling of government-backed mortgages in the United States.

headline: Solar Industry Jump-Starts a Revival in California
abstract: Oakland’s Jack London Square draws energy from Sungevity and the alternative energy start-ups it nurtures.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Back in 2009, when Danny Kennedy was looking for office space for the fast-growing solar services company he had co-founded, his venture capital investors recommended setting up shop in one of the “Twitterville kinds of areas” south of Market Street in San Francisco.

headline: Abolitionist or Terrorist?
abstract: Why Denmark Vesey remains a divisive figure in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N.Y. — ON Feb. 15, a group of activists in Charleston, S.C., unveiled a life-size statue of Denmark Vesey, a black abolitionist who was executed in 1822 for leading a failed slave rebellion in the city.

headline: With Syria, Diplomacy Needs Force
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Assad won’t negotiate a cease-fire without military pressure.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE conventional wisdom about Syria is that nothing can be done. It is said that military action would be either perverse — bringing the jihadists in the opposition to power — or futile, failing to tip the balance against the government of President Bashar al-Assad. Using force, it is argued, would also jeopardize other strategic objectives, like securing a lasting nuclear deal with Syria’s supporter Iran.
