headline: U.S. Orders Tests on Rail Shipments of Oil
keywords: ['Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Recent accidents have drawn attention to the risks of shipping large quantities of crude oil in unpressurized railcars.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Tuesday ordered shippers to properly test and classify crude oil from the productive Bakken region before loading it onto freight trains, a move meant to tighten regulatory standards after a spate of derailments and explosions that highlighted the hazards of carrying crude oil on rails.

headline: For Hotels.com’s Campaign, the Answer Was Obvious
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Amid characters like Dos Equis’s Most Interesting Man in the World and the Geico gecko, Hotels.com is personifying its new ad theme.
lead_paragraph: TO the pantheon of brand mascots that includes the Most Interesting Man in the World, who pitches Dos Equis beer, and the Wisest, who peddles Campbell’s Soup, a website for booking accommodations is hoping to add an advertising character meant to be regarded as the Most Obvious Man in the World.

headline: How the West Can Shape Ukraine
abstract: Can the U.S. and the E.U. foster democracy without antagonizing Russia?

headline: Trust Eroded, Obama Looks Beyond Karzai
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: President Obama is apparently resigned to dealing with the next Afghan president on troop withdrawals and training, since President Hamid Karzai has refused to sign a long-term security agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, apparently resigned to President Hamid Karzai’s refusal to sign a long-term security agreement with the United States before he leaves office, told him in a phone call on Tuesday that he had instructed the Pentagon to begin planning for a complete withdrawal of American troops from Afghanistan by the end of the year.

headline: A Luxury for the Mets: Two Promising Catchers
abstract: The Mets chose Kevin Plawecki, a top college catcher, 35th over all in 2012. About six months later, they acquired Travis d’Arnaud, then one of baseball’s best young catching prospects, in a trade.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — With the 35th overall pick of the 2012 amateur draft, the Mets chose Kevin Plawecki, who was among the top catchers in college baseball. He was polished at the plate and behind it. He could get on base, flash some power and manage his pitchers. He had all the makings of a major league catcher.

headline: A Nonprofit Lender Revives the Hopes of Subprime Borrowers
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Personal Finances', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Mortgages', 'Series']
abstract: An unconventional lender is trying to make it easier for low-income people to buy houses despite the tighter requirements that other lenders adopted after the mortgage bust.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About 200 people struggling to become homeowners filled the pews of Plymouth Congregational church on a recent Saturday morning. Some were self-employed, others short on a down payment, many branded by credit problems. Mortgage lenders would have thrown money at them a decade ago. Now, the chastened industry turns them away.

headline: The Bane and the Boon of For-Profit Colleges
keywords: ['For-Profit Schools', 'Graduation Rates', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: As these institutions play an indispensable role in helping low-income students, new regulations should look to improve the sector, not shrink it.
lead_paragraph: Marc Jerome, the executive vice president of Monroe College, says his business is being unfairly targeted as corrupt.

headline: Turks Are Glued to a Sensational Drama, This One Political
abstract: Although the Turkish period drama “The Magnificent Century” has become an obsession in the country, the show gripping many Turks is their nation’s own political crisis.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turks have always loved a good soap opera. Years ago the fixation was “Dallas,” and Turks of a certain age still refer to a woman who drinks too much as Sue Ellen, the boozy character on that show. More recently, the Turkish drama “The Magnificent Century,” about palace intrigue and romance in an Ottoman sultan’s harem, became an obsession here and in the Middle East.

headline: Back on His Feet and Leading a New Team
abstract: After a series of injuries, the highly recruited guard Maurice Creek transferred from Indiana to George Washington, where he is carrying the Colonials to a surprisingly strong showing.
lead_paragraph: Mike Lonergan, then the coach of Vermont, was scouting an A.A.U. tournament several years ago when he noticed Maurice Creek, a 6-foot-5 guard. Creek was on the same team as a player Lonergan was trying to recruit, and as Lonergan watched Creek effortlessly convert jump shots, some thoughts crossed the coach’s mind: He is a really good shooter, but I will never coach him. He is too highly rated.

headline: Nuclear Waste Repository Set to Reopen After Leak
abstract: Monitors of the mine near Carlsbad, N.M., assured anxious residents gathered at a town-hall meeting that there was no health risk.
lead_paragraph: Almost two weeks after an unexplained puff of radioactive materials forced the closing of a salt mine in New Mexico that is used to bury nuclear bomb wastes, managers of the mine are planning to send workers back in and are telling nearby residents that their health is safe.

headline: Ivan Nagy, Star of American Ballet Theater, Is Dead at 70
abstract: Mr. Nagy was especially celebrated as a partner of the world’s leading ballerinas.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Nagy, a dancer of riveting noble presence who became one of American Ballet Theater’s most popular stars in the 1970s as an acclaimed partner to great ballerinas, died on Saturday in Budapest. He was 70.

headline: Author’s Unmasking Won’t Stop Book
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Literary Fraud', 'Hoaxes and Pranks']
abstract: The revelation that the writer behind the popular Twitter feed @GSElevator had never worked for Goldman Sachs appeared to undermine his credibility, if not the premise of the book.
lead_paragraph: In a book proposal recently sent to publishers, the writer known only as @GSElevator — a popular Twitter account consisting of things purportedly overheard inside Goldman Sachs’s elevators — bragged about being aggressively recruited by the bank.

headline: Don’t Just Do Something. Sit There.
abstract: Is the Cold War back? Actually, today’s geopolitics are so much more interesting.
lead_paragraph: With Russia growling over the downfall of its ally running Ukraine and still protecting its murderous ally running Syria, there is much talk that we’re returning to the Cold War — and that the Obama team is not up to defending our interests or friends. I beg to differ. I don’t think the Cold War is back; today’s geopolitics are actually so much more interesting than that. And I also don’t think President Obama’s caution is entirely misplaced.

headline: Tentatively, European Union Weighs Its Options on Support for a New Ukraine
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Foreign Aid', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, said at a news conference that Europe would offer “support, not interference,” and urged Ukrainians to maintain good ties with Russia.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, spent two days here promising unspecific support for a new Ukrainian government but urging it not to break close trading and cultural links with Russia. Ms. Ashton’s deft dance was inevitable — the European Union and the West are not willing or capable of bailing out Ukraine’s economy, especially if Moscow retaliates with new punitive tariffs, higher prices for natural gas and a cutoff of significant ties to Ukrainian factories and businesses.

headline: Long-Suffering Royals Regain Confidence
abstract: For the first time in decades, the Royals, who endured 17 of 18 losing seasons before last year, begin a season with a realistic chance at the postseason, and all the pressure that comes with it.
lead_paragraph: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Dayton Moore has been coming here for eight years as the general manager of the Kansas City Royals, roaming the practice fields on sun-kissed February mornings, watching his prospects and imagining a better tomorrow. Now, he believes, it is here.

headline: Rethinking Our ‘Rights’ to Dangerous Behaviors
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Food', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Automobiles', 'Corporations', 'Medicine and Health', 'Gun Control', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: An alliance of corporations, banks, marketers and others has essentially promoted and benefited from unhealthy lifestyles.
lead_paragraph: In the last few years, it’s become increasingly clear that food companies engineer hyperprocessed foods in ways precisely geared to most appeal to our tastes. This technologically advanced engineering is done, of course, with the goal of maximizing profits, regardless of the effects of the resulting foods on consumer health, natural resources, the environment or anything else.

headline: Lincoln and the ‘Cannibals’
abstract: In early 1864, the president received disturbing news from the South Pacific.
lead_paragraph: While America was embroiled in a bloody civil war for its very survival, a little over 5,000 miles away from Washington, in the middle of the South Pacific, the people of the Marquesas Islands were in a struggle of their own over slavery.

headline: De Blasio Says New York Can Add 29,000 Pre-K Seats
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio was trying to answer skeptics who questioned whether he could create enough prekindergarten seats to justify an income tax increase.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest questions surrounding Mayor Bill de Blasio’s push for a higher income tax to pay for more prekindergarten seats in New York City is whether he could create enough seats to justify the increase.

headline: Clinton Makes Kentucky Appearance
abstract: The former president spoke at a fund-raiser in Louisville for Alison Lundergan Grimes, a Democratic Senate candidate.
lead_paragraph: The former president spoke at a fund-raiser in Louisville for Alison Lundergan Grimes, a Democratic Senate candidate.

headline: The Education of a Long Island Conservative
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Editorials']
abstract: Representative Peter King took on a new outlook on immigration reform at a town-hall meeting in his new district, which now includes black and Hispanic enclaves.
lead_paragraph: Who says old politicians can’t reinvent themselves, jettison long-held beliefs and emerge from ideological cocoons, fresh as butterflies?

headline: Ex-President Ventures Where Some Might Not
abstract: When red-state Democrats need a popular national leader in their corner, former President Bill Clinton is the man they call.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — When Alison Lundergan Grimes, Kentucky’s Democratic Senate candidate, welcomed former President Bill Clinton to a fund-raiser here Tuesday, she offered a rendering of recent political history suited for red-state Democrats: Mr. Clinton’s tenure was showered with praise, former President George W. Bush was mildly scorned, and President Obama was implicitly rebuked.

headline: North Korea’s Atrocities
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: A United Nations report has produced the most authoritative indictment yet of crimes against humanity unparalleled in the contemporary world.
lead_paragraph: The world has long been aware of North Korea’s repression and brutality against its citizens, through the stories of escapees and reports by human rights groups and the State Department. But a study by a special United Nations commission has produced the most authoritative indictment yet.

headline: At Steinbrenner Field, Heisman Winner Is Star Attraction
abstract: Jameis Winston, the Heisman Trophy winning quarterback from Florida State, brought his celebrity buzz and virtually took over Yankees camp in a preseason game.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees have had encounters with college football stars, including one who played at Florida State University. That was Deion Sanders, nicknamed Prime Time, who signed his minor league contract with a dollar sign for the S in his name, as General Manager Brian Cashman recalled.

headline: Trading Site Failure Stirs Ire and Hope for Bitcoin
abstract: With one of its earliest marketplaces gone, the world of virtual currency may have to to become a more mature part of the financial system.
lead_paragraph: The apparent collapse of Bitcoin’s best-known and once-dominant trading platform has provoked outrage among its users, but it has also stirred hopes that the way may now be clear for more established players to transform and rein in a largely unregulated market.

headline: A Military Budget to Fit the Times
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Military Aircraft', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: The modest proposals from Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel reflect a more realistic assessment of America’s global role.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon’s proposals to reduce the Army to pre-World War II levels and modify some benefits for troops and retirees may seem unsettling to a nation that prides itself on having the world’s most capable military. But these ideas, part of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s 2015 military budget, reflect a necessary and more prudent realism as America ends 13 years at war.

headline: Christian University Resumes Inquiry in Handling of Sexual Abuse Reports
abstract: An investigation into the handling of sexual abuse complaints has resumed at Bob Jones University after it was suspended in late January.
lead_paragraph: An investigation into Bob Jones University’s handling of sexual abuse complaints will be allowed to resume, the university and investigators said on Tuesday, after the school endured two weeks of criticism for cutting off the inquiry, without explanation, as it neared completion.

headline: An Unfinished Ukraine Palace and a Fugitive Leader’s Folly
abstract: Workers hired to build a retreat for Viktor F. Yanukovych have walked off the job, since he will never be able to pay them after his ouster as Ukraine’s president.
lead_paragraph: LASPI, Ukraine — Chased from his sumptuous villa outside the Ukrainian capital and last sighted searching for a sanctuary here on the Crimean Peninsula, Viktor F. Yanukovych, the former president, suffered a final indignity on Tuesday: The masons and electricians he had hired to build a Pharaonic seaside retreat in a historic, old-growth forest decided that he would never pay his bills and started hauling away their equipment and materials.

headline: Christie’s Budget Proposes Sacrifices but No Big Solution to Labor Costs
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Income Tax', 'Government Employees']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie’s speech appeared to betray the frustrations and realities of a leader who has fewer available dollars and far less political good will than he envisioned for his second term.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — A diminished Gov. Chris Christie sought to reclaim the mantle of fiscal sobriety that helped catapult him to Republican stardom, releasing a budget on Tuesday that called for new sacrifices from public employees, offered a painful payment to New Jersey’s indebted pension system and abandoned his cherished plan to cut the state income tax.

headline: Crude Weapons Help Fuel Unrest in Bastion of Venezuelan Opposition
abstract: Protesters are using a variety of homemade weapons against troops, including miniature firebombs and Miguelitos, which are made from hoses festooned with nails.
lead_paragraph: SAN CRISTÓBAL, Venezuela — No one here is hiding the heavy artillery, such as it is. Students camping out on an intersection of this city, which has become a battleground between the authorities and antigovernment protesters, have a variety of homemade weapons — mortars to lob small, noisy explosives, miniature firebombs, slingshots, clubs and nasty-looking things called Miguelitos made from hoses festooned with nails.

headline: Pioneering Aside, Collins Just Tries to Learn Plays
abstract: After two whirlwind days, Jason Collins had a chance to focus on the Nets’ system in a practice.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jason Collins was longing for a sense of normalcy Tuesday at Nets practice.

headline: After Career of Firsts in Air Force, G.O.P. Challenger Has a New Mission
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Martha McSally hopes to unseat Representative Ron Barber, a former aide to Gabrielle Giffords who won the Arizona congressional seat after she was severely injured in a shooting.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — The Air Force Association’s Cochise Chapter had fallen into a rapt silence as Martha McSally — the first female fighter pilot to fly a combat mission and command a fighter squadron — recounted a tale from her days in the military, the time when what was supposed to be a “routine reconnaissance” mission in Afghanistan went awry.

headline: Parade Marches Backward
abstract: An Irish drag queen explains why the New York St. Paddy’s Day Parade is a drag.
lead_paragraph: I have long been opposed to gays marching in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade on Fifth Avenue.

headline: Justice Dept. Informs Inmate of Pre-Arrest Surveillance
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Agron Hasbajrami, who is serving a 15-year prison sentence for a terrorism-related conviction, was told he gave up his right to appeal his case when he entered a guilty plea in 2012.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has informed a former Brooklyn man who is serving a 15-year prison sentence over a terrorism-related conviction that his communications were subjected to surveillance without warrants before his arrest.

headline: Shell Game
abstract: A Wednesday debut from Ruth B. Margolin.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today marks the debut of crossword constructor Ruth B. Margolin, whose first-ever New York Times puzzle has been rated a Wednesday difficulty. Not bad for a newcomer.

headline: El Chapo’s Arrest Unlikely to Break Mexican Cartel
abstract: Officials say the Sinaloa cartel has transcended its leader, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, learning better than its competitors how to produce and move drugs, establish new markets and outsource business.
lead_paragraph: To have a crack at an international kingpin, undercover officers from Boston and New Hampshire went from the mountains of northern Mexico through the Caribbean to Spain, where they discovered operatives of the powerful Sinaloa cartel setting up new routes and new markets.

headline: Toxicology Expert Lifts Kerry Kennedy’s Defense
keywords: ['Ambien (Drug)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving']
abstract: A prosecution witness for Ms. Kennedy, who is charged with driving under the influence, said the sleeping pill she took could mar a user’s awareness of her actions.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — On the second day of Kerry Kennedy’s misdemeanor trial on charges of driving under the influence of a sleeping pill, the prosecution’s pharmaceutical expert said that the drug, a generic version of Ambien, could render users incapable of recognizing that their driving was impaired.

headline: 17 Brokerage Firms Agree to End Analysis Previews
abstract: The deal among firms including Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Merrill Lynch means no clients will receive market-sensitive information ahead of others.
lead_paragraph: Seventeen brokerage firms, including Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Merrill Lynch, have agreed to stop participating in money management surveys aimed at tapping into research analysts’ changing views on companies before those opinions are publicly issued.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 25, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 26, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, February 26, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Why does he need a palace every few kilometers? He thought he was a czar.”

headline: The Wilfred Complaint: Salazar et al. v. The Dept. of Education
abstract: A lawsuit filed in federal court contends that the government should cease collection of loans for students who were falsely certified for enrollment at Wilfred Academy.
lead_paragraph: A lawsuit filed in federal court contends that the government should cease collection of loans for students who were falsely certified for enrollment at Wilfred Academy.

headline: Suit Seeks Relief for Trade School Students With Years of Debt but No Career
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Student Loans', 'Credit and Debt', 'Vocational Training', 'For-Profit Schools']
abstract: The suit contends that the government should stop trying to collect on some loans since it was aware that a nationwide chain of beauty schools routinely falsified student eligibility.
lead_paragraph: The Wilfred Academy promised her “everything you’ll need for your beauty career.” When she enrolled, Ana Salazar, a single mother of four, then 40, believed it was a ticket out of her minimum wage job as a security guard.

headline: Hired to Fight Pirates, but Doomed by Boredom
abstract: Troubling questions surround how two former Navy SEALs working as ship guards ended up dying inside the Maersk Alabama, the ship made famous in the movie “Captain Phillips.”
lead_paragraph: PORT OF VICTORIA, Seychelles — The night before their lifeless bodies were found inside a cabin on a cargo ship, Jeffrey Reynolds and Mark Kennedy enjoyed the night life here, at tourist haunts called Le Rendez Vous and the Pirates Arms.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 26, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Honorific Streets, Now Cataloged
abstract: A history buff and retired urban planner has taken on the challenge of creating a master list that compiles honorific names for New York City streets.
lead_paragraph: For a brief moment, a woman named Zenita Thompson enjoyed a small dollop of immortality. In 2006, City Councilwoman Letitia James of Brooklyn introduced legislation to rename half of a two-block-long street in Crown Heights, McKeever Place, for Ms. Thompson.

headline: 2 Hollywood Stars on Capitol Hill
abstract: Ben Affleck and Seth Rogen are set to testify before separate congressional committees Wednesday on separate subjects: Congo and Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Television and the movies cannot seem to resist juicy Washington settings — “House of Cards” (intrigue!), “Scandal” (high drama!) or maybe “Veep” (zany!) — but on Wednesday, Capitol Hill will provide the background for two Hollywood stars with real-life missions.

headline: Russian Opposition Leaders Get Jail Terms
abstract: The activist Aleksei A. Navalny was among those sentenced for resisting arrest.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A municipal court on Tuesday jailed several Russian opposition leaders, including the activist and blogger Aleksei A. Navalny, for resisting arrest during a rally near the Kremlin that ended with more than 400 demonstrators detained by the police.

headline: Lawyers for American Couple Seek Inquiry in Qatar
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Americans Abroad', 'ADOPTIONS', 'United States International Relations', 'Malnutrition', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Matthew and Grace Huang face a verdict soon in the death of their adopted daughter, but they have questioned the results of her autopsy.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for an American couple, held in Qatar for more than a year on charges that they murdered their adopted African daughter by denying her food and water, have formally asked the country’s attorney general to open an investigation into medical evidence used by the prosecution, asserting that it was fabricated.

headline: New Twist Emerges in ’86 Murder of Swedish Premier
abstract: A Swedish newspaper published new information linking a former military officer, with connections to South Africa, to the murder of Olof Palme, Sweden’s prime minister.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ever since Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden was gunned down on a Stockholm sidewalk in 1986, theories about his unsolved murder have proliferated, with suspicions that Kurdish separatists or apartheid-era South African hit teams were behind it.

headline: Hong Kong Editor Whose Ouster Stirred Protests Is Slashed
abstract: The slashing of the former editor of the Ming Pao newspaper comes just a month after he was dismissed from a job in which he oversaw reporting that was critical of the mainland Chinese government.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:58 a.m. E.D.T.| The former chief editor of a Hong Kong newspaper whose dismissal in January stirred protests about press freedom in the Chinese territory was slashed Wednesday morning, the police said.

headline: New Coalition Takes On India’s Two Biggest Parties
abstract: The alliance of smaller parties comes at a time when opinion polls show regional parties could be key to forming a government if no party wins a majority in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Eleven political parties, including seven regional parties, formed a coalition on Tuesday in hopes of drawing voters away from India’s two main national parties in the general elections in May.

headline: Britain: Police Error Frees Bombing Suspect
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Attacks on Police', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: A man accused of killing four British soldiers in a bombing in London in 1982 will not face trial because he was mistakenly told that he was not wanted by the police.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of killing four British soldiers in a bombing in London in 1982 will not face trial because he was mistakenly told that he was not wanted by the police. John Downey, 62, from Ireland, was arrested at Gatwick Airport last year and charged with four counts of murder. A court in London was told that Mr. Downey, who had denied the charges, was one of 187 suspects who were assured that they would not be prosecuted as part of moves to resolve the conflict in Northern Ireland. In a statement issued Tuesday, the Metropolitan Police said that Mr. Downey’s letter was sent incorrectly in 2007 but that it respected a court ruling that he should not face prosecution.

headline: Imperfect Already?
abstract: The first PATH station platform at the developing World Trade Center hub, for riders to Hoboken, N.J., opened on Tuesday.

headline: Why the I.R.S. Scandal Won’t Go Away
keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'Political Advertising', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The endless Congressional investigations serve a crucial purpose for Republican politicians, strategists and fundraisers.
lead_paragraph: In the continuing battle over Republican allegations that the Obama administration pressured the Internal Revenue Service to obstruct Tea Party applications for tax-exempt status, three well-known political figures are among those likely to benefit: Karl Rove and David and Charles Koch.

headline: Optional Seating
abstract: Chairs this good looking transcend their function through exceptional form.
lead_paragraph: Object of art? Perch for books or a drink? Bedside table? Chairs this good looking transcend their function through exceptional form.

headline: How to Get Fit in a Few Minutes a Week
abstract: A few sessions per week of 30- or 60-second intervals so strenuous you moan, followed by a minute or so of blessed recovery, and a painful repetition or four, may be all it takes to keep fit.
lead_paragraph: High-intensity interval training, a type of workout that consists of very brief bouts of very strenuous exercise, has become enormously popular in recent years. A main reason is that although such workouts are draining, they can be both very effective and very short, often lasting only a few minutes.

headline: The Affordable Care Act’s Multiple Taxes
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A new tax created by the Affordable Care Act and little noticed to date is likely to have significant impact on the labor market, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

abstract: This word has appeared in six New York Times articles in the past 10 years.
lead_paragraph: cant •\ˈkant\• noun and verb

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:35 A.M. (Starz Cinema) A SEPARATION (2011) In this Oscar winner for best foreign-language film, a couple (Leila Hatami, above, and Peyman Moadi) must decide whether to leave Iran for the sake of their daughter or stay to care for a parent with dementia. Either option could end their marriage. “It is a rigorously honest movie about the difficulties of being honest, a film that tries to be truthful about the slipperiness of truth,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this drama, written and directed by Asghar Farhadi and starring his daughter, Sarina, as the couple’s child. “It also sketches a portrait — perhaps an unnervingly familiar picture for American audiences — of a society divided by sex, generation, religion and class.”

headline: As Steel Mill Closes, Guangzhou Loses a Piece of Its History
abstract: The Guangzhou Steel factory, formerly a small, semi-independent city of its own, with 6,000 workers, has largely fallen silent.
lead_paragraph: Few steel mills in China have as storied a history as the Guangzhou Steel mill. Rival factions during the Cultural Revolution engaged in gun battles in and around the sprawling complex. Local residents say that young men and women hoping to flee China’s poverty and chaos in those days prepared for the all-night swim through shark-infested waters from Shenzhen to Hong Kong by practicing in the murky waters of the Pearl River next to the factory.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 26, 2014
abstract: Can you calculate the difference in a year of minimum wage earnings in Oregon and in Idaho?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Airbus to Increase A320 Production
abstract: The move comes amid rising demand in emerging markets and in the United States, and after the plane maker’s parent company announced a jump in 2013 net income.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Record demand for new commercial jets drove a 22 percent jump in profit at Airbus Group last year, prompting the European plane maker on Wednesday to announce a 10 percent increase in production of its most popular single-aisle plane.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The ‘Star Quality’ of Jennifer Lawrence
abstract: What examples does this writer use in the first few paragraphs to show that Jennifer Lawrence was “no ordinary starlet” even before she was famous?
lead_paragraph: In “Being Human Seems Enough,” the Times film critic Manohla Dargis writes an appreciation of the Oscar-nominated actress Jennifer Lawrence.

headline: The Sublime Combination of Butter and Soy
abstract: Reverie and a recipe for the otherworldly fifth flavor.
lead_paragraph: Who knows who first mixed soy sauce and butter and discovered the pleasures the combination provides. Try the mixture on warm white rice, a steaming pile of greens or an old sneaker — regardless, the taste is a sublime velvet of sweet and salty, along with a kind of pop the cognoscenti call umami, a fifth taste beyond bitter, sour, salty and sweet. Soy butter provides warmth and luxury, elegance without pomp. It raises recipes to heights almost indescribable in the telling.

headline: Chris Lehane Out-Washingtons Washington
abstract: For the Democratic strategist shaped by six years in the Clinton White House and the outcome of Bush v. Gore, going too far is never far enough.
lead_paragraph: On a hot Sacramento morning, Chris Lehane burst into a conference room filled with trial lawyers, lobbyists and one aggrieved mother, and laid out his battle plan: How to force California to raise its 40-year-old ceiling on medical-malpractice awards. Lehane, who is 46, spent six years working in the Clinton White House, battling the ethical scandals that seemed to confront the administration every day — typically by discrediting the accuser or leaking a document to undercut an impending news story critical of the president or the first lady. Now Lehane uses similar strategies — opposition research, attention-grabbing antics, the crafty manipulation of old and new media — for groups like this one, the Consumer Attorneys of California. The campaign to raise the cap on damages for pain and suffering in medical malpractice suits, which was set at $250,000, might have been handled legislatively, but much high-impact law in California is made at the ballot box, in the form of well-publicized voter initiatives. Influencing voters with his own extreme brand of performance politics has become Lehane’s specialty.

headline: Empowering Photographers to Embrace an Uncertain Future
abstract: The Magnum photographer Susan Meiselas encourages others to embrace the changing landscape of the photo industry and connect with their viewers more intimately.
lead_paragraph: With a torrent of images from the mundane to the momentous on social media and online, Susan Meiselas has been thinking about how to empower and excite photographers about an uncertain future. Ms. Meiselas, a member of Magnum, was a guest editor for the latest issue of Aperture magazine, where she highlights how photographers can embrace their new tools to make new choices and start new conversations.“Everyone has a smartphone and everyone’s a photographer,” she told the Lens co-editor James Estrin. “So those who have committed themselves to developing the visual language of photography over these decades have to ask, ‘How can we continue to contribute?’ ”Their conversation has been edited.

headline: Is Your Generation Really ‘Postracial’?
abstract: Do you agree with a recent Times article that says, though many believe that millennials are growing up in a colorblind society, “racial tensions are playing out in new ways among young adults”? Why or why not?
lead_paragraph: According to Urban Dictionary, “postracial” is “a term used to describe a society or time period in which discussions around race and racism have been deemed no longer relevant to current social dynamics. Popularized after the election of Barack Obama to the presidency of the United States of America in 2009.”

abstract: Fur, fabrics and fancy dominated the runways during the Italian fashion week.
lead_paragraph: Fur, fabrics and fancy dominated the runways during the Italian fashion week.

headline: New York Today: Bundle Up, It’s Almost March
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: a week of bitter cold, a dash of snow, and Spike Lee rants against gentrification.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Most Democrats Want Clinton to Run in 2016
abstract: While Democrats are eager for a presidential bid by Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Republican field appears to be far more mixed, according to a new poll.
lead_paragraph: More than 8 in 10 Democrats say they want Hillary Rodham Clinton to run for president in 2016, showing a level of interest in her that no other potential candidates – Democrat or Republican – come close to matching among their party’s voters, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: ‘I Have Been Told That I’m Different’
abstract: Alison Chung’s gift for numbers has helped her build a consulting firm that specializes in computer forensics.
lead_paragraph: Alison Chung of Chicago is not wired like most people. This can present challenges socially, but from a business perspective it’s her competitive advantage as the owner of a consulting firm that is essentially a digital detective agency.

headline: Daily Report: As Mt. Gox Falls, Bitcoin Looks to the Future
abstract: Ire over the apparent collapse of one of the earliest online marketplaces for the virtual currency was paired with hope that it could lead to a maturation of virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: The apparent collapse of Bitcoin’s best-known and once-dominant trading platform has provoked outrage among its users, but it has also stirred hopes that the way may now be clear for more established players to transform and rein in a largely unregulated market, Rachel Abrams and Nathaniel Popper report.

abstract: The full results of The New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Private Equity Leaders See Opportunities in Europe
abstract: Europe is ripe for investments as the economic recovery continues there, private equity investors said at the SuperReturn International gathering in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN – Private equity leaders expressed optimism on Wednesday about the prospects for investments in Europe as economies recover.

headline: A Silver Lining in Bitcoin’s Stumble
abstract: The apparent collapse of Mt. Gox, the most prominent Bitcoin exchange, late Monday night stirred ire, but also hope for the virtual currency. | A Senate report says Credit Suisse helped American clients hide billions in assets. | Bank of America is facing two new investigations. | Argentina is asking the United States Supreme Court to throw out a lower-court ruling on its debt.
lead_paragraph: BITCOIN’S SILVER LINING  |  The apparent collapse of Mt. Gox, the most prominent Bitcoin exchange, late Monday night naturally stirred outrage and panic. After all, a document circulating widely in the Bitcoin world said the company had lost 744,000 Bitcoins — about 6 percent of Bitcoins in circulation — worth more than $300 million at current exchange rates. But Bitcoin’s latest troubles did little to shake the confidence of many, and indeed, the virtual currency’s stumble may provide just the spark it needs to become a more mature part of the financial system, Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook.

headline: Carlyle’s Co-Founder Says More Private Equity Firms Likely to Go Public
abstract: The wave of public offerings of private equity firms is likely to continue as smaller firms begin to follow public floats by the industry’s largest players in recent years, said David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder of the private equity firm Carlyle Group.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder of the private equity firm Carlyle Group, said on Wednesday that he believed more private equity firms would seek to go public in the next few years.

headline: In Performance: Bebe Neuwirth of ‘Chicago’
abstract: The actress sings “Nowadays” from the Broadway musical “Chicago,” at the Ambassador Theater.
lead_paragraph: Theatergoers who check out Bebe Neuwirth’s return to the Kander and Ebb musical “Chicago,” where she is playing the prison matron “Mama” Morton through March 9, will hear her sing the character’s signature number, “When You’re Good to Mama.” To celebrate her “Chicago” trifecta — Ms. Neuwirth has also played the principal roles of Velma and Roxie — she chose to sing “Nowadays,” a song she describes as “archetypical Kander and Ebb.”

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Jacquemus Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: VSPs of 2010
abstract: Groupthink and its dangers.
lead_paragraph: Dan Drezner has an interesting article in Politico that’s framed as a rebuttal to Nick Kristof’s condemnation of irrelevant academics, but is actually much broader. Drezner argues that there are three tribes — money men, political insiders, and academics — each of which has its own strengths and weaknesses, and each of which would be well advised to listen to the others (but doesn’t).

headline: Red Spreads
abstract: Son of TED, in China.
lead_paragraph: Uh-oh. Chinese equivalents of the TED spread and other gauges of financial stress in the US have widened sharply. The widening in the TED spread was one of the key reasons I was already very scared in late 2007. If past is prologue, we should be very worried about China now.

headline: Now, Nations Mull the Ways to Regulate Bitcoin
abstract: In the wake of the implosion of the Bitcoin trading platform Mt. Gox, countries like the United States and Japan are gathering data on virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: Authorities around the world are grappling with how to regulate virtual currency in the wake of the implosion of Mt. Gox, a prominent trading platform for Bitcoin.

headline: China Charges Scholar With Inciting Separatism
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The formal arrest of the scholar, Ilham Tohti, demonstrates Beijing’s determination to silence one of the few moderate voices for the country’s beleaguered Uighurs.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Security officials in China’s far western borderlands have formally arrested a scholar and champion of the country’s ethnic Uighurs on charges of inciting separatism, his lawyer said Wednesday.

headline: Media Report | Big (Bad) Data
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Social Media']
abstract: The buzziest idea in business may be its greatest downfall.
lead_paragraph: The buzziest idea in business may be its greatest downfall.

headline: Data Breach Hurts Profit at Target
abstract: The retailer reported that profit plunged 46 percent in the fourth quarter of 2013 and attributed it to revelations of customer data theft.
lead_paragraph: The widespread theft of Target customer data had a significant impact on the company’s profit, which fell more than 40 percent in the fourth quarter, the retailer reported on Wednesday.

headline: A Tough Decision for a Cafe Regular
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A cafeteria regular wanted a stronger morning tea, but didn’t want to threaten the personal service she received.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Thai Army Reinforces Areas Near Protesters
abstract: The army said the reinforcements, which included sandbag bunkers, were meant to keep the peace after two nights of gunfire in Bangkok.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — After two consecutive nights of gunfire in Bangkok’s central business district, the Thai army on Wednesday built sandbag bunkers in upscale neighborhoods and reinforced what officials described as a peacekeeping presence near areas occupied by protesters seeking to overthrow the Thai government.

headline: Feelings, Facts, Food and Genetic Engineering – A Fresh Look
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Biotechnology', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Environment', 'Factory Farming', 'Food', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Meat', 'Poultry', 'Science and Technology', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: A chef, a law professor, a scientist and two journalists discuss the role of genetic technology in our food system.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:16 p.m. | Please watch and weigh in on this open-minded discussion of the intersection of biotechnology, the environment and the dinner plate at Pace University.

headline: Judge Expedites Men’s Wearhouse Lawsuit
abstract: A Delaware judge ordered Jos. A. Bank to quickly submit documents relating to its proposed acquisition of Eddie Bauer, which is seen as a defensive measure to stop a takeover bid by Men’s Wearhouse.
lead_paragraph: A Delaware judge on Tuesday expedited Men’s Wearhouse’s lawsuit against its smaller rival, Jos. A. Bank, in an ugly takeover battle between the men’s suit retailers that is playing out in court.

headline: As Putin Orders Drills in Crimea, Protesters’ Clash Shows Region’s Divide
abstract: The new government in Kiev is faced with the challenge of calming separatism at home while placating President Vladimir V. Putin, who sees Ukraine as a vital part of his strategy to rebuild Russian influence.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — With cries of “Allahu akbar,” Arabic for “God is great,” thousands of protesters in the capital of Ukraine’s Crimea region, a tinderbox of ethnic, religious and political divisions, added an Islamic voice on Wednesday to the tumultuous struggle for Ukraine that last weekend drove the president from power and that has pushed Russia and the West into a face-off reminiscent of the Cold War.

headline: Hazardous Duty
abstract: In “The Port Chicago 50,” Steve Sheinkin tells the story of African-American sailors who were tried for mutiny in 1944.
lead_paragraph: While Steve Sheinkin was researching his last book, “Bomb: The Race to Build — and Steal — the World’s Most Dangerous Weapon” (later a National Book Award finalist and a Newbery Honor winner), he came across an astounding story from that era. In 1944, in the midst of the Second World War, 50 African-American sailors were tried for mutiny, convicted and sentenced to 15 years hard labor. Their only crime was to refuse to load ammunition.

headline: Veterans at Home, on a Mission of Compassion
abstract: A program called The Mission Continues helps veterans find purpose in civilian life by organizing “platoons” to serve those in need.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Gutierrez was an army sergeant in Iraq, but back home in Phoenix she leads a platoon. At 2:30 in the morning last Oct. 18, members of the 1st Platoon Phoenix   gathered at an all-night McDonalds in a bad neighborhood downtown. Their mission was to comb the streets for chronically homeless veterans (who tend to sleep in groups but scatter during the day) and register them to get housing and other services.

headline: A Queen of What-Ifs
abstract: Idina Menzel’s new Broadway show, “If/Then,” is an ambitious effort by the musical team behind the Tony-winning “Next to Normal.”
lead_paragraph: Idina Menzel has a blockbuster voice that seems to have a knack for blockbusters. Not only did she star in the original “Rent,” but she also delivered the anthem “Defying Gravity” in the seemingly unstoppable “Wicked.” And while the success of the Disney movie “Frozen” is a result of many factors, the most underrated might be the force with which Ms. Menzel delivers its signal song, “Let It Go,” which does not easily wear out its welcome. (Trust me, as a father of a 5-year-old fan, I have tested this.)

headline: Walking Through Majorca
abstract: On Foot Holidays has a a new self-guided walking tour of the Spanish island of Mallorca.
lead_paragraph: On Foot Holidays, the self-guided walking tours specialist, has introduced a new route — its 21st — to the Spanish island of Majorca.

headline: A New Title for Angela Missoni
abstract: The creative director of her family’s namesake label will be given an honorary doctorate of humane letters.
lead_paragraph: Soon it will be Dr. Angela Missoni to you.

headline: CreatureCast: A Tale of Two Urchins
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: Many different species do similar things. The pencil sea urchin and green sea urchin, for example, are both grazers in the coastal waters of the Galapagos Islands.
lead_paragraph: Many different species do similar things. The pencil sea urchin and green sea urchin, for example, are both grazers in the coastal waters of the Galapagos Islands.

headline: Two Urchins, Similar but Not
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Biodiversity']
abstract: It’s easy to mix up green sea urchins and pencil sea urchins when you see them while scuba diving. But these two species live very different lives.
lead_paragraph: When does biodiversity matter for the function of ecosystems, and when can we consider different species to be essentially the same? When, for example, is a grazer just a grazer, and when do we need to consider the distinctions between different species of grazers?

headline: Paco de Lucía, Master Flamenco Guitarist, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. de Lucía was born into a musical family and became one of the world’s greatest guitarists, finding new audiences for flamenco by blending it with jazz and other genres.
lead_paragraph: Paco de Lucía, who was born into a musical family and grew up to become one of the world’s greatest guitarists, mastering flamenco music and finding new audiences by blending it with jazz and other genres, died on Wednesday in Mexico. He was 66.

headline: Slalom for Russia as It Seeks to Invest in North Caucasus
abstract: With a $15 billion project to build European-style ski resorts, Russia is trying to lure tourists and investors to a region better known for sheltering Islamic militants.
lead_paragraph: ARKHYZ, Russia — Just over the mountains from where Russia’s Olympic dream played out this month to a worldwide audience, Aleksei Grebennikov, a copper miner, glided down the bunny slope of a brand-new ski resort on the Abishira-Akhuba mountain ridge.

headline: To Die For
abstract: It’s no secret that smoking and drinking are terrible for you. Why, then, are designers determined to make vice look so nice?
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that smoking and drinking are terrible for you. Why, then, are designers determined to make vice look so nice?

headline: No Comment Necessary: The Fake Dangers of Marijuana
abstract: It’s hard finding evidence that you can die from a marijuana overdose—unless you resort to fake news.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard finding evidence that you can die from a marijuana overdose—because no one has ever died from a marijuana overdose. Unless, that is, you resort to fake news, as Annapolis Police Chief Michael Pristoop did on Tuesday.

headline: Little Orchestra Society Wants Your Help to Rename Itself
abstract: Music fans can suggest a new name for the orchestra online.
lead_paragraph: What’s in a name? For the Little Orchestra Society, there’s a lot of history — the orchestra was founded in 1947 and has become renowned for its inventive educational concerts, and also, increasingly, for its inventive presentations of new works. But lately, members of the ensemble’s board and management, as well as the conductor James Judd, who became its music director last season, have been worrying that the name doesn’t fully reflect the orchestra’s mission.

headline: In Our Pages: February 27
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1964: Cassius Clay Beats Liston

headline: The Koch Brothers’ Network
abstract: The Center for Responsive Politics has put together a chart of what it calls “the Koch brothers’ labyrinthine network of political groups.”
lead_paragraph: The Center for Responsive Politics has put together a chart of what it calls “the Koch brothers’ labyrinthine network of political groups.”

headline: Viktor Yanukovych’s Car Collection Was a Private Automotive History Museum
abstract: The former Ukrainian president had a collection of about 70 cars on his luxurious estate, many of them a window into Soviet history.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev last week, the world has gotten a good look at the deposed Ukrainian president’s lavish residential complex. Among the zoo, the golf course and the many garish luxury items on the site (notably the fake pirate ship), Mr. Yanukovych kept a collection of automobiles that would make any collector proud.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Viewer Numbers, at Least if Twitter Is Any Guide
abstract: How many people watched the second season of “House of Cards” on Netflix? The volume of messages on Twitter suggests the audience for the political thriller may have grown substantially.
lead_paragraph: How many people watched the second season of “House of Cards” on Netflix? Only Netflix knows because the streaming service withholds viewership data in a way that Francis Underwood, the show’s conniving main character, might admire. But if the number of messages on Twitter about “House of Cards” is any clue, the audience for the political thriller may have grown substantially.

headline: Metal Singer Pleads Guilty in Plot to Kill Estranged Wife
abstract: Tim Lambesis, the singer for the Christian metal band As I Lay Dying, will be sentenced in May for trying to hire a hit man.
lead_paragraph: Tim Lambesis, the singer for the Christian metal band As I Lay Dying, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to trying to hire an undercover sheriff’s deputy to murder his estranged wife, Meggan Lambesis. The singer’s new plea — he had pleaded not guilty in September — brings the case nearly to an end: he will be sentenced, in San Diego County on May 2, nearly a year after his arrest. Until then, The Associated Press reports, the singer, 32, is free on $2 million bond. He faces a nine-year jail term and a $10,000 fine.

headline: App Smart: Creativity
abstract: Kit Eaton describes three apps that can help in the creative thinking process.
lead_paragraph: Kit Eaton describes three apps that can help in the creative thinking process.

headline: Finding the Right App to Unblock Those Creative Juices
abstract: When ideas stop flowing easily, it may be time to turn to a smartphone and the apps that can help reset the creative thinking process.
lead_paragraph: Creative thinking is a huge part of a job like mine, but it’s also critical to many types of work — including yours, I’ll bet.

headline: To Pay for Infrastructure Repairs, Obama Seeks Tax Changes
abstract: President Obama will ask Congress to overhaul corporate and business taxes to pay for a four-year, $302 billion transportation bill.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Caught between a gridlocked Congress and a Highway Trust Fund that will soon be broke, President Obama on Wednesday urged lawmakers to overhaul corporate and business taxes to pay for repairing and replacing the nation’s aging roads, rails, bridges and tunnels.

headline: Interview: Randy Thom
abstract: Randy Thom, the director of sound design at Skywalker Sound, discusses his work.
lead_paragraph: Randy Thom, the director of sound design at Skywalker Sound, discusses his work.

headline: Prominent Occupations Still Viewed as Male Domains, Study Finds
abstract: A report by Harris Poll found that men and women said there were not enough women in positions of power in the workplace, but a majority of respondents still preferred to have men in jobs like president of the United States and Fortune 500 executives.
lead_paragraph: A new report finds that while both men and women say there are not enough women in positions of power in the workplace, a majority of respondents still preferred to cast men in prominent jobs.

lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — Did she have the cappuccino and carrots for breakfast before the medication? Or did the medication come first?

headline: Poll Suggests Crushing Loss Awaits India’s Governing Party
abstract: Two months before elections, dissatisfaction with the direction of the country and with the governing Indian National Congress party appears to be widespread.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Two months before Indians vote in national elections, a new poll suggests that India’s dominant political party and family may suffer one of their worst defeats in the country’s 67-year history.

abstract: Why content marketing is hot. A new invoicing tool. And business owners who can’t answer a simple question about their businesses may be in trouble.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

headline: The Ellen DeGeneres Synergy Stop
abstract: The Oscars host’s daytime show has long been a pitstop for celebrities promoting their movies. During awards season, it has become a must-stop for nominees.
lead_paragraph: Having an Oscar host with her own talk show is proving to be the very definition of cross-brand promotion. Even before she was chosen to host the broadcast (her second time being the M.C.), Ellen DeGeneres’s daytime program was a popular pit stop for celebrities, but lately it’s served as a synergistic must-stop.

lead_paragraph: Former first lady Hillary Clinton is the popular choice among Democrats in a New York Times/CBS News poll. Also on the Minute, the future for troops in Afghanistan and the growing trend of "phablets."

headline: Artists on Artists | Shirin Neshat on Kaveh Golestan’s Humanistic Portraiture
abstract: The Iranian-born photographer and filmmaker discusses her late compatriot’s arresting images of Tehran’s red-light district.
lead_paragraph: Since the late ’90s, Shirin Neshat has been lauded for photographs, films and videos that explore the lives of Iranian women. Her first video, “Turbulent” (1998), featured a face-off between a male and a female singer in Islamic Iran, while “Women Without Men,” her 2009 feature film, focuses on the problems experienced by four women during the 1953 coup that brought the last shah to power. More recently, her work has addressed other countries in the Arab Spring, as in “Our House Is on Fire” (at Chelsea’s Rauschenberg Project Space, closing March 1), a group of poignant portraits of ordinary men and women in Cairo, survivors of the Egyptian revolution. “I wanted to humanize the people we think of as the other,” Neshat says.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: 36 Hours in Kyoto, Japan
abstract: Explore shrines and temples, browse design shops, sample deep-fried food on skewers and more during a weekend in Japan’s former imperial capital.
lead_paragraph: A full 36 hours, 36 days, or even 36 weeks could be spent exploring the thousands of Buddhist temples, Shinto shrines, Zen gardens, palaces, pagodas, parks and walking paths in Kyoto, the former imperial capital of Japan. So it’s little surprise that the most common complaint about the enchanting city is that there are too many tourists, especially during the spring cherry-blossom season. To avoid crowds, consider seeking out local haunts in far-flung neighborhoods, all within reach thanks to an extensive public transport system. You’ll quickly discover that many of Kyoto’s most rewarding attractions can’t be found in any guidebook. At least not yet.

headline: For Merle Haggard, a Boxcar Was Home. Now It Needs Work.
abstract: The house and its working-class locale near Bakersfield, Calif., served as inspiration for many of the musician’s songs.
lead_paragraph: OILDALE, Calif. — The tanker trains loaded with crude oil still rattle down the tracks at the end of the alleyway where Merle Haggard, a living legend of country music, grew up in a boxcar that his father transformed into the family home.

headline: Q & A: Making Scones and Biscuits
abstract: Read questions and comments about the recipe, or other methods, ingredients and secrets for baking either biscuits, scones or both.
lead_paragraph: Heather Bertinetti, the pastry chef at the Four Seasons restaurant, and Julia Moskin discussed baking tender biscuits and scones with you, our readers. (The master recipe for both is here.) Their replies to questions and comments from readers are below.

headline: Potential Conflicts Cited For Mortgage Servicer
abstract: The state’s Department of Financial Services has found “potential conflicts of interest” between the mortgage servicer Ocwen and four other public companies who share its founder and chairman.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s top banking regulator said he had new concerns about Ocwen Financial, one of the nation’s largest mortgage servicing companies, creating another regulatory headache for the company.

headline: Image of the Day: February 26
abstract: Somdev Devvarman, an Indian tennis player, in action at the ATP Dubai Tennis Championships in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

headline: Barnes & Noble Nook Unit Continues to Sputter
keywords: ['Barnes & Noble Nook', 'Company Reports', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Tablet Computers']
abstract: Despite slow sales and a shrinking market share for its e-reader, the bookstore chain says it will release a new color tablet this year.
lead_paragraph: Barnes & Noble said on Wednesday that it would release a new color tablet later this year, even as losses in its sputtering Nook division continued to weigh down the bookseller in its most recent quarter.

headline: Governor Brewer Promises to ‘Do the Right Thing’ for Arizona
abstract: Gov. Jan Brewer responds on Twitter to the mounting pressure to veto legislation that would allow business owners to refuse service to gays and others.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:58 p.m. Under pressure from fellow Republicans, civic leaders and business groups, Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona announced Wednesday night that she had vetoed a bill that would have given business owners the right to invoke religion to refuse service to gays and others, as my colleague, Fernanda Santos reported.

headline: The Politics of Large Fowl
abstract: Brooks and Collins on animal rights and wrongs.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, here in New York we’ve been having a crisis over swans. Can we talk about that today? I don’t think we’ve ever discussed large fowl before.

headline: ‘Journalism Oracle’? What Was I Thinking?
abstract: The public editor shares some noteworthy articles on how the news business is evolving.
lead_paragraph: I realize now that I may have overpromised. When asked recently to suggest a topic for a speech I will give on Friday to several hundred college journalists at their annual convention, I went with something snappy sounding. My talk is called “Journalism 2020: A Forecast and Guide to the Years Ahead for Young Journalists.”

headline: The Messaging App Wars Are Just Getting Started
abstract: Dozens of messaging platforms are competing to become the YouTube of smartphone messaging. But which ones will win?
lead_paragraph: There are 24 different ways for me to message someone from my phone right now. All for no additional charge beyond my existing cellphone bill.

headline: Clear Channel to Debut ‘iHeartRadio Music Awards’
abstract: The show, to air on NBC in May, is the latest example of media companies’ rush toward splashy awards events that bring waves of social media chatter.
lead_paragraph: If a hit song fails to win a Grammy, it could always win an American Music Award. Or an MTV Video Music Award. Or a People’s Choice Award. Or a Billboard Music Award. And if it’s a country track, there’s always the Country Music Association Awards and the Academy of Country Music Awards.

headline: How a Nurse Created a Silicon Valley Incubator
abstract: Jonathan Nelson’s incubator grew out of Hackers and Founders, an organization that provides a way for Silicon Valley entrepreneurs to meet.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Nelson likens the Silicon Valley organization he started, Hackers and Founders, to something he remembers from childhood, when his family moved to the small town of Anoka, Minn., from Central America. (His parents worked for a nongovernmental organization.) The Nelsons received a welcome basket with information about the community, including where the local supermarket, hardware store, post office and auto mechanic were located.

headline: French Street Artist Taking His Work Onstage at City Ballet
abstract: JR, the artist who decorated the floor of the Koch Theater with a 6,500-square-foot photo, will conceive and direct a work for New York City Ballet’s spring season.
lead_paragraph: JR, the French street artist who specializes in large-scale international projects, is taking his collaboration with New York City Ballet off of the floor and onto the stage.

headline: Do You Know Your Calling?
abstract: A life devoted to soccer has inspired others while also forcing the writer to evaluate her motivation.
lead_paragraph: As I am about to enter my fourth year writing about my soccer journey from the United States to Russia to Sweden and back home, I am often struck by the feedback I’ve received. Readers have related how some of what I have written affects them, and their comments have also given me new topics to ponder. They have all led me to consider why I do what I do.

headline: Why Don’t All New Cars Have Rearview Cameras?
abstract: The Transportation Department has for years delayed carrying out an existing safety law.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Matthew L. Wald reported recently on the Transportation Department’s enthusiastic embrace of a plan to require all new cars to broadcast their location, speed, direction and other data, and to receive similar data from other cars, so as to warn drivers of impending collisions.

headline: T-Mobile Turns an Industry on Its Ear
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Smartphones', 'Company Reports', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: The fourth-ranking carrier blew up the rules on smartphones and wireless contracts, to the benefit of many consumers.
lead_paragraph: A rash of consumer-friendliness has broken out across the mobile data industry. Over the last year, the four major carriers — AT&T, Verizon, Sprint and T-Mobile — have cut prices and offered greater flexibility in how they sell their voice, text and broadband services. The industry could be on the verge of an all-out price war.

headline: Bringing the Happy
abstract: The sunny Pharrell Williams, one of the most transformative music figures of the last year, is back with “G I R L,” his second album as a solo performer.
lead_paragraph: It can probably all be explained by the hat, the indelible success of Pharrell Williams.

headline: In a Retirement, a Loss for Barclays
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Hans-Joerg Rudloff’s retirement as chairman of investment banking at Barclays comes at an unhelpful time for the British lender, writes Dominic Elliott of Reuters Breakingviews. The new chief executive could use his help as a continuity figure and mentor.
lead_paragraph: Hans-Joerg Rudloff’s retirement at age 73 comes at an unhelpful time for Barclays.

headline: For ‘Fifty Shades of Grey,’ More Than 100 Million Sold
abstract: The trilogy by E L James, which began as fan fiction, is in the company of series like “Harry Potter” and “Twilight.”
lead_paragraph: The “Fifty Shades of Grey” erotica series by E L James has sold more than 100 million copies worldwide, its American publisher, Vintage Books, said on Wednesday, a milestone for a trilogy that began as fan fiction and emerged as one of the biggest-selling series in publishing history.

headline: The Lesson of ‘Apocalypse Now’
abstract: The Skywalker Sound guru Randy Thom says his work on that seminal film taught him that even if the script calls for a helicopter, it doesn’t necessarily have to sound exactly like a helicopter, especially in a scene where your main character is hallucinating.
lead_paragraph: By now you may have gathered that whenever you hear a sound in a movie, it’s not exactly what it seems.

headline: Need to Fund School Programs? Just Sell Your Kids’ Clothes
abstract: A website that allows parents to fund a school’s “extra” educational programs by selling their children’s’ “gently used” clothing highlights just how askew our system has become.
lead_paragraph: How’s this for a school funding plan?

headline: Easy on All 12 of Our Legs
abstract: Hugh Kepets and Jackob Hofmann realized a walk-up was no longer for them. It was time for an elevator building.
lead_paragraph: Back when Hugh Kepets left his elevator studio on Gramercy Park for a one-bedroom nearby, he didn’t think twice about moving to a fourth-floor walk-up. “I was a relatively young man at the time and didn’t see the stairs as a problem,” he said.

headline: Water: Teaching About the World’s Most Valuable Substance
abstract: In this interdisciplinary lesson, we explore ways in which humanity is learning to cope with shortages or threats to water, a vital element of life. We also consider ways in which water enriches our life or helps define our interactions.
lead_paragraph: We travel on it, feed it to our crops, swim in it, pollute it and, yes, drink it. In some parts of the world, countries even fight over it. Water is everywhere, and yet in many places there’s not nearly enough of it to go around.

headline: Possible Troop Withdrawal in Afghanistan

headline: Foreign Exchange Firm Fined in Britain
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority said that the British units of FXCM, a retail foreign exchange trading firm, withheld nearly $10 million in profits from its customers but passed on any losses.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Financial Conduct Authority on Wednesday fined the British units of FXCM, a retail foreign exchange trading firm, 4 million pounds forwithholding profits from its clients.

headline: With Games Gone, Will Travelers Still Go to Sochi?
abstract: The site of this month’s Winter Olympics faces an uncertain future as a tourist destination.
lead_paragraph: On a recent evening in Krasnaya Polyana, Russia, Pat O’Meara sat with his wife and two daughters and watched the American Kaitlyn Farrington snag a gold medal in the women’s halfpipe snowboard event.

abstract: Molly Wood says bigger may be better when it comes to smartphones.

headline: Phone, Meet Tablet. That’s Phabulous.
abstract: Big phones that blur the line with tablets — known by a somewhat mocking moniker, the “phablet” — can be useful for unifying your activity and communications on one device.
lead_paragraph: The tablet and the phone are fast becoming the same device, and I for one can’t wait.

headline: European Parliament Approves Tough Rules on Electronic Cigarettes
keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The regulations, which could help set a benchmark for global standards, include graphic health warnings on the devices and limits on nicotine, as well as a ban on ads.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European Parliament on Wednesday approved rules for the region’s fast-growing market for electronic cigarettes, regulations that could help set a benchmark for standards around the world.

headline: Former Time Executive to Open Chelsea Art Gallery
abstract: Ann S. Moore, who retired in 2011 as the chief executive and chairwoman of Time Inc., will open a gallery on West 23rd Street near the entrance to the High Line.
lead_paragraph: The contemporary art world is jam-packed these days with collectors from the halls of corporate America, but few of them take their love of art so far as to open a gallery.

headline: New Bill Proposes Auction Royalties for Artists
abstract: Artists would receive 5 percent of the price of works resold at public auction for more than $5,000 under a new bill.
lead_paragraph: When a collector makes a hefty profit in reselling a contemporary painting or sculpture, the artist rarely benefits. Hoping to change that, three lawmakers introduced legislation on Wednesday that would allow artists to share in those proceeds. The bill proposes that artists receive 5 percent of the price of art that is resold at public auction for more than $5,000. Named the American Royalties Too act (so as to have the catchy abbreviation A.R.T.), the bill is a revised version of legislation that Representative Jerrold Nadler of New York, the ranking Democrat on the Courts, Intellectual Property, and Internet subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee, introduced in 2011.

headline: Rival Protesters Brawl in Crimea
abstract: Clashes erupt between pro-Russian and pro-Ukrainian demonstrators in Simferopol.
lead_paragraph: Clashes erupt between pro-Russian and pro-Ukrainian demonstrators in Simferopol.

abstract: If a child’s eating habits are causing trouble at your dinner table, try these ideas to help you return the family meal focus to conversation and togetherness rather than battles over whether young Sally will eat “just one bite.”

abstract: Niese, who was in line to start on opening day, told Manager Terry Collins that his arm felt dead after throwing a recent live batting practice session.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Spring training is where optimism often reigns, while the cold reality of the regular season is still off in the distance somewhere.

headline: Indian Naval Chief Resigns After Submarine Accident

abstract: Adm. D. K. Joshi resigned after seven crew members on a Russian-made submarine were injured and two left missing in the 10th accident involving an Indian warship in seven months.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s naval chief resigned on Wednesday after a Russian-made Indian submarine caught fire off the coast of Mumbai, injuring seven officers and leaving two missing. It was the 10th accident involving an Indian warship in seven months.

headline: A Shortage of Caregivers
keywords: ['Elder Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Medicare', 'Nursing Homes', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Recent estimates suggest that demand for paid caregivers will far outstrip supply over the next decade.
lead_paragraph: If you want fresh evidence of the caregiving crisis that lies in the not-too-distant future, look no further than the employment projections released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics late last year.

headline: Christie Starts Push to Rein In State’s Labor Costs
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Government Employees']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, insulated from the burdens of a re-election bid, said he would devote his remaining time in office to the issue of skyrocketing government pension and health care expenses.
lead_paragraph: STIRLING, N.J. — Gov. Chris Christie said on Wednesday that he felt insulated from the burdens of re-election and undistracted by scandal as he embarked on a potentially polarizing public campaign to cut the costs of New Jersey’s public employee benefits.

lead_paragraph: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.

headline: Some New Art From ‘Calvin and Hobbes’ Creator
keywords: ['Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Bill Watterson, the creator of “Calvin and Hobbes,” provided a poster for a documentary about cartoonists.
lead_paragraph: In putting together “Stripped,” a documentary exploring the art and evolution of newspaper comic strips, Dave Kellett and Fred Schroeder, the co-directors, interviewed more than 70 cartoonists. One of the biggest gets was Bill Watterson, the reclusive creator of “Calvin and Hobbes,” the beloved newspaper strip about a mischievous boy and his stuffed tiger, which ran from 1985 to 1995.

headline: Feeling Blue, but Not Sad in the Navigli District
abstract: Giulia Scrocchi, 20, describes her style as weird and offbeat.
lead_paragraph: The Navigli district in Milan is known for its graffiti-lined canals, bars and clothing shops. In recent years, the neighborhood has also emerged as a hub for artists, designers and partygoers. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Two Brothers Sentenced in ‘Transformers’ Hong Kong Attack
abstract: An incident during the filming of “Transformers 4″ in Hong Kong results in jail sentences for two men.
lead_paragraph: Two brothers who were arrested after a melee on the set of “Transformers 4,” in Hong Kong in October have been sentenced to jail terms, Reuters reported.

headline: David Guttenfelder on the Second Camera
abstract: David Guttenfelder, photographer for The Associated Press, uses his iPhone to document life beyond the daily news.
lead_paragraph: David Guttenfelder, chief Asia photographer for The Associated Press, has received enormous attention this year for his extraordinary work on Instagram, primarily because of his shots of every day life in North Korea. Still-life pictures of playing cards and computer work stations, or a brief video of two giggling ice-cream vendors, give Guttenfelder’s followers a rare look inside the Hermit Kingdom.

headline: Rival Protesters Clash in Crimea
abstract: Scuffles erupted outside the regional Parliament in Crimea as thousands of pro-Russia demonstrators confronted Muslim Crimean Tatars backing the new Ukrainian leadership.
lead_paragraph: Scuffles erupted outside the regional Parliament in Crimea as thousands of pro-Russia demonstrators confronted Muslim Crimean Tatars backing the new Ukrainian leadership.

headline: Classical Playlist: Luiza Borac, Alisa Weilerstein, Cédric Tiberghien and More
abstract: Critics for The Times share what they’ve been listening to.
lead_paragraph: ARTHUR BERGER: ‘Words for Music, Perhaps,’ and Other WorksBoston Modern Orchestra Project, Gil Rose, conductor(BMOP/sound)The American composer Arthur Berger, who died at 91 in 2003, first emerged in the 1940s writing vibrant, pointed Neo-Classical works. Over time he embraced 12-tone techniques, but, in his own distinctive way, retained crystalline Neo-Classical clarity and directness. A recent recording from the conductor Gil Rose and the Boston Modern Orchestra Project presents a diversity of Berger works ranging from “Words for Music, Perhaps” (songs on Yeats poems originally composed in 1940) to the intricately engrossing Diptych: Collage I and Collage II from the 1990s. Mr. Rose has long been a Berger champion. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: ‘Frozen’ Soundtrack Is Back to No. 1
abstract: The soundtrack to Disney’s animated hit “Frozen” returned to the top of the chart for a fifth time.
lead_paragraph: Disney’s animated film “Frozen” has been a monster hit at theaters, and its soundtrack has proved a big success, too. Released three months ago, the album returns this week to the top of Billboard’s chart for a fifth time at No. 1 — the most weeks at No. 1 for a soundtrack since “Titanic” was at the top for 16 straight weeks in 1998.
