lead_paragraph: The art and technology center Eyebeam has selected WORK Architecture Company (WORKac) to design its future home in Brooklyn, another addition to the Brooklyn cultural district in Fort Greene.

headline: Federal Judge Strikes Down Texas’ Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Although significant, the ruling will have no immediate effect, since the judge issued a stay on his decision pending a likely appeal.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A federal judge in Texas struck down the state’s ban on same-sex marriage on Wednesday, ruling that the laws restricting marriage to a man and a woman violated the United States Constitution and handing gay-rights advocates a major legal victory in one of the nation’s biggest and most conservative states.

headline: New Jersey Criminals, This Time Without the Smirk
abstract: “The Red Road,” a six-episode series on SundanceTV, focuses on crime and corruption in a fictional New Jersey town.
lead_paragraph: “The Red Road” is not the television show northern New Jersey needs. It’s bad enough that the six-episode series, beginning Thursday night on SundanceTV, is about violent crime, police corruption, racial tension and mental illness. But what’s worse is that it validates the thinking of anyone who pictures the Garden State as drab and monotonous. At least the Sopranos knew how to have fun.

headline: Conjuring Big-Screen Romance
abstract: Maude Maggart’s new show at Café Carlyle, “The Door Opened,” suggests a Hollywood world of magical transformations prompted by romantic love’s arrival.
lead_paragraph: Imagine Alice in Wonderland as a beautiful dreamer besotted with old movies and vintage love songs. That enchanting, slightly unstable creature materialized at Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening in the person of Maude Maggart, a child of show business, whose new show, “The Door Opened,” sprinkled fairy dust into the room. If you inhale too much of it, God help you. But in small amounts, it is an extremely seductive perfume.

headline: Lego Pieces Together a New Act
abstract: Legoland in Carlsbad, Calif., has a new attraction inspired by the hit “The Lego Movie.”
lead_paragraph: While the thought of 3 million Legos may have parents instinctively rubbing the soles of their feet, executives at the Legoland park in Carlsbad, Calif., are smiling.

headline: From Kepler Data, Astronomers Find Galaxy Filled With More but Smaller Worlds
abstract: Scientists announced on Wednesday that they have verified the existence of 715 more planets orbiting other stars, bringing the total of exoplanets, as they are known, to about 1,700.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after a pointing system failure ended the main planet-hunting mission of NASA’s Kepler spacecraft, planets continue to pour out of the sky.

headline: The Payments Challenge for Mobile Carriers
abstract: The rise of mobile payments start-ups has raised questions of whether they could be nimble enough to quickly outflank telecommunications carriers, which have invested heavily in their own mobile payments operations.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain – Every cellphone operator is looking for ways to persuade customers to use their smartphones to buy goods online.

headline: After 4-Year Overhaul, Library Is to Reopen in Washington Heights
abstract: When the library opens for the first time in almost four years, it will include what may be the first plaque bearing the name of Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: Snowstorm after snowstorm, imbroglio upon imbroglio, Bill de Blasio has had a tough few weeks. However, even an embryonic mayoralty comes with a few ego-salving perquisites, like dedicatory plaques with your name on them.

headline: At Washington Theater, Imagining Scalia
abstract: The 65th season at Arena Stage in Washington, D.C., will include “The Originalist,” a political drama about a liberal law clerk and Justice Antonin Scalia.
lead_paragraph: Justice Antonin Scalia, meet Justice Antonin Scalia.

headline: A Hedge Fund Manager Says SAC Taint Is Manageable
abstract: Dmitry Balyasny’s hedge fund Balyasny Asset Management has hired three people who used to work for SAC Capital Advisors and, he said, would consider hiring more.
lead_paragraph: Dmitry Balyasny is one hedge fund owner who isn’t afraid of hiring traders from SAC Capital Advisors as long as they were far away from the “messiness” that engulfed the firm during the federal government’s crackdown on insider trading.

headline: The Madness of War Told in the First Person
abstract: “Redeployment,” a debut collection of short stories by an Iraq war veteran, Phil Klay, provides a visceral feeling for what it is like to be a soldier in a combat zone, and what it is like to return home.
lead_paragraph: “You can’t describe it to someone who wasn’t there,” says a Marine who’s served in Iraq, “you can hardly remember how it was yourself because it makes so little sense. And to act like somebody could live and fight for months” there “and not go insane, well, that’s what’s really crazy.”

headline: A Pregnant Worker, Forced to Go on Unpaid Leave, Is Back on the Job
abstract: Floralba Fernandez Espinal, the subject of a recent “Working Life” column, is back at work thanks to the Pregnant Workers Fairness Act.
lead_paragraph: As readers of “The Working Life” column know, Floralba Fernandez Espinal was forced out of her job at a thrift store in the Bronx last month because she was pregnant and could no longer do heavy lifting.

keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Research', 'Age, Chronological', 'Parenting']
abstract: Children born to middle-aged men are more likely to develop any of a range of mental difficulties, like attention deficits, bipolar disorder, autism and schizophrenia, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: Children born to middle-aged men are more likely than their older siblings to develop any of a range of mental difficulties, including bipolar disorder, autism and schizophrenia, according to the most comprehensive study to date of paternal age and offspring mental health.

headline: The Moment | Endless Sunday
abstract: A relaxed hippie vibe runs through men’s wear this spring with casual cuts and let-loose prints — a welcome break from the buttoned-up look of workaday clothes.
lead_paragraph: A relaxed hippie vibe runs through men’s wear this spring with casual cuts and let-loose prints — a welcome break from the buttoned-up look of workaday clothes.

headline: Brain Trauma Extends to the Soccer Field
abstract: Researchers found C.T.E., a disease linked to football and boxing, in a soccer player who loved to head the ball, although they said the cause was inconclusive.
lead_paragraph: Chronic traumatic encephalopathy, the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated blows to the head, has been found posthumously in a 29-year-old former soccer player, the strongest indication yet that the condition is not limited to athletes who played sports known for violent collisions, like football and boxing.

headline: Syria Ships Mustard Gas to Port to Be Destroyed
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: International officials monitoring Syria’s compliance with a pledge to destroy its chemical weapons arsenal called the shipment an important step.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — After weeks of deepening foreign frustration over missed deadlines and other delays in Syria’s elimination of its chemical weapons, the international mission policing the process reported on Wednesday that Syria had delivered a significant consignment of mustard gas, one of the deadliest toxic agents, to the Syrian port of Latakia to be exported and destroyed.

headline: A General Theory of Obamacare Fiction

lead_paragraph: Conservatives appear to be really upset that liberals are actually taking on the facts in the anti-Obamacare ads they’ve been running. How dare you question whether the people in these ads are giving an accurate picture — they’re suffering!

headline: Supreme Court Permits Investor Lawsuits in Stanford Fraud
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'States (US)']
abstract: In a 7-to-2 decision, the court said the suits could proceed under state laws because the scheme did not concern securities traded on a national exchange.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday allowed investors to pursue class-action suits against law firms, insurance brokers and financial services companies that the investors said bore partial responsibility for one of the most brazen frauds in recent history, the $7 billion Ponzi scheme orchestrated by R. Allen Stanford.

headline: Library Renovation Plan Awaits Word From de Blasio

abstract: The future of the proposed renovations to the New York Public Library on 42nd Street is among the big unknowns in the new de Blasio administration.
lead_paragraph: As a candidate last summer, Bill de Blasio told Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that New York City should stop financing the ambitious renovation of the Fifth Avenue flagship of the New York Public Library until someone figured out how much it was all going to cost.

abstract: The Supreme Court unanimously ruled against an antiwar protester convicted of breaking federal law by entering an area near Vandenberg Air Force Base, from which he had been banned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday unanimously ruled against an antiwar protester who was convicted of breaking federal law by entering an area set aside for protests near the main entrance to Vandenberg Air Force Base, from which he had been barred.

headline: Pace Picks Yassky, Ex-Taxi Chief, as Its Law School Dean
abstract: David S. Yassky, who as taxi commissioner in the Bloomberg administration introduced the Taxi of Tomorrow concept, previously taught at the New York University Law School.
lead_paragraph: Law school deans are rarely familiar faces, but Pace University is getting one who should be recognizable to anyone who slid into a New York City taxi cab in the past few years.

headline: Pivotal Point Is Seen as More States Consider Legalizing Marijuana
abstract: A little over a year after Colorado and Washington made the drug legal, more than half the states are considering decriminalizing or legalizing it for medical or recreational use.
lead_paragraph: A little over a year after Colorado and Washington legalized marijuana, more than half the states, including some in the conservative South, are considering decriminalizing the drug or legalizing it for medical or recreational use. That has set up a watershed year in the battle over whether marijuana should be as available as alcohol.

headline: A Republican’s Tax Overhaul Envisions Big Changes
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Income Tax', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Taxation']
abstract: A proposal from Representative Dave Camp of Michigan would collapse seven personal income tax brackets to two and lower the corporate tax rate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Big banks would face a new tax on lending. Taxes paid to state and local governments would no longer be deductible. The earned income credit for low-wage workers would be converted to a more limited deduction on payroll taxes. The mortgage deduction and retirement savings breaks would be curtailed.

headline: Kerry Sees Syrian Retaliation Against Rivals in Talks

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department accused the Syrian government on Wednesday of retaliating against the Syrian opposition’s representatives to the Geneva peace talks by arresting their family members.

headline: Blackstone Said to Be Near a Deal to Invest in Versace
abstract: The Blackstone Group is contemplating buying a roughly 20 percent stake in Versace at a valuation of about 1 billion euros, or $1.37 billion, in the latest sign that the finance industry’s interest in high fashion shows few signs of abating.
lead_paragraph: Versace is in advanced discussions to take on the Blackstone Group as a minority investor, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, in the latest sign that the finance industry’s interest in high fashion shows few signs of abating.

headline: England, Conflicted on Its Place in Europe, Looks to Germany
abstract: But analysts warn that the expectations that the British prime minister has about making changes to the union are unrealistic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany will address members of both Houses of Parliament, have lunch with Prime Minister David Cameron at 10 Downing Street and then meet Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace for afternoon tea.

headline: Josephine Le Tutour Transforms Backstage at Rochas
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Josephine Le Tutour (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Luigi Murenu.

headline: Test Is Improved Predictor of Fetal Disorders
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Medicine and Health', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: The screen, called the cell-free DNA test, was 10 times more accurate than now-standard tests in discovering cases of Down syndrome, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: A test that analyzes fetal DNA found in a pregnant woman’s blood proved much more accurate in screening for Down syndrome and another chromosomal disorder than the now-standard blood test, a new study has found. The promising results may change how prenatal screening for genetic diseases is done, though the test is costly and generally not yet covered by insurance for women at low risk.

headline: Performing Beethoven as a Birthright
abstract: The Vienna Philharmonic, joined by the New York Choral Artists, performed Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony and Schoenberg’s seldom-heard “Friede auf Erden” on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: With the technical level of orchestras rising overall in recent decades, we are almost accustomed to hearing precise, incisive performances of Beethoven’s formidable Ninth Symphony. Yet, on Tuesday night, for the first concert of Carnegie Hall’s ambitious three-week festival Vienna: City of Dreams, the conductor Franz Welser-Möst led the illustrious Vienna Philharmonic in an account of Beethoven’s Ninth that had curious moments of shaky playing.

headline: In Ukraine, Naming of Interim Government Gets Mixed Response
abstract: As the names of the proposed ministers were read in Independence Square in Kiev, it became clear just how completely the ordinary people had seized control of the direction of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Standing before a crowd of tens of thousands in Independence Square, the center of the three-month civic uprising that ousted President Viktor F. Yanukovych, the lawmakers temporarily controlling Ukraine announced an interim government on Wednesday night to be led by Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, a veteran public official.

headline: England vs. Russia-Netherlands at NEC Bridge Festival
abstract: The 19th NEC Bridge Festival was held in Yokohama City, Japan, from Feb. 11 to 16.
lead_paragraph: The 19th NEC Bridge Festival was held in Yokohama City, Japan, from Feb. 11 to 16. Perhaps for the first time, there were no players from the United States or Canada. The only North American presence was provided by the Daily Bulletin editors, Rich Colker of Wheaton, Md., and Barry Rigal of New York City.

headline: Three Types of Passion Made Flesh
abstract: The Lyon Opera Ballet, in France, is offering a triple bill that includes a new work by Rachid Ouramdane.
lead_paragraph: LYON, France — The choreographer Rachid Ouramdane isn’t exactly an obvious candidate for a ballet company commission. Working in a contemporary idiom, he has created a number of impressive pieces that reflect on torture, post-traumatic stress, war and occupation, possibly drawing on his French-Algerian background.

headline: An Orchestra Plays Backup Band as a Countertenor Takes Center Stage
abstract: The Venice Baroque Orchestra and the countertenor Philippe Jaroussky performed works by Nicola Porpora at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: When the Venice Baroque Orchestra visited Zankel Hall a year ago, it showed off the virtuosity of its individual members and of the group as a whole. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday evening, it served mainly as a backup band — an excellent one, to be sure — for the brilliant French countertenor Philippe Jaroussky.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'United States Politics and Government']

abstract: The actor was in Washington D.C. on Wednesday to discuss the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
lead_paragraph: The actor was in Washington D.C. on Wednesday to discuss the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

headline: The Promise and Pitfalls in a Tax Reform Plan
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Law and Legislation', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: A plan to overhaul the tax system, put forward by a leading House Republican, reflects some political bravery but will fall short in revenue, and it is unclear who would gain or lose, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Bold Lines at Dries Van Noten
abstract: A thick swipe of black makeup played up the graphic quality of the designer’s fall/winter 2014 collection.
lead_paragraph: At Dries Van Noten, the only beauty detail as bold as the graphic designs on the fall/winter 2014 collection was the black stripe the makeup artist Peter Philips painted above the models’ upper lashes. He described the arch as having a certain fluidity, exuding “the feeling of being done in one motion.” Philips used a pigment-heavy M.A.C. Chromacake body paint, which he thinned out with a little water-based mixing medium and applied using a flat Giorgio Armani eye shader brush. The rest of the face was kept bare and muted to keep the focus on the colorful, eye-catching looks.

headline: Ben Affleck Urges Action in Congo
abstract: The actor discussed the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo at the State Department with Secretary of State John Kerry and former Senator Russ Feingold, the special envoy for the region.
lead_paragraph: The actor discussed the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo at the State Department with Secretary of State John Kerry and former Senator Russ Feingold, the special envoy for the region.

headline: OSHA’s Investigative Report on Daniel Curry’s Accident in ‘Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark’
abstract: A report by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration on Daniel Curry’s accident on Aug. 15, 2013, during a performance of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.”
lead_paragraph: A report by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration on Daniel Curry’s accident on Aug. 15, 2013, during a performance of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.”

headline: Eat Your Spinach and Win the Game, Too
abstract: Trip Hawkins, the founder of Electronic Arts and other game companies, is introducing a new game meant to teach players social-emotional learning.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has ever made a video game with an agenda beyond entertainment has faced the same challenge: How do you hide that agenda to avoid turning off players? Trip Hawkins, the founder of Electronic Arts and other game companies, describes this as making sure “kids are having fun and not smelling the spinach.”

headline: Injured ‘Spider-Man’ Dancer Discusses His Lawsuit
abstract: A cast member of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” whose foot and leg were partly crushed during a performance, discusses his lawsuit in his first interview since the accident.
lead_paragraph: It was a stunt that Daniel Curry had performed many times before in the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”: Plant himself firmly on a hydraulic lift in the pit beneath the stage, then remain steady as he rose a dozen feet to emerge for the start of Act II.

headline: Huawei and ZTE Look to Sell More Smartphones Abroad
keywords: ['Mobile World Congress (Trade Show)', 'Smartphones', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: Huawei and ZTE have a lot in common. They both primarily sell networking equipment but want to be bigger in consumer products, like smartphones.
lead_paragraph: Huawei and ZTE have a lot in common. They both primarily sell networking equipment, and they both want to be a more powerful force in consumer products like smartphones.

headline: Older Fathers: Assessing the Risks
keywords: ['Age, Chronological', 'Men and Boys', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: In the most comprehensive study to date of paternal age and offspring mental health, researchers found that “children born to middle-aged men are more likely than those born to younger fathers to develop any of a range of mental difficulties.” But as with most such research, this investigation comes with many caveats.
lead_paragraph: The question of whether a father’s age at a child’s conception puts that child at an increased risk of developing various disorders has intrigued scientists for some time. In the most comprehensive study to date of paternal age and offspring mental health (published in the journal JAMA Psychiatry and reported in The New York Times by Benedict Carey), researchers found that “children born to middle-aged men are more likely than those born to younger fathers to develop any of a range of mental difficulties, including attention deficits, bipolar disorder, autism and schizophrenia.”

headline: Don’t Ask for the Moon, Name-Drop the Stars
abstract: The drag performer Charles Busch, in his new stage comedy “The Tribute Artist,” drops the names of countless old-Hollywood figures and accessories. Here’s a guide.
lead_paragraph: Say “Now, Voyager” to a binge watcher of Turner Classic Movies or a gay man of a certain age, and you’ll get a knowing smile, a strong opinion and a quotation. (“Don’t let’s ask for the moon. We have the stars.”) Talk to someone not versed in the Bette Davis canon, and you might get a blank stare and something about “Star Trek.”

headline: In Athens, the Last Man Painting
abstract: Vasilis Dimitriou, 78, is the last movie billboard painter in Greece, and one of only a handful in Europe, his craft on the verge of extinction.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Leonardo DiCaprio’s face glowed triumphantly from a large billboard here atop the Athinaion, an old movie theater where “The Wolf of Wall Street” was recently playing. Mr. DiCaprio had just been nominated for an Oscar, and Vasilis Dimitriou had painted him larger than life, with a gleaming gold statuette against a sea of red and black brush strokes.

headline: As Ukraine Crisis Rumbles, Georgian Premier Visits U.S.
abstract: The prime minister of Georgia said Russia was putting pressure on his country, another former Soviet republic that is leaning toward the West.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Irakli Garibashvili of Georgia met with Secretary of State John Kerry on Wednesday to discuss ways to develop his nation’s economy and reinforce its pro-Western path. But the tumultuous events in Ukraine, and Moscow’s decision to send a message by conducting a surprise military exercise in western Russia, have cast a shadow on the Georgian leader’s visit here.

headline: Flight Suits in Italian Wool
abstract: J. Crew suits get first-class upgrades; the skinny scarf remains a sleeper staple; new takes on socks and sneakers keep feet on trend.
lead_paragraph: Weary business travelers, increasingly inured to the indignities of air travel, take note: J. Crew understands your plight. It has modified its best-selling Ludlow suit with a specially woven three-ply Italian wool to resist rumpling, wrinkling and unsightly creasing. On sale Wednesday, and available in navy, pale gray and charcoal, the suits almost guarantee an upgrade upon arrival.

headline: Kelly Osbourne, From Party Girl to Fashion Sage
abstract: Ms. Osbourne walks out of rehab and onto the red carpet.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Osbourne is certainly no stranger to fame. In fact, it runs in the family.

headline: Police Officer Is Shot in Legs in Brooklyn
abstract: Officer James Li, 26, was injured in Crown Heights on Wednesday after removing a man who had boarded a bus through a back door without paying, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A first-year New York City police officer was shot in the legs on Wednesday evening in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, by a man he and his partner had just pulled off a bus for failing to pay the fare, the police said.

headline: Four Marvel TV Shows to Film in New York
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced that Walt Disney and Marvel Studios would spend about $200 million shooting the live-action series in New York City. All of the shows will debut on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: Across the metropolis, weary residents mutter about a tale of two cities, wondering who will bring back the jobs.

headline: No Conflict of Interest Found in Favorable Review of Keystone Pipeline
abstract: The environmental report was called tainted because an early draft included analysis by a contractor that had previously done work for the company seeking to build the Keystone XL pipeline.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A State Department contractor who prepared an environmental analysis of the Keystone XL pipeline did not violate conflict-of-interest rules, even though the contractor had previously done work for TransCanada, the company seeking to build the pipeline, a State Department inspector general’s investigation concluded on Wednesday.

headline: On Safari in Widowhood
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Reality Television', 'Widows and Widowers']
abstract: After devastating losses, Carole Radziwill, the writer and reality TV star, has moved on with life and love.
lead_paragraph: In Carole Radziwill’s new novel, “The Widow’s Guide to Sex and Dating,” the main character, a woman whose husband died five months earlier, is taken by a friend to the Grill Room at the Four Seasons, a place described as a Serengeti for billionaires.

headline: Disclosing the Fees on Prepaid Debit Cards
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Debit Cards']
abstract: Pew Charitable Trusts has proposed a uniform explanation of terms, and JPMorgan Chase will adopt the format for its Liquid card.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever shopped for a prepaid debit card, you may have found it difficult to determine just what fees the cards charge and what terms they offer, because the cards vary in the type of information, if any, they disclose.

headline: One Unhappy Guy
abstract: Twitter followers react to Alec Baldwin’s New York Magazine article discussing Shia LaBeouf, Anderson Cooper and others.
lead_paragraph: In a 5,000-word cover article in New York magazine this week, Alec Baldwin took aim at Shia LaBeouf (“a jailhouse mentality”), his former MSNBC colleagues Joe Scarborough (“neither eloquent or funny”) and Rachel Maddow (“a phony who doesn’t have the same passion for truth off-camera that she does on air”) and Anderson Cooper of CNN (“the self-appointed Jack Valenti of gay media culture”). Mr. Baldwin’s admission that “I find myself bitter, defensive, and more misanthropic than I care to admit” didn’t find much disagreement on Twitter.

headline: After a Fire Sale, Time to Reminisce
abstract: On Wednesday night, the last of 39 Loehmann’s stores closed for business, including four in New York City, where the company got its start in the 1920s.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, the last of 39 Loehmann’s stores closed for business, including four in New York City, where the company got its start in the 1920s. On the heels of Daffy’s and Filene’s Basement, such a demise may indicate a declining middle class, or a retail landscape transformed by the Internet and Goliath-like chains, or some combination. What’s certain is that it is leaving a lot of nostalgic shoppers.

lead_paragraph: The nationwide poll was conducted Feb. 19 to 23 by landline and cellphone among 1,644 adults.

headline: G.O.P., Though Deeply Split, Has Election Edge, Poll Shows
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Though most Americans agree more with Democratic policy positions, the Republican Party is benefiting from the support of self-described independents.
lead_paragraph: Republicans are in a stronger position than Democrats for this year’s midterm elections, benefiting from the support of self-described independents, even though the party itself is deeply divided and most Americans agree more with Democratic policy positions, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows.

headline: Views on Voting and the Political Parties
abstract: How do the Republicans and the Democrats differ? How are they similar? The New York Times and CBS News asked Americans for their views on various issues, their attitudes toward the parties and their opinion of a number of possible presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: How do the Republicans and the Democrats differ? How are they similar? The New York Times and CBS News asked Americans for their views on various issues, their attitudes toward the parties and their opinion of a number of possible presidential candidates.

headline: Beauty News
abstract: The trend of ordering services on the go through apps has now extended to booking beauty technicians.
lead_paragraph: The trend of ordering services on the go through apps like Uber and Seamless has now extended to booking beauty technicians who will visit the location of your choice. These examples are free to download, and the cost of services includes tax and tip.

headline: Power Tools for a Red Carpet Look
abstract: A few new devices can help create Oscar-worthy hair.
lead_paragraph: As Oscar gowns have become more formal, so too has the hair that accompanies them. Gone are the days when actresses would walk the red carpet with their locks tucked under a crocheted cap (Ali MacGraw, 1971), raked into an outlandish Bob Mackie headdress (Cher, 1986) or casually combed (Michelle Pfeiffer, 1990). On Sunday, viewers will see a parade of stylized looks, like Reese Witherspoon’s Veronica Lake waves at the ceremony last year and Emma Watson’s stern bun at the most recent Golden Globes.

headline: Boldface Gems
abstract: Jewelry designers competing for red-carpet exposure on Oscar night in hope of raising their profile are training their sights on a handful of stars with a strong fashion presence.
lead_paragraph: With eight days remaining until Oscar night on Sunday, Pamela Love wasn’t taking any chances. An arrowhead pendant of her design swung like an amulet from her throat; snakes and pentagrams gleamed on her fingers, and a sprinkling of tattoos marked her wrists.

headline: Connected to the Oven via an App
abstract: GE now makes it possible to control its Profile wall ovens with a smart phone — if you have the nerve.
lead_paragraph: In the push to automate home appliances, the oven remains a tough sell. Who hasn’t panicked that they stepped out of the house and accidentally left the oven on? To do so intentionally seems to invite a leap of faith.

headline: Covering All Corners of the Earth
abstract: Google Earth images are the foundation for a series of locally made carpets.
lead_paragraph: Weaving together geology, anthropology and Google Earth imagery, the Dutch designer Roosmarijn Pallandt has developed a series of carpets called Consider This Landscape a Territory. She begins with a bird’s-eye photograph of a rug-making region like northern Portugal, Nepal or Japan, then spends months researching each culture and its traditional rug-making techniques. Finally, she converts the original aerial image into a carpet produced by local artisans from natural materials. For the Flora rug, for example, which will be exhibited at the International Furniture Fair in Milan in April, a half-dozen women in Portugal hand-knotted felted wool yarn, jute and eucalyptus. The Ice carpet was knotted by a Tibetan family using wool from sheep, yak and goats combined with silk. The rugs can be ordered through Ms. Pallandt’s studio, in collaboration with Casalis, a Belgian carpet company. Prices start at about $1,168 per square meter. Information: roosmarijnpallandt.com.

headline: Dick Button Still Cuts a Fine Figure
abstract: The two-time Olympic gold medalist has a home filled with skating memorabilia and some thoughts about Johnny Weir.
lead_paragraph: When Dick Button, the figure skating analyst and a two-time Olympic gold medalist, faces a question he doesn’t care to answer, he either pretends he can’t hear it (a legitimate alibi for someone deaf in one ear) or acts as if he’s on a bad cellphone connection. “Hello, hello, HELLO!” he says in his deep broadcaster’s voice.

headline: Matters of Taste
abstract: More than ever, food is a promising frontier for designers working with scientists, technologists and, yes, even chefs.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the African country of Togo, Mansour Ourasanah knew what it was like to be hungry. But he assumed that limited food was a universal misfortune, like a head cold or a broken heart. Eventually he discovered that plenty of food was available for people with money; it was just that his family was poor.

headline: Bamboo Takes a Bow
abstract: The best use of the material makes the most of its flexibility.
lead_paragraph: While bamboo is gaining popularity as a sustainable material, it still doesn’t have the status of hardwoods like walnut or oak. But Elora Hardy can envision a day when it will.

headline: An Auction to Feed Others
abstract: The Dining Project, an auction of designer furniture and tabletop goods, will benefit orphans in Nepal.
lead_paragraph: A dining room that can support 4,500 meals a month? That’s what one New York City nonprofit is hoping for when it auctions a roomful of designer furnishings this week to benefit orphans in Nepal.

lead_paragraph: Evan Fry is known for the quirky, irreverent commercials he creates for companies like Volkswagen, Harley-Davidson and Burger King in his role as an advertising executive. One of the wackiest, directed by Spike Jonze, involved the gleeful annihilation of a Gap store by its employees — Mr. Fry’s answer to the question of how an established brand should announce its reinvention.

headline: Citing Long-Delayed G.M. Recall, Senator Calls for Change in Safety Agency’s Process
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Edward Markey faults N.H.T.S.A.’s early warning system over 10-year investigation into G.M. defect that led to a 1.4 million-vehicle recall.
lead_paragraph: The 10-year investigation and problematic recall of 1.4 million General Motors cars related to 13 deaths shows that the government’s early-warning reporting system isn’t working, Senator Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat, said on Wednesday in a letter to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Had the system worked better, it might have saved lives, Mr. Markey said in the letter to David Friedman, the acting administrator of the safety agency.

headline: Art Checks in at a London Hotel
abstract: Dozens of artists have decorated the rooms and public spaces of the Ace in Shoreditch.
lead_paragraph: Guests who check into Room 134 at the Ace Hotel London Shoreditch will find one wall covered with a color photograph by Richard Evans of autumnal countryside. In Room 113, Jonathan Barnbrook has created a large-scale piece inspired by neoclassical Victorian typography, above, while the walls of Suites 533 and 534 are hung with Justine Ashbee’s woven textiles in simple geometric patterns.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Warm and Comfortable Winter Wear
abstract: With head-to-toe matching knits, designers prove that the coziest of clothes can also be chic.
lead_paragraph: With cozy head-to-toe knits, designers are fast turning hibernation into a dressing category of its own. In their fall/winter 2014 collections, they’re layering oversize, monochromatic, luxurious separates — sweaters, pants, skirts and tunic dresses — that cradle the body in coziness. The first sighting of the look was in New York at The Row, where the designers Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen redefined our understanding of comfortable luxury with overwhelmingly voluminous knits including a cowl-necked, bell-sleeved sweater paired with a matching skirt. The trend continued at Marc Jacobs, whose neutral collection was filled with plush, nubby matching separates like a ribbed, V-neck long sweater with coordinating leggings and scarf. And at Edun, a sporty ivory tank dress paired with slouchy trousers and sneakers in the same color looked like the ultimate weekend wardrobe. The trend has continued to unfold in London, Milan and, now, Paris. Come fall, accepting unannounced guests at home will have never looked better.

headline: To Save on Defense, Hire Rivals
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: In the long run, hiring rival producers keeps costs down and weapons quality up.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — RECENT proposals to slash the troop levels of the regular Army illustrate how much pressure the United States government is under to shrink its military budget, even as it revamps and re-equips its forces for future conflicts. To meet all of those goals at the same time, we need to turn to one of the commercial world’s most basic cost-control weapons — competition.

headline: Hard Talk Aside, Little Desire by the West to Leave Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: While President Obama and NATO officials have talked of a withdrawal by year’s end, Western officials worry that swaths of the country would fall back under Taliban control.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Listening to the Western defense officials gathered at a NATO meeting here on Wednesday, it would be easy to think that the United States and the rest of the international military coalition in Afghanistan have shifted into a full-speed withdrawal from the country by year’s end.

headline: Handset Makers Go Big on Smartphones
abstract: The turn to bigger screens is a sharp departure from the dominant strategy of phone makers just a few years ago, when critics said people would never buy them.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Smartphones are going against one of the long-held rules in portable electronics, that smaller is better.

headline: Dodging Queries on Arrest, Felton Looks to Postseason
abstract: The arrest of Raymond Felton, the Knicks’ starting point guard, on gun charges is the latest distraction for a team that has faced many this season.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Appearing without prepared notes, Raymond Felton took a seat Wednesday afternoon behind a thin yellow divider that, from a distance, could have been misconstrued as police tape. This was the setting for a 53-second statement in which Felton, the Knicks’ starting point guard, declined to address his arrest Tuesday on felony gun charges.

headline: Obama’s Pipeline
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Environment', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Keystone XL shows how business still drives environmental policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WHEN I was elected to Congress in 2002, George W. Bush was president and big business wrote environmental policy. We all remember Vice President Dick Cheney’s energy task force — a who’s who of mining and oil interests — and the administration’s constant questioning of climate science.

headline: Federal Court Orders YouTube to Take Down Controversial Anti-Islam Video
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The “Innocence of Muslims” video on YouTube set off a fierce debate over free speech in 2012, but a federal court ruling on Wednesday was about an entirely different legal issue: copyright.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ordered YouTube to take down a controversial anti-Islam video in an unusual copyright decision that Google, which owns YouTube, said raised questions about freedom of speech.

headline: Arizona Governor Vetoes Bill on Refusal of Service to Gays
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: The measure would have allowed business owners to refuse to serve gay people and others if doing so ran counter to their religious beliefs.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Ending a day that cast a glaring national spotlight on Arizona, Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, vetoed a bill on Wednesday that would have given business owners the right to refuse service to gay men, lesbians and other people on religious grounds.

headline: Senate Panel Says Credit Suisse Helped Hide U.S. Assets
abstract: Senators accused the bank of helping thousands of Americans hide billions of dollars in assets from United States tax authorities.
lead_paragraph: Senators on both sides of the aisle criticized Credit Suisse at a hearing on Wednesday, saying it helped thousands of Americans hide billions of dollars in assets from United States tax authorities.

headline: Health Law’s Small Co-ops Have Had a Mixed Success So Far
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Cooperatives', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: How the co-ops perform will help determine whether the new health care law can inject more competition into the nation’s entrenched insurance market.
lead_paragraph: The rented offices of HealthyCT, a new insurer in Connecticut, bustle with the energy of a start-up. The sales force takes pride in noting that HealthyCT is a truly local outfit, governed by members, rather than a for-profit behemoth like Anthem, the state’s dominant insurer whose offices are a 10-minute drive away.

headline: Cable Channel Taps Multicultural Roots
abstract: The El Rey Network, owned by the director Robert Rodriguez, and senior executives outlined their goals for the channel at an “upfront” presentation to advertisers.
lead_paragraph: A FLEDGLING cable channel founded by a filmmaker known for action fare aimed at a multicultural audience is adding to its original programming — and its deals with advertisers — as the annual upfront bazaar for the sale of television commercial time gets underway.
