lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Tesla Plans $5 Billion Battery Factory for Mass-Market Electric Car
abstract: Tesla, which markets a $70,000-plus electric sedan, took aim at the broader market in announcing a way to make the batteries that power the cars cheaper.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors said on Wednesday that it planned to invest about $2 billion in a large-scale factory to produce cheaper batteries for a mass-market electric car within three years.

headline: Funds and New Timetable for Offshore Wind Farm in Massachusetts
abstract: Cape Wind, the much-delayed offshore wind project proposed for Nantucket Sound, said it would finish its financing this fall and begin producing power by 2016.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Cape Wind, the much-delayed offshore wind farm project proposed for Nantucket Sound, said Wednesday that it had received a new loan commitment that would allow it to finish its financing this fall and begin producing power by 2016.

headline: U.S. and European Regulators Call Popular Diabetes Drugs Safe
abstract: In an unusual joint paper, officials said that assertions by some researchers that the drugs could cause pancreatic inflammation were “inconsistent with the current data.”
lead_paragraph: A year after beginning investigations of the safety of some of the world’s most popular diabetes drugs, regulators in both the United States and Europe said their own research and reviews of study data indicated little cause for concern.

headline: Kerry Condemns Uganda’s Antigay Law
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry on Wednesday condemned the antigay measure signed into law in Uganda this week, saying it is as serious a moral offense as anti-Semitism in 1930s Germany or apartheid in white-led South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry on Wednesday condemned the antigay measure signed into law in Uganda this week, saying it is as serious a moral offense as anti-Semitism in 1930s Germany or apartheid in white-led South Africa. “You could be in 1930s Germany or you could be in 1950s, ’60s apartheid South Africa,” Mr. Kerry told reporters. “The signing of this antihomosexuality bill is flat-out morally wrong.” The Uganda law imposes harsh sentences for homosexual acts, including life imprisonment in some cases, according to government officials. Mr. Kerry said the legislation was “bigger than just Uganda” and added that there were 78 other countries in which “you have these laws that are just contrary to human rights and contrary to human nature.”

headline: ‘Tonight’ Starts Well, on YouTube and on TV
abstract: The new “Tonight” show hosted by Jimmy Fallon has gathered a big secondary audience of online viewers in addition to its impressive television ratings.
lead_paragraph: The traditional television ratings have been impressive for the first week-plus of the new “Tonight” show hosted by Jimmy Fallon, but they do not include what amounts to a giant secondary audience that has gathered online to watch carefully crafted and curated highlights of the show on YouTube and other sites.

headline: Shrugging Off Past Setbacks, Obama Plans Personal Role in Middle East Peace Bid
abstract: President Obama will press Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to agree to a framework for a conclusive round of peace talks, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, after avoiding a hands-on role in Middle East peacemaking since the setbacks of his first term, plans to plunge back into the effort, his advisers said this week, starting with an urgent appeal to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

headline: Silver Belles at Dries Van Noten
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: Metallic ankle boots made of solid and stamped gray felt.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.Though it was presented in a gilded, chandelier-lined room in the opulent Hôtel de Ville in Paris, Dries Van Noten’s fall/winter collection was anything but Old World in feel. Day-glo corsages were draped atop men’s wear coats, separates sported rave-like colors and drop-waist dresses cast an iridescent sheen. The shoes, like the clothes, were modern, wearable and a touch futuristic. This ankle boot combined solid and metallic-stamped felt with a mirrored-leather heel for a tone-on-tone texture play that elegantly balanced the old and the new.

headline: A Supreme Court Patent Case Comes Down to a War of Adjectives
abstract: In a closely watched “patent trolls” case, justices seem as concerned about the language of the ruling as the ruling itself.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday heard arguments in two cases that some technology companies hope will address what they say are abusive and coercive lawsuits brought by “patent trolls,” or companies that buy patents not to use them but to collect royalties and damages.

headline: Keepsakes From Across the Border
abstract: Would my American sons look at Mexico the same way I did as a boy, with disdain?
lead_paragraph: It was the summer of 1980, and I was 7 years old, when I traveled to America for the first time. I came to Los Angeles with my mom. The trip, which included visits to Disneyland and Sea World and Knott’s Berry Farm, was the reward my parents gave me for finishing first grade with honors. The Mexican middle class has always been as pampering in its affections as aspirational in its customs, and my family was no exception.

headline: Prize Catch for Ukrainians at Boat Harbor: A Soggy Trove of Government Secrets
abstract: Documents fished out of the water provide a portrait of the final weeks, days and hours of members of a besieged inner circle trying desperately to maintain their grip on the government.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The papers were first spotted swirling in the eddies of a boat harbor on the sprawling compound of the former Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, on the outskirts of Kiev. Intrigued, the protesters-turned-security guards who had taken over the grounds found a raft and began fishing the documents out of the water. Later, they recruited a diver to retrieve sunken nylon bags of files from the riverbed.

headline: Plan Offers No Picnic for Union Square Park
abstract: A proposal to place a high-priced restaurant in the park has been fought for years by neighborhood residents, who say it would eliminate “one of the most famous free-speech sites.”
lead_paragraph: Oh thank God, finally we will have a place to catch a high-toned meal inside Union Square Park.

headline: Targeting the Johns in Sex Trade
abstract: Police are beginning to realize that fighting sex trafficking and prostitution means arresting the men who sustain it. Pimps and johns.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Several police officers are waiting in a hotel room, handcuffs at the ready, when they get the signal. A female undercover officer posing as a prostitute is with a would-be customer in an adjacent room, and she has pushed a secret button indicating that they should charge in to make the arrest.

headline: Rogen Tells Congress of Family’s Struggle With Alzheimer’s
abstract: The comic actor Seth Rogen testified before a Senate subcommittee in an effort to raise awareness of Alzheimer’s disease and tell how it has affected his family.
lead_paragraph: Seth Rogen opened his testimony to a Senate panel on Wednesday with a quip.

headline: No Country for Old Mores
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Just as young people are turning away from religions that don’t tolerate gay and lesbian people, they may turn from the Republican Party, too.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s S.B. 1062, part of the conservative “Jim Queer” crusade to use religious liberty as means of codifying discrimination against people for their sexual identities, once again places conservatives on the wrong side of history and further marginalizes an intolerance-obsessed party during an inclusion-oriented era.

headline: Where Derek Jeter Is, Mark Teixeira Once Was
abstract: Mark Teixeira was 20 when he sustained an ankle injury similar to Derek Jeter’s. Teixeira said Jeter’s age might help him: he doesn’t have to worry about his career, only his final season.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter said he was not concerned about his surgically repaired left ankle on the eve of his scheduled Grapefruit League debut Thursday, 501 days after he shattered it.

headline: Fresh Produce Comes to the Bronx via a Veggie Mart on Wheels
abstract: The leader of a South Bronx nonprofit group is filling an old school bus with a cornucopia of locally and organically grown vegetables and fruit and taking it to the streets.
lead_paragraph: The old school bus painted with big green and purple leaves pushed through the icy rain to ease alongside Southern Boulevard in the South Bronx. The door swung open with a squeak, revealing a cornucopia of organic eggs, potatoes, onions, garlic, cabbage, apples and turnips piled on the seats.

headline: A New York Observer Article Brings a Spat in Trump’s Orbit
abstract: An article on the New York attorney general portrayed him as vindictive and politically opportunistic. It also included a defense of Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Bill Gifford was managing an ice cream shop in Maplewood, N.J., last summer when a customer, Ken Kurson, the editor of The New York Observer, came in with an unorthodox request. He wanted Mr. Gifford, a 28-year-old political science major who was seeking a new job but had almost no journalistic experience, to write an article about the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman.

headline: The State of Arizona
abstract: What went down over a state bill and a governor’s veto was weird, but it means something.
lead_paragraph: Arizona. Wow. How often do you find yourself saying, “Go, entrenched interests of the business community!” Yet here we are.

headline: New York City Council Swiftly Passes Bill to Extend Paid Sick Days
abstract: The more emphatically liberal Council expanded the law to require businesses with five or more employees to provide up to five paid days off a year.
lead_paragraph: The new, more emphatically liberal City Council was in full swing on Wednesday, expanding New York’s law on paid sick leave from the watered-down version passed last year and approving a resolution supporting Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to raise taxes on the wealthy to pay for expanded prekindergarten.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 26, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Cooking Techniques: Frosting a Cake
abstract: Make sure every bite of cake includes an even amount of frosting.
lead_paragraph: Make sure every bite of cake includes an even amount of frosting.

headline: Fertilizer Limits Sought Near Lake Erie to Fight Spread of Algae
abstract: Phosphorus runoff from farms and lawns has helped to create a vast blanket of toxic algae each summer, a United States-Canadian agency said.
lead_paragraph: A United States-Canadian agency called on Wednesday for swift and sweeping limits on the use of fertilizer around Lake Erie to reduce the amount of phosphorus entering the water and creating a vast blanket of algae each summer, threatening fisheries, tourism and even drinking water.

headline: No Respite on the Court for the Knicks
abstract: On the basketball court, Raymond Felton and his much-maligned teammates are reminded of how much they have undermined the mandate of measuring up to mollify Carmelo Anthony.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — As if Raymond Felton weren’t having enough trouble keeping opposing point guards out of the lane, his estranged wife went around him to deliver his gun, unregistered in New York, to the police. Already convicted in the court of public basketball opinion, he’s now been declared guilty by one city tabloid (“Raymond Felon”) of two criminal counts.

headline: Ukraine and the Perils of Division
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Russian Language', 'Editorials']
abstract: A Czechoslovakia-style split is an unworkable idea in a country where languages, ethnic identities and loyalties are mixed and muddled.
lead_paragraph: In the violence and chaos of the past week, the question has been raised whether stability might be served by dividing Ukraine, Czechoslovakia-style, into a Ukrainian-speaking northwest and a Russian-speaking southeast?

headline: Rift at Jewish School in Manhattan Over Canceled Plan for Israeli-Palestinian Talk
abstract: A student group at an Orthodox Jewish school extended an invitation to a Columbia professor to give his views on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but the head of the school rescinded it.
lead_paragraph: During a presentation on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Peter Beinart, an author and columnist who writes frequently on the topic, suggested to a group of high school students that they invite a particular Columbia University professor to give his views.

headline: Tears and Tissues as Editor Testifies in Phone Hacking Case
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: The tabloids Rebekah Brooks once edited might have paid six figures or more for details like those she has been divulging about her personal life during her trial on phone hacking charges.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The tabloids Rebekah Brooks once edited might have paid six figures or more for details like those she has been divulging about her personal life during her trial on phone hacking charges: the celebrity husband, the adultery, the infertility, the daughter by a surrogate mother.

headline: From Alabama, Hockey’s Ultimate Travel Team
abstract: Alabama-Huntsville is the only Division I men’s hockey team in the South, which can make for some challenging road trips.
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — The team’s trip earlier this season seemed planned by a crazed travel agent who threw darts at a map. Outbound, fly commercially from Huntsville to Denver, east to Chicago, then to Anchorage. On the return, jet from Anchorage to Seattle, then a stop in Houston before the final trip home. Total miles logged: 8,282.

headline: Liar’s Jackpot
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Editorials']
abstract: @GSElevator became famous on Twitter for writing about Wall Street co-workers he doesn’t know, in a place he never worked, and won a lucrative contract to tell all about it.
lead_paragraph: An unknown writer becomes famous on Twitter for compiling quotes he didn’t hear from Wall Street co-workers he doesn’t know, in a place he never worked — and wins a lucrative contract to tell all about it, in a real book.

headline: Better Lawyering for the Poor
abstract: A New York State program will give indigents representation in court while giving third-year students full-time practical training, as well as a useful mission.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, is making some innovative changes to the education and training of lawyers as well as to the workings of the court system that bear close watching around the country.

headline: Spike Lee Exchange Highlights Gentrification Debate
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Gentrification', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: During a speech at the Pratt Institute, the film director who grew up in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, blasted developers and gentrifiers who were sweeping into the largely black neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: All of David Crouch’s longtime neighbors on stately Adelphi Street in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, have the same story: the phone calls or the mailings or the knock on the door, week after week, with the same coaxing question and the same shimmering offer.

headline: A Simpler Tax Plan, Not a Better One
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Tax', 'Editorials', 'Taxation']
abstract: The Republican proposal fails to improve a tax code that is inadequate to the country’s needs.
lead_paragraph: The Republican tax plan unveiled in the House on Wednesday ensures that there will be no tax reform in the near future. It refuses to ask for greater sacrifice from the rich to bring in desperately needed revenue for rebuilding the country and improving education, which Democrats correctly regard as a huge missed opportunity. Hard-line conservatives, on the other hand, insist that changing the tax code should include slashing revenue, which the proposal avoids.

headline: Peter Rona, 79, Dies; Explorer Found Hot Springs on Ocean Floor
abstract: Discoveries made by Dr. Rona, a professor at Rutgers, piqued interest in deep-sea mining and the origins of life on earth.
lead_paragraph: Peter A. Rona, an oceanographer who dived into the depths of the world’s seas and surprised his peers by discovering vast mounds spewing hot smoke at the bottom of the icy Atlantic, exciting interests in deep-sea mining and the origins of life on earth, died on Feb. 20 in Plainsboro, N.J. He was 79.

headline: Arizona Governor Vetoes Bill
abstract: Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, vetoed a bill that would have given business owners the right to refuse service to gay men and lesbians on religious grounds.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, vetoed a bill that would have given business owners the right to refuse service to gay men and lesbians on religious grounds.

headline: Warlords With Dark Pasts Battle in Afghan Election
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Elections', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Six of the 11 presidential tickets in Afghanistan include at least one candidate viewed as a warlord, complicating U.S. efforts to get the next administration to sign a long-term security deal.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Ashraf Ghani, the apparent front-runner in the Afghan presidential race this year, was once unstinting in his opinion of one of the country’s most prominent warlords, Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, calling him a “known killer.”

headline: Chokwe Lumumba, 66, Dies; Activist Who Became Mayor in Mississippi
abstract: Mr. Lumumba, a civil rights lawyer who once called for an independent black-majority country in the American Southeast, handily won a race for mayor of Jackson, Miss., last year.
lead_paragraph: Chokwe Lumumba, a civil rights lawyer who once called for an independent black-majority country in the American Southeast before running for mayor of Jackson, Miss., last year, winning handily, died on Tuesday in Jackson. He was 66.

headline: Mind Cleared, McIlroy Now Is Seeking Staying Power
abstract: The Honda Classic represents a chance for 24-year-old Rory McIlroy to redeem himself after a hard lesson in balancing his professional and personal life in 2013.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Rory McIlroy arrived here a year ago ranked No. 1 in the world after an astonishing ascension that included two major tournament titles, bearing expectations that he would challenge and perhaps even dethrone Tiger Woods as golf’s dominant player.

headline: Neighbors Seek to Prevent Return of Chumley’s to Greenwich Village
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A lawsuit is challenging the decision to grant a new liquor license to the bar, which has been closed since a wall collapsed in 2007.
lead_paragraph: Jim Miller had looked forward to 2014. He believed it was the year he would finally reopen Chumley’s, the well-known Greenwich Village bar that has been closed since a wall collapsed in 2007.

headline: Anything Goes
abstract: A Thursday puzzle with a bartender’s wit courtesy of Stanley Newman.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE —#8212; Stanley Newman, the man behind today’s AMAZIN’ crossword, has created a theme set “in a neighborhood bar,” in which four answers together form a sentence you might hear at a local tavern. The sort of place where everybody knows your name — and everyone’s a gossip. Solve the puzzle and you’ll see what I mean.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 19 through Feb. 23 with 1,644 adults throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 19 through Feb. 23 with 1,644 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were in English or Spanish.

headline: Verrazano Bridge Toll Cut Despite High-Level Protest
keywords: ['Verrazano-Narrows Bridge (NYC)', 'Tolls', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted on Wednesday to reduce the bridge toll for Staten Island residents despite strong criticism from a former chairman of the agency.
lead_paragraph: If the Metropolitan Transportation Authority thought it would rubber-stamp a proposed cut in toll rates for the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, Richard Ravitch had other ideas.

headline: Private-Jet Airline Bets on a Thrifty Streak in the Rich
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Private Aircraft', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Just as budget carriers made Spanish beach holidays affordable to Europe’s working class, Wijet has set out to democratize high-end air travel.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Alexandre Azoulay would like to tell you something about the rich today: They aren’t so different from you and me.

headline: Contracts for Milk in New York City Schools Are Flagged
abstract: An audit shows no direct evidence of wrongdoing, but the city comptroller said it was curious how four milk distributors won and then delivered on $134 million in school contracts in 2008.
lead_paragraph: They are guzzled by the half-pint in schools across New York City each day: cartons of milk labeled low-fat, skim and chocolate, the flashiest among them decorated with cartoons of skateboarding cows.

headline: Service Members Testify to Senate Panel on Sexual Violence
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Sex Crimes', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: In a meeting with a subcommittee of the Armed Services Committee, the former service members argued that commanders should be removed from sexual assault cases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former service members who were victims of sexual violence told a Senate panel on Wednesday that military commanders should not be involved in decisions about sexual assault cases. Their views reflected those of Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, who convened the panel to promote a bill she is pushing that she said would help solve the problem.

headline: Turkish Leader Disowns Trials That Helped Him Tame Military
abstract: Prosecutors used dubious evidence to help Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan get the Turkish military out of politics, but now they are after Mr. Erdogan himself.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A series of sensational trials that shook the Turkish military in recent years achieved what many regard as the most important legacy of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s more than a decade in power: sending the army back to its barracks and out of politics.

headline: Rangers Wary of Drop-Off After the Olympics
abstract: There will be little rest for the Rangers in their return to N.H.L. play, as they face the Chicago Blackhawks on Thursday before traveling to Philadelphia on Saturday and hosting the Boston Bruins on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Eight years ago, the Rangers went into the Olympic break 20 games above .500. But after goalie Henrik Lundqvist, then a rookie, led Sweden to the gold medal, the Rangers, who had eight other Olympians, struggled. Although they finished with 100 points, they were third in the Atlantic Division and were swept by the Devils in the first round of the playoffs.

headline: Gardner to Oppose Udall, Complicating Democrats’ Senate Hopes
abstract: An unexpected decision in Colorado by Cory Gardner, a two-term Republican congressman, was unwelcome news for Democrats who hoped Mark Udall’s seat would be safe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Cory Gardner, a rising star in the Republican Party, will run for Senate in Colorado, the latest complication to Democrats’ hopes to hold on to a number of Senate seats that had seemed relatively safe.

headline: For Once, Face of Devils Has Little Use for His Mask
abstract: Goalie Martin Brodeur has been mostly sitting as Cory Schneider has excelled, putting the Devils in position for a playoff push despite little offensive production.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The Devils have historically had success with a defense-minded team led by strong goaltending.

headline: Civilians Flee as Violence Worsens in South Sudan
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: One month after a cease-fire was signed, residents and aid groups say they had increasingly become victims of the warring sides, who attack homes and hospitals alike.
lead_paragraph: KILO 10, Sudan — Martha Akuoch survived two offensives in the South Sudanese civil war, but the third pitched battle in the city of Malakal was more than she could take. She packed up and crossed the border into Sudan with her six children.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: A Family of Spies in Danger
abstract: The business of spying suddenly involves the children.
lead_paragraph: When we last left Elizabeth (Keri Russell) and Philip (Matthew Rhys) things were a mess. It was nothing you wouldn’t expect from two K.G.B. agents posing as an American couple living in a cul-de-sac outside Reagan-era Washington: Their marriage was in jeopardy. Their mentor had just been murdered. Philip had just “married” the F.B.I. secretary who was feeding him secrets, and their daughter, Paige (Holly Taylor), was starting to suspect that they might be more than simply the hardworking owners of a travel agency. And then Elizabeth was shot in a set-up engineered by the F.B.I. agent Stan (Noah Emmerich) who is also their neighbor, who also needs a haircut. (Yes, it’s the ’80s, but he’s an F.B.I. agent, not an earth science teacher.)

headline: Michigan: Detroit Mayor Details Hopeful Vision
abstract: Mayor Mike Duggan on Wednesday laid out an ambitious vision for his bankrupt city, promising to buy new ambulances and buses, among other initiatives.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Mike Duggan on Wednesday laid out an ambitious vision for his bankrupt city, promising to buy new ambulances and buses, to create an affordable car insurance program and to urge tougher laws to stop thieves from stealing metal from streetlights and empty houses. For a city that became the nation’s largest to seek bankruptcy protection and for a mayor whose authority is limited by an emergency manager overseeing operations, Mr. Duggan struck a hopeful note in his first State of the City address. “The change has started,” said Mr. Duggan, who took office on Jan. 1. “The change is real. And Detroit is not nearly as far away from turning around as people think.”

headline: For-Profit School Sued Over Lending Practices
keywords: ['For-Profit Schools', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Student Loans', 'Community Colleges', 'Vocational Training']
abstract: A federal agency on Wednesday sued ITT Educational Services, a major owner of for-profit colleges and trade schools, alleging predatory lending and other charges.
lead_paragraph: A federal agency on Wednesday sued ITT Educational Services, a major owner of for-profit colleges and trade schools, alleging predatory lending and other charges. It is the first suit against a for-profit education company by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, created in 2011, the bureau said. The bureau said the company lured students with zero-interest borrowing that had to be repaid after the first year, then pressured them to take new loans with very high fees and interest, knowing that most of them would default. ITT called the claims “without merit.” The company’s ITT Technical Institutes have about 140 campuses and 55,000 students.

headline: Disbelief After Egypt Announces Cures for AIDS and Hepatitis C
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Hepatitis', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Research']
abstract: The army doctor who announced the cures said they were the result of years of his own study. At some point, he said, military intelligence had taken on his research as a secret project.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — At a news conference late last week, an Egyptian Army doctor confidently announced that the country’s military had developed a cure for the virus that causes AIDS, as well as hepatitis C, one of Egypt’s gravest public health threats.

headline: Venezuela Accuses Intelligence Officers of Murdering 2
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The Venezuelan national prosecutor accused seven intelligence service members of killing a demonstrator and a government supporter after a protest.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Seven members of the intelligence service have been charged with murder in the shooting deaths of a demonstrator and a government supporter after a major protest march here, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Russia: Group to Seek House Arrest for Navalny
abstract: Russia’s powerful Investigative Committee said Wednesday that it would ask a court to put Aleksei A. Navalny, an opposition politician, under house arrest.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s powerful Investigative Committee said Wednesday that it would ask a court to put Aleksei A. Navalny, an opposition politician, under house arrest. In a statement, the committee said that Mr. Navalny had violated the terms of a travel ban in a case pending against him by driving outside of Moscow and by defying police officers at a rally on Monday. Mr. Navalny has said that the case against him, in which he stands accused of stealing more than $800,000 from the Russian branch of Yves Rocher, is politically motivated. The Associated Press said he was accused of doing so by charging an excessive price for shipping services. Mr. Navalny came to prominence by publishing online his investigations into government corruption. If approved, house arrest, which in other cases has included a ban on Internet use, could effectively remove Mr. Navalny from public life.

headline: Nigeria: College Attack Death Toll Rises
abstract: The United Nations reported Wednesday that at least 45 students were killed in the attack by Islamic extremists on a college in Nigeria this week and that the victims were as young as 13.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations reported Wednesday that at least 45 students were killed in the attack by Islamic extremists on a college in Nigeria this week and that the victims were as young as 13. The death toll was higher and the age range of the victims at the Federal Government College of Buni Yadi, in Yobe State, younger than initially reported by the Nigerian authorities. “Many lives were lost,” Manuel Fontaine, Unicef’s regional director for West and Central Africa, said in a statement denouncing the assault, the fourth that has closed a Nigeria school since last June. He said the closings had disrupted the lives of thousands of students, “many of whom have had no access to formal learning for months.” The Islamist group Boko Haram, which has denounced public education in Nigeria as blasphemous, has been blamed for the assaults.

headline: Clinton Addresses a Key Constituency at the University of Miami
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton talked about foreign policy, the Affordable Care Act and the importance of the Millennial Generation during a talk Wednesday night at the University of Miami.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton fielded questions from college students in Miami on Wednesday evening, and in the process positioned herself as sympathetic to a younger generation’s concerns about the country and its political leaders.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 27, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, February 27, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I do not know if anyone has been in this situation; in a time of hurt, at night after a few glasses of wine, you probably shouldn’t get on your computer. But that is obviously what I did.”

headline: Pushing for a Law Against Domestic Violence in China
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'International Relations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Feminists have been campaigning for a comprehensive law against domestic violence in China for nearly 15 years. The National People’s Congress meeting next week may be an opportunity to push the agenda forward.
lead_paragraph: Last Thanksgiving, Kim Lee came down the stairs in her apartment in Beijing to see her former husband, Li Yang, standing in the living room.

headline: Policy Makers Devise Plans to Provide Money to Kiev
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Credit and Debt', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: Substantial assistance from the International Monetary Fund, the United States and others would come after a transitional government is in place in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a financial catastrophe unfurling alongside its political transition, Ukraine is in desperate need of billions of dollars — and quickly. Its economy is shrinking. Its government treasury is empty. Its foreign-exchange funds are low. And its banking system is fragile.

headline: New F.D.A. Nutrition Labels Would Make ‘Serving Sizes’ Reflect Actual Servings
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration will propose major changes to nutrition labels on food packages, including more prominent calorie counts and the adjustment of some portion sizes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration for the first time in two decades will propose major changes to nutrition labels on food packages, putting calorie counts in large type and adjusting portion sizes to reflect how much Americans actually eat.

headline: What Ukraine Needs for Sustained Prosperity
abstract: Ukraine must take strong steps to expose corruption and install an open government in order to flourish, two economists write.
lead_paragraph: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a nonresident senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. Simon Johnson is a professor at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Living With Schizophrenia: Wanting to Connect
abstract: I had been happy in high school, popular even, and the ability to connect with people seemed so effortless then. It’s a goal I’ve been striving to reattain for the last eight years, since my diagnosis of schizophrenia.
lead_paragraph: I still remember the first group therapy session I went to after I got out of the hospital. I was 20 and had been diagnosed as schizophrenic after a road trip that took me from Colorado to the United Nations building in New York City, my mind riddled with notions of good and evil, demons and angels, and a determination to save the world. Now I was in something of a state of shock, having come to understand that amid the delusions and paranoia that swarmed through my head I was, in reality, insane.

headline: Word of the Day | enmity
abstract: This word has appeared in 83 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: enmity •\ˈen-mə-te\• noun

headline: For Teenage Girls, Video Takes Fear Out of a Shunned Topic
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Menstruation', 'Parenting', 'Sex Education', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: “Mythri,” an animated video that teaches girls about their changing bodies, has found success in schools in the Indian state of Karnataka and is set to expand to the rest of the country.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — “Today we are going to talk about becoming a big girl. Who here has become one?” Sinu Joseph, a social worker, said to about 50 squirming 13- and 14-year-old girls earlier this month during a visit to Renuka, a tiny government school in Bangalore.

headline: Nets Endure Most Lopsided Loss Since 2003
abstract: The Nets were unmerciful critics as they took turns roasting their play in an embarrassing defeat at Portland.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The Nets were unmerciful critics here Wednesday as they took turns roasting their own horrid play.

headline: Journalists Fear Attack on Hong Kong Editor Won’t Be Solved
abstract: The Hong Kong police have had trouble trying to solve previous attacks on local journalists or media executives, and now they face a very high-profile case.
lead_paragraph: A day after the stabbing of a crusading former editor of a prominent Hong Kong newspaper, local news outlets expressed fear that the assailants would go unpunished just as similar previous assaults on local journalists have not been solved.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (History) VIKINGS Brother is pitted against brother in this Season 2 opener, as Ragnar (Travis Fimmel, above), now an earl allied with King Horik (Donal Logue), faces battle against Rollo (Clive Standen) and Jarl Borg (Thorbjorn Harr). Princess Aslaug (Alyssa Sutherland), meanwhile, finds her way to Kattegat with a surprise that puts Ragnar in a difficult position.

headline: Cuomo, Up for 2nd Term, Tries to Steer G.O.P. as It Picks His Rival
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, is involving himself in the selection of his challenger, telling some top Republicans that they should be leery of nominating Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has raised an imposing $33 million, is riding high in the opinion polls and is expected to cruise to a second term this November.

headline: Corrections: February 27, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 27, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Merkel Warns Britain Not to Expect Too Much
abstract: The German leader offered warm words but few concrete promises to support the British prime minister’s efforts to loosen his nation’s ties to the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Given red-carpet treatment in London, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany responded Thursday with warm words but few hard promises to Prime Minister David Cameron, who is counting on her support in his efforts to loosen British ties to the European Union.

headline: Gunmen Seize Government Buildings in Crimea
abstract: Activists believed to be pro-Russian made no immediate demands but their actions added to the tension in the ethnically and politically divided eastern region of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — Masked men with guns seized government buildings in the capital of Ukraine’s Crimea region on Thursday, barricading themselves inside and raising the Russian flag after mysterious overnight raids that appeared to be the work of militant Russian nationalists who want this volatile Black Sea region ruled from Moscow.

headline: Qantas Announces Cost-Cutting Measures
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Company Reports']
abstract: The Australian carrier is cutting 5,000 jobs, selling older aircraft and postponing purchases of new ones after reporting a net loss for the second half of 2013.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Airlines in the Asia-Pacific region are carrying more passengers than ever. But for some, times have gotten tougher.

headline: Bailed-Out Royal Bank of Scotland Sees Years of Losses
abstract: After posting losses for the past six years — including a worse-than-expected loss of 8.2 billion pounds, or $13.7 billion, for 2013 — R.B.S. said it could be another three to five years before it returns to profit and rebuilds trust among its customers.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Bank of Scotland dashed any hopes on Thursday that it would return to profit anytime soon.

headline: A Look at India Through the Eyes of Its Visitors
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Hinduism', 'Mosques', 'News and News Media', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The new book “A Strange Kind of Paradise” explores how travelers through the ages – from Alexander the Great to Steve Jobs — have experienced India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — As a longtime foreign correspondent based in New Delhi, Sam Miller knows something about viewing India as an outsider. But it was the conversations he had with the man who would become his future stepfather-in-law that inspired Mr. Miller’s new book, “A Strange Kind of Paradise: India Through Foreign Eyes.”

headline: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 27, 2014
abstract: Can you choose the best synonym for “sanguine,” as it is used in the article?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: North Korea Is Said to Launch Missiles Into Sea
abstract: The North was said to have launched four short-range missiles off its coast, and a South Korean missionary held there appeared at a government-arranged news conference in Pyongyang.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea launched four short-range missiles off its eastern coast on Thursday in what appeared to be a show of force while South Korea and the United States were conducting their annual joint military exercises, officials here said.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Times Minute on Childhood Obesity, Plastic Bags and Politics
abstract: How much did the obesity rate among 2- to 5-year-old children drop over the past decade?

headline: The Mammoth Cometh
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Pigeons', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Science and Technology', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Cloning']
abstract: Bringing extinct animals back to life is really happening — and it’s going to be very, very cool. Unless it ends up being very, very bad.
lead_paragraph: The first time Ben Novak saw a passenger pigeon, he fell to his knees and remained in that position, speechless, for 20 minutes. He was 16. At 13, Novak vowed to devote his life to resurrecting extinct animals. At 14, he saw a photograph of a passenger pigeon in an Audubon Society book and “fell in love.” But he didn’t know that the Science Museum of Minnesota, which he was then visiting with a summer program for North Dakotan high-school students, had them in their collection, so he was shocked when he came across a cabinet containing two stuffed pigeons, a male and a female, mounted in lifelike poses. He was overcome by awe, sadness and the birds’ physical beauty: their bright auburn breasts, slate-gray backs and the dusting of iridescence around their napes that, depending on the light and angle, appeared purple, fuchsia or green. Before his chaperones dragged him out of the room, Novak snapped a photograph with his disposable camera. The flash was too strong, however, and when the film was processed several weeks later, he was haunted to discover that the photograph hadn’t developed. It was blank, just a flash of white light.

headline: Sebastião Salgado: Migrant in a World of Migrants
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Nineteen Hundred Seventies', 'Photography', 'Public and Subsidized Housing']
abstract: In the 1960s, Sebastião Salgado’s left-leaning politics led him to flee from Brazil to France, where he explored the lives of the working poor through photography.
lead_paragraph: Before he was known as a photographer, Sebastião Salgado was something even more essential to his identity: an émigré. His left-leaning politics and commitment to social justice had led him to flee Brazil in 1969 to study economics in France. There, he found countless other exiles — the lucky ones — who had managed to escape the murderous grip of Latin America’s Operation Condor.

headline: Does Reading a Book Count More Than Listening to One?
abstract: Do you have fond memories of being read to as a child? Do you listen to audiobooks? Do you think listening to books counts the same way reading those books would, or do you think listening is less serious? Why?
lead_paragraph: Do you have fond memories of being read to as a child? Do you listen to audiobooks? Do you think listening to books counts the same way reading those same books would, or do you think listening is somehow less serious? Why?

headline: Departing U.S. Envoy to China Praises Growing Economic Ties
abstract: The United States ambassador Gary F. Locke said the countries’ economic relationship was a “steadying influence” but said Beijing needed to make progress on legal and human rights issues.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Gary F. Locke, the departing United States ambassador to China, praised the growing economic ties between the two nations in a final news conference on Thursday but said China needed to make progress in establishing the rule of law and government transparency, and in respecting freedom of expression and human rights.

headline: Obama Starts Initiative for Young Black Men, Noting His Own Experience
abstract: President Obama’s My Brother’s Keeper effort is aimed at finding ways for business and civic leaders to help keep young black men and other men of color on a successful course.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama spoke in unusually personal terms at the White House on Thursday about how he got high as a teenager and was at times indifferent to school as he deplored what he called America’s numbness to the plight of young black men.

headline: German Ex-Leader Acquitted of Graft Charges From His Time as Governor
abstract: A state court found that the former leader, Christian Wulff, had not broken the law by accepting hospitality from a film producer at the annual Oktoberfest in Munich.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A former president of Germany, Christian Wulff, was acquitted on Thursday of corruption charges from his time as a regional governor. The ruling handed him the exoneration he had sought since stepping down from the presidency in 2012.

headline: The So-Called Blackstone Bill, Resurrected
abstract: If a proposal by Representative Dave Camp goes through, publicly traded private equity firms would either have to take themselves private again or pay corporate-level taxes, Victor Fleischer writes in the Standard Deduction column.
lead_paragraph: Representative Dave Camp, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, released a draft of tax legislation his committee has been working on for three years. The legislation is no gift to Wall Street, although neither is it especially punitive.

headline: Ousted Leader Seeks Russian Aid as Tensions Rise in Crimea
abstract: Viktor F. Yanukovych declared on Thursday that he remained Ukraine’s lawful president and appealed to Russia to protect his safety. He went on to suggest that largely Russian regions like Crimea did not accept Ukraine’s new course.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Viktor F. Yanukovych, the ousted president of Ukraine, declared on Thursday that he remained the lawful president of the country and appealed to Russia to “secure my personal safety from the actions of extremists.” Russian news agencies reported that he had already arrived in Russia, but officials did not immediately confirm that.

headline: Updates on the Tensions in Ukraine
abstract: Updates on the crisis in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Masked gunmen raised the Russian flag and barricaded themselves inside government buildings in the capital of the Crimea region of Ukraine as our colleagues  Andrew Higgins and Steven Lee Myers reported. The Parliament has approved a new prime minister who warned the Russian military not to stray outside their boundaries, while the country’s ousted leader, Viktor F. Yanukovych, appealed to Russia to protect his safety.

headline: Credit Suisse Under Scrutiny
abstract: A Senate panel criticized Credit Suisse at a hearing on Wednesday for helping American clients hide billion in assets. | R.B.S. reported a $15 billion net loss for 2013. | Authorities across the globe are moving to regulate Bitcoin after the collapse of Mt. Gox. | Ocwen faces scrutiny over potential conflicts of interest. | Versace agrees to sell minority stake to Blackstone.
lead_paragraph: SENATE SCRUTINIZES CREDIT SUISSE OVER HIDDEN ASSETS  |  A Senate panel criticized Credit Suisse at a hearing on Wednesday, contending that the Swiss bank helped as many as 22,000 Americans hide an estimated $10 billion to $12 billion in assets from the United States tax authorities, Annie Lowrey writes in DealBook. The Senate hearing, the result of a two-year investigation into practices at the bank from 2001 through 2008, followed a scathing report issued on Tuesday by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations that at times read like a legal thriller for its bizarre details on the lengths the bank went to aid Americans in tax evasion.

headline: The Gender Gap in Screen Time

headline: Below the Line: Sound Editing for ‘Lone Survivor’
abstract: The Oscar-nominated editor Wylie Stateman discusses his work.
lead_paragraph: With more than 30 years of experience, the sound editor Wylie Stateman has worked on a wide range of movies, from comedies like “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off” and “Honey, I Shrunk the Kids” to Quentin Tarantino films like “Inglourious Basterds” and “Django Unchained.” He is now nominated for his sound editing on “Lone Survivor,” Peter Berg’s drama based on a memoir by the Navy SEAL Marcus Luttrell about his time in Afghanistan. Mr. Stateman has dealt with war themes before, but he said this film took a different, more personal approach to battle sounds.

headline: Flexing His Might as Newest Valjean
abstract: Ramin Karimloo envisions his character in “Les Misérables” as part Ultimate Fighting Championship brawler, and aims to bring more physicality to the role.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In 45 minutes, Ramin Karimloo would take the stage as Jean Valjean, the antihero of the decades-spanning musical “Les Misérables.” But for now, he was doing chin-ups off the edge of a balcony on the set, his tattooed arms in full Popeye flex. To warm up his voice, he did scales, all the while fending off attackers as he worked out the kinks in a fight scene. He never stopped moving, lightly bounding around the Princess of Wales Theater stage here as if his motorcycle boots were spring-loaded.

headline: Can Doctors Be Taught How to Talk to Patients?
abstract: Research suggests that physician communication about important topics is associated with a better quality of life for patients, but teaching communication skills to doctors is not easy.
lead_paragraph: Recently one of us attended a daylong retreat designed to help doctors communicate more effectively with patients. The course was taught by a colleague with whom we had consulted in the past on patient-related matters but who was known better by his reputation, which was almost laughably stereotypical: brilliant technically, but stunted when it came to interacting with people.

headline: You’ve Got Meal (a Note, Too)
abstract: The Lunchbox,” by Ritesh Batra, puts Old Hollywood style in a Mumbai that has escaped the cyber world.
lead_paragraph: “The Lunchbox,” Ritesh Batra’s debut feature, is a romance that takes place in Mumbai, but its style is more Hollywood than Bollywood, and Old Hollywood at that. Though Mr. Batra and his cinematographer, Michael Simmonds, shot the film on location in the bustling modern city, with a naturalism alien to both American studio-era back-lot fantasies and present-day Indian musical extravaganzas, “The Lunchbox” has the measured pace and Classical restraint of a romance from the ’30s or ’40s. The comedy is more wry than uproarious, the melodrama gently poignant rather than operatic, and the sentimentality just sweet enough to be satisfying rather than bothersome.

lead_paragraph: Adriano Espaillat, the Dominican-born state senator from Upper Manhattan who nearly deposed Representative Charles B. Rangel in 2012, said on Thursday that he would challenge Mr. Rangel, the 22-term Harlem Democrat, again in the primary in June.

abstract: What little is known of the condition of the most successful Grand Prix racing driver in history is not encouraging for his prospects of recovery.
lead_paragraph: GRENOBLE, France — The hubbub of jostling reporters and television crews is a memory now, nearly two months after the helicopter carrying Michael Schumacher, the most successful Grand Prix driver in racing history, landed at University Hospital Center in this old Roman city after traveling from a rocky slope at the Méribel ski resort 45 miles away by air.

lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — The opposition party’s candidate for prime minister, Narendra Modi, laid out a broad economic policy for India on Thursday that encouraged family-owned businesses to embrace competition in a country known for its protectionist policies and endorsed a goods and services tax, which his state government had previously opposed.

headline: Fed Waiting for Thaw to Show Economy’s Health
abstract: The Fed chairwoman’s remarks were the first public hint from a Fed official of any doubts about the schedule for reducing its purchases of Treasury and mortgage-backed securities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Thursday that the Fed was looking closely at a recent run of disappointing economic data as it considers how quickly to retreat from its economic stimulus campaign.

headline: Arctic Monkeys Win 5 NME Awards
abstract: The group received awards for Best British Band and Best Album (for “AM”), two categories for which the band was also honored at the Brit Awards last week.
lead_paragraph: It seemed a big deal when Arctic Monkeys walked off with three NME Awards in 2006, not least because the group was the first ever to win the best new band and best British band prizes the same year. Eight years later, the band remains a darling of the New Musical Express, the British weekly music magazine that has presented the awards since 1953: when the 2014 awards were handed out on Wednesday in London, Arctic Monkeys snagged five of them, including best British band and best album (for “AM”), two categories for which the band was also honored at the Brit Awards last week.

headline: SoftBank’s Investment in Alibaba May Turn Into a Burden
abstract: For now, SoftBank, through its stake in Alibaba, is one of the few ways for public investors to gain exposure to the Chinese e-commerce giant. But that advantage will disappear when Alibaba goes public, writes Una Galani of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: SoftBank’s investment in Alibaba must be one of the most successful of all time. Masayoshi Son, the billionaire chief executive of SoftBank, injected $20 million into the Chinese e-commerce giant in 2000. Today, that 36.7 percent stake accounts for a large chunk of Japanese group’s market value. As Alibaba heads toward an initial public offering, however, Mr. Son’s investment blessing may become a burden.

headline: The Robber Barons of the For-Profit College Sector
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau accused an Indiana-based chain of practicing “predatory student lending.”
lead_paragraph: Honest, well-run for-profit colleges can be helpful to students who do not qualify for traditional schools. But the robber barons in the for-profit sector represent a menace that requires more federal oversight. They saddle students with crushing debt while furnishing them useless degrees – or no degrees at all. These schools have been known to push students who are eligible for low-cost, federal loans into ruinously priced private loans that have fewer consumer protections and that give borrowers who get in trouble little choice but to default. That in turn makes it difficult for them to find jobs, get credit or rent apartments. And because private student loans are difficult to escape through bankruptcy, the stricken borrower might never recover.

lead_paragraph: To come up with “Let It Go,” the chart-topping anthem that parents across America know well, the married composers Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Bobby Lopez took a walk in Prospect Park, near their Brooklyn home. “We stood up on a picnic table in front of the picnic house and imagined what Elsa would be thinking up on her mountain alone,” Ms. Anderson-Lopez has told the Bagger. “And we wrote it in a day.” In this video, the composers assemble at the piano at their home in Brooklyn as they discuss their thinking behind the song and how they collaborate.
