headline: Working Draft of Orson Welles’s Script for ‘Citizen Kane’ to Be Auctioned
abstract: The typed script is described by Sotheby’s as the second draft, with markings and deletions in pencil and pink crayon.
lead_paragraph: Orson Welles’s personal copy of an early script for “Citizen Kane” will be offered for auction at Sotheby’s in London on March 6. The script, by Welles, Herman J. Mankiewicz and John Houseman, was part of the collection of Stanley J. Seeger, a reclusive collector of art and other artifacts, who died in 2011. Sotheby’s lists an estimate of 15,000 pounds to 20,000 pounds (about $25,000 to $33,000).

headline: Joseph Dear, Calpers Investment Chief, Dies at 62
abstract: Mr. Dear, the chief investment officer of the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, restored the pension fund to health after the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Joseph A. Dear, the chief investment officer of the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, who restored the pension fund to health after the financial crisis, died on Wednesday in Sacramento. He was 62.

headline: Image of the Day: February 27
abstract: Noted Indian music composer A.R. Rahman with Salman Khan, Bollywood actor, and Kapil Sibal, Minister for Law and Justice, at the launch of a music album in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: A Playwright’s Status Report
abstract: Terrence McNally revisits the evolving attitudes toward same-sex relationships in “Mothers and Sons,” a sequel of sorts to “Andre’s Mother.”
lead_paragraph: The sky over Central Park was always full of white balloons. At least, that’s how Terrence McNally saw New York City in 1988, when he wrote a short play for an Off Broadway revue about life in the age of AIDS.

headline: At Louis Vuitton, Young Designers Have Stars in Their Eyes
abstract: Nicolas Ghesquière, Raf Simons, Karl Lagerfeld, Anna Wintour, and Kanye West were all chatting with the contestants.
lead_paragraph: The designers Shane Gabier and Chris Peters from Creatures of the Wind were taking in the scene from the LVMH headquarters in Paris Wednesday night when they started thinking about just how many fashion luminaries they had met that night.

headline: Stethoscopes as Germ Carriers
abstract: Doctors’ stethoscopes are contaminated with bacteria that can easily be transferred from one patient to another, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Doctors’ stethoscopes are contaminated with bacteria that can easily be transferred from one patient to another, a new study has found.

headline: Magazine Article Says Biden Has Eye on 2016 but Has Taken Few Steps
abstract: The vice president was livid when President Obama’s former campaign manager publicly pledged his support for a Clinton presidential campaign, a new profile says.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was livid when Jim Messina, President Obama’s former campaign manager, publicly pledged his support for a Hillary Rodham Clinton presidential campaign in 2016, a new profile of the vice president says.

headline: Waiting for Disney’s First Gay Teenager
abstract: Whenever a teen crush plot line is enacted on any of the many teen sitcom programs designed for maximum pre-teen appeal, the path to true love may take many agonizing twists and turns, but the “love” will be straight every time.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say you’re a preteenager, old enough to have begun thinking that at some point Valentine’s Day isn’t going to be about getting a Starburst taped to your “Frozen” movie-themed valentines, but still not quite sure what that would look like.

headline: The Fancy Flock of James Bond Films
abstract: The artist Taryn Simon obsessively photographed all 340 birds that appear in the 24 spy films — a nod to the ornithologist after whom the main character was named.
lead_paragraph: Central to the work of the New York-based artist Taryn Simon are the practices of substitution and replacement, and the resurfacing of seemingly “lost” or secretive material. Where one may find it vaguely interesting that the inimitable character of James Bond was named after a real-life American ornithologist who published a book called “Birds of the West Indies” in 1936 — the author of the popular spy novels, Ian Fleming, was an avid bird-watcher — Simon sees an opportunity. In a two-part exhibition also titled “Birds of the West Indies,” Simon examines the surprising and thought-provoking relationship between the two men.

headline: Today in Small Business: Time to Replace the Van
abstract: Bubbles are not always bad. Seven industries are about to explode. And answers to frequently asked social media questions.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

headline: The Sweet Spot: Here Come the Oscars
abstract: In advance of the Academy Awards on Sunday, David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss some of their favorite picks and some of the movies they loved that were not nominated.
lead_paragraph: In advance of the Academy Awards on Sunday, David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss some of their favorite picks and some of the movies they loved that were not nominated.

headline: Things Are Falling Into Place
abstract: At Rusty Mackerel, the food is fussed over in the kitchen, but unfussy on the plate.
lead_paragraph: The waitress shrieked. A tiny potato had toppled to the side of the carefully stacked bowl she was about to set onto the table.

headline: Painting on a Radio Canvas
abstract: KCHUNG, a fledgling low-wattage radio station and art collective in Los Angeles, has a reach far beyond the range of its broadcast signal.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Max Maslansky’s talk show on KCHUNG radio is called “Riffin’ ” for a reason. When he invited the artist Danielle Adair to the station’s studio on the edge of Chinatown here, above a sewing-machine-repair shop and an herbalist, they touched on diverse subjects like cherry farming in Michigan and her work in progress: an experimental opera called “Caution Bomb” inspired by the radical educator Rudolf Steiner.

headline: Indian Soldier Kills 5 Members of His Unit in Kashmir
abstract: The soldier, who was on guard duty, opened fire on his fellow soldiers and then killed himself, the Indian Army said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — An Indian soldier killed five fellow soldiers with his service rifle and then committed suicide before dawn on Thursday while on duty at the gate of an army unit in the Indian-administered portion of Kashmir, the army announced.

headline: Exam Finds No Shoulder Problem for Mets’ Jon Niese
abstract: The pitcher was found to have “no shoulder problems at all” after an M.R.I. exam on Thursday, Manager Terry Collins said.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets avoided their first potential calamity of spring training Thursday when pitcher Jon Niese was found to have “no shoulder problems at all” after having a magnetic resonance imaging test in New York, Manager Terry Collins said.

headline: Ukraine Crisis in Maps
abstract: The latest updates to the current visual survey of the continuing dispute, with maps and satellite imagery showing rebel and military movement.
lead_paragraph: The latest updates to the current visual survey of the continuing dispute, with maps and satellite imagery showing rebel and military movement.

headline: Balmain: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Why College Supply Matters
abstract: Studies show that public and nonprofit colleges have not maintained per-student spending and graduation rates when demand has grown. For-profit institutions may be picking up the slack.
lead_paragraph: Most of the debate over America’s stagnant college graduation rates focuses on things that affect demand, like college affordability and the availability of financial aid. We ponder whether high school graduates are prepared for a college education.

headline: PayPal Has the Maturity to Go Out on Its Own
abstract: The activist investor Carl Icahn has a point when he says that splitting eBay in two would make investors about 15 percent richer, writes Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: PayPal has outgrown the warm embrace of its parent eBay. Ownership by the online merchant provided rich soil for the payment system to thrive. But PayPal is now mature enough to grow faster on its own. The activist investor Carl C. Icahn has a point when he says that splitting eBay in two — as first suggested by Breakingviews in 2008 — would make investors about 15 percent richer.

headline: Proenza Schouler: 2 Americans in Paris
abstract: The designers, Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough, travel to the French capital for their first retrospective.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In a basement on lower Broadway rests the entire Proenza Schouler archive, cataloged, bagged and unvisited. “From 2005 on, we’ve got every single collection,” said Jack McCollough, one half of the New York fashion label. (The earliest collections, from 2002 on, were sold to finance the ones that followed.) “But we never go down there, and we never reference it, really.”

headline: Day After Governor’s Veto, Arizona Takes Up Abortion Clinics
abstract: Despite being criticized by Gov. Jan Brewer for failing to act on her legislative priorities, the House turned to legislation that would permit surprise inspections of abortion clinics.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — A day after being reprimanded by Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, for failing to heed her call for action on the budget and the state’s child welfare agency, Arizona’s Republican-led House of Representatives promptly took up a new piece of social legislation on Thursday that would permit the surprise inspection of abortion clinics in the state.

headline: A World Tour for Restructuring Enthusiasts
abstract: There’s something for everyone now in the world of restructuring and bankruptcy, including bailouts, bond deals and looming Chapter 11 filings, Stephen J. Lubben writes in the In Debt column.
lead_paragraph: Just when the world of restructuring was becoming dull, the world responded with a wave of financial distress. That sounds like bad news for most people, but for the cognoscenti of financial misfortune, it’s like an early Mardi Gras.

headline: Weak-Kneed Democrats Waver on the Minimum Wage
abstract: Harry Reid decided to postpone a vote on raising the minimum wage, in part because he doesn’t have enough Democratic support.
lead_paragraph: This week Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid decided to postpone a vote on raising the minimum wage, in part, it appears, because he does not have enough Democratic support to pass the measure. The holdouts include several Democratic senators from low-wage and mostly southern states who are up for reelection this year. That is pathetic.

headline: A Final Meal for Manzanilla
abstract: After about a year in business, the Spanish restaurant on Park Avenue South will close.
lead_paragraph: Manzanilla, Yann de Rochefort’s Spanish restaurant on Park Avenue South with the well-known Andalusian chef Dani García, closes tonight after about a year in business. Mr. de Rochefort said that the restaurant was not living up to expectations. “I feel it’s better for me to concentrate on my Boqueria restaurants, which are doing extremely well,” he said.

headline: China’s President Will Lead a New Effort on Cybersecurity
abstract: President Xi Jinping is presiding over a working group on security, a sign that the Communist Party views the issue as a pressing strategic concern.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — President Xi Jinping is presiding over a new working group on cybersecurity and information security, China announced on Thursday, a sign that the Communist Party views the issue as one of the country’s most pressing strategic concerns.

headline: The Gun Report: February 27, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Here at the Gun Report we often come across careless handling of firearms, which can be deadly, especially when children find and discharge them. But it looks like the A.T.F. is having the same problem.

headline: British Regulator Pursuing Charges Against 3rd Person in Libor Case
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority issued a warning against an unnamed individual at an unnamed bank, on allegations that the person colluded with another trader to in an attempt to influence interest rate benchmarks.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s markets regulator issued the third notice in as many weeks that another individual is in its cross-hairs in its wide-ranging investigation into the manipulation of important interest rate benchmarks, including the London Interbank Offer Rate, or Libor.

headline: Study Indicates That Bill Redefining Full-Time Employment Would Have Costs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Insurance', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: The Save American Workers Act would move the definition of full-time employment to 40 hours and require businesses to provide health insurance to fewer workers.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, we reported on the sudden interest among House Republicans in legislation to rewrite the employer mandate in the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Nina Ricci: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Soggy Government Documents
abstract: Protesters sorted through documents discovered at the sprawling compound of the former Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych.
lead_paragraph: Protesters sorted through documents discovered at the sprawling compound of the former Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych.

headline: Ginta Lapiņa Transforms Backstage at Nina Ricci
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Ginta Lapina (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Kennedy Case Goes to Jury After Debate Over How Quickly a Sleep Aid Works
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Ambien (Drug)']
abstract: A clinical pharmacologist, the final defense witness, said people under the influence of a sleeping aid might “become impaired, but don’t know they’re impaired.”
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — In an indignant summation, the prosecutor in the misdemeanor trial of Kerry Kennedy asked the jury Thursday to ignore the defendant’s magnetic background, and convict her for continuing to drive after she became aware she was under the influence of the sleeping pill Zolpidem.

headline: Artists Donate Works for Legal Defense of Man Who Smashed Ai Weiwei Vase
abstract: “We do not support the act, but we support the intention,” said one local artist.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A few dozen artists have promised to donate works for an auction to help cover the legal expenses of a colleague who stunned the art world by smashing a vase by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei at the Pérez Art Museum Miami.

headline: Palestinian Found Dead After Standoff With Israelis
abstract: The Palestinian Authority condemned the killing, as Amnesty International published a report accusing Israeli forces of using excessive force in the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man was found dead in his home in the West Bank town of Bir Zeit on Thursday after a standoff with Israeli forces that had come to arrest him, according to the Israeli military.

headline: A JPMorgan Co-Head of Debt Capital Markets to Take a New Role
abstract: One of JPMorgan Chase’s heads of debt capital markets, Andrew O’Brien, will take on a broader new role overseeing lending activity across the investment bank, the firm announced in an internal memo on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: One of JPMorgan Chase’s heads of debt capital markets, Andrew O’Brien, will take on a broader new role overseeing lending activity across the investment bank, the firm announced in an internal memo on Thursday.

headline: Arizona Democrat Won’t Seek Re-election to House
abstract: Representative Ed Pastor, the first Hispanic elected to Congress from Arizona, said he would not seek a 12th term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Ed Pastor, Democrat of Arizona, announced Thursday that he would not seek re-election this year for a 12th term.

headline: At Abandoned Ukrainian Palace, an Anxious Look Toward the Future
abstract: After three months at the barricades in Kiev, Arthur Pereverziev is in charge of the abandoned presidential palace. He worries that this revolution will be short-circuited by a failure to change the political system.
lead_paragraph: NOVI PETRIVTSI, Ukraine — Arthur Pereverziev is just 24, but he has the calm air of command. Thrown early into politics by the tumultuous decade that began with the Orange Revolution in 2004, he was an instrumental member of the civilian group Vidsich, or Repulse, which opposed the presidency of Viktor F. Yanukovych.

headline: Catching Perth’s Wave in Western Australia
abstract: This city of some 1.8 million, situated near beaches and a historic wine district, has balanced a recent economic boom with a breezy, green personality.
lead_paragraph: Conjure up a city embodying all things right about cities. Assuming you lean toward the progressive, I’ll wager your rendering includes the following: multiple parks and waterfronts; spotless subways and free public buses; restaurant menus with organic, locally sourced food and wine; cool bars in heritage buildings; and pop-up everything, from farmers’ markets to cinema and yoga.

headline: Shopping, Sipping and Slurping in Bushwick, Brooklyn
abstract: In this neighborhood, home to warehouses and graffiti-covered walls, browse vintage clothes, sample of-the-moment cocktails and indulge with a flavorful noodle dish.
lead_paragraph: Bushwick, a crime-ridden, desolate scene throughout the ‘90s, has recently developed a reputation for its raves, which are marked by pulsing electronic dance music and poker-faced Brooklyn hipsters. Fortunately, Bushwick offers more than a neon-tinted night life, and those more interested in mood lighting than strobe lights need not beware. This neighborhood, where hulking warehouses and graffiti-covered walls still far outnumber trees and grass, is a haven for artists, newly minted college graduates, working-class families and freelancers of all stripes, and this shows in its hangouts, which are often whimsical, generally easier on the wallet than their Manhattan counterparts and, as of late, surprisingly sophisticated.

headline: A Certain Something, Repeated
abstract: “A Collective Invention” is the first exhibition to be organized by the Morgan’s new photography department.
lead_paragraph: “A Collective Invention: Photographs at Play” at the Morgan Library & Museum is a gimmicky exhibition. That might sound bad, but it’s not. Some gimmicks are better than others. The one animating this show of more than 80 photographs and photo-related objects borrowed from private collectors makes for an entertaining and illuminating experience.

headline: Montana’s Big Sky Resort Gets Bigger
abstract: Last fall, Big Sky became the largest ski area in the country, making runs even roomier.
lead_paragraph: Bigger isn’t always better, but when it comes to ski resorts, size offers distinct advantages, from variety of terrain to off-the-beaten-path runs. For years, Vail Mountain has reigned as the nation’s largest ski area, but last fall Big Sky Resort, the understated ski area in southwestern Montana, leapfrogged its better-known competitor with the addition of acreage on a series of adjacent mountains, giving Big Sky boosters new talking points: empty runs.

headline: Rick Owens: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Federal Budget Deficit Falls to Smallest Level Since 2008
abstract: The budget deficit dropped to $680 billion in the 2013 fiscal year, from about $1.1 trillion the year before, largely aided by a rise in tax revenue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Closing the books on a fiscal year in which the federal budget deficit fell more sharply than in any year since the end of World War II, the Treasury Department reported on Thursday that the deficit for 2013 dropped to $680 billion, from about $1.1 trillion the previous year.

headline: A Discussion About ‘Bright Lights, Big City’
abstract: Join us for the online discussion of the novel “Bright Lights, Big City” by Jay McInerney on March 10 at 6:30 p.m.
lead_paragraph: This time we outsourced our selection for the Big City Book Club to the writer and satirist Gary Shteyngart. We asked him to pick his favorite book about New York, and he did not demand that we read his own newly published memoir, “Little Failure,” about his upbringing as a Russian émigré in Queens. Instead, he selflessly selected “Bright Lights, Big City,” Jay McInerney’s touchstone novel of the hedonistic ’80s life on the other side of the East River. Join us for the online discussion of the novel with Mr. Shteyngart on Monday, March 10, at 6:30 p.m.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘The Lunchbox’
abstract: Ritesh Batra, the director of “The Lunchbox,” narrates a scene from his film.
lead_paragraph: Ritesh Batra, the director of “The Lunchbox,” narrates a scene from his film.

headline: Art Matters | The Resurgence of Robert Mapplethorpe
abstract: The curator Clarissa Dalrymple, a dear friend of the famous art provocateur, recalls one of his many controversial images.
lead_paragraph: Two high-profile exhibitions are breathing new life into the work of a famous art provocateur. Here, the curator Clarissa Dalrymple, Mapplethorpe’s dear friend, recalls one of his many controversial images.

headline: The ‘Myriopticon’ Game
abstract: A game captures the “Great Rebellion”
lead_paragraph: A game captures the “Great Rebellion”

headline: D.C. Insurance Must Cover Treatment for Transgender Residents, Mayor Says
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexual', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Gender']
abstract: The announcement by Mayor Vincent C. Gray reiterates that gender dysphoria — a diagnosis for psychological discomfort with one’s sex — is a recognized medical condition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Health insurance providers in the District of Columbia must cover treatment for those given a diagnosis of gender dysphoria, including gender-reassignment surgeries, Mayor Vincent C. Gray said Thursday.

headline: An Unreliable Hero Aboard a Troubled Flight
abstract: Liam Neeson stars as an unsettled air marshal trying to prevent murders in the air in “Non-Stop.”
lead_paragraph: A satisfying, primitive bluntness distinguishes “Non-Stop,” an action thriller that makes good on its title. In the 1950s, its star might have been Edmond O’Brien, a character actor who landed a few leading roles, including, in “D.O.A.,” as a poisoned man racing against the clock to find his murderer. With escalating clammy desperation he hurtles toward his fate, ticktock, ticktock. Liam Neeson runs a similarly frantic circuit in “Non-Stop,” as an air marshal trying to outwit a villain vowing to knock off a passenger every 20 minutes, ticktock, ticktock.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: male breast cancer, hepatitis C and antifreeze. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: male breast cancer, hepatitis C and antifreeze. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: A New Theater for Cirque du Soleil in Mexico
abstract: Cirque du Soleil will have a new stand-alone theater on Mexico’s Riviera Maya.
lead_paragraph: Montreal-based Cirque du Soleil has taken its acrobatics-based shows around the world, but put down few permanent roots, notably in Las Vegas, where it produces eight separate shows, and Orlando, where it has one. Now the group is heading south of the border with a new theater under construction on Mexico’s Riviera Maya.

headline: Museums to Display Ensor’s Monumental Drawing
abstract: After eight years of conservation and restoration, James Ensor’s monumental drawing “The Temptation of Saint Anthony” will have its first public showing in more than 60 years.
lead_paragraph: RESTORED ‘SAINT ANTHONY’

headline: Growing Crisis in Its Backyard Snares Russia
abstract: As Russia faces calls for an active response to Ukraine’s deepening political crisis, the question asked by many is whether President Vladimir V. Putin intended it that way.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Despite repeated vows not to interfere or intervene, President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia has now found itself more deeply ensnared than ever in Ukraine’s worsening political crisis, facing appeals to support the country’s ethnic Russians, provide haven for its deposed president and perhaps even undertake a military response. The question is whether he intended it that way.

headline: Brown Seeks Fourth Term as Governor of California
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown, 75, is already the longest-serving governor in the state’s history.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown, already the longest-serving governor in California history, announced Thursday that he would run for an unprecedented fourth term.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘The Lunchbox’
abstract: The director Ritesh Batra narrates a scene from his drama.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Ritesh Batra narrates a scene from his drama about the connection made between a neglected housewife (Nimrat Kaur) and a widowed office worker (Irrfan Khan).

headline: 8 Cities Vie for 2016 Republican Convention
abstract: Republicans announced a list of cities in the West and Midwest, including three in Ohio, in contention to host the official campaign kickoff.
lead_paragraph: No major Republican contenders have announced that they will seek the presidential nomination in 2016, but eight cities are officially in the running to throw the party for the nominee.

headline: De Blasio Seeks to Halt 3 Charter Schools From Moving Into Public Spaces
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said that he would reverse a decision by Michael R. Bloomberg to provide free real estate to the schools so that they could open new programs.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, seeking to curb the influence of outside providers of education, said on Thursday that he would block three charter schools from using space inside New York City public school buildings.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Afghanistan, Syria and Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Afghanistan, Syria and Venezuela.

headline: O’Reilly Considers the ‘Downside’ to Having a Woman President
abstract: His bizarre segment was, unintentionally, a great ad for Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: It’s only February, 2014, but Bill O’Reilly is already out there campaigning for Hillary Clinton, 2016. That’s not what he intends, of course, because I’m guessing Mrs. Clinton would be the last person Mr. O’Reilly wants to be president.

headline: Text to Text | ‘Huckleberry Finn’ and ‘In Defense of a Loaded Word’
abstract: Language can be loaded, and perhaps there is no more loaded word in our culture than the so-called n-word. Here we aim to help students think critically about the word, its history, who says it, who shouldn’t say it and whether it should be buried or reclaimed.
lead_paragraph: “Probably the most offensive word” in the English language. Or, a word that can be used in a “neutral or familiar way and as a friendly term of address.” A word that should never be said. Or, a word that should never be said by white people.

headline: Ask Well: What Helps Motion Sickness?
abstract: A look at the drugs — some used by astronauts — that can relieve car, sea and space nausea.
lead_paragraph: A look at the drugs — some used by astronauts — that can relieve car, sea and space nausea.

headline: Praying for the Home Team in Oklahoma City
abstract: A prayer is delivered before each Oklahoma City Thunder game, briefly turning a sports event into something more akin to a megachurch gathering.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — Before the plumes of smoke and the shimmering pyrotechnics, before the two dozen or so dancers gyrating in microscopic shorts and the hip-hop, before the hairy mascot on stilts and the sponsorships — “Tonight’s free throws are brought to you by Hooters!” — there is prayer.

headline: Ask Well: Medicines for Motion Sickness
abstract: Various patches, drugs and sprays are available for relief of motion sickness symptoms, some commonly taken by astronauts.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Consumer Reports: Lexus Is No. 1
abstract: Japanese brands take seven of the top 10 slots, joined by three German manufacturers; American automakers take the bottom five.
lead_paragraph: For the second year, Lexus has received the top overall score in the Consumer Reports’ Car Brand Report Cards. Acura took second place, and Audi was third.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Nina Ricci Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Matthew Morrison to Star in Weinstein’s ‘Finding Neverland’
abstract: Mr. Morrison will play J.M. Barrie, the creator of Peter Pan, in Harvey Weinstein’s first major theater project.
lead_paragraph: The theater and television actor Matthew Morrison will join Harvey Weinstein’s first major theater project — the musical “Finding Neverland” — in the role of J.M. Barrie, the creator of Peter Pan, according to two theater executives with knowledge of the casting. Mr. Morrison is now preparing for a developmental workshop of the show in March, which — if all goes well — will be followed by the American premiere in late summer at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., the executives said on Thursday. They spoke on condition of anonymity because the Weinstein Company has yet to officially announce the casting and production plans.

headline: A Dire Economic Forecast Based on New Assumptions
abstract: This year’s economic forecasts from the Congressional Budget Office were worse than last year’s because the office stopped treating the recent slow years as outliers.
lead_paragraph: The part of the past that you deem most relevant can be critical in determining your outlook for the future. And nowhere is that clearer than in the changing economic forecasts that come out of the Congressional Budget Office.

headline: Hagel Urges Russia to Be 'Transparent'
abstract: Following NATO talks on Ukraine in Brussels, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel calls on Russia “to respect Ukraine’s sovereignty and avoid provocative actions.”
lead_paragraph: Following NATO talks on Ukraine in Brussels, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel calls on Russia “to respect Ukraine’s sovereignty and avoid provocative actions.”

headline: Klinsmann Invites 24 to U.S. Team’s Camp in Germany
abstract: Jurgen Klinsmann, coach of the men’s national soccer team, released his training camp roster ahead of a March 5 friendly with Ukraine in Cyprus.
lead_paragraph: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States men’s national soccer team, on Thursday released the 24-man roster that he will take to training camp in Frankfurt. The players are expected to report Sunday.

headline: Discussions of Arizona Governor’s Veto
abstract: Reaction to Gov. Jan Brewer’s veto of a bill that would have allowed refusal of service to gay men and lesbians.
lead_paragraph: Reaction to Gov. Jan Brewer’s veto of a bill that would have allowed refusal of service to gay men and lesbians.

headline: The Return of the Happy Atheist
abstract: Some thoughts on the revival of a confident, optimistic, utopian unbelief.
lead_paragraph: As promised, a second post occasioned by the Gopnik essay on belief and atheism — this time, focused on the interesting change that’s come over atheism over the last generation or so, during which time the sunny optimism of 18th century irreligion has made a striking comeback. Reading Gopnik’s remarks on the confident, history-is-going-our-way spirit of so much of the new unbelief, I was reminded of a Leszek Kolakowski essay, “Anxiety About God in an Ostensibly Godless Age,” which appeared more than thirty years ago, in 1981, and can be found in a recent collection of his work. Here’s a relevant excerpt, offering a kind of mini-history of Western atheism and its discontents:

headline: Video: Countdown to Oscar Night
abstract: A look at the best-picture field from the hosts of “The Sweet Spot.”
lead_paragraph: With just three days to go until the big night, Hollywood is working overtime on preparations, and so are pundits. While the Bagger sorts out her predictions in what has shaped up as a very competitive awards season, The Times media columnist David Carr and co-chief film critic A.O. Scott have surveyed the best-picture field in preparation for a special Oscar-night edition of their show “The Sweet Spot.”

headline: Hagel Urges Russia to Be 'Transparent'
abstract: Following NATO talks on Ukraine in Brussels, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel calls on Russia "to respect Ukraine's sovereignty and avoid provocative actions."
lead_paragraph: Following NATO talks on Ukraine in Brussels, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel calls on Russia "to respect Ukraine's sovereignty and avoid provocative actions."

headline: Credit Unions Offer Creative Home Loans
abstract: Credit unions offer some of the more creative mortgage products these days.
lead_paragraph: Large credit unions are offering average borrowers some of the more creative mortgage products these days when compared with the more standard fare of big banks.

headline: ‘Taiping Tianguo’: ‘A History of Possible Encounters: Ai Weiwei, Frog King Kwok, Tehching Hsieh and Martin Wong in New York’
abstract: This invaluable nugget of an art historical show uncovers hitherto unexplored links among four artists of Chinese descent in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: e-flux

headline: Candy Jernigan
abstract: This small survey of Jernigan’s work from the 1980s, at Greene Naftali, is highly evocative.
lead_paragraph: Greene Naftali

headline: Red Grooms: ‘Beware a Wolf in the Alley’

headline: British Spies Said to Intercept Yahoo Webcam Images
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Accounts based on documents supplied by Edward J. Snowden say images — many sexually explicit — were collected from Yahoo users, even those not suspected of illegal activity.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A British intelligence agency collected video webcam images — many of them sexually explicit — from millions of Yahoo users, regardless of whether they were suspected of illegal activity, according to accounts of documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden.

headline: A Storm Washes Away Old Ideas on Wine
abstract: For the wine director of the recently reopened River Café, a message in the bottles that survived the ravages of Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: When Hurricane Sandy sent the East River surging in October 2012, Buzzy O’Keeffe, the owner of the River Café, ordered his staff to open the doors. By letting the water go through his restaurant, which is on a barge at Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn, he believes he saved it from sinking under the weight of the flooding. Even so, the River Café was ravaged.

headline: Alice Herz-Sommer, Who Found Peace in Chopin Amid Holocaust, Dies at 110
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Concentration Camps', 'Classical Music', 'Music']
abstract: Mrs. Herz-Sommer, considered the oldest known Holocaust survivor and a distinguished musician in Europe before the war, credited her devotion to Chopin with saving her life.
lead_paragraph: Throughout her two years in Theresienstadt, through the hunger and cold and death all around her, through the loss of her mother and husband, Alice Herz-Sommer was sustained by a Polish man who had died long before. His name was Frédéric Chopin.

headline: Moving on From Make-Believe
abstract: Tyler and I both changed since college. How could he be sure he didn’t love me if he didn’t know who I’d become?
lead_paragraph: When Tyler and I were 27, we packed up a Penske truck with everything we owned and drove cross-country to move in together for the first time in Portland, Ore., 3,000 miles from my family in New York.

headline: Focusing on Its Digital Strategy, Time Inc. Hires Away an Executive From The Atlantic
abstract: M. Scott Havens is leaving the magazine for Time Inc., which is investing in online efforts before being spun off from Time Warner.
lead_paragraph: Time Inc. announced on Thursday that it had hired M. Scott Havens, the president of The Atlantic, to spearhead the digital strategy for its magazine brands, including People, Sports Illustrated and Fortune.

headline: Start-Up That Analyzes Twitter for Wall Street Raises Financing
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Social Media', 'Start-ups', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Eagle Alpha has raised $1.5 million in financing to expand in a growing field of sifting through social media and the web to glean information on stocks.
lead_paragraph: Eagle Alpha, a start-up that mines social media and the web for market-related information, is expanding with backing from a handful of individual investors.

headline: Costa Concordia Captain Returns to Ship as Trial Examines Generators
abstract: Francesco Schettino’s lawyers have argued that the cruise ship’s operator should also be held responsible for technical failures.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For the first time since the cruise ship Costa Concordia hit a submerged rock and capsized two years ago, killing 32 people, the ship’s captain went back aboard the vessel on Thursday with a team of experts investigating the shipwreck as part of his trial.

headline: A Window-Washing Service on Two Wheels
abstract: A bicycle is the way to travel for Phil Prado, a window-washer with clients all over Lower Manhattan and Midtown.
lead_paragraph: “Dirty windows are bad for business,” said Phil Prado, 50, giving the rationale for his own business: a one-man, two-wheeled window-washing service that has him pedaling around downtown and Midtown Manhattan.

headline: A Farmer’s Breakfast, and Then a Wander
abstract: The actor Michael Emerson and his wife, the actress Carrie Preston, stay in their pajamas until around noon, then feel the need to “get crackin’.”
lead_paragraph: When the actor Michael Emerson, 59, walks around Manhattan, it’s not unusual for people to stop him and ask if he’ll pose for a picture. The television shows “Lost” and, currently, “Person of Interest” have made his spiky hair, thick-rimmed glasses and long sideburns a giveaway. He takes it in stride, even on Sunday, which he designates a day of leisure, reserved for meandering, cultural events and time with his wife, the actress Carrie Preston, 46 — who herself is recognized for her roles in “True Blood” and “The Good Wife” — and her extended family. The couple live with their rescue dog, Chumley, 4, near Columbus Circle.

headline: Wryly Nibbling at His Bread and Butter
keywords: ['Art', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)']
abstract: The Shanghai artist Xu Zhen will present a provocative installation and create a signature look for this year’s Chinese-themed Armory Show.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Is there a Chinese word for chutzpah? If there is, the Shanghai artist Xu Zhen, often called the Maurizio Cattelan of China, fits the bill. Combining the roles of artist, curator and chief executive of his own corporation, MadeIn, he has forged a career of pushing buttons, consistently riling audiences with shocking installations though rarely provoking the Chinese government. He is considered the leader of a younger generation of Chinese artists who have disengaged from the Mao-driven paintings of the 1990s in favor of more conceptual projects. Xu Zhen (pronounced shoo-jen) is also the commissioned artist for the sprawling 2014 Armory Show, which opens on Thursday on Piers 92 and 94 in Manhattan with a focus on China.

headline: An App That Makes Recommendations Based on Tastes
abstract: Qloo is a New York-based app that calls itself a “personalization engine” because it makes recommendations for movies, music, books and more.
lead_paragraph: It is a standard feature of websites to provide recommendations to users based on past activity. On nytimes.com, the “Recommended for You” tab is always at hand. Services like Pandora and Netflix have long suggested music and movies based on algorithms that track users’ preferences.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Truly Glowing Skin at Balmain
abstract: Instead of being plastered with makeup, models received backstage face treatments with nourishing skincare products for a more natural, healthier glow.
lead_paragraph: At Balmain, makeup artist Tom Pecheux focused on creating gorgeous skin. But instead of using makeup to create the illusion of a flawless face, he pampered the models with face massages to help the blood circulate and to suss out an all-natural glow. Pecheux then nourished the skin with Rodin Olio Lusso face oil, for both hydration and luminosity, followed by Estée Lauder’s Revitalizing Supreme and Idealist Pore-Minimizing Skin Refinisher. After this deluxe treatment, Pecheux applied foundation — he advises mixing two hues, especially during transitional seasons — and powder. Eyebrows were teased out to be fuller, “but not bushy, not extravagant, not Frida Kahlo,” he explained, adding that “eyebrows give a woman character.” Overall, it was a spare, natural look. “If your skin looks beautiful, you already look beautiful. After that, everything else is accessory,” Pecheux reasoned. “At Balmain, there is a lot of accessorizing on the body, so you don’t need accessorizing on the face.”

headline: Jos. A. Bank Rejects Latest Men’s Wearhouse Bid, but Agrees to Meet
abstract: Jos. A. Bank said on Thursday that its board had rejected Men’s Wearhouse’s latest takeover bid, worth nearly $1.8 billion, but said that it was willing to meet to try and agree on a higher price.
lead_paragraph: Jos. A. Bank said on Thursday that its board had rejected Men’s Wearhouse‘s newest takeover bid, worth nearly $1.8 billion, but said that it was willing to meet to try and agree on a higher price.

headline: Confused and Enthused at a Sports Bar
abstract: Clyde Frazier’s Wine and Dine, with its bank of TV screens, indoor basketball half-court and potential for celebrity sightings, may hold special appeal for die-hard Knicks fans.
lead_paragraph: THE first time I watched a Knicks game on TV with my stepson Simon, he was 7. He came armed with the remote; I came armed with Vogue. A few minutes in, he fixed me with an icy glare. “You’re not watching the game,” he announced. “You’re reading a magazine.”

headline: Charles Ives’s Workroom, Pencil Shavings Preserved

lead_paragraph: The austere workroom from the 1910s home of the modernist composer Charles Ives in West Redding, Conn., has been transported to Manhattan, complete with pencil shavings, tattered bulletin board postings and a secret stash of alcohol bottles.

headline: The Twins Ran Off? Can I Have Their Share?
abstract: In “Quesadillas,” a novella by Juan Pablo Villalobos, a child narrator mordantly describes his Mexican family’s struggle to stay fed and cope with the dangers of village life.
lead_paragraph: When I was an editor at The New York Times Book Review not so long ago, we usually discouraged reviewers from mentioning the prizes an author had won, unless those prizes were ambrosial — the National Book Award, the Man Booker, the Yale Series of Younger Poets and so on.

headline: Also on the Menu at Empire Diner: New Memories
abstract: The sound of first dates, business trips and strangers shooting the breeze fill a landmark spot in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Freitag walks to work daily and is still giddy when she opens the door to the Empire Diner. A Chelsea landmark from 1976 until it closed in 2010 (briefly reopening as the Highliner), it is, since Jan. 7, her restaurant now. “I can’t believe it, this is such an iconic space,” Ms. Freitag, the chef and owner, said Tuesday in the redone Tenth Avenue diner that kept some dented metal but added Edison bulbs and gray leather banquettes. “Now to see it come to life, and everybody telling their stories, it’s been great.” A celebrity chef with warmth and whimsy, Ms. Freitag has heard friends and strangers tell of first dates at the former diner turned into marriages with children, and waiters getting grown-up jobs. With twists on staples likes burgers and omelets alongside items like lox and burrata and luxuriously creamy orzo “mac and cheese,” the menu breezily mixes memory and modernity.

He also doesn’t shot-list, production-speak for cataloging each day’s scenes, preferring to set up and let the camera roam on location.

headline: White Lies
abstract: In “Boy, Snow, Bird,” Helen Oyeyemi uses “Snow White” as a departure point for a cautionary tale on post-race ideology, racial limbos and the politics of passing.
lead_paragraph: Strange times, crowed too many wise and unwise men over the millenniums. But as the art critic Jerry Saltz wrote in New York magazine last fall, maybe we’re finally at a point where the strangeness of the times is matched by an ability to accept it. In defending the perplexing Kanye West video “Bound 2,” Saltz heralded this as an age of the New Uncanny. The all-American banal-bizarre spectacle of the video (synthetic sunsets; slow-motion galloping stallions; the nippleless ingénue) is “a freakish act of creation and destruction by appropriation,” what Saltz deems “part of a collective cultural fracturing.” Saltz is riffing on Freud’s description of the uncanny as “nothing new or alien, but something familiar and old-established in the mind and which has become alienated from it only through the process of repression.” But maybe we’re not as alienated as we once were, something that occurred to me when beholding another unapologetic, all-encompassing contradiction-celebration: the story-allegory and real-surreal gyre of Helen Oyeyemi’s gloriously unsettling new novel, “Boy, Snow, Bird.”

headline: If You Can’t Get Onstage, Go Online
abstract: New web series are featuring theater actors and stories about the romantic and comic indignities they suffer behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: In an early episode of the web series “Submissions Only,” created by Kate Wetherhead and Andrew Keenan-Bolger, the struggling actress Penny Reilly, excited to be cast in a workshop production of an important new musical, ends up with such a small part that she’s seated behind a piano where the audience can’t see her. The scene is funny, but the humiliation was real for Ms. Wetherhead, who plays her.

headline: State of Our Art, According to Whitney
abstract: The 2014 Biennial features 103 participants in its quest to represent the current art scene, with contemporary works everywhere.
lead_paragraph: WHITNEY Biennials can be daunting, confounding, exhausting and sometimes even outrageous. No matter how the curators organize this sprawling survey of what’s happening in American contemporary art right now, trying to navigate the museumwide exhibition and make sense of it all is a challenge, even for the pros.

headline: Egyptian Military Claims to Cure H.I.V. and Hepatitis C
abstract: The Egyptian military announced last week that it had found a cure for hepatitis C and the virus that causes AIDS, but few appear convinced by the claim.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Kareem Fahim and Mayy El Sheikh reported, the Egyptian military made the unlikely announcement last week that after 22 years of secret research it had found a cure to not just one global public health scourge, but two: hepatitis C and H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: Slaking a Thirst for Beers at Craft Breweries
abstract: Several small-batch breweries have opened in Connecticut within the last two years, aided by a change in state law that allows direct sales to consumers.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday evening in an old factory building in Bristol, people crowded into two back rooms to down pints of beer. It looked like some kind of pop-up party, but it was actually just business as usual at the Firefly Hollow Brewing Company, one of the many new craft breweries to open in Connecticut in the last two years.

headline: Chris Lehane’s Political Theater
abstract: Performance politics is Chris Lehane’s specialty.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s magazine, Adam Nagourney profiles Chris Lehane, a California-based political strategist known for what Nagourney calls “performance politics.”

headline: Google Pays for the Ride
abstract: Google, under fire in San Francisco for not giving back, gave back Thursday, with $6.8 million to fund a city transit program that provides monthly bus and streetcar passes to 31,000 low-income youths.
lead_paragraph: Google, which has been at the center of a controversy in San Francisco over tech company shuttles using public infrastructure, is giving $6.8 million to fund a city transit program.

headline: Two Months In, Attracting Crowds
abstract: Surrounded by other dining spots in the Woodbury Village Shopping Center, MoCA Asian Bistro has become a place where reservations need to be made well in advance.
lead_paragraph: MoCA Asian Bistro in Woodbury has been drawing crowds since its opening two months ago. When I called two days ahead for a Friday or Saturday reservation, I was told that none were available, no matter how early or late. I settled for a Saturday night reservation 10 days in the future and was given a choice of 6 or 6:30 p.m.
