Their skills are on display at Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue, at East 38th Street.

headline: Cervelli and Yankees Teammates Show Support for Protesters in Venezuela
abstract: Francisco Cervelli and about a dozen of his teammates were photographed with the Venezuelan flag and signs for peace.
lead_paragraph: About a dozen Yankees, including Francisco Cervelli of Venezuela, became the latest major leaguers to express support for the growing opposition movement in Venezuela by being photographed with the nation’s flag and signs for peace. Ichiro Suzuki and C. C. Sabathia were among the Yankees in the photo, which was posted to Cervelli’s Instagram account.

headline: Asian Cuisine, Easy on the Fusion
abstract: Ichiro, the White Plains outpost of a popular restaurant on Manhattan’s Upper East Side, can accommodate all kinds of cravings for Asian cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Sleekly designed Asian fusion restaurants have popped up all over Westchester in recent years with lounge-style lighting, pumping music and menus that are not as much a fusion as they are a gathering of offerings from Japanese, Chinese, Malaysian, Korean and Thai cuisines.

headline: A Small Subset of Texas Voters Who Hold a Lot of Sway
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: With low turnout in Texas primaries and the two-decade dominance of Republicans, a bloc of voters is determining how the state will handle long-term public policy challenges.
lead_paragraph: In modern-day Texas, the election that matters is usually the Republican primary.

headline: Creative Cuisine, Vibrant Setting
abstract: The menu at Órale Mexican Kitchen features more adventurous items than are typically found in the standard Mexican-American repertoire.
lead_paragraph: The minute you enter Órale Mexican Kitchen in Jersey City, you can see that the person who decorated it has a fine eye for design. Note, in particular, the beautifully lit bottles of Jarritos soda, in colors that reflect their flavors (lime, strawberry, fruit punch, mandarin and grapefruit). After a flight of tequila and a round of guacamole studded with unexpected treats, like cubes of Cabrales blue cheese or juicy pineapple, you know you are in for more than just visual delights.

headline: Luminous Canterbury Pilgrims
abstract: “Radiant Light: Stained Glass From Canterbury Cathedral,” at the Cloisters, displays windows that depict biblical figures.
lead_paragraph: With monastic masonry shipped in from Europe, an interior filled with liturgical luxe, and its air fragrant with spiritual expectation, the Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museum’s medieval redoubt in Upper Manhattan, is a complete atmospheric package, and one of the city’s great examples of installation art.

headline: Authenticity Is Just Part of an Allure
abstract: The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra performed at Carnegie Hall as part of the festival Vienna: City of Dreams.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Champagne and Roquefort, an appellation d’origine contrôlée, a trade label authenticating a product’s provenance, can be a useful guarantor of quality. But how much do terroir and tradition matter in music? Plenty, according to the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, which continues its New York residence as part of Carnegie Hall’s festival Vienna: City of Dreams.

headline: The Damage That Good Can Inflict
abstract: “Fatal Assistance,” a documentary by Raoul Peck, chronicles the challenges and failures of rebuilding efforts in Haiti after the 2010 earthquake.
lead_paragraph: Good intentions and billions of promised dollars only go so far. That, certainly, is one of the sobering truths in “Fatal Assistance,” a potent, persuasive and quietly furious documentary that examines how international aid agencies failed Haiti after the catastrophic 2010 earthquake. That disaster, which was followed by other calamities, including a cholera outbreak, left an estimated quarter-million people dead and more than a million temporarily or permanently homeless. People and organizations across the world pledged help, and money started to flood in along with journalists, religious workers, relief groups, Bill Clinton and Sean Penn.

headline: Operas Unfolding at a Different Met
abstract: The Gotham Chamber Opera presented Monteverdi’s “Il Combattimento di Tancredi e Clorinda” and the one-act “I Have No Stories to Tell You” at the Met Museum.
lead_paragraph: As ticket holders for a performance by the Gotham Chamber Opera filed into the Arms and Armor Court at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday evening, some did a double take when they saw a soldier in modern uniform sitting behind a glass enclosure, rolling a joint.

headline: So Blissfully Nestled in Her Web of Lies
abstract: The drama “Two Lives,” with Juliane Köhler and Liv Ullmann, focuses on a happily married woman and apparent East German spy whose secrets threaten to destroy her family life.
lead_paragraph: The anxious, melancholic drama “Two Lives” is the story of a woman caught up in the toxic backwash of long-ago events that exert a fearful grip on the present. Unholy forces shaped the double life of this woman, Katrine (Juliane Köhler, “Nowhere in Africa”). Happily married and living in Norway, she has a secret past that merges two of the darker chapters of 20th-century European history.

headline: Many Allies, but Perry Lends Name to Few
abstract: With primary races crowded, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has mostly withheld endorsements, a move that may be politically prudent, given his ties to several candidates.
lead_paragraph: As Republicans poke around for signals on how to vote in crowded primary races — those, that is, who have not taken advantage of early voting — the state’s top elected Republican official is offering little assistance.

headline: The Greatest Story, Retold
abstract: Adapted from “The Bible,” a History channel mini-series, “Son of God” depicts the last days of Jesus.
lead_paragraph: Adapted from the History channel mini-series “The Bible,” “Son of God” runs through the scriptural greatest hits of the Passion with the reliability of a Sunday reader. It’s a movie that embraces the nearly pedagogical predictability of lines like “Where’s Judas? You seen him?” or “Thomas, stop doubting.”

headline: Finding Poetry in Pairs
abstract: Kimberly Bartosik and her dance company, daela, explore the possibilities of pairs in “You are my heat and glare,” at New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Bartosik’s “You are my heat and glare” begins with a song. You might be in the lobby, waiting for the elevator to the third-floor studio, when you first hear it. Two singers (Gelsey Bell and Dave Ruder), part the crowd and then disappear into the stairwell, their luminous harmonies vanishing with them.

headline: A Juvenile Justice System With Few Checks
abstract: The documentary “Kids for Cash” examines corruption in the juvenile justice system.
lead_paragraph: Carefully assembled and soberly presented, Robert May’s “Kids for Cash” takes a lacerating look at America’s juvenile justice system — the United States is one of only three countries in the world to decline to ratify the United Nations’ Convention on the Rights of the Child — and the perils of its increasing privatization.

headline: If You’d Like to Live, Best Not Look Inside
abstract: “The Bag Man” stars Robert De Niro and John Cusack in a neo-noir about crooks in a cat-and-mouse game.
lead_paragraph: Robert De Niro’s silly pompadour in “The Bag Man” is one sign that this sardonic neo-noir, the first feature directed by David Grovic, has a cheeky sense of itself as something extra clever. Mr. De Niro plays Dragna, whose voluminous hairstyle — reminiscent of Paulie’s ’do on “The Sopranos” — is also a reflection of his inflated ego.

headline: You, Me, Us
abstract: Advice on sharing spousal financial decisions, the new marijuana etiquette, gifts for your therapist and more.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I had successful careers in finance before we married. When we had our first child, we agreed that I would quit my job to spend more time with the baby. (We now have two bright toddlers.) But we never agreed how our finances would be managed after I stopped working. Now, he pays the house- and child-related expenses, and I pay my personal expenses from my savings, which will run out at some point. But when investment decisions are required, he calls the shots, even though he asks for my opinion. This often makes me uncomfortable because he is willing to take greater risks than I am. How do you think we should make these decisions?

headline: Truth-Telling in a Medical Setting
abstract: Doctors respond to a Sunday Review article, “When Doctors Need to Lie.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Globalization of Drugs
abstract: Gil Kerlikowske, America’s “drug czar,” discusses drug use in the United States and abroad.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Child Genius Meets Middle-Age Kid
abstract: In “HairBrained,” Brendan Fraser plays a 41-year-old failed gambler who goes back to school and befriends a 14-year-old genius.
lead_paragraph: In “With Honors” (1994), Brendan Fraser played a Harvard undergrad. Twenty years later, he goes back to school in Billy Kent’s “HairBrained” as Leo Searly, a 41-year-old failed gambler who decides to enroll at the fictional Whittman College and befriends a 14-year-old classmate.

headline: Tea Party Group, Celebrating Its Fifth Anniversary, Is Happy but Restless
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Internal differences in the movement were on display as Senators Rand Paul, Ted Cruz and Mike Lee addressed the Tea Party Patriots in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The list of marquee names on hand was testament to the growing clout of the Tea Party: Rand Paul, Ted Cruz, Mike Lee — all three elected to the Senate thanks to its activist support.

headline: The Crowning Glory
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Cornices are out of fashion, but time was when they were the rage.
lead_paragraph: Like coats and ties at a ballgame, cornices have pretty much disappeared from contemporary architecture.

headline: Inroads Into Child Obesity
abstract: Dr. Alvin N. Eden, a pediatrician, responds to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Military Budget
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: A retired lieutenant general endorses a “smaller and smarter” budget.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Curbs on E-Cigarettes
abstract: Dr. Patricia Finn of the American Thoracic Society responds to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A War of Words: Israel Responds to Iran
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Aaron Sagui of the Israeli Embassy takes issue with a letter from the Iranian government.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Eggs Over Easy, With a Side of Weird
abstract: The hero of “Odd Thomas,” an adaptation by Stephen Sommers of the Dean Koontz novel, is a short-order cook who sees dead people and finds their murderers.
lead_paragraph: “I may see dead people,” Odd (Anton Yelchin), the civic-minded hero of “Odd Thomas,” tells us, “but then, by God, I do something about it.” Given that most of the expired souls who crave his attention are crime victims, what he does usually takes the form of hunting down killers.

headline: A Suburban Life Running on Fumes
abstract: In Jay Alaimo’s new drama, Vincent D’Onofrio and Kyra Sedgwick are the married heads of a household that is far from satisfied.
lead_paragraph: A line of cocaine disappears up a nostril in what turns out to be an apt introduction to a movie about curdled characters seeking empty distractions. But “Chlorine,” Jay Alaimo’s sour tale of suburban greed and marital disappointment, can’t even deliver a temporary high; mired in the blahs, the blues and the midlife crazies, this poor man’s “American Beauty” slowly sucks your will to live.

headline: New Butler Services Buff Luxury Hotels
abstract: A new generation of butlers specializing in daily service details and personal assistance is on the rise at luxury hotels.
lead_paragraph: In the race for an increasingly personalized luxury hotel experience, the butler may be the ultimate amenity. Since January, the new Langham, Chicago has employed a rotating staff of eight dedicated butlers for its three club floors.

headline: Humanity, Enhanced, on a Russian Battlefield
abstract: “Stalingrad” includes two story lines in a narrowly focused 3-D depiction of the struggle for a city during World War II.
lead_paragraph: The credits of “Stalingrad,” a Russian-made 3-D film set during a pivotal battle in World War II, attribute the story to selected chapters from the panoramic novel “Life and Fate” by Vasily Grossman. It’s not the source you might expect for a war movie that uses slow-motion as liberally as a Michael Bay film and that heaves its scream-filled skirmishes onto the arena-size canvas of an Imax screen.

headline: Dove Tells Women to Love Their Armpits
abstract: Dove is promoting a new line of deodorant with a campaign that tries to beautify an unlovely part of the body — and also pokes fun at New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: AFTER bearing the brunt of jokes about “Bridgegate,” the scandal surrounding the closure of traffic lanes on the George Washington Bridge that aides of Gov. Chris Christie apparently ordered as political payback, New Jersey residents may not laugh along with Dove billboards that will appear in their state.

headline: More Seems to Be Less for Mets at First Base
abstract: The Mets’ efforts to trade Ike Davis in the off-season were unsuccessful, so he and Lucas Duda will compete to start at first base.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It was not really supposed to be a competition at all.

headline: On a Youth Kick
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: Determining the next generation of great designers is part of the task of the newly established LVMH Prize.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Youth is the cause célèbre here. There is a sour sense that the next generation of great designers has yet to come. Figuring out who they are is part of the task of the newly established LVMH Prize. It will offer 300,000 euros (about $412,000) and industry mentorship to the winner of an open contest — provided he or she is younger than 40, with at least two collections already in hand.

headline: Political Party Ends Blockade of NATO Supply Route in Pakistan
abstract: The opposition politician Imran Khan announced Thursday that his political party, Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, which governs the northwestern Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province, would end its three-month blockade of a NATO supply route.
lead_paragraph: The opposition politician Imran Khan announced Thursday that his political party, Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, which governs the northwestern Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province, would end its three-month blockade of a NATO supply route. Mr. Khan’s party imposed the blockade in November to protest American drone strikes in Pakistan’s tribal regions. On Thursday, party workers removed a protest camp in Peshawar that was used to stop trucks heading toward the border with Afghanistan. This week, a court in Peshawar ruled that the blockade was illegal. A statement released by Mr. Khan’s party said that “the pressure of the blockade had already resulted in a shift in the Obama administration’s drone policy, and as a result drones had been stopped for the present.”

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Several Bombings Leave Dozens Dead in Iraq
abstract: At least 38 people were killed and more than 50 were wounded Thursday in a series of bombings in Iraq, three of them in Shiite areas of Baghdad, Iraqi officials said.
lead_paragraph: At least 38 people were killed and more than 50 were wounded Thursday in a series of bombings in Iraq, three of them in Shiite areas of Baghdad, Iraqi officials said. The deadliest attack killed 24 people when a bomb attached to a motorcycle exploded in a market where motorcycles are sold in the Sadr City area of Baghdad, the police said. Another bomb in Sadr City blew up a bus, killing five people and wounding 14, and a bomb in the Shaab neighborhood destroyed a minibus, killing four people and wounding 13, the police said. At a checkpoint in northern Baghdad, a suicide bomber killed three soldiers and wounded three, and in Tuz Khurmato, north of Baghdad, a blast at a fish restaurant killed two people and wounded 18, security officials said. Also on Thursday, Iraqi security forces carried out operations against militants in Mosul and in Kirkuk and Anbar Provinces, with officials reporting that more than 20 militants were killed.

headline: Brooklyn Communal Cool: The Brand
abstract: A company dedicated to selling the borough’s image has partnered with a collective of eight roommates to try to monetize Brooklyn cool.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday evening, Dickerman Cade Sadler III was in the kitchen making tacos for his roommates, sautéing beef in a frying pan and setting aside a bowl of rice and beans for the vegetarians. In the living room-cum-recording studio, Denitia Odigie was sitting at the drum kit tapping out a beat, her back to the wall papered with old-fashioned damask, while a man who calls himself Sene (his real name is Brian Marc) set up a mike under the glass and bronze chandelier. Standing outside, on the quiet cul-de-sac, two 20-somethings in clunky glasses and knitted beanies braved the freezing winter air to smoke a cigarette.

headline: Evidence of Concealed Jailhouse Deal Raises Questions About a Texas Execution
abstract: The battle to clear the name of Cameron Todd Willingham, who was convicted of murdering his three children by arson, has symbolic value because it may offer evidence that an innocent man was executed 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: In the 10 years since Texas executed Cameron Todd Willingham after convicting him on charges of setting his house on fire and murdering his three young daughters, family members and death penalty opponents have argued that he was innocent. Now newly discovered evidence suggests that the prosecutor in the case may have concealed a deal with a jailhouse informant whose testimony was a key part of the execution decision.

headline: Met Opera Seeking Concessions in Union Talks
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera has begun discussions with its unions, hoping they’ll agree to smaller pensions and other take backs before their contracts expire in July.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera is seeking concessions from its unions, whose contracts are up at the end of July, as it begins a round of labor negotiations that promise to be contentious.

headline: The Cancer Divide
abstract: As nations across Africa have made remarkable progress against infectious diseases, more people are living long enough to develop cancer.
lead_paragraph: As nations across Africa have made remarkable progress against infectious diseases, more people are living long enough to develop cancer.

headline: A Community Center as DMZ in City’s Class War
abstract: The Manny Cantor Center in Lower Manhattan offers gym membership and classes along a sliding scale to reach residents of all income levels, a goal that seems almost mythic in nature.
lead_paragraph: In ordinary times, the opening of a gym in Lower Manhattan might not occasion much reflection, but these, as it happens, are not ordinary times. We are in a moment of class warfare, of punishing the rich for their triumphs of asset management, or so the right labors to convince us. To believe this is to miss the extent to which class warfare is more than a political tool; it is an intimate social reality whose perpetrators come not from the vast aggrieved bottom.

headline: U.S. Moves Toward Atlantic Oil Exploration, Stirring Debate Over Sea Life
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Sonar', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Environment']
abstract: Environmental activists say seismic surveys will harm marine mammals, but other experts say those fears are inflated.
lead_paragraph: The Interior Department opened the door on Thursday to the first searches in decades for oil and gas off the Atlantic coast, recommending that undersea seismic surveys proceed, though with a host of safeguards to shield marine life from much of their impact.

headline: The Tenure Pipeline at Harvard Business School
abstract: Harvard Business School says it wants to improve the gender balance among faculty members, but it is far from that goal without extensive hiring.
lead_paragraph: Harvard Business School says it wants to improve the gender balance among faculty members, but it is far from that goal without extensive hiring.

headline: British Lawmakers Intensify Focus on Head Injuries
abstract: Spurred by the momentum the issue has gained in the United States, Parliament is examining a tightening of the rules governing the response to sports-related concussions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Spurred by the momentum the issue has gained in the United States, British lawmakers have started their own campaign to highlight the incidence of serious head injuries in sports, calling for a tightening of the rules governing the way that players, coaches, team doctors, professional leagues and parents respond to sports-related concussions.

headline: Bakken Crude, Rolling Through Albany
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The instant growth in the oil-by-rail business is increasing the oil supply, but also raising alarms.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — On a clear December morning two years ago, a 600-foot oceangoing oil tanker called the Stena Primorsk left the Port of Albany on its maiden voyage down the Hudson River laden with 279,000 barrels of crude oil. It quickly ran aground on a sandbar.

headline: Ease and Ardor
abstract: Michel de Montaigne and Samuel Johnson provide two contrasting yet compelling examples of how to lead an inner life.
lead_paragraph: Michel de Montaigne and Samuel Johnson are two of the greatest essayists who ever lived. They tackled similar problems and were fascinated by some of the same perplexities, but they represent different personality types and recommended two different ways to live.

headline: Arizona Bill Allowing Refusal of Service to Gays Stirred Alarm in the G.O.P.
abstract: Establishment Republican leaders worried about identifying their party with polarizing social issues at a time when they see the prospect of big gains in congressional elections on economic issues.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Rick Scott of Florida was asked early Wednesday whether he supported Arizona legislation that would make it easier for business owners to refuse service to gay people on religious grounds, he demurred, saying he was unfamiliar with the bill. By afternoon, his office issued a statement saying the measure was divisive and should be vetoed.

headline: No Big Deal
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']
abstract: Talks are stalled on an international trade deal, thanks to negotiating difficulties abroad and bipartisan skepticism at home. But that’s O.K.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that the Obama administration’s domestic economic agenda is stalled in the face of scorched-earth opposition from Republicans. And that’s a bad thing: The U.S. economy would be in much better shape if Obama administration proposals like the American Jobs Act had become law.

headline: SeaWorld Questions Ethics of ‘Blackfish’ Investigator
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Movies']
abstract: SeaWorld Entertainment has come under fire after a documentary criticized its practice of holding whales in captivity. Now, the company is firing back.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — SeaWorld Entertainment, which has come under fire after the release of “Blackfish,” a critical documentary about whales in captivity, struck back Thursday at one of its government monitors for her supposed cozy relations with animal-rights activists and involvement in the film.

headline: Cubs Are Working on Winning Soon, if Not Now
abstract: The Chicago Cubs are coming off their worst two-year stretch, but Theo Epstein, the president of baseball operations, and his legacy in Boston offers hope.
lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — The Chicago Cubs devoted 7,500 square feet to the workout facility of their sprawling new spring training complex here. There is also a 120-seat theater and 22 pitching mounds and 16 batting cages. But the gym is the jewel, two stories of weight machines and treadmills and loud music underneath a canopy of red and blue championship banners.

headline: The Mean Streets of New York
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: How urban design facilitates pedestrian casualties.
lead_paragraph: WITHIN a two-block radius on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, three pedestrians have lost their lives in separate traffic accidents since Jan. 1. Nineteen more have been killed elsewhere in the city since the beginning of the year. Those 22 are just the latest in the city’s epidemic of traffic fatalities. Last year 176 pedestrians were killed by cars and trucks in the city, according to police data, the most since 2008.

headline: When May I Shoot a Student?
abstract: Modest questions about an Idaho bill allowing guns on campus.
lead_paragraph: BOISE, Idaho — TO the chief counsel of the Idaho State Legislature:

headline: Fitness and Redemption
abstract: Tommy Mickens started a company that teaches fitness to senior citizens, a career move that began after he served 20 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Tommy Mickens started a company that teaches fitness to senior citizens, a career move that began after he served 20 years in prison.

headline: Jeter, Held Hitless, Gives Yankees Fans Reason to Celebrate
abstract: Derek Jeter was hitless in his first spring training game of the year, but his ankle did not noticeably slow him, and neither did his calf or his quad.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter walked to home plate in the first inning Thursday and, before looking out to the mound, said hello to the Pittsburgh Pirates’ new catcher, Chris Stewart, his teammate on the Yankees the last two seasons.

headline: A Call to Give Consumers Their Credit Scores Free
abstract: The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau urged credit card companies to give customers free copies of their credit scores.
lead_paragraph: In its new role as consumer credit watchdog, the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Thursday urged credit card companies to give customers free copies of their credit scores — crucial pieces of financial information used to evaluate qualifications for mortgages, credit cards and even certain types of insurance and rental apartments.

headline: Driving Down Childhood Obesity
keywords: ['Obesity', 'Children and Childhood', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Editorials']
abstract: A modest step in the right direction for a small slice of the population suggests further gains may be possible.
lead_paragraph: There are glimmers of good news in the struggle to control obesity, one of the greatest health risks confronting the United States and other affluent nations. The latest federal report shows a significant reduction in the obesity rate among children ages 2 to 5, a vulnerable period when obesity patterns are often locked in for a lifetime. It is only a modest step in the right direction for a small slice of the population, but it suggests that further gains may be possible with a determined effort.

headline: Of Crime and Punishment, Redemption and Aerobics
abstract: After serving 20 years in prison for running a drug empire in his 20s, Thomas Mickens is using his business savvy to operate a Queens fitness company for older adults.
lead_paragraph: It was a stinging 9 degrees on a recent Thursday morning when Thomas Mickens bounded into the Rochdale Village Senior Center in Jamaica, Queens. He was 15 minutes early to teach his 8:30 a.m. aerobics class, and his boisterous entrance was met by friendly jabs and laughter from about three dozen enthusiastic older people. The group ranged from 60 to 89 years old, most on the younger side of old age; none relied on walkers and only two had canes.

headline: As Africans Surge to Europe’s Door, Spain Locks Down
abstract: Large groups of sub-Saharan immigrants have been charging the fences into a Spanish enclave in Morocco, raising alarms over their efforts and the officials’ response.
lead_paragraph: MELILLA, Spain — It is easy to pick out the new arrivals at the shelter for immigrants here on this tiny patch of Spain in North Africa. One man limps by on crutches with a plaster cast on his ankle. Another has a bandaged arm in a sling. Abbdol Cisse, 19, had stitches on his face.

headline: Thailand at the Brink
abstract: Giving regional governments more power could address divisions that are pulling the country apart.
lead_paragraph: Political tensions that have long simmered in Thailand have exploded into violence in recent days. Clashes and gunfights between antigovernment protesters and security forces led to several deaths and many more injuries over the weekend. But the country’s elected leaders and the protesters are digging in their heels even as the conflict tears their country apart. The leader of Thailand’s army recently warned that continued violence could lead to a “collapse” of the country.

headline: Business and the Minimum Wage
abstract: Paying workers more can help companies lower turnover and improve productivity.
lead_paragraph: Much of the discussion about the Democratic proposal to raise the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour by 2016 has rightly focused on the workers who will clearly benefit from the move. But what about businesses? How would higher wages affect them?

headline: Events in New Jersey for March 2-8
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: McIlroy Leads With 63, but He Has Company
abstract: On the same course where he stormed off in the second round a year ago, Rory McIlroy took a one-stroke lead at the Honda Classic.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Rory McIlroy’s emotions often creep into his game, causing his mind to wander far outside the gallery ropes. But if McIlroy blocks out the noise and channels his talent, he can produce special scores like the 63 he fired to take the Honda Classic lead Thursday.

headline: Nagging, as a Force for Good
abstract: At a school fair at the Department of Probation in the Bronx, officers made sure that clients on probation were on the right path.
lead_paragraph: Lurking strategically in the offices of the Department of Probation in the Bronx, Stephanie Arno positioned herself so that no one could walk out to 161st Street without passing her.

headline: Events in Connecticut for March 2-8
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: The Toys of War
abstract: How a board game from Milton Bradley swept through Civil War-era America.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for Christmas 1866, a 30-year-old game creator named Milton Bradley ran an advertisement in Colman’s Rural World, a St. Louis-based publication for farmers. Bradley, a lithographer living in Springfield, Mass., was already well known for inventing “The Checkered Game of Life” in 1860. His 1866 ad promoted his games and amusements as “moral, entertaining, wonderful, and instructive.” Among these wonders was the Myriopticon, a toy panorama containing 22 scenes from the history of the “Rebellion” so recently concluded. The toy evidently caught on, at least for a time. The next year, another Bradley puff described the Myriopticon as “immensely popular with boys,” especially those ages 7 to 12.

headline: Mortgage Servicer’s Ties Raise Regulatory Concern
abstract: State and federal regulators are worried that Ocwen is mishandling some of the mortgages it services, citing examples of shoddy paperwork and faulty technology.
lead_paragraph: Mortgage servicers collect money from homeowners and distribute those payments to lenders. It’s a fairly boring business, but not to William C. Erbey.

headline: Plan to Redevelop Domino Sugar Factory in Brooklyn Hits Snag: De Blasio
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: A $1.5 billion proposal to redevelop Brooklyn’s Domino Sugar plant is in jeopardy as officials ask for a higher quota of affordable housing units.
lead_paragraph: For years, the plan to redevelop the Domino Sugar refinery in Williamsburg was viewed in the neighborhood with dread, roundly derided as a line of bulky new buildings that would clog the Brooklyn waterfront.

headline: A Call to Arms on a Vermont Heroin Epidemic
abstract: Rutland has begun an effort to attack a drug problem with social services, as well as with law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: RUTLAND, Vt. — Block by block, this city in central Vermont has been fighting a heroin epidemic so entrenched that it has confounded all efforts to combat it.

headline: Events on Long Island for March 2-8
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Credit Card Debt Threatens Turkey’s Economy
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Personal Finances', 'Credit Cards']
abstract: The boom in consumer credit has become a serious risk for Turkish lenders, Standard & Poor’s warned in a new report, citing slow economic growth and political turmoil.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Ozcan Yuksel’s descent into debt began with a stroll down Istiklal Caddesi, a popular Istanbul promenade teeming with shops and restaurants.

headline: Antoine Mason Is Driven to Succeed, Just Like His Father
abstract: Antoine Mason, a son of the former Knicks player Anthony Mason, is the second-leading scorer in Division I, averaging 25.7 points a game for Niagara.
lead_paragraph: Longtime Knicks fans probably still treasure memories of Anthony Mason, a powerful 6-foot-7, 250-pound forward who willed himself to prominence as a seemingly tireless worker beside Patrick Ewing in the early 1990s. Mason’s son Antoine, a junior guard at Niagara who is the second-leading scorer in Division I with 25.7 points a game, has a less imposing body type. But he is his father’s son in every other way.

headline: A House With a Modified Loan Is a Symbol of Servicers’ Tug of War With Investors
abstract: Ocwen Financial, a relatively unknown company, has come to occupy a large and crucial presence at the center of the mortgage market in recent years.
lead_paragraph: A small, run-down house in Uniondale, N.Y., may sum up why bad blood is brewing between some of the biggest players in today’s housing market — and why that tension may hamper the nation’s attempts to recover from years of painful foreclosures and depressed housing values.

headline: Copycat Business Model Generates Genuine Global Success for Start-Up Incubator
abstract: Rocket Internet, which funds e-commerce start-ups that mimic proven business models, operates in sharp contrast to Silicon Valley, where originality is prized.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For Linio, think Amazon for Mexicans. For Zalora, think Zappos for Malaysians. For Easy Taxi, think Uber for Nigerians.

headline: Bin Laden Relative’s Lawyers Claim Mistaken Identity as Trial Nears
abstract: A letter to the judge in the terrorism case against Sulaiman Abu Ghaith says that the government may have confused the defendant with a Guantánamo detainee.
lead_paragraph: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, faces a terrorism trial next week in Manhattan. But his lawyers now claim that the authorities have mixed him up with a man with a similar name who is detained at the United States naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Naming of Officials in Ukraine Reflects Homage to Power of the Street
abstract: The inclusion of popular protest figures in an interim government reflected an effort to pay tribute to the role of the street in dislodging a president from power.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Oleh Musiy, a prominent doctor who last week coordinated the improvised field hospitals that treated wounded and dying protesters during clashes with the police, is now the health minister of Ukraine, a nation of 46 million people.

headline: Rare Supreme Court Outburst Caught on Even Rarer Videos
keywords: ['Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Campaign Finance', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: The videos, shot by a protest group that denounced the court’s decision in the Citizens United campaign finance case, represent a major breach of Supreme Court security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A protest group has posted surreptitious videos prepared inside the Supreme Court during oral arguments, one of them showing an audience member standing to denounce the court’s decision in the Citizens United campaign finance case.

headline: At Council Hearing, Calls for New York to Offer Homeless Children and Families More Aid
abstract: Advocates, service providers and council members pressed the city to firm up a proposal for a rent-subsidy program and to improve services for children.
lead_paragraph: Members of the City Council pressed the de Blasio administration at a hearing on Thursday to complete a proposal for rental assistance to New York’s homeless and demanded improved services for more than 22,000 children living in city shelters.

headline: Events in Westchester for March 2-8
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Caged Wife, Desperately Spinning Her Wheel
abstract: In the Young Vic’s production of “A Doll’s House,” at the Harvey Theater in Brooklyn, Hattie Morahan brings out Nora’s manipulative side.
lead_paragraph: How can suspense be so enthralling when you know exactly what’s going to happen? You may find yourself asking that question as you dig your fingernails into your palms during the show that opened on Thursday night at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Can’t Hold Their Feelings, or Their Alcohol
abstract: In Craig Lucas’s new play, “Ode to Joy,” Kathryn Erbe and Arliss Howard play lovers who bond over a tidal wave of vodka.
lead_paragraph: Something scary, and pretty much irresistible, happens in the first act of “Ode to Joy,” Craig Lucas’s eloquent mess of a play at the Cherry Lane Theater. What occurs is both beautiful and ugly, and ticklingly familiar if you’ve ever bonded with someone in the depths of a shared drunkenness. Or is it heights? Whatever’s going on, it’s intoxicating, in all senses of the word.

headline: Turn Up the Music
abstract: Celebrate Friday with a musical puzzle by Martin Ashwood-Smith.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle from Martin Ashwood-Smith may be themeless, but it still has a fair number of references to music.

headline: Timetable Set for Rules on Wheelchair-Accessible Taxicabs
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Amid concerns that New York City was not moving swiftly enough to make more taxis accessible to the disabled, a federal judge set a timetable for the publication of new accessibility rules.
lead_paragraph: Amid concerns that New York City was not moving swiftly enough to make more taxis accessible to the disabled, a federal judge in Manhattan set a timetable on Thursday for the publication of new accessibility rules and a public hearing that is required before they are formally adopted.

headline: A Second Bout of ‘Passion,’ Rawer
abstract: The Berlin Philharmonic, under the conductor Simon Rattle, performed “St. John Passion” in a new staging by Peter Sellars.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion” is contemplative, a study in suffering and transcendence. His “St. John Passion” is tighter and more angular, a battlefield of action and reaction.

headline: State Department Report Details Suppression of Human Rights Abroad
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The government’s annual human rights assessment notes abuses in Egypt, Iran, Russia and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department reported Thursday that an increasing number of governments were suppressing political opponents and restricting the freedom of assembly.

headline: Outrage Over Sexist Remarks Turns Into a Political Fund-Raising Tool
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Political Action Committees', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: With a record number of women in Congress and dozens more on the ballot, attacks on figures like Wendy Davis, Claire McCaskill and Hillary Rodham Clinton can instantly generate contributions.
lead_paragraph: In the past few months, Republicans have called Wendy Davis, a Democratic candidate for Texas governor, “Abortion Barbie,” likened Alison Lundergan Grimes, a Senate candidate from Kentucky, to an “empty dress,” criticized Hillary Rodham Clinton’s thighs, and referred to a pregnant woman as a “host.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 27, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Post-Filibuster, Obama Faces New Anger Over Judicial Choices
keywords: ['Federal Courts (US)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs']
abstract: After Senate rules were changed, some Democrats thought President Obama would have less trouble with his nominations. Now, they are the ones trying to block his latest choices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Democrats changed Senate rules last year to limit the filibuster against White House nominees, it raised hopes among some liberals that President Obama would use his new power to reshape the federal judiciary. Now, just over three months later, some Democrats and progressive groups are instead trying to stop two of the president’s latest nominees to the federal bench on the grounds that they are too conservative.

headline: Workers at Nuclear Waste Site in New Mexico Inhaled Radioactive Materials
abstract: Thirteen night-shift workers at a burial site for nuclear weapons waste were affected, but how serious the risk was to their long-term health was uncertain.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thirteen employees who worked the night shift at a nuclear waste burial site in New Mexico after an underground leak are carrying radioactive materials in their bodies, but it is too soon to say how much health risk this poses, Energy Department officials said on Thursday.

headline: For Drivers on Some City Bus Routes, Requesting the $2.50 Fare Can Be Dangerous
abstract: Unlike subway drivers who are shielded from passengers’ emotions by a thick metal door, many bus drivers are fully exposed to the moods of the fickle, and sometimes violent, New York City commuter.
lead_paragraph: The crime can seem as innocuous as it is common. Short on cash, a rider slips through the back door of a city bus, skirting the $2.50 fare.

headline: U.S. Prosecutors Interview Christie’s Spokesman
abstract: Michael Drewniak was critical to the administration’s response as the controversy over the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge grew, according to a legislative panel.
lead_paragraph: One of Gov. Chris Christie’s closest aides was interviewed on Thursday by federal prosecutors seeking to determine whether the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge in September amounted to a crime, the aide’s lawyer said.

headline: Authorities to Seize a Roman Statue in Queens That They Say Was Stolen
abstract: Italian officials say there is evidence that a marble statue of a reclining, half-clad woman valued at $4 million was looted from Italy decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators on Friday plan to seize an ancient Roman sculpture from a Queens warehouse on behalf of Italian officials who say there is evidence the marble statue of a reclining, half-clad woman valued at $4 million was looted from Italy decades ago.

headline: Rangers Still Going Strong (So Are Trade Rumors)
abstract: Still facing uncertainty over their captain, Ryan Callahan, and defenseman Dan Girardi, the Rangers beat Chicago and stayed hot in their first game since the Olympic break.
lead_paragraph: Picking up where they left off 20 days ago, the Rangers played their first game after the Olympic break and kept on winning, this time a 2-1 verdict over the defending Stanley Cup champion Chicago Blackhawks. A Rangers team that was streaking in the weeks leading up to the Olympics is streaking still; they are 17-6-1 in their last 24 games.

headline: Missing Out on the Latest Texas Oil Boom, One Town Repurposes Its Leftovers
abstract: When an oil boom ends, the pump jacks sometimes remain as an ugly reminder of better times. In Luling, they have turned that notion upside down and have transformed the jacks into art.
lead_paragraph: LULING — Down, up. Down, up. Click.

headline: Jim Lange, Genial Host of ‘Dating Game,’ Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Lange, an affable presence clad in a velvet tuxedo, presided over a hit TV game show that coyly played matchmaker between bachelors and bachelorettes.
lead_paragraph: Jim Lange, the original host of “The Dating Game,” the hit TV show that distilled the Swinging Sixties into a potent blend of on-screen matchmaking, jovial innuendo and unstinting Mod aesthetics, died on Tuesday a his home in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Crimea’s Bloody Past Is a Key to Its Present
abstract: The unrest in this multiethnic region of Ukraine is just the latest in its long history at the center of territorial disputes.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — On Thursday, masked gunmen vowing loyalty to Russia seized the Parliament building in Simferopol, the capital of Crimea.

headline: Guitars and Their Different Moods
abstract: Beverly Maher, the owner of the Guitar Salon, described guitars as being like people, moods and all.
lead_paragraph: Beverly Maher, the owner of the Guitar Salon, described guitars as being like people, moods and all.

headline: The Young and the Rebellious
abstract: Candid portraits by a noted Malian photographer capture the blooming cultural scene of a then new African nation.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, European and American curators and art dealers became aware of African photographs taken in the mid-20th century by the operators of small portrait studios, particularly in Mali. Discovering negatives that had been stored for decades, they went about printing, exhibiting and selling these works, making local photographers like Seydou Keïta and Malick Sidibé international art stars in the process.

headline: No Guitar Is the Same
abstract: The guitarist Virginia Luque demonstrates the difference in sound between a classic American guitar and one from Britain.
lead_paragraph: The guitarist Virginia Luque demonstrates the difference in sound between a classic American guitar and one from Britain.

headline: A Place That Plucks Heartstrings
abstract: The Guitar Salon has the feel of a 19th-century Parisian salon with high-end classical guitars, starting around $6,000, on display.
lead_paragraph: On a small, tree-lined street in the West Village, those who know where to look (or those who have made appointments) will find the Guitar Salon, which occupies a parlor-floor apartment in a brownstone built in the 1830s. The only indication of what’s inside is a small black-and-white sign taped next to the buzzer depicting a Bohemian woman in flowing robes plucking at a classical guitar. The guitars are too quiet to be heard from the street.

headline: Dale Gardner, Astronaut Who Helped Corral Wayward Satellites, Dies at 65
abstract: Commander Gardner helped lead the first salvage operation in space, steering a jet-propelled backpack to bring the satellites aboard the space shuttle Discovery.
lead_paragraph: Dale A. Gardner, an astronaut who helped lead the first salvage operation in space, steering a jet-propelled backpack to corral two wayward satellites and bring them aboard the space shuttle Discovery, all while orbiting 224 miles above Earth, died on Feb. 19 in Colorado Springs. He was 65.

headline: One More Collapse for the Crumbling Knicks
abstract: The Knicks had a chance for a while against the Heat, but the game disintegrated as Carmelo Anthony proved incapable of sparing them from their fifth loss in six games since the All-Star break.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Nobody needed Carmelo Anthony to confirm what everyone already knew. But given his uncertain future with the Knicks, his saying it only added to the angst that has gnawed at this team for months.

headline: Nearly Everything Changes (Except the Red Plaid Shirt)
abstract: An original low-budget musical at the Paper Mill Playhouse is about a good guy with bad luck. The 11 songs in the 90-minute show are heartfelt and worth remembering.
lead_paragraph: There are people in this world who believe the universe is out to get them. And audiences at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn come to know one of the nicest in “The Other Josh Cohen,” that precious rarity, an original low-budget musical with a life-affirming message and songs worth remembering.

headline: South Africa’s Creative Uprising
abstract: Twenty years after its democratic government was established, Mandela’s homeland is emerging as a hub of design innovation.
lead_paragraph: It may be far-flung, but the tip of Africa has been quietly asserting itself as a significant new hub of design talent. And the founders of Southern Guild, a Cape Town-based collective, are doing their part to make sure that the rest of the world notices.

headline: How the Medical Establishment Got the Treasury’s Keys
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Law and Legislation', 'Medicare', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The struggle over American medical costs can be traced in part to the inherently inflationary terms of the deal that created Medicare nearly a half-century ago, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Word of the Day | entree
abstract: This word has appeared in 214 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: entree •\ˈän-ˌtra also än-ˈ\• noun

headline: U.S. Militant, Hidden, Spurs Drone Debate
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The U.S. government is considering whether to again take the extraordinary step of authorizing the killing of an American citizen, now living in Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He is known as Abdullah al-Shami, an Arabic name meaning Abdullah the Syrian. But his nom de guerre masks a reality: He was born in the United States, and the United States is now deciding whether to kill him.

headline: Irish Musicians to Play ‘Danny Boy’ and Much More
abstract: A number of Irish musicians will arrive on Long Island this month before and after St. Patrick’s Day on March 17.
lead_paragraph: When Sharon Corr,  a singer-songwriter, appears at the Y.M.C.A. Boulton Center for the Performing Arts in Bay Shore on March 16, she will include a number of traditional Irish songs — “really lovely ones,” including “Cooley’s Reel” and “Mna Na hEireann,” she said during a recent phone interview from Los Angeles, where she was doing a show late last month. Ms. Corr, of Dublin, will also perform songs intended to appeal to fans who don’t automatically associate her name with her heritage.

headline: With Moments of Tenderness and ‘Ungrandmotherliness’
abstract: In “4000 Miles,” the playwright Amy Herzog drew from her life to create Vera, a character that is not a typical 91-year-old.
lead_paragraph: When her doorbell rings in the middle of the night, Vera Joseph doesn’t hear it at first. She isn’t wearing her hearing aid. When she communicates with the person on the other side of the door (Leo, her 21-year-old grandson), he can’t understand her because she doesn’t have her teeth in. Vera, one of the two central characters in Amy Herzog’s play “4000 Miles,” which had its opening night on Wednesday at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, may not seem like the firebrand midcentury American Communist she used to be, but no one should see her as a stereotypical little 91-year-old lady either.

headline: A Parting Shot at U.S. Ambassador, Inspired by Mao
keywords: ['Chinese-Americans', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The state-run China News Service published a critique of Gary F. Locke’s tenure as the U.S. ambassador to China, calling him a banana for his “yellow skin and white heart.”
lead_paragraph: The departing United States ambassador, Gary F. Locke, gave a farewell news conference in Beijing on Thursday, at which he praised the deepening economic ties between the world’s two biggest economies and urged China and Japan to cool down escalating tensions over a territorial dispute.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) JAZZ AND THE PHILHARMONIC In this concert inspired by Jazz at the Philharmonic, a four-decade series of performances produced by Norman Granz starting in 1944, four arts organizations — the National YoungArts Foundation, the Phillip and Patricia Frost School of Music at the University of Miami, the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts of Miami-Dade County, and Jazz Roots: A Larry Rosen Jazz Series — join forces to spotlight YoungArts alumni and mentors. Performers include the vocalist Bobby McFerrin (above), the pianist Chick Corea, the pianist and composer Dave Grusin, the trumpeter Terence Blanchard, the violinist Mark O’Connor, the opera bass-baritione Eric Owens, the classical pianist Elizabeth Joy Roe, the choreographer and dancer Desmond Richardson, the pianist Shelly Berg, and the Henry Mancini Institute Orchestra, conducted by Scott Flavin. In Karen Goodman and Kirk Simon’s “Becoming an Artist,” at 10:30, Bill T. Jones, Frank Gehry, Mikhail Baryshnikov, Raúl Esparza, John Guare, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Mr. Owens, Rosie Perez, Robert Redford, James Rosenquist and Kathleen Turner discuss the art of the mentor and their roles within YoungArts.

headline: Corrections: February 28, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on February 28, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: You’ve Got Meal (a Note, Too)
abstract: The Lunchbox,” by Ritesh Batra, puts Old Hollywood style in a Mumbai that has escaped the cyber world.
lead_paragraph: “‘The Lunchbox,’ Ritesh Batra’s debut feature, is a romance that takes place in Mumbai, but its style is more Hollywood than Bollywood, and Old Hollywood at that,” A.O. Scott of The New York Times wrote in his movie review.

headline: Crash That Kills Schoolgirls Highlights Thai Road Dangers
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A bus accident that killed 15 people provides a grim corroboration for a study finding that Thailand has the world’s second-highest road fatality rate.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A week after the release of a study concluding that Thailand has the world’s second-highest road fatality rate, a bus carrying schoolgirls on a class trip to the beach collided with a truck on a provincial highway early Friday, killing 15 people and providing a grim corroboration of the study’s findings.

headline: Special Night for Collins, and a Win for the Nets
abstract: Jason Collins, who played the final eight minutes of the Nets’ rout in Denver, planned to meet afterward with the parents of Matthew Shepard, a gay college student murdered in 1998.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Jason Collins trotted onto the court with 8 minutes 2 seconds left in the fourth quarter Thursday night, the way he had done many times during his 13-year N.B.A. career.

headline: Ousted Ukrainian Leader, Reappearing in Russia, Says, ‘Nobody Deposed Me’
abstract: At a news conference, Viktor F. Yanukovych said he had fled his country in fear of his life from thugs who took over the country.
lead_paragraph: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia — Viktor F. Yanukovych, the ousted president of Ukraine, appealed for calm on Friday and rejected separatism or forcible intervention from abroad, even by Russia, where he has taken refuge.

headline: With Military Moves Seen in Ukraine, Obama Warns Russia
abstract: The new Ukrainian government claimed that Russia was trying to provoke a military conflict by sending troops to Crimea, while President Obama warned Russia to respect Ukraine’s sovereignty.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s fragile new government accused Russia of trying to provoke a military conflict by invading the Crimea region on Friday, while in Washington President Obama issued a stern warning to the Kremlin about respecting Ukraine’s sovereignty, in an effort to preclude a full-scale military escalation.

headline: Crackdown on Baby Trafficking Zeros In on Websites
abstract: The police have broken up four online businesses that matched prospective adoptive parents with children needing homes — in reality, baby traffickers, the police said. Some of the sites posed as public welfare interest groups, or disguised the babies as “gold jewelry.”
lead_paragraph: The Chinese police have broken up four online baby-selling rings and rescued 382 infants in an operation aimed at curbing a trend toward highly organized, Internet-based baby trafficking, news media outlets in Beijing reported Friday.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Feb. 28, 2014
abstract: Can you correctly complete the sentences from the article with verbs?
lead_paragraph: Use the following question for practice in subject-verb agreement.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Armed Standoff in Crimea as Russia Assures U.S. on Ukraine
abstract: Why has Crimea been a source of tension between Ukraine and Russia for decades?
lead_paragraph: In “Armed Standoff in Crimea as Russia Assures U.S. on Ukraine,” Andrew Higgins and Steven Lee Myers report on the latest developments in the political struggle in Ukraine.

headline: ‘Somebody That Nobody Thought I Could Be’
abstract: An Oscar-nominated short film examines a prison hospice staffed by inmates.
lead_paragraph: When someone on the Academy Awards broadcast on Sunday announces the nominees for best documentary short subject, a lot of viewers will head to the kitchen to refill the Cheetos bowl.

headline: Do You Pay Attention to Nutrition Labels on Food?
abstract: Does knowing nutritional information help you make healthier eating choices?
lead_paragraph: Nutrition labels weren’t required on packaged foods in the United States until the 1990s. Now they are a familiar sight that many of us take for granted — or even ignore.

headline: Invincible Looks on City Streets
abstract: From 1980 to 1990, Amy Arbus roamed the streets taking pictures for The Village Voice of “anybody that turns your head.” Her photographs, now on exhibit in NoHo, range from everyday people to celebrities like the Clash.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in 1983, the photographer Amy Arbus spotted a woman walking down St. Marks Place in Manhattan wearing a stained overcoat and using a bowling ball bag as an improvised purse. Ms. Arbus photographed the woman, Madonna Ciccone, who mentioned that she was still wearing her pajamas. Yet Ms. Arbus noted that she was also wearing makeup.

headline: Euro Zone Inflation Stays Low; Joblessness Remains High
abstract: The figures come ahead of a meeting next week by the European Central Bank, which is still weighing whether any further stimulus moves are needed.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Inflation in the euro zone remained stuck at a very low level in February, while the jobless rate was unchanged in January, official reports showed on Friday, providing the European Central Bank with crucial data before its monetary policy meeting next week.

headline: British Airways Parent Returns to Profitability
abstract: International Airlines Group posted its first net profit since 2011 after cutting costs at its struggling Spanish unit, Iberia.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways, said Friday that it swung to a net profit last year, reaping the gains of deep cost-cutting and heavy job reductions at its money-losing Spanish unit, Iberia.

headline: New York Today: Seeking the Homeless
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: helping those on the streets, brutal cold, snow ahead, and Kerry Kennedy is acquitted.
lead_paragraph: Good ice-cold Friday to you. The mercury is in the teens. The wind chill is near zero.

headline: Chinese Auction House Raises $331 Million in Hong Kong I.P.O.
abstract: The offering by Poly Culture bolsters the prospects of the company’s auction business in the world’s fastest-growing art market.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:50 p.m. |

headline: The End of the ‘Developing World’
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The old labels no longer apply. Rich countries need to learn from poor ones.
lead_paragraph: BILL GATES, in his foundation’s annual letter, declared that “the terms ‘developing countries’ and ‘developed countries’ have outlived their usefulness.” He’s right. If we want to understand the modern global economy, we need a better vocabulary.

headline: A Conversation With: Kalvakuntla Taraka Rama Rao, Telangana Leader
abstract: India Ink spoke with Mr. Rao about the long fight for statehood and the challenges ahead for India’s 29th state.
lead_paragraph: Kalvakuntla Taraka Rama Rao, an Andhra Pradesh assembly legislator and senior leader of the Telangana Rashtra Samithi party, is the son of Kalvakuntla Chandrasekhar Rao, the party’s president, who is also considered the architect and driving force behind the successful petition for a separate Telangana state, which will be carved out of Andhra Pradesh.

headline: What You Learn in Your 40s
abstract: There are no soul mates. There are no grown-ups. It’s O.K. if you don’t like jazz.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — IF all goes according to plan, I’ll turn 44 soon after this column appears. So far in my adult life, I’ve never managed to grasp a decade’s main point until long after it was over. It turns out that I wasn’t supposed to spend my 20s frantically looking for a husband; I should have been building my career and enjoying my last gasp of freedom. I then spent my 30s ruminating on grievances accumulated in my 20s.

headline: Court Orders House Arrest, and No Internet, for Fierce Critic of Putin
abstract: A judge ruled that Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s leading opposition figure, had violated the terms of a travel ban from a pending criminal case.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s leading opposition figure, was placed under house arrest on Friday and ordered not to use the Internet or telephone for two months, thus removing President Vladimir V. Putin’s fiercest critic from public life.

headline: Times Minute | Heroin in New England
abstract: A town in Vermont fights back. Also on the Minute, Vladimir Putin's calculation in Ukraine and the power of prayer in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: A town in Vermont fights back. Also on the Minute, Vladimir Putin's calculation in Ukraine and the power of prayer in the N.B.A.

abstract: A town in Vermont fights back. Also on the Minute, Vladimir Putin’s calculation in Ukraine and the power of prayer in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Roland Mouret: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Bankia Privatization Starts With Sale of Government Sliver
abstract: The Spanish government announced on Friday that it sold a 7.5 percent stake in Bankia, its first step toward returning the bank to private ownership. The government still owns about 61 percent of the bailed-out bank.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish government announced on Friday that it sold a 7.5 percent stake in Bankia, its first step toward returning the bank to private ownership and recovering part of the bailout money that Bankia received after triggering Spain’s banking crisis two years ago.

headline: Erosion of Faith Was Death Knell for Mt. Gox
abstract: Mt. Gox, once the largest Bitcoin exchange in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins in a hacking attack.
lead_paragraph: As the Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox was careening toward collapse in early February, its owner, Mark Karpeles, found that even some of his fellow virtual currency advocates were losing faith.

headline: Daily Report: British Spy Agency Is Said to Have Collected Yahoo Webcam Photos
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Accounts based on documents supplied by Edward J. Snowden say images — many sexually explicit — were collected from Yahoo users, even those not suspected of illegal activity.
lead_paragraph: A British intelligence agency collected video webcam images — many of them sexually explicit — from millions of Yahoo users, regardless of whether they were suspected of illegal activity, according to accounts of documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden, Nicole Perlroth and Vindu Goel report.

headline: North Dakota Leads on the Road to Recovery
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'States (US)']
abstract: Within the slow recovery in the United States, there is a wide gap in the performance of individual states.
lead_paragraph: SIX years after the recession began, the United States has yet to return to where it was by any of three measures of economic activity: jobs, highway miles driven or house prices. That makes this business cycle unique among recent cycles — within four years of the recessions that began in 1981, 1990 and 2001, each of those indicators was up substantially.

headline: Feb. 28 Updates on the Crisis in Ukraine
abstract: Times reporters are following the latest developments in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s ousted president, Viktor Yanukovych, made his first public appearance in a week on Friday, telling journalists in the Russian city of Rostov-on-Don that he remains in office, as our colleague Steven Lee Myers reports.

headline: Kolkata Rape Victims Find a Police Officer Who’s on Their Side
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Inspectors General', 'Police', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Damayanti Sen, who is leading the investigations of two high-profile rape cases, has developed a reputation for efficiency and sensitivity.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — After his 16-year-old daughter was gang-raped twice in their Madhyamgram neighborhood in north Kolkata in October, then set on fire, allegedly by associates of her rapists, Rama Shankar Jha was distraught.

headline: Chalayan: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: The Demise of Mt. Gox
abstract: Mt. Gox, the troubled exchange for the virtual currency Bitcoin, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday. | Jos. A. Bank rejected Men’s Wearhouse’s latest bid, but agreed to meet with its larger rival. | Ocwen Financial and its chairman are under fire from regulators and investors. | Janet L. Yellen acknowledged at a Senate hearing that the cold weather had contributed to the recent run of disappointing economic data. | A British regulator is pursuing charges against a third person for influencing Libor.
lead_paragraph: MT. GOX FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY  |  As feared, Mt. Gox, the troubled exchange for the virtual currency Bitcoin, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins in a hacking attack, Hiroko Tabuchi writes in DealBook. The Tokyo-based exchange halted trading earlier this week.

headline: Daily Report: Mt. Gox, Having Lost Essentially All Bitcoins, Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Mt. Gox, once the largest Bitcoin exchange in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins in a hacking attack.
lead_paragraph: Mt. Gox, the troubled exchange for the virtual currency Bitcoin, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins, essentially all of them, in a hacking attack, Hiroko Tabuchi reports from Tokyo.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Balmain Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Currency of China Continues to Decline
abstract: The renminbi lost 0.3 percent of its value against the dollar on Friday, and it has fallen 1.5 percent this year.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The value of China’s currency, the renminbi, continued to slide against the United States dollar on Friday, rattling investors by falling to its lowest level in nearly a year before closing higher.

headline: Changes (Personal/Professional)
abstract: Waking up in the city that never sleeps.
lead_paragraph: Some news: I have informed Princeton that I will be retiring at the end of next academic year, that is, in June 2015. In August 2015 I will join the faculty of the Graduate Center, City University of New York, as a professor in the Ph.D. program in economics. I will also become a distinguished scholar at the Graduate Center’s Luxembourg Income Study Center. You can read all about it in the Graduate Center’s announcement.

headline: Hungary: An Election in Question, Part 1
abstract: Hungarian election rigging, part 1.
lead_paragraph: This is the first of a five-part series from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, head of the Law and Public Affairs Program.

headline: Hungary, An Election in Question, Part 2
abstract: Hungarian election-rigging, part 2.
lead_paragraph: Hungary: An Election in QuestionPart II: Writing the Rules to Win – The Basic Structure

headline: Hungary, An Election in Question, Part 3
abstract: Hungarian election-rigging, part 3.
lead_paragraph: This is the third of a series of posts by my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, head of the Law and Public Affairs Program.

headline: U.S. Growth at End of 2013 Is Revised Downward
abstract: The Commerce Department announced revised growth estimates on Friday, saying that the economy grew at a weaker pace of 2.4 percent, not the faster 3.2 percent first announced.
lead_paragraph: The economy finished 2013 on a weaker footing than first thought, the government said on Friday, heightening concern that the United States is in the midst of another of the periodic slow patches that have dogged the recovery over the last five years.

headline: ‘Blackfish’ in the Cross Hairs Again, and Other Developments

lead_paragraph: From floral motifs to texture mixes, designers stage their collections for autumn/winter 2014.

headline: Lanvin at 125: Sporty to Sensual
abstract: Alber Elbaz always seems to know what women need and how they feel.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Lanvin turns 125 this year and Alber Elbaz gave it a happy, tough-and-tender birthday. The fact that one front-row guest was Rihanna, with a boyish new haircut, would surely have pleased Jeanne Lanvin, the founder of a house that has never let women down.

headline: Japan to Revisit Apology to Wartime Sex Slaves
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Prostitution', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A government spokesman said a team of scholars would examine what historical evidence had been used in composing the apology, which was issued in 1993.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan will re-examine a landmark apology it made two decades ago to women forced to work in Japanese wartime military brothels, a government spokesman said on Friday, in a move that could further outrage South Korea, where many of the women came from.

headline: Hungary, An Election in Question, Part 5
abstract: Hungarian election-rigging, part 5.
lead_paragraph: This is the final post of a new series from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, head of Princeton’s Law and Public Affairs Program.

headline: Listen Up | Will Owen Pallett Win an Academy Award This Sunday?
abstract: Regardless of whether he and Arcade Fire take home Best Original Score for the “Her” soundtrack, the artist has a new album out in May to look forward to.
lead_paragraph: “It’s been a really crazy, busy week,” Owen Pallett exclaimed as he returned Tuesday from Haiti, where he was performing with his frequent collaborators, Arcade Fire. A maverick virtuoso of the violin, as well as an in-demand composer and arranger, Pallett is now back in Los Angeles to attend a “private, Oscar-y dinner” with the likes of Burt Bacharach, Randy Newman and John Williams. The event is tied to his recent Academy Award nomination for best original score, which Pallett shares with Arcade Fire for their work on the soundtrack to Spike Jonze’s acclaimed film “Her.” “I’m going to get a haircut,” he said. “I don’t know how else to prep to meet my big hero, Burt Bacharach. It’s kind of strange and disorienting, all that’s happening. It’s not something I’ve been thirsting for my entire life.”

headline: This Week's Movies: Feb. 28, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “The Lunchbox,” “Non-Stop” and “Fatal Assistance.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “The Lunchbox,” “Non-Stop” and “Fatal Assistance.”

headline: Mattel Agrees to Buy Maker of Mega Bloks, a Lego Rival
abstract: Mattel on Friday said it had agreed to buy Mega Brands, a smaller company based in Montreal that sells plastic construction bricks and arts and crafts sets. The deal has an enterprise value, a measure that includes debt, of $460 million.
lead_paragraph: With “The Lego Movie” a box office smash, the toy maker Mattel is getting in on the craze for plastic bricks.

abstract: Waking up in the city that never sleeps.
lead_paragraph: Reposting to put this at the top of the blog for the next few hours.

headline: Citigroup Says Mexican Subsidiary Was Defrauded of as Much as $400 Million
abstract: Citigroup said on Friday that it was revising its results for the fourth quarter and 2013 after it discovered a fraud involving its Mexican banking unit, Banamex, and an oil services company.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:56 p.m. | At the helm of Citigroup for just a year and a half, Michael L. Corbat has been trying to transform into a boring bank a global giant that has been plagued in the past by blowups and bailouts.

headline: Rebellions Simmering and Boiling
abstract: Lionel Rogosin’s quasi-documentary “Come Back, Africa” (1957), new on Blu-ray, captures the state of being black in South Africa in the mid-1950s.
lead_paragraph: An early champion of Italian Neorealism, André Bazin praised movies like “Rome Open City” and “Paisan” for the immediacy of their “re-enacted reportage.” Lionel Rogosin’s 1959 “Come Back, Africa,” a clandestinely made exposé of South African apartheid, is more like reportage re-enacted under fire.

headline: Hotel Review: Lord Balfour in Miami Beach
abstract: After a total renovation, this 64-room property reopened last July, featuring colorful, playful details, but minimal glitz.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Little Nonna’s in Philadelphia
abstract: The menu at this cozy spot, opened in September, is packed with classic dishes as they might be prepared by a modern-day nonna, Italian for grandmother.
lead_paragraph: A craving for a classic Italian Sunday supper — hearty platters of meatballs and macaroni and a long-simmering red sauce — can inconveniently arise on any given evening. Those in Philadelphia are in luck: At Little Nonna’s, a cozy restaurant that opened in September in Center City, the family-style “Sunday gravy” is served every night of the week.

headline: On the Beach, on the Cheap, in Mozambique
abstract: A cultural exchange involving pizza and coconut beer and a big directional assist from two children are all part of this Frugal adventure to the country’s southern coast.
lead_paragraph: An hour up the sand from the little beach town of Tofo, perched on a peninsula jutting off the southern coast of Mozambique on a bay of gently surfable Indian Ocean waves, I met five children who had never heard of pizza.

headline: Fortress Discloses a Paper Loss on Bitcoin
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Company Reports', 'Hedge Funds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Fortress Investment Group is the first large public company to disclose a stake in Bitcoin. It had an unrealized loss of $3.7 million at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: The Fortress Investment Group reported a paper loss of $3.7 million from investments in Bitcoin, the first large public company to disclose a stake in the volatile virtual currency.
